column2: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce reported yesterday that lumber stocks reached their highest level since the war at the end of September, latest month for which it had data.
Columbia's basketball team, steamed up by last Saturday's upset victory over Dartmouth, will have a tougher assignment tonight when it tangles with Yale at the Morningside Heights gymnasium.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 4,178, an all-time high weekly record, compared with 1,346 last week and 3,348 in the similar week of 1948, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 11 (UP) -- Mayor James A. Rhodes, president of the national Amateur Athletic Union, said today he would ask the executive committee to investigate charges of discrimination against Harrison Dillard in the balloting for the Sullivan trophy.
A better average rate on loans made this year was predicted yesterday by Dunham B. Sherer, chairman of the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company, at the annual stockholders' meeting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee decided today to hold public hearings, starting Thursday morning, on the nomination by President Truman of Dean G. Acheson to be Secretary of State to succeed George C. Marshall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Red Cross supplied 110,000 pints of whole blood to 700 hospitals and thirty-three clinics during the first year of its blood program, Basil O'Connor, president, reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 -- Warrants charging extortion, bribery and conspiracy were issued late today for Fire Marshal George J. Gallagher and seven of his assistants, after the special June grand jury recommended their immediate prosecution in a presentment to Judge Raymond MacNeille.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- The British Foreign Office, through its spokesman, called on the United Nations Security Council tonight to take a strong stand on the Palestine issue. The statement was issued as officials expressed concern over the deterioration of Anglo-American relations.

Close to 300 of boxing's followers, promoters, boxers, managers, administrators of the sport, referees, judges and just plain fans will gather at Toots Shor's tonight to honor Ike Williams, world lightweight champion; Dan Morgan, venerable former manager, and Sam Taub, veteran critic and broadcaster of boxing.

On the short end of the count only twice in their last twelve outings, the New York Rangers continue their chase of the tightly bunched field in the National Hockey League title race tonight when they tangle with the front-running Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden.

Total United States commercial exports are likely to show a substantial decline this year, because of dollar shortages and increasing import restrictions, Dempster McIntosh, president of the Philco International Company of New York, said yesterday.
WARSAW, Jan. 11 -- Anti-Government activities by underground forces have increased substantially in this country within the last six months, according to Premier Joseph Cyrankiewicz.

Blessed with balmy, almost yachting-like weather instead of the frigid January blizzards of recent years, the National Motor Boat Show at Grand Central Palace continued on its even keel yesterday. Whereas the throngs appeared slightly smaller than those of Monday, exhibitors and their dealer representatives called it a carriage trade.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- The British Government has received, and is studying, a note from the Chinese Government requesting Britain's views on how China can solve her internal crisis, it was learned here on good authority. Similar notes have been sent to the United States, the Soviet Union and France, it is understood.

EL AUJA, Palestine, Jan. 11 -- During the recent Negeb battle Israeli patrols penetrated deeply into the Sinai Peninsula and reached an Egyptian airfield only eighty miles from the Suez Canal, it was learned today during a front-line visit.

A new group of French provincial cotton decorative fabrics that Altman's will introduce today at $1 a yard is notable for the range of colors. The prints include light and medium blues as well as dark green and black grounds, which are forecast for prominence this year.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 11 (AP) -- The National Collegiate Association Football Rules Committee today made a belated start in its discussion of regulations for 1949.

I hope you will be kind enough to give the same prominence to this letter in reply to your editorial on Jan. 7, entitled "Let's Have the Facts," as you gave to the latter. Your editorial creates the impression that I am making groundless accusations.

GROVELAND, Fla., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Three Pullman cars of the Seaboard Airline Railroad's Miami-to-New York Orange Blossom Special turned on their sides in swampy mucklands fourteen miles southwest of here tonight, injuring at least nineteen persons.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Air Force announced a sweeping revision of its aircraft-buying program today in what was described as an effort to conform to the "line" of President Truman's budget message.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 11 -- The Provisional Government of Israel charged today that Britain's "imposing display of military and political activity" in the Near East is directed against Israel and that its continuance "is likely to endanger the maintenance of international peace and security."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Hoover Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government has reached agreement on a large number of recommendations designed to improve the administration of the nation's foreign policy.

Jan. 11 (UP)--1 WASHINGTON, Three big dairy groups said todayI ] they would drop their oppositiont to repeaI of state and Federal/ oleomargarine taxes if Congresst would prohibit sales of colored! oleomargarine by stores and res-I taurants.

Stockholders of the Manufacturers National Bank of Detroit, at the annual meeting held yesterday, elected as additional directors Ernest R. Breech, executive vice president of the Ford Motor Company and E. M. Ford, president of Wyandotte Chemicals Corporation.

NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 11 -- P. James Pellecchia Jr., former Chief Magistrate of this city, awaiting sentence on pleas of guilty to twenty-one complaints of embezzlement involving $663,000, was cross-examined for three hours today at the second day of the Superior Court trial of the Iovine brothers, three alleged bookmakers whom he has named as major beneficiaries of his confessed peculations.

Making a transatlantic trip by air at the age of 91 is no remarkable feat to Frank Zahourek, a native of Czechoslovakia, who in 1889 took part in the great Oklahoma land rush and spent the following years living the vigorous life of a homesteader.

The Durene Association of America, promotional and quality control organization of nine manufacturers of Durene mercerized cotton yarn, announced plans yesterday for a far-reaching advertising campaign aimed directly at consumers.

OLIVOS, Argentina, Jan. 11 -- The new Constitution that President Peron projected here this morning paves the way for outlawing the Communist party, which cast nearly 81,000 votes in the election of Dec. 5.

PARIS, Jan. 11 -- A 79-year-old French Communist Deputy, Marcel Cachin, gained the approval of the General Assembly today when he said that peace between the Soviet Union and the United States was passible. He cited Generalissimo Stalin as his authority.

New issues of debentures and common stock of Gulf States Utilities Company aggregating more than $19,600,000 in market value will be placed on the market here today. The utility company, which is extending its electrical distribution system in Texas and Louisiana, sold the securities to underwriters yesterday at competitive bidding.

PARIS, Jan. 11 (UP) -- Victor Kravchenko, Russian refugee author of the book "I Chose Freedom," told a heavily guarded press conference today that Soviet agents in the United States had tried four times to kill him in the past year.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- Stockholders of some of this city's major Loop banks held annual meetings today to elect directors for 1949. At the same time directors' meetings were held to pass on new appointments and promotions among officers.
A series of organizational changes and creations of two new positions of executive vice presidents of Time, Inc., was announced yesterday by Roy E. Larsen, president.

Philip Murray had a good many harsh things to say at the national CIO convention about the United Office and Professional Workers, the leftwing union that represents the CIO in the white-collar field. Last week-end this union held a conference in Manhattan Center, at which it asked its members to contribute $100,000 to a war chest intended to expand the union and protect its jurisdiction.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 11 -- In a sharp denunciation of the Netherlands Government delivered here today in the United Nations Security Council, the United States called for early withdrawal of Dutch troops from Indonesian Republican territory and insisted that complete sovereignty be transferred to a United States of Indonesia in a matter of "months, and not in terms of years."

In submitting the highest peacetime budget in the history of the United States, President Truman has called for the appropriation of some $6,700,000,000 for foreign aid and recovery and nearly $15,900,000,000 for national defense. These two items alone comprise more than half the total expenditures.

THE dictionary defines "dumb" as meaning "destitute of the power of speech" or "dull, stupid (colloquial)." Dumb Dan Morgan qualifies on neither count. He holds every Olympic record for garrulity. He's mentally sharp. They call him dumb because he talks so much -just as a giant will get the incongruous nickname of Shorty.

The Amateur Hockey Association squad that will represent the United States in the world amateur hockey championships at Stockholm Feb. 12-20, boarded the Queen Mary last night for the voyage to Europe.

The daytime dress industry, started fifty years ago by manufacturers of apron wrappers has grown to a point where its volume exceeds $500,000,000 annually at retail, according to Erwin Feldman, director-counsel of the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, who visited President Truman today to discuss changes in the National Security Act, said afterward that he believed he would be retained in the Cabinet.

" IT is because all the important facts about Nazi Germany are virtually complete that such a history as this can be written now," remarks Anthony K. Martienssen in his introduction to his "Hitler and His Admirals."* And all the facts are complete because of the German passion to record everything on paper and preserve everything no matter what disasters befell them.
LONDON, Jan. 11 -- Fascists gave Prime Minister Attlee a rough reception tonight when he made his debut as prospective candidate for the West Walthamstow Division of London.

Cottonseed oil futures on the New York Produce Exchange were mixed yesterday. Reports that the Government would allocate an additional amount of fats and oils for the first-quarter exports resulted in considerable buying. Stronger lard and grains also encouraged the buyers.

Business conditions at the beginning of the second quarter will determine the forthcoming tax structure rather than any program now being formulated, Dr. Henry Bund, director, division of management methods, Research Institute of America, asserted yesterday.

GENEVA, Jan. 11 -- President Truman's recent addresses to Congress and the report of the Council of Economic Advisers, full texts of which have just reached here, have put new life in the drive for establishment of a permanent world trade organization.

With the sale of a new issue of $906,631,000 of Treasury bills this week the march of the going market yield for this shortest-term instrument of Government credit has been resumed. This week's average price represented an average yield of 1.16 per cent, a new high for the current movement.
An off-duty fireman attached to Engine Company 285 in Queens became a hero yesterday although he was three floors distant from the fire.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Senator Johnson, Democrat, of Colorado, said today that a Senate subcommittee will begin hearings Jan. 24 on delivered prices and the right of sellers to absorb freight in order to meet competition.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Maritime Commission is prepared to begin a construction and assistance program involving seventeen modern ocean vessels as soon as Congress approves maritime construction urged in President Truman's new budget, it was learned today.

TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 11 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll laid the state's fiscal problems before the New Jersey Legislature today and called for public referendums on low-cost housing and a veterans' bonus.

KINGSTON, N. Y., Jan. 11 -- Disruption of New York newspaper deliveries in Ulster, Delaware, Greene and part of Schoharie Counties, caused by the recent discontinuance of West Shore railroad trains, was cited at a hearing of the Public Service Commission here today as a reason why more trains should not be discontinued.

George Emlen Roosevelt last night was elected commodore of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club of Oyster Bay, L. I. The annual meeting of the organization which, with its years of eight and six meter racing, has held more international matches than any other yachting body in this country, was held in the New York Yacht Club.

NANKING, Jan. 11 -- Tientsin, leading industrial center of North China, was written off as virtually lost here tonight following a radio-telephone report that Communist Gen. Lin Piao had accepted an appeal to issue a cease-fire order in return for a peaceful surrender.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- In her fight for economic recovery last year Britain made gains of 6 to more than 100 per cent, compared with 1947 in the output of her essential industries, according to figures made available here today. Compared with preceding year exports rose 20 to 25 per cent.
California school districts borrowed $31,148,000 in the market for tax-exempt bonds yesterday at interest costs ranging from 1.78 to 1.99 per cent.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Scrap steel dealers serving district steel mills reported today that supplies are improving and prices are easier.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 11 -- A virtually unprecedented snowfall covered many parts of Southern California today in depths up to one foot. More snow was falling in some places tonight.

ROME, Jan. 11 -- The Pope today urged the United Kingdom to improve its relations with other countries in what Vatican, circles said was an allusion to Italy. The appeal, these circles said, was contained in a brief speech that the Pope made during an audience granted to members of a British parliamentary delegation now in Rome.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- An Army report was sharply critical today of the use of uniformed scientific personnel during World II, and the Army, in an accompanying statement, conceded that the study revealed "serious shortcomings in previous procedures."
Seventy-five thousand Jewish residents of Egypt have been the victims of a "general reign of terror" for the last eight months, the American Jewish Committee charged yesterday.

Saul Geltman and Philip Kenner have sold the one-story taxpayer containing twelve store at 220-244 East 163d Street, the Bronx, to Philip Levinson. Sale was subject to a mortgage of $42,000. Samuel Schneider, Samuel Kalisch and Saul T. Levine were the brokers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- About one-fourth, or 108, of the 435 members of the House of Representatives hold their seats as a result of election pluralities of less than 5 per cent, an analysis of complete returns of the Nov. 2 election disclosed today.

The increased control in Tammany Hall of the bloc supporting the leadership of Hugo E. Rogers was further demonstrated yesterday when a decision was reached on two new district leaders for the Ninth Assembly District, and one additional leader was picked in the Fifteenth Assembly District.
The green-hulled Atlantic cruise liner Caronia, introducing a new color note where black and white are traditional, steamed into New York Harbor at midday yesterday on her maiden voyage.

Looking back at 1948 from a safe distance -- if such a thing still exists -- it must be said that the old year had its full share of news to start people worrying about what 1949 and its immediate successors might pull from their sleeves.
A schedule of spring hunt race meetings has been approved by the hunts committee of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The net working capital of American corporations reached a new record level of $65,400,000,000 in the third quarter of 1948, an increase of $1,500,000,000, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

A swing to large hats, the appearance of a "thick look" and multiple layers in brims, a generous use of flowers and transparent fabrics were all trends reflected in the spring millinery picture from better and budget designers represented last night in the Millinery Stabilization Commission's semi-annual showing at the Astor Hotel.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 11 -- The Swedish Riksdag was opened today by 90-year-old King Gustaf with the traditional pomp. Although the throne speech had been pared to a few brief sentences because of the monarch's age, the King read the document with some difficulty as he was seized with a violent coughing spell.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Senator James E. Murray, Democrat, of Montana, denied today that a $15,000,000,000 industrial development fund proposed in a bill which he and Senator John J. Sparkman, Democrat, of Alabama, sponsored would put the Government in "the steel or any other business."

Artists and art editors took the stand in Supreme Court yesterday in support of Alfred D. Crimi, the mural painter whose fresco had been effaced by the Rutgers Presbyterian Church, Broadway and Seventy-third Street.

Rabbi Abraham E. Millgram, educational director of the United Synagogue of America, outlined yesterday a program of Jewish education. He addressed 125 rabbis from various sections of the country who are attending the two-day conference on Jewish education sponsored by the Rabbinical Assembly at the Jewish Theological Seminary, 3080 Broadway.

GENEVA, Jan. 11 -- The recent ban on the free transit of gold through Switzerland was inspired partly by the fact that large amounts of gold were passing through Switzerland to Eastern Europe, according to the authoritative Neue Zurcher Zeitung.
BERLIN, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Harnack House, biggest American club in Berlin, voted today to admit enlisted men rather than spend $175,000 in the next year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Senator Styles Bridges of New Hampshire, senior Republican member and former chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, promised a stiff fight today against President Truman's spending and tax programs.

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- A bill to broaden the power of the State Banking Department over the reserve requirements of state banks that are not members of the Federal Reserve System was introduced in the Legislature today by Senator J. Raymond McGovern of New Rochelle and Assemblyman Benjamin H. Demo of Croghan, chairmen of the legislative banking committees.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The Israeli Government said today that the British authorities who ordered the mission were to blame for the shooting down of five British planes by Israel along the Palestine-Egyptian border last week.
LONDON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The Vulcan Foundry Company said today the Argentine Government has asked to cancel an order for seventy locomotives worth 2,000,000.

Peace in China depends upon the Communists, Dr. V. K. Wellington Koo, Chinese Ambassador to the United States, declared last night at a dinner given by the Columbia College Alumni Association at the Biltmore Hotel. He spoke after receiving the 1949 Alexander Hamilton Medal, awarded annually for distinguished service by an alumnus or faculty member of the college.

Net earnings of Manufacturers Trust Company in 1948 were $10,701,008, equal to $5.19 per share, compared with $9,735,203, or $4.72 per share in 1947, Harvey D. Gibson, president, reported to stockholders yesterday. The report was issued in advance of the bank's annual meeting on Jan. 19.

The future role of the New York Yankees in professional football hinges on the outcome of further peace discussions between the National League and the All-America Conference, it was disclosed yesterday by Daniel R. Topping, president of the local conference club.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Dr. Reed, a $10,000 claim for H. B. Hershon last October, eked out a head victory over Calumet Farm's Faultless in the featured Monseigneur Purse at Tropical Park today.

The emergency-class passenger ship Marine Carp, owned by the Maritime Commission and operated by the American Export Lines, was unable to sail for the Mediterranean at noon yesterday as scheduled when her crew refused to sign shipping articles.

WASHINGTON, Jan 11 -- Reports on foreign agriculture, issued today by the Office of Foreign Agriculture Relations, revealed that the food-deficit countries of Western Europe not only are having much better crops, but also are exerting every effort toward self-sufficiency.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Matthew Woll, a vice president of the American Federation of Labor, sharply criticized the rival Congress of Industrial Organizations today. He said it was directing its anti-Communist pressure exclusively to the "weaker" unions.

Not guilty pleas were entered yesterday by four men indicted in an alleged attempt to "fix" a college basketball game in Madison Square Garden. General Sessions Judge John J. Sullivan continued them in $20,000 bail each to await trial.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Jan. 11 -- As 1,200 delegates began to gather here for the opening of the United Jewish Appeal conference tomorrow, a pre-conference report was made public showing that the appeal, since its inception in 1939, had raised more than $503,000,000 for Jewish needs throughout the world, with special emphasis on Israel.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 11 -- The annual national conference of the South African Communist party ended here today on a valedictory note since it is possible that the new Nationalist Government will have outlawed communism before the next conference can be convened.

BERLIN, Jan. 11 -- Brief chronicles in the Berlin press, noting distinctive personalities among the hundreds who cross illegally each day from the Eastern zone to the Western sectors of this city or to the Bizonal area, have included four cases within the last forty-eight hours that were rated as deserving of mention.
Engineers employed by the Hudson Manhattan Railroad, operator of the Hudson tubes between New York and New Jersey, have voted "overwhelmingly" for a strike against the line, it was learned yesterday.

Gross income of the First National Bank of the City of New York is likely to be higher in the first quarter of this year than in the comparable period of 1948, Alexander C. Nagle, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday. As of Dec. 31 last year, he said, stockholders of record numbered 7,983.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UP) -- There will be a slight charge for using the more popular camps, picnic grounds and other recreation areas in national forests this year.

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Jan. 11 -- Touring members of the Royal Caledonian Curling Club of Scotland experienced outstanding success at the St. Andrews Golf Club's indoor rink today. Captianed by Sir James Denby Roberts, the twenty-five Scots won eight of nine games against members of District No. 2 of the Grand National Curling Club of America for an aggregate point victory of 94 to 44.

LYONS, Ga., Jan. 11 -- Two white men accused of participating in the roadside slaying of a prosperous Negro farmer, as his wife sat beside him in their new automobile, were freed today after a dramatic court room session.

Displaying fleeting samples of the form that carried it to victory in last year's national invitation basketball tournament, St. Louis University scored an easy-going 58-47 victory over Long Island University last night before the season's largest turnout of 18,486 spectators at Madison Square Garden.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 11 -- The annual national conference of the South African Communist party ended here today on a valedictory note since it is possible that the new Nationalist Government will have outlawed communism before the next conference can be convened.

BERLIN, Jan. 11 -- Brief chronicles in the Berlin press, noting distinctive personalities among the hundreds who cross illegally each day from the Eastern zone to the Western sectors of this city or to the Bizonal area, have included four cases within the last forty-eight hours that were rated as deserving of mention.

Paul Vincent, builder, has sold the newly completed one-story gasoline and service station on the south side of Hempstead Turnpike, west of Semton Road, in Franklin Square, L. L., to the Eagle Petroleum Corporation, represented by Harry D. Diamond, attorney.
The liner America lost one passenger and almost gained another in a flurry of excitement as she sailed yesterday afternoon from her West Twenty-first Street pier.

Standing on the record of the most exhaustive survey of the power supply ever made by the private utility industry, the Edison Electric Institute released yesterday a long statement in reply to its critics' charges that the nation's electricity reserves were precarious. The institute forecast a progressively brighter outlook as the intensive five-year expansion programs continue through 1951.

This city received no offers yesterday for a plot of land it owns on the east side of Park Avenue, between Thirty-ninth and Fortieth Streets. The city purchased the property for approximately $1,500,000 in 1937 when it was proposed that the Appellate Division, First Department, have a new building.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 11 -- Samuel L. Wahrhaftig, 35-year-old employe in the civil affairs division of the United States Military Government, left by plane for the United States this morning. He was suspended for reasons of "security" and ordered to his home in Brooklyn to await further instructions.

A large-scale program of Federal scholarships, to provide funds for 500,000 college students, was proposed yesterday by Dr. Byron Hollinshead, president of Coe College, Cedar Rapids, Iowa. He also urged that the Government provide a direct subsidy to America's colleges and universities.

Last year's campaign of the United Negro College Fund, Inc., of 38 East Fifty-seventh Street, brought in a high record of $1,066,112, it was reported yesterday. New York gave $304,942, of which $90,000 was realized by the New York women's division.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 11 -- Resources of the Bank of America have been raised above the $6,000,000,000 mark, largely due to a gain of $172,324,257 in total deposits, President L. M. Giannini reported to the annual meeting of shareholders here today.

The fifty-foot tall advertising tower atop the Rialto Building, Seventh Avenue and Forty-second Street, was being sheathed yesterday with sheet metal to prevent any more of its 600 glass tiles from falling to the street. Police had roped off part of the sidewalk last Thursday night after several tiles, eight inches square, had crashed on the pavement.

The National Labor Relations Board announced yesterday that two hearings would be held this week on petitions for representation elections among the employes of Hearn Department Stores, Inc., and the Namm Store, Brooklyn.

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- The first step toward consolidation of the New York City Court system was taken today with the bi-partisan introduction of two bills. These measures relate to the Municipal Court changes which have been recommended by the New York County Lawyers Association.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 11 -- United States oil interests have given the Syrian Government only four more days to ratify the contract for the passage of the $200,000,000 Trans-Arabian pipeline across Syria, it was reported here today.

Despite opposition from many civic organizations, the chairman of the proposed city traffic commission may be selected by the Mayor from among the commission's six ex-officio members, according to the amended bill. The organizations hold that the executive director, a traffic engineer, should be named chairman.

Leonard Pennario, pianist, played an exacting if not a well-balanced program last night in Carnegie Hall. It ranged from the B flat sonata, K. 570, of Mozart to the Liszt B minor Sonata, sonatas of Prokofieff and Liszt, Toccatas by Ravel and Prokofieff, and Schumann and Chopin between.

The Title Guarantee and Trust Company reported as of Dec. 31, 1948, total deposits of $54,895,715 and total assets of $64,665,568, compared, respectively, with $42,618,339 and $51,952,851 on June 30, 1948. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $16,144,491 against $11,670,690; holdings of United States Government securities to $15,080,025 against $18,432,951 and loans and discounts to $21,245,298 against $13,078,760.

The 12,000,000 persons in the metropolitan area must not be made to suffer the consequences of a harbor-crippling tugboat strike so the remaining issues in the contract dispute here must be resolved before the strike deadline set for 12:01 A. M. tomorrow, William J. McCormack, chairman of the Mayor's special mediation committee, declared yesterday afternoon.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced yesterday the sale to the Dollar Savings Bank of the City of New York of $1,000,000 of 2 1/2 per cent guaranteed serial mortgage notes held in the bank's portfolio since last August when a $12,000,000 loan was made to four Dutch shipping companies.
Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. Stettinius of New York and The Horseshoe, Rapidan, Va., are at the Savoy-Plaza.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 11 -- The British administrators of the trust territory of Tanganyika were accused today by a resident of the African territory of having exploited deliberately the African natives in Tanganyika.

The two-story business building at 181 Fort Greene Place, Brooklyn, known as the Fort Greene Market, and the abutting one-family dwelling at 166 South Elliott Place have been sold by the estate of David Issaacs to the 181 Fort Greene Realty Corporation, represented by Hoffman Rubin, attorneys.

Continuing control over consumer installment credit lending under Regulation W of the Federal Reserve Bank is creating new problems for banks, William F. Kelley, chairman of the consumer credit committee of the American Bankers Association, points out in a letter mailed to all banks inviting them to be represented at a national consumer installment credit conference at the Hotel Jefferson, St. Louis, on March 29, 30 and 31.

The American Export liner Exeter sailed for the Mediterranean at 4 P. M. yesterday, with 100 passengers. Among them were William H. Coverdale, chairman of the board and president of the steamship company, and John F. Gehan, vice president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Senator Elbert Thomas, Democrat, of Utah, chairman of the Labor and Welfare Committee, indicated today that he favored a limited "one-package" labor bill. The bill would encompass repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act, re-enactment of the former Wagner Act and also include perhaps half a dozen amendments to cover President Truman's recommendations to Congress.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- A drive aimed at the elimination of teachers holding emergency certificates, either by disqualification or advancement, was begun here today at the final meeting of the Regional Conference on Teacher Education and Professional Standards.

All factors point to maintenance of retail trade at current levels during the first quarter of 1949, with a variation of not more than 2 per cent in either direction, according to Edwin I. Marks, chairman of the executive committee, R. H. Macy Co. Stores in the Macy chain, he said are planning for a 5 to 10 per cent gain in their ready-to-wear departments.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 11 -- American Protestantism must either adjust itself to a drastically changing world or permit "other agencies" lacking religious motives to relegate the church to the sidelines, the Rev. Dr. Mark A. Dawber of New York, executive secretary of the Home Missions Council of North America, declared here tonight.

BOSTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Nine seconds before the final whistle, Bobby Cousy hooked in a field goal which provided the necessary points for the Holy Cross Crusaders to defeat a taller Loyola of Chicago basketball team, 59-58, tonight at the Boston Garden.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 11 -- C. Powell Whitehead, president of General Steel Castings Corporation, and Clark R. Gamble, president of Brown Shoe Company, today were elected to the board of First National Bank in St. Louis. They succeed two members who have retired, namely, John B. Kennard and E. D. Nims.

Now that the winter doldrums are setting in for the northern rod and gun editors, we have been catching up with some of the recent hunting and fishing books, many of which may be recommended without reservation.

As a flurry of announcements of price cuts, principally for dairy products, came yesterday from several local chain stores, the continuing, gradual decrease in wholesale food prices was emphasized by the issuance of Dun Bradstreet's weekly index.

Net operating earnings of the Marine Midland Trust Company of New York in 1948 totaled $1,605,118, equal to $3.21 a share, compared with $1,771,975, equal to $3.54 a share, in the previous year, according to the bank's annual report.

TOKYO, Jan. 12 -- Japan's first five-year recovery plan has been abandoned only six months after its preparation, principally because the population figures on which it was based have been disproved by a census.

NANKING, Jan. 12 -- The Communist North Shensi radio asserted tonight that the Communists had captured the first of the Kuomintang (government party) figures on their "war criminal" list -- Gen. Tu Yu-ming, commander of the two army groups that had been trapped southwest of Suchow.

Senator Albert W. Barkley, Vice President-elect, came from Washington last night to speak at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in honor of Robert F. Wagner Jr., chairman of the City Planning Commission. Fourteen hundred persons attended the gathering, which was sponsored by the Children's Welfare Federation, of which Mr. Wagner is a director.

PARIS, Jan. 12 -- The French Cabinet, which under a Radical Premier has hitherto leaned toward a free economy, decided today for strict controls in an attempt to freeze both prices and wages at the levels of Dec. 31.
Sales of leading mail-order and chain-store companies increased 7.9 per cent in December, compared with the same month of 1947, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- A joint armed forces committee on medical and hospital services recommended today that for economy and efficiency, the separate services undertake "extensive consolidation" of their hospital care.

The American knit glove industry cannot compete against manufacturers in Japan who are paying workers $9 a month, it was pointed out yesterday by the Association of Knitted Glove and Mitten Manufacturers. A growing volume of knitted glove imports from Japan now is being sold at prices 50 per cent under the American product, officials of the association said, and threatens to wreck the $10,000,000 American industry.

Predicting banking prospects for 1949 is a practical impossibility, unless "you can give me the rules by which we will play this year," John E. Bierwirth, president of the New York Trust Company, answered a stockholder questioner yesterday.

Having appeared on the road fifty-one times since last November, "Along Fifth Avenue," the revue starring diminutive Nancy Walker, opens this evening at the Broadhurst at 8 o'clock. Arthur Lesser, in past seasons sponsor of Maurice Chevalier's visits to this country, is the producer.

Austin Hogan, president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union since 1937 and one of its founders, was removed from office last night along with two other officers by the membership of the union at a meeting at the Manhattan Center.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 12 -- James W. Hubbell, Des Moines financier, was elected chairman of the board of the Bankers Trust Company yesterday. S. C. Pidgeon, executive vice president, was named president to succeed Mr. Hubbell.
Harold L. Turk, formerly attorney for the New York State Tax Commission, has been elected vice president and general counsel of Arco Crown Cork and Cap Company, Inc., Brooklyn.

TEL AVIV, Jan. 12 -- The United Nations mediator has opened a shuttle air service between Tel Aviv and the island of Rhodes to facilitate negotiations for an armistice with Egypt. But the eyes of Israel are not on Rhodes but on London.

It was an evening of pianistic distinctness at Town Hall last night. Zadel Skolovsky, American pianist who made his New York debut in 1939, was the performer. For nine-tenths of his program it was possible to hear every note he played, and any obscurity of detail in the last tenth was intended, and well-served the musical needs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Communications Workers of America, an independent union of telephone workers, is shopping for affiliation offers again from the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Delegates of the National Catholic Resettlement Council, meeting here yesterday to discuss proposed changes in the displaced persons law, recommended that all future immigration should be in proportion to the racial and religious groups and elements represented in the various camps in European countries.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- James B. Carey, Secretary General of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, who is here for talks with the Trades Union Congress to adopt a common policy against the World Federation of Trade Unions, said today that the CIO had considered an outright proposal to disband the federation.

The 178 Arthur Murray Dance Studios in the United States and Canada plan to spend $3,000,000 on advertising during 1949, it was disclosed yesterday by the organization in announcing appointment of Mrs. Arthur Murray as vice president in charge of promotion.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- The shooting down of five Royal Air Force planes by the Israelis and the subsequent tension has shocked and stirred British opinion more than any event since the threat of war over Berlin last summer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The United States Atomic Energy Commission overruled its own security advisory board and its own security officer to give clearance for atomic secrets to Dr. Frank P. Graham, president of the University of North Carolina.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 5:
Not to be outdone by the British with their new luxury liner Caronia, the Irish made shipping history yesterday in New York.

The indoor track season's first scratch competition in the classic mile run will be a feature of this Saturday's meets. Tommy Quinn, Larry Ellis and Phil O'Connell are the spotlighted starters in the big field that will go to the mark at the 102d Engineers Armory in the Metropolitan A. A. U. championships.

Spotty purchasing featured the first three days of the New York Lamp Show, manufacturers and buyers reported yesterday. They said that retail orders of off-brand low-end table lamps were far below expectations but added that brisk buying has occurred in quality lines which have brand recognition in the trade.

Dr. Koussevitzky, leading the Boston Symphony Orchestra, gave last night at Carnegie Hall the first of two programs of an "American Music Festival" to be heard here this week. The program offered five compositions by as many contemporaneous Americans.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- A possible change of front on labor legislation was indicated today by Representative John Lesinski, Democrat, of Michigan, chairman of the House Labor Committee.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 -- Solution of the so-called labor problems will be found in understandings and not in various forms of compulsion under law, Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, warned here tonight.

John M. Cannella, Commissioner of Licenses, told Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson yesterday that his department needed an additional $17,440 in the coming fiscal year to cover the salaries of inspectors for a check-up on unlicensed businesses in the city.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 12 -- The Yugoslav Communist party took its first steps today to counteract the Communist Information Bureau's hostile propaganda disseminated in Belgrade by Soviet bloc reading rooms and libraries when it published an attack on the Polish Government's establishment.

Philip Murray, national president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, predicted last night that labor would defeat Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Republican Minority Leader, in the 1950 elections.

" Prospects for Democracy in Japan," by T. A. Bisson, an appraisal of the successes and failures of our attempt to implant ideas of Western democracy in the minds and institutions of the Japanese, will be published by Macmillan on Feb. 8. Mr. Bisson, the author of three books on the Far East, was a member of the Government Section of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters in Tokyo in 1946-1947.

Prominent Federal, State and municipal figures, impressed with the tremendously fast growth of pleasure boating, yesterday participated with yachting groups as well as industrialists of the National Association of Engine and Boat Manufacturers in a day-long marina forum at the Hotel Shelton to discuss yacht basin needs of the country.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned stronger yesterday and closed 1 to 5 points net higher.

Stating there was nothing wrong with boxing that a "little hearty cooperation and intelligent matchmaking will not remedy," Harry Markson, acting promoter of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, supplied the keynote at the annual dinner of the Boxing Writers Association at Toots Shor's last night. A gathering of 300 was on hand.

Indonesia will, in a matter of weeks or months, be a free, independent, sovereign state and the Netherlands Government will sponsor it for membership in the United Nations, Dr. Eelco van Kleffens, the Dutch Ambassador to the United States, declared yesterday.

The Grievance Committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York receives charges of professional misconduct and unethical practices by lawyers. It investigates the charges and holds hearings at which the attorney charged with misconduct has an opportunity to answer the charge.

After a spirited and at times bitter debate, the Association of American Colleges at its closing session yesterday adopted a resolution calling for a vast system of federal scholarships and fellowships for qualified college students.

PARIS, Jan. 12 -- The talks that Foreign Minister Robert Schuman will have with Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin in London beginning tomorrow are not designed to solve any of the long list of questions that will be touched on, but rather to demonstrate that there is no grave crisis in Anglo-French relations.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 12 -- J. C. Donnell II, president and general manager of the Ohio Oil Company of Findlay, Ohio, and the third member of the Donnell family to head that 62-year-old concern, was elected a director of the National City Bank of Cleveland at its annual meeting yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- President Truman indicated today that he would do something "right away" toward translating his civil rights program into legislation and that he had several bills in preparation for it, according to a delegation of the National Citizens Council on Civil Rights, which visited him in the White House.
The Texas Gas Transmission Corporation told the Federal Power Commission in Washington yesterday that it sold $60,000,000 of long-term bonds to twelve insurance companies privately on last Dec. 23.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Jobbers in gold-mining shares on the stock market here today had to face a rush of selling by Cape speculators. The activity followed reports that South African banks might restrict lending against gold shares, and estimates from Johannesburg that gold-mining costs would rise by 5 shillings ($1) a ton milled if the Rand workers' wages were raised 12 1/2 per cent for a forty-hour week.

Donald Kirk David, Dean of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration since 1942, was the recipient last night of the sixth annual Tobe Award for Distinguished Contribution to American Retailing.

When the average person thinks of a zoo, he thinks of a place where he can roam in the open air, answer the persistent questions of children about why certain creatures look like they do, munch on popcorn and crackerjack and in general while away the hours of a day off.

PARIS, Jan. 12 -- Reports are now current in diplomatic circles that the Soviet Union may shortly institute dramatic monetary reforms culminating in basing of the ruble on gold. These rumors cannot be confirmed. Nevertheless, they are given considerable credence.

Wilbur J. Chapman, a Minneapolis engineer who thirty-five years ago at the age of 10 gave his savings to aid a Siamese leper boy, sailed yesterday aboard the Queen Mary, en route to northern Siam to fulfill his ambition to see missionaries at work among lepers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Robert A. Lovett, Acting Secretary of State, said today that before Britain recently sent troops to the Trans-Jordan port of Aqaba the United States had expressed concern to the British Government over troop movements in the Palestine area.

Events tonight: Verdi's "Rigoletto," Metropolitan Opera, 8:30 o'clock; New York Philharmonic-Symphony, Leopold Stokowski, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Olga Coelho, soprano-guitarist, Town Hall, 8:30; Michael Strange, recitalist, Fritz Kramer, piano, Times Hall, 8:30; Maro Ajemian, music by John Cage, Carnegie Recital Hall, 9.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 12 -- Employing a fast, well-coordinated attack, Pittsburgh University came from behind in the last ten minutes of play to hand the Army quintet its second straight setback, 42 to 35, in the big academy field house today.

BERLIN, Jan. 12 -- The adoption of a penal code for economic offenses in the Soviet zone, reported today by the Christian Democratic organ Der Tag, includes sentences of such severity that in some respects they surpass even the harshness of Nazi regulations in the wartime economy.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- The Board of Regents would be authorized to adopt plans for using school buildings for the care of children of working mothers under the provisions of a bill introduced today by Senator Louis Bennett and Assemblyman Julius Gans, Democrats, of the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Dean G. Acheson, nominee to succeed George C. Marshall as Secretary of State, will have an opportunity to put into the record his views on Soviet Russia at the hearing scheduled for tomorrow by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
Plans for the big airline terminal building projected for First Avenue near Thirty-seventh Street were viewed yesterday by officials of American and international airlines.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Eddie Arcaro, the nation's stake riding champion, today was suspended for ten days at Santa Anita Park by stewards who said he had caused interference in yesterday's sixth race.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 12 -- Although the independent newspapers withheld first-day comment on President Juan Perone's proposed new Constitution, some Argentines who had feared the worst expressed relief.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Jersey Central Power and Light Company, Asbury Park, N. J., received permission today from the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell at competitive bidding $3,500,000 of first mortgage bonds due in 1978.

GUAM, Thursday, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Three United States service men "are being charged" with the kidnaping, rape and murder of Miss Ruth Farnsworth, former WAC, 27 years old. The San Francisco woman was seized the night of Dec. 11 in a jade shop where she worked part-time.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Jan. 12 -- The scheduled appearance of John Gates, editor of The Daily Worker, Communist newspaper, for an address in Memorial Hall at the University of North Carolina tonight was cancelled today by two sponsoring student groups after Chancellor Robert B. House announced that university buildings could not be used for such an address.

Legislation to provide for manufacture and exhibition of merchandise in foreign trade zones will be introduced in Congress this session by Representative Emanuel Celler Democrat of New York, it was announced yesterday by the New York Foreign Trade Zone Operators, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Polish Ambassador Josef Winiewicz opened today a collection of Polish manual arts by trained designers and village folk.

A conductor and refugee from Nazi oppression myself, I am not suspect of being in sympathy with Nazi conductors or pianists. I think it an outrage that professed Nazi sympathizers like the Vienna conductor von Karajan, splendid musician though he may be, are allowed to tour the world freely (not yet the United States) without anyone objecting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Charged with treason for broadcasting Nazi propaganda over the Berlin radio during the war, Herbert John Burgman, an American citizen, has been arrested by the Army in Germany, the Department of Justice revealed today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 12 -- Cuba began drafting today a formal resolution on the Indonesian question asking for a settlement based upon immediate release by the Netherlands Government of President Sukarno of the republic and acceptance of the principle of "self-determination for the Indonesian people."

In "The Smile of the World," which was acted at the Lyceum last evening, Garson Kanin points out that a progressive young man can easily grow into a stuffed shirt. To prove his point he offers a supreme court justice as the stuffed shirt and the justice's young law clerk as the man of progress.

Costly wild game such as the pheasant and chukar partridge mentioned in this column recently may not fit into some of our budgets. At a luncheon yesterday the New York Market Men's Association demonstrated that guinea hen, more reasonable in price, can be almost as great a delicacy.

The long-awaited decision by Commissioner Albert B. Chandler in the Leo Durocher-Freddie Fitzsimmons "tampering" case was given yesterday and in the opinion of most baseball men it fell rather lightly, even though all parties involved, including the Giants' organization, were adjudged guilty.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 12 -- This nation's food industry should not experience a general price decline in its products unless "our economy falls apart at the seams" an there is a substantial amount of unemployment, Arthur W. Lutz of Los Angeles, president of the National-American Wholesale Grocers' Association, said today.

High school graduates will find requirements for entrance into the municipal colleges liberalized in the spring for the first time since the end of the war, except at Hunter College, according to registrars. Hunter will maintain "its 79 per cent minimum."
The stock market continued yesterday to operate in a narrow range. Price changes were irregular and of a minor nature, leaving the index only 0.09 point higher at the end of the day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- On behalf of the Chilean Government, Senor Felix Nieto del Rio, Ambassador to the United States, conferred the order "A1 Merito" in the Rank of Commander, to six American newspaper men at a special embassy ceremony tonight.
Aeroflot, the Russian airline, appeared surprisingly yesterday as one of the three biggest airlines in the world in 1948.

Gloria Swanson has retired temporarily from television to speed her recovery from the emergency appendectomy she underwent last month in Doctors Hospital. Meanwhile, her Thursday night video program over WPIX has been maintained with guest stars.

A syndicate of ninety-four underwriting houses headed by Reynolds Co. will place on the market today issues of new common and preferred stock of Affiliated Gas Equipment, Inc., aggregating $11,250,000 in market value. At the same time, announcement was made that Reynolds Co. had placed privately for the company an issue of $4,000,000 of 4 per cent sinking fund notes due in 1964.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Mi Preferido, hailed as something of a Cuban Citation, virtually ran away from his field in today's $5,000 Cuba-Florida invitation purse at Tropical Park.

HEMINGWAY once said that courage was the ability to show grace under pressure. You can apply that definition in peace or in war, or in the desperate combination of both that so many people of our day have had to endure, with or without grace -- people such as those in H. E. Bates' beautifully written and skillfully planned new novel, "The Jacaranda Tree."*

ROME, Thursday, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Yehudi Menuhin, violinist, said today he will refuse to appear with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra until it "makes good its word" to engage Wilhelm Furtwaengler, German conductor.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 12 -- King Frederik IX of Denmark told his subjects today that his Queen was a "dream wife" and his three princess daughters were delightful.

John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, concentrated his fire yesterday on the Borden Company after three more chain-store companies reduced milk prices one cent a quart, following the lead of the A. P. food stores.

The Forest Service paints a discouraging picture of the handling of private forest lands, which are one of the nation's assets. It shows that while the cut from the national forests last year was three times that of the pre-war cut, tree production on privately owned lands has declined and mills have had to turn to national forest logs to make up the deficit.

For the 400 members of the All-City High School Symphony Orchestra and Chorus last night was a "big" night -- the occasion of the annual winter concert. But for 17-year-old Peter Bertolino, a student at New Utrecht High School, Brooklyn, it was one on which he was "scared and nervous," but nevertheless "thrilled."

Approval of a $78,000,000 Narrows Bridge linking Brooklyn and Staten Island would "lead to the greatest real estate swindle in the history of the city," Representative Donlad L. O'Toole, Brooklyn Democrat, charged yesterday before a joint military board.

The Thirty-fourth Street-Midtown Association's program for the new year will emphasize proposals to improve traffic and transit conditions in Manhattan, Maj. James N. Spear, vice president and treasurer of Spear Co., home furnishings chain, announced yesterday after his re-election as president of the organization.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- The British Government has been conferring with the United States over the question of the Chinese note requesting the views of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union on the internal crisis in China.
BOSTON, Jan. 12 -- Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin urged tonight the establishment of a 75-cent minimum wage as "a contribution to the prosperity of the whole country."

A change in name to American Retail Association Executives was approved yesterday at the concluding meeting of the National Association of Retail Secretaries at the Statler Hotel. Carl Fissell of Philadelphia was elected president of the association, succeeding J. T. Meek of Chicago.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Jan. 12 -- A total of $372,976,905 will be required this year for reconstruction and immigration among the Jewish people throughout the world, particularly in Israel, it was reported here today by the beneficiary agencies of the United Jewish Appeal.

Your "Topics of The Times" reprinted Jan. 5 an ancient notice that hangs on my wall. In it the New Haven Road forbids people to turn their cattle on to the right-of-way on Sunday, because in an emergency it might some time be necessary to run a train over the road on that day.

Reflecting the cut-back in Texas by the regulatory authorities of that state, crude oil production in the United States last week dropped an average of 156,800 barrels daily to 5,453,550, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This compared with 5,610,650 barrels daily in the preceding week and 5,313,137 in the similar week of 1948.

Israel Sachs, president of the Sachs Quality Furniture Company, was elected yesterday as treasurer of the Jewish Conciliation Board of America, Inc., at its twenty-ninth annual meeting, at the Federation Building, 71 West Forty-seventh Street.

BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 12 -- Maintaining the Netherlands Army and Air Force through 1948 in Indonesia in which the Republic has been engaged in a struggle for independence since the end of the war, has cost $436,297,874, according to estimates obtained here.

Fred W. Ramsey of Cleveland, former general secretary of the International Committee of the Y. M. C. A. and until recently Commissioner of Foreign Liquidation of the State Department, became yesterday executive vice president of Church World Service, 214 East Twenty-first Street.

Two big middle periods did the job for the Knickerbockers at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night. They enabled the New York entry in the Basketball Association of America to break the game wide open and romp to an 81-to-64 decision over the Boston Celtics.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 - Organizing for another bitter fight against President Truman's civil rights program, Southern Democrats scored a preliminary victory today in forcing hearings on proposals that would make it easier to break up filibusters in the Senate.

PROFESSIONAL football plunged into a deep-freeze locker during the Philadelphia play-off blizzard almost a month ago but it's beginning to show signs of thawing out once more. The cold war between the National Football League and the All-America Conference has been put on the stove to brew and it should reach a boiling point in Chicago a week hence.

Twice in less than a month Abraham Lederman, president of the Teachers Union, CIO, has been questioned on his "political beliefs and associations" by Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, the union declared yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- Bills mandating a 10 per cent pay increase for all public school teachers in New York State were introduced in the Legislature today under Republican sponsorship at the request of the State Teachers Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Marshall Plan countries will be gripped by "a series of economic and political crises" after 1952 unless they act soon to stabilize currencies and make greater efforts toward recovery, Robert Marjolin, Secretary General of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation, said today.
Modern home furnishings made in Czechoslovakia are introduced in a model room in the Czechoslovak Industries Fair now at the Museum of Science and Industry.

CHICOPEE, Mass., Jan. 12 -- Samuel L. Wahrhaftig American military government official, today arrived at the Westover Field air base on his way to Washington to answer disloyalty charges. A transport plane brought him from Frankfort.
ATLANTA, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Gov. Herman Talmadge's forces introduced in the Georgia Legislature today a four-point white supremacy program, including a revival of the poll tax.

HONOLULU, Jan. 12 -- William (Bill) Odom, round-the-world flier, and his single motored Beechcraft Bonanza took off tonight at 6:31 o'clock (11:31 P. M., EST) on an attempted non-stop flight to New York.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 12 -- Affiliated Fashionists of California subscribe to soft fashions for spring and into summer. These eight women designers, pioneers in establishing a noteworthy place for California clothes, presented the high spots of their collections at breakfast in the Crystal Room of the Beverly Hills Hotel.

As a foreign student I have read with great interest in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 1 the article concerning plans to bring 1,500 students to this country under the auspices of the World Students Service Fund. According to the plans, "these students, coming largely from camps in Austria and Germany, would, as DP's, be eligible for American citizenship" and would receive financial support and also help to find part-time employment.

With employment and the average hourly earnings of workers rising sharply during November, the steel industry's payroll for the first eleven months of 1948 jumped to $2,028,613,000, or 12 per cent above the total for the similar period in 1947, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.
Members of Local 553 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, approved unanimously last night a settlement between their union and 585 fuel distributors reached on Tuesday at City Hall.

William J. Brede, legislative representative at Albany of the Real Estate Board of New York, will speak at a luncheon meeting of the Pelham Realty Board on Jan. 20 at the Pelham Country Club, Pelham Manor, in Westchester County.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Senate Agriculture Committee moved today to determine the Administration's present position on the farm price support issue as the first step toward an early showdown on repeal or revision of the Aiken-Hope Law.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 12 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie announced here today that the United Nations three-nation Concilation Commission on Palestine would hold its first meeting in Geneva next Monday to take up such long-standing questions as settlement of Palestine boundaries, demilitarization of Jerusalem and protection of its holy places.

Three mortgage loans aggregating about $3,000,000 have been placed on Manhattan realty through the Charles F. Noyes Company: One, a ten-year loan at 4 per cent placed for George J. Gillespie Jr., attorney, covers the Longacre Building at the northeast corner of Broadway and Forty-second Street.

A seven-month downward trend in New York City relief applications was reversed in December, it became known last night. Applications for public assistance went up 17 per cent in the last five weeks of 1948, bringing from Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard a warning that the current sharp rise in the unemployment insurance rolls might prove "a very serious development" for the municipal relief authorities.

Walter D. Hoag, Yale Club, third of the three scratch players in the annual squash tennis Bulldog Handicap tournament in progress at the Yale Club to come through his third-round match, defeated Dr. D. H. Manfredi, Columbia University Club, yesterday, but only after a hard contest.

ROME, Jan. 12 -- The Italian Government would consider a joint administration of Northern Eritrea by Italy, Britain and France if proper guarantees were given to protect the interests of Italian settlers in that area, diplomatic circles said today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 12 -- Three correspondents representing the British, French and United States press were permitted today to interview Royal Air Force pilot Frank Harvey Close, who bailed out near the Jewish settlement of Nirim when four British planes were downed over the Rafah battle area.

LONDON, Jan 12 -- The possibility that Britain's bipartisan foreign policy might be severely strained over the problem of Palestine was foreseen here tonight when Anthony Eden, former Foreign Secretary and chief spokesman for the Conservative Opposition on foreign affairs, described the Government's handling of the Middle East situation as one of "confused purpose and ill-considered action."

REHOVOTH, Israel, Jan. 12 -- Dr. Chaim Weizmann, Provisional President of Israel, expressed deep concern today at the recent deterioration of relations between Britain and Israel and appealed to the British people not to pursue a course that must perforce lead to war.

Coffee futures manifested a firm undertone on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Participation by outside interests and scattered short covering advanced prices in Contract D 13 to 24 points. Considerable strength was evident in Contract S as prices advanced 13 to 25 points.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander and many notables were among the 500 guests and campaign workers who attended yesterday a pre-campaign rally in the Salvation Army's Greater New York drive to raise $1,100,000, which starts Saturday and ends Feb. 15.

The erection of semi-temporary buildings to help house the post-war increase in public school attendance is a proposal likely to create some initial misgivings. Yet, under pressure of necessity, it merits careful study, and advantages may well outweigh doubts. The public would have to be assured that the policy was surrounded by safeguards and used only after the most conscientious scrutiny of conditions in specific areas.

John Cage came into his own last night, both as an inventor and a composer. Maro Ajemian played a sixty-nine-minute composition of his on one of his "prepared" pianos and there was no questioning the double impact on the select and intelligent audience that gathered to hear it at Carnegie Recital Hall.

One explanation for the present drop in consumer spending is that consumers have finally been priced out of the market, Malcolm P. McNair, professor of the Graduate School of Business Administration, Harvard University, declared yesterday at the annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

A bill that would give New York's public school system an aditional $28,000,000 in state aid will be introduced in Albany next week, it was said yesterday by Winthrop Rockefeller, chairman of the Public Education Association's committee on school administration and legislation.
The annual meeting and election of the Horticultural Society of New York were held yesterday afternoon at Essex House.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 12 -- James D. Mooney, president of Willys-Overland Motors, Toledo, said today that within six months it would be possible to walk into any automobile agency and buy any car desired.
A meeting among Dan Topping, Ted Collins, Jack Mara and Horace Stoneham has cleared the local deck for peace in professional football, it was learned yesterday.
The nation's twelve top Communists will "challenge the array" of jurors and ask the dismissal of the entire panel when their trial begins Monday.

Written franchise contracts between supplier and distributor on major brands of distilled spirits, a move long sought by jobbers, are currently under serious consideration at the top policy level of one major supplier, Morris O. Alprin, counsel, Greater New York Wholesale Liquor Dealers Association revealed here last night.

If current trends in United States-Latin American trade continue, exports from this country will increase this year only to those countries where substantial investments of United States capital are made, or where large ECA purchases are undertaken, according to an analysis issued yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Industry representatives have agreed to help the Government stockpile asbestos for strategic purposes, the Department of Commerce announced today.

TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 12 -- Compulsory dimming of headlights when motorists approach and pass each other on New Jersey highways will be enforced rigidly by order of State Motor Vehicle Commissioner Arthur W. Magee.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Navy ran up its largest score of the season to defeat Dickinson's quintet today, 71 -- 39.
TOKYO, Jan. 12 -- Japan's future is indissolubly linked with China's, according to the line that Communist party candidates are taking in election speeches.

Columbia's nineteen-game winning streak on its home court came to a dramatic end last night. Yale accomplished the trick with a blazing late surge that transformed a tense, tight basketball game into a final 65 -- 51 romp for the hustling Elis before a packed house of 3,500 at University Hall.

An anti-trust consent judgment terminating certain restraints of trade in the television industry was entered in Federal Court yesterday against the Scophony Corporation of America, Paramount Television Productions, Inc., which is a subsidiary of Paramount Pictures, Inc., and the General Precision Equipment Corporation.

DENVER, Col., Jan. 12 -- Stockholders of the Central Bank and Trust Company voted yesterday to raise capital stock of the bank from $700,000 to $1,000,000 by declaring a stock dividend of $300,000. Stockholders will receive three additional shares for each seven owned.
The Mathieson Chemical Corporation, first company to report on operations in 1948, announced yesterday its net earnings for the year at $4,822,812.

The new Mannes Trio made an auspicious debut at Times Hall last night. Its members -- Leopold Mannes, piano; Vittorio Brero, violin, and Luigi Silva -- proved to be well-equipped, perceptive musicians, each in his own right and together as an ensemble.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- A soldier's funeral and burial were arranged today by the Government of the United States for Felix Longoria, late private, Infantry, Army of the United States, who died in action on Luzon in the Philippines.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 (AP) -- A 33-year-old poolroom operator was indicted today on a charge of trying to bribe Joe Fulks, high-scoring star for the Philadelphia Warriors.

David O. Selznick and Eagle- Lion have concluded "the first phase" of an association under which Eagle-Lion will re-release nine Selznick films and take over "the selling of additional accounts and the rebooking" of two other Selznick pictures, it was announced yesterday .

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Government workers here probably will have a dual reason for celebrating the President's inauguration Jan. 20. A two-day holiday -- or a four-day week-end -- became a likely prospect for them to day.

DETROIT, Jan. 12 -- Warning that world subservience to the Kremlin was the goal of Russia Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, asserted tonight that this country dare not relax for an instant its three-front counter-operation of military preparedness and political and economic stability at home and abroad.
GENEVA, Jan. 12 -- President Truman will be asked by the Economic Cooperation Administration to veto proposed increases in the price of coal exported from Western Germany.

Leaders of the National Maritime Union upheld yesterday its contract with the American Export Lines and ordered out a crew for the emergency transport liner Marine Carp, delayed over a dispute with some members of the old crew.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- President Truman journeyed by air to Pinehurst, N. C., this afternoon to see George C. Marshall while the convalescent General still holds the office of Secretary of State.

BOSTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Montreal's crippled Canadiens spotted the Bruins an early 3-1 lead and then stormed for a 5-3 National Hockey League triumph over Boston tonight before 13,000 fans at the Boston Garden.
Basketball ends its week's schedule in Madison Square Garden tonight with a double-header that will pit Temple against St. John's in the 8 o'clock opener and Syracuse against N.Y.U. in the nightcap.

Anglers interested in tournament bait casting will have all opportunity to compete for several awards during the National Sportsmen's Show, which will open for a nine-day run on Feb. 19 at Grand Central Palace.

Divorce is no solution to unhappy marriages in most cases because the same internal conflicts that cause marriages to break up persist afterward, it was agreed last night by a panel of psychiatrists who took part in a symposium on "The Psychiatric Aspects of Marital Problems."

There's little to keep a gardener busy these days, unless he happens to have a hothouse, in which case he will be found hustling to keep its temperature up as a never-ending parade of neighbors and friends tramps in and out stirring up cold drafts.

A city-wide survey by the Department of Sanitation revealed last night that residents in more than half of the sanitation districts in the city had improved their garbage disposal methods since the start of an intensified educational campaign two months ago.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora reserved decision yesterday on cross motions in a suit brought by E. J. Crofoot of Dallas, Tex., executive, against L. Mario Giannini, president of the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association of San Francisco; the bank itself, and other defendants.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Jan. 12 -- Villanova College's unbeaten basketball team rolled to its ninth straight victory tonight by swamping Fordham, 64 -- 35, before 2,500.

It was a gala occasion yesterday afternoon when Florence Reichman presented her collection of spring hats. Her showrooms, at 1 West Fifty-seventh Street, were packed to overflowing. Present were members of the visiting out-of-town press, the New York fashion press and buyers from all over the country.

CHICAGO, Jan, 12 -- Removal of hedges against sales of flour estimated at 1,500,000 or more sacks to the domestic trade gave the wheat market a firm undertone on the Board of Trade today and more than offset weakness in other grains.

Felix August Inslerman refused comment yesterday on the published report that he had been named by Whittaker Chambers before the espionage grand jury as one of those who developed the pumpkin microfilms.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Jan. 12 -- A hotel clerk, accused of refusing to rent a room to a Negro woman, was ordered today to appear for trial Jan. 27 on a charge of violating the state's civil rights law. The maximum penalty is a $500 fine, ninety days in jail, or both.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Home help like most other things in Britain has been in short supply. But if the new type of government-sponsored "household service" designed to provide efficient part-time help on a nationwide scale that is being organized by the National Institute of Houseworkers is successful, British women can look forward to increasing freedom from the kitchen sink and household chores.

It was a gala occasion yesterday afternoon when Florence Reichman presented her collection of spring hats. Her showrooms, at 1 West Fifty-seventh Street, were packed to overflowing. Present were members of the visiting out-of-town press, the New York fashion press and buyers from all over the country.

A series of nine open letters from James N. Rosenberg to Roland L. Redmond, president of the board of trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, attacking the institution's policies, was completed yesterday.

Off on the wrong foot in their game with the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden last night, the Rangers never were able to untrack themselves. The visitors, surviving early scares when the Blue Shirts missed what looked like certain scores, gradually took command and went on to a 4-to-1 triumph before 13,834 spectators.

If commodity prices fall further, and as industry's expansion programs approach completion, industrial and commercial loans may show some decline in 1949, S. Sloan Colt, president of the Bankers Trust Company, declared in his annual report, issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- W. W. Swift, an examiner for the Securities and Exchange Commission, today ended lengthy and involved hearings before the agency on the proposed merger of the Long Island Lighting Company and two subsidiaries.

The four-family apartment house at 32-57 Thirty-third Street, Long Island City, Queens, has been purchased by John and Helen Nadalin front Marie and Pierina Martini. The property, assessed at $13,500, occupies a plot 25.50 by 97.49 feet. Albert F. Candia was attorney for the buyers, who insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 12 (AP) -- University of Cincinnati reserves carried the load tonight as they led the unbeaten Bearcats to a 65-to-48 victory over St. Francis of Brooklyn. It was Cincinnati's seventh straight triumph.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- President Truman, in his recent message to Congress, used language in discussing monopoly curbs that did not differ materially from what almost every President, Democratic or Republican, has said on the sense subject over the past sixty or seventy years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Accusing the Federal Reserve Board of "depriving millions of Americans from owning automobiles they need and want to buy," Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, said today that he would ask Congress to curb the board's "abuse of credit powers."
Fourteen local housing authorities awarded $34,396,000 in short-term loan notes yesterday at interest rates ranging from 1.10 to 1:20 per cent.

The board of trustees of the Central Savings Bank have elected John P. Freeman a vice president, James T. Lee, president of the bank, announced yesterday. Mr. Freeman joined the bank as an appraiser in the real estate and mortgage department in 1931 and was appointed assistant vice president in 1946.

Provisions of the Taft-Hartley Law relating to injunction and non-Communist affidavits were examined last night by experts discussing the need for a new law for industrial labor peace. A radio forum discussion of the question, "What Kind of Labor Laws Do We Need?" was broadcast over Station WXQR.

STORRS, Conn., Jan. 12 (AP) -- President A. N. Jorgensen of the University of Connecticut said today that two students arrested with five New London men in connection with the alleged operation of a basketball gambling pool on the campus "will be expelled."
FORT WORTH, Tex., Jan. 12 (UP) -- Jasbo Fulkerson, the rodeo clown who became famous for flirting with death in arenas across the country, was killed in a truck accident, it was revealed today.

The extension of television's network from the Atlantic seaboard to the Middle West represents a milestone in many ways. Its importance as a technical triumph, of which both the television broadcasters and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company may be justly proud, was self-evident to those in New York who watched Mayor Martin Kennelly as he spoke in Chicago, some 700 air miles away.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 12 -- Leading Germans of influence in government, labor and industry have united in a carefully wrought program to frustrate non-German control of the Ruhr, it is indicated by an appraisal of reports in the German press plus private information from a reliable source.

A new and unusual strain of cat, essentially a cross of White Persian and Siamese, was presented yesterday at the forty-seventh annual championship cat show of the Atlantic Cat Club, opening in the McAlpin Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The State of Kansas today petitioned the Interstate Commerce Commission to cancel the new temporary rail freight-rate increases.
ATHENS, Jan. 12 -- A force of the Communist-led rebels estimated to number 2,000 men was today attacking the Macedonian agricultural center of Naoussa, the Greek General Staff reported.
