Oliver A. Hahne has been appointed director of industrial sales for the R. M. Hollingshead Corporation, Camden, N. J., manufacturers of Whiz brand products. He succeeds J. F. Jamison.

Joint action by the public and by federal, state and local Governments in the fight against heart disease was urged yesterday by Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 12 -- According to word from England, Rod Geiger's long delayed production of "Christ in Concrete" will go before the cameras early in March at J. Arthur Rank's Pinewood Studios, with Edward Dmytryk directing and Sam Wanamaker playing the leading role.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- An increase of u20,000,000 (about $80,000,000) in gold and dollar holdings of the sterling area in the closing quarter of last year was announced today by the British Treasury. At the end of December reserves were u457,000,000, compared with u437,000,000 at the end of September.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UP) -- Representatives of the steel industry today approved one new voluntary steel - sharing agreement, extended another and provided increased monthly quotas for three industries that are in need of steel.

In from Channel ports on her maiden voyage, wearing a gay green color, the new Caronia came up the bay at noontime, when thousands of New Yorkers could see her. They saw a ship beautiful in line, representing the latest expression of the shipbuilding art, for which her countrymen are justly famous.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 12 -- The Home Missions Council of North America, representing twenty-three Protestant denominations, voted overwhelmingly today to affiliate with the proposed National Council of the Churches of Christ in the United States of America.

Negotiations for a settlement of the dispute between tugboat workers and owners were going on at an early hour this morning at City Hall, where an eleventh-hour offer of the Marine Towing and Transportation Employers Association was being considered.
RHODES, Jan. 12 -- Egyptian and Israeli delegations arrived at Rhodes today for armistice talks. This was the first time that any Arab country had agreed to treat with Israel as a government.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Jan. 12 -- Directors of the Marine Trust Company promoted Clifford H. Cox from trust investment officer to vice president, Theodore F. Scharf from auditor and assistant treasurer to assistant vice president and auditor.

PEIPING, Jan. 13 -- The shelling of Peiping itself by the Communists began yesterday when three shells landed within the city walls -- it was thought then they were possibly "strays" -- and continued today when five shells landed in the center of the town.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- Arthur L. Horner, Communist General Secretary of the National Union of Mineworkers, was rebuked again today by his own union. This time a subcommittee appointed by the union's National Executive made a report saying that in having suggested Right-Wing labor leaders had prepared for war Mr. Horner was guilty of "slander without foundation."

VIENNA, Jan. 13 -- The recent change in the United States Secretaryship of State together with indications from London that military leaders of the Western powers doubt whether it would be safe to withdraw their armies from Austria in the near future have caused considerable nervousness in Vienna over prospects for a peace treaty.

CAIRO, Jan. 13 -- Two persons were killed and twenty-two injured today when a bomb exploded in the street in front of the Palace of Justice. It had been intended to blow up the office of the Prosecutor General handling the cases of the assassination of Premier Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha and other terrorist acts of members of the extremist Moslem Brotherhood.

Accessory departments of retail stores can expect an increase ranging from 4 to 10 per cent this spring, according to Bernard W. Smith, manager of the accessories division of Kirby, Block Co., Inc. Styles being featured, he pointed out at a clinic for accessory buyers of member stores which was held in the Governor Clinton Hotel, will require the use of scarfs, necklaces and other accessories.
MILWAUKEE, Jan. 13 -- The Milwaukee Sentinel said tonight that "all signs point to Charles (Bud) Wilkinson as the new University of Wisconsin football coach."

A survey of the ownership of over-the-counter securities just made by the National Association of Securities Dealers shows New York and California to rank first and second of the states where most of such stock is owned. The survey covered 1,260,421 stockholders and the 362 securities that are the most active of the 3,000 individual securities for which the association maintains a daily quotation service.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UP) -- The State Department's "Voice of America" was praised today by the same joint Senate subcommittee which heaped scorn on it last summer. Members of the Senate Investigating and Foreign Relations Committees, said broadcasts to foreign listeners had "been improved and made more vigorous" as a result of the Congressional inquiry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- President Truman reaffirmed United States policy toward Palestine today after Sir Oliver Franks, the British Ambassador, had submitted to him at a half-hour conference the views of his Government by direction of Foreign Secretary Bevin.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- The convic-ion of I. James Brody, former New York City Deputy Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, and James V. Auditore, one-time boss stevedore, on charges of conspiracy in the subleasing of city-owned piers was unanimously affirmed today by the Court of Appeals.

Four new exhibitions have opened in Greenwich Village or its immediate environs this week, and they are all marked by a respectable amount of fresh, if admittedly immature, talent. These shows include a lively, sprawling "open" annual in oils at the Village Art Center, two one-man shows and a graphic art group.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Senate passed tonight by a vote of 68 to 9, after heavy partisan fighting, a bill to raise the pay and allowances of the President, Vice President and Speaker of the House.
The largest seizure in this area of the bogus $20 bills that have flooded the country since last summer was reported yesterday by Government officials.

Saying that at this time the Liberal party was completely uncommitted, Adolf A. Berle Jr., its state chairman, declared yesterday that it expected to reach its own decision about candidates at the coming city election.
TOKYO, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Documentary evidence available in Tokyo today supplied the particulars of Emperor Hirohito's escape from prosecution as a war criminal.
Following is the list of sabbatical leaves approved yesterday for school system personnel by the Board of Education:

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 -- Liquidation was on in the grain and lard futures markets on the board of trade today, all commodities closing at the bottom under the leadership of soy beans. The latter closed 3 to 4 cents a bushel lower.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 13 -- A charge that the British Government had released 6,000 former Nazi war prisoners for service with Egyptian troops against Israeli forces was made public here today by The Nation Associates.

The four bridges and two tunnels operated by the Port of New York Authority handled 47,040,000 vehicles in 1948, the highest annual volume of traffic in their history, the preliminary annual report of the bi-state agency showed yesterday.

A substantial change in the volume of deposits or loans is unlikely this year, William S. Gray, president of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday. Mr. Gray added that he did not regard a change in the existing interest rate structure as "imminent -- either up or down."

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- The Court of Appeals ruled unanimously today that Long Island University may not set up a branch college on the Oyster Bay, L. I., estate of Mrs. Joseph E. Davies, under existing zoning restrictions.
Twelve of the thirty-five fresh vegetables checked yesterday by the city Department of Markets showed disheartening advances in price since last week-end.
PEIPING, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The Chinese Communists have laid down specific conditions for the beginning of national peace talks, a source here said today.

Their recent decline arrested, commercial, industrial and agricultural loans made by banks in this area, rose $26,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday. According to the data covering the reporting New York City member banks, issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, borrowings by oil companies, manufacturers, tobacco companies and meat packers were the major influences in the expansion.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 13 -- The course of events in Palestine is swift and unpredictable. One thing that can be counted on in this picture is change. It is a moving picture, different today from what it was two weeks ago and may be tomorrow.

The "manufacturing clause" in American copyright laws that prevents the sale here of books published in England; the imposition of duty on foreign-language books and the denial of copyright protection to juke-box music, were singled out for criticism last night by Dr. Luther Evans, Librarian of Congress.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 13 (AP) -- Persons living near Baltimore's Municipal Stadium cannot expect to have "the quiet and peace of the countryside" and will have to tolerate night baseball games, the Maryland Court of Appeals ruled today.
Calvary Cemetery, Middle Village, Queens, the city' largest Roman Catholic cemetery, where more than 1,500,000 persons have been buried in the last century, was hit by a strike yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Dean G. Acheson, nominee to succeed George C. Marshall as Secretary of State, told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that he was no appeaser. But he shunted aside cautiously put questions concerning his possible attitude toward Russia as the head of the State Department.

There are two schools of thought about the January thaw. One, which is inclined to be embittered and cynical, holds that the thaw is more vice than virtue. Not particularly enjoying a hair shirt, it nevertheless has steeled its nerves to face the rest of winter, and finds in January warmth a false witness as well as nature's deliberate effort to get the guard down.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- Heavy Cape and local selling caused another slide in prices of gold-mining shares on the stock market here today and by the close of trading losses up to 3s (60 cents) were seen throughout the list.

While their future status in the professional football picture remains a matter of conjecture, the New York Yankees of the All-America Conference continue active in the player marts. Signing of six new players was announced yesterday by Arthur E. Patterson, publicity director.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- President Truman today revoked an emergency conservation order covering oil and gas issued in a critical period one year ago. At the same time, the petroleum industry revealed a long-range policy for private development of this natural resource.

A committee to increase imports of noncompetitive goods from Europe to the United States was formed yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association at their annual convention in the Statler Hotel. B. Earl Puckett, president of Allied Stores, was named to head the group.

The Duncan-Paris Post No. 1422 received a legal setback yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber refused to compel the American Legion to restore a charter which the post contended had been issued to it in March, 1946, and which was suspended the following September.
GENEVA, Jan. 13 -- The Greek Government was criticized sharply today on the ground that it had failed to carry out its pledges to Jewish victims of Nazi racial persecution.

The New York Public Library submitted yesterday to Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson an estimate of $3,608,022 for operating funds during the 1949-50 fiscal year. This estimate is $541,467 above the current budget.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Federal Government would receive authority to return thousands of dwellings to rent control, including new housing, under a bill introduced in the Senate today.

Days begin to lengthen and cold begins to strengthen. After the countryman starts the fire in the shiny, nickel-plated range he stands a minute looking at the colorful Feed Store calendar hanging between the two south windows, with its picture of a summer meadow and cows pasturing among the daisy-starred grasses.

Glen Head Builders, Inc., have brought their operations to a close in the Hill Terrace development at Glen Head in the Oyster Bay section of Nassau County with the sale of the last three houses. The transactions were made by the Fred Berger Company, sales agent for the development, in cooperation with Theodore Miller.

NEWPORT NEWS, Jan. 13 -- The first of ten supertankers being built for the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) by the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company will be launched here at 11:30 A. M. tomorrow.

Representatives of all branches of the building business last night promised a long period of amicable relations and an efficient industry under more stable conditions that would help to keep construction costs down to the lowest possible point.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Jordan Olivar, young Villanova football coach, accepted an offer today to become head coach at Loyola University at Los Angeles.

Prosperity for the peoples of the United States and South America, economically, socially and politically depends upon cooperation of private, individual and collective interests, Dr. Alberto Dominguez Campora, Ambassador of Uruguay to the United States, declared yesterday at a luncheon of the Pan American Society at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The Realty Luncheon Club of New York will move next Monday to larger quarters in the Metropolitan Room of the Brass Rail Restaurant at Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street. Nathan Wilson, president, said the club had outgrown its present quarters at 25 East Fortieth Street and that the move would enable it to more than double its present membership.

A 27-year-old Presbyterian minister has been trying unsuccessfully for more than a year to compel Sailors Snug Harbor to admit him to its board of trustees in accordance with its charter, it was learned yesterday.

Olga Coelho's recitals at Town Hall have been a matter of anticipation by her admirers for six years. The attractive Brazilian soprano-guitarist's recital last night was no exception. The big audience, miffed at a few minutes' delay in curtain time, clapped like a Saturday matinee crowd at the movies until she put in her appearance.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- President Truman sent to the Senate today a list of nominations for Federal positions.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 13 -- Gov. Earle C. Clements said today that he would appoint Garrett L. Withers, State Highway Commissioner, to succeed Vice President-elect Alben W. Barkley in the Senate.

BERLIN, Jan. 13 (AP) -- British occupation authorities announced tonight that Max Reimann, Westrn German Communist party leader, would be tried next Tuesday on charges of obstructing Allied control of the Ruhr.

After a hearing that lasted for nearly three hours yesterday the Board of Education deferred voting on a resolution that would bar the International Workers Order from using public school buildings for children's classes after school hours.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 13 -- The American President Lines announced today that it would take delivery in the Gulf of Mexico next month of three reconstructed cargo ships of the C-3 design for operation between this country and the Far East.
Several smaller chain store companies and some independent grocers cut the price of milk yesterday 1 cent a quart to meet the reductions of the major chains.

Some places "Along Fifth Avenue" are better than others. In the revue by that title, which opened for business at the Broadhurst last evening, most of the best places came in the second act. Nancy Walker, the distaff clown, sings a very funny "Chant D'Amour" to Irving -- an objectionable character with whom she professes to be in love.

A potentially disastrous strike of the 3,500 tugboat workers employed in this harbor was averted last night with the announcement at 11 P. M. that an agreement had been reached at City Hall between the tugmen's union and the operators on the last remaining issues.

OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 13 -- Capt. William (Bill) Odom landed his single-engine monoplane at Oakland Airport tonight after ice on the wings had forced him to turn back from a point near Reno, Nev., on his projected non-stop flight from Honolulu to New York.

RHODES, Jan. 13 -- Egypt and Israel opened an entirely new phase in the Palestine situation when for the first time representatives of an Arab state met here today with those of Israel to negotiate an armistice on a broad basis.

NANKING, Jan. 13 (AP) -- China's National Government is approaching both military and financial bankruptcy at a speed that may cause its collapse without direct Communist attack on the capital, observers said today.

The proverbial dog's life promises to be a trifle more complex, although beneficially so, for local canines following the official opening yesterday of a drive to tattoo them for identification purposes.

At the close of the showing of his collection yesterday morning in the John-Frederics showrooms at 29 East Forty-eighth Street, Mr. Fred was the center of a surging and admiring crowd. Said one of his admirers: "Fred, you have the lipstick of nearly every fashion editor in the city on your cheeks."

ATHENS, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Field Marshal Alexander Papagos has rejected the job of Commander in Chief of Greek armed forces. He and the Government could not agree on the role of the National Defense Council, an authoritative source said today.

BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 13 -- The report of the members of the three-nation United Nations Good Offices Committee on the Indonesian dispute, who will visit Vice President Mohammed Hatta and other officials of the Indonesian Republic on Banka Island Saturday, will be cabled to the Security Council.

NANKING, Jan. 13 -- More than twenty 81-mm Communist mortar shells exploded yesterday on the airfield laid out alongside the famous Temple of Heaven at Peiping, with "scattered rounds" landing in the heart of China's cultural capital, it was revealed today in an uncensored first-hand report.
HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 13 -- A revitalized Dartmouth team, playing inspired basketball, upset heavily favored Holy Cross, 50 -- 44, before 2,800 fans at Alumni Gym today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13 -- During the current year there will be a definite shift to a buyers' market, with resultant price drops and an end of easy post-war profits, speakers predicted today at the second annual forecasting conference of the Philadelphia Chamber of Commerce Research Council.

Branch Rickey, behind a smoke screen generated by a steady supply of finest Havana perfectos, held his first press conference of the year at his Montague Street offices in Brooklyn yesterday and spiced his formal report on the state of the Dodgers with the following intriguing observations:

Among the participants in a New York Times radio forum Wednesday evening on "What Kind of Labor Laws Do We Need?" was Senator Wayne L. Morse of Oregon. And one of Senator Morse's suggestions was for a labor-management conference as a preliminary to legislation in that field.

New York University's hustling quintet, more impressive in every start, gave the steamroller treatment to Syracuse at Madison Square Garden last night. Piling up a 22-point advantage in the opening half, Howard Cann's pupils went on to hand a 68-45 trimming to the Salt City warriors.

The American military government in Germany is prepared to send over here a number of Germans for special training in psychiatry, Dr. George S. Stevenson, medical director of the National Committee for Mental Hygiene, declared yesterday on his return from Europe.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Jan. 12 -- The United Jewish Appeal, ending its annual sessions here today, set a goal of $250,000,000 to be raised among American Jews this year. The quota, unanimously adopted by 1,200 delegates, was termed the "irreducible minimum."

Selection of items that appeal to all income groups was listed yesterday as an important principle behind the successful premium promotions of the Kroger Company grocery store chain. The company's premium operations, which accounted for $3,500,000 of over-counter volume last year, were outlined by C. Robert Steltenkamp, Kroger's manager of special promotions, in a talk before the New York Premium Club at the Sheraton Hotel.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- A reduction in the assessed valuation of the Hotel Paramount, a nineteen-story commercial transient hotel in the Times Square district of New York, was ordered today by the Court of Appeals, which ruled that income and the sale of capital stock could not be used as a yardstick in determining valuation for taxing purposes.

Louis deRochemont, independent producer and president of Louis deRochemont Associates, will address the fourth annual convention banquet of the Screen Directors Guild, New York, to be held tomorrow night at the Longchamps Restaurant, 19 West Fifty-seventh Street.

A gift of $50,000 by John D. Rockefeller Jr. to the Community Service Society's fund drive for $1,400,000 was announced yesterday by Bayard F. Pope, president of the city's largest voluntary non-sectarian family and health agency.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The privately owned United States merchant fleet increased by one-fifth during 1948, the National Federation of American Shipping, Inc., reported today. At the same time American tonnage at sea declined because of a reduction in the vessels operated under bareboat charter from the Government.

Leopold Stokowski made his first appearance of the season as conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. There was immediately noticeable the greatly improved tone quality of the orchestra.

DETROIT, Jan. 13 -- Through proved flight-refueling methods American bombers based in the Midwest can bring virtually every militarily important sector of the globe within range, it was reported tonight in a paper presented to the Society of Automotive Engineers by one of Great Britain's leading experts in the use of flying tankers.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- The reconnaissance by the Royal Air Force that resulted in the loss of five planes last week was made on Britain's own responsibility, a Foreign Office spokesman said today. However, he added significantly, the United States State Department did agree a few weeks ago to the urgent need for indisputable information on the Israeli incursion into Egypt.

" People do not move through a passageway as water flows through a pipe." That was the opinion of Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, yesterday, when he denied the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company's request for permission to narrow stairways and passageways and convert the space into rental areas.
Cotton futures turned somewhat reactionary on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, and final prices were 12 to 20 points net lower.

Promotion of six officers of the Bank of New York and Fifth Avenue Bank to the rank of vice president was announced yesterday by John C. Traphagen, chairman. They include W. G. Button and Richmond P. Gardner at the Fifth Avenue office and Hugh R. Chace, Paul R. Dotterrer, Ralph C. Glock and L. M. Townsend at the main office.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- The State Nurses Association acted today to alleviate the fear of hospital administrators that they would be compelled to dismiss many auxiliary hospital workers when mandatory provisions of the Nurse Practice Act become effective April 1.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 13 (AP) -- Gustav, Ring's Rare Jewel captured the featured Shanballymore Purse today at Tropical Park.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 13 -- General Anastasio Somoza, dictator and War Minister of Nicaragua, has admitted that his military needs are being met by contraband shipments of arms from the United States.

Directors of the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., resumed the payment of dividends on the common stock with the declaration of 25 cents a share payable on April 1. The last one was distributed to common stockholders in 1928.

The Police Sports Association, which has made rapid strides in all sports with active encouragement from Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander, is expected to play a prominent role in the Metropolitan A. A. U. senior indoor track and field championships, which will be held tomorrow night at the 102d Engineers Armory.

In a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 6 Dr. Garrison Lipton attacked the Physicians Forum for its fight against the A. M. A. assessment of $25, stating "The Forum asks for $2 to help its plans. The A. M. A. asks for a larger amount to help its plans." Now, this is palpably misleading, and contains the misrepresentation which characterizes much A. M. A. propaganda.
Lee D. Nutter has been appointed manager of purchasing for the General Electric appliance and merchandising department. He formerly was assistant manager of purchasing.

For seven months, to December, the number of applications to the New York City Welfare Department for relief had shown a downward trend. In the last five weeks of 1948, however, the applications for public assistance rose 17 per cent over the previous five weeks.

FOR more than a month Happy Chandler has been very much like the fellow upstairs who dropped one shoe. The suspense had been unbearable while baseball men waited for that other shoe to fall. The first one plopped down with a clatter as he summoned both Leo Durocher and Freddie Fitzsimmons to appear before him on charges of tampering, darkly hinting that he'd have to weigh the evidence before giving the blackguards their come-uppance.

Hides futures trading volume during 1948 approached 16,000 contracts of 40,000 pounds each, compared with 12,573 contracts in 1947. Prices fluctuated between a high of 29.75 cents a pound for December delivery and the year's low of 19.40 cents.

Dr. Samuel M. Wishik, former assistant director of the division of health services of the United States Children's Bureau in Washington, has been named head of the Health Department's recently reorganized Bureau for Mothers and Young Children, Dr. Harry S. Mustard, Health Commissioner, announced yesterday.
Herbert Loewenthal, 50-year-old Bronx attorney, was appointed yesterday a Federal bankruptcy referee for the Southern District of New York to succeed Peter B. Olney, who retired on Dec. 31.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told guests at a luncheon of the Woman's National Press Club today that in view of Russian ideological tactics the hope of future freedom and peace lay in an American demonstration of human rights in a democracy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Those citizens who were closely following the returns of the 1948 Presidential election in the early hours of Nov. 3, and especially those whose business it was to inform the public of the outcome, will not soon forget the wobbling count in Ohio and California through the night.

Net operating earnings of the Irving Trust Company in 1948 totaled $6,802,647, or $1.36 a share, compared with $6,305,551, or $1.26 a share in the previous year, according to the bank's annual report, to be published today. The report, signed by Harry E. Ward, chairman, and William N. Enstrom, president, is being made available in advance of the annual meeting of stockholders next Wednesday.

The letter of Dr. Henry D. Gideonse about Indonesia printed on Jan. 10 was helpful for removing some misunderstandings, but I feel that it needs reinforcement from bedrock. Dr. Gideonse covered admirably the most important points in the skirmish line of the current debate.

Teachers of economics in colleges and universities throughout the United States are studying a plan to incorporate the basic principles of Christianity in their courses as a means of combatting the spread of communism, it became known yesterday.

Msgr. John Patrick Carroll-Abbing, founder and director of Italy's Boys Town, and the Rt. Rev. Stephen C. Neill, assistant to the Bishop of Canterbury, arrived at La Guardia Airport at 5:50 o'clock last evening on a Trans World Airline plane.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- Louis Hollander, president of the State Congress of Industrial Organizations, announced here today a legislative program calling for disability insurance, increased unemployment and workmen's compensation benefits and a state minimum wage of $1 an hour.

NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 13 -- Ike Williams, Trenton boxer who defended his world lightweight title three times last year, today was named the outstanding professional athlete in New Jersey for 1948 by the Newark Athletic Club.
ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- Senator Benjamin F. Feinberg, President Pro Tern of the Senate, proposed today that the distribution and sale of comic books be regulated by the State Department of Education.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- The imprisonment of Bishop Lapos Ordass, head of the Lutheran Church in Hungary, and the arrest of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, Roman Catholic Primate of Hungary, were denounced here today by Dr. Geoffrey Francis Fisher, Archbishop of Canterbury.

The majority of hosiery manufacturers have adjusted themselves to the competitive market, it was pointed out by speakers at the hosiery industry forum which opened yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. From the retailers' standpoint, prices are still too high, it was stressed, and too large a percentage of output is lacking in quality.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Taxpayers of the middle-income bracket who should pay more under the new tax program are defined by the Treasury Department as those earning from $6,000 to $25,000 or $30,000 a year, President Truman said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- A. Texan walked into President Truman's office today and flourished a couple of pearl-handled pistols. But nobody was alarmed.

The police broke up a mass picketing demonstration in front of the Gage Tollner restaurant at 374 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, last night by arresting thirty-nine of the pickets on disorderly conduct charges. The demonstrators were taken to the Butler Street station in two patrol wagons.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Jan. 13 -- Beardsley Ruml, noted economist, said today an analysis of President Truman's recently proposed budget fails to show the necessity for the new federal taxes recommended by the Chief Executive to provide an additional $4,000,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- United States shipments to Russia dived below $50,000 in November for the third time in five months, the Census Bureau reported today. In October they had been $500,000.
GENEVA, Jan. 10 -- A considerable reservoir of skilled labor remains untapped in the displaced persons' camps of Europe, the International Refugee Organization reporter today.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Jan. 13 -- "I have always been opposed to communism and all totalitarian dictatorships," President Frank P. Graham of the University of North Carolina asserted in a telegram sent tonight to Fulton J. Lewis Jr., the radio commentator.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 13 -- The United Nations Security Council took an hour and a half out today to congratulate its commission, itself, India and Pakistan for reaching agreement on settling the year-old Kashmir dispute.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 13 -- The Atlas National Bank has announced the ellection of Fred A. Dowd as president to succeed Joseph F. Partl, resigned. Mr. Dowd, a former Kentucky bank examiner, resigned as a vice president of the First National Bank here to accept the Atlas presidency.
MOSCOW, Jan. 13 (AP) -- That tired feeling creeping over you? Take a lemonnik.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- President Truman today refused to be drawn publicly into the one-package versus two-package approach to labor legislation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- During the week ended Jan. 12, member bank reserve balances decreased $270,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

PARIS, Jan. 9 -- One thing frequently overlooked in the hysteria of the diplomatic and propaganda conflict between the Soviet Union and the United States is the economic ability of the Soviet Union to wage a war.

The Board of Estimate returned yesterday to the City Council a bill recently passed by that body to strengthen city controls over rents in hotels and apartment hotels. The measure was recommitted after a spokesman for Council Vice President Joseph T. Sharkey told the board the Temporary City Housing Rent Commission wanted some changes made in it.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- Thousands of people -- a small segment of millions who had laughed at the quips, jokes and antics of Britain's top radio comedian, Tommy Handley, during the last ten years -- lined the six-mile route to Golder's Green Crematorium today to pay their last respects to the man they knew better as "Itma."

Dean Acheson's frank and courageous testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee yesterday strengthened the impression most of us already had that he will make a good Secretary of State. He had been criticized in some quarters for an earlier belief, or seeming belief, that we could get an understanding with Russia by further concessions.

Unqualified opposition to a bill that would give the State Housing Commissioner full authority over the construction of about 80,000 apartments, expected to be built with city and Federal aid, was registered yesterday by Thomas F. Farrell, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- Republican legislative leaders today challenged Democrats in the Legislature to join with them in asking President Truman to allow New York State to proceed with development of the hydro-electric resources of the St. Lawrence River without waiting for Congressional authorization of a combination seaway-power project.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The broad outline of a government-wide program to improve Federal accounting and financial reporting was announced today. Lindsay C. Warren, Controller General, described it as "the most forward step along this line ever taken by the government."

PARIS, Jan. 13 -- Abolition of tariffs between France and Italy by 1950 is expected to be recommended to the two Governments by the joint French-Italian Commission preparing the way for a customs union. The commission, now meeting in Paris, probably will also urge that France and Italy adopt a common policy in international economic negotiations in the European Council for the Marshall Plan, as the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxemburg have done.

The city's school system faces the possibility of a strike that might "shut down" its hundreds of buildings, it was pointed out yesterday by Patrick J. Conway, business agent for Local 94, International Union of Operating Engineers, AFL.

As a result of the severe storms and heavy snows in the West and Midwest, cash letters forwarded by the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis to banks in the Ninth Federal Reserve District have not been received by the drawee banks in many instances, and the situation is particularly acute in South Dakota, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Minneapolis, Minn., announced yesterday that it would receive bids Feb. 2 on bond issues totaling $2,438,000, besides the issue of $2,000,000 of refunding bonds already posted for sale at that time. The issue announced yesterday is to be dated March 1, 1949, and to mature March 1, 1950 to 1979.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Choice beef steaks and roasts will be more plentiful the rest of the winter and the coming spring than last year. This was indicated by an Agriculture Department report today that livestock farmers have a record number of cattle being fattened on grain and other concentrated feeds for the slaughter market.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- Increased exports to the United States and other hard currency markets backed up by a rise in productivity at home, are major economic objectives of Great Britain this year, Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer and Minister for Economic Affairs, said at a press conference here today.

The present effort to obtain more teachers places too much emphasis on the material aspects of teaching and too little on its "dynamic function in building a better world," Dean Millicent Carey McIntosh of Bernard College, asserted last night.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 12 -- American business men were urged here today by Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer to take a new inventory of the nation's resources with a view toward making "full use of our energies and our talents."
TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur today loosened the strings on foreign business activities in Japan so as to attract more international trade.

The Presidential inauguration on Thursday will be covered by WOV for its Italian-speaking listeners on the basis of what its announcers here see on a television screen carrying scenes of the event in Wahsington, it was announced yesterday.

The appointment as vice presidents of George A. Peer, formerly treasurer; William G. DeWitt,. Seymour Dribben and Eugene W. Stetson Jr., formerly assistant vice presidents, was announced yesterday by N. Baxter Jackson, chairman of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, following the annual organization meeting of the board.

Emil Klein, formerly vice president of the New York Custom Tailors Designers Association, was elected president of that organization last night at a meeting in the Engineering Societies Building. He replaces Victor Nafz of Saks Fifth Avenue.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Twenty-three harness horses died today in a fire that leveled a winter stable at Saratoga Raceway.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 13 -- Atomic control negotiations, deadlocked for more than two years and near the point of cancellation a few months ago, will be taken up here again within two weeks, it was learned today.

Reporting yesterday on operations last year of the Chase National Bank, Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board, informed the bank's 89,851 shareholders that net earnings in 1948 were $17,579,000, equal to $2.37 a share, compared with $19,826,000, or $2.68 a share. earned the year before.

NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 13 -- A bass fiddle that collapses in three parts and will take up no more room in a case than a baritone saxophone has been invented by Peter Ruggiero, 30-year-old musician, of 95 South Munn Avenue, this city, he disclosed today.

Monday will be the deadline for filing original and amended declarations of estimated income taxes for 1948, it was said yesterday by James W. Johnson, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Third New York Collection District.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 13 (AP) -- College football coaches were curbed in master mind operations from the bench and offense was encouraged as the National Collegiate Athletic Association ended its football rules committee annual session today.

PARIS, Jan. 13 -- Antoine Pinay, Minister of Economic Affairs, said today that the decrees for limiting and reducing prices adopted by the Cabinet yesterday did not mean a return to a controlled economy.

The mild weather of the past fall not only spoiled much of the shooting for the duck hunters, but may have an effect on the future quality of the fishing in some northern New England waters unless spring arrives early this year.

ITHACA, Jan. 13 -- American colleges and universities are seeking a record sum of $2,000,000,000 to help meet the demands of unprecedented enrollment, Dr. Asa S. Knowles, vice president of Cornell University, declared here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UP) -- Louis B. Mayer, movie producer, heads filmdom's high-salary list for 1948 so far, with earnings of $733,074 from Loew's, Inc., according to the Securities and Exchange Commission today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Supreme Command for the Allied Powers in Japan issued new regulations today liberalizing controls over business activities by foreigners in that country.

In their efforts further to improve efficiency, the nation's railroads will spend in the first quarter of 1949 $100,000,000 more on improvements than in the similar period of 1948, William T. Faricy, president of the Association of American Railroads, said last night.

The New York City Ballet Company last night opened its first independent season as a unit of the City Center aggregation of producing organizations in the various arts. Heretofore it has appeared in the City Center only as a subsidiary of the opera season, but last night's was the first of ten-scheduled performances of ballet alone.

Judge Harold R. Medina reserved decision in Federal Court yesterday on a defense motion asking a ninety-day postponement of the trial of twelve Communist leaders scheduled to begin Monday. The judge said he would announce his decision after receiving affidavits that defense counsel are to file this morning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat of Colorado, said today that he had urged Paul G. Hoffman, European Recovery Administrator, to delay an order cutting Marshall Plan shipments on American vessels.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UP) -- Senate Democrats and Republicans got into a dispute tonight over who is responsible for the elaborate and costly plans for President Truman's inauguration. Senator Wayne Morse, Republican, of Oregon, started it with a charge that the event would be "a Roman holiday" and would "waste many thousands of dollars of the taxpayers' money."

THREE RIVERS, Tex., Jan. 13 (UP) -- This South Texas town apologized tonight to the family of the late Felix Longoria for "an incredible situation" which prevented his being buried here beside his Latin-American ancestors.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 13 -- Great hopes are held here for the armistice talks at Rhodes, but everyone is waiting for the outcome with fingers crossed. It appears that if peace is not reached this time, the repercussions will be felt throughout the Middle East and probably the world, political experts here believe.

ROME, Jan. 13 (UP) -- Pope Pius XII urged Catholic clergymen in the United States today to redouble their efforts toward gaining admittance for refugees and called on members of the Orders of Friars Minor Capuchin to keep the masses away from "fallacious ideologies."

The 115-19 West Fifty-second Street Corporation, Thomas J. McDonough, president, and others, executors of the estate of Patrick J. Mulkern, sold the three-story business building with two stores at that address to a client of Louis B. Brodsky, who leased the entire structure to a restaurant.

The energy and "progressiveness" of the Cunard White Star Line in maintaining high quality service in the transatlantic route was praised yesterday by G. Joseph Minetti, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, in a luncheon aboard the new liner Caronia at Pier 90, North River.

Despite the handicap of increasing yearly deficits, the American Museum of Natural History announced yesterday plans for a new series of exhibits designed to emphasize that the study of man's environment is not an intellectual luxury but a practical necessity.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The Indonesian Republican office here said today the Sumatra emergency goverement had broadcast details of extensive scorched-earth tactics against the Dutch.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 13 -- The United States delegation is drafting a resolution under which the United Nations Security Council would call on the Netherlands to hold elections throughout Indonesia (Netherlands East Indies) under United Nations supervision, it was disclosed today.

Robert Burke, 25 years old, of 39-44 Forty-sixth Street, Sunny-side, Queens, was acquitted yesterday in Long Island City Court of Special Sessions of charges of impairing the morals of a minor and indecent exposure.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 13 -- Warner Brothers today announced that Jane Wyman and Dennis Morgan will go before the cameras in a comedy, "The Octopus and Miss Smith," during the first week in February, ending a virtual production shutdown at the studio which has lasted twelve weeks.

Deputy Chief Joseph M. Ziegler, one of the four high ranking officers of the New York Fire Department facing departmental charges for attending a firehouse party on Dec. 16, has retired, Commissioner Frank J. Quayle announced yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 13 -- Aubrey S. Eban, Israeli representative to the United Nations, emphasized here today that "peace must be founded on the full territorial and political integrity of Israel," in listing other peace conditions.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 13 (AP) -- Gardnar Mulloy, top-seeded Davis Cup star from Miami, defeated Marshall Feld of Florida Southern College, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 0, and Johnny Dennis of St. Petersburg, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2, in the Florida West Coast tennis tournament today.

LONDON, Jan. 13 (U.P.) -- Moscow radio renewed today its criticism of Serge Sergeyevich Prokofieff, Soviet composer, complaining that his works were "not quite up to the mark this year" and did not follow the official Soviet music "line."
Indications appeared yesterday that Mr. and Mrs. Felix August Inslerman had agreed to cooperate more fully hereafter with the espionage grand jury.

The Town House, twenty-four-story apartment hotel at 104-14 East Thirty-eighth Street, in the Murray Hill section of Manhattan, has been purchased by Town and Country Hotels, Inc., operators of a chain of hotel properties in the metropolitan area.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 13 -- The McGrath-Neely Bill, which would open the United States to 400,000 displaced persons as against 200,000 now provided for in the Revercomb Act, was endorsed here today by the Home Missions Council of North America.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 13 -- The Argentine Communist party today attacked President Juan Peron's proposed new Constitution as a betrayal of the workers, a step toward the suppression of all civil liberties, and a move toward concentrating the nation's power in the hands of one party and its boss.

The ouster of Austin Hogan as president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, was made official yesterday when night workers voted 175 to 3 to endorse the removal resolution adopted Wednesday night by 2,500 day workers.

Applications for retirement under the Federal old-age insurance program have risen slightly in the last few weeks, but in only a few spots are there signs that the increase is attributable to declining employment opportunities for elderly workers.

Efforts of isolationist interests in this country to discredit the Marshall Plan will be dealt with in a study that the Economic Cooperation Administration is preparing on aluminum. ECA officials indicated yesterday that this analysis has been undertaken with the aid of Marshall Plan countries and the American aluminum industry.

Plans for an apartment building to cost $3,000,000 and to occupy the site at 860 Fifth Avenue, 2 and 4 East Sixty-eighth Street and 3 East Sixty-seventh Street were filed yesterday by the 860 Fifth Avenue Corporation, of 274 Madison Avenue.

Ferry boat passengers and ocean travelers will sea strange steel structure begin to rise from the middle of New York Harbor next week. It win be the skeleton of the central ventilating building for the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, Ralph Smillie, chief engineer for the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, explained yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 13 -- A quarter of a million Arab refugees in Egyptian-held Palestine will soon be getting a diet of 1,800 calories daily, Delbert Replogle, director of the Quaker group that is administering United Nations relief in this area, said today.

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 14 -- The Economist, influential and politically independent British weekly, criticized today Foreign Secretary Bevin's handling of the Palestine situation. It characterized British moves as "saber rattling" inspired by a fit of bad temper in Mr. Bevin.

The Navy began yesterday a nation-wide drive to enlist 75,000 skilled construction workers as reserve members of the Seabees. They will be trained in the technique of high-speed advance base building, a skill that won them fame in the last war.
" Miss Liberty," the impending Irving Berlin-Robert E. Sherwood musical, is swinging into high gear. Only the other day the production was moved up from next season to this.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 13 -- It was learned tonight that the Yugoslav Government was trying to market $15,000,000 worth of copper and lead in the United States as an initial step toward establishing a credit balance with which to purchase machinery and essential raw materials now being denied to Yugoslavia by Communist Information Bureau countries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Department store sales in the week ended Jan. 8 were 9 per cent above sales in the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- President Truman vigorously defended Dr. Frank P. Graham, president of the University of North Carolina, today and expressed doubt that anyone had disapproved his clearance by the United States Atomic Energy Commission to handle confidential atomic data.

VIENNA, Jan. 13 -- United States Army military police and Austrian criminal police swooped down on an apartment in Vienna's Inner City in a black market raid today and made a richer haul than they had expected.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- French Foreign Minister Robert Schuman, accompanied by several of his top-ranking experts, arrived here this morning and began conversations with Foreign Secretary Bevin and members of the Foreign Office. The meeting will last two days, during which time the entire range of Anglo-French interests in Europe, the Middle East and the Far East is expected to be reviewed.
On Feb. 19 the 110th Street Community Center, Inc., begins its second year as the city's only thoroughgoing inter-racial, inter-cultural social center.

After providing for his family, Carl Gustave Swebelius, a small-arms manufacturer who died last October, set up a trust fund of several millions which was to be spent in finding out the cause and cure of cancer and epilepsy. The humanitarian motives that prompted him to dispose of his fortune in this fashion deserve to be acclaimed.

First of the distance sailing races in northern waters this year will be that of the Storm Trysail Club. Members of the organization gathered for an informal dinner meeting in the New York Yacht Club last night and discussed plans for the organization's annual event, which again will be held Memorial Day out around Block Island.

America's railroads undertook an unprecedentedly large program of equipment trust financing in 1948 to meet the cost of acquiring new freight cars, Diesel locomotives and passenger cars. Seventy-eight issues of serial obligations maturing in from ten to fifteen years and totaling $426,502,000 were marketed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey took over the chairmanship of Americans for Democratic Action today with a press conference suggestion that Congress should enact all the Democratic platform pledges and that Great Britain should "keep her nose" out of the Palestine problem.

Just as the health clinics perform free services, so must there be free legal aid to the poor, Surrogate George Frankenthaler declared yesterday at the opening of the Legal Aid Society's 1949 campaign to raise $200,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- United States Marshal Fred A. (Bull) Canfil of Kansas City, Mo., center of a controversy a year ago, was nominated today by President Truman for another term.

With a midnight strike deadline only two hours away, the City Division of Labor Relations won a one-week postponement last night in a threatened walkout of bus and trolley car employes that would have deprived 200,000 Queens residents of their normal means of transportation.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13 -- Directors of the California Bank, at their annual organization meeting yesterday, voted to issue 40,000 additional shares, bringing outstanding stock to 300,000 shares. Shareholders of record of Jan. 15 may subscribe to rights at the ratio of one share for each six and one-half shares held.

Six settings for midwinter frivolity are presented in a group of table displays which will be on view today in Macy's dinnerware department. All of the tables are designed for "drop-in-afterward" suppers -- after the theatre, after the opera, after Madison Square Garden, or after Carnegie Hall.
Snow-starved skiers will continue to be patient, for the reports from the Northlands yesterday were still discouraging.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 13 -- There are concrete indications that the Western Allies are approaching one of the most critical periods in the operation, of their policies on the creation of a Western German government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- President Truman proposed to the Senate today that Gen. Omar N. Bradley, Army Chief of Staff; Admiral Raymond A. Spruance, retired, and Gen. Carl Spaatz, retired Air Force Chief of Staff, be confirmed in the ranks they now hold.

The Army Corps of Engineers commissioned yesterday a new $450,000 debris-collecting vessel, the Driftmaster, in a ceremony at Pier 11, East River, and then took a group of guests and officials on a demonstration run in the harbor.

Six settings for midwinter frivolity are presented in a group of table displays which will be on view today in Macy's dinnerware department. All of the tables are designed for "drop-in-afterward" suppers -- after the theatre, after the opera, after Madison Square Garden, or after Carnegie Hall.
Snow-starved skiers will continue to be patient, for the reports from the Northlands yesterday were still discouraging.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 13 -- There are concrete indications that the Western Allies are approaching one of the most critical periods in the operation, of their policies on the creation of a Western German government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- President Truman proposed to the Senate today that Gen. Omar N. Bradley, Army Chief of Staff; Admiral Raymond A. Spruance, retired, and Gen. Carl Spaatz, retired Air Force Chief of Staff, be confirmed in the ranks they now hold.

The Army Corps of Engineers commissioned yesterday a new $450,000 debris-collecting vessel, the Driftmaster, in a ceremony at Pier 11, East River, and then took a group of guests and officials on a demonstration run in the harbor.
OSLO, Norway, Jan. 13 -- The talks on the feasibility of a Nordic mutual defense have entered the final stage here in an atmosphere of gloom and pessimism.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- The Court of Appeals agreed today to hear re-arguments during its next session in the case of Benjamin Feldman, 41, Brooklyn pharmacist who was twice convicted of murdering his wife with strychnine poison.

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony, Leopold Stokowski, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 2:45 o'clock; "Lucia Di Lammermoor" (students' performance), at 1:30, and "Siegfried," at 7:45, Metropolitan Opera; Harry Davis, piano, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Joseph Battista, piano, Town Hall, 8:30; Xenia Boodberg, piano, Times Hall, 8:30.

" Union Guy," by Clayton W. Fountain, a personal and "unghosted" account of the building of the United Automobile Workers Union, CIO, will be published Feb. 18 by Viking Press. Mr. Fountain, who has been a member in good standing in that union since 1937, was for a time a Communist and has since helped rid the union of Communists.

The Society for the Prevention of World War III, Inc. denounced yesterday the recently announced plan for the international control of the Ruhr. It said the statute failed to "satisfy the basic security requirements of the United States and called the program a product "of the same men and same ideas which put new life into German militarism after World War I."

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 5 -- Out of the utter confusion that is Burma after one year of independence, one impression comes clearly: none of the continual fusing and fissioning of Burma's amorphous politics, her economic prostration, her four-pronged civil war, or the tide of communism is primarily Burma's headache.

Tony Pellone of Greenwich Village and Vincent Foster of Omaha, a pair of welterweights of considerable promise, will furnish the action in tonight's main bout at Madison Square Garden. It will be a ten-rounder. The supporting features -- Roland La Starza vs. Bill Weinberg and Arthur King vs. Willie Beltram -- are booked for eight rounds each.

As Congress prepares to review the European Recovery Program, on which the United States has already spent $5,000,000,000 and is asked to provide $5,550,000,000 more until the middle of 1950, the French and British Foreign Ministers meet in London to make their own survey and to discuss ways and means of making the program more effective.

CAIRO, Jan. 13 -- Oil men here and Egyptian Government experts indicated today that the big oil well brought in by the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., about fifty miles south of the Suez Canal in the Sinai Peninsula might mean that Egyptian oil production soon would exceed Egyptian needs.

Yesterday in her spring collection, viewed at 78 East Fifty-sixth Street, Lilly Dache added a new facet to her already well-known reputation as a milliner that of a full scale designer of coats, suits and dresses. For this showing not only divided honors equally between her designs but it was also the occasion of her announcement to go into the wholeslae production of her clothes creations later in the spring.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended on Jan. 8, 1949, totaled 721,507 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 136,879 cars, or 23.4 per cent more than in the preceding week, 109,303 cars, or 13.2 per cent less than for the corresponding week last year, and 109,446 cars, or 13.2 per cent less than during the corresponding week of 1947.

Discovery of an extensive deposit of manganese in Aroostook County, Me., was reported last night by Gov. Frederick G. Payne in an address at the forty-fifth annual dinner of the Maine Society of New York in the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Jan. 13 -- A funeral service for Nelson Doubleday, chairman of the board of Doubleday Co., Inc., book publishers, was held in the Cathedral of the Incarnation here today. One thousand persons, including many writers and employes of Doubleday Co., which had closed today out of respect, filled the cathedral.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- A challenge of the non-Communist affidavit proviso of the Taft-Hartley Law gave the Supreme Court today the opportunity to settle the question whether the Communist party was more than a political party.

Traders in the stock market found little yesterday to warrant any change in their sidelines position and prices merely drifted lower. Changes of more than a point were few, the composite rate dipping 0.59 point. Trading shrank further despite a flurry of activity in a few issues and volume in the Stock Exchange reached only 700,000 shares, compared with 710,000 shares on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Counsel for the Transamerica Corporation of San Francisco said today that big branch competitors of banks in which the huge holding company has an interest had contributed "more than $63,000" during the last three years to a lobby fund used to oppose Transamerica.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Farnsworth Television and Radio Corporation, Fort Wayne, Ind., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 270,000 shares of its $1 par value common stock.

The Downtown A. C. took the lead in Group 1, Class C, of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association last night by winning, 4 to 1, from the Rockaway Hunting Club. The victors now have a total of twenty-three victories and only seven defeats, with three weeks of competition remaining.

Grand Champion Rippowam Silver Buster, a 9-year-old Persian cat owned by Mrs. Ralph A. Wilkinson, was judged last night the best cat of the forty-seventh annual championship all-breed cat show held at the McAlpin Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Hoover Commission urged Congress today to give the President broad power, subject to its veto, to initiate administrative reforms not requiring direct legislative action. President Truman is expected to send a special message to Capitol Hill soon supporting the request.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, director of Selective Service, called the national draft system virtually to a halt today with an order discontinuing immediately delivery of registrants to the Army for pre-induction physical examinations, and classification of anyone as available for the draft.

While newcomers to pleasure boating and dyed-in-the-brine old skippers were making another crowded day at the National Motor Boat Show yesterday, climbing on board the displayed cruisers, signing deposit checks for orders and generally swapping yarns as mariners are wont to do, nearly one hundred big-wigs left Grand Central Palace for a couple of morning hours to hold a safety conference across Lexington Avenue at the Hotel Shelton.
Volume selling by trade and commission houses depressed hide future prices on the Commodity Exchange 35 to 87 points yesterday. Activity was confined in a large part to the near-by March position.
TOKYO, Jan. 13 -- The registration of candidates for the Japanese general election on Jan. 23 closed tonight with 1,367 men and women running for the 466 seats in the Diet's lower house.
The Retail Clerks International Association, AFL, with an announced membership of 250,000, made public yesterday plans to spend $1,000,000 to organize more workers in the store.
One of the world's largest chain restaurants is operated in the city by the division of dietetics of the Department of Hospitals.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 -- Harold Glasser, director of the institute on overseas studies of the Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds, sharply denounced the International Refugee Organization here today "for not carrying out its elementary responsibilities for the care of European Jewish DP's and their resettlement in Israel."

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Britain's preoccupation with increasing export sales to Canada was demonstrated today in an appeal by A. G. Bottomley, Secretary for Overseas Trade, for exceptional efforts on the part of exporters to develop sales in the Dominion.

PARIS, Jan. 9 -- According to a detailed report received by this correspondent Lavrenti P. Beria, Deputy Premier, who is believed to be chairman of the Soviet Union's atomic energy commission, has established a large underground factory to produce fissionable materials from uranium on the Sanga River a few miles north of Erivan, capital of the Armenian Soviet Socialist Republic.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., which accounts for about 75 per cent of the $65,000,000 annual production of cellophane, is offering to license competitors to use its cellophane patents gratis, it was announced yesterday. It is also offering to help prospective competitors to get started through the loan of key workers and other assistance.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UP) -Following is the text of the State Department's foreign affairs outline, "Building the Peace":

If, for any reason, legal or otherwise, the Dodgers should not be permitted to put their Negro players on the field in a three-game series of exhibition games scheduled for Atlanta in April, there'll be no games.

DETROIT, Jan. 14 -- Boredom has become an increasingly acute economic problem for the aviation industry on long flights, it was reported to day to the closing sessions of the Society of Automotive Engineers.

Reports from a number of waterfowl guides and hunters in the Long Island, Connecticut and New Jersey coastal areas indicate that the duck kill was well under last year and far below average, despite the increased number of ducks in the areas concerned.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- John Foster Dulles, acting head of the United States delegation to the United Nations, today termed the world organization "the only thing which I see that will stand between us and a third world war."

Shift of the Newark franchise of the International Baseball League to either Montreal or Dexter Park, Queens, home of the semi-professional Bushwicks, is under consideration, Frank Shaughnessy, league president, disclosed last night to The Associated Press.

Vince Foster, the human tornado who tore out of Nebraska a few weeks ago to startle local boxing followers with a victory over Nick Mistovich, continued his path of destruction last night in Madison Square Garden when he knocked out rugged little Tony Pellone of Greenwich Village in the seventh of their scheduled ten-round bout.

In a report prepared last fall for a speech before the aluminum advisory committee of the Munitions Board the conclusion was reached that shipments of virgin aluminum financed by ECA had "created a surplus of this metal in Western Europe." In support of this conclusion the report pointed to figures showing sizable shipments to this country of scrap aluminum.
LONDON, Jan. 14 -- The brightest section in an otherwise dull stock market here today was that for British Government bonds which showed fractional gains on institutional investment buying.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee put extension of rent control at the top of its list of important legislation today. A subcommittee was named to begin early hearings.

Of the 1,555 persons convicted in Kings County Court of felonies in 1948, 31.4 per cent were defendants under 21 years old, according to the annual report of Francis J. Sinnott, county clerk, made public yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Justice Harry E. Schirick of the Supreme Court reserved decision today on an application for the sale of cemetery property which the state opposes.

In your news story of Dec. 27 you report the findings of the inquiry committee set up by the Social Science Research Council to ascertain why the public opinion polls failed to predict the results of the recent Presidential election. It seems to me that a crucial fact has been entirely overlooked.

In your editorial of Jan. 7, "Is the 'College' Necessary?" you admit that it is. And it most certainly is if these United States are to continue as a federal republic of sovereign and independent states. And we can be a democracy and a federal republic at the same time.

The one-story taxpayer containing twenty-one stores and occupying the blockfront at 50 to 64 West Burnside Avenue, between Grand land Harrison Avenues in the Bronx, has been sold by Green Seltzer to an investor. It was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $308,000 through E. Osborne Smith, Inc., broker.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 14 -- The Foreign Ministry confirmed informally tonight that President Peron's proposal in the new constitution to expel or force citizenship upon foreigners after two years' residence here would apply only to immigrants arriving after promulgation the charter and not retroactively.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Assemblyman Richard H. Knauf, Broome County Republican, introduced a bill today to establish a forty-eight-hour work week for state police, with time-and-a-half pay for overtime.

To 10-year-old Karen Goodman, a victim of cerebral palsy, tomorrow will be an extra-special day. The little girl, who came here by plane last month from South Africa for treatment to strengthen her legs and who wants to "dance like other children," will be a guest of the New York City Ballet Company at the matinee performance in the New York City Center.

Staten Island commuters went about their city tasks yesterday with apparent calmness undisturbed by the question whether or not they were going to be able to dunk their crullers in their coffee as they made their twenty-three minute ferryboat trip across the bay.
GENEVA, Jan. 14 -- The executive committee of the International Refugee Organization will meet in Geneva on Jan. 25, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Senator Francis J. Myers, Democrat, of Pennsylvania, will invite spokesmen for organized labor and a group of Senators to confer with him soon on how to further proposals for social legislation pledged by the Democratic party.

The need for more efficient store operation was emphasized yesterday at a session on distributive education held by the National Retail Dry Goods Association in the Statler Hotel. The session terminated the thirty-eighth annual convention of the association.

Ski conditions improved overnight as new snows visited many of the upstate regions and made for good sport this week-end. In New England, new covers, too, were reported; generally there wasn't enough snow at the time to get enthusiasts excited about, only that a base is now to be had.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- A bill now before the Legislature, designed to facilitate the development of power resources of the St. Lawrence River, would at the same time prevent the state from going into competition with existing public utility companies, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- President Truman's nomination of Dean G. Acheson to succeed George C. Marshall as Secretary of State was approved unanimously by the thirteen-member Senate Foreign Relations Committee today.

The main ballroom of the RitzCarlton was the setting last night for the annual Yorkville Dinner Dance, which is given to aid the cultural and recreational projects of the Yorkville Community Association, now in its thirty-fifth year. Mrs. Eliot Lee Ward was chairman of the fete.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- As the Freedom Train neared the end of its historic journey, President Truman received today in behalf of the National Archives the signatures of the 3,500,000 persons who signed the freedom pledge aboard it.

Governor Dewey announced yesterday the appointment of Bruce Bromley to the Court of Appeals to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation due to illness of Judge Thomas D. Thacher. Mr. Bromley is one of the leading trial lawyers of the city, in addition to being learned in the law generally and in the forefront of all worthy movements for the better administration of justice.

Today's Events: "L'Amore Dei Tre Re," at 2 P. M., and "Lucia Di Lammermoor," 8:30, Metropolitan Opera; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky, conductor; Rudolf Firkusny, piano; Howard Hanson, guest conductor; Louis Speyer, English horn; Wesley Addy, speaker, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Ralph Herbert, baritone, Town Hall, 3; Leonard Hungerford, piano, Brooklyn Museum, 2.

GOSHEN, N. Y., Jan. 14 (UP) -- Seventy-four 3-year-old trotters remained in the Hambletonian Stake after the January eligibility payment, June Van Gundy, secretary of the Hambletonian Society, said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- A sweeping strengthening of the country's espionage laws, including the authorized use of wire-tapping and other detecting devices, was urged on Congress tonight by Tom C. Clark, the Attorney General.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- Prices of grains on the Board of Trade today closed around the top figures of the day after an early break on scattered liquidation which had carried May corn to a new low for two months, oats into new ground since early November and soy beans to the lowest level since mid-October. Heavy short covering was given by brokers as largely responsible for the rally.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander directed the top-ranking members of the uniformed and detective divisions yesterday to rid the city of gamblers and racketeers who, reportedly, are filtering into New York as a result of concerted police action in New Jersey.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein ruled yesterday that Mrs. Belle Popper Graumunt, 25-year-old former Marine Corps sergeant, who placed her 18-month-old son, Mark, with the Free Synagogue Child Adoption Committee last March, had done so "of her own free will" and may not regain his custody.

A new English offering, "Mr. Perrin and Mr. Trail," will have its local premiere today at the Little Carnegie. David Farrar, Greta Gynt and Marius Goring are featured in the film, which is described as "a dream of the conflict between the new outlook on life and the old, and a girl caught between the two."

Net income of the Savings Bank Trust Company in 1948 amounted to $816,000, equal to $32.64 a share, compared with $580,000, or $23.20 per share in the previous year, August Ihlefeld, president, disclosed yesterday in his annual report.

Governor Dewey announced yesterday that he had selected Bruce Bromley of the law firm of Cravath, Swaine Moore for appointment as Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Thomas D. Thacher.

PEIPING, Jan. 14 -- The battle for Tientsin, commercial heart of North China, grew intense today. As the fighting neared the main railroad station, more frequent barrages of artillery fire sent shells into the center of the city for the third successive day.

What was termed a "greatly liberalized policy" by the Bank of England in making dollars available for export advertising of British products in the United States is expected to bring considerable expansion of British advertising volume here, it was learned yesterday.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina refused yesterday to postpone for ninety days the trial of the twelve Communist leaders accused of conspiring to advocate the forcible overthrow of the Government. His decision left the trial set for Monday.
PARIS, Jan. 14 -- The Government sought today an understanding with industrialists on the problems presented by its effort to stabilize prices and wages.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Jan. 14 -A concerted move by 700 employes of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad to come under the jurisdiction of the Transport Workers Union was brought into the open today. The disclosure followed the surprise resignation late last night of Matthew A. O'Leary, chairman of the general grievance committee representing three H. M. lodges of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen.

The Giants yesterday were reported to have signed their first Negro player, but refused to confirm or deny that they had purchased Monte Irvin, outfielder, from the Newark club of the Negro National League.

ATHENS, Jan. 14 -- In a statement issued over the Athens radio tonight Premier Themistocles Sophoulis said all efforts the past week to form a new Cabinet coalition on a broadened base had failed and that, subject to King Paul's approval, he was willing to form a revised Government without regard to other party leaders.

A new venture among protestant churches has been announced by the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America for the week starting tomorrow, designated by council's executive committee as "Church and Economic Life Week."
VIENNA, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The board of directors and orchestra members of the Vienna Philharmonic Society today asked the Chicago Symphony Orchestra to support Dr. Wilhelm Furtwaengler.

TOKYO, Jan. 14 -- Dissolution of Japan's thirty-two great family holding companies is virtually complete, Edward C. Welsh, chief of Supreme Command Allied Powers' anti-trust and cartels division, said today. He also declared that studies and orders covering deconcentration of excessive economic power would be finished within a month, leaving only fifty orders subject to approval, change or rejection by the deconcentration eview board.

Wagner's "Siegfried," the first of the season, was the offering last night in the Metropolitan Opera House, with the most personable Siegfried that Metropolitan casts have offered in late seasons, and an authoritative singer and interpreter to boot.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department reported signs today that the nation's appetite for meat may be slipping back toward the pre-war levels.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 14 -- The Twenty-fourth Corps of the United States Army, which for three years has constituted the American occupation force in Korea, will be inactivated tomorrow, said an announcement here today, issued by General Headquarters of the Far East Command.

Cardinal Spellman visited yesterday a young woman patient at St. Vincent's Hospital who was the two millionth person to receive hospitalization benefits through the Blue Cross plan of the Associated Hospital Service of New York since its inception here fourteen years ago.

The thirteen members of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations voted unanimously yesterday to recommend approval of the President's nomination of Dean Acheson as Secretary of State. This action followed a second day of hearings, held this time in executive session for the reason that the committee wished to ask Mr. Acheson "intimate and delicate" questions concerning American policy toward Russia.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 14 -Miss Hannah M. Sayre, 78-year-old descendant of one of Union Township's Revolutionary families, who died Jan. 3, directed in her will that the Sayre homestead at Sayre Road and Morris Avenue, Union, be razed and all tangible personal property, including many antiques, be burned "at the expense of the estate."
Eight hundred students from high schools in the city and suburbs were told yesterday that American foreign policy has been "galloping off in two different directions."

The 21 East Tenth Street Corporation of 885 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, has taken title to the eleven-story apartment house at 60-62 University Place, northwest corner of Tenth Street, which was sold recently by Paterno Estates, Inc., through H. Stanley Hillyer, Inc., broker.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -Secretary Charles Sawyer said today that a survey made by his Department of Commerce indicates that the prospective shortage of steel this year will be "substantially less" than had been forecast by many estimators.

Today at 9 A. M. throughout the United States and in places as far removed as Toronto and Srinagar, India, 21,933 young men and women who want to enter an American college or university will receive the signal to begin a series of tests given by the College Entrance Examination Board.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Jan. 15 UP--Communist forces smashed their way into the heart of Tientsin as far as the United States Consulate today and the Government radio in the city appealed to the Communists to cease firing.
Councilman Walter C. McGahan, Queens Republican, moved yesterday for a Council investigation of Mayor O'Dwyer's recent statements about "graft and corruption" in the Fire Department.

Failure of independent retailers to promote hosiery more aggressively has made it possible for chain stores to capture the major portion of available business, according to Jay D. Runkle, vice president and general manager of Crowley Milner Co., Detroit.
Stimulated by lower crude oil markets in the South and West, a general selling wave engulfed the cottonseed oil futures market on the New York Produce Exchange yesterday.

A note left by explorer Roald Amundsen in a rock cairn near the South Pole on Jan. 6, 1912, twenty-three days after his discovery of the pole, will be presented to the Norwegian Geographical Society by Dr. Laurence M. Gould, president of Carleton College, Northfield, Minn., it was announced yesterday.
