Directors of the Continental Bank and Trust Company of New York declared yesterday a first liquidating dividend of $13 a share. The dividend will be paid on and after the day following the final adjournment of the annual stockholders' meeting to be held on Wednesday, according to a letter to stockholders signed by John T. Seaman, president.
The Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company delivered yesterday a newly converted immigrant ship to her new owners, the Dodero Lines of Argentina.
William Woodward was reelected chairman at the annual meeting of The Jockey Club yesterday. Also renamed to their posts were George D. Widener, vice chairman, and Joseph E. Davis, secretary.

Towboat operations continued along normal channels yesterday while members of the negotiating groups that worked day and night for three weeks to avert a strike attempted to catch up on sorely needed rest and badly neglected personal business.

The Fordham basketball team regained its winning stride last night by crushing the New York State Maritime Academy, 75 -- 37, at the Fordham Gym before 2,000 fans. The victory was Fordham's seventh against three defeats.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- House Republicans left their side of the Committee on Un-American Activities unfilled today on a caucus that approved assignments of members to every one of the other eighteen standing committees.
GENEVA, Jan. 14 -- Widespread changes in the techniques of using coal are necessary if European recovery plans are to succeed, a leading authority on fuel asserted here today.

Joseph Battista, who gave a piano recital last night at Town Hall, has come ahead fairly fast. It was only eight years ago that he made his debut here, yet his appearance last night was but one of seventy-six engagements he has for the current season.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan 14 -Nicholas Ray has notified RKO that he will not direct "I Married A Communist," the studio disclosed today. Ray was not available for comment, but it was reported that he objected to the picture for dramatic reasons rather than ideological reasons.

Sunday school, boys' groups, Girl Guard Troops and other children's activities are included in the twenty-two Corps Community Centers of the Salvation Army in New York City, which carry on a broad character-building program among children of all races and religions during their important formative years.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 14 -- The United States proposed informally today that the Security Council authorize a new United Nations commission to determine the areas in Java, Sumatra and Madura, "consistent with reasonable requirements of public security," that should be gradually evacuated by Dutch troops and returned to the administration of the Republic of Indonesia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Dr. Karl T. Compton, chairman of the Research and Development Board, bitterly deplored today the publication of reports that Dr. Frank P. Graham, president of the University of North Carolina, had been approved to handle confidential atomic data over the objections of a security board.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 14 -- Minister without portfolio Lubbertus Goetzen, who has been entrusted with Indonesia's economic and financial problems, said in an interview with THE NEW YORK TIMES today that Dutch military action would result in increasing domestic trade, better distribution, rising production and lower prices in Federal territories.

Marketing of new issues of securities promises to proceed at a brisk pace next week. The major financing scheduled is the offering of $50,000,000 of Bethlehem Steel Company consolidated mortgage bonds on Wednesday by a syndicate headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co. and Smith, Barney Co.
A double-header at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory and an Eastern League game in Columbia University's gymnasium are the chief college basketball games tonight in the New York area.

A request by the Department of Correction for a 1949-50 expense budget appropriation $1,133,572 greater than its allowance for the current fiscal year drew criticism yesterday from Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson at a hearing in the Municipal Building.

In hope of minimizing the loss or theft of the small metal 1949 tabs that identify current automobile license plates, police officials in the metropolitan area strongly urged motorists yesterday to rivet the metal sticker to their 1948 rear plates.

FAYETTEVILLE, N. C., Jan. 14 -- A paratroop jump master sent thirty-six men sailing safely on silk from a falling C-82 "Flying Boxcar" today, then rode the plane to a crash landing without injury. Three crew members died in the plane, which burned after it struck.

Expansion of the schedule of its local television station, WNBT, was announced yesterday by the National Broadcasting Company, which indicated that it soon would begin full daytime operation. ABC recently announced that it would start full daytime operation in February.

TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 14 -- Dr. Robert H. Morrison, assistant commissioner for teacher training in the State Education Department, foresaw today a shortage of more than 3,000 teachers in the New Jersey school system next fall. Currently, he said, the shortage was estimated at 2,869.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 14 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay disclosed today that he had asked the board of directors of the Joint Export-Import Agency, which is now a three-power body, to prevent former employes of the military government and occupation armies from doing business in Germany for at least two years after they had left here.
ALBANY, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The State Conference of Mayors is expected to ask the Legislature to increase direct state aid for cities and villages under the Moore plan by $70,000,000.

Dave Beck, executive vice president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, and one of the nation's most aggressive labor leaders, served notice yesterday on labor and industry that his union was on the verge of a major organizing drive.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, 4 to 10 points net higher.

The American Federation of Labor called upon the United States yesterday to redeem its pledge of March 27 to return to Italy the free territory of Trieste. Its position was made known in a letter from Matthew Woll, vice president, read at a luncheon at the Hotel Astor given by the Italian-American Labor Council for two delegates from Trieste.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- Tribute to the late Sherwood Anderson, who in the 1920's was known as a founder of "the Chicago School of Literature," was paid tonight at a ceremony in the Newberry Library. The occasion marked the formal opening of a collection of Mr. Anderson's manuscripts, private papers and letters.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 14 -- A proposal that American youth be permitted to help develop its own educational requirements in the face of badly needed overhauling of the secondary school system was advanced here today by Paul Collier, director of youth services in the Connecticut State Department of Education.

Sy Seasonwein has been appointed sales manager of the newly-created retail sales division of Kanmak Textiles, Inc. He formerly was with the retail sales department of Dorset Fabrics and Cohn-Hall-Marx.

If the British Palestinian policy implicated no consequences to others than Great Britain and Israeli it might perhaps be a matter upon which a citizen of the United States might well reserve an expression of his opinion. But no one with half an eye can fail to note that that policy may have disruptive and possibly disastrous effects upon the Anglo-American solidarity which is an indispensable condition of international stability in these dangerous times.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 14 -- A battle of election posters has begun in Israel, offsetting the peaceful calm of the cease-fire. The most aggressive of the poster pasters is the erstwhile terrorist Stern Group, which now is above ground and known simply as "The Fighters."

In preparation for the first public hearing Wednesday on the projected creation of a Manhattan Civic Center, city officials and leaders of private organizations met yesteray to muster popular support behind the proposals put forward on June 24 by the City Planning Commission.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Some of the smoke of the Anglo-American battle over Palestine appeared to have cleared away today This result might well have been partly because of the receipt of the report from Sir Oliver Franks, British Ambassador to the United States, of his talk with President Truman yesterday.
Two hold-up men, proceeding with startling precision, escaped with a $5,667 payroll at 10:30 A. M. yesterday after confining the robbery to the limited area of an elevator at 80 Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The United Consulate General and the offices of the United States Information Service in Tientsin were under Communist shell fire from fighting within the city today, with fires spreading at several points, the State Department was advised in messages from the Consul General, Robert L. Smyth of Berkeley, Calif.
The Bushwick Savings Bank in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn has had a frozen asset for the last two days.
Governmental policies are often a little puzzling, but what is being done now in the diamond industry is hard to understand, at least to me and my friends.

A prisoner's alleged attempt to obtain a supply of marijuana cigarettes by using a Rikers Island prison guard as a messenger resulted yesterday in the prisoner's wife being held in $10,000 bail in Bronx Magistrate's Court for a hearing on Thursday on a charge of illegal possession of narcotics.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -William P. Odom's 2,375-mile flight in a single-engine plane apparently will go into the books as both a national and international non-stop distance record for the largest class of light aircraft.
WINSTON SALEM, N. C., Jan. 14 -- Newly inaugurated, Gov. W. Kerr Scott said today it was time North Carolina stopped dodging the Negro question.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- The United States and British Governments have politely but firmly turned down a Chinese request to "initiate negotiations" toward an end of the Chinese civil war, it is learned here on good authority.

One more twelve-hour watch of the National Motor Boat Show for this year remains before the 238 exhibitors start crating and wrapping their displays and returning them to their home factories to start work on orders generated during the show's eight days.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Jan. I4 -- The officers of the United Jewish Appeal meeting here today at an executive session formulated plans to mobilize the support of 5,000,000 Jews in the United States in raising the appeal's goal of $250,000,000 to meet Jewish needs throughout the world.

The 1949 March of Dimes campaign, aiming at raising at least $30,000,000 for the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, got under way both nationally and locally at noon yesterday in ceremonies at City Hall.
I desire to take exception to Roy E. Larsen's statements appearing in THE TIMES on Jan. 2.

RHODES, Jan. 14 -- Hope for the success of the Israeli-Egyptian armistice talks rose high tonight when the delegations concluded their second meeting with an announcement that they had concluded discussion of one item on their agenda and had agreed on the preamble to an armistice agreement -- all in fifteen minutes.
BOSTON, Jan. 14 -- The Massachusetts Senate began today a three-day recess to find out what its constituency thinks about a ten-day stalemate over the election of a president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- President Truman officially defined "non-combatant" service and training in the armed forces today in a move to clarify the status of conscientious objectors in the Selective Service system.

The Yankees yesterday mailed more than thirty contracts to their players and by now it is quite possible that some of the Bombers examining their 1949 salary terms, are agreed that the documents are a bit odd, if not unusual.
RHODES, Jan. 14 -- Israelis and Egyptians took their first definite step toward peace today by agreeing to keep their military forces in check while negotiations for an armistice were on.

Harry Davis, American pianist, who has played at Town Hall on several occasions, tried his luck at Carnegie Hall last night and it was not consistently good. He was at best in music that moved slowly. In some of the introspective sections of Schumann's "Davidsbuendlertanze," Op. 6, the tone was nicely colored and the phrasing had nuance and character, evoking the personal world of the composer.

The first important title competition of the indoor track and field campaign will take place tonight with the annual Metropolitan A. A. U. senior championships at the 102d Engineers Armory, 168th Street near Broadway. The district meet has attracted a high-caliber entry of 362 individual athletes and forty-seven relay teams for a fifteen-event program.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Britain disclosed today the conclusion of her first post-war long-term trade agreement with an Eastern European nation when the Board of Trade announced the details of a five-year trade and finance treaty signed with Poland in Warsaw this afternoon.

One hundred and twenty members of the United Scenic Artists, Local Union No. 829, who paint scenery for Broadway shows, voted yesterday afternoon to go on strike. Refusal by the Studio Contractors, the association of contractors who hire the services of the artists, to grant a wage increase of fifty cents an hour was given as the reason.

ATHENS, Jan. 14 (UP) -- Greek guerrillas completed their capture of Naoussa in Macedonia, ninety miles west of Salonika, today. A Greek Air Force pilot who flew over the area said huge fires were visible throughout the town.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- President Truman has approved the use of $109,000,000 for the purchase of 158 jet fighter planes and a number of trainers, the Air Force announced today.

LIKE many another storyteller from Somerset Maugham to Rabelais, the two novelists whose books we are reviewing today were trained as doctors. And since storytelling is naturally somewhat clinical, probing into the malaises as well as the manners of men, that is an advantage to any writer. We must also, however, ask other gifts of anyone who is to tell us a memorable story -- imaginativeness, selectiveness, narrative power and a sense of drama.

Junior and senior high school students from seventy-one schools in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Long Island and Brooklyn attended the Metropolitan Opera's forty-third student performance yesterday afternoon. The opera was "Lucia di Lammernoor" and the event was sponsored by the Opera Guild.

VIENNA, Jan. 14 -- General Vladimir Kurasov tried unsuccessfully to get the Allied Council to agree today that the Austrian Government should be censured for having failed to institute stricter price control and rationing and condemned for having given Austrian citizenship to 107,310 displaced persons.

The city rests easier today with the annual threat of a tug strike out of the way at last. Three thousand five hundred men who man the 400-odd craft of the harbor can easily turn off the power behind the vast machine that is the Port of New York, and Mayor O'Dwyer's concern was not exaggerated.

BOSTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- John F. Noxon Jr., paroled for life after being convicted of killing his mentally deficient infant son, today received permission to leave Massachusetts and live in Connecticut.

Our steadily expressed concern over the future of our public libraries and museums is deepened by the facts presented to the city's Budget Director by the New York Public Library and by the newly published annual report of the American Museum of Natural History.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 14 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay said today that the huge smuggling operations, through which German manufactured goods were illegally sold or otherwise carried across the border, constituted the "greatest threat to the economic recovery" of Western Germany.

PARIS, Jan. 14 -- The French Government's growing anxiety about the war in Indo-China led today to an open appeal to Bao Dai, former Emperor of Annam, to return to Indo-China and take the leadership of the Nationalist movement away from Communist Ho Chi Minh.

PARIS, Jan. 14 -- Most youthful and becoming are the calottes or little skullcaps that took first place at Maud et Mano's opening. In a fine, lightweight picot called Rio, they are worn to reveal an inch or two of hairline, but a vizor of stiffened veiling shadows the brow.
BOSTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Boston Weather Bureau tonight issued the following report of winter sports conditions in New England:
PHILIPSBURG, Pa., Jan. 14 -Two 14-year-old boys tried to blow up the high school with 180 sticks of dynamite because they didn't like school work, authorities revealed today.

Promotion of lace is a "must" and "the best time to start is right now," Harold G. Truman of the New England Lace Mills, Pawtucket, R. I., said yesterday. He was elected president of the American Lace Manufacturers Association, Inc., at the annual meeting of the organization in the Commodore Hotel.
LONDON, Jan. 14 (Reuters) -In ports all over the world seamen are looking with increasing interest at a colorful flag that flutters on many ships sailing the seven seas.

A campaign by the Civil Aeronautics Board to prevent the so-called irregular airlines from engaging in operations not permitted them under their CAB letters of registration resulted yesterday in the issuance of Federal court injunction against Modern Air Transport, Inc.

Xenia Boodberg, talented young American pianist, made her debut at Times Hall last night. She devoted half of her program to new music, which she played with the intensity of a partisan. The remainder she approached with mature and musical intentions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The State Department declared today that the Soviet Union's policy necessitated the formation of a North Atlantic Security Pact and advised nations to join up if they expected military aid from the United States.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -The official who looks after the wages-hours law asked Congress today for power to raise the minimum wage above 75 cents an hour for some industries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.5 per cent during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The index is now 160.5 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.7 per cent lower than four weeks ago, and 3.8 per cent below the comparable week in 1948.

The unfurling of 100 of the Salvation Army's new blue and white flags along Fifth Avenue and one on City Hall today will mark the start of solicitations for the Army's campaign to raise $1,100,000 in Greater New York.

BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 14 -- Netherlands troops are insufficient to control the Republican guerrilla bands that move about freely in central Java sabotaging roads and bridges, neutral military observers, attached to the United Nations Security Council's Committee of Good Offices in Indonesia, reported to the committee today.

New and dramatic abuses that have arisen in New York State because of the lack of legislation outlawing "black market babies" were described yesterday at the first citywide meeting on the problems of adoption.
The report of Loew's, Inc., for the twelve weeks ended on Nov. 25, last, disclosed yesterday a net profit of $1,021,156 after taxes and all deductions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Paul C. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, was threatened with Congressional action today to prevent abandonment of the policy of alloting shipment of at least 50 per cent of ECA bulk cargoes to United States flag vessels.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- An air hostess who helped rescue a child from the consulate annex to the Soviet Embassy here last night was accused by the Soviet Embassy tonight of having allowed herself to become the victim of "unsavory political motives" in describing the incident to reporters.

DETROIT, Jan. 14 -- Restrictions imposed on motoring by traffic, parking and garaging were recognized in the remedies offered today in the 1949 cars presented by the Chrysler Corporation. Over-all lengths, heights and widths of the new units of the Plymouth, Dodge, De Soto and Chrysler lines have been reduced to aid in alleviating crowded travel conditions.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 14 (AP) -- Many of the 9,699 spectators who bet $578,414 at Tropical Park today expected the Calumet Farm to win two races, but Fine Fettle spoiled a perfect afternoon for that establishment by taking a decisive beating from First Citizen in the Kettledrum Purse.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Southern Indiana Gas and Electric Company, Evansville, Ind., and its parent, the Commonwealth Southern Corporation, received authorization from the Securities and Exchange Commission late this afternoon to sell 685,000 shares of Southern Indiana's common stock for $18 a share, or an aggregate of $12,330,000.

Yachting sailors may go ahead next summer without more concrete complications of the racing rules. That was settled last night at the annual general meeting of the North American Yacht Racing Union, the ruling body in this country and Canada, which was held in the New York Yacht Club.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 14 The vanguard of some 17,000 leaders in the nation's food industry -canners, brokers, distributors and supply men -- gathering here for the forty-second annual convention of the National Canners Association, today heard the rally get under way on an optimistic note.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Four stockholders of the Standard Wholesale Phosphate and Acid Works, Inc., of Baltimore, have filed a suit to block its sale to the Mathieson Chemical Corporation of New York.

A wave of new "immigrants" has begun to pour into Manhattan's oldest haven, the lower East Side. It is estimated that in three years up to 100,000 newcomers will tenant massive private and public housing developments, reversing a thirty-year trend.

The five crated war surplus airplanes seized a week ago, which customs officials said they believed were destined for transshipment to the Arabs, were owned by a former United States Army officer, it developed yesterday.

Lumber production for the week ended Jan. 8 was 31.8 per cent below the like week last year, according to reports wired to THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday by trade associations. Shipments were down 20.5 per cent and orders 7.8 per cent.

The rolling phalanx of 101 motorcycle policemen that escorted President Truman on his campaign tour of the city last November will not take part in the inauguration parade in Washington next Thursday, Mayor O'Dwyer said last night.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 -Members of the Philadelphia Orchestra have voted against making a European tour this spring because of dissatisfaction with the terms offered, it was announced today.
For his chairmanship of the 1948 campaign of the United Negro College Fund which raised $1,066,000 William E. Cotter yesterday received a certificate of merit.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- The trend toward a more competitive market condition became cleared during December, the report of the business survey committee of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago revealed today. More rapid deliveries, some lowering of prices and reduction of backlogs were reported by members of the association, extending the trend indicated in November.

Although pleased that pennies saved by consumers through recent milk price reductions may add up to $10,000,000 for the year, John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, continued yesterday his crusade to cut milk costs further.

NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 14 -- The United States Government, in a civil suit filed today in the Federal Court here, seeks to sever the American Telephone Telegraph Company from its wholly owned subsidiary, Western Electric Company, Inc., both of New York. Extensive violations of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act in the manufacture and sale of telephone equipment and supplies are charged.

For the second novelty of its season at the City Center, the New York City Ballet Company last night presented "The Seasons," which has been seen heretofore only in subscription seasons of the Ballet Society. In spite of the fact that the audience was a bit bewildered by it, it is an extremely interesting work which improves markedly with acquaintance.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- Arthur A. Bennett, who was ousted on Wednesday by Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson as warden of the Pontiac Branch of the State Penitentiary, "for the good of the service," died today in the home of his brother-in-law in near-by Forest Park. He was 45 years old.
Col. Candler Cobb, New York City Director of Selective Service, released yesterday the following statement, relative to mistaken interpretations of the current draft law:

BOSTON, Jan. 14 -- Barrett L. Crandall, executive secretary of the National Council for Community Improvement, called today for "immediate improvement" in the standard of building codes throughout the country as a means of reducing housing costs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- A spokesman for the Federal Reserve Board denied today that any of its members ever had stated that "the nation must have a depression at once." Henry J. Kaiser, chairman of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, attributed the remark to a "governor of the Federal Reserve Board" in a telegram Mr. Kaiser sent yesterday to President Truman.
TULSA, Okla., Jan. 14 (AP) -- The United States Junior Chamber of Commerce made known today its selections of the "nation's ten outstanding young men of 1948."

NANKING, Jan. 14 -- Mao Tzetung, chairman of the Chinese Communist party, flatly rejected Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's New Year peace bid tonight. The rejection came in a formal statement containing an eight-point counter-proposal that, in effect, demanded the unconditional surrender of the Nanking Government.

BUFFALO, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The New York Telephone Company's proposed $49,000,000 a year rate increase was assailed today as "improper" and "premature" by spokesmen for municipalities that are opposing the advance.
PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 14 (AP) -- Six under par, Bill Nary from Phoenix, Ariz., held the spotlight today in the opening round of Bing Crosby's annual golfing show.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- The Government served notice today it intends to repossess the Tucker Corporation plant promptly if the rent is not paid when due on Feb. 1, regardless of pending court proceedings.

Despite the damage recent storms and cold weather did to citrus groves, oranges, grapefruit and tangerines remain in good supply. Most of this fruit is coming from Florida, where crop losses weren't as great as in California. It will be some time before shipments of California navels increase enough to bring down the current high prices -- 90 cents for five pounds.

Our city scout, AWOL for some time, has turned up with a report. Everybody knows, he says, that spring was in the air last week-end, but nobody has taken proper note of what it did to Fifth Avenue. For that famous thoroughfare looked as if the town had turned out for a parade -- so thronged were the sidewalks.

Net operating income of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company for 1948 totaled $101,611, compared with $99,695 in the previous year, Barnard Townsend, president, told stockholders yesterday in issuing his first annual report. Mr. Townsend, who became president of the bank in June 17, 1948, pointed out that the year's operations included those of the Lawyers Title Corporation of New York for the final three months, that organization having been acquired on Sept. 29.

Many people doubtless were shocked to read of the acquittal by a Georgia court and jury of a white defendant charged with the murder of a Negro, principally because two of the jurors took the witness stand as character witnesses for the defendant and then resumed their places as members of the jury which brought in the verdict of "not guilty."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Dr. George W. Taylor, long an advocate of arbitration clauses in labor-management agreements, said today that it was highly doubtful whether the cause of industrial peace could be advanced through egislation "requiring" such clauses.
ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 14 -- Because of increased operating costs, American medical colleges are in a serious financial plight, Dr. Edmund E. Day, president of Cornell University, said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Three Democratic Senators discussed the proposed development of the Missouri Valley with President Truman today and afterward recommended that its concept should differ from that of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

Mrs. Maria Kramer regained yesterday complete control of the thirty-story Lincoln Hotel, largest hostelry in the Times Square area. A consideration of $10,000,000 was involved in the transaction by which Mrs. Kramer, widow of Max J. Kramer, builder and operator of a chain of hotels, relinquished her holdings in the Edison Hotel to her two stepsons and took over control of the contested interest in the Lincoln.
LONDON, Jan. 14 (Reuters) -- Shareholders in the De Bernales group of Australian gold-mining companies heard officially today that they had lost all or most of their money.

Retailer requests for credentials to the New York winter furniture market are 10 per cent greater than for last January, J. J. Melniker, exchange president, reported yesterday. Buyer requests for admittance passes to the market, which will run from Jan. 17 through Jan. 22, exceed those for last July by 20 per cent, he said.

The Rev. John O. Mellin, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street, appeared yesterday to have won his battle to compel Sailors Snug Harbor to admit him to its board of trustees in compliance with its old charter.

Retail trade made a slight increase here this week due mainly to heavier promotional efforts, it was said. Department store sales were estimated as about 1 per cent over the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were down 2 per cent.

NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 14 -- County Medical Examiner Harrison S. Martland said today the death of Mrs. Helen Stickel Ford, 31 years old, was caused by illuminating gas, a "suicide due to temporary insanity." Mrs. Ford was the daughter of former Common Pleas Judge Fred G. Stickel Jr. and Mrs. Stickel of 183 Ballantine Parkway, this city.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- British Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin and French Foreign Minister Robert Schuman completed tonight a two-day meeting that M. Schuman later described as a forty-eight-hour "tour of the world."
Your editorial, headed "Let's Have the Facts," discussing Councilman Rager's resolution for an investigation of the New York City Administration was not quite fair.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -The Federal Trade Commission today cleared the way for closer Government regulation of the discounts a manufacturer can make to purchasers.

The resignation of George Kletz as president of the Tournament of Champions, Inc., was announced yesterday following a Board of Directors meeting at which David B. Charnay, Allied Syndicates, Inc., was elected to the office.

FORT LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Jan. 14 -- A balanced foreign policy in which a strong military establishment is maintained at home while Western Europe is bolstered with arms and dollars was advocated today by Hanson W. Baldwin, military editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, as the best insurance for maintaining world peace.

WEST POINT, Jan. 15 -- A gathering of 4,000, the largest to attend a game at the field house thus far this season, came ostensibly to see Tony Lavelli and his basketball mates from Yale in action against the Army five this afternoon.

ONE holds in grateful regard the return to the Metropolitan Opera repertory, this season, of Mozart's "Nozze di Figaro." This performance is not only the best of any opera that the Metropolitan has given this season; in the writer's esteem it is the best interpretation of an opera that he has heard there in a number of seasons.

William Lydell, 17 years old, of Valley City, N. D., doesn't like jazz. He was the only one who said so yesterday in a Youth Forum discussion of "Does Jazz Stifle Musical Taste," broadcast over Station WQXR under the sponsorship of THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Gold keys and certificates in recognition of "distinguished service to the State of New York" were awarded to four men last night by the New York State Junior Chamber of Commerce.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- The Marshall Plan supplied about one-fourth of France's total imports and saved her from a serious economic setback in the summer and autumn of 1948, the French Government asserts in a report on the first six months of ERP in France.

IT has been said that I am chasing after my youth. This is true. And not only after my own. Even more than beauty, youth attracts me, and with an irresistible appeal. I believe the truth lies in youth; I believe it is always right against us.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- A special civilian committee on welfare and recreation presented today to James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, a charter and plans for a new United Service Organizations, Inc., to continue on a broader basis the work of the wartime USO.

All but one of the four seeded teams reached the semi-final round as the invitation squash racquets doubles tournament for the Arthur H. Lockett Trophy began yesterday on the courts of the University Club.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Denunciation of the handling of the Palestine situation by Foreign Secretary Bevin came from Conservatives and Liberals alike tonight in speeches in which they chided him for his alleged antipathy toward Israel.
A hint of the forthcoming mayoralty campaign was introduced at the annual Patrolmen's Benevolent Association ball at Madison Square Garden last night.

The 200-inch Hale telescope at the Palomar Observatory in California may not be in operation until next autumn. The first test photographs were made in December, 1947, barely a month after the big mirror was installed in the telescope. Since then, however, the observatory director, Dr. Ira S. Brown, and his staff have been locating "bugs," finding out why they appeared and what could be done about them.

The budget of the United States Government is a statement of the income and outgo of the largest fiscal operation in the world (with the possible exception of Russia's). More than that, it is a measure of America's role in the world and of its political direction and philosophy at home.

In frame at the Henry B. Nevins shipyard in City Island is the largest sailing yacht designed under the cruising, or ocean racing rule, to be built along this coast for years. She is to be a yawl for John Nicholas Brown, new vice commodore of the New York Yacht Club.
JERSEY CITY, N. J., Jan. 15 -- Although engineers of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad have voted to go on strike, it was indicated tonight that the walk-out would not be called this week-end.

Science has yet to find out why a hungry man feels hungry, Dr. Edward M. Scott of the University of Pittsburgh declared at a meeting of the biological division of the American Chemical Society's Pittsburgh section in the Mellon Institute. Emptiness of the stomach or a low level of blood sugar is no satisfactory explanation.

The correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES in Sweden, George Axelsson, informs this department that Dr. Wilhelm Graf, young Swedish anthropologist, has identified and photographed well preserved organic remains of red-blood corpuscles in skeletons of Swedish Vikings buried 1,000 years ago.

A LARGE university is conducting a campaign for funds. The leading writer of creative prose among its graduates undertakes to produce a book likely to inspire affectionate gratitude and arouse nostalgic memories in the hearts of its alumni.

New York State will have a float in President Truman's inaugural parade in Washington next Thursday, Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, announced yesterday. The float, under construction in Washington, will carry a three-dimensional panorama of New York State from the Empire State Building to Niagara Falls.

Minority stockholders of banks who are eager to advise management made the most of their "day" last week as the first of the two-week series of annual bank meetings got under way. Bank presidents, resigned to their yearly ordeal, after presenting their reports, patiently listened to a variety of comments, ranging from washroom facilities to national policies.
The New York Women's Bible Society will bc the beneficiary of a program of scenes from wellknown plays to be given by Eva Le Gallienne on Wednesday afternoon at Town Hall.

Offsetting the improvement in sentiment that followed his State of the Union and economy messages to Congress, a spirit of caution prevailed in financial markets last week with the submission of President Truman's peace-time budget.

Buyers in the wholesale apparel market here last week were encouraged by a brighter business outlook and placed fairly large orders for spring ready-to-wear, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. Better values offered in all lines of merchandise made it difficult for buyers to stay within strict budgets set by retailers.
Columbia's athletes suffered defeat in the three varsity engagements held at the Morningside Heights gymnasium yesterday, losing to Harvard in swimming and wrestling and to Army in fencing.

The second concert of the second "American Music Festival" which Serge Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra have given in this city took place yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. A distinguished group of composers represented in a box, were successively saluted by Dr. Koussevitzky, the orchestra, which repeatedly rose in their honor, and the audience present.

Sonja Henie and her "Hollywood Ice Revue" will be featured at Madison Square Garden beginning Thursday evening for seventeen performances. The figure-skating star and her cast will have a brief rest Jan. 28, 29 and 30, when other events take over the big arena.
HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 15 -- Dartmouth's years of hockey supremacy over Harvard came to an end tonight when the Crimson triumphed by 8-5.

There can be small hope of the reduction of traffic congestion or of major gains in traffic safety unless basic studies are made of existing facilities. Action must, then, be taken by the various agencies of government to carry out sound recommendations. Obviously this is a long-range program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Senator J. Howard McGrath, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, today wrote a letter to 25,000 party leaders in which he summed up President Truman's 'Fair Deal." He termed it a "sound policy" on a "pay-as-you-go" basis.

NANKING, Jan. 15 -- If the Chinese Communists capture Nanking and Shanghai, as they now seem quite capable of doing, they will have achieved -- for all the importance of such a conquest and all the blood, organization and zeal required by such a success -- merely the first phase of victory.

GENEVA, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Austria has applied to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development for financial aid in the construction of two hydroelectric stations estimated to cost $212,000,000, the Economic Commission for Europe announced today.

A California request for an earlier ending to the tennis season in the East was the matter of most concern yesterday to the delegates attending the annual meeting of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association at the Hotel Astor.

PHILOSOPHERS may sing of the pleasures of competition, but the record industry appears to be trying to prove that the thing can go too far. Regardless of the protestations of the executives, the net effect of the decisions of RCA Victor and Columbia is to establish that unwise competition can lead to confusion.
Regarding Arthur Daley's "Which Sport," in former days, baseball pitchers pitched two games a day, and thought nothing of it. Today, two innings is too much for many of them.

GARDENERS in many sections will find it easier to sally forth with shears for the annual winter pruning of deciduous shrubs this season, than they did last year. Then the unusually deep snow buried lower kinds, and even taller ones looked unfamiliar, with only their tops rising out of the snow.

Prompt action by Congress on extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act, eliminating "restrictive" features of the current act, was foreseen in foreign trade circles here last week. Guesses in usually well-informed quarters were that Congress might complete action on the new legislation by early March, or in advance of the meeting of the contracting parties to the general agreement on tariffs and trade scheduled for April 11 at Annecy, France.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Surprise mingled with embarrassment today at the news that the Eva Duarte Peron Social Assistance Foundation of Argentina is donating clothing to care for 600 needy Washington children.

BOSTON, Jan. 15 -- In the face of President Truman's request for $4 billion in new taxes, most New Englanders were counting their blessings in terms of the weather. A snowfall of only six inches this winter already represents tax rate reductions ranging from 15 cents to $1.40 because of lower snow-removal costs.

As Mayor O'Dwyer, Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle and Chief Peter Loftus watched, firemen battled a stubborn five-alarm blaze last night in a six-story combination loft and warehouse building at 220 East 125th Street in Harlem.

Construction of the Port of New York Authority's $20,000,000 union bus terminal will start formally on Jan. 27 when Mayor O'Dwyer breaks ground for the project, it was announced yesterday by Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the bi-state agency.
THE famous Passion Play that this well-known Alpine village has presented periodically for 300 years is in financial straits for the first time since 1840.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The size of President Truman's new budget evoked Congressional cries of anguish and vows to "bring it down to earth" this week, particularly from Republicans. But the chances are that when all of the figures are in, Congress will have authorized the expenditure of the entire $41.9 billion that Mr. Truman requested, and quite possibly even more.

CORNWALL, Conn. -- The State of Connecticut, one of the pioneers in Eastern skiing back in the late Nineteen Twenties and the early Nineteen Thirties, is trying again (snow permitting) to regain front rank in winter sports this year. During the past decade the fame and popularity of such areas as Norfolk, Salisbury and Winsted, where some of the greatest jumpers and cross-country skiers formerly performed, waned.

With thousands of dollars' worth of products on display, the General Motors Corporation show opening Thursday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel will occupy 22,500 square feet of floor space. It will continue through Jan. 27.

HILDA LAWRENCE writes a smooth, insidious kind of chiller, one that doesn't need bangs and shrieks to achieve its effects. Two such tales are combined in "Duet of Death." You open the front door of the book to read "The House," and then a note directs you to turn the book round to read "Composition for Four Hands."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The public showing of German paintings in American museums before their ultimate return to Germany has thus far netted $190,000, the Army Department announced today.

A SLEEPY island in the Adriatic is the setting for this unusual picture book for 5 to 8 year olds. It was there that Cocolo, a small, hard-working donkey, lived contentedly with his poor but understanding fisher-folk family until a capsized boat brought Mr. Fatimus Greedy and his daughter, Fussy, into his life.

ONE of the functions of literary criticism is to create myths -- and one test of a writer's value lies in the series of illusions and superstitions that surround his work like a nimbus or a smoke screen. The merit of Robert Elias' scholarly -- and sometimes prosaic -- biography of Dreiser is in the extent to which it presents evidence that refutes many of the current views about Theodore Dreiser's life and work.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Arnost Heidrich, Secretary General of the Czechoslovak Foreign Office and for fourteen years legal and political adviser to the late Dr. Eduard Benes, has escaped from Prague and come to Washington with a detailed story of Communist activities and plans in Eastern Europe.

TOKYO'S Main Street, the Ginza, has always been a mixture of big city dignity and small-town fair. War took its toll of this thoroughfare, leaving gaping ruins -- and more space for street stalls. Allied occupation, which is mostly American occupation, has brought a new aspect to the scene.
Prices on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday improved selectively in the final session, closing irregularly higher in the slowest trading in three months.

When the Rev. James F. Bradley pleads today from the pulpit of St. Catherine of Genoa Roman Catholic Church, Linden Boulevard and Albany Avenue, Brooklyn, for blood for two of his youthful parishioners, his message will carry the conviction of war-born knowledge of its life-saving qualities.
If the proverbial man from Mars were to read Henry Steele Commager's "Analysis of the American Character," he would visualize all Americans as cast into a stereotyped mold.

The Salvation Army opened yesterday its campaign to raise $1,100,000 in this city. Vincent R. Impellitteri, president of the City Council, broadcast an appeal for aid to the fund and made the first contribution. The campaign will continue until Feb. 15.

EUROPE'S winter climate must have taken a bitter turn for the worse about 400 years ago. The marked change seemed to persist intermittently for two centuries, during which, among other freak happenings, a Swiss glacier toppled over an ancient chapel and threatened several mountain chalets.

ON Jan. 24, 1944, an article appearing in this newspaper reported from the Fifth Army front in Italy that "After a terrific drubbing from German prepared positions, remnants of the American force that staged a series of heroic frontal attacks across the savagely cannonaded Rapido River, through minefields and into a trap of machine-gun cross-fire, withdrew yesterday afternoon by swimming through the raging icy water."

Apropos of your remarks about "The Radio Essay (Jan. 2), I want to say that I quite agree with you. A little variety and personality (in the better sense) would be appreciated by us listeners. I live in the country and so I become, especially in winter, a more or less regular and critical auditor.

At least nine new public housing projects to accommodate nearly 9,500 families at low rents will be started within the next four months under city auspices, Thomas F. Farrell, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, reported yesterday.

Daystrom Corporation booked more orders in the first week of the recent Chicago home furnishings than during any first week of previous Chicago events, John Gorski, sales promotion manager, disclosed last week. He said in an interview that both unit and dollar volume were more than 25 per cent ahead of the first week of the market last July, previous high point.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Army held today that the record of James H. Schaffner, dishonorably discharged World War II veteran, "must ride as it is" unless new evidence was presented.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Probably one of the last things that Congress will get around to before adjourning for the year, if it takes up the question at all, will be President Truman's recommendation for a $4 billion tax increase.

THE United States has the highest divorce rate of any country for which statistics are available. If the trend of marital breakdowns continues, in approximately half a century the number of marriages in a year may be equaled by the number of divorces.

PARIS, Jan. 12 -- In the new law raising rents that some tenants say they will resist, elevators are considered an asset in calculating new rentals. Many contest this assumption. Some dwellers on upper floors are so afraid of elevators that they prefer to walk upstairs.

America's educational system is neglecting the development of hidden talents among large sections of the nation because it spends most of its time and effort on children who are "white, gentile and wealthy," Dr. Harold Taylor, president of Sarah Lawrence College, charged yesterday.
RHODES, Jan. 15 -- The United Nations moved today to bring four more Arab belligerents into the Palestine armistice negotiations with Israel.

Development of an adequate merchant marine and a large-scale fishing industry for Israel has been given high priority by the Tel Aviv Government as vital to the future economy of the new state, it became known yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 -- Paced by Paul Lansaw, Cornell University defeated Pennsylvania in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game at the Palestra today, 47 -- 34, before 3,000 fans.
A POLL of Hollywood opinion on the New York Film Critics encomium to John Huston for "Treasure of Sierra Madre" almost certainly would turn up a mixed reaction.
The Port of New York Authority's success in increasing trade through the Port of Newark was reviewed in detail last week in the annual report of Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the bi-state agency.

Response to retail trade promotions here was fairly good last week. Department store sales were estimated as showing only a slight decline under the like week of 1948, the drop being put at about 1 per cent.

The State Department's review of foreign policy, published yesterday under the title "Building the Peace," would please Woodrow Wilson if he could know about it. It is in line with his declaration in favor of "open covenants of peace, openly arrived at," made thirty-one years ago this month.

NO honest writer today expects to go roaming back into a child's world armed only with pleasant memories and a nice way with youngsters. Under the influence of psychiatry, literary recollections of childhood have taken on the nature of formal exhumations, with a technical autopsy to round out the job.

A REPORT of the work done by the Masters Nursery in Bellevue Hospital, on helping hospitalized children to play, put us in mind of the large numbers of children who must be confined to bed either at home or in the hospital and who need special help for recovery. This need for "help" goes beyond medical care, nursing and supervision.

Money spent for insurance is generally regarded as well spent. Money spent to avoid war is in the same general category. No matter how costly the means of prevention, the cost should be well worth while. Even to spend what a war would otherwise cost, it is still worth while because the destruction of life would go far beyond any evaluation in money.

CYRENAICA, a former Italian possession in northern Africa and now under British military occupation, is to have a definitive, series, says a bulletin from the Crown Agents for the Colonies, in London.

FROM the local boards last night went "Harvey" after 1,775 performances. Brock Pemberton first presented the Mary Coyle Chase comedy at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre on Nov. 1, 1944. It won the Pulitzer Prize that season, and besides Frank Fay it has boasted for its Broadway run James Stewart, Jack Buchanan, Bert Wheeler, James Dunn, Joe E. Brown and Mr. Pemberton, himself.
New York soon will become the center of motion picture production, especially for films for television, Louis de Rochemont, producer of semi-documentary movies, predicted here yesterday.

A 2-year-old thoroughbred filly named Chanceling will be introduced to guests at the second annual Mid-Winter Ball on Thursday night in the Terrace Room of the Plaza. The festive program of the party will be interrupted shortly after midnight, when the horse will be led in through the Fifty-eighth Street entrance of the hotel and tethered in the adjoining Palm Court to be placed up for auction.

LAST year Loula Grace Erdman won the Dodd, Mead-Redbook prize of $10,000 for her first novel, "The Years of the Locust." "Lonely Passage," her second, is a story of the Pembertons, a Missouri small-town family, and especially of the young girl Thurley Renfro, who comes to adulthood through love and suffering, and finds the reward of happiness within this woman-dominated circle.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- The conditions on which Bao Dai, former Emperor of Annam, may return to Indo- China and enable the French to settle the war there will be discussed tomorrow at Cannes between Bao Dai and Leon Pignon, French High Commissioner for Indo-China.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The first test of Congressional sincerity on modernizing the Executive Branch of the Government is apparently near at hand.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 15 -- One hundred dead, 1,000 injured and untold damage to property were estimated tonight as the outcome of the three-day communal clashes between natives and Indians in Durban and its suburbs. The majority of the casualties and all the damage were sustained by the Indians.

HERE, in a familiar setting -- observed, by the way, with an urbanity rare in light fiction -- is a familiar, but altogether pleasing romance sparked with irony: "The Heart Has Reasons," indeed, and the author makes them both charming and convincing, as she gives you an amusing glimpse into the lives of a group of characters somewhat out of this world.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The fever chart at the Truman inauguration committee headquarters shot suddenly upward today but subsided after a transatlantic mix-up over invitations was straightened out.

THE first American exhibition of paintings by Cornelis Ruhtenberg, at the Passedoit Gallery, is a rare find -- a truly sensitive elaboration of a painter's mind facing up squarely to a social climate that must have been at least discouraging.

ALTHOUGH, as Roderick Peattie observes in his introduction to "The Inverted Mountains," there is already an extensive literature on the Canyon Country and "the earlier writers have used all the appropriate superlatives," the experts who wrote this book have managed to bring freshness and interest to their accounts.

HAAKON CHEVALIER'S first novel must be taken in thoughtfully, as a whole, with judgment withheld until the end. It is a novel based on a murder, but it is far from being a detective story. Early in 1929 Steve Callahan, the superintendent of a fruit ranch in Southern California, is murdered by poison.

DR. SILK, in this provocative volume, attacks the popular misconception that Sweden is a socialistic state, reminds us that the workings of its democratic Government and its industrial system are approximately parallel to our own.

There would be many a WAAC (Women's Auxiliary Army Corps) or WAC (Women's Army Corps) who would take issue with Nona Brown's article, "The Forces Find Woman Has a Place." Present volunteers get more advantages and less discomfort than the first volunteers of July, 1942, who obviously entered for patriotic reasons.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 15 -- Phil Ahwesh today was appointed head football coach at Duquesne University, succeeding Kass Kovalcheck.

Participation of a Unitarian clergyman last Sunday in an interdenominational vesper service for students attending fifteen private schools on the East Side was protested yesterday by the Right Rev. William T. Manning, retired Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.

J. M. KERRIGAN tells us of the night he forgot to raise his eyebrows. When another actor addressed a certain line to him Kerrigan would raise his eyebrows. The audience shouted with laughter. At one performance Kerrigan's mind wandered -- he forgot to raise his eyebrows. There came from the audience the same shout of laughter. It was a bitter moment.

IN the late Thirties various members of that distinguished body, the American Law Institute, often discussed the generally inept and ineffective treatment of youthful offenders who so frequently become out-and-out criminals. Such noted judges as Joseph Ulman of Baltimore and Curtis Bok of Philadelphia freely expressed their discouragements piled up over the years.

NOT the nationalization of Britain's steel industry, nor the conduct of her foreign policy, but a threat to the independence of the British "pub" was the controversial sensation of this Parliament. A bill providing for the nationalization of inns and taverns in the new satellite towns the Government plans to build to relieve congestion in the big cities started a real tempest in a beer mug.

THE annual midwinter garden course sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES will open this Wednesday at Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, New York City, with a talk on "The Perennial Family" by Miss Alys Sutcliffe, horticulturist of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Grist for the Eighty-first Congress' legislative mill has been pouring in with the traditional "first-week" superabundance. Already 2,008 bills have been introduced in the Senate and House.
One of the anomalies of life in New York City is the number of ordinances that must be obeyed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The board of directors of the United States Chamber of Commerce urged today that American ships be used to transport half of the ECA cargoes to Europe.
PARIS, Jan. 15 -- About 30,000 tons of vegetables are slowly going to waste in the region of St. Omer, in the northwest corner of France, because nobody wants them.

RUDOLPH KIEVE, a refugee from nazism, now practicing psychiatry in this country, has written a thoughtful chronicle of the destructive relationship of two families in Germany between 1910 and 1919. His book has the drama or melodrama obligatory in a family novel: the violence, sex and loss of fortune.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 15 -- Faultless, from Warren Wright's Calumet Farm, got up in the last nod to capture the $12,050 Tropical Handicap as a forty-day meeting ended at Tropical Park today before a crowd of 14,783 that bet $783,233, largest handle of the meet.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Shim Malone, California-bred 5- year-old, outgamed On Trust in a duel down the stretch at Santa Anita Park today and won the $61,050 San Pasqual Handicap before 43,000 racegoers who bet $2,450,858 on the eight events.
" Who is the first humorist of the age? Who is the man who can make anybody laugh in any context at any time?" Sir Alan Herbert put the questions to a gathering at a literary' luncheon in London.

THIS is the third book by Dr. Lane about the marvels of the physical world. Others have dealt with the seas and with the more important lakes. Both these previous works were welcome contributions to the field of popular science, very much superior to the general run in fluency, grasp and power of image.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 -- A proposed platform that provides new guideposts for Jewish communal life in America and calls for central agencies in each city to plan, coordinate, finance and budget all community service programs has been drafted.

The basketball fans at Morningside Heights Gymnasium last night, all 2,000 of them, went slightly mad as they watched Columbia crack its scoring record by swamping Harvard beneath an 86-49 count. The previous mark, set by the Lions last year, was 76 points against Princeton.
The feasibility of merging the Stock Clearing Corporation and the Curb Exchange Clearing Corporation will be taken under advisement this week by the Association of Stock Exchange Firms.

AT last here is a book that answers the questions children ask about the animals most familiar to them -- colts, calves, lambs, kids, pigs, puppies, kittens and rabbits. The facts about these animals are so simply told and in such an interesting manner that not only will little children learn a great deal but so also will their older brothers and sisters.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 15 -- Senator A. Willis Robertson warned here today that many American workers might find themselves taxed as much as $40 a month, in addition to all other taxes, to finance programs of social benefits and medical insurance recommended by President Truman.
LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 15 -- Israel is planning to make another bid soon for admission to the United Nations as a result of Cuba's recognition of the Tel Aviv government, it was learned here today.

Czechoslovakia's trade relations with the Soviet Union should not be a bar to expanding relations between his country and the United States, Dr. Jaroslav Fukatko, secretary-general of the Central Federation of Czechoslovak Industries, said yesterday at La Guardia Airport on his arrival from Prague.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned slightly easier yesterday and final prices were 1 to 9 points net lower.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- France's Radical Premier Henri Queuille suddenly agreed this week to try once again a system of price controls that is contrary to the principles of his party and which has failed in the past to check rises in prices.

Your editorial of Dec. 26, "What Is Americanism," deserves the unstinted commendation of all Americans who are in accord with the Federal Constitution. The illuminating frankness contained in your editorial should have a sobering effect on Americans who would, through malice or ignorance, jeopardize the foundation on which this Republic was founded: freedom of thought and speech.

A HIGHLY successful attempt to describe social conditions in terms of photographs is demonstrated in Marion Palfi's exhibition, "Children in America," which opened last week at the New York Public Library. It will continue on the main floor, north corridor, through Jan. 31, after which it will be shown in the Muhlenburg Branch, 209 West Twenty-third Street, for a month, with subsequent showings in other library branches.

THE ABC network, which did so well with its documentaries last year, had an off night last Monday. Its study of the German situation, under the title of "The Berlin Story," lacked any real point of view and ultimately got lost in the complexity of the subject which it was reviewing.

THE best-selling (in terms of bookstore sales) 1948 novel wasn't "The Naked and the Dead" after all. "Naked" was No. 2. Young Mr. Mailer had a breath - taking head - start, and looked like the winner all summer and most of the fall. But in mid-November along came Lloyd C. Douglas, and, whoosh, the race was over.

WHATEVER derogatory remarks are to be made about the Twenties, the period did revolutionize the Broadway musical comedy -- a form of entertainment that many authorities consider our highest native art form. Improvements in the medium, especially as regards dancing, are still under way, and the end is not yet in sight.
LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Jan. 15 -- The high cost of relative security was graphically illustrated last week by the projected 1949-50 budget.

DELIVERY of the first of the giant Boeing Stratocruisers to the commercial airlines is scheduled to start this week. It will, however, be at least two months before the first of the new double-deckers goes into regular service.

RESOLUTIONS, so the maxims tell us, are best acted on with promptitude. Two weeks ago, in what was perhaps an excess of conscience, this department made certain commitments concerning the year to come. Among them, I listed my intention to try, so far as possible, to redress the balance between the book that gets too much attention and the one that gets too little.

ANGELS are common enough in the theatre, but they are scarce in the field of opera. A group of sixteen have joined to form Opera Enterprises for "participation in financing and producing operas." Giovanni Cardelli is the general partner and the organization was formed principally to help in backing Benjamin Britten's "The Rape of Lucretia."

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 15 -- This was a somewhat restless week in the Upper South. The weather wasn't right, for one thing. It was so warm that the winter wheat started perking up when it should have been lying down, and wasps woke up and came buzzing around farmhouses. It was too warm for trapping.

SPRING has already arrived in the greenhouse. Amid all the flowers flaunting their colors there now, the gardener busies himself with seed sowing and the rooting of cuttings, so that the parade of bloom will continue uninterrupted.

STANLEY KRAMER, founder of Screenplays, Inc., has completed his second production, "Champion," based on a story by Ring Lardner, in twenty-four days' shooting for $595,000. The economy of time and money represented by those figures are viewed by Kramer as a triumph for the system of pre-production rehearsal and preparation.
EVER wonder what happens at a drive-in movie theatre when icicles mantle the silver screen and snowbanks cover the gravel parking strips?

THAT baldness is caused by a too-active mind, that every 155th year is a wet one, and that cats suck away the breath of sleeping babies are reports still given credence by an unconscionable number of otherwise level-headed people.

ATHENS, Jan. 15 -- King Paul accepted the resignation of Premier Themistocles Sophoulis this afternoon at an interview in the palace. The Premier had previously declined the Kings offer to call upon him at his home, which the King had tendered out of deference for the Premier's great age and infirmity.

SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 15 -- Shopkeepers, stockmen, railroaders and movie house operators have one common conversational topic in this region -- the unprecedentedly severe weather. Snow has fallen in the Mountain States on fifteen of the past eighteen days. Marks well below the freezing point have been recorded on each of those eighteen days.
DURBAN, South Africa, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Officials at Johannesburg estimated that 300 persons had been killed, and a Durban Member of Parliament said the figure was nearer 500.

WITH all the colossal movies that are ground out for juvenile minds, it is ironic how very few of them are aimed to view things as through the eyes of youth. The whole mystic region of child life is very seldom surveyed on the screen, and when it is, the surveying instruments are usually a hodge-podge of adult attitudes.

A RECAPITULATION, prepared for Scott's Monthly Journal, covering first-day sales of the thirty stamps which the Postoffice Department issued during 1948, discloses that collectors and dealers bought 28,592,751 stamps at the first-day ceremonies and paid $916,931.49 for them. The average initial-date sales were 953,125 stamps.

Of the major recommendations of the recent task force reports on the Federal medical services to the Hoover Commission on Organization of the executive branch of the Government, the two that will affect civilian medicine most profoundly are the decisions on those dealing with integration of the Federal and non-Federal hospital systems, and the drafting of doctors.
Dolphin Hall, a new $850,000 training center for Naval Reserve submarine crews, was formally dedicated yesterday afternoon in the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn.

YOU'D hardly recognize polite, policed and protected Gramercy Park today in this picture of goings on there half a century ago. Neither would you, perhaps, recognize in the author the eminent educator who for thirty years was president of Vassar College.
Mauna Loa erupted soon after the new year began. Strange as it may seem, Hawaiians rejoiced -- eruptions always mean a boom in the tourist trade.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Last Thursday morning, in the ornate and crowded Senate caucus room, Chairman Tom Connally of the Foreign Relations Committee opened the meeting by announcing that he would now consider Dean Acheson's appointment as Under (sic) Secretary of State.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 15 -- The abrupt ending of the conference of the Western European Defense Ministers here yesterday has lent strength to the widespread belief that all five participating countries, Britain, France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg, are anxiously awaiting the outcome of talks in Scandinavia and the signing of the Atlantic Pact by the United States and Canada before proceeding further with their plans.

ALONG with all the rest of southern California Hollywood discussed the local weather last week, including several snowfalls and a couple of bad freezes which nipped the tropical herbiage in studio nurseries.

The maritime industry swings this week into another labor dispute, although this one is relatively minor and may be ironed out under arbitration scheduled to begin tomorrow. It involves import warehouse workers of the International Longshoremen's Association AFL.

THE most tantalizing historical document in our literature, "The Diary of a Public Man," made its first and generally ephemeral appearance in the August to November issues of The North American Review for 1879.

ANY or all of these musical biographies would prove a useful addition to the music student's bookshelf. One of them, Opal Wheeler's life of Chopin, is intended for youngsters of 8 to 11. The other three are written for the upper age level, 12 to 16.
LONDON, Jan. 15 (Reuters) -- Wilf Mannion, who has been a holdout since the English soccer season started, returned to action today and led Middlesbrough to a 1-0 victory over Preston North End.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Considerable progress by European Recovery Program nations was reported today by the Economic Cooperation Administration.

December volume of men's wear stores was about equal to that of the same month of 1947, while sales for the entire year of 1948 showed a decline of about 1 1/2 per cent, according to the report issued yesterday by the business committee of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers.

ONE of the paradoxes of American history is that the first democracy should also be the first country to establish elaborate constitutional barriers against democracy. Faith in people and fear of government are twin inheritances of the Revolution, parallel doctrines of some of the Founding Fathers.

Ralph Herbert, Austrian baritone who has won his spurs here as a member of the New York City Opera Company, gave his first recital in this city yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. It was devoted entirely to German lieder.

IN thin rather odd novel, the "edge of light" is that narrow, blurred, sometimes feeble glimmer that seeps over the transoms of the United Nations, promising, if not exactly producing, a rational basis for man's hopes of peace.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15 -- Investigations were put under way today by the Roman Catholic Church and the Mexican Government to determine the legal ownership of more than 1,100 ecclesiastical paintings held in the "protective custody" of the city's police in two local art galleries.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 15 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district recovered sharply from the year-end setback which began shortly before Christmas, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Impressive gains were reported in industrial production, freight shipments and the volume of trade.

IDEAS on foundation plantings are, fortunately, not as static as they once were, and so it is no longer considered obligatory to shroud a house in shrubs. Instead, by taking advantage of certain architectural features which provide sheltered spots for planting, or by using areas next to foundations which feature material that might be grown elsewhere, we can induce spring to arrive earlier and linger longer.

WHEN Maj. Gen. Ralph Smith was relieved for cause during the Battle of Saipan, the papers gave the name of the officer who relieved him as "Howlin' Mad" Smith. The resulting controversy gave the impression that "Howlin' Mad" was a violent, swashbuckling soldier, hopping up and down with fury when events failed to follow his preconceived pattern.

EVEN if film production had been at a high peak (which it wasn't) last year, the chances are Jane Wyatt couldn't possibly have been more active. Her score: one picture released, namely "Pitfall," and three others completed but yet to be distributed, to wit, "Bad Boy," Allied Artists; "Canadian Pacific," Nat Holt-Twentieth Century-Fox, and "Task Force," Warner Brothers.

ANYONE who has driven through West Texas or had a conversational brush with the people who inhabit that garden of Eden is aware that Colonel McDowell was not serious when he subtitled his book "Tall Tales from the Mexican Border."

SHANGHAI, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Victorious troops of Communist Gen. Lin Piao, conqueror of Manchuria, seized the burning city of Tientsin after a fierce artillery barrage that devastated old landmarks and many buildings.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 15 -- Seeking stature as an industrial city with diversified trades as well as the country's leading winter resort, Greater Miami has made great strides in building an apparel industry. More than 100 manufacturers of men's, women's and children's clothing and accessories have settled here to develop a volume at wholesale in excess of $40,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Washington Redskins officials said today that "no concrete proposals" resulted from their conference with Baltimore Colts' representatives concerning the future of the two major professional football leagues.

IN exchanging views at their convention sessions here last week, retail merchants from all over the country agreed that the consumer is now in the driver's seat, and the lady is steering only toward better values.

BRUSSELS, Sunday, Jan. 16 (Reuters) -- A message from Prime Minister Winston Churchill urging King Leopold of the Belgians to come to England with his family after the German break-through in May, 1940, never reached Leopold, according to documents published today in La Libre Belgique, a leading Catholic newspaper.

Americans tomorrow will hail the most versatile of their fellow-citizens on the 243d anniversary of his birth. Benjamin Franklin, born Jan. 17, 1706, was called in his own time a "universal genius" because of the almost limitless range of his interests and talents.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 15 -- Leaders of the United States, British and French Military Governments discussed today the first of a series of far-reaching measures intended to "alleviate the social hardships caused by the war and its repercussions" in Germany.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Mexico will inspect the disputed 1,100 religious pictures in San Francisco to see if they came from churches here.

Thousands of small businesses will be brought into the Quarter-master supply picture as the result of full implementation of the new simplified procedure on orders of $1,000 or less, it was predicted last week. Army buying officials indicated that the so-called one-document purchase encompassing a purchase order, vendor's invoice, receiving and inspection report, and a voucher, will be utilized to its fullest extent in the next thirty days.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 15 (UP) -- President Ismet Inonu today named Shemsettin Gunaltay, Conservative member of the Republican People's (Government) party, as Premier of Turkey.

The freeing on Jan. 11, after a "trial" and nolle prosse, respectively, of two white men in Georgia, accused of participating with a hooded and white-robed gang in waylaying and murdering Robert Mallard, a prosperous Negro farmer, on Nov. 20, as his wife sat beside him in his automobile, and President Truman's reiteration of his civil rights program, should bring immediate action in Congress, making lynching a federal crime.

HOLLYWOOD script writers seldom murder anything -- except the novels they are adapting for the screen. But Robert Stanton is believed to have done in a human victim, or perhaps several of them. His alibis are so flimsy and his motive seems so well established that the gas chamber gapes for him -- unless he can prove that both motive and opportunity are nonexistent.

Guido Cantelli is one of the brightest young conductors to hit this town in many a year. He is 28, Italian and recommended by Arturo Toscanini. He made his local debut leading the NBC Symphony in its broadcast performance from Radio City early last evening.

EVEN junior knows that food costs more; ice cream sodas went up a nickel some time ago. But high prices aren't the only worry; diets are in other difficulties, too. These don't make headlines, but to professional workers (nutritionists in public health, social agencies, etc.) they are quite as pressing.

Four days after President Truman said that he would ask for appropriations to help arm friendly nations in Europe, the American State Department issued an important statement of policy. It stated that Soviet tactics had created "fear and insecurity [which] if left unchecked, might paralyze the [European] recovery effort.

A couple of safe experts decided yesterday that two days was time enough for coddling a seven-ton safe containing $250,000. So beginning at 9 A. M., and for six hours, they resorted to violence, with the result that the Bushwick Savings Bank, Brooklyn, regained actual as well as nominal possession of its funds.

THE United States Senate, which four years ago had as a member a rather retiring and modest gentleman named Harry S. Truman, now assumes the leading role in carrying out the new legislative program of the Truman Administration.

ONE can hardly be surprised at the reply of Mr. Serly to Mr. Schoenberg's article of Dec. 19; for if there did not exist the fundamental misconceptions revealed in that reply, the article of Mr. Schoenberg would not have had to be written.

To enlarge its program of teaching and research in service to the rapidly expanding community, the University of Southern California will need at least $15,000,000 worth of new permanent buildings and $5,000,000 worth of additional land for its campus in the next few years, according to President Fred D. Fagg Jr.

FREE enterprise ( a magic phrase) connotes different things to different people. To the radical it is the cause of human exploitation; to most business men it means retention of the status quo. It is used by labor to defend trade-union practices.

PRESIDENT TRUMAN'S recommendation for "an immediate study of the adequacy of production facilities for materials in critically short supply, such as steel," highlights a long-standing controversy about how much steel the United States should produce.

Getting the jump early, Al Parsells' Manhattan indoor poloists atoned for a previous setback by halting the 20-goal Arlington Farms side headed by Del Carroll, 14 -- 8, at Squadron A Armory last night.

American colleges and universities performed a searching self-appraisal last week when responsible spokesmen for higher education brought into the open many of the significant problems currently found on the campus and in the classroom.

Great Britain expects 130,000 American tourists to spend $65,000,000 in the British Isles during the 1949 season, according to an estimate made yesterday by Sir Alexander Maxwell, chairman of the British Tourist and Holidays Board.

THERE are two schools of thought about what makes furniture modern. According to some sticklers, the only truly modern designs are those which have come out of modern construction techniques -- Charles Eames' chairs of molded plywood, for instance, or Alvar Aalto's seats and tables with the patented Y-construction leg.
BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Dutch Army here today accused the United Nations Good Offices Committee in Indonesia of being biased and badly informed.
