EVER since last February, when the Boston Institute changed its name with such fanfare from Institute of "Modern" Art to Institute of "Contemporary" Art, we have been waiting impatiently for clarification. For at that time it issued a militant manifesto declaring "modern art" signified something "unintelligible" and promised to "distinguish good from bad,"

Arthur Hopkins is a commercial producer, director, and author of note and few would challenge his right to pontificate upon the Broadway theatre. When he goes afield, however, as he did in his article "The Day of Liberation," he becomes almost as fallible as the rest of his Main Stem colleagues.

Ambitious plans for "streamlining" the Federal Trade Commission include an extensive reshuffle of anti-trust law enforcement powers, it was learned yesterday. The proposals, contained in a staff report on which the Hoover Commission on Reorganization of the Executive Branch of the Government will base specific recommendations for improvements, are aimed largely at ending FTC's sluggish and costly operation.

SHANTY-BOAT cruises through Florida's inland waterways are again attracting those who like leisurely sight-seeing. Close-ups of the state's flora and fauna -- parrots, alligators, cypress swamps and orchids -- offer thrills along the lazy trail of the shanty boat, which will continue its meanderings through March 7, leaving Fort Myers every Monday.

BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 15 -- A tour of Southeast Asia extending from India to Indonesia reveals that Communist military victories in China, successes in other countries and the Dutch military operations in Indonesia have had wide repercussions throughout the area. Every mistake mad eby anti-Communist governments, whether political or tactical, has been shrewdly exploited by the Communists.

The third in the series of music history lectures by Dr. Curt Sachs will be presented tomorrow at 8:30 in Room 213 of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. "The Beginnings of Opera; the new dramatic style in Italy and its repercussions in Protestant Germany" will be the subject, covering the first half of the seventeenth century.

Foremost in problems of Government-industry relations, the questions of "how much depreciation should be allowed" and "how these allowances should be provided'' appear to be scheduled for a legislative tug-of-war early in the next Congress.

BERLIN, Jan. 15 -- Safely over the worst flying weather, pilots of the Berlin airlift are daily strengthening the conviction among Germans as well as Western Allied occupation forces that they have clinched their point -- that the blockade of Berlin has failed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The mightiest air armada ever to pass over this city will fly a ninety-minute parade for President Truman on Inauguration Day next Thursday.

DETROIT, Jan. 15 -- Social benefits received priority over wages as the United Automobile Workers, CIO, unveiled today its bargaining "package" for 1949. It will level three sweeping demands on industry, which, if granted, would cost management as much as 30 cents an hour for each employe.

ON Jan. 20, 1949, Harry S. Truman establishes undisputed and solitary possession of the loneliest box in the most colossal organizational chart in all creation. He asked for it and fought for it and won it all by himself, knowing full well that he must occupy it all by himself.

THE stature of Eliel Saarinen as a great architect needs no debating. The quiet, unknown Finn in 1922 was given second place in the famous Chicago Tribune competition -- apparently only because of his Finnishness and because he was all but unknown in this country.

The most complete private collection of Whistler's etchings known, that formed by the late Harris Whittemore, will be dispersed at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street. In Part One tomorrow and Tuesday evenings, one half of the virtually complete collection will be auctioned together with a fine group of plates by Mary Cassatt containing most of her color proofs and a cross-section of her work in drypoint.
LONDON, Jan. 15 -- There are few parts of the world where Anglo-American interests are so interrelated and where concert of policy is more important to the two countries than in the Middle East.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 15 -- The Army Chiefs of India and Pakistan, who met here today to review the Kashmir truce arrangements, confirmed the cease-fire order informally accepted two weeks ago. Thus ended fourteen months of strife between the two Dominions.

A Congressional revision of the Displaced Persons Act of 1948 was urged yesterday by Rabbi David H. Panitz in Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 257 West Eighty-eighth Street. He declared the measure was "so discriminatory that only a relatively small group of Jews can qualify for admission under its provisions."

THE research, styling and engineering of the automobiles and other products of General Motors will be displayed in hundreds of exhibits at the corporation's show opening at the Waldorf-Astoria on Thursday.
Engineers who man the locomotives of the Long Island Rail Road will vote tomorrow on whether to go on strike against the line that carries thousands of daily commuters into and out of New York.

ABOUT this time of year flower arrangers are apt to be at a loss to find suitable material with which to work, for this is the lean period before early spring flowers appear. One source that is often overlooked is the vegetable market, where, surprisingly enough, a practical and inexpensive solution may be found in an arrangement of fruit, vegetables and foliage.

U. S. MARINE CORPS RECRUIT DEPOT, PARRIS ISLAND, S. C. UNACCUSTOMED as they are to defensive operations, the United States Marines have met the onslaught of new ideas in defense planning and military training and seem to have these situations well in hand. Unification, a big air force and peacetime reforms may be the orders of the day on the level of high policy and high brass.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Development of the power resources of the St. Lawrence River by New York and Ontario would result in cheaper power, even without transmission competition with private utility companies, Administration spokesmen predicted today.
Every last customer among the 4,683 at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night got his -- or her -- money's worth in basketball thrills.

AS long as the sun never sets on the British typewriter, tales of intrigue and suspense in far places will find their way between covers and along the shelves of America's lending libraries. Your fictional Englishman at home is concerned with the beauty of the countryside and the sentiment of the fireside.

ORLANDO, Fla. -- A flood of free orange juice is overwhelming visitors to this city, the center of the citrus fruit belt. It is offered them in cafeterias and restaurants; it is available for the asking at public booths get up for that purpose; and even the banks, which seldom give away samples of anything, are serving free orange juice.

A last-ditch fight to compel the Mayor to designate the executive director of the traffic engineering department as chairman of the proposed city traffic commission will be waged Tuesday by minority members of the City Council, it was reported yesterday.

Amid the babel of tongues and the confusion of thinking over the international situation, one might prudently hesitate to enter. If I am tempted to try, it is because the attitude of so many of us who have striven for peace through international cooperation these many years past has been oft quite misrepresented.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Republicans made public today a tentative program for the first post-election meeting of their National Committee in Omaha on Jan. 26 and 27 amid indications that organized opposition to the continuance of Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr., of Pennsylvania as National Chairman had virtually collapsed.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 15 -- A muscular amateur, Frank Stranahan, tossed a par-shattering bombshell into the solid ranks of the big professionals today to pop into the lead in the Bing Crosby invitation golf tournament.

That theory and practice may be combined successfully by a student before he is graduated has been demonstrated after a two-year trial of "work-study" programs at the City College School of Business and Civic Administration, it was reported yesterday.
ROME, Jan. 15 -- An effort to harmonize the strategy of the French and Italian Communist parties is seen in the visit to Italy of the veteran French Communist, Marcel Cachin.

Tommy Quinn, national indoor champion and New York Athletic Club veteran, who has been one of the dominating figures in the mile in recent years, made way for a younger rival last night when he was beaten by 20-year-old Phil O'Connell of Manhattan College at the 102d Engineers Armory.

IN the Sunday, Dec. 26, issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES you referred to Frequency Modulation in part as follows: "The FM art as a purely aural medium had a difficult economic problem during the year, being caught between the existing dominance of standard radio and the sudden onrush of television.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Air Force has proposed a new personnel policy which takes "a long step" toward ending segregation of and discrimination against Negro fliers, it was learned today.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 15 -- The new Constituent Assembly opened its preliminary session today, swore in the members and elected its officers. Jose Maria Vargas was named President of the Assembly.

BATAVIA, Jan. 15 -- The Netherlands Government hopes that general elections for an all-Indonesian Constituent Assembly can be held in August or September, Dr. P. J. Koets, director of the Cabinet under the High Commissioner, Dr. Louis J. M. Beel, said today in an interview.

A request for issuance of a special distinctive plate or identification card to enable wholesale salesmen to park their automobiles in areas and at hours restricted to commercial traffic was forwarded to Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander last week.

MY great and good friend, Arthur Hopkins, who is a great and good friend of the theatre, in an article entitled "The Day of Liberation," appearing in last Sunday's NEW YORK TIMES, made certain statements to which I must take exception.

IT is a pity that this book could not have been published a few years ago when the events it describes were less familiar. Many readers then, of course, would have refused to believe that Molotov was lying when he pledged the Soviet Government not to alter the existing social and economic structure of Rumania.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Canisius came from behind tonight to drop Georgtown, 52 -- 43, in the second game of a college basketball double-header before 8,504 fans in Memorial Auditorium. Niagara upset De Paul, 57 -- 53, in the opener.
A plea by all public carriers asking passengers to help work for repeal of the 15 per cent Federal transportation tax is being issued with every ticket bought, it was learned yesterday.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 15 -- The Deep South turned its eyes toward Georgia this week as the "Empire State of Dixie" launched a fresh attack in the South's losing battle to maintain white supremacy at the polls.

Four-year-old Linda Brown of San Antonio, Tex., this year's March of Dimes poster girl, yesterday visited two institutions in Brooklyn whose work to help victims of infantile paralysis is aided by funds from the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 15 -- Navy's basketball team overcame a 29-27 haft-time deficit to defeat Rutgers University, 57 -- 50 tonight. Dave Mullaney of Elmhurst, L. I., led the midshipmen with 19 points.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The most delicate and the most important relationship in the official life of any President is that with Congress. Under our system of checks and balances, each coordinate branch of the Government -- executive, legislative and judicial -- enjoys certain prerogatives and privileges which are distinctively its own.

RHODES, Jan. 15 -- Col. Yigol Yadin, Israeli Chief of Military Operations, flew to Tel Aviv today, while other Israeli delegates conferred with Dr. Bunche and his staff, who were preparing for the Israeli-Egyptian meeting on the delicate questions of armistice lines and the withdrawal of troops.

The domestic steel industry, as one of the principal advocates of the basing-point system of pricing, endorses the bill introduced at the present session of Congress by Senator Edwin C. Johnson of Colorado concerning the pricing practices of American industry.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 15 -- Princeton University's varsity basketball team maintained its lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate League by conquering Dartmouth, 59 -- 49, tonight before an overflow crowd in Dillon Gymnasium.

School superintendents and principals in Ohio have been asked by Dr. Clyde Hissong, State Director of Education, to give renewed emphasis to the "Zeal for American Democracy" program. In calling the attention of the teaching profession to the program, Dr. Hissong said: "Again in 1949 it is imperative that our schools do everything possible to promote an understanding of American democracy.

Manager Leo Durocher may not be wholly satisfied with the Giant pitching staff as it stands at the moment, but he at least has the satisfaction of knowing there'll be no tardy arrivals when the Polo Grounders gather for training at Phoenix come March 1.

OUT-OF-TOWN critics are periodically taken to task for misleading New Yorkers about the true artistic nature of theatre attractions. The Hinterland Hazlitts, at such times, draw the fire of observers who normally indulge in useful flagellations of the reviewers of New York, the Naughty Nine.

American Protestant and Eastern Orthodox churches Sent overseas in 1948 a total of $16,500,000 in funds and relief supplies through Church World Service, 214 East Twenty-first Street, which is their coordinating agency, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Pressure against soy beans and lard again caused a weak tone in all commodities on the Board of Trade today. Wheat did a little better than other cereals, some buying being attracted into the new crop months toward the close.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Jan. 15 -- The prevalence of crime is giving the authorities here a great deal of concern and as a result Superior Court Judge Frank T. Lloyd Jr. has ordered the January grand jury to keep a watchful eye for evidence of official misconduct especially with regard to gambling.
NORMAN, Okla., Jan. 15 -- Bud Wilkinson, University of Oklahoma's brilliant young football mentor, today signed a new contract as coach, athletic director and professor of physical education.

Printing Education Week will be celebrated for six days, beginning tomorrow, it was announced yesterday by the Printing Education Week Committee, of which Mayor O'Dwyer is honorary chairman. The ceremonies will include special honors to the memory of one of the nation's greatest printers and statesmen, Benjamin Franklin, whose 243d birthday is Jan. 17.

In attempting to fathom the cause for the premature demise, despite several favorable notices from the critics, of so vital and topical a play as "The Young and Fair," I can't avoid a bit of speculation. Wouldn't its author have been wiser had he refrained from posing so many problems all at once?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Washington Capitols turned back the New York Knickerbockers, 75 -- 73, in a Basketball Association of America game before 4,950 screaming fans at Uline's Arena tonight.

Most of New York City (all but the Bronx) is built on islands, and its economy feeds mainly on supplies brought over-water from the "mainland" -- from railroad terminals in Hew Jersey. Tugboats push across the Hudson barges loaded with most of the city's fuel oil (15,000,000 gallons a day), gasoline (2,500,000 gallons), coal and coke (90,000 tons) and perishable foods (13,000 tons).

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- In the indoor track and field season's first sizable gathering of headline stars, Fred Wilt tonight again captured the spotlight. The bounding 28-year-old Indiana graduate ran two miles in 9:09 to provide the outstanding performance of the second annual Washington Evening Star games.

Next Thursday's inaugural ceremonies are being planned in an atmosphere of good cheer which rain, snow or wintry breezes are not likely to destroy. They will not remind us, except by contrast, of that day exactly four years ago when a man about to die stood bareheaded in a bitter wind, taking the oath of office for the fourth time.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 15 -- Renewed hints have appeared in the Russian-licensed press during the past week that the Soviet zone Constitution is about completed and that Russian troops are to be withdrawn. These indications have convinced Western Military Government authorities that the Russians will formally establish a German Government in their occupation zone.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Jan. 15 -- The tolling of church bells and the shouts of two modern Paul Reveres heralded today the start of a South Buffalo crosstown bus route. The reason was that residents of the area had sought such service for twenty years.

IN the spring of 1946, the late Fiorello La Guardia was appointed to succeed Herbert Lehman as Director General of the UNRRA. Later that year, the new Director sent his old friend, Ira Hirschmann, as Special Investigator General on a mission which took him to Turkey, Egypt, Palestine, England, Germany, Poland, Czechoslovakia, Austria, back to Germany and home: the chief object of this journey was to check on DP camps in Germany.

IT is very good news that Valerie Bettis is to repeat her new work, "As I Lay Dying," when she appears in the Dance Theatre Series at the "Y" next Sunday, for it is a stunning piece, powerful dramatically, imaginative in design, and played by just about as fine a company of dancers and actors working together as the field can produce.

PLANS were announced last week for the National Photographic Show of 1949, to be held Feb. 19-22 at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue. The program will include display and demonstration of new products by more than sixty-five photographic manufacturers; the Thirteenth Annual Press Photographers Exhibition, and daily lecture-demonstrations by five of the leading photographic schools in the East.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15 -- The continued unseasonable cold weather put the Pacific Northwest on notice that an electric energy shortage, with a breakdown in the power pool, was a constant threat as the result of freezing rivers that reduce the amount of water flowing over power dams.

The world crisis today has been caused partly by a schism between the natural sciences and the social sciences, Dr. Nelson P. Mead, former acting president of City College and for forty-six years a member of its History Department, declared last night. He said that the natural sciences had invented means for destruction while the social sciences had not yet discovered the means for controlling man's primitive instincts.

In the finest traditions of a fine division, the Eighty-second Airborne, Sgt. Robert Lee Hodgkiss managed the escape of thirty-six paratroopers from a C-82 "flying boxcar" as the airplane rode down fast toward a crash landing in North Carolina. The first thought that comes to mind is that Hodgkiss duplicated the tradition of the skipper at sea, who must be last to leave his ship.

Markets for tires will continue this year to be much larger than at any time before the war, Harvey S. Firestone Jr., chairman of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting held yesterday in Akron, Ohio.

The Board of Education proposed last week a record budget of $220,599,648 to enable the city's schools to meet their expanding responsibilities during 1949-50. The board at the same time frankly admitted that the school system was in a poor financial state.

IN this gaudy tale of the First Crusade, daggers flash, torch-lights glimmer on mailed knights astride foaming stallions and bold-eyed heroes offer whole cities as love gifts. But the strut is authentic, and the ring is of truth as well as of armor.

FOX RIVER GROVE, Ill., Jan. 15 -- A talent-laden field of 104 skiers, one of the mightiest arrays to appear in this country since the 1932 winter Olympics at Lake Placid, tonight anxiously scanned the skies in hope that tomorrow's weather will be favorable for the forty-third annual ski jumping classic of the Norge S. C. of Chicago.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 15 -- Following today's return of Colonel Yadin and Mr. Sasson from the Rhodes conference, there were unconfirmed reports that the talks were passing from the armistice to the peace level, and that the release of the Egyptian brigade trapped at Faluja was imminent.

LAJOS ZILAHY wrote "The Dukays" during World War II, while hiding from the Nazis. Hungarian dramatist as well as novelist, he is now in his late fifties. New York theatregoers with long memories may recall his "Firebird," which was produced here in the Thirties.

THE current comprehensive exhibition of paintings and drawings by Thomas Cole, at the Whitney Museum, is of more than mere historical interest. Organized by the Wadsworth Atheneum of Hartford on the centenary of the artist's death, the event also marked the centenary of the death of the founder of the Atheneum who was a close friend of this pioneer master of American landscape.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 15 -- The Government of the Croatian Republic has been reconstructed and four Cabinet Ministers have been dropped, according to an announcement here today.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 15 -- Oklahoma and North Carolina drew down the biggest "take home pay" today of any colleges playing post-season football games -- $103,081.48 apiece. Sugar Bowl President Frank Schaub said checks for that amount were in the mails, representing each team's share of proceeds from their New Year's Day match here. Oklahoma won the game, 14 -- 6.

Evidence that ignorance is the fundamental cause of much inadequate export packaging has prompted the special steamship packaging committee that had been preparing a code of minimum standards to attempt an educational program before resorting to more drastic measures, it was learned last week.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller, former Assistant Secretary of State and Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, said today that "enlightened, dynamic capitalism" was aiding the spread of democracy in the postwar world.

EVERGLADES NATIONAL PARK, Fla. -- Work done last summer has not only made Everglades National Park far more easily accessible but has also vastly improved arrangements for showing visitors the wonders of this newest of national preserves.
BOSTON, Jan. 15 -- Hydroelectric power remains a vexing problem in New England, despite temporary relief brought by heavy rains in the last two months.

BRIDGETOWN, Barbados -- This island, just about the best tourist buy in the British West Indies, if not in all the Caribbean, is suffering from lack of shipping transport, and hence from a lack of tourists. Which makes Barbados most attractive to vacationists who like to fly and can whip down to this delightful corner of the tropics in a matter of hours.

ROME, Jan. 15 -- The Pope today urged the Italian aristocracy to cooperate in the improvement of Italy's social conditions. Times, he said, have changed and no one today can indulge in frivolous pursuits and squander money while many of his fellow-men are deprived even of the bare necessaries of life.

During 1949, the malleable iron industry will again be able to supply customers whose requirements during past shortages were diverted to other and less efficient materials, and the industry entered the year with an average three-month backlog on its books.

OTTAWA, Jan. 15 -- Canadian interest in the North Atlantic defense pact, now being drafted in Washington, has begun to take a critical form and it is believed that when Parliament meets on Jan. 26 the Government may have a harder task than was anticipated in "selling" the idea to the country.

Last week in Washington the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, after a public hearing and an executive hearing, unanimously recommended approval of the appointment of Dean Gooderham Acheson, 55, to the No. 1 Cabinet post: Secretary of State.

NOW that the connecting link between the East and Midwest television networks has been opened, the inaugural ceremonies for President Truman and Vice President Barkley in Washington on Thursday are expected to be seen and heard by more people than ever witnessed any other event in history.

" Churchill the Artist'' brings to mind another distinguished British amateur -- the novelist Arnold Bennett -- and his trouble with "creating" in paint. On a painting expedition to Ludlow in Shropshire with the fine British etcher, John Wright, it rained one day, so Bennett drew a sketch of a bridge from his hotel window.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 15 Selection of Dr. Warren K. Lewis, Emeritus Professor of Chemical Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, to receive the 1949 gold medal of the American Institute of Chemists was announced today.
OSLO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Dutch speed skater, Kees Broeckmann, 21, showed tonight that it will be difficult to beat him in the long races in the European and world championships next month.

Another June-in-January snowless, sunny day brought to the National Motor Boat Show for its finale yesterday and last night the largest crowd of visitors to this indoor dry land harbor of pleasure boating of its entire 1949 run.

A tool to level out "boom and bust" cycles has been developed by consulting management engineers in the form of a "management audit" that enables industry to plan to meet tomorrow's problems today. This new device to be added to the techniques of executive control was described here by E. O. Griffenhagen, president of the Association of Consulting Management Engineers and partner in Griffenhagen Associates, New York and Chicago.

AMONG the singers who people the stage of the Metropolitan Opera this year is an aquiline-featured newcomer named Italo Tajo. He sings bass, is so tall he has trouble sleeping in Pullman berths and was named Italo because he was the only one of five children of an Italian family to be born in Italy.

The Truman Administration's multi-billion-dollar public housing program is likely to turn out to be a legislative "hot potato" because interest on local housing bonds issued thereunder would not be tax-exempt, as in the past, but would be subject to full taxation, like corporate bonds and obligations issued most recently by the Federal Government.
With the article, "Russia -- A Land of Paradox," was a photograph that should be Exhibit No. 1 in any effort to depict life under the Russian Red Star.

THE oldest "set," or at least one of the oldest, ever used in a motion picture will be seen in "Black Magic," the Edward Small spectacle costarring Orson Welles and Nancy Guild. The "set" is the church dedicated to SS. Nereus and Achilleus, on the Passeggiata Archeologica, a stone's throw from the ruins of the Baths of Caracalla, in Rome.

VIENNA, Jan. 15 -- Potentially important information that the Russians have begun to widen the gauge on the two Hungarian railroad lines that they use to maintain communications from Russia to their zone in eastern Austria, by way of the Carpatho-Ukraine in one case and Rumania in the other, has been brought to Vienna by refugees reaching this capital.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The White House today gave out descriptions of the gowns to be worn by the First Lady and her daughter at the events of Inauguration Week. At the brief meeting held for this purpose some swatches of the materials went the rounds of the newspaper women in the interest of accuracy.

ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 15 -- A bill of rights for civilian students, to provide $1,000,000,000 in annual scholarships and fellowships, was proposed here at the concluding session of the American College Public Relations Association's conference on the Corner University campus.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 15 (UP) -- Gen. George C. Marshall flew here today from his home in Pinehurst, N.C. Rest in this warm climate is expected to speed his recovery from a kidney operation.

Cooperative merchandising of coal fuel as well as heating equipment has advanced throughout the country and there are now fifty-four Coal Heating Service groups of retail coal merchants, aided by coal producers, in cities and localities of twenty-three states. These facts were disclosed here yesterday by Charles A. Owen, president of the National Coal Association, a trade association of coal producers.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Jan. 15 -- The University of North Carolina will meet the University of Notre Dame in football next Nov. 12 at the Yankee Stadium, it was announced today by R. A. Fetzer, North Carolina's director of athletics.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 15 -- The United States Embassy received "Strong assurances" from the Foreign Ministry last night that President Peron's "forced citizenship" plan would not apply to United States citizens or other foreigners down here on specific business or Professional assignments.

Centralized purchasing practices expanded in Government buying circles during 1948, and are due for large further expansion in 1949, according to Albert G. Hall, executive director, National Institute of Governmental Purchasing, Inc. For the first time, professional training in advanced practices of purchasing was formalized by the establishment of a National Academy of Public Purchasing, in conjunction with the Bureau of Federal Supply of the Treasury Department, he added.

Retail activity here last week was good, with increased activity shown in spring dresses, resort and sportswear departments, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

An implication that the Administration should use a bipartisan group in working out details of the proposed North Atlantic security pact was made here yesterday by John Foster Dulles, Republican foreign policy expert and recently acting head of the United States delegation at the Paris session of the United Nations General Assembly.

ATLANTA, Jan. 15 (UP) -- Southern cities in which the Brooklyn Dodgers have scheduled spring exhibition games ignored the protests of the Ku Klux Klan today and heartily welcomed the coming appearances of Negro stars Jackie Robinson and Roy Campanella.

WHAT makes a bridge hand interesting isn't necessarily some unusual arrangement or cards, or a classic play or brilliant bid, or an astronomical score, or the fact that you can replace the impersonal tags North, South, East and West with the names of four celebrities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- While the future of the House Un-American Activities Committee is still a political football, the Federal Bureau of Investigation issued a quiet announcement recently that the loyalty check of Federal workers was virtually complete.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 15 -- Ed Carr, a New South Wales medical student who was unable to walk five years ago, defeated the world record holder Herb McKenley of Jamaica, B. W. I., today in the 440-yard event of an Australian track meet at the Sydney cricket ground.

Construction work estimated to cost $290,045,000 was started in this city in 1948, according to preliminary figures on the year's building operations made public yesterday by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor.
FRANFORT, Germany, Jan. 15 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay said today that the depressed prices for German export coal were costing the United States taxpayers $40,000,000 to $50,000,000 a year.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 -- A syndicate of 100 Philadelphia business men bought the Philadelphia Eagles for $250,000 today to "bring local pro football back to the community."

On Nov. 13, 1945, three months after he became Foreign Secretary in Britain's Labor Government, Ernest Bevin, former van driver and trade union leader, told the House of Commons: "I will stake my political future on solving this [Palestine] problem."
HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 15 -- Gov. Chester Bowles reaffirmed today his opposition to the establishment of a "Jim Crow" unit in the State National Guard to take care of Negro enlistments.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The House Democratic leadership, in a procedure without precedent, moved today to oust Representatives John E. Rankin of Mississippi and F. Edward Hebert of Louisiana from the Committee on Un-American Activities.

NANKING, Jan. 15 -- The Communist radio today announced the complete occupation of Tientsin, North China's leading industrial enter, by Gen. Liu Ya-lou's attacking Communist columns. According to the broadcast the city, which has a population of 2,000,000 and ranks second only to Shanghai as a commercial mart, was taken at 1:30 P. M. today after a final assault lasting twenty-seven and one-half hours.
MOSCOW, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Soviet Press today quoted a United States judge as calling for "physical force against persons who criticize the United States and praise the Soviet Union."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Builders started 56,000 new permanent non-farm dwelling units in December, bringing the total for the year to 926,800, according to preliminary estimates issued by the Bureau of Labor Statistics today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 -- With the inauguration this week of five Central Western Governors -- four of them Democrats who defeated Republican incumbents in the Nov. 2 elections -- a majority of the voters are apparently convinced that the outlook is bright for improved state governments.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- President Truman today told Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican, of Wisconsin, he would make "every effort possible" to prevent "sabotage" of the St. Lawrence Seaway project within his Administration.

Reports are now coming in from many rural areas that dogs again are threatening the deer population, and in order to prevent a repetition of last winter's high deer mortality from this cause, several game wardens have issued warnings to dog owners to keep their pets on home property.
SINCE the movie industry is so frantic about rising production costs and declining attendance, why doesn't it try stimulating public interest with really good short subjects that are advertised?

FOR better or worse, Japanese are being taught to write radio programs in the American manner. Under the direction of Walter Hackett, former NBC staff writer who is now script officer for the radio division of General MacArthur's headquarters, thirty-five alleged radio scripters have started a ten-week seminar covering some ninety classroom hours.

Retailers who met last week at the thirty-eighth annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association returned to their stores confident, almost without exception, that 1949 will be another good year.

The Eighty-first Congress should give early consideration to the need for additional federal judges. This has become a most pressing deficiency in the federal judicial structure. Nowhere is the need for additional judges more urgent than in the Southern, District of New York.
This is a year of decision for the American economy, Dr. Edwin G. Nourse, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- About $68,000,000 had been paid to 260,123 beneficiaries of the Welfare and Retirement Fund of the United Mine Workers as of Dec. 31, it was reported today.
AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 15 -- The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company has announced repossession of its 20,000-acre Dolok Merangir Estate rubber plantation in Sumatra.
OMAHA, Jan. 15 -- What to do with the generous leftovers from 1948 grain crops was a popular topic throughout the Middle West this week, even in the midst of continuing blizzard conditions.
I wonder if George Lawton reviewed the statistics of the last century before writing "Proof That She Is the Stronger Sex"?
TORONTO, Jan. 15 -- The Toronto Maple Leafs came from behind tonight to defeat the New York Rangers 2 -- 1, before 13,838 fans and sink the visitors deeper into the National Hockey League cellar.

American colleges are now experiencing the effects of their neglect of the problem of financing education, Dean Millicent Carey McIntosh of Barnard College says in her annual report to the president of Columbia University, made public yesterday.

The SEC has long been portrayed as the "policeman" of the financial world, but it remained for a clerk in the stock list department of the New York Stock Exchange to find the disagreement in the figures of earnings of Farnsworth Television and Radio, as contained in a registration statement covering the proposed offering of additional common stock land those previously issued by the company for the six months ended last Oct. 31.

Brooklyn Bridge will have a new six-lane mesh steel and concrete roadway to replace its present patched wood block flooring by late 1950, according to preliminary plans now awaiting approval by the Department of Public Works. The proposed modernization is expected to cost $2,400,000.
CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Today's report of the markets in the Union Stockyards by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

The American Telephone Telegraph Company in a preliminary statement covering the twelve months ended with last December, reported yesterday a net income of $207,620,000 after taxes and all charges excluding the company's proportionate interest in undistributed earnings of subsidiaries.
TO the amazement of the average New Yorker, there are a round dozen active ice boat clubs within sixty miles of Times Square and several a good deal closer than that.
A legislative investigation of the State College of Agriculture at Cornell University and its role in milk price controversies was demanded yesterday by the American Labor party.
FORT LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Jan. 16 -- Leavenworth, near the edge of the great mid-continent plains, is now a name to conjure with in world military circles.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- Interest in the Palestine situation has now shifted in Britain to the field of internal politics. Parliament reconvenes Tuesday after its Christmas recess, and Foreign Secretary Bevin will quickly have to face a heavy storm that will be as heavy from his own Labor party benches as from the Opposition.

France is sending another delicacy for the first time since the war -- a little tin of coquilles St. Jacques with four shells in which to heat and present this delicately rich mixture of scallops and seasonings. One pays $2.25 for the product and its "service."
CAIRO, Jan. 16 -- Aziz el Masri, Egyptian Chief of Staff about a decade ago, who tried to flee to the Axis side during the war, has been arrested, it was learned here today.

The Rev. Richard E. McEvoy, rector of St. Mark's Church-in-the-Bouwerie, Second Avenue and Tenth Street, said in his morning sermon yesterday that the pessimism of today's headlines reflected a crisis in family life.
William B. Herlands, former Commissioner of Investigation, was installed yesterday as president of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Congress has before it the urgent task of completing legislation increasing President Truman's salary and giving him a tax-free expense account before he is inaugurated on Thursday.
GENEVA, Switzerland, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The draw was made today for preliminary play-offs in the world soccer cup tournament, to be decided in 1950 in Brazil.

Barring a sharp decline in the Argentina peso, a reflection of the demand for dollars in Buenos Aires, there was no particular stir in any of the foreign exchanges last week. Pound sterling, and the free units of Canada and Switzerland, which have been the focal points of interest recently, showed relative firmness throughout. Business was on a modest scale.

Loomis J. Grossman, operator, bought and immediately resold the two-story taxpayer on a lot 39 by 117 feet at 274-76 Fulton Avenue, Hempstead, L. I. He bought it from Mabel Lemmerman through the Leonard S. Gans Company and resold it to Albet Kassover, owner of the Llwelyn Dress Shops of Hempstead through Edward Ettinger, broker, A new first mortgage loan of $165,000 was obtained from the Jamaica Savings Bank.
NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Newark Bears, who have been casting about for a new home, had an offer of a helping hand today from a Newark official.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- Negotiations begin here tomorrow among the United States, Britain and France in an effort to straighten out difficulties that have arisen over the German occupation statute. The three Western Military Governors in Germany could not agree on two important clauses and referred the issues back to their Governments.

Dr. Eduard Benes, late President of Czechoslovakia, was so disillusioned as a result of his dealings with Premier Stalin and other Communists that in one of the last messages prior to his death, Sept. 3, he wrote that "all Communists are liars, particularly the Russians," Dr. Eduard Taborsky, his former secretary, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UP) -- The Department of Labor reported today that the United States had about 300 women registered as architects and 950 as engineers.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 16 -- Control of four villages in Lebanon close to the frontier with Israel is being relinquished by the Israeli Army, which sent forces into Lebanon during the fighting in the north.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Wilson Co., Inc., meat packers, reported today a net income of $6,702,578, equal to $2.70 a common share, in the fifty-two weeks of its fiscal year, ended on Oct. 30, 1948. This compared with a net income of $15,448,823, equal to $6.82 a common share, in the previous fiscal year, which included fifty-three weeks.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Jan. 16 -- After a lapse of three weeks during the anniversary sailing over at Manhasset Bay dinghy sailing was resumed today at the Larchmont Yacht Club, and Corny Shields with his boat Dainty came through in the Interclub class.
The controversial question of veteran preference in civil service will require careful consideration by the 1949 session of the New York State Legislature.

TOKYO, Jan. 16 -- In line with yesterday's Far Eastern Commission directive concerning freer conditions for traders and investors here, the Occupation Authority's economic and scientific section today announced that commercial concerns might now deal for yen within Japan.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- The Minute Plant of 1948 award will be presented to the Carrier Corporation of Syracuse, N. Y., by the Society for the Advancement of Management at the opening day banquet of the society's national conference, which opens here on Thursday at the Sheraton Hotel, it was announced today by Thomas Sullivan, general conference chairman.

Negroes in Connecticut received better employment and educational opportunities last year than ever before, the Connecticut State Interracial Commission reported yesterday. The Hartford department stores were described as second only to New York in the hiring of qualified young Negro women.

The Metropolitan Opera will reach the half-way mark in its season with the week beginning Jan. 24. Lubomir Vichegonov will sing his first Fafner in "Siegfried"; Eleanor Steber her first Mimi and Giuseppe Valdengo his first Marcello in "La Boheme," and Dezso Ernster his first Sparafucile in "Rigoletto."

The thing an unemployed worker wants most is a job. During most of the last eight years finding new jobs has been relatively easy. Now there are more people looking for jobs than there were yesterday. This situation confronts the public employment offices in New York and other industrial states with a challenge that they must be physically equipped to meet.

Phyllis Moss' first New York piano recital in Times Hall yesterday afternoon had an outward appearance of musical accomplishment. Her nimble fingers seemed unusually strong and accurate: her tone had body and was controlled in volume, and her approach to the opening Loeillet and Scarlatti pieces was on the whole sane and objective.

A pioneer program in which indigent children with rheumatic heart disease receive medical care in their homes was described yesterday by Dr. Martin Cherkasky, head of the department of home care of Montefiore Hospital.

Holders of Republic of Chile external bonds who assented to the recently announced plan for service readjustment will receive interest for 1948 at the rate of 1 1/2 per cent, the Republic's Institute of Amortization of the Public Debt announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Members of the American Veterans of World War II (AMVETS) have indicated overwhelming preference for immediate payment of a service bonus ranging up to $4,500, Harold A. Keats, national commander, reported today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 16 -- The second congress of the Serbian Communist party, strongest of all Yugoslav Communist parties, will convene tomorrow afternoon in Belgrade to examine internal and external problems resulting from Yugoslavia's difficult relations with the states of the Communist Information Bureau.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Marshall Teague of Miami finished with a rush today to win the national championship 200-mile stock car race.

PANAMA, Jan. 16 -- Sandy Saddler of New York, the world featherweight champion, knocked out Young Finnegan of Panama tonight in 2:52 of the fifth round of a scheduled tenround nontitle bout at Olympic Stadium.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Hialeah race course begins its twenty-second winter meeting tomorrow with favorable prospects for a crowd of 15,000 and maybe a new Inaugural Handicap speed record.

Intensified competition in business has tightened the "squeeze" on small agencies, so that many are now "fighting for their lives," it was asserted over the week-end by an agency head. The major reason, he said, is that small accounts are being "hurt." In contrast, he continued, "the big accounts are raising budgets because their experience has taught them that is the way to stay in business when things get tough."
Advocates of euthanasia are seeking to "legalize murder," the Rev. Dr. John Hess McComb, pastor of the Broadway Presbyterian Church, Broadway and 114th Street, said yesterday in his evening sermon.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 16 -- Millions of dollars are being spent here in a six-square-mile heavily industrialized area of western Long Beach to offset the effects of sinking land and the resulting encroachment of sea water.

THEODORE DREISER, that gray, groping, persistently befuddled man, is one of the most controversial figures in modern American literature. His importance as a pioneer in fictional naturalism and his valiant service in winning new freedom for the novelist, the freedom to include all human activity as his proper sphere instead of only the socially approved, are beyond dispute.

Few pleasant words can be said about January, but among them are these: the sun, which has been climbing lazily out of bed at about twenty minutes after seven for the past couple of weeks, very soon will be getting up a minute earlier each day.

In the grand ballroom of the St. George Hotel more than 1,000 persons last night honored Brooklyn's oldest community house. The dinner marked the golden jubilee of the Hebrew Educational Society, which has exerted much more influence but attracted less attention than the hoodlums who became notorious in its vicinity.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies will open spring training at Clearwater, Fla., in March with forty-four players on hand.
PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Ben Hogan, little "Mr. Big" of golf, won the Bing Crosby invitational tournament today, taking top money among the professionals, with a 54-hole total of 208.

ROME, Jan. 16 -- A Communist "peace offensive," in accordance with what are understood to be the latest instructions from Moscow, was launched in Bologna last night by Communist leader Palmiro Togliatti.

Midway in their game with the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden last night the New York Rangers were virtually assured of victory. Lynn Patrick's Blue Shirts at that point enjoyed an edge of 4 goals to none and the assumption was that nothing short of a major collapse would prevent the local skaters from winning.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 16 -- Jack Potter and Bud Morris took a liking to today's balmy weather with gentle southerly breezes and led the B O and Penguin Classes respectively in the first frostbite session of the spring series on Manhasset Bay.

Comparing the Government's loyalty program to those of Nazi Germany and Fascist Italy, an article in the Yale Law Journal published today declared that the current loyalty check not only was unnecessary, but was making the Federal Government an example of repression for the whole nation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UP) -- Two of the world's biggest wheat producing countries -- Russia and Argentina -- apparently will not be represented at the forthcoming International Wheat Conference, it became known today.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- Senator MacNeil Mitchell of New York and Assemblyman Wilson C. Van Duzer of Middletown, both Republicans, announced tonight that they would reintroduce tomorrow a proposed Constitutional amendment to revise the system of preferences given veterans in Civil Service.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The Economic Outlook, organ of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, warned today that profits are "too high for the nation's welfare" and urged that the Federal Government investigate and rectify business policies that turn "booms into busts."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16 -- Some 1,200 delegates to the general assembly of the Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds called today on the International Refugee Organization to make an "appropriate refund" to the voluntary Jewish philanthropic agencies which had assumed "unjustifiably heavy burdens" in the care and resettlement of Jewish displaced persons.

Six variations of the Chinese theme in printed fabrics will be introduced today in new settings in Macy's Plan-a-Home Row. They include both linens and cottons suitable for drapery and slipover fabrics, and all but one are priced below $3 a yard.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UP) -- The United States Public Health Service has ordered quarantine officers at all ports of entry to take extraordinary precautions to prevent yellow fever carriers from entering this country, it was revealed today.

Varsity members of New York University's football and cross-country squads have received 37 major letters, it was announced yesterday by John E. Miller, graduate manager of athletics. Also honored with insignia were 36 freshman athletes and six cheer leaders.

In high school and college class rooms throughout the nation, mathematics instruction has entered a new and esoteric phase. Now, as part of a program to popularize mathematics, students are pushing pianos through pieces of paper eight by ten inches in size, demonstrating mathematically contrived card tricks and recoloring checkerboards with all the aplomb of algebra experts.

Retirement of Peter Fay, assistant general manager of the United States Lines in charge of terminal operations, was announced yesterday by John M. Franklin, president of the company. Mr. Fay will be succeeded by John Nevins, general pier superintendent, who will have as his assistant William B. Rand Jr.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- Assemblyman Philip J. Schupler, Democrat, of Brooklyn, announced today he would advocate curbing the powers of legislative committees to protect the rights of witnesses summoned before them.
CHICAGO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The National Football League and the All-America Conference this week will again attempt to find the shortest distance between viewpoints leading to peace.

NANKING, Jan. 16 -- A peace agreement for North China between Gen. Fu Tso-yi, the Government commander, and the Communists appeared to be in the offing tonight. The usually strict Peiping censors passed a dispatch reporting that General Fu and the Communists already had agreed in principle on a cease-fire order.

BERLIN, Jan. 16 -- The principal orator at a demonstration this morning at the graves of Karl Liebknecht and Rosa Luxemburg in the Soviet sector of Berlin, Walter Ulbricht, German spokesman for Moscow, thundered denunciations against the Western Powers and predicted ultimate victory for the Eastern forces.

TRENTON, Jan. 16 -- Police Chief William A. Dooling of Trenton said today his men had failed to obtain sufficient evidence to stage raids against alleged local bookmaking places, where state agents succeeded yesterday, because his force was known to the operators.

Pincus Sober, Metropolitan A. A. U. president, is among the seven new national committee chairmen whose appointments were announced yesterday by Mayor James A. Rhodes of Columbus, Ohio, president of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States. Sober will head the men's track and field committee.

Notable new exhibitions opening today in local show places include the thirty-third annual exhibition of the Brooklyn Society of Artists, at Abraham Straus; and yet another Piranesi exhibition, a series of architectural etchings, at the Camilla Lucas Gallery.

Ninety-six persons sat on the floor at 14 East Sixty-ninth Street yesterday afternoon, eating hua, lomi lomi salmon, lau lau, moa halekahiki niu and haupia. They were taking part in a Gourmet Society luau, or Hawaiian feast, held at Hawaii House.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- The British press enters tomorrow its third week of operation under a liberalized newsprint quota. The additional paper made available to the daily press is six pages a week, allowing the production of six-page papers three days a week and the familiar war and post-war four-page issues on alternate days.

George Dippel has been a subway dispatcher on the night trick long enough not to worry about men who fall asleep on trains after a Saturday night celebration. But yesterday's sleeper in the camel's hair coat was wearing handcuffs.
Dr. Reuben Fine, playing the black side of a Nimzowitsch defense, defeated Miguel M. Najdorf of Buenos Aires in the second game of a match at the Manhattan Chess Club, last night.

Several trends in color, furniture design and finishes are illustrated in the new provincial room settings that McCreery's opens today. The exterior design of the furniture is a combination of several country styles, characterized by graceful curved details and accents of grillework.
CHICAGO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Legislatures of forty-four states were called on today to permit cities to tax anything not taxed by the state.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 16 -- The attitude of Israel toward the Arab refugees who fled the territory occupied by Israel was discussed yesterday by Foreign Minister Moshe Shertok. He expressed the view that Israel should compensate the refugees for their property on the condition that the money be used constructively to settle them in new homes and not "frittered away" in temporary relief measures.

The New York University-Bellevue Medical Center to be built in the spring in a four-block area north of Bellevue Hospital will cost $32,744,000, or more than twice the previous estimate of $15,575,000, it was announced over the week-end.

PARIS, Jan. 16 -- Premier Henri Queuille called on the French today to imitate the British in making a strenuous effort to balance their accounts with the rest of the world before the end of the Marshall Plan, even if it involved privation.
Theatrical critics in the Soviet Union are now getting a dose of their own medicine -- criticism from the Communist party.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- Within the next five years the institutions that make up the Chicago Medical Center on the West Side will spend $50,000,000 to build hospitals, schools and research structures as well as residential facilities.

The Minneapolis-Moline Power Implement Company, in a letter to be sent to stockholders today, outlines a plan for merger of the company into a wholly-owned Minnesota subsidiary, subject to their approval at a meeting scheduled for Feb. 16.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 16 -- At least $17,000,000 in new ratables were added in Union County last year, according to an estimate based today on the tax books fifteen municipalities have filed with the Union County Board of Taxation.

One way for a young recitalist to get an audience, these days, is to play a lot of new music. That is what Stanley Lock, pianist from Detroit, did last night in his second appearance at Town Hall. His audience was distinguished and attentive, if not over-large.
CHICAGO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Compulsory health insurance, or any other plan, is not a major factor in the health of a country, the National Research Council said today

Nikita Magaloff, the Russian pianist who has been successfully touring in Europe, appeared at the beginning of his first American tour last night in Carnegie Hall, and proved immediately that he had something important and of his own to say.
CAMBRIDGE, England, Jan. 12 -- An essential piece of equipment for every sizable British farm these days is, surprisingly enough, a filing cabinet.
Equality of all "moral vocations" is the only true democracy, Canon Edward N. West of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine declared yesterday in his sermon.

Fred Wilt's 9:09 two miles at Washington was the top performance of the week-end in track and field but the feats of two young milers also were attracting much attention yesterday as railbirds commenced to study form for the approaching sequence of banked-track carnivals in the big Eastern arenas.

In a letter to Mayor O'Dwyer, made public yesterday, Health Commissioner Harry S. Mustard recommended that the pending City Council bill for the control of air pollution be limited in scope to pollution caused by smoke. Control over all other forms of air pollution, Dr. Mustard declared, should remain with the Health Department and the Board of Health.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Jan. 16 -- Ray Blum of Nutley. N. J., and Mary Lynch of Newburgh, N. Y., won championships today in the seventeenth annual Eastern States speed skating events.

ZURICH, Jan. 16 -- Secret deliberations last week of all premiers and foreign defense ministers of Denmark, Norway and Sweden to decide whether these countries should become adherents of the Atlantic Pact has focused attention in Switzerland on the divergence between New York and Zurich in the evaluation of Scandinavian foreign bonds.

Still smarting from their two-point defeat at the hands of the pace-setting Capitols at Washington Saturday, the Knickerbockers tonight will resume what is beginning to appear a futile chase Still in second place in the Eastern Division of the Basketball Association of America, the Knicks will meet the St. Louis Bombers at Madison Square Garden.
The National Life Insurance Company of Vermont today begins its one-hundredth year of business with the announcement that it has reached the billion-dollar-mark in insurance in force.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Business establishments of 500 employes or less obtained nearly one half of the Air Force purchase contracts in the last six months, the Air Material Command headquarters reported today.

A mass meeting of protest against the arrest and imprisonment of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty of Hungary, held yesterday by the city's Hungarian-American community, heard representatives of the Catholic, Protestant and Jewish faiths denounce the suppression of freedom in Hungary and voice faith in its resurrection.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 16 -- Since the end of November the local currency account of the Bank of the Netherlands has remained unchanged at 188,000,000 guilders, an indication that since then no definite settlement by the European Cooperation for shipments under the Marshall Plan has been received from Washington.

Dr. Bryn Hovde, president since 1945 of the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, is expected in academic circles to be chosen president of Queens College, it was learned yesterday. He would succeed Dr. Paul Klapper, who resigned last April.

Charles Schlags, a $75-a-week salesman, walked into the Borough Park police station in Brooklyn early yesterday and turned over an envelope containing $22,100 worth of non-negotiable Government bonds he had found. The bonds later were claimed by Morris Kohen of 14 Woodside Avenue, Brooklyn, president of the Skalar Benevolent Association, Inc., 853 Broadway, Manhattan.

A charming little 10-year-old girl with an expansive smile had one of "the biggest days" of her life yesterday when she saw her first ballet. The child was Karen Goodman, a victim of cerebral palsy, who is being treated at the Institute of Rehabilitation and Physical Medicine.

OSLO, Norway, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Kees Broeckmann, 21 - year - old Dutch skating ace, won one race and finished third in another today to capture first place in the all-around competition of the international two-day meet here.

Marko Rothmueller, Yugoslavian Baritone, who made his operatic debut last November with the New York City Opera Company, made his recital debut yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. His program included songs in Czech and Yugoslav, besides the usual concert numbers in German and Italian.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- A protest to the Netherlands Government against its action in Indonesia was made at a demonstration in Hyde Park in London today and conveyed to the Netherlands Embassy by the Congress of People against Imperialism.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- General liquidation was on in the grain markets on the Board of Trade last week, but wheat showed considerable resistance to pressure and managed to hold above the finish of the previous week the greater part of the time.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 16 -- Sixteen thousand United States troops, consisting in great measure of the First Division and constabulary, were scheduled to go into the first winter maneuvers here since the war at 6 A. M. tomorrow. The war games are planned for one week.

Several hundred persons listened quietly to a sermon yesterday in St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church as lights flickered out and firemen clambered behind a wall of the structure to extinguish a small fire.

While export controls are necessary under present international economic and political conditions, Congress should not extend them for more than one year beyond the present expiration date, Feb. 28, in the opinion of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., announced over the week-end by Joseph A. Sinclair, secretary of the association and director of its world trade department.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 16 -- Shemsettin Gunaltay, entrusted last night by President Ismet Inonu with leading a new Government following Premier Hasan Saka's sudden resignation, has formed his Cabinet.

CAIRO, Jan. 16 -- Britain's recent activity in the Middle East is being attributed in certain influential quarters here to the strategic importance of Africa and in particular to the plan to make northeastern Africa the bastion of western defense if there should be war with the Soviet Union.

The Mark Hellinger Theatre, known formerly as the Warner Theatre, was dedicated here yesterday under the sponsorship of the New York Heart Association at a ceremony attended by leading personages of stage, screen, radio and politics.

While most of the electric utility industry plods along in reluctant compliance with the divestment orders of the Holding Company Act, the world's largest distributor of electrical energy, the $591,000,000 Niagara Hudson Power Corporation, approaches completion of an integration program that began almost a quarter-century ago.

In questioning the need for continuing the present rate of assessment for Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation protection of bank deposits, Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Chase National Bank, reiterated a position other bankers and banking organizations have taken in recent years, but his stand now has greater factual support.

Prices of cotton in the domestic market moved within a narrow range last week. At the week's end active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 10 to 19 points net. At the close of the previous week, prices had shown declines of 10 to 23 points.

On Jan. 12 THE NEW YORK TIMES carried an editorial with reference the United Office and Profession Workers of America, CIO. Disregarding your labored attempt to interpret normal business proceedings of a union conference on its affairs as something mysterious and secretive, I should like to deal with the statement in your editorial: "The economic pronouncement that came out of the meeting illustrated the demagogic way in which the union addresses itself to its responsibilities.

SAUGATUCK, Conn., Jan. 16 (UP) -- Miss Vivien Kellems, Connecticut industrialist, advised the United States treasury by letter today that she was deducting $1,685.40 from her 1948 income tax payment to make up for money she said the Government "illegally took from me."

The Citizens Budget Commission, holding its annual meeting tonight, can look back on its accomplishments of 1948 with much satisfaction. The chief executive of the city has made increasing use of it for special studies and advice on major problems. Although the Commission's avowed aim is a more efficient and economical city government, the rank-and-file civil service worker "has come to look upon us as a not unfriendly force," the annual report says.
ATHENS, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Leaders of nine of the ten political parties, whose chiefs had met with King Paul during the day, conferred for two hours tonight and in a statement afterward said:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UP) -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States today ordered a thirty-day referendum of its membership to decide whether it will fight for Congressional action in the basing point pricing system row.

The large-scale Federal program for tuberculosis control cannot be successful without the aid in therapy and rehabilitation offered by such organizations as the National Jewish Hospital at Denver, Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, surgeon general of the United States Public Health Service, said here yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- Another strong attack on communism, with special emphasis on the arrest of Cardinal Mindszenty, was made today by Herbert S. Morrison. Lord President of the Council, in a speech to the Labor party meeting in Newcastle-upon-Tyne tonight.

The most important event in the week-end programs of the New York City Ballet Company at the City Center was the first presentation in the present series of performances of the Balanchine-Stravinsky-Noguchi "Orpheus" on Saturday evening.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- The stock markets here last week stood up remarkably well to the shock of events in the Middle East. What looked like a promising expansion in Stock-Exchange business was nipped in the bud, but the widespread feeling of uneasiness that resulted from the events in Palestine did not bring any pressure to sell.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Jan. 16 -- In Howard Greer's spring fashions, necklines high and low are treated with simplicity in day dresses and natural, close-fitting set-in sleeves are the standard. On V-necks are featured large revers, pointed or rounded on soft silk suits, street shantungs and late afternoon dresses, often accented with discreet embroidered motifs or made of row on row of gathered baby val.

DETROIT, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings scored three goals in the first twenty-four minutes, then hung on to defeat the Montreal Canadiens, 3 to 2, and tighten their hold on the National Hockey League lead. A crowd of 14.352 fans saw the game.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Max Reimann, Western Germany's No. 1 Communist, said today that United States and British policies would turn the Germans into a race of "coolies." The two countries are aiming at "the complete destruction of Western Germany," he said.

The National Mediation Board intervened yesterday in an effort to avert the threatened strike of 150 engineers on the Hudson Manhattan Railroad and indicated it might take a hand in a similar dispute involving 300 engineers of the Long Island Rail Road.

A new type of music course for amateurs will be offered by New York University's Division of General Education on Washington Square beginning Feb. 3, the university announced yesterday. Featuring the "shirt-sleeve approach," the non-academic course on "Music-Making for Amateurs" is conceived as a means of giving unskilled musicians and amateurs a chance to vent their love of music collectively.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Most of the flags are out, and the over-all stage is set for the inauguration of President Truman on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The American Federation of Labor, calling for "far-reaching" expansion of the nation's social security system, proposed tonight that it be financed by a 4 per cent payroll tax, levied against employes, to be matched by equal contributions by employers.

The trial of twelve top Communist leaders on charges of conspiring to "teach and advocate" the forcible overthrow of the Government of the United States will start at 10:30 A. M. today in the Federal Court House at Foley Square.

Attempts to weed out "disloyalty" in this country, among government employes and others, have recently reached an ironic climax. In attempting to protect democracy some earnest souls in positions of power have come close to scuttling it; in attacking what they considered subversion, or potential subversion, or the taint or suspicion of subversion, or dangerous associations, or dangerous thoughts, or even original thoughts, they have subverted the liberties of the citizen.

BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 16 -- Vice President and Premier Mohammed Hatta and five other officials of the Indonesian Republic are being detained under close guard in two rooms of a large building in the town of Muntok on Banka Island, members of the United Nations Security Council's Committee of Good Offices on Indonesia stated today after a visit to the island yesterday.

GENEVA, Jan. 11 -- The basis for United States foreign policy in Europe is obvious. Its objective is to contain the Soviet Union and prevent Muscovite expansion all the way from Turkey and Greece to Trieste and up to Sweden. Iran, in western Asia, is also involved, although not so directly affected as her Turkish neighbor.

Milo R. Maltbie, who will retire from office as chairman of the Public Service Commission at the end of this week at the age of 77, fired yesterday a parting shot at one of his old adversaries, the Consolidated Edison Company.

The Brazilian Treasury Delegation here announced yesterday the appointment of fiscal agents for issues of dollar bonds of the United States of Brazil. The appointees will succeed White, Weld Co. and Brown Brothers, Harriman Co., who have resigned from the capacities in which they were acting with respect to the Brazilian bonds.
America's economic system will not survive, the Rev. Donald Harrington, a minister of the Community Church, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, predicted yesterday at the morning service.

The industrial demand for silver in the United States last year reached a new peace-time peak of 110,000,000 ounces, an increase of about 10 per cent over 1947, according to Handy Harman, local bullion dealers, in their review of the silver market for 1948.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- Trustees of the State University of New York, in their first annual report today requested $12,000,000 in new appropriations as part of a five-year program for the expansion of higher educational facilities in New York at a cost to the state of $86,077,700, of which $67,432,874 will be new funds.

The press, the radio and the motion picture industry were praised yesterday by the Rev. William T. Greene for contributions toward combatting "the scandal and deadly curse of civil divorce in the United States."

RHODES, Jan. 16 -- Armistice talks between Egypt and Israel are on the verge of a successful conclusion, it was believed here tonight. The delegates spent the day conferring in turn with Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting United Nations Mediator, and ironing out difficulties before the joint meeting that will take up the difficult questions of defining the armistice boundary and withdrawing troops from the front.
Academic education in history and economics is essential for the present - day newspaperman, Dr. Charles P. Cooper said yesterday as he looked back on sixty years of newspapering.
Following is the text of the indictment on which the twelve Communist leaders go on trial today:

Gimbels and Saks Thirty-fourth Street, two of the city's best-known department stores, have signed new two-year contracts with an independent union that submitted membership cards signed by 90 per cent of their 3,300 employes.

A gallant attempt by Mae West to minimize her illness hasn't been successful. The star of "Diamond Lil," scheduled to arrive Feb. 3 at the Coronet in the revival of her play, had appeared in Baltimore last week through Friday night, when she was taken ill.

A LITTLE more than a week ago James Gleason Dunn Conzelman formally tendered his resignation as the coach of the Chicago Cardinals in order to devote his full time to his off-season advertising job. It was a move which was as stunning to the sports world as it was unexpected. Hey, Jimmy! You can't do that sort of thing to us! Football just won't seem the same without you!

At the end of last July, when he called Congress into special session and, among other things, outlined his anti-inflation program, President Truman included in his recommendations a tax on excess corporate profits. This proposal, however, was conspicuously missing from his State of the Union Message of Jan. 5 and from his Budget Message of Jan. 10.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- A sermon in an unusually colorful style for Britain was given this morning by the new rector of Birmingham, the Rev. Bryan Green, who preached a mission series in New York last November at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Linda Brown, 4-year-old March of Dimes poster girl from San Antonio, Tex., received a stuffed panda and a music box from admiring Bronx youngsters when she visited the Yankee Stadium yesterday to pose for photographs at the Lou Gehrig memorial plaque.

The Citizens Budget Commission, in its annual report made public yesterday, urged the city to go slow on the construction of new highways, subways and parks. It listed hospitals, schools, housing and maintenance of existing highways as urgent current requirements.

FOX RIVER GROVE, Ill., Jan. 16 -- Norway's Olympic champion, Petter Hugsted, turned in two flawless flights to win the Norge Ski Club's forty-third annual jumping classic today on a lightning-fast slide.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Senate investigators, headed by Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican, of Michigan, reported today that the Government, through the Maritime Commission, sold sixty-one ships as war surplus without taking into consideration the presence of $511,000 worth of lead ballast in their holds.
DURBAN, South Africa, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Machine-gun and rifle fire crackled today in South Africa's spreading race rioting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UP) -- The Government now owns less than half the stock in regional banks of the Federal Home Loan Bank system, Chairman William K. Divers of the Home Loan Bank Board announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The nonscheduled air services joined today in a single association, the National Independent Air Carriers, and opened a concerted drive against proposed regulations to restrict their operations to individually chartered flights.

The six-story building at 249 to 255 West Seventeenth Street running through the block to 236 to 242 West Eighteenth Street, formerly used by Gimbels for a warehouse, has been resold by Nathan Wilson, the operator, to a client of Henry Baker, broker in the deal.

Phil Watson's New York Rovers had a 4-0 shutout within their grasp with one minute remaining until Shawinigan Falls caged three goals within fifty seconds in the Quebec Senior Hockey League battle at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

Expecting a year marked by determined buyer resistance and keen competition, most of the nation's construction equipment distributors see a drop in sales volume and lower profits in 1949, according to a survey by the Associated Equipment Distributors.

PEIPING, Jan. 16 -- Hopes that there would be a bloodless takeover of Peiping by the Communists waned today. There may be a few days' respite while Communist Gen. Lin Piao takes the virtually undefended harbor town of Tangku, southeast of Tientsin.

Back in the days when our West and Northwest were being opened to habitation and its resources first began to be exploited, missionaries going into those territories complained of the unfair and often brutal treatment the native Indians received at the hands of the newly arrived white men.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 16 -- Walter Wanger will produce his next picture, "The Blank Wall," at Columbia for Columbia release, with James Mason and Joan Bennett (Mrs. Wanger) in the leading roles, if a deal, now in final stages of negotiation, is consummated.
Somewhere in the Presidential inauguration crowd in Washington on Thursday will be a Republican winner, a man who guessed Governor Dewey's vote-getting correctly -- in New York State.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Germany's heavyweight boxing champion, Hein Ten Hoff, left by plane for the United States tonight in quest of gold and glory -- the glory for his Fatherland, the gold for himself.

TORONTO, Jan. 16 (Canadian Press) -- Imperial Oil, Ltd., today announced the sale of its entire holdings in Royalite Oil Company, Ltd., to Dominion Securities Corporation, Ltd., in a deal involving about $15,000,000.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Jan. 7 -- "Capricorn Africa," hitherto merely a concept, bids fair to begin to take shape early next month when an explanatory conference will be held at Victoria Falls, Northern Rhodesia, between representatives of the two Rhodesias and Nyasaland.
Eleven new films, including importations from England and France, will open in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

Coast Guard personnel in the Eastern Area and Third Coast Guard District handled 350 major cases of marine distress during 1948 and processed nearly 250,000 messages pertinent to these and other emergencies, it was announced last week by Rear Admiral Ed. H. Smith, area and district commander.

Defeating the Gjoa S. C., 3 to 2, at Hawthorne Field, Brooklyn, yesterday, the Hakoah F. C. advanced in the National Challenge Cup competition of the United States Soccer Football Association. Deadlocked, 1 -- 1, at the change of ends, Hakoah scored two additional tallies in the second period.

Many buyers attended the National Retail Dry Goods Convention here last week and they also visited the wholesale apparel market to fill in on orders for spring merchandise, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Retailers said January business so far has been good and all indications point to a good spring season.
