BOSTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Little Nobby Warwick, the National Hockey League's top goal-maker, broke a six-game scoreless streak by caging the clincher as the Boston Bruins defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 3 -- 1, tonight before a capacity crowd of 13,900 at the Boston Garden.
R. Lindley Murray has been appointed executive vice president of Hooker Electrochemical Company, Niagara Falls, N. Y. He was formerly vice president in charge of development and research.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 16 Prolonged applause greeted ratification by the Constituent Assembly today of Otilio Ulate's position as President-elect. The motion, which passed unanimously, was the first act after the Assembly held a state opening today in the Congressional Chamber attended by Jose Figueres, president of the Revolutionary Junta, the full Cabinet, and church, judicial and diplomatic corps heads.

ATHENS, Jan. 16 -- King Paul told ten political party leaders, whom he summoned to the palace today, that they must compose their diffferences within twenty-four hours and get a new coalition Government for Greece, or he would be compelled to find his own solution.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Oscar R. Ewing, the Federal Security Administrator, announced grants today of $209,838 by the National Cancer Institute to support laboratory and clinical research in cancer.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Jan. 16 -- David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, warned today that the nation must not be fooled by the "myth of the atomic bomb" into forgetting that the strength of the United States is in its cherished ethical principles rather than military weapons alone.

A new, forceful Moslem nationalism that was awakened in part by the war in Palestine threatens to drive Christianity from the Near East unless Americans are prepared to check religious persecution and Communist infiltration there, Dr. George P. Michaelides, president of Schauffler College in Cleveland, declared yesterday.

Irish Shipping Ltd., which is now getting delivery of the first of two new oceangoing vessels built to sail under the Irish flag, has extensive plans for a two-vessel passenger service between New York and Ireland, it was made known last week.

A new book by Victor Wolfgang von Hagen, author of eighteen books in the field of exploration and biography, has been scheduled for March 12 publication by the University of Oklahoma Press. It is "Ecuador and the Galapagos Islands," a history of the nation and an analysis of its economic position.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 16 -- Last week the steel industry set another peacetime record in steel making. On the basis of the new capacity figures national steel ingot output last week was 99.5 per cent of capacity. The revised rate for the week before was 98 per cent.

The St. Louis Bombers went into last night's Basketball Association of America game at Madison Square Garden billed as the tallest club in the loop. But their "smallest'' man, 6 foot 1 inch Belus Smawley, was the outstanding performer as the Mound City five took down a 79-to-71 decision.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Five Democrats joined with five Republicans in the Senate today to sponsor a bipartisan Federal aid program for improving and extending local public health services throughout the country.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- Senator Elmer F. Quinn of Manhattan, the minority leader, charged on the Senate floor tonight that it was "common talk in New York that you can't get a liquor license in New York City without going to one particular law firm."

Willem Slijkhuis, Dutch distance runner who placed third in the 1,500 and the 5,000-meter events in the Olympic Games last summer, arrived in New York by air yesterday. Here to bid for the National A. A. U. indoor mile title at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 19, Slijkhuis made the trip from his native Amsterdam alone.
BOSTON, Jan. 17 -- Dean Emeritus Roscoe Pound of the Harvard Law School does not believe the Nationalist Government of China is doomed.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 4 per cent last week over the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The rise for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 16 per cent.

In an unusually lively session, members of the corporation of the Metropolitan Museau of Art at their annual meeting yesterday heard Roland L. Redmond, president of the board of trustees, repudiate charges made against the institution's policies and its director by James N. Rosenberg.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 17 -- The first graduate school of industrial administration will be established at the Carnegie Institute of Technology under a $6,000,000 grant established here today by the W. L. and May T. Mellon Foundation.
The cotton market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved yesterday within a narrow range and closed 7 points lower to 4 points higher than on Saturday.

Pale-colored nylons have been selected by some of the top-flight fashion designers as the correct accessory note to blend with clothes for 1949, it was announced by Roy E. Tilles, president of the Gotham Hosiery Company, at a luncheon yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 17 -- While Durban was recovering today from the effects of communal clashes between Zulus and Indians, the Cabinet received a report from Minister of Justice C. R. Swart and Minister of Defense F. C. Erasmus, who had made a preliminary investigation on the spot.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- President Truman started Inauguration Week today by giving the press a list of his fourteen major engagements for the next three days.

A tiny Dutch woman, Mme. Adrienne M. Boissevain, whose husband and two sons were killed by the Nazis in the war, arrived here yesterday on the Holland America liner Westerdam. She came to establish a branch of "The National Skirt," a peace organization she founded after her liberation from a German concentration camp.

The current scramble among rival unions in the department store field is scarcely calculated to inspire respect for the trade union movement. Store workers are being besieged with appeals to join the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, CIO; the Retail Clerks International Association, AFL, or the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, also AFL.

The traditional "three R's" are being augmented in New York's eighty-three junior high schools by a "deliberate and conscious" character-building program, according to a report made public yesterday by Dr. Elias Lieberman, associate superintendent in charge of junior high schools for the Board of Education.

PRAGUE, Jan. 17 -- An Army major was sentenced to death and two other officers to prison terms by a military court today on charges that they plotted with a foreign power's agent against the Republic.

The Board of Education was assailed yesterday for failing to include a provision for teachers salary increases in its proposed budget of $220,599,648 for 1949-50. At an open meeting of the committee on finance and budget, which lasted five hours, representatives of parents, teachers and civic groups complained that the record budget failed "to provide the items needed to bring our educational system in line with living costs."

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- Governor Dewey conferred today with representatives of four major airlines to get their point of view on the dispute that has arisen over leases at the International Airport at Idlewild, the legality of which are now being contested in court actions.

A number of musical debutantes make favorable first impressions without necessarily giving good recitals. But Wilma Thompson, mezzo-soprano, who bowed last night at Times Hall, did both. Her program had as much intelligence, taste and musical excellence as her singing.

The experiences of an ichthyologist who fished Pacific waters in wartime will be published by Lippincott on Feb. 16. It is "Fishing in Troubled Waters," by Wilbert McLeod Chapman, Director of the School of Fisheries, University of Washington.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today agreed to review a National Labor Relations Board ruling that officials of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, must file non-Communist oaths before the board requires the Inland Steel Company to bargain on pension plans.

Challenging the claim that his election victory gave President Truman a mandate to carry forward a "socialistic program," Senator Kenneth S. Wherry, Republican floor leader, yesterday urged business men to fight the President's proposals for Government controls.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Union Light, Heat and Power Company of Cincinnati received permission from the securities and exchange commission today to sell at competitive bidding $5,000,000 of first mortgage bonds and 20,000 shares of common stock.

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- James B. Carey, secretary treasurer of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, indicated here today that the CIO along with the British Trades Union Council and the Dutch Federation of Labor would quit the World Federation of Trade Unions during tomorrow's meeting of its executive committee.

With Cecil Smith and Stewart Iglehart remaining at the top of the list, the United States Polo Association yesterday announced the 1949 handicaps of approximately 750 players representing sixty active member clubs and colleges.

Martin James Monti, former lieutenant in the Army Air Forces, pleaded guilty of treason yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn. Judge Robert A. Inch sentenced him at once to twenty-five years in prison and fined him $10,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Emphasizing that 2,450 independent mining and manufacturing companies have been absorbed since 1940 as a result of the rising number of corporate mergers, the Federal Trade Commission asked Congress again today, as it has every year since 1930, to enact legislation that would enable it to deal effectively with the problem of industrial monopolies.
A strike was called yesterday for 4 A. M. tomorrow on the Hudson Manhattan Railroad. The action is expected to halt all service on the tubes under the Hudson River serving 200,000 commuters daily.

Jimmy Carter, Bronx lightweight, spoiled the local debut of Harold (Baby Face) Jones, Detroiter, last night at the St. Nicholas Arena. The shifty Negro boxer blasted his way to a victory over Jones before 1,862 fans who paid receipts of $3,457.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 17 -- serious rift between Church and State threatened today when the Junta Government sent a formal protest to the Archbishop of San Jose regarding an attack on the Government made by Msgr. Alfredo Hidalgo, vicar general of the archdiocese.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 17 -- Efforts of the Westchester Board of Supervisors to obtain appointment of a conservator in emergencies to handle distribution of fuel and other necessities were called "unfair to labor" today by the Building and Construction Trades Council of the county.
LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Russia announced today she had turned down a request of the Chinese Government to mediate in the civil war with the Communists.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 17 -- In the opening address to the second congress of the Serbian Communist party, which convened today in Belgrade, Edvard Kardelj, member of the Yugoslav Poliburo and Minister of Foreign Affairs, said that Yugoslav leaders had fought their way to power and "would know how to keep it."

The fight between the Port of New York Authority and airlines over use of New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, reached new stages of bitterness yesterday. The matter will be aired Thursday in the Supreme Court at Jamaica, Queens, where the authority will ask dismissal of the airlines' suits for relief on the ground that the court lacks jurisdiction because of the authority's immunity to suit.

Long before 1914 it was apparent that in a modern war engineers and scientists would be needed to make the most of the machinery of destruction. Nevertheless, all the warring Powers clapped gifted young geologists and engineers into uniform and made no great use of their training and abilities.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 17 -- It is believed here that Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery has agreed to ease if possible the financial burden imposed on the Netherlands through participation in the Western European Defensive Alliance.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- The general organizing conference of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Warehousemen and Helpers, AFL, got under way here today on the job of radically reorganizing the union and adding hundreds of thousands to its ranks.

ATHENS, Jan. 17 -- The time limit set by King Paul yesterday, within which the parliamentary leaders were asked to settle their differences and agree upon a new Government representative of all parties, was today extended twenty-four hours to 7 P. M. tomorrow.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 17 -- A convoy supervised by the United Nations will enter the besieged Faluja pocket, where a brigade of Egyptians has been trapped, bringing in food and medical supplies, it was announced here tonight. The sick and wounded, many of whom have been there for more than three months, will be evacuated to the Egyptian lines.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The following are the Democratic House committee chairmen for the Eighty-first Congress:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP} -- The United States Supreme Court decided today that the Federal courts had jurisdiction when there was a dispute over attorneys' fees in a reorganization proceeding conducted under the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Col. J. Monroe Johnson, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, today was named chief of a study group to advise the National Security Resources Board on mobilization of surface transport and storage facilities in the event of war.

Mention concert-guitar music and the name of Andres Segovia comes to mind. He had a hand in most of the arrangements -- and indeed, most of the recent compositions -- for that instrument. Last night he undertook the solo parts in two concertos dedicated to him, in an unusually intriguing concert by the Little Orchestra Society at Town Hall.
To augment its system of showroom selling, the dress concern of Henry Rosenfeld, Inc., will send men on the road this spring for the first time in the company's history, it was learned yesterday.

WARSAW, Jan. 14 -- Fearful that their land will be collectivized, the Polish peasants have been slaughtering livestock in such numbers recently as to endanger the domestic meat production and the supply to fill commitments in some of the country's most important trade pacts, it was learned today.
LONDON, Jan. 17 -- The American Bureau of Shipping is searching for offices here with a view for opening a direct branch for its activities in Britain, it was learned authoritatively today.

A product of French inventiveness is the Mouli rotary grater that has just arrived here. This little kitchen tool is so simply constructed that the French have been able to ship it across the Atlantic to sell in this country for $1. Uncomplicated though it is, the mechanism does a variety of things effectively.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- A growing rift between Governor Dewey and the Board of Regents on educational policy came into the open today when William J. Wallin of Yonkers, Chancellor of the board, renewed his demand that the Regents receive full control over the new State University.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The National Petroleum Council said today that in the event of another war the Government should provide for a specialized vertical, rather than a general horizontal, governmental organization to deal with petroleum problems, and that it should refrain from any attempts to "take over" the industry.

FOX RIVER GROVE, Ill., Jan. 17 -- Following the spectacular Norge Club's international jump here yesterday, Arthur Barth of Milwaukee, president of the National Ski Association of America, today disclosed that the competition will serve as one of a series to determine the personnel of the United States team for the Federation International de Ski (F. I. S.) world championships next year.

CAIRO, Jan. 17 -- Cairo newspapers published today detailed terms of a declaration by the Emperor of Ethiopia under which full equality is given to his Moslem subjects. The step plays an important part in Egyptian plans for closer relations with Ethiopia.
RHODES, Jan. 17 -- An agreement for the release of the long-besieged Egyptian garrison in Faluja, Palestine, was reliably reported to have been reached today by Egyptian and Israeli representatives.

With Washington offices making a holiday of Inauguration Day on Thursday, and the possibility that it might be continued through Friday, the Federal Reserve System's condition statement may be issued a day early, it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (AP) -- a 13-club major professional football league, fashioned from the entire National Football League and five All-America Conference clubs, appeared brewing today as the rival circuits prepared for meetings here.

The United States Foreign Securities Corporation and its affiliate, United States International Securities Corporation, had a combined net asset value of $68,460,735 as of Dec. 31, last, according to the annual reports issued yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- Britain's motion-picture producers turned to the Government for new financial aid today, basing their appeal on the contention that production costs are more than three times those before the war.

Former State Senator Louis B. Heller has been selected to run for Congress in the Seventh Congressional District in Brooklyn on the Democratic ticket, it was announced yesterday by Borough President John Cashmore, the Kings County Democratic leader.

STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 17 -- Fifteen industrialists and business men from the United States and Canada, officers and trustees of the Court of Profit-Sharing Industries, met here today to plan a vigorous campaign to greatly extend the use of profit sharing as a means of promoting labor-management harmony and increasing national income.

Vladimir Horowitz played the first of his Carnegie Hall recitals of the season last night. That should be enough to tell you that there was a sold-out house and much excitement at the piano and in the audience. These are inevitable aspects of a Horowitz recital.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 17 -- The United Nations Security Council asked the Netherlands today to allow the Republic of Indonesia to send one of its captured leaders to Lake Success to testify on the clash in Indonesia.

Three new films will open in first-run theatres today. At the Roxy the attraction is "Chicken Every Sunday," a Twentieth Century-Fox romantic comedy, starring Dan Dailey and Celeste Holm. George Seaton, who directed, was co-author of the screen play with Valentine Davies.

The educational program of New York's printing industry has provided a model for other progressive business groups and an active demonstration of the superiority of democratic ideology, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools of New York, declared yesterday.
BERLIN, Jan. 17 -- (AP) The text of the three-power directive setting up a Military Security Board for Western Germany:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Informed quarters tonight expressed the belief that King Paul's ultimatum to Greek political leaders may presage appointment of Field Marshal Alexander Papagos as Premier of a non-party Government with broad powers to prosecute the civil war and solidify the home front, without being too dependent upon Parliamentary whims and maneuvers.

The formation of The Israel Music Foundation was announced yesterday. Its purpose is to bring the musical culture of Israel to the rest of the world, and it has the backing of such musical personages as Fritz Reiner, Gladys Swarthout, Lawrence Tibbett and Deems Taylor.
The Long Island Rail Road issued yesterday a revised estimate of its probable deficit this year.

OXFORD, England, Jan. 13 -- All Oxford is still talking in pleased wonder about the most munificent gift by an individual for the foundation of a new college since Medieval times. In this case, the wonder is all the greater since the donor is a Frenchman, who had no connection with Oxford and who gave 1,500,000 (about $6,000,000) simply because he admired the Oxford graduates who worked for him.

Pottery ranks first in importance in lines of Italian handicraft merchandise carried by American stores, according to a survey just completed by the House of Italian Handicrafts, Inc., 217 East Forty-ninth Street, among leading department stores, specialty and gift shops and importers throughout the country.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- The question of diverting gasoline taxes and motor vehicle fees from highway uses to general state purposes was raised in the Legislature tonight. A proposed constitutional amendment that would earmark these revenues for road building was introduced.

IF Western civilization survives its present crisis, if the cult of the slave state does not conquer, if atomic and biological warfare does not make us one with Nineveh and Tyre, there is a remote chance that historians of the twenty-first century may give some of the credit to Clarence K. Streit, the man who offered the world a straw to clutch at and so hope for survival.
The trial of twelve top Communist leaders got under way quietly yesterday, with no disturbance inside the Federal Court House and no serious troubles outside.
The New York County Lawyers Association proposed yesterday a state constitutional amendment to give New York City a streamlined two-court system to be supervised by the Appellate Division.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The famed Hohenzollern silver collection, containing 500 place settings and many service dishes and ornaments, is being returned to Germany, the Army announced today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The text of President Truman's Message to Congress today asking for permanent authority to reorganize the Government follows:

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 17 -- Grenville Baker, 27-year-old grandson of the late George F. Baker, wealthy New York financier, was mysteriously killed on a lonely road of his family's plantation early this morning. First believed killed in a mishap in a jeep he was driving, an inquest tonight revealed that he had been shot through the head.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Democrats in the House today approved leadership decision to remove two Southern members, both active in the States Rights Democrats party during the 1948 campaign, from the Un-American Activities Committee.

Net sales of the International Shoe Company for the fiscal year ended with last November reached a new high record, rising $6,886,688 over those of the previous year, but earnings were $181,820 lower, the annual report of Frank C. Rand, chairman, and Byron A. Gray, president, informed 11,000 stockholders yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan set the official wheels rolling today toward the new International Wheat Agreement that President Truman included in his 1950 budget as a $56,000,000 item on a proposed legislation basis.

CHICAGO, Jan, 17 -- Richard F. Uhlmann, president of the Chicago Bard of Trade, said today that persons who attacked organized commodity exchanges should consider themselves fortunate to be living in one of the few countries where free markets still exist.

PEIPING, Jan. 17 -- Peiping's citizens received an open letter today from the Peiping Military Control Committee of the "People's Liberation Army." It was slipped into their daily newspapers and pasted on some shop windows and public walls.

The twelve leading Communists in the country were called to trial in Federal Court yesterday, but only eleven responded. William Z. Foster, national chairman of the Communist party, was absent because of illness, his lawyer explained.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UP) -- After much confusion and uncertainty, the Children's Aid Society, Inc., today accepted six crates of clothing donated to needy Washington children by the Eva Peron Foundation of Argentina.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- President Truman asked the Congress today to give him and those who would succeed him in the White House permanent and broad authority to lead the way in overhauling the Executive Branch of Government.

Retail shopkeepers who want to sell homogenized milk at 23 cents a quart in competition with chain stores were advised yesterday by Investigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh to shop for milk among independent distributors offering it at 19 1/2 cents wholesale.

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin's sturdy, stubborn figure stood firm today against an angry storm of criticism aroused by his management of Britain's policy on Palestine. His opponents within the Labor party decided not to take the initiative in attacking him in Parliament and his Cabinet colleagues showed no intention of deserting him.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the light of the educational campaign that was waged last year in the metropolitan press of New York City regarding the question of an equitable distribution of state funds for local school support, it was indeed discouraging to read your editorial on this issue in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 12.
LONDON, Jan. 17 -- The riots in Durban caused further selling of South African gold-mining shares in the stock market here today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 17 -- A deal is in negotiation for Ingrid Bergman to play opposite Gary Cooper in Cooper's projected independent production of "The Girl on the Via Flamina," it was learned today from a representative of the actor.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Notre Dame will play a ten-game football schedule next fall, its sixty-first football season.

TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 17 -- Governor Alfred E. Driscoll today sent to the State Senate for confirmation the nomination of Theodore D. Parsons, Red Bank lawyer, to succeed Walter D. Van Riper as Attorney General.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 17 -- Argentina sprang a surprise tonight when the Foreign Office announced it had accepted the United States invitation to participate in the international wheat conference opening Jan. 26 in Washington. Dr. Juan Escarpati, Economic Counselor of the Argentine Embassy in Washington, was designated as President Peron's representative.

The hunters and fishermen of this country, numbering almost twenty-six million, spent more than fifty-eight millions of dollars for hunting and fishing licenses during the fiscal year which ended on June 30, 1948, according to the compilation just made by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.

Draft collection items paid to representative New York City banks by Latin-American countries in December declined to 14,900, the smallest number paid in any month since May, 1947, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday.

BERLIN, Jan. 17 -- Details of the already operative tripartite Military Security Board established in conformity with the terms of the London Agreement were announced today by the trio of officers named as commissioners by the Military Governors of the three Western zones.

Every year-end reviewer and prognosticator is primed with statistical hope for a leveling-off in prices in '49 -- all except baby-sitters, incorporated. They who also serve by sitting and waiting the return of fun-starved parents began the New Year by boosting rates from the ordinary 75 cents per hour to as high as $1.25.
ATLANTA, Jan. 17 -- James M. Cox formally dedicated The Atlanta Journal's new plant and $1,250,000 new press today.

Senator Walter George, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, predicted over the week-end that Congress would go "very slowly" on the public health proposal in President Truman's social welfare program. In the light of the "fourth round" demands just announced by the United Automobile Workers, Mr. George might well consider the desirability of broadening his prediction.

The hearings by the New York State Bar Association's recently organized section on anti-trust law, to be held Jan. 26 and 27 at 42 West Forty-fourth Street, will be broadcast daily from 10 A. M. to noon and from 2 to 5 P. M. by WNYC.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan 17 -- Paced by the sensational shooting of Tony Lavelli, who tallied 22 points, the Yale basketball team entrenched its second-place position in the Eastern Intercollegiate League by trouncing Cornell, 59 -- 40, before a capacity crowd of 3,000 in the Payne Whitney Gym tonight.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- Grain markets showed a heavy undertone on the Board of Trade today. Although there were sharp rallies at times under the leadership of corn, the close was at net losses on wheat of 1 1/8 to 1 3/8 cents. Corn lost 3/8 to 5/8 cent; oats, 5/8 cent to 1 1/4 cents; rye, 1 1/4 cents, and soy beans 3/4 cent to 1 1/2 cents.

Additional shopping facilities are planned in Massapequa, L. I., where a taxpayer site adjoining the postoffice has been purchased by Worth Homes, Inc., of which Carl Feller is president. The plot, 140 by 136 feet, on the south side of Grand Avenue, 100 feet west of Central Avenue, was purchased from Elsie J. Ahearn through Irving Berger, broker.

The National Maritime Union, CIO, has called upon all maritime unions -- Congress of Industrial Organizations, American Federation of Labor and independent -- to meet in Washington Feb. 7 to plan a joint program to "refloat the American merchant marine," it became known yesterday.

The stock market staged a comeback yesterday afternoon after a forenoon of weakness, the initiative in both cases stemming from American Telephone and Telegraph. A drop of more than 4 points in A. T. T. in the morning upset the list, but a later partial comeback in this issue inspired a rally which left prices irregularly higher on the day.
LONDON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Union workers in Britain's booming shipyards have proposed Government ownership of the industry for the Labor party's 1950 election platform, a union official said today.

PARIS, Jan. 14 -- The United States position in South Korea, not by any means an economically viable area in itself, has been even more seriously weakened in a long-term sense by gains already registered by the Communist forces of China.
American shipping men will meet in New York tomorrow to discuss industry policy on the controversial world maritime organization under the United Nations.
ATLANTA, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The general idea in Atlanta -- official and public -- is that Negroes Jackie Robinson and Roy Campanella can play baseball here, despite the Ku Klux Klan.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 17 (AP) -- For he second straight year Woolford Farm's Delegate today launched Hialeah's forty-day winter meeting by winning the $10,000 added Inaugural Handicap before an opening day crowd of 20,363.

NANKING, Jan. 17 -- Tangku, the ocean port for Tientsin, has been captured by the Chinese Communists without opposition, it was learned tonight. Informed quarters said that about 20,000 Government troops, after commandeering all available small craft, had fled toward Taku Bar, beyond the range of the Communist artillery.

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- A B-29 bomber with twenty Americans on their way home crashed this morning in a wild highland region of Argyllshire, in Scotland, and all are believed lost. By dark only six bodies had been found, but there was only faint hope that some of the men might have had a chance to bail out.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- In this space last week it was noted that, if the national election of 1948 had been thrown into Congress, there might now have been deadlocks in both the House and the Senate that at noon on Jan. 20, 1949, would have called into operation the Statute of Succession of 1947.

Dr. Francis T. Spaulding, State Commissioner of Education, has been asked to order the city's Board of Higher Education to prefer charges of anti-Semitic discrimination against Prof. William E. Knickerbocker, head of the Romance language department at City College, Prof. Ephraim Cross of the department disclosed last night.

Spring shoes for women are feminine to the nth degree, light, airy affairs with much open work and perforation, fashioned of straw, mesh and such fabrics as shantung and pique, Herman Delman said at his spring showing yesterday at 754 Fifth Avenue.

DALLAS, Tex., Jan. 17 -- United States tanks are out-gunned and out-matched by Russian and British tanks and little progress has been made in his country since the war in the development of a satisfactory medium or heavy tank.
C. O. Richards was appointed general sales manager over all divisions of the Standard Products Company.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Ike Williams, lightweight champion, came back to the ring wars tonight after a two-month lay-off to win a smashing 10-round non-title decision over plucky Johnny Bratton of Chicago at the Arena. Each fighter weighed 138.

The United States, Britain and France have opened in London what is in effect a preliminary peace conference to work out, in the shape of an "Occupation Statute," a preliminary peace settlement with Germany. This "Occupation Statute" is to be, in lieu of a formal peace treaty, the fundamental instrument which will regulate the political relations between the occupation authorities and the new German Government.

Gotham Hosiery Company will introduce a series of special gift packages of nylon stockings, it was announced yesterday by Roy E. Tilles, president, at the company's showing of new spring and summer colors in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The possibility that Wilhelm Furtwaengler, German conductor charged with having figured in Nazi concerts during the war, would appear in Chicago this summer grew even less yesterday as James C. Petrillo, head of the American Federation of Musicians, AFL, made known that he and the union membership disapproved of such an appearance.

Advertising interests that would be affected by drastic new Federal regulations on liquor advertisements were warned yesterday to prepare a counter-attack on probable "dry" efforts to revive restrictive legislation in Congress.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates have been awarded $9,000,000 of Seattle, Wash., light and power revenue bonds, due from 1954 to 1974, on their bid of 2.54999 per cent for 2 1/4s, it was announced last night by W. C. Thomas, city controller of Seattle.

Following their custom for many years, the printers of THE NEW YORK TIMES composing room chapel made their annual contribution to THE NEW YORK TIMES Neediest Cases Fund yesterday in memory of Adolph S. Ochs, publisher of the newspaper from 1896 to 1935, and of Mrs. Ochs.
Collapse of negotiations between bakers and Local 550, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, brought the threat yesterday of a citywide stoppage of bread deliveries at the end of the month.
MELBOURNE, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The Lawn Tennis Association of Australia decided tonight to issue a Davis Cup challenge immediately.

Commendation bars and certificates of merit were presented by Mayor O'Dwyer and Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander in City Hall ceremonies yesterday to fifty-nine taxicab drivers who had rendered "courageous and valuable assistance" to the Police Department and to other city agencies.

GREAT GULL ISLAND, L. I., Jan. 17 -- Only four prospective purchasers of Great Gull Island, which the War Assets Administration is auctioning off, appeared here today aboard a special boat from New London, Conn., for the first of two public inspections. The next tour will come on Feb. 7.

Boris Karloff, last seen on Broadway as a friendly, benign English professor in J. B. Priestley's short-lived play, "The Linden Tree," returns to the local footlights tonight in his usual menacing line. The noted screen bogy man will portray an Englishman "with murder in his heart" in "The Shop at Sly Corner," which opens at the Booth Theatre under the auspices of Gant Gaither.
PRAGUE, Jan. 17 -- Czechoslovak judges who are unwilling to interpret the law in the spirit of Marxism and Leninism were warned today by the Minister of Justice, Alexej Cepicka, to get out.
Bus operators, union leaders and the police have started a drive to curb a small percentage of bus drivers who flagrantly disregard red stop signals on traffic lights, it was reported yesterday.

Heavy cancellations of contracts for shipment of German scrap metal here have occurred in the last few weeks as a result of the recent decline in scrap prices in the United States, the president of a leading American import company reported yesterday.

Today's events: Gilbert Reese, 'cello, Town Hall, 3 o'clock; Philadelphia Orchestra, Ernest Ansermet, conductor. Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Mildah Polia, mezzo-soprano, Times Hall, 8:30; Sonia Portugalova, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Little Orchestra Society, Thomas K. Scherman, conductor, Andres Segovia, guitar, Robert Nabel, trumpet, Brooklyn Academy, 8:30.

A British four-engined Tudor plane believed to be carrying thirteen passengers and a crew of seven disappeared somewhere over the Caribbean yesterday morning and was the object last night of a wide search by planes and ships.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 17 -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine, today requested the United Nations Security Council to liquidate the mediation machinery and turn over its functions to the new Palestine Conciliation Commission.

The trial of a dozen chief leaders of the Communist party in this country opened yesterday under circumstances which were made unnecessarily dramatic by a Police Department announcement. It is entirely proper, and essential, that precautions be taken to prevent any demonstration, either within or outside the court room, that might interfere with the administration of justice.

By the simple expedient of "doing nothing" the Board of Estimate has converted historic Claremont Inn from a picturesque addition to the Riverside Park landscape into a "not very attractive" boarded-up structure, it was disclosed yesterday by the Park Department.

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- One of London's most ambitious projects, staging of the 1951 Festival of Britain exhibition, was taken a step further today by Herbert Morrison, majority leader in the House of Commons.

Buying greatly exceeded expectations yesterday at the opening of the local winter furniture market in the New York Furniture Exchange, 206 Lexington Avenue. Manufacturers' representatives emphasized that few heavy orders were placed but expressed satisfaction at the steady flow of small quantity purchases because they had expected dealers to do nothing but shop the market on opening day.

Banking syndicates competed here yesterday for the purchase of $10,000,000 of new thirty-year bonds of Central Illinois Public Service Company and for blocks of common and preferred stock of Rohm Haas Company priced for public offering at more than $9,600,000. The awards were as follows:

Dorothy Bloom, the elder of two sisters operating a realty business in tenements, was back in the workhouse yesterday to serve a 150-day term for violation of the multiple dwellings law. She had appeared in Municipal Term Court before Magistrates Philip B. Thurston and Vernon C. Riddick on charges that she had failed to remedy conditions in walk-up flats in East Harlem and the Lower East Side.

The Brooklyn Society of Artists has abandoned its usual exhibition premises at its borough museum or the Brooklyn Academy of Art this year in favor of Abraham Straus. The society's thirty-third annual exhibition, composed this year of 130 oils, water-colors, examples of graphic art and sculptures, opened yesterday for a period of two weeks in the Special Events Center of that department store.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 17 -- The Israeli Government is moving at top speed to repopulate the land left empty by the Arab exodus. The shooting had hardly stopped in south Israel two weeks ago when bulldozers began clearing away a wrecked Arab village for the first of nine settlements. Seven were started last week in Galilee also on ground left behind by fleeing Arabs.

BOSTON, Jan. 17 -- Completing a stormy, ten-day voyage from Bremerhaven, the Marine Flasher arrived today with 549 displaced persons from occupied areas of Germany and Austria. They were destined for twenty-three states and the District of Columbia.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Hereafter the Army will buy all the butcher knives for cutting up steaks for the armed forces, but the Navy will choose the knives for trimming shoes and linoleum.
A group of Czettel drawings and paintings covering approximately a decade went on display at the Brooklyn Museum yesterday. The exhibition is presented in conjunction with the Museum's Art School.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Congress completed and sent to the White House today, three days short of a constitutional deadline, a bill providing higher pay and allowance for President Truman, Vice President-elect Alben W. Barkley and Speaker Sam Rayburn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- August Klapprott, a former leader of the German-American Bund, did not receive a fair trial when his American citizenship was revoked and must have a new hearing, the Supreme Court ruled by a vote of 5 to 4 today.
A shipment of new furniture from California was set up yesterday in the three room settings that comprise the principal display in McCreery's modern furniture department.

Conversion of the Board of Transportation into an independent, bond-issuing authority was proposed last night by Harold Riegelman counsel of the Citizens Budget Commission, Inc., as a means of financing new transit construction and improvements without increasing the city's debt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Copper production in 1948 totaled 825,666 tons, the Bureau of Mines said today. The preliminary estimate, the Bureau said, indicated a 3 per cent decline from 1947 production totals.

Radios Out of Taxicabs The City Hack Bureau's order that there must be no radios in New York taxicabs, on the ground that these create a hazard by distracting drivers, points up the problem of how far to go, within the bounds of safety, in the installation of gadgets and other things for the supposed comfort and amusement of the customers.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 17 -- Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, said tonight that academic independence for universities must rely on continued "diversity" of financial support and the autonomy of each faculty.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The Supreme Court decided today that Lewis F. Jacobson of Chicago must pay Federal income tax on money saved by buying his own bonds at prices less than their face value.

Mayor O'Dwyer told the Board of Estimate yesterday that the justices of the Court of Special Sessions had asked that three new Special Sessions justices be appointed to relieve congested calendars. The proposal was based on the overload in Brooklyn.

The Todd Shipyards Corporation is completing the first annual survey made on three Lloyd Brasileiro passenger-cargo ships in connection with their builders' guarantees, Todd spokesmen said yesterday. Two of the vessels, the Loide Paraguai and the Loide Haiti, are now at the company's Brooklyn shipyard, while the Loide Guatemala is in the Todd-Johnson yard at New Orleans.

Soldiers who buy their comic magazines at Army post exchanges may find some of their lustier crime and horror favorites missing from the stands as a result of action taken by the Army Character Guidance Council in Washington, it was learned yesterday.

Deferment of a strike set for yesterday by school firemen and engineers until Jan. 31 was obtained by top union officials to permit the City Division of Labor Relations to inquire into the dispute. The school employes are seeking increased wages and improved working conditions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Treasury Department announced today that tenders for $900,000,000 of ninety-one-day Treasury bills to be dated Jan. 20, and to mature on April 21, which were offered on Jan. 14, were opened at the Federal Reserve Banks today.
A shipment of new furniture from California was set up yesterday in the three room settings that comprise the principal display in McCreery's modern furniture department.

Conversion of the Board of Transportation into an independent, bond-issuing authority was proposed last night by Harold Riegelman counsel of the Citizens Budget Commission, Inc., as a means of financing new transit construction and improvements without increasing the city's debt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Copper production in 1948 totaled 825,666 tons, the Bureau of Mines said today. The preliminary estimate, the Bureau said, indicated a 3 per cent decline from 1947 production totals.

Radios Out of Taxicabs The City Hack Bureau's order that there must be no radios in New York taxicabs, on the ground that these create a hazard by distracting drivers, points up the problem of how far to go, within the bounds of safety, in the installation of gadgets and other things for the supposed comfort and amusement of the customers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On Jan. 12 you published a letter from Gelston Hinds regarding Senator Joint Resolution 2, my proposed constitutional amendment abolishing the electoral college and dividing the electoral votes of each state in direct proportion to the popular vote.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The Plomb Tool Company of Los Angeles has won a conditional stay of a lower court order which, it contends, could wreck its business.

WASHINGTON, Jan 17 (AP) -- Heavy tobacco purchases for Western Germany accounted for more than half of $11,534,000 in new Marshall Plan aid grants approved today by the Economic Cooperation Administration.

Dr. Jacob de la Faille, noted Dutch author and authority on Vincent Van Gogh, arrived yesterday from Europe to deliver a special lecture at the first public showing of a recently discovered self-portrait by Van Gogh.

The O'Hara Bill requiring the Federal Trade Commission to try its cases in the Federal District Courts was re-introduced in Congress yesterday by Representative Joseph P. O'Hara, Republican, of Minnesota. It was quickly endorsed by the Association of National Advertisers in a statement by George S. McMillan, chairman of the ANA's Government relations committee, who is vice president of the Bristol-Myers Company.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- Republican legislative leaders, in the first part of their answer to Democratic demands for a full accounting of the state's post-war reconstruction fund, reported tonight that $63,070,653.32 had been spent for emergency housing for veterans.

An interim report by its special committee on wire tapping recommended yesterday to the New York County Criminal Courts Bar Association that it give no support at this time to Attorney General Tom C. Clark's request for a Federal law permitting wire-tapping in espionage cases.

The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank has sold the six-story forty-eight-family apartment house at 350 Manhattan Avenue to the 350 Manhattan Avenue Corporation, represented by Morel Fuchs, attorney. The property had been held at $215,000. John J. Dickerson, Inc., and Philip Simpson were the brokers.

Wool tops and wool futures were easy yesterday on hedge selling and profit taking. Wool top futures lost 1.5 to 2 cents a pound on sales of 75,000 pounds. Wool futures were down 1 to 1.5 cents on transactions of 126,000 pounds.

ROME, Jan. 17 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi's Christian Democratic party shows no pronounced enthusiasm about accepting the olive branch of peace offered by Communist leader Palmiro Togliatti in his speech in Bologna last Friday.

Ken Norton, Manhattan College coach whose Jaspers meet Holy Cross in the feature of tonight's basketball double-header in Madison Square Garden, has outlined a very simple procedure for beating the Crusaders. To hear Norton tell it yesterday to the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association at Leone's, all Manhattan had to do was to stop Bob Cousy.

CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., Jan. 17 -- After fifteen years of delay caused by the depression, the war and the high cost of construction, a new highway that will help speed traffic to New England is finally being developed through the rocky hills and wooden glens north of here.
A record production of 6,000,000 motor vehicles this year was forecast yesterday by C. E. Wilson, president of the General Motors Corporation, and Alfred P. Sloan, Jr., chairman of the board.

CHANGSHA, China, Jan. 17 -- Although it lies on a possible route of a Communist advance into the southern provinces, Yale-in-China, including the American staff members still here, is determined to stay as long as it is not forced out.

The Tammany leadership of the Park Avenue section, vacant since the resignation of Jeremiah T. Mahoney last month, was formally filled last night at a meeting at the Grover Cleveland Democratic Club, 21 East Seventy-fifth Street.

W. Averell Harriman, the Economic Cooperation Administration's special representative in Europe, arrived at La Guardia airport yesterday after a seven-week trip through Turkey, Greece, Germany, Belgium, France and England. He expressed faith in the European Recovery Program as a means of achieving peace and stability and denied the report that he would resign his present duties.

KINGSVILLE, Tex., Jan. 17 (UP) -- Assault, the King Ranch racer, may try a comeback. The ranch veterinarian, Dr. J. K. Northway, said today: "It's still very problematical,'' but that the 1946 Triple Crown winner may race again this summer.

For the first time since Jan. 3 Whittaker Chambers was brought before the special Federal Grand Jury investigating subversive activities to testify at length yesterday. This was a result, it was learned, of the refusal of Felix August Inslerman, who preceded him to the witness stand, to confirm the confessed spy courier's story concerning the copying of the pumpkin microfilms.
BERLIN, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The merger of the three Western occupation zones is completely stalled, authoritative sources said tonight.

England stands a better than even chance of meeting the production goals set in the four-year plan for national solvency, Dr. Wilfred John Hinton, director of studies of the Institute of Bankers in London, said yesterday at a press conference.

A British automobile trailer, with living accommodations for four persons, was placed on preview yesterday at the Chatham Hotel, Vanderbilt Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, as the first product of its kind to be imported commercially to the United States.
Ten of the ways in which the Community Service Society has helped business in this city in more than a century were pointed out yesterday in a report sent by the society to business executives.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 18 -- The first elections in the Republic of Israel scheduled for next Tuesday, Jan. 25, are for the Constituent Assembly, the body that will adopt a constitution and thus determine the structure, character and form of the government and the basic institutions of the new state.

The long-standing fight among three unions to represent the 8,000 employes of Macy's may be resolved within the next thirty days as the result of an order yesterday by the National Labor Relations Board.

Revenue taxes were paid on 5,769,867,000 cigars in 1948, the fourth largest annual total since 1930, and an over-all increase over the 1947 figure, it was reported yesterday at the annual meetings of the Cigar Institute of America and the Cigar Manufacturers Association of America at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Notre Dame's basketball team trailed Butler University for thirty-eight minutes tonight and pulled ahead just before the gun for a 60-58 victory. Butler had won nine straight games.

In your cogent editorial "TVA After Fifteen Years," in the Jan. 2 issue, you state "What TVA has done is to show that they (other possible river authorities) can be solved in a democratic way, with few or none of the evils of centralized bureaucracy." Clearly an inference is that government in business is a victim of waste, bureaucracy, politics, etc.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Representatives of twenty Asiatic countries are gathering in India this week to consider what they could or should do about Dutch military action in Indonesia. The Government announced tonight that nineteen nations had accepted India's invitation for an Asian conference, opening Thursday.

Before committing himself on the final make-up of the Wanamaker Mile at the Millrose Games a week from Saturday at Madison Square Garden, Fred Schmertz will watch the milers pass in review this week-end at Philadelphia and Boston.
The Cross Brown Company has announced the naming as vice presidents of Eugene C. Quinlan, Harry A. Tunstall, Paul B. Owen and Edward J. Lusk.

An interim rate increase of 5 per cent, designed to meet increased operating costs, has been approved for groups of truck operators under the jurisdiction of the Public Service Commission, it was announced yesterday. The increase will become effective upon five days' notice to the public after the new rates are filed.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The Governments of Britain, Argentina and Chile have agreed "that, in the present circumstances, they foresee no need to send warships south of Latitude 60 degrees during the 1948-49 Antarctic season," apart from the customary routine movements, the Foreign Office announced tonight.

FEW men in the world's history have served a cause as long or as selflessly as Dr. Chaim Weizmann has served the cause of Zionism. With tireless energy, unflagging zeal, passionate eloquence and stubborn persistence he has remained faithful throughout his life to the Biblical motto of Zionism: "If I forget thee, O Jerusalem, let my right hand forget her cunning."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 -Stanley W. Cousley, president of the Fidelity - Philadelphia Trust Company, reported at today's annual stockholders' meeting that net operating earnings in 1948 were $1,343,136, or $4.01 a share, after income taxes.

Last year was the busiest in the history of the New York Telephone Company, it was announced yesterday by Carl Whitmore, president. Growth and improved service, Mr. Whitmore said, resulted from a construction program in which the concern invested $172,000,000, a new high record.

The light cruiser Newark, which was 67.8 per cent complete when construction was halted in 1945, has been offered for sale, it became known yesterday. Bids for the vessel will be opened at 10 A. M. Feb. 23 in the offices of the Sales and Survey Section at the New York Naval Shipyard, Naval Base, Brooklyn.

PEIPING, Jan. 18 -- A battered old city bus carried eleven self-appointed peace delegates out Peiping's West Gate this afternoon to seek a temporary armistice with the Communists. Although the city is under no heavy firing it has been getting a daily dose lately of six to ten shells in the residential sections early in the morning, at noon and at dusk.
LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Ships under construction throughout the world on Dec. 31 totaled 4,140,816 gross tons, Lloyd's Register of Shipbuilding Returns disclosed today.

The stock market staged a half-hearted rally yesterday but the early momentum failed to last and prices at the close were only irregularly higher on the day. Selective trading was the rule and pressure eased on some issues which recently were under attack. Airline
LANSING, Mich., Jan. 18 -- The State Public Service Commission ordered today a rate increase aggregating $7,259,000 for the Michigan Consolidated Gas Company.

Marjorie Margulies bought the five-story building at 1640 Macombs Road, the Bronx, from Harold J. Silbermann and another as executors of the estate of Louis Guerr. The property is assessed at $72,000. Daniel W. Lave was the broker.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Kenneth S. Pitzer, new director of the research division of the Atomic Energy Commission, expressed the hope today that most atomic research projects could be kept out of universities because such projects impose a security curb on free academic discussion.

A "convoy" of brown paper bags, telegrams, night letters and ordinary mail urging aid for wartime seamen will "sail' into Washington today destined for the White House, the offices of the President's Cabinet members and every member of Congress.

Requests from colleges for revisions of game assignments will not be heeded in the future by the Collegiate Basketball Officials Bureau, Asa S. Bushnell notified athletic directors yesterday. The head of the Eastern College Athletic Conference's bureau admitted that it "acted inadvisedly" in twice yielding to requests for changes in officials at recent games.

VIENNA, Jan. 18 -- Because the Austrian Government refused to clear a ten-meter [6.2-mile] wide strip along its side of the Austro-Hungarian border to make it easier for the Hungarian Government to prevent escape of refugees, all "local frontier traffic" has been stopped since yesterday by Budapest's order.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Truman Administration's Congressional leaders disclosed today a determination to move fast in the House to raise the minimum wage from 40 cents to 75 cents an hour, as the first action toward enacting the President's social program.

Mayor O'Dwyer, acting well in advance of a Feb. 1 strike deadline, summoned yesterday representatives of Local 550. International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, and six principal bread bakers to a meeting at City Hall this afternoon.
Leon H. Keyserling, vice chairman of President Truman's Council of Economic Advisers, said last night that he was not responsible for the recent proposal for Government manufacture of steel.

Grave concern for the future of the port of New York was expressed last night by Paul G. Boise, president of the Foreign Commerce Club of New York, who asserted that New York City would "gradually slip" from its prominent position among the world's ports unless changing conditions were recognized and acted upon.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The setting of President Truman's inaugural reception will be more artistic than that of any other President.

George Kaftan, Bob Cousy and Dermott O'Connell spearheaded a late drive that carried Holy Cross to a smashing comeback triumph over Manhattan last night at Madison Square Garden. Ten points down at two stages of the first half, the veteran Crusaders wound up by winning quite easily.

The prospect of increased dividends was a principal topic of discussion at the annual meeting of stockholders of the Bankers Trust Company yesterday. Responding to questions from minority stockholders, S. Sloan Colt, president, explained that consideration already had been given by the board of directors to the possibility of making a greater distribution, and that that body would continue to give its attention to the matter.

Dr. Norman Jolliffe, one of the country's leading authorities on nutrition, has been named head of the Health Department's newly organized Bureau of Nutrition, Dr. Harry S. Mustard, Health Commissioner, announced last night.

BOSTON, Jan. 18 -The Massachusetts Senate cast its 100th ballot today in an unsuccessful attempt to elect president. It then voted to adjourn until londay to permit the twenty Democratic members to attend President Truman's inauguration.

Please permit me to add my comments to those of Gino L. Perera, whose letter was published in your paper on Jan. 8 under the caption "To Curb Delinquency." Contrary to Mr. Perera's suggestion that laws should be enacted curbing attendance by children to certain objectionable motion pictures, it is my belief that public indignation rather than law can do more to discourage the production of undesirable pictures at their source.

Making no pretensions to greatness, prepared to fight any suitable foeman selected, and ambitious to establish himself as a challenger for Joe Louis' heavyweight title, Hein Ten Hoff, Holland-born German heavyweight champion, presented himself for inspection yesterday at the Twentieth Century S. C., to which he is under contract.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's impromptu speech tonight at the pre-inaugural dinner of the Truman-Barkley Club:

Gilbert Reese, 22-year-old 'cellist from Long Beach, Calif., gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. A fair-haired young chap with a lean face and a boyish grin, he revealed an unusually expressive manner of playing.

Coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange in a sharp reversal of the previous day closed firm yesterday. Support from producing interests, trade buying and scattered short-covering advanced prices in contract "D" 24 to 53 points.

The Midwest dominated The Associated Press basketball poll with five teams from that sector named among the top ten college quintets for the week. Honors went to St. Louis University, which has registered eleven victories without a defeat.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 18 (AP) -- S. D. Sidell's Allie's Pal spurted to an easy triumph in the first division of today's Poinsettia Purse at Hialeah Park.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Senate, through an apparently well-organized coalition of Republicans and Southern Democrats, inflicted on the Administration forces their first defeat of the new Congress today, along with a package of embarrassment.

The Long Island Rail Road's misfortunes, unlike some of its trains, are right on schedule. A few days ago local 269 of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers complained about the safety of Long Island engines. Yesterday an engine acted up and between 4 A. M. and sunrise four buses were taking Long Island passengers to their destinations.

With all the preparations for President Truman's inauguration, the great procession, the displays of fireworks and the other gala festivities, it is to be hoped that everything also has been fixed with the weather man.

PARIS, Jan. 18 -- James B. Carey, secretary-treasurer of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, indicated here tonight that his organization was no longer considering itself a member of the World Federation of Trade Unions.

Restyled and with various mechanical improvements, the 1949 line of Chevrolet cars was announced yesterday by W. F. Armstrong, vice president of the General Motors Corporation and general manager of the Chevrolet division. Increased vision and riding comfort were stressed. The cars will be in the corporation's exhibit to open tomorrow at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Cooperative action on price reductions in the fur industry was urged yesterday by Sol Rosenberg, president of the Associated Fur Manufacturers, Inc., at that organization's annual meeting in the Statler Hotel. He also asked for later and more concentrated showings of fur lines and warned against the entrance by manufacturers into the production of new and unfamiliar lines.

Councilman Michael J. Quinn, president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, led 100 union members, employed by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, in an early morning demonstration yesterday at the Thirty-fourth Street entrance of the Queens-Midtown Tunnel.
A Chicago City Opera Company, designed as a counterpart of the New York City Opera Company, will be developed during the next three years, it was announced yesterday.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 3,160, against 4,178 last week and 1,959 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 1,226 arrivals yesterday compared with 2,150 last Tuesday.

The White Plains elevated and subway lines in the Bronx were slowed down to a walk yesterday at 10:51 A.M. by a German shepherd dog on the tracks. The service was affected for thirteen and a half minutes.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 18 -- Samuel Goldwyn gave notice today of his withdrawal from the Motion Picture Association of America and the Association of Motion Picture Producers, the East and West Coast organizations of the major film companies which are headed by Eric Johnston.

NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 18 -- A group of leading fashion creators turned their talents to interior design at the request of L. Bamberger and Company and produced a series of model rooms which opened today. Tina Leser, Jo Copeland, Adele Simpson and Claire McCardell were the four who demonstrated their ideas of fashions in the home.

Successful completion of the time schedule of the Marshall Plan will bring within sight the possibility of re-establishing an international trade system with a minimum of controls, Thomas C. Blaisdell Jr., acting Assistant Secretary of Commerce, said here yesterday.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 18 -- Authorities investigating the puzzling death of 27-year-old Grenville Baker, heir to a New York banking fortune, announced today that the inquiry thus far "doesn't show any indication of murder."

Pessimism in the men's shirt industry is being dissipated, with definite indications that there is now "a proper relationship between supply and demand," Seymour J. Phillips, president of the Phillips-Jones Corporation, said last night at the annual meeting of the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers at the Astor Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Council of State Chambers of Commerce today denounced President Truman's $41,858,000,000 budget as a "new and perilously high plateau of public expenditures."
Public financing transactions involving more than $95,000,000 of bonds and stocks were announced yesterday by managers of underwriting syndicates here.

TOKYO, Jan. 18 -- Minimum standards for foreign investments here were announced today. Generally they merely are a more detailed version of previously-published directives. The only startling provision is that asserting "acquisition won't be validated where there is a reasonable ground for belief that it is being acquired on behalf of a foreign government."

TOKYO, Jan. 18 -- Occupation officials are wondering seriously whether Japan's current general elections, with the campaign now in its last week, should not be declared void on the ground that officials have interpreted the recently revised election law in such a manner as to violate the constitutional guarantees of freedom of speech and assembly.

Arthur Kurzman, in a purchase for investment, has acquired the three-story business building at 860 Bergen Avenue, southeast corner of Smith Street, in Jersey City, N. J., from Miss Mary A. Frye. The two upper floors are occupied by the Girl Scouts of America.

Boris Karloff, the illustrious shudder man, is stalking ominously through "The Shop at Sly Corner," produced at the Booth last evening. This just about concludes the bill of virtues for the occasion. Having had a respectable career in London, Edward Percy's ode to crime has crossed the ocean to a place where crime is taken seriously as an art, science and vocation.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 18 -- Peter Stambolitch, Premier of Serbia and one of Marshal Tito's most determined defenders against the Communist Information Bureau, told the second congress of the Serbian Communist party today that economic sanctions against Yugoslavia would fail to force the Yugoslav Communists to their knees.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumed in December totaled 680,670 bales of lint and 113,854 bales of linters.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The State Department's Voice of America will broadcast to the world a running account of the inauguration of President Truman on Thursday. The broadcast will begin at 11:45 A. M. EST, and continue until the end of the ceremonies.

Benjamin Franklin's prophetic powers in anticipating modern trends in education, business and civic progress were emphasized yesterday at a ceremony held in the Board of Estimate chamber in commemoration of the 243d anniversary of the birth of the patriot and inventor.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan 18 -- "The small Business Committee of the United States House of Representatives will gladly challenge at a public hearing the steel mills which feel they should wipe the small business man off the map by taking away his industrial plant accounts."

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- As a means for lowering construction costs, the Dewey administration is considering creating a special building code commission that would have power to alter the provisions of existing municipal construction codes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Humphrey report for the retention of about 150 steel and other plants in Germany that had been earmarked for reparations recommends that the 10,700,000-ton limit on German crude steel production previously agreed upon by the United States, France and Britain, be maintained, the State Department said today.

The Tea Bureau is asking restaurateurs to feature "the fourth meal" -- teatime. Latest to fall in with this suggestion is the Cardinal, 212 West Fifty - seventh Street. It began a series of Tuesday teas yesterday, with a big splash, at which Margaret Newman showed resort clothes to about 500 guests.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- History always has made quite a point of the order in which Presidents and their wives ride up Capitol Hill for inaugurations and ride back down again.

BERLIN, Jan. 18 -- American Military Government officials sought and won removal of members of the editorial staffs of two newspapers that have featured militarist, nationalist and anti-Semitic material, it was disclosed today in an official report.

Lord Calvert Beverages, Inc., bought the eight-story loft building on a plot 125 by 98 feet at 418-26 West Twenty-fifth Street from Charles Frueauff in a deal reported yesterday by Dwight-Helmsley, Inc., broker in conjunction with Charles G. Keller, Inc. The assessed valuation is $350,000.
A strike scheduled for 4 o'clock this morning by the engineers who operate the trains of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad was postponed for one week last night.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Arthur G. Eilers of Baltimore today was elect president of the Middle Atlantic Conference of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers. He succeeds Harold L. Carson of Trenton. Other officers elected at the close of the conference's annual meeting at the Seaview Country Club include Marshall Davis of Washington, D. C., vice president, and Thomas F. Egan Jr. of Philadelphia, secretary-treasurer.

Alarmed over the growing number of unskilled incompetent persons handing out advice on emotional problems, the reputable psychologists of the nation are making a concerted effort to protect the public welfare.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Seeded players had little difficulty with opening round matches in the national professional clay courts championships today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Mrs. Harry S. Truman led a group of inauguration house-guests across Pennsylvania Avenue from Blair House to the White House today to hear her daughter Margaret conduct a March of Dimes broadcast

Criticism of the Board of Higher Education by Prof. Ephriam Cross of City College's Romance Languages Department, for dropping an investigation of Prof. William E. Knickerbocker, head of that department, may lead to charges of "conduct unbecoming a teacher," Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the board, indicated yesterday.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York adopted last night a resolution endorsing the proposal of Presiding Justice David W. Peck of the Appellate Division, First Department, worked out with the committees of the organized bar, for the "streamlining" of the courts of this city.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 18 -- Preston Sturges, who has completed a two-picture producing-directing deal at Twentieth Century-Fox, will move over to M-G-M under a term contract as a producer-director, it was learned today.

TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 18 -- Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper and State Police officials will aid local authorities in an intensive investigation into charges of widespread gambling operations in Passaic and Bergen Counties, the Attorney General said today.
LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Trading was dull today, the last of the account on the stock market.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- When Parliament reconvened after its Christmas recess today, Foreign Secretary Bevin announced Britain's willingness to release the Jewish immigrants of fighting age now held on Cyprus. He also fully and strongly supported the negotiations now going on between the Israelis and Egyptians at Rhodes.

NANKING, Wednesday, Jan. 19 -- China's Executive Yuan has decided to issue a cease-fire order to Nationalist armies and send a delegation to negotiate peace with the Communists, a high official source disclosed today.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Jan. 18 -- Two officials of the Communist party were fined today by a British Military Government summary court for having conducted a public political meeting without having first obtained Military Government approval.
Mrs. Thomas J. Watson will give a tea on Jan. 27 in her residence at 4 East Seventy-fifth Street to mark the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Foster Home Department of the Children's Aid Society.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- While crowds poured into this city today for President Truman's inauguration, one hotel hawked window elbow-room for the parade Thursday at $12 a person.

Despite an intensive search by an estimated seventy-two aircraft and many ships, no trace was found yesterday of the British South American. Airways tudor airliner Star Ariel. The plane, with thirteen passengers and seven crew members on board, disappeared at about 8:50 A. M. Monday between Hamilton, Bermuda, and Jamaica, British West Indies.

A book containing 200 parchment pages on which the leading figures of all the American republics have placed their autographs soon will be presented to the Pan American Union at Washington, the compiler, Orlando Oyarzun, announced yesterday.

WARSAW, Jan. 18 -- Jewish leaders fear the Polish Government is planning to end the emigration of Polish Jews to Israel. Since the beginning of this year the Polish Government has stopped issuing passports to applicants.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Get-rich-quick Charles Ponzi, the little man who swindled the American public out of big money in 1920, died in poverty at the age of 71 of a blood clot on the brain. He was partly blind and paralyzed on his left side.

A resolution to abolish the local restrictions of the Public Schools Athletic League against high school students from competing for amateur clubs throughout the school year was offered for discussion at the swimming forum held at the New York Athletic Club last night.

A new book by George Fielding Eliot, noted commentator and author of "Hate, Hope and High Explosive," has been listed for March publication by Bobbs-Merrill. "If Russia Strikes" is an analysis of what her military and naval and air forces might do in the event of war and what the defensive and offensive strategy of the nations opposed to her might be.

The system of wholesale distribution is gaining ground with the return of a buyers' market, Henry Matter, executive vice president of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute, pointed out yesterday. There is a greater understanding of the functions of wholesaling than ever before, he said, evidenced by the promotional and merchandising aid which manufacturers are giving to jobbers.

Recent trends in savings reflect the well-being due to full employment rather than any difficulties due to the higher price level, according to a study of developments in national savings patterns issued yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers.
Ownership of a literary manuscript does not necessarily include the right to publish it, according to a decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, made public yesterday.

Today Isaiah Thomas, journalist, of Boston and Worcester, Mass., enters his third century. As a Colonial printer he was continually in conflict with royal authorities. During the four days after he was driven from Boston by the British occupation in 1775 he rode with Paul Revere on the famous midnight alarm and fought as a minute man at both Lexington and Concord.

Diagnosis and treatment of mental disease as early as childhood were urged by Governor Dewey last night when he opened the final phase of a $32,744,000 fund campaign to build the new New York University-Bellevue Medical Center.

BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 18 (Reuters) -- Former Premier Sutan Sjahrir, personal adviser to Dr. Sukarno, the Indonesian Republican President with whom he has been interned by the Dutch in northern Sumatra, today returned to Batavia for conferences with Dutch officials.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- W. Stuart Symington, Secretary of the Air Force, presented the Air Force Exceptional Civilian Award this evening to Thomas G. Lanphier Jr., the pilot who shot down Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto, chief of the Japanese Navy, in the Pacific War.

The Newspaper Guild of New York announced yesterday that the Irving Geist Foundation awards committee had decided that President Truman, by originating the report of the Committee on Civil Rights, had done more than any other man to combat prejudice in 1948.

Republican leaders, about to start conferences looking toward the selection of a 1949 Mayoralty ticket, have indicated a skepticism amounting almost to defeatism over the chances of taking control of the city away from the Democrats, especially if the Democratic ticket is headed by Mayor O'Dwyer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- President Truman, reiterating tonight in his first speech of Inaugural Week his determination to carry out the Democratic platform, pleaded for the cooperation of the Democrats in Congress.

Designers from Germany, England and the United States met on common ground yesterday when the winners of the International Competition for Low-Cost Furniture received their awards at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. Nelson Rockefeller,

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- Republican members of the Legislature, as a result of party conferences, have informed Governor Dewey that they favor an increase of from $25,000,000 to $40,000,000 a year in state aid to education.

A new subsidiary company has been formed by the Procter Gamble Company to take over radio, motion picture and television activities previously handled by its advertising department, it was announced yesterday. The wholly owned subsidiary, Procter Gamble Productions, Inc., is being incorporated in Ohio with a capitalization of $1,000,000, and officers and directors are yet to be designated.

Your editorial "First Bungle," discussing the action of the Senate Democratic majority in changing the ratio of membership on the Foreign Relations Committee from 7-6 to 8-5, gives the impression that the 7-6 ratio is a long-hallowed one. Actually, it stems from the Legislative Reorganization Act of 1946, first effective in the Eightieth Congress.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- As Republicans in the Senate and the Assembly defended the state's administration of mental hospitals, Assemblyman Nathan Lashin, Democrat, of the Bronx, introduced four bills today to broaden and improve the care in mental institutions.

Termination of the Government-sponsored patent pooling agreement in the synthetic or "man-made" rubber field can be expected soon, John L. Collyer, president of the B. F. Goodrich Company, announced here yesterday. Industry sources disclosed that the total amount of rubber made under the agreement exceeded $1,000,000,000 in value and amounted to more than 3,000,000 tons.
