Tenants of the eleven-story apartment house at 31 West Twelfth Street won a reduction in rent and received damages for "partial eviction" from Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter yesterday. The suit was brought against their landlord, Cinema Francais, Inc., for changing a manually operated elevator to an automatic and for other alleged deterioration of services.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Administration-backed bills to continue the Government's authority to control exports and arrange voluntary agreements for the allocation domestically of scarce commodities were introduced today in the House and Senate.

New York aluminum alloy casting ingot refiners announced yesterday the first major price reduction from the peak of post-war prices, which appeared in mid-November of 1948. There had been no increases officially posted following the mid-November, 1948, rises, and refiners said the present trend was toward normal market conditions.

Ernest Ansermet, who appeared as guest conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, is a new figure on its podium, and a most exceptional interpreter. He is not a virtuoso conductor, and may well be a leader whose depth of thinking and extreme sensitivity make him hard for the players to satisfy.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 18 -- The negotiation of a Scandinavian defense pact in an attempt to preserve the political unity of Norway, Sweden and Denmark now seems to be a forlorn hope.
With the other two local major league clubs maintaining a more or less discreet silence, the New York Giants continued yesterday to announce the signing of contented ball players.

Steps were taken yesterday, with the backing of the Administration, to see that two of the Government's basic controls over "shortage" materials are continued in force pending Congressional action on the eight-point program laid down by the President in his State of the Union message.

The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company transacted last year a new high volume of sales and had an increase of $2,485,016 in earnings ove 1947, John C. Whitaker, president, informed stockholders in the annual report released today.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- The Temporary State Fair Commission recommended to Governor Dewey and the Legislature today the establishment of a year-'round Empire State Exposition near Syracuse. The eventual cost was estimated by the Commission at $52,000,000.

Released time religious instruction of public school children creates antagonisms among pupils of different faiths and violates the principle of separation of church and state, it was charged last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Soviet Embassy's Information Bulletin led off this week with a friendly salutation to the American people by one Boris Izakov, who used to report the meetings of the United Nations and the Council of Foreign Ministers for the Moscow newspaper Pravda.
The battle over Communism taking place in the Federal Court House with the trial of the top Communist leaders flared briefly but heatedly in the City Council yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. l8 -- The first test of the Dewey Administration's measure to extend the powers of the State Power Authority in connection with the hydro-electric development of the St. Lawrence River is scheduled for next Monday or Tuesday in the Senate.

The Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America called on Congress yesterday to increase the number of displaced persons eligible to enter this country from 200,000 to 400,000 and to remove from present legislation "any discriminatory percentages based on race or nationality."

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 18 -- The breach between the junta government and the Roman Catholic Church widened today when Msgr. Victor Manuel Sanabria, Archbishop of San Jose, countered a Government demand that he discipline Vicar General Alfredo Hidalgo.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, postponed for another sixty days today the effective date of his order diverting Marshall Plan bulk cargoes to foreign flag ships.
After deliberating one hour, an all-male blue ribbon jury in Kings County Court yesterday found Frank Bruno, 33 years old, guilty of first-degree murder.

" Command Decision," which arrives at Loew's State, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Clark Gable heads the cast of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer wartime aviation drama, which was produced by Sidney Franklin in association with Gottfried Reinhardt and directed by Sam Wood from the play by William Wister Haines and the screen play by William R. Laidlaw and George Froeschel.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 18 -- The United Nations Security Council postponed today a meeting scheduled for tomorrow so that delegates would have another twenty-four hours to try to work out an agreed resolution on the Indonesian situation.
PARIS, Jan. 18 -- Albouy's collection, in lovely flower blues, rosewood pinks, pale water greens and natural straw tones, confirms the calotte as an important trend in hats for summer.

Chief City Magistrate Edgar Bromberger announced yesterday that he would appear before Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson at 11:45 A. M. today in the Municipal Building to request substantially higher appropriations for the probation services of the city's forty-two Magistrates Courts.

The chance to pull themselves to within striking distance of third place in the National Hockey League race faces the New York Rangers tonight when they tackle the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden.

The development of new techniques in the making of phonograph records has precipitated a competitive struggle between two of the major companies -- RCA Victor and Columbia. Whatever the outcome of the battle, the public will be bewildered.
Eleven members of the Communist party national board were ordered yesterday to stand trial without the presence of William Z. Foster, national chairman.

The Columbia Broadcasting System announced last night that it has signed Bing Crosby to appear on both its television and radio networks. Mr. Crosby is heard through the stations of the American Broadcasting Company.

ATLANTA, Jan. 18 -- The Georgia House of Representatives today defeated a motion to postpone indefinitely consideration of a bill to unmask the Ku Klux Klan. The vote, which followed vigorous debate, was 78 -- 72.

Forty religious, charitable and educational institutions were named among the beneficiaries of Jacob R. Schiff, banker and lawyer who died on Jan. 10, in his will, filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

The two-story taxpayer building at 269 Main Street in Huntington, L. I., has been purchased by Loomis J. Gressman, operator, from the Arbee Realty Corporation. The building, on a lot 20 by 119 feet, is occupied by the Singer Sewing Machine Company.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 18 -- Representatives of the merchandising end of the nation's huge food industry agreed today that the "sellers' market" in their business is a thing of the past and that the American housewife will have the final say in how much canned goods are sold in 1949.

A meeting of members of the arrangements and junior committees planning the April Ball was held yesterday afternoon at Le Coq Rouge. The ball, in the form of a dinner dance, will be given April 21 in the main ballroom of the Plaza to mark the fifty-eighth anniversary of the founding of the beneficiary, the Silver Cross Day Nursery at 251 East 117th Street.

ROME, Jan. 18 -- Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza reported optimistically this morning to the Cabinet on the proposed Italo-French customs union, which he said should develop into a full economic union within six years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Howard Bruce, Deputy Economic Cooperation Administrator, whose charges of excessive shipments of aluminum and lead scrap to the United States from Marshall Plan countries are still in controversy, has submitted his resignation to President Truman, effective Jan 31.

Roger Montgomery of Boys High, National indoor high school 440-yard champion, was declared ineligible for the 1949 outdoor season at the monthly meeting of the High School Games Committee of the P.S.A.L. at the Hotel Astor yesterday. Montgomery's career as a scholastic runner ends when the present indoor season, his fourth, is completed. According to a P.S.A.L. rule, no boy is permitted to compete in more than four indoor or four outdoor campaigns.
NANKING, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Diplomatic sources here heard today that they would be notified soon that Government offices were being dispersed as a safety measure.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The National Petroleum Council said today the nation's oil-refining capacity on Dec. 31 was 6,349,000 barrels daily, a 14 per cent increase within twenty - one months. It added that the capacity will be increased 3 1/2 per cent during 1949.
Somewhat the worse for a trip through the mails, a painting that had been stolen from the Metropolitan Museum of Art nearly five years ago was returned last Friday, the museum made known yesterday.

Well-known members of the society are aiding Mrs. Frank Lyon Polk, chairman, and Mrs. John McMaster, co-chairman of the executive committee, in the sale of tickets for the performance of "La Boheme," with Bidu Sayao and Richard Tucker in the leading roles, next Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of St. Barnabas House.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder announced today the offering, through the Federal Reserve Banks, of 1 1/4 per cent Treasury certificates of indebtedness of Series B-1950, open on an exchange basis, par for par, to holders of Treasury certificates of indebtedness of Series B-1949, in the amount of $2,188,813,000 to mature on Feb. 1, 1949.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- Without revealing too much about what had happened in six hours of deliberations behind locked doors today, Benjamin F. Lindheimer, executive committee chairman of the All-America Football Conference, opined that the future of the 3-year-old professional league appears "very bright."

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The Foreign Office announced that Britain had formally recognized the Government in Southern Korea and that Vyvyan Holt, British Consul General in Seoul, had been named the first Charge d'Affaires.
NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Frank Leahy said today he would step down this year as athletic director at Notre Dame but would retain his position as head coach of the Irish.

Although dormant for several years, the movement to establish short stretches of several popular trout streams for fly fishing only seems to have been revived during the past few months. The tremendous increase in the number of New York fly fishermen may result in sufficient pressure to obtain legislative action.

PARIS, Jan. 18 -- The French have made substantial concessions in order to get peace in Indo-China by inducing Boo Dai to return there and assume the leadership of the Nationalists, but they have not yet agreed that the independence of the projected Viet Nam state should extend to full control of its own diplomacy, it was understood tonight.

BERLIN, Jan. 18 -- The Western Allies placed counter-restictions today on the shipment of critical materials to Soviet - controlled areas. The restrictions will be accomplished by requiring all prospective shippers to obtain permits from the Western Allies.

Good old Shakespeare has averted the scuttling of Boston's Repertory Association. Until "Richard III," with Richard Whorf in the title role, was revived Monday night at the Copley Theatre, the season had been scheduled to close Jan. 29.

On Feb. 1, the price of milk will drop for the third time since the first of the year. Whether the cut will be a cent or half a cent will not be known until Jan. 25, when the new lowered farm price formula for the Boston area is announced, a representative of the Milk Market Administrator for New York explained yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Senate confirmed Dean G. Acheson today to succeed George C. Marshall as Secretary of State. The vote was 83 to 6.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 18 -- Trans-Jordan armistice talks with Israel have passed from the Army to the Foreign Office level, according to reliable but unconfirmed reports from Jerusalem today. It is believed that both countries are eager to arrive at some workable formula before the new Palestine Conciliation Commission of the United Nations reaches here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The National Federation of Small Business protested today plans in the Senate to let the Special Small Business Committee die Feb. 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Gen. George C. Marshall, whose resignation as Secretary of State becomes effective on Thursday, said farewell to the State Department and the Foreign Service today in a message praising the organizations and their personnel.

ALBANY, N. Y., Jan. 18 -- (AP) New York's mild winter is costing the state's fifty-one public ski centers hundnreds of thousands of dollars. Only about ten centers have seen enough snow so far this season to operate, and even those have reported poor skiing conditions much of the time.

The "revolutionary" changes for medical security advocated by some Government officials would tend to create a "robot system" of medical care, Dr. Irwin E. Siris, president of the Medical Society of Kings County, warned last night.
A new blizzard struck the already hard-hit midcontinental United States yesterday, The Associated Press reported.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- Liquidation was on in the grain markets in the early trading today but heavy short covering developed and a strong rally followed, with wheat closing at gains of 1/4 to 5/8 cent a bushel and corn up 1/4 to 1/2 cent. Oats and rye lost 3/4 cent and soy beans, 1 to 2 1/4 cents.

Rayon staple imports into the United States, stimulated by the tariff reduction negotiated at Geneva, have reached the point where they seriously threaten domestic industry, it was charged yesterday by Matthew H. O'Brien, secretary of the Rayon Yarn Producers Group.

I have just read with a great deal of interest your editorial of Dec. 24 suggesting that CARE and the United Nations Association might be useful in raising funds for the International Children's Fund.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 18 -- It is not often that Argentines get a chance to laugh at the United States. By our standards, they don't laugh much, anyway, and the "lack of a sense of humor" is invariably listed by Americans here as a standard Argentine characteristic.

The Dec. 22 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES carried an editorial entitled "The Schools of Russia," based on a news item in the Dec. 21 edition signed by Benjamin Fine and headlined "Decline in Schools in Russia Reported." This in turn, judging by its internal evidence, was drawn from passages in Pravda and other Russian papers, mediated through N. Timasheff, a well-known anti-Soviet emgre now on the faculty of Fordham University.

Aubrey S. Eban, Israeli delegate to the United Nations, told an emergency conference of national Jewish organizations at the Park Sheraton Hotel last night that a restrained and "even reticent" attitude on the part of all Governments and their representatives would best serve the causes of Israel and international peace.

Three years after the war, the personal problems of veterans and members of the armed forces and their families remain a major activity of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, the chapter's annual report showed yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 18 -- John Abbink, head of the United States Economic Advisory Commission, is in the middle of a debate between Brazilians who urge more farming and immigration to utilize rich but now barren agricultural lands and Brazilians favoring a policy of industrialization.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose to new high levels for the current move yesterday, and final prices were 7 to 19 points net higher on the day.
Houston, Tex., Independent School District announced yesterday that it will receive bids on Feb. 11 for $9,196,000 of bonds dated March 10, 1949, and due on each Feb. 10 from 1955 to 1978.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- With committees of the House of Representatives ready to begin functioning, the Democratic majority lined up its lieutenants today to marshal the votes needed for or against bills that soon will be glowing.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 18 (AP) -- John F. X. Rea, a St. Louis University senior, was shot and killed today in a hotel corridor at the end of a champagne party and Police Capt. William Pleitner said a hotel guest who became angry when Rea addressed him with "Hy Stupid" is in custody.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 -- The Philadelphia Orchestra today rescheduled a tour of Britain next spring after its members had voted overwhelmingly in favor of new terms offered by Harold Fielding, British sponsor of the trip.
ROME, Jan. 18 -- The Pope today unreservedly endorsed the Marshall Plan and paid glowing tribute to the "true generosity" of the American people.

The Kleinberg Realty Corporation, represented by Joseph J. Catania, attorney, purchased the one-story business building at 1815 Pacific Street, Brooklyn, from the Kenler Realty Corporation. The property is leased to the Pacific Live Poultry Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Total public payrolls, in the country reached $1,331,000,000 in October, 1948, more than double the $649,400,000 level reported in October, 1941, the Bureau of the Census made known today.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- Representatives of eight up-state cities opposed before the Public Service Commission today the petition of the New York Telephone Company for rate rises calculated to increase company revenues about $49,000,000 annually.

The Kleinberg Realty Corporation, represented by Joseph J. Catania, attorney, purchased the one-story business building at 1815 Pacific Street, Brooklyn, from the Kenler Realty Corporation. The property is leased to the Pacific Live Poultry Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Total public payrolls, in the country reached $1,331,000,000 in October, 1948, more than double the $649,400,000 level reported in October, 1941, the Bureau of the Census made known today.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- Representatives of eight up-state cities opposed before the Public Service Commission today the petition of the New York Telephone Company for rate rises calculated to increase company revenues about $49,000,000 annually.

RHODES, Jan. 18 -- The Arab countries, except Lebanon and perhaps Trans-Jordan, will probably refuse to follow Egypt's lead in negotiating an armistice at this time, the best informed sources here believed today.

ATHENS, Jan. 18 -- Themistocles Sophoulis, who resigned the Premiership last Saturday, was reinstated tonight. King Paul appointed the 88-year-old Liberal party leader after the choice had been urged upon the sovereign by leaders of the main political parties, some of whom less than a week ago were declaring that what the nation needed most was young blood.

Never at a loss for an imaginative idea in handling scarves, Brooke Cadwallader came up with a host of amusing designs and original ideas in his spring collection yesterday at 724 Fifth Avenue. He devised brief ties to twist at the neckline of a suit or
CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- Tucker Corporation, which has lost six of its directors in the last year, announced today the election of two employes to the board.

An electronic system that makes use of some of the principles derived from radar to determine instantly the minute-by-minute size and distribution of a radio audience, received its first public demonstration last night at a meeting of the Institute of Radio Engineers.
There is no sign of an automobile price reduction nor has General Motors made any plans for a smaller automobile, C. E. Wilson, president of the Corporation, said yesterday.
The Boone and Crockett Club presented medals and certificates to thirty-four hunters last night, following the completion of the second big-game record competition conducted by the club.

Another good chance to improve their lot in the National Hockey League race was wasted by the New York Rangers last night. The Boston Bruins, even without the services of their ace defenseman, Jack Crawford, carved out a 5-to-2 triumph over the local forces to the surprise and disappointment of 8,727 fans.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 19 (AP) -- An unheralded southtpaw entrant from Houston, Tex., produced the first major upset of the national professional clay courts tennis championships today when he eliminated fourth-seeded Elwood Cooke from singles competition.

Further advances were registered yesterday in the cottonseed oil futures market on the New York Produce Exchange. In a turnover of 324 lots, final prices were 47 to 70 points higher. Trade commission houses were on both sides of the market and offerings were readily absorbed.

It will be 160 years next April since George Washington took the oath of office as the first President of the United States. During those years Inauguration Day has changed with the changes in American life. It has not lost its essential meaning, which is that this occasion marks the assumption or reassumption by one man of more than kingly powers.

Combined action by retailers, fur trade associations and manufacturers to combat misrepresentations in fur cold storage is under consideration, it was learned here yesterday. Many furriers, cleaners and small department stores are advertising cold storage facilities and are actually storing in basements or other unsuitable locations, Jack Gregory, secretary of the Certified Cold Fur Association, a national non-profit group representing the storage members of the industry, charged yesterday

Reporting on operations of the Fulton Trust Company of New York, Arthur J. Morris, president, informed shareholders at the stockholders' annual meeting yesterday that net earnings last year were $138,414, equal to $6.92 a share, exclusive of $43,594 profits on securities sold.

The pros and cons of compulsory national health insurance were advanced in a forum discussion over station WQXR last night. The program was one of the "What's on Your Mind" series of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The eleven Communist leaders lost a move yesterday to bring in an outside judge to hear their motion to prevent a trial. All the defendants have been indicted for conspiracy to organize the Communist party to teach and advocate the forcible overthrow of the Government.

A curiously interesting letter appeared Jan. 17 regarding veterans in civil service. It is curious because although written by a commander of a veterans' group, it does not represent the interest of the veteran.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 19 -- Peace parleys, the coming election and even tomorrow's release of the Egyptian sick and wounded from Faluja seemed to fade into the background today as frantic preparations went on for bringing 11,000 immigrants from the island of Cyprus.
In a stunning upset, J. L. Porter of the Yale Club defeated Norman Porster of the New York A. C. last night in the semi-final round of the Bulldog handicap squash tennis tournament at the Yale Club.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 19 -- The National Canners Association charged today that continued confusion and uncertainty in the legal rules governing the propriety of delivered pricing, freight absorption and the meeting of competition by individual sellers constitute a serious impediment to the American economy.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 19 -- Army registered its second basketball victory of the season today, defeating a gallant but outmanned Wililams five at the academy field house, 72 -- 45. The triumph ended a three-game losing streak for the cadets.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 19 -- In a wild melange of fast-break basketball, a resurgent Yale quintet defeated Fordham, 85 -- 75, before a capacity crowd of 3,000 in the Payne Whitney Gymnasium tonight.
TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 19 (AP) -- Federal Judge Phillip Forman today convicted the General Electric Company and eight other lamp supply manufacturers of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

The Lafayette Hotel and its restaurant at University Place and Ninth Street, which for many years have catered to lovers of leisurely old-world living, will close on March 31, it was announced yesterday.

An old-fashioned "wayz goose" -- a festival at which all classes of the printing industry used to get together to celebrate the completion of a Job -- was held here yesterday for the first time in more than a century, it was believed.

Gaston Reiff of Braine-L'Alleud, Belgium, a clerk for a Brussels sports magazine and a foot-racer of international fame, arrived at New York International Airport last night on a Sabena Airlines' DC-6. He is the Olympic 5,000-meter champion and is here to appear in four track meets, in the last of which he hopes to add our National indoor three-mile title to his collection.

Underwriting syndicates will place on the market here today bonds and preferred stock of public utility and industrial companies having a par value of more than $19,000,000. The offerings are as follows:

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 19 -- The Polish Government's propaganda services in Belgrade made an overt bid today to subvert the second congress of the Serbian Communist party now meeting in this city. The bid was made through a bold display of Communist Information Bulletin slogans placed on exhibit in the ground floor windows of the Warsaw Government's reading room and library.

Ratification by this country of the proposal that the Inter-Governmental Maritime Consultative Organization become an arm of the United Nations will be strongly opposed by the National Federation of American Shipping, it was reported yesterday.

The measure passed by the City Council setting up a Traffic Commission and with it a Department of Traffic is not perfect, and we assume that as time demonstrates the need amendment will follow. Some further steps to relieve the parking space shortage, which depend on a financing agency, are purposely omitted from this legislation.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 19 -- Hussein Cahid Yalcin, chairman of the United Nations Palestine Commission, today cabled the Security Council that the commission hoped that Dr. Bunche would be able to continue presiding over the Rhodes negotiations until their conclusion.

Prof. Ephraim Cross of the Romance Language Department at City College has denied a statement attributed to him in a story printed Tuesday in THE NEW YORK TIMES about charges of anti-Semitic discrimination against Prof. William E. Knickerbocker, head of the department.

Miss Sonja Henie, 1928 Olympic champion, and her Hollywood Ice Revue will present the first of seventeen performances at Madison Square Garden tonight. This will mark the twelfth annual show of its kind and the figure skating star will be featured in six numbers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- House Republican leaders have found that instead of facing difficulty in getting members to serve on the controverted Committee on Un-American Activities, their principal task is the picking of only two men from a growing list of volunteers and those who are being urged to make themselves available for appointment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The Democratic leaders expect to clear through committee and present to the House floor within about a week a bill authorizing the entry into the United States of 400,000 European displaced persons in the next four years.

Now that at long last our people realize that we cannot isolate ourselves from the rest of the world and that this nation has become a great world power, it seems timely that we should give serious thought to the improvement of our first line of defense, which is our Department of State.

The longest inaugural speech ever to be delivered was made by the oldest man ever to be elected President of the United States, the 68-year-old hero of Tippecanoe, William Henry Harrison. The shortest inaugural address, 134 words in all, was delivered by another American war hero, George Washington, at his second inauguration, in Philadelphia on March 4, 1793.
Several voluble stockholders of the Continental Bank and Trust Company, in liquidation, expressed sharp criticism and a charge of betraya at the annual meeting yesterday at 30 Broad Street.

Regular visits to the aged, the sick and the lonely are part of the Salvation Army's work. Last year a large number of women between the ages of 65 and 90 received vacations at the Army's Sunset Lodge in New Jersey.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Three groups interested in civil liberties and freedom of speech were allowed today to intervene in the prosecution of five Baltimore radio stations for their news broadcasts about a murder.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- An official of the Department of Agriculture estimated today that the Government may have $1,000,000,000 tied up in the cotton price-support program by the end of the 1949 crop year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- President Truman announced today that when he takes the oath of office tomorrow his hand will rest on two Bibles, one opened at the Sermon on The Mount and the other at The Ten Commandments. He especially recommended the Tenth Commandment for observance in this capital city.
The Irving Trust Company was one of two New York banks that showed an increase in its deposits during 1948, William N. Enstrom, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting held yesterday.

The Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, CIO, reported yesterday that it had "cracked" the solid front of unorganized Fifth Avenue department stores by signing up an "overwhelming majority" of the employes of Bonwit Teller.

A television production of the last act of Puccini's "La Boheme," using a new English translation, will be presented by NBC next Thursday night from 10:15 to 10:45 over its East Coast video network from its studio here.

Winter flailed the western part of the nation with blizzards, floods and a bitter cold wave yesterday and raked some Midwestern and Eastern sections with destructive winds, The Associated Press reported.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UP) -- Controller Lindsay C. Warren tonight blasted the Hoover commission on government reorganization for a plan calling for sharp cuts in the staff and functions of the General Accounting Office, which Mr. Warren heads.

The plan of several railroads to charge an extra 50 cents to $1 for reserved coach seats received a setback yesterday as a result of the Public Service Commission's ban on the added charge for rides within this state, pending a public nearing on Feb. 10.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 19 (AP) -- Fred W. Hooper picked off the lion's share of the $10,000 added Hibiscus Stakes at Hialeah Park today when his entry of Ocean Drive and Olympia finished first and second. S. I. Crew's Commodore Lea was third in the six-furlong feature and Isidor Bieber's Palestinian ran fourth.

The extent to which public utility financing dominated the new issues of preferred stock put out last year is pointed up by a survey of preferred stock offerings in 1948 just put out by the Union Securities Corporation. Of the seventy-six issues of preferred stock marketed, thirty-eight represented public utility financing, the rest representing issues of industrial, finance, brewery, liquor, chain and department store and baking companies.

Two "new looks" for 1949 were offered yesterday by the Pontiac division of the General Motors Corporation in the new Chieftain and Streamliner series. The cars will go on public display today at the opening of the General Motors show at the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The Vice President-elect, Senator Alben W. Barkley, and the Democratic floor leader, Senator Scott W. Lucas, have given assurances to labor spokesmen that repeal of the Taft-Hartley law will be in the forefront of Senate consideration at an early date.
Night cloaked New York in mid-afternoon yesterday.

A one-man fabric show took place in the Cottage at the Hampshire House yesterday noon. The woolens were all by John Walther Fabrics, Inc. Thirty coat and suit designers participated. The display told an arresting spring fabric story.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures, to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The Export-Import Bank authorized today a credit of $35,000,000 to the State of Israel to assist in financing the purchase in this country of equipment, materials and services for the development of agricultural products.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- Two constitutional amendments relating to the proposed modernization of the judicial system in the City of New York were introduced in the Legislature today. They are part of a series of measures being prepared to carry out the recommendations of New York bar associations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- About twelve Republicans in the House of Representatives are prepared to join the party move, started in the Senate, to sponsor a low-rent housing bill to counter Administration proposals.

Progress in a mediation session between representatives of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad and Lodge 497 of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers was reported yesterday. Both sides met in a six-hour session with Ross Foran of the National Mediation Board, whose eleventh-hour intervention on Tuesday postponed for seven days a strike set for early yesterday morning.

IT couldn't have come as a surprise to anyone. There had been a faint hope, of course, that a change might be made but it was much too flimsy a hope for folks to have put much faith in it. However, the august Football Rules Committee has decided to continue the highly controversial free substitution rule with some relatively inconsequential alterations and that means we'll have gridiron mob scenes for at least another season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- President Truman, like other non-smokers, picks up cigars at banquets to pass them on to his friends. He took three today at the luncheon of the Democratic National Finance Committee.

MADISON, N. J., Jan. 19 -- Leonard S. Hentz, a retired New York cotton broker, left trust funds of $100,000 and $1,800 cash to each of two elderly maids who had worked for $20 a week for more than twenty years on his estate here, under the terms of his will, probated in Morristown today.

Replying to the new Communist "peace offensive," now backed by the Soviet Embassy in Washington, Under-Secretary of State Lovett has, in effect, called on the Soviet Government to demonstrate its purposes by deeds instead of words; he suggests that the Berlin blockade and the Austrian negotiations provide Moscow with opportunities to furnish proof of its good faith.
BERLIN, Jan. 19 -- German Communists are falling into line and endorsing the Soviet Union's new peace propaganda line first expressed by Communist leaders in France and Italy.
The cotton futures market yesterday closed irregular on the New York Cotton Exchange, 8 points higher to 4 points lower, with the near months showing the most strength.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 19 -- President Juan Peron's economic regime underwent its greatest shake-up today.

More than 1,000 persons turned up last night for the first of the three subscription concerts that William H. Schiede's Bach Aria Group is giving this winter at Town Hall. So large an audience for so specialized an event was a token of the group's success last season in a smaller hall.

RHODES, Jan. 19 -- The Egyptian-Israeli armistice talks here have struck an obstacle in disagreement over the line to be drawn between their forces. Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine, devoted today to drafting a compromise agreement for study by both sides in the hope that they would each make sufficient concessions for the work to go on.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- Grain markets closed at about the top on the Board of Trade today, showing a firm undertone from the start, wheat advanced 5/8 cent to 1 1/8 cents, corn and oats 7/8 cent to 1 1/8 cents, rye 2 1/4 cents and soy beans 3 to 3 1/4 cents.

The Union Square subway station, center of the shopping and business area around Fourteenth Street, was crowded at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon when a woman and a small girl appeared and, holding hands, picked their way along the northbound express platform of the IRT.

Rescue operations in a rough sea by seamen of the S. S. Junior were dramatically described in the log of the 7,000-ton United Fruit Company freighter. The vessel picked up eighty-three survivors from the burning Coast Guard cutter Eastwind and took them to Staten Island.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Tomorrow will mark a dual celebration for Mrs. Marion Truitt, daughter of the Vice President-elect, Senator Alben W. Barkley.

The Medical Society of Kings County at a meeting that ended early yesterday voted against the American Medical Association's plan to assess each member $25 to fight a national health insurance system and later voted to disregard the ballot and hold a secret one on Feb. 15.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- President and Mrs. Truman, Miss Margaret Truman and their house-party of Midwestern relatives and friends made the Washington social rounds today in pre-inaugural celebration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that its program for supporting producer prices of eggs during 1949 will be substantially the same as that for 1947 and 1948. It will reflect 90 per cent of parity on a national annual average basis as required by farm law.

NANKING, Jan. 19 -- After a post-war sojourn here lasting two years, eight months and fifteen days, the Chinese Central Government served official notice on foreign diplomats today that it was again moving its capital -- this time to Canton.
TORONTO, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens played rings around a disorganized band of Maple Leafs tonight to hand Toronto a 4-1 defeat before 14,347 fans.
PARIS, Jan. 19 -- French iron and steel production in 1948 made marked gains over the 1947 production and is now well ahead of that recorded in 1938, statistics published today revealed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 19 -- Samuel Goldwyn today carried his fight against the major motion-picture producers to the press with a stinging verbal blast against Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, from which Goldwyn announced his resignation yesterday.

National brands of hosiery can be sold through wholesalers upon presentation of proof that the job can be done efficiently and at less cost than direct selling, it was pointed out yesterday by Virgil D. Reed, associate director of research, J. Walter Thompson Company, advertising agency.
Frank Parker, member of the United States Davis Cup team and former national champion, left yesterday on a tennis trip overseas.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- Frank C. Moore, State Controller, disclosed today that the Federal Bureau of Internal Revenue has ruled that the allowance for quarters and subsistence furnished state institutional employes is subject to Federal income taxes.

"The Shop at Sly Corner" will go out of business on Saturday. Buffeted generally by adverse notices, the Edward Percy thriller, starring Boris Karloff, has decided to quit the Booth Theatre after a total of seven performances. The murder tale was produced by Gant Gaither.

Television receiver servicing presents no appreciable problem to dealers despite fears that it would prove to be a merchandising "bugaboo," Frank W. Mansfield, sales research director, Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., declared yesterday.

Robert Dean Frisbie was a man who made a world of his own in the South Seas. He shared it with a lovely young Polynesian wife and the five children she bore him. He shared it also with the charmed readers of his stories, "The Book of Puka Puka," "My Tahiti," and others.
BOSTON, Jan. 19 -- A record-breaking budget of $208,519,459 was presented to the Massachusetts Legislature tonight by the incoming Democratic Governor, Paul A. Dever.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The professional staff of the House Education and Labor Committee and some of the clerical staff were reported to have been dismissed summarily today and locked out of their offices. It was asserted that Representative John Lesinski of Michigan, the chairman, acted in violation of the Legislative Reorganization Act of 1946.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- The possibility that sabotage was, responsible for the disappearance Monday of the British South American Airways Tudor IV Star Ariel with twenty persons between Bermuda and Kingston, Jamaica, was raised here today by Sir Roy Dobson, managing director of A. V. Roe Co., Ltd., makers of Tudor planes.
CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- Hopes for peace between the embattled All-America Conference and the National Football League apparently waned today.

Charles Baskerville, portrait and mural artist, will leave New York by plane Tuesday on a world trip on which he expects to become the first American artist to enter the kingdom of Nepal, deep in the Himalaya Mountains.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- Thomas E. Dewey told the State Agricultural Society tonight he was "really delighted" he was still Governor of New York, referring to tomorrow's inauguration of his Democratic rival as President of the United States.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Army Quartermaster market center announced today the purchase of almost 10,000,000 pounds of meat from Argentina for military feeding requirements in the European command.

Whittaker Chambers, self-confessed former courier for a Communist espionage group, and Time, Inc., which until recently employed him as a senior editor, were sued for plagiarism in Federal Court yesterday.

No opposition to the City Planning Commission's proposal of last June to set up a master plan for a Manhattan Civic Center in the Foley Square area near City Hall was heard yesterday at a public hearing before the agency.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- President Truman asserted tonight that his supreme interest was to see the United States assume the world leadership that God had intended.

In the death of Benjamin M. Anderson the nation has lost one of its outstanding economists. He combined with clear, rigorous and original thinking the gift of equally clear and forceful writing. He combined, also with a sure theoretical grasp of his subject, the realistic and detailed study necessary in dealing with practical problems.

Although unable to be present, Citation, triple crown winner, was honored as one of sport's top performers of 1948 along with ten athletes at the dinner sponsored last night at the Hotel Astor by Sport magazine. A gathering of 1,000 attended the affair.

Eighteen months after their conviction in August, 1947, I. James Brody, former deputy commissioner of Marine and Aviation, and James V. Auditore, one-time "millionaire stevedore," surrendered in General Sessions yesterday to begin serving prison terms for conspiring in illicit deals on renting city-owned piers.

What is described as a "candid guide for people considering advertising careers" has been prepared by the American Association of Advertising Agencies as part of its examination program for attracting high-caliber personnel, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The United States Embassy in Nanking notified the State Department today that the Nationalist Government had informed the foreign dip- lomatic corps there of its intention to move to Canton and that the corps was now considering the question.

The Port of New York Authority carefully safeguarded its claimed immunity to suit yesterday when it appeared before Supreme Court Justice Thomas J. Cuff in special term at Jamaica, Queens, in answer to a complaint by eight airlines to compel observance of the leases taken over from the city for the New York International Airport at Idlewild.
After being totally blind two years and partly blind for six, Carl Klein, 40-year-old horticulturist, awakened from a brief sleep at 1 A. M. yesterday, able to see.
Wrestling will return to Madison Square Garden.
A sole blinker signal, pleading for help out of the early morning gloom, dispatched the freighter Suzanne's lifeboat to the rescue of survivors from the Coast Guard cutter Eastwind.

The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York started yesterday at a breakfast meeting at the Commodore Hotel a twelve-day "man-to-man" solicitation effort, to be headed by five former presidents, as a feature of its current campaign for $16,500,000. The drive is still $3,900,000 short of its goal.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UP) -- President Truman blocked a strike on Northwest Airlines today by appointing an emergency fact-finding board to investigate a wage dispute between the company and the International Association of Machinists.

J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., had net earnings of $3,371,346 in 1948, compared with earnings of $2,978.963 in 1947, the gain being largely due to higher interest yields on a larger volume of loans and to profits on investment securities. A report of the year's operations was made yesterday to the annual meeting of the bank's stockholders by George Whitney, president.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- A new drive to get the state to increase its contribution toward the support of public libraries in all sections of the state got under way here today with the reintroduction of the Wilson-Mahoney bills calling for a grant of $2,000,000.

While there are many psychiatrists who are competent diagnosticians, there are not enough qualified to give treatment to the many people who are demanding intensive help with their emotional problems. In the opinion of many authorities this is the most pressing problem psychiatry faces today.

BERLIN, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Two major decisions of the Nuremberg war crimes trials were upheld today by Gen. Lucius D. Clay. The United States commander affirmed the sentences against a group of German generals convicted of excesses in the Balkans and leaders of Adolf Hitler's infamous "People's Courts."

The second volume of a three-volume biography of John C. Calhoun by Charles M. Wiltse has been scheduled for March publication by Bobbs-Merrill. Its title is "John C. Calhoun: Nullifier, 1829-1839." The first volume, issued late in 1944, was entitled "John C. Calhoun: Nationalist."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that the United States exported 8,764,000 long tons, or about 338,380,000 bushels, of grain and grain products during the last half of 1948. This was a record for a six-month period.
The Title Guarantee and Trust Company is not for sale, Barnard Townsend, president, declared yesterday at the sixty-sixth annual stockholders' meeting of that institution.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 19 -- The complete withdrawal of Dutch troops from the whole territory of Indonesia and the transfer of full sovereignty to the Indonesian Republican Government by September of this year is the basic demand of the Indonesian Republic that will be considered by the Asian conference meeting here tomorrow.

To a greeting from 1,297 fans paying receipts of $3,482, and the music of a jazz band, the Tournament of Champions, Inc., launched its local boxing activities last night at Manhattan Center, but it's accompaniment of thudding fists was only a desultory, muted overtone.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 -- Eight freighters of the C-3 type have been purchased by the Luckenbach Steamship Company from the Maritime Commission and will be put into the intercoastal trade after four to six months, according to the company's local office.

Greater abundance of textiles has lowered the annual turnover rate of wholesale dry goods merchants, according to John R. Bromell, chief wholesale specialist, marketing division, Department of Commerce.
HANKOW, China, Jan. 19 -- It is authoritatively reported here that Gen. Pai Chung-hsi is preparing to withdraw his armies to his mountain-ringed Provincial capital at Kweilin.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- A trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board condemned today the union-shop provision of the agreement between the United Mine Workers and the soft coal mines of eighteen steel companies.

Mayor William O'Dwyer, accompanied by Deputy Mayor John J. Bennett and Controller Lazarus Joseph, left City Hall at 3:30 P. M. yesterday on a motor trip to Washington to attend President Truman's inauguration. They planned to spend the night in Baltimore.

Skirts with side-jutting folds or graceful moderate fullness and low oval necklines that barely covered the shoulders were two treatments that appeared frequently in the Andre D'Aulan showing yesterday at the Pierre Hotel presented for the benefit of CARE.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 19 -- Despite the fall of Tientsin to Chinese Communist forces, the relief work of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund is being allowed to continue without interference, Maurice Pate, executive director of the relief agency, said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Emphasizing that present supplies of iron and steel scrap "would be inadequate in the event of any emergency," Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, warned today against over-optimism in evaluating current inventories of scrap.

The inauguration of President Truman is expected to be seen today by a record-breaking television audience extending from Boston to St. Louis. Starting at 11:30 A. M., the ceremonies will be carried by virtually every station within reach of television's existing network facilities, including WNBT, WCBS-TV, WJZ-TV and WABD in New York.
The Newark Bears, Triple A farm club which the Yankees put up for sale some time ago, will not leave Newark if the city commission has anything to say about it.

As the ninety-sixth annual meeting of the American Society of Civil Engineers opened yesterday in the Commodore Hotel, 1,300 members heard highway construction and sanitary engineers recite the needs for better future planning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Ten Hardy members of the Women's Army Corps will troop up cold, blustery and snow-covered Mount Washington, New Hampshire, this week-end to find out whether a girl can "stay warm and comfortable in a standard G parka."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Marcus Heiman of New York, it was learned today, registered with Congress on Jan. 12 as a lobbyist for the E Street Theatre Corporation, of which he is president.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture got more bad news today on potatoes and the problem of supporting prices for producers.

PARIS, Jan. 19 -- At a Cabinet meeting today the French Government decided to grant de facto recognition to the State of Israel on condition that satisfactory assurances for the protection of French interests in Palestine resulted from negotiations soon to begin.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, said today that the armed forces had reached the personnel strength proposed for them by President Truman's budget for the 1950 fiscal year.

HOF, Germany, Jan. 19 -- A United States official said today that the Russian zonal administration had invited him to spend a thirty-day holiday in the Soviet Union -- but that he had declined the offer.

Chief City Magistrate Edgar Bromberger told Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson yesterday morning that the Magistrate's Courts would need $925,921 additional to operate efficiently in the coming fiscal year. Mr. Bromberger said that $2,208,256 had been received for present budget needs, but that $3,134,177 was necessary for 1949-50.

TOKYO, Jan. 19 -- The Japanese Government hopes this year to supplement its coastal patrol, against which the Russians have already protested, by about fifteen modern ships modeled after United States revenue cutters it was revealed today.

Five hundred garden enthusiasts from New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania filled Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, yesterday afternoon for the first meeting in the ninth annual midwinter garden course of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- An investigation was reported today to have been completed here by United States and British officials into charges that Great Britain made money by exporting to the United States scrap created from processing aluminum supplied to her by the Economic Cooperation Administration.

There should be widespread support for a concurrent resolution which has been introduced at Albany by Senator Stokes, Republican, and Assemblyman Mauhs, Democrat, reaffirming the principle that the Forest Preserve of the state must be kept inviolate. This principle was approved by both major parties in the Constitutional Conventions of 1894 and 1938.

ROME, Jan. 19 -- Shortly before his departure by plane this evening for New York and Washington, James D. Zellerbach, European Recovery Program Administrator, accused the Italian Communist party of attempting to wreck the Marshall Plan "under the guise of social and economic betterment of workers."

Two new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Radio City Music Hall, the attraction is "A Letter to Three Wives," a Twentieth Century-Fox romantic comedy featuring Linda Darnell, Ann Sothern, Jeanne Crain, Kirk Douglas and Paul Douglas. Joseph L. Mankiewicz, who directed, wrote the screen play from an adaptation by Vera Caspary and a novel by John Klempner.

NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 19 -- James A. Wadsworth, special assistant to Paul G. Hoffman, Administrator of the Economic Cooperation Administration, declared today that the ECA "can claim to have stemmed 'an iron curtain' ideology."

Candies made in the Italian fashion and pastries with a Swiss flavor are the special attractions at Armando's. This shop which opened yesterday at 971 Lexington Avenue, is well prepared for making sweets that are authentically European.
LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Prime Minister Attlee broadcast an appeal to Britons tonight to support the Government's defense program and help to bring "freedom from fear."

Proposals for rezoning many blocks east of Second Avenue "to bring about orderly development of residential, business and commercial districts in the area" will be pressed this year by the First Avenue Association, John A. Cahill, president, reported at the annual meeting of the organization yesterday in the Beekman Tower Hotel.

Philco Corporation yesterday introduced its 1949 television receiver line which features substantially enlarged pictures in sets using ten and twelve-inch direct view cathode ray tubes at a press preview in Sherry's Restaurant. The company's ten-inch tube sets produce a sixty-one square-inch picture and twelve-inch tube units give a ninety square-inch picture.

Louis Schleifer, operator, who last week sold the Hotel Empire, a 600-room building occupying the blockfront on the south side of West Sixty-third Street from Broadway to Columbus Avenue, to Chicago interests, yesterday acquired a hotel property in the Times Square area with the purchase of the ten-story Hotel America, 145-55 West Forty-seventh Street, between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue.

The one-story factory building at 22-19 Thirty-seventh Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by Cole Laboratories, Inc., to Hechler Brothers, Inc., of New York City, who will occupy it as offices and for the manufacture of hearing aid accessories.

Prince, a 2-year-old black collie-shepherd of Elmhurst, Queens, was officially declared yesterday to be a good dog. The court decision, however, did not settle the difference of opinion about Prince between his mistress and his master and so left the dog's fate somewhat in doubt.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 19 -- Alexandre Parodi, French representative on the United Nations Security Council, will return to Paris early in February to take p his new duties as Secretary General of the French Foreign Ministry, usually reliable sources said today.

None too happy about the situation but hopeful that an agreement will be reached, Walker Cooper, New York Giants' catcher, said last night that he has been asked to take a $7,500 cut in salary for the 1949 National League season.

Ralph S. Damon, president of American Airlines, Inc., and vice president of American Overseas Airlines, Inc., resigned from both positions yesterday, saying he was "increasingly out of sympathy with the management programs and policies of American Airlines, including the proposed sale of American Overseas Airlines" to Pan American Airways.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Jan. 19 -- Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, director of the Institute for Advanced Study, called tonight for "openness and freedom of communication" as the only direct path to world peace.

An issue of $8,000,000 of bonds of Consolidated School District No. 1, East Baton Rouge, La., was sold yesterday to an underwriting syndicate headed jointly by the Northern Trust Company and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 101.799 for 2 1/2s for bonds due Feb. 1, 1950 to 1968, an interest cost of 2.34 per cent.

Ten Coast Guard men died and twenty-one were burned or scalded aboard the Coast Guard icebreaker Eastwind when their vessel was rammed amidships in pre-dawn fog yesterday by the Gulf Oil Corporation tanker Gulfstream, sixty miles southeast of Barnegat on the New Jersey coast.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Stimulated by a strong demand for the new Austrailian 3 per cent conversion loan totaling 18,000,000 ($72,000,000), gilt edge issues made gains up to an eighth in the stock market here today. The initial premium for the loan was five-eighths point, but later it touched seven-eighths and closed around thirteen-sixteenths.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- Uncertainty and hesitation over the buyers' market offer newspapers their greatest opportunity for showing more advertisers the value of planned advertising in newspapers, members of the American Newspaper Advertising Executives Association heard today at their annual convention here.

The stock market made a small gain yesterday, overcoming persistent indecision in a last-minute rally. Closing quotations on the Stock Exchange showed gains of fractions to more than a point, with the average up 0.52 point.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 12, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:
BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Netherlands Prime Minister William Drees, who has been surveying Indonesian conditions for two weeks, will leave for Holland tomorrow by plane.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 19 -- Scientific studies by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the fatal shooting of Granville K. Baker, 27-year-old banking heir, upset tonight explanations of local investigators but did little to explain the mysterious death.

A defeat-crazed Republican chef could not have created a worse-planned meal than the Truman-Barkley Clubs dinner held Tuesday night in Washington, Peter Greig, a leading food and wine authority, said here yesterday.

GENEVA, Jan. 15 -- The delay and expense involved in obtaining military permits for truck drivers entering or crossing Western Germany is seriously hindering the growth of economical highway transport in Europe, the International Road Transport Union charged here today.

Ocean tonnage passing through Stockton, California's "inland seaport," increased 94 per cent during 1948 despite the three-months' Pacific Coast maritime strike, according to Elmo E. Ferrari, Port Director.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration is sending a special mission to Europe to determine "the irreducible needs of Marshall Plan countries for Western Hemisphere aluminum, lead and other metals for which their own scrap supplies cannot be substituted.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19 -- The twenty-six Federal Savings and Loan Associations in this city, which held their annual meetings today, reported aggregate assets of $150,127,038 as of last Dec. 31, compared with $141,596,858 in 1947.

Mayor O'Dwyer could not be present last night to receive the first annual Freedom Award presented by the Freedom Lodge of B'nai B'rith at ceremonies held in the auditorium of the Joan of Arc Junior High School, 154 West Ninety-third Street.

The nation's gasoline stocks rose 2,108,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they were 109,219,000 barrels, compared with 107,111,000 a week earlier and 98,751,000 a year before.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Hundreds of thousands of people, their numbers increasing every hour, had swarmed into the capital tonight for the inauguration tomorrow of Harry S. Truman and Alben W. Barkley as President and Vice President of the United States.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Following are the texts of President Truman's informal talks at a luncheon of the Democratic National Financial Committee and the Electoral College dinner tonight:

PARIS, Jan. 19 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations formally abandoned the World Federation of Trade Unions today. The British Trades Union Congress and the Dutch Federation of Labor also left the organization, which they have denounced as a Communist propaganda agency.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 19 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has signed John Ford to a one-picture deal under which he will direct "Pinky," a photoplay dealing with "social conditions in the South," according to the studio. The film will be personally produced by Darryl F. Zanuck, Fox production chief, late in the spring.

SHREWSBURY, N. J., Jan. 19 -- Elmer Elsworth Lever, octogenarian metal worker, has never had time to think much about better mousetraps. But he does know, and he makes, better weather vanes. Consequently he was still hard at work today in his small shop here, trying to catch up on orders after sixty-nine years in which he has been too busy to find out for himself which way the wind was blowing.

Average price increases up to 7.5 per cent on 1949 Chevrolet cars were announced yesterday by W. F. Armstrong, general manager of the Chevrolet division of the General Motors Corporation. He cited increased tooling and re-conversion costs in the development and manufacture of the new models as reasons for the price rise.

The Institutional Securities Corporation, wholly owned mortgage and real estate servicing company of the savings banks of New York State, made $17,098,037 of new mortgage loans last year, Robert E. Pratt, president, announced yesterday at the annual stockholders' meeting.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- The Halpern-Delgiorno bill that would have made Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, a virtual dictator of Federal and municipal housing projects was killed in the Senate and Assembly today. The proposal had aroused the vigorous opposition of Thomas F. Farrell, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, and of civic groups.

Stockholders of Manufacturers Trust Company at their annual meeting yesterday voted to increase the authorized capital stock of the bank from $41,250,000, represented by 2,062,500 shares, to $45,000,000, represented by 2,250,000 shares.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Robert A. Lovett, Acting Secretary of State, called today for official Soviet actions rather than the words of individual Communists if there was to be a convincing demonstration of a change of attitude by the Kremlin in the direction of improved relations with the West.

DETROIT, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Norman (Bud) Poile's 40-foot sizzler in the last eight minutes of play broke a 1-all tie to give the Detroit Red Wings a 2-1 National Hockey League victory over Chicago tonight before 13,155 fans.

Encased in a plastic shell, a glistening automobile engine revolved under a spotlight in topsy-turvy gyrations yesterday at a preview of the General Motors show at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The rest of the 200 exhibits emphasized the farflung scope of the automotive industry.
The West Virginia Coal Coke Corporation. in its preliminary statement covering operations for last year, reported yesterday that its net profit was $2,659.597, after taxes and all deductions.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- An attempt by Winston Churchill to blame Foreign Secretary Bevin for having sent out the British reconnaissance aircraft that were shot down twelve days ago by Israeli fighters was rejected today by Prime Minister Attlee. Addressing the House of Commons, Mr. Attlee took the responsibility for himself and his Cabinet as a whole.

A large movement of Air Force personnel by air from the New York area to Burtonwood, England, took place yesterday. The flight of 301 officers and airmen aboard eight chartered airliners that departed from La Guardia Airport and New York International Airport, at Idlewild, Queens, was said not to be an emergency, however.
PARIS, Jan. 19 -- The changes now taking place in the structure of the Greek Government are designed to accomplish two objectives.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19 -- The Metropolitan Opera Company will return to Los Angeles this spring for its second season under the sponsorship of Greater Los Angeles Plans, Inc., according to announcement made yesterday by Ray W. Smith, vice president and executive secretary of the latter organization.

PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 19 (UP) -- Theodore A. Penland, 99, commander-in-chief of the Grand Army of the Republic, tonight reluctantly canceled his plan to attend President Truman's inauguration despite last-minute assurances that he would be warmly received in Washington.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- During the period Jan. 12-18, member bank reserve balances decreased $44,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 19 -- Shareholders in the Cleveland Trust Company, at their annual meeting today, approved an increase in the bank's capital stock from $13,800,000 to $15,000,000.

So far as occupational classifications are concerned, substantial changes are becoming apparent in the growing number of immigrants to this country, according to an analysis reported yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

BOCHUM, Germany, Jan. 19 -- A British Military Government magistrate, sitting in summary court in the trial of seven Germans accused of having disobeyed a Military Government order to dismantle a steel plant declared today that the British Military Government was not bound by The Hague Convention.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Cubs came up with another surprise today in their campaign to shed the memory of a dismal 1948 season. They signed Mort Cooper, 34-year-old former pitching star of the Cardinals.

It is always a pleasure to read in THE TIMES a column by Anne O'Hare McCormick. Her sagacity, lively perceptions and journalistic clarity are unmatched in the field of political reporting. The article dated from Athens, Jan. 4, is noteworthy, like all her others, for its concision and clear expression of what's what and why.

Award of the Capt. Charles W. Brown Memorial Medal for 1948 to David Krause of St. Louis, a blind man with a fine record of accomplishment, was announced yesterday by Dr. Robert B. Irwin, sightless executive director of the American Foundation for the Blind.

Your Warsaw correspondent, Sydney Gruson, states in his Jan. 2 dispatch that "the (Polish) Government won a grudging acceptance from the majority of the people." This statement is rather surprising in view of the fact that Mr. Gruson wrote the dispatch only a few days after his return to Poland.
Plaid patterns, shades of blue and two-tone yarns to enliven textured rugs were among highlights of the new carpeting shown yesterday by Firth, 295 Fifth Avenue.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- Dr. Wilhelm Furtwaengler withdrew today as a prospective guest conductor for the Chicago Symphony Orchestra next fall. He cabled his withdrawal after discussing with officials of the Orchestral Association the public controversy which had arisen over his having directed the Berlin State Opera under the Nazis.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 19 -- Trans-Jordan is ready -- even impatient -- for peace with Israel. King Abdullah, his Government and the Arab Legion are only waiting for the right occasion to enter formally into negotiations that have been going on informally and intermittently for the last two months.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Hungarian Government made public today a Yellow Book on the case of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, who is held in jail, to document its charge of espionage and treason against the Roman Catholic Primate.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The country's coal mines were safer in 1948 than in any year since the Government started keeping records in 1910, the Bureau of Mines said today in a report based on the number of miners killed or injured in relation to coal produced.

PARIS, Jan. 19 -- Victor Kravchenko, author of "I Chose Freedom," said here tonight that he would bring suit for libel against the Paris Communist-line afternoon paper Ce Soir over an article that appeared today He already has one libel suit drawn up against the Communist weekly Les Lettres Francaises and has another action against one of its writers, Andre Wurmser.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The first draft of an-Israeli-Lebanese armistice agreement was written today at the Lebanese frontier village of Ras en Naqura, a reliable source said here.

BERLIN, Jan. 19 -- Spearheaded by the Taegliche Rundschau, Soviet Army newspaper, the Eastern zone press has released a number of broadsides in the direction of the recently formed Military Security Board for Western Germany.

Rosita Renard, who played at Carnegie Hall last night after an absence from New York of more than twenty years, proved to be a pianist of refinement and touching humanity. Not many pianists today, male or female. can match the sheer sustained beauty of this Chilean's singing tone or the subtlety and delicacy of her perceptions.

ATHENS, Jan. 19 -- The Greek Government formed on a broadened base under Themistocles Sophouils' Premiership is expected to be sworn in tomorrow morning. However, no one can be sure. It would appear that never before in Greek politics has the distance between the cup and the lip been more circuitous or fraught with such unpredictable hazard.

The special Federal grand jury investigating subversive activities heard testimony yesterday from Karl Amatneek, 37-year-old electrical engineer who attended the school of engineering at Cooper Union in the early Thirties, when Felix August Inslerman was a student there.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- The United States Government will shortly announce the appointment of Maj. Gen. Clarence R. Huebner, tactical commander of the American occupation forces in Germany, as "observer" with the Western Union Chiefs of Staff, it is expected here.

Consumer response to the wave of men's clothing promotions thus far this month has been favorable and has cut down retail inventories appreciably, it was reported here yesterday. The announced reductions of 20 per cent or more have produced a highly competitive situation at retail, but indications are that the cuts are spurring both unit and dollar turnover.

A move to raise the Savings Bank Life Insurance Fund above its present limit of $500,000 should be considered, Elliott V. Bell, Superintendent of Banks of the State of New York, said last night at the tenth anniversary dinner of the Savings Bank Life Insurance Fund at the Commodore Hotel.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 19 -- Negotiations are far advanced between the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and Belgium for release here of the banks' first bond issue open to public subscription anywhere outside the United States.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 20 (UP) -- A naval expedition now en route to Antarctica will establish a new Chilean base below the Antarctic Circle, the deepest penetration of the frozen continent by this country, it was reported today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- The National Security Resources Board, in arranging for the quick expansion and conversion of industry that would be demanded for all-out mobilization, is developing a program seeking to simplify paper work, utilize small industry to greater extent, establish regional organizations and prepare complete mobilization plans for each individual industry.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- Grain markets other than corn showed a heavy undertone today on the Board of Trade. Buying of corn by cash interests, regarded as removal of hedges against sales of actual grain to the Government, resulted in closing prices being 3/8 cent a bushel higher to 1/4 cent lower than yesterday.

The Law Center Foundation of New York University will begin dispossess proceedings on Monday to evict tenants from the Washington Square block on which the new Law Center will be located, Russell D. Niles, dean of the Law School, said last night.
Harold E. Stassen, president of the University of Pennsylvania, will make an appearance Tuesday at 9 P. M. as guest host on "We, the People," which CBS carries over both its audio and video networks.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Herbert S. Morrison, leader of the House of Commons, announced today that the debate on Palestine that was promised after the recent outburst of attacks on Britain's policy would be held next Wednesday.

An odd-looking vessel, her bow sheathed with protective steel plating and her stern resembling an excursion boat, will leave the Todd Shipyards Corporation's Hoboken yard tomorrow morning on a 12,000-mile maiden voyage to her home port, Shanghai, China.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- The American Library Association will concentrate emphasis on "library development" in the immediate future, the A. L. A. council agreed today after hearing this policy recommendation from the executive secretary, John Mackenzie Cory.

CAMBRIDGE, England, Jan. 14 -- Post-war farming in England has enough attractions to have made Wing Commander E. R. Benson forfeit a career as a trans-continental airline pilot in the United States and an RAF rank equivalent to colonel.
Alfred G. Tuckerman was reelected president of the National Horse Show, which will be held Nov. 1 to 8 in Madison Square Garden, at a meeting of the board of directors yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 20 -- Col. Gen. Alexander Rankovitch, Yugoslav Minister of the Interior and deputy to Premier Marshal Tito, informed the Serbian party congress in Belgrade yesterday that the Communist Information Bureau and the Communist party of Bulgaria had revived the Macedonian territorial question with the intention of dislocating and destroying the Yugoslav national state as a solution to the problem of eliminating the Yugoslav leaders from power.

The library of the Russell Sage Foundation at 130 East Twenty-second Street, containing one of the most comprehensive collections of materials in the social work field, soon will be transferred to another agency, it became known yesterday.
ATHENS, Jan. 20 -- The new Government of 88-year-old Premier Themistocles Sophoulis, designed to have the character of a National Union regime, was sworn in today before King Paul.

Pointing out that Brazil's average of monthly trade balances with the United States during 1948 crept out of the red in November for the first time, Jose Garrido-Torres, director of the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau here, said yesterday that a continuing trend of this kind will clear up collection delays.
G. W. Gryson has been appointed sales manager of the American Can Company for the metropolitan New York district. S. G. Bridge will succeed him as assistant sales manager.

Something new in bank reports has been developed by the American National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago which has prepared one solely for its employes. Entitled "A Report to the Staff," it deals with general plans, benefits and the future, and attempts to personalize and interpret the bank's accounting statement, in eight pages of texts and charts.

The best friend for composers of operas and Broadway musicals seems to be a writer named William Shakespeare. On Broadway you can note his hand in "Kiss Me, Kate," and at the Metropolitan in "Otello" and "Falstaff." Uptown at Columbia University's Brander Matthews Hall last night there was another lively exhibit, the production of "Sir John in Love," an opera by R. Vaughan Williams with a libretto based on Shakespeare's "The Merry Wives of Windsor."

Activity and strength featured yesterday's trading in cottonseed oil futures on the New York Produce Exchange. At the high point, prices were up as much as 110 points. Profit-taking and local selling weakened prices somewhat. Weakness in western lard and grains furthered the decline and the market closed unchanged to 10 points higher.

The Terrace Room of the Plaza was filled to capacity last night for the second annual midwinter ball in aid of the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital for Animals. The principal feature listed for-the occasion was the placing up for auction of a 2-year-old filly named Chanceling.

The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York which a few months ago bought the old White-law Reid mansion at 451 Madison Avenue, northeast corner of Fiftieth Street, and adjoining realty, yesterday extended its holdings with the purchase from Mrs. Helen F. Hubbard of the four-story building at 455 Madison Avenue and the two buildings and vacant plot at 24 to 30 East Fifty-first Street.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 20 -Motorists, some of them coming from miles away, snarled Traffic Court routine here today as they challenged, by entering not guilty pleas, minor parking charges filed through the new four-ply non-fixable ticket system. It was the first time since the institution of the new system here that defendants have pleaded not guilty to these charges, which normally carry $1 fines.
The Amalgamated Clothing Workers, CIO, announced yesterday that it soon would ask the management of Saks-Fifth Avenue to bargain with it for a contract to cover the store's 2,000 employes.
More than 10,000,000 persons, the largest number ever to witness a single event, were estimated yesterday to have seen the inauguration of President Truman on television.

PARIS, Jan. 20 -- A report to be submitted tomorrow to the French and Italian Governments by their joint committee of experts is expected to lead to a treaty for the abolition of tariff duties between the two countries next year.

Elena Nikolaidi, Greek contralto of European fame, presented a recital of rare brilliance last night at Town Hall. Her program encompassed the whole range of expressive moods, and each accomplished rendition had the large audience cheering.

On his second day of sight after two years of total blindness, and six of part blindness, Carl Klein, 40-year-old horticulturist, discovered yesterday that the world was neither what it used to be nor altogether satisfying.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 -With consumption of petroleum products now greater than at the height of World War II, the development of new sources of liquid fuel has become imperative for our national security itself, Dr. Edward R. Weidlein, director of the Mellon Institute of Industrial Research, Pittsburgh, warned here tonight.

To many families in New York City, Christmas would be just another bleak day were it not for the Salvation Army. Last year 957 families received Army assistance, which meant the difference between happiness and wretchedness to them and to their children. More than sixty welfare and religious services for the needy are maintained in Greater New York by the Salvation Army -- services that lend assistance to every race, creed and age.
