Figure skating's outstanding personality, Miss Sonja Henie, returned to Madison Square Garden last night in another of her Hollywood Ice Revues before a gathering of 11,000.

Commenting on President Truman's inaugural address, Henry A. Wallace declared yesterday that "it comes closer to a declaration of war than the inaugural address of any peacetime President in our history."

The first comprehensive program in this country for testing "natural" childbirth is proving highly successful, it was ported yesterday. Dr. Frederick W. Goodrich Jr. of the Yale University School of Medicine disclosed details on which no previous announcement had been made.

ROME, Jan. 20 -- President Truman's speech surprised Italy. Most people expected him to reiterate the American stand against communism but few thought he would state his position in such strong and unequivocal terms.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Sweeping criticism of the present status of the Royal Air Force was expressed today in the House of Commons by Air Commodore A. V. Harvey, Conservative member and veteran of twenty-three years of military and civil flying.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 20 -- Irving S. Olds, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, called upon American industry here tonight to be "alert to the possible firing of an opening gun in a long-range program for the entry by Government into what has heretofore been regarded as private enterprise."
ROME, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Italy's Communist party today pledged all-out support to Russia in an "international front for peace."

The Youthful Offenders Court, started in 1943 to handle felony cases involving persons between 16 and 19 years old, was described yesterday by General Sessions Judge Saul S. Streit as "no longer an experiment but a proven success".

Judge Clarence G. Galston in Federal Court, Brooklyn, denied yesterday to a veteran an order that would have compelled the Veterans Administration to reinstate him to his $4,275-a-year position as an adjudicator.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 20 -President Truman's pledge that the United States would continue to support the United Nations was warmly welcomed today. Officials were particularly encouraged by the President's endorsement of the economic studies which the United Nations is carrying out in under-developed areas.

Eastern skiers, who have spent most of the winter thinking or dreaming about mountain trails and slopes buried under deep powder snow, must continue to do so for at least another week-end as the prospects for tomorrow and Sunday remain grim.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 20 (AP) -- A close second in both previous 1949 outings, Mrs. Vera S. Braggs Dubious found the third time the charm at Hialeah today.

" The Cricket" is ready to chirp once more for the New York Yankees. Little Phil Rizzuto yesterday became the first of the 1948 Bombers to return his signed contract to play shortstop under the new Yankee manager, Casey Stengel.

Jerome Robbins' first ballet in two years, "The Guests," with music by Marc Blitzstein, the first score he has written for ballet, had its premiere last night by the New York City Ballet Company at the City Center.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- The Republican majority in the Legislature will sponsor a measure providing state aid for school construction and rehabilitation, Senator Benjamin F. Feinberg, Republican majority leader of the Senate, and Speaker Oswald D. Heck of the Assembly revealed today without specifying how much assistance it will provide.

NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Yankees are going to win the American League pennant next year, but "you never can tell what Joe McCarthy has up his sleeve," Joe Di Maggio, the Bombers' centerfielder, said tonight.

The story of how community leaders in Manhasset, L. L., kept pegging away at minute problems until they understood fully the housing situation faced by their Negro neighbors and finally won state aid for low-cost housing was told yesterday by an area spokesman for the group.

Vince Foster of Omaha, whose recent knockout of Tony Pellone in the Garden made such a hit with the local fight fans, has been signed to fight Charles Fusari of Irvington, N. J. in a ten-round bout at the Garden Feb. 18, Harry Markson, managing director of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, announced yesterday.

The State of South Carolina announced yesterday that it will receive bids until Feb. 8 on an issue of $5,000,000 of state highway certificates of indebtedness dated Feb. 15, 1949, and due on each Feb. 15, from 1951 to 1959.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Some of the indignation felt against Argentina over the reduction of the British meat ration came out in the press and Parliament today. Argentina has not fulfilled her contract for meat deliveries, and future contracts are being held up by prices that Buenos Aires is trying to squeeze out of Britain's Ministry of Food.

According to European trade experts at Geneva, there are good prospects that the Iron Curtain will be lifted a bit this year to permit substantial food shipments from agrarian Eastern Europe to the industrialized West. If that should come about it would be a welcome and an important development.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- Although Yugoslavia has now offered for sale in the United States market considerable quantities of valuable metals, including copper, lead, chrome and semi-processed bauxite, no fixed commercial policy has yet been agreed upon by Belgrade and Washington.

Gian-Carlo Menotti, the composer, and Rudolph Firkusny, pianist, provided delightful new sensations at the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra which Leopold Stokowski conducted last night in Carnegie Hall. The work they advanced was Mr. Menotti's piano concerto, heard for the first time in this city.
The whole British policy in the Near East needs to be revised. If Britain is not to be one of the greatest liabilities as an ally, our own State Department must press for this revision.

Realism and speed have been promised by House leaders on amended DP legislation that will be worthy of this country's great traditions. This is the only answer to the shameful and unworkable law passed by the last Congress, and a sign that humanitarianism is still a force in men's reasoning.

ABOARD B-36 BOMBER OVER WASHINGTON, D. C., Jan. 20 -The White House at the scene of inauguration ceremonies was the "target" today for a simulated bombing mission by a group of five of the Air Force's biggest and newest B-36 bombers on a nonstop, 2,340-mile flight from the Eighth Air Force Headquarters at Carswell Field, Texas.
A dream of peace and freedom came true yesterday for 457 European refugees who arrived on the converted transport Marine Marlin.

ATLANTA, Jan. 20 (UP) -- After three hours of fiery debate in which the Ku Klux Klan was held up as "a shining symbol of the Southern way of life," the Georgia House of Representatives today killed a bill to unmask the organization.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The principles and objectives enunciated by President Truman in his inaugural address today drew warm comment from members of Congress. But no guarantees were given that he would escape controversy over his "bold new program" for making American scientific advances and industrial progress available for the improvement and growth of underdeveloped areas of the world.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 20 -- B. G. De Sylva is discussing a deal with Columbia for production and distribution facilities for his projected screen life of Theda Bara, silent film star, it was learned today. Betty Hutton is expected to play Miss Bars in the picture.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The roar of a great crowd -- over a million persons were here as the unofficial delegates of the people of this country -- rose and fell today in broken, happy cadence for Harry S. Truman's inauguration as President of the United States.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Truman inaugural reception at the National Gallery of Art was what the "whistle-stop" campaign train would have been if Vice President Alben W. Barkley had been on it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Harry S. Truman denounced communism as a false doctrine and outlined a four-point program for American world leadership, and peace, as he assumed the Presidency in his own right in the most impressive inaugural of American history.

CRANFORD, N. J., Jan. 20 -- Teen-age pupils have been working with pick and shovel on topsoil supplied by local townspeople in a community-sponsored effort to build a recreation field for Cranford High School. Folks here are proud of the project, which has been a cooperative enterprise from its inception.

CAMDEN, N. J., Jan. 20 -- Representatives of striking employes of two Camden gas plants agreed tonight to permit the manufacturing of enough of the fuel to supply the homes of their 100,000 customers.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 20 -- The best place to study both sides of the Palestine conflict is in Jerusalem. Here are two distinct cities, as far apart in aspect, time, outlook and way of life as they are near in space.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- Jules Pfeiffer of Chicago, one of the owners of the stage play "Maid of the Ozarks," filed suit for .$1,942,665 in Federal District Court today against the Shubert theatrical enterprises and others, charging violation of the Sherman and Clayton Anti-Trust Acts.

President Truman, in a message to the American Jewish Committee, opening its forty-second annual meeting today at the Astor Hotel, praised the committee's work "in the field of individual freedom and human relations."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia said today that an analysis of present economic conditions "suggests that recession will stay 'just around the corner' during 1949."
Despite the lack of snow, reports from Connecticut and New York foxhunters indicate excellent running conditions, and in many areas foxes are reported to be more plentiful than last year.

Another book about China and Russia's role in that country's turmoil will be brought out Feb. 25 by Bobbs-Merrill, entitled "Russia's Race for Asia." The author is George Creel, chairman of the Committee on Public Information for President Wilson from 1917 to 1919, who returned from a visit to China last year.

NANKING, Jan. 20 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's speechwriter, Tao Hsi-sheng, was again reported at work tonight on a farewell statement for the Generalissimo in the midst of a dynamic political situation that has reached a new stage for ups and downs, even in China.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The average cost of slaughter steers here this week was estimated today at $23.75 a hundred pounds, lowest since May 10, 1947. The estimate was made by L. M. Wyatt, market specialist of the United States Department of Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, D. C., Jan. 20 (UP) -- An official of the Washington Redskins said tonight that the National Football League team had offered the job of head coach to Frank Leahy, football coach and athletic director at Notre Dame.

Whittaker Chambers denied yesterday that he had written an article that appeared in the Nov. 22 issue of Life and which was the subject of a plagiarism suit filed against him on Wednesday by Frances Winwar.

William C. Hundt, vice president of the Lincoln Savings Bank in Brooklyn, has purchased the home of Gordon Scholes on Tuttle Road in Briarcliff Manor, N. Y. Regional Associates, Inc., were the brokers.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 20 -The death of Grenville Baker, 27-year-old heir of the New York banking family, tonight appeared destined to become unsolved.

American carpet manufacturers are conducting a buyers' strike against a large Argentine syndicate which is largely responsible for the 100 per cent increase in Argentine carpet wool prices in the last year, a wool buyer for one of the country's most important carpet mills disclosed yesterday.

For the first time the public will be able to participate in the New York Film Critics annual awards ceremony tonight when the presentation will be made on the stage of the Radio City Music Hall. Present to accept their scrolls will be Olivia de Havilland; Director John Huston and Roberto Rossellini, whose Italian-made war drama, "Paisan," was named the year's top foreign-language film.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Washington's principal industry is politics, and Harry S. Truman barely had taken the oath as President today before the capital began to speculate who would be standing in that spot four years hence.

BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 20 (AP) -Dutch Premier Willem Drees said today that talks in Indonesia on forming a national government would be "more fruitful if international interest in this problem would somewhat subside."

Lawrence Tibbett has completed twenty-five consecutive seasons at the Metropolitan Opera, and is now started on his twenty-sixth. Tonight every element connected with the opera -- management, staff, artists, the Opera Guild and the American Guild of Musical Artists, the union that represents the singers in the company, of which Mr. Tibbett is president -- will join in paying tribute to the American baritone.

With Leon A. (Jake) Swirbul, recent appointee to the New York Racing Commission, in attendance the commission met yesterday and announced its approval of the list of officials for the 1949 racing season, which will open April 1 at the Jamaica track. There are no changes in the list.

Operations of J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., and its subsidiaries in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, last, resulted in a net profit of $28,015,270, after all deductions and after an inventory reserve of $5,000,000 set up out of earnings, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

Not long ago you printed a full page advertisement by the Woman's Home Companion, containing an article by Dr. Morris Fishbein on psychiatric quackery. The gist of the article was that psychologists and social workers have been practicing medical psychiatry in competition with doctors, and that this has led to great harm to patients and the public.
A 30-year-old unemployed dishwasher was sentenced to ten to fifteen years in prison in Bronx County Court yesterday for an assault and robbery that netted him only 95 cents.

New Yorkers have been treated in the recent past to a "shabby exhibition" of liquor control criticism filled with "fabrications and distortions," John F. O'Connell, chairman of the New York State Liquor Authority, charged last night at the annual dinner of the National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers, Inc., in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Such criticism, he said, will be answered by verified and fully substantiated, actual facts.

THE footracing fraternity will move out of minor league settings this week-end and into the majors with the staging of a big-time meet in Philadelphia tonight and a bigger-time meet in Boston tomorrow night. Then will come the shift to Madison Square Garden on the following Saturday and the indoor track season will be under way in earnest. It should be a most interesting campaign.

MONTREAL, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens staggered through two periods of hockey tonight, came to life in the third and won, 2 -- 1, over the New York Rangers in a close-checking game that produced plenty of ragged play.

I think that my too-condensed reference at the recent Citizens Budget Commission dinner to a master plan as a test of the need for expanding the city's debt-incurring powers may have caused some confusion among the readers of the accurate press accounts of my remarks.

Steel warehouses in the New York area are raising prices about 3 cents per 100 pounds, reflecting increased freight rates in all lines of regular products, distributors reported here yesterday. The increases apply generally across the board and do not represent an increase in the profit differential of the warehouses, executives pointed out.
LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Yesterday's firmness generally was maintained in the stock market here today.

VIENNA, Jan. 20 -- Hungarian armed forces already have been increased over the strength authorized by the Hungarian peace treaty and are being militarily and politically organized on Russian lines by Russian officers, according to Gen. Albert Bartha, former Hungarian Minister of War.

TV Premium Offers Planned With the approach of extensive daytime television broadcasting, several national advertisers have begun making plans for considerable use of premium offers on the daytime shows, it was disclosed yesterday by an advertising specialty official. Video, he said, is a "natural" for premium promotion, and it promises to open an important new field for the box-top, sales-stimulating campaigns.

More than 100 persons attended a five-and-a-half-hour hearing before the Public Service Commission yesterday on the application of the New York Telephone Company for an annual rate increase of $49,000,000.

The main point of inquiry into the Wednesday pre-dawn crash of the Coast Guard icebreaker East-wind and the oil tanker Gulf-stream will be the use of radar aboard the icebreaker, Coast Guard officials said yesterday. The hearing will begin today at the Coast Guard office, 42 Broadway.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong yesterday and closed 9 points higher to 1 point lower, led by the strength in March contracts.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Army Quartermaster market center today announced successful bidders for more than 9,000,000 pounds of meat purchased from Argentina for military feeding in the European command.

Fownes Hosiery Reduced Prices on Fownes nylon hosiery have been reduced by an average of 15 per cent, it was announced yesterday by Fownes Brothers Co., Inc. The company has expanded the line which was originally introduced late in 1947, for the spring, 1949, season. Its 60-gauge 15-denier hose will be priced at $18 a dozen, wholesale, the 54-gauge 15-denier at $14, service wear 51-15's, 51-20's, and 51-30's at $12 and $11, respectively.

In an action that brought angry cries of protest, six members of the Board of Education shattered a long-established precedent yesterday in voting unanimously to bar the International Workers Order from the city's public school buildings.

Harry S. Truman, taking the oath yesterday as President of the United States, spoke of this nation's "imponderable resources." Those who were physically present in Washington and the many other millions who listened to the proceedings over the radio or perhaps saw them in a historic television broadcast must have felt the presence of those imponderables.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Seeded players won their way into the semi-finals of the national professional clay courts tournament today.

Moving contra-seasonally for the second consecutive week, business loans by banks in this area rose $15,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. According to the data covering the reporting New York City member banks, borrowings by utility and tobacco companies were the principal influences in the latest advance.

HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 20 -- With victory twice snatched from his team's grasp by a desperate Dartmouth quintet, Herb Lyon, tall Penn center, took matters into his own hands, tallying four vital points in a second overtime period tonight to give the Quakers a 76-73 Eastern League victory.

David and Nathan Warhit have purchased the leasehold and business of the garage and gasoline station at 390 Riverdale Avenue, the Bronx, from the Devonshire Garage, Inc. G. Montague Mabie was the broker. The property is about 150 by 200 feet and contains a one and two story building.

Two thousand members of Local 1-2 of the Utility Workers of America, CIO, which represents 21,000 of approximately 26,000 employes of the Consolidated Edison Company in New York and Westchester, voted unanimously last night to call a special strike vote meeting if an agreement is not reached with the company by the middle of February.

New York's unabated craving for new cars and insatiable curiosity as to what makes the automotive wheels go arou d were emphasized yesterday by the 65,000 visitors attending the opening session of the General Motors exposition "Transportation Unlimited" at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Announcement of the itinerary of the New York Yacht Club cruise next summer, which yearly is awaited by yachtsmen, summer vacationists and resort places to the eastward, was made yesterday afternoon by Commodore Henry S. Morgan at the first general meeting of the club this year.
RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Burma's twenty-one-man Cabinet, beset by problems from ten months of civil war, resigned today to permit the formation of a more compact Government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The shortest inaugural address in American history -- 134 words -was made by George Washington upon his second oath-taking at Independence Hall, Philadelphia, March 4, 1793. He said:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- President Truman's inaugural address was generally interpreted in the capital as one of the most ambitious pronouncements on foreign affairs ever made by an American President.
ALBANY, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Central New York may get its first parimutuel race track if and when the $52,000,000 Empire State Exposition gets under way.

Ralph S. Damon, who resigned Wednesday as president of American Airlines and vice president of American Overseas Airlines because he "was out of sympathy with the programs and policies" of the company, declined yesterday to deny or confirm numerous reports that he soon would head Transcontinental and Western Air.

Sgt. Milton A. Gibbons has a practical philosophy concerning young persons who get into trouble, whether it is minor mischief or serious crime. No classroom philosopher or round-table theorist, he has been a hard-headed policeman for the last twenty-six years in Tuckahoe, N. Y. Action instead of talk has been his code.

It is good news that something is being done about the practice of a small percentage of bus drivers who add further hazard to our difficult traffic situation by disregarding red lights. Within the last two months twenty-two drivers of the New York City Omnibus Corporation have been suspended for such practice, and five others, who had bad safety records in other respects, have been discharged.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- The Association of the Bar of the City of New York is having great difficulty in finding a legislator to sponsor its proposal to add six additional grounds for judicial dissolution of marriages to New York's divorce law, Barent Ten Eyck, chairman of a special bar association committee, disclosed today.

Members of the Democratic County Committee of the Fifth Manhattan Assembly District nominated Monroe Flegenheimer for Assemblyman at a meeting last night at the Amsterdam Democratic Club, 2091 Broadway. The special election on Feb. 15 will be to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Irwin D. Davidson on appointment by Mayor O'Dwyer as Justice of the Court of Special Sessions.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20 (AP) -The Pacific Coast League is willing to join a play-off for the minor league baseball championship, and to play exhibitions in Japan next summer if they are financially promising, President Clarence Rowland said today.
Passenger railroad traffic through Grand Central Terminal during 1948 dropped 5 per cent from the previous year, E. B. Moorhouse, terminal manager, announced yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- When the State Tax Commission mails income tax blanks starting Feb. 1 to 3,350,000 potential taxpayers, it will again ask taxpayers to delay the filing of returns until the Legislature has fixed the tax rates.

Another final-hour upturn, this time accompanied by increased demand, occurred yesterday on the stock market. Before President Truman delivered his inaugural address the list moved aimlessly, but once the President's remarks had been weighed, the market became active and final quotations were irregularly higher on the day.
MILAN, Italy, Jan. 20 (AP) -Miss Eva Pawlik of Austria is the favorite candidate to succeed Miss Barbara Ann Scott of Canada as amateur figure skating queen of Europe.

VIENNA, Jan. 20 -- Russian acceptance of Feb. 7 as the date for the resumption of negotiations for an Austrian treaty, taken together with conciliatory Soviet gestures recently, is forcing the generals of the Western occupation armies to give serious consideration to the possibility that a treaty actually may be concluded this year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- With thirty-six years of continuous service in Congress behind him, Alben W. Barkley embarked upon a new career of service to the nation today as he took the oath of office as the thirty-fifth Vice President of the United States.

For those who like frocks of crisp chambrays, trim cotton cords, print spun rayons and soft rayon crepes at prices that hover between $8.95 and $14.95, Franklin Simon showed a collection of charmers in their Kay Dunhill presentation yesterday on the second floor of this store.

Awards for new talent discovered in a nation-wide architectural competition sponsored jointly by the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, and the publication, Architectural Record, were announced yesterday. The competition, which excluded architects whose work had been published in national magazines, called for the design of a memorial community center for a hypothetical town in the Middle West.

The need of a crippled 20-year-old youth for plasma in a life-long fight against uncontrollable bleeding from the slightest lesion, the medical term for which is hemophilia, has set going a blood-donor project among teen-agers in the parish of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street.

The return next month of the Furness, Withy Co. luxury liner Queen of Bermuda to the New York-Bermuda run will be marked by the disappearance from that service of two familiar passenger vessels, the sister-ships Fort Amherst and Fort Townshend.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- A new international labor organization, composed of free trade unions of democratic nations, is expected to attain considerable stature in the next six-months, according to labor spokesmen who hailed with satisfaction today the split in the World Federation of Trade Unions.

The Telecoin Corporation has sold the seven-story and penthouse building at 12 East Forty-fourth Street to a syndicate of investors headed by Albert H. Graham and as part of the transaction leased back the property for a long term on a net basis. Telecoin occupies space on the upper floors.

Customs collections at the Port of New York last month totaled $22,496,251, an increase of $5,547,208 over the same period last year, according to a report yesterday by Harry M. Durning, Collector of the Port.

The right to call witnesses against the grand jury that indicted them was won yesterday by the eleven Communist leaders. Defense lawyers announced they would present their first witnesses this morning. They have contended the jury was illegal and its indictment void, because it was selected by methods that excluded certain minority groups.

Directors of the Irving Trust Company, following the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday, elected as chairman of the board William N. Enstrom, who had been president seven years. Richard H. West, executive vice president and a director for several years, was elected president. Mr. Enstrom thus becomes the chief executive officer of Irving Trust and Mr. West the administrative officer.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 20 -- Pensions of at least $100 a month for 1,000,000 members of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, were put at the top of the union's bargaining program tonight by Walter P. Reuther, president of the union.

The Ward Baking Company attained last year a new high of $86,072,667 in sales, which was $5,524,863 more than the 1947 volume, and reflecting larger dollar and volume sales of Tip-Top bread, Faris R. Russell, board chairman, informed shareholders in the annual report, to be released today.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 20 -- President Juan Peron's new Secretary of the Economy and Secretary of Finance were sworn in this morning. The impression grew in diplomatic and financial circles, meanwhile, that the heretofore unquestioned power of Miguel Miranda over the Argentine economy had been broken.

STILLWATER, Okla., Jan. 20 (AP) -- St. Louis University was knocked from the ranks of the nation's unbeaten basketball teams here tonight as the Oklahoma A. M. five whipped the Billikens, 29 to 27, in a game that went into one overtime period.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 20 -- Delegates from nineteen Asian countries decided at a secret meeting tonight to ask the United Nations Security Council to order the complete independence of Indonesia by the end of this year.
Present prices are cutting demand for milk and thus endanger the economic security of dairy farmers in this state, John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, charged yesterday.

DETROIT, Jan. 20 -- The Detroit Symphony Orchestra, threatened with mass firings for "disloyalty," gave a vote of confidence today to Karl Krueger, its musical director, and Henry H. Reichhold, its president.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- London's popular tabloid, The Daily Mirror, has made a sensational jump in circulation since Jan. 2 and now leads Britain's -- and doubtless the world's -- daily newspapers in circulation. This was stated today in an article in The Tribune, a weekly that represents the Labor party viewpoint.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Following are texts of the invocation, prayer and the benediction of today's inauguration of President Truman:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Comrade: Pursuant to your instructions I hasten to give you my impressions of the celebration here today of the inaugural of President Truman and Vice President Barkley. I am weary with the turmoil and movement of the day and could do with a glass of strong tea.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States urged today a policy of revising the Taft-Hartley Act as the changes are demonstrated clearly to be in the public interest.

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 21 -British newspapers bestowed warm praise today upon President Truman's inaugural address and noted with gratitude its international significance. Its message, as The Times of London says, "was meant for the world."

AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 20 (AP) -- A reduction of 66,188 barrels daily from the January allowable was ordered today by the State Railroad Commission for Texas' February crude oil production. The commission signed an order setting February's maximum daily allowable production at 2,442,044 barrels.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Lesser known names of golf launched the $10,000 Long Beach open tournament today and four wound up in a tie for low-score honors.
The New York Post Home News carried yesterday an announcement by Mrs. Dorothy Schiff Thackrey that she had turned over the "control and management" of the newspaper to T. O. Thackrey.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 20 -- The traditional barrier of "racial restrictions" in connection with job-placement in the South has been lowered in several states in recent months, according to a report released by the Southern field division of the National Urban League.

RHODES, Jan. 20 -- The Egyptian-Israeli armistice talks are in their most critical stage and are still being held up by disagreement on "important points," it was said here today. The next twenty-four hours could decide their success or failure.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The greatest parade in the long history of the national capital honored President Harry S. Truman and Vice President Alben W. Barkley today. Tinged with color and incident, the pageant passed for almost three hours before the reviewing stand where the two silk-hatted men remained standing with apparently unabated interest until the very end.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 20 -- On its fourth and last day tomorrow the search for the missing British South American Airways airliner Star Ariel will be strengthened by the arrival of sixteen aircraft coming here from the United States under orders of the United States Air Rescue headquarters.

The sixty-six-room Andrew Carnegie home at 2 East Ninety-first Street, the largest private residence remaining in the city, has been turned over to the New York School of Social Work of Columbia University.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- A bill that would empower municipal housing authorities to require the listing of housing vacancies was introduced in the Legislature today by Senator Harold I. Panken of Manhattan and Assemblyman Julius J. Gang of the Bronx, both Democrats.

The act of coughing became a labor problem yesterday and a test of dramatic art. Instead of being merely a nuisance in the theatre and concert hall, it suddenly acquired a market value -- from $6, to $12.50 per well-modulated bark.

A ten-week whirl around the banked ovals of the major indoor arenas, eventually bringing into action a majority of this country's top-ranking athletes and six outstanding European stars, will get under way tonight at Convention Hall in Philadelphia.

Disturbing reports have come in this winter from distant places. From such otherwise unconnected spots as White Plains, Englewood and Nyack, their substance has been the same. Borne not by the wind but by honest and reliable word of mouth, they have said that the boys this year like dancing school.

BOCHUM, Germany, Jan. 20 -- German attorneys asked the court today to summon Sir Hartley Shawcross, British Attorney General, and Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, Soviet commander, as defense witnesses in the trial of seven German workers who disobeyed a British order to dismantle a steel plant.

Fifty grateful displaced persons gathered to listen to the broadcast of the inauguration of President Truman and to toast the Chief Executive of their new homeland yesterday at a party given by the United Service for New Americans at the Marseilles Hotel, 103d Street and Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- For the most solemn moment of today's inaugural ceremonies, President Truman raised his right hand, placed his left on two open Bibles and repeated the forty-three-word oath of office after Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson in short phrases.

Clement Cardinal Micare, apostolic delegate to the fifth Colombia Eucharistic Congress at Cali, Colombia, beginning Jan. 25, arrived at La Guardia Airport last night aboard a Trans World Airline plane from Rome. He will stay in New York until Sunday, when he will leave by plane for Colombia.
Following is the text of President Truman's inaugural address yesterday as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
GLENDALE, Calif., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Ewell Blackwell, star pitcher of the Cincinnati Reds, underwent surgery for the removal of a kidney tonight at Glendale Sanitarium.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Miss Louise Suggs, playing in her first tournament as a professional, shared the led at 74 with amateurs Miss Marjorie Lindsay and Miss Peggy Kirk in the opening round of the Tampa women's open golf tournament today.

EN ROUTE TO KODIAK ISLAND, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Hundred-mile-an-hour "williwaw" gales, whipped into whirlwinds by blasts from the Arctic, face 18,000 men and forty ships now heading toward Alaska for "the battle of Kodiak Island."

Refusing to return to his Communist-dominated homeland, Dr. Karel Kase, former head of the Latin-American section of the Czechoslovakian Foreign Trade Ministry, has sought asylum in the United States, he revealed here yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 20 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district last week declined moderately from the near record levels reported in the week ended Jan. 8, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Industrial production was up a little, but the gain was more than offset by decreases in the adjusted volume of freight shipments and bf trade.
Governors of the New York Curb Exchange submitted yesterday by mail to a vote of the membership a proposal to increase the commissions on Curb stock transactions.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Jan. 20 -Ways and means of reaching 40,000,000 to 50,000,000 potential investors to have them share in the ownership of American industry were chief topics today at a meeting of the governors of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms in the Hotel Statler here.

Poultry, rather out of the limelight since the Christmas holidays, is one of the outstanding offerings among perishable foods today. Recent increases in production are reflected in this week-end's retail tariffs on broilers, fryers and roasters, down 2 cents from last Friday.
LONDON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The International Yacht Racing Union decided today to establish a new set of universal regulations incorporating certain improvements from the American code.

The Zashin Realty Corporation has purchased a vacant plot 95 by 200 feet at the northwest corner of Ten Eyck Street and Morgan Avenue in Brooklyn from Louis, Pauline, Leonore and Estelle May Zirinsky. Louis Pressman was attorney for the buyer and Harry Sand acted for the sellers.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Jan. 20 -- Directors of Wittenberg College today elected Dr. Clarence C. Stoughton, of Staten Island, as eighth president of the institution to succeed Dr. Rees Edgar Tulloss, who will retire Aug. 31 after twenty-nine years of service.

Office building occupancy may decline moderately but will remain high for many years, with rental rates finding a level substantially higher than tenants were prepared to accept before the War, in the opinion of J. Clydesdale Cushman, of New York, president of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers.

Macy's annual midwinter furniture show, which opens Monday, has been planned for people on a strict budget as well as for all those who are not too free with their furniture dollars these days. There is furniture at down-to-earth prices for couples in two-and-a-half-room apartments and with less than $1,000 to spend.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- The All-America Football Conference, which for three days had been hinting important announcements concerning its future and its relations with the National Football League, tonight admitted that there would be none, at least until tomorrow afternoon.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 20 -- Warren R. Austin, chief United States delegate to the United Nations, said today that Russia's newest "peace offensive" should be welcomed as a step -- a small step -in the right direction.

With the arrest yesterday of six teen-age youths, the police believed they had solved a series of robberies and assaults committed in the last four months in the central section of the Bronx. Loot was said to amount to almost $2,000. Detectives, meanwhile, are seeking four other boys.

Columbus rediscovered America, the Liberty Bell rang in Philadelphia, a nation united and the American heritage was reaffirmed yesterday by the pupils of he Margaret Knox Junior High School, 410 East 100th Street, in a pageant: "America -- the Hope of the World."
The spring fashion show season in the Terrace Room of the Plaza Hotel opened up appropriately yesterday with a presentation of town suits. It was held by Russeks.

BANGKOK, Siam, Jan. 19 (delayed.) -- Siam appears to have been pulled into the Asian Conference on Indonesia somewhat against the will of her Government which, apparently, would like to steer an independent course in foreign affairs for this prosperous little kingdom.

ISLAND POND, Vt., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Two Lewiston (Me.) men who hoped to snowshoe to Montreal for the international snow shoers congress arrived at the approximate halfway point here today -- still unable to find any snow.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Jan. 20 -- Harry S. Truman's home town, which had expected to spend the day sharing, at a distance, the Washington ceremonies, watched, instead, the worst fire in the community's history.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The improved Baltimore Bullets trounced the New York Knicker- bockers, 82 - 68, tonight in a roughly played Basketball Association of America contest.

Three and a half years ago one music instructor began making weekly trips to St. Albans Naval Hospital in Queens to teach a disabled sailor how to play the saxophone in an experiment designed to test the therapeutic possibilities of music study.
The spring fashion show season in the Terrace Room of the Plaza Hotel opened up appropriately yesterday with a presentation of town suits. It was held by Russeks.

BANGKOK, Siam, Jan. 19 (delayed.) -- Siam appears to have been pulled into the Asian Conference on Indonesia somewhat against the will of her Government which, apparently, would like to steer an independent course in foreign affairs for this prosperous little kingdom.

ISLAND POND, Vt., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Two Lewiston (Me.) men who hoped to snowshoe to Montreal for the international snow shoers congress arrived at the approximate halfway point here today -- still unable to find any snow.

S. B. Thomas, Inc., bakery concern, has purchased the one-story garage building at 43-11 and 43-19 Thirty-second Place, Long Island City, Queens, from the Queens Bry Junior Corporation, of which Benjamin Gottfried is president. The property, on a plot 100 by 100 feet, is currently occupied by the Breyer Ice Cream Company.

Stamped by his peers as a talented playwright, Joseph Hayes finally reaches his goal this evening when "Leaf and Bough" opens at the Cort. Warning to first-nighters: The curtain is announced to rise at 8 o'clock sharp.
BERLIN, Jan. 20 -- German factories and workers in the Soviet zone are contributing, under pressure, to the arming of the Soviet Union, reports reaching the United States Army reveal.

The Metropolitan Museum's extraordinary collections of Near and Far Eastern art are being reopened to the public today. New acquisitions by gift and purchase have been amalgamated with the earlier collections and all are now displayed in an orderly and agreeable fashion.
Three new pictures, including a double bill from England, will have local premieres today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Governments of Great Britain and France, in furtherance of general European economic recovery, have agreed in principle to the retention of about 117 Western German industrial plants, previously scheduled for dismantling as reparations payments.

WILMINGTON, N. C., Jan. 21 (AP) -- A four-hour general alarm fire raged through the Orton Hotel early today, routed forty guests, and spread to six adjoining buildings with a loss estimated at $1,000,000.
ATHENS, Jan. 21 (UP) -- Guerrilla troops captured, the town of Karpenision, 125 miles northwest of Athens, today after a three-day offensive.

PARIS, Jan. 21 -- Suddenly closing the Stock Exchange, the Government announced today the terms of its new loan. The financing is designed to insure a balanced budget through 1949, the success of French recovery under the Marshall Plan and the survival of the existing Government.

Funeral services for Grenville Kane Baker, who was mysteriously killed last Monday in Tallahassee, Fla., were held yesterday at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Lexington Avenue at Eightieth Street. They were attended by 600 persons prominent in business and society circles while 100 curiosity seekers stood outside the church.

With the opening of the Port Authority's consolidated bus terminal still more than one year away, 300 applications have been received for the fifty rentable units in the $20,000,000 structure, it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- Internal industrial controls as a means of lowering operating costs was cited today as the key to successfully meeting competition and keeping up to date on industrial mobilization blueprints. The application of controls and a study of costs were urged here in addresses before the national spring conference of the Society for Advancement of Management.

TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Miles W. (Mike) Casteel, deposed football coach at Arizona University, answered his critics today while a storm of pros and cons over his dismissal raged among alumni groups.

The stock market returned yesterday to a walled-in position with a narrow price drift through the session. Although the composite rate on the Stock Exchange showed a small recession on the day, more issues managed to end the session with gains than closed it with losses.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 21 -- The Middle East will never be the same again after the upheaval caused by the breakup of Palestine and the phenix-like rise of Israel.
BOSTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Claude B. Cross, counsel for Dr. Miriam Van Waters, demanded today that Elliott E. McDowell, State Corrections Commissioner, dismiss his deputy, Frank A. Dwyer.

Discussion, not a police force, is required to settle the problems of world peace, Frederick H. Osborn, deputy United States representative to the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, declared yesterday at the first birthday celebration of the Information Center for the United Nations, 535 Fifth Avenue.

New soil-proof wallcoverings that can be applied like ordinary wallpaper hut which can be easily wiped clean of a variety of stains were introduced yesterday by the Imperial Paper and Color Corporation at a ahowing in the Barclay Hotel.

CAMDEN, N. J., Jan. 21 -- A truce in the Camden gas workers' strike, which had restored a limited amount of fuel for cooking and heating to the homes of 90,000 consumers in South Jersey, lasted only twelve hours today.

The 1949 National Sportsmen's Show, scheduled to open at Grand Central Palace in mid-February, is going to have a "new look" this year, according to its producers, and the entertainment features will emphasize the outdoor activities that made the show popular with sportsmen back in the "old days."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Dean G. Acheson took the oath of office as Secretary of State at 11:13 o'clock this morning at a ceremony in the office of President Truman that had a notable bipartisan and also nonpartisan setting.

While a clerk waited patiently outside the locked jewelry shop at 651 Elton Avenue, near Third Avenue, the Bronx, yesterday at 1 P. M., two hold-up men, who had trussed up with wire the proprietor, Harry B. Rose of 1841 Phelan Place, the Bronx, completed taking $5,000 worth of jewelry and watches and $50 in cash, and then calmly walked out of a rear door and away.

Frank Hawkins of Bedford Village, N. Y., was elected president of the Professional Horsemen's Association at the organization's annual meeting at the Hotel Martinique, which ended early yesterday morning. Hawkins succeeded Ted Wahl of Greenwich, president for two years.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- President Truman's proposed "bold new program" for improvement and growth of under-developed areas of the world met resistance at key Republican posts in the Senate today.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Israeli representatives in London are showing great wariness today toward the issue of British recognition of Israel, which is expected to be extended soon, concurrently with full United States recognition of Israel and Trans-Jordan and recognition of Israel by Australia, New Zealand and France.

Anna Steck, soprano, and Hans Melzer, bass-baritone, gave a joint recital in Times Hall before an enthusiastic audience last night. It was her New York debut, and she sang four unpublished Debussy songs, and first performances of six of Tailleferre and four of John Edmunds. Mr. Melzer has been heard here previously.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- The Treasury announced tonight that last month France, Austria and Greece exercised their right to draw sterling from Britain under terms of the Intra-European Payments Agreement signed in Paris on Oct. 16, last.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Britain's cement industry set a new high record last year with an output of 8,500,000 tons, the Cement Makers Federation announced today. This was one third of a million tons greater than the previous record set in 1939.
TEL AVIV, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Moshe Shertok says that Israel is negotiating with both Lebanon and Trans-Jordan but adds that the talks have not yet reached a decisive stage.

Reflecting the new peacetime sales record established in 1948 by the Caterpillar Tractor Company, earnings exceeded any previous year in its history, according to the preliminary operating results announced yesterday by L. B. Neumiller, president.

To spare housewives the toil of mixing color into margarine at home, the Long Island Federation of Women's Clubs resolved yesterday to demand repeal of the New York State margarine law, which prohibits the manufacture and sale of yellow margarine.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 21 (UP) -- The nineteen nations at the Asian Conference failed again today in a secret meeting to agree on the formation of a permanent Far East bloc along the lines of the Western European Union.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- The wage hour dispute between the railroads and their 1,000,000 non-operating workers appeared today to be heading toward a showdown that could lead to a nation-wide railroad tie-up.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- With the New York Yankees and Brooklyn Dodgers pooling their material in a new organization, completely divorced from their respective baseball interests and playing all games at the Yankee Stadium, the All- America Football Conference will operate as a seven-team league in 1949.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Noble One of the Afton Villa Farms raced to a length-and-a-half victory over Dutoit in the featured Gretna Purse at the Fair Grounds today. Merrymarch was third.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- A determination to hold fairly long hearings on the proposed repeal of the Taft-Hartley Labor Act, despite the demands of the unions for very early decisive action to knock out the act was announced today by Chairman Elbert D. Thomas of the Senate Labor Committee.

A reprint of the November Bulletin of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York, containing nine principal reasons for the organization's strenuous opposition to the proposed St. Lawrence Seaway and Power Project, has been forwarded to all members of Congress from New York, New Jersey and the New England States, C. H. Callaghan, executive vice president of the association, announced yesterday.

James Durkin, president of the United Office and Professional Workers, CIO, yesterday attacked the National Labor Relations Board and the Prudential Insurance Company on a charge of "delaying" a representation election among the company's 14,500 agents in thirty-one states.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 21 -- A Technicolor musical comedy to be titled "Son of Robin Hood" has been scheduled by Universal-International as a vehicle for Donald O'Connor and Charles Coburn, the studio announced today. Oscar Brodney is writing the scenario and Leonard Goldstein will produce the film after O'Connor completes "Curtain Call at Cactus Creek," his next picture.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Vanderbilt University is in the market for a new football coaching staff -- from the head man right down to and including a trainer.

Foot-racing is a wonderfully rewarding sport for spectators, especially when the track is indoor and comfortably protected from the elements. This week-end at Philadelphia and Boston starts the winter sequence of indoor, banked-track running that is the best in the world.

MOSCOW, Jan. 21 -- The chief speaker at a memorial meeting in honor of Nikolai Lenin said tonight, in the presence of Premier Joseph Stalin and other high leaders, that communism was "the brain, honor and conscience of our age, a new era, the era of crushing capitalism."

Thirteen contributions amounting to $107.16 were received yesterday by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, bringing the total given so far in the thirty-seventh annual appeal for the fund to $344,293.37.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Ace Admiral, Maine Chance Farm 4-year-old, won today's $10,000 Ventura Handicap at Santa Anita, churning a mile and one-sixteenth through the mud in 1:45 2/5.

Indoor track and field's busiest week-end to date will provide competition on two more fronts tonight. Most of the headliners will be at the Boston Garden for the Massachusetts Knights of Columbus game but a sprinkling of stars will remain here to join the small army of local athletes entered in the Grover Cleveland Athletic Club games at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- A report of the Department of Agriculture on average daily quotations for Western dressed meat in the New York City wholesale market showed today that choice beef brought $46.70 a hundred pounds last week, a drop of about 15 per cent from mid-January, 1948.
William D. Hartman has been appointed assistant to the president in connection with the marketing of retail items at Wellington Sears Company, Inc.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The Pirates ran into contract trouble today. The National League baseball club learned its best double-play combination isn't happy about salary terms.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 21 -- D. S. Kim, public information director of the Korean Republic, reported that a widespread revolt broke out Wednesday night against the Communist north Korean Government in the city of Haeju in Hwanghai Province, a few miles north of the 38th parallel.

Arthur W. Fiehn bought the two-story dwelling on a plot about 58 by 65 feet at 192-16 Foothill Terrace, Hollis, Queens, from the Foothill Realty Corporation. Title insurance was issued by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
LONDON, Jan. 21 -- The stock markets here were quiet and dull today and only minor features attracted interest.

Fighting at a pace that would have done credit to a lightweight, Bernie Reynolds, Fairfield, Conn., heavyweight, last night stopped Gene Gosney, Seminole, Okla., in the sixth round of the scheduled ten-round feature bout at the St. Nicholas Arena. A crowd of 1,962 attended.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 21 -- A Princeton University junior who dropped a bottle containing a note into the Atlantic last summer "just to see if anything happened" has received a letter from a man in Watefore County, Eire, who found the bottle on a strip of rocky coastline near his home nearly two months after it had started its journey.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates will stay off the baseball television circuit, at home at least, in 1949.

UTICA, N. Y., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Curling rinks from Montreal and Schenectady gained the semi-finals of the Mitchell Medal competition through victories today in the four-day bonspiel at the Utica Curling Club.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Par took a fearful beating today as four crack professionals moved into the lead at the end of the first round of the $10,000 Long Beach open golf tournament.

"Peter Grimes" returned to the Metropolitan last night in a performance of exceptional effectiveness. The cast had as a special feature Lawrence Tibbett, appearing as Captain Balstrode for the first time in his career, and on the night when there were ceremonies backstage to honor him for his twenty-five years of distinguished performances with the Metropolitan Opera Company.

ROME, Jan. 21 -- While the greater part of the Italian press is lavish with praise of President Truman's speech, extreme left-wing labor leaders already are at work on an attempt to so interpret it as to make it help their cause. Communist leader Palmiro Togliatti regards it as evidence that the policy of "imperialist American groups" is suffering a severe crisis.

The first major track meet of the 1949 indoor season at Madison Square Garden -- the Millrose Games -- will receive complete coverage by the cameras of the Columbia Broadcasting System's television network from 8:30 until conclusion, next Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Washington was in a weary slump today. Everybody was tired by the exertions of the inauguration and caught up on his sleep. Everybody but President Truman. He carried on all day and far into the night.
ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Jan. 21 (UP) -- Sen. Estes Kefauver, Democrat, of Tennessee, tonight called for changing the electoral college system "before a national calamity results."
NANKING, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The hasty exit of President Chiang Kai-shek from his National Government today may close a glittering era, grown suddenly threadbare.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- All American Airways is planning schedules which will permit one-change air service between Scranton and Harrisburg, Pa., a spokesman for the company said today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Jan. 21 -- Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers, the stare university of New Jersey, recommended today strengthening of the university faculty and extension of its research to increase its service to the state.

The intention of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee leadership to strike, the tax liability clause from the Truman Administration's two-week-old public housing bill means that the proposal to wipe out the tax exemption privilege of the bonds of the local housing authorities already may be an abandoned issue.

COLUMBUS, Ohio. Jan. 21 (AP) -- Frank J. Shaughnessy, president of the International League, today advised minor league clubs to demand a ten-year contract before permitting their baseball games to be televised.

TROY, N. Y., Jan. 21 (AP) -- The Fordham University basketball team defeated Rensselaer Poly, 83 -- 77, tonight in a see-saw game in which the opponents were rarely more than three points apart until the closing minutes.

The enactment of an effective water-pollution control program during the current session of the state Legislature was predicted yesterday by Assemblyman Harold C. Ostertag, chairman of the joint legislative committee on interstate cooperation.

The sight of swirling snowflakes in the metropolitan area yesterday brought untold delight and jubilation to local ski enthusiasts but the weatherman put a damper on the prospects with a forecast, of freezing rain and sleet in near-by skilands by today.

BOSTON, Jan. 21 -- A special legislative commission served warning today that unless 100 Massachusetts communities made arrangements for the handling of Federal funds by Civil Service personnel the commonwealth would face the loss of nearly $32,000,000 in reimbursements for old age assistance and aid to dependent children.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- A bill proposing a state commission to study overlapping Federal, state and local taxes was put forward today by Senator Seymour Halpern and Assemblyman Fred W. Preller, both Republicans, of Queens. They are members of committees that deal with finance in their respective houses of the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The State Department withheld comment today on the departure of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek from Nanking for Fenghua in the absence of official information as to its significance.

Give Dr. Sergei Feitelberg some radio tubes, wire and a few sheets of plastic and he will turn out some amazing "gadgets" in his little machine shop in Mount Sinai Hospital. They include a camera that takes X-ray pictures of molecules, a pointer that locates cancer hidden within the body, and a device whereby the heart takes a photograph of itself.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- The British Government, which is watching with keen interest the Asian conference of nineteen nations at New Delhi, has decided to maintain a "hands off" policy until the conference ends.

Any new labor legislation enacted by the Eighty-first Congress must impose equal obligations on both management and labor if industrial peace and stability are to be assured, the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce declared yesterday.
As a result of the slow but steady decline in meat prices that started in September, New York City shoppers are paying less for beef, lamb and pork now than they did a year ago.

The Port of New York Authority and Frederick L. Wehran, manager of the Teterboro Air Terminal at Teterboro, N. J., have petitioned the Civil Aeronautics Board for full and open hearings on a proposed air regulation that would seriously cripple if not drive out of business more than 100 irregular, non-scheduled air passenger carriers, it was disclosed last night.

MOSCOW, Jan. 21 (AP) -- THE NEW YORK TIMES, which has had no correspondent in Moscow since the spring of 1947, is to be represented here again. An entrance visa has been granted to Harrison E. Salisbury as a TIMES correspondent, the press section of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced today.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 21 -- The first billion-dollar budget in California's history was submitted to the Legislature today by Governor Earl Warren with the warning that tax increases were essential.

PROVIDENCE, R. I, Jan. 21 -- An increase of $1,130,000 in annual revenue is in prospect for the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company in Rhode Island because Superior Court Judge G. Frederick Frost granted the company permission to adopt an emergency rate increase.
Because of protests from parents and teachers, the New York school system is now re-examining its policy of admitting children to the first grade at the early age of 5 years and 4 months.

The Half Moon Hotel at Coney Island is to be converted into a hospital, it was learned yesterday. The twelve-story 290-room building on the Boardwalk at West Twenty-ninth Street has been purchased by the Harbor Hospital of Brooklyn from Alfred Kaskel for $1,000,000.

Net assets of the Tri-Continental Corporation, an investment company as of Dec. 31 totaled $63,557,710, according to the annual report released yesterday by Francis F. Randolph, chairman of the board. The General Shareholdings Corporation was merged into the Continental on Oct. 1, 1948.
LONDON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The European press, both Communist and non-Communist, generally agreed today that President Truman's inaugural address foreshadowed an all-out offensive against communism.

Consistent commission - house buying advanced hide futures prices 30 to 55 points on Commodity Exchange yesterday. A major portion of the activity was devoted to the near-by March and June deliveries. Sales aggregated ninety-six lots.

As the budget-making process goes on in Albany and New York City it seems to us that what is most needed and too often absent is a sense of proportion and a spirit of fair play. There is, for instance, a great deal of misrepresentation -- some innocent and some by design -- of the extent of state aid to New York City.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- A basis for a written plan providing for the consolidation of leading regional stock exchanges was reached today at a meeting of representatives of the exchanges in the Chicago Stock Exchange. The next step is to prepare the plan after which it is to be submitted to the various exchanges for a vote of their members.

Efforts of the American Labor party to make a New York Telephone Company witness disclose executives' salaries were rebuffed during a three-hour hearing before the Public Service Commission yesterday on the company's application for a $49,000,000 annual rate increase.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- The Government proposes to raise to 500,000,000 (about $2,000,000,000) the maximum liability that may be incurred by the Board of Trade in giving exporters guarantees against loss in export trade transactions.

The French may have been the first to French-fry onions, but a glance at what people are eating in restaurants seems to prove that Americans have made the food their own. This popularity may, of course, be limited to place. Perhaps people order fried onion rings with such enthusiasm only because they seldom savor them at home, where mother won't go to the trouble of preparing them. But is it really trouble?

TOKYO, Jan. 21 -- The Japanese Communists, who expect to score their biggest advance since the surrender in Sunday's general election, have been collecting funds through the black market, smuggling and extortion, according to information in the hands of the United States occupation authorities.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The United States accorded diplomatic recognition to Venezuela and El Salvador today as one of the first acts of the new Administration.

Complete political separation must be maintained between American Jews and Israel although the new nation must continue to receive financial and moral support from American Jews, it was agreed unanimously at one of several workshops held yesterday in connection with the opening of the forty-second annual meeting of the American Jewish Committee.

WARSAW, Jan. 21 -- The Communist Polish Government today relegated its "Marshal Tito," Vice Premier and Minister of Recovered Territories Wladyslaw Gomulka, to a position of unimportance. He was named deputy chairman of the Supreme State Auditing Chamber.
The sixty-eighth annual meeting of the United States Lawn Tennis Association convenes at 1 o'clock today at the Commodore Hotel and may be one of the liveliest in years.

I beg to dissent from the interpretation of the Yugoslav-Russian rift in your editorial of Jan. 3, in which you more or less accept the story of that rift at its face value. The rift may, of course, be genuine, but if it is, Russia and the Cominform have behaved so stupidly that this alone suggests that there must be a different aspect to the entire affair.

Two four-story garden apartment buildings with a total of forty-eight suites at 146-52 Glenwood Avenue, in the Journal Square section of Jersey City, N. J., have been sold by Abraham and Esther Jacobs to Harry Goldklang for investment, it was announced yesterday by J. I. Kislak, Inc., brokers, who arranged the purchase of the houses by the Jacobses in 1942.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan., 21 -- Approximately 200 shots were exchanged between Czechoslovak, border guards and United States constabulary troopers early yesterday during a lively skirmish at Schirnding, near Arzberg, on the German side of the international boundary line.

The flurry of equity financing that has dominated the attention of the financial district since the turn of the year has now passed and the pencils of new-issue analysts are returning to bond-yield concerns. The market next week will be marked by the sale of $50,000,000 of bonds of the Consolidated Edison Company, for which bids will be taken on Tuesday.

Conductors who arrange chamber orchestra concerts are usually good hands at making programs, and Edouard Nies-Berger qualifies. His Nies-Berger Chamber Orchestra, made up of his colleagues in the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, put on another appealing program at Town Hall last night in the second of its series of three concerts.

Homemakers may quietly test their "know-how" around the house by checking with "The School Custodian's Housekeeping Handbook," a manual just published by Columbia's Teachers College and believed to be the most comprehensive and authoritative treatment of the subject to date.

DETROIT, Jan. 21 -- On the basis of industry and labor statistics, it was computed unofficially today that the $100-a-month pension plan sought by the United Automobile Workers, CIO, would involve a first-year outlay in benefits of about $100,000,000.

Export control under the present law which expires on Feb. 28 has been, in the main, "effective," Wallace S. Thomas, director of the export operations division of the Office of International Trade, said here yesterday.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 21 (AP) -- The California team of Frank Kovacs and Bert Brown advanced to the semi-final round of doubles play in the national professional clay courts tennis tournament today. They defeated Harold Blauer of New York and Frank Goeltz of Washington, D. C., 6 -- 3, 19 -- 17.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Early expansion of the program under which the Anglo-American Productivity Council was established to help Britain increase her output was predicted here by American and British business men as the result of President Truman's inaugural address yesterday.

The significance of the contract recently awarded by the state for a new eastward extension of Northern State Parkway on Long Island is that it brings nearer the day when Suffolk County will enjoy the benefits of the Long Island Parkway program. Though predominantly rural in character, Suffolk, through its nearness to New York City, represents a logical territory for future expansion of the immediate metropolitan area.

BERLIN, Jan. 21 -- Otto Grotewohl, co-chairman of the Socialist Unity [Communist] party in Germany, delivered a bitter attack on capitalism and the Western democracies today, veering sharply away from the "peace and collaboration" line of Communist speakers in France and Italy recently.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Governor Dewey was requested today by Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein to call an extraordinary special and trial term of the Supreme Court and to convene a special grand jury to hear testimony on alleged election frauds in Utica during the 1948 election.
The Federal Communications Commission hopes to renew the granting of more television licenses by April or May, Wayne Coy, chairman, indicated here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Air Force announced tonight that it had agreed tentatively to set up a "feedlift" to rush fodder to starving livestock stranded by drifting snows over a large part of the western plains.

Air passengers seeking guarantees of arriving on time at desired destinations should pay extra fares, a planning engineer proposed yesterday at a closing session of the ninety-sixth annual meeting of the American Society of Civil Engineers in the Commodore Hotel.

The General Motors show was described yesterday by former President Herbert Hoover as "a monument to American ingenuity." Preceding the estimated 60,000 visitors that later filled to overflowing the exposition in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel during the day and evening, he analyzed the automotive presentations through critical eyes of an engineer.

New York's movie critics went Hollywood last night in distributing their annual film awards. Not only did they make the affair a public one for the first time, but they held it in Radio City Music Hall, largest movie house in the country.

Officers aboard the Coast Guard icebreaker Eastwind said yesterday it was a "miracle" that more than eleven were not killed in the Wednesday pre-dawn crash with the oil tanker Gulfstream. The Eastwind was carrying a crew of 162 officers and men, twenty-eight more than the vessel's normal complement.

American business, in its relationships abroad this year, will require the support of foreign economic policies aimed at freer export markets, a larger volume of imports into the United States, and better conditions for American private direct investments abroad, according to a statement prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the National Foreign Trade Council.

Detecting the approach of a cold, one of our staff people stepped into a Third Avenue therapy center and ordered a dose of spirits. He was at once joined by a Svengali-eyed, black-fedora sort of fellow who asked if our man had given any thought to Third Avenue art.

In his inaugural address President Truman said: "We must embark on a bold new program of making the benefits of our scientific advances and industrial progress available for the improvement and growth of underdeveloped areas." In other words, Mr. Truman sees as this country's great intangible export of the future the commodity usually referred to by the homely phrase, American "know-how."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's extemporaneous remarks to the women's division of the Democratic National Committee today:

An increase in office salary rates in all but one of twenty-five job classifications during 1948 was reported yesterday by the Office Executives Association of New York, Inc. The report was made following a survey of 163 company and Governmental agencies, representing nineteen types of businesses.

Steel distributors are threatened with being "allocated out of business" under the expanding voluntary steel allocation program which does not include distributors in its provisions, Morris Rosoff, general counsel, National Association of Steel Distributors, disclosed here yesterday following his return from a Midwest meeting of NASD officials and industry members.

Four of the five Republican county leaders of New York City decided yesterday to start a fusion movement for next November's city election by appointment of a city-wide committee to confer with political and civic groups in an attempt to reach agreement on candidates on the city-wide and borough levels.

A pan-orthodox religious service will be conducted at 4 P. M. tomorrow at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 110th Street, under auspices of the Orthodox and Anglican Fellowship. Bishop Charles K. Gilbert of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York will be host and will preside, giving a benediction.

Approval of a Government-subsidized theatre was voted yesterday at a special membership meeting of Actors Equity Association at the Hotel Astor. The meeting was called to consider the problem of employment in the theatre, following the signing of a petition by 100 senior members of the association.

American-flag shipping is carrying two-thirds of our imports from the Straits Settlements and Indonesia compared to 15 per cent before the war and 44 per cent of the exports from this country to the area compared to 2 per cent in 1938, according to the American Merchant Marine Institute.

The weather staged a variety performance yesterday. Winter snow and snow grains fell in mid-day hours, but mild temperatures dissolved the flakes and pellets as they reached the ground. City pavements looked as if there was a spring rain even before regular precipitation started late in the afternoon.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander asked for 2,076 patrolmen and 382 new motor patrol cars in his tentative budget submitted yesterday to Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson for the coming fiscal year.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 21 -- Old-fashioned square dancing is gaining rapidly in popularity this winter in Westchester canteens and clubs patronized by teenagers and young adults, the County Recreation Commission has reported after a survey.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Plans for the first and the greatest Health Center in connection with Britain's cradle-to-the-grave national health service were made known today. It will be built in Northern London at a cost of nearly 200,000 [about $800,000] excluding equipment.

Lawrence Tibbett was honored last night at the Metropolitan Opera by his associates and the public for a remarkable record of twenty-five consecutive years as a member of the company. The tribute was richly deserved, for the American baritone's achievement is notable not only for its duration but its outstanding quality.

The Rev. John O. Mellin, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street, became a trustee yesterday of Sailors Snug Harbor, thus ending a campaign to compel the charitable institution to seat him in accordance with its charter.

The need for wider understanding of the confidential nature of the Association of National Advertisers' current project to compile "case histories" on representative companies' planning of their advertising budgets has been emphasized by slow progress in obtaining the necessary data, it was learned yesterday.

A suit to compel the Board of Education to establish a single salary schedule for elementary, junior and senior high school principals will be argued before Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora on Jan. 31, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Henry Robert Margarita, former backfield star at Brown University and backfield coach at Yale University, was named today to succeed Jack Hagerty as head coach of Georgetown University.

Though there were at first contradictions and uncertainties in the news that came from China, it seems probable now that Chiang Kai-shek has surrendered power to direct the destinies of his hard-pressed government not only in the crisis immediately confronting it but also in the longer trials that lie ahead.

During the past few weeks you have published a number of articles relating to the rising break-even points in industry and the significance of this fact during a period of economic adjustment. In your issue of Jan. 12 there is an article entitled "Cost Saving Cited by Mechanization" in which it is stated that "investment as high as $25,000 per employe may be justified * * * if it increases output and productivity."

GENEVA, Jan. 21 -- Representatives of the six small powers on the Security Council's Berlin Currency Committee predicted today that efforts to solve the currency issue within the framework of the United Nations would soon collapse.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- President Truman ended his inauguration week speeches tonight with a political talk in which he said his inaugural address yesterday and his messages on the budget, the nation's economy, and the state of the Union proved that the Democratic platform "was not a scrap of paper."

At this moment, when the Netherlands Government is jeopardizing its future in Indonesia, it is encouraging for Dutchmen who are deeply ashamed of their Government's present policy to note the vigorous protest of the entire world.

The coordinated efforts of the schools, the police, local businessmen and civic and religious leaders during the last year have brought about a 45 per cent decrease in juvenile delinquency in the South-East Bronx, it was learned yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Jan, 21 -- Four new "wonder" drugs that are effective against some diseases that medicine has not been able to overcome in the past were described today by Dr. Perrin H. Long, Professor of Preventive Medicine at Johns Hopkins University Medical School, Baltimore.

Three men on the Federal jury list testified yesterday they had never been questioned by jury officials about their race, religion, income or political affiliations. All were called as witnesses for the eleven men charged with conspiracy to organize the Communist party to teach and advocate violent overthrow of the Government.
ATHENS, Jan. 21 -- Statements favorable to the new, broadened coalition Government of Premier Themistocles Sophoulis were issued today by the United States and British Embassies.

The Board of Education expects to begin construction this year on a minimum of twenty-three new public school buildings and additions, Anthony Campagna, chairman of its committee on buildings and sites, declared yesterday at a dedication ceremony for two new wings of Public School 106, St. Raymond Avenue and Odell Street, the Bronx.

A FORTY-NINTH STREET GARDEN OF VERSES is devoted this morning to two books written excellently on water -- or thereabouts. One is a fine new incarnation of Brian Curtis' lively classic: "The Life Story of the Fish -- His Morals and Manners." The other is Ferdinand C. Lane's authoritative and entertaining "Earth's Grandest Rivers" -- or how and why the world's great streams wind their muddy and/or picturesque ways to the seven seas.

The questions Federal census-takers will ask in 1950 when they make their decennial house-to-house survey will be determined to some extent by the thousands of suggestions being submitted by private and government groups all over the country.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 21 (AP) -- An easy triumph for Bug Juice in the Everglades National Park purse and a third-race spill which badly jarred / Apprentice Logan Batcheller commanded most interest at Hialeah today.
