LONDON, Jan. 21 -- A suggestion that when Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, arrested Primate of Hungary, appears for trial he will be under the influence of a drug is made in a document to be read Sunday in all Catholic churches of the Diocese of Shrewsbury, Shropshire.

RHODES, Jan. 21 -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting United Nations Mediator in Palestine, abandoned tonight his four-day effort to break the deadlock in the Egyptian-Israeli armistice talks and brought the delegations of the two countries together to try to work it out.

BELGRADE, Jan. 21 -- Marshal Tito today told the second congress of the Serbian Communist party that the Yugoslav leaders were defending the principle of equality of countries -- small and large -- within the Socialist family nations and that the Communist Information Bureau was guilty of counter-revolutionary acts and "revisionism" in attacking a small Socialist state such as Yugoslavia.

NANKING, Jan. 21 -- Chiang Kai-shek, the Christian-Confucianist Generalissimo who ruled the Kuomintang [Government party] and fought the Communists almost uninterruptedly for more than twenty years, retired from active service today as President of China.

Retail sales during the week, although seriously hampered by unseasonably warm weather, were still about even or perhaps a little better than those of last year, according to merchants in the metropolitan area. The gradual changeover from a buyers' to a sellers' market, resulting in the heaviest year-end clearances in ten years, is supporting volume, it is believed.
MIAMI, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Charles T. Winters, 35, pleaded guilty today in Federal Court to a charge of conspiring to export war planes to Palestine.

Retail sales here this week made a small increase despite warm weather that was said to be discouraging sales of winter merchandise. Department store sales were estimated as about 2 per cent over the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were up 5 per cent from last year.

Leonard Bacon Clark, who had pleaded guilty to a grand larceny indictment accusing him of the theft of $200,000 from his father's estate, received a suspended sentence yesterday in General Sessions and was placed on probation for ten years.

A few moments after the curtain rang down last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, Lawrence Tibbett, still in costume, received the plaudits of everyone connected with the opera organization. He had just begun his twenty-sixth season as a Metropolitan baritone by singing a new role that of Balstrode in Benjamin Britten's "Peter Grimes."

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- Grain prices advanced rapidly today on the Board of Trade as the result of general short covering which disclosed an oversold condition and with stop-loss orders uncovered the close was about the top. Soy beans led the advance, closing 3 3/4 to 6 cents a bushel higher than Western.

NANKING, Jam 21 (AP) -- China's new Acting President Li Tsung-jen, reported as "peacemaker" choice to succeed Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek as early as last November, is high on the Chinese Communists' list of "war criminals."

SEATTLE, Wash., Jan. 21 -- A warning that the Western steel industry faced a serious scrap deficiency during the year was voiced today by F. B. Delong, vice president of the Columbia Steel Company. He told the Seattle Chamber of Commerce that the situation remained critical on the West Coast despite the easing of scrap supplies in other sections.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Senate Republicans today flashed go-slow signal to the Republican National Committee on a proposal for a party policy conference this year lest it interfere with Republican hopes of taking control of the Senate from the Democrats in 1950.

Prospects are bright for an early start on the construction of Concord Village, a 968-apartment housing development planned in connection with the projected Civic Center in Brooklyn, it was learned yesterday. However, important prerequisites include upward revision by the State Banking Board of the $25 a room per month ceiling on rentals that may be charged, according to Paul W. Connelly, president of Concord Village, Inc., and of the Fulton Savings Bank.

An appeal to stop thinking of psychotics as people who have "just been given a one-way ticket to nowhere" was issued yesterday to the doctors and psychiatrists of the nation by Dr. Nathaniel J. Breekir, director of group psychotherapy, Brooklyn State Hospital.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Governor Dewey announced today the designation of Maurice C. Burritt as chairman of the Public Service Commission. This was interpreted as presaging the appointment of the Senate majority leader, Benjamin F. Feinberg, to the chairmanship at the end of the current legislative session.

Engineers of the Board of Transportation and "trouble shooters" supplied by the manufacturers are cooperating in ironing out electrical and mechanical "kinks" that have immobilized seventy-four of the 270 new streamlined subway cars delivered to the city since July 1, the board announced yesterday.

ROME, Jan. 21 -- During the six days since Communist leader Palmiro Togliatti, speaking in Bologna, held out the olive branch to the Government, there have been no visible developments of a Communist "peace offensive."

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Taxes collected for the state's fiscal year ending next March 31 may set a new high in revenue receipts, according to figures for nine months released today by the Department of Taxation and Finance.

NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 21 -- Anthony Iovine, 37 years old, and his brother, Luke Iovine, 32, were convicted by a jury of race track bookmaking at 2 o'clock this morning after fifteen hours of deliberation, following a nine-day trial before Judge Joseph E. Conlon in County Court.

Business written at the local winter furniture market in the New York Furniture Exchange, which moved into closing stages yesterday, was described as "good to excellent" by manufacturers' representatives. They emphasized that few large orders were received but pointed out that total volume from small-scale purchases by smaller Eastern retailers was definitely satisfactory.

"All for Love," a revue starring Grace and Paul Hartman and Bert Wheeler, opens tonight at the Mark Hellinger Theatre, formerly the Warner. The producers are Sammy Lambert and Anthony B. Farrell, the up-state industrialist. The latter, it will be remembered, made his entry into show business with the short-lived "Hold It!" and then purchased, for a reported $1,500,000, the Warner with the idea of housing it.

RUTHERFORD, N. J., Jan. 21 -- The average televiewer spends three-and-a-half hours a day at his television set when he stays at home, and to do this, gives up certain former home activities, notably reading.

A 15-year-old Philadelphia girl, Miss Harriet Ella Beloff, whose dad is a high school football coach, skated away with the Middle Atlantic women's junior figure skating championship yesterday at Iceland, atop Madison Square Garden.
NANKING, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The following is the official translation of President Chiang Kai-shek's farewell message:
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Jan. 21 (UP) -- Two critically injured survivors of an Alaska Airlines plane crash were pulled from the wreckage today and were flown 150 miles to a hospital here.

When "Chief" Hill Canoe appeared, yesterday in Flatbush Magistrate's Court, charged with disorderly conduct together with eleven other men who had been found sprawled asleep in the IND subway terminal at Church Avenue, Brooklyn, it was a fortunate day for the others.

On the evidence of "Leaf and Bough" at the Cort last evening, let us suspend judgment about Joseph Hayes, who has written it. "Leaf and Bough" is his first play. There are streaks of good writing in it; there is an occasional imaginative scene done in an elusive style.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Miss Patty Berg smashed through the well-trapped Palma Ceia course today with a record-shattering 68 and a four-stroke lead at the halfway point in the Tampa Women's open golf tournament.

Underwear orders from jobbers which have been late in coming through, will be placed in volume in the next sixty days, it was predicted yesterday by manufacturers. Jobbers' inventories, they said, have been cleaned out by promotional sales which were held to raise cash.

Allie Reynolds, the Yankee righthander who let loose a blast late last season that he "wasn't being given a chance to win twenty games," yesterday became the sixth Bomber to send in his signed contract.

Responding yesterday to numerous inquiries concerning his duties as president of Columbia University, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower defined his task in the first of a series of three letters to alumni of the university.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 21 -- The United States, joined by three other powers, formally called on the Netherlands today to re-establish the Republic of Indonesia as a working government but side-stepped any new demand for immediate withdrawal of Dutch troops from Republican territory.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21 -- Quite at home on the boards, three fast foreigners showed a representative collection of Americans a thing or two about the fine European art of distance running tonight.

TEANECK, N. J., Jan. 21 -- One year after three veterans of World War II had been required by court order to tear down a dry-cleaning establishment, they stood today in possession of a new one across the street. Both had been built by their own hands.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Britain went a long way toward starting a national theatre today when the House of Commons gave a second reading to a bill providing for a 1,000,000 ($4,000,000) guarantee and a site.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange again showed strength yesterday and closed 14 points higher to 10 points lower, with the near months the strongest.
A misunderstanding between three swimmers, on one hand, and a superior number of policemen, on the other, was cleared up yesterday by Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Jan. 15 were 733,272 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 11,765 cars or 1.6 per cent more than for the preceding week, 75,036 cars or 9.3 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 94,788 cars or 11.4 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 21 -- In accordance with the Rhodes agreement, details were worked out here tonight for the evacuation of the Egyptian brigade trapped by the Israeli Army at Faluja for the last three months. Plans disclosed by United Nations sources call for its release with honor and with all military equipment.

The Public Service Commission, by a divided vote yesterday, ordered the six private bus lines that maintain a combined 12-cent bus-subway fare under an arrangement with the city to seek an "equitable" apportionment of these fares.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- Sharply lower retail prices of all meats compared with the peak of last September and a better quality of steaks and roasts are now available to the American consumer, two sources in the trade said here today.

Today's events: Little Orchestra Society Young People's Concert, Thomas K. Scherman, conductor; Suzari Marionettes; Milton Cross, narrator, Hunter College Auditorium, 11 A. M.; Music for Children, Brooklyn Museum Symphony Orchestra, David Le Vita, conductor (for museum members), at the museum, 2

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 21 -- The National Congress of Industrial Organizations put its foot down today on moves to have the CIO follow up its part in President Truman's election victory by seeking to take control of the Democratic party.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 21 -- A story going the rounds among high officials here is that postage stamp economy in Washington delayed for weeks an important statement of President Truman on Israel.

A biographical study of Franz Kafka will be the first of a series of rare books related to the history of literature to be published by Arts, Inc., 756 Seventh Avenue. "Franz Kafka, An Exile at Home," is written by Pavel Eisner, Czech essayist and literary critic, who has translated in Czech the works of many great authors.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Rivalries among trade union organizations of the Western World may delay the formation of a new global labor federation to replace the World Federation of Trade Unions.

THERE is something amazingly unusual -- and revolutionary, indeed -- about Metro's "Command Decision," now at Loew's State. It is a war film about the Air Forces -- or some of its wartime personnel -- yet there isn't a screaming dogfight in it nor a roaring, explosive bombing run.

A 14-year-old figure skator, named for a famous star, gained major recognition yesterday as Miss Sonya Klopfer of Brooklyn won the women's senior Middle Atlantic title at Iceland, atop Madison Square Garden.
What is there to the so-called Russian "peace drive"? Does it mean anything or does it mean nothing? Those are very pertinent questions.

A fund in memory of Laurence Duggan, late president of the Institute of International Education, to carry out the work in which he was "most deeply interested," is being organized among his friends, it was announced yesterday by Archibald MacLeish, former Librarian of Congress.

SUZANNE and Joseph are the central characters of two quite separate novels, "Suzanne et les Jeunes Hommes" and "La Passion de Joseph Pasquier," published in Paris in 1940 and 1941, as Volumes Nine and Ten of Duhamel's Pasquier series.

While temperatures above normal in this area continued to exert an influence on consumer response to January retail offerings, dollar volume nevertheless made a fairly good showing last week. Estimates put department store sales at about 2 per cent above the same week last year.

I was much disappointed to read "Berlin Today: One Family's Story." Has the world forgotten what happened just ten years ago? Don't people remember how this very same German family -- either Schulz, Schmidt, or whatever its name was -- threw out others, either into gas chambers or into exile?

SEATTLE, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The Board of Regents of the University of Washington dismissed three long-time professors today as the aftermath of a controversy over asserted present or former Communist party membership.

Snow or no snow, the days of January lengthen perceptibly. We already have more than half an hour more daylight than was ours at year's end, and from here on the sun rises steadily earlier, swings higher toward the north, and sets later. Groundhog Day will be here in another ten days.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 22 (AP) -- A rank outsider, Lurline B., won the twelfth running of the Santa Margarita Handicap at Santa Anita today.

For nearly two years this newspaper has had no correspondent in Moscow. This gap in our foreign coverage has been due entirely to our inability to obtain a Russian visa for such a correspondent. Now a visa has been granted to Harrison E. Salisbury, a journalist of high standing, who represented The United Press in Russia in 1944 and was for a time foreign news editor of that agency.

The usual weekly report on department store sales by the Federal Reserve Board was delayed last week due to the four-day Inauguration holiday in Washington. For that reason the sales chart is omitted this Sunday.

IN 1939, two years after an ambitious, hard-working young musician from San Francisco had tucked a violin under his seventeen-year-old chin and made a debut at Town Hall, a New York critic's advice to his readers was: Remember the name of Isaac Stern.

TOKYO, Jan. 22 -- Discontent with what may be interpreted as an occupation drive to modify the Japanese labor system is becoming increasingly apparent. It is hard to find an industrial leader who favors industrial rationalization -- which here means the laying off of surplus workers -- and impossible to find a labor leader who wants it.

PRAGUE, Jan. 22 -- Although no word of the alleged officers' conspiracy in Bohemia against the present government has yet appeared in the Czechoslovak press, a communique announced today that sixty members of a large-scale espionage organization working on behalf of the United States Intelligence Service and Slovak emigres had been arrested in Slovakia.
RHODES, Jan. 22 -- The next thirty-six hours will see the end of the Israeli-Egyptian armistice talks, either in success or failure, an authoritative source said tonight.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 22 -- The Federal Security Agency will ask Congress to cut the retirement age for women to 60 under the Federal old-age insurance program, an FSA representative told the United Automobile Workers, CIO, at a union educational conference here today.

IT is none too early to begin to accustom ourselves to the fact that the ballet field is undergoing a pretty complete readjustment. The chief factors in the picture seem to be the recent institutionalizing of the New York City Ballet Company, the uncertain position of the Ballet Theatre and the rise down in Havana of the new Ballet Alicia Alonso.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 22 -- Labor's drive to repeal the anti-closed shop laws in eight Southern states is expected to meet its first test before the 1949 Tennessee Legislature which renews its session on Monday after a week's recess.

CAPETOWN, Jan. 22 -- South Africa has suffered the first communal riots in its history. In Durban Negroes suddenly set upon Indians and continued the attacks for three days. There were more than 100 dead and more than 1,000 injured and there was considerable arson and looting. The Government is appointing a commission of inquiry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Democratic leaders expressed confidence today that Congress would approve whatever measures might be necessary to implement President Truman's new program for the economic development of backward areas of the world. They sought further enlightenment before putting the legislative machinery to work on it.

PEARL BUCK, with the able and outspoken help of Mrs. Paul Robeson, here adds another to her list of "talk books." The "argument" is not as strenuous as it might have been, for both women are what we call in today's jargon "left of center."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Organized labor's pattern for advancement in the next six months is a "double play" -- wage increases and social security.

CAIRO, Jan. 22 -- Reports from relief workers, received here, indicate that the condition of 200,000 to 250,000 Arab refugees in southern Palestine is more dangerous than previous reports have indicated.

EVERGREENS, especially welcome at this time of year, merit a place in small gardens at all seasons. Perhaps the shortest cut to success with evergreens is the yew, particularly upright Japanese yew (Taxus cuspidata capitata).
I resent the inference in the letter to the Magazine criticizing the WAC for its cooking.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 22 -- Various aspects of the Communist question captured attention of many West Coast residents this week. The New York trial of a dozen Communists had a genuine impact on thinking here, and not alone because part of the defense counsel was imported from this Coast.

BOSTON, Jan. 22 -- Department store sales in Boston for the week ended Jan. 15 were 19.5 per cent above the corresponding week of last year. For the first fortnight of 1949 the gain over 1948 was 15.5 per cent. Local merchants are at a loss to explain the sharp upturn in sales since just before Christmas.

ROBERTO ROSSELLINI, who has acquired more international renown with two pictures -- "Open City", and "Paisan" -- than some directors attain in a lifetime of movie directing, slipped quietly into New York from Italy by plane last Sunday night on his first trip to this country.
ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 22 -- Cornell defeated Dartmouth, 57 -- 51, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League basketball game tonight before 6,000 fans.

The probation department of the forty-two Magistrates Courts in New York provides services of "transcendent importance" to the community despite the colossal handicaps under which it is forced to operate, Chief City Magistrate Edgar Bromberger declared yesterday.

THE "trump echo" is a play little known in the average bridge game, but its use is second nature to those who play in the strongest games. It works like this: When a defender wants to tell his partner that he has exactly three trumps, he first plays the middle card, then the lowest.

The 2,159 women who were enrolled in medical schools in the autumn of 1948 have reason to follow with a peculiarly personal interest the ceremonies with which Hobart and William Smith Colleges and the New York Infirmary are honoring today the memory of Elizabeth Blackwell, America's first woman physician.
PRAGUE, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Three nuns and the head of a Franciscan monestary were listed today as among those arrested in Slovakia in an alleged conspiracy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The growth and change of political philosophy in the United States as contrasted with the static folkways of the nation were brightly illuminated by some of the events of Inauguration Day.

BOSTON, Jan. 22 -- In their efforts to open "new doors" to women, American colleges run the risk of making girls unwilling to settle down to the commonplace duties of marriage and home making, Dr. Mildred McAfee Horton, president of Wellesley College, said today.

NO kingly robes were ever more richly colored than the open trumpets of salpiglossis, commonly known as Painted Tongue. Catalogue pictures, while true, hardly do justice to the subtle blending of tones.

Fritz Kreisler's collection of rare and early books and manuscripts, recently donated to the Lenox Hill Hospital and the Golden Rule Foundation, will be auctioned on Thursday and Friday evenings at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

THE Coast Guard last week added another note to the unseasonable winter by inviting amateur yachtsmen and boatsmen of all classes of craft, and anyone who thinks he may at some time this summer take a ride on a boat, to attend courses that will teach them how to be better skippers and better passengers.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Communists in Western Europe who have been wont to denounce Britain and America in vitriolic language recently have taken to dropping some of the more offensive adjectives. By contrast their words have seemed almost to be dripping with honey.

Regarding claims to the invention of the electric light (Letter to the Editor, Jan. 2), I would like to say that an electric light was shining brightly outside a jewelry store on Grand Street, New York, when both Lodygin and Edison were shooting marbles in short pants.

The 15-goal New York Athletic Club side of Zenas Colt, Billy Nicholls and John Pflug defeated the Johnson brothers, Collister, Bob and Ben of Morristown in the feature match of the indoor polo double-header before 1,300 fans at the Squadron A Armory last night.

SYDNEY, Jan. 22 -- Herb McKenley, Jamaica's Olympic runner, bettered the world mark for 220 yards around a curve today and at the same time lowered the Australian mark for the furlong. He was timed in 21 seconds.

HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 22 -- Displaying a polished passing attack despite a slushy skating surface, Dartmouth's hockey team defeated an aggressive Yale sextet, 6 -- 2, before 1,800 in Davis rink tonight.
A week-old threat of a strike by 300 engineers of the Long Island Rail Road was lifted yesterday after three days of negotiation between the company and the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Grains, soy beans and lard slid lower in price on the Board of Trade today. At one time soy beans were down more than two cents a bushel. But a slight rally in the last half hour canceled some of the loss. Dealings were rather slow in all pits.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Dr. E. W. Barnes, Anglican Bishop of BirmingBam, whose tolerant views n communism often have arousec controversy, 'said in a letter published today that "communism is a politico-economic movement for the welfare of* the common mn." "

MEDIEVAL Europe comes vividly alive in this story of Rauf, young son of a Frankish charcoal burner, and his talking magpie, Grump. Bored with the dull life as his father's helper, Rauf dreams of becoming a "dusty foot" -- one of a band of wandering merchant -- and of finding adventure in far-off places.

MR. STUNTZ, a foreign correspondent for The Associated Press for fourteen years, was among the many good newspaper men who served the Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, headed by Nelson Rockefeller, through four years of its stormy existence.

The alleged holdout brigade of the New York Giants was reduced to just one man -- Walker Cooper -- when Secretary Eddie Brannick announced yesterday the receipt of Bill Rigney's contract, along with that of two rookies.

ATHENS, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Selden R. Edner of San Jose, Calif., a United States air observer, and his Greek pilot have been shot down by Communist-led guerrillas and both are believed to have been killed.

THE running battle between the railroads and those of its customers who misuse train reservations -- through black-marketing, failing or forgetting to cancel space early enough, or not showing up at all -- continued on several fronts last week.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 22 -- The "Free University" formed by a group of educators who had been ousted for political reasons by the Peron regime has made little progress, its director, Dr. Alejandro Ceballos, admitted yesterday.

Elsewhere in THE TIMES today we publish the results of a survey of employment conditions conducted by correspondents on the spot in representative cities throughout the nation. These reports come from centers ranging geographically from New England's Boston to Chattanooga, Tenn., in the South; Chicago and St. Louis in the Midwest, Houston, Tex., in the Southwest, and San Francisco and Los Angeles on the Pacific Coast.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 22 -- "Splitting the atom before uniting mankind may change the birth certificate of the atomic age to the burial permit of civilization," Dr. Louis L. Mann, Rabbi of Sinai Temple in Chicago, said here tonight at a dinner in celebration of the 125th anniversary of Bene Israel Temple (Rockdale Avenue) the oldest Jewish congregation west of the Alleghenies.

WITH the signing of Bing Crosby last week to appear on both its television and radio networks, the Columbia Broadcasting System opened its campaign to realign the Wednesday night radio schedules in much the same fashion as it successfully engineered the changes in Sunday's line-up.
RECOGNIZING that the members of his calling are incorrigibly middle class, despite their reputation for Bohemianism, John Beal has found a way to exploit one expression of their bourgeois instinct.

THIS is by way of a plea for playwrights to come to the aid of the television industry. When vaudeville passed into obscurity some years back, one of the unnoticed casualties that went down with it was the one-act play. Now, just as vaudeville is coming into its own once more on television, the one-act play is unnoticed but quite firmly establishing itself in the position it held years ago.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Faced with the probability that the Scandinavian defense talks in Copenhagen will end tomorrow with "agreement to disagree," Sweden was reported today to be making a last minute effort to persuade Denmark not to join the Atlantic pact.

Mayor O'Dwyer threatened yesterday to ask for state legislation to keep the Public Service Commission from interfering with joint fare agreements between the city and private bus companies operating under city franchises.
With one announcement following on the heels of another, the operations of the Newark Baseball Club, for 1949, at least, were settled yesterday.

Financial circles thought last week that the stock market might be peeking around that highly interesting corner where it frequently has found itself since late 1946. The market is now practically plumb on that sidewise line from which every important move has originated, in one direction or the other, over the past two years.

THE new Jean Arp show at the Buchholz Gallery is an event of importance. It should do much to place him properly as one of the master formalists of the modern movement. In matters of humor, paradox, parody, energy and assured control of the creative substance of his art he occupies for sculpture a place such as is reserved for Miro in painting.

CONCORD, N. H. -- New Hampshire winter - resort operators, making a virtue of necessity during the weeks without snow, have been entertaining their guests with activities that were popular in New England long before the rise of skiing.

Gen. Li-Tsung-jen, new acting chief executive of China, is proud of his three Chinese-American granddaughters and so is their maternal grandmother, Mrs. Kim Louie, who runs the Kim Loo Original Creations, theatrical costume shop at 344 West Forty-fifth Street.

WHILE Actors Equity debates the unemployment situation in the theatre and plans are afoot for the ANTA-sponsored industry-wide three-day conference about, more or less, the same subject, the Dramatists' Guild's independent move to work for the cutting of production costs is taking form.

EVERY now and then the dreary formalities of a corporation's annual meeting are broken by the appearance of an irate minority stockholder. Only occasionally, however, does a member of a museum publicly voice his objections to its policy or personnel.

A panel of six junior high school children, plus an audience of 500 others, was pretty generally agreed yesterday that children should not be allowed to make all decisions about their daily activities and that parental advice was something to be heeded.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 -- With a second-half drive, featured by the shooting of Sophomore Hugh Jefferies, the Pennsylvania basketball team defeated Lafayette at the Palestra today, 62 -- 54, before 3,000 fans.

Trading in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday was moderately active and final prices were 6 points lower to 1 point higher than the day before. Only the October delivery rose.

Seymour Harris' article, "Millions of B. A.'s But No Jobs," makes the blanket statement, "There is, of course, a shortage of doctors." This so-called shortage is actually more a maldistribution, large cities being greatly overstaffed while depressed rural areas go begging for medical care.

VINTON FREEDLEY, speaking for the American National Theatre and Academy, and Mr. Robert C. Schnitzer of the National Theatre Conference, "are unjust to their organization when state that their activities have gone unnoticed -- even by one who has been observing theatre movements since the early days of the Drama League of America.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 22 -- The Government of India expressed today deep regret at the "serious deterioration" of relations between Indians and Africans in South Africa.

WHY do producers, with all their experience and all theatrical precedent to guide them, still turn out so many flops? Don't they know a bad play when they see one? The answer to both questions is that there are many people connected with the production of plays whose sole qualification is that they have the requisite cash -- either their own or that of other people.

READERS have begun to give us their reactions to the competition between Columbia's and Victor's new types of records with their different speeds and turntables. The mail has been heavier than on any earlier problem concerning records.

STE. ADELE-EN-HAUT, Quebec -- New England's loss because of poor snow conditions has been the Laurentians' gain. Hotels and pensions in the sixty-mile strip of French Canada from St. Jerome to Mont Tremblant report an increase of 10 per cent in bookings so far this year, most of them directly tracea le to the lack of early winter snow in the Northeastern United States.

The beginning of a new year and the appointment of a new American Secretary of State make it especially pertinent to reconsider some of the underlying factors in current American-Soviet relations. Those relations, which have deteriorated to the danger point during the past two years, can be vastly improved, in my opinion.

Running up the second highest score in its history, the St. John's University basketball team crushed the United States Merchant Marine Academy quintet at the DeGray Gymnasium in Brooklyn last night, 91 to 42. Jerry Calabrese, with 15 points, was the high scorer for the Redmen, who led at the half by 47 to 25.

SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 22 -- With discussions of President Truman's salary boost highlighting inaugural week conversations, Westerners were giving serious thought to legislative salaries in their own region. Utah lawmakers, for example, received a flat $300 per year plus 10 cents a mile transportation and no special session pay.

GREEK letter fraternities are again a subject of heated debate in academic halls and alumni meetings. The recent suspension by a national fraternity of its chapter at Amherst College, in Massachusetts, for initiating a Negro member has revived a century-old argument as to whether the Panhellenic brotherhood of our campuses is a good or a harmful influence in college life.

Intense public interest in the General Motors show at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, as evinced by the estimated 65,000 attendance yesterday and last evening, is expected to hasten the resumption of National Automobile Shows in this city.

Although there is an increasing need of inter-departmental conferences, there is little scientific knowledge of methods and techniques which make conferences successful, according to a group of University of Michigan research psychologists.

The Communist party in the United States, organized in 1919 with seventy-six members, now claims a membership of 60,000. In its own right the party has had scant success; it has elected only a handful of Communist candidates to public office. Indirectly, however, the CP is thought to have wielded influence through organizations set up as "Communist fronts" and by throwing its support to such other parties as the American Laborites and Progressives.

Readers of this department may recall that in 1935 Dr. John J. Bittner, then of the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory but now of the University of Minnesota, discovered what is known as the "milk agent" or "milk factor" in mice.

MISS ANTHONY presents Dolly Madison as the President's wife who most affected American history and as our most famous First Lady. The judgment may be challenged on behalf of two others, Abigail Adams and Eleanor Roosevelt. The former left more complete personal records than Dolly did -- pouring herself into letters, many of which long ago appeared in print.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- President Truman turned from the inauguration and its festivities today to affairs of state and the task of putting his campaign pledges into effect.

The Communist party of the United States, successor -- once removed -- to the American section of the old Communist International, is, in effect, on trial in the Federal District Court in New York. Prosecution of eleven of its twelve national committeemen is the means by which the party itself is being tried.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Jan. 22 -- Strong indications were given in the Netherlands today that this country would fight to the bitter end against the latest United States resolution proposing a solution to the Indonesian question.
BOSTON, Jan. 22 -- The swift Swedes here on a tour of the indoor track circuit gave further evidence of their prowess tonight at the Massachusetts Knights of Columbus Games.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 (UP) -- Snow and driving winds arose today to beat back efforts to save about 1,000,000 head of cattle and sheep facing starvation on Western ranges. Bad flying weather delayed a day at least the start of the Air Force's "Operation Feedlift," by which it planned to fly hay and cottonseed cake to thousands of starving sheep in southeastern Nevada.

DAVID DAVIDSON, author of "The Steeper Cliff," here tells a story that should appeal to adventure-lovers, armchair-travelers and Hollywood scouts. He tells it well, he tells it easily. And in the telling, he displays a shy concern with one of the great themes of modern fiction: the discovery of the price, as well as the value, of the good life.
NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 22 -- A new athletic conference of five smaller New Jersey colleges was announced today.

First large shipments of Yugoslav copper under the new policy of Premier Marshal Tito aimed at trading with the West are now en route to the United States, it was learned here yesterday. A shipment of approximately 3,000 tons consigned to Phillips Brothers, Inc., 70 Pine Street, is due here this week, according to S. Ulman, president of the importing company.
DETROIT, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The car industry has made the heaviest investment in its history to change over to 1949 model production.

THE gloom attendant on Hollywood's production slowdown, which has affected employment so drastically that the Motion Picture Relief Fund now is $325,000 in the red, lifted a little last week with the announcement by two studios that production will be resumed in February.

EVERYONE connected with the Metropolitan's recent performance of "Nozze di Figaro" read the article "Lively Figaro" by Olin Downes in the last Sunday issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES with interest and appreciated the writer's opinion, calling it "the outstanding model, where the Metropolitan is concerned, of what operatic production should be."

LONDON, Jan. 22 (Reuters) -- After two week-ends of cup play English soccer attention centered on league competition today. Not one major upset was recorded, with the teams obviously awaiting the next phase of the cup battle.

The announcement in the Sunday TIMES of Dec. 26 that Milhaud "has completed his fourth symphony" seems to imply that the work has just been finished; and there is an inaccuracy in the statement that "He wrote it in Paris -- to commemorate the hundredth anniversary of the 1848 revolution."

The end of statistical work on entries for the Westminster Kennel Club show in Madison Square Garden Feb. 14 and 15 developed that 2,562 dogs were nominated, twenty-two more than last year, and that the entries of almost 500 others arrived too late, among them the dogs of three members of the Westminster K. C.

Members of Spanish-speaking institutions met yesterday at the 110th Street Community Center, 31 West ll0th Street, to find ways "to lift the cultural iron curtains that wall off our Puerto Rican and other Latin communities." The Spanish-American Youth Bureau Inc. -- an organization of volunteer workers -- and the center sponsored the conference.

WE are indebted to Orazio Frugoni, the pianist, now of this city, for the loan of the score of a novelty, which he introduced in France last summer and of which he will give first American performances, including one with Thomas Scherman and his Little Orchestra in this city next season.

THE letters of D. H. Lawrence contain very much the same things that one finds in his creative work. There is no significant difference between the letters and the novels or short stories, except that of the minimum form his art required.

Indications that non-ferrous metal markets are definitely "off and down" were reported here yesterday by four leading metal refiners. Calculations were being made to figure future price levels of refined secondary metals. One refiner, contrary to others, concluded that downward price revisions on copper scrap are impending.

WASHINGTON. IN his challenging book, "The Man in the Street," Thomas A. Bailey portrays public opinion as a giant, sometimes fickle, ignorant and uninformed, but always and everywhere supremely powerful. He assigns a dramatic role to the body of public opinion formed by the American people. "

Giuseppe Di Stefano, young Italian tenor who made his debut last February, assumed his fourth leading role with the Metropolitan Opera yesterday afternoon. It was Alfredo in the season's second performance of Verdi's "La Traviata."
For the first time a living cell constituent has been identified positively and discovered to be present in exactly the same amounts in all animals of a given species.

BOSTON, Jan. 22 -- The New England Council, the super chamber of commerce for the region, took cognizance of mounting unemployment rolls by authorizing its industrial development committee to launch an immediate "boost New England" campaign on a nation-wide basis.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Jan. 22 -- The Williams basketball team tonight snapped a seven-game losing streak as it topped Fordham, 60 -- 52, in a fast game.

SO appealing, so warm and quick with life are the writings of Sholom Aleichem that he has stimulated translators all over the world. His work has appeared in such various tongues as Lettish, Esperanto and Japanese. Town Hall was packed with a very friendly audience when Myra Hess, returning to America after the interval of a season, gave her piano recital there yesterday afternoon. Miss Hess prefaced her performances by announcing that she would play from the music. She said frankly that she would feel more secure with the printed page before her than without it, and would therefore be able to interpret more freely.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Jan. 22 (AP) -- The Rochester Royals subdued a hustling New York Knicks five, 103 to 98, in a double overtime Basketball Association of America thriller tonight.

While the explosive hazard of heavy inventory holdings is still a factor in the rayon textile markets, an upturn in business since the beginning of the year has brought about a definite easing of the situation, textile men pointed out last week.

NANKING, Jan. 22 -- A separate peace settlement for the Communist-besieged city of Peiping was concluded today as Premier Sun Fo's Cabinet prepared to negotiate for a general peace on the basis of the Communists' terms.

THE word "existentialism," M. Sartre remarked recently, "no longer signifies anything at all." This is not because it means nothing but because it means too much. There is no existentialism, there are only existentialisms. Here now is a Christian version of existentialism from the point of view of the "existentialist intellectualism" of Thomas Aquinas.
Retail activity here last week centered on resort shops, spring dresses and sportswear clearances, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

The fourth lecture in the current series on music history conducted by Dr. Curt Sachs, consultant to the music division of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, will be held tomorrow at 8:30 P. M. in Room 213.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 22 -- The corps of cadets at the United States Military Academy had plenty of opportunity to cut loose with vocal effects today. For Army athletes made a sweep of a six-event varsity program.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Jan. 22 -- Maj. Gen. W. A. Bishop, acting regional director of North Rhine-Westphalia, has pledged Britain to guarantee that German interests in the Ruhr, as provided in the Ruhr statute, will not be breached.

Sometimes bequests made to charitable, educational or religious organizations, ordinarily exempt from the Federal estate tax, may be partly or wholly restricted as to their tax-free status by other provisions of the will.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., Jan. 22 -- John C. Knox, senior judge of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, tonight vigorously defended selectivity in the choosing of grand and petit Federal juries.

A new type of adjustable cable, already in use by airlines for lashing cargo, has been installed recently by the Grace Line in the garages of its passenger liners Santa Rosa and Santa Paula, the steamship company announced yesterday.

ATHENS, Jan. 22 -- A week which brought renewed confidence in the political field was marred by the latest reports concerning military operations. In the capital negotiations among political leaders saved the day for normal parliamentary procedure.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Inter-American Economic and Social Council in a statement today endorsed the program enunciated by President Truman in his inaugural address for world-wide economic cooperation to stimulate production in underdeveloped areas.
During the temporary absence of Catherine Mackenzie, her column is being conducted by Mr. Frank, director of the Caroline Zachry Institute of Human Development.

ROME, Jan. 22 -- While groups of young students staged anti-Soviet demonstrations in the streets of Rome protesting against the delivery to Russia of Italian warships in accordance with the terms of the peace treaty the Communist "peace offensive" apparently designed to induce the United States to adopt a policy of appeasement toward Russia was resumed today.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 22 -- Ownership of tidewater lands and labor and race relations were matters that captured the attention of the Deep South this week on the Government "home front." Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi and Alabama, with Gulf Coast shorelines, are vitally interested in the dispute over Federal ownership of submerged areas.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Jan. 22 -- A libel action against seven trustees of the City Affairs Committee of this city, started in 1942 for $8,400,000 in damages has been dropped by the two surviving members of the Hudson County Board of Taxation removed from office in 1942 by Charles Edison, then Governor of the state.

" PEACE, plenty and freedom," was a summary offered for President Truman's inaugural address. This was called the first of its kind which devoted attention almost entirely to foreign affairs. The "forgotten man" of the New Deal, therefore, becomes a world citizen.

THIS story of Georgia Tech by its president emeritus wanders, as a lively and intelligent mind will wander; it is full of asides and anecdotes; the prose is strictly nineteenth century. Though Dr. Brittain shows no hesitancy to offer advice or polite rebukes, it obviously pains him to say anything harsh about anybody, as he found it necessary to say about some of the latter-day Governors.

AS for the small proportion of life that can be given to the vivendi causae, the things that make it as a whole worth living, that is all of a piece with the ways of nature. Most invertebrate and even cold-blooded vertebrate life is the residue of enormous potential fecundity gone (as we say) to waste -- I forget how many thousand eggs go wrong for one codfish that gets hatched.
President Truman's Inaugural Address was hailed by rabbis in sermons here yesterday.

IN the past there were no literary explorers more intrepid than those who had just visited England or America. Armed with the certain knowledge that both countries were fundamentally the same (except for the slight affectation of superiority existing in each), any English-speaking visitor could feel a pardonable book coming on as soon as he saw either the white cliffs of Dover or the Statue of Lerty.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 (AP) -- St. Joseph's College outshot Rhode Island State by a wide margin tonight to defeat the New England quintet, 91 to 71, in the second game of a double-header at Convention Hall.

Bucknell University's courses in civil, electrical, mechanical and chemical engineering have been accredited by the Engineers Council for Professional Development. The council has granted full accreditation to the first three programs and has voted to accredit provisionally for two years the work in chemical engineering. Of Bucknell's current student body of 2,411 students, 588 are enrolled in engineering courses.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia; Jan. 22 -- The Yugoslav Government shipped $3,676,000 worth of strategiv raw materials to the United States in December and January as a result of a sharp decline in trade relations with the Soviet Union and states in the Soviet bloc.

LITTLE ABINGTON, Cambridgeshire, England, Jan. 15 -- It is hard to find a farmer in these parts who is satisfied with what Britain's Labor Government has done for agriculture, but it is easy enough to find hired hands who are pleased.

Prompted by the recent death of a child from a disease of the blood, a special blood bank will be established at Memorial Hospital next week for all children in this area suffering from cancer and its allied diseases. The undertaking will be sponsored by Local 2, United Association of Plumbers, AFL.

KURT Weill's career may be summed up roughly with this progression: from composer of atonal symphonic and chamber music pieces to author of successful, full-length operas to writer of hit tunes for Broadway musicals.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Redistribution of labor to insure greater production of vitally needed commodities was urged this week by Lord Balfour of Burleigh, chairman of Lloyds Bank, Limited, in his annual statement to stockholders. Present austere living standards, he said, could be improved only by stepping up production in the right places.

Henry Mond, who succeeded his father as Baron Melchett of Landford in 1930, was chairman of the British Committee for the World Jewish Congress in 1933, and a leader in the Jewish boycott of Nazi industry.

CLARENCE STREIT'S "Union Now," proposing a federal union among the United States, the United Kingdom, France, and a dozen smaller European democracies, was first published in 1939. The German victories of 1940 having made this proposal patently impossible, Mr. Streit revised his book in 1941 as "Union Now With Great Britain."

In a move termed revolutionary by one of its advocates, the United States Lawn Tennis Association yesterday scheduled the national amateur championships to start immediately following the Davis Cup challenge round at Forest Hills without so much as an intervening day of grace.

Of the many requests the public receives to support worthy health, welfare, educational and philanthropic activities, there is one that few New Yorkers can conscientiously turn down. That is the Salvation Army's current maintenance appeal for $1,100,000.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 22 -- A ring of international smugglers, including United States military personnel and civilian Military Government employes, illegally transporting high - priced German manufactures as well as currency, gold and silver, has been uncovered, United States Air Force headquarters in Wiesbaden announced tonight.

The New York City Housing Authority found it necessary to collect "only $6.01 a month" in rent subsidies last year to help pay the cost of shelter for each of the 18,370 families living in permanent low-rent housing projects here, Thomas F. Farrell, chairman of the authority, reported yesterday.

The policy pursued by Germany in imperial days for the preservation and cultivation of forests was a model for the world. German advice on forestation was asked by countries that had learned by bitter experience what happened when trees were ruthlessly sacrificed to meet immediate commercial needs. Two world wars and a Nazi regime have left German forests in such a condition that the effect on Europe as a whole is already disturbing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UP) -- Six hundred needy Washington children were outfitted in new clothes from Argentina today, and the political implications of the windfall, if any, did not seem to bother them.

Buyers in the wholesale apparel market here last week looked forward to spring retail business with optimism and the outlook was further brightened by what they called "generally good" values, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

PEOPLE were once deeply upset by the notion that machines could do the work of human muscles. Perhaps it was fear, the nightmare vision of robots running wild, or of a Dictatorship by Machines as pictured in Capek's "R.U.R."

Many business organizations are misusing employe aptitude and intelligence tests in hiring general clerical office personnel, R. L. Forster, president of the Office Executives Association of New York, declared in an interview last week.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- President Truman became the country's first $100,000-a-year President this week by the skin of his teeth. The day before his inauguration he signed the bill raising his pay.

" PATTERNS IN FLOWERS" is the subject of H. Stuart Ortloff, landscape architect, as the annual midwinter garden course sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES goes into its second week. Part of a series of four lectures by garden experts on the theme "Your Garden and Mine," they are held on consecutive Wednesdays at Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

CAMDEN, N. J., Jan. 22 -- With fuel supplies about gone, the two-day strike by 465 gas workers here was ended early this morning after all-night mediation efforts by Federal, state and city mediators.

TO Robert Carbury, born 1891 and lulled by Victorian vistas of continuity and security, World War I was a rude awakening that determined the course of his adult life. To Adrian, his son, "born 1925," and conditioned from boyhood to uneasy headlines and a sense that the world was adrift beneath his feet, World War II was the normal expectancy -- the inevitable detonation of the unrest he had grown up in.

PEIPING, Jan. 22 -- Peiping fell to Communists today -- quietly, politely and in accordance with her traditions -- a feat possible only in China. The Nationalists are bowing their way out while the Communists bow their way in under complicated and somewhat unfathomable agreement.

CHURCHILL, Man., Jan. 22 (AP) -- Twelve men, forced down on a Hudson Bay ice floe when their Dakota aircraft ran out of gas yesterday, were rescued today by a ski-equipped Royal Canadian Air Force Norseman plane.

RHODES, Jan. 22 -- Official peace between Israel and its Arab neighbors may still be a long time in coming, and there is every chance of serious internal trouble in the Arab states before it does. One experienced diplomat predicted recently that those states that had to do so would reach armistice agreements with Israel but refuse peace negotiations in the hope of minimizing trouble in their own countries.

This is the time of year when government on all levels, federal, state and municipal, begins looking around for. new ways to raise more money in taxes, and we hear faintly, here and there, renewed appeals for reform of the tax structure. Duplication of taxation, as between federal government and the states, is of course an old, old story.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., Jan. 22 -- Muhlenberg tonight gained an overtime 46-39 basketball victory over Long Island University before 3,500 fans in Rockne Hall.

Several national advertisers are showing willingness to raise "new money" for television ventures, David Sutton, CBS-Television sales manager, told more than 250 CBS station managers attending the second session of the three-day CBS television clinic at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 22 -- Representatives of nineteen Asian and African nations in closed session here today unanimously adopted a draft resolution calling upon the United Nations Security Council to order the Netherlands Government to effect a complete transfer of sovereignty over all its rich East Indies colonies to the United States of Indonesia by 1950.

MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 22 -- Plans were reported today for using the findings in a survey of Protestant churches in Nassau County as a basis for discussion in a conference of Protestant leaders on the whole problem of the church and the suburbs of the New York Metropolitan area.

Well-known women of society and debutantes of this season will act as hostesses at the three-day preview of paintings by Edna Reindel which-will open tomorrow at the Macbeth Gallery, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street, for the bene-I fit of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service. ' .
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 22 (AP) -- Red-haired Patty Berg soared to a 76 in the Tampa Women's Open golf tournament here today, but held first place by one stroke at the end of 54 holes.

Lavelli is ranked with Hank Luisetti, the famous California player seen before the war around the Garden, and with other basketball greats, although the marvelous Dutch Dehnert, in many minds the best of them all, also called the inventor of the pivot shot, isn't even mentioned.

Congratulations on Allan Taylor's sympathetic, understanding, "Cold War on the Buses." Because of its good humor, I believe it will help all of us, bus drivers and passengers, to be more tolerant of our common problems.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Dr. Edith Summerskill, Parliamentary Secretary of the Ministry of Food, who was recently challenged on her statement that it was impossible to distinguish between margarine and butter, has invited her challenger to take a blindfold test.

ATLANTA, Jan. 22 -- The Ku Klux Klan was a hot issue in the Southeast this week, and although the organization won a battle in the Georgia Legislature, public sentiment against it seemed to be mounting.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 22 -- Seasonal upturn of new orders for shoe manufacturers started to evidence itself in the week just ended, although not to a great extent. Manufacturers expressed the belief it was still too early to determine if the pre-war pattern will show up in satisfactory volume, following the slack of late November and December.

For more than a century changes in the age composition of the population of our country are assuming tremendous import. In 1850, 42 per cent of our population were under 15 years of age and less than 3 per cent were 65 or older. In 1940, only 25 per cent were under 15 and approximately 7 per cent were 65 or more years of age.

FREEPORT, L. I., Jan. 22 -- Why thieves should break into the house of the chief inspector of Nassau County police, ransack it thoroughly and walk out apparently empty-handed was puzzling Nassau County detectives today.
The Soviet Council of Ministers is giving serious attention to improvement in the quality and variety of consumers' goods, according to information from Soviet sources that has just arrived here.

With a major policy address last week by Irving S. Olds, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, a few days after members had approved an enlarged program of the American Iron and Steel Institute, the nation's steel industry has started an intensive campaign to build up public and community understanding of its operation, achievements and problems.

OPPORTUNITIES for a wide variety of photographic activity, both indoors and out, are described in companion books, "Photography Outdoors" and "Photography Indoors" (Baltimore: The Camera Magazine. $3.50 each), just published. Both volumes are part of the Camerette Photo Library series.
After rising from private to four-star general in an Army career spanning forty-five years, Gen. Courtney H. Hodges, First Army commander, disclosed yesterday that he would retire on Jan. 31.

The three national chairmen of the $250,000,000 United Jewish Appeal announced yesterday that no part of the $100,000,000 loan granted to Israel by the Export-Import Bank would be available to meet the needs of the agencies of the appeal.

THIS is the time when pygmy laurel begins sprouting among the scripts of fledgling playwrights and when play-contest jackpots sprinkle checks across Broadway's bush leagues. Harvest time for the playwriting contests is at hand and scriveners who tossed a few acts together for a college drama society some years back are once more waylaying the mailman for the announcement and cash they hope to parlay into Pulitzer Prizes.

TEQUESQUITENGO, Mexico -- The historic haciendas of Mexico, long a top ranking tourist attraction, are going a step farther now and are taking in tourists as paying guests. The trend toward modernizing haciendas and converting them into hotels and guest houses has been even further specialized around Mexico City.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- Proof that the All-America Football Conference, which yesterday decided to carry on in 1949 as a seven-team league, means business, was offered today as the group speedily concluded its meetings. It accepted the resignation of Admiral Jonas Ingram, its two-year commissioner; immediately named his successor; adopted a Shaughnessy play-off plan; elected officers and transacted other business.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 22 -- Stressing that radio must be maintained as a medium of free speech, Wayne Coy, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, denied tonight charges that the commission has been exercising powers of censorship or attempting to curtail the right of expression.

THE one hundred and forty-fourth annual exhibition of painting and sculpture assembled by the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts opened yesterday evening in the institution's galleries with a preview and reception at which awards and prizes were announced by Joseph T. Fraser Jr., director.

Declaring that "we talk glibly about human rights but are unwilling to do anything about it," Walter White, executive secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, urged Senate leaders yesterday to vote for an amendment "permitting cloture by a majority vote and stop the long and disgraceful filibuster on the civil rights program by the Southern states."

ZINNIAS, one of the most popular and easily grown annuals, offer a wide choice in size and color. For the past several years they have given gardeners considerable trouble by coming untrue to color. Last season showed marked improvement in this respect, so careful color schemes can again be planned.

A MINIATURE coldframe, no larger than a wheelbarrow and attached to a south window of the house, will give the gardener a head start in raising his seedlings for spring. For warm air, entering from the house through an open window, plus the light and solar heat penetrating through the glass roof, induces the plants to grow well early in spring, while it is still chilly outside.

The stock market maintained yesterday the pattern of drifting within a narrow range to a slightly firmer close. Due to transfers of large blocks of low-price utility shares, business on the Stock Exchange expanded to 280,000 shares from 270,000 for the preceding short session.

Cooperating with Government plans to protect vital manufacturing areas from possible atomic attacks, America's billion-dollar industries are well on their way toward a decentralized relocation of many installations. In the lead in-this trend automobile, electrical machinery, farm equipment, textile, chemical and metal producing industries are already spreading their operations from coast to coast.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- A Government survey foresaw today more demand in the next few years for college graduates in medicine, psychology, teaching in kindergarten and elementary schools, and some phases of electricity.

THE old recipe for rabbit stew that began, "First catch your hare," relates to steak, too. The directions for preparing a good one, which will be as tender as young lettuce and twice as flavorful and succulent, read: "First get a fine steak." Ensnare the butcher into selling you aged top-grade beef of a cut right for broiling. Age (three to four weeks) and quality count here more than skin at the stove.
A Navy reserve pilot lost his life in one of two airplane crashes in the metropolitan area yesterday. A civilian pilot escaped unhurt from the second crackup.

THIS being an age of specialization, we now have a book concerned solely with the mechanics of lifting things. Boys, and girls too, of 8 to 12 should be interested in Mr. Bechdolt's account of "elevators," ranging from those used by cliff dwellers to those in skyscrapers, in aircraft carriers, and in theatres to move stages.

With top priority given the Administration's bill to extend export controls, the Senate Banking and Currency Committee will hold its first hearing on the new legislation next Friday. The bill extends to June 30, 1951, the President's power under the present law to prohibit or curtail exports. Since the present act, Public Law 395, expires on Feb. 28, the proposed extension would run for twenty-eight months.

Permit me to congratulate you on your recent editorials on the activities of the "Un-American Committee" in Congress. Probably very few of your readers will endorse the criticism expressed in the letter of Eugene-Lyons. He has obviously misinterpreted your attitude.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- Central Westerners this week devoted their attention chiefly to newspaper, radio and television reports of President Truman's inauguration, its preliminaries and aftermath. And it was evident without the research of pollsters that the populace in general, regardless of party affiliation, was sympathetically aware of the Herculean task confronting the President in the next four years.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Jan. 22 -- Boys High School continued to dominate the metropolitan schoolboy track picture today by carrying off top honors again in the third annual St. Peter's College High School meet at the Jersey City Armory. It was an easy victory for Brooklyn's Red and Black clad performers.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 22 -- Three Rings today drove to a half-length triumph in the $12,350 Royal Palm Handicap as the favored Faultless finished third and the highly esteemed Marchons II was last in the field of nine at Hialeah.

OF forty-four 1948-vintage Rumanian stamps, which the Washington Legation of the People's Republic of Rumania made available last week, fifteen are items of which American philatelists until now have had no knowledge. This suggests the possibility that other countries in Europe printed numerous 1948 stamps which have not yet reached New York dealers.
The public phase of the controversy between the Port of New York Authority and the eight scheduled airlines forming the Airport Leaseholders Committee broke out afresh yesterday.

FEW Americans know much about the War of 1812: what little they recall usually adds up to an impression of an American victory won by the heroic exploits of the new American Navy and crowned by Jackson's smashing defeat of the British at New Orleans.

Preliminary arrangements are progressing for the second government-supported field experiment in underground gasification of coal, it was disclosed here yesterday by the Bituminous Coal Institute. In collaboration with the Alabama Power Company, the United States Bureau of Mines will conduct this research on a 300-acre tract near Gorgas, Ala.

THE Mayerling legend, which fascinated the world for many years has found its most glamorous embodiment in the Charles Boyer-Danielle Darrieux film: because the handsome Prince cannot marry his less-than-royal Vetsera, the lovers decide to leave this world behind them forever.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 22 -- The Radical party, which holds all but one of the minority seats at the constitutional reform convention, rejected last night the idea of walking out after seeking to have the meeting declare itself illegal. After several postponements the convention is now set to open Monday afternoon in the Chamber of Deputies.

" TELEVISION, too many second-rate titles and too many $4 and $5 price-tags. Well," said the publisher, wiping away a tear (his martini was extra dry), "I suppose we'll survive, though at the moment I doubt it."

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 22 -- The old question of proprietorship over the Colorado River for power and irrigation purposes turned up in the news in the West again this week as the Arizona Legisatlure ratified the Upper Colorado River Basin states' compact.

THE title, "Tributary Theatre," once used widely to designate dramatic activity off Broadway, now seems to be losing its popularity and to be giving place to another term, "Regional Theatre." "Tributary" has never been a truly descriptive title, not because it implies a dominant position for New York, but because it suggests that all good drama up-country, in the regions, must inevitably direct its flow downward toward the city.

" PERHAPS more important than anything else today is the permanency of Modern design," said Mary L. Brandt, home furnishings consultant, in her talk at the furniture market press-day dinner held early this month in Grand Rapids.

Many young women are aiding in the plans for the annual Valeni tine BaH for the benefit of Irvingon House, a sanatorium in Irv-: !ington-on-Hudson for children suffering from rheumatic heart disi ease, to be held on the night of Feb. 12 at Sherry's.

Caught in a vortex of rising costs and unprecedented demands for service, the New York Telephone Company began last Thursday its formal plea before the Public Service Commission for increases in rates that would add $49,000,000 a year to its revenues.

TORONTO, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The Maple Leafs battled the National Hockey League's pace-setting Detroit Red Wings to a 2-2 tie tonight. Young Tod Sloan banged home the tying marker late in the final period as Toronto gained a fourth-place deadlock with the Chicago Black Hawks in the standing.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 22 -- Labor leaders of anti-Communist trade unions in twelve European countries and the United States met in Berne today to promote labor participation in the European Recovery Program.

New York University ran off with the team title in the revived Grover Cleveland Athletic Club games that prevented New York from being totally eclipsed by Boston in the track and field picture at the Seventh Regiment Armory last night. It was a handicap event, with some good athletes competing against many hopefuls.

DURING the last five months there has been a marked change in business conditions. The boom has leveled off so that the forces of inflation and deflation now seem to be roughly in balance. As a result, the country is now confronted with the problem of preserving stability, not simply of checking inflation.

Unemployment rolls have risen in many parts of the country, but business leaders and Government officials see few signs that the falling off in employment foreshadows any substantial drop from last year's high levels of industrial activity.

THE commanding general of the Western Defense Command early in 1942 issued a memorandum, in the name of the American people, on persons of Japanese descent in the United States. This memorandum can serve as almost a complete catalogue of blind group prejudice and blind thinking.

The impact of higher taxes on bank earnings in 1949 is now receiving increased attention in banking circles. The banks, already concerned over their ability to equal 1948 earning levels this year. see little prospect of business improvement offsetting the anticipated higher tax rates.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 22 -- Yale won its fifth straight basketball game and its eleventh of the season against four defeats by trouncing Providence College, 88 -- 51, before a capacity crowd in the Payne Whitney. Gym tonight.

AFGHANISTAN was a forbidden country when A. C. Jewett, an American engineer, went there to install for the Amir a hydroelectric plant at Kabul. At its then British-Indian frontier a military warning read: "It is absolutely forbidden to cross this border into Afghanistan."

VIENNA, Jan. 22 -- President Truman's definition of democracy in his inaugural speech has attracted all the more attention in Vienna because Austrians have been able to compare it with the authoritative up-to-date definition of the "people's democracy and socialism" by Matyas Rakosi, vice president of Hungary and as head of the Hungarian Communist party, the nation's real ruler.

Germain G. Glidden, three-time national champion from the home club, provided the big upset of the day as the third annual Harry Cowles invitation squash racquets tournament opened yesterday on the courts of the Harvard Club.
The strategy of the Party is not something permanent, fixed once and for all. It changes to meet historical shifts, historical turns.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- President Truman's inaugural speech has echoed around the world and raised hopes and fears, but after a little exploration and meditation by the officials here the tendency is to conclude that there is less in the speech than meets the eye.

On the steps of the nation's Capitol early last Thursday afternoon the thirty-second President of the United States made his inaugural address. Harry S. Truman was speaking his first words as President in his own elected right. The Truman address was profoundly solemn. Its solemnity was all the more pronounced because it stood out so sharply against last week's spectacular inauguration celebration -- a celebration such as Washington had never seen before.

TOKYO, Jan. 22 -- Anti-American propaganda from Communist sources here is becoming increasingly bolder. Communist party candidates in the campaign for tomorrow's elections have been telling audiences that Japan is exporting at low prices and importing at high prices and hence is doomed to become "America's slave."

TRAVELING thirty miles from the old Sampey Place to visit her Aunt Maria at the county seat was a signal adventure for Judy Jemison. Her curiosity about her aunt's house sharpened when, on the train, she met an old lady bound for the same address -- Number Eleven Poplar Street -- but another rooftree.

LUXEMBOURG, Jan. 22 -- A warm tribute is being paid this week-end by the people of the tiniest of the Western European powers to their ruler, the Grand Duchess Charlotte of Luxembourg, on the occasion of her fifty-third birthday tomorrow and the thirtieth anniversary of her reign.
Warfare has broken out between two powerful American Federation of Labor unions for control of 9,000 inside workers of the Railway Express Agency in the metropolitan area, it was learned yesterday.

OMAHA, Jan. 22 -- Prices received by farmers have taken a much sharper drop tha many city consumers realize. But the rural Midwest was well aware this week that the edge was off its eight-year boom. The average farmer is not viewing it with alarm, however, for several reasons.

THE Metropolitan Opera's rerival of Verdi's "Falstaff" and its annual production of Wagner's "Parsifal" will be in the hands of Fritz Reiner, who will conduct at least ten performances with the company. His first appearance will be on Feb. 4 conducting Strauss' "Salome."
MONTREAL, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The Canadiens, scoring in every period, downed Boston, 4 -- 2, tonight to pull into a second-place tie with the Bruins in the National Hockey League.

DETROIT, Jan. 22 -- Five extraordinary steps, requiring an oath of loyalty from all police officers and from newspaper reporters seeking unrestricted police and fire press cards, were imposed today by Police Commissioner Harry S. Toy to meet what he called "the dangers we face from Communists and Communist sympathizers in our midst."

NANKING, Jan. 22 -- The retirement of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek as President of China, which marks the third time that he has stepped down for the sake of political convenience in his two decades of Kuomintang [Government party] leadership, is regarded here as opening the first real opportunity for peace negotiations with the Communists.

There was a better approach last week to the stock market although it was studded with caution, lacked the accompaniment of volume and remained highly professional. Notwithstanding this gingerly nibbling at stocks, which did not allow any individual section to outshine the list as a whole, prices managed to reclaim the losses of the preceding week and do even a little better.

BERLIN, Jan. 22 -- The establishment of a Western German state, originally expected in March of this year, probably will not take place until June, according to United States Military Government sources here.

The American Merchant Marine, which in the past has never figured too prominently in the deliberations of a new Congress, will be the recipient of considerable legislative attention from the Eighty-first Congress if the unprecedented number of bills affecting the future of the maritime industry that have been introduced since the present session started on Jan. 3 can be taken as a criterion.

PLANTS that are grown primarily for their foliage furnish refreshing touches of green throughout the house, when the outdoor scene is drab and dreary. Unlike flowering plants, which must have sun, foliage plants thrive in light alone.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 22 -- An international program to reorganize the building industry -- specifically to scrap "backward handicraft" methods for quick, mass production by prefabrication -- was urged here today as the surest way to ease the world's acute housing crisis.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 22 -- Up on Jerusalem's Hill of Evil Counsel, Arabs and Israelis were working tonight to prepare the former Government House for the United Nations Conciliation Commission, which is due to arrive on Monday. Arab workmen were repairing the furniture and generally tidying up the place while Israelis were replacing telephone lines and arranging for the resumption of the water supply.

SEVERAL airlines last week offered tourists tempting bargains in tours from cities on the eastern seaboard to Bermuda, the Caribbean islands and Miami. Both Colonial Airlines and Pan American World Airways tied their Bermuda flights to domestic lines in a combination that drastically reduces fares to Bermuda as that island's spring season gets under way.

IN last week's Treasure Chest, I included a passage from Gide's Journals (a book that any writer or any reader with a genuine interest in literature must find rewarding) in which he stated his belief that "the truth lies in youth." It was his complaint that so few of his contemporaries had remained faithful to their youth, in the process of what is so often deceptively called "learning from life."
RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 22 -- Some uncertain breezes were blowing around the Upper South this week.

OKINAWA was one of the bloodiest battles of the Pacific War and one of the most sanguinary in the whole history of conflict. It took the lives of both commanding generals, of 110,000 Japanese, of 12,520 Americans. The enemy lost 7,800 aircraft in less than three months in his frenzied Kamikaze attacks upon U. S. shipping. U. S. losses included thi.rt, y-six ships sunk, 368 damaged, and 763 planes destroyed.

In March, 1927, a 39-year-old general named Chiang Kai-shek became the dominant figure in China. He was the successor to the late Dr. Sun Yat-sen -- "father of the Chinese Republic," -- as chief of the Kuomintang (Nationalist) party and head of the armies with which it crushed a group of war lords.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 22 -- Navy took complete charge in the second half to score a 52-to-46 basketball victory over the University of Maryland tonight. The score was tied six times in the first half, but 20 seconds before half-time Captain John Barrow of the middies tossed in a long set shot for a 25-to-24 lead.

TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 22 -- An unemployed New Jersey resident can spend the winter in Florida and still draw his unemployment compensation, according to a policy of the New Jersey employment security division.

TAKING issue with the assertion by New York representatives of Indonesia (the new name for philately's Dutch Indies) that stamps prepared by the Republic of Indonesia are not valid as international postage, Basoeki Djatiasmoro, repres ting the republic in New York, said last week that its stamps "have been and are being used in international postal exchange."
