Milo Roy Maltbie, 77-year-old chairman of the Public Service Commission, the most influential state regulatory body in the country, retired at midnight last night after twenty-seven years of almost constant preoccupation with the formidable task of safeguarding the rates of utility services for 14,000,000 persons.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 -- Sales reported last week in department stores in the Third Federal Reserve District were 7 per cent ahead of a year ago. Last week's sales reported by department stores in Central Philadelphia were 5 per cent greater.

Improved harbor conditions and increased trade were responsible for a 60 per cent increase in 1948 over 1947 of shipping tonnage in the Brazilian ports of Rio de Janeiro and Santos, according to preliminary estimates of the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau here.

Ranking leaders in every phase of Jewish activity gathered last night at a dinner in honor of former Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Proskauer, president of the American Jewish Committee, at which Mr. Proskauer announced he would retire today as head of the committee.

The prospect of New York City's midtown commercial district becoming devoid of commercial activity -- unless the present stringent traffic and parking regulations in that area are modified -- was put forward last week by wholesalers and manufacturers with midtown offices or factories.

Dr. A. E. Mirsky of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research told an all-day symposium of the American Chemical Society's New York Section last week that he had positively identified a chemical constituent of genes, which are to life what atoms are to matter.

FOR THIS WEEK: Order seeds of vegetables and flowers as soon as plans can be made and quantities estimated . . . As root growth permits, bring indoors a few pots of hyacinths or tulips at a time, in order to have succession of bloom for several weeks . . . Cut down, rake up and burn underbrush in out-ofthe-way corners.

NEW ORLEANS, La. -- A major controversy is raging here between a group of business men and the New Orleans Hotel Association over the feasibility of adding more rooms to the city's obviously inadequate supply of hotel accommodations. Because of the scarcity of rooms, and the ever-growing popularity of New Orleans as a resort and trading center, the five-day limit on hotel-room occupancy is still in force.

A burst water main yesterday gave three blocks of midtown Broadway the appearance of a volcano about to erupt. For more than two hours it was feared that an explosion might rip up huge sections of the street between Thirty-seventh and Thirty-ninth Streets.
Pickings must be slim indeed for New York City felines if it takes them a year and a half to reach cathood as stated in "A Cat Is a Cat Is a Cat" by Rhea Talley.
CAIRO, Jan. 22 -- The Egyptian Government has prohibited the export of 25,000 bales of cotton purchased last week by the Soviet Union for delivery to Czechoslovakia.
Italy, once on the brink of collapse and revolt, is well and firmly started on the road to recovery, James D. Zellerbach, European Recovery Program Administrator in Italy, declared yesterday.
City Construction Coordinator and Commissioner of Parks, City of New York. President, Long Island State Park Commission. Chairman,
LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 22 -- Ben Hogan, with a brilliant five-under-par 66 in the rain, moved to the top spot at the midway mark of the $10,000 Long Beach open golf tournament today.

MISS RUSSELL'S newest Crime-Club special takes us to the town of Valsbury and the office of police chief Homer Fitzgerald -- who loves to be left alone, and is really incensed when a lady turns up murdered in his bailiwick.

THERE are many ways of approaching the subject of democracy and of defining its meaning. In this brief volume, scarcely more than an essay, but always challenging and frequently brilliant, the author has chosen to concentrate on the facts of democracy in this generation.

FORT SILL, Okla., Jan. 22 -- The artillery school here at Fort Sill, the professional and spiritual home of the Army's gunners, has developed a new and simplified method of adjusting artillery fire which promises far greater efficiency in training methods, consumption and accuracy.

Some years ago, a 15-year-old boy left school to help support his invalid mother. He learned of an opening for a runner m Wall Street but when he appeared at the personnel department he found that the other boys who were applying for the job were college students.

Results of two successful experiments in group therapy, one with alcoholics in New York and the other with college women in Berkeley, Calif., were made public yesterday. They were reported on at the closing session of the sixth annual conference of the American Group Therapy Association.

" THE worst crime you can commit today, against yourself and society, is to forget what happened and sink back into indifference. What happened was worse than you have any idea of. And it was the indifference of mankind that let it take place." These words of warning are from a 1948 postscript to this profoundly moving concentration-camp diary of Odd Nansen, son of Fridjof Nansen, Arctic explorer and 1922 Nobel Peace Prize winner.

THOSE millions of Americans who are heavy with a book or wistful about one they always meant to begin, are advised to put a red circle around Tuesday's date. W. Somerset Maughum becoming 75 on that day, will throw open for competition one of the top author's billets in the world by retiring from the writing profession.

A BRIGHTER ground-glass image and a new automatic film stop feature the Kodak Reflex II twin-lens camera, which was introduced recently at New York's Camera Club by Fenwick G. Small of the Eastman Kodak Company. Equipped with a pair of matched Kodak Anastar f/3.5 lenses, the camera, with a field case, will sell for $154.91.

More chinks in the "iron curtain" shielding Russia's satellite nations are becoming visible to the financial district as a result of recent developments affecting the service of the external dollar debts of Czechoslovakia and Bulgaria.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- New controversies among Republican leaders developed tonight as Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr. of Pennsylvania, chairman of the Republican National Committee, appointed a GOP Executive Committee of fifteen members -- eight men and seven women.

The growing tendency of school art programs to emphasize "the importance of the art process to the individual" rather than to concentrate on the end products is noted in the 1948 issue of "Art Education Today," published by Teachers College, Columbia University.

THE Goldbergs came to television last week and the word this morning is that they probably are going to be there for just about as long as they choose. Gertrude Berg's account of life in the Bronx with Molly, her family and her neighbors reaches the home with all its warm-hearted and genuine appeal intact.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Possibility of further progress toward international control of atomic energy rests largely on a political change in Russia, a prominent political scientist said today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 22 -- Following the advances in retail business activity during the previous week, reports of retail sales in the Twelfth District for the last week were spotty. Larger stores showed dollar volume ranging from plus 16 per cent in San Francisco to minus 15 per cent in Salt Lake City.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The plan of Senator Elbert D. Thomas, chairman of the Senate Labor Committee, to hold hearings for a month and a half on a bill to repeal the Taft-Hartley Law ran into some dissent today in Congress and in the Administration.

Mr. Truman took a long look at America's responsibilities in this troubled world as he spoke on Thursday from his elevated rostrum on the east front of the Capitol. Some of what he said his hearers might have taken for granted, although it was all well said, and what was old could stand repetition.

SPEAKING of the interim report on European recovery made to Congress by the experts of the nations benefiting from the Marshall Plan, the leading Paris newspaper, Le Monde, said that the United States was in a greater hurry to build and unite Europe than Europeans were.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The District of Columbia was distinguished by having two floats in the inaugural parade Thursday -- an "official" float, devoid of political implications, and an "unofficial" one, sponsored by civic groups and featuring a huge ballot box bearing the legend, "Freedom to Vote."

THIS mystery novel, notable for its sly plot-twists, features two suspects -- a New York racketeer and a successful writer of mystery stories. Sam (the Sport) DeVito positively entered the house in Flatbush, about the time the corpse hit the carpet; Greg Stockton (the expert in literary mayhem) may have done likewise.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 22 -- An eleventh-hour proposal to break the Swedish - Norwegian stalemate on a Nordic defense alliance was made today at the opening of the conference of the premiers and foreign and defense ministers of Norway, Denmark and Sweden, according to reliable sources.

A surprisingly small percentage of shareholders liquidated, their holdings of stock in 1948, or in the market break after Election Day, according to the January issue of The Exchange which published a study of the relationship of trading to the number of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 22 -- In the belief that college students should understand and appreciate the democratic way of life, Cornell University is inaugurating a long-range program that will stress the basic elements of the American and Western tradition. Greater emphasis is to be placed on the role that the young men and women will be called upon to play after graduation.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Jockey L. C. Cook returned today from a ten-day rough-riding suspension to spur Checkerhall to a one-length victory in the $3,000 Black Gold Handicap at the Fair Grounds.

FRANKFORT, Jan. 22 -- Abrupt reversals in the relations between Germany and Russia have developed twice in recent history. Many have warned that German sympathies may veer again as suddenly, in the event the Western powers make enough mistakes in policy here.

MOST stories of contemporary life for older girls stress the molding of character by the exigencies of everyday problems. In this unusual novel, however, a young girl's courage is tested by a desperate struggle against the elements high in the Sierra Nevadas.

AT the beginning of this novel, the protagonist, Neil Miller, burns some canvases he had painted years before. This act, it seems, expressed the author's desire to consign the self-pitying artist hero of recent novels to the incinerator. As an alternative the author devotes himself to those social and intellectual problems which have attracted our serious writers from Fitzgerald to Trilling.

Muzzle-loader shooting seems to be undergoing quite a revival these days, but the big problem confronting many of those now showing an interest in the old rifles is the source of supply, for most of those found in local antique shops are long On decoration but short on utility.

The Charles Frederick Chandler medals, awarded periodically by Columbia University for outstanding scientific achievement, will be presented this year to two emeritus professors of the university. On Tuesday at 8:15 P. M. in Columbia's Havemeyer Hall, Dr. Henry C. Sherman, Mitchell Professor Emeritus of Chemistry, and Dr. Marston T. Bogert, Professor Emeritus of Organic Chemistry, will receive the 1948 medals and give addresses.
Harold E. Stassen, president of the University of Pennsylvania, received yesterday a gold medal for "distinguished Americanism" from the International Benjamin Franklin Society.

SINCE the first airplane flew, the spectacular stunt flight has been the most effective way of dramatizing aviation. Twenty or more years ago daring and unusual hops by private citizens and members of the armed forces served this purpose.

HOW much longer the seller's market in cars will last is one of the major problems to be considered by the National Automobile Dealers Association convention opening in San Francisco tomorrow. The organization has a membership of 35,000 and reports on purchasing conditions will be heard from all sections of the country.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- The State Liquor Authority, in its annual report, revealed today that the great majority of mayors and town supervisors responding to a questionnaire were opposed to an amendment to the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law which would transfer the responsibility of enforcement from localities to the state.

A priest's plea for blood donors to help keep the spark of life burning in two Brooklyn youngsters suffering from Cooley's anemia was answered yesterday when more than 150 persons appeared at his church to make their life-giving donations. Of these, 115 gave blood.

Five factors have combined to indicate that 1949 will be a year of challenges to management, Harold B. Maynard, president, Methods Engineering Council, Pittsburgh, declared in an interview here. Mr. Maynard cited these factors as including (1) unbalanced sales, and production, (2) higher prices, (3) shortages of all types, (4) a labor-minded Government, (5) the defense program superimposed on the current high level of business activity.

The American Jewish Committee ended its forty-second annual meeting at the Astor Hotel yesterday with the election of Jacob Blaustein, Baltimore industrialist, as president, and the adoption of a statement defining the principles that will guide the organization in "the coming years."

The national executive committee of the Zionist Organization of America, meeting yesterday at the Statler Hotel, announced that a special committee headed by Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind would make a study of the "future program and constitution of the World Zionist Organization."

A rise in Italian exports of about 40 per cent over 1947 is the best evidence of the progress made last year by Italy toward economic recovery, according to Leo J. Wollemborg, associate editor of "Economic News from Italy."

The New York Americans of the American Soccer League, just back from Cuba, were eliminiated yesterday from the National Challenge Cup competition at Sterling Oval when they lost an exciting game to an eleven representing the New York Sport Club of the German American Soccer League. The score was 4 -- 3.

SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Ray Blum of Nutley, N. J., and Miss Mary Lynch of Newburgh, N. Y., carried off championships today in the fifth annual Adirondack outdoor speed skating competition. Duplicating performances of last week-end at the seventeenth annual Eastern Skates speed skating at Saratoga Springs.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 23 -- A full-length portrait of Nfrs. Reverdy Johnson, wife of the United States Attorney General under President Zachary Taylor, has been presented to Princeton University by a group of twenty-one persons to augment the university's collection of the paintings of Thomas Sully.

Mayor O'Dwyer's announcement of a training course on all aspects of atomic energy for teachers in the city schools demonstrates once more the alert leadership of New York's school system. It is also a credit to the United States Atomic Energy Commission, which, in cooperating on the course, is fulfilling its policy of informing the public on developments in this great new force in our lives.

Fervor and shouts of foul play in Greek and English created more than the usual excitement yesterday when swimmers retrieved a cross from the Hudson River in the Greek Orthodox Church's celebration of the Feast of the Epiphany.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- The Board of Regents was accused today of raising "bogey-men" that baselessly frighten the people of the state in its efforts to obtain greater control over the new state university. It was charged also that the Regents' campaign for control might defer development of the university.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- The latest return of the Bank of England is noteworthy because it shows that practically all of the exceptionally large amount of extra currency that was required for the Christmas season has now returned from circulation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UP) -- The country's soft-coal operators reported today that they have a fifty-day coal supply on hand. Some industry members saw it as enhancing prospects of peace in the coal fields this spring.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 23 -- Half of the Danish delegation to the Nordic mutual defense conference here swung over today to the Swedish stand on a "neutrality pact," with the result that the conference came close to a breakdown. The talks, scheduled to finish tonight, will drag out to Monday, although Danish political circles estimated tonight that its chances for ultimate success were only "one out of ten."

WHEN David Davidson's first novel, "The Steeper Cliff," was published two years ago it aroused considerable enthusiasm in this quarter. Thinking it over, I still think that I was generally right, if perhaps a little too enthusiastic. "The Steeper Cliff" was an impressive performance, technically accomplished, dramatically effective, refreshing in its concern with moral and ethical problems.

A large Brooklyn industrial property passed to new control with the sale of eight buildings ranging from six to ten stories in the entire square block bounded by Jay, Pearl, Water and Front Streets by Vincent and Mary Coraci to Albert H. Graham, operator.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Miss Patty Berg turned in a 74 today to win the Tampa women's open golf tournament with 295, equaling the women's competitive medal play record.

Miss Vera Halliday and Edward G. Picken of the Washington Figure Skating Association took first place in the senior dance title competition of the Middle Atlantic Skating Association at Iceland yesterday. The runner-up team was the Skating Climb of New York pair of Miss Phyllis Schroeder and Samuel Stokes, while Miss Vera Ruth Elliott and Rex Cooke of the Metropolitan Figure Skating Club were third.

BERLIN, Jan. 23 -- The German Communist party, the Soviet Union's ally in Germany, is to be prepared for the next phase of the cold war for political supremacy by a rigorous purge of all nationalist elements, by organizing activist groups designed to wreck the West German state and absorbing all subsidiary parties into a single socialist front under the hammer and sickle flag.

The Celotex Corporation, in its annual report to be issued to stockholders today by O. S. Mansell, president, disclosed an increase in net sales to $54,190,341 in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, last, from the volume of $46,872,119 of the previous year.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 23 -- The resolution of the Asian conference in New Delhi, urging complete transfer of Dutch sovereignty over all the East Indies to a United States of Indonesia by 1950, was regarded here today by most observers as a move that would hasten United Nations Security Council action on the question.

ZURICH, Jan. 23 -- A resentment that long has been latent among Swiss banks, insurance companies and airlines at the prohibitive gold policy of the Swiss National Bank has burst into a storm of protest.

Showing just a little more hustle and proving more effective in the foul-shooting department, the Washington Capitols, pace-setters in the eastern division of the Basketball Association of America, handed the New York Knickerbockers a 97-to-93 setback before 10,123 fans at Madison Square Garden last night.
CANTON, China, Monday, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Former Premier T. V. Soong, brother-in-law of President Chiang Kai-shek, announced in a farewell radio speech last night his retirement from public life.
The principals in the National League's oldest and most spirited baseball feud will not have to wait long in 1949 before they'll be able to start operating upon each other with customary vigor.

OF all the moves that baseball has made the one which has aroused the greatest envy on the part of other sports is its Hall of Fame. Ever since the Cooperstown shrine has been established there has been constant discussion by devotees of other forms of athletics for similar shrines of their own. Hockey has made the most progress in this regard with a flourishing Hall of Fame in Canada.
New York's Foreign Trade Zone at Stapleton, S. I., received and shipped 281,625 long tons of merchandise during 1947, it was announced yesterday, by Mayor O'Dwyer.
Reversing the downward trend of previous years, philanthropic gifts and bequests showed a 55.09 per cent increase in 1948, according to an eight-city survey made public yesterday.

Fashioned after the crisp, rod-shaped wafers that Europeans serve with ice cream, Stickbits are the most delectable "cookies" we've sampled in a long time. The Continental version, called hohlhippen because they're hollow, are served plain with ice cream.

James R. Brigham has been appointed vice president in charge of production of Diagraph-Bradley Industries, Inc., manufacturer of stencil cutting machines, with headquarters in Herrin, Ill. Jack R. Arthur was named vice president in charge of sales, with New York headquarters at 30 Church Street.

LITTLE SILVER, N. J., Jan. 23 -- The alert high school boy who years ago lighted the gas lamps in the streets of near-by Shrewsbury every night to pay his way through Princeton University will become New Jersey's No. 1 lawyer today when his appointment as State Attorney General is due to be confirmed by the Legislature in Trenton.

TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 24 -- Former Premier Shigeru Yoshida's ultra-conservative Democratic Liberal party apparently has won this morning the Japanese general election held yesterday and will form the next government under Gen. Douglas MacArthur.

The Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at Ninetieth Street, appealed to his congregation yesterday to give blood to save the life of 20-year-old Thomas McQuade, a sufferer from hemophilia (uncontrollable bleeding) and a parishioner of the church.

Flexible arrangements of furniture plus refreshing color schemes characterize the newly decorated rooms that open today at Bloomingdale's. Described as "Settings for Ceramics," some of the rooms take their color cues from earth and clay tones.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 23 (AP) -- The United Automobile Workers Union at the Studebaker Corporation called off a scheduled strike vote today and agreed to return to work tomorrw.

Jean Graham, 22-year-old pianist from Dayton, Ohio, Saturday night made the appearance with the Philharmonic-Symphony at Carnegie Hall which was her reward for winning last year's Leventritt contest. The program, led by Leopold Stokowski, included the first performance of Maurice Baron's "Ode to Democracy" and the first in New York of Henry Cowell's "American Piper."

BERLIN, Jan. 23 -- Two of the five radio outlets in Germany taken over by the American Military Government after the war will be returned to German authority this week. This is the beginning of a process whereby the Germans will recover almost complete control of the information media in the Western zones this year.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Venezuela has announced the withdrawal of her Ambassador to Chile, accusing that country of "unfriendly conduct."

Speaking for an agency which has been active in the displaced persons field from the very beginning and which -- being international and nonsectarian -- has sponsored the admission of displaced persons of all nationalities and creeds, I would like to express my unqualified agreement with your editorial of Jan. 8 concerning DP legislation.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 23 -- The Trusteeship Council -- one of the United Nations' principal organs -- will open its fourth session here tomorrow to examine the progress made in the last year to improve the lot of some 15,000,000 inhabitants of territories under the Council's jurisdiction.
Five physicians, each with a record of fifty years of service to the community, were guests of honor last night at a testimonial dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The National Association for American Composers and Conductors, Inc., gave the second in its series of five concerts at Times Hall last night. The New Music Quartet played Wallingford Riegger's String Quartet No. 2 at the beginning of the concert and again at the end.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Army and Navy Union, the oldest veterans organization in the United States, announced today that its annual Aviation Medal has been awarded to the personnel of the Berlin airlift.
Regarding the letter of James H. Durkin concerning the white - collar worker, I have a comment to make.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Colder weather over the main corn belt has started farmers to sell that grain with high moisture content more freely, offsetting to a large extent heavy purchases by the Government.

The number of discontinuances of profit-sharing plans during the last decade has been "fairly low," with thirty-five out of 202 plans, or 17 per cent, being allowed to lapse, according to a survey of the National Industrial Conference Board, released over the week-end.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks gained undisputed possession of fourth place in the National Hockey League tonight by playing the New York Rangers to a 2-2 tie before 16,618 fans.

SEATTLE, Jan. 23 (UP) -- Three University of Washington professors dismissed after being accused of Communist activity said today they would appeal to the American Association of University Professors to intervene in their behalf.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 23 -- Two meetings to be held here within the next week are expected to play a major role in deciding whether the 2,000 members of the Allegheny County League of Women Voters will follow the lead of their local officers in breaking with the national organization.
In your editorial on Isaiah Thomas you mentioned among his contributions his publication of the first English Bible printed in America.

BOSTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Gordon (Red) Henry, 22-year-old goal tender on twenty-four-hour loan from the Hershey American Hockey League club, enabled the Boston Bruins to break their second-place National Hockey League tie with Montreal's Canadiens by subjecting the latter to a 3-0 shut-out tonight before a crowd of 13,900 at the Boston Garden.
DETROIT, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Nearly five million automobiles built in 1935 or earlier were licensed last year.

Understandably, it is with a mixture of feelings that Dr. Milton James Ferguson, in his eighteenth and final annual report as Chief Librarian of the Brooklyn Public Library, heralds the approach of his retirement in the spring. It is too bad that Dr. Ferguson's thoughts as he prepares to leave his duties must be of the city's inadequate provision for salaries, new books, building repairs and the like.

In this fourth winter of "peace," the International Children's Emergency Fund of the U. N., which is doing splendid and vital work, is still operating at what its chairman calls the "fringe of the problem." For lack of adequate Government contributions, it is reaching but 4,500,000 children with a minimum of milk and food out of the estimated 200,000,000 children whose lives are jeopardized by hunger, disease and homelessness.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Administration leaders in the House and Senate will concentrate this week on speeding "Truman program" bills through several committees that must act before the measures can come to floor debate and vote.

Two books about the life of Christ are scheduled for publication by two concerns. Doubleday will issue on Feb. 3 Fulton Oursler's "The Greatest Story Ever Told: A Tale of the Greatest Life Ever Lived," an account based on the four gospels.

Charges that more than half a million residents of Brooklyn faced loss of access to hospital care and the prospect of increased medical hosts after July 1 were made yesterday by a group of general practitioners at the Israel Zion Division of Maimonides Hospital. They declared that their patients would suffer because the hospital has directed doctors to limit their practice to one field of medicine by that date or be dropped from the staff.
Jascha Heifetz came back to New York yesterday on a concert tour after a twenty-month sabbatical leave from violin engagements.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 23 -- The choice of Walter Schevenels, Belgian labor leader, to head the Paris office of the Trade Union Advisory Committee in the European Recovery Program may lead to the withdrawal of the American Federation of Labor from the group, it was learned today.

Prices of cotton in the domestic market for future delivery continued mixed last week, although spot cotton and the near future deliveries manifested relative strength. At the week's end active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 33 points higher to 1 point lower than the week before.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UP) -- The Air Force announced tonight that it hoped to start operating its new "feedlift" tomorrow in an effort to save thousands of cattle and sheep stranded in the blizzard-swept Western grazing regions.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Creation of a permanent community fund campaign committee, to be headed by Fairfax Cone, advertising executive, was announced today by James L. Palmer, the fund's president.
Research in engine development to reduce automobile motor fuel requirements by more than 40 per cent was outlined yesterday at the General Motors show at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LARCHMONT, N. Y. Jan. 23 -- In an easterly wind of fourteen knots that built up some at the end, the sailing dinghies at the Larchmont Yacht Club today had one of their best regattas of the winter season. There were forty-one of them out and all kept on their feet.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Jan. 23 -- Vandals entered the graveyard of historic St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church at Eastchester here some time last night and overturned, uprooted or otherwise damaged twenty-two headstones and one marble Madonna.

PARIS, Jan. 19 -- Ever since last autumn, when the Foreign Ministers deputies failed to agree on what should be done with Italy's former colonies, the Western powers have been trying to reach an accord among themselves on the future of those areas.

Dr. Mario Emilio Cosenza, academic dean of Brooklyn College, announced yesterday that he would retire on Feb. 1. The 68-year-old dean, who had served in various posts from tutor through acting president with City and Brooklyn Colleges, recalled that it had been "only" forty-seven and a half years since he became a teacher.

The 100th anniversary of the graduation of the first woman to receive a medical degree in the United States, Dr. Elizabeth Blackwell, was observed yesterday in ceremonies at the New York Infirmary, 321 East Fifteenth Street, and at Hobart and William Smith Colleges in Geneva, N. Y.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Miss Margaret Truman will soon return to her musical career with New York as her headquarters, the White House announced today. The statement read: "Miss Margaret Truman has signed a contract with Mr. James A. Davidson of New York City as her manager in concert and allied fields for the season 1949-50."
LONDON, Jan. 23 -- One night shortly before Christmas, 1941, Alf Fry and his wife, who lived in a little house in the Limehouse district of London, got a present from Germans.

Jennie Tourel gave the audience of the New Friends of Music an exceptional experience yesterday afternoon in Town Hall when she sang the 1948 version of the Hindemith cycle, "Marienleben," extensively revised by Mr. Hindemith from the original version of these settings of the Rilke poems, vintage of 1923.

CAIRO, Jan. 23 -- The Governments of Egypt, Britain, the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan and Ethiopia are now considering gigantic projects to build dams at sources of the Nile at Lakes Victoria, Albert and Tana, a canal through the swamps of the Sudd and a new storage reservoir in the Sudan.
BERLIN, Jan. 23 -- The Soviet-controlled Berlin radio played Beethoven's "Appassionata" sonata today in its observance of the anniversary of Lenin's death; and an announcer quoted Lenin as follows:

In his final report as president of Fordham University, issued yesterday, the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, who will retire on Feb. 2, told his trustees that in the seven years since his preceding report the university had maintained its high standards and traditions.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Liquidation was on in lard futures on the Board of Trade early last week. All deliveries sold at new low price for the season and the cash article was quoted at $14.20 a 100 pounds at one time, lowest since June, 1945.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 23 -- Former Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes urged today that the Federal Government put all money received from the sale of tideland oil into a gigantic trust fund to expand and improve public education.

BOSTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The signing of Holy Cross co-captains George Kaftan and Dermie O'Connell was announced tonight by the Boston Celtics of the Basketball Association of America. No salary terms were disclosed.

RHODES, Jan. 23 -- Another day of meetings here has failed to get agreement between the Egyptian and Israeli delegates on armistice terms. Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine, spent the day conferring with the delegations separately in a vain effort to reconcile their viewpoints.
New York continues to be the largest center of small businesses in the world, the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., reported yesterday.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 23 -- For the first time this frostbite season a protest decided the winner of the Class B competition on Manhasset Bay this afternoon.

The Sheffield Farms Company, Inc., which rejected the request of John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, that it reduce its wholesale milk price, contended last night that its profit averaged only one-quarter cent a quart. F. J. Andre, president of the company, made the assertion in an "Adventures in Industry" radio interview over station WMCA presented by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc.

A plea that the Anglican and Orthodox churches may some day be "welded into an ever-deepening unity," was voiced yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Vasile Hategan, rector of St. Demetriu's Rumanian Orthodox Church and president of the Orthodox and Anglican Fellowship.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Representative Frederic R. Coudert Jr., Republican, of New York, proposed today that the Federal Government take the lead in a $3,000,000,000 program of slum clearance.

ATHENS, Jan. 23 -- Greek Army reports today from Leonidion, on the east coast of the Peloponnesus, said that the rebel attackers of the town had been driven westward into the Parnon Mountains. There they were encircled in a small village by two units of the army's new Commando force and were virtually wiped out.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Jan. 23 -- William George, assistant Hudson County counsel, formerly first assistant prosecutor of pleas, here, and at one time minority leader in the New Jersey Assembly, will be arraigned Tuesday morning before Judge Cyril Galvin in the First Criminal Judicial District Court on a charge of atrocious assault and battery.

Details of the group insurance plan that it has adopted and will sponsor for the protection of officers and employes of commercial banks were disclosed yesterday by the New York State Bankers Association. Establishment of the plan, to be underwritten by the Prudential Life Insurance Company of America, will be announced officially this morning at the association's twenty-first annual mid-winter meeting in the Commodore Hotel.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Britain's de facto recognition of Israel, which is now a virtual certainty, will be delayed a few days, it was learned tonight. Before taking this step, Government officials wanted to make known their decision to the Dominions and the Arab Governments.

A union representing employes of American Airlines adopted yesterday a new labor strategem when it decided to conduct a strike that is not officially condoned by the union but is classed as a "spontaneous demonstration."

PEIPING, Jan. 23 -- Peiping remained orderly today as plans for the take-over were being laid behind locked doors. The Communists' political take-over representatives, who are admittedly in the city, have remained hidden and incognito.

Mayor O'Dwyer will open WNYC's tenth American Music Festival, an annual event extending through the period from Lincoln's birthday to Washington's birthday, on Feb. 12 with an address preceding the broadcast by the Westminster Choir from 5 to 6 P. M.

Ralph Kirkpatrick, American harpsichordist, gave another of his absorbing recitals last night at Town Hall. He confined himself to two of the greatest composers for his chosen instrument, Bach and Scarlatti. And again there was instruction, as well as playing that was full of life and spirit.

The Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, which once was reluctant to deal with the League of Nations, has decided to concentrate its major efforts on cooperation with the United Nations, according to its 1948 annual report to the trustees made public yesterday.
The gift of $8,000,000 from the Kress Foundation to the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center is a magnificent contribution to the physical well-being of our people.

In his recent letter Howard W. Toner states that a man with a wife and two children and an income of $5,000 (net) now pays an income tax of $448. He fretfully observes that this man "works a month to pay his income tax." As in the manner of folks handling statistics, he leads us cautiously back to 1929, when, he states, a man similarly situated would have paid a mere $3 tax.

"Leaf and Bough" came to the Cort on Friday night and staggered out after its third performance on Saturday night -- a $97,500 flop. Advance expectations were indeed high for the first Broadway play written by Joseph Hayes, Such a director as Rouben Mamoulian, who doesn't accept anything on the spur of the moment, thought so, too.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 23 -- Ending a four-day conference of nineteen Asian and African nations on Indonesia this morning, India's Prime Minister, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, as chairman, told the delegates and observers it might be hoped "that this historic conference is the forerunner of a period of close cooperation between our respective countries" and a strong new role for Asia in world affairs.

Definite decision of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the United States to launch a promotional campaign on men's and boys' clothing was announced over the week-end by Raymond H. Reiss of the International Tailoring Company, president of the association.

PARIS, Jan. 23 -- Former Soviet official Victor Kravchenko's libel suits against the Communist weekly literary paper Lettres Francaises and Andre Wurmser, one of its contributors, are scheduled to be heard beginning tomorrow afternoon.

Athenagoras I, Patriarch-elect of the Greek Orthodox Church, left the New York International Airport at 3:39 P. M. yesterday for Istanbul, Turkey, where he will be enthroned Thursday as spiritual leader of 125,000,000 members of Eastern Orthodox Churches throughout the world.

President Truman thinks a man with an income of more than $6,000 a year should pay a larger income tax. I know a college professor who receives $6,600 a year, which is a very good salary in his profession. Last year he paid $720 in Federal income tax and $60 to the State of New York.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UP) -- Non-scheduled air carriers today transmitted to President Truman their charges that the Civil Aeronautics Board is attempting to "destroy" them.
Three new films, including an importation from Italy, will arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

The election of Henry Morgenthau, former Secretary of the Treasury, as chairman of the board of the Palestine Economic Corporation, and Henry Montor, former vice chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, as vice president of the corporation was announced yesterday.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 23 -- This community is engaged in a concerted effort to transform itself from a quiet suburb into the 'brightest town in America" in honor of its most noted citizen, the late Thomas A. Edison.
The irregularity of the Argentina peso pending posting of the official schedule of new exchange rates was the only disturbing incident of the week in the foreign exchange market.
OMAHA, Jan. 23 -- Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr. defied his critics today and said he would not resign either as Republican national chairman or as a member of Congress from Pennsylvania.

ROME, Jan 23 -- Palmiro Togliatti, Communist leader, again has called upon President Truman to send a "peace mission" to Russia. He spoke this morning to a large and enthusiastic audience in the Adriano theatre.

Ch. Major Mite of Honan, a rich silver gray, owned and handled by Mrs. Nathan S. Wise of Cincinnati, won the best in show title at the 63rd specialty show of the Pekingese Club of America, under the judging of Miss Sara F. Hodges of Wilton yesterday. The show was held at the Hotel Belvedere.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- The salaries of hospital employes increased 10 per cent in 1948, and their hours of work per week declined from the previous year, the American Hospital Association reported today. The association recently completed its fourth annual countrywide study of hospital salaries, covering 4,623 hospitals of all types except Federal.

NANKING, Jan. 23 -- Six Communist columns under Gen. Chen Yi, with an estimated strength of more than 100,000 men, were reported to be advancing virtually unopposed tonight down the Tientsin-Pukow railway toward Nanking, the now demoralized capital of China.
The third annual children's exhibition of the Village Art Center, 224 Waverly Place, was opened yesterday with some of the gayest paintings in town.

Within the space of twenty-four hours over the past week-end, Sweden's Erik Ahlden and Ingvar Bengtsson, with stalwart assistance from Willy Slykhuis of The Netherlands, banished a myth of twenty years' standing.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Executives of two import-export companies in Chicago charged today that small firms engaged in foreign trade were being ruined by Washington bureaucracy coupled with an allegedly obvious inclination on the part of Marshall Plan officials to favor "big business."

BIRMINGHAM, England, Jan. 15 -- Here in Britain's biggest industrial center, trade union officials and ordinary workers seem to think that the Labor Government in London has justified its existence in three and a half years and will be returned to office in 1950.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 23 (AP) -- A flexible rod has been made that permits bending light shining through it like water running through a garden hose. And it will carry a beam of light better than air.

Fundamental goals of both labor and management can be reduced to about four on each side, according to a forthcoming report of the labor committee of the Twentieth Century Fund, the foundation announced yesterday.

SALISBURY, Conn., Jan. 23 -- Artie Devlin's hill - breaking achievements, interrupted in Feb. 1947, when he fractured his right leg at Leavenworth, Wash., were resumed today as the Lake Placid Club skier carried off the Connecticut State jumping championship.

The already complex traffic situation in the garment area will become even more complicated this week because much of Broadway between Thirty-eighth and Thirty-ninth Streets will have to be torn up and relaid, it became known yesterday.

Since Grace and Paul Hartman are present and accounted for, "All For Love," which opened at the Mark Hellinger Theatre on Saturday evening, is not completely destitute of talent. No matter how dull an occasion may be, Paul always carries that dismal face around with him, looking sullen, stupid, fatuous, bewildered, and resentful by turns; and Grace always retains that embarrassed toothy giggle.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 23 -- The Dutch financial situation threatens to develop unfavorably owing to the heavy military commitments in Indonesia by the Government and requirements connected with enlarging its military power in the frame of the Western Union.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Fonty Flock of Atlanta, Ga., won the first annual 100-mile stock car sweepstake race at the Fort Lauderdale-Davie Speedway today before an estimated crowd of 6,000.

ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Jan. 23 -- A neat little liner, the Dalerdyk, has made its appearance in this port to receive a final polishing and adjustments before sailing next Friday on its regular run between the Netherlands and the west coast of the United States and Canada.

Exporting manufacturers in the United States, whose accounts were handled by 900 agencies, spent about $6,000,000 during 1948 on 19,935 pages of advertising in magazines published here for circulation overseas, according to a survey made by Export Trade Shipper, a weekly magazine.

Miguel M. Najdorf of Buenos Aires succeeded in drawing for the second time against Dr. Reuben Fine of New York in the sixth game of their match contested at the rooms of the Marshall Chess Club, yesterday afternoon.

BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 23 (Reuters) -- Indonesian Republican leaders interned in Sumatra are maintaining their refusal to negotiate with the Dutch over the formation of an interim Federal Government unless the Republican Cabinet is allowed to convene and is recognized as a Government, a usually reliable source here said today.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Jan. 23 (UP) -- Donald W. Douglas, builder of aircraft, told airlines today not to junk the earliest models of his DC-3 transports because he could do a face-lifting job that would make them virtually into new planes.

This week is a notable one in the art world, with an unusually large number of important group and one-man shows scheduled in the New York galleries. Chief interest is centered in the exhibition of Donatello's statue of San Lodovico and a loan collection of Italian nineteenth century paintings from museums and private collections in Italy.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 23 -- The volume of the nation's steel output last week is regarded by steel men here as an answer to those who advocate putting the Government into the steel business. On an annual basis output was more than 96,000,000 tons. Such a rate could not be held indefinitely but; according to sources here, it shows what the industry is capable of doing when it has the raw materials and the equipment.

DETROIT, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Gordon Howe returned to the Detroit line-up after a twenty-game lay-off with a foot injury and scored the first goal as the Detroit Red Wings beat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2 to 1, tonight to hold their wide first-place margin in the National Hockey League.

Robert P. Patterson, president of Freedom House and former Secretary of War, told an audience in Carnegie Hall last night to be wary of Soviet gestures of amity. He declared that courage and resolution were "essential" in facing the discouragements of our time.

The Spear Box Company, which owns and occupies the block front on the east side of Eleventh Avenue, from Twenty-seventh to Twenty-eighth Street, has expanded its realty holdings at that point by purchasing the adjoining six-story building at 547-53 West Twenty-seventh Street through to 548-52 West Twenty-eighth Street.

A vast tragedy of unforeseeable consequences for the Western World is now taking place in China, where the crumbling Government of Acting President Li has apparently abandoned all hope of successful resistance to the Communist armies and is suing for peace on Communist terms that call for its unconditional surrender.

Stanley W. Pearson, national champion from the Merion Cricket Club of Philadelphia, captured top honors in the third annual Harry Cowles invitation squash racquets. tournament at the Harvard Club yesterday. He defeated Germain G. Glidden, three-time national title-holder from the home club, in the final by 15 -- 10, 15 -- 7, 15 -- 12.

The League of Composers paid homage to the late Paul Rosenfeld at the Museum of Modern Art last night, playing a program of some of the composers he discovered. Dates of the music ran from the early Twenties to the late Forties, and Mr. Rosenfeld's published comments on some of it were appended.

PARIS, Jan. 23 -- Although a statement by the French Foreign Office today said talks between French and British experts foreshadowed more French exports to Britain this year than in 1948, British officials said there would be no substantial change.

A favorable outlook on spring business along with improved quality and good values brought prompt confirmation of retail orders for spring merchandise, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The text of a resolution on Indonesia adopted by the nineteen-nation Asian conference follows:

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 23 -- United Nations delegates and officials are devoting intensive study to the question whether Secretary of State Acheson will give a new orientation to United States policy regarding China and Berlin.

Two Cardinals were in the sanctuary at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. Cardinal Spellman presided and Clement Cardinal Micara, Prefect of the Sacred Congregation of Rites at the Vatican, occupied an improvised throne opposite.

Extraneous circumstances lend more than usual interest to the annual report of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, made public this morning. The report was presented to the trustees on Dec. 13, and with it the resignation of the Endowment's President, Alger Hiss.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Changes of prices of grains and soy beans were very rapid last week on the Board of Trade. December corn, September and December oats and July beans sold at new seasonal low prices before a strong rally carried them back above the close of the previous week.

Hardly a day passes but what some individual or community deplores the nation-wide shortage of psychiatrists and calls for action to increase psychiatric services. In the midst of all this clamor for help with mental illness, psychiatrists last week in the columns of this newspaper issued a word of caution.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Officials administering the Marshall Plan will be asked on Friday to work out a system whereby business created by foreign aid spending will be "distributed equitably throughout all sections of the United States."
The National Broadcasting Company apologized last night to Defense Secretary James Forrestal for an "ad lib" remark that Mr. Forrestal had a major interest in a German cartel.

United Nations officials and leaders in government, education and science will discuss the issues of atomic energy before New York's public school teachers in a new training course that is expected to set a pattern for the rest of the nation, Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday.

Doris Doree, American soprano who has appeared with the Metropolitan and City Opera companies, gave her first recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. She recently returned from England, where she has spent two seasons with the Covent Garden Opera.

The eighty-seventh annual meeting of the board of managers and members of the American Bureau of Shipping will be held tomorrow in the bureau's board room at 45 Broad Street. The ship classification society was incorporated in this state in 1862.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Firing a five-under-par 66, young Jack Burke of White Plains, N. Y., moved into the lead of the $10,000 Long Beach open golf tournament today with a 54-hole score of 203.

A survey of vessels tied up for three months by the recent West Coast longshoremen's strike showed no cargo spoilage on ships that had dehumidification equipment, Oliver D. Colvin, president of the Cargocaire Engineering Corporation, reported yesterday.
A seven-week-old strike by 2,000 bartenders against 650 taverns in Manhattan has been settled and will end today, it was learned yesterday.

The Port of New York Authority yesterday denied charges that it had interfered with airline plans to operate the huge new Boeing double - decked Stratocruisers at New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens.

A dispatch from Belgrade last summer telling of a barley seed sprouting after 700 years became a modern parable yesterday when the Rev. Dr. Charles W. Gilkey, dean emeritus of Rockefeller Memorial Chapel of the University of Chicago, used it in his morning sermon to illustrate the durability of Christianity.

Last week the subject under discussion hero was the undistributed profits tax and the economic theory to which it is related, namely, the underconsumption theory. Since then a correspondent has been good enough to contribute a footnote. He writes:

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- As the stock markets here are always happier when Parliament is not in session, it follows that they did not exactly welcome the reassembly of that body last week. It cannot be denied that the political outlook is threatening, not so much on the domestic account as because of foreign affairs.

The struggle between the Communist-dominated Government of Hungary and the peasants of the country has sharpened recently and the Government is ready to unleash another series of discriminatory measures to force the family farmers and Small Landholders to accept collectivization, it became known yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 23 -- The United Nations canceled tonight plans to release the trapped Egyptians in the Faluja pocket after it was learned that the Israelis here had no intention of cooperating. The plan had been agreed to at Rhodes between the Egyptian and Israeli delegations and was to have been executed early this morning.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 23 -- The Ruhr area is again a first-class industrial center and most of the former managers in factories, mines and banks are again in positions of influence, it was learned during a series of intensive interviews in that region last week.

At this time of year man in these latitudes finds himself particularly vulnerable to a number of germs. These leap upon him with whatever expressions pass for glad cries among micro-organisms and begin gnawing and belaboring his frame, which for months has been starved for sunlight, debilitated by steam heat and deprived of fresh air in health-promoting quantities.

Fritz Reiner will make his debut with the Metropolitan Opera in its tenth week, beginning Jan. 31, it was announced yesterday. He will conduct Richard Strauss' "Salome," in a performance also marked by the debut of Ljuba Welitsch, Bulgarian soprano, in the name role.

Although net sales of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company in the fiscal year ended with last October increased to $93,242,724 from $85,989,056 the year before, operating expenses climbed to $82,850,909 from $75,266,675, the annual report to stockholders and employes disclosed yesterday.

Formation of a nonpartisan Citizens Commission on Labor-Management Relations was announced yesterday by Ben Davidson, State executive secretary of the Liberal party, at its headquarters in the Claridge Hotel. The commission will study labor-management problems and make recommendations on labor legislation to President Truman and Congress, particularly on amendments to the Wagner Act in a shift from the Taft-Hartley law.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Britain's civil service had few known Communists in jobs requiring secret or security work, it was revealed today when Prime Minister Attlee gave the latest figures to the House of Commons. The Government undertook last spring to remove Fascists and Communists from such work.

Traffic along midtown Broadway was slowed but not seriously disrupted yesterday as more than fifty men worked in an area between Thirty-seventh and Thirty-ninth Streets. This section had been closed off as a result of a water main break Saturday at Broadway and Thirty-eighth Street.

Measured in terms of scheduled miles flown weekly, the commercial airlines of the United States have a commanding lead over the airlines of the world, according to a Civil Aeronautics Board summary in the latest edition of "World Directory of Scheduled Common Carrier Airlines."

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- A suggestion that British shipbuilders begin now to plan production of other products when the present backlog of orders runs out in about three years has been made by the Economic Cooperation Administration, it was reliably reported today.

Cutting hrough a pea-soup fog early Wednesday morning, the oil tanker Gulfstream rammed the Coast Guard icebreaker Eastwind at full speed ahead, it was testified yesterday before a Coast Guard board of inquiry.

The work of coordinating, promoting and representing the Protestant community in New York City is ably performed by the Protestant Council at 71 West Twenty-third Street, New York 10, which, because of the many-sided nature of its broad program, finds it necessary each year to ask the public for financial aid.

ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- Dr. Francis T. Spaulding, State Education Commissioner, in a series of questions propounded at a hearing,indicated doubt today that he has power to interfere with a decision of New York City school authorities banning The Nation from school libraries.
The threat of a strike of 350 radio and teletype operators employed by American Airlines was deferred yesterday as a result of intervention by the National Mediation Board.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Ben Hogan of Hershey, Pa., and Jimmy Demaret of Houston, Tex., wound up with a flourish and a tie that left a gallery of 5,000 gasping in the inaugural $10,000 Long Beach open golf tournament today.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Great Britain's decision to extend de facto recognition to Israel has been taken, and official sources gave assurances today that there had been no change in the Government's intentions.

SALISBURY, Conn., Jan. 24 -- This peaceful New England town returned to normalcy today after being host to one of the most interesting and spectacular ski jumps held in the East in a decade. Undaunted by the elements, the Salisbury W. S. A. made "snow" for the Connecticut title jump yesterday.

Commercial and industrial failures during the week ended Jan. 20 reached the highest point in more than six years, it was reported yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The week's total of 142 compared with 148 recorded on Dec. 2, 1942, and with 127 in the previous week this year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, endorsed today the "general purpose" of a bill to clarify and formulate a consistent and coordinated national pricing policy in interstate commerce. However, Edwin L. Davis, a member of the Federal Trade Commission, disagreed with the Secretary.

Interrupting extensive road travels, the Theatre Guild's touring "Carousel" will renew acquaintance with New York theatregoers this evening when it sets up shop at the City Center for a four-week engagement. Since it was on Broadway, from April, 1945, to May, 1947, the musicalized "Liliom," as adapted by Benjamin F. Glaser, has visited twenty states and two Canadian cities, covering 15,000 miles and playing to nearly two million patrons.

ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- Governor Dewey, in a special message to the Legislature, recommended tonight that state aid to education be increased by $40,000,000 over the amount required by the existing formula. He suggested that part or all of the extra amount be devoted to school construction and rehabilitation.

The National Retail Dry Goods Association is sponsoring a public relations campaign that is scheduled to start on or about Feb. 15. The theme of the campaign is "Democracy Works Here" and over 200,000 retail merchants located in every city in the Union have signified their intention to participate.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 24 -- Robed and masked men strode into a church service here, causing two women to faint and leaving the minister speechless.

The Adams Express Company had net assets of $38,252,533 at the end of 1948, compared with $41,097,035 a year before, according to the company's annual report, out today. The asset value was designated at $27.02 a share on the 1,415,200 shares outstanding on Dec. 31, 1948, compared with $27.82 a share on 1,477,187 shares on Dec. 31, 1947.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Jan. 24 -- The country's first antiques and decorations forum opened here today with tours of the historic buildings and a reception in the candle-lit Governor's Palace.

THE most incomprehensible thing in sports is the judging of a fencing match. Two masked and canvas-covered characters slash away at each other with their sabers in such violent fury that a spectator could be pardoned if he expected to see a head or an arm drop disconcertingly to the floor. Then the referee or bout director calls: "Halt!"

LONDON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- A London turf expert suggested today that British thoroughbreds be sent to the United States to race, with the view of encouraging the sale of English-bred horses in that country.

DETROIT, Jan. 24 -- State Senator Robert A. Haggerty went back to the legislative halls in Lansing today with assurances that his wife and four children would receive emergency grants from the City Welfare Department to tide them over until the courts released his pay checks.

The results of the first Long Island waterfowl survey made since 1941 should be of real interest to the coastal wildfowler of this area, for while the survey does not assert any accurate count it gives an excellent picture of the present status of waterfowl in this area.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- London's tiniest and most high-flown theatre, the Mercury, reopened triumphantly tonight with its own famous players in an English version of Machiavelli's wickedly amusing play, "La Mandragola."

After years of hoping that the bus companies would devise a plan for loading, especially at and near origins of runs, I conclude they will not. The situation is worse when using intercity buses because of the longer time aboard. There is no system. Arriving early does not mean a choice of seat.

Putting an end to all speculation on the competitors for the Wanamaker mile at the Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden next Saturday night, Fred Schmertz, chairman of the games committee, yesterday announced the names of the six starters for the classic.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 24 (AP) -- "Personal troops" of President Chiang streamed south out of the Shanghai-Nanking defenses today, vastly complicating Government efforts to beg acceptable surrender terms from the Chinese communists.

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- The question of strengthening the European Council for the Marshall Plan by including in it or placing at its head men of high political rank will be discussed by Foreign or Finance Ministers of member countries in Paris Feb. 17.

Advertisers' need for closer tie-ins of national campaigns with point-of-purchase display will soon bring an increased use in store and counter fixtures of sound associated with major ad themes, it was predicted yesterday by an agency specialist in this field.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- A bill proposing $50,000,000 in Federal aid to states, municipalities and communities for the prevention and cure of juvenile delinquency was introduced today in the House by Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican, of New York.
A heavier and stronger Ike Williams will enter the ring against Kid Gavilan Friday night in the ten-round feature bout at Madison Square Garden, if present plans materialize.
After last week's declines, trade covering in near-by positions yesterday brought about a substantial recovery in coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 24 -- Officials of the United Nations are convinced that the organization can gain a lot and contribute a lot if President Truman uses it discreetly to provide scientific and technical assistance to the underdeveloped areas of the world.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Bills to increase the pay of every member of the Federal judiciary were offered today under Democratic sponsorship.

In a hectic three-hour meeting marked by name - calling, booing and shouted political charges and denials, the Medical Society of the County of New York voted last night to support the American Medical Association's $3,500,000 political war chest for fighting "socialized medicine."

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Jan. 24 -- Five detectives, with the cooperation of school authorities and tavern proprietors, investigated several hundred boys and men of this city and the upper Bronx today in a futile search for the vandals who damaged twenty-two headstones and a marble Madonna Saturday night in the graveyard here of St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church, national shrine to freedom of the press.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 24 -- Expansion of the powers of the Public Service Commission to enable it to force railroads to end smoke nuisances was asked today by the Westchester County Board of Supervisors.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Nell K., a stakes-winning filly from James Norris' Spring Hill Farm, opened her 1949 campaign with a hard-earned victory in the Elusive Purse at Hialeah today.

MONTREAL, Jan. 24 (Canadian Press) -Thefts and pilferage of Canadian export and import cargoes have reached "'astronomical figures," it was disclosed today by ..W. Waugh, chairman of the insurance .avtsory committee to the Canadian Marine Board;

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan, 24 -- The United Nations Security Council was informed by its Committee of Good Offices today that Dutch military action and resultant guerrilla fighting had transformed the Indonesian Republic into a land without law and order, plagued by looting, vandalism and a "scorched earth" program of destruction.
NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Buddy Hassett today signed a one-year contract to manage the Newark Bears of the International League.

The Empire City Racing Association yesterday apparently was a furlong or two closer to (1) rounding out the parcel of ground that will be the site of its new $10,000,000-plus race track in the Bronx, and (2) disposing of its old track in Yonkers to a syndicate which presumably will use it for harness racing.
Otis Co., Cleveland investment firm founded in 1899, announced yesterday a program for expansion and named five new officers and seven directors.

Describing the Berlin airlift at a dinner of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences in the Hotel Astor last night, Maj. Gen. Laurence S. Kuter declared that "for the first time in peacetime history strategic air transport has become a conspicuous expression of American air power, peace power and an effective weapon of diplomacy."
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 8 to 12 points yesterday, with the March contract leading.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Administration, with the President himself taking an active hand, threw its force today behind a restoration of the reciprocal trade agreements program of Cordell Hull, former Secretary of State.

PARIS, Jan. 18 -- The curiously intricate position of the British Empire is brought into focus by the tragic battles between Indian and Zulu crowds in Durban. While both factions are resident in the independent dominion, the Union of South Africa, neither has full citizenship rights in any true sense of the word.

Another highlight was added to the local gridiron slate for 1949 with the announcement yesterday that City College would meet N. Y. U. at Lewisohn Stadium on Nov. 19. Other metropolitan opponents on the C. C. N. Y. schedule are Brooklyn and Wagner.

With the warning that other alleged "divorce rings" were under investigation, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday the indictment of ten persons on charges of perpetrating frauds in at least a dozen marital cases.

Recent freezing weather in the West quickly added about $1 a box to the price that Florida growers received for their oranges. With the shipping season at its height, the upswing has tended to put that state's citrus industry back on its feet after two lean years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Formidable resistance among some Senators was indicated today to any reform that would make it possible to impose the "gag rule" against filibusters by anything less than a two-thirds vote.

Many of the new pieces of Swedish furniture shown yesterday at the opening of Swedish Modern, Inc., 675 Fifth Avenue, have been slightly modified for American homes. This is the decorator's showroom for the Swedish Furniture Manufacturers Export Association, which introduced some designs about a year ago.

After spending a record $583,000,000 to expand and improve their facilities last year, domestic iron and steel companies will establish a new record in 1949 with planned expenditures of $627,000,000 for the same purpose, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday.

The CBS network's "raid" on the top comedy properties of the NBC chain continued unabated yesterday. It announced the acquisition of the Red Skelton program for presentation at 8:30 P. M. Sundays next fall. From the West Coast it was learned that "The Adventures of Ozzie and Harriet" also probably will move to CBS next season, possibly in the 6:30 spot on Sundays.

On the insistence of the United States Government, Walter Gieseking, German pianist, who arrived from Europe by plane late Saturday, will start back home this morning without giving any of the recitals scheduled in his American tour.
WASHINGTON Jan. 24 (UP) -- The "liberal vs. Old Guard" argument in Senate Republican ranks broke out anew today on plans for the 1950 Congressional election campaign.

Howard Hughes, controlling stockholder of Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., announced yesterday that he will recommend the election of Ralph S. Damon, formerly president of American Airlines, as president of TWA at a meeting of the company's board of directors today in Kansas City, Mo.

American Airlines announced yesterday that it had flown more air cargo in 1948 than in any other year in the company's history. Composed of air freight, air express and air mail, the total cargo flown last year was 36,939,000 ton miles, compared with 24,878,000 ton miles in 1947, it was pointed out.

MILTON, Mass., Jan. 24 (AP) -- The pastor of the First Congregational Church today had an award -- given in New York last night -- which he said "really belongs" to a couple of pastors of the First Congregational Parish -- a different religious group.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Department of Agriculture continued today to pursue the question of why the price of bread did not decline with the price of wheat, a question raised by Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan before the election.

Henry J. Davenport, president of the Home Title Guaranty Company, became the nineteenth member of "Brooklyn's Legion of Honor" yesterday upon receiving from the Downtown Brooklyn Association a gold medal for his services to that borough.

A proposal intended to eliminate the threat of a strike of 3,500 bus employes on lines of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and the New York City Omnibus Corporation was put before union and company representatives yesterday by Joseph E. O'Grady, director of the City Labor Relations Division.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The eight Democratic members of the Senate Labor Committee formally "resolved" late today that the Taft-Hartley labor law be repealed forthwith and without hearings.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- British officials were asked today to give a firm commitment on the volume of tobacco Britain expects to import from the United States this year. Officials were asked also to indicate if possible the quantities of tobacco required over the next two to four years.
ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- Governor Dewey's proposal to issue $300,000,000 in new state bonds for low-rent housing and to increase state housing subsidies passed the Senate unanimously tonight.

OMAHA, Jan. 24 -- Forces opposed to Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's continuing leadership of the Republican party were striving tonight to reach agreement on a single candidate whom they could back in an ouster movement directed at the National Chairman, Hugh D. Scott, Jr., of Pennsylvania.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 24 (UP) -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today that the Western world should stop treating Asia like a poor relation.

There can be no question of the interest of New Yorkers in what is new in motor-cars, if one is to judge from the throngs that have been pouring into the Waldorf to see the exhibit that General Motors has staged there under the title "Transportation Unlimited."

DETROIT, Jan. 24 -- Thomas Thompson, president of the self-styled "largest local in the world," asked the international officers of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, today to put the union demand for $100-a-month pensions on an industry-wide basis rather than discuss the subject with the various companies in turn.

Two women were killed and another was burned seriously shortly after 9:30 o'clock last night when a fire of undetermined origin swept through a three-story brick building at 4405 New Utrecht Avenue, in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn.

LIVERPOOL, England, Jan. 24 (Reuters) -- Pilfering from cargoes in Britain's docks is a serious drag on the country's export drive, according to the annual report of the Liverpool Underwriters Association, whose members do business in ports all over the country.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Senator Leverett Saltonstall, Norman Thomas and Senator Ralph Flanders will be among the speakers participating in a series of round-table discussions on democracy that will be conducted over WQXR in February on the regular Wednesday night "What's on Your Mind?" forums.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 24 -- There is an air of prosperity in the Ruhr region that cannot be overlooked. Coal miners and other workers are enjoying only a small part of it but it is true also that they shared only small fruits of the previous German prosperity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- "Strengthened" rent control, which was one of the leading issues of President Truman's political campaign, turned up in Congress today in the form of a bill proposing two more years of regulation, re-control of 500,000 hotel apartments and a considerable tightening of restrictions on landlords.

Aggressive search for new business in the men's clothing field has touched off current experimentation with new types of distribution and further development of integration, Martin R. Gainsbrugh, chief economist of the National Industrial Conference Board, said yesterday.

Eight "pre-engineered" church and parish buildings designed to meet emergency needs in the metropolitan area will be erected this spring by the Protestant Episcopal diocese of New York, it was announced yesterday by the Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Bishop of New York.

The nation now faces the serious dilemma of a demand for increasing Government services on the one hand and the danger of excessive taxation on the other, James A. Farley, chairman of The Coco-Cola Corporation, declared last night. Mr. Farley, former Postmaster General and former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, warned that it was not safe to assume that the national income was stable at its current peak.

More than 4,132,591 residential power-driven oil-burning units were in use at the end of 1948, according to an estimate by the Oil-Heat Institute of America made public yesterday. This number includes 350,000 new fuel oil users added during 1948 and about 88,000 owners who replaced old oil burners with new models during the year.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 1 per cent last week over the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday. The rise for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 1 per cent.
The visitor peeled away the high coat collar from his face and raised the earflaps of his fur cap to fair weather level, revealing the homely phiz of our man with the unlikely name of Balboa Prawn.

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- Victor Kravchenko's libel suits against a French Communist paper and one of its writers opened here today with a wild session marked by bitter statements of political opinion by all sides and the presentation of numerous witnesses, including the French atomic physicist, Frederic Joliot-Curie, for the defense.

By a vote of 1,239 to 7, truck drivers employed by six of the city's largest bakers authorized their officers yesterday to call a strike at any time after their present contract expires at midnight Monday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- Plans for a two-year campaign to increase membership in the Boy Scouts by several hundred thousand and thus "strengthen the arm of liberty" were outlined to sixty Scout leaders of Chicago tonight by Dr. Arthur A. Schuck of New York, Chief Scout Executive.

G. William Bergquist is a cross between a detective and a bibliophile, the sort of man who might have resulted from the collaboration of Conan Doyle and Anatole France. He has the bulk and impassiveness of the police station habitue and the soft speech and love of books of the library denizen.

A new novel by Ivy Compton-Burnett, author of "Bullivant and the Lambs," has been scheduled for June publication by Knopf. "Two Worlds and Their Ways" is a story about two schools, one for boys and one for girls, and a family with children attending both.

NANKING, Jan. 24 -- Acting President Li Tsung-jen asked the Cabinet today for swift adoption of a "liberalization" program, including the release of political prisoners and the lifting of martial law. Government military positions north of the Yangtze River melted away in what appeared to be a headlong retreat to the south bank of the river.

BERLIN, Jan. 24 -- German labor leaders in Berlin, alarmed over an increasing movement of Western sector workers into Soviet sector industries, have formulated a proposal to transfer the city's skilled labor to the American and British zones, it was learned today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 24 -- The Israelis will go to the polls tomorrow for the first time, to elect a Constituent Assembly, with both Arabs and Israelis taking full advantage of their first national franchise.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 24 -- The question of a Scandinavian mutual defense pact remained unsettled when the high-level talks between Norway, Sweden and Denmark ended here tonight. The door has been left open for further talks in Oslo.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Congress was called upon today to take the "first effective step" toward the establishment of a national theatre and a national opera and ballet.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Average primary market prices fell 0.7 per cent during the week ended Jan. 18, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index is now 159.3 per cent of the 1926 average, 2 per cent lower than four weeks ago, and 4.3 per cent below the comparable week in 1948.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Two education groups said today they would investigate the discharge of three professors from the University of Washington for alleged Communist activity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- An administration plan to hold down this year's wheat and cotton crops was disclosed today by Senator Elmer Thomas, Democrat of Oklahoma, chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee.
