NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 24 -- Apprehensions in the West that the nineteen-nation Asian conference on the Indonesian question, which adjourned here yesterday, meant the formation of a hostile "Asian bloc" were not borne out either by action or the conduct of the four-day meeting.

In its first year of operation the division of analysis of the Bureau of the Budget has saved $1,160,000 for the city, Abraham D. Beame, in charge of the work, estimated yesterday. The total, which included estimated savings and increased revenue, was contained in a report to Mayor O'Dwyer by Mr. Beame in his capacity as Assistant Director of the Budget.

Severe shortages of finished aluminum sheets here may be eased by Japanese shipments, S. P. Edelman, president, Manhattan Brass and Copper Company, distributors for the Aluminum Company of America, disclosed here yesterday.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 2 (AP) -- There may be twelve starters Saturday in the second running of Santa Anita's $100,000 Maturity for 4-year-olds at a mile and one-quarter but Maine Chance Farms' Ace Admiral, a supplementary nomination, looks like the horse to beat.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- The stock market here generally maintained a bright tone today. Gilt-edged issues were firm in quiet trading. In the foreign section hopes of a favorable outcome of the peace talks between Israel and Egypt were reflected in some of the day's movements.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers today scheduled a strike against fifteen railroads which serve the West for 6 A. M. next Monday, Jan. 31, in all time zones, but Government intervention is expected to defer the threat for at least sixty days.

The first of the "productivity teams" of the Anglo-American Council on Productivity, made up of employes from all levels of appropriate British industrial plants, are expected to arrive here around Feb. 15, Philip D. Reed, chairman of the American section of the council, and chairman of General Electric Company, declared yesterday.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 24 -- Lieut. Gen. Clarence R. Huebner, chief of the United States ground forces in Europe, disclosed today that on the evening of the landing of Allied troops on "Omaha Beach" in Normandy in 1944, the Germans captured the entire battle plan of the Fifth Army Corps.

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- The French Government has received an assurance that Washington favors its effort to make peace in Indo-China by setting up Bao Dai as the Nationalist leader to check the Communist influence from the north that is expected to be intensified by the victory of the Communist forces in China.

The great strides toward economic rehabilitation in France and Great Britain and the importance of continued Marshall Plan aid were stressed yesterday by Thomas K. Finletter and David K. E. Bruce, Economic Cooperation Administration officials.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UP) -- The treason trial of Mildred Gillars, "Axis Sally" of the wartime Nazi radio, opened today before a jury of six men and six women who were admonished sternly to be impartial.
CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Heavyweight Champion Joe Louis' offer to defend his title next June at Soldier Field for a $400,000 guarantee caused complications today in the Democratic party here.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Jan. 24 -- The Dutch Cabinet was occupied for hours today in a debate on its stand in face of the latest Indonesian resolution now before the Security Council. While no hint was forthcoming from official quarters, well informed persons presumed that the Netherlands would reluctantly accept the Council's decision for consideration.

Students of the Food Trades Vocational High School, aspirants to places behind counters and in kitchens, gave prospective employers a taste of food to come at the weekly Partridge Club luncheon yesterday.

John MacCormac's special dispatch of Jan. 9 from Vienna describes the present critical situation of the Jewish population of Hungary with accuracy and understanding. The undersigned feel, however, that a few details contained in this interesting report require further clarification.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- A group of Colgate University honor students in political science, completing a seminar of work in the Government, got their final lesson from President Truman today. He told them to start from the ground up, as he did as a precinct worker.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized motor carriers operating in New Hampshire and Vermont to increase freight rates and minimum charges on shipments by 5 per cent over the rates the ICC prescribed for New England in January, 1948.

It is encouraging, despite the tremendous propaganda campaign put on for the past three years by the school spending groups, and despite the continued pressure by those same groups to bleed the public for greater and greater school spending, more and more state aid for education and higher and higher teachers' salaries, that editors are still able to look with objectivity at the current campaign for more funds for education.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Treasury announced tonight that tenders for $900,000,000 of 91-day Treasury bills to be dated Jan. 27, and to mature on April 28, were opened at the Federal Reserve Banks today.

An increase in city dog license fees to enable the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals to meet higher costs and to continue its services was suggested last night by John D. Beals Jr., president of the organization.

Sir George Sansom, specialist in Far Eastern affairs and former British diplomat, has been appointed director of Columbia's new East Asian Institute, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, university president, announced yesterday.

Strength in the steel issues gave the stock market a momentary lift yesterday but the bulge in prices failed to last and closing quotations were irregularly lower. United States Steel paced the market and some observers saw a connection between the activity in that stock and the fact that the dividend meeting is scheduled for today.

The International Society for Contemporary Music opened its season's concert series with the Second Quartets of Arnold Schoenberg, now in his seventy-fifth year, and Leos Janacek at the Museum of Modern Art, last night. Performances were by the Pro Arte Quartet, assisted by Patricia Neway, soprano, before an appreciative audience largely made up of musicians.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UP) -- Representative August H. Andresen, Republican, of Minnesota, asked Congress today to eliminate Federal taxes on oleomargarine, but to bar the sale of yellow-colored oleo by stores and restaurants.

Exiled King Peter of Yugoslavia visited the exhibits in the General Motors show at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday and paid particular attention to a car with a two-way telephone appliance. Seated in a smart Cadillac, he put the receiver to his ear as though listening intently and sighed into the silence.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Jan. 24 -- Three employes of the Western Electric Company of Kearny today charged the officers of the inactive Western Electric Employes Association with improper diversion of funds.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- President Truman has decided to ask Congress soon to create a Columbia Valley Authority. Today he directed members of his Cabinet and staff to draft a bill as quickly as possible.

Lieut. Carl S. Halvorsen, the "Schokoladenflieger" of the Berlin airlift, arrived in New York yesterday to thank the thousands of Americans who contributed candy and chocolate bars and chewing gum that he and his fellow-airmen have been dropping in handkerchief parachutes to hungry Berlin children.
The Appellate Division yesterday unanimously affirmed the convictions of six men and a woman who had been found guilty in General Sessions of extortionate practices arising from the housing shortage.

Consolidated net income of the Marine Midland Corporation and its affiliates last year amounted to $5,364,145, equal to 96 cents a share, compared with 99 cents in 1947, according to the annual report to stockholders, issued today. Gross operating income was listed at $25,931,031, an increase of $1,861,368 over 1947.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 -- Former United States Commissioner Norman J. Griffin and two other former Government employes were sentenced today to eighteen months each in a Federal penitentiary for their parts in the illegal issuance of passports to Chinese.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 24 -- Ingrid Bergman will conclude a deal tomorrow with Roberto Rosselini, Italian director, to go to Italy within a month to appear in a film based on an untitled screen story by Rosselini, it was learned today from the Music Corporation of America, Miss Bergman's representatives.

Fourteen local housing authorities borrowed $22,310,000 on short term loan notes yesterday at interest rates ranging from 0.90 per cent to 1.10 per cent. Awards of note issues were announced by the Public Housing Administration.
Allan Easton has been named assistant chief engineer of the Tele-Tone Radio Corporation's television division. He formerly was senior engineer of the Emerson Radio Corporation.

RHODES, Jan. 24 -- Unable to reach an agreement on armistice terms, Egyptian and Israeli delegates called a halt to their talks today, during which time they will return to their respective capitals for new instructions. Some members of delegations will remain on Rhodes to continue informal consultations with Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine, until the others return.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 24 (UP) -- Lean Gene Bearden, Cleveland's cool southpaw pitcher, who won twenty games last season and added a world series triumph, said today he would have to have more money than he had been offered for 1949.
PARIS, Jan. 24 -- France has decided upon de facto recognition of Israel following what were termed "satisfactory talks" between the two Governments, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- There has arrived in Washington from Nanking another transcript of the famous press interview given in Shanghai on Dec. 13, 1948, by Paul G. Hoffman, administrator of the Economic Cooperation Administration, that upset the State Department, the Control Yuan of the Chinese Nationalist Government, Mr. Matthew Woll of the American Federation of Labor and sundry others.

HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 24 -- Dartmouth succumbed to a consistent Yale quintet, 62 -- 41, before a capacity crowd tonight at Alumni Gymnasium. Leading the Indians 27 -- 26 at half time, the Elis went on to win easily, largely through the accuracy and speed of Art Fitzgerald, who scored 17 points for the visitors in the Eastern League contest.

TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 24 -- The mild winter has permitted rapid progress on most of the major projects in the New Jersey State Highway Department's broad post-war program to relieve congestion, to cut down travel time between main points, and to add beauty to the state's highway system.

Reflecting sales gains in almost all product classifications, earnings of the Bendix Aviation Corporation in the fiscal year ended last September more than doubled those of the previous year, according to the annual report of Malcolm P. Ferguson, president, to be issued to stockholders today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The governing body of the American Federation of Labor will go on record next week as refusing to take part in the work of the Trade Union Advisory Committee of the nations interested in the European Recovery Program if Walter Schevenels is installed as secretary of the trade union group.
OMAHA, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Two former Republican National Committee chairmen added fuel today to talk of a change in present party leadership.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24 -- The sellers' market in used cars is at an end or in sight and dealers must get back to the "fundamentals" of salesmanship, a used car "clinic" opening the annual meeting of the National Automobile Dealers Association was told here today.
TOKYO, Jan. 24 -- The battle-lines were clearly drawn in Japan tonight, for the first time since the surrender, between the strongly dominant Right Wing and the growing Communist movement.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- In its annual report to Congress, made public today, the Interstate Commerce Commission, noting the increased costs of operation of the railroads and the coastal and intercoastal water carriers, suggested that those carriers search for greater efficiency in order to meet the higher costs.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- Expansion in the heating and ventilating industry this year depends upon the availability of adequate supplies of copper and steel, spokesmen observed today at the opening of the industry's annual meeting and exposition.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The conviction of former Representative Andrew J. May, Democrat, of Kentucky, and of Henry and Murray Garsson, contractors, for conspiracy to defraud the government during the war was upheld, 2 to 1, here today by the Federal Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- First open opposition in Congress to the Hoover Commission's proposal to give the President broad power on a permanent basis to initiate administrative reforms was sounded today as hearings on the plan got under way.

The Ernie Pyle arrived here yesterday afternoon with 510 passengers from Antwerp and Hamburg, including ten German exchange students and a former toy manufacturer interested in rebuilding the partially destroyed town of Rothenberg in Bavaria.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- Removal of hedges against estimated sales of 1,500,000 to 2,000,000 bushels of cash corn to the Government had only a temporary effect today on May corn on the Board of Trade. An early upturn of 3/4 cent was followed by a break of 1 1/8 cents from the top with the close at the bottom with a net loss of 1/4 cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Registration statements covering $40,000,000 of bonds, 100,000 shares of preferred and 10,666 shares of common stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by three companies.

The left-wing store unions that quit the Congress of Industrial Organizations last September reported a third victory last night in their efforts to win new contracts with major New York department stores.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- First open opposition in Congress to the Hoover Commission's proposal to give the President broad power on a permanent basis to initiate administrative reforms was sounded today as hearings on the plan got under way.

The Ernie Pyle arrived here yesterday afternoon with 510 passengers from Antwerp and Hamburg, including ten German exchange students and a former toy manufacturer interested in rebuilding the partially destroyed town of Rothenberg in Bavaria.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- Removal of hedges against estimated sales of 1,500,000 to 2,000,000 bushels of cash corn to the Government had only a temporary effect today on May corn on the Board of Trade. An early upturn of 3/4 cent was followed by a break of 1 1/8 cents from the top with the close at the bottom with a net loss of 1/4 cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Registration statements covering $40,000,000 of bonds, 100,000 shares of preferred and 10,666 shares of common stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by three companies.

The left-wing store unions that quit the Congress of Industrial Organizations last September reported a third victory last night in their efforts to win new contracts with major New York department stores.
OMAHA, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Two former Republican National Committee chairmen added fuel today to talk of a change in present party leadership.

Children will be admitted to the Palace for fifty cents at all times during the engagement of "So Dear to My Heart," which begins its stand on Saturday, it was announced by the management. This, it was stated, marks the first time such a price policy for children has prevailed during the Broadway first-run of a Walt Disney feature-length film.

DETROIT, Jan. 24 -- The Detroit unit of the American Newspaper Guild adopted a resolution tonight condemning Police Commissioner Harry S. Toy for his ruling that requires all reporters who seek unrestricted fire and police press cards to take a loyalty oath.
DUESSELDORF, Germany, Jan. 24 -- The Ruhr miners for the fourth day last week broke their own post-war record by producing 331,230 tons of coal on Saturday.

MANILA, Jan. 24 -- President Elpidio Quirino gave an account of his stewardship today at the opening of the hundred-day session of the Philippine Congress. He reported a balanced budget and the virtual restoration of peace and order in Hukbalahap-infested Central Luzon.

Measured by cotton consumption, cloth production, or spindle hours per man-hour, productivity in the cotton textile industry has not kept pace with wage increases, according to a survey issued yesterday by the Cotton-Textile Institute.

Directors of the Armco Steel Corporation increased yesterday the quarterly dividend on the common stock with the declaration of 62 1/2 cents a share, payable on March 15. This would place the stock on a $2.50 annual basis the highest yearly rate since the early Nineteen Twenties.

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- In the municipal election in Grenoble yesterday, the Communists made a gain in popular votes of 36 per cent, as compared to the election of 1947 in that city. The de Gaullists suffered a slight setback, as did the "third force" parties, the Popular Republicans, Socialists and Radicals.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 24 -- West Coast collections favor one-piece dresses for spring and summer. Although sun tops with separates still are strong, there is a decided swing to decollete dresses whose shoulder covering is an integral part. These represent a refreshing change from the ubiquitous scarf and bolero with strapless boned bodice.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The University of Wisconsin picked Ivan (Red) Williamson of Lafayette for its head football coach today and it assured him he'll be running his own show in the stormy post vacated by Harry Stuhldreher.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24 -- The Waterfront Employers Association today began charting a long-range course to better labor relations on West Coast waterfronts and to increase lagging waterborne cargoes in and out of Coast ports.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- If Congress insists that half of this country's recovery cargoes move in American ships, Marshall Plan officials will seek additional funds to cover the extra cost.

Twelve high school students -- four of whom had to be represented by "stand-ins" -- received the Jesse Isidor Straus Awards for outstanding academic and on-the-job training records at a ceremony yesterday at the Board of Education, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

Enactment of Federal minimum wage legislation advocated by President Truman will result in higher mill prices for Southern lumber, Earl M. McGowin, vice president, W. T. Smith Lumber Company, Chapman, Ala., and former president of the Southern Pine Association, warned yesterday.

In a vigorous letter yesterday to the Chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, President Truman urged that Congress promptly repeal the 1948 Republican tariff law and restore the so-called Hull program "without hampering restrictions." Unless nations can sell each other the products of their agriculture, labor and industry to the greatest possible extent, he declared, "there can be no sure foundation for economic peace."

In an informal survey among readers at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, it was found that only one person in ten knew that the building's collections, services and operation were privately supported.

The vegetables most plentiful and reasonably priced at this season are, unfortunately, the ones many consider the dullest. It's hard to work up much enthusiasm for carrots, parsnips and kale even though the United States Department of Agriculture recommends them highly.

While New York University's Law Center Foundation will begin proceedings today to evict tenants from the Washington Square South block on which the new Law Center will be built, the university is hoping for an out-of-court settlement.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- If Congress insists that half of this country's recovery cargoes move in American ships, Marshall Plan officials will seek additional funds to cover the extra cost.

Twelve high school students -- four of whom had to be represented by "stand-ins" -- received the Jesse Isidor Straus Awards for outstanding academic and on-the-job training records at a ceremony yesterday at the Board of Education, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

Net sales of the Liggett Myers Tobacco Company, both in dollars and unit sales of cigarettes in 1948 exceeded any previous year on record, resulting in the highest earnings in its history, according to the annual report of J. W. Andrews, president, mailed to stockholders yesterday.
BERLIN, Jan. 24 -- Drastic changes in personnel and policy are expected from the Congress of the Socialist Unity (Communist) party that will meet here tomorrow.
Frederick Marantz, who gave a piano recital at Times Hall last night, applied himself studiously and energetically to a performance of music by Mozart, Schubert, Weber and Beethoven.

BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 24 (UP) -- A Netherlands spokesman, backed by the United States and British Consulates here, today described as "grossly exaggerated" a story told in Singapore yesterday that a Canadian and two Americans had been held incommunicado in a Batavia jail after the Dutch had captured their "yacht."

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 25 -- The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, which is in the midst of a post-war plant expansion designed to cost a quarter of a billion dollars, proposed today drastic revision of the income tax laws to encourage plant improvements.

Complete fields for six special events in the forty-second annual Millrose Games, which will launch New York's banked-track footracing campaign Saturday on Madison Square Garden's new and presumably fast eleven-lap track, were announced yesterday by Fred Schmertz.

Two men, who admitted, the police said, that they planned and almost completed a jewel robbery as a means of obtaining working capital for a poolroom they operate in Monticello, N. Y., were "caught in the act" yesterday by detectives of the West Forty-seventh Street Squad.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Substantial applause rang through the House of Representatives today as two Democrats, both recently dropped from the House Committee on Un-American Activities, hailed the discharging of three professors at the University of Washington on charges of Communist activity.

Although the New York City Center has been unable to provide any straight drama this season, either from the Broadway boards or of its own creation, it is not letting down its patrons. Back in the September doldrums there was the return of "Show Boat" to brighten Fifty-fifth Street and not so long ago there reappeared "The Telephone" and "The Medium."

OTTAWA, Jan. 25 -- All the political parties have been getting ready during the last few days for the opening of Parliament tomorrow with the possibility in mind that this summer, or sometime next year at the latest, a general election will be held.
LONDON, Jan. 25 -- The stock markets were quiet today with minor changes. British bonds were quiet and somewhat easier.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- President Truman has directed his advisers to cooperate with Congressional labor committees in working out what is expected to be an Administration bill on labor relations.
I wish to express my appreciation to THE NEW YORK TIMES for publishing the letter of Nat Norman in the Jan. 17 issue.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 25 -- A special corps of courtesy officers to accompany tourists visiting Egypt will be provided in the near future, it was announced here today. The announcement was made by the Hamilton Wright organization, publicity agents for the Egyptian National Tourist Bureau.

OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 25 -- The Republican National Chairman, Hugh D. Scott Jr., declared today that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York, defeated for President last year, "should not, could not and will not be a candidate in 1952."

EVER since its rediscovery in the Renaissance the glory that was Greece has blinded most Western scholars and writers to all Greek history later than the death of Alexander. Enraptured by the triumphs of ancient Greek art and literature, awed by the mind of Plato and the greatness of Pericles, most educated modern readers know nothing whatsoever about some of the most picturesque and dramatic of all national histories.

PARIS, Jan. 25 -- Pierre Courtade, a writer who is considered here as one of the official chroniclers of the Communist line, said today that the present United States policy toward the Soviet Union began in 1944 with the publication of the book "I Chose Freedom."
Reports from Buenos Aires that the Peron Government in Argentina would not devalue the peso rallied a declining hide futures market on Commodity Exchange yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The State Department watched the developing Chinese crisis closely today but was not prepared to say whether all or part of the American Embassy staff in Nanking would move south with the Nationalist Government.

BANGKOK, Siam, Jan. 20 -- Bangkok has become a "home away from home" for revolutionary elements from various Southeast Asian colonial areas. Some struggling "Provisional Government" occasionally sets up here and supporters of numerous independence movements come and go between here and guerrilla war fronts, making Bangkok an informal information center on the state of unrest in this quarter of the globe.
LISBON, Portugal, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Government, which granted temporary freedoms for the current Presidential election campaign, gave an indication today it was beginning to regret it.

A thirteen-state teletype alarm was issued yesterday by the Missing Persons Bureau at Police Headquarters for Capt. Harry W. Chase, 57 years old, of 114 West Seventieth Street, master of the Robbins Line's freighter, the Morgantown Victory.

One point about this year's meeting of the Institute of Aeronautical Sciences immediately strikes the observer. This is the youth of those who received the annual awards on Honors Night. Hardly one of the men thus singled out is more than in early middle life. Some are very much younger.

NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 25 -- The Newark Museum announced today the purchase of a portrait by John Singleton Copley. It was among the first acquisitions of Colonial portraiture by the institution, which had specialized in contemporary and primitive works.

Mayor O'Dwyer will act today to name a panel of prominent citizens to seek settlement of the wage dispute that threatens to cut off delivery of 70 per cent of the city's bread supply, it was reported at City Hall yesterday.

The United States Steel Corporation, the world's largest producer of steel, plans to split its common stock three-for-one to obtain broader public distribution of the securities, Irving S. Olds, chairman of the board, announced yesterday. It would be the first stock split in the corporation's history.

The legitimacy of New York University's status as a nonprofit educational institution will be attacked in Municipal Court, David B. Tolins, counsel for about fifty tenants whom the university is seeking to evict, declared last night. Mr. Tolins said that as the owner of a spaghetti-making concern and other businesses, the university has an interest in profits that could hardly be called academic.

Charges of discourtesy, unfairness and irrelevancy were hurled yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders of the Chase National Bank. Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman, who presided, frequently had to use his gavel, demanding that the proceedings be kept orderly, and at one point, he warned an unruly stockholder that he was likely to be ejected unless he was more considerate.

A wing-back armchair that will never come apart at the joints, because it has no joints, was the product of the research investigation for which James Prestini and the Armour Research Foundation of the Illinois Institute of Technology received last week the $2,500 award in the Museum of Modern Art low-cost furniture competition.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The State Department said today that a visa was issued by the consulate in Paris to Walter Gieseking, the German pianist, to come to this country after the department had given an advisory opinion saying it had no evidence that he was inadmissible under the Immigration law.

Tenants and employes of the Ansonia Apartments, at Broadway and Seventy-third Street, joined yesterday in a double-barreled offensive against the management, with tenants complaining of excessive rents and employes curtailing service in a salary dispute.

The rediscovered statue of San Ludovico by Donatello, characterized as a landmark of the early Renaissance, and some 120 paintings by Italian artists of the nineteenth century -- works lent by Italian museums and private collectors -- have been spaciously installed in the Wildenstein Galleries.

ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- Governor Dewey's proposal to increase state aid for schools by $40,000,000 over the existing formula requirements was attacked today by Democrats and spokesmen for New York City teacher groups. It appeared, however, to have stemmed a threatened revolt of up-state Republicans in the Legislature on the issue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Economic Cooperation Administration announced tonight a new system by which Marshall Plan countries could make direct payment for recovery goods in United States dollars.

Roadside "zoos" where the gamboling of animals often conceals the gambling pitfalls prepared to fleece unsuspecting motorists were denounced yesterday at a meeting of the American Automobile Association's national touring board at the Roosevelt Hotel. A movement was started by the organization to rid the highways of these gaming places.
The State of Louisiana borrowed $50,000,000 yesterday on serial bonds at an interest cost of 3.16 per cent to finance a bonus for veterans of World War II.

Sixty-one members of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association have filed suit in Queens Supreme Court for an accounting by the officers of the organization of all funds taken in and disbursed during the last fiscal year, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Neil Dalton, Louisville newspaper executive, today was named director of information for the Economic Cooperation Administration. His appointment was announced by Paul G. Hoffman, ECA Administrator.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- A new and distinctive slate-blue uniform was prescribed for the Air Force today and all airmen, commissioned and enlisted, will be wearing it by Sept. 1, 1950.

ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- The State Liquor Authority came under debate in the State Senate today as a result of last week's controversy between Republican and Democratic leaders over the confirmation of John F. O'Connell of Larchmont for a new term as chairman.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The United States Fifth Corps' operational plan for the Normandy invasion, taken by the Germans from the body of a young United States officer June 7, 1944, the day after the invasion, was in Adolf Hitler's hands five days later, United States officers said today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 -- Most research work in Great Britain today in heating, ventilation and environmental effects is being carried on in government research stations under the Department of Scientific and Industrial Research, Cyril Tasker, research director of the American Society of Heating and Ventilating Engineers, told 2,000 members today at the society's annual meeting.

TEL AVIV, Jan. 28 -For the first time in their long and troubled history Jews voted as a political entity today to select their own democratic form of government. From 80 to 90 per cent of those eligible to vote exercised Continued on Page 14, Colmn 2

Although there was no intimation of intent to remind Walker Cooper, the Giants' big holdout, that other fellows in the organization can catch, Secretary Eddie Brannick yesterday announced the signing of two mask-and-pad wearers -- Wes Westrum, who is supposed to rate right behind Cooper, and Sal Yvars, Jersey City rookie.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 25 -- Merely to raise the book value of Negro school plants to a par with the white schools, the South would have to spend about $545,000,000, the Southern Regional Council declared today in a survey report.

Balbina Brainina, Russian pianist, who made her debut here twelve years ago, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. She devoted the first half of her program to Chopin in commemoration of the centenary of his death.
A leasehold on the new taxpayer built by the Irvben Construction, Inc., at the southeast corner of Yorkers and Belmont Avenues in Yonkers, N. Y., to a client of Green Selzer, attorneys.

Your editorial of Jan. 14 made the point that the problem of cancer requires more than money for its successful solution. The road leading to the ultimate conquest of cancer is long and steep. Scientists ready to invest years of hard work in experimental cancer research, with no assurance whatever that their efforts will bring any tangible results, are scarce.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 25 -- Dr. William H. Horton, medical director of the state department of public welfare, declared today that the title "non-profit" is no mandate that hospitals must necessarily lose money by their activity.

VIENNA, Jan. 25 -- Since last week's announcement by Deputy Premier Matyas Rakosi that "the proletarian state is the apparatus for the suppression of the bourgeoisie," the last elements of parliamentary democracy as opposed to "people's democracy" have been abolished in Hungary.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The White House announced today that President Truman had persuaded Howard Bruce to remain at his post as deputy economic cooperation administrator. He had submitted his resignation to the Chief Executive with a request that it become effective by Jan. 31.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved by a vote of 11 to 0 today President Truman's nomination of James E. Webb, of North Carolina, to succeed Robert A. Lovett as Under-Secretary of State.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin, who was the first major statesman of Europe to embrace the Marshall Plan, led the way again in welcoming President Truman's "bold new program" for improvement of the world's under-developed areas.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 -- Instead of the usual dry statistical announcement, the Girard Trust Company of Philadelphia presented today its 1948 annual report to stockholders in a booklet illustrated with witty cartoons lampooning various aspects of the banking business, as well as some customers.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 25 -- In Maseru, capital of the British protectorate of Basutoland, a Negro chieftainess and five of her henchmen were acquitted yesterday of ritual murder -- that is, voodoo.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 25 -- Four nations now administering territories under the United Nations trusteeship system lined up today in support of a British proposal that this session of the Trusteeship Council shelve, temporarily, two reports on British supervision of the African Territory of Tanganyika and Belgian administration of Ruanda-Urundi.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Miss Peggy Kirk of Findlay, Ohio, cut 3 strokes off par on the back nine at the Miami Country Club course today to lead qualifiers in the seventeenth annual Helen Lee Doherty golf tournament with a 73.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 25 (UP) -- Horace Wilkinson, one of the founders of the States' Rights party, urged Alabama legislators today to bar Negroes from the polls and place the responsibility for state government "exclusively on reputable white people."

WALTHAM, Mass., Jan. 25 -- John J. Hagerty, regional manager of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, electrified an audience of 5,000 at a mass meeting tonight by announcing that only a few hours before, the Federal agency had agreed to lend the Waltham Watch Company $5,000,000, so it could reorganize.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that wheat stocks in this country on Jan. 1 totaled 857,046,000 bushels.

"D'Homme a Hommes" ("Man to Men"), the French-made dramatization of the life of Henri Dunant, founder of the Red Cross, starring Jean-Louis Barrault, will have its local premiere on Friday, Feb. 11, at both the Ambassador and Elysee Theatres, it was announced yesterday by Siritzky International, the distributors.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Frere Jacques, the old "grass king," returned to his favorite turf course at Hialeah Park today and carried Jacob Sher's silks to a popular triumph in the Ft. Dallas Handicap.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Impropriety but only petty corruption were found by the Tribunal of Inquiry into the allegations of fraud at the Board of Trade and other ministries, it was disclosed today as a 50,000-word report on this sensational case was issued.
Eye surgeons of the Presbyterian Hospital's Institute of Ophthalmology were called upon yesterday to perform one of the saddest operations they could remember.

The first indication of a break in the long deadlock between the Port of New York Authority and eight major commercial airlines over leases at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, came yesterday at a special term of the Supreme Court in Queens.

By dint of persistent effort, Robert Milford is gradually tieing up the loose ends of "Montparnasse," the Anita Loos-Howard Dietz-Alexander Alstone musical. Yesterday we learned from George Abbott that he had agreed not only to stage the presentation for Mr. Milford but also to work on the book with Miss Loos.

Financial circles received the surprise of recent years yesterday when United States Steel Corporation announced a special dividend and the directors recommended a three-for-one split of the common stock. The action was announced after the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Allen C. Phelps, chief of the export trade division of the Federal Trade Commission, said today that the FTC was conducting a campaign "to impose f.o.b. mill pricing on all sellers." "It is fair to say," he added, "that it (the campaign) is progressing smoothly toward fruition, as far as the commission and the courts are concerned."

While commuter trains rumble by at intervals of less than one minute, the complicated task of building a new and longer bridge for the Long Island Rail Road over the Van Wyck Expressway in Jamaica goes steadily forward, according to a progress report yesterday.

NANKING, Jan. 25 -- Although the mighty Yangtze River bisecting China is rapidly becoming a no man's land between the Government and the Communists there is little evidence along its shores of the Government's determination to hold the line.

ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 25 -- The high cost of living on campuses of leading Eastern colleges and universities is threatening to interfere with the education of thousands of students and candidates for entrance despite the fact that the institutions are providing room and board at rates close to deficit operation, it developed here today.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the performance of "Madama Butterfly" on Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House which has been taken over by members of the New York Vassar Club to augment their scholarship fund.

Opposition to United States adherence to the Charter for an International Trade Organization was announced here yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council, leading organization in the foreign-trade field.

In these days of conflicting financial pressures on our national, state, municipal and personal incomes, partisan pleading for more generous spending in any one area becomes increasingly difficult. Yet I must plead now for more generous financing of public education. We need a new philosophy as regards educational expenditures.

The first annual report to Mayor O'Dwyer of the Budget Bureau's Division of Analysis does not make any sensational claims in fulfilling its purpose of "studying and installing improved administrative procedures in the various city agencies with a view toward more efficient and economical operations."

A resolution favoring continuance of Government controls on fats and oils was passed yesterday by the Soap and Detergent Manufacturers Association at its annual meeting in the New Yorker Hotel. About 100 members attended.

ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- Governor Dewey appealed to the American Legion tonight to support his efforts to beat down what he said were Democratic proposals to "raid" the state's $600,000,000 post-war reconstruction fund. He spoke at the thirtieth annual legislative dinner of the State Department of the Legion.
MIAMI, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Railroad representatives told the Interstate Commerce Commission's hearing on rail ticket practices today that new equipment would solve present reserved space problems.

Announcement was made yesterday that subscriptions now will be accepted for apartments in Queensview, a non-profit, 728 unit housing community to be built in Long Island City, Queens, under the sponsorship of Gerard Swope, Louis H. Pink and other persons who have been actively interested in housing.

It must have been with a great deal of satisfaction that the Philippine Congress heard President Quirino's report on the state of the nation. The Philippine budget is balanced, an economic distinction not widely shared these days. More important still, the President reported that the Hukbalahap movement in Central Luzon has degenerated into sheer banditry and is of little importance; the Filipinos have met the menace of communism and found the answer to it.
The retail price of milk will go down on Tuesday for the third time in a month, it was indicated yesterday, bringing local milk prices down to the lowest point since July.

GENEVA, Jan. 25 -- The Chinese Government's representative told the International Refugee Organization today that there was no need for alarm over the fate of European refugees in the path of the Chinese Communist advance.

Walter Gieseking, German pianist, left by Air France plane for Paris yesterday morning less than three days after he arrived. His comment on the cancellation of his sold-out Carnegie Hall recital Monday night as well as his American tour of thirty-seven other days was that he had been "treated too roughly here."

When the new Saw Mill River Parkway Extension is finished and opened for its entire contemplated length from Chappaqua to Katonah in Westchester, metropolitan area motorists will have the benefit of one more modern, high-speed traffic artery providing quick and easy access to and exit from New York City.

There has not been so white a January in many a year, even though the weather has been generously considerate. This has been the whitest January in years because of the swirl of traditional white sales that used to be a normal, fixed part of the post-Christmas scene. White space fills the journals to herald alluring bargains.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Boston Maine Railroad Company today submitted a revised plan for reorganizing its securities. It told the Interstate Commerce Commission the revisions were designed to meet the objections of some stockholders to a plan put forward last August, which provided for a new single class of capital stock to replace eight classes now outstanding.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Final agreement has now been reached on virtually all details of the Atlantic Defense Pact and the pact itself is expected to become a reality within thirty days, it was learned here on high authority.

PARIS, Jan. 25 -- Maud Roser chooses two color groups for her hat collection. One is water blue ranging from the pale greenish tones of the northern seas to the deeper rich blues of the Mediterranean. The other she cans toasted reds, which are soft tangerine tones.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., announced yesterday a consolidated net income of $36,824,881 for 1948, equal to $2.31 a share. This represented a $4,115,201 rise over the $32,709,680 reported for 1947, when share earnings amounted to $1.90.

DETROIT, Jan. 25 -- The Detroit Free Press, announcing its decision to by-pass the ruling of Police Commissioner Harry S. Toy requiring a loyalty oath from reporters who seek an unrestricted police and fire press card, said tonight that it would reserve to itself all tests of its staff members' rights to represent the newspaper.

The 1949 campaign of the Police Athletic League to raise $1,000,000 was opened by Mayor O'Dwyer at City Hall yesterday in the presence of a group of professional athletes, each of whom was once a P.A.L. sports participant.

The two-story garage building on a plot about 88 by 122 feet at 10-12 Van Courtlandt Avenue East, the Bronx, has been purchased by the Esquire Garage Corporation from the North American Instrument Company. Arthur S. Thomases was the broker in the transaction, in which title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
LONDON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Following is the text of a communique, distributed by the Soviet news agency Tass, on the Moscow economic conference:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The American Federation of Labor would like to see the British Trades Union Congress take the lead in creation of a new world labor movement as successor to the World Federation of Trade Unions.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Two houses to open the spring collections of the Incorporated Society of London Fashion Designers are in accord with the slim line and slightly shorter skirts -- thirteen inches from the ground -- for spring.

UTICA, Jan. 25 -- Residents of Oneida County were disturbed today by developments that followed Governor Dewey's call after midnight last night for a special grand jury to look into reported voting frauds in East Utica.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UP) -- Counsel for Mildred Gillars told the jury trying her for treason today that she became "Axis Sally" of the wartime Nazi radio because she was under the hynotic influence of a former teacher in Hunter College, New York.

Retail lumber yards are prepared to support all other segments of the building industry in their fight against Administration-sponsored housing legislation, H. R. Northrup, executive vice president of the National Retail Lumber Dealers Association, declared yesterday.

Progress toward peaceful industrial relations in this State was hailed yesterday by Government, union and employer spokesmen at ceremonies marking completion of hearings in the 10,000th arbitration case handled by the State Mediation Board.
SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 25 -- The Soviet-controlled radio charged yesterday that Korean Republic's Premier Lee Bum Suk was fomenting and financing uprisings against the North Korean Communist Government.
Two items appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Jan. 19 which call, I feel, for pointed comment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- President Truman asked Congress today for a deficiency appropriation of $480,702,340 to meet sixty Federal expenditures which were not foreseen in the budget for the fiscal year 1949.

William J. Ahearn, a slight, meek-appearing bookkeeper, was listed on his employer's payroll records at a salary of $33 a week, but his "take-home" income was closer to $200 weekly, Assistant District Attorney Francis X. Clark declared when the defendant was arraigned yesterday in General Sessions.

PARIS, Jan. 25 -- French officials are carefully preparing for the forthcoming visit of Sir Stafford Cripps, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, to Paris, which is expected to determine the possibility of a kind of economic alliance between the French and British that would take the leadership of the European Council for the Marshall Plan.

AS a practice workout for their annual dinner and show, the local baseball writers annually toss a party for someone they particularly like and admire. It is merely a tune-up in the knife and fork league and, if no one on the diamond holds especial appeal for them, they will even arrange a shindig for one of their own members.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Democratic leaders of Congress informed President Truman today that he could obtain the broad powers he has asked to overhaul the Executive Branch of Government, but said flatly that at least four agencies must not be invaded.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, asked Congress today to extend temporarily the authority for voluntary agreements that have aided the channeling of steel to "essential" users.
Plans for a year-around regular cruise service from New York to West Indies ports to begin early next year were announced yesterday by A. L. Simmons, president of Simmons Tours.

The St. Louis-San Francisco (Frisco) Railway Company announced yesterday a dividend of $1 a share payable to common stockholders on March 1. This will be the first distribution on the stock since the reorganized company took over operations at the start of 1947 and also the first since $2 was paid in 1931 by the predecessor company.
ATHENS, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Greece junked her Supreme Defense Council and placed her campaign against Communist-led guerrillas in the hands of a War Council today.

BERLIN, Jan. 25 -- In a blistering attack on what he called "American imperialism" and "Wall Street hyenas," who allegedly fostered it, Wilhelm Pieck, aging leader of German communism, summoned, the Socialist Unity [Communist] party today to intensify its struggle against the West in Germany.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Representative Carl Vinson, Democrat, of Georgia, chairman of the House Committee on Armed Services, today urged a multi-year aviation program with safeguards against economy cut-backs throughout its span.

New features of the 1949 cars that make for greater safety and easier parking were commended yesterday by representatives of the American Automobile Association at the General Motors show at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Legislation to provide for a continuation of the Freedom Train for two more years will get a hearing Thursday by the House Postoffice and Civil Service Committee. The continuation would be at Federal Government expense, as its sponsors, the American Heritage Foundation, have found that they can no longer raise the necessary funds privately.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The American Federation of Labor declined today to throw its unqualified support behind President Truman's request for full restoration of tariff-making procedures under which the reciprocal trade program of Cordell Hull was developed.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 25 (UP) -- Ralph S. Damon, former head of American Airlines, was named head of Trans-Continental Western Air, Inc., today at a meeting of TWA directors.
An experimental program designed to aid the city's "slow-learning" high school pupils will be introduced next month by the Board of Education, it became known yesterday.
Engineers employed by the Hudson Manhattan Railroad withdrew yesterday notice of a strike against the tubes scheduled for 4 o'clock this morning.
ROME, Jan. 25 -- The Foreign Ministry reported moderately good progress today in negotiations between Italy and Yugoslavia toward an economic agreement.
New York's garment center will dwindle to a ghost town unless more young people take up careers in the needle trades, Abe Stark, City Commissioner of Commerce, warned yesterday.

Beaten only three times in eighty-five ring engagements, Billy Graham, East Side welterweight, tonight will seek to add Wilfred (Fitzie) Pruden, St. Catherine, Ont., to his list of vanquished rivals when they meet in the main bout of ten rounds at Manhattan Center.

A sound plan for attacking what one authority has called "the most pressing nutritional problem in the country today" is offered by the State College of Home Economics at Cornell University. A newly revised booklet, prepared by Home Economist Hazel M. Hauck, discusses overweight and how daily food intake can be changed to alter the condition.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 25 -- President Juan D. Peron decreed today that all tourists and foreigners without permanent resident status must have new "control" cards issued by the federal police. The police will remind applicants for cards of date when they must leave and of their obligation not to engage in remunerative work here without permanent status.

At the annual meeting last night of the Curb Exchange Five and Twenty Club, Edward A. O'Brien, a regular member of the New York Curb Exchange since 1920, was elected president. Vice president of the group since its formation in 1947, he succeeds Mortimer Landsberg, who held the office during that time.
LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 25 -- The United Nations Security Council today heard motions to strengthen the four-power resolution for an Indonesian settlement in favor of the Republican Government.

Recent scientific efforts to control the weather and make rain start or stop at man's will were subjected to the scrutiny of the United States Weather Bureau in the Astor Hotel yesterday and termed "of relatively little economic importance."

The first showing of "Prairie Wings," one of the finest motion pictures of duck hunting and wild-fowl flight ever produced, will be held at the annual Ducks Unlimited dinner, slated for the Hotel Roosevelt on Feb. 3

A resolution calling upon the State Legislature to investigate crime along the city's waterfront was introduced in the City Council yesterday by Councilman Edward Rager, Manhattan Republican. The resolution was referred to the Council's Committee on State Legislation.

Del Webb, co-owner with Dan Topping of the New York Yankee baseball empire, will give his "personal and financial support wholeheartedly" to his partner's football operations, in which Topping just has become associated with Branch Rickey of the baseball Dodgers.

BOSTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Bruins tonight reported they had signed John E. (Jack) Gelineau, McGill University goal-tender, to a National Hockey League contract and that the 24-year-old collegian would be in the nets here tomorrow night, when Boston opposes the Toronto Maple Leafs.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 25 -- The "objectivity" of the Neue Zeitung, the United States Army's German-language publication, has aroused the suspicion in many quarters that it contains a subtle instigation of the revival of German nationalism written by persons of Nazi background.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 25 -- The viewpoint of German officialdom now may be exemplified by the statement of Professor Eric Noelting, Minister of Economics, in North Rhine-Westphalia, which includes the Ruhr region.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Jan. 25 -- Cadets and civilians alike streamed aboard the famed U.S.S. Cabot, which anchored today at this naval base, and saw at first hand the great "mothball" ship which had been successfully unzippered for service.

A biography of Dr. Elizabeth Blackwell, first woman doctor in the United States and Great Britain and founder of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children, is being written by Ishbel Ross. The account is based in part on old family diaries and letters, which have not been available previously.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- As a result of talks initiated last November Britain has agreed to grant drawing rights in sterling in favor of Turkey to the equivalent of $800,000,000, the Economic Information Unit of the Treasury announced tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 25 -- A demand by Henry J. Kaiser for an early Congressional investigation into "abuses" of regulation "W" governing installment buying of cars was applauded today by several thousand dealers attending the National Automobile Dealers Association's convention. He asked for a "fight against 'regulitis.'"
The Salvation Army's Bureau of Missing Persons in this city receives inquiries from all parts of the world and obtains information from every corner of the globe.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,969, compared with 3,160 last week and 1,135 in the similar week of 1948, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 784 arrivals yesterday against 1,226 last Tuesday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 25 -- W. Somerset Maugham, the British novelist, remarked to his hosts at his fiftieth birthday party on Jan. 25, 1924, that he hoped to celebrate his seventy-fifth birthday with them.

Bond houses specializing in local government bonds are wondering how much further municipal bond prices can safely extend their recent spectacular post-election rise, if at all. The market has quieted down a bit as executives take a cautious look around.

ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- Legislative action that would permit payment of the veterans bonus to former residents of New York who were not living in the state when bonus payments began a year ago neared completion today.

There were a lot of red faces around town yesterday. They burned in varying shades of temporary embarrassment in such normally separated places as Salvation Army headquarters and Tammany Hall, to say nothing about the chambers of half a dozen Supreme Court Justices and the hideout of Frank Costello, one-time underworld king who for some time has been seeking respectability and contacts in high social and political quarters.
A telephone booth with a ventilating system is being manufactured to replace the stuffy old-fashioned ones, the Bell System reported yesterday.

Governor Dewey's recommendation to the Legislature that state aid to education be increased by $40,000,000 over the existing formula was received by mixed reaction yesterday among the city's educational groups.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan. 25 -- Announcement of the formation of the new Eastern European economic council was made here today in a special edition of the official newspaper of the Workers' [Communist] party. The announcement did not comment on the exclusion of Yugoslavia as one of the nations represented.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The swift stockpiling of critical materials, essential in the event of war, has become so urgent that the possible effect on the civilian economy will no longer be considered a "limitation."

The heads of three of New York's four largest educational institutions differed yesterday as to whether membership in the Communist party should be sufficient cause for dismissal from an academic position.

RHODES, Jan. 25 -- Egypt and Israel have signed a formal document making the Jan. 7 cease-fire into "a complete and enduring cease-fire between all the elements of our military or parliamentary forces," spokesman for the Acting United Nations Mediator, Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, announced tonight.

The belief that the Coast Guard icebreaker-Eastwind did not sound her fog horn before the early Wednesday morning crash with the oil tanker Gulfstream was expressed yesterday by the icebreaker's commander, Capt. John A. Glynn of Gloucester, Mass.

Deere Co., manufacturers of agricultural machinery and equipment, and its subsidiaries, in the fiscal year ended with last October, transacted the largest sales and earnings in the history of the company.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People called upon the Senate yesterday to amend its rules so as to shut off filibusters against proposed civil rights legislation. At the same time the association sent telegrams to its branches instructing them to urge their Senators to "vote for closure by majority vote."

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 -- Liquidation forced down prices of grain on the Board of Trade today, and the close was at the bottom. May corn and wheat sold at a new low since early last November, and September and December oats sold at a new seasonal low.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Britain and the United States are reliably said tonight to be offering constant encouragement to Israel and Egypt to come to terms in the Rhodes armistice negotiations. No recent special instructions are known to have been sent to British and American diplomatic representatives in Tel Arty and Cairo, but they have been under standing orders to stress the importance that their governments attach to permanent peace in Palestine.
The city's 1949 quota in the thirty-third annual campaign of the American Red Cross is $4,635,000, Brig. Gen E. F. Jeffe, city chairman, announced yesterday.
Bruno Walter will conduct eighteen concerts in the Beethoven cycle to be presented this season at Carnegie Hall by the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York. There will be six main programs.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 25 -- Two Labor parties -- one headed by Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion --led in the first inconclusive returns tonight from the Israeli election.
TRENTON, N. J., Jan 25 -- The Presbytery of New Brunswick, at its annual meeting today, condemned current proposals to legalize bingo games in New Jersey for religious and welfare benefits.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Shooting a workmanlike four-under-par 67, Ben Hogan of Hershey, Pa., defeated Jimmy Demaret of Houston, Tex., by two strokes in the 18-hole play-off of the Long Beach open golf tournament today.

Senator Robert A. Taft, chairman of the Republican policy committee, assailed the Truman Administration's public housing bill last night on the ground that it would permit the expenditure of too much money for homes for families in the lowest income group.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The recent closure of the Waltham Watch Company was cited before the House Ways and Means Committee today as proof that reciprocal trade agreements can harm domestic industry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The Kentucky Utilities Company, Lexington, Ky., received permission today from the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell at competitive bidding $10,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, Series B, due in 1979.

Modernization of the anti-trust laws and enforcement of provisions against unfair trade practices are vital steps by Government in checking monopoly and concentrated ownership, Senator James E. Murray, chairman of the Senate Committee on Small Business, said last night.
LONDON, Jan. 25 -- The Government departments, which are among the biggest regular users of newspaper advertising, entirely disregard the political complexion of the medium in which they buy space.

Out of Stockholm comes a message of gratitude from Bjorn Kjellstrom, president of the Swedish Ski Association, asking this department to convey to the "American skiing public," the heartfelt thanks of the Swedish people for the "warm receptions given and the hospitality shown" to the visiting Swedes, Bengt Jaderholm and Vilhelm Hellman.

Contending that most small houses built today are neither individual nor architecture, Philip C. Johnson, New York architect, declared last night that the responsibility of the architect today is to put art into housing and create orderly developments.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 25 -- In the event of a breakdown in the Rhodes negotiations it is believed that the Security Council will turn the question over to the new Palestine Conciliation Commission, consisting of the United States, France and Turkey, which was established by the General Assembly last December.

Conventional airplanes and engines never were mentioned in the day long sessions of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences at the Astor Hotel yesterday. The three technical sessions were devoted to problems of supersonic flight and jet power.
Your good editorial regarding the new traffic commission recommends the advisability of appointing the traffic engineer as chairman of the commission also.

As the representative of a syndicate known as Algam, George F. Breen of 20 Pine Street yesterday confirmed reports that his group was about to purchase the Empire City race track in Yonkers for use as a night harness racing course.

TOKYO, Jan. 25 -- The Japanese people have strongly supported their new Supreme Court, named eighteen months ago under the new Constitution, it became known tonight as the final results of Sunday's general election are being tabulated.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Jan. 25 (AP) -- With Honey Sister bringing the top price of $57,200, Louis B. Mayer, motion picture executive, is $635,000 richer today from the auction of fifty-one 2-year-olds in the fourth dispersal sale of his vast racing empire.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Vice President Barkley today vigorously defended the Administration's aid-to-education and health programs.

A formula change in the production of blends by Seagram Distillers was disclosed yesterday by the State Liquor Authority. The changes affected only the percentages of straight whiskies and not the percentage of straight whiskies to neutral spirits.

At a special meeting yesterday the Board of Estimate unanimously approved the charter amendment establishing a Traffic Commission to advise on traffic problems and to formulate rules and regulations for coping with the city's traffic difficulties.

I am writing in connection with an editorial which appeared Jan. 15 in your newspaper, and which stated, among other things, "everyone knows, of course, what has happened to the price of books." As an association which includes most of the major book publishers in the United States, we wish to point out that the implications of this kind of statement are unfair as well as untrue.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 25 -- A distressed husband in the French African territory of the Cameroon has asked the United Nations to do something about his matrimonial difficulties, which started when he was off fighting with the forces of Gen. Charles de Gaulle.

The Franklin D. Roosevelt Birthday Memorial Concert, to be held next Sunday evening at the Waldorf-Astoria, will be broadcast by Station WNYC from 8:30 to 10 P. M. and by WNYC-FM from 8:30 to 11:15 P. M.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 25 (UP) -- Manager-shortstop Lou Boudreau received his personal reward today for directing the Cleveland Indians to the world championship -- a two-year contract for $150,000 and an apology from his boss, Bill Veeck, Cleveland president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UP) -- The House Veterans Committee will take up old age pensions for veterans of World Wars I and II as its first order of business, with hearings starting Thursday, Chairman John E. Rankin, Democrat, of Mississippi, said today.

NANKING, Jan. 25 -- With the Chinese Government unable to independent left wing backing in Shanghai and with Communist troops pushing unopposed toward the Yangtze River, the North Shensi radio tonight announced the Communists' willingness to discuss peace with Acting President Li Tsung-jen's negotiators on terms amounting to virtual surrender.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Heavyweight champion Joe Louis tonight boxed with Elmer (Violent) Ray in a six-round exhibition match in the Orange Bowl Stadium before an estimated 15,000 cheering fans.

Because of stringent midtown and downtown parking regulations, the $350,000,000 annual volume of business of 3,000 New York salesmen has dropped 20 to 40 per cent since the end of 1947, it was charged yesterday by Louis A. Capaldo, president of the National Council of Salesmen's Organizations.

MOSCOW, Jan. 25 -- Organization of a Council for Economic Mutual Assistance by the Soviet Union and five of its neighbors was announced today. It was viewed by foreign diplomats here as the East's answer to the West's European Recovery Program.

Planes flying through Arctic-like weather, United States Army bulldozers, foot parties and many other reserve forces were hurled into the battle to save snowbound humans and 2,000,000 sheep and cattle in Far Western States yesterday in one of the most far-flung rescue operations of its kind.

Battling desperately to hold second place in the Basketball Association of America's Eastern standings, the New York Knickerbockers will oppose the Providence Steamrollers at the Sixty-ninth Regimen Armory tonight. Standard Oil and Abraham Straus will clash at 7:30 P. M. in a Knickerbocker Industrial League preliminary.

Extreme opponents of the Taft-Hartley Act (notably the Congress of Industrial Organizations) have strongly urged that modification of the law be achieved by two distinct steps. Under the first of these the 1947 legislation would be repealed and the old Labor Relations Act of 1935 (the Wagner Act) restored in its place.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce reported today retail sales set a record in December, making a comeback from the previous month's lag.

One hundred thousand boys and girls throughout the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York took part in the Catholic Youth Organization program during the last year, the association said yesterday in its annual report.

The vestry of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Clinton and Montague Streets, Brooklyn, has requested the Bishop of the diocese of Long Island to terminate the pastorate of the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, rector of the church for the last forty-four years, it was learned yesterday.

One of Europe's most intricately curious elections is scheduled to take place next month when two elderly generals oppose each other at the polls in Portugal on the ultimate issue of whether that country shall remain a corporative dictatorship state or not.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 25 -- Sam Bischoff, James Nasser, Howard Hughes and United Artists today closed a long-pending deal for the financing of Bischoff's next production, "Mrs. Mike," in which Dick Powell will play the leading role and will participate as Bischoff's partner.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 -- Backlogs of orders in both aluminum and copper alloys are practically non-existent, it was disclosed in a survey of business conditions in the non-ferrous foundry industry, according to officials of the Non-Ferrous Founders Society here today.

Adele Marcus, who played at Carnegie Hall last night, is a good pianist. Her performances have temperament, character and intelligence. They show that she has come to her own conclusions about the shape and nature of a composition by virtue of independent thinking and feeling.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Ship owners and the Maritime Commission endorsed today a bill which would require that half of all aid cargoes financed by American dollars be carried in United States ships.

The first freedom award of the Freedom Lodge of B'nai B'rith was given to Mayor O'Dwyer at City Hall yesterday for his "untiring fight for the betterment of interracial and interfaith relations in New York City." The award, a bronze plaque, was accompanied by a check for $1,000 which is to be given to a charitable cause.

Joseph B. Elliott has been appointed vice president in charge of all RCA Victor consumer products, and L. W. Teegarden vice president in charge of all RCA technical products, it was announced yesterday in Camden by the RCA Victor division of the Radio Corporation of America.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York borrowed $50,000,000 yesterday on thirty-year first and refunding mortgage bonds at an interest cost of about 2.91 per cent. The bonds were sold at competitive bidding to a syndicate of forty-nine investment houses headed by First Boston Corporation at a bid of 101.69 for an interest rate of 3 per cent.

Bertram Kelso, who sang at Times Hall last night, is a handsome young tenor with a handsome, if somewhat small, voice. He deserves credit, first of all, for being content to sing a program that put little strain on the scope of his artistry or the size and range of his voice.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- In the first strong thrust by the pro-civil rights forces in the new Congress, the Senate Rules Committee probably will recommend next week a procedural change designed to weaken but not to destroy the filibuster power of the Southern opposition.

The number of workers drawing unemployment benefits in this city dropped 8,945 last week, according to figures made public yesterday by Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner. The drop followed a decline of 4,013 in the week ended Jan. 14 and reduced the number of persons receiving unemployment insurance and veterans readjustment allowances to 280,643.

The impact of this country's attempt to rehabilitate half the world probably will fall more heavily upon the American maritime industry than on any others, J. Lewis Luckenbach, president of the American Bureau of Shipping, declared yesterday at the eighty-seventh annual meeting of the bureau's board of managers.

Success of retailers' promotions of cotton dresses has spurred sales of most types of combed cotton textiles, it was learned yesterday. The market on numerous constructions has taken on a much firmer tone than was apparent at the end of the year, textile men said, particularly in view of the fact that goods are being bought for periods up to ninety days ahead.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The economic integration of southeastern Europe would cost the Soviet Union at least $500,000,000 a year for financing trade deficits and a like amount in canceled reparations obligations due from its satellite countries, according to expert opinion here.

The extra years of life offered by today's knowledge of nutrition should be thought of as being inserted "at the apex of the prime of life" rather than as an addition to old age, Dr. Henry C. Sherman declared last night upon receiving from Columbia University one of its Frederick Chandler medals.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 25 -- India's food imports for the current year will exceed all records. A Food Ministry official estimated today that imports for 1949-50 would be 4,500,000 tons as against 2,800,000 tons last year.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 25 -- The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, this city's only morning newspaper, will enter the Sunday field March 27, according to an announcement tonight by William Block, co-publisher.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Jan. 25 -- On the outskirts of this city lies a tiny empire with more than 1,000,000 subjects. Its monarch, Harry G. Herrlein, rules with an iron scepter, decreeing how his subjects shall live, what they shall eat and what they shall drink.

Mayor O'Dwyer, marking the start of construction of the Whitestone trunk sewer, described it yesterday as part of the city's housekeeping program to eliminate water pollution and make the bathing beaches safe.

TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 25 -- Senator George D, Aiken of Vermont, co-sponsor of the Hope - Aiken Farm Price Support Act, told New Jersey farmers today that the measure should be supplemented to provide a long-range national farm program.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- During the next four years Britain is going to invest more-money in increasing domestic food production than in raising the output of coal, iron and steel, Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer and Minister of Economics, stated tonight.

BERLIN, Jan. 25 -- More than twenty-four hours after the crash of a Royal Air Force Dakota airlift plane Soviet authorities tonight granted permission for a British investigating team to visit the scene of the crash in a woodland near Schoenberg, about ten miles east of Luebeck.

Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, chancellor of the University of Chicago, declared last night that the world situation was so critical that a convention of nations to draft a constitution for World Government was the only hope of averting war.

Despite heavy seas and a three-day storm on the run from the Channel ports the United States liner America docked at West Twenty-first Street at her scheduled hour of 1:30 P. M. yesterday and company personnel and dock workers immediately took over the task of stocking the vessel for a special cruise to the West Indies.

The rent control bill of 1947 provided for a voluntary 15 per cent rent boost, if the landlord was willing to sign a lease for a period of at least nine months over the intended termination of rent control. In other words the tenant was given an opportunity to pay for the privilege of enjoying a stabilized rent beyond the intended termination of rent control.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -The Federal Power Commission has postponed indefinitely a hearing scheduled for Feb. 7 in its investigation of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line-Company's transfer of natural gas reserves to the Hugoton Production Company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 19:

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Governor Dewey went tonight to New York where he will confer tomorrow with 200 building contractors and representatives of banks and insurance companies with respect to his program for stabilizing employment in the building trades and reducing the cost of private home building.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- In an avowed role of constructive opposition, Republicans in Congress came up today with two alternatives to the Administration low rent housing bill, which calls for 1,050,000 new units in the next seven years.

A financial crisis, caused in part by high educational costs, threatens the breakdown of this country's student exchange program. Unless help is obtained at once, 5,000 foreign students will be forced to withdraw from American colleges and universities next month.

The giant modern airplane has become so fantastically complex and so fabulously expensive that it can no longer be risked in the training of flight crews, Rear Admiral Luis de Florez, USN (Ret.) told yesterday's meeting of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences at the Astor Hotel.
DETROIT, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Tigers bought some first-base insurance today when they acquired Ulysses (Tony) Lupien from the White Sox for the waiver price of $10,000.

Three of Norway's stand-out ski officials and manufacturers, Knut Gresvig, Sverre Baevre and Christian Sorlie, recently arrived from the mother country of the sport, officially met the press at the Three Crowns Restaurant yesterday while snow reports from the Northlands were most promising.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 26 -The Selznick Releasing Organization tonight announced that it will close "most of its branch offices in the United States, temporarily and perhaps permanently." Future Selznick distributing operations will be determined at policy meetings scheduled by executives of the company this week-end, the announcement said.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 26 -Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion's Government and consequently his personal leadership received a vote of confidence from the civilian population of Israel in the first national election yesterday. The Army vote has not yet been counted but it will probably increase the forty-one seats now virtually assured the Mapai party.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Senate Banking Committee approved today a bill extending for seven months the authority for voluntary allocation agreements covering scarce commodities.
Four pints of blood in return for an apartment was the offer made yesterday by a despairing Brooklyn father.
The British India Steam Navigation Company, Ltd., has nineteen ships, including two 15,000-ton liners, building or on order, according to the Cunard White Star Line, agent in this country.
NANKING, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Foreign Office announced today that on Feb. 3 all Government functions will cease in Nanking, now little more than a shell of Nationalist authority.
