It was no great feat, inasmuch as their opponents had bagged only half a dozen victories in their previous thirty-seven tries, but the Knickerbockers were quite happy about the 89-77 success achieved against the Providence Steam Rollers at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Pensions for all disabled or elderly war veterans would be provided under the terms of a bill started today toward House consideration by Representative John E. Rankin of Mississippi, chairman of the Committee on Veterans Affairs.

Bus drivers on the lines of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and the New York City Omnibus Corporation have voted overwhelmingly to accept the proposal of Joseph E. O'Grady, director of the City Labor Relations Division, that they arbitrate their dispute with the companies over pensions and retroactive pay, it was learned last night.

The Public Service Commission has authorized a rate increase of $1,025,000 a year for the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, it was learned yesterday. The new rates, which are expected to become effective on Saturday, will affect 820,000 customers of the utility, which serves large sections of Brooklyn and Queens.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 26 (AP) -Lynne L. White, executive vice president of the New York, Chicago and St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad and the Wheeling and Lake Erie Railway, was named today president and a director of the Nickel Plate.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan 26 (AP) -- Blue Border, an unpredictable gelding that had beaten only one horse in the recent Hialeah Inaugural, was in a running mood today and captured the $12,825 Palm Beach Handicap to pay $16.30 for $2 at Hialeah.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Embattled Southerners in the Senate opened today an action of little hope to try to beat off any stiffening of the "gag rule" wherever it applied to wholly domestic matters, such as the so-called civil rights program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UP) -President Truman favors a "single package" bill to repeal the Taft-Hartley Act, revive the old Wagner Labor Relations Act and strengthen the Labor Department, a White House meeting was told tonight.

ATHENS, Jan. 26 -- Gen. Alexander Papagos, newly appointed Commander in Chief of the Greek armed forces, recalled five generals to active service today from retirement. Among them is Lieut. Gen. Constantine Ventiris, who retired ten month ago, allegedly under the pressure of political influence against him.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- A witness at the "Axis Sally" treason trial testified today that American prisoners of war were hostile toward the woman who allegedly betrayed the United States for Nazi gold.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The United States Associates of the International Chamber of Commerce urged Congress today to extend for not less than five years the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act but strongly objected to the 1948 version of the act.

Safeway Stores Inc., will soon expand their frozen food operations, it was learned here yesterday. In the New York area, the company has been selling froz .en foods in six stores on an experimental basis and has maintained similar operations in other cities throughout the country.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 26 -- The exclusion of Yugoslavia from the Council of Economic Mutual Aid was the subject of lively discussion today among foreign observers in Belgrade.

The United States can and must help financially in world reconstruction and in improving living standards at home, but not at the risk of wrecking its economy under unbearable burdens, Representative Frederic R. Coudert Jr. declared yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- The tone of London spring fashion collections continues on quiet lines -- slim, graceful and with great attention to detail of pockets, cuffs, collars and even buttons that open by pressure and need no buttonholes.

Two new films have been booked for midtown premieres on Saturday, Feb. 5, it was reported yesterday. Loew's Criterion will offer "He Walked By Night," an Eagle-Lion melodrama starring Richard Basehart and directed by Alfred Werker.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Republicans in Congress, seeking to bring harmony and victory in 1950 out of their intraparty struggle between "liberals" and "the Old Guard," charted several new moves today. It was conceded widely at the Capitol, however, that the plans themselves might lead to new strife.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Miss Peggy Kirk of Findlay, Ohio, the medalist moved into the second round of the seventeenth annual Helen Lee Doherty women's golf tournament today when she easily defeated Mrs. Arthur Flash of Scarsdale, N. Y., 7 and 6.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 26 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie and his top economic aide gavethe United Nations' official and hopeful welcome today to President Truman's "bold new program" of technical assistance to underdeveloped regions.

The steel group staged a show all its own yesterday on the stock market under the sponsorship of United States Steel, but the rest of the list moved in a spotty manner. United States Steel, in response to the overnight announcement of a special dividend of $1 a share and the proposal to split the common shares three for one, climbed 4 5/8 points to a close of 77 1/2.

Brooklyn had a day of bounty yesterday when the Fort Greene Retail Market presented its customers with free sandwiches, coffee and buns. Today may be even better for housewives. In addition to free lunch, the market will slash as much as 25 per cent from the price of 46,000 pounds of meat and reduce the quotations on eggs, butter and milk.
RENO, Nev., Jan. 26 -- A Nevada lawmaker today proposed a slowdown for couples getting a six-weeks' Reno divorce.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Although the Administration bill to give President Truman permanent powers to abolish, transfer, consolidate and coordinate with others "all agencies of the Government" is more sweeping than any similar request from President Roosevelt, many who attacked the former as setting up an "Executive dictatorship" and forced basic modifications are supporting the current proposal.

MONTREAL, Jan. 26 (Canadian Press) -- Canada and the United States are again allies in a new war, and the battlefield is "the economic system under which both nations live," Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, said here tonight.

Although the Christmas cards were received long since, they still form a subject for intense brooding. There were the usual number of pictures of children, in which the senders, for some reason, must have been interested.

OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 26 -- Republican unity talks collapsed tonight and opposing forces immediately renewed their hard, bitter, close fight over the proposed ouster of Hugh D. Scott Jr. of Pennsylvania as party chairman and his replacement by Roy Dunn of Minnesota.
The long awaited and constantly predicted conference between Jolting Joe DiMaggio and his New York Yankee employers took place yesterday -- with what may be reasonably termed a negligible result.

Former President Herbert Hoover, speaking for the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government, said last night that he "prays" for the support of the citizens for the commission's proposals, which are to be presented to Congress in twenty reports beginning next week.

UTICA, N. Y., Jan. 26 (AP) -- A deputy Attorney General on election duty in this city said today that he was told to "shut your mouth or you're going to the hospital" when he tried to investigate conditions at a polling place.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- A new international wheat conference opened today with fifty nations represented, including the Soviet Union and Argentina, great wheat producing countries, as full delegates.

Homogenized milk sold by the Borden Company to homes, stores and at wholesale will be reduced one cent a quart on Tuesday, Francis R. Elliott, president of Borden's Farm Products, announced yesterday. A quart of regular milk will go down half a cent.

A new rise of 2,368,000 barrels occurred last week in the nation's gasoline stocks, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies were 111,587,000 barrels, compared with 109,219,000 a week earlier and 100,586,000 a year earlier.

For the first time in the history of measurement of the relative standing of broadcast programs, a single performer, Arthur Godfrey, has one broadcast show and two television programs among the leading ten presentations.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 26 -- A plan to establish minimum standards for physical education in the state's public schools was set in motion here today as about 1,200 delegates gathered for the eleventh annual convention of the New York State Association for Health, Physical Education and Recreation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The general executive board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, CIO, opening a three-day meeting here tomorrow, is expected to make an appropriation of $1,000,000 for the campaign to organize the employes of department stores and retail clothing chains.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -Otis Co. asked today for an injunction to bar the National Association of Security Dealers, Inc., from going ahead with a threatened two-year suspension of the Cleveland banking firm.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

The American Arbitration Association announced yesterday at its twenty-second annual meeting at its headquarters, 9 Rockefeller Plaza, that it had greatly expanded its activity in international commercial disputes.

Donald Strachan of the Princeton Club retained his metropolitan Class A squash racquets title last night by defeating Calvin MacCracken, New York State champion, at the Downtown A. C., 15 -- 12, 15 -- 11, 12 -- 15 and 15 -- 7.

Real as financial crises are in American higher education, the more decisive issue is the task of imparting to students a sense of intellectual integrity and perspective, John Sloan Dickey, president of Dartmouth College, told 700 members of the Dartmouth Alumni Club of New York last night.

Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., plans to offer 404,112 shares of its common stock to present shareholders, Warren Lee Pierson, chairman, announced yesterday. He said a registration statement covering the issue will be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in a few days.
A large group of American figure skating stars boarded the Cunard White Star liner S. S. Queen Mary last night on their way to compete in the world championships at Paris next month.

The 165-year-old residence of Genevieve H. Williams, former honorary commissioner of landscaping under the late Borough President George U. Harvey, in Whitestone, Queens, will make way for a garden apartment project, according to plans announced yesterday by Abraham A. Roth, who bought it recently.

NANKING, Jan. 26 -- In the town of Pukow, across the Yangtze River from this city, troops of the Government's Sixth Army Group were digging in today for a last-ditch stand before the nation's capital. Few of them, however, seemed to believe that it would take place.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson took occasion today in response to questions at his news conference to declare that there has been no change in United States policy toward China.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- An increase of $75,000,000 in state aid to cities, of which $50,000,000 would go to New York, was requested of the Legislature today by the State Conference of Mayors. It was proposed that the additional grants be financed by a rise in the personal income tax that would bring the rates to a new all-time high.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- The New York State Freedom Train, carrying eighty-nine historic state documents for display in all sections of the state, was dedicated officially by Governor Dewey and started on its way today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- The Checker Cab Manufacturing Company was the mysterious financial backer which was to have refinanced the Tucker Corporation but did not do so, a source close to the corporation disclosed today.

Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin said Tuesday that Britain would contribute her "knowledge, ability and resources" to work with the United States in developing economically backward areas of the world. This is already being done. Britain and the United States are now engaged on a long-term program to improve remote, underdeveloped regions as far apart as the Malay Peninsula and eastern Africa.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -House agricultural leaders moved tonight to put through stop-gap cotton legislation so farmers can make plans promptly for their 1949 crop. An agriculture subcommittee, which is studying a long-range cotton program, recessed its public hearing, probably until Friday, so it can consider a resolution dealing only with the current year's plantings.

The groupings for thirty-one college teams that will compete in the mile and two-mile relay races at the Millrose A. A. games in Madison Square Garden Saturday night were announced yesterday by Fred Schmertz. Twenty-five of the varsity teams will strive for the John G. Anderson Memorial Cup, awarded for the fastest time of seven one-mile tests.

By taking down $65,500,000 of new public utility bonds this week, underwriting syndicates have lopped off the cream of new offerings of high-grade corporate securities for the next couple of weeks. At the moment, the only other sizable source of new prime supply is the Kentucky Utilities Company's offering of $10,000,000 of bonds next Monday.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 26 -- The Teamsters Union of the American Federation of Labor gobbled up 6,000 members of a union of the Congress of Industrial Organizations today in its coast-to-coast drive for new members. In taking over the United Distribution Workers local the teamsters brought about what is believed to be the biggest labor raid in the city's history.

The watch officer in charge of the Coast Guard icebreaker East-wind when she collided with the oil tanker Gulfstream told a Coast Guard inquiry board yesterday that a course change he had ordered some time before on the basis of reports from the ship's radar, which, he concluded, later had not been operating properly, had been a major factor in causing the crash.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina warned lawyers for the eleven Communist leaders yesterday to stop their delaying tactics. He said the "whole administration of justice here" would be paralyzed if they continued calling jurors as witnesses without limit.

Dates for the national invitation basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden were announced yesterday by Jack Coffey, president of the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Basketball Association, which sponsors the annual competition.
Hearn's became yesterday the fourth large New York department store to sign a new contract with the left-wing store unions that quit the Congress of Industrial Organizations last September.

Although total sales of America's grocery stores reached an all-time peak estimated at $24 1/2 billion in 1948, there has been a slowing down recently and sales apparently will level off and may even decline slightly in 1949. Retail drug store sales, by contrast, have remained at their 1946 level the past two years, whereas grocery sales increased 18 per cent in that time.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 -- As Roman Catholics look to the Pope in the Vatican, the Rabbinates throughout the world should be unified through the establishment of a central institution around the Chief Rabbinate in Jerusalem, the midwinter conference of the Rabbinical Council of America was told today.
The Syracuse (N. Y.) Housing Authority borrowed $2,335,000 yesterday on temporary loan notes due Aug. 1. The notes were purchased by Salomon Brothers Hutzler at 1.03 per cent interest plus $37.
Mayor O'Dwyer appointed a three-man committee yesterday in an effort to avert a strike that threatens to cut off 70 per cent of the city's bread supply at midnight Monday.

The present controversy in the Fire Department between the Fire Commissioner and the Chief of the Department indicates that an impartial study should be made of these two offices with a view, primarily, of eliminating divided authority and of securing the maximum of administrative efficiency.

A first degree murder charge in the shooting of a man and a woman on a Greenwich Village doorstep last Oct. 21 was dismissed yesterday by General Sessions Judge George L. Donnellan against John J. Scanlan Jr., 26-year-old longshoreman.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Albany weathered a water famine without catastrophe today as a failure of the city's distribution system left thousands of homes without water for more than fourteen hours.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26 -- An overhauling of labor policies to prepare for competitive days ahead was urged upon members of the National Automobile Dealers Association at their national convention today.

A gastronomical half truth by a Broadway columnist yesterday resulted in the turning away of hundreds of requests for Friday night dinner reservations in many of New York's leading Chinese-American restaurants.

The Board of Education started the 1949 phase of its post-war building program yesterday with ceremonies marking the beginning of construction of new P. S. 98 in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn. The structure will be the twenty-eighth in the board's program and the sixth in Brooklyn since the end of the war.

Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson promised yesterday that he would keep the city's budget for the coming fiscal year within the limits of the present budget of $1,160,500,000 even though department heads have already asked for $65,000,000 more than they had for the 1948-49 period.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad and the Wabash Railroad asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to buy from the Pennroad Corporation all the outstanding common stock, 245,329 shares, of the Detroit, Toledo and Ironton Railroad Company.

DETROIT, Jan. 26 -- Designed to extend substantially all the foreign activities of the Ford Motor Company, the Ford International Company has been created as a coordinating agency. Henry Ford 2d, president of the parent concern, said today that the new company would have its headquarters at 445 Park Avenue, New York.

BOWLING GREEN, Ky., Jan. 26 (AP) -- A small bomb, mailed in a package from Newark, N. J., exploded in the post office here today and injured four employes, one seriously, and partly wrecked the mail room.

A resolution endorsing the Johnson-Philbin bill to legalize the basing point pricing system for industry was approved yesterday by 400 members of the Anti-Trust Law Section of the New York State Bar Association at the group's annual meeting in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

In its efforts to find some way of solving New York's constantly bigger traffic problem the City Administration and its experts should find at least some measure of guidance in a survey of parking and traffic conditions in forty-four of the nation's largest cities made by the Thirty-fourth Street Midtown Association.
The argument between the Port of New York Authority and the airlines has seemed a little like that as to whether the hen or the egg comes first. Certainly neither can get along without the other.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- With President Truman leading the way with a $200,000 grant, Federal resources were being mobilized on a wide front today to rush aid to persons and livestock isolated in five blizzard - stricken Western states.

To the consumer about to buy a mechanical refrigerator and bewildered by the many makes offered, K. G. Roe of General Electric's refrigeration division, had this to say yesterday at an all-day workshop of the Electrical Women's Round Table:

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Despite the slow trading most sections of the stock market here today remained firm. Short-dated British Government stocks improved on some institutional buying, but other issues were neglected and tended to ease as much as one-sixteenth.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Charges that patients in state mental hospitals have been flogged, brutally beaten and otherwise mistreated were put before the State Senate today by Senator Elmer F. Quinn, Democratic minority leader, during a debate on the state's hospital building program.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Federal Communication Commission, after extensive hearings, today authorized increased international communication rates to companies operating from the United States.

While processes servers continued to deliver eviction notices to residents of the Washington Square South block between Sullivan and Macdougal Streets yesterday, other agents of New York University pressed their difficult search for apartments to accommodate these 108 families.
By all ordinary standards the presentation of Zoe Atkins' dramatization of "The Old Maid" by the Lighthouse Players at their auditorium on East Fifty-ninth Street last night was excellent theatre.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- President Truman is expected to extend de jure recognition to Israel on Friday or Saturday, after the returns of that country's first election are in.

JOHN ALOYSIUS HASSETT, the best left-handed tenor ever to perform in the big leagues, is the new manager of the Newark Bears, one of the top farm teams in the once vast Yankee organization. It is a very nice promotion for a young man who already has won his master-minding spurs at Norfolk and Binghamton. Furthermore, he seems to have acquired the knack for developing young ball players, a strong prerequisite for the job.

Three economists and a diplomatic correspondent, all of whom had within the year studied "on location" the progress of European recovery and the effects of American aid, presented widely differing findings last night in discussing the question, "Can the Marshall Plan Work?"

Chairman Vinson of the House Armed Services Committee describes in the current issue of the magazine Planes a horse-and-buggy restriction on Air Force procurement that the Eighty-first Congress should remedy. Under present legislation the Air Force must obligate each fiscal year and spend within two years funds allotted to it by Congress.

New York's methods of handling traffic and parking were termed "surprisingly slipshod" yesterday by the French and Italian delegates to the American Automobile Association's international travel conference at the Roosevelt Hotel. Automotive transportation procedure here was likened to that of a medieval European town.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- The Democratic minority in the Senate charged today that the Dewey administration had used the post-war reconstruction fund to conceal a rise in the state operating budget.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 26 -- A slow but progressive improvement in the food situation, coinciding with a decline of exports to the Cominform states -- the Soviet-bloc nations adhering to Communist Information Bureau -- has become apparent in Belgrade in recent weeks.

OTTAWA, Jan. 26 -- In opening the fifth session of the Twentieth Canadian Parliament this afternoon, the Governor General, Viscount Alexander of Tunis, read the Government's declaration of policy which gave the negotiation and ratification of the North Atlantic pact first place as a necessary guarantee of peace and security.

Mary Pickford and Charles Chaplin, co-founders and present equal owners of United Artists, have agreed to an exchange of options whereby either may become sole owner of the distributing company within three months. The fact that Miss Pickford and Mr. Chaplin had agreed to such an arrangement was made known to the company's directors at a special financial meeting held Tuesday at the United Artists home office, 729 Seventh Avenue.

RENO, Jan. 26 -- Vicomte Jacques Jean de Sibour, who left France as a young man to take a job in the H. Gordon Selfridge department store in London and later married the proprietor's daughter, Violette Buckingham Selfridge, filed suit for divorce here today.

The frozen food industry is regarded by financial institutions as having passed successfully through the experimental stage and now in the first phases of a long-term growth period, Arthur S. Kleeman, president of the Colonial Trust Co., declared yesterday at a luncheon of the Eastern Frozen Foods Association in the Biltmore Hotel.
SHANGHAI, Jan. 26 (UP) -United States Consul General John M. Cabot challenged Communist Leader Mao Eze-tung today to demonstrate that his regime was not taking orders from Moscow.

Chief Peter Loftus went on trial yesterday on charges of violating the rules of the New York Fire Department in going to a firehouse party on the night of Dec. 16. But at the end of a four-hour hearing all that had been established was that there was a party, that three women entertained, and that whisky and beer were available for more than 100 guests.

Because his classmates, teachers and friends he never knew were determined not to let him down, 14-year-old Vincent Viviano will be discharged tomorrow from the Evangelical Deaconess Hospital in Brooklyn.

BERLIN, Jan. 26 -- The present military government structure is "more than adequate" to deal with the nationalism now resurgent in Western Germany, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, declared today at a press conference.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (UP) -- The Air Force spread its livestock-saving haylift to five Western states today while floods menaced central sections of the nation.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 26 -- Sharply divergent views of the place of freedom of the press and speech in the democratic framework marked the opening in Criminal Court today of the trial of four Baltimore radio stations and one commentator, cited for contempt because of alleged violation of a local code restricting news about crime.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Democratic legislators proposed today the repeal of the Condon-Wadlin Act calling for automatic dismissal of public employes who go on strike. They were immeditely accused by Republican leaders of condoning strikes against state, county and municipal governments.
Hungary is ready to sell manganese ore to the United States, it was learned here yesterday.

GENEVA, Jan. 26 -- Britain's determination to delay the International Refugee Organization's support for the movement of displaced persons to Palestine has not been altered by the British intention to recognize Israel, it was learned today.
The signal success of musicalized Shakespeare, as exemplified by "Kiss Me Kate," written around "The Taming of the Shrew," may very well have set a fashion for future Broadway stage offerings.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Massachusetts industry will lose money and residents of the state will lose their jobs unless remedial legislation, with respect to pricing policies, is adopted by Congress, Roy F. Williams, executive vice president of the Associated Industries of Massachusetts, predicted today.

Coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, were mixed yesterday. Scattered commission house selling in contract "D" was absorbed by producer interests and trade covering. Final prices were 15 to 20 points lower. Contract "S" was steady in light trading.

The unruly "knock" in an automotive engine should be forced to go to work and produce power instead of trouble, a visiting chemist suggested yesterday at the General Motors show in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WARSAW, Jan. 26 -- A Government spokesman declared today that the formation of an Eastern European economic council was one of the most important steps yet taken in the post-war development of the country's resources.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- General selling was on in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today and May wheat and corn sold at a new low since early last November, with December wheat and all deliveries of oats in new seasonal low ground, with cash oats at a new low since August, 1946.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (UP) -- Thousands of landlords in about ten cities debated a plan today to evict tenants and withdraw rental property from the market to protest proposed rent control extension in Congress.
TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 27 (UP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur said today he was determined to remain in Japan until a peace treaty was signed.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned irregular yesterday and closed 5 points higher to 15 points net lower.
OLEAN, N. Y., Jan. 26 (UP) -Election of the Very Rev. Thomas Plassmann, president of St. Bonaventure College, to the Gallery of Living Catholic Authors was announced today.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 26 -- Franz von Papen was liberated by a German denazification court in Nuremberg today. The court ruled that von Papen, who was serving an eight-year sentence at hard labor as a major offender was only a class 2 offender and that the four years he had spent in prison were sufficient punishment.

Attention was concentrated on Fira Benenson's designs at the luncheon in the Pierre Hotel yesterday. These were supplemented by hats from Germaine Vittu, furs from Dragonetti and Cartier jewels which brought them sparkle.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 26 -While the results of Israel's first election consumed most of the national interest here today, there was great interest regarding the Rhodes talks. It was disclosed through the United Nations that the Egyptian and Israeli delegations had signed a formal agreement confirming the Jan. 7 ceasefire pact.

Aubrey S. Eban, Israeli representative to the United Nations, speaking last night at a dinner of the Zionist Organization of America at the Pierre Hotel, asserted that the most crucial task confronting Israel was establishment of normal relations with its Arab neighbors.

Directors of the United States Steel Corporation voted this week to propose to their stockholders a three-for-one split-up of the company's common shares. At the same meeting they voted an extra dividend of $1 on these shares, in addition to the recently "regular" quarterly disbursement of $1.25.

The dangers inherent in the use of a higher dividend rate as a competitive device were stressed yesterday by supervisory officials speaking at the annual mid-winter meeting of the New York State Savings and Loan League. The meeting, attended by about 350 savings and loan association executives from all sections of the state, was held at the Hotel Commodore.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 26 -- Westchester County's new consolidated office of medical examiner-pathologist will begin functioning on Feb. 15 if Governor Dewey signs the enabling legislation, county officials said this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Secretary of State, Dean G. Acheson, declared today that the objective of President Truman's "bold new program" for making American technological skill available for the "improvement and growth of under-developed areas" was "to enable the individual to attain the freedom and dignity and fullness of life which should be the purpose of all government and of all life on this earth."

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein asked the Board of Elections yesterday to bar thirty-six election inspectors from future duty at the polls because they allegedly allowed at least fifty-four fraudulent votes to be cast last Nov. 2.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Jan. 26 (UP) -- Mrs. Eugene Meyer, Washington civic leader and sociologist, said tonight that President Truman's program for compulsory national health insurance "represents a dangerous short-cut to human welfare."

BERLIN, Jan. 26 -- Communist leader Walther Ulbricht admitted today that serious difficulties had beset industrial production in Eastern Germany. He made it clear, nevertheless, that the Soviet zone and its people would be marched resolutely along the path to a Soviet type of state in 1949.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- In one of his first official pronouncements since his appointment, Secretary of State Acheson made clear today that he intended to press to completion as rapidly as possible the North Atlantic Defense Pact with the countries of Western Europe and Canada.

Mel Ott was "king for a day" (or night) yesterday evening when his long time friends and admirers, the baseball writers of the New York Chapter, tossed a dinner and informal party for him at Toots Shor's.

PARIS, Jan. 26 -- Paulette uses flowers in a new way, not to trim but like fabric, to cover various shapes. Red rose petals are flattened over a mushroom cloche, and green leaves face the brim. Violets smother a sailor in lilac sisal. Calottes held on by bandeaux are one mass of pink rose petals or cornflowers accented by two red poppies on top.

The warm weather fashions seen yesterday at luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel all bore the unmistakable signature of their designer, Claire McCardell. Not only did the clothes illustrate Miss McCardell's imaginative ideas and unusual ways of construction, but even the fabrics were woven and dyed to her specifications.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Western European Commanders-in-Chief who are meeting at Fountainbleau this week under the chairmanship of Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery of Britain will have before them for the first time a complete rough draft of an over-all defense plan for the whole of Western Europe.
Gen. Douglas MacArthur assured the American people yesterday that regardless of the outcome of the Chinese civil war, Japan would not yield to communism "or any other concept of enslavement."

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 26 -- Under the leadership of a soft-spoken Marine Corps Colonel, now senior military observer in Jerusalem, twenty-two Arab and Israeli soldiers have taken over the job of protecting the United Nations Conciliation Commission, which has just arrived in the Holy Land.
LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin's handling of the Palestine problem was upheld by the House of Commons tonight by a vote of 283 to 193.

Another draw -- the fourth of the series -- was the result of the eighth and final game of the match between Miguel M. Najdorf of Buenos Aires and Dr. Reuben Fine of New York last night at the Marshall Chess Club.

DETROIT, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Last-place New York gave a skating and shooting lesson to Detroit tonight to ambush the National Hockey League leaders, 5 to 1, before 12,714 fans at Olympia. The Rangers scored in every period.

The Northeastern Retail Lumbermen's Association called yesterday for Federal legislation permitting lumber mills and other building materials suppliers to quote competitive delivered prices, despite differences in deliver costs because of plant location.

In order to effect certain savings and increase its promotional budget, the Millinery Stabilization Commission has abandoned its consumer protection label, it was announced yesterday by Samuel Finkelstein, executive director, following a meeting of the commission's advisory committee in the Astor Hotel.
GENEVA, Jan. 26 -- The International Labor Office announced today the appointment of Channing Dooley, director of the Training Within Industry Foundation, as consultant on manpower problems.

When a mere violinist has become as famous as a boxer or a baseball star he need not be surprised if a flock of rumors and asseverations accompanying his every deed or public appearance. And so, when Jascha Heifetz, after a sabbatical year away from concerts, made his reappearance in recital last night in Carnegie Hall, the gossips were whispering most busily together.

TILBURY, England, Jan. 26 -- A familiar piece of New York's transient Hudson River waterline, the Queen of Bermuda, absent for nearly ten years, will sail from here tomorrow to resume her "honeymoon service" from New York to Bermuda.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Women's Professional Golfers Association tonight announced plans for a series of tournaments across the country along the lines of those of the men's P. G. A.
Directors of Standard Brands, Inc., reduced to quarterly dividend on the common stock with the declaration yesterday of 30 cents a share payable in March 15 to holders of record of Feb. 15.
Declaring that "gardening is not a static art," H. Stuart Ortloff, landscape architect, emphasized yesterday the importance of simple but definite designs for home gardeners.
SHANGHAI, Jan. 26 (UP) -- The United States officially terminated its program of military training in behalf of China today.

Through a stock purchase reported yesterday the Maybrook Gardens, a 260-family garden apartment development in Maywood, N. J., was purchased by a New York investor, who immediately resold the property in two parts.

BERLIN, Jan. 26 -- The vast and intricate system of smuggling, black marketing and crooked manipulation of German currency cannot be completely smashed until the French improve their zonal border guard, reports of United States investigators disclosed today.

A memorial exhibition of work by the famous illustrator, the late Wallace Morgan; an exhibition of paintings by Edna Reindell for the benefit of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service, and new canvases by Albert Pels figure in the week's art openings.
The trouble with Manhattan, Donald Hyde always says, is that there aren't enough dead trees around.

At the memorial service for the late Lord Melchett held in New York Rabbi Stephen Wise in the course of his moving address drew attention to the circumstance that the service should have been held on the day when "his own country is about to recognize the State of Israel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Senator Elbert D. Thomas of Utah, chairman of the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee, reiterated today after a meeting with President Truman the priority schedule for legislation from his committee as follows: 1. Federal aid to education; 2. The National Science Fund; 3. A bill to raise the minimum wage to seventy-five cents an hour; 4. Repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act.

Rabbi Simon G. Kramer of the Hebrew Institute of University Heights, the Bronx, was elected president of the New York Board of Rabbis yesterday at its annual meeting at the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, 99 Central Park West.

Sam Minskoff Sons, New York City builders, yesterday reported their purchase of a site facing Clinton Square, in the heart of the business district of Syracuse, N. Y., for improvement with a two-story store and office building. The land, which was sold by the Sky Realty Company, is vacant and was the site of the old Empire House, a hotel destroyed by fire some years ago.

GENEVA, Jan. 26 -- No drastic changes in the essentially bilateral character of economic relations among the Eastern European countries were foreseen here today as result of the establishment of the Council of Economic Mutual Aid announced from Moscow yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 26 -- The Israeli Government agreed Monday to pass convoys carrying food and medical supplies for the encircled Egyptian garrison at Faluja, together with the civilian population, Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, Acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine, reported to the Security Council today.

An elderly Bronx physician, driving his two grandchildren to school, lost control of his car at 8:25 A. M. yesterday on busy East 161st Street, between Gerard and River Avenues. The car mounted the sidewalk, killed a woman and a girl and critically injured a third girl.

As an icy sleet and rainstorm kept New York in a state of deep-frozen gloom yesterday, 200 of the nation's leading weather forecasters gathered at the American Museum of Natural History to discuss the most recent scientific developments of their art.

The 200,000 commuters who depend on the Hudson Manhattan Railroad got something new to worry about last night, Less than twenty-four hours after the National Mediation Board succeeded in settling a strike threat by 170 engineers, a new threat arose from 200 power plant workers, guards and clerks.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- Wage and hour negotiations between railroads and representatives of sixteen unions of non-operating railroad workers are expected to reach a crisis by Friday.

Although termed by the court a "greedy wrongdoer who was never too sick to reach out his clutching hand for all he could get," Abraham P. Schwartz, real estate operator and self-admitted rent gouger, received a week yesterday in Special Sessions to produce medical testimony proving he was too ill to go to jail.

A hundred business and professional men and civic leaders, many of them present or former residents in the neighborhood, attended last night a dinner to mark the fiftieth anniversary of Haarlem House, 311 East ll6th Street.

NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 26 -- P. James Pellecchia Jr., who resigned from the police court bench July 13 after confessing he embezzled $663,850 from the Columbus Trust Company, was sentenced today to 10 to 15 years in state's prison by County Judge Joseph E. Conlon.

NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 26 -- P. James Pellecchia Jr., who resigned from the police court bench July 13 after confessing he embezzled $663,850 from the Columbus Trust Company, was sentenced today to 10 to 15 years in state's prison by County Judge Joseph E. Conlon.

The National Council of American-Soviet Friendship expressed "amazement" and "shock" yesterday at efforts of the vestry of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Clinton and Montague Streets, Brooklyn, to terminate the pastorate of the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, rector of the church for forty-four years.

MOSCOW, Jan. 26 -- "Court of Honor," a movie that attacks United States cultural "spies" and Soviet scientists who believe that their knowledge belongs to the world, has become the rage of Moscow only twenty-four hours after its opening.

The letters received in this corner as a result of a recent column on the current proposal to establish "fly fishing only" stretches on some New York trout streams have been interesting, varied, and in some instances quite heated.

PARIS, Jan. 26 -- Victor Kravchenko's case in the libel suits he has brought against the Communist weekly Lettres Francaises and one of its contributors was much strengthened here today when defense witnesses contradicted themselves on one of the Communists' main points.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UP) -- Following is the text of extemporaneous remarks today by Secretary of State Dean G. Acheson at his first press conference, relating to President Truman's world cooperative plan:

An empire of apartment holdings, stretching from Brooklyn to Mount Vernon and including choice Manhattan residences, was disclosed yesterday to be controlled by a family whose head was alleged, in papers on file in Federal Court, to have milked the properties at the expense of bankers, tradesmen and mortgage holders.

In twenty years the airlines have returned to the taxpayer the early Government aid that it took the railroads a century to repay in their case, Carlton Putnam, chairman of the board of Chicago Southern Air Lines, said here yesterday.

Sleet, snow and freezing rain combined yesterday to make traffic conditions hazardous over a wide area of the Eastern seaboard. The taste of winter in an otherwise extremely springlike January was short-lived, however.

A resolution approving the recommendation of its board for national promotion of men's clothing was adopted yesterday by the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers at the conclusion of its convention at the New Yorker Hotel.

The Roseland Ballroom, the dance hall on Broadway at Fifty-first Street -- no liquor (only beer), no taxi girls (only "a few hostesses") and no trouble with the police -- is to celebrate its thirtieth anniversary tonight.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- A bill to cut down the high interest rates charged in financing automobiles and other commodities under conditional sales contracts was introduced in the Legislature today by Senator J. Raymond McGovern, Republican, of Westchester.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Three Pennsylvania lawmakers proposed today to parlay legalized pari-mutuel betting ino a $500,000,000 war veterans' bonus.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Inland Steel Company reported today net income of $38,606,899, equal to $7.88 a capital share, in the year ended on Dec. 31, 1948. This compared with a net income of $29,888,558, equal to $6.10 a share, in the 1947 year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Congress was asked today to take the reciprocal trade issue out of politics on grounds that "only partisan legislation" was possible in the present atmosphere.

BOSTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Toronto ruined Goalie Jack Gelineau's professional debut by sniping at him for a 3-1 victory over the Bruins in a National Hockey League game tonight before 12,865 fans at the Boston Garden.
The Chase National Bank has shifted several of its officers at the top level, it was announced yesterday by Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman. The action was disclosed following a meeting of the board.

The Arabian American Oil Company announced yesterday the election of Fred A. Davies as executive vice president. Since 1947, he has been vice president in charge of production and exploration. Mr. Davies also was made a vice president of Trans-Arabian Pipe Line Company, an affiliate of Arabian American.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that two companies had filed registration statements with it covering $2,150,000 of bonds and 204,000 shares of common stock.

The newly decreed Air Force blues look very snappy as Sgt. Edward T. Ancus modeled them in an Air Force publicity picture released for publication yesterday, but we are sorry to see them adopted as official Air Force garb. As a story in this newspaper pointed out, the new Air Force uniform is unlike that of the Army or Navy in color.

The first order of business now before the Veterans Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives, with possible action foreshadowed for today, is a proposal to pay a pension of $60 a month for the rest of his life to every veteran of either World War upon his reaching the age of 60.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 26 (UP) -Pitcher Bob Feller of the Indians became a holdout today for the first time in his major league baseball career and he was joined by three team-mates who thought they, too, should have bigger rewards for winning the world title.

Crosse Blackwell, food company, of Baltimore, to Erwin, Wasey Co., New York, for advertising of its kippered herring and herring in tomato sauce, Keiller's Dundee Marmalade, cake and shortbread. Julian Snyder is account executive. Other product accounts are not affected.

NANKING, Jan. 26 -- Acting President Li Tsung-jen's Government, which is fast taking the form of an impotent receivership for the Nanking-Shanghai area, urged the Communists again tonight to name their delegates and to fix a place for immediate peace negotiations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- A strong plea for termination of the Government's chartering of ships to private operators was made here today by Waverly B. Garner, executive vice president of the Waterman Steamship Corporation and its subsidiary, Pan Atlantic Steamship Corporation.
Sales and earnings of the J. I. Case Company in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, last, set new high records, according to the annual report to be released today.

Billy Graham, East Side welterweight, defeated Fitzie Pruden of St. Catherine, Ont., in a ten-round bout at the Manhattan Center last night. The feature of the card presented by the Tournament of Champions drew a crowd of 2,097 fans and a gate of $4,479.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 26 -- The case of Columbia University versus the United States is getting slightly monotonous. First it was General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower who was wanted for President in both places. And now it is Dr. Philip C. Jessup, the tall, scholarly Columbia Professor of International Law, who is about to abandon the strenuous glories of the United Nations Security Council for the tranquil satisfactions of Morningside Heights.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- George Gibson, one of the two high officials denounced by the Lynskey tribunal's report yesterday, resigned his post as chairman of the Northwest Electricity Board today. This put an end to the long career of one of the most prominent figures in the Labor party and in the British trade union movement.

The five-story apartment house on a lot 25 by 102 feet at 517 East Eighty-fifth Street, near Carl Schurz Park, has been sold by Florence Stern Alexander to an investing client of Hardy, Brauneis Naumann, Inc., brokers, for cash over a first mortgage of $12,000 at 5 per cent which was extended for three years.

In a dispatch printed in THE TIMES of Jan. 10 from The Hague, Netherlands, your correspondent, David Anderson, speaks of "intervention on the part of the Vatican" in Netherlands negotiations with the Javanese Republicans. He also refers to reported "suggestions" from the Vatican indicating that the Holy See considers negotiations between the Netherlands and the Javanese Republic undesirable.

There are so many demands on the United States Government for so many millions of dollars for so many worthy uses that a line must be drawn somewhere. The Treasury is not bottomless. But surely there can be few pleas more worthy than that of a group of leading educators to the State Department for funds to permit the continuing study here of several thousand students from foreign lands.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Administration put forward today its proposals for spurring the construction of low-rental housing by private enterprise.

GENEVA, Jan. 27 -- To save Europe, all the brains and administrative ability available must be mobilized to prevent President Truman's idea of a world program of the economic development of backward areas from being smothered in ill-informed enthusiasm, in the considered opinion of United States and European economic experts.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 27 -- While Arab and Israeli guards looked on, members of the newly arrived United Nations Conciliation Commission inspected the former Government House today to determine if it would be suitable for their purposes. They will not start deliberations until the arrival of the United States member, Mark F. Ethridge, who is due in about ten days.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Ray Morrison, Temple's head-foot- ball coach for the last nine years, resigned today in a move that caught university athletic officials by surprise.' "We had no-inkling Morrison would resign," said a university spokesman.

The cost of operating New York's public school system during 1947-48 reached the unprecedented amount of $228,119,762, an increase over the previous year of $18,368,349, it was disclosed yesterday in the Board of Education's thirty-eighth annual financial and statistical report.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 27 AP) -- S. D. Sidell's stretch-running Allie's Pal staged a rousing finish to eke out a head triumph in today's Vanity Purse for fillies and mares at Hialeah.

PARIS, Jan. 27 -- A suggestion that Charles de Gaulle join forces with former Premiers Edouard Herriot and Leon Blum to form a national unity government was rejected today by one of the ablest spokesmen for M. de Gaulle, Albert Ollivier, editor of the movement's principal organ, Rassemblement.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The executive committee of the National Catholic Resettlement Council urged legislative and administrative measures today to speed up admission of displaced persons.
Cotton futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday steady, unchanged to 10 points higher.
ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Senator Thomas C. Desmond, Republican, of Newburgh, introduced four bills today to ban billboards from the parkways of the state, including the New York-to-Buffalo throughway.

The new market research division of the National Better Business Bureau, which is now concentrating its efforts on combating deceptive use of survey techniques in door-to-door selling, will begin soon to shift its major emphasis to improving use of research material in advertising, it was learned yesterday.

The large garage building at 500-510 Park Place, Brooklyn, has been purchased by the Larbar Corporation from the S. L. K. Realty Company. Abraham Levine was attorney for the buyer and Furst, Schwartz, Schwager Landau acted for the seller.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Uncertainty and suspicion about Governor Dewey's future political ambitions are responsible in large measure for the difficulties that Republican leaders are encountering in selecting a successor to Glen R. Bedenkapp of Niagara County as state chairman, it appeared today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Congress provided $500,000 today that may be used immediately for relief of storm-stricken western states, while the Senate passed a bill to provide an additional $3,000,000. Meanwhile President Truman was preparing to ask Congress to approve a permanent disaster relief measure with a fund of about $10,000,000 to deal with recurring national catastrophes.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 27 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today that the retail price index had continued its descent for the third straight month. The drop from mid-November to mid-December was 0.5 per cent, the bureau said.
To the many thousands of men and women who are never reached by organized religion, the Salvation Army brings the only religious teaching they will ever know.

LONDON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The radio of Greece's Communist-led guerrillas broadcast peace proposals today. It said the self-styled government of Markos Vafiades was ready to send representatives to Athens immediately if the Greek Government accepted the proposals.
A 'variety of new art exhibitions this. week include a large, rather :conservative annual exhibition by National Arts Club members and guests and one-man shows by an abstract and a romantic painter.

A group said to represent two-thirds of the voting members of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Clinton and Montague Streets, Brooklyn, challenged yesterday the vestry's request to terminate the pastorate of Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, 74-year-old rector.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- During the week ended Jan. 26 member bank reserve balances decreased $98,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Republican leaders introduced for second passage in the Legislature today two proposed constitutional amendments designed to give some relief to cities by easing the limitations on their powers to levy real estate taxes and issue bonds.

Net earnings of the Duplan Corporation amounted to $2,282,153 for the six months to Nov. 30, 1948, a rise of $725,518 over the comparable period in 1947, E. C. Geier, president, reported yesterday. Sales for the respective periods amounted to $25,157,516 and $18,871,826.

THE athletes are not the only persons to have spent long hours of practice for the Millrose Games which will open the big-time track season in our village tomorrow night. The horn-tooters in the band have had to get in some extra licks themselves because they have had to learn the national anthems of Sweden, Belgium and the Netherlands in order to give the proper welcome to the largest foreign contingent ever to compete indoors.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 27 -- Under the terms of the occupation statute, the details of which the Western powers are discussing in London, the projected Western German Government will receive authority to pass legislation in the fields of its competence without prior approval of the three military governments.

Ike Williams, holder of the world lightweight championship, will box Kid Gavilan of Cuba in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. Although Williams' championship will not be involved against his welterweight rival, the fight has aroused considerable interest and promoter Harry Markson is confident that it will attract a crowd of 13,000 fans and a gate of $45,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, told Congress today that war, although not "imminent," was "at least a possibility," and he asked for enactment of a bill authorizing a peacetime army of 837,000 officers and men.

From Nov. 1, 1944, until Jan. 15, the Forty-eighth Street wasn't in the market for new shows simply because it had a paying tenant of marathon endurance. During that span the house was occupied by "Harvey," of blessed memory. Tonight the Forty-eighth Street, will reopen for business with "Forward the Heart," the premiere of which was postponed from Monday.

Comments on the proposal to restrict short stretches of trout streams to "fly fishing only" continue to arrive. Some of them should furnish excellent material for debate during the long evenings between now and opening day.
The "coming of age of bus transportation'' was signalized yesterday at a ground-breaking ceremony for the Port Authority's union bus terminal and at a luncheon that followed at the Statler Hotel.

This week wholesale egg prices have been going "down, down, down," a market news reporter for the trade said yesterday. They have not yet arrived at a comparable level at retail, he added, despite another decrease of 2 cents a dozen in large Grade A white eggs, the fourth to take place recently.
All witnesses called by lawyers for the eleven Communist leaders, Federal Judge Harold R. Medina held yesterday, have testified there has been no discrimination in the selection of juries.

Alarmed over the threatened collapse of the student exchange program, prominent educators, State Department officials and members of Congress are developing plans to permit the 5,000 students who are stranded in this country to remain here, it became known yesterday.

New York harbor must receive appropriations from Congress for necessary dredging and improvements if it is to maintain its position as the nation's leading port, a forum convened by the City's Department of Commerce agreed last night.

Today's events: "La Boheme," (student performance), 1:30 o'clock, and "Rigoletto," 8:30, Metropolitan Opera; Philharmonic-Symphony, Leopold Stokowski, conductor; Byron Janis, piano, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Victor Scholer, piano, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Joseph Schuster. 'cello, Town Hall, 8:30; Dorothy Berliner Commins, piano, Times Hall, 8:30.

The approval by the State Housing Division of a $2,000,000 housing project for the low-income groups of the Manhasset and Port Washington areas of Long Island points to the realization by critics of our large cities that the problems of housing are not limited to the confines of the big cities, but extend to the neighborhoods where the more fortunate have been able to build.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The House Republican minority approved today a complete reorganization of its policy-making machinery. It also voted to set up its own committee on public information to put the record it makes in the Eighty-first Congress before the people for the 1950 campaigns and to keep it there.

With four days remaining in its current campaign for financial support, the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York still is $3,400,000 short of its goal of $16,500,000, it was announced yesterday.
Robert S. Stantial has been a member of the city's school system for more than fifty years, yet, as he has often remarked, "If I had a thousand lives to live I would spend them all teaching."
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Jan. 27 -- Gaston Pilon says he is the last of the once proud guild of hand gold-toolers of book covers. He makes the statement matter-of-factly, wistfully, but not boastfully.

While landlords in this city generally are unfavorable to emulating the mass eviction, threats made by landlords in Tulsa and other western cities, both city and Federal rent authorities here are prepared to oppose any such action legally, it was emphasized yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- A recently-developed treatment for severe frostbite was credited today with savings Sumner Welles from possible loss of his hands and feet.

When 11-year-old Anna Guadagnino grows up she should have no trouble finding a husband. For she has red hair, brown eyes, a sweet smile and knows how to cook a tasty, attractive-and nutritious meal for 20 cents a person.

ROME, Jan. 27 -- At the end of their national congress in Milan early this morning the Right-Wing Socialists voted to continue their collaboration with Premier Alcide de Gasperi's Coalition Government. The opposition to this course was, however, unexpectedly strong, and none of the three motions on which a final vote was taken succeeded in obtaining an absolute majority.

WALTHAM, Mass., Jan. 27 -- (AP) -- President Truman will meet next Wednesday with the mayors of three watch-making cities to discuss problems of the industry, Rep. Harold D. Donohue, Democrat, Massachusetts, reported today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 27 -- The United Nations Security Council gave the Netherlands another twenty-four hours today to decide whether she would accept the four-power plan for settling the Indonesian dispute.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Fred M. Saigh Jr. became president and majority stockholder of the St. Louis Cardinals today by buying out his partner, former Postmaster General Robert E. Hannegan.

The new Argentine motor vessel Rio Primero of the Argentine State Line will leave here tomorrow for Buenos Aires on the return leg of her maiden voyage, it was announced yesterday by Boyd, Weir Sewell, Inc., agents.

Dr. Robert E. Cushman, Professor of Government at Cornell University, outlined last night before distinguished gathering of more than a thousand physicists and physics teachers a "framework of principles" by which, he said, "we can protect our national security and at the same time preserve the civil liberties upon which American democracy is grounded."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Amalgamated Clothing Workers, CIO, pursuing its campaign to organize department store and retail clothing chain workers, announced today that regional offices had been set up in New York, Boston, Philadelphia, Rochester and Chicago, and that they would be extended to other cities.
The Hercules Powder Company last year had the second largest sales and earnings in its history, according to the annual report of Charles A. Higgins, president, sent yesterday to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Alexander S. Panyushkin, the Soviet Ambassador, charged in the Far Eastern Commission today that the United States had "evaded" decisions of the commission through issuing its interim directive to Gen. Douglas MacArthur on Dec. 10, 1948, for stabilizing the economy of Japan.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Sammy Snead's putter behaved on the wet greens here today as the West Virginia slammer took a one-stroke lead in the $10,000 Phoenix open golf tournament with a three-under-par 68.

A special program of instruction by radio, designed to enrich the education of physically handicapped children who are unable to attend regular classes in the city's public schools, will be tried by the Board of Education during the new semester beginning next Wednesday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 (AP) -- A city official disclosed today that there's a strong possibility the Army-Navy football game will be played somewhere other than Philadelphia at least once during the next three years.

The radar operator aboard the Coast Guard icebreaker Eastwind when she was rammed Jan. 19 by the oil tanker Gulfstream never doubted for a moment that there was a vessel off the icebreaker's starboard bow.

RHODES, Jan. 27 -- The Rhodes armistice talks will fail within the next few days unless unexpected developments occur, well-informed sources asserted tonight. Both the Egyptian and Israeli delegations predict an early end to the talks one way or another following visits to their representatives to Cairo and Tel Aviv.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- "Point Four," that passage in the President's inaugural address in which he spoke of "guarantees" to "foster" private investment of capital "in underdeveloped areas of the earth" with commensurate "guarantees in the interest" of the inhabitants of those areas, has now been established as an idea which is not yet a plan.

Air transportation may have developed so fast that it already exceeds the physical capabilities of both pilots and passengers, a long list of speakers told the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences at the Astor Hotel yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- A bitter debate in the Senate today raised the curtain on what promises to be a long and hectic struggle over a labor relations statute.

Net profit of the International Harvester Company increased last year to a new high record of $55,679,337 from $48,469,266 earned in 1947, but the profit margin of 4.7 cents on each dollar of sales declined from 5.5 cents, John L. McCaffrey, president, informed shareholders yesterday in the annual report covering the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31.

ROME, Jan. 27 -- Tyrone Power, screen actor, and Linda Christian, film starlet, were married this morning in what all observers agree was the most magnificent wedding seen in Rome during recent years. Though Power had insisted that the ceremony was not to be "turned into a three-ring circus," a severe strain was put on arrangements by the exuberance of photographers and admirers of the film stars.

After an easy opening, cottonseed oil futures advanced on the New York Produce Exchange yesterday. The market closed at the high for the day with gains of 43 to 53 points. The market developed an oversold condition and rallied sharply under trade buying.

Officials of the Retail Clerks International Association, AFL, charged yesterday that four New York department stores signed contracts with "known Communist unions" rather than increase the wages of their workers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- American corporations public reported cash dividend payments of $6,074,200,000 in 1948, 14 per cent more than the $5,338,300,000 paid out in 1947, the Department of Commerce disclosed today.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2 -- Irene's spring collection favors fancifull hemlines with scallops a featured treatment. Fashions are definitely in the custom genre with accent on soft manipulation of fabrics and silhouettes. This feminine quality invades Irene's famous tailored suits through retaining the clean-cut look.

Antique dealers looking for new ways to attract buyers have opened a permanent bazaar called the Antique Center, 936 Third Avenue, near Fifty-sixth Street, where seventeen exhibitionlike booths occupy a former paint store. Visitors can thus browse along a central aisle and see in a few minutes what would take much longer if separate stores were visited.

Sam Carr, former Communist party organizer in Canada who had been sought for three years as one of the key figures in the Soviet espionage ring uncovered in that country in 1945, was arrested here yesterday morning by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

TOKYO, Jan. 27 -- Economic changes are virtually certain to result from Premier Shigesu Yoshida's sweeping election victory, it was indicated today. There will be tax revisions intended to encourage the flow of domestic as well as foreign capital into productive enterprise. There will be an attempt to stabilize both wages and prices. There will be an adjustment of the rates charged by Government-owned utilities, and there will be general administrative reforms.
The Metropolitan Opera Association yesterday revealed that its total income for the 1947-48 season was $3,024,688.78 and its deficit amounted to $233,357.08.
There is now being enacted in Congress the sickening spectacle of certain members deliberately attempting to thwart the will of the people as regards labor legislation.
SYRACUSE, Jan. 27 -- The Federal tax on tickets for high school games came under fire today from the New York State Association for Health, Physical Education and Recreation.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The first performance of Ernest Bloch's new piano concerto will be a feature of the third International Festival of Music and Drama at Edinburgh from Aug. 21 to Sept. 11. Bloch will conduct the British Broadcasting Corporation's Scottish Orchestra, and the soloist will be Corinne Lacomble, a specialist in Bloch's music.

Although rumors have circulated since last summer that some action would be taken to bar the sand wedge, John D. Ames, chairman of the United States Golf Association's implements and ball committee, denied yesterday that the organization contemplated any action of the kind.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- The American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons went on record at its annual meeting today in support of the American Medical Association's program to educate the public on medical-care insurance.

OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 27 -- Representative Hugh Scott Jr. of Pennsylvania retained his post as Republican National Chairman by a four-vote margin today at the climax of a furious factional row that reflected dissatisfaction with the 1948 defeat and prospective Presidential rivalries in 1952.
The pent-up enthusiasm of Eastern skiers will be released on a tremendous scale this week-end as the best snow conditions of this unusual winter were reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- Profits earned by fourteen leading meat packing companies in 1948 averaged less than three-quarter cent on each dollar's worth of sales, the American Meat Institute reported today. The same companies made about one and one-half cents on each dollar in 1947.

New uses for synthetic detergents not only promise to increase sales to more than one billion pounds a year by 1952, but this figure now appears conservative, according to soap and chemical experts yesterday. They addressed more than 350 members during the second day program of the twenty-second annual convention of the American Soap and Glycerine Producers, Inc., at the Commodore Hotel.

Sid Luckman has first call on the job of coaching the transplanted Boston Yanks of the National Football League, according to reports current in local gridiron circles yesterday. The veteran quarterback of the .Chicago Bears has the high regard of Ted Collins, owner of the eleven that operated in the Hub last season, but which will play its home games at the Polo Grounds in 1949.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- President Truman sent a special message to Congress today, asking a $16,000,000 contribution by this country to the United Nations to assist in the relief of Palestinian refugees.

Export shippers, assured that arbitrary compulsion will not be part of the steamship company-sponsored program for improving export packaging, are now ready to give the undertaking strong support, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Truman Administration asked Congress today to raise the minimum wage from 40 to 75 cents an hour under the Fair Labor Standards Act and to bring new millions of workers under its protection.

Competition among textile finishers for business in the forthcoming period of lower fabric output will bring excessive pressure for lower finishing prices, according to G. D. Harrison, president of the National Association of Finishers of Textile Fabrics.

The "NBC University Theatre" commences its seventeen - week spring semester on Feb. 6 with Swift's "Gulliver's Travels," with Henry Hull in the title role. During the intermission, Mark van Doren will discuss the famous novel, newly adapted for radio by Frank and Virginia Wells.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Declaring the prevalence of cerebral palsy to be "a matter of grave concern to the peoples of our state," Governor Dewey proclaimed today the week of Feb. 6 to 12 as Cerebral Palsy Week.

The appointment of harlesi Stern Ascher as professbr a.nd I chairman of the Department of Political Science at' Brooklyn Col-i lege was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of the college. Professor Ascher has just returned from his position as special assistant to the Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, 'which he entered in 1947.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission said today that it proposed to deny authority for Press Wireless, Inc., to handle official Government communications on a regular basis.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The national military establishment named a committee of eight industrialists today to review a Munitions Board selection of plants held in the national industrial reserve for continued retention or disposal for commercial use.

January home furnishings dollar volume in local department store and home furnishings outlets is running approximately 5 per cent ahead of the comparable month last year, retailers reported yesterday. The situation is counter to most year-end predictions of steadily declining sales for the entire first quarter.

Considerable ceremony surrounded the start of excavation yesterday for the Port Authority's $20,000,000 Union Bus Terminal, west of Eighth Avenue in midtown Manhattan. The gathering of many public officials and leaders in the transportation industry included Governor Dewey, a representative of Governor Driscoll of New Jersey, Mayor O'Dwyer and others high in his administration.

Announcement that Eugene R. Black is returning to the Chase National Bank as senior vice president has uncorked much conjecture as to who will take his place as one of the major full time executives of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- A Congressional "watchdog" committee suggested today that future Marshall Plan aid be on an outright grant basis and it censured the Economic Cooperation Administration for having forced nearly $1,000,000,000 of repayable loans to "impecunious" nations of Western Europe.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities reported to Congress today that its last two years of investigations had established "beyond a doubt" that espionage and other treasonable operations against this country were the primary purpose of the Communist party of the United States.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- Short covering was largely responsible today for a strong close in grain markets on the Board of Trade after an early break. Final sales were about the top with wheat showing gains of 3/4 to 1 5/8 cents a bushel; corn, 3/8 to 1 1/8 cents; oats, 5/8 to 1 1/4 cents, and soy beans, 1 1/4 to 2 cents.

March 15 isn't as far away as it was last July and they will. . . want money, those people. They will want cash on the line. In following the ritual of operative procedure 1040, they will discount the theory that blood cannot be drawn from a stone.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- A routine Thursday meeting gave an opportunity to the British Cabinet today to assess the damage done to the Labor Government's reputation last night by the House of Commons vote on Palestine.

Governor Dewey and leading builders from all parts of the state made it clear yesterday that they were out to break down the old barriers of exclusion and covenants preventing the average man in many neighborhoods from owning or building a little home.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- President Truman declared today that he believed that Western landlords resisting the extension of rent control by attempting mass evictions would not succeed.

Some of the many variations in color and texture possible in decorative fabrics handwoven to suit specific interiors were shown yesterday by Creativce Looms, Inc., at the opening of its new showroom and workshop, 210 East Fifty-first Street.

The Board of Estimate unanimously recommended yesterday that the City Council approve legislation adding three additional positions of associate justice of the Court of Special Sessions. The salary of an associate justice is $15,000 a year.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday that he would ask the Board of Education's committee on buildings and sites to make more schools available for Girl Scout activities. He spoke at the annual luncheon meeting of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York in the Statler Hotel.

The one feature worth talking about of the concert that Leopold Stokowski conducted with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall was the Near York premiere of Vaughan-Williams' Sixth symphony. Speaking of this symphony as such, and not of its performance, it may be designated as one of the most personal and profoundly felt orchestral scores that has appeared in decades.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat, of Georgia, introduced today a bill for a $4,500,000,000 program to encourage and assist the migration of Negroes from the South and of whites to that region.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Argentine Central Bank of the Republic reported today a decline of gold and reserves of about 34 per cent and an increase of around 62 per cent in money in circulation during 1948.
The Corning Glass Works disclosed yesterday it had begun mechanized production of fifteen and sixteen inch glass bulbs for television tubes and would cut prices 24 per cent.

The General Motors show at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel closed last night. The attendance for afternoon and evening was 40,000. C. E. Wilson, president of the General Motors Corporation, emphasized his appreciation of the public response and said:

Bishop Charles K. Gilbert of the Protestant Episcopal diocese of New York joined with other church and civic leaders yesterday in addressing a luncheon at the Biltmore Hotel that marked the opening of the campaign of the Protestant Council of the City of New York for $255,350.

Details of the designs of the "cosmostron," which, when completed, will be the most powerful stom-smashing machine in the world, and many hitherto secret details of a new $20,000,000 atomic furnace (pile), both now under construction at the Brookhaven National Laboratory of the Atomic Energy Commission at Upton, L. I., were revealed for the first time yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Physical Society at Columbia University.

The creations of two of Saks Fifth Avenue's leading designers were featured in a spring fur collection presented in the store's fifth floor fur salon, yesterday afternoon. They were Sophie, long known for her custom designs in the Salon Modern, and Julio Laffitte who has been associated for some time with the fur salon.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Accent on youthful curves is the keynote of Hardy Amies' collection. The main interest is again on skirts -- narrow for town to enhance a classic effect, full for cocktail and summer dresses and a combination of narrow and full achieved by discreet flares and pleated panels to one side or at back.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 27 -- The gap between the needs in the field of social work and the available personnel is greater than in medicine, teaching, nursing or dentistry, according to Dr. Ernest V. Hollis, director of a comprehensive country-wide study of social work education.

Two current developments in connection with the economic and political aspects of our foreign policy render it crucial that we should avoid a serious source of confusion in that policy. These two developments are the all-but-consummated Communist conquest of China and the inaugural statement by President Truman with reference to economic aid to backward countries.
RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Rebel warfare increased on widening fronts today. Rangoon was isolated by the cutting of the railway to Mandalay.
