For the third consecutive year, the Continental Baking Company has expanded its sales to a new high record, with the total for 1948 reaching $161,238,774 compared with $150,284,571 in 1947, the annual report to stockholders disclosed yesterday.

The Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital for Animals, 350 Lafayette Street, cared for 21,728 sick and homeless animals last year, almost 1,000 more cases than in 1947, Mrs. Edward M. Weld, president of the New York Women's League for Animals, which operates the hospital, reported yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The feature of the stock market here today was a revival of interest in shares of British-owned Argentine utility companies on the belief that changes in the Argentine Government might improve prospects for British holders. Gains up to 1 point were made.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Department store sales in the week ended Jan. 22 were 2 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:

Increased building costs make it impracticable for Beekman-Downtown Hospital to proceed with construction of its new hospital at William, Beekman and Spruce Streets at this time, Howard S. Cullman, the president, reported at the annual meeting yesterday.

BOMBAY, India, Jan. 27 -- With memories still fresh of the Bengal famine of 1943 in which 1,000,000 deaths were recorded, the governments of the territorial state units of Cutch, Saurashtra, Baroda and Bombay have marshaled all their resources against the threat of a similar calamity.

LITERARY fantasy is usually a means rather than an end, a means through which novelists seek to achieve such diverse ends as romance, satire, allegory and even political and economic reform. In "If I Were You,"* by Julian Green, it is the artificial framework which supports some obscure and mildly suggestive speculation about the mystery of human personality, the nature of the self and the will of God.

ROME, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Tyrone Power and Linda Christian were wed in a double-ring ceremony today while thousands of screaming Italian bobby-soxers surged riotously across police lines outside the church of Santa Francesca Romana.

Jerome Rappaport, pianist, made his debut in 1920 at the age of 8, and has plenty of technique to show for his long career This he displayed to advantage in his recital at Town Hall last night, where his audience received him warmly.

As large food chains began listing 22 cent as next Tuesday's price for a quart container of homogenized milk, John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, intensified his anti-milk trust campaign yesterday by demanding that the price be cut to 19 cents.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- A bill to establish permanent reserves of wheat, corn and cotton was introduced in the Senate today by Sen. Elmer Thomas, Democrat, of Oklahoma.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Jan. 22, 1949, totaled 709,585 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 23,687 cars, or 3.2 per cent fewer than for the preceding week; 61,554 cars, or 8 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week of last year, and 112,343 cars, or 13.7 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week of 1947.

After repayment of $3,000,000 of Government capital since the end of 1948, capital of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York now is $33,888,473, Nugent Fallon, president, reported yesterday. In submitting his report to the annual meeting of stockholders in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Mr. Fallon put resources at $92,456,330 and reserves and undivided profits at $3,373,273.

A program of "socialized law" by which government funds for the legal aid of the needy would be administered by private agencies was advocated yesterday before the Banking Law Section of the New York State Bar Association at the association's seventy-second annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The Foreign Ministers of the five Brussels pact powers are understood to have taken a step forward today toward the great political concept of Western European unity when they met here in two long sessions. Before the conference ends tomorrow afternoon there is every expectation also that a draft agreement for a North Atlantic defense pact will have been sanctioned by all members.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company's earnings in 1948 were the highest in twenty-three years, Robert V. White, president of the company, announced today.
Led by two clergymen, more than 100 persons appeared yesterday at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest to donate blood for a 20-year-old parishioner who is a victim of hemophilia.

An appraisal of American civilization in this century, as revealed in its newspapers, magazines, comic strips and its advertising, is planned for fall publication by the Vanguard Press. It is a work by Prof. Herbert E. McLuhan of the University of Toronto, tentatively titled "Guide to Chaos."

TORONTO, Jan. 27 (Canadian Press) -- The agreements under which Brazilian Traction, Light and Power Co., Ltd., receives a $75,000,000 loan from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, were signed today in Washington.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Education's major challenge is to develop human power equal to the technical power given by modern science, Dr. Alvin C. Eurich, president of the State University of New York, said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Joe Fulks took over the Basketball Association of America scoring lead by registering 39 points tonight as the Philadelphia Warriors defeated the New York Knickerbockers, 102 -- 96, before 3,841 spectators.

Arrival of 32,155 slabs of blister copper from Yugoslavia, consigned to Philipps Brothers, Inc., 70 Pine Street, was reported here yesterday. The shipment, understood to represent a step in Premier Marshal Tito's program of expanded trade with he West, came in on the Turkish ship Couh, docking at Erie Basin Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (UP) -- Bad weather sharply curtailed the Air Force haylift on the Western ranges today and a new blizzard struck in part of the area. Fresh snow drifted down on Idaho, Utah, Colorado, Nevada and Wyoming.

TOKYO, Jan. 27 -- Japanese trade unions and employers were warned sharply today by spokesmen for Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters to settle their differences peacefully and increase the national production or face disciplinary measures and possible loss of foreign assistance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- American corporations had a net income of $2,900,000,000 after taxes in the third quarter of 1948, compared with $2,845,000,000 in the second quarter, according to a survey made public jointly today by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Trade Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The two major veterans' organizations urged Congress today to enact legislation that eventually would grant pensions, to all of the 18,000,000 war veterans in the United States.

Irene Dunne will be the guest of honor at the luncheon meeting of the Associated Motion Picture Advertisers to be held today at the Picadilly Hotel. Miss Dunne will receive a plaque from the Protestant Motion Picture Council on behalf of RKO's "I Remember Mama," in which she had the title role.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Jan. 27 (AP) -Snow-covered Mount Marcy yielded no trace today of a 22-year-old skier who disappeared at the summit in a blinding snowstorm yesterday.

Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota warned last night that reactionary influences in Congress were seeking to defeat progressive legislation called for by the Democratic national platform and for which the voters of the United States gave a mandate last November by the election of President Truman.

American policy in and toward China was criticized last night from two different points of view, in speeches before the international affairs forum of the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street.

DUBLIN, Jan. 27 -- For the first time since the Irish interparty government was elected last February, Premier John E. Costello and opposition leader Eamon de Valera sat at the same table at an all-party conference in the Mansion House here today to determine what help the south could give to nationalist anti-partition candidates in Northern Ireland's general elections Feb. 10.

At a cost of $100 each, 103 thoroughbreds have been named for this year's eighty-first edition of the Belmont Stakes, it was announced yesterday. First run in 1867 at Jerome Park in the Bronx the Belmont is the oldest of the "triple crown" stakes for 3-year-olds, antedating the Preakness by six years and the Kentucky Derby by eight.
CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- Developments today in the Midwestern landlords' movement to evict tenants in protest against rent control consisted largely of efforts to line-up support for wider action.

Tingfu F. Tsiang, Ambassador Plenipotentiary and Permanent Representative of China to the United Nations, claimed diplomatic immunity yesterday in a separation suit brought by his wife, Mme. Nyok Zoe Dong Tsiang, in Supreme Court, and asked Justice Ferdinand Pecora to dismiss the summons and complaint served on him.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The conference of the three Western powers on the German occupation statute has now agreed to the revised draft for all but two clauses, and sentiment tonight is optimistic for completion of the statute next week.
The State Labor Relations Board had to decide yesterday whether a Yonkers apartment superintendent lost his job because he hated cats or because his employer hated unions.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Miss Peggy Kirk of Findlay, Ohio, medalist in the seventeenth annual Helen Lee Doherty golf tournament with a three-under-par 73, continued her blistering pace today as she led the way into the quarter-finals.
Joe Page yesterday became the twelfth Yankee to sign his 1949 contract.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Three paint companies and three individuals pleaded no contest today to charges of conspiring to violate the Anti-Trust Laws in fixing prices of water-thinned and water-mixed paints and Were fined a total of $15,500 by United States District Judge George H. Moore.
The New York Star, successor to PM, is ceasing publication with today's issue, because of financial difficulties.

BERLIN, Jan. 27 -- Germans received notice today that the strategy of Soviet planning still envisaged the capture of the whole of the country for communism, even though the tactic of the moment called for concentration of the Communist effort to consolidate the Eastern zone.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Nations receiving aid under the foreign assistance program are applying increasing pressure on the United States Government in the dispute over sharing of aid cargoes with this country's merchant marine, it became known here today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27 -- Highway safety pays off in dollars to the automotive industry, speakers asserted today at final sessions of the convention of the National Automobile Dealers Association.

When a ship runs aground the first essential is to get the survivors ashore, the second is to find out whether or not the ship can be floated and the third is to ascertain who was to blame. The Republican National Committee, meeting in Omaha, has been facing all three of these problems.

Chicago, Ill., Sanitary District borrowed yesterday $6,525,000 on corporate purpose tax anticipation warrants at an interest cost of 1 7/8 per cent less a premium of $3,849.75. The bid was submitted by a banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

The Public Service Commission announced here yesterday that it has ordered a general investigation of the service provided by the Surface Transportation Company, bus operating company that runs about fifty routes in the Bronx, as well as the Broadway and Third Avenue routes in Manhattan.
Two badly infected teeth, scheduled for extraction next Monday, may prevent Sweden's Ingvar Bengtsson from showing at his best in the Wanamaker Mile at tomorrow night's Millrose Games.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 27 -- The Argentine constitutional convention to reform the basic charter became a one-party meeting today when the Radicals stayed away while President Juan Peron hailed the ideals behind the proposed changes in the nation's code.

At this time when the tension and struggle between democracy and communism -- or any other totalitarian philosophy -- are apparent to all and when many religious and educational institutions have been subjected to criticism, the Board of Directors of the Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York wishes to make clear its loyalties and objectives.

Despite repayments by department stores and utilities, business loans by banks, in this area were a shade higher last week, rising $3,000,000, it was disclosed yesterday. Figures issued by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, covering the operations of the reporting New York City member banks during the week ended on Wednesday, put the current total of commercial, industrial and agricultural loans at $5,600,000,000.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 27 -- Defense attorneys for four local radio stations that are on trial for contempt in Criminal Court today leveled a full-fledged attack against the court code they allegedly violated, a code that restricts the publication of crime news.
The 5-cent cigar reappeared in New York yesterday for the first time since the war, and mink coats were advertised at a 50 per cent reduction.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, announced yesterday that_ the Democratic party would make state aid for education the No. 1 issue in local elections to be held throughout the{ state next November as the result of what he called the Republican state administration's failure to meet this issue at the present session of the Legislature.

More than 50 per cent of the Catholic clergy in Lithuania has been annihilated by the Russians since Soviet occupation began, declared the Right Rev. Mykolas Krupavicius, chairman of the Supreme Lithuanian Committee of Liberation, a coalition of all Lithuanian political parties in exile, on his arrival last night at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, on an Air France plane from Paris.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- President Truman announced today he had directed Secretary of State Dean G. Acheson to call Federal departmental chiefs together to begin preliminary planning of his "bold new program" for improving the under-developed areas of the world.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Several important decisions have been accepted in principle by officials negotiating the North Atlantic Security Pact. These, it was learned today, include the following:
LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 27 -- The much-married Fon of the Bikom tribe, now turned 80 years of age, at last has informed the United Nations Trusteeship Council in regard to his matrimonial plans.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 27 --- Athenagoras I, formerly Archbishop of New York for eleven years and a United States citizen was enthroned today as Ecumenical Patriarch of the Greek Orthodox Church, which has jurisdiction over the great masses of Orthodox believers and also claims spiritual leadership over Russian Orthodoxy.

Plans for converting the five-story dwelling at 59 East Seventy-second Street into twelve apartments of three rooms each were announced in connection with the purchase of the house by the Kellong Holding Corporation, Charles Peck, president, from the 59 East Seventy-second Street, Inc., Herbert Conway, president.

Four quarterly dividends of 75 cents a share and an extra of 25 cents on the common stock were declared yesterday by directors of the United States Pipe and Foundry Company. Quarterly disbursements of 70 cents each were made in 1948.

VIENNA, Jan. 27 -- Conclusion of an Austro-Hungarian barter agreement under auspices of the Economic Cooperation Administration and negotiation of similar agreements with Poland and Rumania under the same auspices were announced today, while Central Europe was still speculating on the significance of Moscow's new Council for Mutual Economic Assistance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Any attempt by the Roman Catholic Church hierarchy to "break the wall that separates church and state will be resisted and we believe will be beaten," Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam asserted at a national conference on church and state at Constitution Hall tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The National Grange joined several business organizations today in calling on Congress to reject President Truman's recommendation for revival of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act without modifications imposed by the Republicans last year.

OSLO, Norway, Jan. 27 -- In a statement to the Norwegian Parliament today Foreign Minister Halvard M. Lange declared that a Scandinavian military alliance would collapse at the first severe trial because of the different foreign policies of the constituent countries.

The United States Attorney's office is investigating at least one phase of the troubled operations of Samuel Broxmeyer, who assembled a farflung empire of apartment buildings, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The Western European nations' most important task this year is to intensify the cooperative operations initiated among European countries by the Economic Cooperation Administration through the Organization for European Economic Cooperation, Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer and Minister for Economic Affiars, told the House of Commons today.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Consolidated Edison Company, Inc., of New York, has asked State Supreme Court Justice Isadore Bookstein for a speedy decision on its petition for two orders staying a 10 per cent cut in temporary electric rates.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 27 -- Lana Turner's next picture will be "The Reformer and the Redhead," which is scheduled for summer production, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer announced today. Miss Turner has not made a film since her marriage in April, her most recent picture, "The Three Musketeers," having been completed ten months ago.

The high cost of travel threatens to cut about 17 per cent from the touring volume in this country during the year, delegates were told yesterday at the international travel conference of the American Automobile Association at the Roosevelt Hotel.

Promising if elected to fight for greater state aid for education through new school construction and better salaries for teachers, Edgar J. Nathan 3d, started his campaign as Republican candidate for Assemblyman yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the New York Young Republican Club at Schwartz's restaurant, 56 Broad Street He is a candidate in a special election in the Fifth Manhattan Assembly District Feb. 15.

Battalion Chief James M. McMahon told Trial Commissioner William R. Bayes yesterday that he and his immediate superior, Deputy Chief Joseph M. Ziegler, discussed possible violations of the department rules at the firehouse party at which they were guests on the night of Dec. 16.

There have been "some important cancellations of steel orders recently," E. G. Grace, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, disclosed yesterday after expressing his "anxiety whether we're building too much rather than too little steel capacity."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The wartime voice of "Axis Sally" -- beaming Nazi propaganda to American homes -- echoed with dramatic impact at the treason trial of Mildred E. Gillars today.

On Jan. 19 you carried an article by Chief Magistrate Bromberger calling attention to the miserably low-pay scales of probation officers and stating his request to the Budget Director for increases to ameliorate this condition

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The 52-nation International Wheat Conference in its second plenary session today discussed the three main problems in negotiating an international wheat agreement -- price, duration and quantity.

Officials of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and its affiliate, the New York City Omnibus Corporation, requested more time yesterday in which to decide whether they would agree to arbitrate their dispute with the Transport Workers Union, CIO, over retroactive wage increases and an employer-financed pension system.

The Board of Transportation yesterday sold at auction three properties in Manhattan and two in the Bronx for a total of $229,100. The sale was held in the Vesey-Street Salesrooms by Joseph P. Day, Inc.

It was about ten years ago that Tom Brigance came to the United States after several years spent in study in Paris. Since making his debut designing sportswear for Lord Taylor, soon after his arrival in this country, he has branched out into other fields of greater sophistication.

The stock market lost ground yesterday for the fourth consecutive day. Profit-taking in the steels upset the list during the morning, but an afternoon rally in this group repaired some of the damage and left the composite rate lower by only 0.21 point.

NANKING, Jan. 27 -- Although the Nationalists' military plans have gone awry in the past, even before they were put into operation, Acting President Li Tsungjen's "caretaker" government seems to be trying to pave the way for three anti-Communist military zones just in case its efforts to make peace with the Communists are unsuccessful.

PARIS, Jan. 28 -- Gilbert Orcel's new interpretations of the cloche form an important contribution to the millinery openings. Whether in bengal, manila, stitched organdy, or taffeta, there is a soft rather voluminous feeling about the larger cloches.

The stock market settled into further lower ground yesterday when the steels lost favor and joined the list in its fifth successive sell-off. It was the first time since Tuesday that the steels had not run counter to the general trend and, although a firmer note developed in the final hour, reductions only recovered slightly.

The arrest of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, Roman Catholic Primate of Hungary, by the Communist Government is in no sense an ordinary political arrest. The implications far transcend those of personal opposition to a political regime. Examine it against a backdrop of basic Communist ideology, dating back to Hegel and Marx, and you are confronted with the absolute cause: the conflict between communism and the Church, or more exactly, between Communist atheism and Christianity.

The Richard Hudnut Company to Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc., for its recently acquired Chert Yu line. I Bethel Latex Products, Bethel, I Conn., to Ormsbee, Moore Gilbert, Inc., 1VIilford, Conn. Harry F. Ormsbee is account executive.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- For sports suits Mattli uses much gray and yellow in otterburn and linton tweeds. Checks, flecks and herringbones are seen on tweeds for jackets combined with a plain slim skirt frequently buttoned at the back from the knees.
The Congress of Industrial Organizations has given up the fight to retain control of thousands of department store workers here, it was learned yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- The smoldering fight between the state Board of Regents and the board of trustees of the State University over administration of state institutions of higher education flared again today at a meeting of the regents.

Sportsmen's groups that only recently have awakened to the importance of anti-pollution activities will be interested to learn that the largest penalty paid into the New York State Conservation fund during November was the $1,000 settlement of a pollution case.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Jan. 28 -- The current boom in school construction gives to physical training teachers a golden opportunity to "speak up" in favor of improved gymnasium facilities, the New York State Association for Health, Physical Education and Recreation was told today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 28 -- The United Nations Security Council voted approval today of a step-by-step plan that would transfer sovereignty of the rich islands of Indonesia (Netherlands East Indies) from the Dutch to a new United States of Indonesia by July, 1950.

In the war recently ended our basic problem was to mobilize all our manpower in order to win the whole war, not just a part of it. Everyone was made to feel that he had a share and a responsibility in winning the war against the Axis. Everyone ought to be given to feel that he has a share in winning the present war against catastrophe.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- A surprise out-of-court settlement today ended litigation over the $16,500,000 estate of Mrs. Eleanor M. (Cissy) Patterson, late publisher of The Washington Times-Herald.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 28 (AP) -- De Luxe, the Calumet Farm's chief Flamingo Stakes hopeful, took a five-length drubbing from the Greentree Stable's Repentance at Hialeah today. De Luxe and Ponder, the Calumet entry in the Tavernier Purse for 3-year-olds, were favored at 3 to 4.
BOSTON, Jan. 28 -- Two women and a man died today in a flash fire starting in an elevator shaft being dismantled at the Atlantic Avenue station of the East Boston tube.
Ninety-two persons -- hair grayer, postures a bit more stooped, but as one said, "we're still young in heart and spirit" -- sat down to dinner last night at the Commodore Hotel.

PARIS, Jan. 28 -- The Executive Committee of the European Council for the Marshall Plan at its meeting Feb. 3 will discuss the question of better publicity to enlighten Europeans regarding the European Recovery Program and their role in it.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Personal income tax collections in the last half of 1948 were only $716,216,000 below the same period of 1947, despite the tax rate slash last year.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 28 -- Seton Hall College's basketball squad registered its tenth victory in thirteen games tonight by beating Providence College, 67-42, at the Setonia gymnasium. The Pirates led, 38-18, at half time.

BERLIN, Jan. 28 -- German Communist leaders revealed tonight their intention of forcing Eastern Germany into the circle of satellite "people's democracies" by the use of more policemen, more "justice" and a larger and more prying bureaucracy.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Jan. 29 -- The Soviet Union accused the United States and Great Britain today of trying to undermine the United Nations with a North Atlantic defense pact.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Layoffs in manufacturing industries increased in November for the second consecutive month, rising to fourteen per 1,000 workers from twelve per 1,000 in October, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. This was almost double the corresponding 1947 rate. Both the durable and nondurable goods industries reported increasing layoffs.

It will probably never be said of Victor Scholer, the Danish pianist who made his American debut last season, that he is an "emotional" performer. But, at his recital at Carnegie Hall last night, he penetrated the surface of the music he played and gave every composition a life of its own.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Britain, for her own economic salvation, must undertake an intensive drive for expanded markets in the United States, Canada and other Western Hemisphere markets where dollars that Britain badly needs are available, Harold Wilson, president of the Board of Trade, told the House of Commons today.
LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Liberal exiles from countries of the Soviet bloc and from Spain banded together here tonight to work for the overthrow of the Governments of their countries.
NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Jan. 28 (UP) -- The Navy will take over its newest super-cruiser, the 716-foot Newport News, here tomorrow.

Miss Patricia Sinclair of the Ohrbach Swimming Association scored a surprise victory over Miss Betty Mullen of the Women's Swimming Association to capture the women's metropolitan senior 440-yard free-style championship at the Grand Central Y. M. C. A. last night.

The finish and grace of Joseph Schuster's style as 'cellist, and the warmth of his tone commend him very much to his public, which gathered faithfully and enthusiastically to hear him at his recital last night in Town Hall.

Paul Robeson, singer, told a protest meeting called by the newly organized Negro Youth Builders Institute, Inc., yesterday, that "the oppression of the Negro in the United States varies only in degree, in New York, New Jersey, Georgia and Alabama." The meeting was called in the Y. M. C. A., 180 West 135th Street, and was one of two meetings called yesterday where specific acts of violence in Georgia were discussed.
Two Negro ball players came into the New York Giants' organization yesterday, although not signed for immediate service with the Polo Grounds National Leaguers.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 (AP) -- A new lighting system which will permit a greater number of vessels to use the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal on a twenty-four-hour basis soon will be finished on the north bank of the canal, the district Army Engineers office announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Changes designed to remove from the controversial Displaced Persons Act of 1948 the provisions widely assailed as being discriminatory and as presenting obstacles to its administration were urged today by a former key supporter of the original measure, Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican, of Wisconsin.

HAVANA, Jan. 27 -- The formation of a democratic bloc against dictatorial regimes in Latin America, planned by President Carlos Prio Socarras since his election last June, is now under way, according to Government sources. The aim of the bloc will be to fight against internal violence and foreign aggression that might oust democratic administrations.
GLEN COVE, L. I., Jan. 28 -- The annual Luckenbach handicap squash racquets tournament started this evening on the courts of the Nassau Country Club.

Monroe Flegenheimer, Democratic and Liberal candidate for Assemblyman in the Fifth Manhattan District, expressed resentment last evening at being linked with Frank Costello by Edgar J. Nathan 3d, his Republican opponent. In a speech before the New York Young Republican Club on Thursday Mr. Nathan said that the voters of the district were "highly suspicious of the type of candidate proposed by the Rogers-Costello machine."

MOSCOW, Jan. 28 (UP) -- Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, today demanded the "ideological destruction" of unpatriotic theatre critics who attack the "artistic imperfection" of blue-ribbon Soviet plays.

Without any previous announcement, Municipal Court Justice Thomas E. Morrissey Jr. was sworn in as an Associate Justice of the Court of Special Sessions by Mayor O'Dwyer at City Hall yesterday. He will fill the un-expired term of Justice Anthony J. Di Giovanna, serving until June 30, 1951.

Extra - meated, broad - breasted chicken broilers, a week younger than those commercially marketed and yet a half-pound heavier, were barbecued at the Statler Hotel last night for the delectation of experts. Broilers are the adolescents of the chicken clan.

The American Water-Color Society which will open tomorrow its eighty-second annual in the galleries of the National Academy, Fifth Avenue and Eighty-ninth Street, has announced ten awards. More than 400 water-colors, gouaches and pastels have been assembled, a slightly smaller number than last year.

John Golden, who .registered four possible New York opening dates with the League of New York Theatres for his revival of "They Knew What They Wanted," finally has settled on Wednesday evening, Feb. 16. The late Sidney Howard's Pulitzer Prize comedy, starring Paul Muni, will hang up its shingle at the Music Box.

The time-honored Children's Hour, a Sunday morning feature by and for young people, which has been on the air at 10:30 o'clock over WNBC for more than twenty years, will be televised simultaneously each week beginning tomorrow over WNBT.

There has been an accumulation of evidence in recent weeks that demand and supply, over the economy as a whole, were coming more nearly into balance than at any time since the war's end. This transition from a chronic condition of over-all shortages, as is usually the case, has not affected all regions, all industries or all groups uniformly.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 -- Nearly 100 persons were injured, some seriously, today by a blast that tore off the roof of the South Side mixing plant of the People's Gas Light Coke Company, blew out the north wall and broke windows as far as a mile away.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 28 -- Errol Flynn's next picture for Warner Brothers will be "The Candy Kid," a photoplay about the career of an American gambler in the days of Diamond Jim Brady, the studio announced today. Borden Chase is writing the scenario from a magazine story by Michael MacDougall, and William Jacobs will produce the film after Flynn completes his current loan-out engagement in "The Forsythe Saga" at M-G-M.
PARIS, Jan. 28 -- A sudden wave of gold buying in French markets today was considered by financial experts as a political maneuver to prevent the successful flotation of the new government loan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The House Armed Services Committee offered strong evidence today that Congress might demand that $800,000,000 asked by President Truman for universal military training be used instead to strengthen the Air Force.

TOKYO, Jan. 28 -- The Japanese Communist party, with thirty-five seats in the lower house of the new Diet, today formally launched its campaign for a united front of Left-wing groups against the conservative Government of Premier Shigeru Yoshida.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- James E. Webb took the oath of office today as Under-Secretary of State at a ceremony in the office of Dean G. Acheson, Secretary of State.

ARMONK, N. Y., Jan. 28 -- As the first town in the state to build a town hall with capital reserve funds frugally saved over the years, North Castle was preparing today to move soon into its new official home. Although founded in 1736, the town has never before owned a hall. Hitherto the public offices have occupied rented quarters in private homes, taverns and, since 1910, a former horse barn.

SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., Jan. 28 -- A 22-year-old skier lost for twenty-six hours on Mount Marcy, foodless in zero cold, came out of the wilderness today feeling "fine." Eggs and bacon revived the hungry Navy veteran, William Shettler of Mount Vernon.

NANKING, Jan. 28 -- Gen. Chang Chih-chung, leading Kuomintang [Government party] peace advocate, took time off from his busy peacemaking activities here and departed today by plane en route to Sinkiang [Chinese Turkestan]. According to a responsible source, he is scheduled to sign a new Sino-Soviet economic treaty for Sinkiang with a Soviet representative in Urumchi [Tihua].
A fire shortly after 4 o'clock yesterday, morning caused Raymond Le Grand, his wife and their three children to jump from their second floor apartment at 308 Forty-ninth Street, Brooklyn.

Still trying to ease traffic congestion in mid-Manhattan, Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander barred yesterday left turns on three principal crosstown arteries. The rule, effective at 8 A. M. Monday, bars turns on Fourteenth, Twenty-third and Fifty-seventh Streets.
LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 28 -- Following is the text of a resolution on the Indonesian situation adopted today by the United Nations Security Council:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Draftsmen of President Truman's "bold new program" for improving under-developed areas said today the plan contemplated no large-scale financial aid but rather the technical assistance required for exploitation of natural resources.
Five Long Island Rail Road commuter trains were delayed from thirty-three to fifty-eight minutes yesterday morning after a mishap at Laurelton, Queens, in which an automobile was demolished.
The "letters-to-the-editor" campaign in favor of Fire Commissioner Frank Quayle, who is seeking to oust Fire Chief Peter Loftus on the ground of improper conduct, continued yesterday.

An increase in tax revenues is not needed to maintain the Federal budget in approximate balance, according to Murray Shields, vice president of the Bank of the Manhattan Company. It is estimated the cash surplus in the current fiscal year should reach $2,800,000,000 and $1,500,000,000 for the fiscal year 1950, he said, and these estimates would allow for a substantial increase in the defense program and continuation of large scale foreign aid.
A "sculptor" convict who has been serving a life sentence at Dannemora, N. Y., as a fourth offender appeared yesterday in Bronx County Court in an attempt to gain his freedom by a legal technicality.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned downward yesterday and closed 8 to 19 points net lower.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 28 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie today awarded the contract for the construction of the thirty-nine-story building that will provide office space for the Secretariat at the permanent headquarters of the United Nations in Manhattan.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 28 -- The Yugoslav press and propaganda services lifted today the barrier against publication of the news that the Soviet Union and its allies had held a conference in Moscow to establish a Council for Economic Mutual Assistance from which Yugoslavia had been excluded.

Two new films will arrive in local theatres today. Walt Disney's latest feature, "So Dear to My Heart," combining live action and animation, will open at the Palace. Burl Ives, Beulah Bondi and the child performers, Luana Patten and Bobby Driscoll, are the principals.
Mayor O'Dwyer presented scholarship awards of $200 each to fifty students in the city's public academic and vocational high schools yesterday at a ceremony in the Council chamber at City Hall.

A new numerical method of weather forecasting that in its present form would require 75,000,000 separate calculations for a twenty-four-hour prediction that would be valid in a radius of 600 miles was described at the meeting of the American Meteorological Society at City College yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Following is the text of a joint communique issued after today's meeting of the foreign ministers of the Brussels pact nations:

There is little activity in store for the public market for new capital next week. Corporate financing will be restricted largely to a few new issues of public utility and railroad securities. The Kentucky Utilities Company will take bids on Monday on $10,000,000 of bonds, and the Union Light, Heat and Power Company will offer $5,000,000 of bonds on Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- President Truman today set up an emergency board to avert strike action by locomotive engineers.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 28 -- Three local radio stations and the news editor of one were found guilty today of contempt of court because they violated a court rule that restricts the publication of crime news. A fourth radio station, cited for contempt with the others on July 20, was found not guilty in a three-day trial in Criminal Court.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 28 -- A serious examination of the policies governing the publication of the Neue Zeitung, United States Military Government German language newspaper, and an investigation of its alleged Nazi personnel are under way, United States officials indicated today.

MILAN, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Hungarian ice skating stars finished first and second in the European 1949 pairs championships tonight. A capacity audience of 4,000 cheered the first international skating competition ever held in Italy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The United States cautioned delegates to the fifty-three nation wheat conference today that Congress might balk at absorbing too great a loss in shipping American wheat to non-producing countries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada, the new chairman of the Joint Congressional ("watchdog") Committee on Foreign Cooperation, suggested today that the United States give $1,500,000,000 of credits to the Chinese Nationalist Government for military and economic support.

BERLIN, Jan. 28 -- In the first contact between United States and Soviet authorities in Berlin for several months, the Russians approached the United States Military Government this week on two questions involving raft traffic through Berlin.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The All-America Football Conference today met to decide how to strengthen the Chicago Rockets, a key club in the reorganized circuit's continuing box-office scrap with the National League.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 -- Chemists at the University of Notre Dame have isolated a group of four compounds, previously unknown, that show promise of being effective against the destructive RH factor in the human blood, which causes many stillbirths, miscarriages and fatal diseases among infants.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- Revision of court procedure for handling offenses by New York City girls between the ages of 16 and 21 was proposed today in legislation introduced by Senator MacNeil Mitchell, of Manhattan, and Assemblyman Justin C. Morgan, of Erie, both Republicans.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Sid Luckman was mentioned prominently today as a possible successor to Ray Morrison as head coach of Temple University's football team.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Two new developments in the search for the United States B-29 that disappeared Thursday night while flying from Dakar, French West Africa, to Marham, England, raised hopes here today that the craft might be found and the fifteen aboard rescued.
BOSTON, Jan. 28 -- The question, "What is social work?" was raised today by Benjamin E. Youngdahl, president of the American Association of Schools of Social Work.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- President Truman signed today a bill passed by Congress yesterday that supplied $500,000 for his disaster relief fund. Then he turned the money over to Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, Federal Works Administrator, who immediately allocated $250,000 of it for relief of the five storm-stricken Western states.
LONDON, Jan. 28 -- British and United States representatives today concluded talks concerning purchases of American tobacco in the coming year.

SLOATSBURG, N. Y., Jan. 28 -- This incorporated village finally caught up with the rest of the metropolitan area today. Its telephone system was cranked into life for the last time this afternoon and from now on subscribers can try leaving messages with a dial system.

The Evander Childs High School swimming team successfully defended its P. S. A. L. swimming championship in the Columbia University pool last night. With a thrilling victory in the 200-yard free-style relay serving as the high-light of their performance the Evander swimmers amassed a total of 24 points to gain the citywide crown for the third year in a row.

Retail sales declined during the week due to warm wet weather that kept shoppers out of stores. Department store sales were estimated as about 6 per cent below the corresponding Week last year. Sales last week were 1 per cent above last year.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Jan. 28 -- The proposed merger of the villages of Tarrytown and North Tarrytown into a city gained impetus today when a tabulation of votes showed that residents want the school districts merged immediately.
American tourists who sneer at Mexican customs or strut the boulevards of Paris in shorts were described yesterday as hampering President Truman's international good-will policy.

No changes are contemplated by the Professional Golfers Association in the conduct of its 1949 championship, which is scheduled for the Hermitage Club, Richmond, Va., beginning May 25, according to Ed Dudley, tournament chairman.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Southern Senators fell back today to a second defensive line in their fight against a heavy bipartisan thrust to reduce their power, and that of all minorities, to filibuster.

Ben Nash, New York industrial designer, has been elected president of the American Designers Institute, it was announced yesterday at the organization's eleventh annual luncheon meeting, at the Belmont Plaza Hotel. Other newly elected officers are Henry Glass of Chicago, first vice president; Ann Franke of New York, secretary, and Dan Jensen of Philadelphia, treasurer.

In what was said to be the first increase of liquor prices in the last eight years, based on higher costs, major distilling companies disclosed yesterday that many Scotches and lower-price blended whiskies will be raised slightly on March 1.

The Army Corps of Engineers, charged with the responsibility of safeguarding and maintaining the nations waterways, is carrying on its eightieth harbor improvement project in the New York area, it was announced yesterday.

With the large "at value" advance bookings of past seasons conspicuous by their absence, prices to be made at the forthcoming openings of men's wear worsted fabrics for next fall command more than usual attention, it was reported here yesterday.

GENEVA, Jan. 28 -- The International Refugee Organization's executive committee decided today to rescind an eight-month-old ban on financial assistance to refugees entering Palestine under conditions laid down by the United Nations Security Council.

With only four characters to speak for him, Bernard Reines has tried a very difficult theme in "Forward the Heart," which was well acted at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre last evening. He has tried to state and analyze the problems of a blind white veteran of the last war who falls in love with a Negro girl and wants her to marry him.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- National security and foreign policy demand that the present export control program be continued, Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, and A. J. Loveland, Under-Secretary of Agriculture, told the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today.
In your editorial on "State Aid Log-Rolling" you present a picture of the school aid problem that is not justified.

DURHAM, N. C., Jan. 28 -- The first step will be taken next week in developing a country-wide series of regional programs depicting American democracy at the grass roots level for broadcasting by the Voice of America, George V. Allen, Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs, disclosed tonight.

IN "The Hollow of the Wave"* -- a novel of Communist rats in democracy's larder -- Edward Newhouse has taken on one of the toughest assignments open to the novelist. He has written a story that hasn't a really admirable character in it. True, the Larry Holland whose unusual New York publishing house is infiltrated by the Communists has his good points, but he also has his fatal weaknesses.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 28 -- Aubrey S. Eban, Israeli representative, conferred today with United Nations Secretary General Trygve Lie. It was understood that the principal subject of discussion was British Foreign Secretary Bevin's speech in the House of Commons earlier this week.

Active armed resistance by a widespread anti-Communist underground movement in the Baltic states was reported yesterday by two officials of the Supreme Lithuanian Committee of Liberation an interview at the Plaza Hotel.

Archbishop John T. McNicholas of Cincinnati, chairman of the Administrative Board of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, has written to all members of the Roman Catholic hierarchy in the United States, calling attention to their coming drive for $5,000,000 for the aid of war-stricken peoples.

The Aetna Life Insurance Company and affiliated companies reported yesterday for 1948 a premium income of $385,936,515, an increase of 14.6 per cent over the figure for 1947. Of this amount, $255,848,855 was for the parent company.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Federal Judge Michael L. Igoe expressed today the opinion that the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company "by devious methods and means" had tried to gain control of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway Company.
Mrs. Lola Rosen of 259 West Seventieth Street got her theatre tickets back yesterday. They had been taken from her pocketbook Jan 15 while she was shopping in a midtown department store.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Spurred by Senate pressure, Administration officials completed tonight their new Labor Relations Bill to still rumors that President Truman's advisers were in disagreement over its provisions.

A new group of upholstered furniture just introduced by Abraham Straus offers neat solutions to several seating problems. Foam rubber is put to good use to make the individual pieces trim enough for small rooms without sacrificing comfortable dimensions.

Eight college graduates were among 349 probationary patrolmen who participated yesterday in graduation exercises held at Washington Irving High School. The prospective police officers had completed a three-months' training course at the Police Academy.

First sample deliveries to local dealers of Radio Corporation of America's sixteen-inch direct-view tube table television receiver began yesterday. Irving Sarnoff, vice president of Bruno-New York, Inc., RCA metropolitan area distributor, said that sampling will occupy a full week and added he is unable to tell when consumer deliveries will start.

The outlook for skiing in the North Country, generally speaking, is not as gloomy as the weather in the metropolitan area would have indicated yesterday. While rain and mist, in many instances, visited the skilands as far north as Maine, the inroads made on the snow depths were not appreciable.

Each year at about this time Chief City Magistrate Bromberger goes before the Budget Director with an urgent plea for more appropriations for the hard-pressed probation department serving the city's forty-two Magistrates Courts. Invariably the reaction of the Budget Director, who also is hard-pressed, has been rather negative.
Judge Harold R. Medina, presiding over the trial of the eleven Communist leaders, announced from the bench yesterday that he had received threatening "communications" at his home.

Cottonseed oil futures reversed yesterday the trend of the previous day and after a slightly firm start broke sharply on the New York Produce Exchange. Final prices were 38 to 57 points lower on a turnover of 225 lots. Although a scattered demand and light offerings were apparent early in the day, weakness in Western markets forced cottonseed oil to give ground.
A new color remover that will work on synthetic materials such as nylon and acetate rayon, as well as natural fibers, was demonstrated yesterday by the Best Foods, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Attorney General Clark announced today the Government has filed an anti-trust suit at Boston alleging a monopoly conspiracy in the sandpaper industry.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 28 (AP) -- The medalist, Miss Peggy Kirk of Findlay, Ohio, waged an uphill battle today to gain the semi-final round of the seventeenth annual Helen Lee Doherty women's amateur golf tournament with a 1 up victory over Miss Alice O'Neal of Indianapolis.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 -- Liquidation was resumed today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade after an early showing of strength when shorts covered freely. May corn declined 3 1/2 cents a bushel from the top and May wheat, 3 1/8 cents, the latter coming within 1/8 cent of yesterday's low mark.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- The time has come to grant de facto recognition to Israel, the five Brussels Pact powers agreed today. Those British Dominions that have not yet recognized Tel Aviv have also agreed to do so, it was stated here. Therefore a number of recognitions, including that of Britain, are expected tomorrow, Sunday and Monday.

Defeat overtook Ike Williams, world lightweight champion, last night for the first time in two years and over a span of twenty-one ring engagements. When the setback came, however, Williams' title was not affected, for he went down before a heavier foeman; one who could withstand his best blows and come flailing back with a fiery attack of his own.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 28 -- The Ohio River in the Cincinnati area will crest at 54 to 55 feet late Monday or early Tuesday, provided no additional rain falls meanwhile, the Weather Bureau said today.

Establishment of a Federal agency to be known as a Commission on Internal Security that would guard against the invasion of "Soviet communism" here was urged last night by Allen W. Dulles, president of the Council on Foreign Relations.

BOCHUM, Germany, Jan. 28 -- Six of the seven German workmen who disobeyed a British Military Government order to dismantle a plant were found guilty this afternoon by a British court at Bochum and sentenced to two months in prison. The men will serve only six weeks because the sentence was predated to Jan. 15.

The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company increased yesterday the quarterly dividend on the common stock 25 cents to $1.25 a share and reported 1948 net earnings at $35,711,732 before deducting $6,000,000 for increased construction and replacement costs and contingencies.
LONDON, Jan. 28 -- The stock markets here got off to a slow start today, fog delaying many members.

More planes and bulldozers were thrown into the battle of the western blizzards yesterday, but a new storm dealt rescue efforts a severe setback in some areas, The Associated Press reported. The new snow, forerunner of another cold wave, whipped across Wyoming, Nebraska, eastern Kansas and southeast South Dakota and on into southeastern Minnesota, Iowa and Wisconsin.

Chief Peter Loftus was at the Great Jones Street firehouse party on Dec. 16 for fifteen minutes, saw no high Fire Department officers while he was there and estimated that the gathering consisted of not more than thirty persons, according to testimony read into the record yesterday at his departmental trial for allegedly violating the rules and regulations of the Fire Department.

The Department of Agriculture has been unable to meet its commitments for grain exports in the month of January owing to a shortage of ship tonnage, and a similar condition threatens the movement of recovery - program grain in February and March, it was reported here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., Kansas City, Mo., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 404,112 shares of $5 par-value common stock that are to be offered first to its common stockholders at the rate of one-fifth of a new share for each common share held.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 28 (AP) -- Fourteen yachts set out today on the fifty-four-mile run to Cat Cay, Bahamas, in the third annual Fort Lauderdale-Cat Cay Race.
ATHENS, Jan. 28 -- The peace proposals broadcast yesterday and again today by the Markos rebel radio were met with coolness by the Greek Government.

The Oersted Medal, given annually by the American Association of Physics Teachers to an outstanding teacher in the field, was presented yesterday in absentia to Prof. Arnold Sommerfeld, internationally famous German physics teacher and director emeritus of the Institute of Theoretical Physics at the University of Munich.

An offer of between $750,000 and $800,000 has been made for the fleet of four steamboats owned by the Hudson River Day Line, which announced last October that it was suspending operations because of increased operating expenses and diminishing passenger traffic.

International one-mile and two-mile races will command the chief attention of a capacity throng of 15,000 spectators tonight as Madison Square Garden's new eleven-lap board running track receives its first spike scars in the forty-second annual games of the Millrose Athletic Association.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 28 (AP) -- Dick Metz, veteran of almost twenty years of links competition, took the lead in the $10,000 Phoenix open today with a 36-hole score of 137.

The Board of Higher Education submitted to Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson yesterday a tentative budget calling for the expenditure of $19,419,045 during the fiscal year beginning July 1. Its financial estimate is an overall increase of $2,347,635 over its present budget.

Volunteer workers in the Salvation Army's current campaign for a maintenance fund of $1,100,000 for its various services throughout Greater New York reported contributions of $390,364 at a luncheon yesterday attended by 150 persons, including divisional and sectional chairmen, in the Park Lane Hotel, 299 Park Avenue.

The Welfare Council of New York, alarmed at the "serious curtailment of State employment services" at a time when joblessness is on the rise, appealed yesterday to President Truman and Congressional leaders to take specific actions to avert a major breakdown in the field.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Israel was reported today to have asked the United States to try to get Egypt to modify her position in the deadlocked Rhodes armistice talks.

Ted Collins has two "musts" on his list. In order of importance, he must bob up with a new coach for his transplanted Boston Yanks and he must settle upon a new name for the club that will play its home games at the Polo Grounds, sharing that site with the Giants.

Although important developments had been expected around this time, practically, no change has marked the Argentine hide situation, it was reported in the trade here yesterday. Earlier this month interest was aroused by advices that the Argentine Government intended to announce further readjustments of foreign exchange rates for specific exports and imports.

Grenville Kane Baker, 27-year-old son of the late George F. Baker, New York financier, who was mysteriously killed on Jan. 17, last, on the family's 13,000-acre plantation, near Tallahassee, Fla., left $2,500 and a life interest in approximately one-half of his personal estate to his widow, Alicia Grajales Baker of 1001 Park Avenue, according to his will, filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- The marked brevity of the passage on defense in the communique issued here tonight by the Western Union Consultative Council of five Foreign Ministers is regarded as virtual proof that the "nerve center" of Western Europe's defense already has passed to Washington.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- A decline of 0.3 per cent was registered in average primary market prices during the week ended Jan. 25, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The index is now 158.8 per cent of the 1926 average, 2.1 per cent lower than four weeks ago and 3.5 per cent less than the comparable week in 1948.

The City Rent Commission, in its first general decision since its reorganization last November, held yesterday that hotel owners may continue to collect whatever rent rises their tenants have agreed to, even after leases embodying these agreements expire.

The City Rent Commission, in its first general decision since its reorganization last November, held yesterday that hotel owners may continue to collect whatever rent rises their tenants have agreed to, even after leases embodying these agreements expire.

A dispute between United States Lines employes and longshoremen resulted in a brief work stoppage of the longshoremen at Pier 61, North River. The men were engaged at the time in loading the liner America.

Two members of the engine room crew of the disabled Coast Guard icebreaker Eastwind were cited yesterday before a Coast Guard inquiry board as being responsible for saving the vessel after it had been rammed by the oil tanker Gulfstream, Jan. 19.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 28 -- Dr. Hugh A. Brimm, executive secretary of the Social Service Commission of the Southern Baptist Convention, has asked Southern Baptist pastors to refuse "bribe money" offered by the Ku Klux Klan.

Dorothy Berliner Commins, who returned to the concert stage last sea on after an absence of many years, gave a piano recital at Times Hall last night, charming an audience that apparently has a taste for good things done in a thoroughly ingratiating, unexcited way.

While Sonja Henie performed in her own ice skating revue at Madison Square Garden Thursday night, thieves, she reported, ransacked her six-room suite at the Pierre Hotel, broke open three trunks and made off with two mink coats worth $28,000.

NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 28 -- Arriving in Newark today after a twenty-one-hour train trip from her Georgia home, attractive Grace Purcell, who will be 5 years old on Feb. 7, hopes before she leaves this city to have "arms that move."

"Parent and Child," by Catherine Mackenzie, will be published on Feb. 21 by William Sloan Associates. The book is based on her columns about child psychology that appear in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Miss Mackenzie shared the 1947 Lasker Award with Lawrence K. Frank, who wrote a foreword for the forthcoming book, and received the New York State Council for Early Childhood Education citation in 1948.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Federal Communications Commission reported today that it began the calendar year with more than 677,000 radio authorizations outstanding.

Army Secretary Royall appeared before the House Armed Services Committee on Thursday to ask for Congressional authorization for an Army 160,000 men larger than is provided for in the President's budget. Yesterday Air Secretary Symington went up the Hill to ask for authorization for an Air Force of seventy groups, as against the Defense Secretary's and the President's provision for an Air Force of forty-eight groups and ten squadrons. What goes on here?

The Lukens Steel Company of Coatesville, Pa., announced yesterday that it would ask stockholders at the annual meeting on Feb. 8 to approve a proposal to cancel 10,000 shares of capital stock, $10 par value, which had been assigned to its treasury in 1917 for eventual sale to employes.
I read Harold Callender's article in THE TIMES of Jan. 25, and I wish that everyone who reads it with relief and hope would aid to his utmost this cause and all other causes that unite us to France.
WHITE SANDS, N. M., Jan. 28 -- The Army today sacrificed a V-2 rocket that might have gone outside the 1,500,000-acre White Sands proving ground.

The New York Auxiliary of the Blue Ridge School of Virginia gave its fortieth annual benefit dinner dance last night in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Pierre. The fete drew the largest attendance in its long history, according to Mrs. Osborne Bethea, chairman of arrangements.

The Trading With the Enemy Act of Oct. 16, 1917, is the legal basis for the temporary blocking of alien property and for its confiscation. The act provides for the seizure of alien property in favor of the United States, without compensation. On this law are based about 11,000 seizure orders of the Custodian of Alien Property; so-called vesting orders.

Officials of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and its affiliate, the New York City Omnibus Corporation, agreed yesterday to arbitrate their dispute with the Transport Workers Union, CIO, over retroactive wage increases.

Mrs. Julia Carr, 42-year-old wife of Sam Carr, alleged co-leader of a Soviet spy ring in Canada, who was arrested here Thursday, was taken into custody by immigration authorities yesterday and removed to Ellis Island for a hearing on deportation charges.

Samuel Broxmeyer, whose widespread real estate transactions are under investigation by both Federal and New York County prosecutors, arranged last night through counsel to appear for examination in bankruptcy proceedings on Monday morning.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 28 -- The American gas industry plans to spend more than $1,800,000 this year on a cooperative program of promotion, advertising and research, it was announced today by Robert A. Hornby, vice president of the Pacific Lighting Corporation.
EUGENE, Ore., Jan. 28 (AP) -- Long Island University came from behind in the last five seconds tonight to nose out the University of Oregon basketball team, 68 -- 66.

VIENNA, Jan. 28 -- Lieut. Gen. Emile-Marie Bethouart, French High Commissioner for Austria, asked the Russians at today's meeting of the Allied Council to create a better atmosphere for the negotiation of the Austrian state treaty in London by dissolving the so-called "factory guard" organization.

There are many things that a rich man's son can do. One of the hardest must be to accept the grave responsibilities that great wealth imposes on a man of conscience. We believe there will be no dissenters to the statement that John D. Rockefeller Jr. has borne his responsibilities as custodian of one of America's great fortunes beyond reproach.
LONDON, Jan. 28 -- The Western Union powers agreed today to create a "Council of Europe" and thus fulfill a dream of centuries of European statesmen.

In a pessimistic review of Soviet-American relations, Charles E. Bohlen, State Department specialist on Russian affairs, said yesterday that the "deep cleavage" between this country and Russia existed because of a fundamental difference in the concept of international law.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The program advanced by President Truman in his inaugural address for giving technological assistance to under-developed areas of the world has been in successful operation in the field of agriculture within Latin America for the last ten years, the Department of Agriculture pointed out today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The State Department disclosed tonight that the Soviet Union had refused to reveal how many German war prisoners it was still holding in violation of a four-power agreement.

Improved supplies of steel are still short of enough to meet demand in this region, although offers have been made by jobbers trying to dispose of stocks in Detroit and other midwestern industrial centers, New York warehouses disclosed here yesterday.

Helmeted and booted like sandhogs and using electric lanterns to light their way, three luckless patrolmen sloshed 2,000 feet last night through the ooze and slime in the tunnel being built from the Battery to Brooklyn in an arduous but futile search for an Army prisoner who was reported to have escaped from Governors Island.

The recent incidents in connection with the appointment of Dr. Furtwangler and the concert tour of the German pianist Walter Gieseking have certainly done us no credit in the fields of either art or politics.

In your issue of Jan. 15 I read the article by C. B. Trussell concerning proposals by the Attorney General of the United States to the Congress for statutory authority to strengthen now existing spy laws. I and countless other Americans are heartily in favor of guarding to the utmost degree our national security.

BOSTON, Jan. 29 -- Optimism in New England appeared to be increasing in direct ratio to the snowfall this week as the weather began reverting to seasonal character. Along with broadening smiles in the ski-resort areas, unemployment showed a decrease in Massachusetts for the first time since October

An experimental program unique in the annals of the Y. W. C. A. will reach its climax Feb. 7, when the West Side Branch will join in the opening ceremonies of the Amsterdam Houses Community Center on Sixty-fourth Street, the program of which it helped shape.

THE trend in bearded iris, as exemplified by some of the latest introductions, is definitely toward selfs -- flowers of one color. This is a reversal from the comparatively dull colors that were so much in favor a few years ago. Perhaps the greatest progress in this direction is being made in the light blues and so-called 'pinks."

ALTHOUGH most gardeners have their favorite annual flowers, they are always interested in the new varieties, novelties and improved variations of old stand-bys. There is a wealth of such material available now, but the problem is where and how to use it.
DRY skim milk is still impossible to get in many sections. But the Borden Company is branching out with its Starlac in hope of completing national distribution by the end of the year.

WINSTON CHURCHILL, a pink and white Buddha in a rumpled dinner jacket at the trente-et-quarante table in the casino in Monte Carlo; the illusive, statuesque figure of Rita Hayworth; the brisk smartness of the Duchess of Windsor, and the faded faces of a handful of exiled Kings and potentates -- these are the stars that shine through the sea mist along the Riviera in this year of grace.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Very Rev. Msgr. John S. Spence, director of education in the Archdiocese of Washington, branded as "false" today charges by Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the Methodist Episcopal Church that the Roman Catholic Church is "opposed to our system of education."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The following is the test of the Administration's proposed National Labor Relations Act of 1949, repealing the Taft - Hartley Act and re-enacting the National Labor Relations Act of 1935, as prepared for introduction by the Senate Committee on Labor and Public Welfare, of which Senator Elbert Thomas of Utah is chairman:
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Mexican Government outlawed the militant pro-Catholic Sinarquista party yesterday.
MIAMI -- Charges of black-marketing in railroad transportation between Florida resorts and the North were quite thoroughly aired at a three-day Interstate Commerce Commission hearing here last week.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 29 -- The approaching civil rights battle in Congress, new anti-Klan developments and fresh efforts to maintain white supremacy at the polls were subjects of major concern in this area this week.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 29 -- New Anglo-Argentine trade negotiations that will be important to the continued feeding of Britain have begun between British Ambassador Sir John Balfour and Dr. Juan Atilio Bramuglia. The so-called Andes pact of Feb. 12, 1948, runs out on March 31.

IN nineteenth-century Britain, the provision of economic security was almost wholly a matter for private enterprise. Only as a last resort would workers seek aid from the public authorities who through the poor-law institutions offered relief on terms deliberately designed to deter all but the most desperate applicants.

The demands of the railroad unions for higher wages and other benefits, now in process of negotiation in Chicago, if granted in their entirety, will strike a hard blow at the carriers, which are in the midst of a huge improvement and modernization program in an effort to increase their efficiency.
Great Britain's decision to recognize Israel was hailed by rabbis in sermons here yesterday.

THE new post-war snorkel-equipped submarine -- the first true submersible in submarine history -- is an undersea boat which would have made even Jules Verne gasp. The once ugly "pigboat" is now a streamlined "guppy," its place secure in naval warfare -- indeed, in total war -- for years to come.

TORONTO, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks battled the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 4-4 tie tonight with Doug Bentley sliding home the equalizer with only 23 seconds remaining. The deadlock enabled the Leafs to stay a point in front of the fifth-place Hawks in the National Hockey League race.

The downward movement in the stock market was halted yesterday, but the switch to an improved position proved to be of minor proportions. Trading on the Stock Exchange was concentrated in low-price issues but increased in volume to 300,000 shares from 280,000 the week before.

CAT CAY, Bahamas, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The 52-foot yawl Katuna, owned and skippered by George Verney of New York, today won the third annual Fort Lauderdale to Cat Cay sailing race in a corrected time of 16 hours 51 minutes 28 seconds.

Ten thousand atomic bombs could be made from known deposits of fissionable elements, Prof. J. A. Campbell of Oberlin College told a recent meeting of the Erie Section of the American Chemical Society. New mines are being discovered each month throughout the world.

In investment circles, the "bold new program" of President Truman for raising living standards throughout the world through the use of private American capital is regarded as a long-run investment objective having little, if any, bearing on major current concerns of the financial marketplace.

To last year's "Reluctant Rebel," his first-rate story of the colonial war between Vermont and New York, Frederic F. Van de Water has now added a worthy sequel called "Catch a Falling Star." Readers who liked "Reluctant Rebel" will be pleased to know that the struggle for Vermont did not end with Ethan Allen's seizure of Fort Ticonderoga.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Jan. 29 (AP) -- A fireman died and five other persons were injured tonight in a crash between a fire engine and a police car at Seventh Street and Park Avenue, in the center of Plainfield's business district.

For months it has been argued that, given a stimulating piece of news, the stock market would quickly emerge into a new and higher position. United States Steel provided just such an opening last week when it declared a special dividend and proposed a three-for-one split of its common stock.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Jan. 29 -- Construction of a twenty-eight room, three-story brick manor house, the fourth to be built since 1639 on Gardiner's Island, once known as the Isle of Wight, has just been completed.

PEIPING, Jan. 29 -- The sluggishness of the Nationalist military evacuation of Peiping may yet cause a period of disorder within the city. It is understood that until the Nationalist troops leave, the Communist take-over leaders slated to head a joint transition administration will not enter the city.

In Congress the workrooms are the committee rooms. The committees, each assigned a definite field of legislation, are rough cross-sections of the two houses. They sort the thousands of measures introduced in each Congressional session, discard most of them, and argue out the details of the others.

FOR plants offering so much sheer beauty of flower and foliage, polyanthus primroses are surprisingly easy to grow. Fresh seed, however, is essential, and it appears on the market soon after July 15. Summer, rather than winter or spring, is the season for starting this perennial.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 29 -- Britain's recognition and that of the other Western European Union powers, along with the fact that Israel is about to form her first permanent government, have provided a swift transition from adolescence to political maturity.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 29 -- The Dutch Cabinet will meet Monday to discuss the resolution adopted yesterday by the United Nations Security Council.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Jan. 29 -- Illinois' basketball team staged a sensational comeback tonight to hand Minnesota's Gophers their first defeat in fourteen games, 45 -- 44. The Illini took possession of first place in the Western Conference with a record of four victories and no losses against Minnesota's five and one.

THE 1949 catalogues reveal a flush of new vegetable varieties representing, in most cases, years of patient crossing and selection by a battalion of plant breeders at experiment stations and in seed houses.

STUART, Fla., Jan. 29 -- The fishing season for both fresh and salt water species seems to be approaching a peak in this area now and the past few days have seen record and near-record fish taken by visiting anglers.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 (AP) -- A couple of basketball playing brothers named McGuire led St. John's College of Brooklyn to a 62-to-45 victory over St. Joseph's College of Philadelphia tonight in the second game of a double-header at Convention Hall.

The Eighty-first Congress is about to enter on the fourth week of the most extraordinary peacetime session in our history. Mr. Truman has asked it to provide him with nearly $42,000,000,000 and to allocate this almost inconceivable sum among a great variety of enterprises.
THE big news in dahlias this season is the increase in medium-size cactus types. This was so great that the American Dahlia Society added a special class in shows for their exhibition.

Raymond Daniell in commenting on the nationalization of Britain's pubs ("Tempest in a Beer Mug") is in illustrious company. G. K. Chesterton turned his attention to the potentialities of the situation back in 1913.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- However the case of the eleven American Communist leaders now on trial in New York is decided -- acquittal or conviction -- the outcome will be the beginning of a forensic free-for-all of heroic proportions and unlimited possibilities.

UNRUFFLED serenity and plenty of good sense are characteristics of Miss Maud Silver, a governess turned private investigator. The stories about Miss Silver conform to a pattern, and a most agreeable pattern it is -- except for those who are satisfied with nothing less than violent action.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- President Truman took direct action today to increase Federal relief in the blizzard areas of the West in view of the mounting emergency.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The United States Atomic Energy Commission issued a report today to allay public concern over the danger of irradiation poisoning from the wastes discharged by the atomic-energy plants and laboratories that now span the nation.

ON Jan. 21 my play "Leaf and Bough" -- or an unreasonable facsimile thereof -- opened at the Cort Theatre. I do not feel that, on the basis of the exhibit on the stage, the critics were totally unfair. The lack of distinction between what is written and how it is presented we may set down to a general layman's knowledge.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 29 -- Subzero weather sent department store sales diving with the thermometer, the Federal Reserve Bank in Minneapolis reported today. Index figures dropped from the 108 recorded last week to a substandard 98 for the four-week period ending Jan. 22, on the basis of reports of dollar volume in the department stores of Minneapolis, St. Paul, Duluth and Superior.

Don Gehrmann came roaring out of Wisconsin to take two European mile stars into camp last night but America's best was not good enough at two miles against a pair of light-footed, bellows-lunged rivals from abroad.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 29 -- The Egyptian government has published a large volume of reports showing the wide-spread extent of the terrorist wave and the vigorous efforts made to halt it.

Employment opportunities for college seniors who will be graduated in mid-winter are excellent, according to a report from Bucknell University's placement bureau. Of the 145 Bucknell graduates this term, 112 have registered with the bureau and more than 100 have already received job offers.

One of the greatest concentrations of police might in the city's history was brought into play last night to hunt down a man, believed to be a religious fanatic, who at 4:45 P. M. shot and slightly wounded a priest hearing a confession in the Roman Catholic Church of St. John the Martyr at 252 East Seventy-second Street.

ON Tuesday United Service Organizations will begin a drive for $6,650,000 to be used in providing for the welfare of armed forces personnel and hospitalized veterans. Of this total, $1,400,000 is sought for Veterans Hospital Camp Shows, one of the agencies financed with USO funds.

Mr. Mannes is to be congratulated for the formation of a new piano trio ensemble. However, in his article in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 9 he unfortunately distinguishes between string quartet and piano trio in stating that "quartets by their very nature must stress the quality of ensemble. . . .

AS required by law, the traditional "trial of coins" will open at the Philadelphia Mint Feb. 9. The jury will be the United States Assay Commission; the defendant is the 1948 "pyx," a collection of silver coins plucked at random from the production lines of the country's mints in this city, Denver and San Francisco.
