A major move seeking early action by Congress in amending the Tariff Act of 1930 so as to bring American customs procedure in line with the commercial principles of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) was launched last week by the United States Associates of the International Chamber of Commerce.

MR. MASUR'S biography of Simon Bolivar is, in the judgment of this reviewer, the best which has yet appeared in any language. As a result of his careful research in Europe and the United States, supplemented by a long residence in Bogota, the author has been able to look at the may controversial problems in the career of Bolivar with authority and detachment.
It will take the spring calf round-ups and the spring lambing to tell the whole story, The Associated Press reports.

Northeastern retail lumber yards are tightening credit requirements because customers are taking much longer to settle accounts than during the last three years, Willard F. Terrell, new president of the Northeastern Retail Lumbermen's Association, disclosed in an interview last week.

IT shouldn't be long now, perhaps only a few days, before Lillian Hellman completes her adaptation of Emmanuel Robles' "Montserrat" and sends it to co-producers Kermit Bloomgarden and Gilbert Miller. Which, by the way, is right on schedule and as promised by Miss Hellman some two or three months ago when she temporarily put aside the dramatization of Norman Mailer's "The Naked and the Dead."

English and French period furniture, a large group of early nineteenth century decorated luster ware and other objects that include porcelain and Georgian silver will be auctioned in a three-day sale beginning Thursday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Army, appealing to President Truman, wants the administration of the United States zone of Germany turned over to the State Department as soon as possible, it was learned tonight.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 29 -- Nineteen nations of Asia and the Middle East served notice on the world last week that from now on they are going to play a stronger role in international affairs. They asserted this as their right. These nations comprise nearly half the world's population and represent one-third of the United Nations membership.

IT has been years since the seed catalogues have carried so full and varied a list of flowers as they do in 1949. There are enough new varieties to transform a garden completely. And almost that same statement applies to vegetables.

THE California Zephyr, long-heralded Vista Dome streamliner, will begin daily service between Chicago and San Francisco on March 20. Completion by the Budd Company of the equipment for the six trains needed for this schedule ends a long period of waiting by the Burlington, Rio Grande and the Western Pacific, over whose rails the train will run.

TO the history of the cooperative gathering and distribution of "unslanted" news by newspaper publishers, without control or interference by governments, political parties or special interests, M. E. Nichols has added a valuable chapter with his book about The Canadian Press -- or CP.

Because of the need for rehousing families now living on slum sites, the New York City Housing Authority in the future will make increasing use of the "stagger" system in putting up each new project, Thomas F. Farrell, chairman of the authority, reported yesterday.

THIS collection of 238 pictures exhibits Shaw, his friends, his ancestors, his colleagues and his houses -- some of them in the direct line of relationship and others more remote. The pictures have been taken by commercial photographers, newspapers, friends and by the subject himself.

VIENNA, Jan. 29 -- The Czechoslovak Government has announced that a spring fair will be held in Prague March 13 to 19 and that Poland, Yugoslavia, Hungary, Italy, Albania, Switzerland and the Soviet zone of Germany have promised to send exhibits.

The Great Books THUS, though trivial work may die an easy and merciful death, a book, if it be great, continues to live for centuries after the death of the writer, to prosper, to deepen in beauty, in the same way that a garden, possessed of its own architectural system, will develop along the lines laid down for it.

CHRYSANTHEMUMS this year range from the tiniest dwarf to novelty "spiders," with the emphasis this season on dwarf kinds, and hardiness and color of all. For the average home gardener, the most desirable 'mums are those sturdy dependable types that give bright autumn colors.

THE use of the term "twelve-toned scale" in the recent letters stemming from the article by Schoenberg is interesting though vague. Perhaps the $64 question is -- "When is a tone not a tone?" -- the corollary of which is, "How far can a tone be distorted and still be considered the original tone"?

DESPITE a series of minor mishaps, Hollywood Director Arthur Black left here satisfied. He and a crew of American and Japanese camera men shot background scenes for Humphrey Bogart's next picture, "Tokyo Joe."

Compared to the renovations being made in the neighborhood around No. 1 Cherry Street, in the Manhattan shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge, the repairs at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, in the District of Columbia, are insignificant.

If the United States signs an agreement for the security of the North Atlantic community of nations and fails to reaffirm its concern with the security of all members of the United Nations, this country is in "grave danger" of weakening the United Nations, Clark M. Eichelberger, director of the American Association for the United Nations, Inc., warned here yesterday.

THIS book offers specific and concrete advice on almost every conceivable family situation in which children are involved. But it does more than merely deal with the problems of child rearing. It offers a blueprint for creative family life. The authors, Agnes Benedict and Adele Franklin, are both experienced in progressive educational methods and community work.

VISIT any college campus today and you will find many physical changes caused by the war, Quonset huts, prefabricated shacks, makeshift houses, dormitories tiered with double decker bunks. You will also see large numbers of veterans -- 1,100,000 by latest count -- and what is even more unusual, married students wheeling baby carriages.
Washington last week got down to work -- after the hiatus for the inaugural festivities -- and foreign policy became the first concern of the new Administration.

Reorganization in the top economic agencies of the Soviet Government, along with consolidation of industrial Ministries, has been going on during the past year, it became known yesterday with the arrival from Moscow of two official economic reports.

BY now the literature of the French Resistance can surely fill a small library. Although the movement itself was not very large, as Benouville and others even insist, a greater percentage of its members must have written books than that of any other regular or irregular fighting

In a letter to the editor, Dr. Samuel Goudsmit criticizes some statements made in an interview with Waldemar Kaempffert concerning the work on atomic energy in Germany during the war. At the same time Dr. Goudsmit withdraws some earlier statements he had made in his book "Alsos."

IF one of New York City's larger subway stations was closed for three successive nights to accommodate a Hollywood company making scenes for a film, there would doubtless result a storm of protest which would make the bonus march on Washington seem like a Girl Scout taffy pull.

PARIS, Jan. 29 -- The Brussels pact powers' agreement to establish a Council of Europe, announced yesterday in London, was a compromise between the British and French views, French observers said today. In the process of reaching a compromise a good deal of the substance of the project was sacrificed, they said.

The author of "Riding Bus' With a Hospital Interne" attempted in vain to write a pro and con article. It is slanted with abundant experiences of the latter point of view, while limited space and energy are utilized to represent actual interne feeling.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Jan. 29 -- Joseph J. Haggerty of the New York A. C., a Class C player a year ago, went through to the semi-final round of the Luckenbach handicap squash racquets tournament today at the Nassau Country Club. Joining him in the penultimate brackets were Edward C. Oelsner of Nassau, Richard S. Rothschild of the Downtown A. C. and Dr. G. P. Miley of the Yale Club.
The honor of holding the first event under the new rules of the American Horse Shows Association fell to the Brooklyn cavalry, which drew a big entry at Squadron C Armory yesterday.

Not all bus drivers are grumblers. * * * On a rainy late afternoon the crowding on the Chambers Street Crosstown line is something terrific. The driver has to take everything from mild sarcasm to ill-humored invective, and still he manages to laugh it off.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 29 -- Inspired Rutgers toppled Princeton for the Tigers' first loss of the basketball season on their home floor tonight. Growing steadily stronger during a see-saw struggle, the Scarlet won, 48 -- 44, before a capacity crowd in the new Dillon Gymnasium.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 29 -- Senator Robert A. Taft indicated today, without making definite predictions, that measures in President Truman's program would not be passed by Congress without changes.

MORE than one furniture designer this year has worked over a new idea in solitude for several months only to discover that half a dozen colleagues have been heading, each in his own way, in the same direction. Few of the collections introduced at the midwinter markets illustrated so many of these directions at once as the new Romweber group designed by Harold Schwartz, which will arrive in the stores next summer.

IN a previous book, "Family and Civilization," Dr. Zimmerman dealt scientifically with the problem of the family. Now with this popular work, he addresses himself to a wider audience in support of his American Family Institute, which, he feels, can strengthen the institution of the family -- and through it our whole civilization.

A MOTORIST just returned from Mexico reports very favorably on the recently opened paved highway in Mexico that cuts 100 miles off the drive from eastern points to Mexico City. The road reveals a part of the country so far untouched by American tourists' influence.

PASTRY is so old no records of the earliest recipes exist, so Louis P. De Gouy wrote before his death in "The Pie Book," which Greenberg will publish tomorrow. The first "trade union" of pastry makers was created in Paris in 1270, but old as is this branch of cookery, Master Chef De Gouy was able to make his book newsy.

SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 29 -- Winter-weary Westerners, battling blizzards and sub-zero cold this week, were faced by appalling conditions in five states producing fully 50 per cent of the nation's wool and mutton. By best available estimates 1,200,000 sheep are trapped by snow in Utah and 760,000 were on Wyoming ranges in five snow-blanketed counties when the series of blizzards struck.

BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Indonesian Republicans accused the Dutch today of having made a new police roundup of Republican leaders. They charged that the arrests openly defied the United Nations' most recent orders.
Retail demand softened last week and dollar volume of trade slipped under the comparable 1948 period. Department store sales were estimated at about 6 per cent below last year's.

February will prove a crucial month, in so far as business solvency is concerned, it was pointed out last week by New York credit men. Failures which have taken a sharp upward trend in recent weeks will reach new peaks since 1942, it was predicted, as the specter of frozen assets unfolds in the statements rendered both for income tax purposes and credit clearances.

Clearance sales and promotions continued to attract the strongest consumer response in department stores here last week, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

Leading American educators are divided on the issue of whether membership in the Communist party is sufficient grounds for dismissal from a college or university post. The question of academic freedom disturbs many conscientious spokesmen of higher education.

SOONER or later the theatre people of the United States may have to decide just exactly what a national theatre is. Representative Jacob K. Javits of New York has filed a bill that puts the responsibility of devising a national theatre, opera and ballet on the shoulders of professional practitioners of these arts.
RICHMOND, Jan. 29 -- The Upper South turned an uncertain but hopeful eye on the high cost of living this week. Things looked a little better because prices were lower.

AS a regular, paid-up member of the male sex, human race, this writer is genuinely grateful to Joseph L. Mankiewicz. Mr. Mankiewicz has done the greatest service to men in "A Letter to Three Wives" that has been done on the screen in our interest since the devil only knows when.

WARSAW, Jan. 29 -- From 200 to 250 former members of Poland's Home Army of the wartime underground have been arrested in the last fortnight by the Government's Secret Security Police, it was learned today. The wave of arrests is described as the largest since 1947. Various sources attribute these arrests to official reaction to attempts on the lives of several high Government men that are supposed to have been made in recent months.

A COUPLE of gleams appeared last week on the dark financial horizon at which independent film producers had been staring in recent months. The Howard Hughes-United Artists-James Nasser agreement whereby Hughes has made available $600,000 to finance U. A. producers, with Nasser, owner of the General Service Studio, guaranteeing the loans and providing stage facilities, was finally ratified.

In the early days of the income tax, when the rates were low, or even moderate, income tax laws were fairly simple and generally understandable to the average taxpayer. As the tax expanded in rates and became burdensome, so also became the laws governing its application.

GENEVA, Jan. 29 (UP) -- More than 2,500 trained and experienced doctors, many of them highly skilled, are the "forgotten men" of Europe's displaced persons camps, according to a survey made by the International Refugee Organization.

" SERVICE TO OTHERS" is an overworked phrase -- in practice, it is unfortunately rare. In these fifteen "self-portraits," collected and published by the Institute for Religious and Social Studies at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, this ideal of service finds constant and concrete expression in the lives of the contributors to this volume.
It is estimated that, through the amount of paper collected, baled and shipped to mills through the Salvation Army, six acres of trees are conserved annually.
FOR years, whenever there has been a vacancy in the conducting staff at the Metropolitan Opera, the suggestion has come spontaneously from diverse quarters: Why not hire Fritz Reiner?

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Jan. 29 -- The 1,200 delegates at the eleventh annual convention of the New York State Association for Health, Physical Education and Recreation were told today that television poses the greatest challenge yet faced by the physical education profession.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29 -- An increasing flow of goods from the Orient, including household effects of many refugees, and a virtual stoppage of trade with North China ports as well as a reduction in cargoes to Shanghai were reported on the waterfront this week as a direct result of China's war developments.

HORSECARS AND COBBLESTONES. By Sophie Ruskay. 240 pp. New York: The Beechurst Press. $2.75. THIS account of childhood on New York's lower East Side at the turn of the century is unique among books dealing with this milieu. Most of the others have stressed the grim side of life in the slums of the big city; they are realistic reportage but painfully stark.

THIS book is an important addition to the criticism of modern art. By "modern" this reviewer does not mean merely "contemporary" (a starchless and evasive term), but the original art of our time, particularly that produced by artists younger than Matisse, Rouault, Braque and Picasso.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 29 -- Miss Marjorie Lindsay of Decatur, Ill., stroked her way into the final round of the seventeenth annual Helen Lee Doherty women's amateur golf tournament today and will meet Miss Dorothy Kirby of Atlanta for the title.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Representatives of the three occupying powers in Western Germany were in session here this week to find a solution to Western Allied complaints of "unfair" competition by German manufacturers in export markets.

Peter W. Hoguet, New York lawyer now with the Economic Cooperation Administration, will open a direct appeal to New York business men and professional people for contributions to the $600,000 gymnasium fund drive of the Power Memorial Academy, it was announced yesterday.

WHILE the automotive industry is rated as one of the largest users of plastics in the world, there is no indication as yet that car bodies can be manufactured from plastics in the immediate future, according to R. A. Richardson, chief of the technical data department of the General Motors Corporation.
An additional $10,000,000 is needed to complete the largest house of worship in the English-speaking world -- the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

The number of motion-picture courses offered by American colleges and universities is now ten times greater than it was ten years ago, it was found in a recent survey conducted by the New School for Social Research. More than one-fourth of the nation's institutions of higher education now offer programs in the field.

IN the middle of the eighteenth century, on a hot July day, Dave Foster reached his uncle's cabin on the New Hampshire frontier. A few days later he was captured by an Indian war party. On the long and difficult journey to the Indian village on the River of the Wolves, southeast of Quebec, Dave came to admire the strength and courage of Nancy, a fellow captive.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- President Truman's decision to ask Congress promptly to create a Columbia Valley Authority directed the country's attention this week to the program for river development for improved navigation, greater hydroelectric power and reclamation.

TWO things recommend this condensation of an original Indian text (published, 1947, in Bombay): the author was a personal friend and disciple of Gandhi; and he examines Satyagraha as a movement under its own moral power, discounting, wherever legitimate, the glamour lent it by Gandhi's own life and practice.

READERS of 8 to 12 who are looking for a desert-island story in the traditional vein had better be notified at once that this story diverges considerably from the Crusoe pattern. True enough, Robinson Carew, the too- carefully reared son of a millionaire, manages to do very well by himself when he is shipwrecked.

Peace in Palestine can be achieved by the United Nations rather than by negotiations between the Jews and the Arabs, in the opinion of high school students who participated yesterday in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over WQXR.

WILLIAM GRANT STILL'S opera about Haiti, "The Troubled Island," is finally set for production by the New York City Opera Company during its spring season. The campaign to get it produced at the City Center began in June 1945, when Leopold Stokowski was to conduct it.

Techniques having a potent "feminine appeal" are causing the cosmetic and toiletries industry campaign for repeal of the 20 per cent Federal retail excise tax to "snowball" ahead of schedule, it was reported here last week.

WITH the introduction of a variety named Red Duchess, the Brownells of Little Compton, R. I., add a newcomer for 1949 to their renowned list of sub-zero roses. This race of hybrid teas, floribundas and climbers deserves the attention of anyone who plants roses, and that means most gardeners.

IT would be a fine thing if all the books on fishing were as well written as "Fishing in Mexico," by Hart Stilwell. Mr. Stillwell has cast flies, plugs, spinners and spoons below the border for fifteen years. Fishing, he reminds us, is a relaxing sport, generally.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Housewives and farmers may become tax collectors as well as taxpayers under President Truman's proposed expansion of the Social Security program.

EVERY year new varieties of flowers, fruits and vegetables appear in the catalogues, despite the fact that the list of plants to grow is already a long one. Why add more? The answer is that the hybridizers are constantly striving to produce plants that are better suited to particular environmental conditions.

AROUND the story of Rick Sheridan, seventeenth - century Dublin shipbuilder, who was crimped for service as ship's carpenter on the good ship Ouzel, Mr. Rooney has fashioned a lively, if typical, romance. Fearful of returning to Dublin, for personal reasons, Rick welcomes his impressment and his five years of adventure with the Barbary pirates.

RUMORS have been persistent of late that Bill Klem, the self-styled Old Arbitrator and the greatest of all umpires, is finally tinkering with the notion of permanent retirement on his ancestral estate off the Venetian Causeway to Miami Beach. He still is officially the supervisor of National League umpires and he will hold that job for the rest of his life whether or not he ever does a lick of work again.

Cancellations of duplicate orders and cutbacks in excessive orders in industrial materials have caused a considerable easing of metals which have been in tight supply through the year - end. Most marked change was in lead, where talk of lower prices is now active among buyers, a canvass of large metal users in the metropolitan area disclosed here yesterday.
OMAHA, Jan. 29 (AP) -- An old hand at big scale jobs began a blizzard relief project he described as "the biggest bulldozer operation since the Ledo Road."

" It'll take dynamite to blast this stock market," was the comment of one broker to the apathetic reaction last week to the special dividend of the United States Steel Corporation and the proposed three-for-one stock split-up.

BOSTON, Jan. 29 -- Persons who, in their early years, have had emotionally satisfying relationships with their families or with friends, teachers or outside groups, possess the kind of personality likely to be more effective in social work than those who were emotionally deprived during their youth.
NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Navy's biggest, fastest and most powerful cruiser was commissioned today in the city whose name she bears.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 29 -- A $225,000,000 housing and resettlement program for the current year has been launched by the Jewish Agency for Palestine to meet unprecedented immigration demands, it was disclosed today. The planning is based on the expected arrival of at least 180,000 refugees.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Villanova, unbeaten in basketball this year, had an easy time racking up its twelfth victory tonight as it defeated Georgetown, 64 -- 49, before 5,300 fans, a capacity crowd at the National Guard Armory.

" WAY OF A FIGHTER" is an appropriate title, since General Chennault seems to have fought almost everyone. Even more suitable might be "I Was Always Right," or "They Wouldn't Let Me Win the War," or "The Varmints and the Villains That Opposed Me." Or, perhaps, simply "Grrrr-r-r-r."

ALTHOUGH there are undoubtedly an equal number of sins committed in the name of representational painting today, the slips and imprecisions of the abstract artist are somehow more glaring for us and invariably collect a richer body of invective.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 29 -- Showing improvement over her recent winter debut, Walter M. Jefford's Green Baize easily led home a field of classy 3-year-old fillies in today's $11,825 Jasmine Stakes at Hialeah.
NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Jan. 29 -- The Newport News, commissioned today as America's most powerful cruiser, is the Navy's first completely air-conditioned fighting vessel.

ATHENS, Jan. 29 -- A guerrilla band of undetermined strength penetrated the precincts of the American Farm School, near Salonika, at about 11 o'clock last night and abducted thirty-six students, all boys, and three workmen. The incident was reported in today's General Staff communique.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Eamon de Valera, former Prime Minister of Eire, carried his fight against the partition of Ireland into Birmingham in Britain tonight when he flew there to open a campaign for funds with which to fight the "injustice of partition."

IF you haven't time to teach your children chess, just leave this book on the living-room table, a board and men near by, and they will teach themselves. Perhaps taking a hint from "Alice in Wonderland," Miss Weart has adopted the ideal procedure, and allowed the chess pieces to talk for themselves. It is they who explain the game to the reader.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- Ray (Red) Flaherty, once a coaching hero of the rival National Football League, today was named head coach of the rebuilt Chicago Rockets in the All-America Conference. The announcement by Commissioner O. O. Kessing swept out Coach Ed McKeever after a lamentable one-season showing.

IN the Eighteen Nineties Jalna is in its prime, a comfortable, prosperous Canadian estate of spreading acres under the easy management of Philip, the youngest son, while the older brothers and sister are living in England The story itself follows the pattern of many a Victorian romanes.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Dissension in Republican legislative ranks over the new state aid appropriation for education was indicated today when twenty-four of the twenty-eight Republican Assemblymen who revolted against Governor Dewey's leadership last year to support the Young-Milmoe Bill were invited to meet next Tuesday.

The present American-flag merchant fleet, which compares favorably with its pre-war counterpart in numbers and tonnage, includes larger and higher-speed units than ever operated before, and the average age of the American merchant marine has dropped from twenty to approximately eleven years, according to an annual report by J. Lewis Luckenbach, president of the American Bureau of Shipping.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- David E. Finley, director of the National Gallery of Art, has announced the opening tomorrow to public view of the exhibition of the Gulbenkian Collection of Egyptian sculpture.

In a game which saw the last 45 seconds played with only two men on each side, Squadron A beat Red Bank, 9 to 8, in-the feature of last night's indoor polo doubleheader at Squadron A Armory. When Billy Rand, Squadron A's back, was forced out with. a cut over his left eye from a mallet blow, Red Bank dropped Steve Roberts.
A heavy last-minute rush by applicants seeking new licenses and 1949 tabs developed yesterday at the local offices of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles.

Housewives, students, clubwomen and librarians, rallyig to the New York Public Library's first public appeal for funds, have volunteered their services as the institution prepares for its general drive on Tuesday.
LONDON, Jan. 29 -- A Tass dispatch from Oslo today said the Soviet Union had called on Norway to explain her attitude toward the projected North Atlantic defense pact.

A continued decline in back-order schedules and a slight further reduction in production, coupled with a more pronounced declining trend in prices, has marked general business conditions during January, according to the composite opinion of purchasing agents who comprise the Business Survey Committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

WHATEVER may be said eventually about artistic creation in the first half of the twentieth century, its critical activity has certainly been manifold. The universities proliferate doctors of letters; the quarterlies excite their little circles.

Plans for a sweeping change in the training of the nation's Air Reserve personnel were announced here yesterday by Lieut. Gen. Elwood R. Quesada, special assistant to the Air Force Chief of Staff for civilian components.

WNBC's Wally Butterworth is one disk jockey who refuses to get excited over the newest record. Moreover, he puts his theory into practice three nights weekly on Monday, Wednesday and Friday at 11:15 P. M.

ALTHOUGH fertilizers are more plentiful than in recent years, there is still no superabundance. The need exists to plan and use them as efficiently as possible. It would be wise, too, to place an order now so that they will be on hand at the proper time.

A physicist's version of Genesis, based on recent advances in man's knowledge of the atom and the cosmos, which provides the most detailed backward glimpse in space and time on the manner in which our universe was evolved, was presented yesterday at the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the American Physical Society at Columbia University.

If one wanted to leap into print with the announcement that in presenting the 28-year-old Guido Cantelli to its orchestral public the NBC had revealed one of the leading conductors of the modern world, one could not unreasonably do so on the basis of his performance of the Wagner "Faust" overture in Studio H-8 yesterday afternoon in Radio City.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned stronger yesterday, and closed 2 to 15 points net higher after starting 2 to 13 points up.

IF YOU will give me your attention for a moment, I have news to impart. I saw an Old Vic production the other day. "Well," you say very reasonably, "there's nothing in that. He's been telling us about Old Vic productions for years, and we've seen some of them ourselves."

THIS sometimes exciting novel is the story of Memmo. Memmo is not the name of a recently patented gargle or hair tonic. It is the nickname of Guirellmo Rafael Godinez. Snuffy is the nickname of Joseph McFarland Smith, a truck man vaguely out of California, about whom the author meant to center the book; but Memmo comes out way ahead.

NANKING, Jan. 29 -- The surrender pattern at Peiping, where civic leaders negotiated a local peace and an interim mixed ruling committee was established pending a full-fledged Communist takeover, was held up by the North Shensi radio tonight as an example of how the Communists proposed to deal with sixteen other Nationalist centers.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- The guns of riveters fabricating the steel shell of Britain's largest civil service office building, in Whitehall, added irreverent punctuation to a trumpeter's "last post and reveille" sounded there today.

ALTHOUGH publishers are increasingly using radio to advertise new books, with only rare exceptions have book programs in this country been literary in the true sense. And with reason: for what sponsor could possibly take an interest in a bookish program that might reach only a fraction of radio's millions?

IN THE battle of radio versus television the older medium need not depend entirely on Fred Allen. It has a stanch supporter in an eminent author, James Hilton, who asserts it would be a "great pity" if radio disappeared because of video.

" ON the south suburb by the Elephant" is a meeting-place mentioned in Shakespeare's "Twelfth Night." The Elephant and Castle is still a famous tavern of South London, lying a little below the river on the map and surrounded by the teeming industrialism of the regions known as Southwark, Kennington and Lambeth.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 29 (AP) -- United States and British embassies sought tonight to rescue their nationals, including five Americans, stranded in a civil war battle zone less than 100 miles west of Rangoon.

One advantage of extra years is that they allow more time to fathom the art works one loves. And yesterday afternoon Frank Sheridan, who has communed deeply with great composers, gave an audience at Town Hall the benefit of some of his soundings.

THE performance of Paul Hindemith's 1948 version of his "Marienleben" cycle, after the poems of Rainer Maria Rilke, was a distinguished feature of last week's concert of the New Friends of Music, who can count this achievement as among the particularly bright stars in their crown.

ST. PETERSBURG -- The first thing a trailer-tourist bound from New York to Florida notices is the increase in trailer traffic all along the route and the progress made on new trailer park construction in Florida.

To the honors already heaped upon him since he led his Cleveland Indians to the American League pennant last season and then to the world series triumph over the Boston Braves, Lou Boudreau will add another next Sunday night on the occasion of the twenty-sixth annual dinner of the New York Chapter, Baseball Writers Association of America, in the Waldorf-Astoria.
PARIS, Jan. 29 -- The Government announced today that 20,000,000,000 francs of a new loan were subscribed yesterday, bringing the total sold so far to 60,000,000,000 francs.

PROGRESS - of - American - Culture Note, supplied by a local oracle: Kathleen Winsor, following her recent divorce from bandleader Artie Shaw, is Writing Another Novel -- "something entirely different," said the oracle darkly, "and while I dassn't disclose the theme as yet, I can promise it won't be historical."

MONTREAL, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings crushed the Montreal Canadiens, 5 -- 2, tonight in a rough game to stretch their National Hockey League lead to eight points over the Canadiens and Boston Bruins.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Jan. 29 (AP) -- Three former champions and a newcomer moved into the semi-final round tonight in the fifteenth annual Atlantic Coast squash tournament.

Local 32-B, Building Service Employes International Union, AFL, notified leading Manhattan real estate operators yesterday that it was canceling a contract covering 2,000 apartment houses and 25,000 workers.

The report of your correspondent from Germany on the separate opinions filed by Judge Hebert in the I. G. Farben case gives the impression that all the opinion stated was that if important records had not been destroyed by Farben the outcome of the trial might have been different.

Your correspondent James Reston, in commenting on the Atlantic Pact in his column published in THE TIMES on Jan. 13, wrote in part as follows: "One day it will be presented to the press for public disclosure and debate, and to the Senate for ratification as a treaty."

WITH the Columbia Broadcasting System continuing its "raids" on National Broadcasting Company artists, speculation in the industry has been concerned with NBC's seemingly noncommittal attitude about the defections of its brightest stars.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29 -- Retail activity in the Twelfth District showed further losses last week. Sales of the larger stores showed sharp declines from last year in all areas except San Diego, which was up 4 per cent, and San Francisco which held even.

WASHINGTON A SKILLED mechanic is worth more than an unskilled laborer, so the mechanic gets higher wages than the laborer. That seems fair enough, but the principle looks simpler than it is. How about trying to apply the same principle to the higher bracket occupations?

Both the Giants and the Yankees were busy in the contract-signing mart yesterday, Secretary Eddie Brannick leading with the announced signing of three men, bringing the total to twenty-nine, and Red Patterson countering with two satisfied young Yankees, making a total of sixteen in the Topping fold.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 -- In the most thrilling basketball game of the season on the Palestra floor, Penn came through in the last two minutes to defeat a rugged Army five, 60 to 54, tonight.

THE great success which attended the development of hybrid corn (one of the most profitable discoveries ever made in American agriculture) stimulated plant breeders to experiment with hybridizations of other vegetables.

NEW courses in photography for beginners and advanced students are announced by schools in New York and vicinity. At the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, Kurt S. Safranski will give a course in "Pictorial Journalism" at 6 P. M. Tuesdays, beginning Feb. 8.

NOBODY could have stepped more gracefully into a new field than Hanya Holm has done in her transition from the concert dance to show business. The dances she has created for "Kiss Me, Kate" are her first for a Broadway musical, but they have about them the ease and finish of a veteran.

PARIS. JEAN-PAUL SARTRE, who first struck public consciousness with (of all things) a philosophy that other philosophers, ecclesiastics, cafe pundits, politicians and foreign correspondents worried to bits, has a faculty for making news.

CLYDE KLUCKHOHN, a Harvard Professor of Anthropology, who, with the present volume, won the $10,000 Whittlesey House Science Award for popular science books, is the prophet of the new anthropology. Gone is the day when anthropologists traveled to distant places, chopped through, malarial jungle and dodged poisoned arrows to study cat's cradles among the dreaded Boola-Boolas.
There was another strike threat yesterday against the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad, the second in a week and the fourth in less than a month.

The Current Problems Discussion Group of the New York Public Library, meeting every other week in the Riverside Branch, 190 Amsterdam Avenue, has chosen the topic "Another Round of Wage Increases?" for next Tuesday evening.
VIOLETS in the spring lead a parade of flowers whose fresh charm will add beauty to the garden until the last blossom withers with frost.

FREIGHTER trips to Europe, the Orient, South America -- why not one to the Caribbean? So I booked passage on the George Gamblin which sails under the Honduran flag out of Jacksonville, Fla., every third Saturday the year around.

The private maritime industry has completed and will soon present to Congress a blueprint designed to create a "balanced" merchant marine for the nation's peacetime and defense needs, Frazer A. Bailey, president of the National Federation of American Shipping, declared last week.

Although high-level steel operations will be required of the nation's mills for several months yet, the end of the acute post-war shortage of steel is in sight, several of the industry's leaders intimated last week after releasing their 1948 financial statements.

As a naturalized American citizen, Viennese by birth and education, who has always had an active interest in symphonic music, I wish to make a statement concerning today's musical life in America as represented specifically by the broadcasts of New York's two major orchestras.

OVER a long period of time Jonathan Edwards kept a notebook that he variously entitled "The Images of Divine Things," "The Shadows of Divine Things," "The Book of Nature and Common Providence," and "The Language and Lessons of Nature."
DRAWING a simple plan for the vegetable garden now will help insure a successful crop during the summer and fall. A selection of vegetables can be made as soon as the catalogues arrive.

WRITTEN with lucidity and mature craftsmanship, "The Walled City" is a novel to be read at a leisurely pace. In describing the lives of two couples caught within the framework of a British colony's social and official life, Elspeth Huxley has succeeded in accomplishing one of fiction's more difficult aims: she has dramatized general truth in the reality of specific situation.

LOUIS deROCHEMONT will be putting "Lost Boundaries" before the cameras on or about Feb. 14, it was learned last week from the producer and Alfred Werker, who has been engaged to direct. The documentary-type project, the first under deRochemont's independent film producing alliance with the Readers Digest, known officially as the RDDR Corp., will be budgeted at "about $600,000," deRochemont said.

Woodchucks are pretty bright, in their dumb way, and most of them have too much sense to get out of a warm bed and investigate the weather the first week in February. Nine years out of ten the weather isn't worth investigating then, in these parts, and a woodchuck's instinct tells it to keep right on sleeping just as long as the fat it stowed away last summer holds out.

When the Empire State Building celebrates its eighteenth birthday in May, Louis Peteley also will celebrate. Mr. Peteley has been a guard in the building's eighty-sixth floor observatory since the roof terrace was opened to the public.

AN exhibition has just opened in Baltimore, so beautiful and so beguiling that a visit will prove a rewarding experience for anyone who likes art. The show delights the eye; it tempts the imagination on distant voyages into the past; it instructs the mind with lessons in design and expression.

A minor renaissance of church-inspired art was achieved yesterday afternoon at a private showing of sixty water-colors executed by twenty-two youthful parishioners of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church. The exhibit was held in the church's Memorial Hall at 207 East Sixteenth Street.

NANKING, Jan. 29 -- A political crazy quilt started to develop this week on the fringes of the Communist-controlled "middle kingdom" in China as the remains of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's loyal armies moved south and the Communists failed to heed Acting President Li Sung-jen's pleas urging them to name their delegates for a peace conference.

THERE is evidently a law, natural or statutory, which compels every contemporary British writer to produce his autobiography, or at least a family memoir, before reaching middle age. These personal histories are invariably graceful, usually witty, sometimes melancholy. When they are distinguished, it is more for manner than for matter.

RHODES, Jan. 29 -- The Egyptian-Israeli armistice talks here are nearing a final showdown, a member of the staff of Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine, said tonight. Hopes for success are still dim.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 29 -- The Baroda State Government officially has declared that famine conditions exist in 619 villages and has remitted land revenues in these areas to farmers paying up to 50 rupees (about $15).

A gala American welcome to the French Gratitude Train, designed to build an invisible bridge of friendship between the youth of both countries, is being mapped by the Board of Education in cooperation with other city departments.

The Staten Island Rapid Railway Transit Company was ordered yesterday by the Public Service Commission to restore a substantial part of the service discontinued last September in an economy move. The company has until Feb. 13 to carry out the terms of the order.
SHERMAN, Tex., Jan. 29 (AP) -- Ray Morrison today became head football coach of Austin College. He resigned last Thursday as head mentor at Temple University.

Sparked by Bob Kelly and Gerry Cohane, the Manhattan College basketball team gained its tenth victory of the season by beating Iona College last night at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, 53 -- 37. The Jaspers led at the half, 19 -- 12.

EL PASO, Tex., Jan. 29 -- The guns and guided missiles of Fort Bliss and White Sands Proving Ground are making this TexasNew Mexico area near the Rio Grande one of the nation's greatest military centers.

Samuel Broxmeyer and his son-in-law, Edward Becker, appeared before Judge Alfred C. Coxe in the Federal Court House yesterday morning and pledged that they would submit to examination tomorrow morning in a study of their real estate operations.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 29 -- Favored Ace Admiral, a handsome Tennessee-bred chestnut, captured the second running of the $137,200 Santa Anita Maturity Stakes today, whipping eleven rivals before 52,000 fans, largest crowd of the season at Santa Anita Park.

TOKYO, Jan. 29 -- The Japanese Socialist party tonight bluntly declined a Communist proposal for the formation of a "united front" among the parliamentary groups opposed to the conservative Government of Premier Shigeru Yoshida.
FORMATION of a permanent television opera company for the regular presentation of operas in English was under serious contemplation by NBC officials here last week.

SOME of the business statistics which are now coming through reflect the thinking and decisions which were made after the surprising result of the November elections. They are a bit on the gloomy side. In striking contrast the news of the last week or so seems to offer an abrupt about-turn.

JULIAN GREEN, whose earlier novels -- careful studies of violent emotions against the background of French provincial life -- secured him a reputation for artistic craftsmanship and moral seriousness, has now tried his hand at a metaphysical tale.

MAYHEM and comic strips mix in Jack Iams' new mystery. Mr. Iams doesn't add anything to the controversy over the moral -- or immoral -- effect of comics on young minds. He simply offers a new-angle thriller -- and a problem.

STRAWBERRIES and raspberries, particularly the red varieties of the latter, are the most popular of the small fruits for the home garden. This interest, of long standing, is heightened by a steady flow of new and improved varieties.
BEING a studio shopper is nice work if you can get it, and about half the women in Los Angeles appear to be trying.
LONDON, Jan. 29 (Reuters) -- Both Portsmouth, first division leader, and Derby County, five points back in the English league table, gained the fifth round of the Football Association cup today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Factional strife broke out anew in the Ways and Means Committee today as the committee's majority and minority leaders exchanged public statements on the procedure followed in current hearings on renewal of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Administration's proposed new labor law was revealed today as a modified Wagner Act in which President Truman abandons the Taft-Hartley injunction weapon he used in four emergencies.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 29 -- Ben Hogan, the Hershey, Pa., golf king, equaled the Phoenix Country Club competitive record of 64 today as he moved into the lead in the $10,000 Phoenix open with a 204.

THE extraordinary double loan exhibition of Italian art opened at the Wildenstein Galleries in a week full to overflowing. Donatello's "San Ludovico," lent by the city of Florence and restored to its original gilded state, has been installed in a gallery by itself.

GUATEMALA CITY, Guatemala -- This winter season tourism officials in Guatemala are stressing a new approach for norteamericanos desiring to visit the "land of eternal spring." The emphasis is on what they call "seeing the country."

Failure of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee to act favorably on the Small Business Committee is a "decided rebuff" to small independents and a "thumping victory for monopolistic big business," it was declared yesterday by C. W. Harder, president of the National Federation of Small Business, Inc., Washington, D. C.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Advocates of a seventy-group Air Force received informal clearance from House Democratic leaders today for legislation to build up the country's air power far beyond limits established by President Truman.

" USE your head and save your back" is a solid piece of homely advice, and at no time is it truer than when the home grounds are to be planned. Paper is cheap. It is easy and even enjoyable to draw sketches of how the property will look when fully planted. By contrast, moving things in the garden once they have been put in the wrong places may be a back-breaking chore.

IF Bernard Shaw (formerly George Bernard Shaw) ever succeeds in reforming the alphabet it will probably begin with the initials G. B. S., says Denis Sullivan, a young English writer at present engaged on a new life of the 92-year-old sage.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Dr. Frank P. Graham, president of the Univresity of North Carolina, and former American member of the United Nations Good Offices Commission, today called on the U. N. to act immediately and forthrightly for the liberation of imprisoned Indonesian leaders.

IN the days before movies, radio and television, a popular hero of Americans, young and old, was William Frederick Cody, known to all as "Buffalo Bill." Everyone was familiar with his daring adventures as rider, hunter, guide, and scout on the Western plains.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 29 (UP) -- A new Cabinet was sworn in by President Enrique Hertzog today to replace the one that resigned a week ago.

The word "Mahatma" means "the great-souled one." It was the title bestowed on Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi by his followers, but one which he himself eschewed. Today, a year after his assassination by a fanatical fellow Hindu who could not understand Gandhi's plea for peace on earth, there will be few dissenters to his right to that address.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 29 -- More than 2,000 wildly cheering fans, largest crowd to jam into Smith Rink in two years, saw Army's hockey team suffer its first setback of the season today when Boston University beat the cadets, 4 -- 3, in overtime.

" The dragons will be late again," said the policeman. He mentioned this in passing to some photographers as though anyone who knew anything about dragons knew that tardiness was as common with them as fire-breathing.

THE recent resignation of Ralph S. Damon as president of American Airlines and his election last week as president and a director of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., is more than a mere shift in jobs for an able and veteran airline executive.

Earl Wild, young pianist who has been heard on many radio programs as well as in recital, appeared at Carnegia Hall yesterday afternoon before a large audience which had to wait fifteen minutes for him to begin. His playing was marked by a clean, dependable technique, a soft touch, a pleasing legato and a respect for the music at hand.

Apparel manufacturers here last week rushed deliveries of spring and Easter merchandise and as a result retailers have already started to reorder some of these lines, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office.

A routine luncheon meeting to make plans for the celebration of Bill of Rights week in the school system starting Feb. 13 was transformed suddenly yesterday into a debate on what was the greater menace to civil liberties: communism or current methods of combating communism.

CHATTANOOGA, Jan. 29 -- While several legislatures in the Deep South this week were debating the ever-controversial issue of restricting Negro voting privileges, a field agent of the Department of Agriculture's extension service issued a report of regional significance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The United States will proceed with the negotiation of the North Atlantic defense pact with the nations of Western Europe and Canada uninfluenced by the attack launched on the pact by the Soviet Foreign Ministry in a White Paper early today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- Hundreds of thousands of Central Westerners, beset with anxiety, were speculating this week on whether organized landlords had at last found a way to circumvent rent control. Tenants were wondering whether Congress and the Federal courts would permit owners of dwellings to carry out announced plans to evict tenants by withdrawing rental units from the market and serving sixty-day eviction notices before a new Federal rent law is enacted.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 29 -- "The last election convinced us that no individual or group of individuals is wise enough to know exactly what program will receive the support of the electorate," Representative John Davis Lodge, Republican, of Connecticut, told 250 delegates to the annual convention of the Young Men's Republican Clubs of Westchester at the Roger Smith Hotel here today.

The eight-month-old State of Israel last week reached a new plane of political maturity. Yesterday Israel was officially recognized by four Western Union nations -- Britain and the three Benelux countries. Earlier in the week France, Australia and Switzerland took similar action.

Three events in widely separated geographic and political areas converged last week and gave sharp emphasis to the controversy inherent in the issue of public versus private power. They also reflected the long strides that the former has made here and in England, and posed what the private utilities termed an imposition of an ideological threat unequaled since the creation of the Tennessee Valley Authority fourteen years ago.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 29 -- Champion Rip Tide of Blue Bar, 22-month-old orange Belton English setter owned and handled by Edwin J. Schoettler Jr. of Haverford, Pa., was one of the foremost winners as the leisurely thirty-sixth annual all-breed show of the Maryland Kennel Club began its two-day run today.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 29 -- Cold weather covered the Southwest early this week with rain and snow which reached record-breaking proportions in many areas. Later as the storm moved eastward and its grip was loosened, there was indication that it had been both useful and damaging.
The downward movement of food prices from their all-time highs of last fall seems to have developed enough momentum to assure continued declines at least for the next few months.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 -- Women's apparel shops in Central Philadelphia in recent weeks staged their best selling events since the war ended. Sales last week were 23 per cent larger than a year ago and during the four weeks period their sales were 11 per cent greater.

The New York Knickerbockers, capable of better basketball than they played, dropped a 78-73 decision to the Philadelphia Warriors before 9,347 fans at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. It was their seventh setback in eight starts and aside from the damage in the Basketball Association of America Standings, the result could not possibly have hastened the recovery of hospitalized Coach Joe Lapchick.
The Community Service Society, declaring that it faced a "critical need for support," made public yesterday a report of its financial status that resulted in a campaign for $1,400,000.

LONDON. ACCORDING to the Communists, who are often believed, communism is a consistent and undivided doctrine and program. This is not so. There are at least three forms of communism, different and incompatible. Hence arises much of the confusion of thought about the world today.

ROBERT ST. JOHN'S contribution to the long shelf of books about Palestine is offered in a style that will be familiar to readers of his earlier volume on Yugoslavia, "Land of the Silent People." Foreign correspondent in the Balkans, radio commentator and lecturer, he writes a readable, glossy journalese.

OF the important eighteenth-century English novelists, Tobias Smollett is perhaps the least known and the least read today. While most intelligent readers have a bowing acquaintance, at least, with the masterpieces of Fielding and Sterne, there are few who know anything at all about Smollett's most characteristic works.
THE list of annual flowers which have won some kind of All-American Selections award from 1933 to 1949 is a long one. It starts with ageratum and ends with zinnia.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 29 -- The one thing certain as a result of Israel's first national election is that Premier David Ben-Gurion is still sitting firmly in the saddle. He received a very distinct vote of confidence and will probably carry on much as he has done, despite powerful blocs in the new Government.

Considering the astronomical amount of the proposed United States budget, I don't think one point can be over-emphasized. Out of a proposed $41.9 billion for the fiscal year starting next July 1, 78 per cent will go to pay for past wars and prepare for a possible new one.

Rural America, represented by 4,000 "grass roots" delegates from forty-two states and Alaska, began arriving here yesterday for the seventh annual convention of the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association. The sessions will start tomorrow morning in the Commodore Hotel with an address of welcome by Mayor O'Dwyer.

Housing projects for Negroes and other minority groups are a good risk for private builders, the Federal Housing Administration reported yesterday. Approximately 16 per cent of the non-white groups now have incomes of $3,000 and more a year, FHA announced.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, declared last night that, at the close of World War II, there was a "strong element" in the Russian Politburo that favored cooperation with the Western democracies.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Like a locomotive pulling out of the yards with a great huffing and puffing, the Eighty-first Congress, freighted with the greatest legislative load in history, is under way.
The United States Golf Association has again honored one of the best-known figures in the game by naming 55-year-old Francis Ouimet of Boston as captain of the 1949 United States Walker Cup team.

ROME, Jan. 29 -- Speaking on the radio this evening Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza said that the creation of a European Union should be a reason for pride for every Italian, every European and every true lover of peace. A third world war, he added, would represent final ruin for Europe and it could be avoided only by union.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 29 -- Borba, official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party, disclosed today that the propagandists of the Communist Information Bureau in Hungary had been attempting to exploit the case of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty against the Yugoslav leaders by hinting at a connection between the Yugoslav-Cominform split and the Hungarian Primate's supposed plans for the restoration of a Catholic Danubian state under the Habsburg dynasty.
FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., Jan. 29 -- The Army Signal Corps announced today development of a new electric battery that will start an engine at a temperature of 65 degrees below zero.

How fast can man travel through the air or through airless interstellar space without danger to himself? It is generally agreed that speed in itself is nothing to worry about, provided there are no sharp changes in direction. Nevertheless there are human limitations that cannot be ignored, says Dr. John T. Rattaliata, Dean of Engineering at the Illinois Institute of Technology.

TOKYO, Jan. 29 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur declared today that "complete frustration of the Soviet effort to absorb Japan within the orbit of Communist ideology" was responsible for Soviet Ambassador Alexander S. Panyushkin's charges Thursday before the Far Eastern commission in Washington that the Supreme Commander had exceeded his powers here.

IF a half-hour of fantastic gullery on the radio by Orson Welles could spread panic among the well-fed, well-clothed and presumably educated people of New York and New Jersey, it is small wonder that one hysterican Dutchman was able to inflame with disastrous fear a whole rout of refugees, both natives and colonials, fleeing from Burma to India with the Japanese on their tracks.

MORE and more the university presses are assuming an important role in book publishing. Once they were the staid sponsors for books of which the general public never learned, and would have cared little if it had. That picture has greatly changed.

TELEVISION, busy and excited as it is at the moment, should take time out to watch where it is going. Recently, on several different counts, there have been lapses in taste and judgment which, if not checked promptly in the art's formative stages, could have serious consequences for the industry.
VARIETIES of fruits developed in recent years have given home gardeners a much wider choice for planting and greater assurance of success. A new outlook for some older favorites is also important.

Staff members of the Tingo Maria Experiment Station in Peru have discovered in the upper reaches of the Amazon a fruit, the cocona, which, in the opinion of Joseph I. Fennel of the Inter-American Institute of Agricultural Sciences, Turrialba, Costa Rica, "constitutes a definite gain in tropical fruiticulture."

CAIRO, Jan. 29 -- A broad feminist front is in process of formation in Egypt to seek political and civil equality for women, according to a recent statement by Mme. Doria Shafik, editor of two women's magazines and founder of a new political party for women.

California, the leading state in the nation in automobile registration, has adopted a law which makes obligatory the training of high school students in the art and obligations of automobile driving. We applaud this action. Although the support of such training in the schools is gaining ground, still only 15 per cent of the nation's 25,000 high schools offer this important course in the curriculum today.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower warned 2,000 alumnae of seven leading women's colleges yesterday against an increasing tendency in this country to depend on the growing power of centralized government.

MR. DUNLAP, a former radio editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES and now a vice president of the Radio Corporation of America, has written an eminently useful book for the layman who has questions to ask about the burgeoning art of television.

IT is popularly thought that a bridge expert must be, among other things, a master mathematician; yet most of the skillful bridge players go the whole hog in the other direction and maintain that you don't even have to understand arithmetic (except simple addition up to 13).

THIS is the first of a series of proposed guides to individual Latin-American countries, written and published, no doubt, in anticipation of a rising tide of North American tourists flowing -- or flying -- southward, accompanied by dollars which will be welcomed with open palms.

PART of the difficulty which parents find in accepting some of the newer methods of child rearing may be their inability or unwillingness to give up some of their customary ideas about children. Many of the theories by which we try to educate and guide children are a part of our own past, of the ways we were taught and reared.

ONE night the moon moved into the mirror over Amos' bed, but the next morning it was gone. Amos set right out to find and capture it. He asked the tradesmen along the street. They couldn't help him, but each gave him something as a keepsake.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29 -- The picture of fleets of planes dropping food to starving cattle and sheep on snowbound Western ranges captured the imagination of the West Coast this week but brought fears of higher meat prices.

Guatemala has embarked on a national hospital building program designed to create an integrated system of sixty-seven hospitals that will provide a "minimum level of adequate hospital facilities" for the population of the Central American country.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Air Force said today it had developed two new high-altitude rocket guided missiles, with controls which could aim them from the ground at a target while in flight.
Reading in the lyric soprano voice that she is training for a vocal career, blind Bernice Tabach won yesterday the juveniles' first prize in the first Braille-reading contest here.

A critical need exists for Braille and other equipment to aid the 400,000 blind in Europe's war-devastated lands, Dr. Robert B. Irwin, executive director of the American Foundation for Overseas Blind, Inc., asserted yesterday. To obtain this equipment and to enable bombed-out schools for the blind to rebuild, Dr. Irwin disclosed that the foundation is seeking to raise an emergency fund of $300,000 to augment the $130,000 required by its regular services.

OMAHA, Jan. 29 -- The Republican National Committee's Omaha meeting and the huge task of rescuing livestock from blizzard-bound areas monopolized the Midwest's immediate attention this week. But beyond these two activities the region looked toward, and discussed, a series of growing problems.

A RED RIVER ox cart, the mode of transportation a hundred years ago in the Minnesota Territory, will be pictured on the Minnesota Territory centennial 3-cent commemorative stamp to have first-day sale in St. Paul on March 3, the Twin City Philatelic Society of St. Paul and Minneapolis announced last week.

BLEECKER STREET is far from Granada, yet it is no longer difficult for me to credit the fact that a play by my elder brother, Federico, is about to be seen on an American stage -- at Bleecker Street. When my brother wrote the play, it was called Bodas de Sangre."

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Modest gains were made by most commodities on the Board of Trade today. Wheat gave the best display of strength, while oats inclined to lag behind the rest of the market. Dealings were at the rather slow pace that is normal for Saturday.

OMAHA, Jan. 29 -- The Republican party, which sold "unity" at every crossroads in the 1948 campaign as its principal commodity for attracting voters, demonstrated in defeat this week that it is far from united itself.

Glass coffee makers that require no stove or hot plate are the result of the development of new electrically conductive coatings. According to Dr. Robert H. Dalton, chemist of the Corning Glass Works, Corning, N. Y., the coatings on glass are thin, transparent, tough and tenacious.

HAVANA, Jan. 29 -- The American yacht Leatherstocking, sailed by William T. S. Smith of Otsego Lake, N. Y., won the first race in the series for the Bacardi Cup today as the eighteenth annual international Star Class regatta started here.

FOR THIS WEEK: Start to prune and repair shade trees, calling in an expert for critical jobs. It is a little early for safe pruning of fruit trees . . . Turn plants in windows occasionally so that all sides receive light, and growth is uniform . . . Take cuttings of geraniums, fuchsias, impatiens and also any house plants that may be leggy . . .

NOW are we fallen into the season when 4,000,000 Americans scan the leaden skies hopefully, hang on the radio's meteorological reports, and pray for bad weather. They are the "ski bums," a race of week-end hillbillies with wings on the feet and rocks in the head.

More than 43 per cent of the 10,000 individual sales executives who are members of the National Federation of Sales Executives earn more than $15,000 a year, according to the results of a study just completed. More than 11 per cent earn more than $30,000 a year, and at the other extreme only 514 per cent earn less than $6,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- President Truman will deliver "an important message to the American people" at the Jefferson-Jackson victory dinner to be held here Feb. 24, it was announced today.

For forty years, more or less, William J. Mellin has heard embittered felons wish his ears would drop off. He retired from Federal service yesterday, though, with ears intact, after almost twenty-nine years as a Government wire-tapper.

IN a small English manufacturing city of factories, narrow alleys, steep-stepped streets and workers' damp cottages, a murderer spreads terror. His victims are old women, by whose bodies he leaves a drawing of a dead soldier, a dead girl and an old woman sitting on a money bag, with the legend, "Why should only the young die?"

Not so long ago someone lamented in these columns the fact that so few theatres in New York were named in honor of stage stars and cited the reopening of the Warner as the "Mark Hellinger" as another opportunity missed. I suggest to the owners of the Forty-sixth Street Theatre that their house merits a new name in view of the refurbishing it has recently undergone.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Administration's new Labor bill and the Taft-Hartley Law both provide for handling of "national emergency" strikes.

SO many of the new roses have such bright colors in solid tones or contrasting combinations, plus perfection of form in bud and open bloom, that the coming rose season is bound to be an exciting one. Moreover, gardeners get quick results from them.

TOKYO, Jan. 29 -- The Japanese general elections have now come and gone with a smashing victory for the Conservatives and a considerable gain for the Communist party. Tokyo today is attempting to assess what manner of Government the nation will have under the new dispensation.

LAST week on your pages Mr. Owen Davis Jr. expressed his "plea for playwrights to come to the aid of the television industry." This is written as a plea to Mr. Davis and his fellow-television-script editors to come to the aid of the playwrights.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Public Affairs Institute in a study of collective bargaining called today for labor-management conferences in the major industries. It said these were the most satisfactory means of establishing a long-range national labor policy.
The Department of Parks, custodian of the city's ten municipal links, took a lusty swing at the pocketbooks of golf players yesterday in announcing the fees for the season beginning April 2.

MINIATURE camera photography appears to be making a definite comeback despite persistent reports that "35mm black-and-white is on the way out." The popular -- and erroneous -- impression is that 35mm cameras are now being used chiefly for color photography.

In Paris on July 2, 1947, Russia's Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov walked out of a British-French-Soviet conference of Foreign Ministers. The meeting had been called to discuss the plan for European recovery proposed by U. S. Secretary of State Marshall the month before. Mr. Molotov said:

HERE, in a really intriguing juxtaposition, are a tough police reporter, a too-taciturn inventor, and a death-ray machine with a difference. It all begins when a group of newshawks invade the Barrett laboratory in search of a story -- and get snubbed for their pains.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Governor Dewey told the Albany-Chamber of Commerce tonight that the program of increased state taxes needed to finance his record 1949-50 executive budget would help forestall increases in local taxes.

January clearance sales were regarded as very successful by most retailers at the month's end. They expressed the belief, however, that without sharp price cuts a comparison with the good sales of last January would have been quite unfavorable.

MR. MARTIN, who has written many Westerners for adults, now spins a yarn about a boys' ranch for 9 to 12-year-olds. It is chiefly the account of how the Hi-Ho Ranch for Boys works a transformation in the character of deplorably spoiled Randy Peasley.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Britain granted de facto recognition to the State of Israel at 11 o'clock this morning. Behind the terse official language of the Foreign Office announcement lay many hopes and fears.

AMONG the new gladiolus introduced during the past season, several were outstanding and appeared to the definite improvements over existing varieties. After many observations in trial gardens and elsewhere, I predict a great future for these varieties in the garden and shows.

IN his new book Langston Hughes returns to the kind of poetry that made him famous twenty years ago -- songs that express the intricate, paradoxical soul of the Negro. The backgrounds, the simplicity, the humor, the passion and the song, all are here.
LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 29 -- William (Biff) Glassford, 35, today was named head football coach at the University of Nebraska. He had been head coach at the University of New Hampshire for three years.

A request by Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat, of New York, that Congress initiate an investigation of the life insurance industry was met with mixed reaction last week. Mr. Celler will introduce his resolution in Congress with Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada.

PAUL HINDEMITH'S business is composing, and he works at it steadily. His output is prolific, and it uses most of the available forms as well as all manner of instrumental and vocal combinations. Some of his compositions are among the best written in our day; nearly all have at least the craftsmanship of a man of vast knowledge.

Governor Dewey has emphasized recently the need for the state to expand its program of mental hygiene. At present this program is limited almost exclusively to the institutional care of the 97,500 patients in mental hospitals. Its activities in the prevention of mental illness consist of a few undermanned child-guidance clinics.

Ever since the collapse of the Roman Empire the dream of a united Europe has been in men's minds. Too often it was a dream to be realized by brute force. Such was Napoleon's interpretation and such, in a throwback into the Dark Ages or the abysmal depths of the cave man, was Hitler's.

Frederick D. Keeler, formerly assistant sales manager of Bridgeport Rolling Mills Company, has been appointed sales manager of the rolling mill division of Plume Atwood Manufacturing Company, Waterbury, Conn. Charles C. Foster was appointed New England district sales manager.

Both composers whose music was played on Saturday night's Composers' Forum at McMillin Theatre, derive their styles largely from national idioms. Alan Hovhaness, Boston-born of Armenian parentage, writes music of oriental cast; Ray Green's compositions hint at the blues-style of jazz.

HARMON-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Jan. 30 --Redevelopment of the railroad station area and highway system here to make Harmon an improved transportation center for several hundred thousand residents of Westchester and Putnam Counties and southern Connecticut is being planned by Westchester County and the New York Central Railroad.

The Federal Security Agency opened the door yesterday for insurance payments to sick workers out of funds being rebated to employers in New York and other states under the merit rating provisions of state unemployment insurance laws.

GLENS FALLS, N. Y., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Ray Blum and Miss Mary Lynch continued their collection of New York skating honors today by winning championships at the third annual Glens Falls winter speed skating carnival.

The Port of New York's traditional welcome, with an assist from the armed services, will greet the French Gratitude Train when it arrives here Wednesday morning on board the French freighter Magellan.

The Social Science Research Council established projects last year in the fields of world area research and marriage and the family, and continued its work on housing and the labor market and its aid to social scientists in Europe, according to the annual report of Pendleton Herring, president, which was made public yesterday.

CBS has arranged special broadcasts from the Navy's Lockheed 168-passenger transport on its first operational evaluation flight across the United States tomorrow. The broadcasts will be made as the plane wings its way from Moffet Field, Calif., to Washington, D. C.

ROME, Jan. 30 -- Pope Pius XII told 6,000 Italian students today that, even if Rome were to be razed and St. Peter's Basilica, itself, with all its art treasures lost to the world, the Roman Catholic church would survive because "it is indestructible."

TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 30 (AP) -- At the top of the agenda as the Legislature returns for the fourth week of the 1949 session tomorrow is placing the question of a bonus for veterans on the November ballot.

BOSTON, Jan. 30 -- After more than a century of paying almost annual "tribute" for flood damage, the New England States have taken concerted action to control the two principal sources of trouble, the Connecticut and Merrimack River basins.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Washington diplomatic leaders expect that Premier Stalin's comments on the possibilities of improved United States-Soviet relations would get the closest official scrutiny.

JACKSON, N. H., Jan. 30 -- A throng of 4,000 descended upon the Eastern slope skiing area, from North Conway to Pinkham Notch, today to enjoy the finest period of sport this season. By special train from Boston and New York and by what appeared to be an endless cavalcade of automobiles, the snow-starved enthusiasts arrived to make the mountainsides ring with the cry of "track."

The Queens Midtown Tunnel showed a profit for the first time last year and swelled the net income of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority to $7,686,994, George E. Spargo, general manager, reported yesterday.

Devastation and suffering in the Old City of Jerusalem were described yesterday by Mar Athanasius Y. Samuel, Syrian Orthodox Archbishop of Jerusalem and Trans-Jordan, after a service in the Assyrian Apostolic Church of the Virgin Mary in West New York, N. J.

Not a single bogus Caucasian "Ugh" intruded upon the Children's World Theatre production of "The Indian Captive," by Charlotte B. Chorpenning, which opened Saturday on the stage of the Barbizon-Plaza playhouse.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Ace Admiral, winner of yesterday's $100,000 added Santa Anita Maturity, was labeled today as the horse to beat in the third of the meeting's $100,000 purses -- the big handicap in Feb. 26.

Breaking away from the conventional communication to stockholders, W. C. Mullendore, president of the $537,000,000 Southern California Edison Company, in a letter being released today to 47,000 shareholders, told them to beware of the conclusion that the company, or business in general, was enjoying a sound prosperity.

If there is any one charitable cause which can be said to have truly universal appeal -- throughout our country and the many lands around the globe -- it is the Red Cross. Its great works are known everywhere. In time of war it gives itself unstintingly to binding the wounds of the maimed, rescuing the lost, clothing the naked, finding homes for the dispossessed and performing countless tasks of helping sorely pressed humanity everywhere.
The Acorn Holding Company has purchased six buildings in First and East

MAJ. GEN. CLAIRE LEE CHENNAULT (ret.), the man who organized and led the Flying Tigers, was one of the most successful air commanders of the Second World War. He was also one of the most blunt, boastful, short-tempered, belligerent and egoistic soldiers who ever served his country well. Patton was no more flamboyant and self-confident.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Chicago local of the International Typographical Union, AFL, voted today to end its prolonged strike against The Hammond (Ind.) Times and accept a contract granting a $12.50 weekly wage increase. Wages had been $85.50 for day work and $91 for night work. The increase is not retroactive.

The duty of every Christian is to be "a living energy affecting other lives," the Right Rev. Stephen C. Neill, assistant to the Archbishop of Canterbury, declared yesterday in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

PARIS, Jan. 30 -- Diplomats here who long had been in close touch with Russian relations said today they considered Premier Stalin's statement to the International News Service was designed to hamper the pending Atlantic Pact, which his Foreign Office had attacked Friday as a scheme for Anglo-American world domination.

American Protestant church schools in the Belgian Congo are now eligible to receive government subsidies formerly granted only to Roman Catholic institutions, it was announced yesterday by the Africa Committee of the Foreign Missions Conference of North America.
