If Columbia University's experience reflects a national pattern among university students, there is a greater interest in the humanities and social sciences today than ever before, according to Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, former acting president of the university.

The foreign exchange market last week was firm on an extremely light turnover. For a period of trading time (one week) it capped the dullness of the preceding three and stamped January as the poorest month, both from the volume involved and resulting fluctuations in several years.

PERRYOPOLIS, Pa., Jan. 30 (AP) -- This small Western Pennsylvania community population 1,469, the recipient of a $1,400,000 bequest by a Philadelphia woman, is hiring an expert to tell how to spend it.

ATHENS, Jan. 30 -- There is not much thought of Greece in Palestine or of Palestine in Greece. These small countries are too engrossed in their own strange and separate struggles for existence to put their minds on outside affairs. Yet a return stop at Athens after a visit to Palestine sharpens the sense of how much the future of the Middle East in general and Israel in particular depends on what happens here.

Local art events this week feature a large exhibition of theatrical material at the Metropolitan Museum, including miniature stage sets, costumes and drawings, opening to the public on Friday. On Saturday the Whitney Museum will open a comprehensive exhibition of work by Max Weber.
Seven new films, including importations from France and Russia, are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The program follows

The letter by Ross J. S. Hoffman moves me to some real sympathy and to some crocodile tears. His professor may be as unfairly treated as anyone. But he still has some prospect of relief. First, give him a three-cent stamp to inquire of the University of California how much it would cost for a year of attendance even for a non-resident.

Michelangeli, Whose last name alone and itself sufficed to head his program, and who had made a successful appearance as a pianist at a Philharmonic-Symphony concert earlier in the season, gave his first New York recital last night in Carnegie Hall.
OSLO, Norway, Jan. 30 (Reuters) -- The communique said that existing consultations between the three countries on questions of foreign policy would be maintained and strengthened.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Underground coal fires could cause another Donora "smog" disaster, James Boyd, director of the Bureau of Mines, said today.

The net cost to the city of its Golden Anniversary celebrated last year was $333,531, but the promotional and advertising value to the municipality was incalculable, Grover A. Whalen declared yesterday.

An audience of 1,700 attended the Franklin D. Roosevelt memorial concert given last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria to raise money for the work of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 30 -- Britain's recognition of Israel has sharply increased hostility here toward the United States as well as toward Britain.
Helen Kwalwasser, who gave her second violin recital at Town Hall last night, did nothing to undermine the favorable impression she made at her debut two seasons ago.

With the imminent possibility of the passage of President Truman's Civil Rights Bill, which will be a boon to the hopes and ambitions of the minority groups, there arises a question whether many of us are prepared for what such passage will imply. There is a period of "conditioning" that we should go through, for it is possible that a person may receive a gift which will become dangerous and damaging if not properly used.

TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 31 (UP) -- Miles W. Vaughn, The United Press' vice president and general manager for Asia, was reported missing today after failing to return from a duck-hunting trip in Tokyo Bay.

PRAGUE, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, reported gravely ill at a sanatorium at Karlsbad yesterday, was so much improved today that he left the hospital for a while.

The board of directors of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, meeting today for the first time since the departure of Guy W. Vaughan for Europe on last Wednesday, expected to announce important personnel changes as well as additions to its own membership, following Mr. Vaughan's withdrawal from active management.

BERLIN, Jan. 30 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, commander of the Western Allied Armies in the defeat of Germany, was today charged with responsibility for the "senseless destruction" of "many German cities" in an article in the Tag.

GENEVA, Jan. 30 -- Some of the leading members of the executive committee of the United Nations International Refugee Organization, which has just concluded meetings here, believe that a reexamination of the world refugee problem is needed.

Sharp increases in its gross income and net profit were reported yesterday by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development in a report on operations for the six months ended on Dec. 31, 1948.

The departure of many out-of-town buyers upon the Completion of orders for spring merchandise, slowed activity in the wholesale apparel market here last week, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

NOTRE DAME is located just outside South Bend in Indiana. But its hold on the American public transcends all normal boundaries. No college in the country has been so wholeheartedly "adopted" by non-collegians as Notre Dame. The famous subway alumni of New York are not isolated. Such is the universal appeal of the Fighting Irish that the subway alumni spring up wherever they appear.

QUINCY, Mass., Jan. 30 -- A collision between two Squantum Naval Air Station planes 4,500 feet over Cape Cod today killed one Naval Reserve pilot, injured two others and resulted in the crash of a third plane several miles from its base here.

New York's housing emergency is likely to continue "for many years" even if the maximum in public projects contemplated under proposed Federal and state programs is realized, the Citizens Housing and Planning Council warned yesterday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks regained fourth place in the National Hockey League tonight with a 4-2 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs before 17,216 fans.

In June, 1945, a few weeks after the end of the war in Europe, the late Harold Denny, war correspondent of this newspaper, wrote: "We have developed wonderful field armies in this war. Several have won imperishable glory in the European campaign. It is senseless to try to make comparisons among them; they are all great.

Dr. Nahum Goldmann, member of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, emphasized the principle of political separation of Jewish people throughout the world from Israel but stressed that Jews outside must be "tied up spiritually and morally" with Israel.

Surplus boats and other Government equipment now given to the Boy Scouts and Girl Scouts and some other organizations would also be made available to the Coast Guard's civilian auxiliary in legislation to be offered in Congress, Representative Abraham J. Multer told the Third Coast Guard District's Auxiliary convention yesterday at the Astor Hotel.

Prices of cotton in the domestic market moved in a narrow range last week on the New York Cotton Exchange. At the week's end active futures contracts showed changes ranging from a decline of 4 points to a gain of 11 points. These changes compared with a decline of 1 point and an advance of 35 points in the previous week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Members of Congress were wary tonight in their comment on the Administration's proposed new labor law, awaiting more definite assurance that it contains what President Truman really wants.

WALTHAM, Mass., Jan. 30 (AP) -- An employes' stock-buying plan to help finance the reorganization of the closed Waltham Watch Company was outlined last night by Walter W. Cenerazzo, president of the Independent American Watch Workers Union. Mr. Cenerazzo said $40,000 already has been pledged by employes under the plan permitting stock purchases on a time-payment basis.

For the fifth time in the twenty-five-year history of the award and the first time since 1937, a foreign athlete has been voted the Rodman Wanamaker International Trophy as the outstanding performer of the Millrose Games.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 30 -- American Federation of Labor building trades unions and the organized contractors have agreed in meetings here to contnue indefinitely their joint board for the settlement of jurisdictional disputes, but the Administration-backed labor bill is putting a blight on prospects for the machinery's continued success.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- The 300th anniversary of the beheading of King Charles I was commemorated throughout Britain today by devout Royalists and churchgoers. Virtually every important historian in Britain seems to have written about Charles for this week-end and at least two have published books.

The effect of the war in driving down the national income in many countries and the course of the recovery in Europe are shown in a national-income study published yesterday by the Statistical Office of the United Nations.

Linda Richards, the March of Dimes poster girl who symbolizes the fight against infantile paralysis, met some of the veterans of another war last night at the Tavern on the Green, Central Park West and Sixty-seventh Street.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 30--Countless Indians throughout the country paid devout homage today to the man who has been called "the greatest Indian since the Buddha'', on the first anniversary of the assassination of Mohandas K. Gandhi.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 30 -- Netherlands trade circles are becoming more and more active with regard to exports to the dollar areas -especially to the United States markets -- and offerings of special lines are being arranged by certain combines.

The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service will consider today steps to end a strike of oil barge employes that could jeopardize Brooklyn's supply of cooking gas if the walkout continued twelve days.

The famous North German Lloyd liner Bremen is now nearing the end of her career as a pile of scrap near Nordenham on the Weser River, according to a report received here over the week-end from Ralph E. Cropley, former field representative of the Maritime Commission and now purser of the liner Atenas.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Veterans of World War II, or their next-of-kin, received soldier bonus payments from the state to the total of $311,682,632.80 last year. And individual recipients totaled 1,425,395. These figures were made public in a report issued today by Spencer M. Bates, Commissioner of Taxation and Finance.

Mayor O'Dwyer issued several proclamations yesterday. He proclaimed tomorrow as USO Day, ivging observances to "advance the important aims of United Service Organizations through support of the New York USO Campaign during February."

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 30 -- Warren R. Austin, United States representative to the United Nations, said today that he considered Premier Stalin's statement "a move in the right direction toward peace." Secretary General Trygve Lie and other United Nations delegates declined to comment.

Among the several hundred European refugees to arrive in New York a few days ago aboard the converted transport Marine Marlin were ninety children. When the youngsters landed at the West Twenty-second Street pier the refugees' escort officer for the United Nations International Refugee Organization described them as "a pretty serious lot," and added: "They didn't know what to do with a lollipop."

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Governor Dewey's budget for the new fiscal year, which will be submitted to the Legislature this week, is expected to provide the first real test of his leadership of the Republican party in New York State since his defeat for President last fall.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 30 -- A pert wire-haired foxterrier, Ch. Chief Barmaid, an English-bred from the Benrook Kennels of Barrington, R. I., became best in show tonight as the 833-dog thirty-sixth annual all-breed event of the Maryland Kennel Club came to the end of its two-day run.

MUNICH, Germany, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The German bobsled champion, Hans Kilian, said tonight he had turned down an invitation to the world championships in the United States because of the "cold attitude" there towards the German musicians, Walter Gieseking and Wilhelm Furtwaengler.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 30 -- The immediate reaction to Premier Stalin's suggestions for solution of the Alied-Russian difficulties over Germany was that the Soviet Premier had contributed nothing new.

Soviet industrial production last year was well above original plans, and the outlook for fulfillment of the 1950 output goal of the current Five Year Plan is quite bright, the official report of the Soviet State Planning Committee released last week indicated.

The Committee for Progressive Zionism, which includes three former presidents of the Zionist Organization of America, sharply attacked the organization's policies yesterday and called upon Zionists throughout the country "to unseat the present ZOA administration," which is headed by Dr. Emanuel Neumann, at its convention next summer.

The post-war years have seen a steady decline in the number of persons reported missing to the police, Acting Capt. John J. Cronin, in charge of the Missing Persons Bureau, said yesterday in his 1948 report to Chief of Detectives George P. Mitchell.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 30 -National steel output last week was up 1 point to 101 per cent of rated capacity. Such a rate on an annual basis would exceed 97,000,000 tons of steel ingots a year. Last week's output was a new record, and no evidence was reported that it can not be repeated time and again.

PARIS, Jan. 30 -- There has been considerable interest here in statements by the Organization for European Economic Cooperation concerning the need for greater volume of sales of European products on the American market.

No one need season his appreciation of "Uniform of Flesh" with good will. For the newest production of the Experimental Theatre, put on at the Lenox Hill Playhouse Saturday evening, is a thoroughly engrossing piece of work, well directed and well acted and well worth mulling over for the comment it makes on good and evil.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- Liquidation in corn on the Board of Trade last week was severe, and at times there was a lack of support. Withdrawal of the Government from the market as an aggressive buyer of corn was a factor in starting selling, as the domestic demand for cash corn is slow.

LOS ALAMOS, N. M., Jan. 30 -"Clementine," a fast atomic reactor, and a 12,000,000-electron volt electrostatic accelerator now under construction are the latest marvels in the "best-equipped physics laboratory in the world," which are helping this little town retain its international preeminence as the world's atomic bomb center.

HAVANNA, Jan. 30 -- Twin Star, the American yacht skippered by Lockwood Pirie of Wilmette Harbor, Chicago, was first over the finishing line today in the second race of the eighteenth international Star Class regatta for the Bacardi Cup. The victory enabled Twin Star to take the lead for the series with a total of 22 points.

The final sixty seconds of the New York Rovers' last two home engagements have proved a bugaboo to Phil Watson's club. With Goalie Hal Gordon doing a great job protecting the Red Shirt cage, the Rovers topped the Valleyfield Braves, 3 to 2, in a Quebec Senior Hockey League fracas at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 30 -- Emerson Dickman, former Red Sox pitcher, has been signed as head coach of baseball at Princeton University, it was announced today by R. Kenneth Fairman, director of athletics.
Last year the Salvation Army in New York held 8,087 religious meetings in an effort to bring spiritual aid to those who attend no organized religious services,
After you finish reading this newspaper, please do not let it fall into the hands of Gen. Courtney H. Hodges, First Army commander.
BERLIN, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Russians charged today that German sabotage was hindering industrial production in their occupation zone.

BOSTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Winger Bud Poile became a two-goal scorer twice in 24 hours as the Detroit Red Wings shut out the Boston Bruins, 4 -- 0, tonight before 13,909 at the Boston Garden. The victory enabled the Red Wings to increase their National Hockey League lead to four full games over the Bruins and to four and a half over the Montreal Canadiens.
Increased transit revenues of $30,290,910 in the first five months after fares were raised on July 1 were reported yesterday by the Board of Transportation.

An end to the growing waste in Federal departments and agencies, which it said is fostered by "the unprecedented expansion of government in the last decade, and an easy-going attitude on administrative costs," was demanded over the week-end by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., in a letter to Representative Clarence Cannon, chairman of the House Committee on Appropriations.

The appointment of Mrs. Ernest G. Wadel, Dallas, Tex., as chairman of the National Women's Division of the $250,000,000 United Jewish Appeal to organize two million Jewish women on behalf of the appeal, was announced yesterday by the three national chairmen of the drive.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- Liquidation was on in the grain markets on the Board of Trade last week with May wheat selling within 7 cents a bushel of the crop year low. May corn came within 1/4 cent of equaling the lowest price of the season, selling under $1.40 for the first time since early in October.

Two occupants of a small single-engined pleasure airplane were killed yesterday afternoon when their craft collided with a four-engined Pan American Airways Constellation 3,500 feet above Port Washington, L. I.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Although remains lamentably low, business on the stock exchange since the turn of the year has expanded somewhat. This, however, seen to have done little to dissolve the stalemate at which markets have arrived and in which they are likely to remain pending some definitely lead concerning the Government taxation policy.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Jan. 30--In sub-freezing temperature, but on smooth water and with only a suggestion of a breeze most of the time, forty-one sailing dinghies competed today in a mid-winter regatta series at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

At a bargain scale, "Carousel" is thriving at the City Center. So much so that there is talk of the Theatre Guild moving the Richard Rodgers-Oscar Hammerstein 2d musical to a Times Square house at the end of a four-week engagement, on Feb. 20. For the first eight performances at the City Center, through last night, the receipts were estimated at $32,000.

Walter Hendl, the Philharmonic-Symphony Society's assistant conductor, had another opportunity to exhibit his talents in front of the orchestra at Carnegie Hall Saturday night. His program was built of four blocks of sound, unprovocative music, music apparently chosen to satisfy and please without unduly exciting.

Edward Johnson will direct one more season after the present one at the Metropolitan Opera and then retire as its general manager, George A. Sloan, chairman of the board of directors, announced yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The resignations of President John S. Kieffer and three other top administrators of St. John's College in Annapolis were accepted today by the board of visitors and governors

The foods on the United States Department of Agriculture's February list of "plentifuls" are especially appropriate to the season. On a wintry day what could be more satisfying than a steaming bowl of chowder made with canned corn and peas, potatoes, carrots and onions? These tinned and fresh vegetables, as well as many other foods that may be prepared in hearty, cold-weather dishes, are on the Government's list.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 30 -- Faced once again with the threat of devastating floods, the vast Mississippi Valley still lacks adequate protection today despite efforts within recent years to harness its waterways.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 30 -- The five-and-a-half-month regime of President Juan Natalicio Gonzalez in Paraguay came to an end today when a bloodless coup forced him from office and put Gen. Raimondo Rolon, the Minister of Defense, in his place as Provisional President

Declining income and increased costs of operation prevented the Russell Sage Foundation from carrying out last year as extensive a program in the field of social studies as in the past, according to the annual report of the organization made public yesterday.

RHODES, Jan. 30 -- Trans-Jordan has accepted an invitation to join the Palestine armistice talks under way here, it was learned on reliable authority tonight. This move is expected to save the talks here from collapse although it may cause them to drag on for some time.

BERLIN, Jan. 30 -- The United States Military Government has started to restore to their proper owners millions of dollars worth of stocks and bonds stolen by the Nazis and found in German banks after the war.

ZURICH, Jan. 30 -- On last Wednesday, Jan. 26, a general meeting of shareholders of the Cia Hispano-Americana de Electricidad, known as CHADE, a holding company that formerly operated public utilities in Argentina, was held in Luxembourg to (1) approve a directors' report; (2) confirm the fact that CHADE is in a state of dissolution; (3) appoint liquidators. At the meeting 51.34 per cent of the voting power was represented. All resolutions were passed unanimously.

"Guideposts in Time of Change," by John Maurice Clark, Professor of Economics at Columbia University, will be issued on Wednesday by Harper. It is a collection of his lectures in the Charles E. Merrill Lectureship at Amherst College, defining ways to meet the threat of totalitarian countries.
MOSCOW, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Following is the official text of a question-and-answer interview with Premier Stalin by International News Service, as translated from the Russian:

ESSEX, Conn., Jan. 30 -- Belief that the Russians do not want war, that they will push as hard as they can but never to the point where there is real danger of hostilities, was expressed here tonight by Lester Markel, Sunday editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Jan. 30 -- Joseph J. Haggerty, 19-year-old Fordham student representing the New York Athletic Club, won the Luckenbach handicap squash racquets tournament today at the Nassau Country Club.
A bill calling for a far-reaching investigation of the Board of Education and the entire New York City school system is to be introduced in the Assembly at Albany this evening.

The Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Clinton and Montague Streets, Brooklyn, yesterday defied the demand by the church's vestry that he step down as rector. He declared he would "not be put out of the pulpit by any group that does not believe in the liberal tradition of freedom of speech."

The Rangers won a good one at Madison Square Garden last night. And they won it in most emphatic style, rolling up the greatest number of goals they have scored in National Hockey League play this season. The score, 9 to 0.

INGERSOLL, Ont., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Canada's challenger for the Harmsworth Trophy, Harold Wilson, takes exception to Gar Wood's criticism of recent changes in rules for the world's premier power boat racing event.

The Cunard White Star Lines last week announced to all of its agents that rates on two Caronia cruises in March and April had been reduced 20 to 30 per cent. No reduction was made on earlier cruises, scheduled for Feb. 12 and 28.

OSLO, Norway, Jan. 30 -- Plans for a defensive alliance between Norway, Sweden and Denmark, which have been under discussion for the last five months, were definitely shelved today. This was announced in an official communique that said the three Scandinavian countries had found it impossible to agree at present on the formation of an independent defensive pact.

Although his aim is usually atrocious, President Truman seems completely unable to resist the temptation, whenever the opportunity seems to present itself, to take a pot-shot at the steel industry or United States Steel.

A superliner committee including representatives of the Navy and the Maritime Commission has been formed in Washington to complete studies on the proposed new superliner for the American merchant marine. The membership of the committee and the fact that it is already well along in its deliberations became known yesterday, and it was reported that a decision on the ship is now expected within two or three weeks.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- The manner in which Argentina's economic practices and policies during and since the war are now recoiling on her own head is the subject of a good deal of discussion here. That Argentina will receive much help from abroad in solving the difficulties into which she has now run is very doubtful.

Pan American Airways announced yesterday that its "coach service," found successful in the New York Puerto Rican run, would be extended to Buenos Aires on March 1. While other airlines announced various reductions in fares and freight rates, no further extension of air coach fares within the United States was scheduled.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Almost one-third of all women of working age are drawing a pay envelope, the Women's Bureau of the Labor Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--At least five Cabinet members will be among top-ranking Government spokesmen to appear before Congress committees this week to help the legislators speed Administration bills to early adoption.

OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 30 -- Army snow - moving equipment battled drifts in Nebraska and South Dakota today in an all-out effort to open roads to marooned cattle. Sunny weather and moderating, but still severe low temperatures, eased the problems of the clearing crews.

The towering apartment houses in which thousands of New Yorkers live are particularly vulnerable to strikes. A cessation of work by superintendents, elevator operators and other service employes means no hot water in the pipes, halls reeking with uncollected garbage and weary trudges up endless flights of stairs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio said today that Federal, state and local taxes were now approaching $60,000,000,000 annually, or 27 per cent of the country's income, and he warned that "if we don't hold government down we are going to kill the whole free-enterprise system.''

BERLIN, Jan. 30 -- Still awaiting deeds rather than words to prove Soviet good-will and intentions, western observers here gave a cool reception tonight to Premier Stalin's latest pronouncement on the Berlin blockade and the solution of the German problem as a whole.

PARIS, Jan. 30 -- With imagination and expert craftsmanship Rose Valois adapts wicker to hats of town formality. She softens this cool basket substance by allying it with silk print, grosgrain or felt, or threading it with narrow velvet ribbon.

An article appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Dec. 26 under the headline, "East Indies Trade Held Monopoly," says American merchant exporters have charged that Netherlands trade regulations are in restraint of United States export trade. Since this charge is not true, I should like to clarify the matter.

The church has been called upon by God to serve as a "coworker" in the establishment of a just and durable social order, the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken, pastor 3f the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122nd Street, said yesterday in his sermon.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Miss Dorothy Kirby of Atlanta, Ga., called on her fighting heart today to win the seventeenth annual Helen Lee Doherty women's amateur golf tournament in a tense thirty-six hole match with Miss Marjorie Lindsay of Decatur, Ill.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Brooklyn Gothams forfeited an American pro basketball game to the Bridgeport Steelers here tonight following a disturbance which involved players of both teams, spectators and police.
Municipal bonds coming up for sale this week aggregate $80,597,480, compared with $97,529,600 last week and a weekly average of $71,076.545 for the year to date, according to The Daily Bond Buyer.

Wherever Joachim H. Themal goes he manages to pick up at least one trade and usually a language. Considering that he has been on the move since his escape from Nazi Germany sixteen years ago, Mr. Themal has built up an unusual vocational and linguistic range.

Although equity financing in January has shown an improvement in volume over recent months, the problem of stimulating a greater flow of venture capital into industry still remains a major one for investment bankers, who since the first of the year have sought ways of remedying the situation.

Premier Stalin, described by President Truman as the leader of the conciliatory group and by General Eisenhower as the leader of the aggressive group in the Politbureau, has given another interview to an American correspondent. In it he expresses Russia's desire for peace, disarmament and better relations with the West.

Defeating the Hakoah F. C., 6 -- 1, in an American Soccer League contest at Hawthorne Field, Brooklyn, yesterday, the Philadelphia Nationals annexed two additional points and strengthened their hold on first place. The Quakers established a 4-1 lead at half-time.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- In a collection consisting mostly of day dresses, Molyneux uses the simplest and slimest of outlines for fine plain wool and pastel checks. The result is a quiet elegance that will survive many fashion eccentricities.

Chinese Communists have slain eighty-seven priests, brothers and nuns, the Most Rev. Thomas J. Mc-Donnell, auxiliary Bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, said yesterday. He addressed the annual communion breakfast of Charles Carroll General Assembly, Fouth Degree. Knights of Columbus, held in the George Washington Hotel.

MOSCOW, Jan. 30 -- Premier Stalin said today that he had "no objection" to a meeting with President Truman at some mutually acceptable place to discuss a "pact of peace" between the United States and the Soviet Union.
Tenants in five of the largest apartment buildings controlled by Samuel Broxmeyer banded together yesterday to avoid demands for current rent in cases where rents had been paid in advance.

ASPEN, Colo., Jan. 30 (UP) -- Art Devlin of Lake Placid, N. Y., swept the field today to win first place in both the Open and Class A brackets in the Rocky Mountain Ski Association's jumping championships.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- The most comprehensive selection of domestic and imported giftwares, china, glass and pottery since the end of the war were on display here at the opening of the Spring Market Week, with many additional lines of popular-priced items in evidence, Wallace O. Ollman, general manager of the Merchandise Mart, said today.
There are no psychiatric treatment facilities for the 4,500 men and women who daily fill the city's prisons and houses of detention.

More emphasis on the general ineffectiveness of advertising claims based on deceptive use of research data was urged by a number of marketing officials here last week to curb this practice. In most cases, it was said, misleading or "phony" statements supported by "national surveys" are the result of riding old ideas.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 -- The Curtis Institute of Music was damaged by fire today, but its valuable collection of musical manuscripts and instruments was unharmed.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan 30 -- Dinghy racing on Manhasset Bay today was conducted under real frostbite conditions -- a light, variable northerly breeze and below freezing temperatures.
There were no signs of dissatisfaction in the large audience that heard Alexander Sved, Metropolitan Opera baritone, sing at Town Hall yesterday afternoon, and there will be few from this quarter.

It is pleasant to learn from the final report of Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal as acting president of Columbia University that despite the great national interest in technology and science spurred by the development of atomic energy, "there has been no lack of achievement among scholars devoted to the humanities and social sciences."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 30 -- At the request of Katharine Hepburn, Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer has purchased "Man and Wife," a screen comedy by Garson Kanin and Ruth Gordon, as a prospective vehicle for her and Spencer Tracy. The story deals with an assistant district attorney and his lawyer wife, whose professional and domestic lives run separately and smoothly until the meet in court.

Hopeful that the Wolfe-Noel International Challenge Cup will stay in England after their meeting with the United States women's squad at the Merion Cricket Club, Philadelphia, Feb 23, the members of Great Britain's women's squash racquets team arrived here yesterday aboard the Britannic of the Cunard White Star Line.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Faint hopes for fifteen American airmen whose B-29 went down in the Atlantic four days ago were revived today. Signals were reported to have been received from the British steamer Godfrey B. Holt that she had sighted Verey lights and flares fifty miles north of Las Palmas at 8:45 o'clock last night.

Richard Bimonte, author of a 10-inch record entitled "Storris Fram Mama Gus," four fables and four poems adapted from Mother Goose and accomplished in Italian dialect, is the current favorite of the record-collecting set at City College, where he is employed as a veterans' counselor.

Declaring that "the doom" of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty had already "been sealed by his enemies," the Rev. Charles J. McManus of St. Patrick's Cathedral staff yesterday asked Catholics to pray continually for the Hungarian Primate.
The details of the Administration's substitute for the Taft-Hartley Act were revealed over the week-end, and hearings on the projected legislation are scheduled to begin today.
SHANGHAI, Jan. 30 -- Wusih normally is a quiet textile and trading community where several rutted dirt roads converge in southern Kiangsu. Today it is bursting with caravans.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- The Continental Casualty Company and the Continental Assurance Company set new records in 1948 in assets and surplus and in the volume of business, Roy Tuchbreiter, president of both companies, said today.

Four detectives, huddled in a narrow, dark hallway of an East Side rooming house, won a gun battle yesterday with a barricaded religious fanatic accused of the wounding on Saturday of a Roman Catholic priest.

The Church offers a basis for solution of the Dutch-Indonesian conflict, the Rev. Dr. Egbert Emmen, secretary of the General Synod of the Dutch Reformed Church of the Netherlands, said yesterday. Speaking at the West End Collegiate Church, West End Avenue and Seventy - seventh Street, he declared that governments came into being to promote brotherhood but failed because they put more faith in power than in Christ.

NANKING, Jan. 30 -- Gen. N. V. Roschin. Soviet Ambassador to the Chinese Government, is scheduled to leave Nanking for Canton within a few days, it was reported here tonight. His departure would make him the first representative of the Big Four to proceed to the new Nationalistic capital.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 30 -- The final results of Israel's first election have given forty-four seats of the 121 in the Constituent Assembly to Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion's Mapai party. The left opposition Mapam party was in second place with eighteen seats.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- The Chicago Transit Authority reported today that its net income exceeded operating expenses and reserves by $116,320 during 1948, the first full calendar year of its public ownership operation of the street car and elevated lines.

Ernest Bloch knew what he was about when he picked the 'cello for the solo instrument in his Hebrew Rhapsody, "Schelomo." Leopold Stokowski matched his astuteness by choosing Leonard Rose to play the part in yesterday afternoon's Philharmonic - Symphony concert at Carnegie Hall. It was a moving performance.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Ben Hogan and Jimmy Demaret tied for first place in the $10,000 Phoenix open golf tournament today. Both had 72-hole scores of 278, six under par.

"We Christian leaders of Germany repent before God and man," Gustav-Adolf Gedat, representative of the German Y. M. C. A. and guest speaker at Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, declared yesterday.
Mayor O'Dwyer won a week's delay last night in a strike that threatened to cut off 70 per cent of the city's supply of white bread at midnight tonight.

It is "impossible to believe" that in a national budget of nearly $42,000,000,000 savings cannot be found sufficient to obviate the choice between a Treasury deficit and higher tax rates, the Guaranty Trust Company of New York asserts in its monthly survey, published today.

LONDON, Monday, Jan. 31 -Here in London more significance was attached to the Soviet threat to Norway than to the soft words of Premier Stalin in his interview. At the Foreign Office one found some anxiety over Norway but no hopes raised by Premier Stalin who, according to a spokesman, said nothing new in his replies.

I note from your issue of Jan. 25 that the Interstate Commerce Commission has expressed fear that efforts by the railroads to meet the problem resulting from increased costs by increasing rates might be self-defeating and has urged large capital expenditures to reduce operating costs.
RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 30 (AP) -- A plane load of American and British subjects told today of their rescue from the town of Bassein, which has become a flaming battle-ground in Burma's civil war.

Wool futures were among the soft spots on the local exchanges yesterday. Wool top futures were down 1 to 1.8 cents a pound on sales of 235,000 pounds. Grease wool futures dropped 0.5 to 1 cent a pound on a trading volume of only 30,000 pounds.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Britain takes a "serious view" of Argentina's failure to fulfill her contract for meat shipments to this country, the House of Commons was told today by Hector McNeil, Minister of State.
SHANGHAI, Jan. 31 -- Acting President Li Tsung-jen visited this city today for a series of conferences at which the possibility of a separate peace for Shanghai was reported to have been discussed.

MOSCOW, Jan. 31 (UP) -- The Communist party organ, Pravda, only newspaper appearing here today, ran on its front page the text of Premier Stalin's answers to the four questions asked by The International News Service, but did not comment editorially.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- An ordinance of Trenton, N. J., against the use of sound trucks emitting "loud and raucous noises" was upheld today by the Supreme Court in a 5-to-4 vote. But this was only after some justices accused the high tribunal of repudiating a ruling of June, 1948, and of passing on an issue not directly before it.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Voluntary controls over steel and other key materials and facilities in tight supply, at least until next Sept. 30, were approved by a voice vote of the Senate this evening.
LONDON, Jan. 31 -- The biggest relaxation since clothing rationing began in Britain nearly eight years ago will enable a man or woman to buy a new suit or dress from tomorrow on without coupons.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Former President Herbert Hoover declared today that this country had reached the "saturation point in the way of taxation" and appealed to Congress to give the President broad powers to overhaul the executive branch of government.

The complete newspaper kit for the Advertising Council's series on the program to improve public understanding of the American economic system will be ready about the middle of this month, it was learned yesterday. Adaptations of the first three of the eleven basic advertisements are now available for newspaper use.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The capital is the political sounding-board for the Republic, and therefore millions of citizens who missed the speech made to the Republican National Committee at Omaha by the Governor of Nebraska, Val Peterson, are thoroughly aware of the differences of opinion between Senators Taft and Lodge over how their party should be reorganized.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Southern Senators gave notice today to the Administration's leaders that if they insisted upon early action on the civil rights issue they would do so at the peril of the whole of President Truman's legislative program.

A statement designed to "sound a note of reconciliation" in the controversy between the vestry of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, and its rector, the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, will be issued on Thursday over the signatures of fifteen Protestant and Jewish clergymen, it was announced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowie, dean of students at Union Theological Seminary.
LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 31 -- According to the principle of alphabetical rotation, new chairman will assume office in United Nations bodies tomorrow, it was announced here today.

No institution or free man can be neutral in the world struggle between democracy and totalitarianism, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, asserted yesterday as he urged the city's schools to adopt a "strong, positive approach" to teaching democracy.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Gene Bearden, Indians' pitching star, who carries a platinum plate in his head and another in his leg as a result of war injuries, tonight was named "most courageous athlete of 1948" by the Philadelphia Sports Writers Association.

The Metropolitan Opera Association will start its annual spring tour on March 21. It will include sixty-one performances in fourteen cities over an eight-week period. The company once more will go to Los Angeles, where it returned for the first time last year after a forty-two-year absence.

Two men who obviously knew what they where after beat and robbed a diamond merchant of stones valued at $55,000 in a taxi ride through midtown Manhattan Streets late yesterday afternoon. Thorough as they were, the two left behind several gems and $1,253 in cash.

Borough President Hugo E. Rogers announced yesterday that he would recommend a sweeping reorganization of the New York War and Peace Memorial Committee at a meeting of the committee's directors tomorrow.
TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 31 -- A state budget of $160,704,287 for the next fiscal year was proposed today by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll to the New Jersey Legislature.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- The British Foreign Office is in contact with Washington and Paris concerning the Kremlin's attack on the western European union and the Atlantic Pact, it was learned today. However, a joint reply to Moscow is not expected.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina rebuked counsel for the eleven Communist leaders yesterday for time-wasting, wrangling over trivial matters and "trifling" with the court. He also warned them of "too much guesswork and too many gaps" in the evidence they were presenting against the jury system.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Jan. 31 -- The Fifteenth Air Force, representing about half of the nation's strategic bombing strength, is rapidly increasing its combat efficiency.

A record last-day rush to beat the deadline for the renewal of automobile licenses took place yesterday at three borough offices of the State Motor Vehicle Bureau. Normal last-day crowds were reported in Brooklyn and Queens.

Even in these heavy-spending days an investment of an additional ten or twenty billion dollars to control floods in the Mississippi Valley, and put the still largely untamed waters of that mighty system to beneficial uses, sounds like a lot of money. But the Mississippi Valley is, a lot of land -- 41.3 per cent of continental United States.

" Yellow Sky," a Western melodrama by Twentieth Century-Fox, begins an engagement today at the Roxy. Gregory Peck, Anne Baxter and Richard Widmark play the lead roles. . . . "The Chips Are Down," a French drama, representing the first screen writing of Jean-Paul Sartre, will open at the Trans-Lux, Madison Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

Concerned over the national problem of "black market" babies, the United States Children's Bureau urged the welfare departments of all states yesterday to provide complete supervision over the whole question of adoptions.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The Maryland Jockey Club announced today seventy-five eligibles for its May 14 Preakness, one of the three major turf classics for 3-year-olds seeking championship honors.

The State Advisory Council on Placement and Unemployment Insurance recommended yesterday that 450,000 workers in small businesses be brought within the protection of the State Unemployment Insurance Law.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Maj. Gen. Lewis Andrew Pick, who is directing storm-relief operations in the West, was nominated by President Truman today for the post of Chief of Engineers, United States Army. General Pick is noted as builder of the wartime Ledo Road in Burma.

Louis Kramer, in an investment purchase, has acquired the fee to 7 East Fifty-seventh Street from Webb Knapp, Inc. The property is improved with a five-story building, occupied under a net lease by B. Weinstein, women's furrier and apparel store.

Two six-story buildings at 164 and 167 Seventy-first Street in Brooklyn, to house 186 families were among plans filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. Cost of the project is estimated at $1,640,000. The P. M. L. Company of 16 Court Street, Brooklyn, is listed as the owner. Kavy Kavovitt, Inc., are the architects.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Treasury Department announced tonight that tenders for about $800,000,000 of 91-day Treasury bills to be dated Feb. 3, and to mature on next May 5, were opened at the Federal Reserve Banks today.

The common household variety of straight chairs should be designed functionally for comfort, in the opinion of 1,200 homemakers from nine states who took part in recent furniture discussions on all the things a straight chair should be.

ALBANY, Jan 31 --The Senate passed tonight with only one dissenting vote the Scanlan bill to increase the aggregate amount of annual housing subsidies from $13,000,000 to $25,000,000. This completed action in the upper House on the three Republican program bills on public housing.

An attempt by the special Federal grand jury investigating subversive activities to link Soviet espionage in this country with that in Canada was indicated yesterday with the disclosure that the jury had subpoenaed Sam Carr, alleged co-leader of the atomic spy ring exposed in the Dominion in 1945, and his wife, Julia.

Sectional bookcases and chests of drawers made of fiberboard reinforced with wood are items in two new groups of inexpensive storage accessories designed to come out of the closet and serve wherever there is space.
A special burglary squad of fifty-five detectives has been formed to attempt to halt the recent series of thefts on the East Side, it was announced yesterday morning.

This is very much the snowy, sleety season when kippers have an appeal for breakfast. We're not thinking of breakfast in terms of that brief pause over coffee before diving into the subway or hopping the commuters' train, but rather of that morning meal that sets the right leisurely "day-off" note for Saturday and Sunday.

When Casey Stengel arrives here Thursday for a press conference at Yankee headquarters, the new manager of the Del Webb-Dan Topping baseball squad will find at least seventeen of his thirty-seven-man group under contract. But whether the Yankee pilot will find his ace Joe DiMaggio bound to a legal document is extremely doubtful.

With reference to the report appearing in THE TIMES of Jan. 27 on an address delivered by me before the Rabbinical Council of America, on the setting up of a central religious body in Israel, a comparison of such a body to the position occupied by the Vatican in the Catholic world was wrongly attributed to me. I should like to clear up any possible misleading impression that might be gained as a result.
A surprise attack on Dixie by winter's bitter cold dealt Texas crops a sub-zero blow yesterday, causing multi-million dollar damage, The Associated Press reported.

Carpet manufacturers and department stores have set up a new committee to improve merchandising and promote better understanding of mutual problems, Merrill A. Watson, president of the Carpet Institute, Inc., and David H. Woog, manager of the home furnishings and appliance group, National Retail Dry Goods Association, jointly announced yesterday.

The House Committee on Education and Labor was urged yesterday to sponsor immediate legislation to amend a section of the Fair Labor Standards Act under which stevedoring companies are liable for millions of dollars in overtime-on-overtime payments.
RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Government sources said that a force of entrenched Karen rebels surrendered today after a bitter nine-hour battle with Burmese troops on the outskirts of Rangoon.
LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Fur buyers from all over the world crowded today into the auction room of Beaver House, headquarters of the Hudson's Bay Company, for the opening of the company's winter fur sale.

TOKYO, Jan. 31 (UP) -- Miles W. ("Peg") Vaughn, United Press vice president and general manager for Asia, was drowned Sunday when his sampan capsized while he was hunting ducks in Tokyo Bay. He was 57 years old.

HAVANA, Jan. 31 -- The American yacht Twin Star, sailed by Lockwood Pirie of Wilmette Harbor, Ill., won the Bacardi Cup for the second consecutive year today by finishing second in the third and final race of the series in the eighteenth international Star Class regatta.

Board of Transportation figures and comments on the first five months' operation with the increased subway and bus fares raise once again the question whether the city's best interests are served by any fare less than a straight 10 cents. Thus far, at best, we are just getting by as to the avowed, unsatisfactory aim of a fare that covers operating expenses only but not debt service.

At the end of its Town Hall season last night, the Little Orchestra Society announced its plans for 1949-50. Thomas K. Scherman will conduct the less-familiar works of famous composers from the seventeenth to the early twentieth centuries at three-week (instead of two-week) intervals.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- Need for efficiency in management to offset the impact of a possible business recession this year on sales and profits was stressed in addresses presented at the opening sessions today of the seventh annual seminar sponsored by the Office Management Association of Chicago and Northwestern University.

Air Secretary Symington appeared before a committee of Congress yesterday to estimate what an additional $800,000,000 would do for the Air Force. He did this in response to a suggestion made by Congressmen themselves. Unfortunately, the $800,000,000 in question is the same $800,000,000 which President Truman has ear- marked in his budget for the first year's cost of a program of universal military training.

PARIS, Jan. 31 -- Three Russians from displaced persons camps today gave harrowing descriptions of life in the Soviet Union during testimony marking the start of the second week of Victor Kravchenko's libel suit. Communist defendants refrained from extensive cross examination of the witnesses.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 31 (AP) -Carroll C. Widdoes, coach with the best record in Ohio State University football history, will take over March 1 as mentor of the Ohio U. Bobcats at Athens, Ohio.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor, told the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee today that the Administration Labor bill would rely solely on the power of public opinion to prevent strikes that would paralyze the nation.

CAPT. TOM HAMILTON moves in today as the director of athletics at the University of Pittsburgh, a revolutionary change for him. It means a complete break with the Navy he loved so deeply and served so faithfully for a quarter of a century. That he is shifting his base of operations from Annapolis to Pitt would seem to indicate that the Pitt authorities are a lot smarter than the big brass at the Naval Academy.
ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 31 (AP) -- Heavyweight Champion Joe Louis knocked out Dixie Lee Oliver, veteran Negro fighter from St. Petersburg, Fla., in the fourth round of their exhibition bout tonight.

Formerly a scarce item which has now become abundant, steel nails are now jamming warehouse space so much that agents for rail makers want strict export license controls lifted. They warned yesterday that continuation of controls would give European nail makers an unfair advantage in selling to this country's natural foreign markets in South America and Africa.

New York's great concentration of private realty wealth has risen in value to $18,230,305,297 on the city's tax books, according to tentative assessment rolls for 1949-50 presented yesterday to Mayor O'Dwyer by Harry B. Chambers, president of the Tax Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The United States extended full diplomatic recognition today to the Governments of Israel and Trans-Jordan in a manner indicative of the Administration's desire for an early composition of differences between Israel and the Arab states.

The fight to end racial and religious prejudice is "one of the biggest news stories of our time," Irving Geist said yesterday at the presentation of the first annual awards of the Irving Geist Foundation at a luncheon at the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Marking a decade of American atomic energy development, the Atomic Energy Commission told Congress today that it was engaged in peak production of the most destructive types of atomic bombs and of the radioactive products that were good for mankind.

The annual East-West All-Star basketball game, sponsored by The Herald Tribune Fresh Air Fund, will be played in Madison Square Garden on April 2, it was announced at the basketball writers luncheon at Leone's yesterday. The clash will present Adolph Rupp of the University of Kentucky against Vadal Peterson, University of Utah, in the roles of opposing coaches.
ALBANY, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The New York State Society of Editors today upheld the Desmond-Mailler newspaper confidence bill and urged its adoption by the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- A former medical chief of the Veterans Administration charged today that a health program report made by Oscar Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, contained "downright lies."
OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 31 (AP) -Fifty F-82 fighter planes and three C-47 supporting aircraft will leave Kearney, Neb., tomorrow on a nine-day training flight into the Caribbean area.

In connection with the current five-year plan, the Soviet Government is attempting to transform its 240,000 collective farms into "factories in the field" by growing state interference with the economic pursuits of collective farmers, Alexander Vucinich reported yesterday.

Dr. Raymond B. Allen, president of the University of Washington, said in an interview here yesterday that, contrary to general reports, he had sustained the majority, not the minority, of a faculty committee in recommending the dismissal of three professors from the university for Communist party membership.

Your Washington correspondent James Reston made the following statement in his story, "High Escaped Czech Depicts Prague as Soviet Colony," in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 16: "The Czechoslovak Embassy here first denied knowledge of such a man, but later identified him as Bedrich Geminder."

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- The five Western European Union foreign ministers who met here last Thursday and Friday agreed privately later to oppose any proposal to impose sanctions on the Netherlands in connection with the Indonesian question, it is reported on good authority.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 31 -- The Karen rebellion in Burma is the outcome of several fundamental cleavages among racial, religious and political groupings.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The Senate Small Business Committee criticized today the way a few big companies controlled a major part of the petroleum industry from oil well to filling station. It said that it "presents a real challenge to American ideas of free enterprise."

Sales of New York and Brookly department stores declined 7 per cent last week below the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 1 per cent.

A gathering of physicians was told last night by Maj. Gen. R. W. Bliss, Army Surgeon General, that in spite of dire predictions of no defense against an atomic blast and its radiological after-effects, "a good, well-meshed system of civilian defense organization can and will be achieved."

The practice of collecting small fees for seamen's charities from visitors boarding ocean liners on sailing days has been resumed by most of the major steamship companies operating from New York. It was announced yesterday by the Seamen's Welfare Committee.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 31 -Miss Betty Howe of New Haven, Conn., runner-up in the 1948 women's squash racquets nationals, was the top-seeded American player as the 1949 Connecticut State championship opened today on the Greenwich Country Club and Greenwich Field Club courts.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Sir Ronald Campbell, British Ambassador in Cairo, has been instructed to make "further and forcible representations" to the Egyptian Government against the detention of nine British subjects who still are held by Egyptian authorities, Hector McNeil, Minister of State, said in the House of Commons today.

KEARNY, N. J., Jan. 31 -- Members of the Hudson County Police Department today celebrated the home-coming of six-day-old Donald Stralkus of Harrison, at a reception in his honor at county headquarters, here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The National Planning Association, celebrating its fifteenth anniversary, presented tonight gold medals to Gen. George C. Marshall, for originating the plan which bears his name, and to Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, for carrying it out.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board said today that the pilot of the "Yale Special" plane which crashed in Seattle, Wash., Jan. 2, causing the deaths of fourteen persons, had received take-off clearance from the airport control tower.

The tangled real estate affairs of Samuel Broxmeyer and his family moved a step toward clarification yesterday when stock in ten apartment corporations was turned over to Abraham I. Menin, Federal receiver in bankruptcy.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -The Veterans Administration moved today to cut an estimated $10,000,000 a year from its operating costs through a major overhaul of its administrative set-up.

Battering his foe to the canvas four times, Jimmy Flood, unbeaten young Yorkville middleweight, pounded out a decision over Jimmy Snedeker, Plainfield, N. J., last night in their return bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas arena. It was Flood's twenty-fifth victory, and it was a unanimous decision.

Kensley Rosen, violinist, and Howard Wells, pianist, serious young musicians from the West Coast, made their local debut as a sonata team last night at Times Hall. It was the pianist's first appearance here, but the violinist has given two previous New York recitals.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 31 -- In his first speech since the election, Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion outlined today the policy that probably will be followed by his new Government. In substance it is cooperation with the United States and the Soviet Union, an Israeli-Arab alliance, conformity with United Nations policy and the promotion of world peace.

ATHENS, Jan. 31 -- Since the campaign to clear the Peloponnesus of rebel forces estimated roughly at 3,000 got under way about a month ago 1,647 have been put out of action, according to a special General Staff communique issued here tonight.
BERLIN, Jan. 31 -- The elected Government of the Western sectors of Berlin has asked the Allied Kommandatura to include the city as a twelfth land [state] in the West German State.

DETROIT, Jan. 31 -- The iron curtain of Russia and the "iron veil of secrecy" in the United States regarding atomic energy may have a common ending in war, Senator Brien McMahon, chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy, said today.

Rough seas encountered in the transfer of an injured Greek tanker officer at sea last Wednesday resulted in the injury of a ship's doctor and seven members of the crew of the converted transport Marine Perch, Capt. John V. Redmond, master of the vessel, reported here yesterday.

We hope that the subcommittee on Rivers and Harbors of the House of Representatives Appropriations Committee will give careful consideration to the protest of the Port of New York Authority against deep cuts in funds recommended by the Army Engineers and the Authority for New York Harbor improvements.

Some of the first advertisements in the new program for "selling" the American way of life abroad through the advertising of American companies overseas will be started next month by International General Electric Company, Inc., it was disclosed yesterday by G. E. Kendall, advertising and publicity director of the company.

Three of the largest food producers in the country, whose combined products cover the entire grocery line, reported yesterday that unit sales during January have increased "amazingly" over the same period last year.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- A constitutional amendment to streamline the courts in New York City along the lines suggested by David W. Peck, presiding justice of the Appellate Division, First Department, was submitted to the Legislature tonight by Senator Pliny W. Williamson of Westchester and Assemblyman John R. Brook of Manhattan, both Republicans.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Registration statements covering more than $33,000,000 of new financing were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by five organizations.
A young man who has suffered from cerebral palsy since childhood received a diploma from Seward Park High School yesterday at a ceremony at which Mayor O'Dwyer was present.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 31 -- Gen. Raimundo Rolon, provisional President of Paraguay, named his Cabinet today. The ousted President, Juan Natalicio Gonzalez, remained in the refuge of the Brazilian Embassy, according to radio reports from Asuncion, the capital.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Three major airlines, operating westward runs out of New York City, today applied to the Civil Aeronautics Board for authority to increase the number of non-stop flights between New York and their principal terminal cities. At present, these airlines are required to make obligatory intermediate stops on many flights.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Diversion to the Air Force of $800,000,000 now earmarked in the budget for universal military training would finance nine more groups than current authorizations provide, W. Stuart Symington, Secretary of the Air Force, said today.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Whether a tourist class will be organized aboard planes flying the North Atlantic is the object of discussion that opened today in Brussels.

OSLO, Norway, Jan. 31 -- Foreign Minister Halvard Lange will ask the Storting (Parliament) this week for authority to inform the Western powers that Norway is ready to accept an invitation to join the proposed North Atlantic pact despite the veiled threat in the week-end note from the Soviet Union asking for Norway's intentions toward the pact.

TOKYO, Jan. 31 -- The Japanese are beginning to display puzzlement and some chagrin, over criticism from abroad of the general election at which Premier Shigeru Yoshida and his Conservative party were returned by a large majority.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco, in an interview appearing today in The London Daily Telegraph, said that he did not consider the time propitious for Spain's joining the United Nations, taking part in the Western European Defense Union or the proposed North Atlantic pact, but would like her to be included in the European Recovery Program.

A difference of opinion over contractual interpretations, resulting in the holding up of proposed wage increases for certain cast members of "The Madwoman of Chaillot," has developed between Alfred de Liagre Jr., producer of the Jean Giraudoux play, and Actors Equity Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP) -- A bill calling for a 1,000,000-home public housing program under which low-income families could rent for as little as $13 a month, was introduced today by Senators Harry P. Cain of Washington and John W. Bricker of Ohio, Republicans.

To end alleged interference by city officials in the operation of the public schools, the Public Education Association urged yesterday that the Board of Education be made fiscally independent of the city government.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in the first month of the new year was the smallest since last September and the slowest for January since 1944.

Coolerator Company will protect dealers against prices cuts on its appliances which occur between now and Sept. 30 by giving rebates on merchandise in stock, W. C. Conley Jr., general sales manager, announced yesterday. He made the company's price protection policy known at introduction of its 1949 line to local retailers in the Statler Hotel.

WHITE OAK, Md., Jan. 31 (AP) -- The Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Air, John Nicholas Brown, today chided scientists for spreading the idea that wars might be won easily with gadgets and "extraordinary weapons."

An expansion program that will add a ten-story maternity pavilion and two research laboratories to the facilities of Mount Sinai Hospital was announced yesterday by Alfred L. Rose, president of the institution. The cost was put at $7,000,000.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 31 (AP) -- George P. (Maje) Odom, young New York horseman, and Jockey Warren Mehrtens batted 1,000 per cent on the Hialeah card today.

Religion should be "big enough" to include differing points of view and should "abolish name-calling, denunciations and excommunications," the Rev. Dr. Stanley I. Stuber, director of public relations for the Northern Baptist Convention, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission voted today not to take any steps to prevent about a dozen railroads, effective tomorrow, from charging a reservation fee ranging from 50 cents to one dollar, depending on distance or the amount of the fare, on coach trains.

RHODES, Jan. 31 -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine, presented new compromise armistice proposals today to the Egyptian and Israeli delegations "to crystallize matters."

The fifth semi-annual report of the United States Atomic Energy Commission shows Chairman David E. Lilienthal and his colleagues still struggling with two opposing problems: defense, which involves the utmost secrecy; and the peacetime development of atomic energy for beneficent purposes, which demands the widest possible spread of information.
The Gordon Baking Company, producer of Silvercup bread, shut down its big Long Island City bakery yesterday because of a strike of 300 truck drivers.

BERLIN, Jan. 31 -- German Communist leaders obediently hailed Prime Minister Stalin's latest statements today as a "very important step toward peace" but Western sector political chieftains generally expressed skepticism of the Soviet Union's intentions.

Modern youth is veering away from cynicism toward "a positive and constructive approach to the world," Dr. Charles S. Johnson, president of Fiske University, told 441 Hunter College graduates at the college's ninety-fifth commencement last-night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -Defense officials looked at two publications today and wondered whether unification was here to stay.

Eight police officers and detectives received the personal congratulations of Mayor O'Dwyer at City Hall yesterday for the part they played on Sunday in the capture of the religious fanatic accused of wounding a Roman Catholic priest.

How the human brain operates was described before a meeting of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers yesterday afternoon by a bearded psychiatrist who used only common engineering terms thoroughly familiar to electronics experts in his audience.
OMAHA, Jan. 31 -- Nebraska is a snow and ice-locked country of mystery today.

Snow that blanketed the Atlantic seaboard brought a fall of more than four inches to the city yesterday morning. Ending in rain, it turned streets into masses of slush through which vehicles and pedestrians splashed.

Almost on the eve of the Hoover Commission's report to Congress recommending that the activities of the Rural Electrification Administration be curtailed, Secretary of Agriculture Charles A. Brannan urged yesterday that the Federal Government extend the RZA's program into the field of telephony by granting loans that would bring telephones to about 3,000,000 of the 5,850,000 farms in rural America.

Gen. Courtney H. Hodges stood with his wife at the after end of an Army ferryboat yesterday afternoon and waved farewell to Governors Island, to the officers and men of his First Army command and to the active career of soldier upon which he had entered as a private forty-three years ago.

NANKING, Jan. 31 -- In one of the strangest maneuvers yet generated by the collapse of the Nanking Government, Gen. Chang Chih-chung, Minister Without Portfolio in Premier Sun Fo's vanishing Cabinet, is now en route to Sinkiang, prepared to swing northwest China into the Soviet orbit, it was learned today on reliable authority.

Operations of the National Biscuit Company for last year resulted in a net profit of $22,713,736, after taxes and all charges, but including an extraordinary income of $1,400,000, according to the report issued yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 31 (AP) -Paul Brown tonight announced he had cast his lot as a football coach with the Cleveland Browns for another seven years by signing to extend his present contract as coach and general manager for five years through the 1955 season.

Restrictions on dollar remittances from foreign markets, high basic costs in picture production and distribution and some falling off in domestic theatre attendance were responsible for the $3,162,812 loss sustained by Universal Pictures Company, Inc., in the fiscal year ended with last October, according to the annual report released today.
Mayor O'Dwyer received last night a comprehensive program -- applicable to the city as a whole and to other communities throughout the nation -- to combat juvenile delinquency at its source.

Commuters who depend on ferryboats operated by the New York Central's West Shore Railroad, as well as those who like them just for the ride, will pay more for their trips to and from Weehawken if the Interstate Commerce Commission approves a rate increase petition filed in Washington yesterday.

The current comparative breathing spell in the marketing of prime-risk corporate bonds is giving occasion to the winter's first major test of the market's points of resistance to lower yield levels. On one hand are the securities distributors, with their nation-wide feel of the demand in the secondary market, and with their willingness to gamble on the money market implications of a softening in the general business picture.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today agreed to review a decision that a company may not make independent use of a basing-point method of quoting selling prices although it has no agreement with other sellers who use the same method.

The stock market idled along yesterday, with meaningless price changes dictated by the smallest turnover since early last October. A few of the key issues managed to resist the generally lower trend which was arrested slightly in the final hour but on balance close was slightly below Saturday's final level.

The Maine Turnpike Authority had operating income of $669,795 for 1948, as against operating expenses totaling $220,498, according to the authority's first annual report of its operations made public yesterday. The authority ended the year with more than $460,000 in reserves and expects to have more than $600,000 on hand by the end of 1949.

Milton Berle has been forced by illness to refuse from his headline role on the television production of the Texaco Star Theatre and will not appear at 8 o'clock this evening before the NBC cameras. His assignment will be taken over by Jack Carter, who had appeared as master of ceremonies on the program last year and was seen on Broadway in "Call Me Mister.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 31 - Acting independently, both the Soviet Union and the Philippines proposed today that the United Nations Trusteeship Council accord a voice in the Council's affairs to native inhabitants of territories under the supervision of the United Nations body.
LONDON, Jan. 31 (Reuters) -- Young Americans will be able to study at London's famous Old Vic Theatre Center under a scholarship which the trustees of the Thomas Wall trust have decided to create.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- By a unanimous vote the Supreme Court today sustained a New York City traffic regulation excluding advertising vehicles from the streets except when the owner's own business is being advertised.

People who were frightened off from Benno Moiseiwitsch's piano recital at Carnegie Hall last night by the bad weather have cause for regret. They missed an evening of piano playing that repaid generously the bother of wading through slush and snow.

Tragedy cast a shadow yesterday over the midyear graduation exercises of the Samuel J. Tilden High School in Brooklyn. Shortly before the ceremonies began, Miss Phyllis Marcus, 17 years old, who had been voted "the most versatile senior," was buried in the Beth David Cemetery at Elmont, L. I.

The Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries reported a record net income of $2,401,768 last year after taxes and all charges, equal to $3 a share on the 800,000 capital shares outstanding, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

For the first time in the history of the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers' Association of America the plaque for outstanding service to the game down through the years will go to a major league president at the twenty-sixth annual dinner of the organization next Sunday night in the Waldorf-Astoria.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31-- A plea to avoid hasty action in the United Nations on the proposed international convenant on human rights, was voiced today before the house of delegates of the American Bar Association.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Army today moved to tighten its requirements for new recruits. At the same time it kept the door open to veterans who wish to re-enlist.

O. John Rogge, who was the American Labor Party's candidate for Surrogate of New York County last November, announced yesterday that he had no intention of running for Mayor on that party's ticket this fall. Mr. Rogge had been mentioned frequently as a possible ALP nominee, in the event that Representative Vito Marcantonio did not choose to run for the Despite Mr. Rogge's statement and the

Manhattan beat Brooklyn College, 81 -- 63, at the Flatbush gymnasium last night but the Jasper fans among the 900 spectators will have to wait until the Kelly Green five meets Boston College tomorrow before Bob Kelly scores the 1,000th point of his collegiate career.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP) -- Mildred E. Gillars' former boss in the wartime Nazi radio service testified today that she made "Axis Sally" propaganda broadcasts of her own free will.
Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander will retire on March 1 after thirty-five years in the department, it became known last night.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange stiffened late in yesterday's session and final prices were 1 to 22 points net higher, with new-crop months showing the most strength.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- About twenty of the fifty-four nations now represented at the International Wheat Conference turned in estimates today on how much each expected to import or export.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Dr. Hewlett Johnson, Dean of Canterbury, was one of twenty-two clergymen who today issued a statement condemning widespread denunciation of the Hungarian Government for arresting Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty.
Today was proclaimed United Service Organizations Day by Mayor O'Dwyer at a ceremony yesterday at City Hall. The USO is campaigning for $800,000 in this city.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Ruth Liebstadter, 17-year-old Israeli girl who was born in Nuremberg, where Hitler's infamous anti - Jewish racial laws were conceived, hoisted the flag of Israel in London for the first time today.

Notion buyers are placing fair-sized orders to replenish stocks that were kept low during the inventory taking period, it was learned yesterday at the Notion and Novelty show in the New Yorker Hotel. Over 500 buyers registered on the first day of the show which will continue through Friday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 31 -- The United Nations Little Assembly today approved a United States proposal at its first session this year that would focus the attention of the interim organ on a long-range program for the peaceful settlement of disputes.

New financing in January showed a marked improvement over recent months and was the largest for any corresponding month in several years. Flotations of new bonds totaled $379,097,000 for fifty-three issues, the largest for any January since 1945, when $459,891,000 in twenty-two issues was marketed.

Your London correspondent, reporting on the formation of a "Council of Europe," wrote in the Jan. 29 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES that "there will be a committee composed of government ministers meeting in secret and capable of making binding decisions, which means the actual delegation of sovereign powers to a European body." This conclusion seems to me unwarranted and misleading.

The Security Bureau, Inc., did not receive a single report of theft or pilferage from docks here during the strike of East Coast longshoremen, which occurred between Nov. 10 and 27, E. E. Conroy, executive vice president of the bureau, reported yesterday.

Paraguay, which has just undergone a bloodless inter-party coup, is the subject of a book by Harris Gaylord Warren entitled "Paraguay: An Informal History." Mr. Warren, a Professor of History in the University of Mississippi, became interested in the history of Paraguay while serving in the American Legation at Asuncion. The book will be issued on April 15 by the University of Oklahoma Press.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- Trade in grain futures was the lightest in several days on the Board of Trade here today. A considerable part of the business was of a professional character, and a majority of operators showed a disposition to go slow on either side.

The post of executive director of New York's new Traffic Commission has been offered to T. T. (Teke) Wiley, assistant city traffic engineer of Detroit, it was learned yesterday.
