He is scheduled to be present this afternoon when Mayor O'Dwyer signs the local law formally setting up the separate agency to come to grips with traffic chaos here.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 31 (AP) -Jimmy Demaret squared play-off accounts with Ben Hogan today as he won a three-stroke victory in an eighteen-hole extra round to decide the $10,000 Phoenix Open golf tournament.
PARIS, Jan. 31 (AP) -- French Premier Henri Queuille said tonight action, not words, was needed to consolidate the peace.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 31 -- Dr. Paul Andresen, head of a Danish Red Cross team that, in conjunction with the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund, is combatting tuberculosis in Yugoslavia, said today that this country was in the midst of a dangerous tuberculosis epidemic, with a mortality rate as high as 100 daily.
LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Scores of policemen had their hands full tonight trying to prevent opponents from clashing with supporters of Sir Oswald Mosley at his meeting in the Borough of Kensington.

Tomorrow is Groundhog Day. Tradition decrees that everywhere in the land, inclusive of Bear Mountain, the groundhog will poke his nose from the surface of the earth and will glance around. If he sees his shadow, he will shudder slightly and will return for six weeks to hibernation or to whatever else he may do down there.

The Congress of Industrial Organizations continued to move in reverse yesterday in its drive to enroll department store workers. A right-wing CIO union representing 1,900 Wanamaker employes transferred its affiliation to the American Federation of Labor, depriving the CIO of its last remaining store stronghold in this city.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Jan. 31 -- Temporary adjournment of a Military Government summary court was taken here today when more than 100 Communists assembled outside singing the "Internationale" during the trial of their party chairman, Max Reimann, on
TOKYO, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Reparations shipments from Japan to date have hardly touched the equipment in her arsenals or her gigantic war-supporting industries.

The Massachusetts Investors Trust reported yesterday net assets of $207,322,061 on Dec. 31, compared with $202,967,455 a year earlier. Net assets at the end of last year were equal to $24.27 a share, against $25.36 a share at the end of 1947.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 31 -- There were signs today that the Western Military Governments intend to proceed with formation of a Western German regime and also that they do not expect the Soviet blockade of Berlin to be lifted.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 31 (Reuters) -- The rulers of Baroda and Kolhapur announced tonight that they were to merge their states into Bombay Province, India.

Secretary of Labor Maurice Tobin appeared before the Senate Labor Committee yesterday to open the discussion of the Administration's new labor-management relations bill. He was in the position of defending a measure which, as Senator Aiken of Vermont observed, "has hardly any teeth at all" for dealing with strikes in key industries that threaten a national disaster.

CANTON, China, Jan. 31 (AP) -- China's four southern Provinces centered on Canton will make a last-ditch stand against the Communists, whatever the outcome of peace efforts elsewhere, Gen. Hsueh Yueh declared today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Official Washington studied Premier Stalin's latest "peace offer" today and expressed interest in only one part of it. This was Mr. Stalin's failure to mention settlement of the Berlin currency question as a condition for lifting the Soviet blockade of the former German capital.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 31 -- The American Federation of Labor executive council, opening its winter meeting here, called today for a comprehensive housing law that would provide not only low-rent public housing but also direct Federal loans to assist the "middle-income" groups.
LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Gains in British Government securities gave the stock market here today a cheerful background.
The Masters Nursery, which provides daytime care for preschool children, was welcomed officially yesterday to the New York City Housing Authority's Amsterdam Houses by Thomas F. Farrell, chairman.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- Officials of the National Wash Apparel Show which opened yesterday predicted today buyers for retail stores will place orders for $10,000,000 of merchandise before the show closes Friday.

STUART, Fla., Jan. 31 -- We climbed aboard a "palmetto buggy" yesterday for a two-day bounce across the wide palmetto barrens behind this fishing port, and if the second day of the expedition is as successful as the first everyone will be satisfied.

Mortgage financing was reported arranged yesterday for the last three units in the $3,000,000 Jewel Garden Apartments project on part of the Arrowbrook Country Club site in Kew Garden Hills, Queens. About 250 families are now living in the completed part of the development, which extends from Seventieth Road to Jewel Avenue and from 136th Street to 141st Street.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 31 -- The Motion Picture Industry Council, established late in 1947 at the suggestion of Eric Johnston to weld all elements of the industry into a solid front after the enunciation of the anti-Communist hiring policy, was split wide open today by the withdrawal of the Hollywood AFL Film Council, which represents AFL motion picture unions, including the Screen Actors Guild and the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes.

NANKING, Jan. 31 (UP) -- The Chinese Governent today rejected a Communist demand for the detention of "war criminals," including President Chiang Kai-shek, and strong Communist forces were reported massing east and southwest of this capital.

Raffaele Caccia has purchased the four-story apartment house at 507 Park Place, Brooklyn, from Michael W. Dene and others. A. V. Moratto was the broker. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 31 (AP) -- The Mercantile National Bank of Miami Beach was held up and robbed of an estimated $60,000 to $70,000 in cash shortly after 8 A. M. today.

Reporting on the expenditure of $85,064,439 for land purchase and settlement in Palestine in the last five years, Magistrate Morris Rothenberg announced last night plans for the establishment of fifty-one new colonies in Israel within three months and for an additional eighty to be developed later.

ROME, Jan. 31 -- Premier Stalin's offer to meet President Truman and the reaction in the United States have disconcerted Italian anti-Communist newspapers and evidence of this may be seen in the fact that the majority have so far published not a single word of comment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP) -- Representative John S. Wood announced today that the House Committee on Un-American Activities, of which he is chairman, had voted unanimously to exclude radio recorders, newsreels, television and news photographers from future hearings.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- Superintendent of Insurance Robert E. Dineen told the Joint Legislative Committee on Insurance today that a serious need existed for facilities with which to scrutinize better privately placed life insurance loans, now estimated at $10,000,000,000.

GENEVA, Jan. 31 -- Why doesn't Eastern Europe take economic sanctions against the Marshall Plan? More than one Western official considering the implications of the new Council for Mutual Economic Assistance is wondering what the real answer to this question is.

Spring has bloomed on the bonnets of 200 Salvation Army lassies who will trudge today through slush and snow to ask New Yorkers to "Give to Your Heart's Content" to the Army's campaign for $1,100,000.

Four new directors, including an attorney who headed a committee of stockholders in opposition to the management at the last annual meeting, were added to the board of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation yesterday. In addition, two vice presidents of the aircraft manufacturing corporation retired in the second major shakeup in the administration in the last two months.

BUCHAREST, Jan. 31 (Reuters) -- Hearing of an appeal by Alexander Evans, British former director of the Steraua Romana Oil Company, against a three-year jail sentence on fraud charges took an unexpected turn here today when it was disclosed that he had been allowed to leave for Britain and would only be represented in court.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- The United States will shortly extend formal invitations to Norway and Denmark to send delegates to Washington to discuss participation in the Atlantic defense pact, it is believed here in well informed circles.

Two bond issues totaling $11,300,000 were sold to underwriting syndicates at deadline bidding transactions yesterday. The Erie Railroad borrowed $6,300,000 on one - to - ten - year equipment-trust serials at an interest cost of about 2.23 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today that a plan of the Burlington Railroad for a short-cut freight route between St. Louis and Kansas City will be considered independently of other cases relating to the trackage involved

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- The Government's bill to abolish special juries that was introduced in Commons today brought a sharp exchange between Conservatives and Laborites over "class prejudice" in trial by jury.

The city will give a spectacular welcome with traditional surface and air displays to the French Gratitude Train when it arrives in New York Harbor on board the French freighter Magellan at about 9 A. M. today.

After a bit of juggling with dates, Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse have fixed March 23 for the premiere of Sidney Kingsley's melodrama, "Detective Story," at the Hudson. The local debut will be preceded by a Philadelphia stand, starting March 9. Leading contenders for the cast, in which Ralph Bellamy is starred, are Lou Gilbert and Edgar Stehli.

The Giants yesterday added another Negro player to their baseball organization with the announcement that the Jersey City farm club has signed Henry Thompson. A versatile performer capable of playing both infield and outfield, Thompson was purchased from the Kansas City Monarchs with whom he played last year.

Senator Thomas of Oklahoma has introduced a bill in Congress which, in his words, creates "ever-normal granaries" for wheat, corn and cotton. The measure is essentially a form of stockpiling, and contemplates building up a reserve of 400,000,000 bushels of wheat, 600,000,000 bushels of corn and 4,500,000 bales of cotton.

A new scheme to control the world with electronic devices invented by electrical engineers was unfolded yesterday afternoon during an otherwise uneventful session of the annual meeting of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers at the Statler Hotel.
RHODES, Feb. 1 -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, United Nations Acting Mediator for Palestine, proposed today armistice talks between Israel and all the Arab nations at war with her.

ATHENS, Feb. 1 -- Nowhere does the Stalin peace offensive stir the waters so deeply as in Greece. This is the hot spot in the cold war and anything touching Soviet relations with the West is felt here in the flesh, so to speak, like a blow on a bruise.

Humberto Sierra, Cuban lightweight who boasts a victory over Sandy Saddler, world featherweight champion, makes his local ring debut tonight at the Manhattan Center. Under the auspices of the Tournament of Champions, the Cuban is to battle rugged Paddy DeMarco, Brooklynite, in the stellar bout of ten rounds.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- The State Health Department is planning to start a fundamental research project with the aim of developing a blood test for cancer and a vaccine for it, Governor Dewey disclosed in his budget message today.

PARIS, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Four former Russian citizens testified today that they had been beaten, tortured and shut up in concentration camps in the Soviet Union. On the basis of their own experiences, they said, they could say under oath that Victor Kravchenko's book, "I Chose Freedom," tells the truth about life in Russia.
The custom-made clothes of Muriel Evart of Meriden, Conn., were presented yesterday at her initial showing here during tea time at the Cardinal Restaurant, 212 West Fifty-seventh Street.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- New York City will receive $53,500,000 to $59,900,000 more in state assistance for various functions under the executive budget submitted today by Governor Dewey. The increase is 27.4 to 30.2 per cent over the total for this fiscal year, which ends March 31.

The shortage of electric power in the United States is so acute that it has reached a point of state emergency, T. E. Craddock, retiring president of the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Judging from Nanking reports the Soviet Union may soon be in a position to gobble up a huge piece of Central Asia in which it has been interested for a long time but where Muscovite influence had atrophied before the great battle of Stalingrad.

A story of international dickering Over oil rights in Saudi Arabia was unfolded in Federal Court yesterday at the opening of the trial of a $6,000,000 suit by James A. Moffett, former Federal Housing Administrator, against the Arabian American Oil Company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Members of the Senate and House Banking and Currency Committees suggested today that any extension of export controls should include a provision authorizing Secretary of Agriculture to determine the over-all amount of any agricultural commodity permitted to be exported.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Manufacturers' sales totaled $210,000,000,000 in 1948, an increase of 12 per cent over 1947, the Department of Commerce reported today.
ATHENS, Feb. 1 -- Parliament met tonight after a two-and-a-half-month recess to hear Premier Themistocles Sophoulis plead for confidence in the new broad Governmental coalition of which he is head.

BULAWAYO, Feb. 1 (Reuters) -- A heavy rainstorm deprived the English cricket tourists of victory in their match against Rhodesia today. The game ended in a draw. With about an hour and a half left for play the touring team required only 31 runs to win, but then came the storm which had been threatening nearly all day and had previously caused two delays.

After reading the cold and matter-of-fact description of how the oil monopoly is holding up prices and consumers by curtailing production, as reported by J. H. Carmical in THE TIMES of Jan. 24, one wonders what the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice is waiting for in the way of evidence.

An exhibition of radios, machine tools, clothing, jewelry and art work -- all produced by Jewish war victims in twenty-six countries -- was opened last night at 318 West Fifty-seventh Street to an invited audience by the Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training.

Papers' National Gain 20% Newspapers led all major, media in national advertising for December, making a gain of 20 per cent over the like month of 1947, it was reported yesterday by Printers' Ink. The general index for all national advertising was up 6 per cent. Outdoor increased 12 per cent, all types of magazines, 2 per cent, with radio unchanged.

Trading in coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange was active yesterday. Commission-house selling and scattered long liquidation was absorbed by trade hedge covering. At the day's end the market rallied slightly from the low point.

The City of New York was sued for $250,000 yesterday by two persons who were injured in a collision between a cab and a fire truck a few hours after a party broke up in the Great Jones Street firehouse on the night of Dec. 16. The fire truck came from that firehouse.

The downward trend on the stock market was reversed yesterday. Brokers characterized the change as purely technical. The share list showed the best bids in the final hour and produced the widest rally since Jan. 7.
OSLO, Norway, Feb. 1 (UP) -Following is the text of Norway's reply to the Soviet note on the proposed North Atlantic defense pact:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The State Department said today it hoped "soon" to bring Norway and other countries into the North Atlantic defense pact negotiations.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 1 -- Argentina's import trade was brought to a temporary standstill today when the National Economic Council advised the Central Bank to return all the requests for exchange permits that it now has under consideration.

VIENNA, Feb. 1 -- The trade accord sanctioned last week by the Economic Cooperation Administration, under which Austria would import more than $3,000,000 worth of rye and fat from Hungary and pay for it with surplus United States cotton bought with Marshall Plan dollars, was bitterly attacked by the Austrian Communist party over the week-end.

Revision of Mexican policies and laws hampering trade with the United States and participation of outside capital in the economic development of Mexico was urged yesterday by the Committee for Mexico of the National Foreign Trade Council.

This morning's newcomer, at the Paramount, is "My Own True Love," a romantic drama, produced by Paramount and starring Phyllis Calvert, Melvyn Douglas and Philip Friend. Wanda Hendrix, Binnie Barnes and Arthur Shields are also in the film, which was directed by Compton Bennett from a script prepared by Theodore Strauss and Joseph Mischel.

Twenty new Fords, the first automobiles with post-war styling purchased by the city for police duty, were inspected yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer and Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander at a brief ceremony in front of Police Headquarters.

HAVANA, Feb. 1 -- The first Cuba Cup race of the eighteenth international Star Class regatta was won today by Lockwood Pirie of Chicago, representing the Wilmette Harbor Fleet with his Twin Star in the time of 2 hours 1 minute 19 seconds. F. S. Dixon was his crew.

The Rev. George Antonio Laberge, who spent more than three years in Moscow as spiritual leader of the American Roman Catholics there arrived at La Guardia Airport yesterday afternoon aboard an American Overseas Airlines plane from Stockholm.
Today is Groundhog Day, but even if the Bronx Zoo's groundhog were to cast a shadow it would be a mere shadow of a shadow.
LONDON, Feb. 1 -- The feature of the last day of the account in the stock market here today was continued firmness of British Government issues, which made gains up to 7/16 point.
PARIS, Feb. 1 (UP) -- Members of the French National ski team have revolted against the decision of the French Ski Federation to send them to compete in United States and Canadian meets.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- A Labor party leaflet depicting a bevy of thriving infants with the caption: "The prams of Britain are filled with the bonniest babies in living memory" misfired as a Socialist promotion piece and was withdrawn tonight.

The Long Island Lighting Company and two affiliated companies that supply gas and electricity to Nassau and Suffolk Counties and parts of Queens reached a wage agreement with their unionized employes yesterday, removing any possibility of an interruption in light or power in areas served by the concerns.

John J. (Johnny) Broderick, the former detective with a Broadway reputation for handling the underworld, staged an "at home" last night at 1225 Avenue of the Americas, at Forty-eighth Street, one flight up over a Chinese restaurant.
ALBANY, N. Y., Feb. 1 (AP) -- The State Commerce Department reported today the following conditions at New York ski centers:

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- The bipartisan conference of war veterans in the Legislature decided today to take the initiative in seeking a compromise between two conflicting proposals to extend Civil Service preference currently accorded to war veterans by the State Constitution.

The metropolitan Class B squash racquets singles championship got under way last night at the University Club, with none of the seeded players in action. The tourney is headed by John B. Russell 3d, Yale Club.
As promised declines in milk prices took effect yesterday the city's study of pricing by the milk industry struck out in another direction.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Four railroad companies today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to issue $26,205,000 in equipment trust certificates to help finance the purchase of new equipment.
Louis Caridad, who is well acquainted with the inside of the Brooklyn and Queens jails although he has not been convicted of a crime, escaped the toils of the law again yesterday.

Controls in wartime were justified by the wartime emergency. All such controls as were carried over into peacetime failed utterly in their purpose. When they were lifted, the natural economic forces, thus unshackled, came into play again.
The Sun Oil Company and its subsidiaries last year had a consolidated net income of $42,853,839, compared with $24,339,913 in 1947, Joseph N. Pew Jr., chairman of the board, reported yesterday.

Admiral Thomas C. Kinkaid, commander of the Eastern Sea Frontier; Maj. Gen. R. B. Woodruff, commanding general of the First Army, and hundreds of noon-time strollers in the Wall Street area yesterday got doughnuts for dollars or less donated to the Salivation Army drive for $1,100,000.

The Macy Department Store Union, Local 1-S, an independent group, won by almost five to one in an election held yesterday to choose a collective bargaining agent for the 7,300 employes of the four Macy stores in this city.

James J. Lyons, Borough President of the Bronx, submitted his departmental budget estimate of $4,515,117 for the coming fiscal year at a hearing yesterday in the office of Thomas J. Patterson, Budget Director. The figure was $1,155,875 higher than the present budget.

The Consolidated Grocers Corporation, in a report yesterday for the twelve and twenty-four weeks ended on Dec. 11, last, included the results for the first time of its wholly owned subsidiary, Rosenberg Brothers Co., Inc., covering the period of ownership since Aug. 26, 1948.

Oscar Keuker, 13 years old, who with his father and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Frans Keuker; his brothers, Karel, 11, and Christopher, 9, and sister, Frances, 19, spent three and half years in a Japanese concentration camp in Java, thanked the Protestant Council of the City of New York last night for helping him to lose his memories of imprisonment.

Consolidated income of the New York Curb Exchange and its operating affiliates in 1948 was $1,419,927, Francis Adams Truslow, president, reported yesterday. Consolidated expenses aggregated $1,500,131. The 1947 figures were $1,469,108 and $1,442,259, respectively.

J. Donald Kingsley, assistant to Oscar Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, described yesterday as "a remarkable concoction of personal malice, personal opinion and plain old-fashioned hog-wash" the charge made against Mr. Ewing the day before by Dr. Paul R. Hawley, former medical chief of the Veterans Administration.
CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Jackson Park Theatre today agreed to accept $456,000 as damages suffered during the two years of trial of its successful suit to outlaw the Chicago system of film booking.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,498, against 1.969 last week and 1,072 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

When I bought tickets for Walter Gieseking's concert, I thought this eminent musician had been cleared of any taint of nazism. When I reached Carnegie Hall for the concert, I found a moiling mob of ticket holders and pickets, the latter placarding a variety of accusations against Gieseking.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Pacific Gas and Electric Company, San Francisco, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission 754,038 shares of $25 par-value common stock that are to be offered pro rata for subscription by its common stockholders.

WARSAW, Feb. 1 -- Three Polish Peasant party leaders and associates of Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, former Deputy Prime Minister of Poland, have fled the country successfully, it was learned reliably today. All three were members of the Polish Parliament.

Mayor O'Dwyer named First Deputy Police Commissioner William P. O'Brien to succeed Arthur W. Wallander as Police Commissioner yesterday, several hours after he "reluctantly" accepted Mr. Wallander's resignation effective March 1.

WHO is "the most famous character in the English language?" Hamlet? Robinson Crusoe? Scarlett O'Hara? Tarzan? No, none of these, says John Dickson Carr. He is a tall, gaunt detective who smoked an underslung pipe and wore a deerstalker hat, Sherlock Holmes. Mr. Carr, who has written some thirty detective stories himself, probably has a slight prejudice in favor of the greatest of all fictional detectives.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- General liquidation struck the grain markets on the Board of Trade today, with all deliveries of corn, soybeans and rye, and December wheat and July, September and December oats selling at new seasonal low prices and Number 2 yellow corn at the lowest price since February 1947.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- President Truman pleaded tonight for a "planned economy" rather than a "controlled economy" because "we have become the symbol of what governments should stand for -- the welfare of the people."

Complaints by riders, including one that students could not get to school by bus, led Public Service Commissioner Spencer B. Eddy yesterday to order "a broad general investigation" into the service given by the Surface Transportation Company, a subsidiary of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation.
The legendary "Bowery bum" -- drinking, brawling and sleeping in hallways -- is not an amusing character to the families of the Lower East Side. He is a source, rather, of deep anxiety.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- The first legislative action on measures to streamline the New York City court system was taken today in the Assembly, where two bills authorizing Municipal and City Court judges to act temporarily as Supreme Court justices and referees were passed unanimously.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- How York City fares under the state budget submitted by Governor Dewey is shown in the following table. Figures for 1948-49 are on an expenditure basis rather than appropriation; those for 1949-50 on an appropriation basis.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Senate Committee on Labor and Public Welfare postponed today its formal approval of a bill calling for $300,000,000 in annual Federal aid to education until a companion measure designed to safeguard the health of school children was drafted and considered.

Mayor O'Dwyer signed the City Charter amendment creating a Traffic Commission yesterday and announced that he had appointed John C. Riedel, chief engineer of the Board of Estimate, to be the first Traffic Commission chairman.
Philadelphia, Pa., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Feb. 24 on bond issues totaling $44,200,000. Dated March 1, 1949, the bonds will come due on Jan. 1, 1950 to 1999.
A local law establishing a Smoke Control Board in the Department of Housing and Buildings was unanimously approved yesterday by the City Council.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Senate Rules Committee completed today its hearings on heavily backed proposals to harden the "gag" procedure against filibusters, such as those by which the Southerners have always beaten off the civil rights program.

An investigation of the office of the Borough President of Manhattan in connection with the dinner given recently by Frank Costello, gambler and ex-convict, at the Copacabana Club, was demanded in City Council yesterday by Councilman Edward Rager, Manhattan Republican.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- Increases in four taxes, designed to raise $168,200,000 in new revenue, were proposed today by Governor Dewey as he submitted a record-breaking budget of $936,190,300 for the fiscal year 1949-50 to the State Legislature.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- It was announced from 10 Downing Street tonight that L. J. Edwards, parliamentary secretary of Ministry of Health, had been appointed parliamentary secretary of the Board of Trade. He replaces John W. Belcher, who resigned during a hearing of inquiry into fraud in the Board of Trade and other Government departments.

OSLO, Norway, Feb. 1 -- The Norwegian Government informed the Soviet Union today that, while it would investigate the conditions under which Norway could participate in a North Atlantic defensive alliance, it would never grant bases for foreign powers unless attacked or subjected to threats of attack.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Republic of Hungary became a "People's Republic" today.
LONDON, Feb. 1 -- Britain's motion-picture industry was depicted today as indulging in "wild extravagance," operating at a loss and failing to produce the quota of films set for it by the Government.
BATAVIA, Java, Feb. 1 (AP) -Guerrillas continued attacks throughout Java and Sumatra all through the last week, hammering at road traffic and hampering industry, a Dutch military review said today.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- Following is the text of Governor Dewey's budget message:

EASTON, Pa., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Maurice J. (Clipper) Smith, fresh from the professional football ranks, today was named head coach at Lafayette College and promptly announced that he would introduce his own version of the "T" formation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- President Truman last week argued the relative qualities of Missouri steaks with a Representative, and today he went up to Capitol Hill to do some sampling.

In an effort to wipe out tropical diseases in New York, the Health Department will open two additional diagnostic units near medical schools here for the detection, treatment and study of parasitic infections.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- Governor Dewey proposed in his budget message today an appropriation of $350,000 "so that a complete State Fair can be conducted during 1949 on the existing Syracuse fair ground."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP) -- Ullrich Haupt, 33-year-old former Berlin actor, testified today that Mildred (Axis Sally) Gillars played the leading role in a wartime Nazi radio horror drama aimed at discouraging the Normandy invasion.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- Liquor, cigarette, racing, inheritance and un-incorporated business taxes either are at or have passed their peak yields at present rates but the personal income, corporate franchise, gasoline and motor vehicle levies are still climbing, Governor Dewey told the Legislature today.

" A Dreamer's Journey," the autobiography of the late Morris Raphael Cohen, will be published by the Beacon Press on Feb. 28. Dr. Cohen, a graduate of City College, held its chair of philosophy and was a visiting lecturer at many universities.
Nannette Levi, 22-year-old California violinist, who has been the concert mistress of the orchestra at the last two Carmel Bach Festivals, gave her first New York recital last night at Times Hall.

John D. Crimi, mural painter, lost yesterday his fight to compel the Rutgers Presbyterian Church to remove obliterating paint from his mural, "The Spreading of the Gospel," on the chancel wall of the church at Broadway and Seventy-third Street.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Feb. 1 -- At a meeting at City Hall here tonight, the Mayors and other representatives of New Rochelle, Mount Vernon, Larchmont, Harrison, Rye and Mamaroneck endorsed a plan to fight an increase in commutation fares on the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad by hiring Dr. John Bauer, New York rate expert, to appear before the Public Service Commission.

Four more members of the grand jury that indicted the eleven Communist leaders testified yesterday there had been no discrimination in their selection for jury duty. Twenty-one of the twenty-three grand jurors have now told Federal Judge Harold R. Medina they were never asked any questions by jury officials about their race, religion, political or social affiliations, or financial worth.
LONDON, Feb. 1 -- If present plans work out, the first meeting of the Council of Europe will be held in Strasbourg, France, before the end of 1949.
All friends of the United Nations have reason to be alarmed because of its tendency to become a forum for bitter accusations and recriminations rather than for mutual understanding and conciliation.

Gathering last night in an enthusiastic overflow meeting in the Amsterdam Democratic Club, 2091 Broadway, 250 tenants of Ansonia Apartments voted a "war chest" to eliminate their grievances against Samuel Broxmeyer, owner of the building.

Maj. Louis H. Wilson Jr., a Marine winner of the Congressional Medal of Honor, took command of Marine Corps recruiting in the metropolitan area at a ceremony yesterday in the Federal Office Building, 90 Church Street.

Unemployment in this city declined last week for the third consecutive week, according to statistics made public yesterday by Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner. The number of workers drawing unemployment insurance and veterans' readjustment allowances here declined from 280,643 in the week ended Jan. 21, to 273,389.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Chinese Embassy announced tonight that the Bank of China had made a final $21,000,000 payment in paying off a $33,000,000 loan made by the American Export-Import Bank to help China buy cotton.

The Port of New York Authority has asked Congress to eliminate a 25 per cent cut made by the Bureau of the Budget in the $4,650,000 allotted from 1949-50 Federal funds for New York harbor improvements, it was announced Monday by Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the bi-state agency.

Three unidentified thugs, one of them armed, in a daring daylight robbery yesterday took jewelry valued at more than $7,000 and cash from occupants of a two-family house in the Midwood section of Flatbush, Brooklyn. They escaped after ransacking the rooms for an hour and a half and left two housewives, a son of one, and a maid bound and gagged.

An agreement whereby life insurance and accident benefits will be provided for 1,800 workers in the iron and structural steel industry in this area was made effective yesterday by employers of the Allied Metal Industries, Inc., and several independent employers.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- Re-election of Miss Susan Brandeis of New York to the State Board of Regents appeared more likely today following reports that the post might go to Jacob L. Holtzmann, Brooklyn lawyer and friend of John R. Crews, Kings County Republican chairman.

The Salvation Army maintains four training schools in the United States with an aggregate graduation of 450 officers in peace time. These men and women have dedicated themselves to an unselfish life of service to the needy, without regard for race or creed.
In John Davis' letter of Jan. 29 he condemns the recent Gieseking incident as Fascist and, apparently, terms "the mixture of politics and art" as undemocratic and learned from Hitler.

A woman who had used the New York Public Library for decades and a child just getting acquainted with the wonders it holds were among the first contributors yesterday at the start of the institution's appeal for funds from the public.

STUART, Fla., Feb. 1 -- The real dateline on this column should read "Long Slough by Piney Woods," but as there is no post office here, and as the only inhabitants are the winged, furred, bristled and scaly citizens of the barrens, the nearest town must serve our purpose.

PARIS, Feb. 1 -- Asymmetry is the theme song of Claude Saint Cyr's cloches and toques, all with tilted crown. The collection is revolutionary in color. There is no navy, gray or beige. Deep corn-flower blue and grass green take the place of traditional navy. Gray-pink replaces grays.
HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 1 -- Gov. Chester Bowles recommended today a $355,700,000 and biennial state budget and proposed an income tax to help pay for it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Cyrus S. Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, opposed today the Administration's bill turning conciliation functions back to the Labor Department. He called it a "step backwards" in the task of strengthening industrial democracy by promoting sound collective bargaining and minimizing labor disputes.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 1 -- Maj. Gen. Bryant E. Moore, new head of the United States Military Academy, said today that he hoped every cadet could be sent abroad to study before receiving his commission as second lieutenant.

Issuance companies remained generally inactive as either buyers or sellers of Treasury bonds last month, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York notes in the current issue of its Monthly Review, published today. Reviewing money market conditions in January, the bank reports that commercial banks widened their operations in Government bonds to include the longer-term eligible issues.

PARIS, Feb. 1 -- Premier Henri Queuille announced tonight in a broadcast to the nation that more than 100,000,000,000 francs of the new national loan had been subscribed. He said that nearly 60,000,000,000 francs of this total represented new money. The rest consisted of conversion of old bonds.

NORTH CONWAY, N. H., Feb. 1 -- Ten years ago next week, skiing's most fabulous figure, Hannes Schneider, fled from Nazi-controlled Austria with his family for a new life of freedom in this country. Under a long archway of skis and surrounded by most of the natives of this peaceful community, he made his abode in North Conway.

THE old Empire City race track in Yonkers will soon revert to its original role as a harness racing center and a new Empire City race track will some day arise in the Baychester section of the Bronx. A lot of old-timers will be saddened by the shift because they loved the countrylike flavor of the meetings there. But the sport had outgrown the location and there was no recourse except to move.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Louis B. Mayer's lavish horse breeding farm was sold today to Ellsworth M. Statler of the hotel family and Mrs. Meredith Howard Harless, wife of Richard F. Harless, former Congressman from Arizona.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, strongly indicated today his belief that the world situation had improved markedly since last spring and he intimated that the limits placed by President Truman on defense expenditures reflected that improvement.

Because of violations of intellectual freedom in Argentina, nine of the most distinguished philosophers in the United States have rejected invitations to participate in a National Congress of Philosophy to be held in the South American country from March 30 to April 9, it was learned yesterday.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 1 -- As Public Administrator of Westchester County since 1934, Kenneth C. Cole has performed some strange tasks in settling estates.

BERLIN, Feb. 1 -- The Soviet Military Administration has abolished all Works Councils for the Eastern zone in a move interpreted by United States officials here as another admission of Russian failure to win the German workers over to communism.

Abraham Green has been appointed merchandise manager of the basement store at Abraham Straus. Formerly with Filene's of Boston, he joined A S in March, 1947, as assistant merchandise manager of the basement store.

The city has decided to set up its own placement service to find foster homes for needy children, Commissioner of Welfare Raymond M. Hilliard announced yesterday. This will supplement the efforts of private agencies but will by no means supplant them, Mr. Hilliard explained at his office in 902 Broadway.
LONDON, Feb. (AP) -- Supply Minister George Strauss assured British auto makers today that their booming factories will be untouched when the Government takes over the iron and steel industry.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Senate Democratic conference discussed at length today how it should treat with small business during the Eighty-first Congress and, while no binding decision was reached, the implication was plain that the subject would not be handled by a special committee.

Nearly complete returns in a survey of New York fur retailers on adoption of a voluntary "code" regulating use of comparative prices in advertising and selling show a close division of opinion on the proposal, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Government officials acknowledged today that the Air Force's tiny "faster-than-sound" test plane had flown faster than 850 miles an hour and reached an altitude above 40,000 feet. Unofficial information is that its best speed has been around 1,000 miles an hour and its best altitude something more than 60,000 feet.

Such a close balance exists with prospective supplies of hides and skins and requirements for shoe output that a shortage could develop which would lead to Sharply higher prices, according to the report presented yesterda at the meeting of the board of the National Shoe Manufaeturers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by John H. Patterson, economist of the association.

The nutrition exhibit that opens to the public tomorrow at the Museum of Natural History puts pupils in the happy role of teachers. Seventy-five entries from homemaking classes in New York's public schools will instruct visitors on how to eat and why.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 1 -- The United Nations Trusteeship Council today turned down a Soviet proposal and a similar Philippine recommendation that would have allowed the native inhabitants of territories under the Council's supervision to send a representative to the Council's sessions.

TEL AVIV, Feb. 1 (UP) -- James G. McDonald, head of the United States mission here, visited Foreign Minister Moshe Shertok today and formally read the proclamation of United States recognition of Israel.

TALLADEGA, Ala., Feb. 1 -- More Negro farmers in the rural South will grow their crops without mortgages this year than ever before in the region's annals, according to a survey by Thomas M. Campbell, field agent of the Department of Agriculture's extension service station at Tuskegee Institute.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 1 -- A broad program of activity at national, state and local levels was laid out today by labor's League for Political Education.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Truman Administration registered its opposition today to a bill to provide old-age and disability pensions for all veterans of the two World Wars and estimated the ultimate cost at billions of dollars annually.

NEWARK, N. J., Feb. 1 -- Henry Diffany, octogenarian retired business man, and his wife, Rosa, about the same age, who had been known to neighbors as recluses for many years, were found dead here today in their tightly shuttered, dilapidated house at 1106 Broad Street.

A series of twenty-six films based on Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's book, "Crusade in Europe," will be presented over the ABC video network as result of an agreement reached yesterday by the network, the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Doubleday Co., publishers of the general's book, and the March of Time, which will produce the shorts.

We welcome Mayor O'Dwyer's choice of T. T. Wiley of Detroit for the post of executive director of New York's new Traffic Commission. Mr. Wiley is a trained engineer, with broad experience. Certainly Detroit has posed a major problem for him, with its tremendous in-and-out flow of vehicular traffic at both ends of the business day, its complicated street pattern, and its great population growth.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Senate Democrats made the opening move today toward a first major change in the Legislative Reorganization Act of 1946. They proposed that Congress have until April 1, at least, to submit a legislative budget.
Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decrease of 4 per cent in January, compared with the same month last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Rutgers University athletic teams will make sure of adequate democratic housing arrangements before filling dates with Southern schools in the future, The Targum, university newspaper, said today.

At the Yankee baseball offices yesterday, Coach Red Strader of the newly formed Yankees-Dodgers All-America Football Conference team named seven players acquired from the "dead" Dodgers. At the same time, via The Associated Press, news was received from Chicago that James C. Thompson was the new "angel" of the defunct Chicago Rockets, henceforth to be known as the Chicago Hornets.

Some retailers shortly will drop one or more competing top brand major appliance lines because of the continuing slump and failure manufacturers to increase "inadequate'' discounts, dealers reported yesterday. Other outlets plan to retain all name brand Supply sources but will refuse to buy units in any line which do not carry discounts assuring an operating profit, buyers said.

When a homemaker comes to an impasse in deciding whether the living room wall should be green or tan, she might solve her perplexities by considering the functional value of each color. A detailed explanation of the psychological effects of color was presented yesterday by executives of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. at a conference at the St. Regis Hotel.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Vaudeville flashed to a four-length triumph in today's featured Aquamarine Purse to give Owner George D. Widener, president of Belmont Park, his first score of the season at Hialeah Park.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 1 -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder said today the Truman Administration's economic program will continue to be one of promoting high-level prosperity in the years ahead by encouraging healthy business development, while continuing to restrain the excesses which in the past have been responsible for business recessions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- At least two non-scheduled passenger airlines are negotiating to sell their equipment to foreign countries in the face of a threat by the Civil Aeronautics Board to frame regulations which they consider would put them out of business, a spokesman for the independents said here today.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Heavyweight Champion Joe Louis kept intact tonight his record of always looking better in his second fight with an opponent.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange held within a comparatively narrow range yesterday, but turned somewhat easier toward the close. Final prices were 7 to 14 points net lower.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Miss Margaret Truman has resumed her vocal studies in New York, the White House announced today.

The $936,200,000 budget for New York State's fiscal year 1949-50 which was delivered to the Legislature yesterday, the tax increases suggested, and the very strong possibility that the completed budget may be still larger will have a sobering effect on all taxpayers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that consumer credit jumped $618,000,000 in December under the impact of Christmas buying.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 1 -- Modern Jerusalem has formally become a part of the state of Israel, according to a Cabinet decision terminating the military governorship there. "Governmental arrangements obtaining in other parts of the state of Israel" will apply there, a Foreign Office spokesman announced.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The major part of the first semi-annual report sent by the Displaced Persons Commission to Congress today was devoted to telling why the act, under which the commission operates, is "all but unworkable."

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Feb. 1 (AP) -- A group of church leaders declared today the recent Dutch action against the republic of Indonesia was "the only reasonable step the Dutch Government could have taken under the present circumstances."

PARIS, Feb. 11 -- The European Council for the Marshall Plan has been asked by United States officials to examine henceforth all applications for counterpart funds to make sure that the governments seeking them will invest them so as to aid the recovery of Europe as well as that of their own nations.

Twenty-eight election inspectors from four Manhattan Assembly districts were blacklisted yesterday by the Board of Elections at a hearing on alleged voting irregulatities during the Nov. 2 elections. Eight other inspectors were warned by the board but not dismissed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Under-Secretary of Interior Oscar L. Chapman said today that the nation's power output ought to be doubled in the next ten years or so. Most of the additional power, he added, should come from hydroelectric sources.
One of England's best known smaller automobiles, the Morris, was added yesterday to the ever-increasing line of British-made cars now available in this country.

Heading the organization of eighteen thousand men who maintain the peace and protect the persons of the law-abiding citizens of the world's largest city requires a first-class man. Police Commissioner Wallander, who steps down at his own request on March 1, has met this test.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- President Truman today appointed George William Taylor, educator and arbitrator of Philadelphia, as chairman of an emergency board to investigate a dispute on fifteen Western lines between more than seventy railroads and the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers which threatens to interrupt interstate commerce.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Feb. 1 -- Chief Magistrate H. S. Meech this afternoon in a Military Government summary court found Max Reimann, German Communist leader, guilty of "encouraging discrimination against those who give aid and assistance to the Military Government and Allied forces."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP) -- If Congress fails to authorize Federal loans to start a synthetic fuels industry now, this country may find its future oil supply "too little and too late," Secretary of the Interior J. A. Krug said today.

NANKING, Feb. 1 -- The "Peiping formula," in which civic leaders took the initiative in negotiating a peace with the Communists, is now being implemented for Shanghai, Nanking and Hankow with the encouragement of the Acting President, Gen. Li Tsung-jen, as a possible means of reaching a political settlement with the Communists.

Savings Accounts Deposits in the nation's mutual savings banks rose $612,000,000 last year to reach a new high mark of $18,400,000,000, it was reported yesterday. William L. Maude, president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, in issuLug the report, pointed out, however, that the gain was approximately one-third below that of 1947.

Appearing as guest conductor with the Philadelphia Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, Alexander Hilsberg opened his program with a performance of the early Beethoven overture to "The Creatures of Prometheus," which was a model of fine musicianship and classic style.
William J. Wobbekind and Phillip Goos have been admitted to partnership in the firm of Edward A. Viner Co., members of the New York Curb Exchange, according to the weekly bulletin of the exchange.
GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 1 -- Betty and Peggy Howe, twin sisters of New Haven, Conn., will meet tomorrow afternoon for the Connecticut State women's squash racquets title at the Greenwich Country Club.
Two boys and two girls who overcame physical handicaps to achieve success in their school careers were honored yesterday at a ceremony at the Board of Education.

The half-dollars paid by Americans throughout the country for a chance to view 150 masterpieces of painting from the Kaiser Friedrich Museum in Berlin, will go to Germany in the form of $181,000 worth of shoes, clothing and bedding for that country's needy children, it was announced yesterday.

The American Merchant Marine must receive its "rightful share" of Economic Cooperation Administration cargoes originating in the United States, Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, declared yesterday afternoon.

It was with emotions at high peak that I read your story of the projected midwinter assault of parka-and-mukluk-clad Wacs on inhospitable Mount Washington. Your correspondent, it seems, was either a genius at understatement or else a wag who wrote playfully with tongue in cheek, or perchance he had never been on Mount Washington in winter.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 1 -- ''Heart to Heart," a screen story by Lionel Houser, has been purchased by Paramount and will be produced and directed by William Wyler, it was learned today. Contracts have not yet been signed, but agreement has been reached on the deal and it is probable that Jean Arthur will star in the film as her first assignment under her new three-picture deal with the studio.

New York University and Manhattan are so closely matched that the mile and two-mile relays, which close the program, probably will decide the disposition of the team title at the seventh annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate indoor track and field championships at the 102d Engineers Armory Friday night.
Kentucky has replaced St. Louis University as the country's No. 1 college basketball team in the third weekly poll of sports writers and broadcasters, conducted by The Associated Press.

Thomas P. Brophy, former Chief Fire Marshal who retired from the Fire Department Dec. 31, 1948, after forty-one years of service with the department, was the guest of honor last night at a testimonial dinner given by his friends in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel and attended by 1,000 persons.
WASHIINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- A series of cross-country public hearings on the railroad industry's plea for new long-term freight-rate increases was announced today.
A program to relieve congestion in New York's twenty-eight municipal hospitals was announced yesterday by Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, the new Commissioner of Hospitals.

TOKYO, Feb. 1 -- British and American charges that the Japanese, despite occupation supervision, are being allowed to dump knitgoods are met with denial here today. Both occupation officials and traders agree British and American manufacturers are fighting hard to get and hold markets the Japanese supplied before the war and are resorting to general misrepresentation of the facts for propaganda purposes.

Under pressure from unionized employers, the Dress Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, decided yesterday to renew the organizing drive that led to assaults, arrests and charges of "strong-arm" tactics on both sides when it was originally pressed last fall.

City police and legal authorities were uncertain yesterday whether a United States Supreme Court decision sustaining the exclusion of advertising vehicles from the streets pertained also to noncommercial posters such as displayed by the American Red Cross.

The type of furniture people can plan and build themselves, using simple construction and finishing methods, is shown in the new exhibit, "The Creative Approach to Home Design," which opens today at America House, 485 Madison Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 -- The Rev. Carl McIntire, president of the International Council of Chris tian Churches, disclosed this afternoon the contents of the letter received from Chancellor Kok by Dr. Garman, pastor of Callender Memorial Church, Wilkinsburg, Pa.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- A bill to revise and implement existing laws barring racial and religious discrimination in public accommodations was introduced in the Legislature today following a conference between a New York City group and Governor Dewey.
ALLIANCE, Neb., Feb. 1 -- Stories of their battle against the snows were told today by victims of the Great Plains blizzards as planes and Army forces freed them from isolation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Army Nurse Corps, celebrating its forty-eighth birthday tomorrow, made a last minute tally which showed 4,469 nurses on active duty and almost 10,000 signed up as reserves willing to serve in time of war.
CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (UP) -- The Army smashed its big bulldozer disaster force into the Western snow today to "liberate" isolated towns and relieve starving livestock.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- The United States Senate should not ratify the United Nations convention on the prevention and punishment of genocide "until and unless there has been accorded the time and opportunity for adequate public discussion and understanding of the convention," the House of Delegates of the American Bar Association declared unanimously today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The North Atlantic defense pact draft contains the following main points, according to reliable information, already published:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's talk before the National Planning Association tonight:
Earnings of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane, the nation's largest brokerage firm last year were more than double those in 1947.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 2 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie took a cautious look at the newly created Council of Europe today and said that it did not seem to present any danger of interfering with the functions of the United Nations.

We heartily endorse the action of the House Ways and Means Committee yesterday in approving a bill to restore the Hull reciprocal trade agreements program to its original form, and we welcome the fact that there were at least two Republicans who voted with the Democrats on this question.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 2 -Princeton University will hold its 215th commencement exercises here tomorrow afternoon as 274 seniors, including seventy-three men who completed their studies last September, receive degrees at Princeton's sixth and last winter graduation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 2 -- Samuel Goldwyn, Roberto Rosselini, Ingrid Bergman and Ilya E. Lopert today announced the conclusion of an agreement for Mr. Goldwyn to handle distribution in English-speaking countries of Mr. Rosselini's projected Italian film starring Miss Bergman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The United States produced 8 per cent more iron ore in 1948 than in 1947, but the total was still well below the production level of the record years of 1943 and 1944, the Bureau of Mines said today.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- When news of Premier Stalin's latest statement reached London, Britons in responsible positions felt sure that nothing could come of the maneuver. When Secretary of State Dean Acheson's reply was issued n Washington there was great satisfaction here.

MELBOURNE, Feb. 2 -- John Bromwich won his stubborn fight with the Australian Lawn Tennis Association today when he was chosen with Billy Sidwell and Frank Sedgman to challenge for the Davis Cup in 1949.

A new group of inexpensive decorative fabrics introduced yesterday at Gimbels has been designed to bridge the gap between stark abstract patterns and quaint provincial designs for informal rooms. In several of the Riverdale fabrics by John Little, simplified small-scale motifs create a provincial effect, while fresh arrangements and combinations of colors provide a contemporary feeling.

Jobs and housing for 10,000 displaced persons have been assured through the United States Resettlement Service of the National Lutheran Council, Miss Cordelia Cox, acting director, told the council yesterday at its thirty-first annual meeting at the Prince George Hotel.

The opening skirmishes for the metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championship will take place today, starting at 1 P. M., with the four field events to be contested at Columbia's South Field. The rest of the program will be held tomorrow night at the 102d Engineers Armory.

WARSAW, Feb. 2 -- In a traditional ecclesiastical ceremony, Dr. Stefan Wyszynski was installed today as Archbishop of Gniezno and Catholic Primate of Poland. The ceremony, which took place in the ancient cathedral city of Gniezno will be repeated here Sunday when Dr. Wyszynski also will be installed as Archbishop of Warsaw.

A burglar made himself so much at home yesterday in a Brooklyn house he was ransacking -- sitting down to a bottle of whisky and a television show -- that he could not bear to leave even to escape capture by the police.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -Effectiveness of Puero Rico's million dollar rum advertising campaign was questioned today by Harry L. Lourie, executive vice president of the National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers.

BOSTON, Feb. 2 -- A wage increase for 23,000 workers in twenty-four American Woolen Company mills in New England, New York and Kentucky was denied today by Raymond F. O'Connell, arbiter between the company and the Textile Workers Union of America, CIO.

Three electric eels in the grand ballroom of the Statler Hotel performed uneasily yesterday afternoon under the scrutiny of 200 electrical engineers attending the annual meeting of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers.

Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator; is expected to appear before the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee in Washington this morning to explain the ECA's first official viewpoint on pending legislation affecting the employment of United States vessels in the shipment of aid cargoes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -Pensions of $100 a month for 65-year-old veterans until social security is broadened to carry the load was urged today by Harold A. Keats, commander of ANVETS (American Veterans of World War II).

STUART, Fla., Feb. 2 -- Little Mile Lake, removed from this fishing village by the width of the St. Lucie River and a few miles of palmetto barren, is like a jewel in a tarnished brass setting and it has the kind of bass fishing you'd like to find near home.
MOSCOW, Feb. 2 -- Premier Stalin said today that his health would not permit him to go to Washington but that he would be glad to meet President Truman in the Soviet Union, Poland or Czechoslovakia.

James A. Moffett, former Federal Housing Administrator, told a jury in Federal Court yesterday that two officials of the Arabian American Oil Company asked him in 1941 to use his influence with the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt to obtain financial assistance for King Ibn Saud of Saudi Arabia.

Fortified with sundry bits of information from the Encyclopaedia Britannica and Webster's Dictionary, a native New Yorker spent forty-five minutes yesterday afternoon discussing sweet potatoes with eleven South Carolina youngsters.

Columbia College will sponsor a three-day Forum on Democracy next week for 120 high school and preparatory school boy student leaders, representing sixty-five schools, Dr. Harry J. Carman, dean of the college, announced yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 2 -- Edvard Kardelj, Yugoslav Minister of Foreign Affairs, announced today that he had informed the Soviet Government and governments of the Soviet bloc yesterday that Yugoslavia could not and would not participate in the Council for Economic Mutual Assistance recently constituted at Moscow.
Abe Stark, City Commerce Commissioner, charged yesterday that, when he turned his back for a moment, Grover A. Whalen "appropriated" his plans for promoting the city's commerce.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -Commerce Department agents are checking the costume jewelry trade and other tin users in "New York, Providence, R. I., and elsewhere" to insure compliance with Government orders to conserve supplies of that scarce material, officials said today.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Lord Pakenham, Minister of Civil Aviation, disclosed during a debate in the House of Lords today that he had directed the three British nationalized aviation corporations to reduce their deficit from an anticipated u9,000,000 [$36,000,000] during 1948 and 1949 to u5,500,000 for 1949-50.
The Transport Workers Union, CIO, announced yesterday settlement of a dispute with American Airlines affecting 4,500 service workers throughout the country.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The House passed and sent to the White House today a bill to continue through Sept. 30 the voluntary allocation program for scarce commodities.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UP) -- Speculation in grains and many other commodities has undergone a slump since the big speculative price boom which broke a year ago this week, it was revealed today.
BUDAPEST, Feb. 2 (UP) -- Cardinal Mindszenty, 56 years old, will go on trial tomorrow on expected charges of treason, espionage, plotting to overthrow the Government and black marketing.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 -- Ten companies and six individuals were indicted here today by a Federal Grand Jury on charges of conspiring to fix wholesale wallpaper prices in the United States.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Hydro-electric power developed in the International Rapids section of the St. Lawrence River would cost $20,000,000 a year less than comparable energy produced in steam plants, the State Power Authority declared in its annual report today.
ALBANY, N. Y., Feb. 2 (AP) -The State Commerce Department reported today the following conditions at New York ski centers:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- A delegation representing the American jeweled-watch-making industry reported after a White House visit today that President Truman had promised to consider granting them relief from Swiss competition.

Secretary of the Interior Julius A. Krug, described as "the biggest power operator in the world," gave further evidence yesterday of his claim to the title with the disclosure that the Northeastern section of the United States, including New York and the New England area, eventually may derive its electricity from the Federal Government.

Trade hedging and scattered commission-house selling of coffee futures eased prices in contract "D" 10 to 21 points on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Trading was general with the selling absorbed in part by trade hedge covering. Contract "S" declined 15 to 21 points.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- A House Armed Services Committee gave tentative approval today to a proposal that the authorized strength of the Air National Guard be fixed at a maximum of thirty-five air groups and 100,000 officers and men.

GREAT FALLS AIR FORCE BASE, Mont., Feb. 2 -- From this "city" of tarpaper shacks and subzero cold, the United States Air Force maintains a six-day-a-week flight service to Alaska, and in January carried 213 passengers, 174,148 pounds of cargo and 11,136 pounds of mail.

The price level of realty bonds reached a new high in January, according to Amott, Baker Co., which reported yesterday that it has replaced its former 200 issue index with forty issues. The former index had been in use since 1933. The company said the smaller list will permit greater flexibility in replacements.

LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 3 -- Enthusiastic plaudits for "The Heiress," which opened at the Haymarket Theatre last night, were re-echoed by British critics in today's newspapers. Not for a long time has a straight play received such benevolent notices.

Young as she is, Bonnie Douglas of Seattle, showed in her debut at Town Hall last night that she is already an accomplished violinist with a keenly refined musical sense. And the consonance between her technique and her musicianship gave her recital a special quality.

VIENNA, Feb. 2 -- Istvan Barankovics, head of the last real opposition party in Hungary, fled from that country today. He announced while passing westward through Vienna that he had dissolved his Democratic People's party in defiance of an order from Communist leader Matyas Rakosi that he take no such action until the trial of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty was over.

Reflecting unfavorable weather conditions in the West, the nation's gasoline stocks last week increased 3,090,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 114,677,000 barrels, compared with 111,587,000 a week earlier and 102,986,000 a year ago.
I had proposed ignoring the letter sent to you by Dr. Bernard C. Meyer, chairman of the New York Chapter of the Physicians Forum, and published in THE NEW YORK TIMES recently.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14, a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The program follows:

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 2 -- Robert L. Proctor of Tucson, Ariz., 23-year-old livestock inspector for the Mexican-American Commission to eradicate the foot and mouth disease here, lost his life as another victim of the ignorance in rural communities where the aims and methods of a scientific campaign are misunderstood.

Members of the syndicate marketing the $50,000,000 issue of thirty-year bonds of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., voted at a special meeting here yesterday to maintain "full adherence" to the week-old public offering price which would yield 2.88 per cent to investors.
A Bronx father evicted his only daughter, her husband and four young children from their home at 936 East 212th Street yesterday morning.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 2 (AP) -- A pair of brothers who once sold peanuts at Sportsman's Park -- Bill and Charlie DeWitt -- purchased controlling interest in the Browns today.
BOSTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Boston Weather Bureau issued today the following ski conditions in New England:

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- A fairly bright start for new account in the stock market here today was spoiled by losses in Anglo-Argentine issues following the decision of the Argentine central bank to stop granting foreign exchange permits pending the drafting of new peso exchange regulations.

Dr. Emanuel Neumann, president of the Zionist Organization of America, denounced the Committee for Progressive Zionism yesterday as part of a "chain of front organizations which have been disturbing the peace and unity of the Zionist movement."

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 -- The presidential fact-finding board that made recommendations on Dec. 17 in the dispute between the country's railroads and the sixteen non-operating railroad unions was asked today to re-enter the case to help reach a settlement.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The United States rejected a demand of Hungary for the return of two members of the crew of a Hungarian-Soviet airline plane who took control of the craft and escaped to the United States zone in Germany Jan. 4.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Meeting with the mayors and building commissioners of most of the cities of the state, Governor Dewey outlined today a program for setting up a state-wide building code that he believes can cut housing costs 10 per cent.

A new type of electron tube, no larger than the average tube in a home radio set, yet so outstanding in performance at very high frequencies that it is expected ultimately to triple or even quadruple the television program-carrying capacity of any inter-city video-relay link in existence, was described here last night at a meeting of the Institute of Radio Engineers.

LONDON, Feb. 2 (UP) -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said in a radio broadcast tonight that "we must not allow ourselves to be taken off our guard when we see other countries, who are none too friendly to us, maintaining large armed forces while we allow ours to wither away into insignificance."

The affairs of the $22,000,000 apartment holdings controlled by Samuel Broxmeyer, alleged bankrupt, were found yesterday to be so snarled and snagged as to require the retention of a specialist in real estate law by Abraham I. Menin, receiver for the Broxmeyer assets.

TOKYO, Feb. 2 -- Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, told a press conference here today he hoped to be able to turn over the administration of the United States occupation of Japan to civilian authority -- that is, the State Department -- as soon as practicable.

Organizations representing four countries, producing more than two-thirds of the world's apparel wool, have combined forces to increase the usefulness and the markets for wool in the United States and Canada, it was announced yesterday in San Antonio, Tex.

In another message through the press, Mr. Stalin has turned down President Truman's standing invitation for a return visit to Washington on the ground that his doctors veto it. But he repeats his offer to meet the President at a "mutually suitable place," provided that suitable place is in Russia or somewhere else behind the Iron Curtain.
SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The University of Utah basketball team won easily from the barnstorming Long Island University Blackbirds, 65 to 42, tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 26:

President Truman's concern over inflation, as indicated in his message to Congress, "is mainly retrospective" insofar as it applies to the private part of the economy, according to the National City Bank of New York. Discussing the outlook in the current issue of its Monthly Letter, published today, the bank asserts that "if there is further danger of inflation, it must lie in the contemplated increase in Government spending."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- President Truman expressed his deep regret today because the illness f Dr. Chaim Weizmann, Provisional President of the State Council of Israel, had caused the postponement until April of his trip here for a dinner in New York that they both were to attend.

Judge Harold R. Medina hinted at contempt proceedings yesterday in the trial of the eleven Communist leaders. This came when United States Attorney John F. X. McGohey called the court's attention to the distribution outside the court house of a pamphlet issued over the name of the New York State Committee of the Communist party.

BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 2 -Industry must recognize that the percentage of older persons in America's labor force is growing and "probably ought to gear itself to use them," Ewan Clague, Commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, said today at a University of California institute on adjustment of the aging population.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 2 -The trial of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty and of a still unknown number of his fellow-accused will open tomorrow morning. The trial will be held in the same room of the same building -- that of the Ministry of Justice -- and in the same week of the year as the trial of Matyas Rakosi twenty-four years ago on a similar charge.

Though the 1949 refrigerators aren't radically different from last year's models, they have one big advantage -- they're easier to get. Most of the leading manufacturers have held showings recently to introduce their new products. At these gatherings for the press and trade it's been emphasized that the units already are on dealers' floors.
C. Monteith Gilpin in your Jan. 20 issue repeats an old suggestion: The establishment of a diplomatic academy to train future diplomats.

Legislation that would tighten restrictions on stowaways and increase penalties has been introduced in the House of Representatives and is now in the hands of the House Committee on the Judiciary, it was reported here yesterday. The bill was written by Representative Emanuel Celler of New York.

The new arrival this morning at the Capitol is "The Bribe," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer melodrama starring Robert Taylor, Ava Gardner and Charles Laughton. Robert Z. Leonard directed and Pandro S. Berman produced. Vincent Price, John Hodiak and Samuel S. Hinds are also in the cast.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Office of Defense Transportation announced today that the provisions of its general order O.D.T. 18A, Revised-1, which requires heavy loading of carload freight, will be under suspension from 12:01 A. M., of Feb. 14, to 11:50 P. M., April 16. The suspension applies to all permits and special directions that have been issued under the order.

PARIS, Feb. 2 -- The French Cabinet discussed today President Truman's suggestion for the development of the backward areas of the world with United States technical aid. It decided that France would cooperate with her overseas territories and that her Ambassador should seek from the State Department a clarification of the project.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Dr. Leonard Scheele, Surgeon General of the Public Health Service, told the annual meeting of the American Social Hygiene Association today that there had been a surprising decline in syphilis during the past twenty-seven months.
Leaving for his Florida vacation yesterday by plane from La Guardia Airport, Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander emphasized that there was "no politics in his retirement."

The departmental trial of Fire Chief Peter Loftus came to an end yesterday before Trial Commissioner William R. Bayes. The commissioner said he would give a decision on Feb. 16, after the opposing attorneys had submitted briefs.

A plaque in memory of Martha and John Truman, parents of the President, will be unveiled by Leslie L. Biffle, Secretary of the United States Senate, at 4:15 P. M. today at the Four Chaplains Memorial Pool, Bronx Veterans Hospital, 130 West Kingsbridge Road, it was announced yesterday.
PARIS, Feb. 2 -- Small sailors, bretons and cloches in daffodil or beige lawn brought forth deserved enthusiasm at Legroux's opening.

City-sponsored negotiations to avert a strike of 1,500 bakers of rye bread, pumpernickel and rolls collapsed last night and the two unions involved told their members to quit work at 4 P. M. tomorrow. The delay in the walkout was intended to prevent spoilage of bread in preparation when the parley in the Municipal Building broke off at 8 P. M.

PARIS, Feb. 2 -- The first foreign witnesses for the Communist defense in the Kravchenko libel suit, a Member of the British Parliament and an American writer, today testified that "I Chose Freedom" was an inaccurate and unfair description of life in the Soviet Union.

With the help of enthusiastic friends whose number is legion, the George Junior Republic at Freeville, N Y., near Ithaca, is about to embark upon the long-range program of a larger physical plant and wider opportunities for serving youth that was envisioned for it in 1947.
A five-hour meeting yesterday at the city's Division of Labor Relations failed to produce a formula for forestalling a threatened Queens bus strike scheduled for 12:01 A. M. tomorrow.

An attempt by a Chicago brewery, controlled by the reputed "financial genius" of the Al Capone gang, to "push" its beer here through a recently formed corporation headed by Joe Louis, heavyweight champion, and Ray Robinson, welterweight champion, was blocked yesterday by the State Liquor Authority.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 2 -Plans by the University of Kentucky and Kentucky State College, a Negro land-grant institution, to provide "separate but equal" educational facilities for graduate students in this state have been only partly successful, authorities of both schools said today.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Charges of brutality and mismanagement at Central Islip State Hospital were declared today by Dr. Frederick MacCurdy, Commissioner of Mental Hygiene, to "be wholly without any basis of fact."

Bids have been received from St. Paul, Minn., Lake Placid, N. Y., and Boston to stage the 1950 International Ice Hockey Federation world championship tournament, it was announced yesterday at an executive meeting of the Amateur Hockey Association of the United States held at Madison Square Garden.

The Esso Zurich, first of a series of fourteen 26,555-deadweight ton "supertankers" being constructed for the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), has entered service after a successful trial trip during which the new ship exceeded her designed speed of 16 knots, M.
