G. Gamble, general manager of the company's marine department, announced yesterday.
ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Carrying out a plan in the Democratic program, Assemblyman Leonard Farbstein of Manhattan introduced a measure today to set up a statewide health insurance system.

Brazil is foremost among countries with large opportunities for investment of American capital, James A. Farley, chairman of the board of the Coca-Cola Export Corporation, said yesterday. He addressed more than 175 persons in the first of a series of international luncheons by the United States Trade Mark Association held yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

W. Whitehead, president of the Norwalk Tire and Rubber Company of Norwalk, Conn., said yesterday that the company will ask its bondholders to eliminate some of the present restrictions in the 4 per cent bond indentures so as to permit the company to seek new funds.

Despite his physician's assertion that the "emotional strain" of a prison sentence might "lead to dire consequences," Abraham M. Schwartz, real estate operator who admitted exacting illegal fees from apartment seekers, received an indefinite penitentiary term yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Secretary of State Acheson in effect rejected today the latest unofficial proposal of Premier Stalin for a "peace" conference with President Truman behind the Iron Curtain, at least on the basis on which it has been presented.

DETROIT, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings scored the first four goals, then went on to beat the Chicago Black Hawks, 6 to 4, tonight in a National Hockey League clash before 13,421 fans. Detroit's Ted Lindsay scored three goals.

The Dramatic Workshop Film Department of the New School for Social Research is expanding its schedule of motion-picture courses to include a full-time television production program under the supervision of John Reich, former CBS television director, for the spring semester, beginning Feb. 7.

Retail sales this spring will run from 5 to 10 per cent ahead of last year, according to Richard Bond, vice president in charge of merchandising, John Wanamaker, Philadelphia. Retailers seeking to realize this gain, which has been predicted as possible by the country's top-flight merchandising men, he said, will need full cooperation from fashion manufacturers.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 -- Magistrate John J. O'Malley, former chief of the city's minor judiciary, was aquitted of misfeasance in office late today by a jury of six men and six women.

TSINGTAO, China, Feb. 2 -- With the exception of a protective detachment similar to the one afloat at Shanghai, all United States marines stationed here will leave shortly, probably Monday. The departure is part of the Navy's gradual withdrawal from the Asiatic mainland after United States ships had operated out of Chinese ports since early in the century.

The converted transport Marine Shark, operated by the United States Lines, docked at Pier 62, North River, yesterday morning with 399 displaced persons. This was the seventh group of immigrants to arrive in this country under the terms of the Displaced Persons Act of 1948.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 2 -- Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, British Military Governor, sharply rejected today criticism by British business men that German recovery was resulting in unfair competition in the export field.

The City Planning Commission deferred action yesterday on a proposal that would lead to authorizing the Bulova Watch Company to build an assembly plant in what is now a predominately residential district in Forest Hills, Queens.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Britain is ready to resume normal diplomatic relations with the Franco Government in Spain, a Government spokesman indicated tonight, but Britain would not welcome Spain into the United Nations or the projected North Atlantic defense pact.

The centennial of the gold rush to California is causing the issuance of four books. Last month Atlantic-Little, Brown re-issued "Forty-Niners: The Chronicle of the California Trail," by Archer Butler Hulbert, with a new introduction by Joseph Henry Jackson.
SHREVEPORT, La., Feb. 2 (AP) -- A young naval airman put in a claim today for the title of the "forgotten" man of the year.
The Yankees yesterday announced the purchase of the contract of one Negro star and admitted negotiating for another.

The old order changes, and the places that we knew are lost in the shuffle. The Lafayette, in University Place, is the latest to be marked for that fate. And though we first found creature comfort and cheer there when it was run by J. B. Martin, it has been the Lafayette for more than thirty years, and in all that time has been much the same.

The audience that turned out for last night's "Concert for Civil and Human Rights" at Carnegie Hall wasn't remarkable for its great size, but it spared nothing in showing its appreciation of Carol Brice, the young Negro contralto. Most of the applause was occasioned by some excellent singing, but there is no doubt that a fair measure of it was tendered Miss Brice for her pluckiness in singing despite a case of laryngitis.
Emetia (Joe Pledge) Polizio, the Queens gambler who was convicted a year ago on charges of bookmaking, started a six-month penitentiary sentence yesterday.

Although many steel officials foresee a definite easing in the pressure for steel deliveries by the middle of the year, it is still expected that the industry can produce and market a record tonnage of finished materials during 1949. In New Orleans this week, Irving S. Olds, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, predicted that output of finished products this year would reach 68,000,000 tons.

In the atmosphere of "heightened social consciousness" in which industry operates today, it is apparent that human relations are as important as any of the relationships that must be considered by management in developing its employe program, Holgar J. Johnson, president of the Institute of Life Insurance, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The exertion of diplomatic pressure, both official and unofficial, through the media of the press and radio has been perfected by the Soviet Government in its frequent use of the totally controlled newspapers and broadcasting stations in the Cominform areas.

" Special deals," offered by some housewares manufacturers to retailers for quantity purchasing, are beginning to reach pre-war proportions in a limited number of items, buyers reported yesterday. The transactions, involving wholesale price discounts or special services, have occurred from time to time since the end of the war, but were stepped up appreciably last month and will increase from now on, they said.
W. Somerset Maugham, who speaks as sardonically as he writes, observed pointedly yesterday that he was not one of those who liked making speeches.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -Georgetown University upset Princeton's Eastern intercollegiate leagues leaders, 68 -- 60, in the second game of a basketball double-header tonight before a crowd of 3,881 in the National Guard Armory.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., minority leader of the House, introduced today a bill to reduce the excise tax rates on twenty "luxury" goods and services to their pre-war levels.

Larger deliveries of aluminum sheets have been received during recent weeks, and now this item is in "ample supply," Strahs Aluminum Company, Inc., 79 White Street, disclosed here yesterday. Some other semi-finished aluminum products remain hard to get, they added, but sheet inventories are plentiful.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UP) -Defense counsel for Mildred E. Gillars today won permission to call two witnesses from Germany to testify that she made "Axis Sally" broadcasts in wartime under Nazi death threats.

Mrs. Harvey B. Gaul received yesterday the Distinguished Service Cross posthumously awarded to her only son, Lieut. James Harvey Gaul, USNR, Office of Strategic Services officer, who was captured and shot by the German army in January, 1945.

BOSTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- After coming from behind twice, the Boston Bruins set off a three-goal explosion in the final period to regain their winning stride by defeating the New York Rangers, 5 -- 3, tonight. A crowd of 13,100 saw the National Hockey League battle at the Boston Garden.

A proposal that the International Monetary Fund be asked to furnish statistics on the position of foreign nations which would be of service to American exporters in warning them of impending dollar shortages or foreshadowing trade improvement was made yesterday at the meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Whether the number of atom bombs the United States has should be kept secret today became an issue within the Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy almost immediately after it convened for its first meeting in six months.
Three American public figures with widely different backgrounds agreed last night on a definition of democracy on THE NEW YORK TIMES' radio forum, "What's On Your Mind?" over Station WQXR.

Miss Helen Hokinson, caricaturist and creator of the plump and fluttery clubwomen familiar to readers of The New Yorker, stepped into one of her own "Madame President" cartoons last evening as she addressed a gathering of clubwomen at the American Women's Association, 111 East Forty-eighth Street.

Mrs. Sterling S. Beardsley of 784 Park Aveune and her son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. William Lawrence King, are sailing today on the Stockholm for Stockholm, Sweden, where they will attend the marriage on Feb. 14 of Miss Gunilla Stalhammer to Henry W. Beardsley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Beardsley.

Directors of Beaunit Mills, Inc., announced yesterday a 25-cent dividend payable to holders of common shares on March 1. Last year the common stockholders received 50 cents quarterly. I. Rogosin, president, explained that the reduced dividend was considered advisable in order to conserve funds to accelerate the payment of loans incurred in connection with the acquisition last Dec. 21 of the North American Corporation and the American Bemberg Corporation.
A cooperative shipper-carrier-underwriter movement to reduce huge losses caused by inadequate export packaging through improvement of standards got under way here yesterday.
That was no earthquake that was recorded last week on the City College Babor Seismograph Station. That was a spider.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 2 -- The Danish Parliamentary Committee for Foreign Affairs discussed today Denmark's future after the failure of the Nordic pact talks.

The New York Housing Authority received bids yesterday on issues of temporary-loan notes aggregating $23,500,000, for the temporary financing of four limited-subsidy projects -- the Eastchester Houses in the Bronx, Sheepshead Bay Houses in Brooklyn, South Beach Houses in Staten Island, and Woodside Houses in Queens.
The program of the Citizens Union for the current year is contained in its annual report made public yesterday. The list of the 1949 objectives of the union follows:
The Rev. Laurence J. McGinley, a tall, slim New Yorker who worked in a bank before he entered the Society of Jesus in 1922, took office yesterday as Fordham University's twenty-seventh president.

The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York increased its assets last year by $72,400,000 to $1,997,142,194 on Dec. 31, largest in the company's history, the 106th annual report to policyholders will disclose today.
TEL AVIV, Feb. 2 -- Mrs. Golda Myerson, Israeli representative in Moscow, will return here to take up a Cabinet post, it was stated authoritatively tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today for expected early Congressional action an authorization for a special contribution of $16,000,000 by the United States to help alleviate starvation and other distress among 479,000 Palestinian refugees.

GENEVA, Feb. 2 -- President Truman's statement of the United States policy to support the efforts of the free peoples of the world to develop their resources was warmly welcomed by David Morse, Director General of the International Labor Office, in a statement here today.
The chairman of a Westchester commuter group opposing the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad's application for a higher commuter fare challenged the railroad's cost figures yesterday.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 2 -- The American Federation of Labor strongly endorsed today a broad social security program, Federal aid to education, civil rights laws and a minimum wage of $1 an hour.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 2 -- Miss Betty Howe of New Haven defeated her twin sister, Peggy, in three straight games to win the 1949 Connecticut State Women's Squash Racquet singles championship today at the Greenwich Country Club. The scores were 15 -- 7, 15 -- 12, 15 -- 6.

The Dress Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, announced last night that strikes involving several thousand New York dressmakers would be called this afternoon as the first move in an organizing drive demanded by unionized employers.

Charley Ewart, quarterback at Yale a dozen years ago, yesterday was named coach of the New York Bulldogs (nee Boston Yanks) by Ted Collins, owner of the club that finished in the National Football League eastern division cellar last season.
NANKING, Feb. 2 (AP) -- China's Acting President, Gen. Li Tsungjen, may dare all and fly to Communist territory in a dramatic bid for peace, his friends said today.
RICHMOND, Va., Thursday, Feb. 3 -- The Commonwealth of Virginia seized public transit facilities in three cities at midnight. The action followed a long wage dispute.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The House Ways and Means Committee, by a vote of 17 to 8, approved without change today a bill to restore until June 12, 1951, the full authority under which the Hull reciprocal trade program was developed.

Deep hush of winter is on the land. Twice in each cycle of seasons Nature seems to pause as if gathering its strength for a new effort. In August and in February the tempo slows and days seem long. Walk abroad on a second-month night when white beauty is on the hills and a waxing moon follows its sky trail.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad reported today net earnings in 1948 of $34,429,934, virtually five times the carrier's 1947 profits of $7,285,125. In 1946, the first post-war year, the company operated at a loss of $8,530,317.

The directors of the New York War and Peace Memorial Committee voted yesterday to accept Borough President Hugo E. Rogers' proposals for a complete reorganization of the citizens' group formed two years ago to sponsor a World War II memorial in Manhattan.

From California came the fashion collection exhibited yesterday noon in the Cotillion Room at the Pierre Hotel. By Edith Small of Los Angeles, the fashions will be at Milgrim's in West Fifty-seventh Street.

The West Side branch of Americans for Democratic Action announced yesterday endorsement of Edgar J. Nathan 3d, Republican candidate for Assemblyman in the Fifth Manhattan District at the special election on Feb. 15. Most of the candidates previously endorsed by the organization in New York have been Democrats.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UP) -- Following is the official transcript of Secretary of State Acheson's press conference remarks on the Stalin "peace talk" bid:

The Board of Education submitted a budget estimate of $283,738,728, the largest for any of the city's 107 departments, to Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson yesterday. The figure is $23,749,237 above the present budget of the education unit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- A charge that the Bureau of Reclamation was "indulging in an unwarranted grasp for power" that threatened the continuance of the civil functions of the Army Corps of Engineers rang out today as the Senate started hearings on the Executive Reorganization Bill.

Modifications of the skip-bombing technique that battered and terrified the enemy during World War II have been used to put food on the doorsteps of farmers and hay under the nose of cattle snowbound in four Western states, Lieut. Col. Robert L. Rizon, commanding officer of the 2151st Rescue Unit of the Military Air Transport Service, said here yesterday.

OSLO, Norway, Feb. 2 -- On the day after the Norwegian Government delivered its reply to the Soviet Union on the proposed North Atlantic defense pact there is a hangoverish atmosphere in political circles here today. The feeling appears to have developed overnight that the Soviet Union will pick some flaw in the Norwegian statement and revert to the matter once more, whereas only yesterday Oslo seemed confident that the incident was closed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark advised the Senate Labor and Welfare Committee today that even in the absence of specific injunctive relief in the Administration's labor relations bill the President would have authority to seek an injunction in emergencies affecting national health and safety.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- A Republican campaign to force a quick Senate showdown in the effort to stiffen the closure or "gag" rule against filibusters was in preparation tonight.

NOTHING ever was particularly stationary about the Chicago Rockets except their position at the bottom of the standings in the All-America Conference. The owners changed every season and so did the coaches. But along with the annual house cleaning this year something new has been added. The name of the Rockets has been abandoned in the hope that the new one will carry a bit more fragrance.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Feb. 2 -- The strained period of uncertainty and of waiting for developments in Indonesia now appears to be nearing an end. A Government statement on the Netherlands' policy is expected soon.
The Salvation Army is mobilized twenty-four hours a day to meet emergencies that may strike any community. Minutes after a disaster occurs, the Army is on the job.
Research grants totaling $158,814, to be used by five New York medical colleges for studies of the circulatory system and its disorders, were announced yesterday by the New York Heart Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Charter of the Organization of American States, drafted last April at Bogota, Colombia, by representatives of twenty-one countries of this hemisphere, was placed before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in closed session today.

People may ask if it would not have been better if we had had fewer doctors and less treatment. Perhaps we tried to do too much. But Johnny loved life desperately and we loved him desperately and it was our duty to try absolutely everything and keep him alive as long as possible.

The bill to clear up the basing-point price confusion caused by court decisions and governmental agency rulings was endorsed yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc. The endorsement was contained in a letter by Thomas Jefferson Miley, executive vice president of the association to Senator Edwin C. Johnson, chairman of the Senate Trade Policies Committee, sponsor of the measure.
Traffic, police and legal experts strove yesterday to unravel a jurisdictional snarl brought about by the United States Supreme Court decision banning advertising on vehicles using the city streets.
RHODES, Feb. 2 (UP) -- Egypt has accepted, with some modifications, Dr. Ralph J. Bunche's proposals for a Palestine settlement, well informed sources said tonight.

As officers of organizations working for a just and humane solution of the problem of Europe's displaced persons, we feel that some comments are called for by the letter on DP legislation published in your paper on Jan. 12, signed by the officers of six important Jewish organizations.
EL PASO, Tex., Feb. 2 (AP) -Ben Hogan, king of the golfers, suffered a fractured pelvis, broken collar bone and possible fracture of a rib in a collision of his auto and a bus today.

Robert N. Carson, formerly a trust officer, has been elected a vice president of the Lawyers Trust Company. He succeeds the late Lane F. Gregory as manager of the branch office in the Empire State Building.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- British industrialists and trade unionists have become so concerned about German competition in world markets that they sent a delegation today to complain to Harold Wilson, President of the Board of Trade. After a long discussion he promised them an early statement on the whole position in the House of Commons.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Feb. 2 (AP) -A major New York milkshed producer group today endorsed a dealer proposal for a reduction in price to assure a market for surplus milk this summer.

The first break as a result of efforts by liquor retailers here to gain larger mark-ups, was disclosed yesterday when Russell Brown, president of American Distilling Company, Inc., said that after March 1 the last wartime liquor tax will be included with the 33 1/3 per cent mark-up now being extended.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Feb. 2 -Syracuse University's quintet routed Fordham tonight, 76 -- 42, for its tenth victory of the season. The Orange led throughout, piling up a 24-8 margin after 10 minutes of play. It was widened to 41 -- 19 at the half.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Secretary of State Acheson, unlike his last two illustrious predecessors, is approaching the press conference, not as an ordeal, but as an opportunity.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier yesterday in sympathy with other commodity markets, and final prices were 5 to 14 points net lower.

Charles B. Benenson sold the five-story business building at 52 West Fifty-seventh Street, between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, to the Rosenberg Foundation, a philanthropic fund, in a transaction negotiated by L. V. Hoffman Co., brokers.

The Welfare Department breaks new ground in policy with Commissioner Hilliard's announcement that a Foster Home Program is being set up by the city to find homes and place and supervise children in these boarding homes. As the Commissioner says, the private agencies, Protestant Catholic and Jewish, have made a "valiant effort" to find enough hoarding homes for children from households temporarily broken by illness or misfortune.

Concerned over mounting setbacks to the Congress of Industrial Organizations in the store field, leaders of two CIO unions put the finishing touches yesterday on a jurisdictional pact intended to prevent further defections and clear the road for organizational progress by both unions.
OMAHA, Feb. 2 -- Blizzard-rocked Nebraska, South Dakota and Wyoming faced a critical situation tonight as the Weather Bureau forecast another blizzard for Friday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Sergei Aleksevich Borisov, head of the Russian delegation, told the International Wheat Conference here today that his country was prepared to supply a substantial quantity of wheat for the world market during the life of the proposed multilateral compact, the International Wheat Conference reported.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Increases in the personal income, corporate franchise, gasoline and harness racing betting taxes recommended by Governor Dewey appeared today almost certain of legislative approval despite grumblings by some members of the Republican majority and united Democratic opposition.

Because he carried the fighting all the way, Paddy DeMarco, Brooklyn lightweight, received a decision over Humberto Sierra, Cuban, in the feature bout of ten rounds at the Manhattan Center, Tournament of Champions show, last night.

Harry Uviller, impartial chairman of the dress industry in New York, was elected chairman of the Nonpartisan Citizens Commission on Labor-Management Relations, sponsored by the Liberal party, at its first formal meeting yesterday at 1440 Broadway. Murray Baron was named secretary.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- (AP) -- The House of Representatives passed today a bill providing that any future cotton acreage allotments shall be figured without taking into account this year's plantings. Passage came on a voice vote in which no opposition was heard.

The Bristol-Myers Company and its subsidiaries earned $4,324,677 after taxes and all charges in 1948, the preliminary report disclosed yesterday. This is equal to $2.94 a share on the common stock and compares with $3,942,810, or $2.66 a share shown in 1947. The company is a large distributor of pharmaceuticals.

NANKING, Thursday, Feb. 3 (UP) -- The Chinese Communists offered a new peace plan last night after the Government suddenly stiffened its resistance and its Yangtze River gunboats opened fire on Red positions twenty-six miles northeast of Nanking.

PEIPING, Feb. 2 -- The United States Economic Cooperation Administration is withdrawing from Communist-held North China cities in spite of earlier indications that it would try to continue the distribution of its present stock of supplies after the Communist takeover.

HAVANA, Feb. 2 -- With sunny skies and smooth seas prevailing, three American and two Cuban yachts sailed today in the second race of the Cuba Cup series in the eighteenth international Star Class regatta.

A four-hour ground-and-air television program giving viewers aerial sights of New York, Washington, Cleveland and Chicago will be presented next Sunday at 1 P. M. by NBC in cooperation with the Air Force.

The French freighter Magellan, transformed from a lowly ore carrier to the envy of her country's merchant marine, brought the French Gratitude Train to New York yesterday amid a wel coming din surpassing that accorded the maiden arrival here of an ocean passenger queen.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- A United States compromise proposal aimed at breaking the deadlock over the German occupation statute is now being studied by the French. It concerns one of the two crucial points that have prevented an agreement -- a court of arbitration between the proposed German goernment and the occupying forces. The other point at issue is the collection of occupation costs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -Government export officials told Senators today they are considering the possibility of lifting all export license requirements for shipments of lard and other edible fats and oils, except to Europe.

RHODES, Feb. 2 -- The Israeli armistice delegation cannot accept the compromise proposals of Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, Acting Mediator for Palestine, for breaking the deadlock with the Egyptians and has handed him a series of counter-suggestions, an Israeli representative said tonight.

Miss Susan Brandeis, first woman lawyer ever to appear before the Supreme Court and daughter of the late Justice Louis D. Brandeis, has been a member of the Board of Regents of the State of New York since 1935. She was elected by the Legislature in that year to fill an unexpired term, then re-elected in 1937, the unanimous choice of both parties, to a full twelve-year term.

The stock market made small gains yesterday, but the advance was labored and price changes were only fractional. The drift was narrow most of the day and the composite rate rose but 0.21 point. Business on the Stock Exchange was slightly under Tuesday's volume of 730,000 shares, aggregating 720,000 shares.

Miss Susan Brandeis, first woman lawyer ever to appear before the Supreme Court and daughter of the late Justice Louis D. Brandeis, has been a member of the Board of Regents of the State of New York since 1935. She was elected by the Legislature in that year to fill an unexpired term, then re-elected in 1937, the unanimous choice of both parties, to a full twelve-year term.

The stock market made small gains yesterday, but the advance was labored and price changes were only fractional. The drift was narrow most of the day and the composite rate rose but 0.21 point. Business on the Stock Exchange was slightly under Tuesday's volume of 730,000 shares, aggregating 720,000 shares.

As one means of breaking down the barriers between the peoples of the many nations, a Friendship Train was organized last year by Drew Pearson and thousands of tons of foodstuffs were sent to Europe, a beau geste from us who have so much to others who had little.
ALAMEDA, Calif., Feb. 2 -- The Navy took over today the world's largest commercial-type landplane, the ninety-two-ton Lockheed Constitution, for its "airlift" between the Atlantic and Pacific Fleets.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 2 (AP) -- Jacob Sher's Frere Jacques lived up to his title of "Turf King" at Hialeah Park today when he won the $11,900 Bougainvillea Handicap in 1:57 1-5 to equal the track record.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 3 -- Four hitherto unstudied cuneiform inscriptions chiseled twenty-five centuries ago into the bluff face of Mount Behistun in Iran were revealed today to contain nothing but an exact duplicate of the neighboring designs relating the fabulous conquests of Darius the Great.

School District No. 5, Fulton County, Georgia, will receive bids on Feb. 15 on an issue of $5,000,000 of 2 1/2 per cent bonds dated March 1, 1949 and due on each March 1, from 1950 to 1973, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- A bill to exempt certain "basing point" price systems from anti-trust law prosecutions for two years is in the hands of the House Judiciary Committee. No date has been set for hearings.

The stock market failed yesterday to hold the gains it made earlier in the week and closed moderately lower. Interest was largely concentrated in a few low-price issues, all with insignificant price changes, and the average declined 0.19 point.

There are hundreds of shut-ins in New York City, who have few, if any, visitors to contribute cheer and comfort to lives that are lonely. The League of Mercy is an organization of women Salvationist officers who visit patients at Welfare. .Island, Bellevue and other hospitals, bringing flowers and small gifts, writing letters, doing outside errands and giving musical programs in the wards.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Some good lawyers here, asked by this correspondent for their opinion, flatly disagree with the Attorney General's statement that the President has implicit powers to seek injunctions to end emergencies that threaten the national welfare.

PARIS, Feb. 3 -- After a bitter debate, the National Assembly found tonight that there was no justification for a charge that Andre Marie, Minister of Justice and Vice Premier, had protected contractors who had helped the Germans build an "Atlantic Wall" in France during the war.

Agreeing that although the millennium was by no means in sight, Governor Dewey declared last night that New York State was leading the nation in combating discrimination and making the state a better place to live in. He cited as evidences of progress the creation of the State Commission Against Discrimination in Employment nearly four years ago and enactment last year of a law prohibiting discrimination in the field of higher education.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Liberty from Government control is the main Republican issue today, Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, chairman of the Senate Republican Policy Commissions told the advisory board of the National Federation of Women's Republican Clubs today.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 3 -- Laurels were pinned on White Plains today by the Automobile Club of New York because of the city's pioneer use of curb parking meters and off-street, self-liquidating, metered parking lots.

One of the most comprehensive displays of foreign-made motor vehicles ever offered in this country will be presented at the first International Automobile Show opening tomorrow at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, Twenty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue.

Representatives of schools, colleges, religious and community groups, the press and the entertainment world will meet at 4 P. M. today at. 500 Park Avenue to give progress reports on plans for the 1949 Brotherhood Week, which will be observed Feb. 20 to 27.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Counsel for the Transamerica Corporation pleaded today with the Federal Reserve Board to stop building up a "meaningless record" in its anti-trust proceedings against the huge holding company. The lawyer contended that documents introduced as evidence by the Reserve Board were "based on inferences, based on hearsay."
LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The process of drafting a constitution for the Council of Europe began today when the Permanent Commission of the Brussels Treaty Powers met in secret at the Foreign Office.

The time is drawing near, Judge Harold H. Medina indicated yesterday, when he will make his decision on the challenge to the Federal jury system whereby the eleven Communist leaders hope to avoid trial. He warned defense counsel if they have any briefs to file or arguments to make they had better prepare them promptly.

First offers of foreign magnesium have appeared in the New York market, attracted by a growing trend of American manufacturers to substitute this metal for more expensive aluminum alloy and corrosion resistant steel materials, purchasing sources disclosed here yesterday.

Leon Jolson paid his last $100 installment yesterday on a $2,000 loan he got from the United Service for New Americans about a year ago. Not only that. He gave Edwin Rosenberg, president of the service, a separate check for $1,000. "Please give it to someone who can be as lucky as I am in this wonderful country," he said.

A plan for establishing units in eleven neighborhoods to refer emotionally disturbed children to appropriate public or private agencies for treatment is included in the $2,335,000 year-round delinquency prevention program of the New York City Youth Board outlined yesterday by Herbert Bryan, its research consultant.

TOKYO, Feb. 3 -- The Japanese Government today asked the nation's farmers to turn in an additional 6,500,000 bushels of rice for ration distribution in urban communities so as to minimize the necessity for United States aid.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 3 (AP) -- Bug Juice, the Bermill Farm's Widener Handicap candidate, turned on one of his typical stretch rushes today to capture the Sunny Isles Purse at Hialeah Park.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings boosted their National Hockey League lead to six full games as they took a 4-2 decision from the Chicago Black Hawks before 15,931 fans tonight. The defeat dropped the Hawks back to fifth place, one point behind Toronto.

Americans' lack of understanding of their own business system and of the relationship of prices and profits "poses a major task for industry," Franklyn Waltman, director of public relations, Sun Oil Company, declared yesterday. He addressed the Sixth National Conference of Business Public Relations Executives at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Development of a real state university would be endangered if the Legislature should yield to the demand of the Board of Regents to reduce the temporary university trustees to the status of a planning board, Henry D. Sherwood, master of the State Grange and a university trustee, declared today.

Dr. Charles E. Fletcher, head of the Abbey Veterinary Hospital, has purchased the two-story building at 322 West 231st Street, southeast corner of Riverdale Avenue, the Bronx, as the new quarters for the hospital. It has been at 5220 Broadway for many years, in the area recently taken over by the city as the site for the Marble Hill housing project.

A rather serious minded Casey Stengel breezed into town from his Southern California home yesterday, flecked a few imaginary snow-flakes from his coat collar and forthwith let a roomful of baseball scribes in the Yankee offices know he had no illusions of the task that lay before his as the new manager of the Bombers.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Reasonable railroad profits are essential to the American system, William T. Faricy, president of the Association of American Railroads, declared today.

Duding the two months' halt in inductions because the Army recruitment quotas are full, the local draft boards will be busy classifying all their registrants for the first time in the post-war period, Col. Candler Cobb, New York City director of Selective Service, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Truman Administration is planning to create a special corps of negotiators to help represent the United States in future international conferences.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- A former American soldier who was captured by the Germans testified today that "Axis Sally" posed as a Red Cross worker when she interviewed wounded United States prisoners for Nazi broadcasts.
Acting Police Commissioner William P. O'Brien issued a stern order yesterday to top-rank officials of the Police Department to head off an influx of New Jersey gamblers into the city.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Berlin airlift has a higher safety record than the United States Air Force as a whole, it was reported here today in a special study of the airlift by a representative of the Civil Aeronautics Board.

An extensive and colorful exhibit of theatrical costume design opened last night at the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, arranged by Mrs. Aline Bernstein and Miss Polaire Weissman, president and executive director, respectively, of the institute.

Applications are now being taken for the third annual American Association of Advertising Agencies' examination for advertising to be held in New York on Feb. 19 and 26, it was announced yesterday. The closing date for applications is Feb. 11.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 3 -- The steering committee at the parliamentary assembly at Bonn, which is writing a constitution for the West German regime, accepted today an appeal by the city administration of Berlin to be considered the twelfth state in the projected confederation.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 -- The Transportation Association of America formally established here today a Central Atlantic regional forum, one of twenty-one groups being set up throughout the country to oppose nationalization of transportation and to deal with economic problems of the industry.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- Officers and directors of World Champions, Inc., headed by boxers Joe Louis and Ray Robinson, will meet here Tuesday to decide their course in view of yesterday's refusal by the New York State Liquor Authority to grant the company a wholesale beer license in New York City.

Proficiency in the indoor sport of pool, which some persons used to assume was a mark of a misspent youth, now may be an indication of many fruitful hours passed in the schoolhouse long after classroom studies were over.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 3 -- The increasing frequency of border clashes between North Korean Communist Army forces and South Korean police was described today by Defense Minister Lee Bum Suk as an "indication that the North Korean Communist regime is testing the strength of our defenses, with the intention of mounting an invasion of South Korea."

The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad should have showed a profit of $20,000 in June, 1948, on its Westchester County commuter business instead of a claimed loss of about $38,000, according to George E. Goldthwaite, consulting engineer for the Public Service Commission.
Translucent straws and big and little sister brims were featured by Irene of 16 East Fifty-second Street when she introduced her spring millinery yesterday morning.

The commandant of the Coast Guard has approved, with certain "specifications," the findings of the Third Coast Guard District Marine Board of Investigation into the collision between the tanker Eliza J. Nicholson and tug Ann Marie Tracy and the two barges that were in the latter's tow, it was announced yesterday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 3 -- Race relations in this city were described today by Negro leaders as "a yes-and-no policy of segregation, varying from situation to situation and likely to give the visitor a false picture of either progress or backwardness."

With prices of scrap metal having declined as much as $9 a ton since the beginning of the year and continuing to show weakness under extremely limited demand, the domestic scrap trade is becoming concerned lest the decline carry to a point to discourage collections of the material, a scrap official disclosed yesterday.

TSINGTAO, China, Feb. 3 -- Persistent reports of Nationalist plans to blow up the waterworks and power plant prior to leaving this city help to explain recent hints by the local Communists that the United States Marines are welcome to stay until the Communists are in full control.

Net income of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation and its consolidated subsidiaries increased last year to $102,335,053 from $75,666,792 in 1947, according to the statement issued yesterday for release today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Paul G. Hoffman, director of the Economic Cooperation Administration, urged Congress today to modify materially the pending and strongly backed demands for greater use of American ships in transporting aid cargoes "to avoid very serious damage to the European Recovery Program."

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 3 -- The American Federation of Labor plans to make its pronouncement tomorrow on the Administration's proposed new labor law, and indications are that it will be generally friendly. Criticism, if any, will be mild and deal with minor issues, it is said.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UP) -John L. Lewis was re-elected president of the United Mine Workers in December's balloting by the largest vote ever given him in his thirty years as head of the mine union.

The New York State car of the French Gratitude Train trundled up Broadway from the Battery to City Hall yesterday amid swirling ticker tape as 200,000 persons roared a tumultuous "Thanks" to the people of France.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 3 -- The independent Union of Marine Firemen, Oilers, Watertenders and Wipers will dedicate a new $300,000 hiring hall here tomorrow in memory of members killed in World War II.
Radar - directed recreation, featuring television tactics and walkie-talkie techniques, will make future camp vacations educationally profitable as well as pleasurable, it was said yesterday.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 3 -- Six-year-old Gloria Jean Keefe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Keefe of 69 Fifth Street, died today in the Elizabeth General Hospital of burns suffered ten hours earlier when her clothing caught fire in the kitchen of her home.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 -- In view of the acquittal of Magistrate John J. O'Malley, which it termed a "gross miscarriage of justice," the Commonwealth today decided to drop all pending charges against him and four other magistrates accused of wrongdoing in office.

MARYKNOLL, N. Y., Feb. 3 -- Maryknoll missioners will remain at their posts in China unless forcibly restrained, the Very Rev. Thomas S. Walsh, vicar general of the Catholic Foreign Mission Society of America, known as the Maryknoll Fathers, declared today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UP) -- The Administration today asked Congress to take away from the states and hand over to the Federal Government authority to issue oil and gas leases for lands under coastal waters.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 3 (UP) -- A twin-engined naval plane with five scientists and a crew of two aboard was missing tonight on a flight between the California desert and the Alameda naval air base.

The American Institute of Electrical Engineers met in New York to discuss the calculating machines which were developed during and after the war and which have been romantically called "electronic brains." At this meeting the machines were discussed in terms of human physiology and the human being in terms of electronics.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- Seven guest conductors were named today for the 1949-50 season of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra in a long-awaited announcement by Edward L. Ryerson, president of the orchestral association. Victor de Sabata, conductor of the La Scala Opera of Milan, will direct the subscription concerts of the first four weeks.

The Citizens Union announced yesterday that it would express no preference on candidates for member of the Assembly in the Fifth Manhattan District at the special election on Feb. 15 and pronounced all three "qualified." The Union's statement follows:
By a vote of 74 to 67 the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York at its monthly meeting yesterday at 65 Liberty Street adopted a resolution calling for a federalized National Guard.
RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Karen rebels tightened their hold on the Rangoon-Mandalay railway today and attacked a military police battalion at Tawa, thirty-eight miles north of Rangoon.

BUCHANAN, N. Y., Feb. 3 -- Organization of the National Police Associates Athletic League and the opening of a campaign for $3,000,000 to finance its fight against juvenile deliquency were announced here today by Mrs. Harold I. Thompson, secretary.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Merle Cochrane, United States representative on the United lations Good Offices Commission in Indonesia, who hgm been here for consultations, has left for Batavia, Java, plaything to have talks with officials of interested Governments en route, the State Department announced today.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The action of the Netherlands in Indonesia was praised here today by Winston Churchill during a ceremony at Guildhall in which Britain's wartime Prime Minister received from representatives of The Hague Government the Grotius Medal.

Although purchases have been spotty, the dress market is active both in the low and medium price ranges, it was learned yesterday from resident buyers and manufacturers. Extensive liquidations of stocks in January dress promotions, buyers said, have placed them in an open-to-buy position with indications that low-priced garments will be purchased for delivery through March 5, and higher priced goods through April.
GENEVA, Feb. 3 -- The Berlin Currency Committee of the United Nations Security Council will hold a plenary meeting tomorrow at which it will attempt to decide its future course

" The Situation in Asia," an analysis of the recent revolutionary upheavals of the Far East by Owen Lattimore will be issued April 14 by Atlantic-Little, Brown. The author was at one time political adviser to Chiang Kai-shek. The hook has been chosen by the Book Find Club as its April selection.

Ever since generous friends began to bring Coleman stoves instead of boxes of home-made fudge to his new apartment, it has dawned on the veteran that some confusion seems to exist about how life goes on in one of the big new housing projects springing up on Manhattan's East Side.

BUDAPEST, Feb. 3 (Reuters) -- Cardinal Mindszenty admitted that he had written to the United States Budapest Legation about ten days ago asking that a car and a plane be readied for an escape. The letter was produced in court by the prosecutor. It read:
ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey declared today that the trial of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty of Hungary would be "merely a mock formality, an insult to religion and a cruel parody of justice."
The National Arts Foundation, 60 Broadway, a philanthropic organization formed in 1947 for the encouragement of the arts, announced yesterday the appointment of new advisers to its councils.
High school students from this city won ten of forty bids to compete for $11,000 in Westinghouse Science Scholarships, it was announced in Washington yesterday.
Revival of a waterfront racket known as "gypsy chasing" was disclosed yesterday in Brooklyn with the arrest of two truck drivers on a charge of coercion.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 3 -- The conviction of Max Reimann, Western Germany's Communist leader, by a British Military Government summary court for attempting to intimidate German officials who cooperate with the occupying power has inspired a series of strong objections from non-Communist quarters.

Plans for a new retail center in Queens were revealed by Webb Knapp, Inc., yesterday in connection with the announcement of the acquisition of the land at the southwest corner of Parsons Boulevard and Union Turnpike in Flushing from Joseph Balducci.
OMAHA, Feb. 3 -- Racing against the menace of a new blizzard, "the greatest bulldozer operation ever organized" freed 4,856 more persons in snowbound Nebraska, South Dakota and Wyoming today.

The Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, acknowledged yesterday the jurisdiction of its sister CIO union, the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, in the department store and men's clothing field throughout the country.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 3 -- Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, Roman Catholic Primate of Hungary, denied today that he had ever participated in a plot to overthrow the Hungarian Government, but said, "I am guilty in principle and in detail of most of the accusations made."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- President Truman told a group of young student visitors from the seventeen countries participating in the European Recovery Program today that he hoped that by the time they were as old as he, the United Nations would have assured world peace.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- John W. Belcher, former Parliamentary secretary of the Board of Trade, against whom a finding of improper conduct was brought last week by a Tribunal of Inquiry, gave up today his seat as a member of Parliament.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 3 (AP) -- Lloyd Mangrum of Chicago paced the field in the first round of the $10,000 Tucson open golf tournament today with a six-under-par 64. One stroke behind was the long hitting Chick Harbert of Detroit, Eric Monti, Santa Monica, Calif., and Johnny Bulla, Pittsburgh.
OSLO, Feb. 2 (UP) -- Foreign Minister Lange told Parliament today that Norway must seek security through regional defense treaties because the United Nations "cannot be counted on."

TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 3 -- State Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper, reporting on his 1948 administration on the eve of his retirement, declared today everyone of 200 gambling raids conducted by his operators could have been made by municipal police if they were "doing their full duty."

In 1911 State Senator Franklin D. Roosevelt introduced a resolution in the New York Legislature looking toward revision of the divorce laws and calling for New York's representatives in Congress to initiate action toward a Federal uniform divorce law.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- A prediction that the Senate would accept no sort of amendment hardening the "gag" rule without important advance reassurances from its proponents was made today by the chairman of the committee in control of the issue.
Assets of the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, as of Dec. 31, amounted to $1,234,396,623, a gain of $80,633,848 for the year, Alexander T. MacLean, president, reported yesterday.

The elegant simplicity that marks furniture by T. H. Robsjohn-Gibbings has been highlighted effectively in a series of three spacious interiors completed yesterday at Altman's. This is the first time that Mr. Gibbings' designs have been presented in New York City on such an expansive scale.

To the people of the snowbound cattle country of the Great Plains and the Mountain States, the sound of a plane's motors overhead today means, as it does to the non-Communist residents of Berlin, not war but peace, not destruction but rescue.

The recent reactivation of the United Service Organizations has called to mind that there is a big job to do for the men in our armed services and for wounded veterans. Throughout the country a drive is under way with a goal of $6,650,000 which must be raised if the men in the armed services and our invalid veterans are to be served properly.

Twenty years ago a crusade was begun to liberate an army -- an army of the blind. Today, The Seeing Eye, a national philanthropy which receives its support through membership and public contributions, has reached a milestone in its untiring campaign as it embarks upon its third decade of training and providing dog guides to the blind, both civilian and military.

Intensive research on the causes of mental disorders, their cure and prevention is being carried on at the Psychiatric Institute and Hospital, owned and supported by this State. The fourteen-story building overlooking the Hudson River at 168th Street is the research center of the State.

Large Grade A eggs at last have come down to a level at retail that, according to one authority in the trade, is more fairly in line" with the wholesale price. The city-wide average today, the City Department of Markets reports, is 69 cents a dozen, which is 4 cents less than that of last Friday. In one large chain the price is 65 cents.

For the first time in this country, Helen Hayes and her daughter, Mary, will be seen in "The Glass Menagerie." Two performances are planned for late July as part of the Rockland Foundation Summer Theatre Project. They will given in the Nyack High School Auditorium with the entire proceeds going to the foundation.

James A. Moffett, Federal Housing Administrator from July, 1934, to September, 1935, asserted in a letter written some years later that while he was in Washington he "was really doing more work and was in a much more helpful position for the Standard Oil Company than if I had remained in the office at 30 Rockefeller Plaza."

HAVANA, Feb. 3 -- Lockwood Pirie's Star Class yacht Twin Star of Wilmette Harbor, Ill., won the Cup of Cuba for the second consecutive year today when she crossed the finish line in second place for a three-race total of 16 points.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The State Department indicated today that the United States might be prepared to support a movement in the United Nations for restoring ambassadorial representation by the powers in Spain but that it would not take the initiative in the matter.

The Koppers Company, Inc., in 1948 had the largest sales and earnings in its history, but the margin of profit was only 5.25 cents for each dollar of sales, the annual report to stockholders disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- President Truman agreed today with Tom C. Clark, Attorney General, that he had inherent power under the Constitution to halt national strikes affecting health and safety without specific authority derived from the Administration's labor relations bill.

NBC finally announced yesterday its decision to permit use of recordings of programs made in advance of broadcast time. The action, which had been rumored for several weeks, follows similar steps taken by ABC and CBS and comes as an aftermath of complaints by NBC performers who felt they could put on better shows without the pressure of knowing they were on the air.

BOSTON, Feb. 3 (AP) --Manhattan College defeated Boston college, 68 to 54, before 6,575 basketball fans at the Boston Garden tonight. In the first game of the double-header, Holy Cross beat Temple, 59 to 50.

PARIS, Feb. 3 -- Although there was visible regret in some quarters today that Mr. Stalin's indirect overture to Mr. Truman had proved futile, this episode in the Soviet-Western tension showed the French Government and many Frenchmen to be far less jittery and more sympathetic to the United States attitude than they were a year or so ago.
Consumers of rye and pumpernickel bread and rolls were assured temporarily last night of a continuing supply of their favorite bakery products.

Many women who have taken an active interest in Colony House, Brooklyn, are serving with Mrs. Charles S. Ackley on the patroness committee for the dinner dance in behalf of the organization to be held tommorow night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein said in his annual report today that the Department of Law closed 40,839 legal matters and collected $2,706,466 for the state during 1948. The volume of work handled was about 6 per cent greater than in 1947.
Traditional furniture that does not cost a small fortune is the theme of the "Penny Wise Shop" that will reopen Monday morning at W. J. Sloane.

A gift of $1,000 was presented yesterday to the New York Public Library toward its fund drive by the American Academy of Arts and Letters and its affiliated organization, the National Institute of Arts and Letters.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Two Texas football products, Phil Handler and Ray (Buddy) Parker, today were elevated from assistant to co-head coaches of the Chicago Cardinals of the National Football League.
MONTREAL, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs hung a convincing 4-1 defeat on the Montreal Canadiens tonight in a rough and tumble National Hockey League game.

The draw for the 1949 Davis Cup play will be held in New York and will be conducted by Trygve Lie, secretary general of the United Nations, it was announced yesterday by the U. S. Lawn Tennis Association. The ceremony, usually conducted in Washington, will be staged next Tuesday morning at the Manhattan Building of the United Nations, First Avenue and Forty-second Street.

MOSCOW, Feb. 3 (UP) -- G. M. Popov, secretary of the Moscow branch of the Communist party, charged today that United States and British leaders were afraid an agreement with the Soviet Union would "undermine * * * their aggressive warmongering policy:"

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- President Truman today appointed his friend and former Senate colleague, Mon C. Wallgren, former Governor of Washington, as chairman of the National Security Resources Board, whose mission is to plan mobilization on an over-all national security basis.

The cutbacks in naval personnel and ships in operation reported to Congress yesterday by Navy Secretary Sullivan mirror a change in strategic concepts more than a reduction in fighting capacities of the United States fleets. Despite the cutbacks the United States Navy remains the most powerful in the world; probably more powerful than the combined fleets of the rest of the maritime nations, including both sure friends and potential foes.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Feb. 3 -- Morris S. Karp was removed today from the post of city manager after he had been accused of incompetency, inefficiency and "conduct unbecoming a city manager," by Russell E. Ficke, president of the City Council, and Councilmen Frank Barbieri and Morris Fleishman.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 3 -- The twenty-six-nation executive board of the Untied Nations International Children's Emergency Fund today approved plans for undertaking a second world-wide collection of funds from private sources in 1949, to supply supplementary food, medicines and clothing for needy children.

New York University, defending its varsity team title, will carry a 1-point lead over Manhattan into tonight's concluding session of the seventh annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate indoor track and field championships at the 102d Engineers Armory.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Department of Commerce today suspended for six months all export-license privileges of the Sheldon Merchandising Corporation, 2 West Forty-third Street, New York.

A Federal judge and a Supreme Court justice signed separate orders yesterday to stay the Sheriff's hammer from falling this morning on the lounge furniture, refrigerators, blankets and linens and other movables in the Ansonia Apartments, at Broadway and Seventy-third Street.

" John Loves Mary," a Warner Brothers farce-comedy version of the stage success, starring Ronald Reagan, Jack Carson and introducing Patricia Neal, opens today at the Strand. Phoebe and Henry Ephron wrote the script from the Norman Krasna play, and David Butler directed, with Jerry Wald as producer.
William J. Crawford has been appointed manager of dealer sales for the Great Lakes Carbon Corporation's building products division.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Administration supporters hammered away at the need for 1,050,000 new units of low-rent housing in the next seven years as Senate hearings opened today on more than a half dozen major housing proposals.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 3 -- In a casting switch, Universal-International today assigned Ann Blyth to the leading feminine role opposite Robert Montgomery in "Come Be My Love," and named Marta Toren to replace Miss Blyth in "Desert Legion," Robert Buckner's projected film about Palestine, in which Miss Blyth had been scheduled for the chief feminine role.

NANKING, Feb. 3 -- Politically, Nanking, former capital of China, has become a backwater. Yu Yujen and Tung Kuan-hsien, presidents of the Control and Legislative Yuans respectively, have urged Premier Sun Fo to bring his Cabinet back to Nanking to tackle the job of making peace.

In a letter to the editor on Jan. 21 Dr. Sam Parker, director of psychiatry, Department of Hospitals in New York City, charges psychologists and social workers with seeking licensure only to extend their activities in the psychiatric field. To grant them licensure, he insists, is only to ensconce them further in their already illegitimate practice of medicine.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The long and happy "marriage" of the Hickey-Freeman Company and the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, marked by collective bargaining and the closed shop, was cited as worthy of emulation for industrial peace in a case study issued today by the National Planning Association.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The National Cotton Export Advisory Board will meet here Feb. 23 and 24 to discuss the world market outlook for the staple.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- John L. Sullivan, Secretary of the Navy, disclosed today plans to reshape the nation's sea power for the double purpose of strengthening its anti-submarine forces and conforming to President Truman's proposed Navy budget.

As the climax to the largest gathering of public-power proponents in history, the convention of the politically influential National Rural Electric Cooperative Association fired yesterday a barrage of twenty resolutions urging President Truman and the Congress sharply to increase the public-power budget and broaden the powers of several public agencies.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- Under Dr. William M. Leiserson as chairman, a Presidential fact-finding board will start a new effort here Monday to settle the wage-hour dispute between the railroads and sixteen non-operating unions with 1,000,000 members.

Last spring we witnessed the spectacle of three brotherhoods threatening a nation-wide strike even after the facilities of the Railway Labor Act had been exhausted and after the White House had intervened directly in the dispute. How was a breakdown of the national transportation system avoided on that occasion?

Washington Wilkerson, a Harlem taxi cab driver, vowed last night that he was going to try another business if he got another passenger as whimsical as George Carter, 23 years old, of 105 Vilest 114th Street.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 3 -- War weapons might have been developed "as dangerous" as the atomic bomb but more difficult to control, Maj. Gen. Frederick H. Osborn, deputy United States representative to the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, declared here today.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Replying to expressions of concern about Britain's ability to hold Hong Kong a Government spokesman said in the House of Lords today that Britain intended to stand fast and that, in view of the success of the Communists in China, would take all practical measures for the colony's defense.

A syndicate formed by Samuel Knepper had purchased from Samuel Greenberg the fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 175 West Seventy-sixth Street, corner of Amsterdam Avenue, for cash above a first mortgage of $705,000 held by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company which has been extended for ten years in connection with the deal.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and final prices were 4 to 8 points higher on the day.

ROME, Feb. 3 -- A Vatican spokesman today branded Cardinal Mindszenty's trial a "travesty" while Osservatore Romano editorially remarked that the Budapest Government had failed to produce a single convincing proof of his guilt.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 3 -- Ithaca College, with an enrollment of 1,450 students and faculty and staff of 172 persons, is giving consideration to moving from Ithaca, where it is overshadowed by Cornell University, and perhaps settling in Westchester County, it was learned today.

In connection with reports of the possible drugging of Cardinal Mindszenty during his trial by the Hungarian Quisling Government, I was surprised to see no mention made in these reports of the fantastic conduct of the "defendants" in the Soviet purge trials of the Middle Thirties.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 3 -- The first important purchase of Indonesian raw material by the United States for strategic stockpiling purposes was announced here today. It calls for delivery within six months of about 10,000 tons of palm oil worth about $3,970,000, representing nearly 50 per cent of the exportable surplus of the commodity on Sumatra.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 3 -- Secretary of State Acheson's reply to Premier Stalin is interpreted here as indicating that, unless the Soviet Union backs down, there is no immediate prospect for the settlement of the Berlin dispute.

The maintenance of Christian missionary activities among Jews had become a means of combating anti-Semitism, the Rev. Harold Floreen of Chicago, secretary of the Department for the Christian Approach to the Jewish People of the National Lutheran Council, declared at a session of the council's thirty-first annual meeting yesterday afternoon in the Prince George Hotel.

Reference is made to your editorial of Jan. 27 on another "bonus." What was said and the tune of the editorial were contrary to that of many citizens and veterans. Certainly something is forthcoming for the time and sacrifices made by the veterans. A year in the service during wartime is equal to two or three years in civilian life. In view of the circumstances, the benefits as set forth by the several veterans'@

NANKING, Feb. 3 (UP) -- The Communist armies began withdrawing from the Yangtze River line at several places today in a series of unexplained moves. Whether the withdrawal was in connection with renewed Government peace efforts was not known.

Tax exemption in Puerto Rico offers outstanding advantages to United States companies in many Simons, attorney and tax authority, told the luncheon meeting yesterday of the American Marketing Association at the Sheraton Hotel.

EL PASO, Tex., Feb. 3 (AP) -- They said at the hospital today that Ben Hogan, golf's terrific atom, had a bright disposition. As some pal of the links, knowing the durability and spirit of the little Texan, might quip: "why shouldn't he -- he only has a fractured pelvis, broken collar-bone, fractured rib and a few other assorted injuries?"

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Miss Katharine F. Lenroot, chief of the Children's Bureau, told the National Commission on Children and Youth today that this country should consider setting up a system of family allowances.

For increased customer service, Abraham Straus, Inc., will open officially on Monday their new thrift fashion floor where misses and women's budget-priced coats, suits; dresses, rainwear and millinery will be grouped in a series of inter-opening shops.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The House Committee on Expenditures in the executive departments reported favorably today a compromise bill giving the President broad powers to make administrative reforms conducive to greater economy and efficiency in Government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Jan. 29, 1949, totaled 679,255 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 30,330 cars, or 4.3 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 47,090 cars, or 6.5 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 155,796 cars, or 18.7 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.

Lines of men's wear worsteds and woolens for next fall will be opened on Tuesday by the American Woolen Company, it was stated yesterday by Charles H. Silver, vice president and general sales manager. He indicated prices will hold to current (spring) levels. Mr. Silver added that women's wear fabrics will be opened between Feb. 15 and 20.

Recent acceleration of the Government program of stockpiling large quantities of copper, lead, zinc and other critical and strategic materials may influence world trends in production and prices for some time to come and will stimulate world-wide development and exploration in the field of non-ferrous metals, according to the Northern Trust Company, Chicago.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- An increase since September of 10 to 15 per cent in the number of school lunches served in New York State schools participating in the Federal-State school lunch program was reported today by John J. Ward Jr., senior education supervisor in the State Department of Education.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Southwest Power Administration has rejected an offer of eleven private utility companies to buy its power output for twenty years.

Readers of this newspaper this morning will find Winston Churchill's familiar name in two stories and several columns. Mr. Churchill yesterday made a speech in the London Guildhall as he received the Grotius Medal "in recognition of his services to the cause of peace."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The National Labor Relations Board split three to two today in barring the organizing committee of the Optical and Instrument Workers CIO, from participation in a collective-bargaining election because Philip Murray, CIO president, had not filed a non-Communist affidavit.

If a performer takes a personal interest in his work, you can expect a fascinating performance. Every member of the Vinaver Chorus -- and the string orchestra which assisted it last night at Town Hall -- seemed to be dedicated, and the result was highly satisfactory.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Feb. 3 (AP) -- Misses Pat Devany of Grosse Isle, Mich., and Marjorie Lindsay of Decatur, Ill., opened defense of their women's international four-ball golf championship today with a 2 and 1 victory over Alice O'Neal of Indianapolis and Lee Bongart of Champaign, Ill., at the Orange Brook Country Club.

Skiing prospects for the week-end are the brightest of the season thus far but what the elements do overnight will decide the type of sport that metropolitan enthusiasts are to have tomorrow and Sunday. Currently, skiing opportunities are unlimited in most places and the Poconos, Catskills and Adirondacks, the Berkshires, Green and White Mountains and the Laurentians of Eastern Canada are buried under mantles of white.

The Dress Joint Board of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, AFL, called strikes yesterday against twelve dress manufacturers who had refused to sign new two-year contracts with the union. Eight hundred workers were involved in the walkouts, the union estimated.

An ingratiating exhibition of American paintings that hark back to the Victorian and early twentieth-century eras in art has opened at the American British Art Center. Work by Innes, Whistler, Homer, Chase, Hassam, Lawson, Eilshemius and early realists, such as Bellows, Sloan and Henri, is included in this show that has been assembled from a number of local galleries and private collections.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- During the week ended Feb. 2 member bank reserve balances decreased $324,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The strangulation of liberty that is being perpetrated in Eastern Europe after a war fought in the name of freedom is illustrated again by the "trial" of Cardinal Mindszenty, which began in Budapest yesterday. The Cardinal is accused of treason, espionage and -- in line with the methods introduced by Hitler to discredit the churches -- with the nonpolitical crime of black market operations.

CHICAGO, Feb, 3 -- About 110 of the brokers who handled the first public offering of stock of the Tucker Corporation were told today by Preston Tucker and Floyd Cerf that their "spiritual" cooperation on behalf of the company's reputation would be appreciated, as would more earthly assistance if there is a second stock sale.

The Zoe de Salle collection that made its spring debut yesterday noon in the Terrace Room of the Plaza Hotel -- it was the first time that this designer has shown outside of her own establishment at 18 East Fifty-third Street -- abounded in vibrant and beautiful prints.

After floundering around for the last two seasons, the American Negro Theatre has taken a new lease on life. Last evening it put on two interesting one-act plays at the Harlem Children's Center, 28 West 134th Street -- Synge's "Riders to the Sea" and Kenneth White's "Freight."

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- Changes in grain prices were irregular on the Board of Trade today. Liquidation was not heavy except in corn, which ended around the low for the day with losses of 1 3/8 to 2 1/2 cents, the latter on December which has declined 7 1/4 cents in the last two days.

After thirty-eight years of uninterrupted service as a community center, Bronx House, at 1637 Washington Avenue, closed its doors last night as the culmination of a labor dispute. Mrs. Louis Langman, president of the center, expressed hope it would reopen Monday morning.
For the first time in military history within the United States, three Army enlisted men sat in judgment yesterday on one of their fellows as he faced court-martial proceedings.

After registering increases in three successive weeks, business loans by banks in this area declined $27,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday. According to the data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, repayments by utilities, grain and food processors and paper manufacturers were the principal influences in the latest decline in borrowings from the New York City reporting member banks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture issued an order today suspending the registration of Irving Weis Co., New York commodity brokerage firm, as a futures commission merchant for ten days. The suspension will become effective on Feb. 11 and ends on Feb. 20.
BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 3 -- The University of California unveiled today a noisy new atom smasher which, though relatively small, is the world's most potent producer of X-rays.
For the first time in military history within the United States, three Army enlisted men sat in judgment yesterday on one of their fellows as he faced court-martial proceedings.

After registering increases in three successive weeks, business loans by banks in this area declined $27,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday. According to the data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, repayments by utilities, grain and food processors and paper manufacturers were the principal influences in the latest decline in borrowings from the New York City reporting member banks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture issued an order today suspending the registration of Irving Weis Co., New York commodity brokerage firm, as a futures commission merchant for ten days. The suspension will become effective on Feb. 11 and ends on Feb. 20.

Eliezer Kaplan, Minister of Finance for Israel, arrived at Idlewild airport at 10:10 o'clock last night for a conference with United States officials on arrangements for a $100,000,000 loan from the Export-Import Bank to Israel.

RARITAN, TOWNSHIP, N. J., Feb. 3 -- A woman was killed and three persons, including a Roman Catholic priest, were seriously injured when a car in which they were riding swerved off of Route 25 near Main Street and crashed into a telephone pole shortly before 1 o'clock this afternoon.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Hector McNeil, Minister of State, questioned today Premier Stalin s motives in proposing a meeting with President Truman. Speaking in Sheffield, Mr. McNeil said the loudspeaker appeared to have become an instrument of diplomacy. He added that both Adolf Hitler and Mr. Stalin had employed it extensively, but neither with marked success.

Eliezer Kaplan, Minister of Finance for Israel, arrived at Idlewild airport at 10:10 o'clock last night for a conference with United States officials on arrangements for a $100,000,000 loan from the Export-Import Bank to Israel.

RARITAN, TOWNSHIP, N. J., Feb. 3 -- A woman was killed and three persons, including a Roman Catholic priest, were seriously injured when a car in which they were riding swerved off of Route 25 near Main Street and crashed into a telephone pole shortly before 1 o'clock this afternoon.

A proposal that strategic military bases be administered by or under the direction of the United Nations was advanced yesterday by the American Association for the United Nations. The group, reviewing the work done by the world organization during the last year, called the quest for such bases one of the greatest causes of fear in the world today, and it urged that they be created as "police stations for the maintenance of collective security."
LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Although the stock market here today generally was quiet, most sections were firm.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Navy made a record of sorts here tonight when it flew its Lockheed Constitution from Moffett Field, Calif., to the Washington National Airport non-stop with ninety persons on board. The biggest land plane in service made no speed records. The run required nine hours and thirty-one minutes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- President Truman, through a last-minute appeal by telephone, prevented a Democratic split in the House Banking and Currency Committee today with the result that the Administration's Export Control Bill was reported out virtually unchanged.

The Harmonie Club won top honors in Group 1 of the Metropolitan squash racquets Class C interclub league last night by defeating the Seventh Regiment team, 4 -- 1. As a result, the Harmonie team finished the league season with thirty-two victories and eight defeats, while the Downtown A. C., which ended its schedule earlier, was next with 30 -- 10, and Seventh Regiment third, 23 -- 17.

The Port of New York Authority has again asked the Civil Aeronautics Board for a "full investigation" of the proposed new economic regulations that would restrict if not cripple the irregular or noncertificated air carriers of the nation, Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the bi-state agency said yesterday.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 3 -- The Hungarian Government today refused to allow a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES to attend the trial of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty. A ticket to the court room was refused the correspondent on the ground that there was "no room."

OSLO, Norway, Feb. 3 -- Foreign Minister Halvard M. Lange told Parliament today that before Norway decided her attitude toward the North Atlantic defense pact the government would investigate its terms closely so that more information that was at present available could be put before Parliament.

Henry Morgenthau Jr., who headed the United Jewish Appeal in 1947 and last year, received an inscribed silver plaque in tribute to his leadership in the appeal's drives at a special ceremony yesterday in his office at the Modern Industrial Bank, 116 Fifth Avenue.

RHODES, Feb. 3 -- Egypt offered today to accept the compromise proposals of Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine, for an armistice with Israel with "minor alterations," according to a reliable source.

SCRANTON, Pa., Feb. 3 -- An Italian immigrant who was sentenced to die in the electric chair in 1923 for murder was granted United States citizenship today over objections by the Immigration and Naturalization Service.
