Several new pieces of furniture by the noted Swedish designer Bruno Mathsson were introduced yesterday at Bonniers. 605 Madison Avenue, along with variations of his "lying-down" chair of webbing and wood, which has inspired many recent lounging pieces.

VIENNA, Jan. 28 -- A report that the terrorist Moslem Brotherhood in Egypt has formed a suicide squad of 200 men, each sworn to give his life to the cause in some venture such as the assassination of Premier Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha, was received by foreign diplomatic quarters just before this correspondent left Egypt recently.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- President Truman declared today that this country would not consider any negotiations with the Soviet Union outside the ordained councils of the United Nations.

A "Spitfire" Prelude and Fugue by William Walton, taken from a score he composed for a picture, received its New York premiere last night when Leopold Stokowski directed the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall. One is driven to ask why?
CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The American accidental death rate with lower last year than in any year for which records were compiled.

Despite a record construction year for the New York City Housing Authority in 1948, the city is still short about 260,000 apartments, James H. England, executive director of the authority, reported yesterday.

RED BANK, N. J., Feb. 3 -- William S. Mustoe, Captain of Detectives of the Monmouth County Prosecutor's Office, variously known as "The Man Who Can Make a Horse Talk," "The Parson" and "The Cop With a Hundred Hats," is observing his thirty-fourth anniversary as a "sleuth with a heart" this week.

VIENNA, Feb. 3 -- The Hungarian Government served notice on Catholic Bishops of Hungary three weeks ago that they must sever all relations with the Vatican and agree to creation of a national Catholic church.

The Society of Tammany or Columbian Order, the century-and-a-half-old patriotic and fraternal organization, has resumed its former relations with Tammany Hall, the political organization, after a lapse of more than five years, it became known yesterday.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Feb. 3--Because he never says "no" when asked to do something for his community, former Judge Abram A. Lebson tonight became the first recipient here of the Community Chest Red Feather Award for service.

BERLIN, Feb. 3 -- The Soviet military administration of Germany today forced a division of Berlin courts in an action that spoke louder for Western authorities than all the peace talk of the Russian propaganda in the last few days.

The license of a veterinarian, charged with having certified dairy herds to be free of tuberculosis without having first examined the animals, was revoked recently. A physician, accused of drug addiction, was banned from his profession. A certified public accountant received the same penalty because he allegedly attempted to bribe a Federal revenue agent to conceal a tax fraud.
Prices of hide futures rallied late yesterday on the Commodity Exchange, prompted by short covering and trade buying which was influenced by strength in allied markets.

CEDARHURST, L. I., Feb. 3 -- Miss Janet Morgan of the English Wolfe-Noel squash racquets team and Miss Betty Howe of New Haven, Conn., reached the third round of the New York state singles championship at the Rockaway Hunting Club courts today.

STUART, Fla., Feb. 3 -- Al-thought the off-shore fishing today was not so good as it was yesterday, and it never is, every boat we saw pass through St. Lucie inlet had one or two sailfish pennants flying. Some had four or five.

Mrs. Sonja Loew, victim of a $50,000 jewel robbery last Sept. 29, withdrew yesterday her identification of Stephen Bayer as one of the three men who invaded her suite in the Madison Hotel, 15 East Fifty-eighth Street, to perpetrate the theft.

Five hundred persons attended last night informal ceremonies at the Bronx Veterans Administration Hospital, 130 West Kingsbridge Road, to mark the completion of a pool and exercise room constructed by the Four Chaplains Memorial Fund for use of patients in that institution.

The tomb of Gouverneur Morris, Colonial statesman and diplomat, was entered and desecrated by four young boys on a treasure hunt last Sunday night, it was learned yesterday. Two urns containing the remains of other members of the Morris family were disturbed, but the remains of the Revolutionary figure are protected by a heavy bronze coffin.

The American Guild of Musical Artists has passed a resolution urging Congress to eliminate the 20 per cent amusements tax on nonprofit opera, orchestra and ballet companies, it was announced yesterday.

A large-scale national advertising and promotional campaign to persuade all consumers to completely electrify their kitchens with the long-range objective of increasing over-all electric power utility revenue by $2,333,000,000 annually and opening up a vast untapped retail electrical appliance market estimated at $35,000,000,000 annually was begun yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.

A FEW years ago a new label was given to an old product in the world of books. Which bright writer of jacket blurbs in which publishing house first called an old-fashioned thriller a "suspense story" is not a matter of official record. Detective stories, mystery stories and spy stories had all acquired a certain respectability as well as a loyal body of insatiable readers.
The city's three-day-old Traffic Commission will hold its first full-scale meeting today with a wide range of controversial problems up for action, John C. Riedel, chairman, said last night.
ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Two proposals to stimulate home building for middle-income groups were introduced in the State Legislature today.

The stand of the vestry of Holy Trinity Church in Brooklyn should focus attention on the record of its rector. For outstanding leadership in religious influence on crucial social issues constitutes that record.
TSINGTAO, China, Feb. 4 -- Fifty-one years after its founding by the Germans, this port faces for the first time the prospect of being a Chinese city.

Governor Dewey announces that the State Health Department, the Sloan-Kettering Institute and the Roswell Park Hospital of Buffalo will conduct research in the hope of discovering a simple test for cancer -- something remotely comparable with a Wassermann -- and of developing a preventive vaccine.

DETROIT, Feb. 4 -- A continuing clash between the musicians and the management of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra brought on a new crisis today when it was announced that the spring tour of the South and Middle West had been peremptorily canceled.
PRAGUE, Feb. 4 (UP) -- Selden Chapin, United States Minister to Hungary, said today in Budapest that he had "not offered to help Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty escape from Hungary."

ATHENS, Feb. 4 -- Any report on Greece is misleading that does not end by sounding an alarm. When all elements of hope in the situation are summed up, the stark fact remains that the Greek war has reached a point where resistance is in danger of collapsing if it is not strengthened.

CANTON, N.Y., Feb. 4 -- A heavy snowstorm that buried this up-state college town under a deep white mantle today ushered in the fourteenth annual St. Lawrence University Carnival at the school's imposing Snow Bowl, twenty miles southeast of here.

GUATEMALA, Feb. 4 -- An exception filed by the United Fruit Company to citation to appear before the Labor Court for arbitration of a controversy with stevedores and other workers at Puerto Barrios was denied today.

Hundreds of persons rushing to work were startled into near panic early yesterday morning as two detectives chased a hold-up suspect on Eighty-sixth Street from Park Avenue and shot him at the entrance of the IRT subway station at Lexington Avenue.

TOKYO, Feb. 4 -- Indications that General Douglas MacArthur's officers are now willing to have the Japanese stamp out Communist cells in the universities as they did in the mid-Twenties are contained in a speech yesterday, in which an occupation officer declared: "It is clear the Communist cells which exist in your universities should be wiped out as contrary to the Japanese constitutional fundamental law of education."

Governor Dewey disclosed yesterday that he was considering a plan under which New York City would receive half of his proposed $40,000,000 fund for the construction, maintenance and repair of public schools throughout the state.

The first national conference on cerebral palsy will open a five-day session at the Statler Hotel tomorrow. Its aim will be to formulate a national program of aid for the 500,000 children and adult sufferers from the disease.

Catching fire with five events to go, New York University's defending squad put on a rousing finish to snatch the team title from the expectant grasp of Manhattan College in the seventh annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate indoor track and field championships at the 102d Engineers Armory last night.

On Dec. 21, 1948, THE NEW YORK TIMES published an article by one Mr. Benjamin Fine on public education in the U.S.S.R. On the following day the paper devoted an editorial to the subject. Both articles are based on fabrications and are totally at variance with reality.

May our American youth be spared from the baleful philosophy of Henry P. Fairchild, as evidenced in his letter to you on Russia's schools, published Jan. 19. His discussion strains both the facts and the principles of statistics in order to laud the Soviet schools and discount ours.

The stock market became highly vulnerable yesterday to gaining and prices suffered the worst reversal in a month. Approximately two-thirds of the gains registered since the first of the year were eliminated in the broadest and most active market since early January as quotations melted from fractions to 2 points and even wider inroads in a few scattered issues.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UP) -- President Truman did not shut the door to future meetings of the Big Four Foreign Ministers when he ruled out big-power parleys outside the United Nations, the White House said today.

REDDING, Conn., Feb. 4 -- Legend here holds that when Mark Twain was a resident, cannon-balling non-stop expresses of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad screeched to a halt to pick up only the famous humorist-author.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 4 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor decided today to support the Administration's labor bill without important reservations.

ROME, Feb. 4 -- In the Cabinet Council, held this morning by Liberals, Republicans and right-wing Socialists who share the responsibilities of government with the Christian Democrats, expressed their approval of Italy's participation in the European Union and in the directorate of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.

Negotiations to achieve peace in the baking industry took a bad turn yesterday despite the fact that a union of 1,500 bakery drivers postponed a scheduled walkout against the city's six largest producers of bread.

In cooperation with the Advertising Council, the Columbia Broadcasting System will offer a thirty-minute drama from the pen of Walter Bernstein on Sunday from 1:30 to 2 P.M. The play, "Work in Progress," is a vignette of a small Oregon community threatened by the imminent failure of its largest industry.

PARIS, Feb. 4 -- An enthusiastic audience reviewed Jacques Fath's dramatic collection in which he elevates hemp sacking to evening formality and proves that real almond and walnut shells can associate with sequins in handsome embroidery.

Grains broke badly to new seasonal lows for all but two deliveries under general liquidation on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. The day was the anniversary of last year's dramatic break in the commodity markets.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 4 -- Nearly 1,000 delegates attending a special session here of the General Council of the Congregational Christian Churches were locked in debate for more than six hours today over a proposed merger with the Evangelical and Reformed denomination.

BERLIN, Feb. 4 -- The United States and British Military Governments further tightened their counter-blockade against the Soviet zone today by closing their zones to trucks going to or coming from the Russian area. Similar rail traffic probably will be halted soon.

Mae West, the actress-writer from Brooklyn, whose "Come up and see me sometime" became a national catch-phrase and after whom the Army and Navy named a life-preserving jacket, returns to Broadway tonight in a revival of "Diamond Lil" at the Coronet Theatre.

The New York Central and New York, New Haven Hartford railroads were justified in taking over a Park Avenue apartment house they own when the operating company failed to meet $450,000 in rent arrears, Isidor Wasservogel, Supreme Court referee, has decided.

Reorganization of the medical staff of Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn must be viewed as part of a comprehensive development program to give the borough enlarged facilities for medical care, research and education, Edward Neimeth, president, declared yesterday.
RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 4 (AP) -- A Government victory at suburban Insein eased the immediate threat of the Karen rebellion to Rangoon today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Census Bureau reported today that some 700,000 persons lost their jobs in January. The number of employed persons stands at 57,500,000, which is 2,000,000 below the figure for a month earlier.

ROME, Feb. 4 -- President Truman's statement that he would meet Premier Stalin only in Washington caused deep satisfaction today in Vatican circles, where it was held to have indicated that United States policy would not be swayed by what was termed his latest move in the Soviet peace offensive.
Charging improper conduct in court, Federal Judge Harold R. Medina threatened lawyers for the eleven Communist leaders yesterday with disciplinary action.

NEWARK, Feb. 4 -- August Schulenberg, 70 years old, of 725 Prospect Place, and his brother, William, 68, of 101 Palmetta Street, both Brooklyn, came here today to claim the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Diffany, in their eighties, who were found dead of natural causes Tuesday in their twelve-room antique-cluttered and expensively furnished home at 1106 Broad Street, a rooming house area.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy will meet soon with the Joint Chiefs of Staff of the armed services to discuss possible widening of publicity about the atom bomb, Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat, of Connecticut, chairman of the committee, said today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- The American College of Surgeons announced today that 3,150 hospitals in the United States, Canada and a few other countries had been approved as a result of the college's thirty-first annual hospital standardization survey as of 1948.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- Grain broke badly on the Board of Trade under general liquidation, the only exception being May wheat which showed stubborn resistance to pressure. Except May and July wheat, all deliveries of grain sold at a new seasonal low with No. 2 yellow corn selling in the cash market at $1.28, the lowest price since a ceiling price of $1.18 1/2 was removed on June 30, 1946.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Members of Congress debating the future of American air power will view the old and new of the nation's aircraft on Feb. 15, when the Air Force will put on a special show of its fighters and bombers for members of the House Armed Services Committee, it was announced today.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 4 -- The United States Army Quartermaster General has decided not to sign further contracts for Argentine beef, according to reports to two large packinghouses here from representatives in the United States. An Argentine source also predicted that the Army's meat-buying activities here would wind up within three months.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 4 -- Yugoslavia's agricultural production has attained pre-war levels in terms of value and volume, according to published reports of the second plenary session of the Central Committee of the Yugoslav Communist party, which took place in Belgrade in the closing days of January.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- Representatives of the three major farm organizations today took three different points of view on the issue of a compulsory national health insurance program, in addresses before the National Conference on Rural Health.

LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 4 -- The Fifth Army's Operation Snow-bound appeared today to have licked the snow and ice in Nebraska, Wyoming and South Dakota as 7,846 more persons and more than 200,000 animals were freed in the three-state area in the last twenty-four hours.

Samuel Broxmeyer, 54-year-old principal in a tottering $22,000,000 real estate empire, was described yesterday by his attorney as a man who got into financial difficulties through injudicious borrowing.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Administration officials directed Congressional attention today to groups "particularly hard hit by the high cost of housing."

CEDARHURST, L.I., Feb. 4 -- An international final will mark the New York State squash racquets tournament tomorrow when Miss Betty Howe of New Haven meets Miss Janet Morgan of England at the Rockaway Hunting Club.

A gentle reproach arrived from Mrs. Alfred M. Brooks of Gloucester, Mass., who asked why in discussing Italian chestnuts this department failed to mention "that delicious dessert which one used to get so often in France and Italy and which makes such a good dinner party dessert -- Mont Blanc. It is a mound of chestnut puree sweetened and forced through a ricer, topped with whipped cream."

TOKYO, Feb. 4 -- American movie men are angry and their French and British counterparts are chortling over a poll of the best 1948 film releases conducted by the magazine Kinema Jumpo. Five of the ten best films were French, three British and two American.
What many Americans want now is a clean-cut statement of United States policy in respect to China. What do we propose to do about recognition? What about future aid?

The United States Navy's new 180-passenger, four-motored Lockheed-Constitution sounds like a great airplane. It set no records on its non-stop flight from Moffett Field, Calif., to Washington, but with the aid of built-in jets it took off after a run of only 3,500 feet, which is well within the limit of most airfield runways, and braked to a stop at Washington in a like distance.

Metal fabrication facilities of the steel plumbing fixture industry could be quickly converted to 100 per cent use in war production in any future emergency, spokesmen for the Steel Plumbing Fixture Division of the Porcelain Enamel Institute told the National Security Resources Board during a recent meeting in Washington, D.C., industry members disclosed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The National Commission on Children and Youth today urged that a 1950 White House Child Conference be of the grass-roots type, in which the citizenry would do much of the talking while the experts sit on the sidelines.

The "siege" of the Winthrop Hotel at Forty-seventh Street and Lexington Avenue continued into its third day yesterday with tactical movements by both the hotel management and the pickets of the Building Service Employes International Union, Local 32-E.

Raymond M. Hilliard, Welfare Commissioner, told Thomas J. Patterson, Budget Director, yesterday that "the tremendous and unexpected increase in unemployment in December" had caused his department to seek $6,004,663 in additional city and Federal funds for the fiscal year, beginning July 1.

With the consent of all concerned, Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman signed an order yesterday discontinuing a suit by the West India Fruit and Steamship Company, Inc., and a number of intervening plaintiffs against Seatrain Lines, Inc.

NANKING, Feb. 4 -- Acting President Li Tsung-jen took action today on multiple political fronts in a twin attempt to pry open the door for peace talks with the Communists and to solidify his own ranks here so that his loose political apparatus could take on at least the semblance of a government.

For the eighth consecutive year, daily and Sunday newspaper circulations in the United States reached an all-time high during 1948, it was reported yesterday by Editor and Publisher magazine. At the end of the year dailies' circulations totaled 52,285,297, and Sunday's 46,308,081, a gain of 1.2 and 2.7 per cent, respectively.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- The British Government protested to Hungary today over refusal to admit a representative of the British Legation in Budapest to the trial of Cardinal Mindszenty. The warning was given that "His Majesty's Government further formally reserve their rights under the treaty of peace of Feb. 10, 1947."
LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 4 -- Maj. Gen. T. S. Airey, commander of the British-United States zone in Trieste, urged again today that the free territory be returned to Italy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Representative Frances P Bolton of Ohio, first woman member of the House Republican Policy Committee, today told Republican women leaders that there was no question but that the Republican party had neglected the thinking of the people.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Neue Zeitung, United States official newspaper for the Germans, underwent a policy change today.

With the announcement that the striking engineers of the Utah mine of the Kennecott Copper Corporation would return to work on Monday, an additional 20,000 to 25,000 tons of copper a month will be soon made available to the users.
ROME, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi said today Italy had joined the movement for political and economic unity of Western Europe because of the prejudice and hostility of Russia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Federal Reserve Board was accused today by counsel for the Transamerica Corporation, San Francisco, of "predetermining" the results of its anti-trust proceedings against the huge holding company.

SEOUL, Korea. Feb. 4 -- The entire population of 106 of a small Korean island in the north Yellow Sea within the Soviet zone revolted against the Communist authorities on Jan. 19, killed the officials and left their homes to move into South Korea, it was revealed here today.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 4 -- Under questioning of the president of the court trying him on a variety of charges, Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty today retracted the letter that he had written before his arrest in which he repudiated in advance any statement that he might make while in custody of the Hungarian Government.
ROME, Feb. 4 -- Vatican circles said that the trial of Cardinal Mindszenty had been rigged to make the Primate of Hungary look "ridiculous, weak and tottering."

An offer by Municipal Court Justice Thomas Chimera to serve as mediator between the Law Center Foundation of New York University and the tenants it seeks to oust from a Washington Square South block was accepted yesterday by both sides.
PARIS, Feb. 4 -- Separate panels, sometimes full back width, sometimes one box pleat wide, give back interest to suits and dresses in the Balenciaga collection.

ATHENS, Feb. 4 -- The Communist "Free Greece" radio announced tonight that Gen. Markos Vafiades had been relieved of his political responsibilities; and the broadcast was officially interpreted here as meaning the veteran guerrilla leader might be dead. General Markos was proclaimed Premier and War Minister of the self-styled "Provisional Democratic Government of Free Greece" on Dec. 24, 1947.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 4 -- Final action on the controversial Georgia voters' qualification and registration measure was delayed today because only thirty of the fifty-four members of the State Senate were present, but passage of the bill seems assured Monday or Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Jose Rafael Pocaterra, who is here as Venezuelan Ambassador on an official mission, gave formal assurances at a news conference today on behalf of Dr. Luis Emilio Gomez Ruiz, his Foreign Minister, that his Government would fulfill strictly "at all times" all international obligations "assumed by the Venezuelan State."
HAVANA, Feb. 4 -- The Cuban yacht team defeated a United States group, 12 points to 9, in the wind-up of the eighteenth international Star Class regatta here.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The defense failed to shake the testimony of a key Government witness today in the two-week-old treason trial of "Axis Sally."
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange became unsettled yesterday and final prices were 8 to 27 points net lower.

It's easy to get the cooperation of manufacturers in a campaign to reduce the nuisance of smoke in a city when they are convinced that their dollars "are going out of the chimney when you make smoke."

WHATEVER happened to those twelve men who alone understood Einstein? Or were there only seven, banded in that lonely and austere eminence? Anyway, we used to take immense comfort in their mere existence, secure in the assurance that the picked posse of scientific geniuses would be thinking deeply and adequately, say, about the way the theory of relativity bent light around the sun -- while we merely basked in its pleasant and beneficent rays.

Tuition in private camps this year will be the same as in 1948, according to George M. Feigin, chairman of the Association of Private Camps, which is holding ts annual convention at the New Yorker Hotel.

The charter of a 17,811-gross-ton former troopship now being converted to passenger vessel status to the American Export Lines was announced yesterday by the Maritime Commission. At the same time, the commission made known that the vessel would be named La Guardia, in honor of the late Mayor of New York City, Fiorello H. La Guardia.

The election to the Institute of Arts and Letters of thirteen new members, the majority of whom are recognized exponents of the modern school in their fields, was announced yesterday by Douglas Moore, president.

The two former transports, the J.W. McAndrew and George F. Elliot, which are being reconverted to passenger-ship status for the Farrell Lines' service between New York and South Africa, have been renamed African Enterprise and African Endeavor, John J. Farrell, chairman of the steamship company's board of directors, announced yesterday.
Studies aimed to achieve a wholesome integration of a child's learning experiences increasingly recognize the importance of play, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools declared yesterday.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 4 -- A Hungarian Government spokesman tonight asked foreign correspondents covering the trial of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty to "make it plain to your readers that Mindszenty is not a brave man or a hero."
BOSTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Boston Weather Bureau reported today the following skiing conditions for the New England area:

GENEVA, Feb. 4 -- Signatories of the Geneva tariff agreement of 1947 have asked the International Monetary Fund for formal consultations on South African import restrictions, it was learned here today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee reported out the Administration's export control bill today with an amendment designed to exempt fats and oils.

Although scattered Valentine's Day promotions have been launched throughout the city during the past week, heaviest promotional emphasis will appear tomorrow in the form of newspaper advertising and window displays, retailers disclosed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Civil Aeronautics Authority has sent teams throughout the country to check safety procedures of scheduled airlines and non-scheduled carriers alike. D. W. Rentzel, administrator of civil aeronautics, revealed this new move at a press conference.

The thirteenth annual masters individual contract bridge championship tournament got under way last night at the Park Sheraton Hotel, formerly the Park Central. The tournament is divided into two sections, the life master section and the senior master section.
ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 4 (AP) -- The State Commerce Department reported today the following conditions at New York ski centers:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The United States Government has agreed to appoint an Ambassador to the fledgling State of Israel and to see the status of the Israeli mission in Washington raised to that of an embassy.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Great Spirit carried the famed Calumet Farm silks to victory in today's Tropical Holiday Purse at Hialeah Park -- and his recently claimed former stablemate, Alpho, was second.

Albany County, N.Y., sold yesterday $1,300,000 of equipment and public improvement bonds due Dec. 1, 1949 to 1957, to Chemical Bank Trust Company and associates at a bid of 100.22 for 1 1/2s. The bonds were reoffered at prices to yield from 0.85 per cent to 1.50 per cent.

International cordiality and cooperation were emphasized at the automotive presentations of five European countries at a press preview of the first International Automobile Show here yesterday. The displays covered 35,000 square feet of floor space of the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, Twenty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 4 (UP) -James F. Breuil, owner of the All-America Conference Buffalo Bills, charged today that only a "small minority" was blocking peace in the costly football war between the A.A.C. and the National League.

The contribution of the amusement industry to the movement for understanding and brotherhood among all groups, without regard to race or creed, was acknowledged by civic leaders yesterday at the twentieth annual luncheon of the Amusements Division of the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

Brig. Gen. J. Leslie Kincaid, New York National Guard (ret.) and former military governor of Italy, sailed yesterday aboard the Italian liner Vulcania with 4,000 cakes of soap he plans to distribute in Naples.

A 23-year-old deaf-mute disarmed last night a 16-year-old student who attempted to rob him on the pedestrian walk of the Williamsburg Bridge. The mute then used a pad and pencil to obtain statements from his captive until the police arrived.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 4 (AP) -- It was all a mistake, Eric Monti said today of his statement that he had taken only 18 putts in the first round of the $10,000 Tucson open golf tournament. Actually he used 32.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 4 (AP) -Amateur Skee Riegel reeled off a six-under par 64 today to move into a tie with Lloyd Mangrum, Chicago, for first place at the half-way mark in the $10,000 Tucson open golf tournament. Both had 36-hole scores of 130.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4 -- More than eighty planes and 100 men on the ground are searching the rugged canyon country east of Inyokern for five scientists and two airmen missing since Thursday on a flight from the Inyokern Desert Naval Base to Alameda.

The inquiry by John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, into milk prices received a setback yesterday when he was served with show-cause orders restraining him from subpoenaing records of two milk companies. The action marked the second time that he had been halted by court order in his campaign against high milk prices.

SALERNO, Fla., Feb. 4 -- According to the local angling experts this was not the right day for fishing the river, but having checked the local shooting, off-shore fishing and lake fishing we decided to try the river anyway.

Ruth Duncan, an attractive and efficient young pianist who may be heard these days at Bill Bertolotti's in the Village, was the debutante presented on last night Town Hall program in the Debut and Encore Concerts series. Sharing the program with her, but not the distinction of making a debut, was the contralto, Louise Bernhardt.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- There was no net change in average primary market prices during the week ended Feb. 1, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index remained at 158.8 per cent of the 1926 average. This was 1.5 per cent less than four weeks ago and 3.5 per cent below the comparable week in 1948.

PARIS, Feb. 4 -- The mature conclusion of leading diplomats here is that Mr. Stalin's "peace offensive" was designed to check the slow yet marked trend toward integration of the Western world. They suspect also that it might have been intended to cover some new Russian move in Eastern Germany or in Finland.

Miss Margaret Truman, soprano, met the press yesterday noon. She conducted herself with a cordiality and naturalness that disarmed the corps of seasoned men and women reporters who converged on the office of her agent, James A. Davidson, in the Steinway Hall Building on West Fifty-seventh Street.

DURHAM, N.C., Feb. 4 -- Capitalizing on the many mistakes of a totally inept New York University five, Duke University upset the Violets in a surprise 73-44 rout before 6,000 spectators tonight at Duke Indoor Stadium.

Reporting on operations of Bruck Mills, Ltd., Montreal, Gerald L. Bruck, president, informed shareholders yesterday that record yardage production in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, last, resulted in the largest sales and earnings in the company's history.

The Julliard School of Music yesterday announced appointments for its 1949-50 academic year. Mark Schubart, present director of public activities, has been named dean of the school, and Jean Morel, conductor of the City Opera Company, was appointed head of the orchestra department.

In mid-March, 1943, Paul Hartman was a soldier with the Second Corps Headquarters stationed in Tunisia, near Tebessa. His commanding officer approached him and a group of his comrades and ordered them to get their rifles and helmets.

WARSAW, Feb. 4 -- A sweeping reorganization of the Polish Government's economic controls patterned on Soviet lines was introduced in Parliament today. The proposed law, which is considered certain to pass, would make Hilary Minc, Minister of Industry and Trade, Poland's undisputed economic czar.

It seems to us that the Administration is playing a dangerous game in its handling of that part of the pending labor bill which deals with national emergency strikes. This is the most vital area of the proposed legislation, and as such calls for courage, candor and clarity.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 4 -- Glenn McCarthy, independent producer, today announced that his next picture for RKO will be "My Darling Is a Kangaroo," a screen comedy about life in an animated cartoon studio, which Monty F. Collins and Frank Gill have written.

VIENNA, Feb. 4 -- The 13 per cent drop between mid-December and mid-January in Austrian black market food prices, reported by the Austrian Institute of Economic Studies, was "incontrovertible proof of the progressive development achieved with American help and Austrian work," Clyde N. King, chief of Marshall Plan mission to Austria, said today.
Along with their school studies, girls of 12 and 14 are concerned with the effects of food on their figure, fun and fitness.

Directors of the Creole Petroleum Corporation, an affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), declared yesterday a dividend of 75 cents a share on the capital stock. Previously, the company had paid 90 cents a share at quarterly intervals.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Herbert John Burgman of Minnesota, long-time employe of the prewar American Embassy in Berlin, was flown back to the United States in a military plane today to face charges of treason.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- British legal experts were trying to figure out today a way to get rid of the man no country wants, the irrepressible Sydney Stanley, who came to Britain as a Polish immigrant boy of 13 and ended up hobnobbing with ministers of the Crown.

A voice vote for rent control and approval of international control of atomic energy, expressed by loud applause for three speakers on that subject, was registered yesterday by the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs.

STILLWATER, Okla., Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Oklahoma Aggies operated their offense at top speed and downed the Long Island University Blackbirds, 55 -- 33, in a basketball game here tonight. It was the second victory of the season for the Aggies over the Long Islanders.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- Dr. Herbert L. Mantz of Kansas City, president of the National Tuberculosis Association, said here today that the fight on tuberculosis in the United States definitely had reached the eradication stage.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 4 (AP) -- The $50,000 San Felipe Stakes at Santa Anita tomorrow may develop into a free-for-all for the 3-year-old division, with racing luck the big factor.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- An Administration bill extending the Marshall Plan through its second year reached Congress today.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 4 -- New import procedures for the bizonal area of Germany were announced today. These new policies, together with recently instituted export procedures, place virtually the entire operations in the field of foreign trade, exclusive of food, in the hands of the Germans.
BUFFALO, Feb. 4 -- The County Welfare Department believes eighteen years is too long for an able man to remain on relief.

VIENNA, Feb. 4 -- Comment here by competent American and Hungarian observers who listened to Cardinal Mindszenty's testimony as broadcast from Budapest was that the Cardinal was now a completely broken man but that the Hungarian Government had rendered itself absurd in its over-eagerness to exploit that fact.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 4 -- The United Nations Commission for India and Pakistan arrived in Karachi today, but the man who headed the group when it brought peace between the conflicting countries was not among the arrivals.

The cross-country travels of the French Gratitude Train, bearing cultural, historical and personal gifts for the American people in appreciation for the Friendship Train sent to France in 1947, begin today with the departure of the Southern section for Washington.

BOSTON, Feb. 4 -- Gen. Omar N. Bradley, Army Chief of Staff, said tonight he would "much prefer to take some military risk, rather than to have to weather the dangers of an economic bust," in subscribing to the need for prudence in spending.
PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Feb. 4 -- "It wasn't anything to get excited about."

A streamlined Frank Shea, bearing scarecly any resemblance to the barrel-shaped Nugget who reported at St. Petersburg last March, strode into the Yankees' Fifth Avenue offices yesterday and without further ado affixed his signature to a 1949 contract.

The Whitney Museum opens to the public today the second of its series of annual retrospective exhibitions of work by leading American artists initiated last year with the work of Yasuo Kuniyoshi. This year Max Weber has been selected. The installation is spacious and impressive, the whole museum with the exception of the sculpture gallery being given over to the event.

Having nothing more cosmic to do for the moment, Albert Bassermann is appearing in a German-language revival of "The Rape of the Sabine Women," which opened a brief run at the Barbizon-Plaza last evening. Despite the classical aura of the title, this is a broad farce by Franz and Paul V. Schoenthan, which has knocked about the German theatre for a number of years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UP) -- Two tired but happy Russian army lieutenants, who fled the Soviet Union last fall, arrived here today for a week's tour of Virginia, something they've looked forward to since they heard about the state two years ago on a Voice of America broadcast.

Peter Pirogov and Anatole Barzov just had to see Virginia. They had listened to a radio program describing it, and they just had to. Maybe beat biscuits were mentioned, maybe ham, maybe scenery, maybe climate, maybe George Washington and Robert E. Lee, and maybe not.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- A bill to extend the validation of New York City's laws relating to rent control and evictions was introduced in the Legislature today by Senator Elmer F. Quinn and Assemblyman Irwin Steingut, Democratic minority leaders.

In a spectacular battle worthy of a better setting, Paddy Young, sturdy Greenwich Village Middleweight, last night got off the floor at the St. Nicholas Arena and knocked out Frankie Palermo of the Bronx in the eighth round of their scheduled ten-round bout.

The Whitney Museum opens to the public today the second of its series of annual retrospective exhibitions of work by leading American artists initiated last year with the work of Yasuo Kuniyoshi. This year Max Weber has been selected. The installation is spacious and impressive, the whole museum with the exception of the sculpture gallery being given over to the event.

Having nothing more cosmic to do for the moment, Albert Bassermann is appearing in a German-language revival of "The Rape of the Sabine Women," which opened a brief run at the Barbizon-Plaza last evening. Despite the classical aura of the title, this is a broad farce by Franz and Paul V. Schoenthan, which has knocked about the German theatre for a number of years.

"Those who shout loudest about 'the Reds in our schools' have done little to inform themselves at first hand or to make sure that we had good schools," Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, declared in his second letter to university alumni, made public yesterday.

An electrical break-down in the Statler Hotel yesterday afternoon plunged the annual meeting of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers into Nineteenth Century darkness made unusually gloomy by the presence of some of the nation's leading electrical experts.

PARIS, Feb. 4 -- Lieut. Gen. Alfred Fagalde, whose command held the Germans at bay while the remnants of the British Expeditionary Force made their historic 1940 withdrawal at Dunkerque, today appeared at a Paris court martial to answer charges of treason.
Mohammed Reza Pahlevi, upon his succession, was recognized immediately by the Allies and at once set out to put his country into the Allied column.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 4 (AP) -City College of New York performed brilliantly in every department tonight to score a surprisingly easy 67-57 basketball victory over highly rated Stanford.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Senate Democratic leaders proclaimed today their determination to defeat a Republican maneuver to thrust at once upon the floor a preliminary aspect of President Truman's bitterly controversial civil-rights program.

The Henry J. Kaiser empire and some members of Congress have begun to challenge the propriety of the record peacetime contract for aluminum negotiated recently between the Reynolds Metals Company and the Wisconsin Electric Cooperative for delivery of 715,000,000 pounds of aluminum requisite to production of electric conductors for rural electric cooperatives.

The General Electric Company, it became known yesterday, has circularized its 200,000 employes in 126 plants all over the country, sending to each an eighteen-point questionnaire entitled: "How would you revise our labor laws?"

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 4 -Streamlined law enforcement down to the municipal level, with immediate emphasis on a gambling clean-up, was mapped today by New Jersey's new Attorney General, Theodore D. Parsons.

A "modern Ponzi," said to have swindled relatives and friends out of more than $250,000, was sentenced yesterday to five to ten years at Sing Sing Prison by Bronx County Judge James M. Barrett. Sentence was imposed on only one count of a ten-count indictment to which defendant pleaded guilty last October.

The cooperation of Protestants, Roman Catholics and leaders in interfaith projects has been invited in connection with the coming to the United States this spring of eighty Germans selected under the auspices of the Religious Affairs Branch of the American Military Government in Germany, to take part in a large-scale program of reorientation and cultural exchange.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 4 -- A group of some twenty-eight American tourists who visited Egypt recently have informed a representative of the United States Consulate that the system developed by Egyptian authorities for preventing possible difficulties arising out of the strained situation in the Near East has worked perfectly.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- Britain's veteran 29,000-ton man-of-war, the Royal Sovereign slid slowly through mist into the Firth of Forth this morning, a Soviet commodore in command and a Soviet crew smartly drawn up at attention at the rail. From the masthead flew the Soviet Union's naval ensign.

Fifth Avenue's largest post-war skyscraper may rise on the site of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, 82-year-old Gothic landmark at Forty-eighth Street, under a proposed deal involving both a lease and purchase of the property, it became known last night.

The fifteen-minute demonstration which followed the curtain at the end of the "Salome" performance last night in the Metropolitan was proof enough of the eloquence and fire which distinguished the interpretation, as also of the greatness of an opera which may be called the lyric masterpiece of the German decadence, when it is so performed.
TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 4 -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi was shot and wounded today in an unsuccessful assassination attempt.

John L. McCaffrey, president of International Harvester Company, yesterday warned the Sixth National Conference of Business Public Relations Executives that industry can not go to the public with a story of unbroken success. He emphasized it should admit its mistakes and "be realistic" in corporate disclosures as well as "on the level" with the public.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 4 -- The Indonesian Government is aiming strongly at granting more import freedom and considers the present situation a temporary emergency, Minister Lubbertus Goetzen said here today. "The Government has already decided to accept newcomers, but under stringent conditions,'' he said.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- Britain's veteran 29,000-ton man-of-war, the Royal Sovereign slid slowly through mist into the Firth of Forth this morning, a Soviet commodore in command and a Soviet crew smartly drawn up at attention at the rail. From the masthead flew the Soviet Union's naval ensign.

Fifth Avenue's largest post-war skyscraper may rise on the site of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, 82-year-old Gothic landmark at Forty-eighth Street, under a proposed deal involving both a lease and purchase of the property, it became known last night.

The fifteen-minute demonstration which followed the curtain at the end of the "Salome" performance last night in the Metropolitan was proof enough of the eloquence and fire which distinguished the interpretation, as also of the greatness of an opera which may be called the lyric masterpiece of the German decadence, when it is so performed.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 4 (AP) -- A B-25 bomber, believed to have eight men aboard, exploded and crashed in Lake Pontchartrain just before 5 P. M. (EST) today. No survivors were found.

Bucklin Moon, author of "The Darker Brother," has received the George Washington Carver Award for his new novel, "Without Magnolias." The award presents an outright grant of $1,500 and $1,000 in advance against royalties. Mr. Moon's book will be published by Doubleday April 7.

American industry has thrived on competition, but some of the legislation designed to promote such competition holds promise of more harm than good. A case in point concerns three bills now in the hands of the Senate Committee on the Judiciary, aimed at reorganizing the oil industry.

Herbert C. Erhard has been appointed sales manager of the Anderson Stove Company of Anderson, Ind., recently taken over by the Breeze Corporations, Inc., Newark, N.J., which announced an expansion program to increase distribution and sales of Anderson Gas Ranges.

ROME, Feb. 4 -- Osservatore Romano this evening urged Catholics to discount what it called an "alleged confession" made by Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty at the opening of his trial in Hungary yesterday. No matter what he will say, the Vatican newspaper declared, it must be remembered that when he was free he had warned intimates and members of the clergy not to believe statements that he might make if and when he was arrested.

John L. McCaffrey, president of International Harvester Company, yesterday warned the Sixth National Conference of Business Public Relations Executives that industry can not go to the public with a story of unbroken success. He emphasized it should admit its mistakes and "be realistic" in corporate disclosures as well as "on the level" with the public.

In protest against the city's failure to grant them an additional $250 annual wage increase, several hundred maintenance men and firemen employed in twenty-eight projects of the City Housing Authority engaged in a work stoppage yesterday.

Commission house and trade selling of rubber futures increased sharply yesterday on the Commodity Exchange as prices declined 15 to 26 points. The market closed at the low point of the day with a barely steady undertone. Market observers attributed the decline to the sharp break in stocks and other commodity values.

Because I am a publisher of comic magazines (so-called) I need hardly say that I am vitally interested in all aspects of the nation-wide controversy now raging in connection therewith. There are many developments growing out of the present situation which alarm me very much, not as a publisher but as a citizen.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- The Permanent Commission of the Brussels Treaty powers set forth five recommendations for the future Council of Europe in a communique issued here today. In guarded language the communique declared that the Permanent Commission in accordance with its directive received last week from the five foreign Ministers after their two-day meeting had carefully considered detailed plans for a Council of Europe.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The first week's hearings on the Administration's new labor relations bill have shown a deep split between its proponents and opponents. This chasm will probably widen as the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee's sessions enter their second week Monday.

In a complete break with traditional language study methods, Phillips Academy, at Andover, Mass., has extended its unique French program to include all school levels, it was learned last week. Initiated on a limited basis four years ago, the program is taught wholly in French and places special emphasis on the development of aural and oral skills.
" BETWEEN 6 and 11 years of age, 95 per cent of the boys and 91 per cent of the girls throughout the nation, with few regional differences, read an average of fifteen comic books per month.

Jean Cocteau, French poet and playwright turned movie director, would fasten upon this amazing metropolis the title of a highly esteemed French comedy of a half century ago, "The World Where One Is Bored."

Three 16-year-old Brooklyn youths charged with violation of the Sullivan Law and participation in a series of hold-ups on the Williamsburg Bridge pedestrian walk were held in a total of $50,000 bail when arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Week-End Court before Magistrate John F. X. Masterson. The three will have hearings tomorrow in Brooklyn Adolescents Court.

The Maritime Commission has directed its trial examining unit to hold public hearings as soon as possible on the complaint filed by the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc. against two North Atlantic freight conferences, it was learned yesterday.

WITH a of record amount of highway construction scheduled throughout the country this year, the forty-sixth annual meeting of the American Road Builders Association opening tomorrow in Washington will consider many transportation problems of economic importance.

OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 5 -- Weather rescue operations, gigantic in their scope, had reached a point today from which it became possible to sit back and calmly compare the possible benefits of bad weather alongside the heavy damage.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Hoover Commission today was reported weighing plans to propose a civilian chairman over the United States. Joint Chiefs of Staff in order to cool inter-service rivalries.

A PACKED Bushnell Memorial at its opening concert some days ago was only one of the surprises that attended the revival of the Hartford Symphony Orchestra. The large crowd which welcomed the orchestra was a pleasant surprise to some eighty musicians, but the public received the initial surprise from the musicians themselves more than three months ago.

My compliments on "The Marines Still Have the Situation in Hand," an article that provides empirical evidence why the world will never have peace. Take a man who is raised in a country that is ostensibly peace-loving, beat him into the ground, drive every spark of idealism from his breast, and you have the product of Marine Corps "training."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Restoration in full force of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act was labeled today "legislative business of the highest priority" in a report by the House Ways and Means Committee calling for immediate Congressional action.

The front page newspaper stories about the break in commodity prices brought a heavy volume of selling into the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, and final prices were 21 to 26 points net lower.

PEDRO of Old Mexico enjoyed his talent for drawing pictures, but his ambition was to become a bull fighter like his Uncle Jose and to earn thereby a great deal of money. He would become the richest man in San Juan and build a fine church for the village padre and see that his mother never had to work another day.

Earnings of S. H. Kress Co. for the year ended Dec. 31 amounted to $12,838,578 net, it was reported yesterday. Earnings were equivalent to $5.46 a share. These figures compared with $12,672,077 or $5.39 a share in the previous comparable period.

SAMUEL GOLDWYN, who loves press conferences as much as he does good pictures, called in reporters the other day to announce his association with Roberto Rossellini (director of the notable Italian films "Open City" and "Paisan"), Ingrid Bergman and Ilya E. Lopert in their Italian production, as yet untitled, which will go before the cameras about April 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- A plan for immediate resumption of steamship service to Alaska through the use of chartered Government ships was disclosed today by Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat, of Washington, and Delegate E. L. Bartlett, Democrat, of Alaska.

Twenty-nine persons were convicted in the criminal courts of New York State last year for practicing medicine or dentistry without licenses, it was learned yesterday. In addition, four persons were found guilty of the same charges in the field of nursing, two in podiatry and two in optometry.

LINCOLN'S Birthday celebrations have been planned for next Saturday at a number of resorts. Indications are that sizable week-end ski crowds will converge on slopes from the Poconos and Catskills to the White Mountains and Canada. Special ski trains and planes will operate.

Personnel executives in all types of business are following new developments in the social sciences as well as national and world affairs with an interest never shown before, officials of the American Management Association disclosed last week.

WHEN movie theatre owners get together to discuss business these days television is bound to be on the agenda. It was one of the big topics at the board meeting of the Theatre Owners of America in Washington, but if the boys found a way to harness television to serve their interests as showmen no announcement was made to that effect.

City College's metropolitan championship swimming team was defeated by a local opponent, yesterday for the first time in four years as Kings Point scored a 38-37 victory in the last lap of the final event at the C. C. N. Y. pool.

In a Bronx police precinct, Sgt. James O'Rourke quietly handles the family fights, ambulance calls and fires that crowd the police switchboard daily. He is a man who wanted to be a teacher, became a scholar of Joyce and is now a policeman and the father of five children.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP) -- Secretary of Defense James Forrestal reported to President Truman tonight that the western storm disaster was being brought under control. He said relief operations were "proceeding satisfactorily" and should straighten out the situation unless another big storm hits the stricken states.

President Truman served notice on the American steel industry in his message on the State of the Union, that unless its productive capacity is expanded promptly -- presumably to an extent satisfactory to the Administration -- the Government will engage directly or indirectly in the production of steel.

BERLIN, Feb. 5 -- Apparently spurred by Premier Stalin's concern over the establishment of a Western German state, German politicians in Bonn settled today important differences that had delayed the writing of a constitution for the projected new state.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- The state board of the American Association of University Women today supported the Board of Regents in the latter's fight for amendment of the law which on April 1 will transfer control over the thirty-one state-supported colleges from the regents to the board of trustees of the new state university.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 5 -- The Yugoslav Government published today an official order revising the system of construction priorities for the third year (1949) of the five-year industrialization program, to counteract economic sanctions imposed by the Soviet Union and the other states of the Communist Information Bureau.

A smoldering cigarette, unnoticed in a pile of rubbish, was believed responsible for a five-alarm fire that swept the eighty-six-year-old Webster Hall at 119 East Eleventh Street early yesterday morning.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 5 -- Israel's first Parliament, an elected Constituent Assembly, will meet in Jerusalem on Feb. 14, the Feast of Trees, just nine months after the State was proclaimed.

NAPLES, Italy, Feb. 5 -- The first shipload of Jewish refugees from Shanghai arrived in Naples today and immediately transshipped onto an Italian vessel for Palestine. It was composed of 881 men, women and children and will be followed by another group of 900-odd within a week.

THE week's business news was still on the easing side. In more than a few quarters it was interpreted as meaning that a recession was at hand. However, some plants put on workers as others laid them off. It was not clear what the immediate trend could be called.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- Senator Thomas C. Desmond, Newburgh Republican, announced today that he had drafted for introduction in the Legislature next week a bill which would make court appointments and fees a matter of public record.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Feb. 5 -- In the first of a projected series of sailing dinghy team matches at the Larchmont Yacht Club today, the local skippers took four races in a row against the challengers from the Merchant Marine Academy across Long Island Sound at Kings Point.

LONDON, Sunday, Feb. 6 (Reuters) -- In a special communique broadcast by the Moscow radio today, the Political Bureau of the French Communist party expressed its views on Premier Stalin's proposal for peace pact talks with President Truman.
The appointment of James P. Sutherland as passenger agent and Ralph Roskelly as assistant passenger agent of the Panama Line was announced yesterday by T. H. Rossbottom, company vice president.

ONE Miss Lutrelle MacNair is suspected by the police of having murdered J. Cryder Johnson, the Candybar Czar, in his suite at the Park Royal. The body is discovered by Gil Vine, who bears the proud title of Chief Security Officer, the Park Royal euphemism for house dick.

NEWARK, N. J., Feb. 5 -- A smooth-working Princeton University polo team, blanking its opponent in three chukkers, trounced the Georgetown trio, 19 to 2, tonight in a one-sided contest at Essex Troop Armory.

IRA WOLFERT, author of the best-selling novel, "An Act of Love," took time out the other day from his coverage of the trial of the eleven Communists to talk a little about his ideas on writing -- especially on the war novel.
A new project for the reading and discussion of books, sponsored by the New York Public Library, will be started in the Washington Heights branch on Thursday.

BUT scantily represented in collections in this country, the English mid-nineteenth century painter Samuel Palmer has had a remarkable acknowledged influence on the group of young modern British artists, including Sutherland, Piper and Tunnard.

On Jan. 11, 1949, in Paris, Marcel Cachin, member of the French Communist Politburo, said in the French National Assembly, "Would anyone dare to assert that at this moment two powerful nations are irrevocably at odds? * * * Do not people speak of the possibility of a meeting between Stalin and Truman?"

THE two top prizes of $5,000 each in United States Savings Bonds in Popular Photography's $60,000 contest have been won by Wellington Lee, Chinese owner of a laundry at 1563 Southern Boulevard, the Bronx, and by A Aubrey Bodine, feature photographer for The Baltimore Sun.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 5 -- The "blaze of glory" in which this town will celebrate the 102d birthday of its most famous citizen, the late Thomas A. Edison, will commence tomorrow and continue through the Edison anniversary day of Feb. 11.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Norway, whose population is 3,000,000, has politely hut firmly informed the Soviet Union, whose population is 193,000,000, that she is prepared to discuss with the Western powers her entry into the North Atlantic Pact.
COCOANUT, come and play at soldiers."

MONTREAL, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins scored two goals in the third period to come from behind and defeat the Montreal Canadiens, 3 -- 2, in a National Hockey League game tonight. The defeat was the fourth straight for the Canadiens, who have had twenty-two goals piled up against them in the same four games.

LAST Sunday Mr. Jack Gould commented on recent lapses in taste and judgment in television. Having witnessed many, many incidents of the most questionable taste on television, I can agree wholeheartedly with his statement that television good taste must be controlled by the television industry.

" How to Write -- By Maugham" is at best only the author's own theory. Writing is a gift. Some writers, who are endowed with genius, burst like a new comet from out of the cosmos. Through strange, untried-before ways they leap into prominence.
What's the matter with the stock market? This has been a leading question for the last two years.

GEORGE ABBOTT, the veteran theatrical producer, is of the opinion that television in the long run is going to be good for the theatre. He is taking no chances, however, and for the moment has placed his feet cautiously in separate troughs.

Six men who held high office in the Czechoslovak Government before it was deposed by a Communist coup in February, 1948, arrived here yesterday on their way to Washington, where they plan to set up what will be, in effect, a Czechoslovak Government in Exile.

The stock market ended the week yesterday on a further reactionary note with the price structure at the lowest levels since last mid-December. Losses for the two-hour session ranged from fractions to 3 points in the largest volume for a Saturday in three months.

THE grand jury as an institution is one of the most ancient and most powerful in our system of law. It has a vital role in bringing criminals to justice -- and protecting the innocent from injustice. Yet the grand jury is little known. Few Americans ever serve as grand jurors.

Rumors that margin requirements would soon be reduced -- a report that was quickly denied in authoritative quarters as being without foundation -- caused a momentary stir in Wall Street last week, where agitation for a change in the credit regulations governing stock trading has been active for some time.

IN the first of his two new books the indefatigable Mr. Reinfeld crams into small space a large amount of chess wisdom, together with well-chosen examples of how that wisdom should be applied over the board. The openings, the middle-games, and the endings are taken up in order; the great time-tested ruling principles that govern in each stage are discussed and examples given.

Collecting four of his six goals in the second half, Al Parsells did yeoman work in leading the 16-goal Squadron A trio to a 13 to 11 victory over the Red Bank Polo Club in the feature match of the indoor double-header staged before 1,400 fans at the Squadron A Armory last night.

Two significant remarks were made in a Budapest court room yesterday as the trial of Cardinal Mindszenty and his fellow-defendants dragged toward its expected close. Judge Vilmos Olthys, who rose to his present position from former membership in the Hungarian Nazi party, took note of both of them.

VIOLAS, those gay small flowers that look somewhat like pansies and somewhat like violets, deserve planting in every garden. Whether the space is large or small or almost completely taken by other plants, room can always be found for these "tuck-in" perennials.

CANTON, N. Y., Feb. 5 -- St. Lawrence College's powerful ski unit spread-eagled the field in winning its fourteenth annual winter carnival which was completed under superb snow and weather conditions today.

The Board of Examiners of the New York City school system, now completing its fiftieth year of continuous service, is preparing for one of the most active years in its history. Because of the rising birth rate, an increased enrollment is expected at all educational levels, from kindergarten through the academic and vocational high schools.

ANY little girl whose best friend has gone away will know exactly how Sue Ann felt at the beginning of a long, lonely summer, her boredom accentuated by the fact that she had spent all her allowance. Then she saw the three little silk flags which would look just right on her scooter and started in to earn some money.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 5 -- While Georgia's proposed law for registration and qualification of voters was assailed today as "unfair to the average layman" and probably illegal, many legislators were revealed to have been unable to answer some of the questions which would be asked of prospective voters.

SCIENTIFIC methods of photographing overprints on United States stamps have become part of legal procedure for the first time in the history of the Federal courts. On Jan. 27 the proprietor of a former New York stamp firm was convicted before Judge Simon H. Rifkind in the United States District Court here of having possessed and sold altered United States postal paper.

ST. PAUL, Minn. -- A winter sports festival crammed with everything from hockey and ski tournaments to a bridge match and an ice ballet has been selected by state officials to touch off Minnesota's 1949 Territorial Centennial celebration.

BOSTON, Feb. 5 -- A mighty last-ditch effort by Sweden's Erik Ahlden, plus a bit of bad racing luck, sent Gaston Reiff, Belgium's Olympic 5,000-meter champion, down to defeat in his second American start at two miles tonight.
THE most recent effort to unite the elements of the motion picture industry into a solid front for purposes of public relations went on the rocks last week in the process of organization.

" PIONEER RAILROAD," the biography of the Chicago North Western, is the work of two veteran Chicago journalists, Casey and Douglas. Their heroes are William B. Ogden, whose genius carried the road through lean days and panics, and Marvin Hughitt, whose fifty-year association with the North Western transformed it into one of the chief transportational systems of the nation.
DETROIT, Feb. 5 (UP) -- Henry H. Reichhold hinted today that he might withdraw his support from the Detroit Symphony unless music critics stop "twisting" stories about strife within the orchestra.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 5 -- Poland and Czechoslovakia urged the United Nations today to step in for the second time to try to save the lives of ten Greek trade unionists condemned to death by their Government.

WASHINGTON, Feb, 5 -- It was almost inevitable that President Truman's "bold, new program" for improvement of so-called backward areas should be received with enthusiasm in Europe and with some bewilderment at home. It was the same when Secretary of State Marshall broadly outlined at Harvard the basis for the cooperative venture which was to bear his name.
MANILA, Feb. 5 (AP) -- A fire of undetermined origin today was reported to have, wiped out half of Cotabato, provincial capital on the southwest coast of Mindanao Island.

TORONTO, Feb. 5 -- Rookie Jack Gordon fired a goal with less than three minutes to play to earn the New York Rangers a 1-1 tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight in a National Hockey League game before 13,922 fans.

THE marital, extra-marital, and cross-marital relationships involving members of the Alexander family make up the matter of this novel by the author of "The Hour of Nightfall." Since the Alexanders live in Hawaii, most of the action of the book is set against a romantically rendered island background, though characters move to and from San Francisco as if that city were just across the river.

ATHENS, Feb. 5 -- Reports current here today indicated that the forces of the rebellion were now commanded by George Vontitsias, a Greek Communist officer who goes by the party name or nom de guerre of General Geussis.
MUNICH, Germany, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Eight GI boxers battled their way to the all-Army European command championships tonight and won free trips to the United States.

The absurdities to which the "white supremacy" advocates in some parts of the South ascend, or descend, is illustrated in the fifty questions that are proposed for prospective voters in the Voters' Qualification and Registration Act that is now before the Georgia Legislature.

For the first time since before the war North Atlantic travel to and from Europe and Mediterranean ports and the United States and Canada neared the 1,000,000-passenger mark last year, a survey of the principal steamship and air line companies showed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The trial of "Axis Sally," gray-haired American woman accused of treasonably striving to damage her native country's morale by broadcasting Nazi propaganda in World War II, moves into its second week as the Federal Government takes up treason charges against another American, Herbert John Burgman, who refused to leave Berlin when the war began.

BALLET THEATRE has at last got around to its first official announcement about personnel and repertoire for its forthcoming season. As the company has been inactive since the close of its spring season last year, there are naturally a number of changes to be expected, and this first communique will be followed by several others before the picture is complete.

A LIFE dedicated to religious study and profound spiritual pondering has gone into "The Essence of Judaism." The reader familiar with the tragic story of Rabbi Baeck's life during the past decade and a half might look here for some heaven-battering outcry or expression of bitter disillusionment.

Expansion of Manhattan College's sports program was seen in the announcement yesterday by Brother B. Thomas, F. S. C., president, of the appointments of Brother D. Joseph as moderator and Richard J. Cole, assistant professor, as acting director of athletics.

THIS is a critical time of year for the small-property fruit grower. For along with the urge to order more fruit trees comes the flood of beautifully colored catalogues and how can he resist? But the grower will do well to consider certain factors before ordering.
Wall Street is conceding that the key to the success of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane lies in its intelligent merchandising program.

AN exhibition of about 300 news and documentary photographs of the past hundred years will open Wednesday at the Museum of Modern Art and will continue until May 1. Selected by Edward Steichen, director of the museum's Department of Photography, who has been working on the idea for the show since 1934, the exhibit will occupy the entire first floor of the museum.

Darden, president of the University of Virginia, has wished the Communist-controlled Charles University of Prague a happy six-hundredth birthday and has expressed in Ciceronian Latin his hope that its students of future days might be led in the way of truth, liberty and peace.
Within recent weeks a good deal of material on Russia's domestic airlines has come to light in this country. Most of the information is unofficial, but aviation authorities here consider it accurate.

The newspapers propped up before them gave sample display to this trend. In adjoining columns, however, they read also of new state tax proposals as each of the six regional legislatures settled down to the serious business of uncovering additional "lodes" of revenue.

Hess will coach the Brooklyn-Queens squad, Wolfe the combination of Manhattan, Bronx and Richmond players.

For those who take an interest in science last week's news was enlivened by the proceedings of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers in New York, where electronic "thinking" machines, among other matters, were discussed. WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP) -- Bette Davis, the actress, received the United States tax collector's rating today as the highest-paid woman of the year.
