BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 5 (Reuters) -- Reporters covering the trial of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, with two exceptions, issued today a statement denying that censorship of any kind was being enforced on their dispatches or that the official interpreters were guilty of distortion.
Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat, of Tennessee, declared last night that talk of the lower Tennessee valley becoming the Ruhr valley of America presented substance rather than fantasy.

Up to 77 per cent of all persons over 50 years of age and up to 52 per cent of those under 50 were affected by the near-catastrophic poison smog which hit Donora, Pa., and environs in late October, says Dr. Clarence A. Mills of the University of Cincinnati College of Medicine.
OMAHA, Feb. 5 -- A blizzard of bills of varying importance, many of which bear costly price tags, are descending on Midwestern legislators. The bills provide a topic of widespread interest.

TO wander through a country with no more than a few words of its language is a test to any traveler's temper; but, gagged by this handicap, to write an interesting book about that country and its people is an even greater challenge to an author's talent.

MONTAUK, L. I., Feb. 5 -- The three military establishments that helped protect New York City from enemy naval attack during the last war by defending the entrance to Long. Island Sound here will be stripped of the last remnants of their armament Monday.

WITH the dress rehearsal of Richard Strauss' "Salome" last Wednesday, Fritz Reiner conducting, and Ljuba Welitsch, the Bulgarian soprano, making her American debut in the title part, and with an excellent supporting cast, it was clear that at long last this famous opera had returned in its full significance to the Metropolitan stage.

A proposal that should attract much interest has been made before the Institute of Aeronautical Sciences by Admiral Luis de Florez, USN, retired, who contributed to the war effort through his development of special devices for the Navy. Admiral de Florez points out the enormous and often unrealized growth in the complexity and cost of modern aircraft of all types as compared with their prototypes of only a few decades ago.

Sixty-three medical, educational and health authorities, including representatives of Federal, state and local agencies, will address the First National Conference on Cerebral Palsy beginning today and continuing through Thursday at the Statler Hotel, it was announced yesterday by Arthur Larschan, vice president of the New York State Cerebral Palsy Association, sponsor of the conference.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The St. Louis University Billikens rallied gamely tonight to snatch a 43-37 overtime victory from a stubborn Long Island University quintet before 11,000 fans.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 5 -- Rutgers took an early lead here tonight and held it throughout the game to defeat the visiting Fordham Rams, 84 -- 73. The victory was the Scarlet quintet's ninth in 17 starts while Fordham's record is now 8 and 7.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Hoover Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government is expected to present the first part of its official report to Congress soon, probably on Monday. Subsequent parts will move at the rate of about three a week until the end of the commission's official existence on March 13.

Describing the Displaced Persons Act as "inadequate," a panel of six junior high school students appearing on the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over WQXR yesterday urged Congress to adopt the nine major changes recommended by the Displaced Persons Commission.
GLASTONBURY, CONN., Feb. 5 -- The Connecticut State Police Department is about to get serious with the radar detection device it uses to teach speeding motorists the error of their ways.

One boy was drowned and another rescued yesterday afternoon when they went through thin ice covering Prospect Park Lake between the mainland and a tiny island. The surviving boy tried to rescue his school chum before being saved by a man who dived into the icy water.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 5 -- The United Nations Department of Economic Affairs predicted today a brighter economic year for the world, with 1949 bringing the long-awaited break in the inflationary spiral, and farms, factories and mines going far toward eliminating "pent up demands" for consumer goods.

Officials of a large buying organization disclosed last week that they are taking active steps to increase importations of foreign-made merchandise. At the present time, they said, twenty buyers are combing Great Britain and Europe to collect samples, sketches and prices of items suitable for this market.

TELEVISION dived into the corn last week, presenting without advance warning the first soap opera to be seen before the cameras. The title of the precedent-making cliff hanger is "These Are My Children" and it has everything: problems, crises, hysterics, cliches, sobs, tensions and the inevitable little joys.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 5 -- Shattering three records and equalling another, Coach Bob Giegenback's Yale track team easily overpowered Princeton by 79 -- 30 in the Coxe Cage today.

CEDARHURST, L. I., Feb. 5 -- Miss Janet Morgan of Surrey, England, made a determined bid for the singles title in the New York State women's squash racquets tournament today, but after a sharp five-game struggle bowed to Miss Betty Howe of New Haven, Conn., 15 -- 10, -- 11 -- 15, 13 -- 15, 15 -- 7, 15 -- 7, at Rockaway Hunting Club.

The New York A. C., with John Flinter its bright particular star, stepped to the team title in the second annual track meet of the Long Island Chapter, Knights of Columbus, in the 106th Regiment Armory, Brooklyn, last night.

Baseball's current off-season will go swirling to its grand climax tonight when some 1,400 guests invade the grand ballroom of the Waldorf - Astoria to attend the twenty-sixth annual dinner of the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America.

ARTHUR MANN is a whimsical gentleman who now serves as Branch Rickey's right-hand man with the Brooklyn Dodgers. But before he became a junior Mahatma he had been a baseball writer. Once during his pre-Dodger days he remarked, tongue in cheek: "Have you ever stopped to consider the fiendish revenge that the baseball magnates took on our profession for stealing Sid Mercer from them some forty-odd years ago?

As an itinerant scholar in this country seeking the ground of Western democracy, I welcome the letter published in your columns in which a Dutch national supports his hard and unswerving heritage. On such spirit, surely, is the will of a people based, and no adventuring nation can sever this spirit from its roots so long as patriots continue to proclaim their deeper loyalties even in face of the aggressive failures of their own Government.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 5 -- The Lebanese and Syrian Premiers agreed in principle after a five-hour conference today to take part in Palestine peace negotiations at Rhodes. Quarters close to the Lebanese Government believed that this decision was made on the basis of the United Nations resolution that said that each party in the fighting must return to its original territories.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 5 -- More than 700,000 Indian Government employes have walked off their jobs or have threatened to strike in the next month for increases in wages or cost of living allowances. This labor unrest, which is country-wide, is an expression of the ordinary literate Indian's rebellion against continually rising prices for his few necessities of life.

SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 5 -- While temperatures remained below par in the Mountain States this week, a respite from severe snowstorms gave harried officials and residents a chance to assess the situation.

DOD ORSBORNE is an ex-runner, whaler, sea captain, British Naval Intelligence agent, paratrooper, Commando and convict. He has hunted pearls in Patagonia and tigers in India. He has sabotaged aircraft assembly depots in Tripoli and railroad bridges in French Morocco and has been jailed in Spain, England, Burma and Devil's Island.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 5 -- Lloyd Mangrum of Chicago "salvaged" a 68 from what he called a "bad" round of golf, to hang on to a two-stroke lead over the field today at the end of the third round in the $10,000 Tucson open with a record 12-under par 198.

The budget of New York State is more than an itemization of one year's income and outgo. It is a legislative program which affects, in one way or another, the state's 14,000,000 people. It is also an exposition of the Governor's philosophy of government.

A revision of the 50-year-old Gregg Shorthand System, the first since 1929, designed to simplify greatly the learning and writing of the phonetic alphabet, was announced yesterday by Robert E. Slaughter, vice president of the Gregg Publishing Company, business education division of the McGraw Hill Publishing Company.

At the end of the second session of the life master individual contract bridge championship tournament, which was played yesterday afternoon at the Park Sheraton Hotel, Stanley O. Fenkel of Philadelphia retained his lead with 260 points for the two sessions.

Miss Pearl B. Zimmerman, in past years a stormy petrel in the Welfare Department, is quitting her post as assistant to Earl V. Bradsher, head of the bureau of welfare administration, to become an associate executive director of the Federation of Jewish Agencies in Cincinnati, it was learned yesterday.

Julian Olevsky, the 22-year-old violinist who made his North American debut at Town Hall yesterday afternoon, is an expert violinist. At his best he produced tones of meaty 'cello-like quality and the precision and clearness of articulation of a woodwind.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- When the liner Queen of Bermuda, absent from passenger service since her conversion to a troop carrier in 1939, enters Hamilton Harbor on Feb. 14, she will be freighted with Bermudian hopes for the full resumption of the island's tourist trade.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 5 -- The American Federation of Labor announced today that it was ready to discuss the formation of a new international labor organization embracing all free trade unions. However, it laid down a number of conditions on which it will insist.

WHEN Sir Arthur Conan Doyle died in 1930, literally worn out by his labors at the age of 71, he was one of the most famous and genuinely interesting men in the world. That he has since slipped into an undeserved half oblivion is largely attributable to the lack of a first-rate life -- in spite of biographies and other studies.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Mrs. Fanny Blankers-Koen, The Netherlands' Olympic star, broke her week-old Australian record for the 80-meter hurdles today when she won at the New South Wales Track and Field championships in 11.4 seconds.

FROM the unlikely hand of a University of Nevada English professor comes this historical romance of frontier days along the upper Mississippi. The story opens in 1813 with the at rival of 20-year-old Mark Eldridge at the fur-trading post of Goshen, Ill.

Mr. Thomas Quinn Curtiss writes (Jan. 9) that in presenting Brecht's work to the American public I have neglected Brecht's best play, "The Threepenny Opera," and that the reason "is something of a mystery." The mystery is soon cleared up.

Frank G. Worbs Jr., commenting in your Letters column on my article ("A Cat Is a Cat Is a Cat"), tells of a 10-month-old tom that can lick anything in the barn and describes it as a "full-grown" cat. No doubt it is a physically

THE author of those delightful "Tales of the South Pacific" (which so well deserved the Pulitzer award they captured in 1948) has now exploded into print with a hot-headed, heavy-handed, grimly-in-earnest novel that will startle, if it does not increase, his public.

FROM the American Theatre Wing yesterday came word that plans for the awarding of the third annual set of Antoinette Perry prizes now are being made. Which, as sure as last week's snow, is positive proof that spring and the theatre's prize-giving season are not far off.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 5 -- Unleashing a dazzling display of sharpshooting, Yale's brilliant captain, Tony Lavelli, tallied 40 points tonight to pace the Elis to an easy 74-48 triumph over Princeton.
If Norway should sign a non-aggression pact with the Soviet Union, she would be departing from the customary Scandinavian policy of neutrality and the shunning of commitments to a specific country.

MR. JOHNSTON, a Pacific war correspondent, landed the first wave of the Second Marine Division on Tarawa and remained throughout the battle. His book, "Follow Me," tells the story of the Second Marine Division -- a story enriched by the wealth of information provided by some 7,000 Leathernecks who wrote to the Division History Board, offering suggestions, anecdotes and memories.
AUCKLAND, N. Z., Feb. 5 (AP) -- Man must turn more to the ocean for food to survive, Dr. J. L. Kask of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization told the Pacific Science Congress today.

THE most popular, long-run religious program on the air is "The Greatest Story Ever Told." The program is distinctive on two other counts as well: the usual windy commercial is mercifully omitted and the subject-matter has an appropriateness to the day.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Senate Democrats agreed today to throw their undivided weight against a Republican effort to force an immediate showdown in the drive to curb filibusters.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Most reluctantly and apprehensively the Arab states seemed this week to be moving toward a grudging and sulky peace with Israel. They were subsiding into acquiescence in the existence of a Zionist state, if not the acceptance of it.
" People," said Deputy Chief Inspector Frederick L. McKenna cheerfully, "always are getting involved in unusual situations. If the cop on the beat can't handle it, out we roll."
signed Clyde (Smackover) Scott as the third member of what they considered the greatest offensive trio in football.

THE thirty-third edition of the International Flower Show will open at Grand Central Palace on Monday, March 21, and continue through Saturday, the 26th. Taking "The Americas" as a keynote, a large portion of the exhibits will have a Latin-American theme.
CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (UP) -- New snowstorms and high winds threatened today to wipe out the gains made in the blizzard-burdened West's struggle against one of the worst winters on record.

BESS FURMAN, to her credit, has never mistaken herself for the wheel during twenty years as Washington correspondent. But she has had a perfectly glorious time watching the wheel go round, finding out what makes it turn, and occasionally giving it a guiding push.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 5 -- Princeton University's speedy hockey team bounced back from a pair of stinging defeats to halt Clarkson Tech, 7 -- 3, in Baker Rink today. The defeat snapped the visitors' four-game winning streak.
ROME, Feb. 5 -- The Vatican today announced that it had reorganized a "press service" that was inaugurated in 1937 and that functioned on a much reduced scale during and since the war.

IN recent weeks there have been numerous comments on the retirement of Fordham University's distinguished president, the Rev. Robert I. Gannon. His brilliance as an educator and his fame as an after-dinner speaker have been universally discussed.

Local government budget-making time is now at hand and it is the turn of state and municipal officials to feel the money pinch of price inflation. Just as private enterprise, because of the shrinking market for equity capital, is going more and more into debt, so local government, because of the insufficiency of traditional real estate tax yields, is dropping new kinds of tax hooks into the disposable income of the people.

IT would be ridiculous for a New York drama critic to travel out of town to see a play which will never reach Broadway. The art critic's province is not so limited. Although out-of-town art shows are usually strictly local affairs, they are not tryouts but finished productions which often have interest outside the home town.

The doctrine that alcoholism is a sickness has provided drinkers with a handy alibi, according to Edward J. McGoldrick Jr., director of the city's Bureau of Alcoholic Therapy for which Bridge House at 912 Bronx Park South is the clinic.

FOR THIS WEEK: Remove broken branches swaying on trees as soon as they are noticed. . . . Use sand or ashes, not salt, to melt ice from sidewalks and driveways. If salt must be used, flush the soil around trees with water to leach out the chloride in spring. . . . As weather permits, prune suckers from lilacs and apple trees. . .

IF one seeks points of concentration in which Lincoln's basic ideas converge, and from which they radiate, he will do well to restudy the inaugural addresses of 1861 and 1865. For Lincoln these were more than "speeches." They were compass and chart -- standards, reasonings, declarations of faith, assurances, persuasions.

Realty men must take concerted action to bring tenant-owner relations out of the low estate into which they have fallen since the war as the result of "deplorable" acts of a few greedy landlords, Lee Thompson Smith, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, warned the industry last night.

IN 1899, Buster Crow, whose reputation for violence has preceded him, drifts into the Western town of Pearl City, where the open-range cattlemen are engaged in a losing battle with homesteaders. Buster needs money; the cattlemen have it -- so he undertakes, for a handsome fee, to rid the region of the undesirables who would fence in the land.

If Mr. Stalin was actuary trying to bring about peace when he made public last week his interview with the International News Service, he must realize by now that he tried a wrong method. If he was merely attempting to divide the Western Nations or to strengthen his propaganda line, he must realize that this effort has not worked very well, either.

RICHMOND, Feb. 5 -- Things were pretty peaceful and quiet in the Upper South this week. It was cold, but not cold enough to damage crops or ice up the roads, and residents of this region kept their eyes generally on home-town affairs.
In an attempt to increase the facilities of City College, plans are under way to purchase the buildings and campus of the Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Southern states section of the French Gratitude Train arrived in Washington at 11:15 o'clock tonight after a trip from Jersey City that was notable for the outpouring of warm-hearted greetings at civic ceremonies in way stations attended by thousands.

In an effort to increase world production, particularly in the Marshall Plan countries, the International Labor Office is planning to provide a training-within-industry service for its fifty-nine member nations, according to Channing R. Dooley of Summit, N. J., who sailed yesterday for Rotterdam aboard the Holland-America liner Noordam.

A committee of the New York State Chamber of Commerce has recommended that the Chamber go on record in favor of federalization of the National Guard. The committee went to the root of the matter when it pointed out that national defense is clearly a national responsibility.
AN orchid with palm-like foliage that will grow as a house plant is impressive enough. When it also turns out to be easy to grow, then it is really something.

THE fact that Paul Muni will open in Sidney Howard's Pulitzer Prize comedy, "They Knew What They Wanted," on Feb. 16, at the Music Box, is no longer a secret. In reply to the queries of friends as to whether I will attend the premiere, the answer is, I will not.
Benjamin Fine discussed a very important issue in his education column of Jan. 24 in THE NEW YORK TIMES and raised a very important question about the status of academic freedom in America today.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Feb. 5 -- Plans for Protestant churches in two communities of Nassau County and surveys that may lead to building in four additional sections has been sanctioned by the comity committee of the Nassau County Christian Council, the Rev. J. Kenneth Miller, the chairman, announced here today.

MISS WOOD and her husband, whom she identifies only as Mac, had dreamed for years of returning to the land. Once their children were grown, they made the move. The croft they chose was on the coast in Inverness, Scotland, just onshore from the islands of Rum and Eigg, facing the Gulf of the Hebrides.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 -- A warning that privately endowed research libraries will be "taxed out of existence" if they become too exclusive was sounded here today at a meeting of historians.

A resolution protesting the "rejection" by the United States of "numerous offers of the Soviet Union" to confer upon unresolved international problems and "particularly on existing differences" between the two nations was approved yesterday at a luncheon meeting of 200 women at the Commodore Hotel.

The Eighty-first Congress last week took up one of the hottest issues of last November's elections -- labor legislation. It began working over a Truman proposal -- submitted eight days ago -- for thorough revision of the nation's labor law. Froth the outset it was clear that the issue would provoke one of the most bitter controversies the Congress has to face.

DETROIT, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Automobile prices could level off this year -- if the industry finds ways to cut production costs. There may be no price cuts, but there could be a halt to continuing increases.
ALBANY, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Governor Dewey will make two major speeches next week in which he is expected to chart a course he believes the Republican party should follow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Democratic members of the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee asserted today that Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, was completely wrong in forecasting that Congress would re-enact most of the provisions of the Taft-Hartley Law.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Rear Admiral John Esten Whelchel signed today for a spell of shore duty as head coach of the Washington Redskins professional football team.

THE year 1948 will doubtless be starred in furniture annals as the year that saw the phenomenon of the cocktail chair. While homemakers wistfully eyed chairs tagged $236 and wondered if prices would ever come down, while socially minded designers searched for new materials and techniques which might put furniture within reach of everyone who needed it, there suddenly appeared on the market a good-looking, comfortable, armless, upholstered chair priced under $20.

RHODES, Feb. 5 -- With Egyptian and Israeli delegates apparently making some slight progress toward an armistice agreement, Dr. Bunche is preparing to send an emissary to find out whether the other Arab states would accept his invitation to open armistice talks with Israel.

Proposals of a Civil Aeronautics Board member last week for greater participation by the Government in the financial affairs of the air-transport industry attracted mixed reaction in airline, aircraft and financial circles. Upon preliminary examination of the suggestions, most airline officials favored the plan as a "last resort," but aircraft and private investment authorities signified general opposition to the program.

WITHIN the deceptively simple outlines of Anne Goodwin Winslow's latest book are displayed the several qualities of excellence that distinguish all her novels. Here, as in "The Dwelling Place" and "A Winter in Ge neva," is the same effective use of understatement, not studied or clipped in the way of much modern writing, but with a gentle, quicksilver touch about it.

LONDON, Feb. 5 (Reuters) -- Upsets marked today's fourth-round replays in the Football Association cup. Manchester United, last year's winner, was held to a 1-1 draw by lowly Bradford, and Blackpool, the 1948 runner-up, was eliminated by Stoke City, 1 -- 0.

Control of the Rh blood factor that causes many stillbirths, miscarriages and frequently fatal infants' diseases is promised by a discovery reported the Chicago section of the American Chemical Society by Prof. Charles C. Price, chairman of the Department of Chemistry in the University of Notre Dame.

Cardinal Spellman has designated today as "a day of prayer and protest in behalf of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty in all the churches of the archdiocese." He announced also that he would speak from the pulpit in St. Patrick's Cathedral and would have "much to say" about the Mindszenty trial.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 5 -- The departure from here of a Nationalist preliminary peace delegation to Peiping has been delayed several days while the delegation receives "final instructions" from Acting President Li Tsung-jen, it was announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP) -- A special medical advisory committee tonight urged James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, to start a countrywide drive to recruit nearly 4,000 doctors and dentists for the armed forces by December.

WITHIN the past few years, African violets have gained in popularity by leaps and bounds. So many people are growing varieties from single leaves, divisions or from seeds, that the plants promise soon to be as ubiquitous as the traditional rubber plant.

PARIS, Feb. 5 -- A continued fall in food prices in France in January and the apparently assured success of the Government's new loan are considered good auguries for the official fight against inflation, he success of the loan is expected to be announced uesday.
A GOOD way to begin thinking about a new labor law, now taking shape in Congressional hearings, is to compare the policy pronouncements of the Taft-Hartley Act and the Wagner Act.

A GROUP and three one-man exhibitions this week offer the curious spectacle of examples from the past, in the prints of Lautrec, that have a more intense contemporary interest for us than the present-day work on view.

POPULARIZED biographies of great composers too often resemble the heroic skirmishes of a figure out of Lord Byron's imagination. The world has always idealized the life of a genius. Excuses are easily found for his faults, and his creative output is placed in the realm of the gods where none may question its absolute perfection.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- Indicative of the people's reaction to Premier Stalin's proposals to meet President Truman were these comments obtained in on-the-street surveys in metropolitan areas: "Russia is beating around the bush," and "The important thing is that Truman and Stalin meet -- anything is worth trying in an effort to attain world peace."

THE NEW YORK TIMES last week sent a wire addressed to "Editor of local paper, O'Neill, Neb." -- in the heart of the blizzard area -- asking him for some data on the effects of the winter on small-town life. Here is his reply:
In your issue of Jan. 23 Corliss Lamont raises his voice in favor of more agreements with Soviet Russia and "calmness, restraint and willingness to compromise."
LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Anglo-Soviet relations received a small but significant boost up at the Firth of Forth, Scotland, today -- and all because of some last minute rugby tickets.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 5 -- Daily meetings and far-reaching measures by the newly constituted National Economic Council suggest that President Peron is making an earnest effort to right the country's economy after the controversial era that generally is taken to have ended with the resignation of Miguel Miranda as head of the Council.

Spurred by a confidential survey which disclosed that metal working business in many major industrial centers is now 5 to 15 per cent below 1948 operating rates, heavy equipment industries have started a three-phase drive to counteract recession tendencies.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 5 -- Favored Olympia raced to an easy victory in the $75,550 San Felipe Stakes at Santa Anita Park today, routing seventeen rival 3-year-olds before 45,000 fans.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 5 -- Gov. G. Mennen Williams stood by quietly today as the Congress of Industrial Organizations took over the reins of the Democratic party at one of the largest gatherings in that political group's history.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 5 -- The exchange of public statements between Moscow and Washington this week has strengthened the general belief here that there is to be no let-up in the "cold war" and that it is high time for the democracies to speed up their plans for regional defense agreements.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 5 -- Beset with income tax headaches and faced with a prospect of new or increased state taxes, West Coast residents wondered this week about a widely publicized downward trend in living costs.

Since it is one of the theatre's more treasured theorems that a playwright must see his script on the stage to help him learn his craft, the Dramatic Workshop of the New School has rendered Roy Bradford invaluable service. Mr. Bradford, a student in the workshop, is the author of "Chameleon," produced at the President Theatre over the week-end, and it is to be hoped that the manifest flaws displayed will not be repeated.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 6 -- Reports in the trade last week showed most consumers ordering steel in good quantity. Except for alloy steels, requirements were still heavy. But there was more evidence that extra heavy pressure by steel users was becoming less insistent.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 6 -- United States policy toward the Soviet Union has the full support of the American Federation of Labor, the AFL executive council said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The ability of the Democratic majority to move the Administration legislative program through the Eighty-first Congress is expected to meet revealing tests in the House and Senate this week.

Lentils are to an Egyptian, a Russian or to almost any European what baked beans are to a Bostonian; indeed beans and lentils are both classed as legumes. Though this staple for many centuries in other parts of the world is seldom used in America, now is an opportune time to become acquainted with it.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 26 -- Operational experiments have begun at the rocket township of the joint British-Australian long range weapons organization called Woomera, a neatly planned area of huts, hangars, storehouses and an increasing number of permanent buildings 240 miles northwest of Adelaide.

The New York Knickerbockers did all in their power to break the stranglehold the Chicago Stags have held on them, but their efforts were to no avail as the visitors beat the locals for the ninth Straight time, 87 to 75, in a Basketball Association of America clash at Madison Square Garden last night.

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Feb. 6 -- The Ardsley Curling Club's No. 1 rink, skipped by Addison B. Hastings and including Edward Fiske at No. 1, Harold Weston No. 2, and Harold Sothern No. 3, won the district medal in the annual bonspiel for members of district No. 2 of the Grand National Curling Club of America as the two-day event wound up at St. Andrews Golf Club today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- With a Soviet offer of a non-aggression pact awaiting an answer at home, Norway's Foreign Minister flew to the United States today to learn what his country's obligations and degree of security would be if it were to join the proposed North Atlantic defense pact.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 6 -- With the election of Hicks Griffiths of Detroit as chairman of the State Central Committee, Michigan Democrats opened the way for restoration of peace within the party for the first time in longer than a year.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Feb. 6 -- The metropolitan ski jumping season, delayed for a month by unfavorable weather, got under way today as a field of forty-eight participated in the annual Telemark Trophy competition on Bear Mountain's fifty-meter hill.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Completing a journey from the far corners of France to the nation's capital, the southern section of the French gratitude train was welcomed here today by a crowd of 3,000, which included Vice President Alben W. Barkley and top-ranking officials of the Government and diplomatic corps.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UP) -- The winter of 1948-49 in the West probably will go down as the worst in the country's recorded history, the Weather Bureau said today.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Feb. 6 -- Dissemination of facts and public discussion about atomic energy must increase if science is to protect freedom and democracy, David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, told Lehigh University's mid-year graduating class this afternoon.

As a reflection of the listless trading in the foreign exchange market last week the small business involved came up with only minor prices changes. In particular, this applied to the Europeans, which ruled firmly. In the South American group, however, there was some stir originating out of the rumors of currency devaluation.

PARIS, Jan. 28 -- Several hundred American students here are beginning to think about the mid-year examinations due in many schools at the end of February. Many will be prepared for them, and many will not. Actually, those who are not prepared probably will not suffer, because, so far, according to a representative of the Veterans Administration, no post-war American has been "flunked out" of a French school.

Debussy's "Pelleas et Melisande" will have its first performance at the Metropolitan Opera in four years, during the company's twelfth week of Feb. 14. Jacques Jansen, French tenor of the Opera Comique, will make his American debut as Pelleas.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 6 -- With the exception of a few minor details the West German Parliamentary Assembly has completed writing the constitution it began to draft last September. A plenary session scheduled for Friday will vote on the current draft, already agreed upon in committee meetings.

PARIS, Feb. 6 -- On a theme song of scarfs or stoles Jean Desses designs asymmetrically. Only a master dressmaker could produce such apparently effortless grace, but the beauty of these gowns should be sustained by equal grace in the wearer.

VIENNA, Feb. 6 -- As a substitute for capitalistic incentives in the newly nationalized and strictly rationed economy of Czechoslovakia, the newspapers of that "people's republic" publish daily appeals to the workers' loyalty to state, party and unions.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- Alexander Knox Helm, who was a gunnery officer in the army that liberated Palestine from the Turks in 1917 and opened up the country to extensive Zionist immigration, was named tonight as Britain's first representative to the Government of Israel. Mr. Helm is now British Minister in Budapest.

The editorial "What's In a Uniform?" published in the Jan. 27 edition of THE TIMES, is in contrast to the unbiased concept of news as reported in THE TIMES, and which has won it an enviable reputation.

The greatest persecutor of the church today is the demon of indifference, the Rev. Robert C. Hunsicker said yesterday in a sermon at Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street. Mr. Hunsicker is a member of the staff of Trinity Church.

State Senator Elmer F. Quinn and Assemblyman Irwin Steingut attacked yesterday the state budget submitted to the Legislature by Governor Dewey last week as "a wasteful, extravagant and reckless budget," and declared that the Democratic members of the Legislature would oppose some of its proposals.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- An "honor system" under which prices for Marshall Plan goods are policed after they are paid for has been approved by a committee of four former OPA executives, a foreign aid official disclosed today. They agreed that price ceilings are unwise, he said.

Walter Hendl, the Philharmonic-Symphony's assistant conductor, who was named conductor of the Dallas Symphony on Friday, conducted the New York organization in Carnegie Hall Saturday night. The evening's soloists were Michael Rosenker and Carl Stern, the orchestra's assistant concertmaster and assistant solo-'cellist.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Wisconsin's tiny mite of the nation's milers, 130-pound Don Gehrmann, brought his indoor campaign back to the Middle West last night in impressive fashion.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Feb. 6 -- Thirty-eight dinghies turned out for today's frostbite regatta on Manhasset Bay and sailed in a light, fluky easterly breeze.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 6 -- Virginia Kellogg, scenarist, has returned to Hollywood after a two-month tour of women's prisons, during which she entered a series of penitentiaries incognito as a convict with the connivance of the authorities, it was learned this week-end from Warner Brothers, for which company she undertook the tour as a screen-writing assignment.

The Department of the Army's ambitious historical project, the "United States Army in World War II," is now well launched. Forty-seven of the proposed ninety-nine volumes are in preparation. Three of the books have already been published. When the work is completed it will form a large and valuable source of reference for scholars and students of the military.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 6 -- Hugh R. Pomeroy, planning director of Westchester County, is generating in conversational circles something of the heat and blast effects of nuclear fission. He is doing it by expounding a theory that in an atomic war people would be safer in the hills of New York and New England than on the prairies of the Middle West.
Thousands of Boy Scouts throughout the city participated in special services offered by churches of all denominations yesterday in observance of Scout Sunday and the opening of Boy Scout Week.

Urging America to awake and arise, Msgr. Fulton J. Sheen, professor of philosophy at the Catholic University of America, said last night in a radio address that "we can save the world by raising again in the United Nations the question of Poland, Hungary and all the Eastern Europe that fell from the frying pan of Nazism into the more terrible fire of Communism."
MOSCOW, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Soviet Government's proposal of a non-aggression pact to Norway may soon be followed by an offer of such treaties to Sweden and Denmark, foreign observers predicted today.

Joseph Szigeti, violinist, last night gave the only Carnegie Hall recital he is scheduled to give this season. He confined his program to Schubert's C major Fantasy, Beethoven's "Kreutzer" Sonata and two contemporary works, Henry Cowell's Sonata (1945) and Benjamin Britten's Suite (1934-5).

Capt. J. H. Sellevis Smit, Chaplain in Chief of the Royal Netherlands Navy, declared yesterday that although the Dutch were "ashamed and guilty" of shortcomings in Indonesia in the past, they believed their battle there now was justified.
PARIS, Feb. 6 -- It has been officially confirmed that French and American banks have begun talks to work out a joint plan for capital investments in French overseas territories.

DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Sverre Farstad, 29-year-old councilman from Trondheim, Norway, won the European speed skating championship today, after a spectacular two-day meet in which three world records were broken and another tied.
Plans for the nationalization of four major areas of industry in Pakistan were disclosed by M. O. A. Baig, Counselor of the Embassy of Pakistan, in a speech before the Cooper Union Forum last night.

Cardinal Spellman, in the pulpit of St. Patrick's Cathedral, called yesterday morning upon the American people to unite in prayer and protest to stop the Communist penetration of our nation, lest there should be a third world war. His sermon was titled "Rebellion to Tyrants Is Obedience to God."

Apartment house owners formally notified representatives of 25,000 unionized Manhattan building service workers yesterday that they considered the union's wage demands "unreasonable" in the light of existing rent ceilings.
CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (UP) -- A big new snowstorm driven by gale winds howled out of the northwest today on the dying heels of an earlier Western blizzard.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The New York Rangers rose out of the National Hockey League cellar tonight with a 2-to-0 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks before 16,659. The Hawks dropped into last place as a result.

DETROIT, Feb. 6 (AP) -- A first-period goal by Pete Horeck stood up for the Detroit Red Wings tonight as they beat third-place Montreal, 1 to 0, for Goalie Harry Lumley's fourth shut-out of the National Hockey League season.
The regrettable Gieseking affair seems to cause a chain reaction which if not stopped early may result in more bitter feeling at home and abroad.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Raymond E. Blum, 29-year-old engineering student from Nutley, H. J., and Miss Myra Shapiro, a Brooklyn bank clerk, won the 1949 Middle Atlantic outdoor speed skating championships, today before a crowd of 8,000.

DUBLIN, Feb. 6 -- The most significant aspect of the renewed struggle over the partition of Ireland is that unless partition is ended and Ireland unified the Republic of Ireland will not join the Atlantic Pact.

A grant of $35,000 has been given to the National Records Management Council by the Rockefeller Foundation for a study of problems in the preservation of business records, Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University announced over the weekend.

Though having a professional and profitable production plan, a producer would have to be addled not to follow his own format. And Bryan Foy, far from being daft, has cleaved to the pattern he set in "T-Men" and "Canon City" to come up with a taut and realistic melodrama in "He Walked By Night."
Charles A. Myers has been appointed vice president of S. B. Penick Co., producer and importer of essential oils. Mr. Myers will be managing director of the company's essential oils division.
THE War Cabinet met at 10 a.m. on the 17th [of May, 1940] and I gave them an account of my visit to Paris, and of the situation so far as I could measure it.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- The stock markets here have fallen into such a dull and idle condition that traders eagerly seize upon any event, however trivial, in an attempt to reawaken public interest. Thus the incident of the suggested Stalin-Truman meeting was made the excuse for putting prices rather higher.

The Rev. Dr. C. Franklin Koch, executive secretary of the Board of Social Missions of the United Lutheran Church in America, cited yesterday the number of homeless men in New York to point up the need for Christian service. He spoke at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street.

In one of the first exchanges of its kind, a girl factory worker in the United States and one in England will swap jobs and living conditions for a month so that they can acquaint their fellow workers with conditions in the foreign countries. Both factories make fluorescent lamps.

The National Committee for Labor Israel, holding a conference yesterday at the Commodore Hotel, received $1,072,900 in cash and checks and pledges of $1,500,000 from representatives of labor, fraternal and social organizations. The money will be transmitted today to Histadrut, Israel's labor federation, for which the committee raises funds in this country.

Congress will be asked this week to authorize $5,650,000,000 for the fifteen months of the European Recovery Program which will begin next April 1 and end June 30, 1950. This is less than the present rate of spending, but it is not small change. It is important that Congress and the public should have confidence that the money is being well used.

Common Cause, Inc., of 444 Madison Avenue, a non-sectarian movement to combat Communism and defend human freedom, endorsed the statement of Cardinal Spellman yesterday in defense of Cardinal Mindszenty. The message was issued jointly by Mrs. Natalie Wales Paine, president, and Christopher Emmet, chairman of the board of Common Cause.

ROME, Feb. 6 -- The tensions at the other end of the Mediterranean are so palpable every minute that arriving in Italy is almost like a return to a normal world. This, of course, is a superficial impression, for strains and cracks hidden by the comparatively cheerful face of this country are deep and dangerous.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 -- Livestock losses resulting from storms over the Western states will have little immediate effect on consumer beef supplies, but may be reflected in the country's live stock markets as long as two years from now, according to H. M. Conway, market analyst for the National Livestock Producers' Association.

Every so often a decision is rendered by the Supreme Court which has the effect of upsetting established industrial practices or presumably settled principles of law. In some cases the possibilities opened up by these decisions are so far-reaching that the Court is prevailed upon to clarify its position or Congress steps in to legislate on the matter.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 6 -- What is probably the largest private estate in the world owned by a single individual, the Nizam of Hyderabad's lands, will be nationalized, it was reported today from Hyderabad. These lands, totalling about 7,000 square miles in area, are equivalent in size to Connecticut and Delaware combined.
ROME, Feb. 6 (UP) -- Pope Pius will denounce the trial of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty "at the first opportunity after the sentence is known," an authoritative Vatican source said today.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- A striking change in the attitude of the Western nations toward the Soviet Union seemed to be manifested today in London's reaction to Moscow's proposal for a non-aggression pact between the Soviet Union and Norway.

Uncovering what is expected to be decisive data on the question of television's effect on the radio audience will be the first project of the Association of National Advertisers' new committee on radio, it was learned over the week-end. The group also will work on methods for measuring "impact" of video commercials.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Republican leaders have assured Gov. Thomas E. Dewey he will have a full house when he comes here Tuesday night to tell the GOP how he thinks it can win the next election.

Four three-story buildings occupying a plot 76 by 80 feet at 189 to 195 Third Avenue have been sold by the Estate of Princess Elizabeth de Caraman Chimay to the Ardor Realty Company in a deal negotiated by J. Edgar Leay-craft Co. and Walter Kaufmann, brokers.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- As a result of temporary rate increases authorized in the past, the Public Service Commission faces the need of reviewing virtually every gas utility, railroad commutation, bus fare, water and motor carrier rate under its control in the next two years.

The North American Company announced yesterday plans for divestment of its 100 per cent stock interest in the West Kentucky Coal Company in further compliance with requirements of the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

Gallantly supported by four or five handsome, muscular leading men, Mae West has brought "Diamond Lil" back to New York, where it began its renowned career twenty-one years ago. She wriggled through it at the Coronet on Saturday evening, attired in some of the gaudiest finery of the century -- the femme fatale of the Bowery, bowling her leading men over one by one with her classical impersonation of a story - book strumpet.

The United States Maritime Commission has completed an exhaustive study of additional preservation measures needed for its vast reserve fleet. An eighty-five-page report, detailing its plans to proceed with a drydocking and bottom-preservation program affecting 2,300 vessels, has been released by the House Merchant Marine and. Fisheries Committee, to which the commission referred the project.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 6 -- Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty was kept under constant guard in his gray prison today, while Budapest newspapers gave prominent display to selected passages from his final statement to the court trying him for treason.
The reconstructed liner Queen of Bermuda, absent from the waters of New York and Bermuda for nearly ten years, will arrive here today to resume the service interrupted by the war in August, 1939.

Direct express cargo service between United States East Coast ports and Lisbon, Portugal, will be resumed this week by the American Export Lines after a lapse of almost a decade, according to John E. Slater, executive vice president of the company.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UP) -- Clothes buyers shopping for bargains were warned to day not to expect any permanent price slashes on quality men's and ladies' wool suits "in the foreseeable future."

A dozen members of the Col. Aaron Burr Association, half of them named Burr and all of them dedicated to clearing the name of the man who was the nation's third Vice President, made a pilgrimage yesterday to his one-time home in Washington Heights on the 193d anniversary of his birth.
CANTON, China, Feb. 6 -- Premier Sun Fo said today that the Chinese civil war would continue until the Communists dropped their demand for punishment of "war criminals."

The parents and teacher of 12-year-old Denise Dubs proved they had a talented child on their hands when they presented her in her New York debut two years ago. They proved it again on Saturday night when they brought forward the young Brooklyn pianist for her second Town Hall recital.
The Curtiss-Wright Corporation will present in a "road show" its history and those of its current products that the military services will release for display, the company announced yesterday.

The development of adequate programs for comprehensive prepayment medical care has been slow and largely unsupported by the organized medical profession, whose policies are determined by persons primarily concerned with retaining the status quo, Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, dean of Columbia University's Faculty of Medicine, declared in his annual report, made public yesterday.

Marjorie Lawrence, Salvatore Baccaloni and Giuseppe Di Stefano, Metropolitan Opera singers, and the Philharmonic-Symphony, conducted by Enrico Leide, performed at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. The occasion was a benefit for the College of St. Elizabeth, Convent Station, N. J., in its Golden Jubilee year.

For an independent theatre that is not sedulously aping Broadway, Federico Garcia Lorca's "Blood Wedding" is an ideal choice. It is a bitter idyll with verses, songs and dances, and it was imaginatively produced by New Stages, 159 Bleecker Street, last evening.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- An analysis of factors which must be considered in a program of industrialization for war-depleted and undeveloped areas abroad was presented today by the Machinery and Allied Products Institute, speaking for the capital goods industries of the country.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 6 -- The eighth session of the Economic and Social Council will get under way here tomorrow when delegates from eighteen countries meet to take up the heaviest agenda the United Nations organ has carried so far.

PARIS, Feb. 6 -- The United States is encouraging rebellion among the subject races and is thus creating "disorder" from which the Soviet Union may profit, according to Andre Siegfried, a popular French writer on contemporary politics whose books have been widely read in the United States, Britain and France.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 6 (AP) -- So-called "pretty good" golf today won Lloyd Mangrum, Chicago, $2,000 first prize money in the $10,000 Tucson open tournament. It also enabled him to set a new course record of 263 for the 72 holes. This was 17 under par.

When Ake Bonnier is asked how many magazines his family publishes he says, "About two dozen." He has to count on his fingers to compute the number of Bonniers now ruling the Swedish publishing empire that has been in the family since 1804, when it was founded by great-grandfather Gerhard Bonnier.

JAMES A. MICHENER, author of the brilliant and delightful "Tales of the South Pacific," which won the Pulitzer prize for fiction last year, has his first novel out today. It is "The Fires of Spring,"* one of those long, emotional studies of the growing-up of a sensitive young man which nearly every novelist itches to write and which to many do.

The Mathieson Chemical Corporation, as a result of negotiations with directors and principal stockholders of the Southern Acid and Sulphur Company, Inc., is contracting to purchase the business and assets of that company, Thomas S. Nichols, president, announced for publication today.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 6 -- The presence of five Negro men in the University of Notre Dame, and of three young Negro women in St. Mary's College for Women in the neigboring college community of Holy Cross was alluded to today as "an actuality, and no longer a reason for concern."

WINSLOW, Ariz., Feb. 6 -- Smoke signals and modern heliograph calls for assistance rose today from dozens of points on the far-flung Navajo reservation. A 300-mile lifeline operated both overland and by air to alleviate distress among thousands of Indians stricken with the worst winter in a generation.

OSLO, Norway, Feb. 6 -- Premier Einar Gerhardsen held an informal meeting with other members of the Norwegian Government today to discuss the note that the Soviet Union delivered to Norway last night, offering a non-aggression pact between the two countries.

Baseball's waning social season went out with a rush and a bang last night and if it left in its wake a bewildered host this was understandable enough. For it was that sort of evening as the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America held its twenty-sixth annual dinner and frolic in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, with more than 1,400 guests present.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The State Department of Commerce under fire by Democratic legislative leaders, said today that its efforts to attract new industries and to develop tourist business, "paid off with many millions of dollars in additional income for New York communities in 1948."
A three-week national drive for $5,000,000 to combat heart disease will be started today by the American Heart Association, it was announced yesterday by A. W. Robertson, chairman of the board.
In his sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday, Canon Thomas A. Sparks, cathedral pastor, made a plea for financial support for men who wish to enter the ministry.
Seven new films, including importations from England, France and Russia, are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

By defeating Hakoah, 4-1, on a muddy field at Sterling Oval in the Bronx yesterday, the New York Americans remained tied with the Brooklyn Hispanos for second place in the American Soccer League standing. Each side scored once in the first half.
CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Danny McGoorty of Los Angeles today knocked Juan Navarra of Buenos Aires out of a first-place tie in the national three-cushion billiard tournament.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UP) -- The Government conceded today that its 1948 potato price support program, which thus far has cost the taxpayers $150,000,000, left something to be desired.

The New Haven Railroad will run an experimental "show train" into New York on Tuesday, March 1, for the benefit of theatregoers in southern Connecticut, the railroad announced yesterday. The announcement said it was believed that the train would be the first ever operated into the city for the exclusive use of theatre patrons.
DULUTH, Minn., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Matti Piethainen of Finland today soared 220 feet to break the meet record and capture the Class A honors in the Duluth invitation ski jump.

Better values were offered by many apparel manufacturers here last week in an effort to stimulate sales of ready-to-wear, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Consumer response to the greater values was described as good and retailers followed through with a substantial increase in reorders for fast-selling merchandise.

The first test as to whether the latest Soviet "peace offensive" that was climaxed by Mr. Stalin's bid for a meeting with President Truman behind the Iron Curtain is a genuine bid for peace or merely another "international political maneuver" will come this week, when the Big Four Powers meet in London in another attempt to reach agreement on a peace treaty for Austria.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Unions won fewer collective bargaining elections during the first year of the Taft-Hartley act than in any year under the Wagner Act, the National Labor Relations Board reported to Congress today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today it is extending its minimum price guarantees for certain types of uranium-bearing ores until June 30, 1954. The floors, placed on carnotite-type and roscoelite-type ores of the Colorado plateau area, are aimed at encouraging investment in development of new mines.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Conceivably Generalissimo Stalin is perplexed by the cool and unenthusiastic reception of his latest venture into the field of propaganda through the channels of the English-speaking press. If such is the case, it would be useful for the secretariat of the Soviet Premier to re-examine similar statements on post-war relationships made by the U.S.S.R.'s Chief of State during the last three years.

RHODES, Feb. 6 -- The Egyptian-Israeli armistice talks have made positive progress in the joint informal meetings of the military men of the two nations during the last few days despite the apparent deadlock, Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine, said tonight.

Four small room suggestions in Altman's decorative fabrics department take their color cues from new inexpensive materials designed by the Waverly Fabrics Division of F. Schumacher Co. The fabrics are part of a group color-related so that homemakers may select plain textured ones in tones that will harmonize with the prints.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 6 -- Instead of old-fashioned gold bricks, they are offering uranium for sale in Brussels these days -- "the very best stuff, very powerful."

NORTH TONAWANDA, N. Y., Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Rudolph Wurlitzer company reported a consolidated net profit of $167,848, or 20 cents a share, after reserves and taxes, for the quarter ended on Dec. 31. This compares with a net profit of $816,125, or $1.04 a share, in the same quarter of 1947.

How can you get away from it? Spectacular winners of a big weekend in track and field, like Erik Ahlden, Willy Slykhuis, Jim Grosholz, Dave Bolen, Jim Gilhooley, Frank Fox, Harrison Dillard, Ed Conwell, Bill Vessie, Bob Richards, Jim Fuchs and Don Gehrmann all have to run second today to the broken blister on Gaston Reiff's left foot.

With doubtless more than a casual eye cast in the direction of night baseball's lush returns at the box office, a total of 199 nocturnal engagements will be played in the American League this year. This is revealed in the official 1949 championship schedule of the Will Harridge loop, released for publication today, and sets a new all-time high.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- The Financial Times, in a leading article, makes another attempt to analyze the American business scene. It opens by saying that this is more than usually confused and uncertain at present. Few observers, it remarks, have felt able to make any confident predictions about the way the economy will behave under the impact of the program recently outlined by President Truman's messages to Congress.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- A Democratic member of the temporary board of trustees of the new State University is slated for election by the Legislature this week to the Board of Regents, which has been battling for more than a year to curb the powers of the trustees.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 6 -- The Norwegian Government will reject the Soviet Union's offer of a non-aggression pact, Oslo and Stockholm official circles are confident tonight.
WARSAW, Feb. 6 -- An enthusiastic crowd of more than 50,000 cheered the new Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, Dr. Stefan Wyszynski, today as he was enthroned as Archbishop in Warsaw.

Dr. and Mrs. Seth M. Milliken of 951 Madison Avenue, will give a reception at their home today for the sponsors of the Blue Hill Troupe and the trustees of the Lenox Hill Hospital. Members of the troupe, known for their productions of Gilbert and Sullivan operettas, will sing selections from the operetta "Patience."

Anna Turkel, who sang at Town Hall yesterday afternoon offered her listeners additional evidence in support of the fine things she had established at her debut here three seasons ago: a clear, ringing soprano voice of Italian flavor, stimulating temperament, and enough confidence, authority and all-around know-how to outfit a half dozen young singers.

The Yankees ought to know within a few hours whether their salary controversy with Joe DiMaggio is at an end or whether it will drag on, possibly into the training season. For at 11 o'clock this morning, in the Yankees' Fifth Avenue offices, the Clipper is to sit down for another conference with Dan Topping, president of the Bombers, and George Weiss, general manager.

Three hundred representatives of unions of the Congress of Industrial Organizations in this city will meet at the Capitol Hotel Thursday to establish rules of affiliation for a new city CIO council to take the place of the left-wing group that was dissolved by the national CIO three months ago.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The average income of United States families as $3,000 in 1947, the Census Bureau reported today, adding that it was the highest figure up to that time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UP) -- Dr. Edward U. Condon, head of the National Bureau of Standards, called today for revision of city building codes to help solve the housing shortage, which he described as "perhaps even more critical than is commonly known."

A program for government and private aid to this country's 500,000 victims of cerebral palsy was offered yesterday at the first national public conference devoted to the problem. Twelve hundred persons attended the opening session of the four-day conference at the Statler Hotel.

IF the historians are to be believed, an ancient Greek named Thespis originated the dramatic art. The old boy probably never regretted it more profoundly than he did last night when the Baseball Writers Association grossly mutilated the sock-and-buskin profession in their annual show. This one had much more sock to it than buskin.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 6 -- World Christianity stands face-to-face with more uncertainties, difficulties, and "ominous perils" for the future than ever before in modern history, the Rev. Dr. Henry P. Van Dusen, president of Union Theological Seminary, New York, said here tonight.
Three big American Federation of Labor unions have pooled their strength to expedite the organization of department store workers under the AFL banner.

ATHENS, Feb. 6 -- A report submitted to the United Nations Special Committee on the Balkans by its observer group operating in northern Greece, and made public here today, sets at naught the rebel argument that parents have willingly given up their children in the civil war area on promise of safe refuge for the children in the neighboring countries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Ferenc Nagy, former Hungarian Premier, said today that an admission by Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty that he prevented the return of the Hungarian royal crown "is the best evidence that he has been forced to confess untrue charges."

Garry Moore's "Take It or Leave It" quiz show will leave next Monday for Germany where, during a ten-day tour, Moore and his company will entertain troops of the Berlin airlift with thirty shows. In Wiesmaden and Frankfort two shows will be transcribed for the network shows on Sunday, Feb. 20, and Sunday, Feb. 27.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 6 (UP) -- Argentine Ambassador Pedro Juan Vignale today denied charges that he promoted the Nov. 24 revolution which ousted President Romulo Gallegos and swept a military junta to power in Venezuela.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- There was real old-fashioned hospitality -- Russian style -- on the gray misty Firth of Forth today when Soviet officers aboard the British battleship Royal Sovereign received a courtesy call from the Lord Provost of Edinburgh, Andrew Murray.
CHICAGO, Feb. 6 -- A wave of selling engulfed the lard market on the Board of Trade last week, stop-loss orders being uncovered.

STOCKHOLM, Feb. 6 (UP) -- The United States' men's table tennis team scored a decisive 5 to 0 victory over Wales today and the women's team beat Czechoslovakia, 3 to 1, as the world championships entered the third day.

Compassion, kindness and humbleness are the most practical things in the world, the Rev. William Howard Melish, assistant rector of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Clinton and Montague Streets, Brooklyn said in a sermon yesterday.
A parade of 1,000 persons protesting the prosecution of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty was held yesterday afternoon in the Bronx under the sponsorship of the Ancient Order of Hibernians in Bronx County.
GENEVA, Feb. 6 -- In 1948 Europe west of Russia produced 47,000,000 tons of steel, a gain of 29 per cent above 1947, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe reported today.

Everything has been arranged for "The Ivy Green," Mervyn Nelson's play dealing with Charles Dickens, to go into rehearsal today, Roy Hargrave directing. Among those mentioned for the company of twelve are such performers as Judith Evelyn, Hurd Hatfield, Carmen Mathews, Ernest Cossart, Dan O'Herlihy and Neva Patterson.

It has long been known that the "emergency" DP legislation of 1948 would meet no DP emergency at all -- that, on the contrary, as President Truman warned when he reluctantly signed the bill, it would prove impractical and in general "form a pattern of discrimination and intolerance wholly inconsistent with the American sense of justice."

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 -- Net income of Illinois Bell Telephone Company rose to $8,919,344 in 1948 from $2,410,137 a year earlier, Graham McCorkle, president, told stockholders in his annual report. However, he asserted that without rate increases granted in 1947, the company would have operated at a substantial loss last year.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Feb. 6 -- In support of the Eastern Seaboard contention that it is not a Greenland coast in winter, and now compares favorably with the shoreline of California, four Star Class sloops were put overboard and raced today off the Larchmont Yacht Club.

" Western Union: The Story of European Federation," by Andrew and Frances Boyd, has been scheduled for March publication by Public Affairs Press of Washington. The book reviews the need for European unity and the major movements toward bringing it about. Mr. Boyd is the author of "The United Nations Organization Handbook," which was issued in 1946.

Substantial opposition has developed to the proposals by David W. Peck, Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division in the First Department, for streamlining of the court system here to end calendar delays.

Dr. Francis W. Reichelderfer has endeared himself to a large group of hardy citizens by something he said the other day when he and two hundred other top-ranking weather forecasters, gathered here for the 101st meeting of the American Meteorological Society, were caught in a fall of sleet and a downpour of rain as they emerged from their conference at the American Museum of Natural History.

HARRISON, N. Y., Feb. 6 -- Nathan D. McClure, vice president and a director in charge of the Chicago office of Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., investment bankers with main offices at 63 Wall Street, New York, choked to death on a bite of steak last night.

The proposed treaty for the Atlantic alliance, on the basis of the available information about it, would be an unsound and dangerous weapon to use in the cold war, James P. Warburg, economist and author, declared yesterday.

John R. Crawford of Philadelphia, considered one of the strongest bridge players in the country, took the lead in the life master individual contract bridge championship tournament with a total score of 488 points, at the end of the fourth session yesterday afternoon at the Park Sheraton Hotel, with the final night session to be played.

Prices of cotton in the domestic market moved last week into lower ground. At the close of trading active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net losses for the week of 39 to 48 points. In the previous week the change in prices ranged from a decline of 4 to an advance of 11 points.

After an ownership of a few months the Anmar Realty Company has resold two industrial buildings at the northwest corner of Thirty-seventh Avenue and Ninth Street, in Long Island City, Queens, to the Maddox Carpet Dyeing Company of Long Island City.

Last year, 2,172 discharged prisoners turned to the Salvation Army for help and received aid of some kind. Persons placed in jobs numbered 496. Every one of the men and women assisted was enabled to make a new start in life.

Payment of transportation charges by cotton goods converters may be illegal within the meaning of the Robinson-Patman Act and trade practice rules promulgated by the Federal Trade Commission, it was pointed out over the week-end by W. P. Fickett, president of the Textile Fabrics Association.

In making public its annual report containing its program and civic recommendations for the coming year, the Citizens Union, 41 Park Row, extended an invitation to "everyone in sympathy" with its work to "join in and help." It would be very difficult for any New Yorker who has the best interests of his city at heart not to want to join in and help.

Thirty-two thousand units of the aviation branch of the Soviet civilian military training organization were established last year. This was reported a few days ago to a conference of the organization in Moscow, according to information received yesterday from a Soviet source.

" 'Talking tough' doesn't solve our relations with Russia; it only confuses the peoples of the world," the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman said yesterday at the morning service in Christ Church Methodist, Sixtieth Street and Park Avenue.

Displaying the ability that prompted their selection as members of the international squash racquets team that will seek to take the Wolfe-Noel Trophy in competition here next month, the English women's aggregation made a clean sweep against a group of metropolitan players in an informal clash at the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday.
A recent paper issued by the State Department, entitled "Building the Peace," suggests that the United States is to be united with six other nations in a "North Atlantic community."
The Air Force and NBC television, in a joint operation, took Americans yesterday on a cross-country sightseeing tour.

The divisions now existing among the 256 separate Protestant denominations in the United States are "indefensible," the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken, minister of the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive, said in his sermon yesterday.

Special programs and exhibitions at five of the branches of the New York Public Library will begin today in observance of Negro History Week. Performances by noted musicians, dancers and singers will be given each evening this week through Friday at the branch at the 104 West 136th Street, and the work of Negro artists, among them Jacob Lawrance and Charles Alson, will be exhibited.

BOSTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Cal Gardner turned the three-goal "hat trick during the first period while pacing the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 4-2 triumph over the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game tonight before 13,909 fans at the Boston Garden. It was the Leaf's fifth straight decision over the Bruins.

The annual report of the State Advisory Council on Unemployment Insurance provides forceful new evidence of the destructive effect that an unwise federal economy has had on administration of the New York job insurance system. The council asserts that "grave injury" has been done to the unemployed by the inadequacy of federal administrative grants and that the state has been compelled to operate "in an atmosphere of monthly, weekly and even daily emergency."

The United Jewish Appeal, seeking $250,000,000 to meet Jewish needs throughout the world, called attention yesterday to an immediate need to provide funds for the transfer of many thousands of refugees from Europe to Israel. It announced the formation of a National Committee on Community Quotas to give maximum support to the appeal's campaign.

The Textile Workers Union, CIO, recommended yesterday that its locals representing 65,000 workers in woolen and worsted mills drop arbitration proceedings for a wage increase of 10 cents an hour. The recommendation followed an arbitrator's decision in Boston last week, denying an increase to 23,000 employes of the American Woolen Company.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The twenty-three mutual assistance pacts signed among the Soviet Union and its satellites since December, 1943, follow:

A better prepared and more poised runner than he was when he first appeared here three years ago, Marcel Hansenne of France yesterday expressed himself as confident of turning in creditable performances in the four races that are lined up for him.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- Informal approval of the conversion of Camp La Guardia near Chester in Orange County to a tuberculosis hospital for New York City was given today at a State Health Department hearing. Formal approval will be forthcoming shortly, it was said.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (UP) -- Shrieking winds shuffled the immense snows of the West into new drifts today, stalling transcontinental trains, isolating towns, and threatening some areas with the complete loss of livestock.

PEIPING, China, Feb. 7 -- In their first week of control in Peiping the Communists have made themselves known to the people largely through demonstrations. There are troops, which are impressive both in numbers and discipline, and organized workers and students who march and dance down the streets waving paper pennants. They now have succeeded in giving the city a carnival air for a week.
Voluntary hospitals are in a "slightly better" financial state today than they were a year ago, according to Dr. Henry N. Pratt, newly appointed director of the New York Hospital.

Gas range and water heater producers, convinced that peak post-war volume ended last year, wil cut this year's production back appreciably, James I. Gorton, promotional manager of the Gas Appliance Manufacturers Association, disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- An over-all plan to utilize the civilian aviation resources of the country in event of war will be completed soon, the Air Coordinating Committee told the President today in its annual report.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The Democratically - controlled Senate broke late today a Republican effort to force at once to the floor a preliminary aspect of President Truman's harshly disputed civil-rights program.

The Atlantic Coast Line Railroad borrowed yesterday $10,665,000 on equipment-trust certificates due annually on March 1, 1950 to 1964, at an interest cost of about 2.578 per cent. The certificates were sold at competitive bidding to a banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 99.37 for 2 1/2s.

Price reductions on imported linens, made possible by reduced tariffs and lower quotations at the source of supply, have stepped up sales in recent weeks, it was learned yesterday at the linen trade show in the Commodore Hotel.

" Foreign Governments," a study of the dynamics of politics abroad, has been edited by Dr. Fritz Morstein Marx and will be issued on Feb. 16 by Prentice-Hall. In it eight specialists analyze the evolution of constitutional government in Britain, France and Italy; trace the origins of absolutism in Russia and Southeastern Europe, and appraise the "reconstruction" governments in the Near East.

Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., in its statement for the nine months ended on Dec. 31, showed an increase of 32 per cent in sales to $172,017,000 from $130,034,000 for the same period of the previous year. Net earnings for the nine months, estimated by the company at $9,467,000, equaled $4.43 a common share.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 7 (AP) -An underdog St. Thomas College quintet tonight turned in a stunning 45-to-43 upset of Hamline University, the last of the nation's unbeaten college basketball teams.

Answers to the homemaker's lament that a well-styled modern table lamp costs as much as an upholstered chair may now be found in new groups of lamps being introduced. They offer a wide variety in color, style and design from which a homemaker may choose without having to go into the sky-high "one-of-a-kind" field.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 7 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council opened its eighth session here today with strong indications that debate on such important issues as world economic problems and President Truman's project for aid to underdeveloped areas would be put off for at least two weeks.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 7 -There are indications here of behind the scenes activity that may lead to some action against Netherlands interests by the nations represented at the recent Asian conference unless negotiations are reopened with the Indonesian Republic on a basis satisfactory to them.
Kentucky's wondrous Wildcats poured it on four more rivals last week, and just about convinced the nation's basketball experts that they are the best of the college fives.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- The proposed consolidation of the courts in New York City above the Magistrates Court level into a two-court system may be sidetracked by the Legislature in favor of further study on the subject of court reforms by a commission.

Directors of the International Nickel Company, Inc., elected yesterday Dr. John F. Thompson as president to succeed Robert C. Stanley who continues as chairman. Dr. Paul D. Merica was elected executive vice president and Henry S. Wingate a vice president in addition to his present office of secretary.

Raya Garbousova was in exceptionally fine fettle for her 'cello recital at Town Hall last night. In a program of unusual variety and interest she played with zest, brilliance and expressiveness that left a large audience clamoring for more.

BERLIN, Feb. 7 -- A West German Socialist leader said today the Russians had built up a spy force of 70,000 Germans in the Soviet zone with half of it composed of trustworthy Communist volunteers and half of persons forced to spy on pain of imprisonment, withdrawal of food rations or punishment of their families.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- New York was described today as a "dead-end" city blighted by traffic blunders and motorists were warned to leave hope behind when entering Manhattan with the intention of parking.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- The defection of at least one and possibly more Republican members of the Legislature put in doubt tonight the program of the Republican leadership for supplanting Miss Susan Brandeis of Manhattan on the Board of Regents with Jacob L. Holtzmann of Brooklyn.

Twenty students aspiring to follow in the footsteps of Schiaparelli and Mainbocher, chosen as the most promising in the January graduating classes of the city's high schools, have won full scholarships at the Fashion Institute of Technology and Design, the institute announced yesterday.
