WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Following is the text of the report, entitled "General Management of the Executive Branch," submitted to Congress today by the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of Government:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- President Truman welcomed today a pledge by the National Association of Manufacturers to back up his "bold new program" for improving undeveloped areas of the world with "most of the productive know-how in America."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -President Truman called today for prompt Congressional action to extend the life of the War Assets Administration until June 30. He made the request at a White House meeting with Democratic leaders in Congress.
RHODES, Feb. 7 (Reuters) -Prospects of an Israeli-Egyptian armistice receded today as it became apparent that the conference here was floundering in technical difficulties.
LONDON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- World Flyweight Champion Rinty Monaghan and two highly regarded American welterweights dropped decisions tonight in a series of upsets at the Harringay Arena.

Herman Levin will ring up the curtain at the Booth Theatre tonight -- the proceedings are announced to get under way at 8 o'clock sharp -- on "Richard III," Shakespeare's drama of the hunchbacked monarch, whose lust for power cut a wide and bloody swath in English history.

Although last week's Supreme Court decision concerning Advertising on vehicles was based solely on affirming New York City's right to enforce restrictions, lawyers for advertising interests have started a study of its possible effect on all forms of display visible from traffic lanes.

BOSTON, Feb. 7 -- The American Heart Association's "declaration of war on cardiac disease was pronounced tonight on a note of confidence by Dr. Paul D. White of Boston, chief adviser to the American Heart Institute.

Commodity futures on the local exchanges yesterday had their sharpest break in the current movement. Under pressure from scattered long liquidation and commission house selling, support was only on a scale down and it came largely from short-covering and only moderately from processing interests.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 7 -- The annual silver sailfish derby of the Palm Beaches is now at its height and although the weather has resulted in lighter catches this year the event has lost none of its popularity with visiting anglers.

CANTON, China, Feb. 7 -- Premier Sun Fo formally established Canton as China's temporary capital today. Thus he returned to this city the National regime that had its beginning here more than twenty years age.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 (AP) -- A merger between the National Football League and the All-America Conference is impossible under present conditions, Commissioner Bert Bell of the N. F. L. said today.
ROME, Feb. 7 -- Assurances have been given to the Italian Government that the United States is planning to invite Italy to join the proposed North Atlantic pact as a member of the European Council.
PARIS, Feb. 7 -- Jacques Heim, as always, gives new life to handsome tailored suits by interesting detail.
The United Service Organizations must be prepared this year to serve 2,100,000 service men, 60 per cent of them under the age of 20, Walter Hoving, chairman of the USO board, said yesterday.

Controller Lazarus Joseph deposited yesterday in his general fund $17 he had received from a conscience-stricken Bronx resident, who said he had broken a street light while he was a juvenile delinquent. The anonymous sender addressed his note to Borough President Hugo E. Rogers, who turned the ten-dollar, five-dollar and two one-dollar bills over to the Controller.

It would be well for New York motorists to remember that the winter is far from over. Regardless of the portents and forecasts, the only safe policy is to be prepared for at least six more weeks of treacherous winter driving.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Administration bills to authorize outlays of $5,430,000,000 for the European Recovery Program during the next fifteen months were introduced in Congress today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Export-Import Bank today made a $20,000,000 loan to the Corporation de Fomento de Chile to complete construction of an $83,000,000 steel plant at Concepcion, Chile.

Mortimer W. Loewi, executive assistant to Dr. Allen B. DuMont, assumed yesterday the post of director of the DuMont Television Network. He succeeds Lawrence Phillips, who has resigned to reenter the management consultant business with offices at 8 West Fortieth Street.

Sixty artists have contributed their work to an art-auction party to be held on Saturday evening for the benefit of the United Art Workshops of the Brooklyn Neighborhood Houses, it was announced yesterday.

College-trained women, who enjoyed great employment opportunities during the war, found fewer superior jobs open to them in 1948 than in 1947, according to the annual report of Robert F. Moore, director of placement at Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Formation of the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government was completed on July 17, 1947, when President Truman announced the names of his appointees.
LONDON, Feb. 7 (UP) -- The financial district was astonished by the South African Government's announcement.

Serge Rubinstein, international financier who is serving a two-and-a-half-year prison sentence for draft evasion, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury which charged him with having engaged in a $3,000,000 stock fraud conspiracy.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora yesterday upheld the claim of diplomatic immunity of Tingfu F. Tsiang, Ambassador Plenipotentiary and Permanent Representative of the Republic of China to the United Nations, and dismissed the complaint in a separation suit brought against him by Nyok Zoe Dong Tsiang.

All further speculation on whether Joe DiMaggio would be in uniform when the Yankees open their spring training operations March 1 came to an end yesterday when the famed Clipper came to terms with his employers for the 1949 season.

Net operating revenues of the Staten Island Edison Corporation last year amounted to $345,000 on an investment of $21,350,000, Charles H. Edlund, vice president and treasurer, testified yesterday at a hearing before the Public Service Commission on the company's petition for higher rates.

At the risk of seeming greatly to oversimplify a phenomenon that is necessarily complicated, it may be said that one incident clearly furnished the signal, if not the impulse, for the renewal in 1947 of the upward march of prices. It was the partial failure that year of the American corn crop, which, at 2,400,000,000 bushels, fell one-third short of the harvest planned.

POINT JUDITH, R. I, Feb. 7 -Driven from their fishing boat by fire, three young Rhode Island fishermen reached Block Island safely this morning after rowing for seven hours in a small dory through heavy seas.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Further rent increases of 50 to 60 per cent unless Federal controls are extended and strengthened were prdicted today by Tighe E. Woods, housing expediter, as the Administration opened its fight in Congress for this phase of its anti-inflation program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- By a vote of 356 to 9, the House approved and sent to the Senate today a bill vesting in the President broad and permanent authority to initiate administrative reforms for greater efficiency and economy in the Federal Government.
CINCINNATI, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Xavier University Musketeers caught fire after a slow start tonight to roll over Long Island University, 75 -- 51, in a basketball game witnessed by a crowd of 4,000.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 7 -- The American Federation of Labor executive council tried today to persuade the leadership of the Canadian Trades and Labor Congress to declare war on Communists in the congress. The attempt was reported to have failed.
Opening its 1949 drive for $2,500,000 yesterday, the New York Catholic Charities organization reported that it had helped almost 400,000 distressed individuals last year.

Undeterred by growing Soviet pressure on his country, the Norwegian Foreign Minister has arrived in Washington to discuss terms for joining the North Atlantic Pact. Officially he is merely making inquiries about the obligations Norway would be expected to assume and the measure of security it might expect in return.
The Johns-Manville Corporation reported yesterday that in 1948 it produced a record volume of goods and had the largest sales and earnings in its history.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 7 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration has abandoned the principle enunciated here on Dec. 13 by its administrator, Paul G. Hoffman, of continuing relief to the chief Chinese cities at least until the color of China's new Government had been established.

The election recently in which the villages of Tarrytown and North Tarrytown in Westchester County decided to consolidate their school districts clearly revealed the need for clarification and modernization of the New York State Education Law, Section 1510 and thereabouts.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 7 -- The growing trend toward the separation of religion from education in this country is an opening wedge for the creation of an "all competent" state which will ultimately destroy individual rights and freedoms, the Rev. Dr. Erwin L. Shaver of Boston declared here today.

The Salvation Army maintains guidance, testing and placement services in the city through which, students, veterans and others seeking counsel receive aptitude tests and the services of a trained psychologist.

A proposed new law to license business brokers and their salesmen, introduced in the State Legislature at Albany by Assemblyman Angelo Graci of Queens, "is not clearly drawn and in its present wording could be interpreted as a measure to require licensing of all salesmen," it was pointed out yesterday at the offices of the National Council of Salesmen's Organizations, 80 West Fortieth Street.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 -- Liquidation and bear pressure developed in the grain and lard markets after an early upturn, and final sales on the Board of Trade today were sharply lower. Weakness in lard and soy beans was a factor in starting selling of grain futures with wheat off 1 3/8 to 2 1/2 cents at the last.

Detailed preliminary plans for the new Supreme Court Building in the Brooklyn Civic Center were submitted yesterday for final approval to the City Art Commission by the office of Borough President John Cashmore. The estimated cost of the structure is $12,500,000.
CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Frank Davis of Detroit handed Miguel Marquez of Mexico City his second straight defeat today in the national three-cushion billiard tournament at Navy Pier.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The International Congress of Liberal Newspaper Editors voted today to create a consultative and advisory international committee.

As Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty waited yesterday in a closely guarded prison in Budapest to be called to hear the verdict and sentence in his case, protests against his trial mounted in this country and in Western Europe.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 7 -- Grasslands Hospital, the Westchester institution at Eastview, was instructed today by the County Board of Supervisors to report on the feasibility of making extensive use of electro-shock treatment in the care of mental patients.
Murray E. Nichols has been appointed sales manager for all Frigidaire parts and accessories of the Frigidaire division of the General Motors Corporation,

Robert F. Wagner Jr., chairman of the City Planning Commission said yesterday in a letter to Mayor O'Dwyer that he and his associates on that body were "deeply disturbed" by one part of a recent report from Grover A. Whalen.

The Long Island Rail Road is on the verge of bankruptcy, having a total indebtedness of $52,100,000 and a cash balance of only $60,059 on hand as of last Jan. 31, a top executive of the road testified yesterday before the Public Service Commission.

Nicholai Berezowsky's Sextet for Strings, commissioned nine years ago by Mrs. Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge, was performed for the first time in New York last night at the Musicians Guild's third concert of the season at Times Hall.
WARSAW, Feb. 7 -- The Polish Government charged today that the United States had deliberately blocked the growth of Poland's trade with four Marshall Plan countries.

PARIS, Feb. 7 -- A curious crowd jammed the court room today expecting a fiery domestic scene between Victor A. Kravchenko and his first wife, Zinaida Gorlova, in his libel suit against the newspaper Les Lettres Francaises.

Add to the list of films arriving this week, "It Always Rains on Sunday," a British-made drama presented by J. Arthur Rank and released by Eagle-Lion, which will open at the Sutton Theatre on Saturday. Googie Withers, Jack Warner and John McCallum head the cast of the offering, which was directed by Robert Hamer and produced by Michael Balcon.

Metropolitan followers of the thrilling sport of ski jumping will be glad to learn that the Norsemen S. C. of New York will sponsor its once-postponed New York State title jump next Sunday at Salisbury Mills with a talent-laden field.

A "crusade to strengthen the arm of liberty" by the Boy Scouts of America, to start today, was hailed yesterday by President Truman in a message to the 2,221,157 members. The President is honorary head of the Scouts.

The stock market suffered a new set-back yesterday, prices going to the lowest levels since last Dec. 3. In a furtherance of the downward movement which began last Friday, the list sagged under short but successive waves of selling. The composite average fell 1.07 points on the day, with the usual wider decreases in the thin-market and higher-price stocks.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Feb. 7 -- The outlook for a solution of the Indonesian question appeared less favorable tonight after the first full day of conversations between Dutch authorities and Merle Cochran, United States member of the United Nations Commission for Indonesia.

Generations ago a European housewife devised the recipe that Mother's Food Products of Newark is using for its new sweet and sour fish. That anonymous woman would be much surprised today if she could see her prize formula employed in the modern New Jersey plant to turn out the product on a mass scale.

Illustrating the utility industry's problems of increased operational costs, the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation reported yesterday that operating revenues of $138,160,000 last year represented a $9,160,000 increase over the same item in 1947, but that net income was off $1,400,000, to $13,460,000.

The public display of objects from the New York car of the French Gratitude Train, organized by the Mayor's committee for arrangements, was officially opened last night in a brief ceremony at 500 Park Avenue. The train, comprising forty-nine box cars of the "40 and 8" type, arrived aboard the French freighter Magellan last Wednesday.

If U. N.'s Economic and Social Council, which yesterday opened its eighth session at Lake Success, could do all that the Charter lays out for it to do, it would undoubtedly remake the world. It has one great advantage and one great disadvantage. Its great advantage is that its eighteen members may decide any question by a majority vote of those present and voting.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Additional projects to enlist the aid of the United States in the development of backward colonial areas in Africa, in which President Truman recently expressed an interest, are now in preparation, the British Colonial Office said today.

On the basis of recent statements by "dry" leaders assailing all forms of liquor advertising, including that on wine and beer, advertising and distiller groups are preparing for another battle against legislation restricting contents and style of liquor advertising, it was learned yesterday.

The United States Treasury issued yesterday a call on its war loan accounts with the Class B banks. Under its terms, 10 per cent of such deposits, as of the close of business on Feb. 5, must be provided on Feb. 14. For the banks in this area the total involved is $51,601,600, and the aggregate for banks throughout the country is $178,065,600.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Tuesday, Feb. 8 -- The sentencing was the final act in the historic courtroom drama that began last Thursday with the Cardinal's confession "in principle and in detail."

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 7 -- Finance Minister Havenga played the part of a South African Sir Stafford Cripps today. He told the House of Assembly "luxurious living" and "extravagance" must end "in the interests of South Africa's economic health."
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Tuesday, Feb. 8 -- Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty was sentenced today to life imprisonment.

I am glad that Ross Hoffman in his letter to THE TIMES realizes that his college professor receives high income for his profession. I can cite a professor in one of our leading women's colleges, a scholar of international reputation in his field, who will retire shortly without ever having known the fancy salary of even $6,000 a year.

Ride on a TrainIn a town within commuter flight of Times Square a show of hands lately revealed a pathetic situation. No member of the entire class, adult to the extent of five dreary years, ever had been on a railroad train.

Two hundred authors of crime and detective stories had a part yesterday in the election of John Dickson Carr as president of Mystery Writers of America. The writers' mailed ballots were counted at the annual meeting of the organization at the Fontainebleau Restaurant, 9 West Fifty-second Street.

Although the people of the United States are bearing a heavy load in giving aid to the needy and homeless abroad, they must continue with this help "as long as we possibly can," Cardinal Spellman declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Alf M. Landon, the Republican Presidential candidate in 1936, warned in a letter to President Truman today that the American oil industry was threatened with a "recession" unless crude oil imports are reduced.

Rounding a curve on the Third Avenue Elevated line at 4:10 A. M. yesterday, the motorman of a northbound, five-car local "misjudged the distance" and crashed into the rear of a collection train at the Tremont Avenue station, the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Mariner S. Eccles, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, was accused today by Amadeo P. Giannini, West Coast financier, of "trying to put the Bank of America (National Trust and Savings Association) out of business."

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- The bipartisan conference of war veterans in the Legislature decided unanimously tonight to recommend to their colleagues that action be withheld at this session on two conflicting proposed constitutional amendments relating to veterans' preference in civil service employment.
LONDON, Feb. 7 -- The stock market had a bad day following Saturday's set-back in Wall Street and uneasiness on international affairs as a result of developments in Norway.

The American Labor party, through Arthur Schutzer, state executive secretary, called yesterday on Mayor O'Dwyer to end his silence on the state budget, submitted to the Legislature by Governor Dewey. It suggested he "speak out for repeal of the local tax program, which hits the low income groups unfairly, and revision of the budget to meet the people's needs."

No evidence of discrimination was found in an investigation of the Federal jury system here conducted under the auspices of the United States Supreme Court. This was testified at the trial of the eleven Communist leaders yesterday by the man who made the investigation -- Leland L. Tolman.

NANKING, Feb. 7 -- The Chinese Communist party informed Acting President Li Tsung-jen by radio tonight that it would not be rushed on the question of formal peace negotiations with his Nanking Government.

The deputies of the Foreign Ministers of the Big Four have reconvened in London to resume negotiation of the Austrian Peace Treaty. The deputies are expected to agree on a draft treaty by which the satisfactory solution of all major political issues (German assets) and also of the Austrian restitution problem should be guaranteed.
The city welcomed yesterday the latest addition to the fleet of luxury tonnage serving the port's many passenger trades.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 7 -- Recent increases in unemployment and the drop in the cost of living "does not in any sense mean we are headed for a depression," Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, said today.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 7 -- Ten German members of the staff of Neue Zeitung, United States Military Government German language newspaper, filed their resignations today after they were read the terms of a new policy directive issued by Military Government headquarters in Berlin. Four more resignations are expected tomorrow, to bring the total to more than half of the German staff.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7--The demand of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers for a second engineer on diesel-electric locomotives is "indefensible featherbedding," Howard Neitzert, chief counsel for the railroads, told a Presidential fact-finding board today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 7 -The deal for Sam Bischoff to utilize financing from the Howard Hughes-United Artists-James Nasser Fund for production of "Mrs. Mike" has been called off, Bischoff disclosed today, and instead he will make the picture in partnership with William and Edward Nassour, although it will Still be released by United Artists.

Since last summer, actual purchases of shoes by the Navy, together with additional purchases said to be contemplated, total 3,000,000 pairs, or almost six pairs for every man in the Navy, according to trade estimates here yesterday.

New housing construction produced 20,150 completed dwelling units in this city during 1948, figures released by the Department of Housing and Buildings showed yesterday. Conversion of buildings provided another 1,307 units, but after deducting 3,639 demolished, and 1,093 dwelling units altered to other uses, the net gain was 16,725.

No sooner had the fanfare attending the signing of Joe DiMaggio at the Yankee offices quieted yesterday than the Giants broke out with a rash of excitement on West Forty-second Street when Secretary Eddie Brannick announced that Walker Cooper, the Polo Grounders' catching stalwart, had come to terms.
Visitors to the First National Conference and Exposition on Cerebral Palsy at the Statler Hotel yesterday heard a doctor's plea for a layman's movement to help handicapped persons fit into society.
TRENTON, Feb. 7 -- Action began in the New Jersey Legislature today on measures to curb racial and religious discrimination, provide a veterans bonus and finance construction at welfare institutions.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- In one of its characteristic splits, the Supreme Court by 5 to 4 today sustained a contempt sentence imposed upon a lawyer by a Texas judge.

William H. Davis, former chairman of the War Labor Board, proposed yesterday that Congress give the President power to seize plants when a "national emergency" strike is threatened. Mr. Davis told the Senate Labor Committee that he had come to this conclusion reluctantly, but that when the nation's health and safety are really threatened -- as by a general railroad strike -- the President must have power to take action.

ANNE GOODWIN WINSLOW has written five books, not counting an early foray into verse, and her fifth, "The Springs,"* is now published. On four previous occasions her praises have been sung in this space with increasing urgency and now the same virtues which have been cited before must be cited once again. There isn't anyone now writing at all like her.
Higher bank reserve requirements could bring on a depression, the president of the American Bankers Association declared yesterday.

For the first time, mass production of compost or organic fertilizer made from industrial, municipal or farm waste, is expected to provide a major new consumer merchandising item for retail grocery, hardware, seed, general and chain stores.

Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard, in a bulletin board notice, warned department employes yesterday that he would not discuss any employe problem 'while under duress." He demanded that those seeking to disrupt the department's public service desist immediately.
Substantial buyer registration yesterday following the heavy attendance on Sunday marked the spring showing of the Men's Apparel Club of New York City at the New Yorker Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Wendell Berge, former Assistant Attorney General, today challenged the right of the Army Department to discipline a member of the Army's Berlin civil administration for criticizing his superiors in testimony before an official investigating committee.
ROME, Feb. 7 -- The Vatican newspaper l'Osservatore Romano stated today, "We affirm that Cardinal Mindszenty is morally and civilly innocent."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today by 8 to 1 that New Orleans and Louisiana may tax tugboats and barges owned by out-of-state corporations. Justice William O. Douglas delivered the court's opinion. Justice Robert H. Jackson noted a dissent.

The President of the United States, like any other chief executive, is the man who has to take the rap if anything goes wrong. He is not, however, the Executive Branch of the Government, on which the Hoover Commission reported yesterday. The President is politically and otherwise mortal.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -Two former soldiers, one of them crippled, told a Federal Court jury teoday that Mildred E. Gillars, 48 years old, represented herself to them as a Red Cross worker.
A check for $1,525,167 for cancer research enriched the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation last night as the gift of 10,000 General Motors automobile dealers in the country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Joining the national campaign to reduce the toll of heart disease, President Truman today urged every American to support Governmental and voluntary programs which are endeavoring to reduce the scourge.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Halvard M. Lange, Norwegian Foreign Minister, conferred with Secretary of State Dean Acheson for half an hour today about the political and military implications of the proposed North Atlantic security pact.

Closer cooperation between sales and research organizations of the pharmaceutical industry was urged yesterday by Dr. Gustav J. Martin, director of research, the National Drug Company. He addressed the annual Eastern meeting of the American Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association in the Commodore Hotel.

BOSTON, Feb. 7 -- Trustees of the Waltham Watch Company said today they "hoped" to resume operations in March, but offered no assurances to 2,300 idle workers that their jobs also would be restored them.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- In an unexpected move, the Supreme Court today consented to grant a rehearing to Carl Aldo Marzani, former State Department employe, whose conviction for concealing Communist party affiliations was recently upheld by a 4 to 4 decision.
CARMEL, N. Y., Feb. 7 -- Three of four persons indicted by the grand jury in the Putnam County jail scandal investigation were arraigned before County Judge John P. Donohoe here today.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores decreased 7 per cent last week compared with the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- A Congressional declaration that President Truman should never meet with Generalissimo Stalin unless the Soviet Union were to agree to let its people have full access to the President's views was sought today.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- In a nationwide demonstration of both devotion and outrage, Britain's Roman Catholics voiced a protest tonight against the imprisonment and trial of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, of Hungary. The Cardinal's trial was denounced by Foreign Secretary Bevin as being utterly repugnant to the British conception of human rights and liberties.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- The 66 2/3 per cent state increase in personal income tax rates recommended by Governor Dewey was assailed tonight by the Democratic legislative leadership as inequitable, dangerous to the nation's economy and a potential cause of unemployment and depression.

THERE was a rather childish dispute a few years ago between two otherwise sane, respected and highly intelligent business men. Walter Briggs, the money bags who owns the Detroit Tigers, and Alva Bradley, the then ditto of the Cleveland Indians, permitted themselves to get involved in a newspaper argument as to which of them was paying his star pitcher the fancier salary.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The complete transcript of Attorney General Clark's opinion (endorsed by Mr. Truman) on the implied powers of the President to dissolve national emergencies became available today, and it shows that Mr. Clark was taking no new or advanced position on the subject.
New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it will receive bids on Feb. 15 on an issue of $1,250,000 of temporary loan notes dated March 1 and due on Sept. 1.

A mobile 'trade show, operating as a free port, is planned by a group of American industrialists wishing to cooperate with the Government in its effort to stimulate world trade and' thus obtain some return on ECA_ dollars, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- A Federal official said today that the oil supply situation was one requiring "serious consideration but not alarm."
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Feb 7 (AP) -- Two of six touring English women were eliminated today in the opening play of the revived Atlantic Coast women's squash tournament at Haddon Hall.
STOCKHOLM, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The United States women's team won the world table tennis championship and the Corbillon Cup tonight, defeating Great Britain, 3 to 1.

Simon Barere, who appeared in recital at Carnegie Hall last night, has the mechanical equipment to be one of the outstanding pianists of our day. For reasons difficult to fathom, he does not make the best use of his natural gifts and ends up by being an unpredictable interpreter.

LONDON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The axe has fallen on many amateur boxing referees and judges who participated in the 1948 Olympic boxing tournament. Seventeen of the thirty-seven referees and nineteen of fifty-six judges have been purged.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association, worried about its "most difficult" season in basketball officiating, has changed its whistle-blowing arrangement for the N. C. A. A. tourney.

Andrea Television Corporation yesterday introduced a new television - AM - FM radio - automatic. phonograph console combination with a fifteen and one-half inch direct view tube to list at $1,085, at a press preview of its 1949 line in its Long Island City showrooms.

Dr. Lloyd A. Rider always wanted to be a teacher. As far back as he can remember it was that way. But he soon found out, after joining the profession fifty-one years ago, that to be a good teacher one often had to be a good policeman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate defeated a motion by Senator William F. Knowland, Republican, of California, to speed up action on a filibuster-killing change in the rules. Mr. Knowland wanted to take a resolution calling for the rules revision from the Rules Committee and put it on the Senate calendar.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, was made an honorary member of the Columbia chapter of Phi Beta Kappa society at a brief initiation ceremony yesterday afternoon in the rotunda of the university's Low Memorial Library.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Cattle arrivals at the Union Stockyards today were the highest, at 18,000 head, for any day since Monday a year ago when the estimate was the same. Prices dropped 50 cents to $2 a hundred pounds. Steers and heifers fell to new low prices since 1947.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will be away from his duties as president of Columbia University for seven or eight weeks while serving as a consultant to the Army in Washington, Frederick Coykendall, chairman of the university trustees, announced yesterday.

Fifty-two teams of contract bridge stars began play last night at the Pierre Hotel in the annual tournament for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup and the national team-of-four championship of the American Contract Bridge League. It was the largest field ever to enter this contest, the oldest of all contract bridge tournaments, played annually since 1929.

Commuters on the Hudson Tubes, who are beginning to count the day lost that goes by without a strike threat, got quick relief from a threatened walkout yesterday. The Transport Workers Union, CIO, announced at 12:57 P. M. that a strike of 400 track walkers and station agents would begin at 3 P. M.

KODIAK, Alaska, Feb. 6 (Delayed) -- A naval task force "attacking" Kodiak Island was battling heavy seas in the stormy Gulf of Alaska today, as about 18,000 men, thirty ships and 200 planes participated in the first cold-weather amphibious exercise in the Pacific since the war.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 7 -- A filly named Allie's Pal, owned by D. Sidell, made her 1949 Hialeah Park record three for three today when she won the best of the afternoon's races. It was a seven-furlong sprint that drew four fillies and two mares, and the winner made it with a couple of lengths to spare.

Although enjoying a virtual monopoly of the North Atlantic luxury passenger trade, the Cunard White Star Line does not intend to rest upon its laurels, according to Frederic Alan Bates, chairman of the company, who arrived here yesterday with his wife on the new liner Caronia.

OSLO, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Scandinavia's non-Communist newspapers pre dicted today that Norway would hold out against mounting Russian pressure and make her own decision on whether to join the projected North Atlantic Alliance.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 (AP) -Ezzard Charles of Cincinnati won a furious slugging match from Johnny Haynes of New York tonight, scoring a knockout at 2:38 of the eighth round of their scheduled ten-rounder at the Arena. Charles weighed 179, Haynes 214.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 7 -States Rights Democrats today formed the National States Rights Bureau to fight invasion of states' rights.

PARIS, Feb. 7 -- Installed in a magnificent 18th century mansion, from which Louis XVI's coach left when he fled Paris, Maggy Rouff, couture, and L. Mendel, furs, inaugurated their association at an evening opening.
RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Burmese Government forces launched a powerful land and aerial offensive today against Karen rebels fighting in Rangoon's suburbs.

A special service advertising program for retailers has been set up by the retail advertising committee of the Advertising Council, it was announced yesterday. Members of the newly formed committee represent retail stores, newspapers, syndicated mat services, the National Association of Broadcasters and the National Retail Dry Goods Association. James Rotto of the Hecht Company, Washington, is chairman of the committee.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Foreign of Minister Halvard M. Lange of Norway went to the State Department today to discuss the security of his country.

KANSAS CITY, Feb. 7 (AP) -The heaviest February run here of cattle, estimated at 19,000 head, jammed the stockyards today. The run, reflecting an apparent uneasiness of stockmen due to recent sharp declines in beef prices, included nearly 300 loads of grain-fed steers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Dr. William Haber, adviser on Jewish affairs to United States Army commanders in Germany and Austria, said today that the task of resettling displaced Jews in occupied zones was "over the hump" and predicted the closing of the remaining fifty-three camps by June 30, 1950.
DUBLIN, Feb. 7 -- Irish political leaders of all parties insist that the partition question is not solely an Irish issue but one in which Britain is deeply involved.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -President Truman formally nominated today Mon C. Wallgren, former Governor of Washington, to the chairmanship of the National Security Resources Board.

Directors of the General Motors Corporation increased yesterday the annual dividend rate on the common stock to $5 a share, the highest yearly disbursement in twenty years, with a declaration of a regular quarterly dividend of $1.25, payable on March 10.

Charles L. Singer, a dentist, was cautious last night in commenting on a Washington announcement that President Truman had nominated him for the job of superintendent of the United States Assay Office here.

The 171st nniversary of the signing of the treaty of alliance between France and the Continental Congress was commemorated by the France-America Society yesterday at a reception in the Metropolitan Club, Fifth Avenue and Sixtieth Street.
There was heavy trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, and final prices were 24 to 37 points net lower, virtually at the lows of the day.

Legal action will be taken to contest the merger of the Congregational Christian Churches with the Evangelical and Reformed Church, it was announced yesterday by the Committee for the Continuation of the Congregational Churches of the United States.

Billy Murphy, 134 1/2 pounds, promising young Brooklyn lightweight, turned the tables on Jimmy Watkins Jr., 135 1/2, New London, Conn., last night in their eight-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena. Before a crowd of 1,234 fans paying receipts of $2,784, Murphy, flooring his foe three times during the battle, won a split decision that could have just as well been unanimous.

Imports of Scotch whisky have a strong chance of becoming smaller and French champagne prices will go up, Richard L. Blum, president of Julius Wile Sons Co., Inc., importing house, predicted yesterday. Mr. Blum has just returned from a three months tour of Great Britain and Europe, his third since the war.

More than one-third of the $100,000,000 loan by the United States Import-Export Bank to Israel has been allocated for agricultural development, Eliezer Kaplan, Israeli Minister of Finance, said last night.

A reorganization plan to streamline the Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance of the State Department of Labor will become effective Feb. 16, Edward Corsi, Industrial Commissioner, announced yesterday.

Important contributions to such modern maritime developments as the steam turbine, prefabrication techniques and structural design are credited to the Bethlehem Steel Company in the current issue of The Review a publication of the company.

Negro History Week, established to bring to light the role of the Negro in the culture and heritage of this nation, began yesterday. It is traditionally observed during the week in which Abraham Lincoln's birthday falls.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- William H. Davis, former chairman of the War Labor Board, advocated today a four-point program to deal with critical strike emergencies and included in it Presidential authority to seize plants, which he said should be provided.
TOKYO, Feb. 7 -- Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall stated today that there had been a change in emphasis in United States policy toward Japan. That policy, he said, is now entering a new stage.

VIENNA, Feb. 7 -- "Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty's trial is a perversion of human life to a degree which until now had been considered impossible," the United States Army newspaper in Vienna, Wiener Kurier, will comment.

OTTAWA, Feb. 7 -- Hope that the people of Newfoundland would become satisfied citizens of Canada was expressed by the leaders of all parties in the Canadian House of Commons today, when the first steps were taken toward including the old British colony in the Dominion.

ATHENS, Feb. 7 -- Reports from reliable private sources but not confirmed by the General Staff said that the town of Karpenision, 125 miles northwest of Athens, which has been in the possession of the guerrillas since Jan. 22, had been retaken by Government forces after a long and dragging battle in severe weather conditions.

SEATTLE, Wash., Feb. 7--Whether the ousting or "probationing" of six faculty members of the University of Washington for alleged or admitted pro-Communist activities constituted a blow at academic freedom or an unprecedented step in its defense was a major debate issue among the 16,000 students and 1,500 faculty members today, more than two weeks after the Board of Regents acted. It was a leading topic in many Puget Sound communities as well.

A plan to curb the powers of the Board of Examiners by establishing an Appeals Board with the power to overrule the examiners' decisions will be formally submitted Feb. 17 to the Committee on Law of the Board of Education, it was announced yesterday.

The housing picture is so complicated and necessarily fraught with statistics of all kinds that it is easy even for housing experts, public officials and reporters to get confused occasionally. However, it is important to reduce public misunderstanding of the various housing programs to a minimum.
An internationally known professor of philosophy testified yesterday that an advertisement had "psychologized" him into joining the Book-of-the-Month Club, Inc.

NEWARK, N. J., Feb. 8 -- In letters to Governor Dewey of New York and Gov. Albred E. Driscoll of New Jersey, Meyer C. Ellenstein, City Commissioner of Newark, urged today legislation that would make the Port of New York Authority liable to taxation on projects not involved in direct operations of airports and seaports.

I am in accord with the review of the telecast of the inauguration of President Truman, and in particular " * * * the insistence of the announcers * * * to talk beyond all reasonable need." This struck a responsive chord and uncovered what seems to be a basic flaw in many of today's television presentations, which, after all, are intended primarily for the eye, and secondarily for the ear.
CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- Grain and soybean futures declined the permissible limit on American Grain Exchanges today as the result of heavy liquidation that uncovered stop-loss orders.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- The Senate today passed unanimously a bill sponsored by Senator Sidney A. Fine, Democrat, of the Bronx, that would guarantee a hearing on charges to all civil service employes in the competitive class after ten years of service.

STOCKHOLM, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Dick Miles and Martin Reisman of New York stroked their way into the quarter-finals of the world table tennis championships today as the defending title-holder fell by the wayside.
ROME, Feb. 8 -- About a score of persons were wounded in Ancona today when police opened fire on crowds during severe riots. The uprising followed a "hunger march" staged by the unemployed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved the first application of a major railroad system for authority to modify its securities structure with the consent of the holders.

The obligation of a free press to be responsible and to present the news objectively was stressed yesterday by Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in opening the fifth annual course for teachers on "Evaluating the News."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--Mrs. Harry S. Truman today cut the ribbon to open an exhibit of arts and crafts by displaced persons. The display was arranged here as the first public activity of the newly opened World Affairs Center in downtown Washington.
BELFAST, Feb. 8 -- Ulster's position in the United Kingdom will be "retained and maintained as never before," Sir Basil Brooke, Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, declared tonight.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 8 -- The Peron regime is faced with one of the most stubborn and significant labor revolts it has had to deal with. The printers, whose rank-and-file strike was declared illegal at the end of last week, have refused to return to work.

In fascinating array, forty-nine little ladies from France representing two centuries of fashion stand on display in the show windows of 590 Madison Avenue covering nearly half a block and around the corner on Fifty-seventh Street.

Some furs, particularly mink, have staged a price recovery of 15 to 20 per cent from the December lows, it was reported in the fur trade here yesterday. Even mink prices, however, are well below last year. Ranch mink, selling around $18 or $19 at this time a year ago, and reaching a low of $9.50 to $10 in December, is now around $12.

With shipments in December at a new monthly high point, shipments of finished steel products by domestic steel companies in 1948 established a record of 65,973,138 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York warned a Republican Lincoln Day dinner tonight that the party "is split wide open," with a reactionary group attempting to return it to the philosophy of the Nineteen Twenties.

PARIS, Feb. 8 -- Henri Bernstein, playwright-producer, who is something of a fixture on the Parisian theatrical scene, tonight presented his first play since 1939. The audience applauded the excellent acting of the cast, headed by Jean Gabin, film star.

Mayor O'Dwyer's annual message to the City Council yesterday is a report of substantial progress achieved during 1948, especially in renovation of the city's transit system, in school construction, in erection of low-cost housing and in recognition that a determined attack must be made on certain long-neglected problems.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Almost as many displaced persons will settle in this country in the short month of February as in the four previous months, the International Refugee Organization, which provides the transportation, announced today.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Al Severance, Villanova basketball coach, today called for standard interpretation by officials of the "body contact" clause in the rule book.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UP) -- Following is the text of Secretary of State Dean Acheson's statement today on foreign aid to a joint meeting of Senate and House Foreign Affairs Committees.

A northbound ten-car train crowded with 1,800 to 2,000 passengers came to an abrupt halt in the Forty-second Street and Eighth Avenue subway station of the IND system at 5:02 P. M. yesterday when a woman reaching for a strap in the ninth car pulled the emergency cord.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 8 -- United States Army headquarters announced today that six of the twenty persons arrested last November had been formally charged as espionage agents for the Czechoslovak Government. The accused will be tried in Munich Feb. 14 in the first post-war spy trial in Germany.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Louis B. Seltzer, editor of The Cleveland Press, and three members of the paper's editorial staff were fined today on contempt of court charges resulting from a fake divorce arranged and publicized by the paper.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 8 -- The Howe Sisters of New Haven, Conn., Betty and Peggy, advanced today into the semi-final round of the Atlantic Coast women's squash tournament at Haddon Hall.
LONDON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Financial Times said today that South Africa had decided to sell gold at a price above the world official level because of "pressing foreign exchange difficulties."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Administration economic advisers told Congress today that a new depression following the "boom- and-bust" pattern of the one that began in 1929 would cost the United States $800,000,000,000.

BOSTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Coming from a 10-point deficit early in the second half, Colgate's Red Raiders, led by the accurate Ernie Vandeweghe and Ed Brett, tonight defeated Holy Cross, 74 -- 66, on a Boston Garden basketball program which marked the surge of the losers' Bob Cousy over the 1,000-point mark in his third year of competition.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- Senator Harold I. Panken, Democrat, of Manhattan, served notice in the Senate today that he would force a test vote next week on the question of segregation and discrimination in the National Guard.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson met with the diplomatic representatives of Canada and the Brussels Treaty powers today to renew the private discussions on the proposed North Atlantic defense pact.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- The British Foreign Office is in contact with the United States State Department about a possible protest to the Hungarian Government over the trial and sentence of Cardinal Mindszenty.

" Now You See It," a new television show employing Andre Baruch as master of ceremonies and enlisting the services of magicians, will be introduced by WCBS-TV on Wednesday, Feb. 16, at 7:45 P. M. According to the plan for the program, the magicians, after demonstrating their legerdemain, will reveal to the audience how each trick is worked. Sherman Dryer and Cayton, Inc., will be the producers.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- An emergency fact-finding board reviewing demands of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers for a second engineer on diesel electric locomotives today denied a petition of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen to intervene in the proceedings, hut held out a chance that the latter union might, have some voice in the matter.
FONTAINEBLEAU, France, Feb. 8 -- At high noon of any weekday the historic cobbled courtyard of the Cour Henri Quatre here is a strange and motley sight.
Jurisdictional rivalry for control of New York department store workers brought a strike threat yesterday involving 150 workers in the Brooklyn warehouse of Frederick Loeser Co.

ATHENS, Feb. 8 -- John Ioannides, a veteran Communist revolutionary, has replaced Markos Vafiades as leader of the Greek rebellion, according to an announcement by the rebel radio today. Markos again pleaded ill health, the broadcast said.

Narcotics seized here on Monday night were worth $2,631,562 in the illicit market, the police announced yesterday, revising their original valuation of $1,000,000. They also reported that the man they had arrested, Joseph Basile, 39 years old, of 327 East Forty-seventh Street, was one of the most important distributors of narcotics in the country.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 8 (AP) -- Miss Marjorie Lindsay of Decatur, Ill., and Miss Peggy Kirk of Findlay, Ohio, tied for medalist honors today in the qualifying round of the twenty-fourth annual Palm Beach women's golf championships.

A severe decline in business activity is unlikely in the next twelve months, members of the American Bankers Association were told yesterday. Speaking at the association's midwinter Trust Conference, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Finance at New York University, observed, however, that "the forces which brought about inflation have run their course."

The New York Telephone Company announced yesterday that net income for 1948 amounted to $30,230,414, a drop of $4,227,698 below the $34,458,112 reported for 1947. After dividends of $33,704,000, there was a deficit of $3,473,586, compared with a balance of $754,112 after dividends in the same amount in 1947.
Ground was broken yesterday for two low-rent housing developments in the Bronx. Ceremonies were held at the site of the Bronx River Houses and the Lester W. Patterson Project.

With death rates from cancer reported on the decline, there is strong reason for optimism, Dr. Louis I. Dublin, second vice president and statistician of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, said yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 8 -- The Western powers will not agree to a conference with the Soviet Union at the level either of the heads of states or of the Foreign Ministers until the Berlin problem has been settled and the blockade lifted, Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, said today.

The little wrap became the "big" wrap in the spring fur collection offered by Gunther at a press review yesterday. There were capes and capelets, stoles and short jacklets, all ingeniously draped to give them a new softness in the handling of fur.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The National Federation of American Shipping, Inc., today protested strongly the Maritime Commission's proposals to qualify legislation that would make mandatory the shipment of 50 per cent of Economic Cooperation Administration cargoes in United States merchant vessels.

TOKYO, Feb. 1 -- In the three and one-half years since the surrender, Japan has built up a small but serviceable merchant marine. Already it exceeds the 1,500,000 tons suggested in 1946 by Reparations Commissioner Edwin W. Pauley as the top level to be allowed the nation's post-war economy.

The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday that it would lay off 5,000 workers in its locomotive and car repair shops Friday and 3,000 more in the maintenance of way department Saturday. A spokesman for the line said both actions were based on a 10 per cent decline in passenger and freight traffic since last year.

The United States Court of Appeals, reversed yesterday the conviction last September of a Hartford, Conn., union and its president on charges of violating a provision of the Taft-Hartley Act prohibiting political spending by labor organizations.

The reports of the trial of Cardinal Mindszenty, published in the press, strongly suggest that here is another "Moscow trial." The confession of Cardinal Mindszenty, affirming that he is guilty in principle and in detail of the charges leveled against him, reads as weirdly as did the forced and self-contradictory confessions of Zinoviev, Bukharin, Radek and other victims of the Moscow trials.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Republicans waged a losing fight today to preserve at least part of the procedural curbs they had imposed last year on the Reciprocal Trade Agreements program as the House debated the issue with party politics rampant.

PARIS, Feb. 8 -- Two former members of the wartime Soviet purchasing commission in Washington testified here today that Victor Kravchenko had been recognized as a one-time criminal and as a person of questionable general reputation long before he left his Soviet post in March, 1944.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- An unofficial ruling by Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein today added a new complication to the legislative dispute over the provisions of a proposed constitutional amendment extending preferences to war veterans in civil service.
Nineteen Polish seamen failed to report for the sailing of the Gdynia America line Batory last Wednesday and are being sought by immigration authorities, it became known yesterday.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Feb. 8 (AP) -- Michigan State College's baseball coach today criticized the Cincinnati Reds for signing Hobert N. Landrith, the Spartans No. 1 catching prospect for this season.
To speed distribution of current gray goods inventories, the Textile Distributors Institute has set up a voluntary clearing house for listing converters' offerings, it was learned yesterday.

Voluntary settlement of the Government's ten-year-old anti-trust action against Paramount Pictures Corporation, with the company proposing to separate its film producing-distributing and domestic theatre operations, now is a distinct possibility, it was learned yesterday.

After an absence of two months, the old street signs on Park Avenue from Forty-fifth to Fifty-sixth Street were back again yesterday, attached to the new aluminum lampposts in silver brackets. This is only for the time being, as new streamlined signs, in style with the lampposts, are in the making.
Paul Block, newspaper publisher, left an estate of $3,577,355 when he died on June 22, 1941, it was indicated yesterday with the filing of an accounting in Surrogate's Court.
GENEVA, Feb. 8 -- The first attempt at a multilateral approach to the problems of East-West trade will begin in Geneva Monday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The Army has held up action against Alexander Sacks of New York, a civilian employe in Germany suspended for criticizing high officials in testimony before an investigating committee, pending a report from that committee, Gordon Gray, Assistant Secretary of the Army, announced here today.

The Baxter Mile will serve as the introductory vehicle for Marcel Hansenne when the great French runner opens his current American tour on Saturday in the New York Athletic Club games at Madison Square Garden.

The mock trial of Cardinal Mindszenty has come to its predetermined end in a travesty of justice staged for their own purposes by the Kremlin and its Communist henchmen in Hungary. The Cardinal and his six co-defendants have been found guilty of opposition to the Communist dictatorship in Budapest and have been sentenced to a living death in prison from which few can hope to emerge alive.
At an angry session of the City Council yesterday, the members voted sixteen to two to approve a resolution condemning the arrest, imprisonment and condemnation of Cardinal Mindszenty.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,969, compared with 1,498 last week and 1,547 in the similar week of last year, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 939 arrivals yesterday against 758 last Tuesday.
General selling swept through the local commodity exchanges yesterday and prices had their sharpest decline since the postwar break of a year ago.

The vote in the House of Representatives on the bill vesting in the President "broad and permanent authority" to initiate administrative reforms in the Federal Government is one of the most remarkable votes taken in that branch of Congress in recent years.
SHANGHAI, Feb. 8 (UP) -- Acting President Li Tsung-jen today warned high-ranking Nationalist officers to plan for possible continuation of the civil war.

PARIS, Feb. 8 -- Naming his new silhouette trompe l'oeil, an optical illusion, Dior shortens perceptibly, by means of one or more floating panels and distributes an illusory fullness asymmetrically about a stem skirt. Though always respecting the natural curve of the shoulders, he gives them new importance by building out the gown in front.

Jesse Jones, formerly Secretary of Commerce and head of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, denied in a deposition read in Federal Court yesterday that he had conditioned a $425,000,000 loan to Great Britain in 1941 on that country's giving King Ibn Saud of Saudi Arabia money or supplies.

LONDON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Soviet News Agency Tass disposed of the conviction of Cardinal Mindszenty with an eighty-three-word news item. The agency's dispatch from Budapest merely listed the sentences of the Cardinal and his co-defendants but did not mention the charges.
PARIS, Feb. 8 -- Pierre Balmain selects cherry red, cornflower blue and Irish green to share honors with gray, greige and black in a gay and youthful collection abounding in exciting detail.

ROME, Feb. 8 -- Rome is the city of fountains. Life in this new old city goes on to the purl and splash of running water. Nearly every block and courtyard adds its spray or trickle to swell the murmurous music that is the most familiar of all Roman street sounds. Now most of the fountains are silent.

Sales of bottle carbonated beverages will break all records this year, it was predicted yesterday by officials of the American Bottlers of Carbonated Beverages at a sales management conference in the Statler Hotel.

New York is "checkmated and blocked at every turn" by the unrealistic legal restrictions and unsound fiscal practices" of the state government, Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday in an address to the City Council.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Class I railroads showed an average return of 4.38 per cent on net property investment in 1948, the Association of American Railroads reported today. This compares with 3.46 per cent in 1947.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- A measure calling for the consideration of all regular appropriations in a single bill each year was introduced today in the Senate. It was offered by three Democrats and three Republicans who believe the proposals, if accepted, will help curb "nonessential Federal spending."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Leaders of American foreign policy told Congress today that the European Recovery Program was winning against the economic and political forces it set out to combat last year.

Lord Taylor admittedly is "as happy as the cat that swallowed the canary" about its new suburban shop in Millburn, N. J., which will be opened for business at 9:30 o'clock this morning. All over the store at previews yesterday, white wire cages -- shaped like cats five times life size and filled with fluttering, singing birds -- proclaimed this pride.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 8 -- There were some amused looks around the United Nations Economic and Social Council table here today when word circulated that Byelorussia's new delegate bears the rather, unsocialistic name of Skorobogaty -- which in Russian means "get rich quick."

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- With ten Republicans and one Democrat voting in the negative, the Assembly today approved three measures to increase state housing loan funds and subsidies subject to the approval of the electorate at a referendum this fall.

In an exhibition entitled "Westward Ho," opening to the public today, the Brooklyn Museum has gone to some pains to document the history of American westward expansion for the period from 1800 to 1860 in a group of costume examples, decorative ornaments, oil paintings and prints of that period.
Doane Twombley, Short Hills, seeded No. 1, scored an opening-round victory in the Metropolitan squash racquets Class C championship at the Downtown A. C. last night.

Sizable tonnages of steel products, canceled by Midwestern manufacturers, are being brought into the New York market for the first time because steel buying continues to hold the most active spot in purchasing offices of larger industries here, it was learned yesterday in a canvass of more than twenty plants.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Prices on live hogs declined today to their lowest levels since price controls were in effect in October, 1946. In general the market was 75c to $1 a hundred pounds lower than yesterday. Today's top price was $20.50, compared with the OPA ceiling of $16.25 and the high record of $31.85 made on Aug. 19, last.
Your forthright and courageous denunciation of Representative Rankin's proposed "bonus" bill stated the objections to such ill-advised legislation long held by the American Veterans Committee.

For several years Peg Newton of 3 East Forty-eighth Street has been providing specially designed and specially sized fashions for young women of five feet seven inches or more. However, the spring collection, seen yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel, outdid all previous efforts both in variety and chic.

Relying on the ability of Philip Barry, Jean Pierre Aumont, Lilli Palmer, Arlene Francis, Robert B. Sinclair and Stewart Chaney, the Theatre Guild is putting its best foot forward tonight at the Lyceum, where "My Name Is Aquilon" will have its premiere.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 8 -- Philip Murray, president of the CIO and of the United Steelworkers of America, who underwent an emergency appendectomy on the eve of his scheduled re-election by the steel men's union, was reported tonight as resting "as well as could be expected."

Nashville, Tenn., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on March 1 on an issue of $5,000,000 of electric revenue bonds. Dated March 1, 1949, the bonds will be due on each March 1, from 1952 to 1958, and on June 1, 1959.
BOSTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- A public hearing on the dismissal of Dr. Miriam Van Waters as head of the Massachusetts Women's Reformatory ended today after eighteen turbulent sessions.
A series of classes for expectant mothers will be opened next week by the Visiting Nurse Service of New York at nineteen places in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens, it was announced yesterday.

Interest rates during 1949 probably will remain comparatively stable at approximately present levels, according to the Bankers Trust Company. Commenting on the outlook in its annual review, "United States Government Securities and the Money Market," issued yesterday, the bank observes that sales of Government bonds to the Federal Reserve banks this year will be substantially less than during 1948.

Ambassador Sava N. Kosanovitch of Yugoslavia has taken exception to an Athens dispatch published in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday that dealt with a Greek insurgent radio report of the relieving of a Yugoslav general named Popovitch by the rebel forces.

The Sun Life Assurance Company of Canada last year increased its assets by $68,887,128 to a new high of $1,490,870,041, of which about 50 per cent are in United States investments according to the report of Arthur B. Wood, president, issued yesterday at the seventy-eighth annual meeting in Montreal. More than 40 per cent of this Canadian leading life company's business is in the United States.

" Secret Agent," a Soviet-made drama, which arrives at the Stanley, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Pavel Kadochnikov is starred in the offering, which is based on incidents from the wartime files of the Russian Intelligence Service. Boris Barnet directed at the Kiev Film Studios.
The American ORT Federation presented a citation to the United States Army last night for "humanitarian service."

If Commissioner of Commerce Abe Stark has his way New Yorkers may soon learn from motion picture and television screens that they are living in the most friendly, liberal, prosperous and inviting city in the world.
MOSCOW, Feb. 8 (UP) -- A noted Russian commentator today accused Finland's coalition government of seeking "a direct or roundabout deal with American expansionists."

CLEVELAND, Feb. 8 (UP) -- Bobby Feller of the world champion Indians had to take the first pay cut of his illustrious career today, but he remained the highest paid pitcher in the history of baseball.
MONTREAL, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Doug Bentley, the little center of the Chicago Black Hawks, continues to show the way in the National Hockey League's individual scoring parade today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Jimmy Caras of Upper Darby, Pa., tonight stayed with the pace in the national pocket billiard tournament by notching his seventh straight victory without a defeat, turning back veteran Bennie Allen of Kansas City, 125 to 49, in fourteen innings. Caras had a high run of 38, Allen 11.

Crime among American women has lessened steadily in the last thirty years because they have gained economic security, Lieut. Col. Agnes McKernan, former territorial director of the Salvation Army's Women's Prison Bureau, declared here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Counsel for the Transamerica Corporation, San Francisco, was denied permission today to pursue a line of interrogation which he contended would refute, in part, the Federal Reserve Board's anti-trust charges against the huge holding company.
Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, Chief of Air Staff, received the Frank Hawks Memorial Award of Air Service Post 501, American Legion, at a dinner of the post last night at the Savoy Plaza Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Mildred E. (Axis Sally) Gillars collapsed at her treason trial today after hearing her own voice on wartime Nazi broadcast describing American airmen who bombed Berlin as "murderers."
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 8 (UP) -- Government press officer explained today how Cardinal Mindszenty's sentence was reached under Hungarian law.

Presiding Justice David W. Peck of the Appellate Division, sponsor of the plan to streamline the court system in this city, said yesterday that he would continue to fight for enactment of some kind of a court reorganization plan at the current session of the Legislature.

Abraham I. Menin, receiver in the bankruptcy proceedings against Samuel Broxmeyer, obtained a Federal Court order yesterday temporarily blocking a $50,000 creditor's suit involving one apartment of the $22,000,000 Broxmeyer chain.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- The Federation of State Boards of Medical Examiners recommended today that no foreign applicant, graduated since 1935, be permitted to take an examination in any state for a license to practice.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- Condemning the ban on the showing of Jean-Paul Sartre's "The Respectful Prostitute" by Chicago law-enforcement authorities, Marc Connelly, author of "Green Pastures" and other successful, plays, asserted tonight that "the theatre as an agency for the effective cultural advancement of society has always been the natural enemy of those who fear knowledge."
ROME, Feb. 8 -- The Catholic Church's Holy Congregation of the Council has issued a decree tightening rules for abstinence and fast that were relaxed in 1941.
The report of the Timken-Detroit Axle Company and its subsidiaries reveled yesterday a net profit of $3,158,261 for the six months ended with last December, after deducting taxes and all charges.

Nine Hungarian officials in this country, including the acting Consul General in New York, resigned yesterday and sought asylum here as political refugees from the Communist-controlled Budapest government.

Taking formal cognizance of the tighter money market conditions that have existed during recent weeks, the National City Bank of New York has advanced its interest rates on certain types of loans to brokers and dealers. Effective today, the bank's minimum dealer rate for short-term carries will be raised from 1 1/4 per cent to 1 3/8 per cent per annum.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 8 -- Harold E. Stassen, president of the University Pennsylvania, declared of here today that the action of the Communist-controlled Hungarian Government in condemning Cardinal Mindszenty to life imprisonment was "a travesty on justice" which could only result in "an increased yearning for freedom by all peoples behind the Iron Curtain."

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 8 -- More than a score of countries have informed the United Nations Economic and Social Council that they are setting up "automatic stabilizers" in their economies as emergency safeguards against possible wholesale rises in unemployment.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 7 (Delayed) -- The recognition of Israel by Turkey is under consideration, Foreign Minister Nedjmeddin Sadak said today.
Customarily held in Washington, D. C., when the United States is the champion nation, the draw for the Davis Cup matches was conducted in this city yesterday for the first time in years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The Navy Department announced tonight it was contracting for 700,000 pairs of shoes at a cost of $3,843,897 from five manufacturers and explained it was entering the shoe market now to "raise stock levels to meet normal peacetime needs."

The report of the United States Fidelity and Guaranty Company of Baltimore released today disclosed an increase in total admitted assets on Dec. 31 last to $143,728,203 from $126,066,426, a year earlier.

SEATTLE, Feb. 8 -- The retention on two-year "probation" of three former members of the Communist party on the faculty of the University of Washington, center of a lively controversy in recent days, represented a compromise within the Board of Regents, according to Joseph Drumheller of Spokane, president of the board.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 8 -- Dore Schary, Loew's vice president in charge of production, today told the film company's salesmen, who are in convention here, that M-G-M, Loew's Hollywood studio, has scheduled forty-nine pictures for production in 1949-50, in addition to six pictures now before the cameras and twelve pictures already completed and awaiting release.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The International Monetary Fund said today it had approved a sale of alloy gold at a premium price on condition that the metal be used only for industrial or professional work.

Two more books dealing with polls and public opinion have been scheduled for publication. "The People Know Best: The Ballots vs. The Polls," by Morris Ernst and David Loth, will be brought out by the Public Affairs Press of Washington next Wednesday.
The Chase National Bank of the City of New York announced yesterday that it had made a short-term loan of $25,000,000 to the Institute of Foreign Exchange, a Spanish Government agency.

The olive branch is about to be hung in Wall Street. Yesterday officials of the New York Stock, Curb and Cotton Exchanges accepted labor's invitation to a "good-will" luncheon at the Com modore Hotel on Feb. 28 where they will discuss with leaders of the American Federation of Labor and its affiliate, the United Financial Employes, negotiations looking to "harmonious relations" in the world's financial center.

WARSAW, Feb, 8 -- More than twenty Catholic priests have been arrested by the security police for haviing read in their churches a pastoral letter written by Bishop Stanislaw Adamski, Bishop of the Katowice diocese, Catholic circles disclosed today. Priests had been warned by the police not to read the letter.

Advertising in the eight major daily newspapers of metropolitan New York during January totaled 10,549,248 lines, a gain of 12.09 per cent over the like period of last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. All categories recorded gains, with automotive up 93.6l per cent; general, 14 per cent; classified, l2.10 per cent; retail, 8.85 per cent, and financial, 2.62 per cent.

The opposition to a Columbia Valley Authority on the part of the private power companies, as reported in THE TIMES of this date, again raises the question in one's mind: Can't those who oppose the extension of the Federal Government's social welfare programs present some positive alternative, rather than a pure negativism which persuades no one but themselves?
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UP) -- The text of Governor Dewey's address follows:

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 8 -- The possibility of a sentence of death still hung over Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty tonight despite a People's Court decision that he must serve the remainder of his life in prison.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Senator John L. McClellan of Arkansas made it plain today that the Senate Committee on Expenditures in the Executive Departments did not intend to "railroad through" proposed legislation giving the President wide power to overhaul the Executive branch.
Bad weather struck the blizzard-burdened West with triple-barreled blows again yesterday -- and still another storm was whistling down out of Alaska, The Associated Press reported.

With their goals set at $2,000,000 and a bigger program of Scouting for the boys of New York, friends of the Greater New York Councils of the Boy Scouts of America have raised $435,565 since their two-month campaign began Jan. 5, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, submitted to Congress today a uniform code of military justice for all of the armed services designed to protect the accused and increase public confidence in the fairness of the courts-martial procedure.

Further efforts by the drug industry toward establishment of detailed, uniform guides on the common problems of production, labeling and distribution were suggested by George P. Larrick, assistant commissioner of Food and Drugs of the Federal Security Agency. He spoke at the meeting of the Eastern production section of the American Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association in the Commodore Hotel.

NEWARK, N. J., Feb. 8 -- American Federation of Labor officials will serve as "visiting professors" in a one-week education experiment intended to give Newark high school seniors the "unvarnished truth about unions" as labor sees it.

Spectators applauded Judge Harold R. Medina in Federal Court yesterday when he quelled a disturbance by delivering an excited youth from the hands of the bailiffs and giving him a seat near the bench.

Thirty - two contract bridge teams out of a starting field of fifty-two survived the two elimination rounds in the play last night at the Pierre Hotel for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup and the team of four championship of the American Contract Bridge League.

Assertions by the General Council of Salesmen's Organizations that transient hotel room rates have increased 50 to 100 per cent since Office of Price Administration controls were lifted were characterized yesterday by Charles A. Horrworth, executive vice president of the American Hotel Association, as "unwarranted and literally astounding."

Proper medical care can reduce the incidence of cerebral palsy in newborn infants up to 50 per cent, according to a recent hospital study made public yesterday during the First National Conference and Exposition on Cerebral Palsy at the Statler Hotel.

In the information given by The United Press from Teheran and published in your columns on Feb. 5 concerning the dastardly attack on His Imperial Majesty the Shah, it is stated in the two concluding paragraphs of the article that "Iran has been the scene of unrest since the end of the war.
ALBANY, N. Y., Feb. 8 (AP) -- The State Commerce Department reported today the following conditions at New York ski centers: Bear Mountain State Park -- 2 inches wet snow, poor.

Specific recommendations to make comic books more wholesome and constructive and a warning that the industry faces regulation unless it cleans house and produces comics that will not be injurious to children, were made public yesterday by a voluntary committee of city officials through Presiding Justice John Warren Hill of the Domestic Relations Court.

Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, presented his estimates to Congress yesterday of the dollar cost of the second year of the European Recovery Program. The sum required to cover the interim period April 3-June 30, and thus to bring the program into alignment with the Government's fiscal year, is $1,150,000,000.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Feb. 8 -- A year's test of radar detection of speeding motorists indicated today that the system works, but at a cost.

The honey cakes just appearing at Macy's and a number of delicacy shops here are made in one of the oldest food factories in the world. Since 1593, the House of Jacob Bussink of Deventer, Holland, has been baking these long, oblong loaves of what might almost be called the Dutchman's daily bread.

The stock market set up some resistance yesterday to the continued sharp break in commodities and arrested its recent weakness at about the closing levels of the previous day. Prices operated in an irregular manner through a greater part of the session and, although the list leaned slightly to the lower side at the finish few price alterations in excess of a point appeared.
MOUNTAINSIDE, N. J., Feb. 8 (AP) -- Two young girls who fell through thin ice on Echo Lake in an attempt to save a dog were rescued today by a Westfield High School senior.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The Senate smashed down late today by 57 to 20 a Republican effort to repudiate a decision by its new Democratic presiding officer, Vice President Alben W. Barkley.

A seven-inch direct view tube portable television with a built-in antenna to retail at $149.95 was introduced yesterday by Tele-tone Radio Corporation during the presentation of its 1949 line to distributors in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The set is the only portable on the market with a built-in antenna and is priced $50 below other 7-inch portables, according to S. W. Gross, president.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The resignation of Mark Edwin Andrews as Assistant Secretary of the Navy was accepted by President Truman today with "very genuine regret." It is effective Feb. 15.
