In his first speech on national affairs since the end of the Presidential campaign Governor Dewey told a Republican audience last night that "the Republican party is split wide open." And to this he added: "It has been split wide open for years, but we have tried to gloss it over. We have tried to deny it to ourselves and conceal it. That doesn't work.
The text of Mayor O'Dwyer's address to the City Council on the city's finances follows:
HANOVER, N. H, Feb. 8 -- Dartmouth broke a four-game losing streak tonight at Alumni Gymnasium by overcoming a fast-breaking Boston University quintet, 55 -- 45.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Robert N. Denham, head of the independent office of "General Counsel, National Labor Relations Board," strongly defended today the major provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act before the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee.

After an absence of three weeks, college basketball returns to Madison Square Garden tonight, with N. Y. U. facing Manhattan College in the featured attraction. St. John's will engage Canisius of Buffalo in the 8 o'clock curtain-raiser. Tickets for the twin bill still were available yesterday and indications are that 16,000 fans will attend.

A total of 67,299 persons received services from the Community Service Society during 1948, according to the agency's annual report published yesterday. The organization, with a current budget of $3,733,171, is appealing for $1,400,000 to help support its program.

TV: Future and Present In our part of the world people rapidly are being divided into two classes: those who own television sets and those who do not. It may be observed that a number of those who do not have been spending more and more time of late sitting about with long faces trying to decide how television eventually will affect what they speak of as Life as We Know It.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UP) -- A bill authorizing a seventy-group Air Force was started through Congress today as President Truman reviewed his military budget with Chairman Millard Tydings of the Senate Armed Services Committee.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- Jacob L. Holtzmann, Brooklyn Republican, was nominated officially today by the Senate and Assembly to replace Susan Brandeis, Manhattan Democrat, as a member of the Board of Regents after the Republican legislative leadership had quelled a threatened rank-and-file revolt against dropping her.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 8 -- Tomorrow morning at 10 o'clock the Government's preliminary peace delegation is finally scheduled to fly from here to Peiping. The delegation of six has bowed before yesterday's blast by the Communist radio.

Fall prices for men's wear lines of American Woolen Company show no change from those now in effect, it was announced yesterday. Publication of the fabric price list which, it is believed, will set the pattern for the whole industry, removed the possibility of any further deep cut in men's clothing prices.

A young Chinese laundryman from the Bronx and a top-ranking professional lensman from Baltimore shared the honors yesterday in a national photographic contest that brought to each a first prize of $5,000.

The Chicago, Indianapolis Louisville Railway Company borrowed $4,500,000 yesterday on serial equipment trust certificates maturing from March 1, 1950 to 1964 at an interest cost of about 2.74 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- President Truman tonight emphasized the extensive congestion and unsafe traffic conditions on many main urban highways and cited the "imperative" need for a greatly enlarged highway program throughout the country.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 8 -- The Soviet Union proposed today that the Big Five supply the United Nations Security Council with "complete data concerning their armed forces and all types of armaments, including atomic weapons." A deadline of March 31 was proposed in the Soviet resolution, which also contained a paragraph that was interpreted by Warren R. Austin, United States representative, as condemning both the American hemisphere defense agreement and the proposed North Atlantic pact.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The Senate today approved by a voice vote a bill to give authority to the Administration to continue control of exports until June 30, 1951. The House is expected to act next week.
Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was very heavy yesterday, and losses of 18 to 48 points were registered on the day.
The 52 Association of New York played host last night to 150 wounded servicemen and veterans at its fourth annual dinner dance at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, attended by 1,000 persons.

The management of the Winthrop Hotel, Forty-seventh Street and Lexington Avenue, closed the hotel bar early yesterday evening to remove twenty members of Local 32-E, Hotel Service Employes International Union, AFL, who had filled the room. The men drank beer or soda pop.

The Orion Shipping and Trading Company, one of the largest operators of American-flag vessels in the tramping trades, has completed arrangements for the purchase of three Liberty ships owned by the Waterman Steamship Corporation, it was reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Gen. George C. Marshall, leaning on a cane but erect and soldierly as ever, called at the White House today to thank President Truman for his "hospitality'' and comforting assistance during his recent illness.

Walls of red, white and blue bunting on the second floor of 500 Park Avenue bulged figuratively yesterday as thousands of young and old New Yorkers shuffled slowly through the maze of narrow corridors lined with gifts from the New York State car of the French Gratitude Train.

A general flood of selling yesterday swamped the nation's markets for the major domestic farm products and prices had their most severe setback since the break of a year ago. Some prices dropped to the lowest level since the ceilings of the Office of Price Administration were in effect.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 8 (AP) -- A trio of 1948 Olympic bobsledders headed the field of United States drivers today seeking berths on the United States two-man bobsledding team for the world championshps here Feb. 12-13.

Flash bulbs were popping off, and so were Branch Rickey and Manager Barney Shotton, as the Dodger president held a press conference in his Montague Street offices yesterday to announce the signing of Jackie Robinson Ralph Branca, Dick Whitman, Billy Cox and Johnny Van Cuyk.

ROME, Feb. 8 -- The sentence passed in Budapest on Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty though not unexpected was received in the Vatican with deepest sorrow and indignation. It was mixed with relief that at least he was not condemned to death.
MIAMI, Feb. 8 -- The American Federation of Labor served notice today on the leaders of the Canadian Trades and Labor Congress that it would not compromise with Communists in that organization.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- President Truman sanctioned today the appointment of William M. Boyle Jr. of Kansas City, one of the leading strategists of his political campaign, as executive vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- An arrow-shaped XB-47 jet bomber streaked through the stratosphere at an average speed of 607.2 miles an hour today in the fastest transcontinental flight ever made.
LONDON, Feb. 8 -- Following the new set-back on Wall Street, conditions were unsettled on the stock market here today.

RHODES, Feb. 8 -- Trans-Jordan's formal acceptance of the invitation to hold armistice talks with Israel on Rhodes reached the Acting Mediator, Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, today through his representative in Amman.

Don Lee, ring warrior who boasts a couple of victories over the spectacular Vince Foster will have his local unveiling tonight under the auspices of the Tournament of Champions. He is a brother of Glen Lee who fought here a decade ago, and he comes from Edison, Neb., heralded as the Nebraska Wildcat, a capable successor to the originator of that appellation, Ace Hudkins.

Apparently the Richards have a natural affinity for Shakespeare's bloodiest scoundrel. Richard Burbage was the original Richard III. Richard Whorf is playing him now. Limping around malevolently in the midst of a swift and taut production, Mr. Whorf opened at the Booth last evening in the best of evil spirits.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 8 -- Those who have chummed for tuna in the middle of the Mudhole fleet in August would have been right at home in the confusion which existed on Hobe Sound today, when twenty-one boats darted, dashed and spun in an effort to put baits over a big school of sailfish.
A working woman living with her family in New York State needs at least $40.13 a week to support herself properly. And this amount does not include keeping up to date with the "new look."

Merger of Foremost Dairies, Inc., and Maxson Food Systems, Inc., will be proposed to stockholders of both companies at a meeting on March 14, according to the respective boards of directors who approved the action yesterday.
Protests against the sentencing to life imprisonment of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty reached a new pitch of intensity yesterday as the 56-year-old Catholic Primate of Hungary appealed the sentence.

Those terrible but stirring days when the people of Britain stood alone between Hitler and his plan to turn back the clock of civilization come to life again in the memoirs of Winston Churchill. It is good that the dark days of 1939 and 1940, and the years that followed, should be recalled.
Dean Millicent Carey McIntosh of Barnard College is giving up her academic duties temporarily to devote full time to a fund-raising campaign for the school, she announced yesterday.

For every dollar you contribute to the Salvation Army, the Army renders $2.93 worth of care to the needy. This is possible because the Army is partly self-sustaining through some of its services and bequests.

Celedonio Sevilla, 50 years old, of 218 West Fourteenth Street, his wife, Delphina, 25, and Francisco G. Obregon, 29, of 203 West Seventy-eighth Street, were found guilty by a Federal Court jury yesterday of mail fraud in connection with a new version of the old Spanish prisoner swindle.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- A group of Republican members of the Legislature from Westchester and Erie Counties may attempt to cut Governor Dewey's record $936,200,000 budget sufficiently to make the proposed gasoline tax increase unnecessary.

The American Government is consulting with the British and French Governments on ways and means of dealing with the destruction of personal, political and religious liberty in Hungary, as revealed by the trial of Cardinal Mindszenty. According to Secretary Acheson, one means, though not the only one, now under consideration is to bring the matter before the United Nations.

DO you remember how they laughed when he sat down at the piano? At least that is what the old-time advertisements used to proclaim. Well, sir, Charlie Johnston sat down at the piano last October and folks started to snicker. Quite a card that Johnston. And the loudest guffaws came when Charlie insisted that "my Scotsman" (sic!) would knock out Willie Pep for the world featherweight championship.

The playing of Jose Echaniz, the Cuban-born pianist and conductor of the Grand Rapids Symphony who returned to Town Hall for a recital last night, is brisk and efficient, cool but attractive in tone, and ventures only into shallow and medium depths in matters of interpretation.

TOKYO, Feb. 9 -- Japan will take another long step back toward private business management on April 1 when the special Government corporation for petroleum distribution will be abolished. Thereafter foreign and Japanese corporations will handle distribution.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Senator Millard E. Tydings, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, asked today that the President be required to submit military reorganization plans to the Congress in a separate package.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- The state medical service has proved so much more popular than had been expected that the British Government had to ask Parliament today for an increase of one-third in its appropriation for the service.

More than 80 per cent of 1,400 druggists responding to a national survey oppose the Truman health-insurance program, although some 52 per cent were shown to be ignorant of how it would work, according to details of the study made known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Parked, stalled and abandoned cars in the streets of New York keep the city snowbound during and after heavy storms, delegates were told today at the closing session of the annual meeting of the American Road Builders Association here.

TRENTON, Feb. 9 -- A rise of $35,726,000 in demand and time deposits in state-supervised financial institutions has been reported by the New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance. Deposits on Dec. 31, 1948, stood at $2,749,123,000, compared with $2,713,397,000 on Dec. 31, 1947.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 9 -- Poland charged in the United Nations Economic and Social Council today that the trial and life imprisonment sentence of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, Primate of Hungary, had been seized upon for political reasons to whip up "hysteria" in various parts of the world.
Financial considerations are bringing to the austere halls of Barnard College a degree of self-help hitherto unknown there, a poll of students indicated last evening.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 9 -- No great effect upon the work of the Protestant Episcopal Church in China from the Communist victories is foreseen by the Right Rev. Alfred A. Gilbert, retired bishop of the Diocese of Hankow.

Business and business men, in many instances, have now made themselves the wards of government, Frank E. Holman, president of the American Bar Association, declared yesterday. Addressing some 1,800 members of the American Bankers Association, in attendance at the closing session of their mid-winter Trust Conference in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Mr. Holman asserted that the extent to which the national government was engaged in business now threatens the existence of free enterprise.

With an estimated total attendance up to closing time last night of 40,000 persons, the first International Automobile Show will end its six-day run tonight at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, Twenty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue.

Three suspicious fires were discovered last night in the cellar of a brownstone house on the East Side occupied by persons prominent in the entertainment world, but the fires were extinguished before they damaged the premises. An investigation to determine their origin is being conducted.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- The Department of Mental Hygiene, in a new publication describing the state's mental health program, said today that it had established a pattern of development designed to keep pace with the growing needs of the mentally afflicted.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Yugoslav Communist newspaper Borba made bitter charges of trade discrimination today against the Soviet-bloc nations.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Joe Chamaco of Mexico City clinched a berth in the world's championship three-cushion billiard play today by overwhelming Juan Navarra of Buenos Aires, 50 to 16, in 38 innings. It was Chamaco's sixth victory against one defeat.

The highly touted "Death of a Salesman," the new Arthur Miller drama, which caused the out-of-town critical appraisers to toss their hats as one into the air, makes its New York debut tonight at 8 o'clock at the Morosco Theatre.
Following is the text of a statement issued here yesterday by Cardinal Spellman:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The House rejected Republican efforts today to retain part of the procedural curbs imposed last year on the reciprocal trade agreements program and voted to restore to the President the full powers that he previously exercised.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- President Truman asked the support of the Advertising Council today to get higher salaries for Government officials to get and keep men of higher caliber in Federal service.

RHODES, Feb. 9 -- Egyptian-Israeli armistice talks appeared today to be marking time for the second day in succession but a well-informed source said that positive developments were expected within a few days. Official sources would make no statements but it was believed that this pause meant that the delegates were consulting their governments again.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The National Planning Association urged today the creation of a full-time civilian "watchdog" agency of the Government to check upon expenditures by the armed forces.

Reductions of from two-tenths to half a cent a gallon in the price of home heating fuel in the New York metropolitan area were announced yesterday by a majority of the large oil companies and by independent distributors.
" The rush for spoils had begun. But Mussolini was not the only hungry animal seeking prey. To join the Jackal came the Bear."

Two major upsets marked the resumption of college basketball at Madison Square Garden last night. After Canisius had stunned a crowd of 14,503 with a 59-48 victory over St. John's, Manhattan College gained a spine-tingling triumph over New York University.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 9 -- A determined Columbia quintet, overcoming a five-point deficit in the final three minutes of regulation time to tie the game with only five seconds remaining, caught fire in the overtime period tonight to down Princeton, 57 -- 50, and take second place in Eastern League standings.
NANKING, Feb. 9 (UP) -- Local governments discussed piecemeal peace plans today.

Crosswinds that have been influencing basic bond prices since the national election have pretty well subsided and for the moment the markets for giltedge issues -- both taxable and tax-exempt -- may be said to be becalmed. The tone of Government bond prices continues firm, with each day giving more evidence of the broadening of investment interest, particularly by out-of-town banks, in the Treasury's longer maturities.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Congressional action on President Truman's request for a $4,000,000,000 tax rise became increasingly remote today in the light of statements by Senator Walter F. George of Georgia, chairman of the Finance Committee, and Representative Robert L. Doughton of North Carolina, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- Grain prices closed about the top on the Board of Trade today, staging a violent rally after an early decline of 9 5/8 cents a bushel in wheat and 10 cents in soy beans, the latter being off the daily limit at one time.

A rose garden, to produce the best results, must be planned properly, planted securely and pruned and cultivated regularly, Miss Dorothy H. Jenkins, garden editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared yesterday at the final lecture of a series in Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.
Columbia Records, Inc., took official notice yesterday of the undeclared war between its long playing record and the new record of its RCA Victor competitor by issuing a "no-surrender" communique.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The electoral college system of choosing Presidents defrauds voters of their franchise while emphasizing the influence of pressure groups, Clarence F. Lea, former Representative from California, said here today.

A majority of small business men are for elimination or simplification of Government reports and for small business equality in labor legislation, according to a survey by the National Federation of Small Business, Inc., the results of which were released yesterday in Washington.
Raging ground blizzards threw up new mountainous drifts on the snow-smothered western plains yesterday, piling up fresh blockades to rail and auto travel, The Associated Press reported.

A program of education based on "teaching people instead of teaching subjects" was advanced by Dr. Richard Boyd Ballou after he was installed formally last night as director of the Ethical Culture Schools.

Coats and suits figured prominently in the showing of spring fashions held yesterday at B. Altman Co. Included in the coat roster were soft camel's hair and fleeces for those interested in the casual mood, as well as stiff modish fabrics in elegant small-waisted coats for Easter morning.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 9 -- After hours of debate, the General Council of the Evangelical and Reformed Church adopted unanimously tonight a resolution calling a special session of the General Synod here on April 20 and 21, to vote on the proposed merger with the Congregational Christian Churches to form the United Church of Christ.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- A gigantic eight-jet "Flying Wing" roared non-stop across the country today at the speed of 511.2 miles an hour.

Battering his foe to the canvas five times, Walter Cartier, Fordham middleweight, knocked out Don Lee, Edison (Neb.) boxer in the eighth round of their scheduled ten-round bout at the Manhattan Center last night.

Morris Lippman sold the fourstory building containing twentythree apartments at 1629 Park Place, Brooklyn, to the Juldave Realty Corporation, represented by Joseph Wechter, attorney. Title was insured by the Home Title Guaranty Company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson reached back to 1863 today to support his contention before the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations yesterday that the United States should show forbearance toward Western Europe while it struggled for unity.

The photograph taken by Joint Task Force One: Bikini as the atom bomb exploded over the Pacific atoll is shown in a huge mural at the entrance to an exhibition of American news photography that opened yesterday in the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street.

The prevalence of cerebral palsy in New York state and the lack of Government funds to help rehabilitate child victims of the crippling affliction were stressed yesterday at the National Conference on Cerebral Palsy at the Statler Hotel.
The highest temperature on any Feb. 9 since the Weather Bureau was set up here was recorded yesterday on the fifteenth anniversary of the city's coldest day.

Horace Stoneham, president of the Giants, told The United Press last night that he was "glad" a Federal Court of Appeals in New York State had ordered a $300,000 law suit by his former outfielder, Danny Gardella, brought to trial.

DETROIT, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Smashing home five goals in the second period, first-place Detroit breezed to an 8-0 National Hockey League victory over the fifth-place Rangers before 12,938 fans at Olympia tonight. It was Harry Lumley's fifth shut-out of the season and his second in a row.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- In a mood sharply in contrast with the optimism voiced yesterday by top international policy officials as they asked for $5,580,000,000 to continue the European Recovery Program, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee cross-examined Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, for four hours today.

Two questions are being asked in Washington as a result of the weakness that has characterized the commodity markets since the closing days of January. One question is, What lies behind this price decline? The other is, Why hasn't the cost of living reflected the decline in agricultural prices to a greater extent than it has?

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 9 -Arthur M. Loew, vice president of Loew's, Inc., and chief of the company's international subsidiary, today told the company's film salesmen, who are in convention at the M-G-M studio here, that the foreign film market has not fully disappeared.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Danny Gardella said tonight that Mickey Owen, who also was banned from organized baseball for jumping to the Mexican League, had urged him to drop his $300,000 damage suit.

The seven-story fifty-one-family apartment house at 181 East 161st Street, the Bronx, has been sold by Wilbar Associates, Inc., to the Janesteel Realty Corporation, represented by Schiff, Dorfman, Stein Broff, attorneys. Pearce Mayer-were the brokers.

PARIS, Feb. 9 -- The Louis Fifteenth epoque subtly influences Molyneux's collection, which is, nevertheless, most modern, simple and youthful. This influence is felt in Watteau necklines with a deep volant of chantilly, in the double reticule bags matching gowns, in the enormous pockets on suits, some of them reaching to the jacket hemline.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 9 (UP) -Lewis L. Strauss, member of the Atomic Energy Commission, said tonight that "virtually all" secret atomic energy work was being done in Government laboratories, while universities and industry carried out non-secret research.
A promoter whose "pious talking left misery wherever he went" was sentenced yesterday to ten to twenty years in state prison for obtaining $21,000 in a fake realty development scheme.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 9 -- John Abbink, co-chairman of the joint United States-Brazilian Economic Mission, presented his group's findings today to President a great factor toward attaining sailed for home on the liner Uruguay.

Reporting on 1948 operations of the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company, Inc., James DeCamp Wise, president, informed shareholders yesterday that employment, payrolls, production, sales and earnings reached new peaks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- President Truman and Secretary of State Dean Acheson have decided to appoint Dr. Philip C. Jessup, Professor of International Law at Columbia University, as a roving negotiator for the United States in future international conferences.

" THE SERVANT,"* by Robin Maugham, is the shortest novel of the year and "They Never Had It So Good," by Joseph Gies, is the longest anecdote of the war. These two new books are brisk studies in evil, sin and general corruption, and we are happy to say that both authors take a very dim view indeed of such frailties of the flesh.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Personal income in 1948 reached a level of $214,000,000,000, an increase of 18,000,000,000 over the 1947 total, the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce reported today.

CAIRO, Feb. 9 -- Reports of member states of the Eastern Mediterranean of the World Health Organization submitted to the religion's first conference here have disclosed that almost the whole area is infected with energy-draining diseases.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Senate once more is about to perform the function which our system of government imposes on and expects of it. This function is to improve legislation which has been rushed through the House by the political force of the Administration.

General unrest and sabotage are increasing throughout Central Europe and when the time is "ripe" the whole area will "blow up" in the face of the Russians, Dr. Joseph Cerny, former Minister of Interior of Czechoslovakia declared yesterday.

The Cardinal's Committee of the Laity, named in connection with the thirtieth annual drive of the Catholic Charities of New York, which opened Monday, will seek to raise $800,000 of the 1949 goal of $2,500,000, it was announced yesterday by John A. Coleman, executive chairman, at an organization meeting of the special gifts committee of the Cardinal's laity Committee in the Empire State Club, Empire State Building.

Archie Herzoff has been appointed studio advertising and promotion manager for Universal-International by David A. Lipton, advertising and publicity director. Herzoff will move to Universal from Columbia, where he had been studio advertising executive handling basic campaign approaches since June, 1946.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The major share of the $4,280,000,000 which the Economic Cooperation Administration has requested of Congress to run the European Recovery Program through the fiscal year starting July 1 would go into Great Britain, France, Western Germany and Italy.

The fourteen-week-old strike against the Roger Smith Hotel in White Plains ended yesterday with an agreement between the hotel management and the president of the striking hotel workers to submit all matters in dispute to an impartial arbitrator for settlement.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Robert N. Denham, in charge of the administrative functions of the National Labor Relations Board, declared today that the only modification he would make in the Taft-Hartley Act would be in the section dealing with union security.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 9Florida Agricultural and Mechanical College held a formal groundbreaking ceremony today for its $2,000,000 hospital, health center and nursingschool building, which will be the most expensive building ever constructed on a Negro college campus in the county.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Administration spokesmen fighting for Congressional enactment of legislation giving broad economic powers to President Truman contended firmly today that recent declines in consumer prices did not measurably change the threat of inflation.

Attempts to find out whether the $25 assessment voted in secret session by the House of Delegates of the American Medical Association without referring the matter to their constituent societies was obligatory have been made directly to the authorities of the American Medical Association in Chicago.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Administration moved today to shore up farm prices, ordering an investigation of the commodity market slump, which it attributed in part to "speculative influences."

The showing that Arnold Constable presented in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday noon had an international flavor. There were a goodly number of British woolens in conservatively modish style, the Dior collar and swing-back short jacket gave zest to many a spring and summer outfit, and there were good New York fashions in woolens, cottons and pure silks geared to the figures of matron and junior.

A rupture in the Richmond County Republican organization between the leadership of Edward A. Ruppel, county chairman, and a group headed by former Representative Ellsworth B. Buck and former State Senator Robert E. Johnson came to the surface yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -Vice President Alben W. Barldey today was added to the list of Jefferson-Jackson Victory Day dinner speakers Feb. 24. He will speak in San Francisco. Before making his address, the Democratic National Committee ad, I%{r. Barkley will speak or five minutes at the start of a halfhour national broadcast of Presi-[ dent Truman's talk from a Washington dinner. The program here starts at 10:30 P. r_ .
MOSCOW, Feb. 9 (UP) -- The New Times said today that President Truman and Secretary of State Dean Acheson were pursuing a "hypocritical" foreign policy aimed at war.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 9 -- Armed's return to the races and Delegate's near-record victory in the $11,975 Seminole Handicap provided the big moments of the Hialeah Park proceedings today.

OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 9 -- The Permanente Metals Corporation, through its sales affiliate, the Permanente Products Company, opened today its aluminum wire and cable production schedules to all users of aluminum electrical conductor throughout the country.

There are always many things one can say about a great artist, but perhaps the outstanding aspect of Isaac Stern's recital last night at Carnegie Hall was that, no matter which of the five composers he was playing, one felt one was listening to the outpouring of a human spirit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Air Force will ask Congress tomorrow for authority to erect a $161,000,000 radar aircraft warning network providing "irreducible minimum" protection against enemy air attacks on the United States.

ROME, Feb. 9 -- The Vatican today released the text of a letter sent by Pope Pius on Jan. 2 to the Hungarian Episcopate protesting against Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty's arrest, which had occurred the week before, and urging all Hungarian Bishops and Archbishops to pray for their persecutors but to stand firm against persecution.
ROME, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial translation of the letter sent Jan. 2 by Pope Pius XII to the Hungarian Bishops on the arrest of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty:

BUDAPEST, Feb. 9 (UP) -The Hungarian Government has charged a United States Legation official with helping Hungarians flee the country and has ordered him to leave within twenty-four hours, authoritative sources said tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The voice of "Axis Sally" told United States women listeners in a 1943 Nazi broadcast that the war made Hitler "very, very unhappy."

Lilli Palmer is making her American stage debut in "My Name Is Aquilon," which was acted at the Lyceum last evening. That practically exhausts the good news for this morning. Although the Theatre Guild has produced it, "My Name Is Aquilon" is one of the most superfluous social events of the winter season -better than Sacha Guitry, but not much better.

ALBANY, N. Y., Feb. 9 -- The Public Service Commission today approved a revised scale of charges proposed by the New York Central Railroad for coach seat reservations on all its reserved-seat coach trains. The new scale is a substitute for one proposed earlier by the road but suspended by the commission.

An expanded program of adult education, designed to promote "friendship and understanding among all the peoples of the world," is being mapped by the New School for Social Research, which today observes the thirtieth anniversary of its founding.

With storage facilities filled virtually to capacity, the Creole Petroleum Corporation announced yesterday that it has reduced its Venezuelan crude oil output by about 100,000 barrels a day. The company said the reduction brought output to about 15 per cent below the post-war peak of 652,000 barrels daily but that it still is above the average of 500,000 barrels daily produced at the beginning of 1946.

The contract bridge contest for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup entered its third day of play at the Hotel Pierre last night with thirty-two teams, survivors from a starting field of fifty-two, paired in knockout matches of thirty-two deals each.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 9 -- A brilliant display of electric lighting in honor of Thomas A. Edison, long this town's first citizen and inventor of the first commercially practical electric light, is attracting thousands of motorists nightly to the civic center in Main Street here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson scathingly denounced the Hungarian Government in a statement today for its trial and sentencing to life imprisonment of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty. The Secretary called the action a "conscienceless attack upon religious and personal freedom" that "sickened and horrified" the people of the United States and of other freedom-loving nations.

The United States Court of Appeals directed the Federal District Court yesterday to determine whether the televising and radio broadcasting of games had brought organized baseball within the scope of the anti-trust laws and whether it had violated those laws.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Feb. 9 -- Active preparations are under way by the United States and Britain to place civilian military government personnel under the German economy. Preliminary conversations among British officials in Luebbecke today will be continued with United States officials tomorrow in Frankfort.

The Sylvania division of American Viscose Corporation will expand its capacity for cellophane to bring annual output up to 100,000,000 pounds, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Frank H. Reichel, president. The expansion program will be completed in about two years, he said, and will double current production at the Sylvania plant in Fredericksburg, Va., making it the largest single cellophane unit in the world.

Steadiness crept into the stock market yesterday for the first time in almost a week. Assisted by the moderate recovery in the commodities after the recent sharp plunges, the share list made its best gain since the first of the month, the composite rate rising 0.66 point on the day.

Louis Hollander, president of the State Congress of Industrial Organizations, challenged Governor Dewey yesterday to prove that he was "something more than a banquet-table liberal" by supporting CIO proposals for payment of benefits to sick workers within the framework of the State Unemployment Insurance Law.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Any hopes that the quarrel between Moscow and Belgrade might cause the Soviet Union to withdraw its support from Yugoslavia's claims against Austria were dispelled today when the Deputies of the Big Four Foreign Ministers resumed their discussions of a peace treaty with Austria.

Eight women, the first of 680 German men and women selected to visit this country under the German Reorientation Program, will arrive in New York some time this month. They will spend two months observing Governmental functions from town meetings to Congressional committees, and will return to Germany to stimulate democratic activity among German women.

Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, told Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson yesterday that the city department would need an additional $16,401,379 for maintenance of the "overcrowded" hospitals in the fiscal year to begin July 1.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Co-medalists Peggy Kirk of Findlay, Ohio, and Marjorie Lindsay of Decatur, Ill., won their first-round matches in the twenty-fourth annual Palm Beach golf tournament today.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty will remain in his Budapest prison until his appeal from a life sentence is decided, a Government spokesman said tonight.

Strong response to his offer to buy $600,000 worth of off-price men's wear merchandise for his stores' sixtieth birthday sale on Feb. 28 was reported yesterday by Henry Modell, sporting goods retailer operating five stores here.

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company announced yesterday that net income last year amounted to $903,512, contrasted with a loss of $216,260 for 1947. Share earnings amounted to $1.21 each in 1948; in the preceding year the loss amounted to 29 cents a share.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- The inquiry ordered by Secretary of Agriculture Charles E. Brannan into the market break on the Chicago Board of Trade Monday and Tuesday stirred little reaction among major grain traders in Chicago today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 9 (UP) -- West Coast exporters and importers stand ready to do business with a Communist regime in China.

If next Monday seems less blue and the weather like June, though the thermometer may tell of winter, the calendar will show why. Mail boxes may provide an answer trimmed with red hearts and paper lace. And love may lurk in a rose, because it is Saint Valentine's Day.

Carey McWilliams has won one of the five Thomas Jefferson Prizes for the Advancement of Democracy for 1948. The award was made for his book "A Mask for Privilege: Anti-Semitism in America," which was issued by Little, Brown. The presentations are made annually by the Council Against Intolerance in America.

Awards for building and engineering construction work in the New York metropolitan area last month amounted to $54,232,000. The total comprised non-residential projects costing $24,217,000, residential contracts aggregating $20,859,000 and heavy engineering jobs of $9,156,000.

Tommy Henrich, "the ball players' ball player," will start his tenth playing season with the Yankees this year as "the fourth highest paid player" in the Bombers' history of numerous well remunerated hired hands.

The Feb. 8 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES carries an editorial entitled "Power of 'Seizure' " which comments on the testimony of William H. Davis before the Senate Labor Committee. In his testimony Mr. Davis advocated a Federal statute giving the President power to seize plants when a national emergency strike threatens.

The Bronx High School of Science was established eleven years ago and since then its teachers have had only one major complaint--often it is difficult and sometimes impossible to keep students from coming to school too early, or from staying too late.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Business men who have become alarmed at the unexpected return of strong German competition in world markets received assurances from two British Ministers in the House of Commons today that unfair trade practices by Germany would be effectively curbed.

BOSTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins celebrated Coach Dit Clapper's forty-second birthday anniversary by outskating the Chicago Black Hawks for a 5-3 victory tonight before 13,200 at the Boston Garden. It was the last-place visitors' fourth straight National Hockey League setback.

A rural medical center, under the sponsorship of New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, will be established, with the financial aid of the Federal Government, in Hunterdon County, N. J., it was announced yesterday.

MANILA, Feb. 9 -- Growing Philippine concern over Communist victories in China and their implications is reflected here in assertions that the Filipinos will actively seek a revision of the military assistance treaty with the United States looking toward expanded defense plans and more modern equipment for the local armed forces.

Some important Southern bedroom furniture factories are curtailing production and will not resume capacity operations until current substantial inventories are liquidated, manufacturers' representatives and retailers reported yesterday.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 9 -- Sailfishing has now taken a decided upswing, and if the present trend continues until Sunday, closing day of the Silver Sailfish Derby, the totals may approach last year's record catch.

A suggestion that independent retail grocers increase funds for advertising to "at least a minimum of 1 per cent of gross sales" is being urged by the New York State Food Merchants Association, it was learned here yesterday.

The State of Oregon announced yesterday that it will receive bids on Feb. 28 on an issue of $3,000,000 veterans' welfare bonds dated April 1, 1949, due on April 1, 1961, and callable on April 1, 1954. Interest must not exceed 2 per cent.

Reflecting the 20 per cent larger sales volume, net earnings of the Union Bag and Paper Corporation last year reached a new high record of $13,607,780, increasing 16 per cent over the $11,756,608 earned in 1947, Alexander Calder, president and board chairman, reported in the preliminary annual statement released today.

PARIS, Feb. 9 -- The French Government cannot accept inclusion of Berlin as a twelfth state in the projected autonomous Western Germany, as approved by the German constitution makers in Bonn, a spokesman for the Quai d'Orsay said today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were active again yesterday and prices rose 39 to 58 points above Tuesday's final levels.

An irregular plot about 100 by 209 feet at the southeast corner of Parsons Boulevard and Eightyninth Avenue in Jamaica, Queens, containing two dwellings, has been purchased by Herbert H. Pensig and others from Fairchild Sons, Inc.
Two practitioners of a "cure" for the effects of a mysterious "evil eye" and its attendant maladies went out of business yesterday when detectives threw the switch on their nonexistent "ray machine."
The 10,280-ton combination passenger-cargo vessel Dalerdyk of the Holland-America Line is due here today on her initial post-war voyage with forty-six passengers from Antwerp.
A parade of Easter suits by Paul Parnes was presented by Sada Sacks of 671 Madison Avenue during luncheon yesterday at the Pierre Hotel.

A strike of 400 station agents and maintenance men on the Hudson Manhattan Railroad, all members of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, went into effect at 11 o'clock last night. Trains continued running, however. The strike was called in protest against the scheduled discharge of forty-nine employes.

Mohawk Carpet Mills, Inc., yesterday increased prices of many of its major running carpet lines on an average of 2 per cent. The company said that no advances will be made on some grades. Substantially higher carpet wool costs were cited as the reason for the increases.
NEW DELHI, India, Thursday, Feb. 10 -- Nathuram Vinayak Godse was sentenced today to hang for the slaying of Mohandas K. Gandhi on Jan. 30, 1948.
LONDON, Feb. 9 -- The United States will have to make two important decisions when the North Atlantic pact is consummated. Those decisions, affecting the defense of Western Europe, are these:
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 9 (AP) -- A new campaign against the hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church in Czechoslovakia was discernible today in the wake of the Mindszenty case.

GENEVA, Feb. 9 -- The United States has advised the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe that the export of steel scrap from Western Germany to Eastern Europe is possible under bilateral agreements.

A Frugal Country Town One of the marvels of suburban development is that the Town of North Castle, 213 years old and only thirty-five miles from Times Square, has remained rural in character. A little larger than Manhattan Island, it sprawls across the "reservoir country" of Central Westchester.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The United States has proposed to Canada and the Brussels Treaty powers that two changes be made in the draft of the North Atlantic security pact.

The chief witness for the eleven Communist leaders in their attack on the Federal jury system admitted yesterday he had misstated statistics affecting the proportion of manual workers on juries. The witness was Prof. Doxey Wilkerson of the Jefferson School of Social Studies in this city.

SEATTLE, Feb. 9 -- The way was paved by a state legislative committee last spring and summer for discipling of University of Washington faculty members. On Jan. 22 the university's board of regents dismissed three faculty members and placed three on two-year probation.

Dr. Izaak Werfel, head of the immigration department of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, the ruling body of the world Zionist movement, said yesterday that the agency had set a goal of 250,000 Jews for immigration into Israel this year.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 9 -- Western Allied and German officials, in fear that anti-German sentiment in the United States might interfere with the western German industries fair planned for April 9 to 24 in the New York Museum of Science and Industry, are trying to guard against the participation of any German whose record is not clear.
WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Baseball Commissioner A. B. (Happy) Chandler said tonight that "no major leaguer makes less than $5,000 a year and some make up to $100,000."

The way was cleared yesterday for a contractual wage review for three warehousemen's locals of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, when an arbitration decision was handed down in favor of the workers.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 9 -- Handcuffed to a deputy sheriff, Robert Mitchum of the films, 31 years old, was taken to the country jail today to serve two months for his participation in a marijuana smoking party in the Hollywood hills last Sept. 1.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 9 -- A spokesman for the United States delegation to the United Nations, which had been reported as studying what steps might be taken to bring the case before the world peace agency, declared tonight that any mention of United States intentions should emphasize that Washington was only "considering" possible moves with nothing specific in mind at this stage.

The corner grocery is closed, the refrigerator practically bare and guests have arrived unexpectedly at dinner time. This is a situation to unnerve any housewife unless she's an adherent of the Boy Scouts' motto, "Be Prepared." In that case she'll have tucked away in the kitchen cabinet a few well-chosen canned and packaged foods of the sort noted in a recent tour of city shops.

The Esso Zurich, first of fourteen 26,555-deadweight ton "super-tankers" under construction for the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) made her initial appearance in this harbor yesterday with a full cargo of oil from Corpus Christi, Tex.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 9 -- The mushroom growth of Protestant parochial schools and its ultimate effect on the public education system of this country was warmly debated here today by delegates attending the annual meeting of the International Council of Religious Education.
The Salvation Army Bushwick Boys Club in Brooklyn, with its well-equipped interior and broad character-building program, has a membership of 850 and a long waiting list.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Legislation extending for four months, until July 1, the power of the Maritime Commission to sell, charter and operate ships was approved today by the House Merchant Marine Committee.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Sam Carr, one of the leading figures in the Soviet Canadian-wartime spy ring, was ordered deported to the Dominion today, along with his wife.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- A change in the state insurance laws to permit the purchase of "package policies" covering practically every type of insurance written by a single fire or casualty company was proposed in a bill introduced today by Senator MacNeil Mitchell of Manhattan and Assemblyman William H. MacKenzie of Allegany County.
A novelist, a labor leader and a rabbi presented their views on democracy last night in THE NEW YORK TIMES radio forum, "What's On Your Mind?" over WQXR.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Transamerica Corporation, San Francisco, "has nothing to worry about under this proceeding," Marriner S. Eccles, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, said today at hearings on the board's anti-trust proceedings against the huge holding company.

Ljuba Welitsch, who gave a super-heated performance of Salome in her debut last Friday night, took on the name part of "Aida" as her second role at the Metropolitan Opera last night. And she did it again. She sang and acted like an artist and conquered just as thoroughly as she did with Salome.

In the interest of home-town reputation I am driven to comment on your story on Page 12 in the issue of Jan. 31 on the high water peril on the Mississippi Vaney. I am referring particularly to the map and that part of the story which lists the major expenditures for reduction of flood losses.

TEL AVIV, Feb. 9 -- Judgment in the case of Nathan Friedman-Yellin, former head of the Stern group, will be given by a military court in Acre tomorrow. He is accused of conducting a terrorist organization and participating in its activities.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Two non-union workers sued a union for $50,000 each today, charging they lost their jobs because of the union's closed-shop policy.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 9 -- Sir Basil Brooke, Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, offered today to cooperate with the Irish Republic in "a common defense policy" as long as Ulster's position as a member of the British Commonwealth was not affected.

The code of military justice submitted to Congress by Defense Secretary Forrestal includes many improvements, over the present codes of the three services, in addition to possessing the major advantage of uniformity. It still does not include the one basic reform urged by every civilian group that the armed services have appointed to advise them -- namely, separation of courts-martial from command and placement in an independent Judge Advocate General's office.

Frank Sinatra announced yesterday his decision not to return to the cast of NBC's "Your Hit Parade" next season, according to a report by The United Press from Hollywood. The singer was said to have described his leave-taking from the American Tobacco Company, sponsor of the Saturday night program at 9, as "friendly," and based on a desire for a program more readily convertible to television.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey asked President Truman today to consider returning Federal port facilities at Hoboken and Bayonne to state control as a means of reviving waning commerce and aiding the municipalities.

The nation's gasoline stock last week increased 2,199,000 barrels to a new peak of 117,169,000, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A week earlier they amounted to 114,970,000 barrels, the previous peak, and a year earlier 105,100,000.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Overseas earnings of British insurance companies in 1947 are estimated by the British Insurance Association, which represents nearly 200 companies, at 33,000,000 ($132,000,000), consisting of underwriting profits of 19,000,000 and interest of 14,000,000.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 9 -- A three-man board of prominent military government officials was named today to "supervise and direct" the operation of the United States Military Government's German language newspaper Neue Zeitung.

In a ceremony starting an unusual pre-campaign drive for immediate funds to meet emergency needs overseas, a $300,000 check was presented yesterday to the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York by the Refugee Relief Fund of the Coat and Suit Industry.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Although the stock market here today seemed to have a more settled look after recent "touchiness," public interest remained at low ebb and prices began to ease again toward the close.

Lloyd Paul Stryker will represent Alger Hiss, it was learned yesterday, when the former State Department official is tried on a perjury indictment returned last Dec. 15 by a special Federal grand jury investigating subversive activities.
More than 600,000 pennies were forced to remain idle in New Yorkers' pockets and purses yesterday.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 9 -- After more than a week of changes and postponements the Shanghai preliminary peace delegation was again ordered by telephone from Peiping this morning to delay its trip to the Communist-controlled city two more days.

BERLIN, Feb. 9 -- A Polish naval patrol in the Baltic took thirteen German-operated fishing trawlers into custody nearly three weeks ago and nothing has been heard officially since of their whereabouts.
Americans of other faiths were asked yesterday by Cardinal Spellman to support an international crusade against communism.

For successive Saturdays little Willie Slykhuis, Holland's best miler, and a good one, has been suffering through horrific renditions of what track meet bands have thought was his country's anthem, "Wilhelm von Nassau." Willie says most of them have sounded as if they were playing "Yankee Doodle Dandy."
A pyramid of mortgages, six on one property and eleven on another, was discovered yesterday in a continuing investigation of the $22,000,000 Samuel Broxmeyer realty interests.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- A $400,000 lump-sum, tax-free payment to Eleanor M. Patterson's daughter today ended the contest over Mrs. Patterson's will.

A strong recovery in commodities on the various exchanges here yesterday partly offset the sharp reversals of Tuesday. Generally, the markets opened in a continuance of the down trend of the previous day but late rallies steadied prices and gains were recorded at the close.

KODIAK, Alaska, Feb. 8 (Delayed) -- St. Paul's Harbor, Zomenbds Bay and the ice-fringed shores of English Bay were emptied of ships tonight as vessels of the Navy's First Task Fleet with 2,000 Marines aboard steamed seaward toward the first of two amphibious landings on this island's rocky coasts.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- A bill to provide stricter regulation of automobile driver schools to correct abuses uncovered during a two-year investigation by Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein was introduced today under sponsorship of the Joint Legislative Committee on Motor Vehicle Problems.
CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- Despite a recent setback, Joe Louis said here today that he was "still interested in the beer business or any other that offers the possibilities of a profit."

Both local and national bar association officials were sharply critical yesterday of what were termed "inadequacies" in the uniform military justice code as presented to Congress Tuesday by James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 9--Lieut. Gen. Simon Bolivar Buckner, who was killed by a Japanese shellburst on Okinawa in 1945, was buried at the foot of his father's grave today in historic Frankfort Cemetery.

The predominantly foreign-operating International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation edged into the television field yesterday. Col. Sosthenes Behn, 67-year-old founder and chairman of the $515,000,000 communications system, and a majority of the board of directors approved a plan to purchase the Farnsworth Television and Radio Corporation following a two-hour-and-forty-five-minute regular monthly meeting which ended at 2:30 P. M.

KEARNY, N. J., Feb. 9 -- Daniel Noble, surprised beneficiary of a big chunk of the estate of an estranged brother, said here today that he intended to stick at his $50-a-week job with the Hudson County Road Department even though he was getting on in years.

The trial of Cardinal Mindszenty was stage-managed in all its details from Moscow, Msgr. Bela Varga, self-exiled president of the Hungarian Parliament, charged here yesterday. He declared the Russians were using the trial as a weapon in a determined effort to intimidate the Hungarian people and to break the power of the Catholic Church in Hungary.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 2:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey discussed proposed St. Lawrence power development and the prospective selection of a new Republican state chairman with members of the New York Republican Congressional delegation at breakfast today.

Lee Savold, Des Moines, Iowa, heavyweight, via Paterson, N. J., returned to this country from England yesterday on the liner Queen Mary, and proceeded immediately to pose Promoter Harry Markson of the Twentieth Century S. C. with a problem.

Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, in a policy speech before the Wings Club yesterday, described the huge Consolidated-Vultee B-36 bomber as the weapon upon which the Air Force would depend most in the next war if one were fought within five or six years.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Feb. 9 -A drive for 10,000 new members of the Church Mission of Help Youth Consultation Service of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island will begin on Valentine's Day, Supreme Court Justice Charles S. Colden of Whitestone, Queens, drive chairman, announced today.

After thirteen years of faithful and valuable service on the state Board of Regents, Miss Susan Brandeis, daughter of the late Supreme Court Justice, has received her reward at the hands of Republican legislators. In joint session yesterday Senate and Assembly replaced Miss Brandeis with a Republican.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Senate Rules Committee approved today by a vote of 10 to 3 a proposed tightening of its closure procedure, a first step toward approval of President Truman's civil rights program. Indications were that the Senate would begin to grapple with the amendment within three weeks, with a bipartisan majority favoring it and the Southerners arrayed against it.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 9 -- Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, asked for a decision today by the Federal Post Office Department on whether it will continue to block a $5,500,000 state-financed public housing project here by refusing to vacate a dilapidated garage building that occupies a small, although vital, part of the site.

Your article of Feb. 2, in which you account the reaction of a number of American philosophers to the invitation extended to them to attend the First National Congress of Philosophy in Mendoza, Argentina, conveys, it seems to me, two wrong impressions. It seems as though the invitation had been extended to but nine American philosophers, and as though every one who had been invited had turned down the invitation categorically.

The American Red Cross, with the aid of the Advertising Council, Inc., will conduct one of its most intensive peacetime advertising campaigns in connection with its annual fund drive, it was announced yesterday by Howard Bonham, ARC vice president for public relations.
MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Feb. 10 (UP) -A embittered Danny Gardella said today, 't's just too bad if my case is huting baseball because I've been Hurt pretty badly myself."

A. E. Bollengier has been appointed treasurer of both Eagle-Lion Films and Eagle-Lion Studios, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Arthur B. Krim, president of the companies. Mr. Bollengier, who was controller of Eagle-Lion Studios for the last two years, formerly served as assistant controller at Universal.

"Freedom of Information," by Herbert Brucker, an answer to critics of the morals of our free press, will be brought out by Macmillan on March 15. Mr. Brucker, editor of The Hartford Courant and author of "The Changing American Newspaper," believes that the press must remain free to act as a check on government and that high standards of journalism will offset the dangers of "policy" in the owners.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Lieut. Gen. Raymond A. Wheeler denied today that the Army Corps f Engineers, which he heads, had inspired the flood of telegrams addressed to Congress asking that the corps be exempted from the purview of Presidential reorganization powers.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 -- The grain markets in the Board of Trade fluctuated widely today and the undertone was nervous. Prices ranged higher as the result of more aggressive buying and a let-up in liquidation. Wheat and corn at the extreme were 16 cents a bushel above yesterday's low points; rye was up 17 1/2 cents, and soy beans, 17 cents.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 10 -- The Evangelical and Reformed Church is making a distinct contribution toward "healing of nations," Dr. Henry C. Koch of St. Louis, executive secretary of the denomination's Commission on World Service, reported today at the concluding session of the General Council.
The temporary withdrawal from service of 110 of the 170 new streamlined subway cars recently purchased by the city was announced last night by William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Department store sales in the week ended Feb. 5 were 4 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported tonight. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:
LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 10 -- Russia's demand for a Big Five accounting of all troops and arms was rejected today by the United Nations Security Council.

CALCUTTA, India, Feb. 10 -- Rangoon has become a frontline city, according to arrivals here. Armed guards patrol the streets day and night; lorry loads of troops stream north to battle for Insein, a suburb of the capital, while in the opposite direction refugees in jeeps, trucks, pony-carts and on foot, unwashed, unkempt and dazed, flood into Rangoon.
ROME, Feb. 10 -- Italy will press for restitution of all her four pre-Fascist colonies, undertaking to administer each in a different way according to local conditions.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 10 -- A 5-year-old mare named Bab's Damion, running in a $12,000 claimer, barely missed equaling Hialeah Park's turf course mark for a mile and a furlong today. She scored by about five lengths, paid better than 9 to 1 and was timed in 1:51 3-5, only a fifth of a second over the record.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 10 -- Warner Brothers announced today that Jack L. Warner, studio production chief, has scheduled a film based on the trial of Cardinal Mindszenty, the Hungarian prelate condemned to life imprisonment by a People's Court in his Communist-dominated country, for immediate production.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 10 -- A group of Negro educators, physicians and nurses established an informal "activation committee" today to enlist country-wide support of proposed Congressional legislation that would add $22,000,000 in Federal allotments for hospital construction in all states.

PARIS, Feb. 10 -- A radio attack by Moscow on France today because of her prospective adherence to the Atlantic Pact, plus the interview of the three Scandinavian Ambassadors with Foreign Minister Robert Schuman to discuss the defense alliance, have caused marked anxiety here.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- President Truman declared today that the treatment of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty in Hungary was "infamous" and would go down in history as a black spot on that country.

Imbued with diplomatic tendencies, Robert Morley, co-author and leading actor of "Edward, My Son," has brought his persuasive powers to bear on Gilbert Miller, co-producer of the hit. At Mr. Morley's insistence, the well-known producer will become an actor once more -- for one performance only -at the American National Theatre and Academy's gala "Album Benefit," to be given March 6 at the Ziegfeld.

Aircraft manufactured exclusively for war purposes cannot be classified as "goods for commerce," Federal Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in Federal Court, Brooklyn, ruled yesterday in denying overtime pay to twenty-six employes or former employes of the Republic Aviation Corporation.

United States foreign policy, as now applied in China, covers the period of transition between the disintegration of the Kuomintang movement and the final crystallization of a new situation resulting from the swift and successful advance of communism.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Chinese Communists have branded thirty-seven more Chinese Government officials and supporters as "war criminals," it was learned today.

DUBLIN, Feb. 10 -- While the last votes were being cast in the ballot boxes in Belfast, Premier John A. Costello of Eire, former Premier Eamon de Valera and representatives of all parties in the Republic, issued a statement tonight characterizing the Ulster election as a fraud and undemocratic.
If freedom is not talked about, we will not have it to pass on to future generations, Dr. John A. Krout, acting director of Columbia's School of General Studies, said yesterday.

The Board of Estimate approved yesterday the smoke-control bill passed recently by the City Council. The legislation calls for the creation of a board of smoke control in the Department of Housing and Buildings. The measure now goes to Mayor O'Dwyer for consideration.

VIENNA, Feb. 10 -- Laszlo Suller and his wife, Hannah Fischer, two well-known handwriting experts who testified in Budapest last week that documents unearthed by Hungarian political police in the cellar of the palace of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty were genuine and that his later "confession" was not written under duress, have arrived in the United States zone of Austria. The two admitted today that they themselves had testified under duress.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -President Truman today nominated Alfred E. Modarelli to be United States Attorney for New Jersey.
LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 10 -- The Republic of Indonesia complained today to the United Nations Security Council that the Netherlands was continuing military action in Indonesia.

The city's new Traffic Commission will require at least $200,000 for its first full year of operation, it was indicated yesterday when the Board of Estimate appropriated $80,000 "to enable it to begin functioning at the earliest possible date."

One day last summer a woman boarded a bus at Fifth Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street. She bought a transfer to the Twenty-third Street bus and asked the driver to tell her when to get off. At almost every stop she asked, "Is this Twenty-third Street?" Finally, he told her she had reached her destination.

PARIS, Friday, Feb. 11 -- In a letter appearing in today's issue of Figaro, which is publishing the French version of Winston Churchill's memoirs, Gen. Maurice-Gustave Gamelin both disputed and supplemented the account Mr. Churchill gave of a meeting of May 16, 1940, in Paris.

A demonstration of the way in which floral and leaf designs on fabrics and wallpapers can add a fresh, informal feeling to the home may be seen in the exhibition of home furnishings at the studio of A. K. Bartholomew, 124 East Thirtieth Street.

Refusing to accept the evidence unfolded before their very eyes, or through the channels of the airwaves or the daily prints, some 18,000 fans will pack Madison Square Garden tonight to see the fifteen-round featherweight championship fight between titleholder Sandy Saddler of Harlem and Willie Pep, veteran gladiator from Hartford, Conn.

The state Congress of Industrial Organizations has paid $10,000 in debts and rejected $4,600 in other "political expenditures" of the defunct city CIO council, dissolved three months ago by the national CIO, it was reported last night.

Many citizens who have had contact with our diplomatic representatives abroad will dissent vigorously from the view expressed by G. Di Rosa in regard to their need of foreign languages. It is true that it takes time and money to learn languages properly, but may we not demand that those who wish the privilege of representing the United States in other lands be adequately equipped, irrespective of cost?

The Export-Import Bank has refused to grant a request from the Radio Manufacturers Association for loans to Latin American countries with unfavorable dollar balances for the specific purpose of building television broadcasting facilities with American technical standards.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Soviet insistence that the proposed Austrian peace treaty require Austria to repatriate refugees and displaced persons from her territory -- even against their will -- brought the second day of treaty talks here to eventless close. United States, British and French delegates stood fast in opposing the Russian suggestion and in refusing to accept the principle of "involuntary repatriation."
Working on the principle of turnabout is fair play, the Chicago Black Hawks dropped the New York Rangers back into the cellar of the National Hockey League at Madison Square Garden last night.

The report of Warner Bros. Pictures, Inc. and its subsidiaries, released for publication today, disclosed a net profit of $3,093,742 after all deductions including $2,000,000 provision for Federal income taxes, for the quarter ended on Nov. 27 last.
The city's efforts to rent municipally-owned waterfront properties in racket-ridden areas have borne fruit in the leasing of two North River piers, it was disclosed yesterday.

Another Big Four conference on Austria is under way. But if there has been any change in those Soviet policies which led to a breakdown of previous negotiations on Austria and then to the whole "cold war," that change is still to be revealed. Indeed, the new conference opens with another Soviet attempt to impose peace on Soviet terms.

Leopold Stokowski continued to follow the procedure that loads his programs with non-controversial -not to say superficial -- music last night, when he conducted the Philharmonic-Symphony at Carnegie Hall.

Dr. John G. Lipani, eye specialist, has purchased the three-story building at 921 President Street, Brooklyn, containing sixteen rooms and two baths, from Philip Vary and will occupy it as his home and office. The Charles Partridge Real Estate Company, broker in this transaction, also reported the sale of the three - story two - family house at 382 Vanderbilt Avenue for Mrs. Regina C. Valentine to Giossi Malafonte.

MOLINE, Ill., Feb. 10 (UP) -Some 300 members of the rival CIO Farm Equipment and United Auto Workers unions battled at the gates of the International Harvester plant late today. Twenty-two men were injured. Brass knuckles were said to have been used.

PEIPING, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Press Workers Association today demanded the expulsion of Spencer Moosa of The Associated Press and Michael Keon, United Press correspondent, and called on the Military Control Committee in this Communist-occupied city to "put an end to all work of reactionary American journalists and illegal activities of the American Consulate and United States Information Service."

Everything happening along the perishable food front this week has been in the consumer's favor. Steer beef dropped at wholesale to the lowest levels since the start of price regulations in 1942; at retail eight different cuts of that meat declined from 2 to 4 cents a pound, according to the City Department of Markets.
TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 10 (AP) -Officials of the American Bowling Congress today promised a "thorough re-examination" of the "white male" rule restricting participation in congress tournaments.
LONDON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The British, who like a wager, are going to look into their $4,000,000,000-a-year gambling habits.

Bank examiners now give too much attention to auditing, according to Richard Rapport, Connecticut bank commissioner. Mr. Rapport, who spoke yesterday at the Savings Bank Conference on Operations, Audit and Control, at the Hotel Commodore, urged wider adoption of internal auditing systems by banks.

A collection of hand-made pitchers, bowls and ash trays by the concern of Alexandre of Wemmel, Belgium, was introduced yesterday at Stern Brothers. Distinctive decorations are made of strands of clay that have been braided to form handles on pitchers, "laced" along the tops of bowls or woven like wicker to form intricate borders on vases.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 10 -As a center of the fashion industry, New York has been caught in a "squeeze" between Paris and California because of high-speed transportation between continents and a national trend toward informality in living, it was reported today in a survey prepared by Dr. Charles S. Goodman for the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Michigan.

The first stake list for the New York horse racing season of 1949 was announced yesterday by the Metropolitan Jockey Club, which conducts the opening meeting of the local campaign at the Jamaica race track from April 1 to May 5. A total of twelve stakes with an aggregate value of $270,000 in purses and added money will be distributed through the period.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The tax increase issue was forced further toward the end of the legislative calendar today as liberalization of the Social Security system received first priority in the House Ways and Means Committee. Extensive hearings are to begin in about ten days.

With the addition of three more city hospitals and indigent patients in two voluntary hospitals to the ranks of recipients of free blood, the mammoth Red Cross blood-donor program will mark its first anniversary in May with a "successful and encouraging" momentum.

In response to many public requests, the Italian loan exhibition at the Wildenstein Galleries will be open to the public Sunday afternoon from 1:30 to 5:30. Beside the Donatello statue of St. Ludovico, lent by the City of Florence, 120 paintings by Italian nineteenth-century artists are being shown -- examples selected from public and private collections in Italy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, indicated today that he was prepared to agree to modification of the ban on the closed shop in the Taft-Hartley Law if something could be done to protect those who did not want to work under the exclusive requirements of the closed shop.

The United States senior golf team that will cross the ocean to compete against a British squad was announced yesterday by John G. Jackson, the captain and former president of the United States Golf Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--The "personal bias and prejudice" of Marriner S. Eccles, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, caused him to promote bank holding company legislation that would have "discriminated against the Transamerica Corporation" and benefited the Eccles' family banking interests, counsel for the corporation charged today.

The 1949 Plymouth cars, consisting of nine models, are lower, shorter and narrower than previous models yet are roomier, R. C. Somerville, general sales manager, Plymouth division, Chrysler Corporation, said yesterday at a preview showing and dealer meeting at the Astor Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Existing radar aircraft warning defenses were described by Air Force officials today as wholly inadequate for the security of the United States.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 10 (UP) -- Gen. Jose Mendes Ribeiro Norton de Matos announced tonight officially his withdrawal as Opposition candidate in the Presidential elections. He said he would continue the fight against the regime of Premier Antonio de Oliverira Salazar.

SEATTLE, Feb. 10 -- If the American Association of University Professors can show that the administration of the University Washington and its principles were "wrong" in the recent disciplining of six faculty members "we will be the first to want to see it," Dr. Raymond B. Allen, president of the university, declared today.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 10 -- The Georgia Senate today passed a voters' registration and qualification measure, 29 -- 17, after opponents of the bill charged during debate that "the sole purpose of the bill is to purge as many Negro voters as possible."

In preparation for the city election next November, Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran, New York County Republican Chairman, announced yesterday the appointment of a city-wide committee of Republicans to act as a liaison group with other parties and organizations to bring about fusion on a city ticket.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat, of Washington, said today he wanted to get the Army and Navy "out of competition" with the American merchant marine.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Dr. Edgar Reynolds Smith, chief of the physical chemistry section of the National Bureau of Standards, has won the 1949 Hillebrand Prize of the Washington section of the American Chemical Society, it was announced by Professor Charles E. White of the University of Maryland, section chairman, at a meeting here tonight.

The Government bond market made another impressive showing of strength yesterday. The list of long bonds without exception moved up by fractions ranging up to 5/32 point, with the result that most of them are approximating the peak prices of last year.

W. J. Duffy, Inc., floor covering and rug cleaning concern, has purchased the property at 19-21 Oakland Avenue, Jersey City, N. J. from the Crompton Food Products Company and will use it for warehouse purposes. The property comprises two one and two story attached buildings containing 20,000 square feet of space and an adjoining plot of land, 50 by 200 feet. Ludwin Lipton, Inc., were the brokers.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 10 (UP) -- Heavy drama and frenzied emotions came out on top tonight in Hollywood's nominations for "Oscar" honors of 1948.
For the first time in history, the domestic steel industry in January produced more than 8,000,000 tons of raw steel, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Burmese troops fought Karen rebels on the outskirts of Rangoon today while a strike of Government workers caused turmoil in the center of the city.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--The Government's top loyalty review board today rejected disloyalty charges against William W. Remington, who had been described before a Senate investigating committee as a Communist who supplied confidential wartime information to a courier of a Soviet spy ring.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Joe Chamaco of Mexico City won the national three-cushion billiard title tonight and qualified for tomorrow's world play-offs by defeating his fellow citizen, Miguel Marquez, Mexico City, 50 to 31, in fifty-two minutes. Chamaco's final standing was seven victories against one loss.

The list price of the Bendix Home Appliances, Inc., standard automatic washer will be reduced to $189.50 some time next week, it was learned in the trade yesterday.
