The appliance now retails for $219.50. Dealers feel that the price reduction will force other automatic washer producers to reduce their list prices and add that the price structure of conventional washers is threatened.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UP) -Eagle Scout George Barron, 15 years old, of Franklin, Va., smoothed down his unruly cowlick and grinned at the newsreel cameraman.
ALBANY, N. Y., Feb. 10 (AP) -A 2-cent fare increase has been approved by the Public Service Commission for two street railway lines operating from Yonkers to Mount Vernon and New York City.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 10 -- A high Arab source said today that representatives of the Arab states who met here last week-end had decided that proposals of the Conciliation Commission should not be considered separately by each state but should be of such a nature that they could be considered by all the Arab states as a unit.

The State Liquor Authority revoked yesterday the wholesale beer license of Canadian Ace Brewing Company, Albany, controlled by Alex Louis Greenberg, reputed "financial genius" of the Al Capone gang. The brewing company has its headquarters in Chicago and used the local license to distribute its beer in the Albany district.

Governor Dewey was charged yesterday with having ignored his administrative responsibility to an stimated 22,000 cerebral palsy victims in New York State by failing to provide sufficient increase in public funds for palsy clinics and facilities for training teachers for the handicapped.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein urged Governor Dewey today to lend his support to a measure to wipe out rackets among the so-called "non-profit" cemeteries, which comprise 70 per cent of the cemeteries in the state.

Thomas Kerrigan of the Ardsley C. C., eliminated top-seeded Doane Twombly, Short Hills, in a first-round match of the Metropolitan Class C squash racquets championship at the Downtown A. C. last night. Kerrigan's margin was 15 -- 12, 6 -- 15, 15 -- 8, 18 -- 16.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Irving K. Peck, vice resident and general manager of the Home Gas Company, which supplies natural gas to operating utilities in the southeastern part of New York State, urged the Public Service Commission at a public hearing today to modify its order prohibiting utilities from increasing the number of their customers using natural gas for home heating.

Development by the Economic Cooperation Administration of a simplified trade procedure to be used by nations participating in the European Recovery Program was urged yesterday by Gerald LeVino, president, Guiterman Company, Inc., and chairman of the foreign trade department of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.
GENEVA, Feb. 10 -- A crude steel output of 56,000,000 tons in Europe, outside the Soviet Union, is forecast for 1949.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- During the week ended Feb. 9, member bank reserve balances decreased $114,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Feb. 10 (AP) -- "I hope Danny Gardella loses his suit against baseball," Mickey Owen said today.

STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 10 -- The banking business shed some of its traditional dullness today for a group of school children participating in the first of a series of unusual programs by the Stamford Trust Company and local industries.

A plan by the city to construct a low-level bridge connecting Welfare Island and Queens County, thereby alleviating increasing traffic difficulties on the Queensboro Bridge, was disclosed here yesterday at a hearing before Col. W. W. Wanamaker, District Engineer, U. S. Army Corps of Engineers.

Karl Kritz, who has been an assistant conductor at the Metropolitan Opera during the past five seasons, got his chance last night to direct an opera there. His opportunity came because Fritz Busch, one of the principal conductors, is away for several weeks.

The Jewish National Welfare Board services during 1949 to Jewish Community Centers, to Jewish personnel of the armed forces and to hospitalized veterans will cost $1,491,955, according to the budget it made public yesterday. The board represents 321 Jewish Community Centers and is the Government-accredited agency to serve the religious, morale and welfare needs of Jews in the armed forces and in Veterans Administration hospitals.

Isaac Don Levine, editor of Plain Talk magazine, testified for three hours yesterday before the special Federal grand jury investigating subversive activities. After the session he said he gave the jury a list of twenty-two persons named by Whittaker Chambers as being involved in Communist espionage.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Stung by Democratic charges that the state, since Governor Dewey took office, had been extragagant with tax money, Republican legislative leaders today accused their adversaries of "shocking ignorance" of state government and the influence of inflation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Three members of President Truman's Cabinet carried to Congress today a concerted argument for adoption of his anti-inflation program on the ground of necessity to support the governmental programs of finance, business and agriculture.

Twenty-five Roman Catholic priests representing dioceses in seven Eastern states gathered yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel to chart plans for the third annual campaign of the Bishops Fund for Victims of War, which has a $5,000,000 national goal this year.

PHILADELPHIA, Friday, Feb. 11 -- To enforce a demand for a fourth round of wage increases, 11,000 operating employes of the Philadelphia Transportation Company went on strike at 12:01 A. M. for the second time in three years.

It will require about $2,500,000 to take care of the financial needs of the 3,610 Chinese students now in this country, according to a report submitted last night at the annual meeting of the board of trustees of China Institute of America, in China House, 125 East Sixty-fifth Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- A baseball man turned Congressman said today that organized baseball may suffer a death blow from the law suit brought by Danny Gardella, former New York Giants' player.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The State Department said today that it was opposed to and had consistently opposed a contract concluded between Matthew Fox, New York business man, and Dr. A. K. Gani, Finance Minister of the Indonesian Republic, under which the American-Indonesian Corporation was set up to act as sole purchasing agent for the Indonesian Republic in the United States and as the sole sales agent for that republic.
SOFIA, Feb. 10 (AP) -- A Government official said that trial of the fifteen probably would begin at the end of this month.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Among those Senators who this week voted down a Republican effort to accelerate consideration of an anti-filibuster rule were Democrats who forced into the party platform last July a legislative pledge which it is the object of the proposed rule to redeem.
Snowslides and flood menace flung new trouble to the snow-burdened Northwest yesterday, the Associated Press reported.

ROME, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Pope will speak almost a full hour, probably expressing the wrath of the Roman Catholic Church at Hungary's imprisonment of Cardinal Mindszenty, when he addresses his Cardinals Monday, Vatican sources said today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 10 -- Although it is agreed that an overwhelming majority of the United Nations membership condemns the life sentence imposed upon Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, no effective action is expected here if the United States appeals the question to the United Nations.

THERE were seven sharpshooters in the file in the Danube campaign of 1809. They fought in the first important defeat Napoleon had suffered on land since his failure to capture Acre in the Egyptian campaign, the battle of Aspern and Essling. A few months later they fought again in the great victory of Wagram.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Army made public today a 32,000-word report on a Soviet spy ring in the Far East that was credited with a major development in diplomatic history and with having aided materially in the defeat by the Soviet Union of the Nazi armies invading Russian soil.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Democratically-controlled Congress put off today, over Republican protest, its obligation to establish by five days hence a proposed ceiling for Federal appropriations and spending.
In World War II, the Salvation Army took 225,000,000 services to fighting men on twenty-maintains sixty religious and six fronts. The Army's assistance to men in the armed forces is well known.
Miss Agnes Smedley angrily denied yesterday that she had been "a spy and agent for the Soviet Government," as charged in the Army's report on the ring led by Dr. Richard Sorge.

The twelve-day strike of 105 oil barge workers against the Reinauer Transportation Companies of Staten Island ended yesterday afternoon as both sides agreed to submit the points in dispute to arbitration. Union members resumed work last midnight.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- The feature of a generally quiet stock market here today was fresh weakness of oils. There were some gains at the opening but with support lacking share prices slipped and the close was at fractional losses.

The second round of knockout matches in the Vanderbilt Cup contract bridge tournament was played last night at the Pierre Hotel. Sixteen teams participated. The eight winners will meet tonight for the quarter-finals. The semi-finals will be played tomorrow afternoon and evening and the finals Sunday afternoon and evening.

The penetrating articles of your correspondent Anne O'Hare McCormick from Israel are a reminder that, whether individual Americans be pro or anti Israel, there are certain basic goals of American policy in which almost all of us believe. Likewise, the discussion of liberalization of existing displaced persons legislation should remind us of certain basic humanitarian goals which almost all of us share.
ROME, Feb. 10 -- Several thousand persons gathered in the Church of the Gesu this evening, where "an hour of reparation" was held to implore divine protection for Cardinal Mindszenty.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 10 (AP) -William (Big Bill) Tilden, on his 56th birthday, today started serving a one-year jail sentence.

The strike of grave diggers and other members of Local 293, United Cemetery Workers, CIO, which had begun on Jan. 13 in the Calvary Cemetery, Middle Village, Queens, spread yesterday to the Gate of Heaven Cemetery in suburban Hawthorne, N. Y., where forty-seven employes received instructions not to report for work today.

ROME, Feb. 10 -- A Jesuit priest who attempted to carry Pope Pius XII's letter of Jan. 2 to the Hungarian hierarchy was arrested three days after reaching that country "and will surely not be heard from for at least ten years, if ever," Jesuit circles here said today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 10 -- In a final dramatic act, Israel's Provisional Government granted amnesty tonight to all prisoners now held except those under life or death sentence and prisoners of war. The decree, which was passed unanimously, was sponsored by Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion.

William Kestenbaum, assistant project engineer for the Sperry Gyroscope Company, has purchased a dwelling under construction at 69 Dalton Street, Long Beach, L. I., from Stewart A. Burkland, builder of the Daylight Homes project. The four-room house, of modified Cape Cod style, designed by Howard A. Burkland, is in a group of more than 100 year-round dwellings in the $7,900 price class being offered to veterans.

Another business building in Queens is planned by Sam Minskoff Sons at the southeast corner of Queens Boulevard and Seventy-seventh Avenue, Kew Gardens. Construction is to be started at once on the two-story building, which will have stores on the ground floor and offices on the second floor. Occupancy is scheduled for September.

A state prison sentence of twelve and a half to twenty-five years was imposed yesterday in General Sessions on Rubin Axler, who had been found guilty of swindling businessmen out of an estimated $250,000 in fake deals for nonexistent steel and textile materials.

Along what path does a respectable and useful future for the Republican party lie? To the discussion of this question which was begun on Tuesday by Governor Dewey in Washington, Senator Vandenberg contributed a significant chapter in Lincoln Day speech last night at Detroit.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 10 (AP) -- A new Ohio corporation today went after a huge chunk of railroad business with a plan to build a $210,000,000 conveyor system to haul iron ore from the Great Lakes to the Ohio River and carry back coal.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Feb. 10 -- The country's experts on public opinion, including the pollsters, agreed today they had a long, hard row to hoe in getting at mass opinion, prevailing attitudes and the impending behavior of people.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 10 -- Fifteen Evangelical ministers were indicted by the public prosecutor here today on charges of espionage and irregular political connection with officials of the United States and British political missions in Bulgaria.

TOKYO, Feb. 10 -- The United States soon may undertake a re-study of the value of Japan as an American base in the Pacific in view of recent world events, it has been learned on good authority. This is expected to be one of the results of the visit of Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, to Far Eastern and Pacific areas.

We have been trying, without much success, to discover what is the true gospel of Democratic policy on state taxation. On Tuesday Mayor O'Dwyer, a respected party spokesman in New York State, charged that "the state has been grossly overtaxing the people" for the last six years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government sent to Congress today a far-reaching program for transforming Government employment into a career service and ridding the Federal payroll of unnecessary and incompetent employes.

Adelbert R. Dennis, former assistant secretary-treasurer of the Ramapo Trust Company, Spring Valley, N. Y., was sentenced to a month in jail in Federal Court yesterday on his plea of guilty to a five-count indictment charging that he made false entries to conceal a $6,000 embezzlement.

BERLIN, Feb. 10 -- The civil service grievance hearing of Alexander Sacks of New York, who was suspended from his job with the United States Military Government for attacking the integrity of Military Government officials, was canceled today on direct orders of the Army Department. Mr. Sacks has returned to his work.
The Hudson and Manhattan Railroad maintained virtually normal service yesterday, despite a strike of change makers and maintenance men called by the Transport Workers Union, CIO.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Dr. Halvard M. Lange, Norwegian Foreign Minister, will see President Truman and Secretary of State Dean Acheson tomorrow afternoon and then leave for London to open a new phase of the projected North Atlantic defense pact talks with foreign secretary Bevin.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- President Truman announced officially at his news conference today the appointment of Dr. Philip C. Jessep of Columbia University as Ambassador-at-Large.

More students were graduated from schools of social work in 1948 than in any previous year, and the number of full-time students enrolled this year is setting still another record, it was learned yesterday.
AS the debate on the new federal labor law unfolds we cannot afford to disregard certain fundamental facts and principles upon which a sound labor law must rest:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UP) -Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat, of Colorado, Chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee, today promised an inquiry into proposed regulations of the Civil Aeronautics Board for governing non-scheduled air carriers.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 10--Less than 10 per cent of this country's weekday church school classes have been forced to cease functioning as a result of the Supreme Court decision outlawing released-time religious education in public school buildings, it was disclosed here today by the Rev. Dr. Roy G. Ross, general secretary of the International Council of Religious Education.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 10 -- There is a growing conviction here that the Right wing of the Kuomintang [Government party] under the active leadership of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, is determined to retain its strength in the areas not yet overrun by the Communists, even at the price of continuing the war.

The firmness that developed in the stock market on Wednesday evaporated yesterday with a resumption of selling which dropped prices to the lowest mark since early last December. The liquidation, which, however, never reached major proportions, produced a return to bearishness in the financial district.

Friends of Dr. Philip C. Jessup, until recently Deputy United States Delegate to the Security Council, say that he gave up that arduous job because he wanted time to think. As an authority in the field of international law he has done fruitful thinking in the past. His little book on "A Modern Law of Nations," republished last year, brought this thinking down to date and established new order in a chaotic field.
Magistrate Alex Pisciotta won an $18,399 award yesterday from Supreme Court Justice Frank E. Johnson in Brooklyn in an action against the city. The amount represented a differential in wartime pay.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- President Truman flatly refused to disclose today the number of atomic bombs stored in the United States atomic armory, and furthermore declared that this should not be a matter for public discussion.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- A warning that the Government budget might rise to $50,000,000,000 through international and domestic plans was injected into hearings on the European Recovery Program today.

Arthur Miller has written a superb drama. From every point of view "Death of a Salesman," which was acted at the Morosco last evening, is rich and memorable drama. It is so simple in style and so inevitable in theme that it scarcely seems like a thing that has been written and acted.
NANKING, Feb. 10 (UP) -- Civic leaders appealed to Acting President Li Tsung-jen today to declare Nanking and Shanghai open cities and to stop fortifying the Yangtze River line.

BERLIN, Feb. 10 -- Western Germany will have to face the facts of post-war economic life under a new major policy decision whereby the Western Allies in effect will halt the subsidizing of German exports.

Accessories of Chinese housekeeping will be displayed in an exhibition of 200 everyday utensils to open at the Brooklyn Museum today at 10 A.M. The display of antique articles, chosen from private collections and shown for the first time in public, will continue through April 17.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va., Feb. 10 (AP) -- Lieut. Peter Pirogov, one of the fugitive Soviet airmen touring this country, declared today that he would protest to the State Department that he had been mistreated.

STRABANE, County Tyrone, Northern Ireland, Feb. 10 -- "I have it in my mind," said the Unionist ward heeler, "that Willie John, down the road, voted his poor dead brother today. But no matter, we're doing fine."

Entries for the 1949 Father's Day Ad Contest were urged yesterday by Alvin Austin, executive director of the Father's Day Council. Tear sheets of ads should be submitted not later than June 30. "The purpose of this contest," Mr. Austin said, "is to raise the standard of Father's Day advertising to the highest possible pinnacle."

The Carnegie Corporation of New York yesterday filed plans for alterations in the former Carnegie residence at 2 East Ninety-first Street, which is to be occupied by the New York School of Social Work, a part of Columbia University.
Apparently the mid-winter warning of the Yankees that their ball players had better report in good physical shape this spring, "or else," is having its effect upon the athletes.

For some years this newspaper has been urging the adoption of the group method of research in cancer -- a method which was introduced by industrial laboratories early in the century and which has given us more efficient electric lamps, radio communication, television, plastics and scores of other products.
GENEVA, Feb. 10 -- The World Council of Churches denounced growing governmental interference with the freedom of worship and conscience, in a statement issued tonight.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 10--Written fourteen years ago on a Guggenheim Fellowship, Douglas Moore's musical setting of Philip Barry's play, "White Wings," received its world premiere last night at the Julius Hartt School of Music here.
A cooperative community service program so ambitious and varied that it will require ingenious coordination was announced yesterday at Abraham Lincoln Houses in Harlem.

TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 10--Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll and other New Jersey Republican leaders discussed today ways to revitalize their party and proposed that the first national regional conference on policy and program be held in this state.

Charging that the heavy importation of crude oil into the United States is hurting the oil industry in Texas, Gov. Beauford H. Jester of that state in a letter to American oil importing companies has requested that imports be reduced. He charged that heavy imports accounted for the recent move of the Texas Railroad Commission to curtail production.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 10 -- A whirlwind tour of the factories, farms and shipyards of this sturdy little nation offers convincing proof that the Danes have made the most of Marshall Plan aid and that they would be doing even better if it were not for a fundamental conflict between the foreign, economic and military policies of the United States.

CARMEL, N. Y., Feb. 10 -- A fire in one wing of the main building of Drew Seminary for Young Women destroyed three floors of the four-story building this afternoon. No one was injured, but many of the students of the Methodist school lost all their personal belongings.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 10 (AP) -Long-shot Alablue captured the inaugural running of the $25,000 Christopher J. Fitzgerald Stakes at Santa Anita today.

"The Adventures of Ozzie and gram will orginate from the sales Harriet" will shift to the CBS net-work on April 3 and will be heard at 6:30 P. M. Sundays, preceding the Jack Benny program at 7 o'clock. It now is heard on NBC, which will have to fill another half hour on its Sunday night schedule.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- President Truman reiterated today his determination to press for enactment of his eight-point anti-inflation program and his $4,000,000,000 tax-rise proposal despite the current drop of some prices and the slump in the commodity markets.
While the volume of trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange diminished yesterday final prices were 4 to 17 points net below the level of Wednesday's close.

Taking the cue from fluctuations in lard and grains, cottonseed oil futures moved erratically and closed 5 to 15 points higher on the New York Produce Exchange yesterday. Firm crude oil in the South encouraged buying. News from Washington indicated that controls on fats and oils may soon be lifted.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Feb. 5 were 682,143 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 2,888 cars, or 0.4 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 64,793 cars, or 8.7 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week of last year, and 85,158 cars, or 11.1 per cent, fewer than during the corresponding week of 1947.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -The Federal Trade Commission was told today it's important to the cosmetics industry that it be allowed to choose its sales outlets.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Negro Shortstop Artie Wilson, currently playing manager of the Mayaguez club of the Puerto Rican League, signed a contract today to play with the Cleveland Indians.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 10 -- Fly rod fever seems to have infected most of the bass, tarpon and redfish anglers who fish the canals and rivers, for on a fifty-mile trip along the canal that borders the Tamiami Trail almost everyone but the Seminoles had this tackle.

The importance and wide diversity in styling of the spring coat and suit was marked by the Rosette Pennington shop yesterday by devoting an entire showing to these fashions at the Plaza Hotel. Flared treatments that give such verve to this season's style were reflected in jackets that sprang into back fullness and skirts swept out to one side or cut with concentrated fullness at the rear.

A snow performance went on in the city at 1:50 P. M. yesterday, and by 10:35 P. M. the one-day stand had ended in a total fall of 1.87 inches -- all in line with the booking notices filed previously by the Weather Bureau.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Dave Douglas, gangling professional from Wilmington, Del., who has been on the golf tour a little more than a year, led twentyseven par smashers through the first round of the $10,000 Texas Open today with a 65.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 10 (AP) -Israel apparently has decided to oppose a merger of the Arab part of Palestine with King Abdullah's Trans-Jordan, a United Nations source said today.
Allegheny County, Pa., announced yesterday that it will receive bids on March 8 on bond issues totaling $7,260,000. Dated March 1, 1949, the bonds will come due on each March 1 from 1950 to 1979.

Railroad equipment financing involving the issuance of $6,050,000 of equipment trust certificates maturing over ten years was executed yesterday by the Virginian Railway and by the Texas Pacific Railway.

The New York University Heights Daily News, a student paper, took university officials to task yesterday for pushing plans to erect a new law center in Washington Square while permitting half-finished construction on the Heights to lag.

Construction will be started soon in Pittsburgh of a modern research laboratory devoted exclusively to the development of safety equipment for mines, industry and public-service organizations, it was announced yesterday by the Mine Safety Appliances Company.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- A proposal to set up minimum standards for the protection of residents of multiple dwellings against fire and other hazards in communities under 500,000 population was made today by the Joint Legislative Committee on Housing and Multiple Dwellings.

DETROIT, Feb. 10 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg charted for the Republican party tonight a course over "the high center read" of sound conservatism and liberalism at home while pursuing friendship abroad on a "two-way street" to secure a peace which he said was now denied by Russia.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 10 (AP) -- One Belgian bobsled racer was killed and another critically injured today in the first fatal accident ever to occur on the Mt. Van Hoevenberg bob run.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The flood of Republican Lincoln Day oratory, now mounting toward its peak, reflects a continuing basic difference within the GOP over the reasons for its surprising defeat on Nov. 2: Whether the battle was lost because of the unpopularity of the record of the Eightieth Congress, or whether it was lost by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey himself and his mild-mannered campaign.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was honored yesterday for her work in helping to rehabilitate 40,000 refugee children in Israel. More than 1,000 persons attended the meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel where she received the first citation and cash award given for humanitarian work with children by Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, in memory of the late Henrietta Szold, founder of the organization.

One of the aims of the New York University Law Center will be "a simplified law adapted to the need of changing times," Chief Justice Arthur T. Vanderbilt of the New Jersey Supreme Court said last night at the sixty-first annual dinner of the New York University Law Alumni Association.

BAYONNE, N. J., Feb. 10 -- Civic leaders representing several faiths and political groups met tonight at Bayonne Hospital to honor Dr. Lucius F. Donohoe, 81-year-old former mayor, in the observance of his sixtieth anniversary as a physician.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- United States exports rose sharply in December as settlement of maritime strikes ended a long tie-up of shipping, the Census Bureau reported today.

Skiing enthusiasm in the Metropolitan area was heightened considerably by the appearance of swirling flakes yesterday, but the Weather Bureau officials were not too promising about sport in our backyard for the week-end. Something was reported developing last night off Hatteras.

Plans are being made for the Bellevue Ball to be held April 19 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria to aid the work of the Social Service Auxiliary of Bellevue Hospital. Mrs. Charles Englehard Jr. is chairman of the benefit committee, of which Mrs. Henry Bristol is a member.
LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Winston Churchill caused a fifteen-minute uproar in the House of Commons today when he accused the Government of "gross financial mismanagement."

The United States Rubber Company cleared $20,141,585 last year, after taxes and all charges, compared with $21,753,317 earned in 1947, according to the fifty-seventh annual report to stockholders issued yesterday for publication today by Herbert E. Smith, chairman, and Harry E. Humphreys Jr., president.

PARIS, Feb. 10 -- Lanvin introduces a supple, unfitted waistline on blouses worn outside skirts, on jackets and a coat. Although these models are cut in toward the natural waistline, they do not mold it. But they are a minority, most gowns and suits fitting snugly.

More than $500,000 has been raised in Harvard Law School's drive for $2,500,000 for building and academic purposes, Dean Erwin N. Griswold told members of the Harvard Law School Association at their annual dinner last night at the Harvard Club, 27 West Forty-fourth Street.

The British Cotton Board has urged its Government to be as liberal as possible in making dollar exchange avialable for American exports of textiles, according to Sir Raymond Streat, chairman of the board. The development of export markets is of greatest importance, he held, no matter who sells them.

An actual majority of House Republicans present and voting joined with House Democrats in approving the restoration of the Trade Agreements Act along the lines on which that statute operated between 1939 and 1948. Except for a wartime extension in 1943, this is the first time that Republicans have given this policy their approval.

The Protestant 'piscopal Bishop of Long Island directed all ministers in his diocese yesterday to lead their flocks in prayer on Sunday for Cardinal Mindszenty of Hungary, while a Presbyterian minister in Brooklyn urged Americans to "think twice before they join the 'holy' crusade on behalf of Cardinal Mindszenty."
TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 11 -Premier Shigeru Yoshida's Cabinet resigned today at the opening of the Japanese Diet's special session.

The American Woolen Company, Inc., the world's largest manufacturer of woolen and worsted fabrics, which this year celebrates its fiftieth anniversary, transacted the largest sales volume and second highest earnings in its history in 1948, according to the annual report of Moses Pendleton, president, issued yesterday.

A new shield that may be used by graduates and students for stationery, jewelry and pottery has been adopted by Columbia University, it was announced yesterday. The university's seal, unlike the new shield, is restricted to official business of the university.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 10 -As Nathuram Vinayak Codse, the slayer of Mohandas K. Gandhi, was sentenced today to hang, co-defendants staged a Hindu nationalist, anti-Pakistan demonstration in the court.
LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 10 -- The Soviet-installed Government of North Korea submitted a formal application for membership in the United Nations today.
The eleven Communist leaders suffered a serious reverse yesterday in their attempt to avoid trial by challenging the fairness of the Federal jury system. Prof. Doxey Wilkerson, their own...

On Monday last the querulous eye, turned on Paris, encountered Christian Dior. Reports generally agree that it was he who founded that something called the New Look and, on Monday last, there was a certain morbid interest in whether he now thinks better of it.

Cottons with new finishes and interesting textures resulting from the ideas and opinions of college girls were introduced to the press yesterday at a fashion show given by Bates Fabrics at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Earning assets of the reporting New York City member banks dropped $351,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday. According to the figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, business loans were higher, however, rising $10,000,000 to a total of $5,583,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- A wartime American paratrooper testified today that Mildred E.(Axis Sally) Gillars plied him with 45-year-old brandy in seeking to have him make a Nazi radio broadcast.

A group whose main function will be importing popular-priced lines of infants' and children's apparel from Germany will begin operations April 1, it was learned here yesterday. The group, which is capitalized to import approximately $2,000,000 worth of merchandise during the first year of its operation, plans to enter other apparel import fields gradually.

With a sextet of foreigners commanding the center of the stage, the stars of the spiked-shoe circuit will settle down to a four-Saturday stand at Madison Square Garden tonight. Launching the sequence is the annual carnival of the New York Athletic Club.

There came a clear call from Colorado the other day, when Professor Amanda M. Ellis of Colorado College addressed the College English Association, meeting in New York, on "the failure of many students to speak well, write well and think coherently."

RED BANK, N. J., Feb. 11 -- Capt. Charles P. Irwin, grand old man of the Shrewsbury River, is ready at 81 to match his forty-seven-year-old undefeated ice-boat, The Georgie II, against "any or all comers."

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 12 (UP) -- Mr. Yoshida said today that unwise interference by American Military Governors in the January Parliamentary elections was partly responsible for Communist gains. He said that there were "some grains of truth" in reports that many Japanese voted for Communists in protest against the occupation.

Juvenile delinquency among German youth is higher than before the war; is higher than in any other country for which records are available and constitutes "an immediate social problem of serious proportion." This was reported yesterday by Herschel Alt, one of this country's leading authorities in the study of juvenile delinquency.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (AP) -- An agency in Buffalo, N. Y., that bought one of the thirty-eight Tucker rear-engine automobiles produced so far sued today to have the automobile company return it to Buffalo.
OTTAWA, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The Royal Canadian Mounted Police today booked Sam Carr on a charge under the Official Secrets Act of Canada.

Twenty men with four pushcarts who went forth from Hogan's Alley, back of 26 Cherry Street, on New York's Lower East Side in 1897 to gather waste paper, old furniture and clothes, initiated what today has grown to be more than 900 Red Shield Salvation Army trucks operating in communities from coast to coast.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- Following yesterday's weakness on Wall Street, dollar stocks were lower in the stock market here today. General Motors finished with a loss of 2 1/4 points, while other losses ranged up to the 2 points recorded by United State Steel.

VIENNA, Feb. 11 -- The Austrian press today reported that reconstruction of war-damaged railway stations in five Austrian towns and of the opera house in Vienna would have to be halted for lack of funds. The affected towns and Viennese music lovers promptly sent messages of protest to the Government.

NANKING, Feb. 11 (UP) -- The Communists have agreed to call a formal peace conference within a month to halt the civil war, reliable sources said today. But a few hours later the Communist radio accused the United States of planning active assistance to the Nationalists.

Four of the five Republican county leaders in New York City joined yesterday in a reply to Mayor O'Dwyer's criticism of Governor Dewey's proposal to increase the State income tax 66 2/3 per cent and use current tax revenues to help defray the costs of capital projects. They asserted that the Mayor has never understood the details of state or city fiscal matters and has no particular desire to understand them.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe was close to defeat tonight by Juan Navarra of Buenos Aires but recovered in time to score his second successive victory in defense of his world's three-cushion billiard title.
Judge Harold R. Medina charged counsel for the eleven Communists yesterday with trying to make a "mockery" of and to "sabotage" the administration of justice.

HONOLULU, Feb. 11 -- Hawaii is still an important, link in the United States defense chain, Secretary Royall said here today. He added that a drastic reduction in Hawaii's troop strength during the last two years had been because of "more stresses" elsewhere in the world.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 11 -- As a result of intensive research carried on at the Weizmann Institute of Science, the indigenous castor oil bean has been converted into a wide variety of plastics, from nylons to building insulation. These processes may revolutionize Israel's industrial base.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 11 (AP) -- The world two-man bobsled championship will be run off Sunday as a one-day event as the result of the death of Max Houben, 52-year-old Belgian driver, in a practice run on Mount Van Hoevenberg Thursday.

The decision of the Senate Labor Committee to prolong the period for hearings on the Administration's labor bill by another two weeks does not come as a great surprise. When it was announced on Jan. 25 that this group was planning to rewrite the nation's fundamental labor law on the basis of only twelve days of public testimony we, in company with many other commentators, found the proposal unbelievable.

In shape, the newest handbag has the wide, shallow silhouette of the flapper's 1925 underarm envelope. In material, milady's carry-all, whether bag, basket or bucket, runs the gamut from handsome polished calf and natural pigskin to bamboo, linen, silk shantung and split wood.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 11 -- Cardinal Mindszenty and the fifteen Evangelical ministers who were indicted yesterday by the Bulgarian Government on charges of espionage may be "necessary" Christian martyrs, a former religious education consultant on the staff of Gen. Douglas MacArthur said here tonight.
Harvey Rosen will be dropped as secretary of the Fire Department on Feb. 28, it was learned last night. The name of his successor was not made known immediately. The position pays $7,250 annually.

Ever since CARE's first food shipments arrived at Havre in May, 1946, this non-profit, private relief agency has carved itself a bright and honorable and ever-widening place in communities the world over. It is a revered name to hundreds of thousands of individuals and families and orphanages and schools where its special food, blanket, wool, layette and linen packages -- generously contributed by the American people -- have meant the difference between health and sickness.

PARIS, Feb, 11 (AP) -- Guenther Stein, author and journalist, arrived in Paris today from New York, and said United States Army charges that he had been a Russian spy "are false from beginning to end."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- J. C. Van Essche, vice chairman of the International Wheat Conference, said today that enough progress had been made in informal conversations to indicate that a new international wheat agreement could be drawn up.

Joanna and Louise Leschin, who made their New York debut a year ago, gave a well-attended program of music for two pianos last night in Carnegie Hall. Their list included Brahms' Sonata, Op. 34 bis, a Vivaldi Concerto, the first performance here of Tansman's "Carnival Suite," and works by Hummel, Michailow, Godowsky and Saint-Saens.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- As keenly as the United States desires political unity in Europe, this Government does not propose to dictate such an integration as a part of the Economic Cooperation Administration Program, Dean G. Acheson, Secretary of State, told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Severe and often grave shortages of power in the United States are aggravated by scant construction materials that have set back plans for building additional facilities by as much as five years, Julius A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, told the Congressional Joint Economic Committee today.
Sales and earnings of the F. W. Woolworth Company and its Canadian subsidiary last year were the largest in its history, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

Formal annmmcement of the from 5:30 to 6:30 P. I., under acquisition of the Edgar Bergen the general title of the "Chuck program was made yesterday by Wagon," well-known commissaryCBS, which plans to offer the on-wheels of the plainsmen.
Five new films, including a twin bill of English entries, will open today at local theatres.

Athens, Feb. 11 -- The United States military mission reported today that a body believed to be that of Lieut. Col. Selden R. Edner of the United States Air Force, missing since Jan. 21, had been found and brought to Athens for identification. The body had been found on the outskirts of Karpenision following recapture of the town from the rebels by the Greek Army three days ago.
Metropolitan brewers will stage a Bock Festival on March 9 at the 165th Infantry Armory to herald the return of bock beer on an industry-wide basis, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 -- Laymen dedicated to bringing the kingdom of God to realization in this world at this time were called for today at the opening of the first annual meeting of the National Council of Presbyterian Men.

Work on stage settings for five forthcoming Broadway theatrical productions was resumed yesterday after settlement of a wage dispute between the United Scenic Artists, Local Union No. 829, AFL, and the Theatrical Contractors Association, representing seven contractors.

In a conference held yesterday to expand a thirty-five-year activities report that was delayed in publication because of far-flung interests in Africa and the United States, the Phelps-Stokes Fund of 101 Park Avenue decided that the most significant development in modern history was the progress of the Negro Americans and peoples of African descent in other areas.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 11 -- There was a once-around-the-track main event at Hialeah Park today in which Louis I. Greenberg's Cer Vantes -- that's the way the 4-year- old colt's name was registered with the Jockey Club -- displayed considerable gameness to win by a head at better than 11 to 1.

A 37-year-old state parole board officer, accused of obtaining bribes from convicted criminals and their relatives on unkept promises to obtain their release from prison or parole, was arraigned yesterday in General Sessions on a twenty-count indictment.

CLAYTON, N. Y., Feb. 11 (AP) -- Seven children and their mother were burned to death early today when they were trapped in the flaming bedroom of their three-room home two miles west of this northern New York village.

PARIS, Feb. 11 -- Mme. Gres continues to make beautiful clothes with her own individual stamp upon them. Defying the current tendency to shorten, she keeps skirt lengths about eleven inches from the floor.

MOSCOW, Feb. 11 (UP) -- Russia put in a claim to a full voice in any discussions pertaining to the vast Antarctic area today through a resolution passed by the All-Union Geographical Society at a meeting in Moscow.

GENEVA, Feb. 11 -- The committee of experts appointed by the president of the Security Council to consider solutions of the Berlin currency problem concluded its sessions today after having adopted a noncommital report.

Magistrate Charles F. Murphy sharply rebuked the Board of Health and New York landlords yesterday for their failure to recognize that the legal heat minimum of 65 degrees for New York apartments was inadequate for the comfort of the tenants.

ROME, Feb. 11 -- This morning the small police force of the microscopic state of Vatican City, very decorative in sweeping black capes lined with purple, stood at attention on the road leading to St. Peter's. A few thousand people gathered in the square and a scattering of flags, mostly on government buildings, flew over the Roman streets.

A plea to the Washington Square community to help find suitable new quarters for fourteen artists, sculptors and musicians facing eviction from premises where New York University's Law Center Foundation plans to build, was voiced yesterday by Dean Russell D. Niles of the university law school.

Proposed doubling or tripling of tariffs on imported textiles by Venezuela has brought about a sharp reduction of rayon goods orders from that country, it was learned yesterday. If the duty is raised, textile exporters said that they will be squeezed out of the largest rayon goods market still remaining.

Twenty of the sixty free-parking spaces at the north end of Union Square have been set aside as a pound for abandoned vehicles, although there is an acute shortage of parking facilities in the area, it was learned yesterday.

What had been, more or less, an unhappy relationship between the New York Knickerbockers and Sid Tanenbaum was terminated yesterday with the announcement that the former N. Y. U. ace had been dealt away to the Baltimore Bullets.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 -- With a flat warning that transportation must be made available, Federal authorities intervened today in the strike of 11,000 operating employes of the Philadelphia Transportation Company.
AUBURN, N. Y., Feb. 11 (AP) -- Two investigators of the State Liquor Authority, charged by state police with accepting a bribe, were suspended tonight by John F. O'Connell, chairman of the Authority.

Liquor and wine sales last year by Park Tilford, Inc., exceeded those of 1947, Arthur D. Schulte, president of the company, disclosed here yesterday. He also predicted good sales for the industry during 1949 and warned of "really tough going in 1950 and 1951 when oceans of whisky distilled in 1946 and 1947 attain their maturity."
BOSTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The Boston Weather Bureau reported today the following conditions for the New England area:

Votes are piling up for the most popular painting in the exhibit of art by skippers at the Seamen's Church Institute of New York, 25 South Street. By March 1, when the show ends and the ballots are counted, the institute expects some of the exhibitors now on the high seas or in foreign ports to be on hand for the tally.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Feb. 11 -- The increasing use of public opinion polls in a growing number of fields was predicted today by pollsters and social scientists. Undismayed by the failure to forecast the November election, they saw a brilliant future for polls in public health, government, economics, crime, labor relations, education, law and other fields.

ON BOARD U. S. S. CURTISS, Off Kodiak, Alaska, Feb. 11 -- Operations of naval vessels and planes of all types in sub-arctic latitudes are entirely feasible, "Micowex," the Navy's "minor cold weather exercise," has shown.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 11 -- Mrs. Arnold Eaves, the former Rhoda Wurtele, one of Canada's famed twin skiing sisters, and a member of last year's Olympic team, took first place in the Lake Placid Club's international downhill race today and gave her Canadian team-mates a slight lead over their American opponents in the annual competition sponsored by the Sno Birds for the Kate Smith Trophy.

Coated with ice in the freezing temperatures that followed the light snowfall on the city late Thursday, the West Side Express Highway, the East River Drive and all bridges leading into Manhattan were strewn with sand and cinders early yesterday to assure the regular movement of traffic and reduce skidding.

A month of concerts, broadcasts, dramatizations and sermons will mark the National Jewish-Music Festival, which begins today and continues to March 15. Monday is set aside as "Salute to Israel Day," when special programs will be beamed to England, the Middle East and South America.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Governor Dewey today proclaimed the period of Feb. 12 to 22 "Security Week" and urged that all civic groups join with the Reserve Officers Association in that time "in giving full consideration to the immediate development of an integrated program of national security which will safeguard the United States and the peace of the world."
The furious assault of wind, snow and cold against the nation's northwest quadrant swirled with renewed strength on the northern plains yesterday, the Associated Press reported.
Thousands of Brooklyn-bound subway riders were delayed last night, some as long as an hour, by a breakdown on the BMT division's Fourteenth Street-Canarsie line at the peak of the rush hour.

More than 2,500 retail stores throughout the country have agreed to participate actively in the first annual carpet fashion opening for consumers from March 1 through March 10, the Carpet Institute reported yesterday.

TOKYO, Feb. 11 -- Shigeru Yoshida, 75-year-old former Ambassador to Britain and life-long Japanese foreign-service officer, was re-elected tonight as Premier in his role of leader of the nation's Conservative forces.

PARIS, Feb. 11 -- It was reported tonight that Andre Marie, Minister of Justice, Vice Premier and member of the Radical party, would resign tomorrow to be replaced by Robert Lecourt, Popular Republican.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Mrs. Anna Arnold Hedgeman today was made assistant to Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, succeeding Harry N. Rosenfield, who was appointed to the Displaced Persons Commission.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11 -- The Marine Firemen's Union ended a seven-day conference here today with a threat to tie up foreign vessels that obtain cargoes by undercutting American wage standards.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- A letter purporting to show that the Federal Reserve Board "scuttled" a program which might have resulted in an amicable solution of its differences with the Transamerica Corporation of San Francisco was introduced as evidence today in the hearing on the board's anti-trust charges against the corporation.

There was a ghostly stillness in Moriarity's and in Paddy Clarke's over on Third Avenue and a similar atmosphere seemed to pervade other Irish bars yesterday afternoon as election results from Ulster revealed that the anti-partitionists had remained entrenched in Northern Ireland.

The twenty-eighth event of the Associated Terrier Clubs today at the Twelfth Regiment Armory, Columbus Avenue and Sixty-second Street, starts the ball rolling for the round of canine activity that will make New York the dog capital of the United States for the next four days.

If newspapers were limited to publishing only such news as had the source identified, the usefulness of the press would be immeasurably damaged. Anonymity for the public official, the Government employe in lower ranks and for the private citizen is, when promised by the reporter, frequently the only key that will unlock valuable information whose publication is in the public interest.
Every soldier in the Salvation Army is given something to do and he remains in good standing only so long as he does it. Soldiers in the Army serve God through helping their fellow men.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UP) -- Henry A. Wallace accused both Democrats and Republicans tonight of trying to forget their civil-rights campaign promises now that the election was past.

The Brazilian Government announced yesterday through its Treasury Delegation here that the outstanding $10,413,505 of State of Sao Paulo dollar bonds deriving from the 7 per cent coffee realization loan of 1930 would be paid in full on April 1. Sterling bonds of the same issue, outstanding in the amount of 2,229,680 ($8,918,720), are to be redeemed likewise in London, it was announced.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 11 -- President Juan D. Peron failed to attend tonight the opening of the third Inter-American Travel Congress despite the fact it had been generally announced that he would appear and make a speech, and the official program bore out this is announcement.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- President Truman and Winston Churchill, the wartime Prime Minister of Great Britain, will appear at a special convocation at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Since 1870 the Library of Congress has received a copy of every book or other publication copyrighted in the United States. The intention was to build in Washington a great national collection comparable to the British Museum collection of books published in Britain or the Bibliotheque Nationale collection of books published in France.
Dr. G. V. Slottman has been appointed director of research and engineering for the Air Reduction Company. He was previously technical assistant to the vice president in charge of sales.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- William W. Remington, cleared yesterday of charges of disloyalty preferred against him before a Senate investigating committee, went back to work today as Director of the Export Program staff of the Department of Commerce's Office of International Trade.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies decreased 2.6 per cent in January, compared with the corresponding month in 1948, according to compilation covering forty-two companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. In December, an increase of 7.9 per cent was shown.

Dr. Sterling W. Brown, who has been on leave for two years from his post as assistant to the Rev. Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, president of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, serving as religious coordinator with the American Military Government in Germany, is expected home next Friday.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 11 -- A Dutch Government spokesman said today that although the Cabinet would not accept the latest United Nations Security Council resolution on Indonesia in its entirety, it would now accept its timetable leading to a United States of Indonesia and its call for the release of Republican leaders.
Mayor O'Dwyer granted yesterday three additional holidays each year with pay to 12,000 employes of the Department of Sanitation.

A manuscript copy of the immortal document with which many a school child is familiar even before he can read -- the Gettysburg Address -- will be publicly auctioned in April at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, it was announced yesterday.

As though baseball weren't having enough surprises these days, the diamond scribes themselves came up with a big one yesterday when they announced through Ken Smith, secretary of the Baseball Writers Association, that their annual poll had failed to name a single candidate for the Hall of Fame at Cooperstown, N. Y.
Your editorial of Feb. 8, "Power of 'Seizure,'" opens up a chance to clarify the deep confusion that has surrounded the question of how to handle emergency strikes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Even as Western Senators launched a move today for new funds to fight drifting snow and flood threats, Federal agencies received orders to prepare to halt their relief work.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Feb. 11 (AP) -- The American Locomotive Company, charging CIO union workers with a deliberate twoweek slowdown, today ordered its main shop closed at midnight tonight.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- No one who could speak for Winston Churchill would give any information tonight on the former Prime Minister's forthcoming visit to the United States. In authorized sources it was said that a full statement probably would be made tomorrow.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that he would send to the Legislature next week a bill to strip the Public Service Commission of all jurisdiction over fares on private bus and street car lines operating under city franchises. The bill has been drafted and will go to Albany with the solid backing of the Board of Estimate.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Average primary market prices declined 1.2 per cent in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
TOKYO, Feb. 11 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Charles A. Willoughby, chief intelligence officer for General MacArthur, said today that Russian spy activities "multiply with the passing years."

Medals awarded for outstanding achievements in the field of anthropology and related sciences in 1948 were presented last night to three leaders in their respective fields at the annual dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel of the Viking Fund, Inc.

Liberale Parrino, 48 - year - old grocer, of 113 Dean Street, Brooklyn, was convicted by a Federal Court jury yesterday of participating in the kidnapping and torturing of a French seaman in August, 1934.
WE must now quit the field of military disaster for the convulsions in the French Cabinet and the personages who surrounded it at Bordeaux.

LINCOLN'S birthday is a very good time to be reading Fletcher Pratt's "Ordeal by Fire,"* a spirited and informal history of the War Between the States that is now playing phoenix to its own ashes -- having become something of a classic in the world of Robert E. Lee and Abraham Lincoln.
LONDON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The[ Brazilian Government paid over u2,000,000 ($8,000,000) today forI the redemption of the British-held bonds of the State of Sao Paulo] 7 per cent coffee realization loan

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Registration statements covering 50,000 shares of preferred stock, 950,000 shares of common stock and $15,000,000 of bonds were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by three companies.

ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 11 -- Skiers of Syracuse University led an eight-team field in the Western Division Intercollegiate Ski Union meet after the downhill and cross-country events in the near-by Caroline Hills today.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Feb. 11 -- Far-reaching Government regulation of Rumania's church groups, ranging from control of their property and funds to supervision of their religious art, was officially decreed here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 - The United States retaliated today for the expulsion of two American diplomatic secretaries from Hungary by demanding the departure from this country "as soon as possible" of John G. Florian, first secretary of the Hungarian Legation.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- The Soviet Union and the three Western powers who are meeting here to frame an Austrian peace treaty agreed in principle today on one article that would forbid Austria in the future to use weapons or armaments of "German origin or design."
The cotton futures trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday, but price changes were irregular. Final prices were 15 points higher to 13 points net lower.

Today's events: "Peter Grimes," at 2 P. M., and "La Boheme," at 8:30, Metropolitan Opera; Tanglewood Alumni Association Concert, music of American composers, Brooklyn Museum, 2; Solomon, piano, Carnegie Hall, 3; Madelyn Clifford, piano, Town Hall, 3.

The first American-British-Indian industrial team has arrived for "Know-How" training in this country. Six Indian engineers employed by the Government of India arrived here yesterday for an intensive three month' training program in making chemical fertilers, Maj. Gen. William N. Porter, (Ret.) president of the Chemical Construction Corporation, a division of American Cyanamid Company, disclosed in a conference at the New Weston Hotel yesterday.

Retail Sales Dropped in Week ` Retail sales here declined during the week, due partly to the comparison with an earlier Easter shopping season last year that stimulated February sales. Department store sales were estimated as about 8 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were 7 per cent below last year.

NANKING, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Reports seeping through the "bamboo curtain" of Communist China say that the crackdown on foreigners has begun, even to the point of requiring church missions to give daily lessons in communism.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 11 -- All day exercises, including opening of a new exhibition of Thomas A. Edison inventions, a luncheon of the Edison Pioneers, and final display of lighting at the Town Hall today ended a community observation of the 102d anniversary of the birthday of the late inventor, who was this town's first citizen.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The House Ways and Means Committee agreed today to begin hearings Monday, Feb. 28, on President Truman's recommendation for liberalization of the social-security program.

TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 11 -- New Jersey school authorities were requested today by Dr. John H. Bosshart, State Commissioner of Education, to defer plans for senior class visits to Washington in the 1949-50 school year until a problem of alleged segregation of Negroes in hotels could be studied.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- President Truman named Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today to serve temporarily as "presiding officer" of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

Unless provision is made for the satisfying employment of the many future college graduates resulting from the expansion of higher education called for by President Truman's Commission on Higher Education, many college-trained persons may turn to extreme forms of political action that promise a radical transformation of society, Bryn J. Horde, president of the New School for Social Research, warned last night.
The refurbished liner Queen of Bermuda, converted from transport status at a cost of $7,500,000, will make her post-war "maiden" voyage to Bermuda today with 620 passengers.

RHODES, Feb. 11 -- Egyptian-Israeli armistice talks have again come to a complete standstill, and Col. Yigal Yadin, senior Israeli military representative and chief of military operations, flew to Tel Aviv today to consult his Government.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 11 -- The Unionist party, loyalist and Protestant, won a smashing victory over both Irish nationalism and Labor in Northern Ireland's parliamentary elections yesterday.

Severance by the United States of commercial relations with Hungary as a result of recent developments would be a "pity" and a "mutual loss" to both countries, Lajos Kadar, Commercial Counselor of the Hungarian Legation, said here yesterday at the offices of the Hungarian Consulate, 37 Wall Street.
The chewless days for thousands of subway riders are about over.

Charges by traveling salesmen that hotel rates have been increased 50 to 100 per cent since the end of the Office of Price Administration will be substantiated with facts, dates and figures when they are called before Congressional committee hearings on rent controls in Washington, spokesmen for the National Council of Salesmen's Organizations said yesterday at their offices, 80 West Fortieth Street.

No matter how many bookshelves there may be in the home, magazines, books and newspapers eventually seem to accumulate on tables convenient to comfortable reading chairs. Since the tables must also hold lamps, smoking accessories and similar items, current reading matter may be kept in an orderly fashion in new racks designed for just that purpose.

New Capital Issues Debt financing continues to dominate the market for new capital issues. Bond issues totaling $62,900,000 are scheduled to come up for sale next week, with chief interest centering in the bidding on Tuesday for $40,000,000 of bonds of the Duke Power Company, an AAA-rated credit not often available to bond buyers in substantial supply.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- The State Banking Department announced today it has approved a certificate of increase of capital stock of the Garden City Bank and Trust Company, 100 Seventh Street, Garden City, from $450,000, consisting of 18,000 shares of par value of $25 each, to $600,000, consisting of 24,000 shares of the same par value.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- An embarrassed Army was trying with some difficulty today to explain the origin and implications of a news story, prominently published and widely discussed, emanating from its headquarters in Tokyo.
ALBANY, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The State Commerce Department reported today the following conditions at New York ski centers:

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, Feb. 12 -- The metropolitan police announced last night the discovery of a plot to assassinate by a bomb the members of the United Nations Commission on Korea as well as top Korean Government officials during a welcome rally for the commission here today.

TOKYO, Feb. 2 -- Japan will add forty-seven ships with a total tonnage of 153,570 tons -- about 3,200 tons each -- to her reconstituted merchant marine during the coming year, according to Shigeru Taniguchi, president of the Japanese Shipping Corporation.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 -- Some 200 holders of preference stock of the Central-Illinois Securities Corporation gathered here today to protest against actions of the company's president, C. Arvid Johnson of New York City, were interrupted by the unscheduled appearance of Mr. Johnson himself. The investment company's head defended his policies in a long discussion, but did not deter the shareholders from appointing a committee to press for liquidation of Central-Illinois through court action if necessary.

Kings County Hospital, the city's largest user of blood and the first hospital selected to receive free Red Cross blood in its current campaign to make adequate supplies available to New York's sick and injured, is approaching the point where it will eliminate all purchases of the life-sustaining fluid.

BERLIN, Feb. 11 -- In a new effort to work their way back into the publishing business, a group of former Nazi newspaper plant owners have tried to squeeze out present licensed publishers through rent gouging, the United States Military Government reported today.
CAIRO, Feb. 11 -- Empress Eugenie's tortoise which was so taken with the banks of the Nile that it ran off from its imperial mistress eighty years ago has died here at the age of 90.
Moves were made yesterday aimed, it was said, to "blow the lid off" the proposed merger of Pan American Airways and American Overseas Airways.

A precedent was set in the featherweight ranks last night when Willie Pep, the redoubtable little battler from Hartford, Conn., became the first boxer in the history of the 126-pound class to regain a lost world championship.

VIENNA, Feb. 11 -- The Soviet representative on the Allied Council for Austria endorsed today a fourth political party, which has admitted hoping to gain the greater part of votes of former Nazis. The Western representatives refused to recognize the party.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer tonight removed export quota controls from fats and oils, including butter.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 11 -Dr. Charles E. Haines, vice president of Ithaca College, came here today to discuss the possibility of that institution moving from Ithaca to Westchester County. He found the proposed transfer endorsed unanimously in principle by county and city officials.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- The indictment of fifteen Bulgarian clergymen "on the usual charges" was characterized by a Foreign Office spokesman today as part of a "concerted assault" on religion in Eastern Europe.

February is the month of birthdays, so it is said, and birthdays suggest parties. No segment of our population welcomes this idea more than the young set, who have a natural and enviable enthusiasm for festivity. Among this group St. Valentine's Day and Washington's birthday are seized on as providing an apt excuse for some sort of entertaining.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- John Nicholas Brown resigned today as Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Air, and President Truman named Dan A. Kimball, a Los Angeles business executive, to succeed him.
The quarter-finals for the Vanderbilt Cup, which is emblematic of the national knockout team-of-four contract bridge championship, was played last night at the Pierre Hotel.

ROME, Feb. 11 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi was received in solemn audience by the Pope today to commemorate the twentieth anniversary of the Lateran pacts, which re-established peace between the Church and the State in Italy in 1929.

The stock market slipped yesterday to the lowest levels in two months under a further whittling-away of prices. A faint attempt at a rally developed in the early afternoon but the effort failed to follow through and final prices, as measured by the averages, were lowered 0.28 point. Activity was most pronounced in low-price issues, but despite transfers of some large blocks, business on the Stock Exchange receded to 880,000 shares from 980,000 on Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UP) -- The Eire Legation said today that Prime Minister Sir Basil Brooke's Unionist party could not have helped winning the Northern Ireland elections.

Lincoln's Birthday is also the fortieth birthday of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, an organization which is highly respected as the champion of civil rights for the Negro American. Not known to many people, the Association was started in this city by white people who were alarmed by the rise of reaction in the South and the race riots in Northern cities.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- A group of Pacific Northwest members of Congress decided today the market outlook for peas next season was not good and that the planned acreage would have to be sharply cut.

A three volume history of the development of national music in Italy covering the period between 1480 and 1650 has been set for Feb. 28 publication by Princeton University Press, entitled "The Italian Madrigal." It is the work of Alfred Einstein, a musical scholar who devoted forty years to its research.
Phillip Marshall Brown's protest against U. N. intervention in Spain, Palestine and Indonesia is a "states rights" argument carried into a larger sphere.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The Southern Senators put forward today a third gesture of compromise in their determined effort to fight off limitations upon their essential power to filibuster against the President's civil rights program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson gave the Norwegian Foreign Minister, Dr. Halvard M. Lange, some hard answers to some hard questions about the proposed North Atlantic defense pact today.

Baseball, just regaining its breath from the reverberations of Danny Gardella's $300,000 suit that could blow the entire game apart, reeled under a fresh explosion yesterday as George M. Weiss, general manager of the Yankees, and Bill Veeck, dynamic owner of the world champion Indians, squared off in a verbal battle that threatened to toss another knotty problem into Commissioner A. B. Chandler's lap.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Feb. 11 -- Speeders in this village have been reacting quite differently for the last year when told to "pull over." But then again, they are being detected quite differently -- by radar.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- President Truman discussed the downward swing of commodity prices and other problems with his Cabinet today in an hour-long session.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 11 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie said today that regional security agreements "can be a very useful element in building a United Nations system of collective security provided they recognize the supremacy of the Charter."

The three American Indian boys who flew in from their reservations in the West this week to aid in a drive for funds to support Catholic missions of the Marquette League, 105 East Twenty-second Street, dramatize with their stories of the bitter life on the reservations this winter a responsibility to the original inhabitants of the United States that our Government has inadequately discharged.

The Hudson Manhattan Railroad announced yesterday that twenty striking change makers and maintenance men would be back on the job today. The Transport Workers Union, CIO, said it knew of only one defection from its ranks.

Greater supplies of hydrazine, a high - energy, clean - burning fuel used in rockets and submarines, will be available as a result of an intensive chemical research program now being conducted, it was disclosed last night by Prof. L. F. Audrieth of the University of Illinois, former military chief of ammunition research at Picatinny Arsenal.

NANKING, Feb. 11 -- This city's delegation of professors and civic leaders returned here today from Peiping with what one of its members described as the Communists' "program" for peace negotiations. He declined to elaborate on the program or even to state whether it was contained in a document.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Senator MacNeil Mitchell, Republican, of Manhattan, declared today that he would seek to force a full airing at this session of the Legislature of the controversial problem of veterans preference in public employment.

The lifting of export controls on fats and oils brought a disappointing response into the cottonseed oil futures market on the New York Produce Exchange yesterday. Prices moved irregularly over modest limits. Some attributed this reaction to the holiday atmosphere prevailing.

SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Chunky Johnny Palmer of Badin, N. C., glittered with a five-under-par 66 today to shoot into the lead at the midway mark of the $10,000 Texas open golf with a thirty-six-hole total of 133.

TOKYO, Feb. 11 -- The Japanese Government is making plans to care for more than 2,000,000 additional jobless this year. The expected administrative reform would cut at least 905,000, or 30 per cent, from the public payroll.

Joan Hammond, the Australian soprano, who has sung in many lands, at the Vienna Opera and Covent Garden, and in concert under Furtwaengler, De Sabata and other noted conductors, appeared in recital last night in Town Hall.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -Claim for jobless insurance checks, reflecting the number of unemployed in the country, kept climbing last week for the tenth straight week, the Government reported today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent of Canada arrived here tonight to pay his first official visit to this country as President Truman's guest.

The decision of the American Federation of Labor to fight Communist influence in the Canadian Trades and Labor Congress will promote unity between Canadian affiliates of the AFL and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, Samuel Baron, vice president and Canadian director of the Textile Workers Union, CIO, predicted yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Governor Dewey "will take off his gloves" to answer "irresponsible" Democratic attacks on his pay-as-you-go policy in a speech in New York tomorrow, his executive assistant, James C. Hagerty, announced tonight.

A 9-year-old boy who had been active in his school safety campaign in the Williamsburg district of Brooklyn was killed yesterday afternoon when he fell under the wheels of a five-ton truck a few minutes after he left his classroom.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People accused the International Workers Order yesterday of misusing funds intended for the defense of a Georgia Negro woman, Mrs. Rosa Lee Ingram, who was recently sentenced to life imprisonment for the murder of John E. Stafford, a white neighbor.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Mary Chesebro, a model, who under the name Dana Chessman was chosen typical Gibson Girl at New York's Golden Jubilee last September, to Thomas Wilton Phipps of New York, son of Mrs. Maurice B. Flynn, the former Miss Nora Langhorne. Mr. Phipps is a nephew of Lady Astor of London and Mrs. Charles Dana Gibson of New York, widow of the creator of the Gibson Girl.

Insufficient water supplies on the Netherlands West Indies island of Aruba, the site of large oil refineries, are responsible for the large-scale movement by tanker of both drinking and boiler water from the New York area, it became known yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 11 -- Some important diplomats here have expressed the view that the United States prevented a Scandinavian regional accord to bring Norway into the proposed North Atlantic defense pact. Some of the Brussels Treaty powers would have preferred a neutral Scandinavia from the viewpoint of West European defense.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 11 -- An occasional surf fishing check during the past weeks seems to indicate that the same mild weather that has been reducing the sailfish catches has had an equally bad effect on the fish that normally feed within casting range of the beach.

National Distillers Products Corporation has scheduled weekly, or semi-weekly insertions in 560 newspapers of 369 cities for its February-March campaign on its PM blended whiskey, it was announced yesterday. The newspaper ads, ranging from 100 to 750 lines, will have five changes of copy for a continuous emphasis on the theme "PM is Pleasing Millions With That Clear, Clean Taste."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration announced today it was preparing regulations to pay foreign agents of suppliers of ECA-financed commodities and services their commissions in local currencies instead of dollars.
BOSTON, Feb. 11 -- Boston welcomed today its third deputation of displaced persons when the S. S. Marine Flasher docked with a passenger list of 549 from Bremerhaven.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Feb. 11-- Racquets and court tennis enthusiasts in the metropolitan area are here for two three-day tournaments, the Tuxedo Gold Racquets championship and the Tuxedo Gold Racquet court tennis event, which mark the fiftieth anniversary of the Tuxedo Racquet and Tennis Club.

The continued slump in American-flag shipping was sharply reflected in a monthly United States Customs report, made public yesterday by Harry M. Durning, Collector of the Port. The report showed a sharp drop of close to $6,000,000 in customs collections in January, compared to the same period of last year.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Feb. 11 -- One hundred and fifty Protestant clergymen in the Englewood Hospital area today began an eight-week series of lectures at the hospital in which the doctors and administrators of the institution are doing the "preaching" and the ministers the listening.

The indictment in Bulgaria of fifteen Evangelical clergymen on charges of espionage evoked sharp condemnation yesterday of Communist anti-religious activity as well as a denial that there is world political power in Protestantism.

TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 11 -- Among the 3,000 gifts of the French people to New Jersey in the Gratitude Train were ten little oak and beech trees, which State Department of Agriculture experts eyed with professional suspicion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The Army declined today to express actual agreement with some of the statements made in the report made public yesterday by Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters, on Soviet spying activities in Japan before Russia's entry into World War II.

There is "little difference" between a doctor under socialism and a doctor under fascism, Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, dean of Columbia's Faculty of Medicine, declared yesterday.
