Fifteen per cent of the doctors in Germany in 1939 were in private practice when he was studying there, he said, while today in Great Britain only 1 per cent of the doctors are in private practice.

LONDON, Saturday, Feb. 12 -- Russia told Yugoslavia yesterday that she had no chance of cutting herself in on the Soviet-sponsored Council for Economic Mutual Assistance until she dropped her "hostile policy" toward the Soviet Union.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 11 -- Because Albert Camus, French author, has called off the deal by which M-G-M acquired his novel, "The Plague," the studio has revived another story, "Basra" which also deals with the work of a doctor under pressure, and which Metro has owned since 1947.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Supporters of a railroad connection to Alaska decided today to seek quick passage of a resolution directing the President to negotiate with Canada as the first step toward construction of the $500,000,000 project.

The largest combined promotional effort in the history of retailing will be made this week by stores in the United States. On Wednesday the Retail Associations of America, an organization made up of sixty individual retail-trade groups, will emphasize the successful operation of democracy in a week-long promotion labeled "Democracy Works Here."

DESPITE the evidence, much of which has been collected by himself and the detectives under him, Captain Honegger does not believe that Lester Ward is guilty of the fatal shooting of Andrew Newcomb. Something in the confident bearing of the man convinces Honegger that Ward will, when the proper time comes, be able to prove his innocence.

" DREAM NO MORE," Palestine Films' first feature picture, is, prophetically, no longer a dream and will be ready for release here in April, it was revealed last week by Joseph Krumgold, who wrote and directed the "comedy-documentary" in Israel.
MIDLAND, Mich., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Pelleted seeds, which are getting into full production at a small factory here, may bring about some radical changes in farming methods.

If the Nipponese can find a middle way -- a democratic relation between government and citizen -- the Chinese, the Filipinos, the Indonesians and the Viet Namese may likewise be persuaded to spurn both communism and :feurlnllmm.

TORONTO, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs moved into third place in the National Hockey League tonight with a 3-1 victory over the Detroit Red Wings. The Leaf triumph ended a six-game Detroit winning skein.

PARIS, Feb. 12 -- While Congress has been hearing from Paul G. Hoffman and W. Averell Harriman of the ECA optimistic reports on European recovery, there has been an unwonted amount of favorable news from France, long considered the main weak spot in the Western European economic picture.
The report published on Feb. 6 of James Reston, on what he rightly terms the Kremlin's "agreement to agree," has very grave implications.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Feb. 12 (AP) -- The American Bowling Congress opened its forty-sixth tournament today as pickets protested the A. B. C. "white male only" rule. Fifty pickets sang the national anthem, the CIO's "Solidarity" and other songs in an hour-and-a-half demonstration outside huge Convention Hall.

Wall Street ("Of all places," the cynical probably will remark) may be setting the stage for a new development in the history of labor and management relations. For on Feb. 28, the officials of the New York Stock; Curb and Cotton Exchanges will be guests of the American Federation of Labor and some of its affiliates at a "goodwill" luncheon in the Commodore Hotel.

TECHNICALLY, a garden in a pit is one that is dug partly below ground, provided with adequate insulation and a slanting glass roof that faces due south. Economically, it is the answer to the problem of heating the small greenhouse, the cost of which is often far out of proportion to the original investment.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Air Force insisted today it wrecked the Navy's fleet in the mock "Battle of Kodiak" and offered pictures to prove it.

THE effectiveness of a deceptive play usually depends upon surprise; it should be a play that the opponent has no reason to suspect. Nevertheless there are some bits of bridge deception that have become standardized without losing all their effectiveness.

THE formula for success in growing the modern hybrid amaryllis from seed is not a complicated one, but patience is an important prerequisite. For two or three years will elapse between the beginning of the project and the day it first pays off with big colorful blooms

MIAMI BEACH -- The revolution has come at last to Miami Beach, and with such dazzling speed that both the guests and the hotel operators are still in a mild state of shock. The guests are enjoying it no end, much more than their hosts, and the stories they will bring back from their winter vacations here will be fabulous.

HOLLYWOOD. THE ultimate development in the school of realistic cinema, generally called semi-documentary, came to light last week with the disclosure that Virginia Kellogg, working on assignment for Jerry Wald, Warner Brothers' chief advocate of reportorial motion pictures, had completed a two-month investigation of women's penitentiaries, living inside the walls of four prisons and actually sleeping in the cell block of one disguised as a convict.

An interdepartmental course on the "Great Books" has been introduced at West Virginia University. The books chosen represent "a fundamental dilemma in our civilization -- the persistent conflict between the actual and the ideal -- and suggest that the great task of the modern world may be to effect a reconciliation between reality and absolute values."

A BOUQUET of the new French hybrid tea, Happiness, was presented to the First Lady in Washington, D. C., last week, in conjunction with the arrival of the Gratitude Train in that city. Happiness is the latest creation of Francis, Meilland, of Peace rose fame, and was flown from France to Mr. Robert Pyle, president of the American Horticultural Council.

I AM 13, and my hobby is "modernistic art." I think the picture entitled "The Farmer's Dinner" in the book review of your paper is very well drawn and does put across its meaning, but I think it is not modernistic at all.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Chairman Tom Connally predicted today that the Senate Foreign Relations Committee would approve the new $5,580,000,000 European Recovery Program without even a "token" cut.
SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 12 -- The United Nations Commission on Korea today held its first public meeting in the Duk Soo Palace here.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Feb. 12 -- Cattlemen and sheepmen, long numbered among the nation's rugged individualists, now admit this bitter winter has turned their thinking toward planned Government assistance.

Shipping men in New York yesterday criticized the failure of the Department of Agriculture to maintain its schedule of grain exports "because of a shortage of tonnage," while regular liner services out of New York and other Atlantic ports are sending out vessels half full and in some cases almost empty.

PARIS, Feb. 12 -- European authorities who have been in closest touch with entire negotiation looking to a North Atlantic defense pact contend that the "mess" that has resulted is of United States making -- except for the unexpected intervention of Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations yesterday.
The problem of placement of needy children in foster homes is to receive the combined attention of representatives of private and public agencies, it was learned yesterday.

TEL AVIV (By Wireless). ON the twisting road from the rocky heights of Jerusalem to the sea-level town of Tel Aviv, you behold a summary picture of the drama of conflict and creation being played out against the scriptural landscape of the Holy Land.

IN the hard-boiled novel (U. S. model) We have come to expect certain stereotypes: the killer, the mobster, the gun moll, the detective. Moreover, the pattern of their behavior has become fairly well standardized. We know when to expect the gun-volleys and the corpses sprawled in attitudes of final defeat and despair.

ROME, Feb. 12 -- The sentencing of Cardinal Mindszenty in Budapest is regarded in Rome as merely the latest and most startling episode of the world-wide struggle between the Roman Catholic Church and communism. It has highlighted a situation that has been developing for years and is certain to grow tenser as time passes.

Current discussions of the Atlantic Pact, of the Western Union of European states and of the Marshall Plan tend to obscure the circumstance that the really important issue in Europe is that of making peace with Germany. This is a business that concerns all of Europe deeply and especially concerns the Big Four. It is due to bring the biggest test yet between the West and the East.

Once again last night, those superb runners from across the sea gave their American rivals an illustrative lesson in the fine European art of distance running. Five of them started in the annual games of the New York Athletic Club and, only by, their own company, were any of them beaten.
Retail trade here continued to show a downward trend in dollar volume. Department store sales were estimated at about 8 per cent under the like week a year ago.

The treatment and trial of Cardinal Mindszenty by the Hungarian Government is another example of Communist attempts to suppress religion, Juan Pablo Lojendio, Spanish Minister to Uruguay, said yesterday upon his arrival at La Guardia Airport, on a Trans-World Airline plane from Madrid. He was en route to his post in Montevideo.

AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 12 -- A late January cold wave destroyed more than 30 per cent of the Texas citrus crop and shrunk livestock drastically, the United States Department of Agriculture said today. The department estimated loss of unharvested grapefruit at 38 per cent and of unharvested oranges at more than a third. Estimates before the freeze indicated grapefruit production of 19,000,000 boxes and orange production of 4,700,000 boxes this year.

The nation-wide drive of the American Heart Association for $5,000,000 to combat heart disease is now on and the public has an opportunity to help a cause whose appeal is universal. Anyone who himself has suffered the ravages of heart disease or who has seen loved ones fall victim to it will not need to be persuaded to give money to the Heart Association's magnificent effort to overcome it.

Important signs of expanded industrial plant construction activity have arrived, indicating that strong pressure for maximum production and deliveries in heavy equipment industries will continue, it was learned here yesterday in a canvass of leading engineering, construction and manufacturing concerns.

ATLANTA, Feb. 12 -- Sharp drops in meat prices and a leveling off of building activity, combined with reports of similar trends in other business activities over the country, led Southeasterners this week to a firmer view that the long-predicted "adjustment period" had arrived.

The dedication of the statue "Lincoln and Boy" by Charles Keck on a playground of the Abraham Lincoln Houses near Madison Avenue and 133d Street by officials of the New York City Housing Commission was the occasion yesterday of tributes to the freeing of the Negro slaves and to the clearing of slums in Harlem.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 12 -- The Pittsburgh Pirates today tore up Manager Billy Meyer's old contract and gave him a new one for the next three years with a substantial but undisclosed salary increase.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The Hungarian Government demanded today the recall of Selden Chapin, the United States Minister in Budapest, on the ground that he was "no longer agreeable" to it.

General Electric research scientists have developed a new method of coating one metal on another. A layer of metal powder is applied on a surface to be coated. The surface and coating are then heated to a degree just below the melting point of the two metals for a few minutes, and finally "cold-rolled" several times.

The American Medical Association will announce tomorrow a twelve-point program for the advancement of medicine and public health, suggesting it as an alternative to the Federal Government's plan for compulsory health insurance.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The following information, gathered from official sources, indicates the main points in the proposed North Atlantic and Scandinavian pacts:

FOR THIS WEEK: Put up windbreaks to protect broad-leaved evergreens from the brighter sun of late winter. A line of twigs is sufficient for some of the azaleas . . . Order seeds that must be started indoors at once. Decide on fruit so that it may be planted early in spring . . . Pinch back the stems of house plants an inch or more if they are spindly.

The new Cunard White Star liner Caronia, largest passenger vessel to be built since the end of World War II, left here yesterday morning on the first of a series of four fourteen-day "Sunshine Cruises" to the West Indies and South America. The vessel departed from Pier 90, North River, with an estimated 590 passengers.

AN artist's statement about his own work is often of less value than one would expect. Frequently it is only vague adumbration; sometimes it is a collection of misleading aphorisms which, lifted out of context and exaggerated beyond intent, boomerang back to plague the artist and to confuse the spectator.

TUXEDO PARK, Feb. 12 -- Robert Grant 3d had little trouble defeating Clarence C. Pell Jr., 15 -- 8, 15 -- 12 and 15 -- 2 in the semi-final round of the annual Tuxedo Gold Racquets tournament today at the Tuxedo Racquet and Tennis Club, which is celebrating its fiftieth anniversary.

THE art museum has become a matter of public concern -- one of the Issues of the Day. For one thing, like opera companies and symphony orchestras, museums all over America are feeling the financial pinch. They are seeking public support and so their programs and policies are debated as never before.
MARY CHU says people who come to dine at the Midtown Chinese Rathskeller, where even an anchorite would forget about fasting, invariably want to know how to cook at home in Chinese.

CHRISTIAN-JAQUE, the hyphenated French director, eschews both a given name and his own growing reputation here as a specialist in spectacle films. Much as Hollywood will designate a super-production as, say, a "Michael Curtiz," French producers have taken to classifying an epic as a "Christian-Jaque."

AN aura of romance has hovered over the West Indies since Columbus first sighted them -- and thought he had found a western passage to India. Mr. Waugh calls them "The Sugar Islands," a fitting title, for sugar had a long reign in the Caribbean.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 12 -- Overcoming a half-time deficit of four points, the Williams basketball team defeated Amherst by 38 -- 36 today.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 -- Despite strikes along the waterfront, ship movements at the Port of Philadelphia in 1948 reached an eight-year high of 14,317, including 7,252 arrivals and 7,065 clearances.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 12 (UP) -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley led a pilgrimage to Abraham Lincoln's tomb today as the nation observed the birthday anniversary of the Civil War President.

SHAKESPEARE'S "Julius Caesar" is to be presented in full on television -- and with a sponsor. The production will be staged by the Masquers of Amherst College in the Elizabethan playhouse of the Folger Shakespeare Memorial Library in Washington on Sunday, April 3.

TO readers familiar (not necessarily in life, but in literature) with Roman Catholic convents and nuns, the Anglican Sisters who occasionally make their appearance in contemporary fiction are apt to seem -- speaking in purely novelistic terms -- not quite adequate. Nuns are used in a novel for a purpose--to symbolize religion, the dedicated life; and for this purpose Anglican Sisters cannot equal their Roman Catholic counterparts.

SHERRILL, N. Y., Feb. 12 -- Each of the twenty-nine churches of all denominations in the cities of Oneida and Sherrill and the villages of Oneida Castle and Vernon received this week a $500 contribution from the Oneida, Ltd., silverware manufacturers.

Matthew Fox, president of the American Indonesian Corporation, was quoted in a statement issued here yesterday as saying that his corporation "has no monopoly on Indonesian trade with the United States." He said the corporation was set up "to serve the usual function of a foreign government purchasing commission, which will transact business for the Indonesian Republican Government only and have nothing whatever to do with business between private interests in the two countries."

DANBURY, Conn., Feb. 12 -- The scheduled appearance of Henry A. Wallace, former Vice President and unsuccessful Progressive party candidate for President last November, as guest speaker at next Thursday's luncheon meeting of the Danbury Lions Club drew an attack today from the pastors of the city's six Roman Catholic churches.

Although reports from retailers throughout the country varied sharply last week, depending on local weather and employment conditions, the over-all retail picture is favorable, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. A highly satisfactory volume of reorders for some apparel lines helped to brighten the business prospect, it was said.

WHEN Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels published the Communist Manifesto one hundred years ago they prophesied, "The first step in the revolution by the working class is to raise the proletariat to the position of ruling class and to establish democracy."

MISS TEY, an English novelist, has written her mystery in a rather well-known pattern: once again an English gentleman (in the manner of the Donnequoting Peter Wimsey) rescues a lady from the brink of disaster. The tender dialectic between gentleman and lady is always in the foreground, while the "mystery" itself is more of a shadow-play.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 -- A continuation of the downward trend of business activity was in evidence during January, the business survey committee of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago reported today. The committe's survey also predicted slightly less production this year compared with 1948.
THE film screenings of the Museum of Modern Art have become increasingly popular through the years -- so much so, in fact, that since the war you have to have a reservation to get in at all.

TWENTY-TWO years ago Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, who up to then had been called the "Red General," scourged out of the new National Government of China the Communists who had been his allies under Dr. Sun Yat-sen in a successful revolt against first the Manchus and then the warlords.

The policy of the United States Military Government in Germany on socialization was outlined in a letter by an aide of President Truman to Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, which the latter made public yesterday.

The market for high grade bonds presents a checkered picture today. Until the new price declines in commodities and equity shares, it seemed as if the bullishness behind the winter's rise in bond prices might have been spent. Now, the status of the market is more uncertain than ever.

A SHORT essay often can give as fair a prespective of a big subject as a weighty tome. A brief work, in fact, can be more valuable to those who do not have the time or desire to be distracted from the main theme by an abundance of detail, no matter how delightful.

Solomon, the English pianist, proved himself worthy of using only his last name yesterday afternoon. Music, as it was projected through his fingers in his recital at Carnegie Hall, was communication of the highest order: eloquent, searching, warm and deeply satisfying.

MANY people who have stopped listening regularly are now reserving Wednesday evenings in Canada as their favorite radio night. The reason is the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation's special series of cultural programs from 7:30 to 11 P. M. The series has been steadily gaining in popularity and after its first year now is considered to be out of the experimental phase.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 12 -- Flashing down the fast though short Whirlaway Trail in 43.2 seconds, Netberg of the Norway Ski Club won the New York City downhill ski race at Jiminy Peak today.

President Truman led the nation yesterday in commemorating the 140th anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln. Civic and patriotic ceremonies at shrines erected to the memory of the Civil War President at several places in the deep South and across the rest of the nation attracted countless thousands of Americans who paid solemn tribute to his name.
CHICAGO, Feb. 12 -- Residents of the Central States were outraged this week by the conviction of Cardinal Mindszenty in Hungary.
Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Mc Gowan celebrated the fiftieth an niversary of their wedding yester day with a breakfast on the thirteenth floor of the Brooklyn Municipal Building, 208 Joralemon Street.

THE business of presenting awards for various achievements in the cinema is booming these days. The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences entered the last lap of its annual sweepstakes the other day with the announcement of nominations.

BUENOS AIRES. SINCE August, 1947, when delegates of nineteen nations gathered at Rio de Janeiro to draft a treaty of mutual defense and assistance, governments have fallen in Ecuador, Peru, Venezuela and Paraguay. In Colombia, one of the most swift and savage revolts in the history of this hemisphere made a shambles of an Inter-American Conference.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 12 -- Sheikh Hassan el Banna, 39-year-old head of the outlawed Moslem Brotherhood, extremist Egyptian nationalist movement that was banned after authorities had declared it responsible for a series of bombing outrages and killings last year, was shot five times today by a group of young men in a car and died tonight in a hospital.

With all thirty-two Giants already in the fold for the 1949 baseball season, interest in contract signing is now being focused on the efforts of the Yankees and Dodgers to get their remaining athletes in line before the March 1 training grind begins and yesterday the Bombers fortified their lead by announcing their twenty-fifth signer.

DETROIT, Feb. 12 -- A plan for the assembly-line production of 20,000,000 low-price houses in the next ten years through initial financing by the Federal Government and utilization of idle aircraft plants was advanced today by Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO.

According to the Scientific Director of the Nutrition Foundation, Dr. Charles Glen King, the shift in distribution of our population from youth to middle and old age, largely a result of success in learning how to combat infections, "has brought medical research to a new frontier of intensive exploration."

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 12 -- Last October Mrs. Helen S. Reineman, wife of a Chicago steel manufacturer, claimed a race horse named Dinner Hour for $12,500. Today she received an $8,525 return on the investment -- plus the top thrill of her brief racing career -- when the 5-year-old gelding ran off with the $12,250 Miami Beach Handicap at Hialeah Park.

THE United States section has declined to submit any compositions for the International Society for Contemporary Music's festival in Palermo this April. The move was made after considerable deliberation, because the leaders here wanted to register a protest against the treatment of the American branch without breaking with the international body.

I should think Brooks Atkinson would resent the implication in Henry Sherek's article, "How to Tell a Flop," that the sort of review he writes depends on the dinner he's had. Donating good cooks to critics won't help a bit.

By a slight majority, 500 high school students voted yesterday that the House Un-American Activities Committee should be retained only if its procedures are changed. A relatively few voted for the retention of the committee in its present form.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The European Recovery Program stood before the bar of Congress this week in the role of a probationer seeking approval of its trial period. It asked a grant of authority and the wherewithal to continue its endeavors for another year.
After a six months' chase that wound in and out of the southwestern United States, Mexico and the West Indies, law enforcement agents seized William P. Buckner Jr. in Puerto Rico yesterday.

BILL SLATER, by trade a master of ceremonies, knows how it feels to wear the shoe on the other foot. Not so long ago when he was a teacher and headmaster, he belonged to the legion of educators and parents who, on occasion, hurled criticism at radio's commercials. Today he can rattle off a sales spiel with all the assurance of a veteran at the microphone.

ST. VALENTINE'S DAY, according to calculations of greeting card manufacturers, is the cause this year of putting more than 300,000,000 appropriate missives in circulation. Curiously, only about half of them are being exchanged between lovers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- On Lincoln's Birthday, Republicans, surveying the state of their party in the nation, found it none too good. They had lost five straight Presidential elections; they were a minority in the House and Senate; and they could claim only nineteen of the forty-eight Governors.

ONE of the outstanding floral displays in the country, the Azalea Trail at Mobile, Ala., is preparing for the earliest opening in its history. A week from today a high school girl will cut the ribbon that will start the official motorcade around the seventeen-mile-long trail opening the flowery stretch to the public.

The article "Movie Mogul, $800,000 -- Truman, $100,000," by David Cushman Coyle, fails to present a clear picture. It makes no mention of the $90,000 tax-free expense account, palace with servants and most expenses paid, the yacht which even a man making $800,000 a year could not afford, the airplane, fleet of cars and all the other things that the President gets in addition to his salary.

Despite the fact that prices of steel-making scrap metal have fallen as much as $10 a ton in certain localities since the beginning of the year, there has been no indication that the substantial decline will be reflected in lower steel prices in the near future.

EXCEPT for the return of "Laurence Olivier and Vivien Leigh to London as Sir Peter and Lady Teazle in the Old Vic production of "The School for Scandal," a little too decorative and not quite dramatic enough, we have had no very important home-grown products on view since the turn of the year.

The new import procedures for the bizonal area of Germany under which the Germans will get virtual control of their foreign trade will probably have two major effects, according to views in foreign trade circles here last week. These are increased intra-European trade by the zone and from a longer-range standpoint an improved volume of commercial imports from the United States and easier payments for them.

ALTHOUGH the phrase was coined in grandma's day, we have it from lyric writer Sylvia Dee ("Barefoot Boy With Cheek"; song hits "Chickery Chick," "My Sugar Is So Refined," etc.), whose first novel this is, that the major portion of her title was still apt a generation ago.

A COMMENTARY on the state of poetry in America is the history to date of Archibald MacLeish's "ActFive and Other Poems." This book is a remarkable event in American letters. MacLeish is a poet who spent years in a position of power in our nation's affairs during a period of crisis and in "ActFive" he makes his report on what he learned from that experience.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Feb. 12 -- A public opinion researcher of the Fourth Century was quoted today in outlining to modern pollsters and social scientists the stage of thinking they have reached in their work.

FOR how many Sundays I have sat pen-poised and ready to address the Mailbag I know not. Desperation has conquered vanity, however, and, if you please, won the day. Just what do you mean by that word Rialto? There! To paraphrase Betty Garrett, I've asked it and I'm glad!

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Feb. 12 Defying a west-southwest wind that slapped between fifteen and twenty-two miles an hour, the dinghies at the Larchmont Yacht Club today went through the first session of their dual holiday races.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 12 -- With bunting, flags and festive array covering its battle scars, Jerusalem will be host Monday to members of Israel's first elected Government. Although it is still outside the state, it was selected as the site for inaugural of the Constituent Assembly because of its historic and symbolic significance.

LIKE 90 per cent of Actors Equity I am currently unemployed in the theatre. Yet as a lecturer on the theatre I am booked six nights a week for twenty-five weeks before sold out houses in 132 cities from Philadelphia to San Francisco.

NO PLANTS are capable of more bloom in relation to the area they occupy, or the attention they require, than climbing roses. Against fences, along walls, over arches and in many an odd corner they display masses of colorful and appealing flowers. This is a good time to select them for spring planting.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 12 -- Industrial leaders here voiced the opinion today that the Government should continue its policy of import licenses if it wants industry to thrive. There has been a serious struggle on this issue between organized industry and disorganized agriculture.

THE current show at the Feigl Gallery is a herald of the Oskar Kokoschka retrospective, which is to be held at the Museum of Modern Art later in the year after the close of its present tour. In the present exhibition are a dozen of the Austrian expressionist's recent water-colors and a single oil painting.

An extensive collection of French period furniture and a large quantity of fine household appointments will be auctioned in five sessions from Tuesday through Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

I had cut out a page of the TIMES containing the review of "The Boy With Green Hair" and just read it again after seeing the picture. That was a fine review, especially the paragraphs concerning the mental attitude involved.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 12 -- Army's varsity swimming team handed Princeton its first Eastern Intercollegiate League defeat tonight, coming from behind in the final two events to down the Tigers by 43 -- 32. The victory was the cadets' seventh in eight starts this season and their second in three league meets.

BUFFALO, Feb. 12 -- City College of New York strengthened its claim to the metropolitan leadership tonight by following St. John's 59-55 loss to Niagara with an easy victory over Canisius, 70 to 54, before 11,374 fans in Memorial Auditorium.

Hungary's present activity as one of Soviet Russia's satellite states, zealous to carry out the orders of Moscow, forms a strange contrast to events in Hungary 100 years ago this year. For in 1849 Russian armies joined with Austrian armies to crush the Hungarian independence movement.

A LIFE of George Lloyd -- champion of empire and ultimately peer of the realm -- had it been written independently of family, friends and formalities, might have been a distinctive contribution to historical biography.

IN lieu of more brutal explanations for the recurring cycles of poor films which seem to invade our theatres, we patient reviewers often give the seasons as kindly excuses. In our sweet generosity, we will say that a big flock of "turkeys" in August is just the usual influx of "summer fare," or a pile-up of duds before Christmas is a normal "pre-holiday lull."
PARIS, Feb. 12 -- For the second time in recent months Charles de Gaulle hinted tonight that he might be compelled to take power by other than democratic means.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Winston Churchill will sail on the Queen Elizabeth on March 18 for his visit to the United States. His program, which includes engagements in Cambridge and New York and a visit to Washington, was announced here today by Conservative party headquarters a day after a similar announcement was made in Washington.

DETROIT, Feb. 12 (UP) -- Chrysler Corporation proposes to find out if there is any sizable market for smaller and cheaper cars. This spring, or early summer, it will begin marketing its new short wheelbase Plymouths and Dodges. If a big market is found, Chrysler will be all tooled and ready to roll.

ON an afternoon not long ago in Studio H-8, Radio City, two men, one 82, the other 28, sat side by side, listening to the rehearsal of Ernest Ansermet. The octogenarian was Arturo Toscanini. The infant by his side was Guido Cantelli.
PARIS, Feb. 12 -- The lawsuit brought by Victor Kravchenko against the Communist weekly, Les Lettres Francaises, is certainly the biggest single public attraction in France at the present time.

Having served during the recent war as a target for submarines, a hunter of submarines and a Naval staff operations officer concerned with submarine defense, I naturally read Hanson Baldwin's "'The Snorkel' in the War of the Future" with the greatest of interest.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent of Canada began an ambitious week-end of policy discussions here today, looking forward to talks with President Truman about such matters of mutual interest as the North Atlantic defense pact, European recovery and the proposed St. Lawrence seaway.

Two hundred Boy Scouts and scouting executives took part yesterday in a torch-Lighting ceremony at the Statue of Liberty on Bedloes Island, and began a two-year crusade to "strengthen the arm of liberty."

" I PRESENT these tales," says Graham Greene at the beginning of this new collection of his short stories, "merely as the by-products of a novelist's career." There are eighteen stories and a fragment of an abandoned novel. Most of them are very good in themselves -- two of them brilliant -- but it is not only for their solid virtues as English short stories, their quietness and lucid ease, that they are important.
THERE appears to be a growing tendency for program makers on one or two nation-wide concert broadcasts to insert "overtures" and other bravura - style selections at midpoint spots in their programs.

A LOT of guessing about the business outlook was being done in Washington and other quarters last week as a result of the setbacks sustained in commodity and security markets. Out of all this experting there was nothing clear and convincing enough offered to indicate which way business affairs are really moving.

The availability, adequacy, distribution and method of providing medical care has become one of the most discussed and controversial of our domestic issues. Many of these problems require much thought, debate and long-range planning. One facet, however, which demands immediate attention is that of medical care in the armed forces.

In Washington one day last month a man in a blue business suit started to enter the Pentagon Building. A guard challenged him: "Do you have a pass?" The civilian grinned and said: "I'm Eisenhower." He got in.

Mel Hein will be back in New York next fall, but not with the New York Football Giants, the club with which he starred for fifteen years in the National Football League. Yesterday the combined Yankees-Dodgers of the rival All-America Conference announced that Hein had been signed as assistant to Head Coach Norman (Red) Strader.
CHICAGO, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Today's report of the markets in the Union Stockyards by the United States Department of Agriculture follows

While long range implications of economic and political developments are necessary to plot the future course of retail business, they have little bearing on the immediate program for merchandising seasonal apparel, it was pointed out last week by Joseph L. Dubow, executive director of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association.

SIXTY - TWO prize winners shared $5,000 in cash awards in the 1948 Graflex Photo Contest. Philippe Halsman won first prize in the professional action class for his picture, "Dali Atomicus"; Meyer Liebowitz of THE NEW YORK TIMES for a sports shot, "Pardon My Glove," took second prize in the same class. He also won a $300 press award.

The recent news from Japan reporting the almost total destruction by fire of one of the most famous monuments in the Orient probably found its way only to the back pages of a few of the great newspapers of America. This was the destruction of the Kondo, the Golden Hall, of the Buddhist monastery of Horyuji in Nara.

Based on a desire for lower operating costs, industry is buying boilers and oil burner combinations at a rate higher than ever before, G. E. De Siena, vice president, Superior Combustion Industries, Inc., 1475 Broadway, revealed yesterday, following a survey of engineers' demands in all major portions of the country.

SOWING seeds indoors can become quite a complicated ritual, because of the various kinds of equipment that are now available. Actually, a few labels, plus adherence to certain routine measures, are all that are needed for window sill seed-sowing.
Graham D. Perley Jr. of Philadelphia has been appointed national agent of the Amplex Manufacturing Company to handle sales of the Amplex standard acrylic plastic lighting canopy for retail stores.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- An effort to reach a compromise between the proposed North Atlantic defense pact and the proposed Scandinavian pact has been made in Stockholm, but so far no formula has been found that is satisfactory to the United States, Norway, Sweden and Denmark.
EZEIZA, Argentina, Feb. 12 -- Representatives of all nations of the Western Hemisphere this morning had the first official view of the new airport here that Argentina is building.

Dr. Halvard M. Lange, Norwegian Foreign Minister, left here yesterday after a visit of nearly a week during which he engaged in exploratory talks on the feasibility of his nation's entering upon conversations looking toward the setting up of a North Atlantic defense pact.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The American Federation of Labor is considering putting state legislators on its payroll so labor sympathizers can afford the lawmaking jobs.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Portugal will vote in national elections tomorrow, with President Antonio Oscar de Fragoso Carmona unopposed as a result of the last-minute withdrawal of the only opposition candidate.
LONDON, Feb. 12 -- It was in 1943 that three principal Allied powers announced in Moscow a declaration of their intention to restore Austria's independence after the war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Affiliation with the Congress of Industrial Organizations was recommended today by the executive board of the Communications Workers of America, one of the country's largest independent unions.
Benjamin Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, has withdrawn as a co-sponsor of the annual dinner of The Churchman, Protestant Episcopal magazine, it was learned yesterday.

Textile and electrical appliance distributors in the last year have been the cause of more concern to credit executives than have any other lines of business, according to Mortimer J. Davis, executive manager of the New York Credit Men's Association.

With the appointment of two new members to the Board of Regents last week, attention was focused on the controversy that is now taking place as to who shall control the system of higher education in New York State. After being kept behind closed doors for nearly a year, the struggle finally has burst into the open.

ATHENS, Feb. 12 -- A large-scale rebel assault on Florina, a major western Macedonian center seven miles from the Yugoslav frontier, was launched early this morning and has been repulsed, according to a special Greek General Staff communique late in the day.

AN exhibition of 100 years of news and documentary photography, "The Exact Instant," which includes examples from the daguerreotypes of the Eighteen Forties to the best pictures in yesterday's newspaper, opened last week at the Museum of Modern Art.

Bankers who believed that further credit restrictions were not likely to be authorized in view of the current deflationary trend received a public warning last week. The caution was delivered by their own titular leader, Evans Woollen Jr., president of the American Bankers Association, in an address here before the group's annual Trust Conference.

The Cunard White Star Line has adopted an unusual light green hull paint for the new liner Caronia and apparently is determined to preserve it as long as possible, it was apparent from the elaborate precautions taken during the berthing of the vessel last week.

Two bed ridden women were rescued and 100 persons, including sixty children, escaped safely at 2:40 A. M. yesterday after a fire had broken out in a top floor apartment at 213 Avenue of the Americas, in lower Greenwich Village.

Herman L. Weisman, acting national chairman of the United Palestine Appeal, urged the Government of Israel yesterday to curb by "prompt and unequivocal action the multiplicity of splinter campaigns" in this country that are threatening the priority of the United Jewish Appeal campaign for $250,000,000.
NANKING, Sunday, Feb. 13 (UP) -- The Government prepared today to abandon Tsingtao, headquarters of the United States Western Pacific Fleet.

The Court Street Seamen's Club in Brooklyn is one of the Salvation Army's sixty religious and welfare services in New York to men, women and children, regardless of race or creed. Last year the club had an attendance of 56,209.

The Board of Higher Education has adopted a resolution recommending that Mayor O'Dwyer take steps to purchase the eighteen-and-a-half acre plant of the Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart "at the earliest possible moment" for City College, Benjamin Ribman, a member of the board, reported yesterday.
HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 12 -- Dartmouth's basketball team concluded the winter carnival weekend with an easy 60-25 victory over Harvard tonight in an Eastern League game at Alumni Gym.

WHEN this play was published in Great Britain a year ago I persuaded the manager of the theatre in which it was (and is) playing to place copies of the book on sale in the auditorium and in a burst of pride offered a prize to the usher who first sold fifty copies.

Coats, like spring, "are busting out all over." They are lined with swishing taffeta in gay colors; they are bright in hue as the spring itself. If their hips are not padded, as in the case of the Christian Dior design, they are cut to simulate padded roundness (note the Matlin model) or have extended pleat flanges (as in the case of the Vincent Coppola coat).
Snow and arctic air continued to spread blizzard conditions yesterday over the northern plains. The Associated Press reported subzero at midday in the blizzard belt.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Feb. 12 -- British authorities released German Communist leader Max Reimann from prison today after they had suspended the three-months' sentence imposed on him Feb. 1. These authorities explained that Herr Reimann had been liberated for the duration of the constitutional discussions in Bonn.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Protestant ministers are negotiating with the Government to form a new "loyal" Evangelical council, Director of Cults Boris Iliev announced today.
The influence of Abraham Lincoln is needed more than ever today in a world in which Communists are reviving religious persecution, rabbis declared in Lincoln's Birthday sermons here yesterday.

THE title of Howard Mumford Jones' book is accurate. These essays, which were originally part of the Messenger Lectures at Cornell, do not deal with American literature directly. Nor do they present a close analysis of the various histories of American literature that extend from Samuel Knapp's "Lectures," in 1829, to the recent "Literary History of the United States."

NEWARK, N. J., Feb. 12 -- A basket by Paul Labanowski with three minutes of play remaining gave St. Francis College a 55-53 victory over Rutgers College of Newark in the Newark Armory tonight. The triumph was the sixteenth this season for the Terriers against six setbacks.

THIS book begins with some rather pointed questions concerning the prospective furniture buyer's family life, profession, income and place of residence. Since each of these has an important effect on what furniture one should buy, it follows that such questions are in order and help prevent expensive mistakes.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 12 -- With more than 3,000 fans jamming Payne Whitney Gymnasium and cheering him as much when he missed as when he connected, Yale's peerless Tony Lavelli tonight became the third ranking all-time major college scorer as the Bulldogs beat Navy, 64 -- 47, for their tenth straight triumph.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Associate Justice Robert H. Jackson, chief United States prosecutor at the Nuremberg war trials, disclosed tonight how "stubborn and deep" discords with Soviet representatives had persisted in the preparation for those trials.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 12 -- Signs of spring appeared this week in many areas of the Southwest, and people took advantage of clear skies and the warm sun by motoring, picnicking, golfing, hunting and just being out of doors.
Spring classes will begin at the city's four municipal colleges tomorrow for an estimated 26,785 matriculated day session students, the Board of Higher Education announced yesterday.
ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 12 -- Cornell moved into third place ahead of Princeton in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League race by defeating the Tigers, 59 -- 44, before 5,000 tonight.

TOKYO, Feb. 12 -- Determined warfare against Japan's Communists was pledged today by Premier Shigeru Yoshida. Already, it appears, instructions have gone out through Liberal party channels for the organization of a lower house Committee on Un-Japanese Activities.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 12 -- The Central News Agency reported today from Lanchow, capital of Kansu Province in northwest China, that Gen. Chang Chih-chung had resigned from the Government's first-string team of peace negotiators.

ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- Two bills to encourage automobile driving courses in all high schools will be introduced in the Legislature with the backing of the Joint Legislative Committee on Motor Vehicle Problems. One will urge the schools to establish courses designed to improve driving, and the other will provide for issuing a full operator's license at the age of seventeen to students who pass approved courses.

IN spite of the implication in the title, Dr. Hutchinson has not devised a formula for writing a St. Matthew Passion, painting a Sistine ceiling or solving problems in mathematical logic. A research psychologist and teacher now connected with an industrial firm, he has probed the experience of creative thinkers in the arts and sciences of today and of the past, trying to extract from them those factors which were common to all.

SALZBURG, Austria, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Two fugitive Hungarians said tonight they had "final and absolute proof" that the conviction of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty was "a farce built on a stack of forged and extorted documents." They acknowledged, however, that they had not been asked to testify at the Cardinal's trial because the defense attorney never raised the question of the validity of the documents introduced.

STATION WNYC's tenth American Music Festival, which opened yesterday and will continue until Feb. 22, will present more than 150 studio and concert hall programs dedicated to the best and newest in American music. Programs will range from a New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra rehearsal to a session of barbershop ballads.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 -- Despite increased pressure by Federal, state and city officials, negotiations toward settlement of the strike of 11,000 operating employes of th Philadelphia Transportation Company remained deadlocked tonight.

MELVIN HALL'S earlier book, "Journey to the End of an Era," gave promise of more to come. Here, a year later, he fulfills that promise with more of the same. The first book, laden with the gold, frankincense and myrrh of memory, was issued as an autobiography.

AS indicated a few pages farther on, in Mr. Thompson's "In and Out of Books," no book of recent months has provoked more sharply divergent reactions among the reviewers than the new Dos Passos novel, "The Grand Design." In the published response to this novel you can find reflected as in a clear glass all our critical confusion, all our insistence on applying political and social yardsticks to matters that cannot be so measured.

True, MacNeice did not have Auden's rather overpowering virtuosity, nor did he seem so "serious," so reflective a poet as Spender or Lewis.

PATRONS of museums and art galleries, together with educational authorities and college students throughout the country, will have opportunity during the coming months to compare United States postal art with that of foreign governments.

A "sweeping paralysis of thought," an acceptance of "paternalistic" measures from gov ernment and the surrender of the individual citizen's own responsibilities could lead to a dictatorship in this country, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, warned yesterday.

ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 12 -- Syracuse University captured the two-day Western division Intercillegiat Ski Union meet, adding a slalom victory and a second place in the jump today to the double triumph in the downhill and cross-country yesterday to amass 576.4 points.

THE current retrospective exhibition of work by Max Weber, at the Whitney Museum, is doubly interesting in that it not only presents clearly the progress of an outstanding contemporary American artist but also mirrors in miniature so much of the development of the modern movement as a whole.

Valuations of unlisted common stock, determined on the basis of earnings attributable to tangible and intangible assets of a corporation, according to the method employed, can produce vast variations in the results.

ON BOARD U. S. S. CURTISS, Off Kodiak, Alaska, Feb. 12 -- Present types of landing craft are not entirely adequate for cold-weather operations, the amphibious landings of the Navy's "Operation Micowex" -- Minor Cold Weather Exercise -- have shown.

General Electric Company is maintaining first-quarter production of most appliances at levels reached in the last quarter of 1948 and is increasing output of some items from 10 to 40 per cent, Hardage L. Andrews, vice president in charge of the appliance and merchandising division, disclosed in an interview last week.
ALBANY, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Citizens Public Expenditure Survey called today for cuts in Governor Dewey's proposed $936,200,000 budget and said such reductions would make tax increases unnecessary.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Economic soft spots are developing in various sections of the country and in many industries, Kenton R. Cravens, chairman of the credit policy commission of the American Bankers Association, said here today. "We may be at an economic cross-roads," he told 900 bankers at the mid-winter meeting of the Ohio Bankers Association.

Describing Latin America as "Economic Frontier No. 1," Raymond F. Pelissier, teacher of international trade at the University of Notre Dame, in a statement for THE NEW YORK TIMES, said "private capital will be the greatest need if the expected development of this area is to occur."

IN your book section of Jan. 30, Mr. Herschel Brickell, reviewing a travel book, used the word "metropoli," evidently thinking it was the plural of "metropolis." Now, I don't blame Mr. Brickell for not knowing the plural of the word, but he must have remembered that he had not studied Latin or Greek.
HOLLYWOOD. MOTION pictures are entering their third major era. First there was the silent period. Then the sound era. Now we are on the threshold of the television age.

ROME, Feb. 12 -- The Sacred Consistorial Congregation, of which Pope Pius himself is head, issued a "declaration" today excommunicating and declaring "infamous" all persons who "raised sacrilegious hands" upon Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, Hungarian Primate sentenced to life imprisonment, and who "led him before a civil tribunal and by iniquitous sentence prevented him from exercising his ecclesiastical archiepiscopal jurisdiction."

The Furness liner Queen of Bermuda is carrying her first post-war contingent of passengers in the familiar run between New York and Bermuda, a welcome addition to the growing roster of luxurious liners serving this port. Some of the tonnage is new, but many of the ships are old friends, returning at long last after years of war service and after extensive and costly reconditioning.

JOHN BERRYMAN of 120 Prospect Avenue, Princeton, N. J., is working on a biography of Stephen Crane (1871-1900). He would be grateful for any documents (photostats or exact transcriptions) or reminiscences. All borrowed material will be returned at once, Mr. Berryman says.

SALT LAKE CITY -- With perfect snow conditions prevailing throughout this region, Utahans are hoping for record-breaking crowds as well as record-breaking leaps at the National Ski Jumping Championships scheduled to begin Saturday on near-by Ecker Hill. The contest will run through Feb. 22.

ONE of the most vexing problems in higher education today is the training of competent college and university instructors. Our teachers' colleges prepare teachers for elementary and secondary schools; little attention is paid to training for teaching on a collegiate level.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 -- A program to "capture more of the airways for God" and to obtain a "significant share" of television for religious programs was outlined today before the first annual meeting of the National Council of Presbyterian Men.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 -- Women's apparel stores in Philadelphia reported 14 per cent greater sales last week than they had a year ago and for the year to date their sales are 8 per cent above those for the first five weeks of 1948.
A record number of foreign study opportunities is being mapped by American colleges and universities for the summer, a TIMES survey discloses.

The week starting tomorrow has been designated National Heart Week. In that connection THE TIMES asked Dr. Alfred E. Cohn, physician, scientist, author, member emeritus of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, to describe the structure and workings of the heart.

THERE are thousands of American youngsters who will always believe that Hamlet looked like Laurence Olivier and for whom Dumas' Milady will forever evoke a Technicolor image of Lana Turner. In pre-cinema childhoods it was the illustrations in books which left indelible impress on the mind's eye. There were Tenniel's pinafored Alice and Howard Pyle's dashing Robin Hood.

GENEVA, Feb. 12 -- The International Refugee Organization will make immediate payment of $2,000,000 to the American Joint Distribution Committee in reimbursement for movements of eligible displaced persons to Palestine since May 18, 1948, it was announced here today.

SAVANNAH, Ga. -- Tourist traffic through this colorful port city of the South is unusually heavy right now, with Savannah getting a big play from motorists en route to Florida resorts and those on the way back North.

THE forceful portrait on the right of King Amenemhat III is one of the prize objects of the Gulbenkian Collection, which has just been sent from England on indefinite loan to the National Gallery of Art in Washington. It focuses attention on the ancient Egyptians' supreme achievement in the art of portrait sculpture, of which a few examples are presented on these pages.
WASHINGTON -- Rural roads, neglected during the war years, today present an estimated $5,000,000,000 rehabilitation problem which Federal, state and county governments are trying to solve.

The California Research Corporation, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of California, and the Isotopes Division of the Atomic Energy Commission announce that the corporation's research staff is successfully using radioactive piston rings to test the effects of fuels and lubricants on engine wear.

I am with your Ira Henry Freeman all the way down the mountain ("Six Fables About Skiing -- And the Facts") until he gets to the skier's reward. A hot buttered rum, of all things! You don't butter a rum like you butter a bun.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- The possibility that the Austrian treaty negotiations might be making headway behind the scenes was seen here today when it became known that United States Representative Samuel Reber had conferred privately with Yugoslav Foreign Minister Dr. Ales Bebler. This was the first meeting between Mr. Reber and Dr. Bebler since the latter's arrival Wednesday, the day the four-power negotiations were resumed.

WITH "Diamond Lil" and "Richard III" opening during the last fortnight and the return of "They Knew What They Wanted" on Wednesday, it is interesting to note this morning that the current season has seen the reversal of the revival trend. In fact, the way reissues had been pouring forth in recent years Broadway had almost taken on the shape of one big repertory theatre devoted to dusting off the library shelves.

Unemployment among railroad workers passed the 100,000 mark last week, reports from railway sources showed yesterday. This is around 10 per cent of the total working force in the industry and is sharply higher than levels of idleness a year ago.

SO many conflicting judgments about the future of the book world have recently been proclaimed that bookmen's row resembles nothing so much as a stageful of Wagnerians baying out "Goetterdaemmerung." Before making these utterances on the state of the book world almost nobody consults the people who actually sell books, so it seemed a good time to trot around to various of Manhattan's 500 bookshops and ask what was going on.

THE annual Charleston Azalea Festival is the background for this story of murder and Southern chivalry. Dr. Victoria Grant, a woman physician from Connecticut, is less interested in the festival than she is in meeting her old friend and schoolmate, Maggie Fairlee, who has married into an old Charleston family.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 12 -- The three members of the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission arrived here from Jerusalem today to begin their tour of the Arab countries.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 -- Soviet Communist leaders, to forward their objective of world conquest, are endeavoring to turn the peaceful evolution now under way into violent revolution, John Foster Dulles charged here today.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 12 (AP) -- The battle for honors in the two top divisions provided the main interest at the opening of the national speed skating championships today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Lobbying was a $6,000,000 industry in Washington during 1948, and by all signs it will flourish even more in 1949.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Leon Keyserling, one of President Truman's top economic advisers, declared today that prosperity in the United States should hit an all-time high in 1949.

BOSTON, Feb. 12 -- Dave Creighton and Zellio Toppazzini, teenaged rookie wingers, made auspicious National Hockey League debuts as the Boston Bruins toppled the New York Rangers, 4 -- 2, tonight before a packed 13,900 crowd at the Boston Garden.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 12 -- Paced by their brilliant Olympic star, Mrs. Rhoda Wurtele Eaves of Montreal, a team of Canadian women skiers defeated an American team today to win the Lake Placid Club's annual international competition for the Kate Smith Trophy.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 (AP) -- La Salle's slick basketball team outpassed and outshot Manhattan College tonight to bury the New Yorkers under a 76-to-46 score before 3,611 at Convention Hall. Temple University whipped Penn State, 56 to 46, in a battle of zone defenses in the opener of the collegiate court double-header.

I should like to make the suggestion through your columns that the word "very" be eliminated from our language. It is superfluous, it no longer has any force as the result of maddening over-usage, and it carries on a parasitic existence at the expense of dozens of words that do have meaning.

For the first time since the end of hostilities, the petroleum industry has an excess of supplies. Storage facilities have been filled and every division from the well to the consumer has ample facilities to take care of any reasonable demand that may be made upon it. Its huge post-war expansion program, now virtually completed, appears to have brought an end to the "shortage era," barring another military crisis.

Eighteen newspaper men will attend a three-week seminar for managing editors and news editors sponsored by Columbia's American Press Institute and opening tomorrow at the university, it was announced yesterday.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Dinner Gong scored an easy victory in the $50,000 added San Antonio Handicap today and sounded a new threat for the $100,000 Santa Anita Handicap two weeks away.

TAKEN together, these volumes offer a fact-filled survey of the state of agriculture in this country today. They complement each other uniquely, for Mr. Denison's history is the story of the mechanization of farm machinery in the last century and the volume by Dr. Taylor and his colleagues assesses the results of this mechanization in terms of the human beings who work the fields and harvest the crops.

LONDON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The energy potion, credited with helping little Yeovil Town's non-league soccer team roll up one upset after another against major opponents in the Football Association Cup tournament, failed today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Seton Hall walloped Georgetown, 70 -- 53, tonight for its thirteenth basketball victory of the season. Forward Pep Saul tossed in 23 points for the victors.

THE author of this small but timely volume -- a masterpiece of condensation -- is a leader of the Congregational churches in Britain and an official of the London Missionary Society. OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 12 -- Uneasiness was rising in the Midwest this week because of continuing sharp declines in the commodity markets.

The aristocracy of American and Canadian dogdom will occupy Madison Square Garden tomorrow and Tuesday for the seventy-third annual Westminster Kennel Club show. They will number 2,562 and their competition will extend through morning, afternoon and evening both days.

IN "Mind in the Shadow," which is to be repeated at 12:30 next Sunday afternoon, the CBS Documentary Unit has probed deeply and thoughtfully into the problem of mental health. With its customary painstaking regard for research, the unit for the first time has laid bare before radio's mass audiences the shameful inadequacy of the country's facilities for providing proper psychiatric care.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UP) -- Former Gov. Ellis Arnall of Georgia, W. B. Huebsch of the Viking Press and Prof. Roscoe C. Martin of the University of Alabama have been appointed to the United States National Commission for the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 12 (UP) -- Residents and merchants of this little winter resort village mourned Max Houben, bobsledder, killed in a trial run on Thursday, in a high requiem mass today, then started a fund for his family in Belgium.

There was a mystical quality in that face which eluded the brush of the painter, which could not be burned on the photographic plate.

Mary and Margaret, circus Siamese twins, are the subject of medical attention because both have high blood pressure. Margaret developed high blood pressure, Grade 2, at the age of 34. Mary's blood pressure was unstable and went up at times, though never as high as Margaret's.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Despite the spectacular drop in farm prices, the rise in unemployment and other signs that inflation may be running its course, Government economists are far from recognizing the existence of any deflationary trend.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- First installments of the Hoover Commission's program for making the Executive Branch of Government, more efficient and less costly demonstrated both the need for action and the back-breaking job it will be to get that action.

IT took a long time to do it, but the bed is finally getting back to the simple thing it used to be in the days of antiquity. Wood frames laced with hide or ropes and piled with layers of linen appear to have satisfied the Egyptians.
ALBANY, Feb 12 -- The State's Department of Commerce urged today that the Federal Government clarify its policy on delivered pricing systems.

COPENHAGEN, Feb. 12 -- Danish Foreign Minister Gustav Rasmussen suggested today that the United States was not serving the cause of world peace by insisting, as a condition for military aid, on the participation by Denmark and Norway in the North Atlantic Pact independently of a mutual defense alliance among the Scandinavian countries.

THE TIMES of Feb. 2 reported President Truman's speech before the National Planning Association. The President was quoted as pleading for planned economy as opposed to controlled economy. THE TIMES report commented: "In making this distinction he implied that he considered a controlled economy totalitarian and a planned economy democratic."

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 12 (UP) -- A proposal to build a mile-high building big enough to house half the city's population, overcome the school shortage and provide underground parking for 80,000 automobiles has been submitted to the Mayor by an architect, A. McF. McSweeney.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 12 -- Spurred by desire to overcome food shortages in Germany, a group of Allied and German scientists has produced and is ready to distribute two food substitutes that are said to taste and have the same nutritious qualities as milk and meat, it was disclosed today.

At least a dozen chemicals are on the market which have only to be sprayed on walls and in crevices to rid the house of vermin, according to common belief. Of these chemicals DDT is by far the best known. There is no question of the efficacy of the group as a whole.

OTTAWA, Feb. 12 -- By electing a Progressive Conservative instead of a Liberal candidate to the Federal Parliament the Quebec district of Nicolet-Yamaska last Monday achieved national and even international renown.

THE prima donnas of a couple of generations ago were fabled creatures. They knew their business as artists, and they knew that they knew. On the stage they were vivid, commanding figures, and off it some were holy terrors.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Feb. 12 -- The Netherlands Government was understood today by well-informed circles to have reached a decision on its attitude to the United Nations Security Council's resolution which called for agreement with Indonesian Republicans and Federalists by Feb. 15.

Columbia teams in three sports were defeated at University Hall yesterday, losing a fencing engagement to N. Y. U., 18 -- 9; a swimming meet to Pennsylvania, 54 -- 21, and a wrestling match to Rutgers, 26 -- 5.

DUBLIN, Feb. 12 -- Sean MacBride, Minister for External Affairs of the Republic of Ireland, declared here tonight that the partition of Ireland was a matter for joint discussion by the participants in the North Atlantic pact.

HAL ELLSON'S first novel is the grim unfolding of the day-to-day existence led by a delinquent teen-age Negro in a Harlem slum area. The author, who worked for several years as a recreational therapist, has drawn upon case material for his story -- including the thorough documenting of Duke's addiction to marijuana.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 12 -- Four professionals -- Johnny Palmer, Dave Douglas, Sam Snead and Dick Metz -- were tied for first place today at the end of fifty-four holes in the $10,000 Texas open golf tournament.

Chairman Edward P. F. Eagan of the State Athletic Commission will be asked on Tuesday to listen to a protest over Referee Eddie Joseph's handling of the featherweight battle in which Willie Pep regained the world title from Sandy Saddler last Friday night in Madison Square Garden. At the same time, he will be asked to entertain a request for a return bout between the 126-pound rivals.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 12 -- Some of the world's most pressing problems will be considered in their broadest aspects at the spring convocation to which the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has invited President Truman and Winston Churchill.

URBANA - CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Feb. 12 -- The University of Illinois reports that this state leads the nation in production of refined corn products, particularly corn starch and its derivatives. In a discussion of "wet-milling," or corn refining, it states that Illinois has three of the country's largest refining plants, including one at Argo having an annual capacity of 60,000,000 bushels.
DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 12 (AP) -- A new unofficial speed record from Dayton to Washington of 33 minutes and three seconds was set Friday in a jet plane, the Air Materiel Command announced today.

A full legislative inquiry into the operations of the Port Authority to determine the feasibility of reducing toll charges on its tunnels and bridges was called for yesterday by J. R. Crossley, vice president of the Automobile Club of New York.

Documents were presented yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES giving a version of the capitulation of the Belgian Army in May, 1940, at variance with the account related by former Prime Minister Winston Churchill in the instalment of his memoirs published by this newspaper last Monday.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 12 -- Outplayed until midway in the second half, Army's basketball team came through with a thrilling rally, only to lose to Colgate by a point almost at the very end of a 5-minute overtime period today, 67 to 66.

The tussle between forces for inflation and deflation proceeded last week along a path replete with pitfalls. The stock market stole some of the limelight away from the dried-out commodities as the staples showed evidence of steadying at currently deflated levels, but the share list continued to back away from the January highs.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UP) -- Congress rushed action today on a $44,000,000 loan plan to help Western farmers get over the heavy blizzard losses.

THE haste with which Columbia has brought out its recording of the entire score of Kiss Me, Kate is an indication that it anticipates a large public demand. In view of the show's success, Columbia is probably right. Plenty of disappointed ticket seekers will acquire the records while they wait to get into the theatre.

VIENNA, Feb. 12 -- With the conviction of Cardinal Mindszenty this week, Hungary took a very long step, under her Communist dictators, toward integration with the Soviet Union. Cardinal Mindszenty was the last focus of real resistance to communism in Hungary. In his person he represented the political and spiritual power of the Catholic Church.

THE French have reached out an adult hand and cuffed some of the writers of literature for the young. The National Assembly has adopted a bill providing for the censorship of all publications for children and adolescents. Cartoons and stories glorifying "banditry, lying, stealing, laziness, cowardice, hatred or any acts of crime" are henceforth to be forbidden.

A spectacular second quarter, during which they amassed twenty-seven points, paved the way for an 85-58 victory for the New York Knickerbockers over the Fort Wayne Pistons yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden.

With six Violets getting 10 or more points each, New York University bounded back following defeats at the hands of Duke and Manhattan to crush Brooklyn College, 91 to 52, in the feature of the basketball program before 2,541 fans at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night.
Two of the strongest teams in the country reached the final rounds of the Vanderbilt Cup Contract bridge tournament last night at the Pierre Hotel. They will play for the national title today.

Richmonders will concede, perhaps, that their city is not so old as the one on the Tiber, but they are not so sure that its history is any less remarkable.
