CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 12 -- Of particular interest to the cotton-growing Deep South this week was the action of Gov. Gordon L. Browning of Tennessee in signing a bill to repeal all state taxes on colored oleomargarine.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Estimates of cost for the first stages of a military assistance program by this country to the nations of Western Europe are being feverishly prepared for the quickest possible consideration by Congress.
Columbia clung to second place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League race by turning back Penn, 65 to 57, before a capacity gathering of 2,500 in the Morningside gym last night.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 12 -- Defective machinery from Czechoslovakia, indicative of deliberate sabotage and growing resistance among the technicians in the Skoda Works, has been reported to the Danish Federation of Industries by a number of manufacturers lately.

Last week the long war between communism and the Roman Catholic Church entered a new and intensely bitter phase. In Communist-dominated Hungary Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty (pronounced MEEND-sen-tee) was sentenced to life imprisonment -- the first prelate to be tried and punished while a Cardinal in the 1,900-year history of the Church.

ISLAMORADA KEY, Fla., Feb. 12 -- Trout and salmon anglers are, traditionally, a contentious group, but they are a quiet, agreeable body of men compared to the fly rod anglers who stalk the flats adjacent to this key in search of bonefish.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 12 (UP) -- Hungary today asked the United States to recall the United States Minister in Budapest, Selden Chapin, and accused President Truman of "brutal attempts" to interfere in this country's internal affairs.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 12 -- A sweeping indictment of the recent mushroom growth of Protestant parochial schools was voted here today by the International Council of Religious Education. The council represents the religious education interests of forty Protestant denominations and thirty-three state councils of churches.

A greater effort to make democracy work in every community throughout the nation will strengthen our position of world leadership and lead eventually to world peace, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, United States Representative to the United Nations, declared yesterday in addressing a conference on human relations, sponsored by the Joint Veterans Council for Americanism of New York County.

STOCKHOLM, Feb. 12 -- The United States team defeated Switzerland today, 12 -- 5, in its opening match in the world amateur ice hockey championships. Pouring it on in a wild -scoring first period, the United States team rolled up a 6-to-2 lead at the intermission and never was headed.

The Ellistan (N. J.) indoor polo team composed of the three Johnson brothers -- Collister, Bob and Ben, rode to a 12 to 10 victory over Squadron A in the feature of a double-header at the Squadron A armory last night.

HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 12 -- The rampant Indians of Dartmouth did a thorough scalping job today in winning their own thirty-ninth annual winter carnival, oldest of its kind in the world. The Big Green skiers, who have been licking wounds inflicted upon them by Middlebury the past two years, sent the Panthers back to their Vermont lair beaten by an incredible margin of almost thirty points.

The twenty-eighth Associated Terrier Clubs competition involving a dozen breed clubs at the Twelfth Regiment Armory that provided the opening skirmishes of "Westminster Week" yesterday developed some interesting possibilities though nothing conclusive for the big show that opens in Madison Square Garden tomorrow.

For four hours yesterday afternoon cheers filled the Seventh Regiment Armory at Sixty-sixth Street and Park Avenue -- and with good reason. On hand and competing under the green banner of the Police Athletic League were 850 youngsters, ranging in age from 10 to 17, in the league's fifth annual indoor track championship.

Early spring apparel attracted a stronger consumer response in department stores here last week, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports, Inc. Blouses and neckwear made the best seasonal showing, however.

The European Recovery Program, as last week's news from Washington reminded us all, is now moving toward the end of its first year. Strictly speaking, the books for the initial twelve months cannot be balanced until the first week of April. Still, we know about how much will have been spent by that time and we know something about the tangible and intangible results.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat, of Virginia, said today that scrapping the Taft - Hartley Law for the Truman labor bill would be "little short of a tragedy" and could "lead to another depression."

ROANN, Ind., Feb. 12 (Religious News Service) -- A joint citizens' council here has built a small chapel just outside the Roann grade school building, and there pupils get religious education along with their regular class work. Bible classes in churches and homes have been started at four other grade schools near here until similar chapels can be built.

LAST week a jet bomber of the United States Air Force streaked across the continent from the State of Washington to Washington, D. C., in 3 hours and 46 minutes. It covered the 2,289-mile route at an average speed of 607.2 miles an hour.

BUENOS AIRES -- Delegates and observers from all the nations of the Western world are leaving here today for San Carlos de Bariloche, where the Third Interamerican Travel Congress will finally get under way Tuesday.
CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Champion Willie Hoppe ran up his fourth straight triumph in defense of his 3-cushion billiard crown tonight.

Orders for spring, 1949, on handmade lingerie and blouses are 20 per cent ahead of last year on a dollar volume basis, according to Herbert L. Miskend, president of Yolande, Inc. Quality brand lines of lingerie, he said yesterday, are reaping the benefits of a staple pricing policy when merchandise was comparatively in short supply.

A tired but still amiable Texan named Claude Allen Williams climbed aboard an airplane here yesterday afternoon for a two-stop 1,400-mile flight back home to Houston with a justifiable feeling of a job well done. Behind him he left a story, sprinkled with superlatives, about the largest gas pipeline in the world.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- President Truman by proclamation tolay designated March as Red Cross Month and urged every citizen to respond "as generously as possible" in that period to the organization's $60,000,000 campaign for funds.

FOR the last month, the billboards of Philadelphia and Boston have held that block-letter legend, IN PERSON, which draws so careful a distinction between the theatre and its technicolor associate. For the last month, the public of the two cities has read, understood and attended, the latter, it is safe to say, not so much to see "They Knew What They Wanted" as to see the In Person play Tony.

A "salesmen's code of ethics," designed as a guide to improve relationships between wholesale salesmen and their employers, will be the topic of discussion at an early meeting of the committee on trade practices of the National Council of Salesmen's Organizations, 80 West Fortieth Street.
Western Europe, excluding the Western zones of Germany, last year marked up these economic gains over 1947:

Walter E. Myer ("Teaching Today's History -- A Vital Task") argues that if we teach current history according to the methods outlined by him America's youth will begin "reading, thinking and discussing vital issues."

IT appears that someone is trying to murder Daphne Winters, the First Lady of the American Stage. That is the conclusion to which Chief of Police Reed comes when he learns that one of Daphne's satellites, a girl named Gretchen, dropped dead soon after taking a headache capsule from a bottle offered her by Daphne.

As it has done on three conspicuous occasions in the past, the Metropolitan Opera turned to the public yesterday with an appeal for funds. It is asking for $250,000. Most of the money will be used for the 1949-50 season, but part of it will be devoted to a detailed study of whether the Metropolitan should rehabilitate its present opera house or build a new one.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla. -- The drive down here from New York via the inland route is a trip of 1,460 miles that we made in four days of steady, fast driving, the we including my wife and 3 1/2-year-old daughter, who turned out to be a good traveler.

Vigorous support by all churches in the Protestant Council in the City of New York for United Nations adoption of the human rights declaration of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization was unanimously recommended yesterday at a conference sponsored by the Council's human relations commission.

BOSTON, Feb. 12 -- The fall of commodity prices and increasing industrial lay-offs continued to hold public interest this week in New England. But even these economic factors appeared to be secondary to the reaction to the trial of Cardinal Mindszenty of Hungary.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Vanderbilt University officially announced today the appointment of William (Bill) Edwards, line coach of the Cleveland Browns, as head football coach and director of intercollegiate athletics.

Two special elections will be held on Tuesday, one in the Seventh Congressional District in Brooklyn to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Representative John J. Delaney and the other in the Fifth Manhattan Assembly District to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Assemblyman Irwin D. Davidson on appointment as Special Sessions Justice.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The Children's Bureau in the Federal Security Agency today filled a long-standing gap in its guides to parents by issuing "Your Child From 6 to 12."
A new "rule book" for advertising has been prepared by the National Better Business Bureau, it was learned last week.
Barnard College is sponsoring a new arrangement for summer study in Europe to be known as the Barnard Plan, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The debate on the North Atlantic Pact has been dealing so much lately with the obligations and hesitations of Norway, Denmark and Sweden that the obligations and hesitations of the United States are being overlooked.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- It seemed likely tonight that the United States would charge Hungary had violated the two-year-old treaty of peace she made with the United States, Great Britain and the Soviet Union in her arrest, trial and sentence to life imprisonment of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty.

When Robert Brown thinks of coffee, just about the last thing that comes to his mind is a cup of the breakfast brew. To him the aromatic beans mean a variety of products from soap, shampoo and cleaning powder to headache tablets and shoe polish.

PARIS, Feb. 13 -- Anny Blatt crochets an evening gown in spunglass yarn. Of a soft gold tone, it is enchanting in strong light but more so in half light, which brings forth its shimmering iridescent tone.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion served notice on the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission tonight that Israel would oppose the internationalization of Jerusalem. He declared that Jerusalem would remain an Israeli city.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The Republicans charted today an all-out fight on President Truman's call for universal medical-care insurance.

Most industrial executives see a general business decline this year but they believe it can be characterized as a "mild adjustment in the economic picture" rather than the "oft-heralded depression or violent recession," the National Industrial Conference Board reports.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 13 -- Coming up from third place in yesterday's downhill race, the five-man team of the Amateur Ski Club of New York today won the New York interclub title by capturing the slalom event.

The four-day strike of station agents and maintenance employes on the Hudson Manhattan Railroad ended last night. The strikers returned without winning reinstatement for forty-nine dismissed workers or recognition for their union, the Transport Workers Union, CIO.

The Ocean Kimball Garage, Inc., has sold the one-story manufacturing building occupied by the Atkins Wood Products Company and the three-family dwelling at 103-12 to 103-18 101st Street, Ozone Park, Queens, to the Ansali Realty Corporation, represented by Eugene E. Lefkowitz, attorney.

Harry Ferguson, Inc., Detroit, manufacturers of farm machinery and implements last year had a net profit of $540,968 on net sales of $33,132,074, "despite major difficulties arising out of its break with the Ford Motor Company," Horace D'Angelo, executive vice president, reported in the annual statement issued for release today.

TOKYO, Feb. 13 (Reuters) -- Washington's categorical denial that high ranking United States Army officials had said in Tokyo last week that the United States contemplated withdrawing occupation troops from Japan has caused surprise in informed quarters here today.

The changeover from a sellers' to a buyers' market during the past year did not catch New York manufacturers "napping" and a majority increased their sales organizations, it was reported over the week-end by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc.

Mrs. Henry W. Lark's Ch. Four Roses from Dewart, Pa., a "sleeper" in the 241-dog American Boxer Club specialty, went to best of breed in that big pre-Westminster event at the Twelfth Regiment Armory last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UP) -- Canadian Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent left by train for Ottawa today after having discussed United States-Canadian problems during a two-day visit to Washington.

While the hockey wars were in progress upstairs yesterday, the basement of Madison Square Garden looked and sounded like a dog show, lacking only the judging, as preparations went on for the seventy-third annual Westminster Kennel Club event. Westminster begins this morning and runs through to almost midnight tomorrow night.
New rates and charges affecting first and second class express shipments, authorized by the Interstate Commerce Commission last Dec. 29, become effective today throughout the United States.

Many otherwise devout persons, with the excuse that these are days of high costs, are neglecting their obligations to church charities, the Rev. Theodore Thormahlen, executive director of the Lutheran Child Welfare Association, declared yesterday.

" Sixteen Self Sketches," the "unconventional" autobiography of Bernard Shaw, will be brought out on March 28 by Dodd, Mead. The book ranges from recollections of his youth to his failure as a novelist, his success as a dramatist and his opinions on a score of controversial subjects.

Confidence that new price breaks will have little effect on experienced advertisers' budgets or plans for this year was reiterated last week by a number of key officials. Greater knowledge of markets and potential demand, as well as recognition of the need for

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 13 -- Oral hearings have been concluded in the case of the United States and British Military Governments against the Bosch enterprises for "excessive concentration of economic power."
HAVANA, Cuba, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Francis Cardinal Spellman of New York today assailed "anti-Christian tyrants" for vicious persecution of the followers of Christ.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 13 -- Lana Turner will play the leading role in the screen version of Rebecca West's story, "The Abiding Vision," after she completes "The Reformer and the Redhead," Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer has announced. Voldemar Vetluguin will produce the film, and Samson Raphaelson has been engaged by Metro to write the adaptation.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Eight states have added tobacco taxes to their fund-raising levies during the last two years, the Federation of Tax Administrators reported today. Tobacco taxes are now cellected in thirty-nine states, an increase of eighteen since 1938, the federation's survey showed.
TOKYO, Feb. 13 -- A high occupation official was reported to have moved today to allay fears that Japan would be left holding the bag in the event of war between Russia and the United States.

ROME, Feb. 13 -- Italy's post-war successes in the field of foreign policy almost justify the statement that she has regained by diplomacy what she lost in battle. This statement is subject to many obvious qualifications, but it is substantiated by a comparison of the Italian position today and the below- zero status at the end of the war.
STOCKHOLM, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The United States hockey team ran up five straight goals in the first period and went on to trounce Norway, 12 -- 1, in the world ice hockey championships today.

Monday is notable, or notorious, for a number of reasons. In the first place, it is the start of the working week, and there is nothing good about that. It is the day upon which the Supreme Court hands down decisions, and it all depends on which lawyer you know whether that is good or bad.

NANKING, Feb. 13 -- The official Central News Agency reported today that Sino-Soviet negotiations under way in Urumchi, capital of Sinkiang Province, were expected to give vast economic and mining concessions to Russia in Sinkiang.

Ivriah, New York women's organization, has acquired the two five-story buildings at 48-50 West Seventy-fourth Street for occupancy by Beth Hayeled, its experimental, bicultural foundation school. The St. Elizabeth Industrial School was the seller. Joseph and Trinidad Hidalgo were the brokers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Representative Christian A. Herter of Massachusetts accepted the presidency of the Foreign Service Educational Foundation tonight with the assertion that there was a heavy need for competently trained men to take on the responsibilities of world leadership.

Deeper into the cellar of the National Hockey League went the New York Rangers last night. The Blue Shirts, in the throes of a losing streak that bids fair to eliminate them from the post-season play-offs, were unable to do anything right against the Toronto Maple Leafs in the presence of 15,711 fans, and as a result absorbed a 3-to-0 beating from the resurgent skaters from the Dominion.

H. G. Wolff, Trade Commissioner for Indonesia (representing those areas of the Netherlands East Indies still under Dutch control), has written a letter to THE TIMES in answer to an article which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 26, 1948, under the headline, "East Indies Trade Held a Monopoly."
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Branch Rickey Sr., president of the Dodgers, said today that "without the reserve clause baseball cannot endure."

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- Drastic liquidation developed in the lard market last week. Prices at the low were in new ground since 1942, with futures off $4.20 to $4.25 from the high on Jan. 31. Loose lard was quoted at $10.50 at one time, a new low since December, 1941.

The New York Sport Club of the German American Soccer League, which eliminated the New York Americans from the National Challenge Cup competition earlier in the season, tied the Brookhattan-Galicia team at Sterling Oval yesterday, 2 -- 2.

" Forward the Heart" vacated the Forty-eighth Street on Saturday night. Written by Bernard Reines, the four-character play managed to eke out a run of nineteen performances. Based on a sociological theme, the story dealt with the love of a blind veteran for his mother's Negro maid.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 13 -- Two hundred persons have been arrested since the assassination yesterday of Sheikh Hassan el Banna, Supreme Guide of the outlawed Moslem Brotherhood, the Ministry of Interior stated today.

The eighty-eight-year-old former West Flatbush Town Hall at 9 Reeves Place, Brooklyn, has been purchased by the Windsor Terrace Post 1175 of the American Legion, which has occupied the property for the past eleven years. Title was taken in the name of the post's
HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 12 -- A call for help from an Albuquerque, N. M., patrolman reached his police headquarters all right today -- but it had to go some 5,000 miles by way of this town.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 13 -- National steel ingot output last week was off no more than one-half a point to 100.5 per cent of rated capacity. It was the fourth straight week for the rate to remain at or above 100 per cent of capacity and on an annual basis of more than 97,000,000 tons.

The New York Hospital, 525 East Sixty-eighth Street, appealed yesterday to Greek-Americans to donate blood with which to treat young sufferers with a rare blood disease that attacks Greek-American children.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 13 (AP) -- The ill-fated world bobsled championships, plagued by unfavorable weather and accidents, are now scheduled to get under way Tuesday over Mount Van Hoevenberg's treacherous icy run.

" Academic freedom" and religious teachings in universities were criticized yesterday at the thirtieth anniversary communion breakfast of Newman Clubs of the New York Province at the Commodore Hotel. The speakers were Bishop Joseph E. Kearney of Rochester, N. Y., and Elizabeth T. Bentley, former Communist agent.

It was unfortunate that the new Rovers came up with their best game of the season yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden. It was unfortunate because they had to finish on the short end of the count, 4 -- 3, as they bowed to the Montreal Royals in a Quebec Senior Hockey League clash.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- A twelve-point program for the advancement of medicine and public health was offered today by the American Medical Association, representing 150,000 physicians of the nation. One point urges creation of a Federal department of health with cabinet status.

BERLIN, Feb. 13 -- German Communist declared today a "national state of distress" and ordered an all-out propaganda offensive to sell the idea that the United States was preparing for war and was determined to maintain the division of Germany.

The City of New Orleans, La., will be back in the market tomorrow to raise $15,000,000 to finance construction of the Union Railroad Terminal about which the city has been talking for more than half a century. Last April the city moved to finance the improvement by selling $15,000,000 of bonds to a banking syndicate at an interest cost of 2.731 per cent.

Msgr. Fulton J. Sheen, Professor of Philosophy at the Catholic University, Washington, told 1,000 men at a communion breakfast yesterday that J oseph Cardinal Mindszenty had said to him two years ago, when the Roman Catholic Primate of Hungry visited this country, that he knew he was "marked for death" but was returning to Hungary "to be crucified."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, said today the AFL would leave to state federations the question of giving financial aid to labor-minded but poorly paid state legislators.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- Unsettled and rather worried describes the state of the stock markets in London at present. For this, foreign rather than home developments are responsible, although the disclosure that Government expenditures had run ahead of estimates by more than 220,000,000 came as a distinct shock to the City and to the country generally.

Prices in the domestic cotton market moved over a wide trading range last week but closed the period with relatively moderate net changes. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed for the week net losses of 23 to 36 points, although at the lows of the week they had been down 80 to 133 points from the previous week-end.

The prediction that American Airlines and some others will operate at a profit in 1949 was made yesterday in a review of operations by W. L. McMillen, assistant secretary and assistant treasurer of American. He said that by April 1 it will have completed the installation of three whole new fleets of aircraft since the war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The treatment of the case of Dr. Edward U. Condon in New York City newspapers was cited today by six eminent scientists as a "peculiarly striking demonstration" of the need for reform in the conduct of Congressional investigations.

Last year, 3,867 families in this city received help from the Salvation Army -- help that contributed toward preserving family solidarity and keeping intact the strong family front that is the greatest bulwark of society.

In the thirty-two years since the City of New York's zoning ordinance was adopted we have increasingly come to realize that the predicament the city finds itself in today is due in no small measure to the legalization of a situation whereby the residential areas of the city were zoned for a total potential population of 77 million people

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Joe Van Winkle of Charleston, W. Va., scored an impressive 1,872 today to take an early lead in the all-events competition of the American Bowling Congress tournament.

A New York entry, Champion Yankee Debutante, 16 months old, owned by E. D. Boehm and handled by Fred Lucas, also of New York, captured best-in-show honors at the forty-first annual specialty of the Boston Terrier Club of New York yesterday at Lincoln Square Center.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Officials of the Department of Agriculture report that preliminary calculations show that the 1948 per capita farm income was 60 per cent higher, as compared with other segments of the population, than in 1909-14.

C. W. Rulon, chief engineer of the Underwriters Laboratories, will discuss the work of that organization at the monthly meeting of the management division of the Real Estate Board of New York at 6:30 P. M. tomorrow at the Brass Rail Restaurant, Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street.

ROME, Feb. 13 -- When Romans left the churches after mass this morning they were astonished and not a little amused to see newspapers being hawked in the streets by well-dressed middle-aged men. Their astonishment and amusement grew when they identified the news venders as Communist leaders.

State unemployment insurance payments to jobless workers were nearly twice as high last month as they were in January of last year, according to statistics made public yesterday by the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Ray Blum of Nutley, N. J., swept to the men's senior title of the national speed skating championships today, turning back the attempts of two former titleholders to regain their crowns.

A "well-rounded" Christian experience implies an awareness of "not simply what Christ has done for us, but also what we can do for Him," the Rev. Dr. Phillips P. Elliott, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, Henry and Clark Streets, Brooklyn, said yesterday in his sermon.

Buyers' activity in the wholesale apparel market here last week centered mainly on shopping summer dress lines, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Their reaction to summer merchandise has been favorable for the most part, although they shopped thoroughly before placing orders, it was said.

Brooklyn police arrested a love-struck 22-year-old printer yesterday and charged him with homicide by arson in the setting of a fire at 194 Utica Avenue, Brooklyn, that killed one man and inflicted burns on seven other tenants of the four-story brick dwelling.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 13 -- Although one of the two candidates in Portugal's Presidential election withdrew at the last minute, today's voting for the Presidency brought a record poll. Women especially voted in unprecedented numbers.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 -- A young pilot in an organized reserve squadron at the Willow Grove Naval Air Station near here was killed today when his fighter plane fell 30,000 feet and crashed into the front yard of a home at Sewell, N. J., ten miles southeast of Philadelphia.

Former middleweight king Tony Zale has informed the Tournament of Champions that he wants a return bout with champion Marcel Cerdan and the T. of C. said yesterday it is prepared to promote the fight.

The concertgoers who had been looking forward to Edith Schiller's return in a recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon were not disappointed with the showing made. The young pianist, who made her debut here in 1946, was in fine form, and fine form, for her, is something of which the connoisseurs may well take notice.
KONGSBERG, Norway, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Maria Isakova of Russia retained her world speed skating title today with three firsts in four events.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Feb. 13 -- Heinrich Fritz Hauser, who paid his disrespects to various aspects of life in the United States in a critically analytical book "The German Talks Back," nevertheless wants most right now to return there and become a United States citizen.

The Prudential Steamship Corporation is extending its Mediterranean service to include calls at Persian Gulf ports on a basis of one sailing a month, it was announced yesterday by Stephen D. Stephanidis, managing director of the corporation.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 13 -- The cut suggested by Paul Hoffman in allocations of the European Cooperation Administration to the Netherlands for the second year by $152,000,000 caused great disappointment in economic and financial circles here as it was believed that this doubtless would affect seriously the Dutch recovery and defense program and might even jeopardize establishment of the Benelux (Belgium, the Netherlands, Luxembourg) Union.

Patsy and Polly, twin baby girls, the 7,000th and 6,999th child placed for adoption by the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Society, are in a new adoptive home today, St. Valentine's Day.

An inspection of twenty-two public school buildings on the lower East Side during the last four weeks has disclosed "a most shocking condition of deterioration and neglect," the East Side Chamber of Commerce reported yesterday. It demanded that immediate steps be taken by the city to correct them.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Star golfers need a vacation just like anyone else, says George Schneiter, tournament director of the P. G. A., but they have worked out a schedule of co-operation with the tournament sponsors in taking it.

Only a glance at the latest Census Bureau figures on family incomes in the United States is needed to make plain that our housing programs, federal, state and local, must be directed with far greater singleness of purpose to production of a low-cost living unit. Almost half of the nation's 37,000,000 families have an income less than $3,000 a year; 30,000,000 of the 37,000,000 have an income less than $5,000.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe, the old master, successfully defended his world's three-cushion billiard title for the fifth time tonight by defeating Joe Chamaco of Mexico City, 50 -- 43, in fifty-seven innings.
Grady L. Roark has been appointed New York district manager of the electronics department of General Electric Company. He joined General Electric in 1933.
Grady L. Roark has been appointed New York district manager of the electronics department of General Electric Company. He joined General Electric in 1933.

At this stage in the disintegration of sprawling China, the country has divided up into three broad belts of control or influence. Whether this transitional phase hardens or whether these masses coalesce remains to be seen. United States political strategy in the Far East will depend upon this.

ROME, Feb. 13 -- Pope Pius spent the greater part of the day putting finishing touches to his allocution on Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, Primate of Hungary, which he will deliver to the Sacred College of Cardinals gathered in extraordinary secret consistory tomorrow morning.
Automatic washers and dryers recently introduced in New York stores have new mechanical refinements that should enable homemakers to save hot water and electricity as well as time and energy.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Fort Wayne lost five of its nine players on personal fouls tonight but still came scooting from behind in the final quarter to take a 82-73 Basketball Association of America tilt from the New York Knickerbockers.

Bound for a Paris meeting of the Council of Ministers of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation on Thursday, W. Averell Harriman left New York International Airport at 12:45 yesterday afternoon.

Much-needed additions to the war-depleted fleet of American-flag passenger vessels in the near future were predicted last night by Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute.

QUITO, Ecuador, Feb. 13 -- An enraged mob that hurled gasoline and flaming balls of paper took fatal vengeance here last night for a panic caused by an Orson Welles-type radio dramatization of an "invasion from Mars." The mob attacked and burned the building of the newspaper, Comercio, which housed the radio station, and killed fifteen persons and injured fifteen others.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 13 -- President Charles Seymour of Yale University tonight termed the inter-faith fellowship among Protestant, Catholic and Jewish student groups "an essential aspect of Yale education."

In launching its 1949 drive for $2,500,000 the New York Catholic Charities organization has pointed out that the need for private benevolence persists despite unemployment insurance, tax-supported welfare projects and other governmental programs for aiding the sick, the wayward, the under privileged and the poor.

The winners of the Vanderbilt Cup national knockout team of four championship last night at the Pierre Hotel were Charles S. Lochridge, Lee Hazen, Morrie Elis, Harry J. Fishbein and Larry Hirsch, all of New York. They defeated the team of Mrs. Helen Sobel, B. Jay Becker and Myron Fields of New York, Charles H. Goren of Philadelphia and Oswald Jacoby of Dallas, Tex., by 200 points.
TARRAGONA, Spain, Feb. 13 -- Twenty-nine persons, including one American and three Englishmen, were killed last night in one of Spain's worst train wrecks.

The Associated Hospital Service, New York's Blue Cross Plan, 80 Lexington Avenue, announced yesterday an increase in subscription charges to meet higher hospital costs. The new charge will become effectively immediately for persons who enroll today or later.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- Eleven months ago five Foreign Ministers met in Brussels and bound their countries into a fifty-year alliance called Western Union. Among other things, they created a defense organization and they ordered their military chiefs to form a combined fighting force.
ROME, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Further steps were taken today before Pope Pius XII toward the creation of three new saints of the Roman Catholic faith, among them a former Queen of France.

LENOX, Mass., Feb. 13 -- Twenty-two persons fled, many down ladders, as fire destroyed the interior of Our Lady of Mercy Preparatory School, conducted by the Society of the Fathers of Mercy of Brooklyn, N. Y., early this morning.
The name of Jeanne Mitchell, who gave a recital in the Twilight Series at Carnegie Hall yesterday, is one that belongs near the head of the list of up-and-coming young violinists.

The average countryman does not pretend to be a scientific meteorologist, although there are occasions when his prognostications do not suffer in comparison with those he reads in the paper or hears over the wireless. A man knows that when his hens stand around arguing instead of scratching in the oat straw a change of weather is due within thirty-six hours.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UP) -- The National Security Resources Board said today that there "appears no prospect" that industrial gas users in scarcity areas will have enough fuel in peak winter seasons for some time to come.

Siding with Communist party criticisms of the Federal jury system, the American Labor party moved yesterday to intervene in the trial of eleven leaders of the Communist party before Federal Judge Harold Medina.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 13 -- Despite the political uncertainty engendered by the absence of President Juan D. Peron from the capital and the lack of newspapers because of the printers' strike, Argentina's economic prospects have brightened. The Economic Cooperation Administration is now known to be in the market for an additional $5,000,000 worth of Argentine hides for Western Germany.

Nine radio stations in Iowa, Illinois and Wisconsin have made charges that a subsidiary of the American Telephone Telegraph Company violated Federal anti-trust laws and provisions of the Federal Communications Act late last year.

The five county medical societies of New York asked the city yesterday to establish a minimum payment to approved hospitals of $12 a day for care of premature infants whose parents could not meet the cost.

A major development in the mental health movement of this country was announced yesterday. The National Committtee for Mental Hygiene, which started the mental hygiene movement in the United States, made public the names of three women leaders in the mental health field who will head three newly created divisions in the organization.
ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 13 -- From blood samples and charts, scientists at Cornell University are figuring out the state of nutrition of the average family in a typical American community.

The fastest regular train schedule ever offered between New York and Boston will go into effect on March 1 at the same time that several trains will be discontinued or consolidated, the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad announced yesterday.

RHODES, Feb. 13 -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting United Nations Mediator-for Palestine, seeking new angles that might make his armistice compromise acceptable to both the 'Egyptian and Israeli delegates, conferred separately with them last night and today.
ALBANY, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Senator Thomas C. Desmond announced today that he would introduce a constitutional amendment tomorrow to establish a one-house legislature in New York.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Hunter Lott Jr., Merion Cricket Club, defeated defending champion Stanley W. Pearson Jr., Philadelphia Cricket Club, today to enter the final round of the thirty-third United States squash racquets singles championship at Merion Cricket Club.

The Rev. Dr. Paul Scherer, Brown Professor of Homiletics at Union Theological Seminary, declared yesterday that modern culture is in danger of falling apart "from false tensions created by man's trying to live in one world at a time."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The United States oil industry is trying to end its dependence upon Argentina for a critical drilling material, quebracho. And its best bet, the Department of Interior disclosed today, may be these lumber products long discarded as worthless:
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Dave Douglas of Wilmington, Del., found the pot at the end of the rainbow today -- he won the 72-hole $10,000 Texas open with a score of 268.

In reply to Governor Dewey's Saturday night speech at the Lincoln dinner of the National Republican Club, Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, challenged the Governor yesterday to prove "good faith" by putting a new padlock on the balance in the Postwar Reconstruction Fund until the public received a full explanation of where some $400,000,000 already had gone.

Twenty-two thousand persons, including non-Catholics, marched yesterday in Jamaica, Queens, in a parade sponsored by Catholic organizations in protest against the trial and conviction in Hungary of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty on charges of treason and other crimes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The National Council against Conscription, which includes Albert Einstein, Louis Bromfield, Pearl Buck and others, asserted today that the danger of a military-controlled America was "by no means past."

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 13 -- The words "Columbia Valley Authority" are fighting ones in the Pacific Northwest. Here, in a region cut through with one of the world's potentially great power generating streams, a sharp battle is shaping up over President Truman's plan to vest direction of the seven-state Columbia Basin's resources in the hands of a super-board, similar to that which watches over the affairs of the Tennessee Valley.

An improved understanding of world conditions, an increased appreciation of and devotion to democracy and a realistic approach to the nation's dwindling natural resources represent the three major challenges that must be met by American education if it is to overcome present uneasy tension.

Although gross revenues of the Detroit Edison Company last year increased 12.4 per cent to a new high record of $120,222,888, higher costs of operations resulted in a net income of $10,450,641 or 5.9 per cent below the 1947 net income of $11,112,568, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

It took Artur Rubinstein three tries to become one of the kings of America's musical castle. He gave his first Carnegie Hall recital of the season last night, thirty years after his second invasion. There was an audience of 2,800 on hand to greet him and to attest to his sovereign position.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Feb. 13 -- Robert Grant 3d, national racquets champion, had little difficulty in winning the annual Tuxedo Gold Racquet tournament today, defeating James R. Leonard in three straight games. The scores were 15 -- 8, 15 -- 9 and 15 -- 6.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 -- Federal conciliators brought company and union representatives back to the conference table today in the third round of negotiations to end the strike that has halted all city transit facilities since Thursday midnight.
PARIS, Feb. 13 (Reuters) -French flat and steeplechasing jockeys tonight called a strike, two days before the steeplechasing season opens.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The National Committee of the Progressive party called on President Truman today to "reopen the door to peace" by accepting Marshal Stalin's offer to negotiate differences between the United States and Russia.

Two Administration economic advisers, testifying last week before the Joint Committee on the Economic Report, struck a note which must have sounded strangely familiar to those whose memories go back to the days of the Temporary National Economic Committee and the events preceding the latter's creation on June 16, 1938.
Establishment of the first Israeli-flag freight service between United States and Canadian East Coast ports and Haifa and Tel Aviv was announced here yesterday.

Headed by Dr. David Freeman of Pasadena, Calif., the United States badminton team, American zone champion, left La Guardia Field yesterday on an American Overseas Airlines plane for Glasgow, where it will meet Malaya, Pacific zone winner, in a semi-final match of the world title play fund of $8,000 was raised to make the trip possible.

Race Relations Sunday was observed yesterday in Protestant churches throughout the city and the nation. The annual observance, which began in 1928, is sponsored nationally by the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, with headquarters at 297 Fourth Avenue.

It's always a toss-up who derives more pleasure from the Zilberts Choral Society's annual concert, the listeners or the participants Few choruses of its type inject as much enthusiasm into their singing, have as knowing a leader as Zavel Zilberts, and wind up making the kind of sounds their steady year-after-year admirers relish.

Grants during the fiscal year ending Sept. 30 last totaling $1,992,208 were made by the Commonwealth Fund for all purposes, according to its thirtieth annual report released yesterday. These included $667,705 for medical education and mental health, and $555,761 for medical research.
PARIS, Feb. 13 -- The Parisian touch, which is never dull, runs through Robert Piguet's handsome collection, in which he turns dresses frontside back.

The Rev. Laurence J. McGinley, new president of Fordham University, told the assembled Bronx posts of the American Legion yesterday that the group best able to mobilize public opinion against Communism and thus "avert the horror of another World War" was "those who fought in the past two World Wars."

The New York Stock Exchange had a net loss of $435,597 in 1948 compared with $116,171 in 1947, Emil Schram, president, announced yesterday in his annual report to members. Gross income was $6,890,140, a decrease of $171,689 from the 1947 figure.

American indoor track titles have gone overseas before, but never more than one in any single year. With the National A. A. U. championships coming up at Madison Square Garden next Saturday, three prized crowns are already virtually postmarked for delivery abroad.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Feb. 13 -- It was off again, on again and off again, like Finnegan's report of the railroad mishap, for the dinghies racing today at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- Dr. Halvard M. Lange, Norwegian Foreign Minister, who was in Washington last week inquiring about benefits that Norway might derive from joining the proposed North Atlantic defense pact, arrived in London today in search of further information and advice.
Action of the Communist-controlled government of Hungary in condemning Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty to life imprisonment was deplored yesterday from many of New York's Protestant pulpits.

BOSTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The top-place Detroit Red Wings put on a furious third-period drive to gain a 4-4 tie with the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League clash tonight before 13,909 fans at the Boston Garden. Bud Poile and Ted Lindsay provided the deadlock by scoring 27 seconds apart after Howe had made the second Detroit goal in 2:14.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 13 (Reuters) -- Disorder broke out in Tsingtao, last Government-held city in North China, last night when crowds, taking advantage of the growing panic and confusion, tried to storm and loot shops and private dwellings.

The city's general fund revenue for the fiscal year beginning July 1 will total $401,692,399, according to a tentative estimate made public yesterday by Controller Lazarus Joseph. In a report to the Board of Estimate and the City Council Mr. Joseph estimated general fund receipts for 1949-50 at $360,431,789 plus a cash balance of $41,260,611 to be carried over from the 1948-49 general fund on July 1.

There was little to the foreign exchange market last week to provoke a rate-movement of any significance. Lacking incident or event in the international picture, rates were generally steady on small turnover.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Dr. Edmund A. Kokat of Chicago, a finish-line judge in the national speed skating championships here, was in a St. Paul hospital today with a skull fracture suffered when a skater knocked him down.

On the same day that THE TIMES asked whether the United States Navy could not "stand a little more pruning" the news columns gave cause to wonder whether even the "pruning" presently proposed is prudent. If Russia's submarine threat is to be taken seriously, it must be remembered auxiliaries, cruisers and all heavy craft are especially vulnerable and not speedily replaceable.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UP) -- There were 18,800,000 living United States war veterans last June 30 and the number is still increasing, the Veterans Administration advised Congress today.

VIENNA, Feb. 13 -- Now that the Catholic Church in Hungary has been deprived of its leader, Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, the Communists are seeking the means of bringing the Lutheran Church in that country completely under their control.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period Feb. 5 to Feb. 11 are given in the appended tabulation:

PARIS, Feb. 13 -- The French Government is understood to have insisted in Washington that the proposed Atlantic defense pact cover French North African territories lying along the Mediterranean. Without this inclusion of a region lying east of the Atlantic the pact would be incomplete and unsatisfactory from the French point of view.
Six films, including importations from France and England, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

WHEN the Petain Government was formed, the plan of going to Africa to set up a centre of power outside German control was still open. It was discussed at a meeting of the Petain Cabinet on June 18 [1940]. The same evening President Lebrun, Petain, and the Presidents of the Senate and the Chamber met together.

PARIS, Feb. 13 -- Officials of the French iron and steel industry are seeking to develop foreign markets in 1949 for their steel and sheet products. They have an eye in particular on the United States, where they say some manufacturers are seeking European steel, although no formal conversations on the subject have yet begun.
LA JOLLA, Calif., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Mrs. Patricia Canning Todd and Richard (Pancho) Gonzales won La Jolla's tennis crowns today.

Ch. Majara Hahabat, owned, bred and handled by Mrs. Frederick A. Jagger of Dunellen, N. J., added another victory to his growing list yesterday when he took the best-of-breed award at the eleventh annual specialty show of the Afghan Hound Club of America at the Hotel McAlpin.

ATHENS, Feb. 13 -- A 4,000 strong rebel force that attacked Florina near the Yugoslav border yesterday left 216 counted dead in gullies and ravines near the town after being forced to withdraw, according to today's general staff communiqu.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 13 -- As this city, really animated for the first time in many months, made its final arrangements for tomorrow's meeting of Israel's first Constituent Assembly, it appeared tonight that there might be at least two discordant notes -- neither one seriously affecting the comprehensive civic symphony marking the inauguration of the Assembly.

The city's general fund revenue for the fiscal year beginning July 1 will total $401,692,399, according to a tentative estimate made public yesterday by Controller Lazarus Joseph. In a report to the Board of Estimate and the City Council Mr. Joseph estimated general fund receipts for 1949-50 at $360,431,789 plus a cash balance of $41,260,611 to be carried over from the 1948-49 general fund on July 1.

There was little to the foreign exchange market last week to provoke a rate-movement of any significance. Lacking incident or event in the international picture, rates were generally steady on small turnover.

A new frozen food product of special interest to those with a fondness for Middle European cookery are the cheese blintzes that Mrs. Elly Lupinska makes in her home in Princeton, N. J. The thin pancakes folded over cottage cheese are already cooked.
" It broke our hearts," Miss Dorothy Gant said yesterday. "It's the first year we haven't had a snake."

In the event of a recession many of the projects in the city's $4,925,000,000 public works program will provide real work rather than mere relief, or so-called made work, Mayor O'Dwyer was told yesterday.

ZURICH, Feb. 13 -- In an advertisement inserted in leading Swiss newspapers on Feb. 9 the Swiss Bankers Association and the Association of Swiss Stock Exchanges announced that the Netherlands Government now is willing to recognize the full validity of most black-listed Royal Dutch shares held in Switzerland.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- A concerted drive by organized teachers, parents and local school boards to obtain a bigger increase in state aid for education than the $40,000,000 recommended by Governor Dewey will reach its climax this week at a public hearing on Mr. Dewey's record breaking $936,200,000 budget.

Cuba and Panama, with identical ratings, held top positions in both credits and collections in the forty-first semi-annual survey of commercial credit and collection conditions in Latin-American markets during the last half of 1948, it was announced over the weeke

ATHENS, Feb. 13 (Reuters) -- Tony Ambatielos, Greek trade union leader was acquitted by a military court tonight of charges of conspiracy, high treason, recruiting and collection of funds for purposes of rebellion.

SASKATOON, Feb. 13 (Canadian Press) -- The Winnipeg veteran, Frank Stack, and Miss Patricia Lawson of Saskatoon gained the senior titles at the Canadian amateur speed skating championships after two days of tests in which seventeen records went into the books.

Events in Europe, highlighted by the drive against the churches in the Soviet satellite states and the Soviet pressure on Scandinavia, may be taken as further evidence that the Kremlin is still stepping up the pace of the "cold war" against the West, and that Mr. Stalin's recent "peace offensive" was merely the cover for an offensive of a far different kind.
IRONWOOD, Mich., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Joe Perrault, Ishpeming, Mich., went 213 and 214 feet today to top Class A competitors in the eleventh annual Wolverine Hill ski jumping meet.
The Army attacked a new snow-disaster area in North Dakota yesterday as the national weather picture presented a kaleidoscope of snow, rain, and mild temperature, according to the Associated Press.

The Metropolitan Opera's revival of Verdi's "Falstaff," conducted by Fritz Reiner, will be presented for the first time this season on Saturday afternoon, Feb. 26. Leonard Warren, who sang the name part in the opera when it was last given in the 1943-44 season, will again be the fat Sir John.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Feb. 13 -- An early afternoon rain failed to dampen the spirits of Manhasset Bay's frostbite sailors today as thirty-nine turned out for competition in a brisk westerly wind.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department said today no sharp drop in food prices is anticipated this year. However, they are expected to average somewhat lower than last year.

KODIAK, Alaska, Feb. 12 (Delayed) -- The major phases of the Navy's "Microwex" -- Minor Cold Weather Exercise -- the first held in these Northern latitudes since the war, ended today. The 18,000 men of the First Task Fleet prepared for a few days of rest and recreation before the vessels return to West Coast ports.
CHICAGO, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks rallied for two goals in the third period tonight to snatch a 4-3 National Hockey League victory from the Montreal Canadiens before 16,874 fans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Expressing satisfaction with the first year of Marshall Plan operations, the National Planning Association warned today that "western Europe has problems which economic recovery will not solve, but which, if freedom and stability are to be assured, must be solved."
CHICAGO, Feb 13 -- The National Council of Presbyterian Men ended its first annual meeting today after adopting a three-point program and setting a goal of 2,000 local chapters for the coming year.

A planting this spring of 450 flowering cherry trees in Central Park, whose blossoms it is hoped will rival the display along the Tidal Basin in Washington, has been made possible by a gift of Macy's department store, it was announced yesterday by the Park Association of New York City.

On the contrary, a long-drawn-out and bitter struggle over much of Europe and Asia, involving million-strong land armies, vast military casualties and widespread civil war, would be inevitable."

Seven hundred leaders of Zionist regions, affiliated with the Zionist Organization of America, overwhelmingly endorsed yesterday the policies of the organization's administration after a special daylong session at the Astor Hotel. The vote of confidence was given to Dr. Emanuel Neumann, president of the organization and Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, chairman of the American section of the Jewish Agency for Palestine.
Above all else, small light shapes were stressed in the Hattie Carnegie millinery showing in the East Forty-ninth Street specialty store yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Columbia Gas System, Inc., New York, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $20,000,000 of twenty-five-year debentures that are to be sold at competitive bidding.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- When Senator Vandenberg, supported by Senator Connally, told the Senate and the people today he would assent to nothing in the proposed North Atlantic pact that would constitute "a moral obligation" for the United States to go to war under that treaty, he was dealing with an ancient and perplexing relationship between Congress and the Chief Executive.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- Halvard M. Lange, Foreign Minister of Norway, said today that United States authorities had made it clear to him in Washington last week that the Norwegians "without jeopardizing any important interests or opportunities" could take their time in deciding whether to enter the proposed North Atlantic defense alliance.

The Utility Workers Union, CIO, instructed its local on the Hudson Manhattan Railroad yesterday not to seek to sign up members of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, as they returned to work after an unsuccessful four-day strike.

Short covering and demand from producer interests resulted yesterday in sharp advances in coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Prices for contract "D" were 76 to 96 points above Friday's levels. The near-by delivery position was the strongest feature.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 14 -- Follow-is an unofficial translation from the Hebrew of Dr. Chaim Weizmann's address to the first session of the Israeli Constituent Assembly:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 14 -- An official Foreign Office spokesman said today that rigid United States policy regarding adherence to the North Atlantic Pact was isolating Sweden as the only Scandinavian country capable of resisting Soviet aggression.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Unions and employers were at loggerheads in a hearing today before the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee in which a labor spokesman indicated that prolonged consideration of a new labor-relations law might create strained situations in the spring when contracts in the steel and other industries expired.
ATLANTA, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Three Georgia lawmakers tossed in a bill today that would prevent two Dodger Negro baseball stars from playing here but they may have acted a little too late.

Three men and a woman suspected of having taken part in recent grocery store hold-ups, mostly on the upper East Side, were captured yesterday by the police of the East 104th Street station. One suspect was wounded in an exchange of shots with two policemen.
BERLIN, Jan. 27 -- German nationalism is on the march again.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- The Yugoslavs won a minor but significant concession here today at the Big Four powers' negotiations on an Austrian peace treaty. After more than an hour's debate, the Big Four deputies agreed to let Yugoslav representatives appear later before the council to air their views on the treaty -- even to restating their oft-rejected territorial claims against Austria.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UP) -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, CIO, presented to a Senate Banking subcommittee today his plan to use idle warplane factories to turn out 20,000,000 prefabricated homes in the next ten years.

BOSTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Miss Cecile Bowes of Philadelphia opened defense of her women's national squash racquets championship by defeating Mrs. William Sargent of Beverly, Mass., 15 -- 7, 15 -- 10, 15 -- 6, at the Harvard Club today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the Federal Wage-Hour Administrator may use a civil contempt action to force an employer to pay back wages which the administrator contends were unlawfully withheld.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 14 -- In an interview that Czech newspapers will carry on their front pages tomorrow, President Klement Gottwald declares that he does not believe there will be a great war between the Soviet area and the West "within a reasonable time" and that Czechoslovakia is willing to do business with the Western countries on the basis of equality.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 14 -- The Soviet Union insisted today that the United Nations Security Council consider the application for membership of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea -- a government created in the former Russian zone of occupation.

" Treasure of Sierra Madre" and "Johnny Belinda," the Warner Brothers dramas which had their first local showings at the Strand last year on Jan. 23 and Oct. 1, respectively, will be brought back to that theatre as a double-feature attraction on Friday, Feb. 25, it became known yesterday.

Westminster, the nation's foremost dog show, began its two-day run in Madison Square Garden yesterday, with breed judging in a dozen rings bringing most but not all of 2,559 dogs, in a total entry of 2,666 before the public.
One of America's largest industrial equipment manufacturers has designed a sales plan aimed at breaking the bottleneck of bank restrictions on credit to equipment distributors.
Democracy takes for granted that the people are worthy of governing themselves and are competent to do so.
National Heart Week, proclaimed by President Truman, was opened here formally last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Government introduced testimony today seeking to link Mildred E. (Axis Sally) Gillars with four acts of treason.

A tendency to advance cropped out yesterday during the morning session of the stock market, but the drive quickly lost its power and the list eased to mixed close. The rally was not impressive after the general deterioration of last week and, although the market ended on the higher side in terms of issues showing gains, the composite rate slipped 0.26 point.
If someone were to inquire as to what single thing impressed us most during our recent southern fishing check-up the answer would be simple: fishing contests.

Trailerships, Inc., which conceived the idea of transporting truck trailers to and from New York and Albany on an eleven-hour, nightly service, again has been forced to discontinue operations, it was learned yesterday.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Feb. 13 (Delayed) -- Men of this frontier town are busy growing whiskers these days in preparation for its annual fur rendezvous at the end of this month. The fur run is keenly anticipated by the old-time residents of this community, which mushroomed from a population of perhaps 2,800 before the war to 18,000 to 20,000 now.

NANKING, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Members of an unofficial Nanking peace delegation disagreed among themselves today, adding new complications to the Chinese Government's efforts to arrange an armistice with the Communists.

A three-alarm fire, set accidentally by a 14-year-old boy who dropped a match into some gasoline on the floor of his parents' apartment, caused considerable damage yesterday afternoon to the seven-story apartment house at 348-52 East Sixty-sixth Street and drove a hundred tenants to the street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Two leaders of the Congress of Industrial Organizations today declared the St. Lawrence Seaway and power project to be vital to a national program of full employment and "business for all."

RHODES, Feb. 14 -- The Egyptian-Israeli armistice talks have made the first real step toward breaking the deadlock that has lasted nearly a month, it was learned tonight. The Israelis have indicated for the first time within the last twenty-four hours a willingness to review some of their military demands that the Egyptians have found unacceptable, it is understood on good authority.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Baltimore physicians using a drug in an Army-sponsored experiment today reported a cure and preventive for seasickness.

The lack of parking space has been considered in designing the 1949 De Soto line, which was shown yesterday at a dealer preview in the Hotel Astor. The overall length is less than that of previous models, although the wheelbase has been increased three inches and additional interior space has been obtained.

A policeman's summons to a grocer for permitting a 17-year-old errand boy to deliver an order containing a dozen bottles of ale touched off a test case yesterday in Bronx Magistrate's Court. Involved is the right of errand boys all over the state to handle deliveries containing beer and ale.

Operations last year of the National Distillers Corporation resulted in a net profit of $26,867,248 after taxes and all charges, on net sales of $351,569,291, according to the annual report to stockholders, released for today. The net profit for 1947 amounted to $36,443,638 on net sales of $395,375,828.

The report of a comprehensive survey of New Jersey's waterfront, with its several recommendations for a long-term development program, which was submitted to Trenton yesterday by the Port of New York Authority, is a direct product of Governor Driscoll's determination to promote Jersey potentials to the full.

After listening to the personal pleas of the heads of 109 departments in the city government, Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson announced yesterday that the budget estimate for the 1949-50 fiscal year was $89,222,427 above the record budget for the current year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that a harbor worker who was blinded in the left eye by an accident after having lost the sight of his right eye earlier was not entitled to permanent total disability pay from his employer.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Livestock prices advanced as much as $1 and $2 a hundred pounds today on the basis of sharply reduced salable receipts. Hog receipts were smallest since Oct. 11 and cattle since March 15.

All gifts of flowering trees and shrubs donated to the Citizens Golden Anniversary Planting Program of the Park Association of New York City must be made before March 1 if they are to be planted this spring, it was announced yesterday by the association. May 1 has been set as the deadline for the receipt of later gifts, to be planted next autumn.
The parade to the pawnbrokers is on.
TRENTON, Feb. 14 -- Veterans bonus legislation cleared the New Jersey Assembly tonight after long, bitter debate. Senate approval in March after a legislative recess virtually was certain.

Westinghouse Electric Corporation will seek to distribute its line of electrically heated sheets and comforters through soft goods jobbers as well as appliance dealers it was learned yesterday at the Domestics and Linen Show in the New Yorker Hotel.

Bill of Rights Week was opened officially yesterday in a ceremony sponsored by the Bill of Rights Commemorative Society in the building of the State Chamber of Commerce at 65 Liberty Street. Messmore Kendall, head of the society, presided.
Joseph F. McKenzie, jury clerk, denied yesterday that in the selection of jurors he ever discriminated against anyone for reasons of race, color, creed, sex, or political, social or economic status.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UP) -- President Truman told Congress today that the Russian-directed campaign to defeat the European Recovery Program was not measuring up to the Communists' expectations.

Payments on drafts by Latin American countries as a whole in January improved slightly, but there was an increase of about $8,500,000 in the backlog of outstanding collections, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
Dr. Harry S. Mustard, Commissioner of Health, announced yesterday the appointment of Dr. George Rosen as head of his department's bureau of health education.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- Governor Dewey appealed to the Legislature tonight to enact measures recommended by Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein to provide strict state control over cemetery corporations.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 14 -- The French Government has agreed to making the central administration of the projected Western German state responsible for handling the occupation costs, it was learned here today from authoritative sources.
The three key executives of the city's new Traffic Commission went into a huddle yesterday around the single desk that they share and tried to figure out how to answer 175 letters.

A program for rehabilitation of the New Jersey waterfront at a cost of $50,000,000 was presented yesterday to Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll by the Port of New York Authority.
TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 14 -- Ordered by a Federal court to provide heat for his tenants or go to jail, a New Brunswick landlord provided heat -- and more heat -- and more heat.

Akron, Ohio, City School District sold an issue of $2,780,000 of bonds due on Oct. 1, 1950 to 1971, to Braun, Bosworth Co. at a bid of 101.846 for 2 1/2s. The bonds were reoffered at prices to yield from 1 per cent to 2.50 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The estimate of $5,580,000,000 as the minimum outlay needed for the second year of Marshall Plan operations is under intensive restudy by the Economic Cooperation Administration for possible reduction in the light of falling commodity prices.

Some of the actors of the Six O'Clock Theatre are playing something derived from de Maupassant, "Madame Is Served," which opened at the Charles Weidman Studio in Sixteenth Street last evening. This is the group that disturbed the complacence of the town last season with their short-order performance of Harrity's "Hope Is the Thing With Feathers."

The Executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, which has been in session for more than a week in an effort to resolve Zionist problems, met again yesterday at 16 East Sixty-sixth Street, headquarters of the American section of the Agency.

As a General Sessions jury was about to be impaneled yesterday, four men accused of plotting to "fix" a major college basketball game at Madison Square Garden last month pleaded guilty to charges of attempted bribery and conspiracy.
PARIS, Feb. 14 -- All the collaboration cases still untried since the liberation of France will be "liquidated" in the next three months, according to Robert Lecourt, new Minister of Justice.

The pricing of the AAA-rated $40,000,000 issue of Duke Power Company bonds today will be watched closely in the financial district, not only for a clue to the investment position of the big insurance companies, but for what effect it might have on the outstanding float of undistributed new bonds.

Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company announced yesterday plans for the issuance of 464,912 new shares of common stock to be offered for sale first to holders of the company's 2,324,564 shares of outstanding stock. The offering price has not yet been determined.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 14 -- The Hollywood AFL Film Council, which represents the great bulk of organized labor in the motion-picture industry, announced today that it would request a governmental ban on the exhibition of pictures in the United States made in countries which impound the earnings of American movies if no other means could be found to keep American producers from increasing their activities abroad.

GENEVA, Feb. 14 -- Trade experts of twenty-three Eastern and Western European countries were warned today that they had better begin thinking about the problems of a buyers' market, that the days when nearly anything produced could be sold are over.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- Grain markets reversed their action of last week on the Board of Trade today and closed active and sharply higher. Soybeans led the upturn, closing 10 cents higher, the daily permissible limit, and showed 22 1/4 to 23 1/2 cents above the low on Feb. 9 when a 9-day downturn culminated a drop of 38 3/4 to 40 cents from the high on Jan. 31.

Today's events: Maurice Wilk, violin, and Kenneth Spencer, bass, Times Hall, (admission free), 3:30 P. M.; Cleveland Orchestra, George Szell, conductor, Rudolf Firkusny, piano, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Robert Cornman, piano, Times Hall, 8:30; Faya Kiselva, soprano, and Marienka Michna, piano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Feb. 14 -- Dr. Louis J. M. Beel, High Commissioner of the Crown in Indonesia, will fly to The Hague to obtain clarification of the Dutch policy in Indonesia since the replacement of E. M. J. A. Sassen as Minister of Overseas Territories by the less inflexible Dr. J. H. van Maarseveen.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Feb. 15 -- Anna Louise Strong, American journalist who has been a prolific writer of books and magazine articles sympathetic to communism, was arrested by Soviet security police yesterday on charges of espionage, the Soviet news agency Tass reported today.
A second victim was added yesterday to the dead in the Brooklyn fire early Sunday morning that allegedly was started by a 22-year-old Bronx printer after a quarrel with his girl friend.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Henry A. Wallace, whose Progressive party has one vote in the House and one in the Senate, held a press conference today to outline a $54,000,000,000 Federal "budget for abundance." He proposed it as a substitute for President Truman's fiscal program.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Feb. 14 -- Thirty-two medical scientists, including four from Europe and one from Canada, assembled here today to study the use of radioisotopes as "tracer atoms" in the field of research.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- A petition by the Central Railroad of New Jersey for higher fares was described today as a spearhead for similar requests from other railroads.

SCHENECTADY, Feb. 14 -- The practice of probation is becoming more closely allied to psychiatry in many countries of the world, Nicolaas Pansegrouw, an international authority on probation, declared today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 14 -- Dr. Josef Korbel, the diplomat who was dismissed by the Czechoslovak Communist regime from his job on the United Nations Kashmir Commission, asked the United States today to give political asylum to himself and his family.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 14 -- Drained by a river with the greatest power potential in the nation, the Pacific Northwest nevertheless faces a critical power shortage for several years even if construction of dams and transmission lines goes ahead at a maximum rate.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals today reversed a ruling of the Federal Power Commission that the East Ohio Gas Company was subject to Federal regulation.

It is typical of sensitive prices such as those in the commodity markets that after a precipitate break they frequently rebound almost as sharply, nullifying a good part of their extreme loss. That is one phenomenon which makes it decidedly hazardous to generalize too freely or too early about such market episodes.

Filmy off-white curtains that are easy to keep that way despite strong sunlight or soot are now ready for city windows. Tailored panels of Orlon, one of du Pont's newest synthetic fibers, are at McCutcheon's. The first readymade ruffled and plain curtains of Fiberglas are being introduced today at Altman's.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- President Truman today nominated Ernest A. Gross, legal adviser of the State Department, to be an Assistant Secretary of State in charge of Congressional relations.

Measurements of the new combination cruising and racing yawl being built at the Nevins Shipyard in City Island for Vice Commodore John Nicholas Brown of the New York Yacht Club were announced yesterday by Sparkman and Stevens, her designers.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The sharpest January drop in California factory employment since 1939 was reported today.

On the eve of the adoption of the United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine -- Nov. 29, 1947 -- Dr. Eleazar Lipa Sukenik heard shelling outside his study in Hebrew University at Mount Scopus, Jerusalem. Fascinated by the ancient Hebrew script of a blackened leather scroll, he disdained the clamor and the shouting.

In a letter made public yesterday, Mayor O'Dwyer urged members of the city's Congressional delegation to back the city's efforts to obtain "adequate allotment" of Federal funds for improving the city's harbor.

The American Merchant Marine Institute has warned its members that there is "considerable danger of delay" to American flag vessels because of a threatened shortage of properly documented radio officers after April 1. Beginning on that date all radiomen must possess the newly authorized Coast Guard license in order to ship out.

The substitution of buses for trolley cars in connecting New York subways with New Rochelle is favored by 99 per cent of the residents of that community, Mayor Stanley W. Church of New Rochelle said yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 14 -- John Wayne will play the leading role in "Best of the Badmen," a photoplay by Jack Natteford and Iuci Ward, which Jack Gross will produce at RKO in May, the studio announced today.
The trend of prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was reversed yesterday and at the close the market showed net gains of 30 to 50 points.

Two 10-year-old girls, dancing out of a candy store at 205 East 103d Street, were cut down in the street and crushed to death by a seven-and-one-half-ton coal truck yesterday, a few minutes after they had been released from school for the noon recess.

General Manager George Weiss of the Yankees announced yesterday he had acquired the contract of Second Baseman Mickey Witek from his Kansas City farm club. Witek, a former Giant who went to Louisville in 1947 when injuries beset him, bobbed up in Kansas City last year.
CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The golfing-for-gold brigade this summer will be sharp-shooting at a $255,200 purse on a fifteen-tourney schedule.

Discovery of the body of an 87-year-old woman in a half-filled bathtub at 115 East Eighty-second Street soon after noon yesterday sent forty detectives to the neighborhood after the death was described as "suspicious." Detectives at midnight detained five persons for questioning.
ROME, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The following is the official English text of Pope Pius' allocution to today's secret consistory on the arrest and imprisonment of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty of Hungary:

HONOLULU, Feb. 14 -- The body of Ernie Pyle, the war correspondent, is now at Pearl Harbor. It arrived late last evening aboard an LST (landing ship, tank) bringing the bodies of 1,350 war dead from Saipan.

March being the month of the annual scuffle with the income - tax people, said the man in the green plaid shirt, it is none too soon to begin studying the latest regulations in order not to skin one's self. There was some commotion in January on tax matters.
A scattered poll of major league baseball players, past and present, by The Associated Press, indicates player support of organized baseball's controversial reserve clause.

THOSE of us who were responsible at the summit in London understood the physical structure of our Island strength and were sure of the spirit of the nation. The confidence with which we faced the immediate future was not founded, as was commonly supposed abroad, upon audacious bluff or rhetorical appeal, but upon a sober consciousness and calculation of practical facts.

NORTH CONWAY, N. H., Feb. 14 -- Granted any break in weather and snow conditions, a record-breaking throng of recreational and competitive skiers will descend upon the northlands for the extended Washington Birthday holiday period starting next Friday night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The House Appropriations Committee approved the first big money bill of the new Congress today, and recommended a total of $466,882,117 to carry on various Government activities during the rest of the fiscal year, ending June 30.
