PARIS, Feb. 14 -- Mad Carpentier retains merely a suspicion of barrel lines, on the side of skirts that have unpressed pleats across the front and back. At the hemline of envelope skirts, draping starts from a slight barrel swell and slants up to the hip on the opposite side.

A Chopin program was given by Malcuzynski -- the program did not vouchsafe his first name, perhaps with the pleasing notion that he did not need to be identified save by his last -- yesterday evening in Carnegie Hall. This program was announced by the Kosciuszko Foundation as the "inauguration of the Chopin centennial."

Your well-informed chief foreign correspondent, C. L. Sulzberger, reported recently: "If a Balkan 'settlement' that can truly end the Greek civil war is to be envisioned, some diplomats feel that it would be necessary for Greece, * * * to forego her claim for restoration of northern Epirus."

A television version of Julius Caesar in modern dress will be presented by CBS at 7:30 P. M. Tuesday, March 1. Worthington C. Miner is adapting the Shakespearean tragedy for an hour-long presentation on Studio One. He also will produce and direct the show.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Letters indicating that the Federal Reserve Board approved in 1917 the banking policies adhered to by the Transamerica Corporation, San Francisco, were made public today. They were identified and portions of them read into the record at hearings on the board's anti-trust proceedings against the huge bank holding company.

Acting on the assumption that Mayor O'Dwyer is a candidate for re-election, Tammany Hall is giving serious consideration to the shelving of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan and the nomination in his place of John M. Murtagh, Mayor O'Dwyer's Commissioner of Investigation.

" Briton Hadden: His Life and Time," a biography of the cofounder of Time, Inc., with Henry Luce, has been set for publication in May by Farrar, Straus. It is the work of Noel F. Busch, senior writer for Life magazine and a cousin of Mr. Hadden.
BERLIN, Feb. 14 -- Britain was reported reliably tonight to have come around to the United States desire to make the West Deutsche mark as the sole legal currency in the western sectors of Berlin.

Juanita Carter, American soprano whose previous recitals have won her favorable notices here, appeared at Town Hall last night. Her program, sung in glass-clear English and French, included many unusual items, for which her listeners are indebted.
The opening of the official 1949 tea-testing session yesterday afternoon was featured, appropriately enough, by one of the most elaborate tea parties held in these parts in recent years.

A cooperative effort toward working out a voluntary agreement regulating comparative price claims in advertising and selling of fur garments in New York City is virtually a closed issue as far as the Better Business Bureau of New York is concerned, it was asserted yesterday by Hugh R. Jackson executive vice president of the bureau.

As the successive reports come from Mr. Hoover's Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government, it is increasingly evident that here is indeed a big job done with spectacular thoroughness. The series of reports began with consideration of the organizational set-up needed for the wise handling of top-level policy decisions.

Deputy Fire Chief Joseph M. Ziegler, who submitted his application for retirement as a result of the firehouse party on Dec. 16, was reinstated yesterday to active duty when the trustees of the Fire Department pension board permitted him to withdraw his application.

Eddie Dowling usually is described in theatre programs as "a triple threat man in entertainment -- an actor, director, producer." His versatility was tested again yesterday when he sat down in the Rainbow Room with the United States Board of Tea Experts to taste and talk about tea.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 14 -- An assertion that no major change in United States occupation policy in Japan was under consideration was made today by Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, on his arival here from an inspection trip to the Far East.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 14 (AP) -- An under-dog quintet of Ohio State Buckeyes staged a major basketball upset tonight when they toppled the St. Louis Billikens, who are ranked second nationally, 68 to 60. It was the Bills' second defeat in eighteen games.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 14 -- Israel's first Constituent Assembly was formed today with rejoicing, tears and the heat of debate. The tears were hardly dry after a moving address by Dr. Chaim Weizmann, Provisional President, when the deputies launched into the battle for power.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 14 -- Before he left Nanking three weeks ago, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek carried out a number of moves that outlined a prospective political escape route extending from his former capital through Fenghwa and the Fukien coast to the island of Formosa.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 -- Federal-sponsored negotiations in the strike of 11,000 operating employes of the Philadelphia Transportation Company produced their first tangible results tonight when agreement was reached on two of the points at issue.

Although net sales of the McCrory Stores Corporation last year rose to a new high record, earnings declined from 1947 as a result of higher operating costs, according to the annual report mailed to stockholders today.

The Macy department store gift of 450 flowering cherry trees to be planted in Central Park is a pleasant, and appreciated, way of saying thank you to the people of New York. All who have visited Washington can visualize what this planting will mean to our own park.

Life insurance in force with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company at the end of 1948 totaled $39,958,517,854, Leroy A. Lincoln, president, announced yesterday. This represented a gain of $2,701,913,139 in the year.

Business organizations will soon be competing with each other for the services of top-flight sales managers as well as salesmen, Fen Doscher, vice president in charge of sales for the Lily-Tulip Cup Corporation, predicted yesterday. He spoke before a luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York in the Roosevelt Hotel.

Consolidated net income of the Columbia Gas System, Inc., in 1948 amounted to $13,970,003, equal to $1.14 a share, it was announced yesterday. This represented a decline of $2,695,563 below the $16,665,568 reported for 1947, when share earnings amounted to $1.36 each.

Joan Rowland, 18-year-old pianist of Toronto, gave her first New York recital last night at Times Hall. She proved to have a definite flair for the keyboard, and her unaffected manner charmed the audience, but her musicianship is still quite a long way behind her digital dexterity.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- New strides in the conquest of space by rockets make it necessary for the United States to have a 3,000-mile proving ground for launching such weapons, Congress was told today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 14 -- The United States demanded here today that the United Nations throw a searching spotlight on Russia's slave labor camps, where, it was charged, 8,000,000 to 14,000,000 persons were in chains and dying in tragic numbers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Federal Reserve Board's chief spokesman urged Congress today to continue the board's sweeping authority over bank credit and installment buying to check "a tremendous potential" of inflationary forces. This authority expires June 30, 1949.

Britain will invest one-fifth of her national resources in capital equipment this year, it was reported here yesterday by the British Information Services, an agency of the British Government. This will involve, the agency explained, about the equivalent of $7,600,000,000 and cover new factories, machinery, ships, houses, mechanization of agriculture and replacement of worn-out equipment.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Supreme Court rejected today former Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers' appeal for a review of his conviction for inducing another man to lie under oath.

Asserting that there was too much intimidation of teachers, Dr. Roma Gans, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, charged yesterday that the present educational pattern tended to undermine individual initiative and to curb free approach to teaching.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores decreased 6 per cent last week compared with the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 5 per cent.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 14 -- Coaltown, Citation's understudy, gave one of the most astounding performances in turf history at Hialeah Park today.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- With United States share and commodity markets still unsettled, prices on the stock market here today went lower. The account ends tomorrow. Oils and coppers that are especially under the influence of American affairs led declines which by the close had spread to virtually every section.

Tribute was paid yesterday to Peter B. Olney, who retired Dec. 31 after twenty-seven years of service as a Federal bankruptcy referee in the Southern District of New York, at a luncheon at the Statler Hotel. More than 500 lawyers and business men attended.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today ruled that the Wisconsin Electric Power Company must pay Federal tax on electrical energy it sold to twenty-seven customers engaged in the dairy business in the Milwaukee area.

PARIS, Feb. 14 -- A proposal that the Marshall Plan countries all commit themselves to stabilize their currencies this year will be submitted to the foreign and finance ministers of those countries when they meet in Paris on Thursday.
CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- The nursing profession has to "run to stand still," Miss Pearl McIver, president of the American Nurses' Association, asserted today.

Modification by Brazil of its recent ban on the importation of flour is expected soon, according to reports here yesterday in foreign trade circles. Under the modification, shipments by American exporters to Brazilian ports north of Recife in Pernambuco are expected to be permitted.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Feb. 14 -- John T. Pratt Jr., a son of Mrs. Ruth Baker Pratt, former Representative from the Fifty-seventh Congressional District, New York, reported to the police this afternoon that jewels valued at approximately $30,000 had been stolen from a wall safe in his home here on Old Tappan Road.

Ten persons were injured, none of them seriously, soon after noon yesterday, when a Third Avenue Elevated train, pulling into the 125th Street station, crashed into a second train about to discharge passengers on the south-bound platform of the station.

Defamation of ethnic and religious groups stands revealed today as a prime cause of discord in group relations and in the embitterment of millions of individuals. Fairness and humanity demand remedial measures. The group libel bill introduced by Representatives Dawson, Keough, Keating, Javits and Klein attempts to furnish safeguards against the established evil with scrupulous regard for constitutional guarantees of freedom of expression.

Headed for Broadway, possibly under the auspices of Cheryl Crawford, is "To Tell the Truth," a play by Morley Callaghan, front-ranking Canadian novelist and short-story writer, whose books include "They Shall Inherit the Earth" and "Such Is My Beloved." Present plans call for a fall production.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government urged Congress today to concentrate the direction of federal "housekeeping" in one agency directly responsible to the President.
Matches in the National Squash Tennis Association's championship went through the preliminary round and two first-round pairings yesterday afternoon at the Columbia University Club.

Through the new report just submitted to the Mayor by City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses and the City Planning Commission, the citizens of New York City are afforded a comprehensive picture of the current status of New York's vast $4,925,000,000 public works program.

For the first time since the depression, the Federal Government would contribute to local home relief costs under Social Security Act amendments to be sponsored by President Truman and the Federal Security Agency, it became known yesterday.
STOCKHOLM, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The United States ice hockey team qualified tonight for the final round-robin tournament for the world championship.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Of 214 women now serving in state Legislatures, 126 are Republicans and eighty-eight are Democrats, Mrs. Robert W. Macauley, assistant chairman of the Republican National Committee, reported today.

The Appellate Division, Second Department, upheld yesterday a lower court ruling denying to evening high school teachers a salary schedule equal to that of teachers in day schools. In another decision, the tribunal reversed Supreme Court Justice Alfred V. Norton, who had ordered the Board of Education to approve the nomination of a teacher to the Board of Examiners.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UP) -- The Economic Cooperation Administration today announced an agreement with the Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company for conversion of the company's British pounds sterling into dollars. The agreement, it said, is in line with its program to encourage American industry to invest dollars abroad to aid European recovery.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The new international wheat agreement moved slowly forward today on two fronts, the diplomatic and the semantic.

Manhattan College's basketball team, in the running for the metropolitan crown, engages St. John's in an important intracity court clash at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory tonight. In the preliminary, the freshman quintets of both schools cross paths starting at 7:30 P. M.
Some relief was promised yesterday to the great mid-continent area, numbed by repeated blizzards and Arctic cold, The Associated Press reported.

The voters in four of the city's sixty-seven Assembly districts will take part today in two special elections. One is to choose an Assemblyman on the West Side of Manhattan, and the other to choose a Representative in Congress from the Brooklyn area that includes Williamsburg, Brooklyn Heights, Borough Hall and part of Park Slope.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Senator Tom Connally, Democrat, of Texas, and Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, asserted today that the proposed North Atlantic security pact would not obligate the United States to go to war, even if one of the members of the pact were attacked.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Southern Democrats pledged themselves today to filibuster against any move to curb filibusters in the Senate.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Olympic Realty Company team of Los Angeles, the first "name" team to roll, took second place tonight in the team event of the forty-sixth annual American Bowling Congress tournament.

Edwin J. Fitzpatrick has been appointed executive vice president of the Industrial Tape Corporation. He was formerly vice president and director of American Home Foods, Inc., and president of its Chef Boy-Ar-Dee division.

Eighteen of the homes for the aged affiliated with Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies are accepting Old Age Assistance clients, W. Noel Hudson, executive vice president of the federation, announced yesterday at a meeting of the administrative committee at the Bankers Club.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 14 -- The White Plains Housing Authority said this afternoon that it had received word by telephone that the Post Office Department would vacate the old garage building here on the site of a proposed $5,500,000 public housing project, thus allowing construction of the housing to begin about April 1.
LAKE RONKONKOMA, L. I., Feb. 14 -- An alert track walker averted this morning the probable wreck of a main line Long Island Rail Road passenger train four miles west of here.

Great Gull Island, which is not such a faraway place as its name might suggest, is likely soon to be a cancer research station, a bird refuge or a "fishing outpost." Its future depends on which, if any, of three leading bidders for the 17-acre area is successful.

A strike of 3,000 Bloomingdale department store workers was threatened yesterday unless the National Labor Relations Board schedules an election to determine a bargaining representative for the employes before the present contract expires Feb. 28.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- By a strictly party vote of 30 to 25, Senator Harold I. Panken, Democrat, of Manhattan, failed tonight to obtain passage of a motion to discharge the Senate National Defense and Military Affairs Committee from further consideration of his bill to ban segregation of Negro troops in the National Guard.

CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 14 (Reuters) -- Australia decided today to spend $592,000,000 on a vast system of hydro-electric power stations to feed huge factories deep below the earth and safe from the atom bomb.
KANSAS CITY, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Leroy (Satchell) Paige, the legendary Negro pitcher, nonchalantly announced today he had signed "a pretty good contract" with the Cleveland Indians for 1949.

COPENHAGEN, Feb. 14 -- Denmark, with the support of other Marshall Plan deficit countries, will urge radical changes in the intra-European payments plan for the second year on the ground that the present system perpetuates bilateral trading and stimulates exports of semi-luxuries rather than basic recovery materials.
This city must build a minimum of 153 additional public elementary schools in the next five years to meet the gravest enrollment emergency in its history.

ROME, Feb. 14 -- Declaring that "our soul" has been "crushed with most bitter grief," Pope Pius XII, in an allocution delivered this morning to the Sacred College of Cardinals in extraordinary secret consistory, protested in the most forceful manner at his command against the trial and sentencing of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty.

Four years ago American troops smashed their way into Japanese-held Manila, Corregidor and Bataan and planted the American flag atop Mount Suribachi on Iwo Jima. On the other side of the world the Battle of the Bulge had ended, General Patton's tanks were approaching the German borders and Roosevelt, Churchill and Stalin met at Yalta.
FORT LEWIS, Wash., Feb. 14 (AP) -- A small unmanned Army aircraft circled above Fort Lewis and neighboring Tacoma for three hours today, then vanished.

Doubts that have arisen in Europe regarding American foreign policy, owing to the confusions surrounding the North Atlantic Pact, are being echoed in the Pacific areas because of intimations that the United States might withdraw from Japan. These intimations arose in connection with a Far Eastern visit by Army Secretary Royall and have since been denied by Washington, Tokyo and Mr. Royall himself.

Establishment of fair trade regulations condemning contract repudiation and calling for use of written sales contracts was hailed yesterday by the Textile Distributors Institute as the greatest single advancement toward a stabilized market in selling finished rayon goods.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Supreme Court promised the Federal Government today an opportunity to press still further its oft-repeated claim to absolute ownership of the rich oil lands under the marginal sea of this country. The areas in question are those between low water and the three-mile limit.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- In an obvious effort to preserve harmony in the ranks of the Republican legislative majority, Governor Dewey tonight invited all GOP members of the Legislature to meet him next Sunday night on "pending legislation."

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- Commissioner of Agriculture C. Chester du Mond announced today that a full state fair would be conducted this year at the present fair grounds near Syracuse, provided the Legislature approves the $350,000 budget item for the purpose.
WASHINGTON Feb. 15 (AP) United States officials appeared puzzled today by Moscow's announcement that Anna Louise Strong, writer, was being deported from Soviet Russia as a spy.

A boxer, Champion Mazelaine's Zazarac Brandy, climbed to the highest pinnacle of American dog-dom last night by going best in show in the seventy-third annual Westminister Kennel Club event in Madison Square Garden.

A collection of Swedish-designed dresses, ensembles and evening gowns was presented for the first time in America at a press preview yesterday at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel. The designer was Nicol of Sweden.

Although as former administrator of the Walsh-Healey and Fair Labor Standards And I have not always agreed with THE TIMES on its Federal labor policy, may I commend your recent editorial opposing Government seizure in certain types of labor disputes as proposed by my good friend, William Davis, former chairman of the War Labor Board.

The European Recovery Program has made good progress in its first ten months, but problems now arising here and in Europe call for hard political decisions, James Reston, diplomatic correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared yesterday.

" The Wandering Jew," an Italian-made film drama, starring Valentina Cortese, now under contract to Twentieth Century-Fox, will have its local premiere at the Little Cine Met on Thursday, March 3, it was announced yesterday by Globe Films, the distributors.

PRAGUE, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Gen. Rajmund Mrazek, 52 years old, was convicted today of having plotted with Britain and the United States against the Communist Czechoslovak republic. He was sentenced to life imprisonment.

A 43-old-old window cleaner was booked on a charge of homicide early yesterday morning at the East Sixty-seventh Street station house, after police said he confessed to the killing of an 87-year-old woman who had surprised him Monday morning as he was looting the hoard of Roosevelt dimes her grandson had collected.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- A special committee of five appointed by Governor Dewey to make suggestions for improving operations of the Civil Service department unanimously recommended today that administrative powers of the commission's president be broadened.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Pensions of $90 a month beginning at the age of 65 for all veterans who served as long as ninety days in either World War were approved by the House Committee on Veterans Affairs today.

The French poodle requires hours of primping before being exhibited at a dog show. By the time his particular specimen has been made ready to face the judges, the handler, who must then put down his charge in the ring in nearly perfect condition, is almost worn out.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation at the year-end had a backlog of orders amounting to $195,900,000, Robert E. Gross, the president, reported yesterday. He said that 1948 operations were characterized by the return to profitable operations, retirement of bank indebtedness and an increase in the order backlog.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Feb. 15 -- To help reduce juvenile delinquency, the education division of the New York State Youth Commission will recommend the use of pupil adjustment ratings in elementary public schools so that teachers may detect early signs of maladjustment.

An atomic bomb exploded under water in New York Harbor could contaminate the entire metropolitan area and adjacent sections of Connecticut and New Jersey for "centuries to come," Dr. David Bradley, Army radiological monitor at the Bikini tests, told 1,400 persons yesterday at a Book and Author Luncheon at the Astor Hotel.

CAIRO, Feb. 15 -- The United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission has raised the question here of whether the Arab countries would be willing to give permanent homes to Arab refugees from Palestine. Egypt's reply to the inquiry was a declaration that where the refugees belong is back in their own homes, with adequate guarantees of security and full equality.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Senate hearings on the reorganization bill that vests broad power in the President to initiate administrative reforms, ended today. Final pleas were for outright exemption of civil functions of the Army Corps of Engineers.

The American Writers Association, of which Rupert Hughes is the president and Fulton Oursler the executive vice president, announced yesterday that it would intervene in the Federal courts in support of Congress and the House Committee on Un-American Activities in the case of the ten Hollywood writers cited for contempt of Congress for refusing to say whether they were Communists.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 15 -- Dr. Philip C. Jessup, newly appointed United States Ambassador-at-large, maintained today that as long as talks continued on the Berlin situation, there was hope that the Soviet Union and the Western occupying powers would reach eventual settlement.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 15 -- Standing on the rostrum of Israel's new Constituent Assembly under a painting of Theodor Herzl, founder of Zionism, the Arab Deputy from Nazareth made a dramatic appeal today for peaceful relations with the Arab states.

In the closing Republican brief for the Taft-Hartley bill, delivered in June, 1947, New York's liberal Senator Ives told his fellow-members of that chamber that he had hoped originally that no new legislation of the kind would be necessary. After a few days of hearings, however, he was convinced, he said, that there were abuses and inequities that required correcting. But, he added:

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 -- An unauthorized walkout of cab drivers today virtually completed the paralysis of Philadelphia's street transportation system as negotiations in the strike of 11,000 bus, trolley, subway and elevated train operators dragged through their fifth day.
The show presented by Mary Lewis in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel yesterday at the luncheon hour was not only instructive but was good fun.

A syndicate of 114 investment houses headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will place on the market today a new issue of $40,000,000 of 30-year first mortgage bonds of the Duke Power Company at 101.31 to yield about 2.81 per cent.

Strong, well managed local distributors are of vital importance to the entire liquor industry, Henry Morris, general sales manager of Gallagher Burton's, declared yesterday at a meeting of the company's wholesalers' salesmen in the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.

The United States must act quickly to eliminate racial and religious discrimination if it is to win strong allies in the "crusade against communism," Robert C. Weaver, visiting professor at New York University's School of Education, warned yesterday.

Edward L. Kropa will join the Borden Company's chemical division as chemical director on March 1. For the past twelve years he has been with the American Cyanamid Company, heading its research on resins and plastics since 1943.
LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 15 -- The United Nations Security Council rejected today two Russian attempts to block consideration of the membership application of the Republic of Korea.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- A dam or series of dams on the upper Delaware River and its tributaries to insure future water supplies for New York City and metropolitan areas of Pennsylvania and New Jersey is contemplated in a bill introduced today under the auspices of the Joint Legislative Committee for Interstate Cooperation.

At Albany the Assembly has passed a bill sent to it by its Motor Vehicle Committee which would prohibit installation of television sets in automobiles if the screen is within the view of the driver. According to an Albany dispatch to this newspaper, the bill would not outlaw television screens visible to other occupants of motor vehicles.
The fact that eggs have dropped in price 11 cents a dozen within the last seven weeks should delight consumers, because, an inquiry among restaurants shows, consumers like eggs.

STOCKHOLM, Feb. 15 (UP) -- In a bitter, fist-swinging battle in which a Canadian, Jim Russel, was banned from the remainder of the meet, Czechoslovakia defeated Canada by 3 to 2 today while Switzerland defeated the United States, 5 to 4, in another rough opening-round match in the championship division of the world amateur hockey tournament.

The Grace Line will solicit bids soon for the construction of two large liner-type vessels to team with the liners Santa Paula and Santa Rosa in the company's service to the Caribbean, it was reported yesterday.

The steels and motors lent a little life to the stock market yesterday but the trading was the dullest in four months. Price changes were generally confined to fractions, with the composite rate raised 0.35 point, but a few of the pivotal issues showed gains of more than a point.
Would you kindly let me comment on certain statements made by Hussein Ala, Ambassador of Iran, in his letter printed in THE TIMES of Feb. 9, 1949.

PARIS, Feb. 15 -- In the face of violent cross examination and impassioned verbal lashings Soviet Air Force Lieut. Gen. Leonid Rudenko today huffily left the witness stand and strode out of the courtroom where the Kravchenko libel suit is being heard.

The first primary fight in sixteen years against Tammany Hall as a political entity was announced yesterday by a group of young Democrats, most of whom .are affiliated with the New York Young Democratic Club, an organization set up last year by the Democratic State Committee.

A solemn field mass Was offered yesterday morning in the Fourteenth Regiment Armory, Fourteenth Street and Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn, for the spiritual welfare of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, imprisoned Hungarian prelate, before 12,000 Catholic students.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 15 (Reuters) -- Hungary has met a Yugoslav complaint with a counter-blast accusing Yugoslavia of spying, provoking frontier incidents and seizing Hungarian property, it was announced here today.

Cooperation in the military field with the free nations of Western Europe would be advantageous to the United States in the opinion of 89 per cent of 540 "leading citizens" in twenty-three cities of this country who were polled by the Council on Foreign Relations, according to a report made public yesterday at the council's offices, 58 East Sixty-eighth Street.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 2 points higher to 8 points lower than Monday's final levels.

Although marred by some unpleasant aspects, the 1949 food industry outlook appears "encouraging," William R. Dunn, credit manager of General Foods Corporation, declared yesterday at a meeting of the Bank Credit Associates of New York.

The leadership of Dr. Edward M. Bernecker in formulating the city's $150,000,000 hospital expansion program was praised yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer at a luncheon at the Statler Hotel for the former Commissioner of Hospitals.

Exports by India to the United States this year may be expected to exceed the $300,000,000 figure of 1948 as the result of special measures taken by the Indian Government to divert trade to this country, I. F. Baker, vice president and treasurer of the Westinghouse Electric International Company, said yesterday.

Republic Steel Corporation declared yesterday an extra dividend of 25 cents a share in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of the same amount on the common stock, payable on April 2. The company paid in 1948 an extra of 50 cents in April and 25 cents additional in each of the other three quarters.

Because the United States still operates under a mainly free market" economy, "the Government cannot prevent a recession," Lewis H. Brown, chairman of the board, Johns-Manville Corporation, declared last night. He addressed more than 1,000 executives at the annual Purchasing-Sales dinner of the Purchasing Agents Association of New York at the Commodore Hotel last night.

Formation of Charles Schlaifer Co., Inc., new advertising and public relations organization, at 212 West Fiftieth Street, was announced yesterday, in making the announcement, Charles Schlaifer, who until recently was director of advertising-publicity-exploitation and radio for Twentieth Century-Fox, said that the company will not confine itself to motion-picture advertising and public relations.
ROME, Feb. 15 -- Pope Pius will speak twice again in the immediate future on the case of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty.

TOKYO, Feb. 15 (UP) -- Several investigations were under way today to determine whether members of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters were making unauthorized policy statements or whether Japanese reporters were issuing false stories.

The Port of New York Authority yesterday filed reports with Mayor O'Dwyer of New York and Mayor Murphy of Newark outlining its operations for 1948 of La Guardia, New York International and Newark Airports and the Newark Marine Terminal.

ANDREWS AIR FORCE BASE, CAMP SPRINGS, Md., Feb. 15 -- The Air Force awed President Truman with the most impressive show of its history this afternoon, but left him apparently pondering the ultimate cost of air power. The show took on particular significance because of the struggle between the proponents of a 70-group air force and those led by Mr. Truman who advocate a 48-group force.
LONDON, Feb. 15 -- The last day of account found the stock market subdued and most prices lower.
Another arctic storm moved in on the northern Plains States yesterday. The Associated Press reported it drove frigid gale winds, accompanied by snow, into the Mountain States.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UP) -- The Senate Banking Committee set the stage today to reject the idea of a special Senate committee on small business.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, in its fiftieth year of operations, established a new peacetime sales record of $704,875,941 in 1948 and earned $30,595,518, P. W. Litchfield, chairman of the board, reported to stockholders yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Republicans waged a fight on the House floor today against the administration's public power policies as Democrats sought unsuccessfully to obtain quick passage of the first big money bill of the new Congress.

It took a jury of eight professional artists one hour and three minutes yesterday to give a Brooklyn bartender the biggest surprise of his birthday -- a gold first-place medal for artistic excellence pinned on the chest of his chubby 11-year-old son.

" Outline of Psychoanalysis," the last book to be written by Sigmund Freud before his death in 1939, will be published on Feb. 28 by Norton. A brief foreword says the book's purpose is "to bring together the doctrines of psychoanalysis and to state them, as it were, dogmatically -- in the most concise form and in the most positive terms."

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- United States Attorney Otto Kerner Jr. announced today that the regular February grand jury on Monday would begin an investigation of "Preston Tucker and the activities and certain aspects of the Tucker Corporation." Mr. Tucker, president of the company, said in Washington that the "hearing will provide a welcome opportunity to explain our side of the story."

Major league hockey's top forward line of Ted Lindsay, Sid Abel and Gordie Howe will lead the front-running Detroit Red Wings against the New York Rangers in a National League contest at Madison Square Garden tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, returned from a three-week tour of the Far East today with the belief that it would be "impractical" now to strengthen United States forces in Japan.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Norway's Foreign Minister Dr. Halvard M. Lange spent most of his time here today writing a report to the Norwegian Government on his mission to Washington and London to make inquiries about the proposed North Atlantic defense pact. He will leave London tomorrow.

Members of the Medical Society of the County of Kings voted 861 to 755 yesterday against paying the $25 assessment levied by the American Medical Association to finance opposition to the proposed national health program.

New York City's bus lines seldom get into the news except when they are in danger of not running at all because of a strike threat, or when the unpleasant subject of fare increases comes up. It is a pleasure, therefore, to take note of the excellent record for increasing safety of operation made in 1948 by the Third Avenue Transit Corporation, which received awards yesterday from the Greater New York Safety Council.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- Spokesmen for New York City department stores and other retail organizations throughout the state declared at a public hearing here today that price rises would follow enactment of a proposed bill to regulate conditional sales contracts and chattel mortgages.

Two weeks have now elapsed since Governor Dewey presented his $936,200,000 budget. Hearings on that budget will be held today in Albany and there will be, on the one hand, a substantial number of witnesses appearing in behalf of more state aid to education and, on the other hand, a considerable body of testimony against the over-all size of the budget and the tax increases it brings with it.

Reorder business in New York's garment market reflects sharply the lag in retail trade, it was pointed out yesterday. Unseasonably warm weather along the Eastern seaboard thus far has proved no better stimulus for spring apparel than the deep snows in the West, manufacturers said.

One of the more depressing aspects of the reports which Hanson Baldwin has been making to this newspaper on defense preparations by the United States in its outposts concerns the manner in which our armed forces are housed. Life in the boondocks (the Marine term for any rugged backcountry billet) apparently is about as uncomfortable as it can be made.

Sightmaster Corporation has placed its initial 1949 order for 3,500 fifteen-inch direct view television tubes entirely in all-glass units, Michael L. Kaplan, president, disclosed yesterday. He said that his company has chosen glass tubes for several reasons although sixteen-inch metal tubes giving the same 125-square-inch picture are considerably cheaper.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Spokesmen for sixty non-scheduled passenger-carrying airlines appealed to the Civil Aeronautics Board today to cancel contemplated orders which they said would spell the end of their business.

A half-filled, 2,000-gallon tank of liquid hydrogen cyanide exploded yesterday at the sprawling plant of the Koppers Coke Company at Kearny, N. J., injuring two employes, one fatally, and generating a concussion that shook surrounding communitiese as well as much of New York across the Hudson River.

The Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company announced yesterday that its net income last year was $8,166,655, a rise of $332,223 over the $7,834,432 reported for 1947. Share earnings in the respective years amounted to $4.70 and $4.49.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 15 -- Tonight in Nanking Acting President Li Tsung-jen broadcast an appeal for unity and discipline in the shattered Chinese Nationalist camp. He said the country had been "ruined" to such a degree that the last hope for the Nationalists was the reform of the widespread corruption among politicians and army officers.

Activity on a downward scale carried rubber futures prices to new lows for the movement on the Commodity exchange yesterday. In a turnover of 1,650 tons, prices fell 8 to 18 points. All deliveries sold from one-half to one cent a pound below the Government's fixed price for general-purpose synthetic rubber. Prices were 5 cents below the post-war OPA support level.

Robert Cornman, who was heard in a recital in the Times Hall last night, is one of those rare pianists who can perform contemporary music brilliantly and exuberantly, and at the same time can work his high-tension, individual way through the classics without upsetting the purists to any alarming degree.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 15 -- Dr. David M. Spain, 35 years old, took office today as Westchester County pathologist and head of laboratories. He was to have become medical examiner also, but state legislation creating the consolidated position has been found defective.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today denied a petition of motor carriers operating in the Northeastern section of the country for an immediate 10 per cent emergency increase in rates for transporting property. The increased rates would have affected all parts of New England and points in the New York City area.
The "greedy" landlords of Tulsa will undoubtedly draw the acrimonious censure of unthinking humanitarians, whose voices will amplify the shouts of politicians and the curses of tenants.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The specter of current surpluses of American commodities arose today to haunt the Senate and House foreign policy committees in their consideration of an authorization of $5,580,000,000 to finance the Marshall Plan through its second year of European recovery.
Bath Democratic candidates were successful in the two special elections held here yesterday, one in Brooklyn for member of Congress and the other in Manhattan for the Assembly.

Existence of four "colored" lists of prospective jurors for 1941 in the Federal jury clerk's office was shown yesterday by counsel for the eleven Communist leaders. Three of the lists came from the Federal Grand Jury Association.
LONDON, Feb. 15 -- A sharp rise in appropriations and a small drop in manpower were envisaged in Britain's defense budget for 1949-50, which the Government submitted to Parliament today.

Allegedly fraudulent use of inside information, said to have resulted in a profit of $300,000 from trading profits and brokerage commissions, has led the Securities and Exchange Commission to seek judgments against five persons and an over-the-counter brokerage firm.

A local law to increase taxicab fares about 27 per cent was reported out for favorable action yesterday by the Committee on General Welfare of the City Council. The rise would be the first since Oct. 24, 1933.

BATAVIA, Java, Feb. 15 (AP) -- United Nations commissioners suggested to the Security Council today that they postpone for two weeks making their own recommendations to the Council for settling the fighting between Indonesians and the Dutch.

ATHENS, Feb. 15 -- Greek national forces were today pursuing battered rebel contingents through the ravines west and northwest of Florina. They were further reported to have captured all the features from which the rebels, 4,000 strong, launched their determined attack against the town last Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Speaker Sam Rayburn declared today that Congress "in all probability" would have to increase taxes to prevent deficit financing.
Individuality of detail gave news value yesterday to the showing of spring coats, suits and furs in the Imperial Salon of I. J. Fox.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- The Senate Codes Committee voted unanimously today to report Senator Thomas C. Desmond's reporters confidence bill, with the understanding that it would not be advanced pending public hearings on a companion assembly bill.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,610, against 1,969 last week and 1,200 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 66 arrivals yesterday, compared with 939 last Tuesday.

In its first debate on the projected North Atlantic Security Pact, the Senate has raised again the main issue affecting American participation in world affairs. Technically the debate revolved around the meaning and the implications of the Atlantic Pact in view of the constitutional provision that only Congress can declare war.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The chief spokesman of Hungarian Communists now says that Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty was brought to trial only after the Vatican had passed up an opportunity to withdraw him.

ROME, N. Y., Feb. 15 -- Earnings of the Rome Cable Corporation for the quarter. Oct. 1-Dec. 31, 1948, were $356,483, equal to 89 cents a share of common stock. This compared with earnings of $203,437, or 59 cents a share, for period in 1947.

As the largest private non-sectarian family and health agency in the United States, the Community Service Society last year proved its right to the high regard and earnest support of all New Yorkers. For, according to the organization's annual report, in 1948 it administered services to 67,299 persons.

Announcement that the Better Business Bureau of New York City is dropping, at least temporarily, its active participation in trade efforts to formulate a voluntary agreement limiting use of comparative price claims in fur advertising was criticized yesterday by Irving Genfan, executive secretary of the Greater New York Retail Furriers Association.

Most of the newspapers in this country are honest and objective in their presentation of the news and could not remain in business if they failed "to satisfy the people of our democracy," Edwin L. James, managing editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared last night at the winter meeting of the New York Academy of Public Education.

Six lawyers told an investigating committee yesterday that the police in this city and state often illegally enter homes and search persons without warrants in efforts to solve crimes. They all expressed the opinion that it was "a bad situation," some likening it to "terrorism."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The West Indies Corporation, New York, registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission 74,880 shares of its $1 par value common stock. West Indies proposes to offer the stock in exchange for 16,000 shares of the $100 par value common capital stock of the Compania Azucarera Boca Chica.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Avilion, 44-foot sloop owned by Fred M. Temple of Toledo, Ohio, had a 40-minute lead tonight in the Miami-to-Nassau sailing race when she rounded Great Isaac's. With approximately one-third of the course covered, the trim sloop was well ahead of the other twenty-one yachts left in the classic.

BOSTON, Feb. 15 -- Columbia University's small but swift basketball team handed Harvard its thirteenth consecutive setback, 57 -- 53, before 2,529 fans in an Eastern League game at the Boston Arena tonight.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 15 -- The Soviet Union today denounced the slave labor charges made here against it by the United States and other countries as "filthy libel" and served curt notice to the United Nations that no investigation of Russian camps would be tolerated.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The Truman Administration's bill to elevate the Federal Security Agency to Cabinet rank, transforming it into a Department of Welfare with a vast jurisdiction, was approved tonight by a House committee.
Eight men and four women jurors scaled a claim for $25,000, put forward by Frank F. Schrader, luggage dealer, for his services as an expert on hidden treasure, down to $10 in Supreme Court yesterday.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 15 -- Rivalry between the Corps of Army Engineers and the Federal Bureau of Reclamation, as well as dissension among other agencies in the development of the Columbia River Basin, has been advanced as an argument for establishment of a Columbia Valley Authority, now a foremost issue in the Pacific Northwest.

Ethel Merman, erstwhile star of "Annie, Get Your Gun" and other Broadway successes, is in the midst of negotiations which soon may lead to a regular spot on television. At the moment, Miss Merman is enjoying a vacation which she started after the closing of "Annie" last Saturday.
There is still hope for many wives and sweethearts who did not receive a message or token of love on St Valentine's Day.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The Census Bureau said today in its annual report on the labor force that virtual full employment prevailed in this country during 1948.

The Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company yesterday increased the quarterly dividend by 25 cents, reported a new high record in sales and earnings for 1948 and announced the election of James S. Adams as a director.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- A Dutch radio singer and an American war-time paratrooper today identified Mildred E. (Axis Sally) Gillars as having made Nazi propaganda broadcasts in Holland in World War II.

Securities houses participating in a Blyth Co. syndicate thought they had a "good deal" for a short while yesterday afternoon after a post-deadline exchange of bids on the $15,000,000 New Orleans union railroad terminal issues. Lively competition had generated three bids from the same syindicate participants in the first bidding for the bonds in April of 1948.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Paul A. Porter, former head of the Office of Price Administration who has served as attorney in a number of loyalty cases, today told the National Citizens Conference on Civil Liberties that the Government loyalty program should be abolished.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- Increasing Republican concern over the possibility of defections in their ranks on Governor Dewey's recommendations for a tax increase and additional school aid was manifest today on the eve of a scheduled public hearing on his record $936,200,000 budget.

GENEVA, Feb. 15 -- The United States will continue to forbid exports of goods of potential military value to Eastern Europe as long as the Soviet Union continues to display an aggressive policy, Paul R. Porter told assembled European trade officials today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The Transamerica Corporation, San Francisco, spent more than $2,800,000 in 1936 to gain control of an "independent" bank in Oakland, Calif., so that it could merge it into another bank in its huge system, an examiner of the San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank stated today.
For the second time in eight days the case of Cardinal Mindszenty produced a protracted row in the City Council yesterday.

Social investigators employed by the city's Department of Welfare have agreed to conduct tomorrow from 5 P. M. to midnight a "service sit-in" demonstration against alleged speed-up policies put into operation by Raymond M. Hilliard, Commissioner of Welfare, the officials of Local 1, United Public Workers, CIO, made known yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- Governor Dewey's program bill directed at an expansion of the state's mental-hygiene facilities and the training of psychiatric and other personnel needed for proper care in mental hospitals was approved unanimously today by the Senate.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 15 -- Sao Paulo's industrial leaders are worried and have sent an SOS for farmers to attend an agricultural convention next week. The bugaboo is Africa.
New Yorkers stole a page from spring's calendar yesterday as vernal temperatures exceeded two previous records of the local Weather Bureau.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Feb. 15 -- Tighter bonds between the Presbyterian family of churches in America and the Reformed communions of Europe and Asia were urged here today. The plea was made before 125 church leaders assembled for the opening of a three-day meeting of the Western Hemisphere Section of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches holding to the Presbyterian system.

After a miscount of the votes indicated that the measure had been defeated, the City Council adopted yesterday a proposed local law for the creation of three additional positions of associate justice in the Court of Special Sessions at $15,000 a year each.

Finding a new script worthy of his favorite character actor had John Golden stumped. Not one to be balked, he did the next best thing. He pounced on Sidney Howard's Pulitzer Prize play of the 1924-25 season, "They Knew What They Wanted," which was first produced by the Theatre Guild, as a proper vehicle for Paul Muni.

Reflecting the increase in sales to $23,668,718 last year from $19,848,936 in 1947, the net profit of the Woodward Iron Company amounted to $5,194,553 in 1948 against $4,308,727 the year before, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
CHICAGO, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Attorneys continued today with efforts to choose a jury to try National City Lines, Inc., and others on charges of conspiring to monopolize transit lines in forty-two cities.
BERLIN, Jan. 28 -- The new nationalism has not yet conquered any of the major political parties in Western Germany.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The Army admitted today that the report on the Sorge spy ring in Japan, formally issued by its public information division last Thursday, did not represent Army policy. Some Army officials, who were not present when the long report was made public, went on also to say they believed a "public relations faux pas" had been committed for which only the Army could take responsibility.

A new issue of $5,000,000 of Fulton County, Ga., school district school bonds due on each March 1 from 1950 to 1975 was bought yesterday by a banking syndicate headed by Chase National Bank at a bid of 101.61 for 2 1/2s. The bonds were reoffered at prices to yield 0.90 to 2.45 per cent.
HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Willie Pep of Hartford was hailed today by the Connecticut State Legislature as a "great world champion."

BOBSLED racing is probably the only sport in existence which requires all contestants to sign a preliminary waiver absolving all authorities from any blame in the event of accident. This obvious warning is blithely ignored by the riders of these steel juggernauts because the game is such a fascinating one that it is worth every risk.
Separation of the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, and its Dramatic Workshop into two independent units was announced yesterday.

Winners in the thirteenth annual interfleet accident reduction contest were announced yesterday by the Greater New York Safety Council. They include a mail truck and bus in Manhattan, milk wagon in Queens, and a coal truck in Brooklyn.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 15 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, announced today a United States-British agreement to institute customs control by the Germans over all Western Allied visitors to the bizonal area. He added that he expected the French zone to join with the bizonal area in customs administration in about four weeks.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 15 -- With the aid of slow-motion films, monkeys and rerouted muscles, surgeons of the University of California, in what was described today as an unprecedented operation, have restored a man's ability to swallow.

The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company in 1948 placed in force new insurance amounting to $1,324,806,459, Paul F. Clark, president, announced yesterday in the company's eighty-sixth annual report.

LONDON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The 1948 Olympic Games made a profit of $119,400. A preliminary financial statement from Lord Burghley's Olympic Organizing Committee tonight reported that surplus from the greatest amateur sports competition in history.

VIENNA, Feb. 15 -- Two Rumanian Orthodox priests who refused to help the Patriarch of Rumania coerce the Rumanian clergy into accepting incorporation of the Rumanian Orthodox Church into the Russian Orthodox have fled to Austria via Yugoslavia, it was learned here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Charging a conspiracy to eliminate competition in the manufacture and distribution of dental goods, the Federal Trade Commission issued a complaint today against the American Dental Trade Association, Washington, D. C., its officers and 144 manufacturers and distributors of dental goods.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 15 -- One hundred employes of the Wagner Awning and Manufacturing Company, from sweeper to vice president, tonight assumed control of the 84-year-old concern, reputed to be the largest retail awning manufacturer in the world.

James A. Moffett, former Federal Housing Administrator and oil company executive, received a $1,150,000 verdict from a Federal Court jury yesterday for services he said he performed for the Arabian American Oil Company in 1941 in protecting its rich oil concessions in Saudi Arabia.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- The Foreign Ministers' deputies of Britain, France and the United States met with head-on Soviet opposition here today when the talks on an Austrian peace treaty entered their "key" phase -- a discussion of what constituted "German assets" in Austria.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, asserted today that the American Federation of Labor was demanding "the most extraordinary special privilege any organization ever claimed in the United States."

A system developed to end the proverbial arguments between the homemaker and the housepainter on the exact color she wants and he mixes was demonstrated yesterday afternoon at the sixty-fifth annual convention of the Painting and Decorating Contractors of America.
A sunbeam strayed through a window of the Aldine Club at 200 Fifth Avenue yesterday and sparkled on a silver cigarette case held by Miss Anna Beach.

The standing committee of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island rejected yesterday a request by the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, rector of Holy Trinity Church, Brooklyn, that hearings on the controversy between the vestry and the 74-year-old rector be postponed until April 18.

BOSTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Top-seeded stars, including a team of English women, continued to advance today in second and third round matches of the Women's National Squash Racquets championship at the Harvard Club.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 15 -- James W. Smith saddled his last horse for Mrs. Elizabeth N. Graham's Maine Chance Farm today. He saddled a winner. Royal Blood did the job for him in the best of the afternoon's races before 16,654 at Hialeah Park.
The city campaign in behalf of the 1949 Red Cross Fund got under way yesterday at a luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria. Hotel.
Fifty carloads of fruit were stranded at Pier 29 of the Pennsylvania Railroad for two hours yesterday morning by a "quickie" strike of produce drivers, loaders and checkers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Administration forces today introduced a bill that would grant to President Truman all of the powers he has requested in his "anti-inflation" program.

PARIS, Feb. 15 -- Agreement in principle that the Foreign or Finance Ministers of the Marshall Plan countries should meet at least once a month in the Executive Committee of the European recovery council was reached today by the special committee named to consider this question. A recommendation to this effect will be put before the full council of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation Thursday.

CAIRO, Feb. 15 -- The Egyptian Government launched yesterday without previous notice the first measures of an austerity campaign. The drive was made necessary by a shortage of hard currencies and an unfavorable balance of trade for 1948 of 29,000,000 Egyptian pounds [about $116,000,000].

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 15 -- In response to a question at a press conference today, Gen. Lucius D. Clay said that he had been made aware of anti-Semitic inclinations on the part of some members of the Military Government, including high officials, and he vigorously denounced them.

Degrees will be awarded tomorrow night to 246 persons at the fourteenth commencement exercises of Queens College at the Forest Hills High School, 112th Street near Sixty-seventh Road, it was announced yesterday. Donald I. Shank, vice president and secretary of the Institute of International Education, will be the principal speaker.

The Associated Cardiac Leagues, Inc., announced yesterday through its president, Mrs. Samuel N. Shapiro, that it had bought an eighty-acre estate in Verbank, Dutchess County, N. Y., for the establishment of a summer camp for cardiac children.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- A State Department spokesman asserted today there were "no differences" between the Executive Branch and the Senate over "objectives" of the proposed North Atlantic defense pact. However, a number of diplomats took a reserved view of latest developments and their probable effect upon solidarity among Western European powers.

The 475 tenants of the Ansonia Apartments, Seventy-third Street and Broadway, the owner of which, Samuel Broxmeyer, is involved in Federal bankruptcy proceedings, have received demands to pay rent to two different parties, each claiming to operate the building, it was learned yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 15 -- Sweden will be forced to cut her wood pulp prices for the United States drastically if she hopes to preserve this backbone of Swedish exports overseas, it is generally predicted in Stockholm business circles tonight.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- Five major Jewish organizations announced today their support of the trustees of the State University who are resisting efforts of the Board of Regents to strip them of administrative functions and reduce them to a planning agency.

The sixth annual Greenwich Village Antiques Show was opened yesterday afternoon with a ceremony at Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street, in which the Broadway stars Dorothy Stickney and Howard Lindsay of "Life With Mother" and Henry Fonda of "Mister Roberts" reversed an hour glass and lighted candles to symbolize the turning back of time.

The "sky is not the limit in aviation" and future airports in New York and Newark will be "cities within cities," Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, declared here yesterday.

If one were to poll the fans regarding the season's most exciting college basketball game, 3,422 votes would be cast for last night's St. Johns-Manhattan clash at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, where the Brooklyn Redmen took the measure of the Jaspers. 53 -- 46.

The customary tranquillity of the weekly luncheon gathering of track coaches, officials and writers at the New York Athletic Club gave way to raging controversy yesterday when it was announced that the Ogden starting gate would be used for the sprint and hurdles in Saturday's American indoor championships at Madison Square Garden.
BOSTON, Feb. 15 -- The Paul Revere bowl, one of the earliest symbols of American independence, was presented to the Boston Museum of Fine Arts today by the citizens of the commonwealth.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- C. Arvid Johnson of New York, president of the Central-Illinois Securities Corporation, who was enjoined yesterday from removing the company's assets from the state, already had transferred most of the assets involved to New York City, it was disclosed in Superior Court today.

Pan American Airways yesterday told the Civil Aeronautics Board that the purchase price for its proposed acquisition of American Overseas Airlines would be "at least $18,845,000." Pan American also asked the Government agency for expeditious handling of the sale proposals, drafted on Dec. 13, 1948.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Players from Wilmington, Del., dominated play tonight in the American Bowling Congress tournament.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 15 -- Samuel Goldwyn has withdrawn from his deal with Roberto Rossellini and Ingrid Bergman to participate in the production of their film in Italy, it was learned today from Goldwyn. At the same time, the Music Corporation of America, Miss Bergman's representative's, disclosed that Ilya E. Lopert, also a participant in the project when it was previously announced, is no longer associated with it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Senate Democratic leaders will "not hesitate" to interrupt any civil rights or allied filibuster whenever other important hills in President Truman's program might otherwise be delayed. Senator Scott W. Lucas of Illinois, made this known today after a meeting with the Democratic Policy Committee, which he heads.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 15 -- The United States asked the United Nations Commission on Conventional Armaments today to give priority to the job of drafting plans for an international agency to collect and check information on the world's armed forces.
Along with yesterday's spring-like temperatures came the year's first retail showing of summer furniture.

Because business and the publics are continuing active buying, tire dealer quotas for 1949 have been raised 12 1/2 per cent in over-all 'attainment goals" compared to 1948, and a 20 per cent larger advertising appropriation has been provided to back up dealers' efforts, L. A. McQueen, vice president.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Prime Minister Shigeru Yoshida announced today formation of his third Cabinet. Of the seventeen portfolios fourteen went to his Democratic Liberal party (actually conservative). Two were given to the Democratic party, second ranking in Japan, and one went to a non-party man.

Many a reader's eyes probably lighted on a news item published recently and bearing the headline in this newspaper, "U. S. Automats in China a Dream of Communists." An Associated Press correspondent reported from a Communist headquarters in China that the soldiers were keen about America's mechanical wonders -- nothing was said about capitalistic wonders -- and that an officer said, "Twenty years after all China is Communist we shall have Automat restaurants."

The State Athletic Commission is satisfied that Referee Eddie Joseph "tried to carry out the board's rules and instructions to the best of his ability" last Friday night in the featherweight championship bout in Madison Square Garden which saw the title transferred from Sandy Saddler back to Willie Pep.

The National Sportsmen's Show, that extravaganza of wilderness by-products, will again attract thousands of anglers, hunters, hikers and gadget collectors to Grand Central Palace from this Saturday to the closing day on Feb. 27.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The National Labor Relations Board has submitted a brief to the Second Circuit Court of Appeals in support of its petition to enforce its order against the hiring-hall demand of the National Maritime Union, CIO, on the Great Lakes.

PARIS, Feb. 15 -- According to those in closest touch with European discussions of security, Sweden's leaders contend that there is no chance of their entering a Scandinavian pact that would be linked with the proposed Atlantic pact, as Washington apparently now desires.

Mothers of East Harlem, a hundred strong, set up a barricade of baby carriages yesterday afternoon at Second Avenue and 103d Street, cutting off traffic to the street. The women blocked the passage twice, from noon to 1 o'clock and from 2:40 to 3:40 P. M.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- All-American Airways plans to start its new passenger service in eight Eastern states and the District of Columbia on March 7.

The Judicial Council of the State of New York recommended yesterday the temporary emergency assignments of County Judges and Justices of the City Court to the Supreme Court to ease calendar congestion in the higher tribunal.
There was no mistaking the importance of floral trims in spring millinery in the Russeks showing yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 16 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council formally urged here today that fundamental human rights of inhabitants in Palestine and surrounding areas be safeguarded. The resolution was approved by a vote of ten in favor, none against and seven countries abstaining.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Feb. 16 -A committee to study salary standards for probation officers throughout the state was created today at the closing session of the annual State Conference of Probation Officers.

Dr. Abba Hillel Silver and Dr. Emanuel Neumann, two of America's leading Zionists, resigned yesterday from the Executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine in protest against a decision of the agency, announced simultaneously, calling on Henry Morgenthau Jr. and Henry Montor to manage the United Jewish Appeal campaign for $250,000,000.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 16 -- While the Assembly was still wrangling late tonight over technical points of the transitory Constitution, plans were completed for Dr. Weizmann's inaugural tomorrow at noon.

THE reader of these pages in future years should realise how dense and baffling is the veil of the Unknown. Now in the full light of the after-time it is easy to see where we were ignorant or too much alarmed, where we were careless or clumsy. Twice in two months we had been taken completely by surprise.

ROME, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Following are the texts of the remarks made by Carlos Arango Velez, Colombian Ambassador representing the diplomatic corps, and by Pope Pius XII at a audience at the Vatican today:

THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 1, 1949, published a letter under the title "Czech Official Identified," signed by Dr. F. C. Weisskopf, Minister Plenipotentiary of the Czechoslovak Embassy in Washington. This letter has a bearing on an article which was published by your Washington correspondent James Reston, in the issue of Jan. 16, 1949, after my conversation with him, under the title "High Escaped Czech Depicts Prague as Soviet Colony."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson re-affirmed today the policy of President Truman's inaugural address as the goal of negotiations looking toward an effective North Atlantic defense pact.

MANILA, Feb, 16 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, Philippine Ambassador to the United Nations, departed by air for New York today with a new standing among his countrymen as a potential figure in the Philippine Presidential elections next November.

The hats that Tatiana du Plessix conjured up for the Saks Fifth Avenue spring millinery collection are irresistible. They have a dainty and flattering charm; are original and yet not extreme. If one can point out a single feature that puts them in the A-1 class it is the manipulation of the brims.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 16 (UP) -- Steel industrialists from the United States have encountered difficulties in their plans to develop Brazilian manganese deposits and may turn to Africa for new sources of the mineral, authoritative United States sources disclosed today.

The argument in the Security Council over the admission of a Korean government to the United Nations does not reflect so much a division among the Koreans themselves as a division between Soviet Russia and most of the rest of the world. The two conflicting governments there -- the U. N.-established Republic in the south and the Russian-sponsored government in the north -- do not reflect the wishes of the Korean people.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Representatives of the Atomic Energy Commission urged mining engineers and geologists today to join the new hunt for uranium deposits.

A majority of manufacturers and retailers of men's sports shirts are opposed to measuring and designating these garments with the same neck sizes as regular shirts, according to the results of a survey announced yesterday by the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers.

A New York syndicate has taken the 800-acre estate of Adolph Zukor, motion-picture executive, at New City, in Rockland County, N. Y., and will operate it as a private club under the name of the Dells Golf and Country Club, it was learned last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UP) -- The Government rested its treason case against Mildred E. Gillars today after an ex-Commando accused the wartime "Axis Sally" of selling out her country to Germany.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UP) -- The men who write insurance on overseas shipments complained to Congress today that policies of the Economic Cooperation Administration were driving them out of business.

Letter of credit shipments to Argentina came to a standstill here yesterday as the result of the new exchange permit system set forth in the decree of President Peron. The Commerce and Industry Association of New York protested immediate application of the decree to pending exports and cabled the American Embassy in Buenos Aires urging it to seek exemption for shipments covered by letters of credit about to expire.
TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 17 -- Neither Army Secretary Kenneth C. Royall nor any other high-ranking American gave any indication while here that the United States intended to withdraw from Japan.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- Despite the start of the new account, the stock market here today was unable to shake off its recent lethargy. What little business was passing, however, helped some sections to close slightly firmer.

Igor Stravinsky, with his son, Soulima Stravinsky as piano soloist, conducted a program of his works with the Boston Symphony last night in Carnegie Hall. The younger Stravinsky, who in contrast to his father is a tall youth, played with great respect and precision his parent's concerto for piano and wind instruments with double bass and tympani re-enforcements.

MUNICH, Germany, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Secrecy imposed for reasons unknown even to Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, masked the opening of a spy trial before a United States military commission here today.

THE novels of Jerome Weidman and Frederic Wakeman are written with such savage eloquence that they invite savage reviews. Yet these lively pastorals of metropolitan jungle life throw off so much heat and so little light that one need not take them any too seriously. They are, really, entertainment in the melodramatic manner, using the old reliable cliches of jealousy, betrayal and revenge to animate fabulous characters in modern dress.

Setting in motion for final action the largest corporate financing in history, directors of the $9,000,000,000 American Telephone and Telegraph Company approved yesterday for ratification by stockholders at their annual meeting on April 20, the sale to the 765,000 shareholders of $391,000,000 of convertible debentures.

The banning of The Nation by the Board of Education and similar "acts of suppression" by other school boards were condemned yesterday by the Association for Supervision and Curriculum Development of the National Education Association.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Felix Longoria, a young Mexican-American, was buried in a hero's grave today in Arlington National Cemetery.
Milwaukee County, Wis., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on March 7 on bond issues totaling $4,310,000. Dated Feb. 1, 1949, the bonds will come due Feb. 1, 1950 to 1956.

American falconers, who have been opposed at almost every turn in their efforts to revive this ancient sport, received another setback recently in their efforts to include a live hawk in the falconry exhibit to be featured at the coming National Sportsmen's Show.
The fate of Cardinal Mindszenty places a grave responsibility upon all who wish to maintain a system of government wherein justice, rather than one-sided dominance, operates.

WILLEM SLYKHUIS of the Netherlands has the wiry little physique and the puckish sense of humor of a leprechaun. What a leprechaun would be doing in Holland, however, certainly would baffle every Irish historian. At any rate, the stylish Willy has run faster indoor miles in this country than any other foreigner yet imported, faster in every race than even the immortal Paavo Nurmi at his best.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The House passed the first big money bill of the new Congress today after handing decisive defeats to the Republican minority on all issues raised in two full days of consideration.

With its Ukrainian and White Russian subdivisions, Soviet Russia has withdrawn from the only specialized agency set up by the United Nations which it had ever joined. This agency is the World Health Organization, from which the Soviets have resigned on the ground that they are dissatisfied with its work and that its expenses are too heavy for the member states to bear.

William Church Osborn, attorney and an officer in numerous civic and cultural organizations, was elected unanimously chairman of the board of trustees for the Children's Aid Society at its ninety-sixth annual meeting yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 16 -- News of the notices of withdrawal of the Soviet Union, Byelorussia and the Ukraine from the World Health Organization was received with shock and some dismay at United Nations headquarters here, but officials immediately discounted talk that the withdrawal moves might portend a Soviet boycott of the United Nations itself or other of its agencies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The State Department has been giving a great deal of thought to the question of whether to demand the withdrawal of Dr. Andrew Sik, the Hungarian Minister to the United States, but has not yet reached a decision, Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today at his news conference.
JERUSALEM, Thursday, Feb. 17 -- Dr. Chaim Weizmann, elder statesman and lifelong fighter for Zionism, was elected President of the State of Israel today.
The annual Junior Red Cross enrollment drive will begin March 1, it was announced yesterday by Dr. C. S. Johnson, city director of the organization.
PARIS, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Dick Button of Englewood, N. J., gave a remarkable display of rhythm today to take a long lead in defense of his world figure-skating championship.

Newspaper advertising in fifty-two cities during January totaled 163,977,331 lines, a gain of 5.5 per cent over the like period of last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. Gains by major categories were: automotive, up 142.1 per cent; general, 7.6 per cent; retail, including department stores, 6.7 per cent, and financial, 1.09 per cent.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 16 -- Led by William (Bucky) Hatchett, Rutgers beat a fighting Lehigh quintet by 87 -- 56 tonight for its second victory in Middle Three competition this season.

Chuck Taylor, veteran Coalport, Pa., welterweight, came back from the verge of a knockout last night at Manhattan Center to pound out a victory over youthful Al Hersh of the East Side in a ten-round bout viewed by 1,824 fans, who paid receipts of $3,716.

BOSTON, Feb. 16 -- Dartmouth, aided no little by the brilliant defensive work of Goalie Capt. Dick Desmond, defeated Harvard, 4 -- 3, in a blistering pentagonal hockey league game at the Boston Arena tonight.

BOSTON, Feb. 16 -- Henry Bothfield 2d of Wellesley Hills, Mass., excelled in his final preparatory school game by scoring three goals and assisting on two others as Exeter defeated Andover, 8 -- 2, in the forty-fourth meeting of the schools at the arena today.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 16 -- The Yale basketball team experienced little difficulty in defeating Dartmouth tonight, leading all the way for a 71-43 victory over the Indians.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Sixty operators of irregular air passenger services who face sharp restrictions under a contemplated order of the Civil Aeronautics Board received strong and unexpected support today fro mthe Department of Justice.

" Ideological Differences and World Order," edited by Filmer S. C. Northrop, will be published by the Yale University Press on March 9. The volume contains contributions from twenty-one writers each of whom discusses the philosophy and science of his own culture in an effort to make it more understandable to others.

HAMILTON, N. Y., Feb. 16 -- Myron Schaffer, a substitute center at Cornell until Saturday night, threw in a basket in the last 20 seconds of play tonight to give the Big Red a thrilling 71-69 victory over Colgate.

Secretary of State Dean Acheson gave the reporters a brief talk yesterday about the objectives and dilemmas involved in the North Atlantic defense pact, but like many another good lawyer in a tough spot, he avoided the points at issue and tackled the points that were not at issue.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- Agreement was achieved here today among the Big Four Foreign Ministers' Deputies on the exact wording of a joint note that will permit Yugoslav representatives to appear before them and give their latest views on the pending Austrian peace treaty.
