WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 16 -- A resurgent Army basketball team, fighting desperately to stay in the game in the first half, overwhelmed Fordham, 70 -- 49, with a devastating last-half rally in the academy field house today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Russian shipments of manganese and chrome ore to the United States practically doubled in December, the Census Bureau reported today.
Frank S. Hogan, District Attorney of New York County, announced yesterday that he was a candidate for renomination for that office on the Democratic ticket.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Top-secret research on a 10,000-mile-per-hour "space ship" that might some day be the key to world military domination is being conducted by Government scientists, it was disclosed today.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 -- Robert E. Reuman, 25 years old, an instructor in philosophy at Temple University, and Robert Young, 23, a sophomore at Swarthmore College, were sentenced today to a year and a day in Federal prison for refusing to register under the Selective Service Act of 1948.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 16 -- Dr. Walter H. C. Laves, deputy director general of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, stated today that the organization's entire program for this year was being streamlined.
The practice of faking evidence in uncontested New York divorce cases, now known to all, is cited in many quarters as proof that the grounds for divorce in this state ought to be enlarged.

A young man who told detectives that he had signed the name of Gene Bearden, star pitcher of the Cleveland Indians, fifty-one times in the last three days was arrested yesterday in his room at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on a worthless check charge.
LONDON, Feb. 16 -- The Western European Union allies are spreading an air-raid warning network across Europe, from the Baltic to the Mediterranean.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 16 -- The United Nations Security Council refused today to consider the membership application of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea -- the government formed in the northern part of the country and championed by the Soviet Union.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- Governor Dewey's tax increase and spending program for next year came under attack from taxpayer groups and representatives of educational, parents, teachers and other civic organizations at a legislative hearing today.

Obviously in the belief that lightning will not strike him twice Robert Villemain, French middle-weight, is coming back to America for another fling at the native fighter. The gallant little Frenchman is due by plane today, to learn he is matched for a ten-round bout with Jake LaMotta, rugged Bronxite, in Madison Square Garden March 25.

RHODES, Feb. 16 -- Egyptian objections to the revised form of the compromise armistice plan of Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, United Nations acting mediator for Palestine, have produced a new hitch in negotiations with the Israelis.

Financing totaling $16,905,000 for the purchase of new railroad equipment was arranged yesterday by the Pennsylvania and the Denver Rio Grande Western railroads. Award of the new issues of trust obligations following competitive bidding, was as follows:

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Feb. 16 -- The Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, 74-year-old rector of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, said today that he was "cheerful" but not "very hopeful" regarding the outcome of a two-day closed hearing on efforts of the church's vestry to terminate his forty-five-year pastorate.

Mayor O'Dwyer persuaded representatives of 26,000 unionized employes of the Consolidated Edison System yesterday to resume direct negotiations with the company to avert a strike when the present contract expires March 1.

TOKYO, Japan, Thursday, Feb. 17 -- Army Secretary Kenneth C. Royall's denial that he ever said anything to American newsmen here about the withdrawal of United States troops from Japan in the event of war with Russia does not conform with what he told twelve American correspondents on Feb. 6 at the United States Embassy.

The nation's gasoline stocks increased last week by 2,611,000 barrels to a new peak of 119,780,000, according to the weekly figures of the American Petroleum Institute. A week earlier the total was 117,169,000 barrels and a year earlier 107,169,000.

Up at the Master Institute Theatre on Riverside Drive the Abbe Practical Workshop had been doing some interesting dramatic work this season. The group's presentation of "Rose in the Wilder ness" last month was well received in many quarters.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 16 -- Despite some traffic trouble at the head of the stretch, Samuel D. Sidell's 4-year-old filly Allie's Pal made her 1949 Hialeah Park record four for four today when she won the $12,075 Columbiana Handicap for fillies and mares.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The combined strength of the armed services reached 1,665,000 officers and men on Jan. 31, about 39,500 more than were on active duty at the end of the year, the National Military Establishment reported today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UP) -- For the first time in five years the United States has quit eating steaks faster than it grows them, the Department of Agriculture reported today.
GENEVA, Feb. 16 -- The Eastern European countries have asked the West to present "shopping list of products that the Western nations will need from Eastern Europe to supplement their recovery plans.

Allen B. DuMont Laboratories, Inc., has reduced the price of its fifteen-inch, all-glass direct view cathode ray tube from $77.19 to $59.50, I. G. Rosenberg, general manager of the cathode ray tube division, disclosed yesterday. He said the reduction of approximately 22 per cent was made possible by price reductions on the part of glass blank suppliers because of mechanization combined with lower production costs realized through volume output.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Senator Harry P. Cain, Republican of Washington, failed today to obtain any advance assurance of support from the Republican policy committee of the Senate in his fight to block confirmation of Monrad C. Wallgren as chairman of the National Security Resources Board.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Just imagine the sensation if President Truman's bathtub had crashed through the ceiling into the midst of a White House reception.

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 16 -- An end to a three-day strike by about 300 employes that had made 5,600 workers idle at a United States Rubber Company plant was ordered today by Local 101 of the United Rubber Workers of America, CIO.

Prof. Ralph H. Gundlach, one of the three faculty members recently dismissed at the University of Washington, Seattle, asserted here yesterday that the report in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 1 indicating that he was a Communist or had been severed from the university for Communist party membership, was not true.

ROME, Feb. 16 -- The diplomatic corps accredited to the Vatican this morning expressed to Pope Pius in the name of their governments their collective solidarity and sympathay at this moment when the Pontiff still is suffering from the impact of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty's trial and sentencing by a Hungarian court.

Carrying large bundles of newspapers and photographs that told the story of the receptions given to France's Gratitude Train, three members of the French committee that brought the train to this country left the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, at noon yesterday on an Air France plane for Paris.

ATHENS, Feb. 16 -- Speaking to the press today, Deputy Premier Alexander N. Diomedes, one of the country's leading economists, who in view of Premier Themistocles Sophoulis' continued indisposition, has assumed virtual leadership of the Government, said the prosecution of the war against the Communist-directed rebellion "must have first priority."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UP) -- Russia has agreed to return the cruiser Milwaukee to the United States and the 8,000-ton warship is scheduled to dock at Lewes, Del., late this month.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 16 -- Dr. Lo Lung-chi, spokesman of the Democratic League, charged today that the United States in its alleged trend toward support of the Chinese Government in Canton was dooming future American influence in China.
HONOLULU, Feb. 16 -- Hawaii's twenty-fifth Territorial Legislature convened here today in historic Iolani Palace on the traditional opening-day notes of music, hulas and flowers.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 -Although operating revenues climbed 10.9 per cent to $154,876,017 in 1948, the net income of the Bell Telephone Company dropped to $12,177,389 from $13,498,581 the previous year, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Senate Republican leaders disclosed today that they had reached a tentative understanding with the Administration Democrats to open on Feb. 28 the first floor battle in behalf of the Truman Civil Rights Program.

Millions of dollars are spent annually by the Federal Government on conservation of our natural resources, forests, soil and streams. But how much does the Government spend on the improvement of our finest resource, the young citizens of America?

The United Service Organizations is many things to many men. To hospitalized veterans it is a Veterans Hospital Camp Show, a singer, a dancer, a play or sketch artist -- all testimony of the remembering hearts of the American people.

More than 80 per cent of the merchant vessels of a thousand or more gross tons now on order or under construction in privately owned United States shipyards are oil tankers, according to a construction report released yesterday by the Shipbuilders Council of America.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Secretary of State Acheson spoke an obvious truth today when he said "there are no real differences in regard to the objectives" of the North Atlantic Community Agreement, now being negotiated with Canada and the Western European nations.

The Port of New York Authority prepared last night to resume construction of its giant union motor-truck terminal in Newark, a project it abandoned two months ago because of opposition from the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, American Federation of Labor.

In the chain stores today, partly as the result of further declines this week, retail prices of beef steaks and roasts are anywhere from 25 to 56 per cent lower than they were last September. That was when the cost of meat hit the highest peak since the removal of Office of Price Administration ceilings a couple of years earlier.

Influences as diverse as fashions in furs and politics in China are combining to put nylon to work about the house in still another manner -- as the bristles in the paint brush, Isidor A. Rubin, president of Rubico Brush Manufacturers, Inc., said yesterday.

Wilson G. Green has been appointed sales manager of the Fisk tires division, United States Rubber Company. He succeeds H. M. Ramsay, who has been transferred to the United States tires division to supervise farm tire sales.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- The Tucker Corporation's 1,800 dealers and distributors were urged today to back a plan providing for the ouster of Preston Tucker, president of the company, and the establishment of a ten-man management committee headed by Fred Rockelman, executive vice president and director.

The stock market gave yesterday its best performance in a week, but the generally higher prices failed to cause any marked increase in interest. Trading remained purely professional, with best attention accorded to the aircrafts, rails, rubbers, oils, films and tobaccos.

GENEVA, Feb. 16 -- The Soviet Union, the Ukraine and Byelorussia have notified the World Health Organization that they no longer consider themselves members of the organization, Dr. Brock Chisholm, the director general, announced today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- Grain markets fluctuated in a very nervous manner within a wide range of prices on the Board of Trade today. May wheat was the market leader, rallying 4 1/4 cents after an early dip on buying attributed to removal of hedges against liberal sales of cash wheat to the Government.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks went into a tie for fourth place in the National Hockey League tonight as they defeated the Boston Bruins, 5 to 1, before 15,681. Chicago and the idle Montreal Canadiens each have 43 points, but the Hawks have one more victory and two less ties.
Cotton prices on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated over a moderate range yesterday, and final prices were 5 to 15 points net lower.
Chief Peter Loftus was found guilty yesterday of four violations of the Fire Department's rules and regulations when he attended the Great Jones Street firehouse party on the night of Dec. 16.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Although 1948 revenues of Class I steam railways increased $4,324,900,000, or 80.9 per cent, over those of 1941, operating expenses were up $3,807,400,000, or 103.9 per cent, and railway tax accruals increased $481,300,000, or 88 per cent, over 1941, according to a monthly study of transportation statistics issued today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

BOSTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- One upset featured the completion of the third round of play in the women's national squash racquets championship today at the Harvard Club. Miss Margaret Howe of New Haven, Conn., eliminated Miss Betty Cooke of Somerset, England.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 16 -- After a set-down strike during a lunch period, more than 1,000 boys and girls stormed out of Thomas Jefferson and Thomas A. Edison High Schools here in a mass demonstration against the recent rejection by the board of school estimate of a $300 salary increase for teachers.

PARIS, Feb. 16 -- Foreign Minister Robert Schuman discussed the Atlantic pact negotiations at a Cabinet meeting today, for the first time informing his fellow Ministers of major details that the Foreign Office had until now kept to itself.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Back from a visit to Japan, John W. Gibson, assistant Secretary of Labor, said today that he was concerned about Communist influence in the newborn labor movement there and the lack of an adequate counter-attack.
The protracted legal battle of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, against the eight left-wing locals that seceded last fall ended in an out-of-court settlement yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Manufacturing plants laid off twenty-two of every 1,000 workers in December. The rate of dismissals was the highest for the month since pre-war December, 1939.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson confessed today that conflicting pressures for publicity and secrecy in formulating the North Atlantic pact illustrated "the bureaucrat's dilemma -- or why diplomats become dipsomaniacs."

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- Dr. Halvard M. Lange, Norwegian Foreign Minister, who has been in Washington and London making inquiries about the North Atlantic defense alliance, returned to Oslo today, leaving the British Government unperturbed by allegations that negotiations for the pact had been bungled.

LIVINGSTONE, Northern Rhodesia, Feb. 16 -- Thirteen earnest men today laid the foundation of what they hope may become a United States of Africa. They represented Southern Rhodesia, Northern Rhodesia and Nyasaland -- a self-governing colony, a crown colony and a protectorate, all British.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- A Government plan to help store surplus corn, wheat, cotton and other crops, even if it means buying or building elevators and warehouses, won general support today from the Senate Agriculture Committee.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 16 -- The Westchester County Medical Society announced today its opposition to any form of national compulsory health insurance.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 16 --If a Columbia Valley Authority is set up to direct the destinies of the Pacific Northwest's great river basin, it will be tantamount to substituting "totalitariansm" for "democracy," according to those opposing President Truman's CVA proposal.

Terms of the proposed consolidation of the AMRA Corporation (holding company) into the American Bosch Corporation were announced in a proxy statement mailed yesterday in connection with stockholder meetings of both companies called for March 14 to vote on the merger.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16 -- Individual shipping companies engaged in the transpacific trade indicated today that they were ready to carry cargoes from this port to Communist-held North China if they received the "green light" from the State Department.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Senator Wayne L. Morse, Republican, of Oregon, indicated today the main outlines of the bill that he will sponsor with Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican, of New York, as a compromise substitute for the Taft-Hartley Law and the Administration's labor bill.
ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- The Workmen's Compensation Board announced in its annual report today that 1948 was marked by a record high in referee workload and performance.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 16 -- The Russian repatriation mission, which has an authorized strength of four officers and four soldiers, has been requested to cease operations in the United States zone by March 1, United States Army Headquarters announced tonight.

On tour since Labor Day, during which it has played the nation's key cities, Robinson Jeffers' adaptation of the Greek tragedy, 'Medea,' starring Judith Anderson, will return to New York for a two-week engagement at the New York City Center, beginning May 2.

A strong plea for a Federal program of aid to education was made yesterday by Senator Irving M. Ives at the opening session of a four-day convention of the Association of Towns at the Commodore Hotel.

Champion Mazelaine's Zazarac Brandy, the boxer that achieved international fame Tuesday night by taking best-in-show at the Westminster Kennel Club event in Madison Square Garden, is going to be campaigned through the immediate post-Westminster circuit embracing Hartford, New Haven. Boston and Buffalo.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Feb. 16 -- The Western Hemisphere Section of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches holding to the Presbyterian system, now in session here, today heard reports on "The Witness of the Church Abroad."

Not to beat about the bush, the part of Tony in "They Knew What They Wanted" is not a happy choice for Paul Muni. Mr. Muni is playing it conscientiously with a wealth of detail in a revival of the Sidney Howard drama, which opened at the Music Box last evening.

" Troubled Island," a new American opera by William Grant Still with libretto by Langston Hughes, will receive its world premiere during the six-week spring season of the New York City Opera Company, which opens March 24 at City Center.
Seven pages missing from a jury clerk's record book created at least a temporary mystery yesterday at the trial of the eleven Communist leaders.

Hirsch Schwartzberg, modern Solomon of the displaced persons camps who worked miracles for hundreds of his fellowmen, saw a miracle work for himself yesterday. His "passport to nowhere" of last year had become a passport in fact -- leading to the United States.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 16 -- The Bank of Mexico stepped into the dollar market today to steady the falling peso.
VIENNA, Feb. 16 -- A purge of the Communist party of Czechoslovakia that will temporarily reduce its membership by one-quarter has been nearly completed, according to reports from Prague.

Speaking last night at the annual dinner of the Kings County organization of the American Labor party at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn, Henry A. Wallace expressed pleasure at the presence of the Rev. William Howard Melish, assistant rector of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church.
Wholesale prices of all meats except veal went higher in this city yesterday for the third successive day, but retail prices were generally 2 to 6 cents a pound below last week's.

A few days ago government officials were testifying before a Senate committee on the Administration's labor bill. Since that measure would abandon the prerogative granted the President under the Taft-Hartley Act to seek court injunctions in the case of strikes threatening public health and safety, the witnesses were asked how the Administration proposed to deal with situations of this kind in the future.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The United States and the United Kingdom concluded a consular convention today under which they exempt their Government-owned consulates from taxation. The convention was signed by Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, and Sir Oliver Franks, the British Ambassador.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 -- Union negotiators late tonight walked out of the Government-sponsored mediation conferences directed toward settlement of the six-day strike of Philadelphia's transit workers.

VIENNA, Feb. 16 -- Laszlo Szulner and his wife, Hanne Fischhof, Hungarian handwriting experts who asserted last week after they had fled to Vienna that many documents used by the Hungarian police to convict Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty were forgeries, said today they had hepled to forge them.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- A bill to continue the validation of the New York City rent control and eviction ordinances was sped through the Legislature today with the aid of an emergency message from Governor Dewey. He later signed the measure.

Blair Holdings Corporation had consolidated net operating earnings of $347,000 for the year 1948, compared with net earnings of $52,000 the year before, according to preliminary estimates in a report made yesterday to stockholders by Virgil D. Dardi, chairman of the executive committee.

The annual report of the Westinghouse Air Brake Company and its subsidiaries disclosed yesterday a net income for 1948 of $15,875,193, equal to $5 a share, compared with $13,376,662, or $4.22 a share, earned the year before.

Today's events: "Die Walkuere," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 P. M.; Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Ervin Laszlo, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Martin Boykan, pianist, Times Hall, 8:30; Vehanoush Hovivian, violinist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; William Masselos, pianist, Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A., 8:40; United States Army Band, free concert, WNYC American Music Festival, Carnegie Hall, 3:30.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 16 -- A deal is in negotiation for RKO to take over financing and distribution of the projected Roberto Rossellini-Ingrid Bergman production from which Samuel Goldwyn has withdrawn, it was learned today.

Peter Pirogov and Anatole Barsov, the two escaped Russian fliers, arrived yesterday for a three-day sightseeing tour of the city. They reported that they had found America exactly as they had expected it to be, with two exceptions.

The problem of caring for Arabs displaced by the hostilities in Israel is becoming increasingly serious, with the death rate among Arabs in the Gaza area alone amounting to 230 persons daily, William L. Gower, delegate for the American Red Cross in Europe, declared yesterday.

The vast relief work still to be done for European displaced persons was emphasized yesterday when the board of directors of the Church World Service announced budget requirements of $18,427,388 for this year. The amount would cover overseas relief and reconstruction for the twenty-three Protestant and Eastern Orthodox churches represented by the service.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., Feb. 16 -- Price's, once the gathering place for Presidents, New York and Philadelphia society and leaders of the sporting world, is observing its ninety-fifth anniversary this week.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16 -- San Francisco shipping disclosed today that it no longer was carrying the bulk of the mail from this country to Australia and New Zealand. The result, it was estimated, was a loss of $240,000 annually in freight revenues, plus a reduction in work for local longshoremen.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (AP) -- A proposal to liquidate the United Light and Railways Company and its subsidiary, the Continental Gas and Electric Company, was announced today by United's chairman, William G. Woolfolk.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, asserted today that the United States stood ready to "meet all comers" in the Far East and that no changes were planned that would either strengthen or weaken American forces in Japan.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 16 (AP) -- A private Moslem business group will seek to take over British and United States oil interests in the Middle East, it was learned today.

A Florida lumberman who was born in Louisiana paused here yesterday on his way to Boston, whence he will escort 10,000 Rhode Island Red eggs from Massachusetts to British West Africa. The deal was arranged with a man from Georgia, now working for the Colonial Development Corporation of London.
LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 16 -- Costa Rica and Paraguay are in danger of losing their votes in the United Nations General Assembly and officials here are a little embarrassed about the whole thing.

Educating children for democracy is a challenge to the child, the family, the teacher, the school environment and the school administration, three educators agreed last night on the "What's On Your Mind?" Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast by WQXR.

Employes in the city's Department of Welfare will be forbidden to take part in the "sit-in" demonstration that the United Public Workers of America, CIO, has scheduled for this evening, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Prominent economists speaking for industry and business challenged alike today the need for President Truman's "anti-inflation" program and the premises on which it was based, as developed by the Council of Economic Advisers.

It is regrettable that a dispute has arisen over the delineation of powers granted in the setting up of the State University of New York. Until this dispute abates it is certain to be an obstacle to rapid and orderly expansion of needed facilities for higher education.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UP) -- The Emergency Court of Appeals ordered tonight that rent controls be scrapped in Miami Beach, Fla., and nearby resort areas. It overruled the Housing Expediter, Tighe E. Woods, who recently rejected recommendations for decontrol by the area advisory board.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -Haiti charged the Dominican Republic with "moral aggression" today and invoked the Rio de Janeiro mutual defense treaty. The council of the organization of American states, however, adjourned without taking any action.

WORCESTER, Mass., Feb. 16 -- Columbia University's basketball team, playing its second rugged game in twenty-four hours, lost by 55 -- 49 to Holy Cross before 3,200 spectators in the Municipal Auditorium tonight.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- Two West Indian labor leaders claiming to represent 120,000 workers arrived here today to defend Earl Baldwin, Governor of the Leeward Islands, whose behavior has presented to the British Government an embarrassing dilemma that may have to be resolved by Prime Minister Attlee himself.
STOCKHOLM, Feb. 16 (AP) -- In one of the most thrilling matches of the tournament, Canada and Sweden battled to a 2-2 tie tonight in the world amateur ice hockey championship.

Northwest Airlines moved yesterday to meet the coast-to-coast cut-rate fares of the nonscheduled air carriers by proposing a coach fare between New York and Seattle that would amount to about $96, or $3 less than the $99 charged by the irregular lines and more than $50 less than its own regular fare of about $157.

The second annual state-wide grocery promotion will be held by approximately 15,000 stores during the first two weeks in May, the New York State Food Merchants Association disclosed yesterday. Promotional efforts will be intensified, it was stated.

A new wire system to link 100 banks in thirty-six cities is being planned by four large banks here, it was learned yesterday. The system, intended to compete with a similar but smaller network established nearly a year ago by the Bankers Trust Company, would involve an annual operating cost of about $500,000.
BERLIN, Feb. 16 -- The Soviet military administration today enrolled Johann Wolfgang Goethe on the side of communism in the political struggle for Germany.

A Bronx resident and his wife, both more than 70 years old, were killed at 6:45 P. M. yesterday at Prospect Avenue and 166th Street, the Bronx, by a hit-and-run motorist. A suspect driver was captured after a four-block chase by a policeman in a commandeered taxicab.

Operation of the municipal transit lines at the increased fares in effect since July 1, 1948, produced for the six months ended Dec. 31 a total revenue of $103,867,895 collected from 1,181,673,697 passengers, the Board of Transportation announced yesterday.

Net premiums written by the Home Insurance Company in 1948 aggregated $134,747,714, an increase of about $20,000,000 over the figure for 1947, Harold V. Smith, president, revealed yesterday in the annual report. Earned premiums totaled $132,335,796, a gain of $32,000,000 over the previous year.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16 -- Attorneys for railroads and water carriers sparred orally today as Clyde B. Aitchison, a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission, began hearing testimony in a case which is expected to determine the future of the West Coast seaborne trade.

City College and Long Island University return to Madison Square Garden tonight, following their respective trips to the Pacific Coast, and immediately find themselves cast in the roles of favorites. Nat Holman's Beavers are quoted a 9 1/2-point choice over Niagara, while Clair Bee's Blackbirds are rated 2 points better than Seton Hall in the court twin bill.

An unusual high school course giving first-hand experience with laboratory animals and equipment has been organized by the Board of Education for 800 boys and girls who want to be doctors, nurses and biological technicians.

David Grenfell, British Minister of Mines in the wartime coalition Government of Prime Minister Winston Churchill, arrived here yesterday for a speaking tour. In an interview he suggested immediate parleys among leaders of the Big Four so that the West can make it clear to Premier Joseph Stalin that we are determined to go on building up free political conditions throughout the world."

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 16 -- Public utilities must be permitted to attract investment capital to maintain their vital position in the American economy and to insure good service to the public, Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank of New York, said in an address here tonight.

The City Rent Commission issued yesterday amendments to its regulations covering an estimated 35,000 accommodations in 500 hotels. A spokesman for the Hotel Association of New York City promptly welcomed the changes as indicative of "the commission's recognition of the need for relief for hotels."

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16 (AP) -The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company has reported that 1948 was the biggest year in its history except for the return on its investment. This was placed at 4.78 per cent.

Samuel Broxmeyer, real estate operator whose $22,000,000 transactions are being investigated by Federal and New York County authorities, asked Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard yesterday for permission to reorganize Ansonia House, Inc., owner of the Ansonia, seventeen-story apartment hotel at Broadway and Seventy-third Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 9, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

A couple of husky young catchers became the latest Yankee contract signers yesterday when announcement was made that Charlie Silvera and Ralph Houk had accepted terms for the 1949 campaign. A total of 31, therefore, are now in the fold, according to Arthur E. Patterson, the Bombers' public relations man, with only seven more to be coralled.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that he would leave this afternoon for an eleven-day vacation trip to Havana aboard the passenger freighter Agwiking, sailing at 4:30 P. M. from Pier 34, North River at Spring Street.
The United States Golf Association has added a brand new championship to its list and has also decided upon a new system for conducting the women's amateur title tournament.

Scrap paper, old match covers and crumpled cigarette wrappers were dumped out of several wastebaskets in the office of the New York Heart Campaign late yesterday afternoon in an effort to store an unexpected harvest of checks and cash sent in by generous New Yorkers.

' Vast markets throughout Europe for millions of dollars worth of milk processing machinery await American manufacturers, Jeno Vegh, former secretary-general of the Federation of Hungarian Factory Industries, declared yesterday.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 16 (UP) -- An airborne irritant cost a few more women here their nylon stockings today but authorities said they were lucky they still had their health.
Realty deals by operators involving properties scattered from downtown Varick Street to the Dyckman and Inwood sections of northern Manhattan were reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The falling prices in basic commodity markets have provided no ground for any significant change in the original estimate of $5,580,000,000 as the minimum required from the United States to finance the European Recovery Program through its second year, Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today.

A program consisting of vocal solos and duets from cantatas by Bach and the bass aria, "Domine Deus" from that composer's Mass in A major was presented by the Bach Aria Group, William H. Scheide, director, at its second concert of the season last night at Town Hall.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- A New York landlord asked Congress today to authorize a mandatory 25 per cent rent rise over mid-1947 levels.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- Under the will of Jan Masaryk, Czechoslovak Foreign Minister, published here today, $5,000 will go to Dr. Jan Papanek, former Czechoslovak representative to the United Nations. The bequest implied a political understanding between Dr. Papanek and M. Mazaryk who plunged to death from a window in Prague last March.

The Truman Doctrine, the North Atlantic Pact and other western alliances were characterized last night as "a growing danger to the maintenance of world peace." Dr, Juliusz Katz-Suchy, permanent delegate from Poland to the United Nations, made this charge at the opening day's session of a conference on the United Nations at New York University.

Valentine's Day is over now, and he sits depressed, chin sunk on chest. Valentine's Day is over and his score reads, as it has lately read, one valentine received. It came on Feb. 14, but it was not until the end of Feb. 15 that all hope again was abandoned.

A strongly worded protest assailing a Federal Trade Commission attorney's "bombshell" action at the Feb. 10 hearing in Washington on proposed trade practice rules for the cosmetic and toiletries industry has been sent to acting FTC Chairman Lowell B. Mason by the Toilet Goods Association, it was disclosed yesterday by S. L. Mayham, executive vice president of the organization.

DANBURY, Conn., Feb. 16 -- Ten Protestant ministers of this city and Newtown made known today that they disapproved the withdrawal of an invitation to Henry A. Wallace to address the Danbury Lions Club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The country's small business men were given an opportunity today to "speak their piece" on Capitol Hill. They called upon Congress to reduce expenditures, eliminate inequities in corporation income taxes, abolish double taxation on corporation dividends, and to "go slow" on any plan to abandon the Taft-Hartley Act.

A threatened strike of 1,500 truck drivers and loaders that would have cut off most of the city's supply of fresh fruit and vegetables was averted yesterday through the efforts of the State Mediation Board.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The Government charged today that four corporations were conspiring to monopolize the cast iron pressure pipe industry. Such pipe is widely used in water and gas systems and also in pipelines handling crude oil, gasoline and similar materials.

The turn in the road came for the New York Rangers last night. Losers of their four previous games, Lynn Patrick's skaters snapped out of their slump by plastering the Detroit Red Wings with a 4-0 defeat at Madison Square Garden, much to the satisfaction of the crowd of 12,201 fans on hand.
Justice Felix Frankfurter of the United States Supreme Court defended last night this country's efforts to obtain justice for the rich and poor alike.

Four 12-year-old girls, all schoolmates and all members of the same Girl Scout Troop, were injured, one fatally, at 9:10 o'clock last night when they were hit by an automobile at the intersection of Eastern Parkway and Kingston Avenue, Brooklyn.

Trade hedge covering and support from producing interests advanced coffee futures in contract "D" 21 to 43 points on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. The market was steady, and selling was scattered. Contract "S" was in demand by trade interests.

The consecration of three bishops of the Roman Catholic Church on Monday, March 7, in Chicago's Holy Name Cathedral will be carried by the combined Eastern and Midwestern television networks of NBC, of which WNBT is the local outlet, from noon to 3:45 P. M.

According to reports in underwriting circles, a "selling job" lies ahead in the marketing of the $40,000,000 issue of bonds of the Duke Power Company before the issue can be marked down as an underwriting triumph on a 2.81 per cent yield basis.
CANTON, China, Thursday, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Premier Sun Fo expressed belief today that President Chiang Kai-shek would not return to active political leadership of China's Nationalist Government.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 16 -- Bids for the construction of the first three units of a total of five, which will mark the largest low-cost housing project in Westchester County, were opened tonight by the White Plains Housing Authority, which has obtained a state loan of $5,500,000 for the project.

Organization of a new type of Army supply reserve division embodying most of the field supply lessons learned in World War II and since, is nearing completion in the New York area, it was learned yesterday.

New York State's once vaunted system of highways deteriorated so markedly during the depression and war years that an expenditure of nearly $2,000,000,000 over a fourteen-year period has become necessary to restore it, Bertram D. Tallamy, State Superintendent of Public Works, reported yesterday.

" Caught," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer romantic drama, which arrives at the Capitol, is this morning's lone film newcomer. James Mason, who is making his debut in an American film; Barbara Bel Geddes and Robert Ryan head the cast of the offering, which was directed by Max Opuls and produced by Wolfgang Reinhardt from a screen play by Arthur Laurents and the novel, "Wild Calendar," by Libbie Block.
CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- Although few medical care plans include bedside nursing service, there is increasing interest in providing this feature, a conference of nurses was told today.
Neglect, abuse and criminal maltreatment of children in the city increased in 1948, the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children said yesterday in its seventy-fourth annual report.

A complaint charging fraud in obtaining and reselling war surplus materials has been filed in the Southern District Federal Court against a former assistant purchasing agent of Syracuse University and two other men alleged by the Government to be co-conspirators, it became known yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- Figures published today in the Commonwealth Economic Committee's "tobacco intelligence" show that during 1948 Commonwealth nations provided 35 percent of the United Kingdom's total tobacco imports against 27 per cent in 1947 and 24 per cent in 1938.

The most that can be said for the revival of "Pelleas et Melisande" at the Metropolitan Opera House last night is that it was routine. It was a performance without much magic of illusion, and without these things Debussy's masterpiece, which inhabits a world of quivering shadows, is but a shadow of a shadow.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 16 (AP) -- Twenty yachts rounded Great Stir-rup Light today and headed for Nassau on the last leg of their 184-mile ocean race. They bucked a 22-mile southeast wind and were not expected in Nassau until early tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The co-author of the Taft-Hartley Labor Law, former Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr., accepted the presidency of the Tool Owners Union today.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 17 -- After a secret trial before a United States military commission in Munich, a 31-year-old Sudetan German was found guilty today of having committed acts against the security of the United States occupation forces and was sentenced to twenty years in jail at hard labor.
ROME, Feb. 17 -- Clashes between strikers and police took place today at Isola del Liri near Frosinone, where workers had occupied a local paper mill.
LOS ANGELES, Calif., Feb. 17 -- The Beverly Hills police discovered today a "master burglar's lair" in the city's apartment district and recovered more than $120,000 in stolen jewels and furs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Senate pledged itself today to open on Feb. 28 a great struggle, of uncertain duration and outcome, to determine whether its rules against the filibuster shall be hardened for the second time in 143 years.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 17 (tP) --A fresh-water crew from Detroit today von the 18-mile 1Kiami-to-Nassau sailing race aboard the 55-foot cutter Blitzen.
There is logical basis for the belief that Moscow is reluctant to see too great an expansion of the powers of Chinese communism, and for more than one reason.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UP) -- Emory S. Land, president of the Air Transport Association, said today that the Department of Justice was putting its own economic theories about air transportation ahead of effective law enforcement.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- A withholding of all Marshall Plan aid from any participating country that failed to comply with orders or requests from the United Nations Security Council was proposed in an amendment offered to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today as it completed public hearings on a $5,580,000,000 authorization to finance the European Recovery Program through its second year.

PARIS, Feb. 17 -- At a Cabinet council, called ostensibly to consider a new rent law, Premier Henri Queuille today continued the effort he has been pressing since the opening of the reconstruction loan for a political truce until after the March cantonal elections.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Feb. 17 -- The Western Hemisphere Section of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches Holding the Presbyterian System, representing eight Reformed and Presbyterian communions in North America and Mexico, concluded today its three-day meeting here after taking a firm stand in favor of religious freedom.

The possibility of a strike of 26,000 Consolidated Edison employes in this city March 1 makes it clear that there is nothing academic about Congressional consideration of new legislation to cope with emergency strikes. It is perfectly apparent that an Edison walkout would jeopardize the welfare and even the lives of millions of persons in the metropolitan area.

Mayor O'Dwyer completed yesterday arrangements for resumption of contract negotiations intended to avert a strike of 26,000 Consolidated Edison employes when their present union agreement expires Feb. 28.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 17 -- The eclipse of feudal princely India, whose royal courts within the last two centuries were the most dazzling anywhere, and which spoke with powerful voices in this part of the world, was almost completed today.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Republican leaders of the Legislature are advocating a sickness disability plan very much like the proposal of the State Federation of Labor for benefits financed by employer and employe contributions.

TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 17 -- A substantial rise in kindergarten enrollments in New Jersey public schools confronts educational authorities with a problem of acute teacher shortages in the 1949-50 school year.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 17 -- A number of foreign business men declared here today that Gen. Tang En-po, the Shanghai-Nanking-Hangchow garrison commander, was "putting the squeeze" on the city on an unprecedented scale. The general, they said, had asked merchants for 300,000,000 gold yuan a month, beginning in January, for distribution to his troops.
The classic answer to the ancient question: "When is a deer not a deer?" is now being offered by a number of Westchester County citizens who reply: "When it comes from Westchester."

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 17 -- The Chief of the Cabinet of the Cyrenaican Emir, Adris el Senussi, has published here a statement that Cyrenaica would seek complete sovereignty independent of the fate of the Tripolitanian half of Libya if the United Nations did not ettle at it next meeting the issue of the future of Libya in a manner that the Cyrenaicans could accept.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- For the first time since the Austrian treaty talks were resumed here last week official sources confirmed today that the Yugoslavs were planning to modify their two major claims against Austria. These claims, which are strongly backed by the Soviet Union and involve a slice of Austrian territory and $150,000,000 in reparations, have been one of the main stumbling blocks to a Big Four agreement on a treaty.

Buying interest expanded in the stock market yesterday and prices advanced more than a point. The session proved highly selective, however, with trading scattered through a long list of issues in the low-price category. The upturn, in its third day, was labeled technical by most brokers, who felt that greater attention must be accorded the prime stocks before the rally can be taken seriously.

The compositions of Mozart, Bach, Brahms and Schoenberg will occupy the programs of the New Friends of Music for another season next fall, it was announced yesterday. Mozart's chamber music will continue to form an important part of the programs, and Schoenberg's string music and his song cycle, "Buch der haengenden Gaerten," will be presented in celebration of his seventy-fifth birthday.

King County, Wash., sold yesterday two issues of bonds totaling $4,250,000 to a banking syndicate headed by Union Securities Corporation. For $3,000,000 of bridge bonds due on March 1, 1951 to 1964, the bid was 100 for a combination of interest rates resulting in an interest cost of 2.0792 per cent.
May I be permitted to clarify for the record a statement of mine reported in your issue of Feb. 11, which might be misunderstood without some elaboration.

" Operation Fresh Kills," a ten-year project to reclaim 1,830 acres of marshy land on the west shore of Staten Island for a parkway system and possibly an airport, is being carried out by the Sanitation Department's fleet of three tug boats and forty-two scows.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President Truman said today that current price declines shown in some consumer products was the leveling-off that everyone had been wishing for. He added that he hoped there would not be another spiral in prices.

FRANCIS BACON, a wise as well as a worldly man, wrote in his essay on adversity, "He that hath a wife and children hath given hostages to fortune; for they are impediments to great enterprise, either of virtue or mischief." These words are not quoted on the title page of Lenard Kaufman's novel, "Tender Mercy,"* but they might well be.

SUMMIT, N. J., Feb. 17 -- Death defeated today by twelve days the ambition of 62-year-old Michel Kadenacy, mechanical engineer and inventor, to become an American citizen. He died early today in his home, 6 Manor Hill Road here, apparently of a cerebral hemorrhage, after spending a large part of yesterday completing arrangements for his naturalization, although he had not recovered from a brain operation performed in December.

TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 17 -Spencer Miller Jr., State Highway Commissioner, said today in his annual report that his department placed $31,064,000 of improvements to the New Jersey highway system under contract during the 1947-48 fiscal year.

I wish to congratulate THE NEW YORK TIMES on the admirable reporting which its representative, Lawrence E. Davies, has been giving of the unhappy events at the University of Washington. As a visiting professor on that campus last year I am acquainted with the local situation and with the principals involved.

New York University and Manhattan, the local collegiate spiked-shoe palladins, will concentrate on relay objectives in the fast company of the American indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- During the week ended Feb. 16 member bank reserve balances decreased $150,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

ATHENS, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The battle of Florina, biggest single action of the Greek civil war, has ended in a complete Government triumph, an official account said today. The battle lasted from Feb. 12 to Feb. 15.

" Man to Men" ("D'Homme a Hommes"), a French-made dramatization of the life of Henri Dunant, founder of the Red Cross, with Jean-Louis Barrault portraying Dunant, will have its local premiere today at both the Ambassador and Elysee Theatres. Christian-Jacque directed from a script which he wrote together with Charles Spaak.

MOSCOW, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Soviet Ministry of Foreign Affairs today confirmed to the United States Embassy the arrest of Anna Louise Strong, American writer, on charges of spying. The embassy, in a note sent Tuesday, had asked for confirmation of Moscow newspapers' accounts of the arrest and asked what the charges were.

A series of free lectures on the American theatre, by three theatrical experts will be given at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on consecutive Sundays from Feb. 20 through March 6 at 3:30 P. M. The lectures will supplement the exhibition, "Behind American Footlights," on view in the Costume Institute of the museum.
The Callot Soeurs of 17 East Fifty - third Street presented a group of spring fashions from their Paris house at a party yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel.

Unaccountably missing from his Chicago home for two years, Harry Lanning, 42 years old, was reunited with his wife yesterday morning in a Queens police station after being recognized from one of the hundreds of thousands of descriptive circulars Mrs. Lanning had circulated across the country.

The Rev. Dr. Guy Emery Shipler, editor of The Churchman, a Protestant Episcopal weekly magazine, announced yesterday that Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota would be unable to speak at the magazine's annual award dinner Wednesday at the Astor Hotel, and also that Cass Canfield, chairman of Harper Bros., had resigned as a vice chairman of the dinner committee.
BERLIN, Feb. 17 -- The Soviet Military Administration began the physical division of Berlin today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission said today that it is deferring action on a proposed purchase of broadcasting stations by Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., in view of an anti-trust judgment against the company.
CHICAGO, Feb. 17 (UP) -- Spring temperatures touched the winter-locked West today, but a cold wave cut the thaw short.
Four factors have combined to stiffen prices and increase orders in both machine tools and heavy contractors' equipment, industry members revealed here yesterday. These factors included:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Employers were advised today to consider their responsibility to economic stability when they are dealing with "fourth-round" wage demands.

PARIS, Feb. 17 -- In a letter to be published in tomorrow's Figaro, Gen. Rene Prioux contests a statement in Winston Churchill's memoirs that the Frenchman "seemed prepared to surrender [his] entire force but General de la Laurencie would not obey."

DETROIT, Feb. 17 -- With lay-offs in Detroit and Michigan industry sending unemployment this week to a three-year high the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation announced today that it would suspend work for 7,000 production workers for as long as three weeks.

Life insurance in force with the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States on Dec. 31, 1948, aggregated $13,170,000,000, Thomas I. Parkinson, president, announced yesterday at the annual meeting of directors. New business written during the year was $984,020,297.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The House today disregarded Republican assertions that it was setting the pattern for permanent regimentation of the economy, and passed, 259 to 102, an Administration bill to strengthen and extend until June 30, 1951, the Government's power to control exports.

In 1885, in the little forest town of Motele, Lithuania, a 12-year-old schoolboy sat down to write a letter to his teacher. It was about his own people, whose plight rested heavily on his young heart. Yesterday, in Jerusalem. Dr. Chaim Weizmann, the writer of that letter of sixty-four years ago, was inaugurated as President of the State of Israel in Palestine.

The aggregate of unsold new corporate bonds in the hands of underwriters dropped sharply yesterday to the lowest level in about a month as insurance companies and other institutional investors made substantial purchases of the new thirty-year obligations of the Duke Power Company and the Consolidated Edison Company.

Local business groups donated more money last year to the Greater New York Fund for support of 423 social service agencies and hospitals than ever before in its eleven years. Henry C. Brunie, fund president, announced yesterday.
Margaret Truman was guest of honor yesterday at a buffet luncheon aboard the United States liner America, marking her twenty-fifth birthday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The United States child-feeding program in Germany was inaugurated nearly two years ago on the basis of recommendations by former President Herbert Hoover as chief of the President's economic mission to Germany and Austria, Army officials said today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UP) -President Truman said tonight that "a strong and economically stable" United States is the surest guarantee of world peace.
An annual group exhibition of oil paintings by members of the Salmagundi Club and three one-man shows of considerable diversity are of special interest in this week, crowded with gallery activities.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Measures to permit private interests to construct public parking garages and acquire parking areas with the aid of the condemnation power of cities will be introduced in the Legislature tomorrow under bipartisan sponsorship.

David S. Meister, operator, yesterday reported his purchase of the eight-story loft building on a lot 21 by 98.9 feet at 41 West Twenty-fourth Street, between Broadway and the Avenue of the Americas, from the Berke Manufacturing Company.

Negotiations have been completed for two store projects in Elmhurst, Queens. The estate of Max Blumenthal sold the vacant plot, 100 by 100 feet, on the north side of Broadway in the block between Pettit and Britton Avenues, to the Chain Food Markets, represented by Harry A. Reffelt, broker in the transaction, for improvement with a one-story taxpayer.

The most artistic and finely proportioned interpretation of the concert that Leopold Stokowski directed with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall was the Haydn "Imperial'' symphony, so-called, heard for the first time at these concerts.

Most local home furnishings and department stores are entering the closing stage of the February furniture-sale period with dollar volume 10 to 20 per cent behind last year, buyers reported yesterday. In a few exceptional instances volume is equal to last year or slightly ahead, they said.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -The defense contended today that Mildred E. (Axis Sally) Gillars was innocent on the ground that "mere words" did not constitute the crime of treason.
CHICAGO, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Officials of the National Association of Home Builders said today their industry would attempt to match in 1949 their record of nearly a million new homes last year.
William P. O'Brien, First Deputy Police Commissioner, was sworn in yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer to succeed Arthur W. Wallander as Police Commissioner on March 1.
A 13-year-old boy accidentally was shot and killed last night when a pistol that a playmate was exhibiting went off and a bullet entered the youngster's body just below the heart.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17 -- Four hours after 3,900 taxicab drivers ended their three-day "wildcat" strike, negotiators in the tie-up of bus, trolley, elevated and subway lines appeared tonight to be on the road to a compromise.
Governor Dewey made last night the most vigorous defense to date of his policy of paying for long-term state improvements out of current state revenues or surpluses.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Feb. 12, 1949, totaled 699,442 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 17,299 cars, or 2.5 per cent more than for the preceding week, 34,428 cars, or 4.7 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 100,535 cars, or 12.6 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Differences of opinion over the proposed Puerto Rican rum promotion have been completely settled, Harry M. Lourie, executive vice president of the National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers, Inc., told the press yesterday at a meeting in the Plaza Hotel called by the Puerto Rico Industrial Development Company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Northern Stats Power Company (Minnesota) of Minneapolis asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to borrow $15,000,000 from six banks on its 2 per cent promissory notes that are to mature on or before Dec. 30, 1949.

Charging resumption of delaying tactics, Judge Harold R. Medina took over from defense counsel yesterday the examination of a witness in the trial of the eleven Communists. He then proceeded in a few minutes to bring out evidence the like of which takes counsel a long time.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 17 -- In a brief, solemn ceremony that marked another milestone in the history of the newly born state of Israel, Dr. Chaim Weizmann was sworn in today as its first President. It was probably the greatest moment of his life when he took the oath of allegiance to the state that he had helped so much to create.
Contrary to the more distant deliveries, near-by March delivery of hides declined 15 points yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. The June, September and December positions advanced 20 to 30 points.
Bus service given by the Surface Transportation Company in the Bronx "is not fit for human beings," Public Service Commissioner Spencer B. Eddy declared yesterday.

Although the Senate Banking [Committee leadership has moved [to delete that section of the Truman Administration's housing bill i(Senate Bill No. 138) which would withdraw the immunity to Federal [taxation now held by local housing authority bonds, the issue is by no means dead.

TROY, N. Y., Feb. 17 -- Formation of a state counterpart of the Hoover commission to be headed by Herbert H. Lehman, New York's last Democratic Governor, was urged tonight by Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman.

Further borrowing by utilities and sales finance companies offset repayments by food, grain and cotton interests, and business loans by banks in this area expanded $1,000,000 last week. According to the data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks, as of last Wednesday, stood at $5,584,000,000.

A unified group whose purpose will be to study tax problems of the alcoholic beverage industries was formed yesterday for the first time in the history of the liquor industry at a meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony, Leopold Stokowski, conductor; William Kapell, piano, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; Nies-Berger Chamber Orchestra, Edourd Nies-Berger, conductor, Aurora Mauro-Cottone, piano, Louis Kaufman, violin, Town Hall, 8:30; Alan Ziskin, piano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- A political feud, rooted in the state of Washington, sprouted here today as Senator Harry P. Cain sharply challenged the qualifications of Mon C. Wallgren for the post of chairman of the National Security Resources Board.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 17 (AP) -- High level talks between Government and Roman Catholic Church leaders began here today, the Czechoslovak Press Bureau announced. The subject of the talks was not disclosed.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 17 -- Calumet Farm's 8-year-old Armed, in the second race of his comeback campaign, had to settle for another $350 at Hialeah Park today. As in his 1949 debut last week, he finished third in a $3,500 purse that automatically became the race of the day when his name went into the entry box.

Despite currency restrictions and import quotas, indications are that trade between the United States and Palestine will increase this year, Elazar Silberstein of R. W. Silberstein Brothers, Tel Aviv and Jerusalem, said here yesterday.

Not to be outdone by his Scandinavian competitors, a food purveyor presented Danish smorrebrod yesterday at a luncheon at the Pierre Hotel accompanied by the Danish version of the "boilermaker." The food was tasty and arty and the drink was potent.
LONDON, Feb. 17 -- All work was stopped at one of J. Arthur Rank's most important studios here today as technicians walked out upon learning that 250 of them were due to be laid off.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President Truman defended today the acceptance by his aide, Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, of the medal of the Order of San Martin from Argentina. He said General Vaughan's acceptance was according to law and that the medal had been presented to many other officers.

Last May the House of Representatives voted 192 to 152 not to allow the Tennessee Valley Association to begin work on a big new steam plant at New Johnsonville. Last Wednesday a differently composed and disposed House approved the project by a vote of 192 to 105. The split was almost entirely along party lines.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 17 -- The United States Army quietly has made a gift to the school children of Western Germany of about $44,000,000 to pay for daily noon meals.
Fifty-eight dollars is an excessive amount for an ordinary $1.75 cab ride, Bernard Greenwald, 46-year-old taxicab driver of 1785 Asterdam Avenue, learned yesterday in Bronx Magistrate's Court.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- New corporate securities offered for cash sale in 1948 totaled $6,500,000,000, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today. Security flotations for new capital purposes, including plant, equipment and working capital, reached a peak of $5,600,000,000, about 24 per cent of which represented additional debt financing, the SEC said.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 17 -Business streets of the city were invaded again today by singing and shouting high school students, who skipped classes and paraded for the second day in succession to show their disapproval of an action by their elders on the Board of School Estimate.

GENEVA, Feb. 17 -- Behind the self-righteousness and injured innocence displayed in the Eastern European attacks on the United States policy of preventing the exports of strategic items to Soviet-dominated countries are real criticisms of that policy, which have never been met by the United States Government.
RCA Victor notified dealers yesterday that its new 6 7/8-inch plastic records will retail for 95 cents for Red Seal recordings and 65 cents for popular numbers.

Borough President Hugo E. Rogers, leader of Tammany, added yesterday his endorsement of the candidacy of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan for renomination on the Democratic ticket at, an interview at the Tammany headquarters, 331 Madison Avenue.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- Britain's senior civil servants, who are renowned for integrity and competence, but whose pay has long lagged below that of other professions, will at last have their salaries increased this year, the Treasury announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President Truman today appointed as Commissioner of Education Earl James McGrath, born in Buffalo, N. Y., a resident of Iowa and Professor of Education at the University of Chicago. His name went to the Senate for confirmation.

The adjustment of manning scales and the elimination of certain existing salary inequities are to be the principal points of contention in negotiations with ship-owners for a new contract to replace the present agreement, Joseph Curran, president of-the National Maritime Union, asserted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President Truman told Congress today about the "truly appalling" weakness of the White House and of the risk that it might have fallen in on him and on sightseers and guests at state functions. He asked $5,400,000 for its reconstruction.

HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 17 (AP) -- Par was broken thirty-six times today as Jim Turnesa of Briarcliff, N. Y., led 141 golfers over the Pine Forest Country Club course in the first round of the $10,000 Houston open.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Rev. Hunter Guthrie of New York, dean of the Graduate School of Georgetown University for the last six years, became rector and president of the university tonight. Father Guthrie follows another New Yorker, the Very Rev. Lawrence C. Gorman, who had been president since December, 1942.
STOCKHOLM, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Canada slammed home four goals in the final period tonight to defeat the United States, 7 -- 2, in the world amateur ice hockey championship tourney.

Making a plea for better teachers, Dr. Harry J. Carman, dean of Columbia College, declared yesterday that the majority of college professors do not know how to teach. They are dull, he held, and frequently are uninspiring and suffer from mental inertia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Base hit or foul ball? In a few weeks now, fans will be advising umpires to go and have their eyes examined, after calling a close one just inside or just outside the foul line.

Mrs. Curtis A. Peters and Miss Mae Meurer gave a tea yesterday in the Palm Court of the Plaza for a group of debutantes aiding in the plans for the annual card party and fashion show to be held on April 5 in the main ballroom of the hotel for the benefit of the Faith Home for Incurables in Brooklyn.
PARIS, Feb. 17 -- The European Council for the Marshall Plan decided today that its work of coordinating the European economies would continue after the end of United States aid.
PARIS, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Nineteen-year-old Richard Button of Englewood, N. J., reaffirmed his men's figure skating supremacy today by winning his second straight world championship.

Perfume will lose its "save-it-for-special-occasions" aura and come down to earth as an everyday necessity if the fragrance industry carries out the sort of switch in its selling program that was talked about yesterday at a luncheon of The Fashion Group in the ballroom of the Biltmore Hotel.

POINT BARROW, Alaska, Feb. 17 -- Scientists under contract to the Navy, working in the 30 below zero temperatures of this northernmost point of United States soil, are trying to plumb the mysteries of Arctic life.

The annual pamphlet report of the Western Auto Supply Company, mailed to stockholders yesterday, disclosed an unbroken record of annual profits since 1916 and of annual dividends on common stock since 1928. In its forty years of operation net earnings have aggregated $51,000,000, of which $24,000,000 has been paid out in dividends and $27,000,000 retained in the business to help finance continued growth.

In a move unprecedented in this city, Mayor O'Dwyer summoned the twenty-one members of the Board of Higher Education to City Hall yesterday and rebuked them for their anticipated choice of a new Queens College president.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Feb. 17 -- Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, British Military Governor, today appealed to the representatives of the Allied and German press to use their influence to allay former enmities and to promote good, mutual relations between nations.

With less than three minutes remaining, C. C. N. Y. held a nine- point lead over Niagara last night at Madison Square Garden. But incredible though it may appear, the decision went to the visiting Purple Eagles, 66 -- 64, following a feverish five-minute overtime session This believe-it-or-not affair followed a 57-53 victory for L. I. U. over Seton Hall.

Ervin Laszlo, 16-year-old Hungarian pianist, gave his second New York recital last night at Town Hall. At his local debut last spring, the youthful artist made an unusually favorable impression. But unfortunately, his performance yesterday evening failed to live up to the expectations aroused at the previous appearance, though in some respects his playing was admirable, considering his age.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- Professional operations dominated the action of the grain markets on the Board of Trade today, and price changes were rapid. An opening dip was followed by a strong rally and a late break, and the close was irregular.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Governor Dewey and Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, today voiced their support of the Mitchell-Van Duzer resolution for revising the constitutional preferences given war veterans in the Civil Service system.

National Distillers Products Corporation has scheduled staggered insertion of 300-line ads in some fifteen newspapers for a new campaign throughout 1949 on Gilbey's Spey-Royal Scotch. The ads will feature authors and famous fictional detectives to tie in with a mystery story play on "the case of Scotch." Lloyd, Chester Dillingham, Inc.

The Nassau Theatre building at 337 Grand Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Rosen Brothers Company, Inc., to the Nassau Theatre Corporation. A purchase money mortgage of $30,000 was executed at the closing. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumed during January was 674,463 bales of lint and 123,038 bales of linters. This compared with 680,670 bales of lint and 113,854 of linters consumed during December and 860,704 bales of lint and 101,850 of linters consumed during January of last year.
BERLIN, Feb. 17 -- Soviet Germany, the "people's democracy" destined to join other satellite states of Eastern Europe, will take form some time after March of this year.

The President's civil-rights program is a misnomer. It is a program of special privilege for minority groups, for political purposes, to be obtained by Congressional act contrary to the provisions of the Constitution.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 17 -- With North China closed, the lower Yangtze region shaky and Kwangtung already affected by guerrilla activity, the China branch of the Economic Cooperation Administration is displaying renewed interest in Formosa [Taiwan] as the only major Nationalist area still free of Communist control or immediate threat.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 17 -- Opposition to higher rail rates along the West Coast was expressed by representatives of sugar, milk and canning industries today at a water-rall rate hearing before Clyde B. Aitchison, Interstate Commerce Commissioner.

Rocky Castellani and Charlie Fusari, middleweight rivals, will furnish the action in the top ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. Castellani, a Luzerne, Pa., product, is the replacement for Vince Foster, who recently withdrew from the contest following a skirmish with the law.

The New York State Power Authority announced yesterday that its trustees were "unalterably opposed" to a measure introduced in Congress last Tuesday in regard to the St. Lawrence seaway and power project, or to "any other bill that fails to include the Federal-State accord provision."

The Washington Birthday week-end, usually marking the climax of the ski season each winter, will be a woeful one, generally speaking, for both skiers and resort operators this year. Instead of the familiar exodus of thousands of skiers by rail, bus, plane and motor to favorite resorts, comparatively few will depart tonight.

The Board of Justices of the Second Judicial District, representing the counties of Kings and Richmond, have decided to discontinue the pre-trial calendar of the Supreme Court at the end of the February term, it became known yesterday.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 14 -- One of the signs of reviving foreign trade here has been the formation of the German-American Economics Association. Its purpose is to further trade between Western Germany and the United States.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- Fifteen thousand of the country's private pleasure-craft owners, members of the Coast Guard Auxiliary, were welded together into one nationwide body today at the close of a meeting attended by senior officers of the Coast Guard and the Auxiliary.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Warriors climbed within a virtual tie for third place in the Eastern Division of the Basketball Association of America by defeating the New York Knickerbockers, 86 -- 82, before 3,580 spectators tonight.
DANBURY, Conn., Feb. 17 -Members not seen at a meeting in many a moon were on the scene today as the Lions Club held its weekly luncheon in the Green Hotel.

THIS modern, mechanical age is wonderful and man's ingenuity is marvelous to behold. But the sprinters at the National Amateur Athletic Union track and field championships in the Garden tomorrow night already have begun to grumble. Instead of being afforded the opportunity of trying to beat Jack Lavelle's starting gun like the little gentlemen they are, they are being jammed into the new-fangled starting gate by the cruel AAU officials.

LIVINGSTONE, Northern Rhodesia, Feb. 17 -- Delegates from Southern Rhodesia, Northern Rhodesia and Nyasaland, meeting at Victoria Falls near here, agreed today on procedure to bring into existence a central African federation -- yet to be named -- as advocated yesterday unanimously.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President Truman said today there was no mystery or confusion about United States policy on the proposed North Atlantic defense pact.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated in a moderate range yesterday and closed 2 to 12 points net lower than on Wednesday.
" Last night they gave me a key to my room. I cannot describe the feeling. It was the first time since before the war that I had my own place for myself and my family."

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- Organized groups of physicians and hospital administrator are among those who oppose "adequate" licensure laws for nurses, an American Nurses Association conference was told here last night.

A smooth-talking "society burglar," a fishing enthusiast who had been sought for three years in connection with one shooting and a number of jewel robberies in homes of wealthy residents of Westchester County, was a prisoner in Cleveland yesterday, virtually a victim of his own net.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 17 -- After holding about unchanged in the two preceding weeks, business in the Pittsburgh district showed a moderate gain last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- Aneurin Bevan, Minister of Health, dared Conservative opposition in the House of Commons tonight to vote against an additional appropriation for the country's new universal free medical service.

Unqualified opposition to parking meters and a dim view of any traffic relief proposals that would alter the "unique" character of the Fifth Avenue section was registered yesterday by the Fifth Avenue Association.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 17 -- A bill to curtail the affiliation of Bulgarian churches with parent churches outside the country was introduced in Parliament today by Foreign Minister Vassil Kolarov.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 17 -- A special commission of the Bonn Constitutional Assembly has been touring the three Western zones in search of a provisional capital for the forthcoming regime.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The State Department announced today that the United States Embassy in Moscow had been unable to see Anna Louise Strong, the American writer who has been arrested on espionage charges and is to be deported from Russia, notwithstanding guarantees in the Roosevelt-Litvinov agreement of 1933 that Americans under arrest or detention in Russia would be permitted to communicate in person with American officials.

In a move to protect the public well as the ball club, it was announced yesterday that the League Realty Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of the New York Yankees, had purchased two large parcels of land adjacent to the Yankee Stadium to be used for parking space for automobiles. The purchase price was announced at $300,000.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Housing needs of low-income families can be met only with federal help, spokesmen for the United States Conference of Mayors told a Senate Banking subcommittee today.

In "City of Kings," which had its opening performance last night at the Blackfriars' Guild Theatre on Fifty-seventh Street, Father Urban Nagle has told a rich and compeling story of the zealous labors of an humble man of God.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Government sped action today on a $44,000,000 storm relief fund and sounded a warning that devastating spring floods might follow the winter's great blizzards in the West.

Abraham I. Menin, receiver in bankruptcy for Samuel Broxmeyer, whose $22,000,000 real estate holdings are being investigated by Federal and New York County authorities, was designated yesterday as trustee of Ansonia House, Inc., with full power to operate, manage and control the Ansonia Apartments at Broadway and Seventy-third Street.

In a move protecting their summer resort facilities, a group of residents purchased a large part of the westerly end of Fishers Island, off New London, Conn., it was announced here yesterday by William B. May Co., the brokers in the transaction. The realty was bought from Fishers Island Farms, Inc., and consists of twenty-four furnished homes, the Hay Harbor Club and the Hay Harbor Golf Club.

It is a rather surprising and certainly disappointing fact that this nation, so proud of its industrial know-how, has failed thus far to make more substantial use of its mass-production experience and skills on the housing problem. Now Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, has come up with an idea for doing so, through use of idle aircraft plants, assembly-line production and government aid.

PARIS, Feb. 17 -- Selden Chapin, United States Minister to Hungary, heading home for what may be the last time, charged tonight that the trial of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty was a "travesty of justice."

The number of vessels in the privately owned United States-flag ocean-going merchant fleet totaled 1,212, representing about 14,200,000 deadweight tons, as of Feb. 1, according to the monthly report by the National Federation of American Shipping on the status of the merchant marine.
