Nine printed fabrics with motifs keyed to specific types of rooms -such as a circus print for a child's room, or one of Cape Cod scenes for a seashore home -- go on display tmorrow along Macy's Plan-A-Home Row. The fabrics are inexpensive cottons ranging from $1.30 to $3 a yard.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 17 -- Robert Montgomery and David E. Rose have concluded a deal for the production of "Your Witness," a photoplay by Ian Hunter and Hugo Butler, this summer in England, they announced today. The arrangement consists of a partnership between Montgomery's independent company, Neptune, and Rose's company, Coronado.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 17 -- Russia challenged the West today to accept a British-proposed candidate for the Governor of Trieste but was told immediately that London, Paris and Washington were sticking to their demand that the Adriatic seaport be returned to Italy.

TOKYO, Feb. 17 -- Gen. Douglas McArthur's headquarters, seeking to prepare the Japanese people to meet the deflationary effects of the economic "austerity" program it expects the new Diet to enact, asked Japanese labor unions today to plan actions to ease for their members the probable consequences in unemployment.

Asserting that we have in Washington an Administration that to gain power promised all things to all people, Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr., Republican National Chairman, charged the Truman Administration last night with "welshing" on its campaign promises.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- The American Meat Institute today characterized as "ridiculous" and "just plain nonsense" many of the statements attributed to a group of Allied and German scientists in a dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES from Frankfort, Germany, in which the scientists disclosed that they had produced and were ready to distribute "two food substitutes that are said to taste and have the same nutritious qualities as milk and meat."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President Truman asserted with emphasis today that United States policy relating to the occupation of Japan was set and fixed, that it had not changed and that there had been no intimation of a change.

Augusta Turkel, in a purchase for investment, has acquired the taxpayer building containing six stores at 375-379 Avon Avenue, corner of South Twelfth Street, Newark, N. J., from the Joroy Realty Corporation. Ludwin Lipton, Inc., and the Frank Bucino Organization were the brokers.

An hour-long television program featuring the Fred Waring musical organization is scheduled for early presentation by the General Electric Company. Mr. Waring's orchestra, his glee club and his solo artists would comprise the talent roster of the offering.

The graduating class of Queens College was told last night at its commencement that men of intellectual and spiritual faith were needed to "shake the social world" as effectively as the physical world had been shaken by technological advances.

More than 111,981,600 pounds of supplies have been distributed through the Council of Relief Agencies Licensed for Operation in Germany (CRALOG) in the three years since it was licensed by the United States to represent sixteen voluntary agencies, it was reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the council in the Gramercy Park Hotel.

Famines in milk and other dairy products will threaten this city every winter until at least 25,000 miles of "town roads" in rural areas of this state are rehabilitated, Senator Austin W. Erwin of Geneseo said yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 17 -- George Killion, president of American President Lines, announced today that its freighter President Fillmore, with about 2,500 tons of cargo for merchants and importers at Tientsin, would call at Communist-held Taku Bar according to schedule.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 17 -- Upon the role that Senora Eva Duarte de Peron plays henceforth will depend, to a great extent, the immediate political future of Argentina. Some diplomats close to the political situation here, as well as some Argentines, are now convinced that the Army within the last week has increased its pressure upon President Juan Peron to get his wife out of public life.

FORT MEADE, Md., Feb. 17 (UP) -- The trail left by a cripple's cane today led an Army patrol to two armed soldier convicts who hid in a woods near this Army base after shooting and clubbing their way out of a cell.

Boston scouts yesterday sent encouraging word that Eugene O'Neill's condition is showing remarkable improvement. So much so that the Nobel and three-time Pulitzer Prize winner has started work on a brand new play. Not much is known about the script except that it will have no bearing on the cycle begun by him.

Two men and a German shepherd dog, adrift in a rowboat on the windswept waters of the Upper Harbor, were rescued about 10:15 A. M. yesterday by a passing tugboat while two harbor police launches, two Coast Guard picket boats, and the Police Department helicopter were rushing to their aid.
The entire field of atomic energy faces an over-all shortage of qualified personnel, Sumner T. Pike, vice chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, warned yesterday.
Alastair B. Martin gave a performance in the East court at the Racquet and Tennis Club yesterday that compares with the finest court tennis played there by an amateur in years.
LONDON, Feb. 17 -- Business again was slack in the stock market here today and price changes of note were few.

Some $2,300,000 is now awaiting 4,500 persons in this and other countries and the Tracers Company of America is out to find them. The organization, with offices at 515 Madison Avenue, announced yesterday that it was looking for missing stockholders of the Midland Utilities Company and the Midland United Company of Chicago.

The two young Russian fliers, Lieut. Peter Pirogov and Lieut. Anatole Barsov, who fled from their army because they wanted to live in this country, saw an actual broadcast yesterday of "The Voice of America," the medium through which they said they first heard about personal freedom in the United States.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 17 -- Provisional Foreign Minister Moshe Shertok gave a clear definition today of Israel's position regarding the future of Jerusalem. In substance it is that Jewish Jerusalem should be included in the new state and that the Old City, with all its holy places within the old walls and outside, should come under an international regime.

E. Laurence Palmer, Professor of Nature and Science Education at Cornell University and author of the forthcoming "Fieldbook of Natural History," is planning to leave for New Zealand toward the end of May. He was invited to spend five months there by the New Zealand Educational Foundation to help their schools improve their work in the field of natural history.

A New York design team, Muller-Barringer, won first award for furniture this year in the Annual International Design Competition sponsored by The American Institute of Decorators, results of which were announced yesterday.

John T. McCloy, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, told 400 fellow alumni of Amherst College last night that the Marshal Plan is showing "real progress" by checking the Communist surge in Europe and by keeping peoples alive and bolstering their standard of living.

MONTREAL, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Ken Mosdell drove home two goals tonight while his team was shorthanded to lead the Montreal Canadiens to a 3-0 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game before a crowd of 11,227.

The six-months controversy over control of a Government-owned $28,000,000 blast furnace in Cleveland was settled amicably yesterday in a five-year agreement between the Republic Steel Corporation, which had been operating the facility, and the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, whose leasing of it last August precipitated a storm of Congressional and industrial protests and threats of legal action.

The City Council at a special session yesterday extended until May 1 the four municipal rent control laws scheduled to expire on March 1. Immediately afterward the Board of Estimate held a special meeting at which the Council's action was approved.

Consolidated net income of the Houston Oil Company of Texas and its subsidiary, the Houston Pipe Line Company, last year increased to $6,092,536 after taxes and all charges from $4,046,094 earned in 1947, according to the annual report to be issued today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 --Department store sales in the week ended Feb. 12 were unchanged from the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:
BALTIMORE, Feb. 17 (AP) -Teachers from Catholic high schools in the Middle Atlantic States were advised today that the program of studies they offer may need an overhaul.

BOSTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Unseeded Miss Margaret Howe of New Haven, Conn., continued her brilliant play with an upset victory over the defending titleholder, Miss Cecile Bowes of Philadelphia, in a quarter-final match of the women's national squash racquets championship today at the Harvard Club.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- A reduced but still ambitious advertising campaign for bringing recruits into the Army and Air Force was jointly disclosed today by the two services.

A newly reconverted 15,969-ton Army transport, formerly the Navy vessel Admiral Hugh Rodman, was officially renamed yesterday afternoon the Gen. Maurice Rose, in honor of the wartime leader of the Third Armored Division, in a shipboard ceremony at Pier 4, Brooklyn Army Base.

The initial bids for fame by authors whose works are among the classics of English literature will be shown in a new exhibition opening today in the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

Often in these days it seems to the quivering layman that the inventive mind is going too far. The automobile, the airplane, the radio, television and various new ways of preparing food -- these are fine. Modern medicine prolongs our lives and eases our pain. It is a blessing we wouldn't want to give up.
The crisis over the "sit-in" demonstration planned for last evening by union members in the city's Department of Welfare fizzled into nothing,

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 17 -- The Social Committee of the United Nations Economic and Social Council today voted to establish a sub-commission of freedom of information to see that news and information were disseminated freely to the people of the world.

VIENNA, Feb. 17 -- Mr. Chapin said here he did not believe that his expulsion necessarily meant that the Hungarian Government wished an open break with the United States. He said that the action came as the crowning step in a long process of isolation of American and other Western diplomats in Budapest.

A vacant tract of more than three acres at the corner of West 254th Street and Arlington Avenue in the Riverdale section of the Bronx has been sold by Webb Knapp, Inc., to the Riverdale Park Holding Corporation in an all cash transaction. Maurice Iserman of Spencer Iserman was attorney for the sellers and Julius Birgenthal of Freedman Birgenthal acted for the buyer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company, expressed "genuine alarm" today over the Administration's labor bill. He said that it threatened "our individual and collective freedoms through removals of safeguards now so wisely in force."

Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, national commander of the Disabled American Veterans, appealed yesterday for additional entries in the organization's $100,000 prize contest. The net proceeds will go to the DAV's service foundation.
At a preview of spring fashions for the teen-aged girl held yesterday by Gimbels in the high school shop, the empire silhouette was shown as one of the most important styles.
A market basket into which have been tucked the following items will reflect a purchaser who is buying this week-end with both pocketbook and palate in mind:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Senators Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of Massachusetts and Owen Brewster of Maine probably will be the Senatorial appointees to the Republican Policy Committee, it was indicated today.

Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation will begin shipping a new television - radio - phonograph console combination to dealers today or Monday, Benjamin Abrams, president, announced yesterday. The set has a twelve-inch direct view tube, FM-AM radio and an automatic record changer for standard records only. It will retail for $529.50.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Alexander S. Panyushkin, the Soviet Ambassador here, renewed at a meeting of the Far Eastern Commission today his running attack on United States policy in Japan and in particular the interim directive issued by Washington to Gen. Douglas MacArthur last Dec. 10 for an economic stabilization program.

With the first offerings of fall wool goods to women's wear trades indicating that prices will show little or no change over current levels, garment manufacturers will place very conservative initial orders, it was predicted yesterday in the trade.

BOSTON, Feb. 17 -- Eleazar de Carvalho, Brazilian conductor who will lead the Boston Symphony Orchestra in four concerts next week, completed a flying itinerary today that will enable him to commute between New York and Cleveland, almost daily, for the first two weeks of March, on his next two assignments.

The Pennroad Corporation reported yesterday for 1948 a net income, excluding profits on sales of securities, of $2,718,736, equal to 54 cents each on the 5,000,000 capital shares outstanding. This compared with $2,126,890, or 42 cents a share, for 1947.

IN these summer days of 1940 after the fall of France we were all alone. None of the British Dominions or India or the Colonies could send decisive aid, or send what they had in time. The victorious, enormous German armies, thoroughly equipped and with large reserves of captured weapons and arsenals behind them, were gathering for the final stroke.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Hoover Commission today urged Congress to take the Post Office Department out of politics and put it on a straight business basis.
The "Subway Sun," New York's only underground newspaper, tells us in its current issue that: "Seats Are for Passengers -- Not Packages!"

Commenting on the Senate debate on the projected North Atlantic Pact, both President Truman and Secretary of State Acheson have emphasized again that the United States seeks an effective instrument to prevent aggression that would endanger our national security. They are certain that this can best be done by making it plain in advance that an armed attack on the free nations will be met by overwhelming force.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Feb. 17 -- Pending receipt of the occupation statute, which is bound to exercise an important influence on its work, all sessions of the Parliamentary Council at Bonn have been postponed, it was announced tonight.

BERLIN, Feb. 17 -- A world-wide boycott of the German diamond industry has been instituted in an effort to prevent repetition of wide-scale unemployment and hardship caused in other diamond centers by price and wage cutting and dumping practiced here before the war.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 17 -Argentina has become a large factor in the dollar black market in Brazil.

VIENNA, Feb. 17 -- Mr. Chapin said here he did not believe that his expulsion necessarily meant that the Hungarian Government wished an open break with the United States. He said that the action came as the crowning step in a long process of isolation of American and other Western diplomats in Budapest.

ROME, Feb. 18 -- The Communist-dominated Chamber of Labor called a one hour general strike in Rome this afternoon to protest against clashes between police and strikers in Isola Del Liri yesterday. The strike order was generally disregarded. In addition, all workers in the paper mills and typographical trades, including newspapers, are to strike for twenty-four hours.

Cardinal Spellman received last night the eight gifts sent to him on the French Gratitude Train at an informal ceremony at 500 Park Avenue, where the "New York Car" gifts have been on exhibit since Feb. 8. The exhibit, which thus far has attracted 50,000 visitors, will close tomorrow.

It is the plan of Publicker Industries, Inc. to reintroduce a number of straight whisky brands, L. J. Gunson, president of Continental and Kinsey Distilling, divisions of Publicker, disclosed in an interview yesterday.

I was shocked to learn recently that a leading mutual accident and health association, chartered and operating in the State of New York, by its by-laws limits its membership to "any white man" meeting the qualifications of age, health and occupation. Upon inquiry, I was informed that the association in question "accepts only those applicants who can qualify as a preferred risk.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 18 -- If Calumet Farm doesn't have the winner in the $25,000-added McLennan Handicap tomorrow at Hialeah, there'll be a new 1949 record for mass astonishment at a Florida horse park.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 18 -- The United States, as two major steps in its campaign against communism, should end the "shameful practice" of attacking genuine liberals as Communists and should refrain from supporting "self-seeking, corrupt, or fascist" foreign governments, Justice William O. Douglas of the United States Supreme Court said tonight.

The Indian with the fringed buckskins, tall war bonnet and very flat feet, whom you may meet at Lexington Avenue and Forty-seventh Street at noon today, will not be a refugee from a Carnarsie tribe but merely waiting with a thousand or so outdoor enthusiasts for the doors of Grand Central Palace to open once more on the annual National Sportsmen's Show.
Stacking cars one on top of another in the streets was called yesterday "about the only ineffective program for parking relief" not attempted here.

Five foreigners have been elected to the National Institute of Arts and Letters, Douglas Moore, president of the institute, announced last night at a dinner-meeting held at the Knickerbocker Club to welcome thirteen Americans elected earlier this month.

Whether the American Red Cross would be permitted to display posters for its 1949 drive on trucks here remained undecided yesterday when the Traffic Commission decided "to study further" the puzzling issue raised by a United States Supreme Court decision.

LONDON, Feb. 18 (Reuters) -- Representatives of all sections of the British film industry today began conferring on whether cuts in production costs could solve the industry's present crisis. They were asked to report on the situation as soon as possible to Harold Wilson, president of the Board of Trade.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 18 -- The Bizonal Economic Council overwhelmingly approved today the expenditure of 195,000,000 Deutsche marks for food, fuel and other necessities to be transported via the airlift to Western Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- A move to forestall hasty Congressional action on legislation designed to clarify existing laws governing pricing policies of business and industry gained momentum on Capitol Hill today.

A re-enactment of film of the inauguration of George Washington at the Sub-treasury Building, on Wall Street, will be televised Tuesday by WABD and the Du Mont television network. The program will be put on the air during Bob Emery's "Small Fry Club" between 6:10 and 6:20 P. M.

The force of the recovery effort by the stock market was arrested yesterday and the list suffered the first reversal in recent sessions. The downward movement on the Stock Exchange was most pronounced in the late afternoon.
CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (UP) -- A single issue appeared today to be holding up peace between the nation's railroads and 1,000,000 non-operating employes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Argentina, one of the major exporting nations, withdrew as an active participant in the International Wheat Conference today on the ground that the price scales being discussed were not enough, even at maximum, to cover the prices being paid her producers.

It took twenty-seven persons, including ten policemen, to waken 12-year-old Louis Grossman yesterday by taking turns banging on his bedroom door at 1370 Forty-second Street, Brooklyn. The siege of the modern Rip Van Winkle began at 7:15 A. M. and ended nearly an hour later.

PARIS, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Miss Alena Vrzanova of Czechoslovakia won the world's figure skating championship for women tonight, taking the title left vacant when Miss Barbara Ann Scott of Canada turned professional.
National Security Week was observed here yesterday at the City Hall with speeches and martial music.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18 -- With negotiations suspended, Mayor Bernard Samuel urged 11,000 transit workers today to accept a 7-cent-an-hour increase and restore, service on 110 bus, trolley, subway and elevated lines.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18 -- An intensive drive on the West Coast by port, labor and management representatives to obtain a share of merchant fleet and navy shipbuilding for idle yards along the Pacific Seaboard was started today by the newly organized Pacific Coast Committee for Shipbuilding for National Defense.

Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company yesterday ended dealer allocations on three Axminster carpet grades in twelve-foot widths. G. C. Denebrink, vice president for sales, emphasized that allocations still apply to Beauvais, the company's most popular Axminster product, all velvet grades and Wilton carpeting.

Among the benefits of a mild winter hereabout has been an ice-free Hudson River. This is said despite -- indeed, is called to mind by -- the fact that two ships were caught in ice off Catskill, 100 miles up, early this month and had to be assisted by tugboats.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- At the request of Mayor O'Dwyer, Senate Minority Leader Elmer F. Quinn and Assemblyman Louis F. De Salvio reintroduced in the Legislature today a bill to permit the city to convey the former Aquarium in Battery Park to the Federal Government for its restoration as a national monument.

ATHENS, Feb. 18 -- Today's Greek Army communique stated: "A rebel band coming from Yugoslav territory had captured frontier post No. 68 near Florina after heavy fighting. Greek troops reoccupied the frontier post."

GENEVA, Feb. 18 -- Western delegations expressed considerable satisfaction today with the progress in East-West trade discussions being held here under the auspices of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

Rush-hour congestion at the Long Island Rail Road Station here late yesterday afternoon delayed the departure of twenty-eight trains from five to thirty-six minutes. As a result, seven connecting trains eastbound out of Jamaica and three connecting trains eastbound out of Long Island City also were held up.

Rocky Castellani's march to eminence in boxing's middleweight ranks was rudely checked last night in Madison Square Garden when stout-hearted Charley Fusari, welterweight from Irvington, N. J., came off the ring floor to pound out a victory over the Star from Luzerne, Pa.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- President Truman will do "everything possible" to get compulsory health insurance legislation enacted by this session of Congress, Federal Security Administrator Oscar R. Ewing today told a luncheon meeting called by the Committee on the Nation's Health.

Merely because an article has been taken out of its original package, placed in a showcase or window and handled by prospective customers does not mean it can legally be sold at a price less than the fair trade price fixed for it. This is the decision of Justice Carroll G. Walter, handed down Thursday in the New York Supreme Court in the case of the Empire State Camera Exchange, Inc., vs. Reynolds Photo Shop.

Two former Holy Cross stars, George Kaftan and Dermie O'Connell, will make their local professional debuts tonight when they play with the Boston Celtics against the Knickerbockers in a Basketball Association of America game at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- The International Transport Workers Federation is to prepare a list of ships that have been transferred to Panamanian and other flags because they are obsolete or uneconomic or cannot continue to operate under their original flags because they no longer satisfy survey safety and other requirements.

Harry Hecht, a stockholder of the Farnsworth Television and Radio Corporation, began an action in the Supreme Court of New York here yesterday to prevent the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation from acquiring the assets of the Farnsworth company.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -Two mining industry representatives expressed opposing views today on legislation to stimulate domestic mining of strategic metals and minerals for stockpiling.
VIENNA, Feb. 18 -- Dr. Karl Gruber, Austrian Foreign Minister, said today prospects for the conclusion of an Austrian treaty in London did not seem bright.

The 1949 alumni award medallion "in recognition of outstanding loyalty and devotion to the college" was presented last night by the Alumni Association of Stevens Institute of Technology, Hoboken, N. J., to John H. Muller, vice president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States.
OSLO, Norway, Feb. 18 (UP) -- Norwegian Premier Einar Gerhardsen and Foreign Minister Halvard M. Lange conferred here today with the Swedish and Danish Premiers on Scandinavian defense problems.

Dr. L. N. Palar, chief delegate of the Indonesian Republic to the United Nations Security Council, declared yesterday in an interview that Republican harassing tactics had placed "the Dutch completely on the defensive" and predicted their continuation "will cause Dutch collapse shortly."

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- Deputies of the Council of Foreign Ministers received today from Yugoslavia's Deputy Foreign Minister, Dr. Ales Bebler, acceptance of their invitation to appear before them and state Yugoslavia's latest claims against Austria.

Segregation in housing, by keeping people divided into mutually unacquainted and mistrustful groups, breeds many evils, speakers at the initial luncheon and conference of the New York State Committee on Discrimination in Housing said yesterday.

Desmond FitzGerald, chairman of the Committee of Five Million, announced yesterday that the committee had retained a staff of trained investigators to look into conditions in depart ments of the city government in the hope of getting sufficient evidence to warrant the committee in asking for a legislative investigation of the administration of Mayor O'Dwyer.

Edward J. McGoldrick Jr., director of New York City's "Bureau of Alcoholic Therapy," disseminates opinion on alcoholism that are apt to confuse this already difficult subject further. He feels that alcoholism is not a disease, although his training as a lawyer can hardly have equipped him with the qualifications that medical men and psychiatrists have acquired.

Spokesmen for parent, civic, educational and labor groups angrily accused Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday of "political interference" with the city's system of higher education by his intervention in the pending appointment of a Queens College president.

Beginning May 1, 10,000 patients and personnel of the Hospital Department's seven institutions on Welfare Island will have their clothes and linens washed and pressed by what city officials say is the largest hospital laundry in the country.

BERLIN, Feb. 18 -- In one of the heaviest fogs of the winter the Western Allied airlift flew the millionth short ton of supplies into Berlin today. A big-bellied York of the Royal Air Force Transport Command landed at Gatow Airfield, in the British sector, at 4 P. M. with seven and one-half tons of potatoes and mixed foods from Wunsdorf, in the British zone, and established the new total.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board proposed today permanent mail-pay rates, along with retroactive payments of $868,000, for two air carriers.
CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP) -- A common table salt substitute was blamed today by the American Medical Association for at least four recent deaths.

New low prices at which Burlington Mills Corporation is offering finished rayon goods will set off a price war in the rayon textile industry between integrated and non-integrated distributors, it was predicted yesterday. Cuts ranging up to 25 per cent have brought prices of Burlington finished goods below those of comparable fabrics sold by rayon goods converters who, it was said, will be forced to lower prices to stay on a competitive footing.

LONDON, Feb. 18 - Winston Churchill, in a message to Anthony Fell, Conservative candidate in the coming South Hammersmith parliamentary by-election, declared today that the "multitude of regulations and restrictions" of which socialism consists had inflicted "needless hardship" on the mass of the British people.
ALBANY, N. Y., Feb. 18 (AP) -- The State Commerce Department reported today the following conditions at New York ski centers:

ALBANY, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The Senate Democratic leader made a second move today to strip The Jockey Club and the National Steeple-chase Association of their authority over horse race meetings in New York.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Feb. 18 -- A shattering blast rocked a fashionable residential district today. The police said the explosion uncovered a plot to dynamite doctors and members of the Industrial Accident Commission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- A hearing of the House Foreign Affairs Committee on $5,580,000,000 of new funds for European recovery took a sharp turn today when its former chairman, Representative Charles A. Eaton, Republican, of New Jersey, asked:

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 -- Price fluctuations in the grain markets were very rapid on the Board of Trade today. Wheat had an extreme range of 4 3/4 cents a bushel, and corn, one of 2 3/4 cents, with an irregular close. Wheat ended 1 3/8 cents lower to 3/4 cent higher than yesterday, May leading the decline.

Socialized medicine and the nationalization of steel and other industries were described by Governor Dewey last night as "relapses toward totalitarianism." The Governor spoke at the fiftieth annual dinner of the University of Michigan Club of New York at the St. Regis Hotel.

Orders for iron ore preparation and coal cleaning plants are setting new all-time high records, and indications are that the demand will continue to increase, machinery manufacturers disclosed here yesterday. In both large and small coal and iron areas of Michigan, Minnesota, Alabama, West Virginia, Ohio, Pennsylvania and other important producing states these installations are going ahead on an unprecedented scale, industry members declared.

The Swedish American liner Gripsholm sailed at noon yesterday for Goeteborg with 209 passengers, including a group of eighteen Russian minor officials, in cabin class accommodations, and Sergei Sergeev, first secretary of the Soviet Embassy in Washington, who locked himself in his first-class cabin to avoid an interview.

Mayor O'Dwyers summoning of the Board of Higher Education to City Hall to exert official pressure on the choice of a new president for Queens College is a remarkable performance. State law says that the Board of Higher Education shall appoint "officers of administration and instruction." The Mayor has no standing in law, precedent or principle for intervening.

In his ringing history of Britain's wartime years, "Their Finest Hour," Winston Churchill ended his chapter yesterday about the late summer days of 1940, when the British were momentarily expecting a Nazi invasion, with the statement that "This was a time when it was equally good to live or die."

With the Washington's Birthday holiday falling on Tuesday -- the traditional No. 1 day for new financing transactions in Wall Street -- public offerings of new issues of securities will be on the scanty side next week. The city of Philadelphia's offering of $44,200,000 of new bonds on Thursday is the biggest marketing scheduled.

TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 18 -- Five streamlined governmental forms to replace New Jersey's conglomeration of municipal administrations were proposed today by the State Commission on Municipal Government. Acceptance would be optional among the state's 566 municipalities, but by 1955 all would be required to conduct public referendums to determine whether the citizens wanted changes in their community administration.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- A maneuver is being prepared among Senate Republicans designed to force the Democratic leadership to make the filibuster-civil rights issue the one, unalterable priority of the Senate before the end of March.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Opposition to repeal or any slackening of Taft-Hartley Law controls was voiced today before the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee by the National Association of Manufacturers and the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.
Three thousand "grievances" were reportedly filed yesterday morning by union members in the city's Department of Welfare -- and probably will be ignored.

RHODES, Feb. 18 -- The chances for an Egyptian-Israeli armistice agreement are "reasonably good," the Acting Mediator, Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, said tonight, but he added that there were major issues still unsettled.

ST. SAUVEUR, Que., Feb. 18 -- Again demonstrating its remarkable balance and unity, the Dartmouth ski team appeared to be well on its way to winning its second major intercollegiate competition in a week as the opening half of McGill University's colorful winter carnival ended today in this sun - drenched French - Canadian hamlet.

NANKING, Feb. 18 (UP) -- Acting President Li Tsung-jen, strong advocate of an immediate peace with the Communists, appeared today to have won an initial victory over Premier Sun Fo in their dispute over the Government's peace or war policy.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Johns Hopkins University today appointed Dr. Robert Ballentine of Rutgers University to an associate professorship in biology and assigned him to nutrition research work with radio-active elements.
MONTREAL, Feb. 18 -- A beautiful 20-year-old Negro, daughter of a Canadian Pacific Railways porter, was crowned queen of the McGill University winter carnival tonight.

The plight of those sightless souls who must always live in eternal darkness is a sad one anywhere, but it is only natural that many of us should feel especially touched by the case of the blind of war-ravaged Europe. War's destruction of their chances of education, employment and recreation cut them off from the pre-war help of devoted teachers and braille libraries.

Six-year-old Patricia Egan was credited yesterday with having saved from death or injury her mother, two sisters and a woman living in the Egan apartment on the top floor of a four-story building at 265 Albany Avenue, Brooklyn, by her alertness when a fire broke out there at 4 A. M.
Thirty-three of thirty-five projects operated by the New York City Housing Authority were affected yesterday by a walkout of maintenance workers that threatened to continue well past the week-end.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The Second Chamber of the Dutch Parliament (House of Representatives) defeated 76 to 15 tonight a motion of non-confidence in the Government. The debate was on the Government's Indonesian policy.

The Salvation Army is playing a vital role in a drive to halt Communist infiltration among the poor and underprivileged in this country, Brig. Gen. Clifford C. Nutt, Vice Commander of the First Air Force, Fort Slocum, N. Y., told 160 Salvation Army leaders yesterday at the Shelton Hotel.

MANILA, Feb. 18 -- An open battle for political power between President Elpidio Quirino and Senate President Jose Avelino started today in the Philippine Senate. Both men have been courting the Liberal party nomination for the Presidential elections in November.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- In its endeavor to better its competitive situation in Kansas City-Chicago traffic, the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad Company today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to approve plans that will shorten its route between those points twenty-three miles and cut running time for freight and passenger trains.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- The State Banking Department announced today that the County Trust Company, 169 Main Street, White Plains, filed an application for permission to change the location of a branch office from 26 to 47 South Broadway, Yonkers.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 18 -- Declaring that Russia was manufacturing fear behind its "Iron Curtain," Dr. Phillip C. Jessup warned tonight that "we do not want any country to underestimate the seriousness with which we intend to support the peace system for which the United Nations stands."

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 18 -- Motion picture stars in California were next on Gerard Graham Dennis' list of prospective burglary victims, he told District Attorney George M. Fanelli and the Westchester police chiefs here today when questioned concerning memoranda found in his wallet.

EDGEWATER, N. J., Feb. 18 -- The two escaped Russian fliers, Peter Pirogov and Anatole Borsov after completing a two-mile inspection tour of the interior of the Ford Motor Company assembly plant here today, declared that if they hadn't seen with their own eyes the cars rolling off the assembly line at the rate of nearly 300 a day they wouldn't have believed it.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The Department of Agriculture called today for a 20 per cent cutback in cotton production this year to avoid surpluses.

St. John's University's quintet packed too much experience for a younger Fordham squad last night at the Sixty - ninth Regiment Armory as the Redmen swept to an easy 67-48 triumph. The victory kept alive any hopes the Brooklynites may have for a bid in the forthcoming invitation tournament.

THE most readable -- and revealing -- background for what is going on in France today is to be found in "The Unknown Warriors,"* by Guillain de Benouville, for this spirited personal narrative of the Resistance years is also really the story of a (comparatively) unknown civil war that is by no means over.

NOME, Alaska, Feb. 18 -- Weasels and dog teams crunched across the Bering Sea ice pack today as the Arctic Indoctrination School of the Air Force put another class through its rigorous curriculum of survival procedures.
DETROIT, Feb. 18 -- The flurry of work suspensions in the motor capital appeared today to be small but spectacular downward movements in an over-all picture of rising automotive employment.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 -- The protest of 136 members of the American Medical Association against the organization's "fundamental failure in its attitudes and policies bearing on the general problem of medical care" in view of the Government's compulsory insurance proposals drew a sharp reply from the AMA today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Senator Eugene D. Millikin of Colorado served notice today that Senate Republicans would fight for retention of the "peril-point" procedure laid down last year in a stop-gap extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act.
Rock Hill, S. C., sold two issues of bonds totaling $2,950,000 to banking syndicates yesterday.

The city will watch with interest the cooperative community service program planned for the 5,000 persons who have moved within the past year into Abraham Lincoln Houses in Harlem. Boy and Girl Scout troops will appeal to youngsters in various age groups. Supervision for children's dramatics and arts and crafts will be provided by the Red Shield Club of the Salvation Army.

ATHENS, Feb. 18 (AP) -- A United States investigating officer charged today that Greek guerrillas lynched Lieut. Col. Selden R. Edner, an unarmed United States military observer whose plane crash-landed behind the guerrilla lines near Karpenision four weeks ago.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 18 -- President Peron tonight lashed back at rumor-mongers and the newspaper Critica. He said the nation's economy was "good, safe and flourishing," and mocked the idea that he intended to ask for a foreign loan.
TOKYO, Feb. 9 -- Signs are multiplying here of a revival of some forms of Japanese nationalism after three and a half years of Allied occupation.
"Lost -- One Borough President. Please Return to Citizens of Borough of Queens. Information Desired by Forest Hills Taxpayers Association. No Reward."

A million and a half daily loaves of Silvercup bread, the kind that has been absent from store shelves and consumers' tables since Jan. 31, when 300 truck drivers struck against the Gordon Baking Company in Long Island City, will be available again on Monday.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 18 -- Gov. Fuller Warren today ordered county law officers to arrest all bookmakers in Florida.

Judge Harold R. Medina announced from the bench yesterday that counsel for the eleven Communists have "proved nothing" in their five-week challenge to the Federal jury system, and halted the cross-examination of the Federal jury clerk.
Because Nathan Kagel, 54 years old, of 275 Prospect Place, Brooklyn, recommended a lawyer to a woman entering Brooklyn Adolescents Court recently, he now needs one himself.

The Nies-Berger Chamber Orchestra, under Edouard Nies-Berger, gave its third and last concert of the season, last night at Town Hall Louis Kaufman, violinist, and Aurora Mauro-Cottone, pianist, were the soloists of the elaborate program which featured the first American performance of Martinu's Concerto da Camera in F minor for violin solo, with accompaniment of piano and strings.

The commutation service in the New York area of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad was not credited in 1948 with the road's portion of the ground rentals in the Grand Central Terminal zone, it was shown yesterday in testimony before the Public Service Commission in an application of the New Haven for higher commutation fares within New York State.
The management of two cemeteries was accused yesterday of "strike-breaking and union-busting" in a strike of grave-diggers.

American Youth for Democracy, a campus and community organization listed as subversive by Attorney General Tom Clark, and since its organization in 1943 the center of violent controversy at local colleges, is dissolving its national organization, it was announced yesterday.

Teachers must deal in the classroom with controversial issues as well as with "safe" subjects, Frank N. Trager, program director of the Anti-Defamation League, declared yesterday. He made this statement at the final day meeting of a conference on the United Nations at New York University.

Wendell Willkie's dream of One World was interpreted last night as a democratic accent on human rights. Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War and president of Freedom House, in a message commemorating Mr. Willkie's birthday anniversary, paid tribute to his capacity to change with changing conditions.

Two 17-year-old girls, both students of Prospect Heights High School, received yesterday the first and second prizes in the fourth annual Brooklyn Scholastic Art Exhibit of Abraham Straus Fulton and Hoyt Streets.

A snow-charged sub-zero cold front hit the northern plains yesterday, toppling temperatures as much as 52 degrees. The Associated Press reported strong winds carried their bite across the snow-laden expanses of Montana, Wyoming, and North and South Dakota, including most of the area where emergency relief operations have been continuous for nearly a month.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- A Navy captain due to retire in July has been relieved of his duties as a public relations officer and faces a formal reprimand for having called a United States Senator "a politician" not fit for an admiral "to wipe his shoes on."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Representative John E. Rankin, Democrat, of Mississippi, asked the House Rules Committee today for a hearing on whether his bill, which would give $90-a-month pensions to all veterans of both world wars at age 65, would be taken to the floor for a voting showdown.

TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 18 -- Studies of the records of New Jersey prison inmates and parolees will be made by the newly formed State Parole Board, in cooperation with the Department of Institutions, to seek means of reducing crime and criminal tendencies.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 -- A machine that may enable the deaf to hear and speak a code language based on vibrations filtered from the fundamental sounds in human speech has been developed by scientists at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a Professor of Mathematics at that school reported here tonight.

OTTAWA, Feb. 18 -- Notice has been given to all international airlines operating through the airport of Gander that from April 1 when Newfoundland will enter the Canadian Confederation commercial landing rights at that airfield will be canceled and only technical landing rights for refuelling and repairs permitted.
LONDON, Feb. 18 -- The stock market here today was quiet before the week-end and no decided tendency was observable.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 18 (AP) -- United States officials said today that they had been blocked thus far in attempts to obtain the release of two United States Army soldiers and a civilian held by Czechoslovak authorities.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission authorized the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation today to increase the delivery capacity of the Big Inch and Little Big Inch pipelines by 75,000,000 cubic feet a day to a total of 508,000,000 cubic feet.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- A defense witness turned in sudden accusation against Mildred E. (Axis Sally) Gillars at her treason trial today, shouting that she threatened American soldiers in a German prison camp in 1944.
Three men were arrested at 6 P. M. yesterday in front of a Bronx motion picture theatre and charged with the possession of a package of counterfeit $10 and $20 bills with a face value of $10,000.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UP) -- Secretary of State Acheson sent the following telegram to General Clay tonight:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson explained the draft of the proposed North Atlantic defense pact to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today and some progress apparently was made toward reaching a compromise on the operative clause.

PARIS, Feb. 18 -- Emmanuel d'Astier de la Vigerie, an extreme Left Deputy, today filed a demand that the Government explain how and under what conditions Victor Kravchenko received a French visa. M. d'Astier charged that Mr. Kravchenko had admitted coming to France for the express purpose of suing a Communist paper as an attack against the Communist party.

Retail sales declined during the week, according to estimates made here yesterday. Department store sales here were believed to be about 9 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were 5 per cent below last year.

To help remove the clutter from the too-few closets of many apartments, new storage equipment has been designed that makes good use of the plain wood surfaces of doors to hall closets, bathrooms and kitchenettes. New attachments now available make the backs of these doors as serviceable as those in clothes closets, which usually are burdened with tie racks, hooks and the like.

The Vocational High School Division of the Board of Education is trying to work out a curriculum that will be of maximum value to all pupils, regardless of intellectual or physical abilities, without sacrificing at the same time the best school standards.

From the reports that sifted this way from Boston, where the National Sportsmen's Show made its opening run, the 1949 exposition is the best since the beginning of the war, so thousands of New York sportsmen undoubtedly will be on hand when the show opens at Grand Central Palace today.
Governor Dewey emphasized yesterday that his "major job" this year was "to break the cost of houses."

The Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe (CARE) has under consideration the distribution of supplies to needy American Indians, sources close to the organization made known yesterday. The proposal which was advanced last week at the monthly board meeting, had the support of many of the twenty-six cooperating organizations, and will be acted upon March 1.
PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 18 (AP) -Portland's newspaper pressmen, on strike last week-end for two days, walked off the job again today.

The Cunard White Star Line announced yesterday that the cruise liner Mauretania had been forced to curtail a scheduled eight-day cruise to Nassau and Havana because of "engine irregularities" and was returning to New York for repairs. She is due here Monday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Meat operations of Armour Co. during the first quarter of the current fiscal year were "not satisfactory," George A. Eastwood, chairman, said today at the packing company's annual stockholders' meeting.

The National Supply Company, leading independent manufacturer of oil and gas field equipment, and its subsidiaries had last year the largest earnings in its history and the highest peacetime sales on record, according to the report announced yesterday.

A vacant plot at the southeast corner of Thirty-first Avenue and Crescent Street in Astoria, Queens, has been purchased by the Brecher-Wohl Realty Corporation, headed by Morris Brecher, for improvement with a six-story garden-type apartment building to accommodate eighty-six families.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Edwin G. Nourse, chief economic adviser to President Truman, today characterized the current business situation as one of "disinflation" that was healthy unless the public became "jittery."

ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 18 -- A two-day strike of more than 1,000 high school pupils here that started Wednesday when the students remained away from classes in protest against the Board of School Estimate's failure to grant $300 salary rises for teachers was ended today as school attendance returned to normal.

CAIRO, Feb. 18 -- Serious consideration is being given by Arab representatives here to the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission's proposal that Old Jerusalem be administered by Arabs and New Jerusalem by Jews with a federal authority over both.

PATERSON, N. J., Feb. 17 (AP) -- Seventeen persons were felled today by chlorine gas in the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association building. Police said a pipe connection came loose while workmen were removing the chlorination system, used to purify water in the swimming pool.

The Public Service Electric and Gas Company has revised its plans for a new issue of refunding mortgage bonds and now intends to come to market to borrow $75,000,000 on a long-term bond issue in the latter part of July, it was learned yesterday.

Weakness in the nearby March delivery of hide futures carried over to other deliveries on Commodity Exchange as the market declined 5 to 33 points. Volume was moderately high. Although brief rallies occurred during the day, short selling and March liquidation outweighed the buying.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 18 (AP) -- Explosive Olympia and his stablemate, Ocean Drive, hold dominating roles in the twelfth edition of Santa Anita's $100,000 Derby tomorrow.

The new Congressional bill to restrict liquor advertising was cited by advertiser representatives yesterday as further evidence that distiller and advertising interests must maintain constant vigilance against "dry" moves in Washington and individual states, Because of recent political setbacks, and a less powerful influence in Congress, "dry" die-hardedness had been underestimated by some industry members, it was noted.

The Home for the Aged and Infirm Hebrews of New York sold the five-story store and apartment building on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 930 Columbus Avenue to an investor in a cash deal negotiated by the Pettit-Waterman Company, broker.

March winds may raise shorter skirts in Paris, but women in New York will hold them down to an average thirteen inches from the sidewalk with the help of American designers, the New York Dress Institute reported yesterday.

Miss Marie Corridon of the Women's Swimming Association, national 100-yard indoor free-style champion, added to her list of championships by winning %he 200-yard Metropolitan A. A. U. senior back-stroke title at the London Terrace Pool last night.
Fordham Prep retained its title by scoring 40 points in the twenty-third annual Catholic High Schools A. A. swimming meet held at the New York Athletic Club pool last night.

BOSTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- A Senate committee today attacked business-created charitable trusts which it asserted milk corporations of their assets and deprive the Federal Government of millions in taxes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., asked the Federal Power Commission today to authorize construction of pipeline facilities in the New York metropolitan area or to declare the company not subject to commission jurisdiction.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 18 -- Poland told the United Nations Economic and Social Council today that the slave labor charges brought in the Council against Eastern European countries were part of a United States propaganda campaign to plunge the world into a new war.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Feb. 19 -- It was learned here today that both the British and United States Consuls had requested instructions from their respective Governments on how to deal with the request of the Shanghai city government that the city's merchants give a "contribution" to the local army garrison.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 18 -- Paramount announced today that Hedy Lamarr had been signed for the leading feminine role in "Copper Canyon," with Ray Milland and Macdonald Carey. Charles Marquis Warren and Jonathan Latimer are writing the screen play from the story by Richard English about a post-Civil War western community in which the bitterness of the war persists until the people are pacified by an ex-Confederate Army officer.

For solitary drinkers -- of coffee, we hasten to add -- the Bazaar Francais has some new single-cup pots, one of the expresso style from Italy, and another a drip model made here after a French design. These are just two of the aids to an easier culinary career that are reported today after a tour of gadget-stocked shops.

Even our mistakes these days take on the characteristics of the age of speed. In order to calculate the magnitude of an error the formula is Mistake times Speed at which it was carried out. When that lady who was bound for Puerto Rico got into the wrong plane at La Guardia a few weeks ago, she was in London before she knew it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The New England Telephone and Telegraph Company, Boston, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $35,000,000 of 25-year debentures that are to be sold at competitive bidding.
STOCKHOLM, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Czechoslovakia moved a step closer toward regaining the world amateur ice hockey championship today.

An inter-racial service was sponsored last night by the Free Synagogue of 40 West Sixty-eighth Street with the cooperation of the Presbyterian Church of the Master of 86 Morningside Avenue, a Negro church; the Japanese Methodist Church of 328 West 108th Street and the Church of the Divine Paternity, Universalist, of 76 Central Park West.

We hope the Senate will concur in the decision of the House to double the deficiency appropriation recommended by the Bureau of the Budget for the administration of state unemployment insurance systems. The $10,000,000 supplementary grant approved by the House will help relieve a situation that has made it virtually impossible for New York and other states to provide adequate service to the workers who are being added to the rolls of the jobless.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- A "more than seasonal" drop in employment between mid-December and mid-January does not mean that the country is out of the full-employment era, Ewan Clague, Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, told a press conference today.

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony Young People's Concert, Walter Hendl, conductor: Elizabeth Rich, piano; George Rasely, Leonard Stokes, Earl Rogers, James Ballister, singers, Carnegie Hall, 11 A. M.; "Aida," at 2, and "L'Elisir D'Amore" at 8:30, Metropolitan Opera; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Igor Stravinsky, conductor; Soulima Stravinsky, piano; Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Paulist Chorister, Town Hall, 3; Young People's concert, New School, 3:15; Edna White, trumpet, assisted by the Andrew Tietjen Chorus, Carnegie Hall, 5:30.

A group of stockholders of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation is preparing a suit seeking to invalidate the five-year agreement between the automotive company and the Republic Steel Corporation relative to operations of the government-owned $28,000,000 blast furnace in Cleveland held by Kaiser-Frazer under a long-term lease, it was reported yesterday.
"State Department-File 649," a Film Classics melodrama with Virginia Bruce and William Lundigan playing the lead roles, will open this morning at the Globe. The photography is in Cinecolor.
PEORIA, Ill., Feb. 18 (AP) -- Grand jury charges against three public officials, a newspaper reporter and three gangland figures simmered down today to one indictment.
LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 18 -- Nine months of suspension were ended today for the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Average primary market prices advanced 1 per cent in the week ended Feb. 15, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index is now 158.5 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.5 per cent lower than four weeks ago and 0.9 per cent less than the comparable week in 1948.

Reflecting record net sales of $15,607,429, a rise of 42 per cent over the $10,859,709 volume of the previous year, net profit of the Artloom Carpet Company in 1948 increased to $835,191 from $636,496 in 1947, the report announced yesterday.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 18 (UP) -- A Vatican courier sent into Hungary after the arrest and before the trial of Cardinal Mindszenty is being held "under detention" by police, authoritative sources here said today.
A streamlined board-track version of the Olympics will be presented tonight at Madison Square Garden in the sixty-first American indoor track and field championships.

ROME, Feb. 18 -- The budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1 will be presented to the Chamber of Deputies before the end of February. This is part of the routine business of every government, but Italian budget makers and members of the ECA mission in Rome talk of it as excitedly as if it were the turning point in a war.

A syndicate organized by Robert E. Simon Jr., who also is president of Carnegie Hall, Inc., has purchased the well-known Fisk Building at 250 West Fifty-seventh Street from Louis Berry, who owns hotels in many parts of the country.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18 -Representatives of West Coast ship owners and of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, testified today before Clyde B. Aitchison, Interstate Commerce Commissioner, in favor of increased railroad freight rates on this coast.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 18 -- In the first week of efforts to carry out the General Assembly's December resolution calling for unification of divided Korea, the United Nations Korea Commission has met strong opposition from President Syngman Rhee's Administration to any attempts to negotiate with the North Korean Soviet-sponsored regime or its officials.
Herbert W. Widdop has been named sales manager of the Synthane Corporation, Oaks, Pa., manufacturer and fabricator of phenolic plastics for industry, it was announced yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 18 -- Selden Chapin, United States Minister to Hungary, said here today that "Hungary is under complete domination of a group of Moscow-trained Communists whose sole allegiance is to the Kremlin."

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- The resignation of Glen R. Bedenkapp as chairman of the Republican State Committee was announced today by the office of Governor Dewey. It also made public an exchange of correspondence between Mr. Bedenkapp and the Governor.

AFTER Dunkirk, and still more when three weeks later the French Government capitulated, the questions whether Hitler would, or secondly could, invade and conquer our Island rose, as we have seen, in all British minds. I was no novice at this problem. As First Lord, I had for three years before the First Great War taken part in all the discussions of the Committee of Imperial Defence upon the point.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange became highly irregular yesterday and closed 17 points lower to 15 points higher than the day before.

I am deeply indebted to Harold Barger for writing, and to THE TIMES for publishing, the letter in your issue of Feb. 12 proposing the use of copyright to strengthen The New York Public Library. Because of the immediate and urgent need of the library for assistance and important questions of national policy involved, I venture to press Mr. Barger's suggestion to a somewhat broader conclusion.

KAOHSIUNG, Formosa, Feb. 17 -- Gen. Sun Li-jen former commander of the New First Army of Manchuria has leaped into prominence again here as director of an army camp where 30,000 Nationalist soldiers are undergoing GI-style training with what United States equipment he can procure.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 18 -- A nine-count indictment charging felony and misdemeanor violations under Tennessee's anti-Ku Klux Klan statute has been returned by a county grand jury against Charles R. Terry, 48 years old, a grocery store operator here.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- Reluctant to sanction any possible extension of the policy of white supremacy, British official quarters showed marked coolness and reserve today toward the proposed creation of a new British Dominion in Central Africa. Such a dominion is envisaged by the conference of representatives from Southern Rhodesia, Northern Rhodesia and Nyasaland now being held at Livingstone, Northern Rhodesia.

Services will be conducted tomorrow in the city's churches in celebration of the opening of Brotherhood Week. Many programs have been arranged to be held during the week, particularly on Washington's Birthday. These will include interfaith meetings in collaboration with the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth departed for England at 10 o'clock last night from Pier 90, North River, at 50th Street, with 1,585 passengers, including Frederic Alan Bates, returning to London after an eleven-day visit to New York and Washington, his first trip here in his new post of chairman of the board of Cunard-White Star, Ltd. Mrs. Bates accompanied her husband.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- More than 500,000 tourists came to Britain last year, according to official figures issued tonight. This biggest influx of overseas visitors for twenty-eight years included 75,000 Americans.

Directors of First National Stores, Inc., yesterday voted a special dividend of 50 cents in addition to the regular quarterly of 75 cents a share, payable to common stockholders on March 30. This brings total disbursements for the fiscal year ending March 31 to $3.50 a share, or 25 cents less than the amount distributed in the preceding fiscal year.

The North Atlantic, unusually tranquil during the last few winter months, has suddenly reverted to its traditional character, with a resultant delay of up to forty-eight hours in passenger steamship arrivals.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 18 -- Dr. Chaim Weizmann, who was inaugurated yesterday as President of Israel, came back today to his first love -- science -- making his first public appearance since becoming the new state's number one citizen before the staff and laboratory assistants of the Weizmann Institute of Science at Rehovoth.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The Army acknowledged publicly tonight that it had made a "faux pas" in releasing a "philosophical" report of Communist spying in Japan and China, and said it had no proof to back charges that Miss Agnes Smedley, United States author, had been a member of the alleged spy ring.

The extension of "civilization" into Africa depends upon "the development of leadership among the African peoples," Albert J. Luthuli, a full-blooded Zulu chief from Umvoti, Natal, South Africa, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting sponsored by the Westminster Foundation at Columbia University's Faculty House, 400 West 117th Street.

LONDON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Miss Peggy McLean of New York, the United States champion, qualified tonight to meet Miss Helen Elliott of Scotland for the women's singles crown in the English table tennis championships.

Some measure of relief to United States exporters in meeting shipping validation requirements of the new Argentine exchange permit system, decreed recently by President Peron, was indicated yesterday in advices received by the Argentine consulate here and the Office of International Trade in Washington.

ATHENS, Feb. 18 -- A decree law adopted tonight by the Inner Cabinet, one of the most drastic financial measures in principle ever enacted by modern Greece and amounting to a virtual capital levy, is designated to raise special relief revenue. The estimated yield is put at 150,000,000,000 drachmas [about $15,000,000].

For the second time in his career, Joseph A. Fields, who has had as many as three plays running concurrently on Broadway, is fashioning a script without the assistance of a collaborator. It is untitled as yet, but Max Gordon, to whom Mr. Fields recently outlined the plot, is interested to the point of wanting to produce it next fall.

HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 18 (AP) -- A heavy rain canceled today's second round of the $10,000 Houston open golf tournament and washed out a beautiful nine-under-par 63 scored by Bob Hamilton of Landover, Md.

The city's Division of Labor Relations and the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service announced yesterday that they were ready to work together to avoid a possible strike on March 1 or after by 26,000 Consolidated Edison Company workers.

The theme song for four burglars in Brooklyn for a few crucial minutes yesterday, beginning at 2:30 A. M., might have been "Stumbling All Around." But the quartet was too busy to sing and managed to muddle through to dubious victory.

VIENNA, Feb. 18 -- Theodore G. Pozzy, chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration's Paris office for travel development, yesterday told a gathering of Austrian officials that Austria was missing an opportunity that other countries were taking by not applying for Marshall Plan aid in reviving the tourist industry.

Johann Wolfgang von Goethe is the subject of two books that will be issued in May. Farrar, Straus has scheduled for May 24 Ludwig Lewisohn's two volumes "Goethe: The Story of a Man." It is a reconstruction of the great German's life based on documents, letters and diary excerpts, pertinent passages from his poetic production, reports by contemporaries and conversation fragments.

MUNICH, Germany, Feb. 18 -- Soviet soldiers riding a locomotive made a quick sortie into United States occupation territory and hauled thirty-one freight cars into the Russian zone, the United States Military Government reported tonight.

Among the latest inventions being promoted this season by many of the fashion designers and dress houses is the zipper with a key that unlocks the teeth of the slide fastener when part of the dress fabric or the lingerie beneath is ensnarled in the track.

The letter by Philip W. Swartz on the subject of "Our Aging Population," in a recent issue of THE TIMES, fails to take into consideration the great bulk of our population, those from 15 to 64 years of age. In 1850 this group was 55 per cent of our population.

Included in her cargo but not listed on the manifests of the Irish Pine, which left Pier 1, Hoboken, yesterday afternoon, was a sizable shipment of dreams -- those of a once-young Irishman who will soon return to his native land.

AS a man who long ago discovered that ASCAP is an anagram of ASPCA, and who is therefore against the flogging of dead cats, I wish to point out that most anti-Hollywood generalizations will simply not hold water.

WITH her massive four-volume war diary finally published (in England), Mrs. Millin has returned to the field of her best endeavor -- history and fiction. "King of the Bastards" is a historical novel that treads ground no South African writer, to my knowledge, has ever covered before.

Emphasizing that no deaths have been reported locally from the use of lithium chloride, the Department of Health moved swiftly yesterday to embargo all stocks of the substance here. Highly poisonous under certain conditions, it is used widely as a substitute for common table salt by persons on salt-restricted diets.
SHAWBRIDGE, P. Q., Feb. 19 -- Dartmouth's resurgent band of skiers continued their inexorable march to intercollegiate supremacy by capturing the McGill Carnival today in the Canadian Laurentians.

HERE is a book that has needed writing for a long time. It is the story of an American worker and why he joined a union. It tells how the union (the United Automobile Workers) grew into one of this country's strongest economic and social forces and what its growth has meant to the men and women who helped to build it.

MONTREAL, Feb. 19 -- The Montreal Canadiens hung a 3-1 defeat on the New York Rangers tonight and established themselves more firmly in fourth place in the National Hockey League before a crowd of 11,217.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Senator Wayne L. Morse, Republican, of Oregon, asked Secretary of the Navy John L. Sullivan today to call off disciplinary action against Capt. Ross A. Dierdorff for making an uncomplimentary remark about Senator Harley M. Kilgore, Democrat, of West Virginia.

The Atlantic Pact is an indispensable step in the containment of Soviet aggression. Its purpose is to assure our allies and deter the Kremlin by making it clear that we have solemnly resolved to go to war in defense of any member of the alliance. We can make this clear only by an unequivocal commitment so to do.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 19 -- The veteran Augie Galan, a free agent, was signed today by the New York Giants.

NEW HAVEN, CONN., Feb. 19 -- Yale gained its twelfth straight basketball victory tonight and virtually clinched the National Collegiate Athletic Association tourney bid for District 1 by conquering classy Holy Cross College 60 -- 52. This pulsating clash was viewed by an overflow crowd of more than 3,000 in Payne Whitney Gymnasium.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Feb. 19 (UP) -- The long-seething question of whether to permit Negroes to compete in the annual American Bowling Congress will be discussed officially at a special meeting here on March 7, it was announced today.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 19 -- Twenty-five Southerners from nine states, all of them active in liberal movements throughout the region, met in two off-the-record sessions today to explore liberal strategy for the South in domestic and foreign policy.

PARIS, Feb. 19 -- France, which has been suffering steadily from the effects of inflation, is for the first time since the war experiencing and, to some extent is worried by a growing slump in prices. Food and agricultural products are so far alone affected but the effects both in economic and political fields are being felt to such an extent that the best observers think that the French economy has entered a new stage.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 19 -- Yale University's program to make the teaching of history more interesting and more valuable to the students has been pronounced a success by both students and faculty members. The new method employs "laboratory" techniques and visual aids to bring the events of the past down to the present.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Minnesota stayed on the heels of front-running Illinois in the Big Nine basketball race by snapping a five-game winning streak of Michigan's defending champions, 54 to 47, tonight before 10,000 fans. It was the eighth victory in ten starts for a Minnesota team that previously had beaten Michigan, 45 to 31.
IS there any way by which the producers of straight dramatic programs could be gotten to eliminate the ear-splitting clashes of cacophonous "background music" which mar most of the plays on radio?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's first and foremost task in his new role as presiding officer of the Joint Chiefs of Staff will be to keep the armed services "in line" on the military budget for the fiscal year 1951.

PARIS, Feb. 19 -- The debate in the United States Senate Monday, when leaders of both parties appeared to rule out any specific commitments by the United States under the projected North Atlantic defense pact, came as a severe jolt to Europeans.

DETROIT, Feb. 19 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, said today that any economic "package" won this year from the Ford Motor Company, or from the Chrysler Corporation, would be demanded at once of General Motors.

HERE is a pioneer story to rank with the best. West Lathrop, who brought colonial New England vividly alive in "Black River Captive," has done an equally effective job with the Oregon Trail. We can fairly glimpse the far-off peaks, smell the choking alkali dust, hear the labored roll of wagon wheels.

PENINSULA CITY fully deserves the reputation which the title of this story gives it. Virtually all the city officials are in cahoots with Fats Pulaski, who controls all the rackets with the aid of a gang which stops at nothing to maintain and strengthen its hold on the city.
How about this for an answer to David Cushman Coyle's article on the President's salary?

I write to take issue with the letter of Walter Preiss of Jan. 30. In the first place there is no elenent of compulsion in radio listening. If one does not like a particuliar musical selection one simply turns off the radio. That is what I do when a composition of a contemporary American, or European, composer is announced. By bitter

Two sales will be held this week at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street. Paintings will be offered Thursday evening and English and American furniture and decorations on Friday and Saturday.

BOSTON, Feb. 19 -- Consolidation of health and social welfare agencies to assure more efficient spending of private and public charity dollars was under discussion this week in two New England States, Massachusetts and Maine.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Archbishop John T. McNicholas of Cincinatti, chairman of the administrative board of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, has issued a statement expressing indignation at the imprisonment of fifteen Protestant church leaders in Bulgaria.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 19 -- A drive for a "fourth round" of post-war pay increases was opened today by the United Rubber Workers of America, CIO, as its general executive board assembled here to plan its bargaining strategy for 1949.

If Secretary of Defense James V. Forrestal had not admitted some weeks ago that Government scientists were taking a 10,000-mile-an-hour space ship seriously, the press would not have paid much attention to a booklet and chart issued last week by the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, in which such a craft is suggested.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- President Truman announced today the reactivation of the United Service Organizations in view of conditions "which make it necessary for us to have a large peacetime defense establishment."

Seventeen Republican State Senators and Assemblymen from this city met late yesterday afternoon at the National Republican Club with three county leaders, Thomas J. Curran of New York County, John R. Crews of Kings and Frank Kenna of Queens, and issued a statement attacking Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, and Mayor O'Dwyer.

BONE a bit of history, season strongly with Hollywood, overheat, and the result will be something like this gaudy novel about Attila the Hun and fifthcentury Europe. Readers addicted to highly romanticized versions of history will probably be entertained.

OUR good neighbors to the north would seem to have a lesson for us. The second annual Canadian Ballet Festival is to be held at the Royal Alexandra Theatre in Toronto, March 1-5, with ten companies participating from various cities.

WEMBLEY, England, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Two Americans -- Martin Reisman and Peggy McLean, both of New York -- took the men's and women's singles titles, respectively, today in the English open table tennis championships. The United States also won the mixed doubles.
Revision of United States propaganda and procedures within occupied Germany was advocated yesterday at a luncheon of the American Association for a Democratic Germany.
ROME. THE papacy of Pius XII, which began ten years ago next month, seems destined to go down in history as the most difficult period of the Roman Catholic Church since the Reformation.

RETURNING to Broadway this week after a seven-year absence, Clifford Odets is bewildered and angry. He hotly denies that he deserted the basic ore of real life for Hollywood. To those who whisper that he's "played out," he answers defiantly, "I'm going to write twenty-five or thirty plays before I'm done."

RELATIVELY few Czech writers have been translated into English, and even those lucky ones not necessarily in their best works. The late Karel Capek, for instance, is remembered in the Anglo-Saxon world mainly for his fantastic and satirical plays, although his greatest accomplishments lie in the field of narrative prose.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 19 -- Civil rights were a subject of widespread attention this week throughout the Southwest.

About 400 B. C., when the ancient Jews returned to Israel after the Babylonian exile, they set up a 120-man legislative body called the "Knesset Hagdola" -- Hebrew for Great Assembly. Last week in Israel the first formal Jewish Parliament since the Biblical Knesset convened.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Ezra Pound, who is under indictment for treason and is in a mental hospital here, won a $1,000 prize today for the best poetry published in 1948.
Seven German women arrived in the United States yesterday for a two-month educational survey of democratic processes in this country.

Despite powerful Congressional demand for "exemption" of the Federal Trade Commission in executive reorganization measures business lobbyists are looking to other methods that will produce at least a beginning of changes in the trade tribunal, it was learned last week.
Of the various "health weeks" held during the year, the one affecting the greatest number of sufferers is National Heart Week, which opened on St. Valentine's Day.

FEW men have been more genuinely erratic than Bronson Alcott, but he showed extremely good judgment in picking Abba May as a wife. "Marmee," as she was called by her daughters, possessed in abundance the qualities of thrift, hard-headedness and tolerance necessary to keep her family clothed and fed.

Olivier Messiaen, noted French composer, will make his first visit to this country to teach at the 1949 session of the Berkshire Music Center, it was announced yesterday. He will teach with Aaron Copland, the school's assistant director. The term runs from July 4 to Aug. 14.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- President Truman may be reflecting these days that while a soft answer turneth away wrath, it also hath an annoying tendency of encouraging transgressors to see what else they can get away with.
