AROUND the spindle of Pontiac's war with the British in the Seventeen Sixties, Mr. Hamilton has wound a tale of star-crossed lovers, of knavery in high places and of adventure in trail and town. In the neighborhood near Fort Detroit and Kaskaskia tomahawks crack skulls open, feathered arrows slither through the leaves and lovers meet, almost meet or separate.

H. R. Trevor-Roper's article, "Stalin Would Have Liqui dated Marx," was unsatisfying. His faint charges against communism sound like apologies. Perhaps Marx would have been purged by Stalin, but it has been said also that Christ would be crucified again were he alive today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19 -- Increasing unemployment, California pensions and the weather vied for attention this week in the Pacific States, with more than ordinary interest centered on pensions. This interest was high because of a hint that a recall move might be directed against Gov. Earl Warren if he called a special election for a vote on the repeal of the state's pension act.

ON reading Louis Kronenberger's introduction to the Modern Library "Daniel Defoe" (consisting of "Robinson Crusoe" and "A Journal of the Plague Year") the reader may find himself provoked. "Of all the great heroes of fiction," writes Mr. Kronenberger, "Crusoe is surely the one who would have bored us the most in the flesh."
THE story of the Longines Symphonette is not the usual radio story: it begins with a listener who had a complaint and was able to do something about it.

Opening the first regional convention of the Gold Star Wives of America, seventy-five war widows from the Middle Atlantic States met at the Henry Hudson Hotel yesterday afternoon to discuss the legislative program of the organization.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 19 -- There is a strong movement in Brazil in favor of foreign capital investment. Its backers desire that foreign capital should be free to come and go as it pleases. They hold the theory that capital always stays where it prospers.

PEIPING, Feb. 19 -- More than one hundred tons of flour have been removed in the last two days by the Communist authorities from the United States Economic Cooperation Administration compound here without ECA permission.

With most of the new long-term bonds of the Duke Power Company and the Consolidated Edison Company of New York distributed among investors at yields substantially under 3 per cent, the market for gilt-edge corporate debt is now more confident of the lower yield area it has invaded this winter.

THE men of New Bedford don't go down to the sea in ships any more; at least, not to hunt whales. But the old thrilling cry of "She blows!" bellowed by the lookout in the crow's nest when a catacean was sighted, rang throughout this bustling industrial city last Tuesday night.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 19 -- President Charles Seymour announced today the establishment of a Department of Geography at Yale University.

The private utilities still lack that usually decisive factor of unity. While one segment of the industry continued last week to fight the adherents of public power, typified by the thousands of organizations that have thrown their support behind the proposed steam plant at New Johnsonville, Tenn., for the Tennessee Valley Authority, several other groups of private utility "leaders" separately attack a variety of problems, in-including taxes and regulation by state agencies.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 19 -- The Czechoslovak Ambassador to India, Jaroslav Sejnoha, has been removed under circumstances that have shocked the diplomatic corps and the Indian Foreign Office. The popular Ambassador was a former associate of the late President Eduard Benes and the late Foreign Minister Jan Masaryk.

The current controversy over the fund-raising policies of the United Jewish Appeal grew in vehemence yesterday as spokesmen for two factions of the United Palestine Appeal, one of the principal beneficiaries of the annual campaigns, charged each other with hampering progress toward a peaceful settlement.

CONGRESS received the Administration anti - inflation bill last week and shortly thereafter President Truman was explaining that there is nothing to be alarmed about in the current commodity price decline and mounting unemployment.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 19 -- It is patently clear today that all organized opposition to the Communist regimes in Eastern Europe in terms of leadership, political parties, non-Communist trade unions and peasant cooperatives has been thoroughly smashed.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Notre Dame avenged a previous setback with a 54-49 triumph over DePaul after last - pace Northwestern scored a 62-50 Big Nine upset over Ohio State in a Chicago Stadium basketball double-header witnessed by 10,052 fans tonight.
CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- The Tucker Corporation, the new automobile concern beset by organization and financial troubles, announced today a sweeping reshuffle of its board of directors.

ASIDE from the intrinsic interest of the exhibition of Chinese frescoes more than eight centuries old, at the gallery of C. T. Loo, the work shown proves of additional interest because of its essentially abstract nature.

The Squadron A Regulars outclassed the New York Athletic Club, 15 to 7, in the feature of an indoor polo double-header last night. Walt Nicholls, Regulars' back, scored nine goals to tie Paul Miller and Luke Travis for individual scoring honors of the season at Squadron A Armory.

EVEN the people who have had nothing to do with the production of Arthur Miller's "Death of a Salesman" take a kind of platonic pride in it. What Mr. Miller has achieved somehow seems to belong to everybody.

TO own large tracts of country without ever being asked to pay for them is the privilege of writers. Faulkner can claim much of the South; Hardy had all Wessex; Byron annexed Greece. And Capri belongs to Norman Douglas. Not that he owns a single foot of land, for the various houses that were at one time or another his have all been sold long ago.

LET'S get the records straight. In the Feb. 6 edition of Book Review I read a review ref: "Follow Me: The Story of the Second Marine Division," by Richard W. Johnston, wherein is quoted: "Johnston, describing the action on Tulagi and Gavutu in the Solomons, tells how the Second Marine Division became the first American troops to land on enemy soil in World War II."

HOME nut growing in the northern states is a fertile field for the amateur, and by trying out untested rarities of promise and recording the results, he can render a real service. Advice and comfort is forthcoming, too, from such sources as the New York State Agricultural Experiment Station, the Bureau of Plant Industry of the United States Department of Agriculture, and that enthusiastic group, the Northern Nut Growers' Association.

The first pilot plant in this country to use a new process of chrome-alloying by diffusing chrome through the surfaces of a variety of steel or iron parts has been opened by Diffusion Alloys Corporation at 109 West Sixty-fourth Street, S. I. Wick, chairman of the board, disclosed here yesterday.

GENERAL MARSHALL has now twice publicly denied that he intends to write his memoirs, but the big-brass boom is still booming. It's definite that Admiral Nimitz has a book in progress. So has Admiral Leahy, the scuttlebutt being that 350,000 words of notes are already in editorial hands.

MARCEL PROUST died in 1922 at the age of 51. With better health he might have been alive today, as are his slightly older contemporaries, Julien Benda, Paul Claudel, and Andre Gide. But he lived to complete the one great work he had in him to write; and it is hard to see what he might have done in another quarter-century beside spinning that work out for another sixteen volumes.
HOLLYWOOD labor, hard hit by unemployment, gave voice loudly last week to its major complaint -- foreign competition financed by Hollywood capital.
SAN FERNANDO, Argentina, Feb. 15 -- When the Cristo Rey was launched fifteen years ago there were no churches in the sprawling Parana delta, so the sea-going chapel was conceived to take their place.

WHO has not experienced moments of dismay at the bad manners of our more restlessly experimenting moderns and wished for Rouault as our proper laureate? His name is a favorite dodge in the parlor guessing game that ponders the survival of current artistic reputations.

IN the world of free competition books sell according to the pleasure they give. In a controlled economy this is not necessarily the case. Monopoly may not prove the value of an article, but at least it sells it, even if it is a book.

EARNEST young North Americans who want to understand their southern neighbors already have, or should have, a Delia Goetz bookshelf. This latest addition goes straight to the heart of understanding, answering such questions as "What do boys and girls do about dates in Latin America?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The confusion in Washington and elsewhere about the proposed North Atlantic security pact arises primarily from the confusion within the Government itself about what the pact was intended to do.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 19 -- Old Rockport, a 33-to-1 outsider, and youthful Gordon Glisson, an apprentice rider, teamed today to score a resounding victory in the $141,800 Santa Anita Derby.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 19 (UP) -- Premier Ibrahim Abdul Hadi Pasha proposed today that the United States give Marshall Plan aid to the Middle East to help it turn back communism "before it is too late."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- American watchmakers said today that special treatment for them under the Reciprocal Trade program is essential to national defense.

Leading figures in Government, labor, medicine and public life joined yesterday to dedicate the new $3,500,000 Union Health Center of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, 275 Seventh Avenue.

MR. EVELYN WAUGH'S recent book, "The Loved One," was an attack, and by no means a good-natured attack, on American civilization, but in "Scott-King's Modern Europe" he shows himself willing to handle his native Continent with at least equal rudeness. America worships corpses but Europe mass-produces them, is what he seems to be saying.

Shedding a long cloth overcoat and a small jacket, a 15-year-old girl clad in a two-piece bathing suit suddenly leaped into the North River at 2:05 yesterday afternoon from the lower deck of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western ferry Scranton.

The Household Finance Corporation, in its annual report for 1948 to be released today, disclosed a net income of $9,883,894, compared with $8,173,769 in 1947. These sums were equal to $3.89 and $3.19 a comman share, respectively.

WASHINGTON. FIFTY business men write me every day and I write them. They ask me questions, and I ask them questions, and we swap news and views about how things are with them in their trades and localities.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Feb. 19 -- Westerners chuckled ruefully this week when they recalled the Utah-Nevada feud of a year ago which resulted from aerial snowmaking attempts. There was little else to smile about as resorts, rangelands and cities were again assaulted by blizzards and roaring chinook winds.
Thirty Midwestern women from rural areas of the Corn Belt States will leave Tuesday for a month's tour of Europe to study conditions there on a "woman - to - woman basis."

WASHINGTON. "JAMES EDWIN WEBB is a good man and a good administrator." These were President Truman's words explaining why he had named Mr. Webb Under-Secretary of State. Mr. Webb is also a good soldier, which is why he accepted the appointment.

Enactment of the proposed McGovern bill by the New York State Legislature will force increases in cash prices of furniture and other home furnishings in stores which also maintain credit operations, James B. McMahon Jr., executive vice president of the Associated Furniture Dealers of New York, declared last week.

OTTAWA, Feb. 19 -- So much controversy has marked the debate on the entry of Newfoundland into the Canadian Confederation that long desired and long delayed fulfilment of what was planned eighty years ago has been shorn of all glamour and has completely failed to stir any public enthusiasm.

An upturn in demand for industrial types of electrical equipment has appeared, and sizable orders for new products are being placed, electrical manufacturers disclosed here yesterday. W. H. Haines, vice president, Electric Specialty Company, Stamford, Conn., disclosed that among new items his company is developing for other larger electrical equipment companies, "a small sized radar" is included.

New rayon - producing plants in Brazil, Chile and Egypt, going into operation in 1948, have augmented substantially the supply of filament yarn and staple fiber being produced in the world, according to a report by Oscar Kohorn Co., Ltd., rayon plant engineering concern.

Prices of shares drifted in a narrow range during yesterday's abbreviated session on the Stock Exchange, closing the week irregularly lower in quiet trading. The day's volume dropped to 250,000 shares, the smallest for a two-hour session in four months.

In honor of the memory of George Washington, Americans were urged, in sermons by rabbis here yesterday in connection with Brotherhood Week and Washington's Birthday, to strengthen our democracy by promoting active brotherhood among all its citizens.

Hollywood's Dore Schary is much mistaken when he says (in "Plan for Hollywood -- By Schary," by Sam Boal): "I don't think people will especially like to sit around their homes and watch a television movie."

Marking a significant phase of its expanding production and research program, the Union Chimique Belge of Brussels is now seeking to introduce in American markets two of its new pharmaceutical products. The company is the largest chemical and pharmaceutical manufacturer in Belgium.
OTTAWA, Feb. 19 (Canadian Press) -- A Government-appointed board hearing a dispute between deep-sea ship owners and the Canadian Seamen's Union reported today that it had "failed at conciliation."

AARON COPLAND wrote his Sonata for Piano, commissioned by Clifford Odets, in the interval between 1939 and 1941. On first hearing some considered it difficult in form and style and unyielding in content. But if you give yourself a fair chance to become well acquainted with it, the sonata proves to be none of these things.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 19 -- Dollar volume of department store sales here last week and the four weeks ending Feb. 12 was 8 per cent below the level of last year. Bank debits dropped 11 per cent, comparing this January to last.

Almost no attention has been paid thus far in the year to the fact that 1949 is the fifteen-hundredth anniversary (as near as it can be figured) of the "Coming of the Saxons." The English show little interest in this matter which would seem to concern them as the modern representatives of the Angles, Saxons and Jutes.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 19 -- The world is well over the hump in its long struggle to eliminate the critical coal shortage, but global steel output -- despite a resultant increase -- continues to be an obstacle to further recovery of industrial production, it was disclosed here today by the United Nations Department of Economic Affairs.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The Air Force disclosed today a new jet-powered research plane with a triangular wing -- the first of its kind to fly.

WHEN Celia Laighton's father was defeated for Governor of New Hampshire in 1839 he left the mainland forever to become lighthouse keeper in the Isles of Shoals. This is the story of those years as seen through the eyes of his eager, perceptive little daughter, Celia, who lived a life of freedom and joy with her parents, two young brothers, birds, flowers, the sea and, later, the schoolmaster, Mr. Thaxter.

BERLIN, Feb. 19 -- An Englishman here remarked the other day that "the Fourth Reich is born." The remark was occasioned by the fact that the West German parliamentary assembly at Bonn had completed the draft of a Constitution for the new West German State.

FORT MEADE, Md., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. George E. Pinard of Wessington Springs, S. D., has been acquitted on charges of mistreating American soldiers in a disciplinary barracks at Wurzburg, Germany.

WHEN the green hired-hand from the East prepared to ride Midnight, the unmanageable black gelding, the cowboys of the Lazy-E lined the corral fence to watch the fun. Bill Stephens astonished them that day, and it wasn't the last time he was to do so.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth presented a sparkling contrast to her recent salt-stained appearance when she arrived here last week. The big liner had been completely overhauled during a six-week lay-up in Southampton.

KAESONG, Korea, Feb. 19 -- A United States Air Force pilot was shot down a mile and a half east of here this morning by North Koreans as the United Nations Korean Commission inspected the border of North and South Korea in the area.

MAZATLAN, Mexico -- Mazatlan, on the Pacific coast of Mexico, practically astride the Tropic of Cancer, seems to have been designed especially for those who miss the Acapulco of pre-war days -- uninflated prices, superb surroundings and a healthy respect for the principle of laissez-faire.

The 217th anniversary of the birthday of George Washington will be marked Tuesday by various ceremonies in the city, including a celebration in Carnegie Hall sponsored by twenty-five patriotic organizations and the re-enactment, on the steps of the Sub-Treasury Building at Broad and Wall Streets, of the first inauguration of General Washington as President of the United States.

GENEVA, Feb. 19 -- Twenty-four European nations and the United States agreed here today to proceed immediately to reduce to practical terms the possibilities of expanded trade between Eastern and Western Europe.
More meat, in the form of good red beef as well as pork, will be available this year than had been expected and next year, if this year's corn crop is not cut, meat should be plentiful and cheap.

BERLIN, Feb. 19 -- A number of experienced diplomats representing the Western powers in Berlin expect the Soviet Union will approach the West soon in the hope of arranging a four-power conference on Germany.

For thirty-eight years the Phelps-Stokes Fund has initiated reforms in race relations in this country, and to a degree has aided the education and health of large areas of Africa. Although the Fund was free to work among Indians and white people as well, it saw fit to concentrate in the field of Negro-white relations, and devoted nine-tenths of its income for 1911-46 to work in education, housing and interracial activity.

THE Metropolitan Opera will have presented twenty-five operas by the time it closes its season on March 19. This figure can be ascertained because "Falstaff" and "Parsifal" are known to be the only productions coming up that have not been given earlier.

GEORGE WHARTON of Scotland Yard has often reproached his friend Ludovic Travers for being too much given to theorizing. This story proves that Wharton has good ground for his reproaches. In a case involving murder, blackmail and other crimes, Travers comes up with two separate and distinct theories, each of which appears plausible enough -- although a jury might think the evidence insufficient to warrant a conviction.

ROME, Feb. 19 -- The Prefect of Pontifical Ceremonies has published the first program of the "Holy Year" or "Jubilee Year," which will be celebrated in Rome from next December to December, 1950, and which is expected to draw several hundreds of thousands of pilgrims from all over the world to the center of Catholicism.

More than 1,500 tons of German products -- token shipments symbolizing the gradual revival of German industry -- will arrive in New York in the next few weeks as exhibits in the German Industry Fair to be held at the Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center in April, according to Herbert Maybaum, freight representative of the United States Lines in Germany.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Representatives of management and labor in the American jeweled-watchmaking industry pleaded anew today for Congressional protection, in the interest of national efense, from Swiss competition.

THE Second Eastern Regional Gladiolus Conference will be held at Rutgers University, New Brunswick, N. J., on Saturday, Feb. 26. Among the topics to be discussed are "Soil Management," by Dr. O. W. Davidson: "Exhibition Varieties," by H. M. Sherman Jr., and "Disease and Insect Control," by Dr. A. A. Foster.

WITH estimates that there will be at least 50,000,000 motor vehicles in service in this country by 1959, Federal agencies and private groups are becoming increasingly concerned over the lagging program of highway construction in urban and rural areas.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 -- Although pressed in the closing minutes, Pennsylvania defeated Harvard today in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game, 76 to 71, before 2,500 spectators at the Palestra.

PARIS. EARLY in 1942 Jean Giraudoux took advantage of a trip to Switzerland to deliver a series of lectures, to make a transatlantic telephone call to me that would not be subject to the censorship that prevailed in Paris.
THE work in transparent and translucent materials which comprises the exhibition at the Addison Gallery in Andover could belong to no other century than ours.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 19 -- Borba, the official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party, today unexpectedly entered the case of Anna Louise Strong, American writer, whose arrest and expulsion from Moscow has been ordered by the Soviet Government.
John A. Rumsey has been appointed to head the accounting department of the Rensselaer, N. Y., plant of General Aniline and Film Corporation.

Willy Slykhuis of the Netherlands and Gaston Reiff of Belgium led anticipated European sweeps of the mile and three-mile runs in the sixty-first American indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden last night, but thanks to the finishing power of a 19-year-old Cornell sophomore from Malverne, L. I., the threatened 1,000-yard crown remained on these shores.

STANLEY WOODWARD, who until a few months ago doubled as sports editor and first-string sports columnist of the New York Herald Tribune, has turned out a highly readable, frank, informative and at times mordant book on the work of the sports writer.

FOUR years ago, on Feb. 4, opened the most discussed and surely the most misjudged conference of World War II. By now Yalta is considered by many unbigoted persons as an occasion when a dying President lost his grip on American interests and made a number of fateful surrenders to the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UP) -- Two Democratic members of Congress today urged a full-dress investigation of the Army report on prewar Communist espionage in the Far East. The Army has admitted it made a faux pas in releasing the report.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Circle K Farm's Athlete liked the muddy track and splashed ahead to win the Gentilly Handicap by two lengths today at the Fair Grounds.

ROME, Feb. 19 -- The walls of Rome were being covered today with posters inviting all Catholics to participate in a demonstration of solidarity and sympathy for the Pope which will be held in St. Peter's Square tomorrow morning.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange staged a late rally yesterday and closed 1 to 17 points net higher.

HOLLYWOOD'S favorite pastime at the moment is to offer assurances that in all good time the film capital will bestow its limitless blessings upon television. With a condescension bordering on the benign, its assorted leaders suggest that once they get around to the matter they will lift television from its present state of indecision and thrust it into that exalted world where everything is colossal.

Two personalities have been pitted against each other in Washington for the past two weeks. One was A. (Amadeo) P. Giannini, son of Italian immigrants who rose to dominate the financial scene on the West Coast; the other, Marriner S. Eccles, deposed chairman but still a member of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve Board.

BURBANK, Calif. IN the Lockheed Aircraft Company's executive offices here in the sunshiny San Fernando Valley sits Hall L. Hibbard, who is a Lockheed vice president and the company's chief engineer. He looks like a good, sound business man, which isn't odd, because that's what he is.

NO one thing contributes more to the over-all attractiveness of a garden than the neatness and distinction of its edging. It makes up for lack of bloom in perennials and -- even in winter -- an evergreen edging of boxwood, germander and ivy will brighten the landscape.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The Rio Mutual Defense Treaty, which binds the twenty-one American Republics to maintain hemisphere peace, successfully weathered its first test today when Costa Rica and Nicaragua agreed to a peaceful settlement of their two-months-old dispute.
The United States last week launched upon a great debate the outcome of which may be crucial for the future of the nation and of the world.

When Justice of the United States Supreme Court leaves the bench to make a public speech he generally has something to say that is politically non-partisan and that concerns us all. Justice William O. Douglas did this when he delivered a lecture in Los Angeles on Friday evening.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 19 -- House and Senate committees in the Tennessee Legislature this week recommended approval of bills removing the poll tax as a prerequisite for voting in primary elections.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 19 -- It is hoped here that by the time the United Nations Conciliation Commission, now touring the Arab countries, reaches here on Thursday, there may be a concrete plan for Palestine prepared.

THE problem that concerns Robin Maugham, nephew of W. Somerset, is the relationship between master and servant. While the employer, Tony, a young ex-army officer, has a private income and a home, the employe, a sinuous figure, called Barrett, is completely dependent on his master for both.

STOCKHOLM, Feb. 19 -- An improving United States team upset previously unbeaten Czechoslovakia, 2 -- 0, today in the world amateur ice hockey championships and made the tournament a race again. It was a stirring match played before 8,000 spectators who cheered the Americans long and loud, because the victory prevented the Czechs from clinching the title.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UP) -- Railroad unions estimated today that 100,000 rail workers had been laid off in the past sixty days.

First efforts of the Association of National Advertisers' new committee on cooperative advertising toward obtaining support of retailer groups have hit a snag in the proposal for a "clearing house" on rates paid by manufacturers to retailers.

QUEBEC, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Canada defeated the United States in the Lapham Cup matches today for the international squash racquets title of the Quebec Winter Club. With seven of the ten matches completed, Canada held a 6-1 lead and could not be overtaken.

A DISPASSIONATE survey of child psychology literature over a period of years will reveal two trends. One is the tendency to state the same "basic truths" over and over again. The other is the tendency to go off on a tangent of fads or issues.

The stock market surrendered much of its "despair" attitude last week, made a comeback for the first time in three weeks and indicated a return to a more normal attitude. Business remained highly professional and the only interest shown by the public was in the liquidation of stocks in the low-price category which were affected by corporate developments.

GIBRALTAR, Feb. 19 -- Mystifying radio messages from the United States freighter William Phips apparently were clarified tonight when the vessel landed here and debarked a radio operator suffering from a nervous breakdown.

* * * It is obvious to me, if not to Dore Schary, that mankind is in for a new and better era with the advent of television. We will become again what we once were -- a home-loving nation. With the kids in the house all the time (try to get them out) where Mom can keep an eye on them, the problem of juvenile delinquency will disappear overnight.

AS in her last book -- that collection of muted, evocative short stories, "Ivy Gripped the Steps" -- Elizabeth Bowen in her new novel reflects on the English during the war; particularly, the effect of enormous social dislocation on individuals.

WASHINGTON. THE best way to look at the White House is from the far boundary of the south lawn when it is bathed in the late afternoon sun and soft shadows are thrown across its ancient facade. There it sits amid its spreading elms and gently sloping greensward like a serene and brocaded old dowager on her throne.

Tomorrow night's free music history lecture in the series "500 Years of Music" conducted by Dr. Curt Sachs at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, will be "The Age of Beethoven and Schubert." The remaining two lectures will deal with twentieth-century music.

UNUSUAL opportunities to gain practical experience in photographic techniques mark the third annual National Photographic Show, which opened yesterday at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue, for four days through Feb. 22.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19 -- For the fourth consecutive week retail business in the Twelfth District has suffered losses in sales as compared with the same period of 1948. Building activity in the Far West during January showed declines from both the previous month and January, 1948.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, a man of demonstrable tact, wisdom and experience in the military field, was back this week in a Government job that will demand all three qualities in generous measure.

" We can do more than anybody else, Stalin included, to drive the Chinese Communists into the arms of Russia," Dr. Nathaniel Peffer, Professor of International Relations at Columbia University and an authority on contemporary China, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- President Truman accepted today the resignation of Maj. Gen. William H. Draper Jr. as Under-Secretary of the Army, effective Feb. 28.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 19 -- Governor Dewey was threatened today with an intraparty revolt on his proposed $936,000,000 state budget when the nine Westchester County members of the Legislature, all Republicans, voted at a conference here to disapprove his budget unless the Governor cut his tax program drastically.
Since last year there has been a running battle between the Administration and Congress over the question: How big should the United States Air Force be?

Although President Truman and other Administration authorities reiterated last week their pleas for increased taxes, particularly on corporations, the domestic steel industry has not abandoned hope for a reformation of the tax laws to allow greater deductions for depreciation.

OSLO, Norway, Feb. 19 -- United States entries got off to an auspicious start in the world speed skating championships here today with Ken Henry of Chicago and Johnny Werket of Minneapolis finishing 1 -- 2 in the 500-meter event. A sell-out crowd of 29,000 spectators cheered the Americans.

PHILADELPHIA, Sunday, Feb. 20 -- The international president of Philadelphia's striking CIO transit workers announced early today their ten-day strike was over, but his decision was overruled fifteen minutes later by the local president, who called for another meeting later today.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 19 -- Hope for peace runs high in the state of Israel. Except that the army is still mobilized and all frontier posts are heavily armed, one would suppose that peace was a reality.

* * * David Cushman Coyle ("Movie Mogul, $800,000 -- Truman, $100.000") is trying to show how overpaid our high-salaried leaders in private business are, but he has chosen the wrong person to compare them with when he cites the President of the United States, because Mr. Truman happens to be the highest paid individual in the nation, when all the extras that go with the office of the Presidency are taken into consideration.

I had occasion last week to attend a performance of "Richard III" and was interested in the use of Shostakovitch's "Fifth symphony" as "incidental music" in the play. If my ears served me correctly, the music was furnished through a recording by the Philadelphia Symphony Orchestra.

To ask a question like the one given above is to answer it. The United States has always defended itself when attacked. The most recent example is the course that was followed after Dec. 7, 1941. Current discussions of the proposed North Atlantic Pact might be easier to follow if this basic fact were kept in mind.

IN the course of a year the United States Air Force takes part in many public air shows held at various places throughout the nation. It does so on the indisputable theory that a flying display of its weapons is an excellent way to sell itself to the public.

MANY, too many, of our recent novels about the big money milieu have betrayed a curious belief that incessant wisecracking is the speech of sophisticated people, and, furthermore, that such wisecracking is synonymous with wit.

WHEN Laura Hobson asked Darryl Zanuck why he decided to make a moving picture of her novel, "Gentleman's Agreement," Mr. Zanuck came up with a somewhat personal reason: "I did not want my son, when he grows up, to be able to say: 'Dad, what were you doing twenty-five years ago when you were a big shot in Hollywood?

A FRENCH friend always says halfway through the roast or bird, "Now don't drink all the wine; save up some for the cheese." Whether one "saves" or opens another bottle of the same is a matter of purse and palate; what's important is that cheese is one of the best foods to team with a red table wine of almost any type.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Atlantic powers, the State Department and the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations appeared to have moved closer together on the drafting of a North Atlantic defense pact as a result of an informal conference Secretary of State Dean Acheson held this morning with the Ambassadors of the negotiating powers.

The influence on national and world affairs of new discoveries in the natural and social sciences will be the subject of a course, "Contemporary Trends," to be offered this spring by the University of Wisconsin. Open only to seniors, the course is designed to acquaint natural science students and engineers with the viewpoint of social scientists and to give social scientists knowledge of the natural sciences.

An appeal to Mayor William F. O'Dwyer for an audience with him at City Hall, to present their arguments in favor of permitting special parking privileges for salesmen during business hours in the Manhattan "no parking" areas, was contained in a letter to the city's chief executive yesterday from the traffic committee of the National Council of Salesmen's Organizations.

The American Bridge Company, a subsidiary of United States Steel, has been awarded contracts for structural steel, cable steel wire and erecting material for the Delaware River Memorial Bridge, connecting the states of Delaware and New Jersey, on a low bid of $13,731,090.
HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 19 -- Cary Middlecoff, Memphis, Tenn., dentist, used a remodeled putter today to take eight strokes off par for a 64 and the lead at the halfway mark of the $10,000 Houston open.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Lucius (Luke) Easter. 26: year-old Negro outfielder-first baseman from St. Louis, accepted terms from the Cleveland Indians today to play for their San DiegoI Pacific Coast League farm club. Easter won the Puerto Rican Winter League batting championship with a mark of .402 for the penant-winning Mayaguez ndians.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Feb. 19 -- The scarcity of housing to shelter workers still needed in the Ruhr looms as a possible major problem for both the British Military Government and the German administrators. The acuteness is indicated by report just submitted to the regional commissioner in which the assertion is made that at the present rate of appropriations by the civilian administration, seventeen years must pass before stabilization will be reached.
Comic books, recently much assailed by sociologists as contributory to juvenile delinquency, were absolved from much of the blame yesterday by a New York University Professor of Sociology.

AT Hollywood's Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, the home of the much ballyhooed "Oscar," a less publicized, but possibly more constructive, project is under way. It is a comprehensive series of recordings by motion-picture pioneers in which the trailblazers of the silent screen speak for posterity, describing some of the high spots in the early history of the movies.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19 -- The effective answer to communism is "the human welfare state" in which the "fetish" of property rights is subordinated to "the right to work" and security for the masses, Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the United States Supreme Court declared today.

IT has been stated by several reviewers, including your critic, that the person mainly responsible for the current production of "Richard III" is Richard Whorf. This, however, is a mistaken impression, Richard Barr, who directed the lighting and the production, is actually the person most responsible for this piece of theatre.

PARIS, Feb. 19 -- The decline in prices in the United States is being watched anxiously by financial and business circles in Europe. Experts consider it presents a serious problem that may directly affect the European Recovery Program and even the issue of security against war.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Did the Administration's handling of its labor relations bill, bogged down in prolonged committee hearings, arise from too many quarterbacks or too few?

THE New York International Color Slide Exhibit, planned as the first in a series of similar annual events, is announced by the New York Color Slide Club. Entries, up to four color slides, must be in by May 15. The exhibition will be held at the Central Needle Trades High School, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street, June 3 and 5.

Although the money supply -- demand deposits and currency in circulation -- was reduced nearly $2,000,000,000 in 1948, the first decline in ten years, production and delivery of new coins from United States Mints in the current fiscal year show no marked change in volume from the 1948 fiscal period, it was learned in an interview last week.

THE illustrations on this page are from "Jean Fouquet and His Time" by Paul Wescher (New York: Harcourt, Brace. $10). This book, containing ninety-five plates, six in full color, was printed in Switzerland. Wescher discusses simply, directly, sympathetically the man whom Elie Faure called "the father and master of French painting, the father and master of the great sober portrait."

THE veil of semi-secrecy which has long enshrouded the activities and doings of that actors' fraternity known as The Lambs is due to be raised with proper pomp and circumstance at 8:30 next Sunday evening.

IT is one of America's literary deficiencies that we have never produced an essayist-historian capable of such fine combinations of narrative and interpretation as J. A. Froude's "Short Studies on Great Subjects" or John Morley's political and historical papers -- not to mention the best of Macaulay's essays.

IT is a good rule, in bridge, not to make a takeout double unless you have considered each of the three suits in which your partner may respond and have decided that you can handle any response he makes.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 19 -- Army makes a practice o. dashing Villnova's hopes annually on the football field, but it's another story in basketball.
Another fight is brewing between commercial and savings bankers on the one hand and savings and loan associations on the other -- this time over safe deposit boxes -- it was learned last week.

MARK TWAIN, on a visit South in 1874, viewed the capitol at Baton Rouge as a "little sham castle"; saw every Southerner afflicted with "the Sir Walter disease"; and in exasperation with the whole stiff-necked, rebel race, wound up by putting the blame for the Civil War itself on the region's too-steady diet of Waverley Novels.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Canisius rolled- over Manhattan, 76 -- 52, tonight in the feature of a basketball double-header before 6,237 fans in Memorial Auditorium. The University of Buffalo outlasted Bucknell, 58 -- 50, in the opener.

On reading John E. Pfeiffer's review of Wiener's "Cybernetics" in your Jan. 23 issue I am moved to comment, since the impressionistic construction of the re view fails to note any point for criticism.

THE movies' public relations problems were considered among a number of other pressing trade matters at the recent board meeting of the Allied States Association of Motion Picture Exhibitors in Washington.

VIENNA, Feb. 19 -- The Austrian Ministry of the Interior protested today to the Russian occupation authorities against confiscation by Russian troops of 250,000 pieces of anti-Communist election propaganda belonging to the Austrian People's party and the temporary detention of two drivers who were transporting them to Linz, in the United States zone.
Warmer weather stimulated sales of spring ready-to-wear in department stores here last week, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

IN most cases making movies on location is surrounded with an aura of glamour. As far as Hollywood is concerned, it means the arrival of wagon loads of technicians, equipment and stars at some city, town or selected place in the great-outdoors.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 19 -- Through the agency of two undergrounds, one Russian and one Ukrainian, about 300 Soviet citizens are being smuggled monthly out of the Soviet Union itself and the Soviet zone of Germany.

Edna White, trumpeter, gave a recital at Carnegie Hall late yesterday afternoon, in which she was assisted by the Andrew Tietjen Chorus, Coenraad V. Bos, pianist, and Carleton Sprague Smith, commentator. Dr. Smith spoke at the intermission, and called this "the first real trumpet recital in New York."

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 19 -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican, of New York, told Republicans today that they could get out of the "political doghouse" by standing firmly behind the party's 1948 platform.

CZECHOSLOVAKIA'S stamp-issuing program for 1949 includes according postal honor to four Czechoslovak notables -- Julius Fuchik (1903-1943), Janko Jesensky (1873-1945), Jan Sverma (about 1900-1944) and Vladimir Vanchura (1891-1942). All will be newcomers to philately's gallery.
HENRY MORGAN is essaying the comeback trail in radio with a new comedy show which he will unveil for the first time on March 13 in the 8:30 to 9 P. M. spot on Sunday nights over NBC.

Buyers continued to shop summer ready-to-wear lines in the wholesale apparel market here last week, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

STUART, Fla. -- The usual calm of this little community between Palm Beach and Fort Pierce has given way to the excitement that always accompanies the annual sailfishing tournament. This is the sailfishing season and Stuart is the center for that sport. The tournament will run until May.

TOKYO, Feb. 19 -- The Japanese Democratic party, which occupied a dominant position in the coalition governments of 1947 and 1948 appeared virtually disintegrated today. A series of meetings among its members has failed to solve a split over party participation in the new conservative Cabinet of Premier Shigeru Yoshida.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Feb. 19 -- Breaking a 29-29 deadlock with five minutes of the first half remaining, Lafayette College's basketball team halted Lehigh University, 74 -- 69, tonight in Grace Hall.
Retail volume continued to decline here last week. Department store sales were estimated at about 9 per cent below the like week of 1948.

The fourth consecutive week of sales declines in comparison with figures of last year was suffered by New York department stores last week. In addition, sales for stores throughout the nation did little better, with declines during three of the last four weeks and the other week breaking even.

STRAVINSKY'S Mass, his first large liturgical work, is also his first Roman Catholic service. (Two earlier short choruses are for the Orthodox Greek Church.) It is scored for a choir of thirty male voices, fifteen boys and fifteen men, and ten wind instruments -- two oboes, an English horn, two bassoons, two trumpets and three trombones.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 19 -- Donald H. McLaughlin of New York and San Francisco has been appointed chairman of the National Committee of Sponsors of the Harvard Foundation for Advanced Study and Research, President James B. Conant of Harvard University announced today.

A new formula for setting prices on national defense production contracts has been developed, Col. L. A. Codd, executive secretary of the American Ordnance Association, Washington, D. C., disclosed yesterday in a statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES, following a meeting of the AOA executive committee in Washington.

The prediction that the building industry in the metropolitan area would be free of jurisdictional strikes regardless of the labor legislation passed by Congress was made yesterday by William G. Wheeler, secretary of the Building Trades Employers Association.

Replying yesterday to complaints of non-delivery of holiday food packages abroad, officials of CARE expressed regret at the delays and said current shipments were proceeding rapidly, but there was still a backlog of more than 15,000 parcels.

A citizen of the United States is ordinarily taxable by the Federal Government on all his income irrespective of where he resides. One of the exceptions to the rule is where the citizen establishes residence and is employed in a foreign country.

THE chief point made these days by scholars and writers who are examining the Sherwood Anderson Papers at their recently opened home in Chicago's Newberry Library is that their literary quality equals that of his novels.

ONE of the many reasons for taking great heart and hope from the new documentary, "The Quiet One," now at the Little Carnegie, is that this excellent little picture about a 10-year-old Negro "problem child" was made for comparative "peanuts" by a tiny outfit here in New York.

Carl Joyce, a young distance star who already has cut quite a swath for himself in open competition, easily stole the spotlight yesterday afternoon as he led Seton Hall Prep to its third straight victory in the prep school division of the National A. A. U. interscholastic track and field championships at Madison Square Garden.

Brotherhood Week, sponsored by the National Conference of Christians and Jews, begins today. The week will be marked by special services in churches, synagogues, programs over radio and television channels and other ceremonies. President Truman is honorary chairman of the observance.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- The sun broke symbolically through the overcast as the rebuilt Queen of Bermuda swung smoothly to her Front Street dock here last week on her first post-war sailing from New York.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 19 -- Deposits of feldspar, important mineral constituent of pottery and other ceramic products, have been located in the mountainous regions of New Jersey, it was announced today by the bureau of mineral research at Rutgers University.

DES MOINES, Feb. 19 -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan said today that his department's recommendations for a farm program would be ready for Congress within thirty days. He indicated that the broad field of agriculture would be covered.

BUENOS AIRES -- From New York to Montreal by train, and thence by cargo boat to Argentina has taken me thirty-one days. Generally, from New York the trip takes twenty-three or twenty-four days. Thus can a wanderlust be indulged, using time as an alternate for money; for this means of seeing foreign countries is considerably cheaper.
TOKYO, Feb. 19 -- Three and a half years after the surrender the occupation of Japan has moved into a new phase that will shape the nation's destiny for a considerable period.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- An exhaustive analysis of world trends in 1948 proves that the course of the "cold war" has by no means been favorable to the Western democracies, according to the findings of the International Committee for the Study of European Questions.

H. Malcolm Owen and Robert M. Ingle Jr., of the Department of Wild Life and Fisheries, and Charles R. Maduell Jr., an electronic engineer, have invented an instrument which they call an ostreodynamometer and which they describe in Science. The instrument tells electronically what goes on inside an oyster's shell when it is tightly closed.

Columbia's athletes went victoryless for the second consecutive Saturday afternoon yesterday at the University Hall gym, bowing to Syracuse in swimming, 47 -- 28, and to Cornell in wrestling, 28 -- 7 and in fencing, 17 -- 10.

From Baltimore last week came the news that Drs. Leslie N. Gay and Paul Carliner of Johns Hopkins had discovered that dramamine (trade name for betadimethylaminoethyl benzohydryl ether 8-chlorotheophyllinate) prevents and cures seasickness. The discovery was made as the result of an accident.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Extolling the proposed Atlantic pact in a speech before a large trade union audience today, Foreign Secretary Bevin prophesied that there would be "no war for hundreds of years" provided the Western democracies and "other peace-loving nations" coordinated their defense efforts.

Florida farmers are planting watermelons and harvesting cabbage, and the shrimp fishermen say the winter has been too warm for their trade. Hibiscus are in bloom, and so are petunias and nasturtiums, which some fervid folk consider Nawthern weeds. But it's the rare menu that offers anything but frozen peas, and the string bean is nowhere in sight.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Grains slumped on the Board of Trade today. Corn met the most selling. The yellow cereal was off a couple of cents a bushel at times and showed little rallying ability. Soy beans also dropped a few cents under persistent selling and a lack of demand.

HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 19 -- Princeton's quintet put down a thrilling fourth-quarter Dartmouth rally and emerged triumphant, 44 -- 39, in a nip-and-tuck basketball battle tonight before 2,500 fans in the Alumni Gymnasium.

ATLANTA, Feb. 19 -- While the Ku Klux Klan continued to burn crosses and parade in a number of communities in the Southeast, two actions this week emphasized the mounting opposition to the activities of the hooded order.

Critics of the New York State Commission Against Discrimination charged yesterday that too few cases are being handled to justify the salaries and upkeep of the commission. The charges were made by persons active in the formation of the Committee to Support the Ives-Quinn Act.

Now that an American sub-committee of the International Penal and Penitentiary Commission has been named, it is fitting that both this committee and the Commission itself should be headed by an American who has done as much as anyone in our time to advance penology.
ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 19 -- Columbia tightened its hold on second place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League by defeating Cornell, 58 -- 50, before 7,500 spectators tonight.

William M. Leiserson's analogy (in "For a New Labor Law -- A Basic Analysis") between a husband-wife squabble and a labor-management issue is poorly based. Husband and wife have a community of interest involving some mutually beneficial family or household objective.

AS with any small boy, life on a ranch suited city-bred Peter exactly. In this picture book 4 to 7 year olds can experience vicariously all the pleasures of setting up a home in the Western hills. They will share Peter's yearning to ride herd with his father and will watch with joy as Peter tames a wild pony into a faithful companion.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- Apartment dwellers and tenants of residential hotels in cities throughout this region this week paid considerable attention to the rent-control hearings before the House Banking and Currency Committee in Washington.

THIS is an exciting city. Many of its more colorful sections are off-limits to Americans. But those who have dug deep enough have found an overwhelming production of musicals and an unexpected Japanese craving for entertainment.

GREAT interest has been shown recently in the writing of South Africans. South Africans themselves have never shown livelier interest in their own problems and books. We probably write less frankly about our own affairs than do citizens of more mature countries.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Western lumbermen were warned today that the Administration has made the lumber industry one of its first targets in an effort to impose a "regimented welfare state" on the country.

Only a single project of the thirty-five operated by the New York City Housing Authority was without maintenance men yesterday as the walkout of firemen, repairmen, laborers and porters passed its second uneventful day.

A fast-breaking group of Boston Celtics outran and outscored the New York Knickerbockers, 87 -- 77, in a Basketball Association of America encounter at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night. The defeat jeopardized New York's second-place standing in the Eastern Division.

HARD as nails, this novel is built around the murder of Delight Dawson, wife of a labor leader in the Pacific Northwest. Although the style is post-Hammett, the material is somewhat old fashioned, as witness the well-worn local newspaper editor, the many references to the Wobblies and the home grown capitalist who is trying to frame the labor leader.

The National Sportsmen's Show opened to a capacity crowd yesterday. When the doors of Grand Central Palace swung wide at noon, the line of waiting sportsmen extended from Lexington to Park Avenues and up Park to Forty-seventh Street, proving that the exposition was as popular as ever with outdoor enthusiasts.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 19 -- Coach Bob Giegengack's Yale track team swept to a 77-32 victory over Harvard today, winning nine of the thirteen indoor events.

A payroll tax of 8 per cent, including employe contributions of not more than 3 per cent, is recommended by the Liberal party as part of its program for domestic legislation presented to members of both houses of Congress, the party's state committee announced yesterday.

Shortage of machinery and industrial equipment to meet the needs both of its rapidly expanding domestic economy and of its satellites is the central problem of Soviet foreign trade today, study of recently released information indicates.

BOSTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Miss Janet Morgan of Surrey headed a British Victory parade today in winning the Women's United States Squash championship with a 15 -- 12, 18- 17, 15 -- 3 triumph over Miss Peggy Howe of New Haven, Conn.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 19 -- Ch. Mazelaine's Zazarac Brandy, the boxer that became dog of the year by taking Westminster earlier in the week, followed up by winning best in show in the twentieth and biggest all-breed event of the First Company Governor's Foot Guard A. A. tonight.

THE promise of a job with "no questions asked" lures Jim Pryce, a deserter from the British Army, away from Italy, where he has been comparatively safe, and back to his native Cornwall. He takes passage on a freight steamer and is smuggled ashore at a point near the place where he was born.

NANKING, Feb. 19 (UP) -- Acting President Li Tsung-jen is prepared to negotiate directly with the communist leader Mao Tze-tung, it was reported tonight, but authoritative sources said that retired Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek retained a veto power over any peace talks.

FOR THIS WEEK: Look over coldframes and hotbeds to be sure that sashes are ready for spring. . . Don't start seeds too early indoors. House temperatures are fine for germination but not for growing-on evenly. Six to eight weeks before outdoor transplanting is usually time enough. . . Make cuttings of bouvardia for flowering plants next winter. . .

THIS year, for the first time since the end of the war, the upholstery leather tanners can say without hedging: "Leather is now available." Even if no one had mentioned it, the fact ought to be clear enough from the profusion of leather coverings to be seen on the newest chairs, tables, desks, dressing tables, serving tables and even headboards for beds.

FROM the Metropolitan Opera Guild, which has assumed the main burden of raising the $250,000 asked as a public contribution to balance the Metropolitan Opera Association's budget through the season of 1949-50 and provide opportunity for the study of its financial and organizational problems in following years, comes the formal appeal to John Q. Citizen for aid.
NANKING, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The "retired" Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek was reported today to be throwing his weight back into the muddled affairs of the Chinese Government.

The Berlin Airlift achieved its millionth ton on Friday, in a little less than eight months of operation, when a British plane landed at Gatow Airport. Visibility at the time was a quarter of a mile. Skill and courage as well as hard work on the part of our own and allied fliers have gone into this tremendous enterprise.

BUTLIN'S Bahamas Vacation Village, now building on Grand Bahama Island in the Bahamas group off Florida's east coast, will offer American tourists early next year a close-to-home holiday along the lines of the Butlin holiday camps so popular in England.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 19 -- President Peron, while addressing an audience of 5,000 at an open air theatre last night, ridiculed the idea that he was contemplating asking for a foreign loan.

Walter E. Meyer, in "Teaching Today's History -- A Vital Task," contends that the weekly current events hour in high school history classes is usually treated as a playful interlude, isolated from the subject-matter.

In the past four national elections the Republican party fumbled about for a national leader and then abandoned him to fumble about in search of a sufficient number of constituents. The party did not present a firm position upon any vital domestic issue. It offered nothing more than the means to vote against the Democratic party.

" The Emperor's New Clothes," a new children's opera by Douglas Moore, was presented in concert form at Carnegie Hall yesterday morning with a spirit which had at least one young listener dancing in the aisle. The work was part of a Philharmonic-Symphony Young People's Concert, conducted by Walter Hendl.

To broaden the knowledge of students who are specializing in particular subjects, Bennington College's workshop program, already used in music, drama and the dance, will be expanded next month to include the social sciences.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 19 -- Usually well-informed sources said today that Hungary's Roman Catholic Bishops had considered and reserved decision on a letter from the imprisoned Joseph Car dinal Mindszenty urging "an agreement" with the Communist-led Government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Nathan P. Feinsinger, teacher and mediator, advised the Senate Labor Committee today that if conditions of private employment were to be fixed by law, as Congress had started to do in the Taft-Hartley Act, workers logically would press for new legal rights in their jobs that supporters of the law had never thought about.

RHODES, Feb. 19 -- A new element of delay entered the Egyptian-Israeli armistice negotiations here tonight when it was confirmed that the Egyptians would send the latest compromise proposal to Cairo for study before discussing it.
RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 19 -- Problems of liquor and labor held wide interest this week in the Upper South, along with political developments.
HAMILTON, N. Y., Feb. 19 -- After trailing most of the way, Colgate's basketball team put on a second half spurt to defeat Syracuse, 71--67, tonight.

Racial and religious prejudices both in the home and in school were attacked yesterday by a panel of six junior high school students on the weekly Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over WQXR.
OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 19 -- Attempts by Missourians to whet interest in two major projects received close attention this week throughout the Middle West.
OSLO, Norway, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Norway's Labor party gave its Government the go-ahead signal tonight to join the proposed North Atlantic alliance talks. The vote, taken at a convention, was 330 to 35.
LONDON, Feb. 19 (U.P.) -- A wave of upset defeats hit powerful Portsmouth and its three closest pursuers in the first division of the English Football League today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 19 -- Israel is reducing her army to peacetime standards, but at the same time she is still establishing a formidable periphery of settlement "forts" that will make this country one of the best defended in the world.
TORONTO, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Little Max Bentley scored twice to lead the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 5-2 triumph over the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game tonight.

IN last Sunday's column I used the critical reception accorded "The Grand Design," by John Dos Passos, as an example of one of the difficulties confronting the writer today: the tendency of reviewers to praise or condemn his work for irrelevant reasons.
PRUNING as well as choice of varieties plays an important part in the adaptation of plants to their surroundings. Many a woody plant becomes a garden asset, as a result of spring pruning.

TOMORROW evening will see the opening of what has come to be known as the spring season, despite the fact that spring will not be along officially for another month or so. At any rate, the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo gets its engagement under way at the City Center.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 19 -- It was "1" and "1A" on the Hialeah Park result board after the running of the McLennan Handicap before the season's record crowd of 21,297 today. For Warren Wright's Calumet Farm made a one, two hit, Coal-town giving another flawless performance to win it and Faultless being his closest pursuer at the end of the mile and an eighth.

DENNIS KING, one of the first actors of major stature to devote himself almost exclusively to television, is a hundred per cent sold on the fact that television is a boon to actors and the acting profession.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Franchised dealers in new automobiles were held by the National Labor Relations Board today to come under the provisions of the Taft-Hartley Labor-Management Relations Act.
WASHINGTON -- An effort has been launched in Congress to extend the validity of passports. For more than three-quarters of a century passports have been limited to two years, plus a single renewal.

The decline in prices in recent months has been variously defined. Business spokesmen have called it the beginning of a post-war deflation which could lead to a depression. Government spokesmen have called it a loop in a strong inflationary cycle.
A second-half scoring spree enabled New York University's basketball team to pull away from Rutgers at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory and win by 82 to 65 yesterday afternoon.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Feb. 19 (UP) -Paraguayan armed forces issued a manifesto today voicing their desire to have Provisional President Gen. Raimundo Rolon elected for the next constitutional term. General Rolon took over the Government Jan. 31 after a bloodless "palace coup" had overthrown President Natalicio Gonzalez. He has caUed Presidential and Congressional elections for April 17.
Sportsmen's Show sidelights.
Apropos of the discussion in your Letters column about ending sentences with prepositions, you might be interested in the following quotations from Shakespeare:

It is an axiom of wide acceptance that an honest confession is good for the soul. The Army Public Relations Department's announcement that the release last week of a report on the pre-Pearl Harbor Communist spy ring in Japan violated Army policy and American tradition appears to fall in that category.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 19 -- The Republic of Indonesia "Emergency Government," taking note of asserted military successes against the Dutch, now demands a return to the Cheribon Agreement of 1947 rather than the United Nations Security Council resolution of Jan. 28, 1949, as a basis of a settlement, the Indonesian Republic's office here announced today.

SUPPOSE you want the family car for a date, or want to buy a new dress, and your parents say "No." What do you do then? Have a temper tantrum? Pout? Get depressed and feel sorry for yourself? Or get sick at the stomach and have to go to bed? These are ways of behaving that may creep up on us in childhood and become fixed habits if we don't watch out.

The substantial increases in rates granted to the railroads in the past two-and-a-half years by the Interstate Commerce Commission to compensate for increased costs have failed to provide the carriers with the additional revenue needed to keep them in a strong fiscal position.

A SELECTION of gladiolus for the garden, show table or hobbyist's collection, may be started with those that have been around long enough to be in good supply. More promising new varieties may be added as they come along, or as they drop year by year into the popular price range.

We have to take with a grain of salt the report from Frankfort, Germany, last week which told of some synthetic foods developed by the Economic Cooperation Administration for hungry Germans in particular and middle Europeans in general.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 19 -- A purported confession from Vassil Ziapkov, leading figure among the fifteen Bulgarian Evangelical churchmen who are charged with espionage and black market currency dealings was published here today.
The Redmaur Laundromat, 205 Second Avenue, is usually closed on Sunday. Yesterday it was wide open, filled with neighbors soaking up culture.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee will end its hearings on labor legislation Wednesday. Today a 2,500-word letter from Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, was received by the committee chairman, Senator Elbert Thomas.

ROME, Feb. 20 -- Discussion of the Atlantic Pact revives in Europe all the old questions regarding the attitude of the United States, but not to the extent the Government spokesmen and newspaper commentators imply. The ordinary European does not take too seriously the Senate opposition to including an automatic war clause in the proposed treaty.
A 50 per cent reduction in the number of tickets allotted to the Sullivan-Tyson agency for attractions in Shubert theatres has been decreed by the Shubert office.

With the help of a pair of shoddy goals, the New York Rangers defeated the Montreal Canadiens in their National Hockey League game at Madison Square. Garden last night. The local crew, trailing until well past the half-way mark, suddenly came to life to send the Northern visitors down to a 3 to 2 defeat while a crowd of 15,178 fans looked on.

Opposing adoption of a permanent registration system, the committee on law reform of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York made public yesterday a report urging the Legislature to retain the present voting law requiring annual personal registration in communities of 5,000 or more population.
Bishop Emeritus Francis J. McConnell of the New York area of the Methodist Church declared yesterday that it was about time that the American churchgoers began "thinking in Marshall Plan terms."

The Gotham Trading Corporation, which took title to the seven - story apartment house on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 58-60 East Ninety-fourth Street last month, has resold the property to Donald M. Hyman Co., owner of the adjoining realty at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street and now controlling a plot of 14,500 square feet.

STE. AGATHE, Que., Feb. 20 -- The popular Laurentians of eastern Canada, overrun with skiing enthusiasts from the Dominion and the United States this holiday week-end, tonight was making "all-out" preparations to welcome a visiting French ski team, the first to compete officially in North America, due to arrive in Montreal tomorrow or Tuesday.

The Rev. Dr. John W. Woodside of Ottawa, president of the Canadian Council of Churches, attributed yesterday much of the pessimism and melancholy in the world to "those who have too much money and too little to do." He added, in a sermon at St. Nicholas Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue at Forty-eighth Street, that the cure was hard work and responsibility.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Feb. 20 -- In a shifting but light northerly breeze, Pat O'Gorman, that sailor throughout the four seasons of the year, won the Interclub Class racing today at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

The Sun Oil Company reported yesterday for 1948 a record consolidated net income of $42,853,839 after charges, taxes and provision of $7,000,000 for accelerated depreciation of facilities. After dividend requirements on the preferred stock, this was equal to $8.61 each on the 4,928,597 common shares outstanding at the year-end.

SOON after war broke out on September 3, 1939, the German Admiralty, as we have learnt from their captured archives, began their staff study of the invasion of Britain. Unlike us, they had no doubt that the only way was across the narrow waters of the English Channel. They never considered any other alternative. If we had known this it would have been an important relief.

Retailers throughout the country said last week that sales were holding up well, especially in the medium and popular price merchandise brackets, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

The present "Fabian" phase of American policy toward China is founded upon the assumption that Mao Tze-tung's Communist movement has a strong nationalist bias and that it fought for ten years first against the Japanese and then against the Chiang Kai-shek regime as the "agent of American imperialism," for nationalistic reasons.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- The break in American stock and commodity prices continues to be the dominating influence in the London Stock Markets. It follows, therefore, that the somewhat calmer feeling now being displayed by Wall Street should have found its reflection here and that the markets closed the week with a more confident feeling than that with which they started it.
All but thirteen of the 134 maintenance employes scheduled to work at projects of the New York Housing Authority reported for duty yesterday, the third day of a walkout to protest city wage policies.

Continued activity by the Security Bureau, Inc., has resulted in re-introduction of legislation to require the fingerprinting of all watchmen on the New York waterfront, according to a report yesterday by E. E. Conroy, executive vice president of the bureau.
AMSTERDAM, Feb. 20 -- In the last two weeks the Stock Exchange showed an almost continuous recession until Thursday, when a sudden rally set in.

Leo R. Gilleran, controller of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., has been elected treasurer of Encyclopaedia Brittanica, Inc. and its affiliated company, Encyclopaedia Brittanica Films, Inc. He succeeds L. R. Raemer, who has resigned.

John Knight, young Canadian pianist with a bright future, made his United States debut in a recital at Times Hall yesterday afternoon. His intent bearing held the audience in breathless silence and he filled his playing with delicate, but sharply delineated musical shapes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Committee for the Nation's Health declared today that the American Medical Association was trying to hide its opposition to national health insurance behind "a fancy press-relations job."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, threw his support today behind a strong North Atlantic security pact that would pledge United States aid to Western Europe in case of attack.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 20 (AP) -- California racing fans were hoping today that they had a horse which could win both the Santa Anita Derby and the grand old race of them all, the Kentucky Derby.

New York University's observance of Negro History Week will begin today with a program of Negro spirituals and an exhibit of portraits. Various events will be held in the week in La Guardia Hall, student lounge at the School of Education.

From Geneva, where a twenty-five-nation committee of the United Nations Economic Commission has been sitting, comes what seems to be a cautious admission by Russia that under some conditions and to a certain extent the economic facts of life are stronger than politics.

When New York's tall buildings soar upward against a clear blue sky, a keen wind sweeps down the Avenue and the sunshine descends steeply at midday, it is a wonderful time to take a walk, enjoy the spectacle and look for changes in the familiar scene.

The audience assembled yesterday afternoon in Town Hall had to thank the New Friends of Music for a rarely finished and perceptive interpretation of Arnold Schoenberg's "Pierrot Lunaire," after the poetry of Albert Giraud.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- A sharp increase in expenditures and a new high in revenues were the chief features of state government finances during fiscal 1948, according. to a report issued today by the Census Bureau of the Department of Commerce.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Feb. 18 (Delayed) -- More than 300 flights over or close to the North Pole and 2,720,000 miles of flying through Arctic weather are the records of two of the Air Force's most experienced Alaskan squadrons which are based at Ladd Air Force Base here.

A reorganization plan for Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation, designed to separate its theatre operating business from production and distribution, is now being mailed to stockholders, the company announced yesterday. The plan arises from the recent decision of the United States Supreme Court in the so-called "Paramount Pictures case," which has been before the courts more than ten years and in which RKO and other principal companies in the industry were defendants.

The wave of religious persecution that first swept through Soviet Russia, then spread to Nazi Germany and is now inundating the Soviet satellite states, has finally brought to a head what is the fundamental conflict of our age. That conflict, which in the political and economic fields has been obscured by conflicting ideologies, is not, as some see it, a convict between Communism and the Roman Catholic Church alone.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 20 (UP) -- The Sailors Union of the Pacific, AFL, announced yesterday that it would meet with the National Maritime Union, CIO, which has contracts on the east coast, to discuss the effective working out of a joint national labor program for American seamen.

Fashionable and functional, the short coat seems certain to become one of spring's important styles. Originally classified as an extra jacket, the topper has developed a versatility that makes it the choice of many women who buy a single spring coat.

BERLIN, Feb. 20 -- A demonstration against alleged anti-Semitism in the British film, "Oliver Twist," forced its withdrawal from tonight's program in a British sector movie theatre and raised bitter protests against any further showing of the picture here or in the British zone of occupation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 20 -- Gloria Swanson will go before the cameras next month in Paramount's "Sunset Boulevard" after an eight-year absence from the screen. In the picture, which will deal with contemporary Hollywood, Miss Swanson will play a star of the silent screen, thus depicting a character who is superficially similar to herself.
CHICAGO, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs capitalized on Chicago Black Hawks' shorthandedness tonight to take a 4-to-3 National Hockey League victory marked by rough play and injuries.

DANVILLE, Va., Feb. 20 (AP) -- Dan River Mills, Inc., today reported a 1948 net profit of $15,108,988, equal to $9.92 a common share, and record high net sales of $103,603,913. This compares with a 1947 net of $12,188,297, or $7.98 a share.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 20 -- The Standard Oil Company of Egypt, an affiliate of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, has decided, after twelve years in Egypt and the investment of about $12,500,000, to suspend operations until the Egyptian Government makes clear the policy framed under its law governing natural resources.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 20 -- A new American reputation in the culinary arts is being built up here.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 20 -- An imported pure-white miniature poodle, Ch. Snow Boy of Fircot, took best in show tonight in the twenty-seventh annual all-breed event of the Elm City Kennel Club. It was a 760-dog fixture, one of the best Elm City ever ran.

TEANECK, N. J., Feb. 20 -- The $9,000 remaining from the $25,000 raised in Teaneck through volunteer war salvage will be devoted to a monument to the seventy-nine dead of World War II, it was announced today. Sixteen thousand dollars was given to welfare agencies here, Alvin L. Gardner, chairman of the Teaneck Salvage Custodial Fund, reported.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- Grain markets ranged higher on the Board of Trade last week, but pit observers say most of the support came from professional interests rather than from operations against cash grain. The Government stepped up its buying of cash wheat to some extent, purchasing around 7,000,000 bushels during the week, but this proved ineffective as a major market influence, and the best prices were not maintained.

OMAHA, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Cold weather froze the flood threat in southeastern Nebraska today. Thousands of acres of farm land in Richardson County were under water as the overflowing Nemaha River began falling after the temperature dropped to 13 above zero.

The recommendation of the Judicial Council of the State of New York for easing calendar congestion in the Supreme Court by making temporary assignments of County Judges and Justices of the City Court to the higher body is one that deserves serious study by the Legislature.

EVANSTON, Ill., Feb. 20 -- The slight retardation in social maturity which is fairly common in the deaf child is more often a result of inadequate parental training than an inevitable consequence of deafness, according to Helmer R. Myklebust, Associate Professor of Audiology in the Northwestern University School of Speech.

Insurance in force with the Home Life Insurance Company of New York on Dec. 31 aggregated $780,024,409, compared with $731,182,772 a year before, James A. Fulton, president, announced in the company's annual report, to be published today.
Refusal to face the reality of fear is more dangerous than fear itself, the Roy. Robert J. McCracken declared yesterday morning in his sermon at the Riverside Church.

The performance of "Where's Charley?," with Ray Bolger, at the St. James Theatre on the afternoon of March 5 has been taken over as the fourteenth annual theatre benefit for Bonnie Brae Farm in Millington, N.
