J. The co-chairmen of the committee are Harry V. Osborne, head of the farm's board of managers, and Mrs. Wilfred J. Funk of Montclair, N. J., a member of the board.

The editorial "Housing and the Family" on Feb. 14 illustrates the "slow pace" of housing construction by reference to figures for New York City. According to these figures, only 16,725 units were added to the housing supply in New York City after deduction of demolitions and other losses.

A resolution urging that a single auditing service be made available to cover both the paid and unpaid portions of the circulation of business publications has been adopted by the board of directors of the National Industrial Advertisers Association, it was announced over the week-end by William A. Marsteller, president.

Introducing a further simplified form of report to stockholders, the $73,000,000 Florida Power Corporation will issue today a twenty-four-page illustrated report for 1948 that features four pages of "favorable" and "unfavorable" aspects of the year's operations.

The General Electric Company, the country's biggest electrical manufacturer, turned down yesterday a demand for a fourth-round wage increase for the United Electrical Radio and Machine Workers, CIO. The company also made clear its opposition to union demands for a shorter work-week and liberalized pension and welfare programs.

George McAneny, president of the American Scenic and Historic Preservation Society, said yesterday that Secretary of the Interior Julius A. Krug had notified Mayor O'Dwyer that the national park service would include in its budget estimates a request for funds for the repair and rehabilitation of Fort Clinton, the former aquarium, as soon as there was assurance that the property would be transferred to the United States.
RHODES, Feb. 20 (Reuters) -- An informed conference source said that some of the main points of the compromise were:

NANKING, Monday, Feb. 21 -- Reports filtering through the Communist news barrier today described thirteen Americans in the United States Consulate at Mukden as virtual prisoners under the Communist regime there. Mukden fell to the Communists last Oct. 30.

The nineteenth annual exhibition of newspaper typography sponsored by N. W. Ayer Son, Inc., will be held early in April at the Ayer Galleries in Philadelphia. All daily newspapers are invited to participate. The date of publication required for all entries will be chosen by lot from among the week day dates during the week of March 7.
The State Congress of Industrial Organizations threatened yesterday to go to court to establish the right of sick workers to obtain benefits under the state Unemployment Insurance Law.

The final round of the twenty-third annual Golden Gloves amateur boxing tournament will be held at Madison Square Garden tonight. A crowd of 18,000 fans is expected to attend. The program will include sixteen bouts, eight in the sub-novice class and eight in the open.
Evelyn Sade, who served as a Wac sergeant with the Army Air Forces for two years and three months during World War II, works just as hard today at being a veteran as she did in the service.

PARIS, Feb. 20 -- High French officials contended today there should be a meeting of the Foreign Ministers of the United States, Britain and France to agree on a common policy toward Germany for the three Western powers.

Although some factory workers have developed an intolerance for alcoholic drinks after exposure to fumes containing tetraethyl thiuram disulfide, a new physicians committee on alcoholism warned yesterday against public acceptance of the drug at this time.
Traffic over the Manhattan Bridge was halted for two hours early yesterday morning after two automobiles collided head-on in the bridge's center lane.
ROME, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Naples is going to get a dry dock that will take any ship in the world. It is 60 per cent financed through the European Recovery Program.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 20 -- It is believed here now that the recent decline in prices of scrap metal was a barometer of an easier steel market in the coming months.

Plans for a new one-story building for expansion were announced in connection with the purchase by Clarke's Saw and Machine Works of a plot at 657 - 59 McCarter Highway, Newark, N. J., from Andrew Martin of Spring Lake and Leo Marks of Newark, through Edwin C. Butler, broker.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 20 (UP) -- Bolivia was officially under a state of siege today after the Government announced that it had circumvented a plot to overthrow the present regime in a revolution scheduled for the early hours of this morning.

An attractive partita for Wind Quintet, by Irving Fine, was played for the first time here Saturday night at the concert given at Times Hall by the League of Composers in cooperation with the American Music Festival of station WNYC.

Dr. Chaim Weizmann, first President of Israel, urged yesterday united support by American Jews for the current nation-wide $250,000,000 campaign of the United Jewish Appeal. He called upon them to sink all differences to this end.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- The attempt of the State Board of Regents to have the direct administration of the thirty-two publicly supported state educational institutions put in its hands through proposed legislation has raised "the specter of dual control," according to Dr. Paul Klapper, president emeritus of Queens College and member of th Board of Trustees of the State University.

After forty-seven years of service Dr. Nelson Prentiss Mead has retired from City College. In an unprecedented testimonial of affection, hundreds of City College alumni gathered the other day to honor this beloved Professor of History. From 1938 to 1941 Dr. Mead served as Acting President of the college, but on his own request he returned to the classroom and the students.

The United Brewery Workers, CIO, defied yesterday threats by Dave Beck, executive vice president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, to "take over" the 7,000 New York members of the brewery union.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 20 -- The newspaper Politika reported yesterday that the Albanian people had been reduced to a near starvation diet of beans as a result of the abrogation of trade agreements with Yugoslavia that Albanian Communist leaders had ordered soon after the expulsion of Yugoslavia from the Communist Information Bureau.

Now that nearly all of the 1949 automobile models have made their bow, we can see that the engineering departments have been influenced to an encouraging extent by the requirements of the driving and riding public rather than by the dreams of the futuristic artist.

Price changes were mixed in the foreign exchange market last week, but the strength of the Canadian free dollar and the good demand for the pound sterling overshadowed the irregularity of the Mexican peso and the Holland guilder. Elsewhere, Swiss free franc continued dull, with insignificant changes in several South Americans.

BOSTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Donald Jacoby of Syracuse, N. Y., and Miss Sonya Klopfer of New York City today won the senior men's and women's divisions, respectively, in the twelfth annual Eastern figure skating championships.

THE more some novelists look at the world around them the more they seem to retreat into the cool privacy of their own minds. The case of Elizabeth Bowen is a good example. An Anglo-Irish aristocrat, a subtle and distinguished writer, Miss Bowen has preferred in most of her work to explore the secret places of the heart and to analyze the emotional conflicts of the sheltered life.

World peace is "the greatest miracle Our Lady of Lourdes could work and certainly the most desirable," the Most Rev. Pierre-Marie Theas, Roman Catholic Bishop of Tarbes and Lourdes, declared yesterday.

The cutter Half Moon, latest addition to the fleet of Coast Guard vessels assigned to weather patrol duty out of New York, will leave her pier at St. George, S. I., today at noon on her first voyage in the service.

Marina Koshetz, soprano, gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. Extra glamour was lent to the event by the fact that the youthful artist was accompanied at the piano by her mother, Nina Koshetz, vividly remembered by local music lovers for her remarkable accomplishments as a vocalist at her frequent appearances on the concert stage of this city during the Twenties and early Thirties.

Despite yeoman work by Odie Lowe, who came up with four goals, the plucky New York Rovers dropped a 6-5 decision to the front-running Ottawa Senators in a Quebec Senior Hockey League battle at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Federation of American Scientists urged the United Nations today to undertake supervision of the international distribution of "non-dangerous" radioactive isotopes for use in peaceful scientific research.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- No change was made last week in the Government's buying policy in corn, the bid price being the same as of late and for 14 per cent moisture grain, which elevator interests will not offer in volume as the damp grain on being dried to that low percentage of moisture will be so brittle as to make it hard to handle.

RED BANK, N. J., Feb. 20 -- John H. Stamm, rugged Spanish War veteran who saw action around Corregidor and Bataan nearly fifty years ago, is observing his seventy-fifth birthday this week by putting the final touches on what he calls his masterpiece as a crochet hobbyist.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Senator George, Democrat, of Georgia, held out an olive branch to Republican and business critics with a proposal today that Congress rewrite the Trade Agreements formula in the next two years.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 20 -- Many leading American educators today sharply attacked Mayor O'Dwyer of New York City for his "political interference" with the Board of Higher Education in its search for a Queens College president.
Six new film arrivals from Hollywood will open in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

The Mindszenty case continued as a leading topic of discussion from pulpits here yesterday, with several Protestant pastors affirming their shock at his trial but dissenting from the remedies pressed by leaders of the Roman Catholic Church.
A man posing as a musician on his way to a jam session got into a jam without music at the West 100th Street police station yesterday afternoon.

To a chemist a synthetic is one of the noblest works of man. The reason is that synthetic vitamins and hormones and synthetic perfumes, dyes and flavors cannot be distinguished from their natural counterparts. Most of our plastics are true synthetics that nature forgot to make.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- Constantin Tsaldaris, Greek Foreign Minister, arrived in London tonight for general consultation with Foreign Secretary Bevin and his advisers. When they meet tomorrow Mr. Bevin will probably hear for a second time in a week proposals of support from a Mediterranean political leader for a Mediterranean defense pact to supplement the projected North Atlantic alliance.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The acting Republican State Chairman, Jane E. Todd, accused the Democratic Chairman, Paul E. Fitzpatrick, tonight of making "reckless" and "wretchedly evil" statements in attacking Governor Dewey's fiscal program.

Accessories from Israel, made by European craftsmen who recently have settled in Tel Aviv, Haifa and Jerusalem, are in a new display at the Palestine Galleries of Arts and Crafts, 60 East Sixty-sixth Street. Several of the pieces, including a few religious items, are for sale.

HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 20 (AP) -- Johnny Palmer of Badin, N. C., with brilliant iron shots offsetting spotty putting, won the $10,000 Houston open golf tournament here today, finishing with 71, 67 for 272. Thirty-six holes were necessary today since rain washed out play on Friday.

The Anglo Norse, a whale-processing ship of 8,000 gross tons, is due in New York harbor Wednesday, with the largest sperm oil haul since World War II. The vessel, whose cargo is valued at $3,720,000, is returning from a nine-month expedition to the whaling grounds off the coast of Peru.
Sportsmen's Show sidelights.

"Gertrude Stein: Form and Intelligibility," critical evaluation by Rosalind S. Miller, a member of the English Department of Tufts College, has been scheduled for publication this season by The Exposition Press. It contains her earliest manuscripts, written in her schooldays at Radcliffe College, which relate her views of life to her theory of writing.

ATLANTA, Feb. 20 -- A broad and informal program of "liberal strategy" for the south in matters of domestic and foreign policy was agreed upon today for use in political action at the state and community level.

Reinald Werrenrath gave his first New York public recital in twelve years yesterday afternoon, but the baritone succeeded in making it more like a gathering of friends than a formal concert. He chose the small Carnegie Recital Hall for his reappearance, he talked about his selections with the audience and he introduced one of his pupils, Tom Donohue, as an assisting artist.

Tired of the Oriental and exotic fare of recent dinners, 128 members and guests of the Gourmet Society dined yesterday afternoon at the Caviar Restaurant, 18 East Forty-ninth Street, confining themselves to Continental and French dishes.
The article by Gladwin Hill on conditions on the Navajo Reservation prompts me to venture some suggestions of needs for the Indians as I observed them when I was on the reservation.
ISHPEMING, Mich., Feb. 20 (AP) -- Olympic star Joe Perrault of Ishpeming won the Class A competition today at the sixty-second annual tournament of the Ishpeming Ski Club at Suicide Hill.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- Faced with declining residential sales and growing resistance to high prices, members of the National Association of Home Builders today announced plans to stress the production this year of their so-called "economy" or minimum house throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Fourteen Washington lawyers and law school deans today denounced the recent trial of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty in Hungary as a "brazen attempt to prostitute the judicial process" for purposes of the Communist party.

Prices of cotton in the domestic market were mixed and nervous throughout the week as active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 26 to 39 points compared with net declines of 23 to 36 points in the week previous.
ROME, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The text of Pope Pius' address to Catholics in Rome today, in an unofficial translation, follows:

OSLO, Norway, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Hungary's Kornel Pajor closed with a rush today to capture the world speed skating championship as the United States' Ken Henry and John Werket finished fourth and fifth.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- The American Medical Association used figures ascribed to the Truman Administration today in an effort to demonstrate that the Government's proposal for medical care insurance would cost the nation more than $18,000,000,000 a year, "just as a starter."

Homemakers looking for inexpensive floor coverings can once again find some choice in color and design among printed enamel felt-base rugs, sometimes confused with linoleum. Several new patterns recently added by manufacturers are suitable for covering unsightly floors in living rooms of temporary apartments.

Seized with fear when a policeman whistled at him for "jumping" a red light, a 17-year-old boy driving his father's car sped for twenty blocks through midtown Manhattan streets last evening, halting only when three shots had been fired into the car by pursuing policemen.

Four police departments collaborated early yesterday morning in speeding a collapsible iron lung from Willard Parker Hospital at Sixteenth Street and the East River to Greenwich, Conn., in an effort to save the life of a 21-year-old Navy veteran.

The plans just announced by the Board of Education to intensify "teaching for democratic living" at all levels of the city's public school system should be particularly effective because they call for the vigorous practice of democracy in the schools themselves.
TOKYO, Feb. 10 -- Harder times may be ahead for the practitioners of Japan's traditional arts and sports -- expected to wither away after the occupation but actually enjoying a boom.

PARIS, Feb. 20 -- The discovery of a fabulously rich uranium lode was announced tonight by the semi-official French News Agency. Samples from the deposit, which is situated near Limoges in central France, have assayed at 20 per cent uranium, according to this report.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 20 -- The second of the fifteen Evangelical ministers charged with espionage, Yanko Ivanov of the Methodist church in Bulgaria, has confessed guilt, according to reports published here today. Vassil Ziapkov of the Congregational Church was reported yesterday to have confessed.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 20 -- This city is planning litigation for damages in civil court against opponents of the city's Union Station and grade separation program. The commission council voted this action by 3 to 1 after a suit filed by Dr. Joseph A. Lanasa and his attorney, Maurice Woulfe, caused the withdrawal of bids on the $15,000,000 program.
The Board of Education will begin today a sustained, long-range campaign to intensify "teaching for democratic living" on all levels of the city's public school system.

RHODES, Feb. 20 -- The Egyptian and Israeli armistice delegations, in a formal meeting today, approved the text of the compromise draft of Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine, which will be submitted to the Egyptian Government tomorrow.
STOCKHOLM, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Czechoslovakia won the world amateur ice hockey championship today, defeating Sweden, 3 -- 0, in the final round.

OBJECTION was made in this space yesterday to the present system of voting ball players into the diamond Hall of Fame at Cooperstown. The feeling here was that entrance requirements had been so eased the entire idea had been cheapened. Still being in a most objectionable mood -- and we really can be objectionable at times -- we want to weigh in with another protest.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UP) -- The Department of Labor plans to overhaul the cost-of-living index that is issued by its Bureau of Labor Statistics. It is proposed, according to a spokesman for the department, to make the index reflect more accurately the post-war buying habits of the average consumer in the United States.

The international racing that has spiced this indoor track season will continue next Saturday. The Intercollegiate A. A. A. A., whose twenty-eighth annual title meet is the next item on the spiked-shoe calendar, yesterday completed arrangements for a special mile race that will pit four swift European invaders against three American stars.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 20 (AP) -- Kentucky's top-ranking Wildcats will face an ancient nemesis -- The Florida Gators -- in the first round of the Southeastern Conference basketball tournament at Louisville on March 3.

DETROIT, Feb. 20 -- The Taft-Hartley Labor Law has caused only confusion in industrial relations and only its outright repeal can restore any semblance of order, Herbert J. Thatcher, general counsel of the American Federation of Labor, told the ninth annual convention of the National Lawyers Guild today.

Details for the Jackson Day Dinner broadcasts of President Truman and Vice President Alben Barkley were made known here over the week-end. The speeches, which will originate in Washington and San Francisco, will be carried over the major networks and most independent stations Thursday evening from 10:30 to 11 P.M.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 20 -- Growers and warehousemen here estimate that when the last basket of burley is sold, during the coming week, approximately 101,000,000 pounds of leaf will have passed under the auctioneer's gavel since the tobacco-selling season opened on Nov. 29.

PARIS, Feb. 20 -- The private French citizen today heard bits of good and unusual news: most of the remaining household commodities will be taken off rationing soon, and retail prices have dropped some 5 per cent in the last month.
Brotherhood Week opened yesterday with inter-faith observances throughout the nation and city.

Price declines in the food, clothing and shelter items that constitute the average American consumer's living costs have been moderate and spotty, correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES reported yesterday after surveys of market places variously over the country.

The season's final performances of Wagner's "Siegfried" and "Goetterdaemmerung" and Bizet's "Carmen" will be presented during the Metropolitan Opera Company's fourteenth week, beginning Feb. 28, it was announced yesterday.

A variety of new group exhibitions and one-man shows this week range in point of time from copies of Buddhist cave paintings dating from the China of Wei and Tang periods to recent work by well-known contemporary American and European artists.

ROME, Feb. 20 -- Speaking to an enormous crowd in St. Peter's Square shortly after noon today the Pope made it clear that no understanding or compromise was possible between the Catholic Church and atheistic communism.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- People were now fed up with tax increases, Governor Dewey was told tonight as he went into conference with 102 Republican legislators in an effort to quiet rumblings of revolt over the $168,200,000 in new taxation which he has proposed to finance a record $936,200,000 state budget.

HOUSTON, Texas, Feb. 20 -- Because of the movement of industries to the Gulf Coast area, industrial construction in the Southwest in 1949 will at least reach the high level, of 1948, it was forecast here today by C. W. Roberts, Southern district manager of the H. K. Ferguson Company, industrial engineer and building concern of Cleveland, New York and Houston.

Two plots comprising a total of ninety-two lots in Forest Hills Park, Queens, were-sold by Realty Associates, Inc., to Punia Marx, operators. One parcel of forty-six lots takes in most of the block bounded by Yellowstone Boulevard, Sixty-fourth Road, Sixty-fifth Avenue and Continental Avenue, with the exception of the stores on the latter.
GENEVA, Feb. 20 -- Czechoslovakia intends to charge the United State formally with violation of the Geneva Tariff Agreement, according to an authoritative Czechoslovak source here.

The pot of porridge shouldn't be put on the stove to cook till about ten minutes before breakfast is to be served. Probably this advice from the food marketing service of the New York State Colleges of Agriculture and Home Economics would shock our grandmothers, who were accustomed to cooking cereals half an hour or even overnight. There are sound nutritional reasons, though, for following the new method.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 20 -- Acting on evidence of an extensive plot for the sabotage of the railroads, the Indian authorities have arrested between 400 and 500 Communist leaders throughout the country, principally in Calcutta, Hyderabad and Madras, since yesterday.

Dmitri Shostakovich, the world-famous Russian composer, is scheduled to come to the United States next month as a member of the first important Soviet cultural and scientific group authorized by the Soviet Government to visit America in recent years, it was announced yesterday.
SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Art Devlin of Lake Placid, N. Y., scored 230.7 points today to win the Intermountain ski jumping tournament.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 20 -- An Israeli - Trans - Jordanian bilateral agreement exchanging 615 Israelis captured by the Arab Legion and the Iraqi Army for 4,800 Palestine Arabs and fifteen Trans-Jordanian Arab Legionnaires in Israeli prisoner camps went into operation today.

The concert version of Jacob Weinberg's "Hechalutz" was presented Saturday night at Carnegie Hall as an event in the ninth Festival of the Jewish Arts. The work, concerned with the experiences of pioneer workers in Palestine in the days after the first World War, was given in honor of Chaim Weizmann, president of Israel, and enlisted the services of 150 participants.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UP) -- There is plenty of room for more women scientists in the United States, according to the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- As the Senate Foreign Relations Committee appeared nearly ready to approve authorization for the full $5,800,000,000 requested by the Economic Cooperation Administration for foreign assistance next year, Senator Homer Capehart disclosed today he would seek to cut the amount in half.

Lotte Lehmann gave her first recital of the season yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. As usual, the eminent soprano attracted an audience that packed the house, with many listeners seated on the stage. Every offering was fervently received by her large following, and there was an uncommonly prolonged ovation for the artist when she appeared for the opening group of a program devoted to Lieder by Schubert and Wolf.

OSLO, Norway, Feb. 20 (UP) -- Labor party officials released the text of a resolution, adopted last night by a vote of 329 - to 35, which virtually assures that Norway will join the North Atlantic Security Pact despite Russian opposition.

Although mechanical baby sitters are not yet in the market, manufacturers of nursery equipment have recently introduced several ingenious products to help mothers take care of small fry with less work and more efficiency.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 20 -- Under American administration, the former Japanese-held, islands in the Pacific have made "gratifying" progress in the political, economic and social fields, the United States said today in its first annual report to the United Nations.

The Jordan L. Mott Estate sold the entire block bounded by Morris and Ryder Avenues, East 140th and 141st Streets, in the Mott Haven section of the Bronx, to Max Boritzer and Roy Magmuson in a deal negotiated by Joseph P. Day, Inc., and the Billings-Douglas Company, brokers.

SAN CARLOS DE BARILOCHE, Argentina, Feb. 20 -- Because of an underlying feeling that world conditions make this a bad time to remove basic travel controls, the United States has succeeded in writing into a resolution of the Third Inter-American Travel Congress a provision that makes impossible the use of a hemisphere "tourist card" for a passport.

Providing a real golden anniversary, sales and revenues of the Jewel Tea Company, Inc., for the first time last year exceeded one hundred and fifty million dollars, according to the annual report to be released today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr., Republican National Chairman, said today that the Soviet Union should decorate Senator Claude Pepper for his "newest efforts to follow the Moscow party-line by trying to create class differences in the United States."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Big fighting ships will begin moving from East Coast ports tomorrow for the Carribbean area to take part in the greatest peace-time maneuvers ever held by the Navy.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 20 (AP) -- Norway's Pert Hugsted gave a convincing display of his Olympic championship form today by soaring 195 feet to the Class A championship of the St. Psul winter carnival international ski-jumping tournament.
LONDON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- A boilermaker in Kansas City smacks home a half-dozen rivets in two minutes. It earns him a loaf of bread.

In a streamlined presentation ceremony at the New York Athletic Club yesterday, 18-year-old Robert Bruce Mathias received the 1948 James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy, annual award of the Amateur Athletic Union to the "amateur athlete who, by performance, example and good influence, did most to advance the cause of good sportsmanship."

Shirley, Trepel, Canadian born 'cellist, who is Gregor Piatigorsky's assistant at the Curtis Institute, was the artist late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. She was the second member of her family to make a New York debut in the hall's "Twilight" series, for her husband, Berl Senofsky, violinist, made his bow there at a similar concert two months ago.
Julian E. Parodi has been appointed export sales manager of the Whitehall Pharmacai division of the American Home Products Corporation.
Yesterday was social freedom day for the seven German women who arrived in this country on Saturday for a two-month study of the role of women in American democratic life.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period Feb. 12 to 18 are given in the appended tabulation:

Harvey O'Connor, in a letter published in your issue of Feb. 2, makes some remarks about oil prices and production which are a little hard for one familiar with the oil industry to accept without comment.

Sales of gas ranges and oil heating stoves by Sears, Roebuck Co. in 1949 will better those of last year despite declines last month, B. J. Weinberg, head buyer of this merchandise for the chain, predicted yesterday at a meeting of divisional and store managers in the Governor Clinton Hotel.

PARIS, Feb. 21 -- The Soviet Embassy officially demanded today that the French Government "immediately" turn over to it three Russians who had testified against the Moscow regime in the current libel hearings of Victor Kravchenko.
An American Federation of Labor union yesterday entered the already complex labor picture in the city's Department of Welfare.

Government taxation policies will have a bearing on whether the textile industry will continue its program of modernization started after the war, it was pointed out yesterday. Reimposition of the excess profits tax would bring about curtailment of many mill expansion programs, textile men said, which during the first six months of 1949 will show an increase over the corresponding period last year.

There is no conflict between the Federal Housing and Rent Act of 1948 and the city's Local Law 66, the Appellate Division, Second Department, ruled yesterday in denying landlords the right to withdraw apartments from the rental market.

Sole leather hides have declined six cents a pound, or more than 20 per cent since the first of the year, and represent the "only significant and substantial decline in raw material costs" during this period, John H. Patterson, economist of the National Shoe Manufacturers Asociation, reported yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 21 -- The United Nations Security Council shelved the Trieste case today after the Soviet Union decided not to press for a vote on its demand for the immediate appointment of a Governor for the Free Territory.

Monday-night boxing matches from the Philadelphia Arena will be carried over the Du Mont television network, starting next week. The telecast will start at 10 P. M. and will be visible to set owners within range of New York, Baltimore, Chicago, Cleveland, Detroit, Pittsburgh and Washington.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 21 -- Jane Cowl, who has ignored the screen, will make her motion-picture debut opposite Robert Montgomery, in "Come Be My Love" next month, it was learned today. The picture, which Montgomery is producing for his own company, Neptune, for release by Universal-International, will start March 10, and Miss Cowl will play the role of a society matron who is also a lawyer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Congressional Republicans are planning to spend five times as much as usual to finance campaign activities curing 1949 in a determined effort to win back control of the House and Senate in the 1950 elections.

A few days ago the Norwegian Foreign Minister, Halvard M. Lange, flew to this country to make certain inquiries regarding the proposed North Atlantic Pact and the conditions which would govern his country's entrance into it, if that course should be decided upon. Mr. Lange talked with Secretary Acheson. He visited London on his way home, and talked with Mr. Bevin.

TOKYO, Feb. 21 -- The revision of Japan's post-war Constitution as a result of the sweeping victory of Premier Shigeru Yoshida's party in last months' election is now again quickly coming to the fore here. Some of Premier Yoshida's supporters are urging that the revision be undertaken as a high-priority matter on the party's legislative program when the Diet meets again next month.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 21 -- Thirty police officials and Federal agents from places as distant as California arrived here today to try to determine whether Gerard Graham Dennis, the fabulous "Raffles" who ransacked country estates, was responsible for numerous unsolved burglaries throughout the nation.

The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York may cut a fine figure when it comes to computing longevity, but the facilities provided for its Sidewalk Superintendents Club seriously underestimated the initial curiosity of the average New Yorker.
CANTON, China, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Premier Sun Fo said today that it had not been decided whether he would return to Nanking with the Acting President, Gen. Li Tsung-jen.
The importance of the German reparations program to European recovery has been emphasized by the highest officials in the Government, including former Secretary of State Marshall.

In view of the internal authority and external reputation it once enjoyed, it is interesting to study the fate of the Spanish Communist party since the end of the Civil War and to review the latter-day careers of its leaders.

GENEVA, Feb. 21 -- The executive board of the United Nations World Health Organization decided today to make strongest representations to the Economic and Social Council and elsewhere to get recognition of the connection between health programs and programs for developing underdeveloped areas.

Laden with gaily colored souvenirs of Bahamas handicraft, 641 cruise passengers trooped happily off the Cunard White Star liner Mauretania when she arrived here yesterday after cutting short a scheduled eight-day cruise to Nassau and Havana because of engine trouble.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Despite a strengthening of Republican opposition to Governor Dewey's proposed $168,200,000 state tax increase, the Republican leadership in the Legislature decided tonight to press for an early vote on the tax bills and the Governor's $936,200,000 budget.

MONTREAL, Feb. 21 (Canadian Press) -- Count Jacques Duge de Bernonville, under sentence of death in France as an alleged wartime collaborator, today won his fight to remain in Canada as a political refugee.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 21 -- By the tip of his bobbing nose, in as exciting a finish as the meeting has produced, Greentree Stable's Blue Border won the best of the afternoon's races at Hialeah Park today and made amends for a Greentree flop at 2 to 5 in an earlier contest.

GENEVA, Feb. 16 -- In the three and a half years that have elapsed since the end of World War II civil strife, political persecution and minor international wars have produced as many, and by some measures more, displaced persons and refugees than were left by the great conflict.

As the last public hearing on the smoke control bill was held at City Hall yesterday, it became apparent that the first problem of the new agency would be to find a suitable director at $7,500 a year.
AUSTIN, Texas, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Anti-trust suits were filed against ten major oil companies in the ninety-eighth district today by Texas Attorney General Price Daniel.

DETROIT, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Kaiser-Frazer Corporation will increase its dealer discounts effective April 1, bringing them to a more competitive level. The company confirmed today that the new dealer discounts will range from 24 to 28 per cent. This is an increase of about 6 per cent in various models.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Feb. 21 -- Decrying discrimination in the admissions policies of some colleges, Sarah Gibson Blanding, president of Vassar College, in her 1947-48 report released here today, declared: "We rejoice that at Vassar our admissions system makes no distinction as to race, creed or color."

An enterprising young ensemble which calls itself Chamber Group "27" (the figure refers to the number of players) gathered under the baton of Saul Schechtman to give a concert in Carnegie Recital Hall last night. The soloist was Robert Starer, composer-pianist from Palestine, who played the first performance of his own Piano Concerto.

Arthur Krock has quoted me as saying that the Knowland resolution [to take up a new Senate closure rule at once] "was obviously a political attempt to embarrass the Democrats and start taking control. If the Republicans who voted for the motion will support the program (civil rights), then we shall deliver every single pledge made by both national conventions."

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 21 -- The United States told the United Nations Economic and Social Council here today, in the opening debate on world economy, that political fears and threats of aggression must vanish if the world was to get down to its real job of putting food on the table and roofs over people's heads.

Thousands of Bronx rush-hour subway passengers were delayed for an hour yesterday morning when a woman toppled to her death at 7:58 A. M. in front of a southbound IRT train at the Freeman Street station. The slow-down lasted until 9:01 A. M., when normal traffic was resumed.

The Playwrights Company, whose attraction, "Anne of the Thousand Days" is at the Shubert Theatre, took an open stand yesterday against the recent Shubert office decision to reduce by 50 per cent the number of tickets allotted to the Sullivan-Tyson agency for attractions in Shubert theatres.

BERLIN, Feb. 21 -- The Soviet Union through Lieut. Gen. G. S. Lukyanchenko, chief of staff of the Soviet Military Administration in Germany, tonight lodged a bitter protest against the American order for withdrawal of the Russian repatriation mission from the United States zone of occupation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The schoolhouse of the future should have smaller classes in larger classrooms, a commission of educators and architects said today.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended today totaled 640, compared with 1,610 last week and 551 in the similar week of last year, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There are no arrivals recorded today due to the holiday.

HAVANA, Feb. 21 -- Mayor William O'Dwyer of New York arrived here this morning aboard the freighter Agwiking for a brief visit. He was welcomed at the pier by the Mayor of Havana, Nicolas Castellanos, Dr. Pedro Rodriguez Capote, Chief of Protocol of the Ministry of State; American Ambassador Robert Butler and officials of the Army, Navy and police.
SYRACUSE, Feb. 21 -- The New York Milkshed Price Committee today recommended a new pricing formula for Class 1A (fluid) milk in the metropolitan area.

GEORGE WASHINGTON was an honorable man. If the Father of Our Country stirs uneasily in his grave on his birthday today, it merely will be because the sport (?) of wrestling is returning to the big time in Madison Square Garden. The one nice thing about rassling is that no one can libel it. Even the authorities resolutely refuse to permit matches to be billed as contests, which they are not.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and closing prices were 21 points higher to 2 points lower than on Saturday.

The State Banking Department has approved a group insurance plan for employes of savings and loan associations, it was announced yesterday. The plan, originally proposed last year by the New York State Savings and Loan League, is the first such arrangement to be established for savings and loan associations in this state.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Senator Wayne L. Morse, Republican, of Oregon, said today that the Senate Labor Committee hearings, which are about to close, had shown an "un-Christian attitude toward labor" on the part of many employers who testified.

If, as we like to think, providence brings a great man upon the stage when he is needed, then time, necessity and the man were surely joined in George Washington. He was, in a sense, three men: General Washington, President Washington, and as one of his many biographers has remarked, George Washington the man whom we still know only imperfectly.

Although the privately owned American merchant fleet increased by 213 vessels in the last year, 774 vessels under bareboat charter agreements were returned to the Maritime Commission with a resultant serious rise in unemployment among seamen.

DETROIT, Feb. 21 -- Spotty readjustments now causing a slight reduction in the cost of living do not indicate an economic collapse, Ewan Clague, Federal Commissioner of Labor Statistics, declared today in an address to the Economic Club of Detroit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- President Truman was quoted by a White House visitor today as saying the displaced persons problem could have been solved "overnight" if this country had agreed to admit 400,000 European refugees and if other countries had taken commensurate numbers.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 21 -- A school bond issue of $1,662,000 was sold today by the city of Elizabeth to C. J. Devine Co., Inc., of New York City and associates at an interest rate of 2.15 per cent. The successful bidders agreed to take $1,660,000 in bonds and to pay $1,662,188.54 in a transaction equal to a premium of $2,188.54.
LONDON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Prime Minister Clement Attlee was asked today to help Britain's limping movie industry.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Amendments to the State University Act which would strip the State University trustees of their administrative control over the existing thirty-one state institutions of higher learning were introduced tonight by Senator William F. Condon of Westchester and Assemblyman Elisha T. Barrett of Suffolk, both Republicans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- A proposal that the millions of church bells in all the free world be tolled simultaneously in condemnation of Communist "offenses against freedom of religion'' was made in the Senate today.
NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 21 (AP) -- Ships of the Atlantic Fleet sailed southward tonight to engage in the Navy's largest peacetime war games.
Traditional ceremonies honoring George Washington will be held here and elsewhere throughout the country today on the 217th anniversary of the birth of the first President.

War with Russia probably can be prevented if the Soviet Union is shown, through such an instrument as a North Atlantic Security Pact, that she would meet effective resistance, Sir Norman Angell, 1933 Nobel Peace Prize winner, declared here last evening.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 21 -- Members of the student body are protesting here the imminent dropping from the teaching staff of an English instructor who has been teaching on his own time what he describes as the only course in contemporary American literature at Princeton University.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Feb. 21 (AP) -- A portly 46-year-old salesman from Grand Rapids, Mich., calmly bowled into first place today with 709 in the singles event of the American Bowling Congress tournament.

WINTER PARK, Fla., Feb. 21 -- Rolllins College awarded the honorary degree of Doctor of Humanities to Mrs. Mary McLeod Bethune, one of the nation's leading Negroes, at its midwinter convocation today.

Joe DiMaggio received the Graham VicNamee Award as the n who contributed the most to sports during 1948 at the second nual dinner of the Sports Broadcasters' -Association at Ruppert's Brewery last night. Quentin Rey'nolds was the toastmaster and the presentation was made by Phil]ips Carlin, vice president of the 1VfuaI Broadcasting SysteL
A challenge to "practice what you preach" about erasing religious and racial prejudice was made yesterday by two public officials at ceremonies marking the second day of Brotherhood Week.

VIENNA, Feb. 21 -- From Hungarian refugees and from other sources in Hungary, evidence is accumulating that the Communist Information Bureau is laying plans to use that country as a jumping-off place for hostile operations against Yugoslavia.

Failure of elementary and secondary school textbooks to cope with the problem of intergroup relations has built up a distorted conception of the democratic way of life, Dr. Howard E. Wilson of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today authorized Trans-Pacific Airlines, Ltd., to operate a regular passenger and cargo service among the Hawaiian Islands.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 21 -- Ending the first leg of a 15,000-mile journey from Shanghai to the new State of Israel as, part of "Operation Freedom," 447 Jewish refugees came into port today on the liner General Gordon and prepared to board a "liberty train" for New York.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 21 -- The United States and British Military Governments today decreed a new German civil service law, spelling out an official's personal responsibility for his orders or official acts.

" We of the Americas," by Carlos Davila, former Ambassador from Chile to the United States and Chile's representative on the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations, is the only book published today. It is an analysis of inter-American relations from the American Revolution to the Bogota Conference in 1948.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UP) -- The Government adopted today a General Electric Company plan to use high-intensity lights to help pilots land at fog-bound airports.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- A legislative investigation of the New York City transit system, with particular emphasis on the reasons why new cars purchased for the subways have not been placed in service, was proposed tonight by Assemblyman William J. Drohan, Bronx Republican.

Development and modernization of agriculture in Brazil would go a long way toward making that nation prosperous, according to John Abbink, co-chairman of the Joint Brazil - United States Economic Mission that is preparing a report on the Brazilian economy.

Radio and television audience research can help advertisers and agencies use these media more effectively if used as "a tool, not a crutch," the radio clinic of the Advertising Club of New York was told at its meeting last night.
ROME, Feb. 21 -- A twenty-four-hour transport strike immobilized today all street cars and buses in Rome, Milan and other leading cities.

Coley Wallace retained his Golden Gloves heavyweight honors last night before a gathering of 18,533 amateur boxing followers in Madison Square Garden, and brought to the Salem-Crescent A. C. another victory in the tournament's team struggle.
A proposal to send a joint Anglo-American textile survey mission to Japan has been approved by three United States cotton industry associations.

About 170 of the 239 persons who participated on Saturday in the first half of the 4-A's annual examinations for advertising will take special knowledge tests in the second half, scheduled for Saturday, Feb. 26, at the Packard School, it was announced yesterday by the New York Council examination committee.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- The Bulgarian Government has ignored two British requests for information concerning charges against the fifteen Bulgarian Evangelical clergymen, who have been indicted on counts of espionage and black market currency deals, Hector McNeil, Minister of State, told the House of Commons today.
GLASGOW, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Malaya took a 3-1 lead over the United States today in the semi-finals of the Thomas Cup badminton matches.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 21 -- L. S. Buckmaster, president of the United Rubber Workers of America, CIO, today asked the union's policy committee to approve a 1949 bargaining program covering a fourth post-war round of wage increases, pensions, health and sickness insurance and a guaranteed annual wage.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The text of President Truman's message to Congress today concerning the Institute of Inter-American Affairs follows:

A good supply of French and Italian giftware for immediate delivery at wholesale prices 20 to 30 per cent below those of last year featured the opening yesterday of the thirty-sixth semi-annual New York Gift Show in the New Yorker and Statler Hotels.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Speaker Sam Rayburn and Senator Scott Lucas, Senate Majority Leader, defended, after a White House visit today, the progress of the Administration program in Congress against criticism that it was bogging down.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 21 (UP) -- The Cabinet of President Enrique Hertzog resigned today as the country remained in a state of siege after the discovery of a plot to overthrow the Government.

Lives of great men oft remind us that they were written by persons remote in time and perspective from the subjects of their biographies. Washington, garbed in the ermine of "first in war, first in peace and first in the hearts of his countrymen," serves as a case in point.
CHICAGO, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Robert (Red) Hamill, Chicago Black Hawks hockey player, was fined $250 today and suspended from his team's next game with the Toronto Maple Leafs.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 -- The 3,000 trolley cars, buses and the subway-elevated trains of the Philadelphia Transportation Company provided normal service today, while the system's 11,000 operating and maintenance personnel cast secret ballots to confirm terms that ended the ten-day transit tie-up.
DETROIT, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Paul Ronty's last period breakaway goal brought the Boston Bruins from behind tonight to gain a 2-2 tie with Detroit's National Hockey League leaders before 13,582 fans.

Weakness in the railroad issues yesterday undermined the stock market, which drifted to an irregularly lower level in the dullest session in four months. The closing of the markets today in observance of Washington's Birthday infused into the trading the usual pre-holiday caution and found most of the boardrooms deserted by active traders who took advantage of the holiday for a long week-end.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The announcement by Senator Lucas, the majority leader in his branch of Congress, that he intends periodically to interrupt the forthcoming debate on tightening the Senate's closure rule with a request for action on legislation with higher priority may postpone the debate before it really begins on the day appointed, Feb. 28.
Five diminutive women principals of Korean schools, here to observe American education practices, have come to the conclusion that "hugeness" is an American characteristic.
The Long Island Rail Road was described in a hearing in Flushing Magistrates Court yesterday as "a cold-blooded, heartless corporation" whose main interest was in making profits.

An investment banking syndicate headed by Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis placed on the market yesterday an issue of $3,000,000 of fifteen-year 4 1/2 per cent convertible sinking fund debentures of American Box Board Company at 100.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The National Labor Relations Board held unanimously today that the General Motors Corporation violated the Taft-Hartley Labor Law when it tried to institute a group insurance plan a year ago without consulting the union representing its 225,000 production workers.

Today is the 139th anniversary of the birth of Frederic Chopin, and various organizations are planning celebrations in commemoration of the event. The great French-Polish composer died Oct. 17 a century ago. Many of the events will fall between the two dates.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 21 -- Whether there will be an armistice with Egypt depends entirely upon the Egyptians, Foreign Minister Moshe Shertok said today. The Israelis have agreed along the lines discussed at Rhodes and it is now up to Cairo to make the decision, he said.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 -- Although many American producers may be affected adversely, exports and imports between the United States and Marshall-Plan countries must be brought into "rough balance" by July, 1952, Paul G. Hoffman, head of the Economic Cooperation Administration, declared tonight before 700 persons at the annual dinner of the Philadelphia Chamber of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Following is the text of the recommendations for the reorganization of the "Foreign Affairs" set-up of the Government submitted to Congress today by the Commission of Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government, Herbert Hoover, Chairman:

Unable to raise $15,000 bail, William P. Buckner, who was brought back here from Puerto Rico to face gambling charges arising from a so-called benefit party on Park Avenue last July 26, was held in the City Prison yesterday.

Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, assured Rockaway water users yesterday that the city would continue to provide ample supplies in that area, although the emergency water-well project had been abandoned.
LONDON, Feb. 21 -- The British Government proposed to Parliament today to spend 189,250,000 ($757,000,000) on the Royal Navy during the coming fiscal year.

OUR fate now depended upon victory in the air. The German leaders had recognised that all their plans for the invasion of Britain depended on winning air supremacy above the Channel and the chosen landing-places on our south coast. The preparation of the embarkation ports, the assembly of the transports, the mine-sweeping of the passages, and the laying of new minefields were impossible without protection from British air attack.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 -- New York City colleges swept both ends of a basketball double-header tonight, as New York University trounced Temple, 67 -- 55, and City College edged St. Joseph's, 68 -- 65. Only 4,543 spectators attended.

Preparations for the '49 baseball campaign started at Fordham yesterday as fifteen battery candidates reported to Coach Jack Coffey for the inaugural indoor drill. Coffey, who is marking his twenty-seventh year as Ram diamond mentor, announced practice for the full squad will begin March 1, when he expects to move the sessions outdoors.
SHANGHAI, Feb. 21 -- The President Fillmore, which her operators say is the first American ship to touch in Communist China, has arrived and is unloading off Tientsin.

Arpad Rosti, known for his lamps and ceramic accessories based on abstract sculptured forms, has branched out into furniture designing. Tables in wood, mosaic and copper are among his latest pieces, which went on display yesterday at the Chinese Gallery, Ltd., 38 East Fifty-seventh Street.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 21 -- French brakeman Henri Adan was seriously injured today while the Swiss Olympic championship team of Felix Endrich and Friedrich Waller smashed a pair of records in capturing the world two-man bobsled title on the Mount Van Hoevenberg run.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Sweeping proposals to expand the nation's social security system, carrying out President Truman's campaign promises, were placed before the Congress today.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The Sofia press reported today another of the fifteen Bulgarian Protestant church leaders accused of treason had confessed he was a spy for the United States and Britain.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Glen R. Bedenkapp, former chairman of the Republican State Committee, and Francis T. Mylott, of Jackson Heights, Queens, were appointed by Governor Dewey today to fill two of the three vacancies on the Public Service Commission.

Borough President Cornelius A. Hall of Richmond, who was elected on the Republican-American Labor party ticket three years ago, caused a stir in Staten Island last night by declaring that he would support Mayor O'Dwyer for re-election.

One of the things that make it particularly difficult for the public to appraise intelligently the recent declines in commodity prices is the confusion that seems to prevail among the President's own experts. The most important single contributor to this confusion, it seems to us, is John D. Clark of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.
LONDON, Feb. 21 -- Although business in the stock market here today was small, prices generally held up well.

Vincent R. Lapi, 60-year-old evangelist, of 280 Park Avenue, Harrison, N. Y., was held in $15,000 bail and his daughter, Rosemarie, 18, in $5,000 bail when they were arraigned yesterday before United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter on a charge of possessing counterfeit currency.

The Hoover Commission on the Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government has now made its report on the control and direction of American foreign policy. This report, thoroughly in keeping with the high standards set by the Commission in its previous surveys, carries twenty-one specific recommendations, affecting not only the State Department but every branch of the Government, including the Presidency and Congress.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall is preparing a reply to the protest from Agnes Smedley, New York writer, that an Army report falsely named her as a Communist agent.
SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Marvin Crawford of Steamboat Springs, Col., won the Class C division of the national ski jumping tournament today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The House overwhelmingly approved a bill today to relieve employers in the longshore, stevedoring, building and construction industries of the obligation to include premium rates in their calculation of overtime pay.

It is a measure of the forward-looking policies of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union that its Union Health Center in this city should be celebrating its thirty-fifth anniversary at a time when most unions are just entering the health field. The garment workers and the employers who have made possible a $3,500,000 expansion in the center's facilities are jointly deserving of the congratulations and the thanks of the community.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Life insurance companies will be exempt from Federal income tax for the second straight year as the result of a legal oddity, the Treasury announced today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- Edward R. Carr of Washington, D. C., former president of The National Association of Home Builders, charged today that expansion of public housing was the "real reason" behind stoppage of rental-housing construction in New York by banks and insurance companies.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- An increase in some postal rates was sought from Congress today by Postmaster General Jesse Donaldson.

The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation, in its annual report of operations issued to stockholders yesterday, revealed a net income of $5,433,143 after taxes and all charges, equal to $1.18 a share on 4,600,000 common shares outstanding. Gross revenues for the year totaled $32,729,240.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- After a talk with Foreign Secretary Bevin today, Greek Foreign Minister Constantine Tsaldaris said that he had found among Western European statesmen a full understanding of the desire of Greece and Turkey for a Mediterranean defense alliance to supplement the Atlantic Pact.

BIG DELTA, Alaska, Feb. 20 (Delayed) -- This isolated little post, where the temperatures drop to thirty or forty below zero and the winds work up to fifty miles an hour, is the site of the Army's arctic training center.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- Industrial life insurance companies, the "retail side" of insurance, with agents collecting premiums every week or month from door to door, have submitted their case against state ownership to the Labor Party Executive.

FENGSHAN, Formosa, Feb. 18 (Delayed) -- After two months as a prisoner in Communist "liberation" camps, Major Yu Man-ching has decided to string along with the Chinese Nationalists. He is one of more than 100 officers of the American-trained New First Army who have made their way back from Manchuria to rejoin their old commander, Gen. Sun Li-jen at his training camp here in southern Formosa.

It takes the average teen-ager more than thirteen hours to make a dress with set-in sleeves but, despite the time involved, 80 out of every 100 girls interviewed by the National Needlecraft Bureau said that if clothing prices went higher they would make even more clothes at home this year than they did last.

The projected sale of 73.84 acres by the Kensico Cemetery Corporation, operator of a nonsectarian burial ground at Valhalla, to another corporation for development of a Jewish burial ground was stayed yesterday by a ruling of the Appellate Division, Second Department.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 21 -- A long-range program of school building expansion, calling for twelve billion dollars over the next twelve years, was proposed here today at the regional conference of the American Association of School Administrators.

PARIS, Feb. 21 -- A widespread reorganization in the leadership of the major unions of the General Confederation of Labor has been undertaken in the past few weeks by the French Communist party in an attempt to strengthen its principal arm against the present regime.

BERLIN, Feb. 21 -- The moving picture "Oliver Twist" was withdrawn temporarily from circulation in Berlin tonight after a crowd of Jews protesting the film's alleged anti-Semitism had rioted outside a theatre in the British sector and halted the showing of the film for a second consecutive day.

BOSTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Holy Cross soundly thumped Boston College, 66 -- 48, and Boston University handed Harvard its fifteenth consecutive defeat of the season in a basketball double - header which drew a small crowd of 3,102 to Boston Arena tonight.

OSLO, Norway, Feb. 21 -- Foreign Minister Halvard M. Lange received assurances on his recent visit to Washington of sufficient deliveries of steel plate to complete Norway's merchant fleet reconstruction program now under way in British, Swedish and Danish yards.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 21 -- Borba, official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party, announced today that the Albalians had provoked numerous incidents on the Albanian-Yugoslav frontier since the Communist Information Bureau's action against Marshal Tito.

In a move to further its chances of carrying away the team championship, Michigan State College has decided to enter the fast-stepping Jack Dianetti in the mile run at the twenty-eighth annual Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. indoor track and field games at Madison Square Garden Saturday night, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- President Truman today sent a message to Congress asking extension of the life and enlargement of the scope of the Institute of Inter-American Affairs.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Doubling of soft coal shipments to Marshall Plan countries was urged before Congress today on the basis of an indicated surplus in this country.
MUNICH, Germany, Feb. 21 -- Documents produced today in the trial of five persons charged with spying on the United States Army in Germany included a contention that an atomic bomb was "lost."

Your very interesting editorial on "Test for Cancer" in THE TIMES of Feb. 5 brings to mind some experiments relating to that subject made some years ago by a friend of mine, Dr. Arnold J. Gelarie of New York City. In these, he used fertile hen's eggs which he attempted to hatch after injecting them with blood serum taken from various individuals, some normal and some pathological.

TOKYO, Feb. 21 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Charles Willoughby, chief United States intelligence officer in the Far East, today accepted full responsibility for the Sorge report and said he would welcome libel suits by persons it named as prewar Soviet spies in Japan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The Senate passed and sent to the House today a resolution authorizing an appropriation of $16,000,000 to help an estimated 720,000 refugees, most of them Arabs, from the recent hostilities in Palestine.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- An inquiry into the operations of the Marshall Plan's oil program was undertaken suddenly by the House Committee on Foreign Affairs today after an attorney for the Independent Petroleum Association of America, L. Dan Jones, had made charges as follows:

An "unofficial" slow-down against the Railway Express Agency was started yesterday by the Brotherhood of Railway and Steamship Clerks, AFL, in a protest against alleged stalling tactics by the management at wage talks in Chicago.

Coffee futures declined substantially yesterday in light trading. Under scattered trade and commission house selling along with some liquidation in the March delivery, the contract "D" closed 30 to 56 points below Friday's finish. The spot month was the weakest. Sales amounted to 8,500 bags. Contract "S" closed 20 to 40 points net lower on sales of 7,500 bags.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Expansion of the National Guard and reserve branches of the Army was called for tonight by a civilian-military study committee headed by James F. Byrnes, former Secretary of State.

The United Palestine Appeal was directed yesterday to implement immediately a decision of fifty-five members of its board of directors for the return of Henry Morgenthau Jr., former Secretary of the Treasury, and Henry Montor to the leadership of the 1949 United Jewish Appeal campaign for $250,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- President Truman will seek new authority to transfer non-surplus military equipment to Western Europe and other areas overseas under the terms of a world arms bill now being written in the State Department.

Today Florida has a birthday. On Feb. 22, 1819, papers were signed in Washington by which Spain sold Florida to the United States for the sum of $5,000,000. This sum was used to satisfy claims of United States citizens against Spain -- claims incurred during clashes between Spanish officials and turbulent American pioneers who had actually conquered Florida by colonization.

Since sameness is a quality which apparently strikes no terror to the heart of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, it is perhaps not surprising that it opened its spring season at the City Center last night with exactly the same program that opened its fall season at the Metropolitan Opera House last September.

The stages of a concert performer's career have become fairly clearly marked by now, and after hearing Fredell Lack's recital last night at Town Hall one can say she has passed securely from the stage of talented young violinist to that of serious young artist.

A further effort to contain Communist influence in the building programs of European countries was cited yesterday as part of the agenda laid before a delegation of four leading American building trades representatives scheduled to take part in an international conference opening March 15 in Rome.

Several new products for home decorating and equipment will be exhibited in "Dream House II," the redecorated version of 'Mr. Blandings' Dream House," Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, when it reopens to the public at 11:15 A. M. Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, told Congress today that military pay scales needed broad revision and recalled that President Truman's budget proposed $400,000,000 in increases.

Business pessimism was attacked and continued high production predicted as some 1,700 representatives of the paper and pulp industry began their annual "Paper Week" meetings here yesterday. The gatherings marked the opening of the American Paper and Pulp Association's seventy-second annual convention, being held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in conjunction with those of affiliated organizations.
PARIS, Feb. 21 -- Frederick Joliot-Curie, France's Commissioner of Atomic Energy, announced today that France would henceforth be self-sufficient in atomic raw materials.

Three new films will arrive in midtown theatres today. The holiday attraction at the Astor is "Knock On Any Door," the first independent picture to be made by Santana Productions headed by and starring Humphrey Bogart. The melodrama, released by Columbia Pictures, was directed by Nicholas Ray and produced by Robert Lord from a screen play by Daniel Taradash and John Monks Jr. and the novel of the same name by Willard Motley.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Picketing to support a secondary boycott, even if it is "peaceful and uncoercive," is prohibited by the Taft- Hartley Labor Law, the National Labor Relations Board ruled today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The Senate Armed Services Committee today voted to recall Mon C. Wallgren before it to answer charges that he had been "soft" toward Communists.
Operations last year of Sunshine Biscuits, Inc., resulted in a net profit of $6,923,284, after taxes and all charges, according to the report issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The Hoover Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government called today for a vertical organization of the State Department that would give the Secretary a clear line of command from top to bottom.

Price declines of fine steaks and roasts have been headlined here and elsewhere in the paper. But other outs of beef also are cheaper -- as much as 8 cents a pound less in some instances than they were six weeks ago. Today's column plans to show how these economical, though less epicurean, selections may be prepared for middle-of-the-week service.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- Details of a last-minute attempt by Preston Tucker to capture control of the Tucker Corporation's new fifteen-man board of directors became known today as a Federal Grand Jury started a projected month-long investigation of the business practices of Mr. Tucker and the company.

Seventy heavyweight oarsmen, forming four varsity and three freshmen shells, started Columbia's outdoor crew season yesterday with a short row on the Harlem River. The Lions, coached by Walt Raney, had been practicing since early November in an indoor tank on the college campus.
The Kentucky Wildcats head down the homestretch of the college basketball season virtually assured of No. 1 ranking in The Associated Press poll of sportscasters and sports writers.

RHODES, Feb. 21 -- Trans-Jordan will send a delegation to Rhodes on Thursday for armistice talks with the Israelis, it was officially announced tonight. Actual negotiations are expected to begin on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UP) -- Emil Beckman, former propaganda writer for the wartime German radio, testified at the treason trial of Mildred (Axis Sally) Gillars today that all employes of Hitler's broadcasting service were warned to hew to the Nazi line.

Steps under way by the Port of New York Authority to improve the dock and terminal facilities of this city and to do a better service job to assist foreign traders were outlined yesterday by Walter P. Hedden, the Authority's director of port development.

MANILA, Feb. 21 -- The politically powerful Senate President, Jose Avelino, was shouldered aside today by twelve of his Senatorial colleagues who support President Elpidio Quirino. They organized a rump Senate, composed of half the membership, and blew the lid off the most sensational political scandal in the short history of this republic.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Representative E. E. Cox, Democrat, of Georgia, served notice in the House today that he would fight any maneuver designed to block floor action on pensions for veterans of both World Wars. It was conceded among his colleagues that he was in a position to prevent such a blocking.

AS each volume of Sean O'Casey's serial autobiography appears it becomes more and more apparent that this is indeed a strange and powerful book. Misshapen, seamed with horrid flaws, sinfully human and willfully pig-headed though it is, this tumultuous, wild and sometimes beautiful book is an impressive achievement.

Security and commodity exchanges throughout the United States will be closed today in observance of Washington's Birthday, but various livestock markets will operate as usual. European and Canadian markets will be open.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -Representative Wright Patman, Democrat, of Texas, cautioned Congress today to go slow in trying to change the electoral system, lest it make possible election of a President by the Communists or the Ku Klux Klan.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 22 -- In one of the stunning reversals of the basketball season, Princeton defeated Yale and its renowned Tony Lavelli tonight, 47 -- 45, ending the Elis' twelve-game winning streak and sending Columbia to the top of the Eastern Intercollegiate League as Yale fell to second place.
MANILA, Feb. 22 (UP) -- Jose Avelino, ousted President of the Senate, was ordered today to appear before a committee investigating charges that he received more than $250,000 illegally.

Though its facade is unpretentious, the Park East Restaurant isn't apt to be overlooked by anyone familiar with the cooking of Mrs. Olga Hartman, for every dish in this homey little establishment, at 12 East Ninety-seventh Street, is prepared to order by the charming and competent proprietress.

The campaign against fake use of marketing research techniques in direct selling, being conducted by the National Better Business Bureau with the aid of a group of research organizations and advertising agencies, has been endorsed by the Association of National Advertisers, it was learned yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Reasonable voting qualification, which needs time and patient effort for attainment, meets with lethargy and even defeatism, although unrestricted suffrage has so vitiated politics that both parties bid recklessly for unworthy votes -- creating balance of political power, in national government, out of those unfit even to govern themselves.

Theodore W. Kheel, former director of the city's Labor Relations Division, proposed yesterday that the so-called "O'Dwyer Plan for Industrial Peace" be adopted nationally as the best, surest route to industrial stability.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Congressional action in behalf of the American jeweled watchmaking industry, which professes to be imperiled by competition from Swiss imports, was advocated today by Scott W. Lucas, majority leader of the Senate.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 22 -- Trainer George P. (Maje) Odom, who majored in economics at Columbia University and is majoring in winners at Hialeah Park, marked up another one today in a $4,000 purse billed as the Martha Washington. A 3-year-old filly named Cheesecloth, carrying the Odom silks, did the job with the greatest of ease.

" The Alchemists: Founders of Modern Chemistry," by F. Sherwood Taylor, will be brought out in April by Henry Schuman. It is a history of alchemy in Africa, Europe and China. Mr. Taylor, curator of the Museum of the History of Science at Oxford, England, is the author of sixteen books related to science.

" Down to the Sea in Ships" set an "all-time record" at the Roxy Theatre yesterday when the film grossed $2,268 one hour after the house opened at 8 A. M., it was reported by the management. According to an estimate by A. J. Balaban, executive director, the attraction would "gross more than $30,000 for the complete opening day."

BERLIN, Feb. 22 -- Demonstrations by Jews against showing of the British film "Oliver Twist" -- although they have forced withdrawal of the film -- also appear to have awakened a measure of anti-Semitism that is taking the form of threats against Jews.

PARIS, Feb. 22 -- A new fall in the price of gold today was characterized as "sensational" by Administration experts. The gold louis fell from 5,000 to 4,500 francs, while the kilogram gold bar [2.2 pounds] fell from 657,500 to 635,500 francs.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- The British Army will drop 300,000 men -- more than one-third its present strength -- from its rolls in the coming year, but its net expenditure will be cut by only 300,000 [$1,200,000]. These figures were published here today as the Government presented to Parliament its army appropriation for the coming fiscal year.

Big John Lindell and George Weiss of the Yankees saw eye to eye in a long-distance phone conversation yesterday and the hard-hitting outfielder finally agreed to terms. From his home at Duarte, Calif., Lindell informed the New York general manager that he will leave immediately for Florida, and, after participating in the ballplayers' golf tournament at Miami he will report to the St. Petersburg camp of the Yankees.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 22 -- Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, warned today that if the support of private enterprise faded out of the national pattern of education it would fade out of other areas as well.

We fear that the authorities who are planning the budget for New York City's reorganized attack on the smoke and soot nuisance are arming for a popgun war instead of the real article. It will be utterly impossible to get a first-class director of the Smoke Bureau for $7,500 a year. A man with the technical engineering qualifications and administrative ability needed would not consider such a salary for a moment.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 21 -- The entire island of Formosa, now serving as a repository for the Chinese Central Bank's gold reserve and as an expanding base for the Nationalist Army, Navy and Air Force, is scheduled to be sealed off from the outside world for several days this week while Gen. Chen Cheng's Government here conducts a Province-wide "census" check-up.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 22 -- Tallying three goals in the second period, and adding three more in the third, the Yale hockey team defeated Princeton, 6 -- 1, in a Pentagonal League game at the Arena tonight.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- The Desmond - Mailler newspaper confidence bill received the support of editors and the American Newspaper Guild, CIO, at a public hearing today, but was condemned by the State Association of District Attorneys as "privileging hearsay."

The Kaiser Virginian, a Sports model, was added yesterday to the 1949 line of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation. The New York price, exclusive of sales tax, is $3,689. This includes radio, heater, defroster, white side-wall tires, air conditioner, undercoating, directional signals and chrome wheel rings.
LONDON, Feb. 22 -- Closing of the American markets in observance of Washington's Birthday accentuated the slackness ruling in the stock market here today.

TOKYO, Feb. 22 -- Documents recently made available to this correspondent indicate that the Japanese Communist party expected its projected general strike of August last to turn into an armed revolt by October and to result in the formation of a Red "People's Government" by this February.

PARIS, Feb. 22 -- It may be said on high authority that the leaders of the Western European states believe Secretary of State Dean Acheson has made an unexpectedly quick recovery from the confusion that surrounded the Atlantic Pact negotiations ten days ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The bituminous coal industry warned Congress today that unless it continued the legal requirement that labor organizations be obliged to bargain collectively, as provided by the Taft-Hartley Law, "the country may again face a crisis in coal" when the present agreement expires June 30.

Five thousand members of the Knights of Columbus and other Catholic organizations joined yesterday in combining a Fifth Avenue protest parade on Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty with the annual memorial mass of the Knights of Columbus in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Members of Knights of Columbus Councils throughout Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island attended Solemn High Masses of Requiem yesterday for all the members of the order in that area who had died. The masses were arranged by the Long Island Chapter of the order.
