The concert that Eugene Ormandy conducted last night with the Philadelphia Orchestra in Carnegie Hall, with Clifford Curzon, pianist, as assisting artist, will long be remembered. For this was an evening of the rarest music making.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 22 (AP) -Gaffery, 3-year-old miss from the Foxcatcher Farms, sneaked up from nowhere today to snatch a fancy victory from fourteen rival sisters of the turf in the $69,000 Santa Susana Stakes.

A strong plea for Senate ratification of the proposed North Atlantic pact was made last night by Senator Irving M. Ives at the annual dinner of the Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel

E. T. Ladd, vice president and works manager of the Isco Chemical Division of ,In!,, Speiden Co., has been appointed vice president in charge of the division. C. H. Berle, assistant works manager, has been named works manager of the division.
We must take September 15 [1940] as the culminating date. On this day the Luftwaffe, after two heavy attacks on the 14th, made its greatest concentrated effort in a resumed daylight attack on London.

PARIS, Feb. 22 -- Statements to a Communist party meeting today by its leader, Maurice Thorez, were interpreted widely as an incitement to French Communists to side by force with the Soviet Union should it come into conflict with France, and they caused a sharp reaction in the French Parliament.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 -- Enactment of the Truman Administration's program, now before Congress, would mean abandonment of liberty, in the United States, Senator Robert A. Taft charged tonight at the fortieth annual dinner of the Pennsylvania Manufacturers' Association.

The 217th anniversary of the birth of George Washington was marked yesterday by traditional observances at the scene of his first inaugural here, at his tomb in Mount Vernon, and elsewhere throughout the nation.

At its special holiday matinee yesterday at the City Center, the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo gave the season's first performance of "Rodeo," along with the "Nutcracker" and a repetition of "Pas de Quatre."

An Equity Library Theatre company offered last night at the Weidman Studio a spirited and powerful production of "Stevedore," by Paul Peters and George Sklar, originally staged here fifteen years ago at the Civic Repertory Theatre.

WINNIPEG, Feb. 22 (Canadian Press) -- The United Kingdom was allocated more than 1,000,000 bushels of wheat under the Canadian agreement in export business reported on the Winnipeg Grain Exchange today.

Tradition came through with flying colors yesterday afternoon and the Washington Birthday matinees attracted hordes of theatregoers. As a matter of fact, Washington's Birthday is rated the best matinee day of the year. The demand for the outstanding hits was terrific. Consequently, hundreds were disappointed at their inability to buy tickets and many of the performances were witnessed by customers who didn't mind standing.

Charges in Albany by a Republican Assemblyman that the New York City Board of Transportation had purchased 5,000 beach umbrellas for the use of transfer distributors were denied yesterday by William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: This is to take issue with your editorial of Feb. 19, criticizing Mayor O'Dwyer's recent action in regard to the Board of Higher Education, wherein you state: "The Mayor has no standing in law, precedent or principle for intervening."

FLORENCE, Feb. 22 -- No place is more typical than Florence of contrasts and paradoxes in post-war Italy. In the late summer of 1944 this correspondent watched from the heights of Bellosguardo the nightly exchange of shellfire between the Germans on one side of the Arno and the Allies on the other.

An IRT station agent and a passenger saved the life of Cornelius O'Donnell, 57 years old, of 540 West 204th Street, when they halted a subway train yesterday fifty feet from where Mr. O'Donnell had fallen to the tracks.

The New York City Opera Company will present Offenbach's "Tales of Hoffmann" and Gian-Carlo Menotti's "The Medium" during its six-week spring season that opens March 24, Laszlo Halasz, artistic and music director, announced yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- A 20-year-old Quaker who testified that he could not "participate in preparation for violence" was found guilty today of willful failure to register for the peacetime military draft.
Thirty married women from the Middle West, most of them the wives of farmers, left yesterday from La Guardia Airport for London on a trip to study conditions in nine countries of Western Europe.
BERLIN, Feb. 22 -- American and British fliers established a new record by bringing 7,513 short tons of supplies into Berlin over the Russian blockade in the twenty-four hours up to noon today.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 22 -- President Charles Seymour of Yale University today told 1,000 alumni that "none of us can afford to minimize the Communist threat to America."

GENEVA, Feb. 22 -- The reaction of European governments and industries to the growing competition in international markets presents to the United States Government a serious test of its world economic policy, in the opinion of United Nations and United States economists here.

Gail Nicoletti came home yesterday. And on Saturday she will have a party to celebrate her fifth birthday, which really fell on Jan. 10 while she was receiving the attentive but despairing care of the surgeons and nurses of Greenpoint Hospital, Brooklyn.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 22 -- Senator J. Howard McGrath, Democratic National Chairman, proposed tonight a constitutional amendment for the election of three Senators from each of the forty-eight states to expedite and make more efficient the business of the Federal Government.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 22 -- The present blueprint of President Truman's "bold new program" of help to economically backward countries calls for a relatively modest financial outlay by the United States -perhaps $50,000,000 to $100,000,000 at the outset -- it was learned here today.

Borough President Cornelius A. Hall, of Richmond, who made a surprise announcement Monday night that he would support Mayor O'Dwyer for re-election, served notice yesterday that he would run in both the Democratic and Republican primaries in June for the nomination for Borough President.

TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 22 -- The New Jersey Employment Service reported today that more than seasonal unemployment hit the labor market in January, affecting many industries and indicating "a certain degree of overproduction." The service, however, found a belief in business and industry that a turning point had been reached.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- Contracts are known to have been entered into between German shipbuilders and Norwegian ship owners that raise in acute form the questions of competition and of sales at below world prices.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 16 -- In view of prevailing international uncertainty, the Swiss Government has decided to permit the continued operation of a small fleet of ocean-going merchant ships under the Swiss flag.
SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Pett Hugsted, 1948 Olympic ski-jumping champion from Norway, today won the National Ski Jumping Tournament with leaps of 262 and 263 feet.

PEIPING, Feb. 22 -- Peiping slid silently into its long expected role as the capital of the North China People's Government two days ago with the city's populace completely unaware of it until today when the official Communist People's Daily formally announced that Government headquarters had been moved from Shihchiachwang.

With 17,655 licensed doctors, this city has "the largest concentration of physicians in any city in this country, and perhaps in the world," according to data published yesterday by the Hospital Council of Greater New York.
CHICAGO, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The nation's convention business was estimated today at more than $200,000,000 in 1948.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 22 (AP) -Jockey Willie Garner was suspended today for the rest of the Santa Anita Park meeting for his ride on Olympia in the Santa Anita Derby.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) --Kunn faces a long fight if he attempts to follow through oon his announced intention to seek reinContinued From Page I statement of the American citizenship that he lost by court order in 1943.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- Republican opponents of Governor Dewey's budget and tax increase programs scored a tactical victory today by forcing the Senate Finance Committee to defer action on the proposals and winning a promise from the Assembly Ways and Means Committee to consider amendments before a final vote was taken in the lower chamber.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 22 -- Sweden's outstanding ski jumpers, Wilhelm Hellman and Bengt Jaderholm, today demonstrated a technique that will be long remembered as the Scandinavians finished first and second, respectively, in the twenty-eighth annual Lake Placid Sno Birds Club classic on the Intervales Olympic slide.

Legislatures in an increasing number of states now have before them bills requiring periodic inspection of motor vehicles. New York is one of these. The bill in question would provide for compulsory inspection by state-maintained and operated inspection stations, on the same general plan as that which has proved so useful in New Jersey.

The pros and cons of the compulsory national health insurance supported by President Truman were debated last night at America's Town Meeting of the Air. The debate was broadcast and televised over the ABC networks from Town Hall.

When President Truman spoke in his Inaugural Address of making available to the world the benefits of our scientific and industrial progress he was not improvising or suggesting an untried formula. A precedent can be found in the successful Latin America program inaugurated in 1942 by Nelson Rockefeller, then Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs.

A provision in the Truman Administration's public welfare bill to extend Federal aid to state programs for the needy, requiring each participating state to offer similar benefits throughout its jurisdiction, would not affect public assistance in this state, Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard declared yesterday.

MERIDEN, Conn., Feb. 22 (AP) -- A special edition of The Meriden Record was published today, and the newspaper's editor, Thomas H. Warnock, did not know a thing about it until it began tumbling from the presses.

BOSTON, Feb. 22 -- Champion Mazelaine's Zazarac Brandy, the boxer that won best in show at Westminister and Hartford for Mr. and Mrs. John P. Wagner of Milwaukee last week, led a quality-filled 1,417-dog entry to victory in the breed judging that opened the thirty-sixth and biggest Eastern Dog Club show today.

Desirous of joining other West Indies nations now enjoying preferential markets in the United States and other countries, the Dominican Republic will strongly advocate a drastic reduction of trade barriers at a meeting of the International Trade Organization in Annecy, France, in April.

PARIS, Feb. 22 -- It was understood tonight that an agreement between the French Government and Bao Dai, former Emperor of Annam, regarding a future regime for Indo-China had been virtually completed and would be submitted to the Cabinet tomorrow. Bao Dai had a long visit with Premier Henri Queuille today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UP) -Lawyers for Miss Dorothy Bailey, former employe of the Federal Security Agency who was ordered dismissed by President Truman's Loyalty Review Board, said today they would spare no effort to clear the woman's name.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government agreed today that the Department of Agriculture needed a better grouping of its functions, but members split sharply on how much money could be saved thereby.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The greatest "undeveloped crop" in Europe is its boys and girls, a House committee studying Marshall Plan aid was told today by a farm leader who urged that they be trained into an agricultural force vital to lasting recovery and peace.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- A bill to outlaw the "black market" in the adoption of babies was introduced in the Legislature today by Assemblyman Samuel Rabin, Republican, of Queens, with the backing of several New York civic groups. It would set up regulations for the permanent placement of children in homes.

Exorbitant prices and inadequate housing have impaired the welfare of thousands of American families, the Rev. John J. Donovan declared yesterday in his annual report as director of family service of Catholic Charities. New York Catholic Charities, 477 Madison Avenue, is making it yearly appeal for funds. The goal is $2,500,000.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of Feb. 11 Kermit Roosevelt gives his own theory to explain away the flight of the Palestinian Arabs from their villages. No one can accept this theory who has seen Arab villages near Jewish settlements going on their wonted ways, or the city of Nazareth, where an Arab population double that prior to the war is living and working peacefully.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 22 -- At a closed meeting today Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, and a staff of research experts reported to the Hollywood film chiefs that the industry's domestic gross in 1948 was 8 1/2 per cent below that of 1946, but was still as good as 1945.

A special section of Pennsylvania Station, set aside for the occasion, became a joyous meeting place last night when 149 displaced persons from Europe were greeted by a large gathering of relatives and friends. The DP's had arrived in Boston from Europe earlier in the day.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 22 -- Pennsylvania's two-year reign in the Polar Bear triangular track meet with Princeton and Columbia came to an end in the rain today.

The executive committee of the United Palestine Appeal voted last night, after five hours of debate, to set up a committee that is to meet in a few days with Henry Morgenthau Jr. in an effort to reach a settlement of the issue caused by the opposition of one element to the designation of Henry Montor as executive director of the 1949 United Jewish Appeal.

SUNDSVAAL, Sweden, Feb. 17 -- At a pace reminiscent of a six-day bicycle race, a group of fourteen American newspaper men has been rolling across Scandinavia studying some of the results of the Marshall Plan. They have walked through factories, shipyards and distilleries, across barnyards and courtyards, into Parliaments and palaces.

Henry Morgan, the comedian with the highly developed allergy to commercials, has been signed for a regular television series on NBC. He will have a fifteen-minute spot at 7:30 P. M. and will be seen on a Monday-through-Friday basis, starting March 21.
CHICAGO, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Charts showing purchases of supplies were described today to a Federal court jury hearing the anti-trust trial of National City Lines, Inc., and others.

Four silk-screen murals from original designs by Calder, Matisse, Matta and Miro -- the first in a series of Mural-Scrolls by prominent artist planned for homes -- were introduced yesterday in an exhibit at the showroom of Katzenbach Warren, Inc., 49 East Fifty-third Street. The designs will be reproduced in full scale on canvas so they can be applied directly to a wall or hung in scroll form.
Former State Senator John L. Buckley, an active leader of the so-called "Irish bloc" in Tammany Hall, announced last night that he would retire as leader of the Fifth Assembly District South.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 22 -- A twenty-car "Liberty Train" left this afternoon for Jersey City carrying 447 Jewish refugees from Shanghai on the second lap of their 15,000-mile journey to Israel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Government purchases were the dominant factor in the notable expansion of business and trade in 1948, which rose to a level 10 per cent above that of 1947, the Department of Commerce reported today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Ned Day of West Allis, Wis., defending all-events champion in the American Bowling Congress tournament, couldn't make the pins behave today and finished out of the first ten in that division.

BERLIN, Feb. 22 -- Russian political strategists through the agency of German Communists are circulating a new plan for solution of the German problem. It provides for withdrawal of the occupation forces by phases and establishment of a united Germany.
ZURICH, Feb. 22 -- At first sight the balance sheet and profit and loss account for 1948 of the Swiss National Bank suggest an extraordinary expansion of business.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- President Truman declared tonight that "any s. o. b." who thinks he can cause him to discharge any member of his staff "by some smart aleck statement over the air or in the paper, he has got another think coming."

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- A combination of political party and labor opposition to permanent personal registration of voters at a hearing here today appeared to have doomed its chance of approval so far as this year's session of the Legislature is concerned.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Mayor O'Dwyer's public interference in the matter of the selection of the president of Queens College by the Board of Higher Education has evidently had the strong disapproval of the public, educators throughout the country, and even a large segment of the people of Queens.

FAIRFAX, Va., Feb. 22 (UP) -- Joseph W. Martin Jr., Republican leader of the House, said tonight that the Truman Administration should be trying to head off a depression instead of pressing for higher taxes and new anti-inflation controls.

The cargo-passenger vessel Schiedyk of the Holland-America Line is in Rotterdam, whence her maiden voyage will start next month, it was announced yesterday by Frederick R. Wierdsma, general manager in the United States. The Schiedyk was constructed at the shipyard of Harland Wolff, Ltd., in Belfast, Ireland.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 22 -- Five of the country's leading educational officials, representing 1,000,000 teachers and administrators, appealed today to President Truman and members of Congress for immediate passage of a bill appropriating $300,000,000 for aid to education.

Forty Protestant clergymen and laymen made public yesterday a protest against "the current organized attacks" upon The Churchman, a Protestant Episcopal weekly magazine; its editor, the Rev. Dr. Guy Emery Shipler, and Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam, head of the New York district of the Methodist Church.

RHODES, Feb. 22 -- The success or failure of the Egyptian-Israeli armistice negotiations hangs entirely on the fate of Beersheba, an especially well-informed source declared tonight. Up to tonight the Egyptians had not announced whether they would accept the proposed armistice formula of Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, United Nations Mediator, and the latest information from Cairo to the United Nations delegation was that the Government had not yet made a decision.

What happened in Madison Square Garden last night was all in the spirit of good, clean fun. Bill Johnston, grown old in the promotion of boxing and what passes for wrestling hereabouts, essayed the Herculean task of reviving the ancient mat sport as an important attraction at the arena where it had been banned for twelve years since its degeneration into a hippodrome.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 -- New directors of the Tucker Corporation have served notice on Preston Tucker that they want no interference from him in handling policy-making matters in the future, a source close to the company said today.

The people of India may be forced to turn to "some other creed" unless their standard of living improves within the next five or ten years, Sir Benegal Rama Rau, retiring Indian Ambassador to the United States, declared last night.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The Communist party newspaper Babotnichesko Delo quoted various Bulgarian Protestant churches today as denouncing fifteen Protestant churchmen accused of spying for the United States and Britain.
Only by opposing the ideology of Christianity to that of communism can the basic American freedoms be defended, Bishop James P. DeWolfe declared yesterday.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Feb. 22 -Unemployment in up-state industrial communities is going up nearly three times as fast as in New York City. The number of workers on the up-state unemployment insurance rolls has increased 110 per cent in the last four months.

City College's basketball team, campaigning for a bid to the national invitation basketball tournament, will face Fordham tonight in an intracity contest at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory. Also on the local schedule is a game between Columbia, a candidate for the District 2 N. C. A. A. nomination, and Brown at the Lion's gymnasium.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 22 -Starting the spring series of dinghy racing today at the Larchmont Yacht Club, Corny Shields went to the front with his boat Dainty in the Interclub Class, winning two of the four races held and getting a second and a third place in the others for 77 points, three more than Jack Sutphen with his Rum Dum.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- Britain's Attorney General, Sir Hartley Shaw-cross, said today that "the remedy for libel is to forget about it." That bit of free legal advice from the country's chief prosecutor was offered at a luncheon meeting of the Newspaper Society, a publishers' association.
Net income and sales of the Monsanto Chemical Company last year were the largest in its history, according to the forty-seventh annual report of operation to be issued to stockholders today.

ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 22 -- Floyd R. Newman, Cleveland petroleum industrialist, has made a gift of securities estimated to be worth about $1,000,000 to the Cornell University Laboratory of Nuclear Studies, it was announced here tonight.

DETROIT, Feb. 22 -- The National Lawyers Guild ended its ninth annual convention here today with a plea for the revocation of orders calling for loyalty oaths for labor unions and for "substantially strengthened" rent controls.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 22 -- Robert Rossen, independent produc r-director, has reached a verbal agreement with Columbia for the distribution of three of his projected productions, and contracts are now being drawn up to conclude the deal, he disclosed today.

If the New York Rangers are to keep their hopes alive for a play-off position in the National Hockey League race, they will have to go all-out in their battle with the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden tonight.

The future of advertising will be discussed at the final forum discussion in the "New Directions" series, sponsored by the Art Directors Club of New York, tomorrow, in the Willkie Memorial Building, 20 West Fortieth Street. Frederick Gamble will speak on "Summary and Conclusion of Forum and the Future of the Advertising Business."
ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- Governor Dewey signed today his three housing program bills providing for a $300,000,000 bond issue and increases in the annual and aggregate amounts of public housing subsidies.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 22 (UP) -- The official Hungarian news agency today published the text of a letter that it said Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty had sent from his prison cell Feb. 12 to the nation's two remaining Archbishops. The text:

The partial relaxation last week of discriminatory import regulations imposed by the Union of South Africa about three and a half months ago will do much to clear up the confused situation as it concerns American-flag steamship operators in the African trade, S. J. Maddock, vice president of the Seas Shipping Company, Inc., said yesterday.

" While we in the State of New York alone may neither cure nor ruin the national economy, it is incumbent upon us, as the Empire State has done in so many things, to lead the way with courage, honesty, and with a decent respect for the heritage we pass on to our children." -- Governor Dewey to the Legislature, Jan. 7, 1948.
Here is the text of Drew Pearson's radio remarks about Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan on Sunday, Feb. 6, as given out by the American Broadcasting Company at that time:

TOKYO, Feb. 22 -- Occupation policies appear to be running into a difficult period. Producers are beginning to say "if you insist, we will adhere strictly to your three point economic program, but after next month we shan't be able to pay any wages."

CAIRO, Feb. 22 -- Two thousand fierce, camel-riding tribesmen, led by a desert chieftain bent on revenge, have recaptured the bandit-held fortress of Hillin in Aden Protectorate, it was reported today.

VIENNA, Feb. 22 -- The gradual structural reorganization and socialization of Czechoslovak agriculture in the next twelve months are foreshadowed by public statements and newspaper articles surrounding the celebration of the Communist coup of Feb. 25, 1948.

Mainbocher's most recent collection, shown to the press on Monday morning at his salon, 6 East Fifty-seventh Street, is more Mainbocher than ever. This artist designs with a single purpose -- to please the American woman who can afford to pay for custom-made clothes.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 22 -- A clear priority for a demand for an across-the-board wage increase of 25 cents an hour in 1949 was established tonight by the general executive board of the United Rubber Workers of America, CIO, as recommended by the international policy committee.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's remarks at a dinner for Maj. Gen. Harry Vaughan, as phrased in a version released by the White House:

There was not enough room on the Madison Square Garden scoreboard to post the Minneapolis total, as the powerhouse Lakers routed the New York Knickerbockers, 101-74, in a Basketball Association of America matinee yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- Britain's political bosses, Right and Left, are closely watching today the spirited election campaign in the West London Borough of Hammersmith, looking for signs that may show whether the nation will vote Socialist again in the next general election.
Sportsmen's Show sidelights:

MUNICH, Germany, Feb. 22 -A German appellate court today freed Fritz Kuhn former German-American Bund leader and convicted major Nazi, by cutting his ten-year prison sentence to two years already served.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 22 -- Ten men went on trial today before a Belgrade district court on charges of having attempted to start an armed Chetnik rebellion in Yugoslavia early in September, 1948 -- three months after the Communist Information Bureau's resolution expelling Yugoslav Communist leaders.
CANTON, China, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Acting President Li Tsung-jen today warned the Communists that they must not cross the Yangtze River if they wanted peace. General Li then took off for Kweilin.

CAIRO, Feb. 22 -- The Egyptian Government put through the Senate here today the most important single measure in the program of a group that is fighting to narrow the gap in Egypt between excessive wealth and poverty.
Sponsors of the Military Government German Exhibition to be held here in April said yesterday that the million-dollar trade display would include a wide variety of German pre-war specialties.

MOSCOW, Feb. 22 (AP) -- American diplomats are the target of a little book -- newly published by the Literary Gazette -- that bears the name of Annabelle Bucar, the Clairton, Pa., girl who quit her job with the United States Information Service here a year ago.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 22 -- Stan Benham, 35-year-old chief of the local fire department, who gave up coaching ski jumping several years ago for "bigger thrills," today culminated his meteoric bobsledding career by driving the United States No. 2 four-man team to the world championship over the lightning-fast Mount Van Hoevenberg one-mile run.

Sixteen paintings by nineteenth and twentieth century European artists, from the collection of Mrs. H. Harris Jonas, have been lent for exhibition at the New School for Social Research through the New School Associates. They will be shown in the fifth-floor galleries of the chool through March 1.

That holiday is over now, and again there bears repeating the surly question, whose holiday? Not that of the postman on the beat, nor the banker nor the baker. It is perhaps true that they did not work at their usual occupations, but they worked.

The Maritime Commission's plan to do its own drydocking work in the conditioning program announced for the laid-up merchant fleet reserve was protested last week by Representative James J. Murphy, of the 16th District, which includes Staten Island and lower western Manhattan.
Seeking to fill the gap in fabric ales made by curtailment of ready-to-wear output and loss in export markets, textile mills and converters will step up promotional efforts for home sewing.

It's up to Yale and Army to keep Michigan State from taking the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. indoor track and field title West for the first time in Saturday's varsity carnival at Madison Square Garden.

Since the United States and Canada in 1941 agreed formally to carry out the St. Lawrence Seaway and Power Project more than twenty bills in approval have been introduced in Congress. All stipulated that the hydroelectric power plant to be constructed was to be turned over to the State of New York, provided the state paid its share of the cost.
Patriotism was the keynote yesterday of New York's observance of Brotherhood Week.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 22 -- Gerard Graham Dennis, society "raffles" accused of ransacking homes and estates in this country and Canada, began dickering with the authorities today for a prison sentence that would not keep him behind bars for the rest of his life.

Senator Morse of Oregon, one of the few Republicans who opposed the Taft-Hartley bill in the Eightieth Congress, believes, he says, that the attitude of some business men toward modification of the law is motivated by "unchristian selfishness." On the other hand, he is warm in his praise of Senator Taft, a fellow-member of the Labor Committee and co-author of the 1947 law.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Strengthened National Guard and Organized Reserve units were urged today by the Army Committee on Civilian Components.

NEWARK, N. J., Feb. 22 -- A white rat, left last night in a makeshift cage on the doorstep of Arthur Meyers of 475 South Tenth Street, Newark, found a home today and the warm companionship of a cat and dog. That is the story, anyway.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Soviet Minister of the Armed Forces, said tonight Russian fighting men must "maintain constant combat preparedness on a high level" because of the United States "policy of aggression," the Moscow radio reported.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Registration statements covering $8,500,000 of debentures, 91,510 shares of common and 40,000 shares of preferred stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by three companies.

" Family Honeymoon," a Universal-International comedy, starring Fred MacMurray and Claudette Colbert, will have its local premiere this morning at the Radio City Music Hall. Claude Binyon directed and John Beck and Z. Wayne Griffin produced from a screen play by Dane Lussier and the novel by Homer Croy.

The end of a three-day work slowdown of railway express agency workers at terminals and depots in the New York metropolitan area, was recommended last night at an emergency meeting of the New York District Board of Adjustment of the Brotherhood of Railway and Steamship Clerks, AFL, the union announced.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Charles G. Ross, White House press secretary and high school chum of President Truman, underwent today an operation on his right forearm.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 23 -- Pennsylvania overpowered Navy in an overtime period to score a 67-52 basketball victory over the middies today.
ALBANY, N. Y., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Bills to outlaw the reserve clause in baseball players' contracts were introduced in the Legislature today by two Manhattan Democrats.

An intracity basketball rivalry that dates back to 1908 will headline the twin bill at Madison Square Garden tonight, when N. Y. U. clashes with St. John's. The 8 o'clock curtain-raiser will pit Manhattan against La Salle of Philadelphia.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Feb. 23 (UP) -- Gov. Luis Munoz Marin said today that his administration was against "stealing" industries from the United States because whatever was bad for the mainland economy was also bad for the island.
Renewed efforts to forestall a paralyzing strike of 26,000 Consolidated Edison employes collapsed yesterday after a brief meeting between officials of the company and the Utility Workers Union, CIO.

Suits played a major role in the showing of women's spring fashions in regular and proportionate sizes held yesterday on the third floor of B. Altman Co. Swinging, hip-length capes and deeply fringed stoles worked with passementerie distinguished several.

Communist parties in the Western World are apparently about to be committed to the proposition that, no matter what the circumstances, they would never fight against Soviet Russia; that in such circumstances they would do their best to undermine their own countries' resistance to the point of overthrowing their governments, and that they would welcome an invasion of their own countries by the Soviet armies.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Four bills carrying out recommendations of Brooklyn Supreme Court justices to relieve congestion in New York Supreme Courts were introduced today by Senator James J. Crawford, Democrat and Assemblyman Lewis Olliffe, Republican, of Kings.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Despite the opposition voiced yesterday against their bill to set up a system of permanent personal registration for voters in the state, the League of Women Voters and the Citizens Union still entertained hopes tonight for its adoption.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 23 -- The American Joint Distribution Committee, flying Yemenite Jewish refugees from Aden to Israel, will end the first phase of this operation next week when the last of 4,500 women, children and elderly persons land at Lydda airport, it was disclosed today.

Miss Esther Ridder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor F. Ridder of 944 Fifth avenue, heads a group of young women aiding Mrs. Kimball G. Colby and members of the executive committee in furthering plans for the annual luncheon and card party in behalf of the Catholic Big Sisters to be held next Tuesday at Sherry's.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Article 5 of the projected North Atlantic defense pact and provisions of the French and British treaties of mutual assistance with the Soviet Union are providing the Communists in general and the Soviet propagandists in particular with a lot of fancy arguments these days.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- A temporary order restraining the financially troubled Tucker Corporation from paying out further funds from a special reserve account was issued today by Federal District Judge Michael L. Igoe. The order, in effect, ties up virtually all activities of the company since it has little other cash available.

IF Gorgeous George has not killed wrestling in New York for good and for all, the sport (if you will pardon the expression) is hardy enough to survive a direct hit by an atomic bomb. It was a most insufferable and obnoxious performance that he gave in Madison Square Garden the other night as the mat game was returned to a big league setting in our town for what undoubtedly was the last time.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- For the first time since depression days the specter of rows of unsold new homes in key cities over the country has risen to plague builders despite the continuing housing shortage.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 23 -- Tony Holguin, a 22-year-old Guadalajara, Mexico, professional, out-stroked some of the United States' leading golfers today in winning the Mexican open tournament with a 12-under-par 201 for fifty-four holes.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 23 -- Foreign Minister Vassil Kolarov announced today that no papal mission would be allowed to work in Bulgaria any longer. Announcing the order during his introduction into Parliament of a bill to regulate religion in the State, Mr. Kolarov attacked the Vatican as an agent of "dark forces inciting a new world war."

Citizens in a representative government should revolt against any elected leader who attempted to violate fundamental democratic rights, three speakers agreed last night on the "What's On Your Mind?" forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast by WQXR.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Feb. 23 (UP) -- University of South Carolina students peppered a Ku Klux Klan meeting at West Columbia with stench bombs tonight while the grand dragon, Samuel Green, was making a speech on white supremacy.

Turkey was described yesterday as the most stable element in the Near East and as an "excellent risk as far as the United States is concerned." The statement was made by Dr. Floyd H. Black, president of Robert College and of the American College for Girls in Istanbul.
The beauty salon is moving into private hospitals and may prove almost as important as the blood bank, especially to women patients who consider it a live-saving necessity.

Sales and earnings of the Bendix Aviation Corporation for the December quarter were larger than for the 1947 period, but "current trends in business activity will unquestionably challenge continued earning power," Malcolm P. Ferguson, president, informed shareholders at the annual meeting held yesterday in South Bend, Ind.

W. G. Holloway Jr., a rising young player of marked promise, and H. W. Carhart Jr. won their opening matches in the national amateur racquets championship yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club. Robert Grant 3d is the defending titleholder.

An alleged resale of war surplus material given to Seton Hall College, South Orange, N. J., is under investigation by the Federal Works Agency, it was announced yesterday. William D. Jones, FWA regional office director, said the purpose was to determine whether the school resold any of the material and if it did, how much.

By comparison with the female, the male is inherently a weakling in health in all periods of life from birth to death, a group of Harvard Medical School scientists reported last night after an extensive research project at Massachusetts General Hospital.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 23 -- After losing an 8-point lead in the closing minutes of regulation play, Dartmouth College regained its poise in the second overtime period today and handed Army a 61-58 defeat in the last home game of the basketball season for the cadets.

Two hundred and fifty articles ranging from sacred feline figurines of ancient Egypt to cat-decorated textiles and costume jewelry of today will go on display this morning at the Cooper Union Museum in an exhibit titled "Nine Lives: the Tale of the Cat in History and in Art."
VIENNA, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Two American women, visiting in Vienna, figure in an incident with Russian soldiers that is under investigation by the United States provost marshal's office today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Some aeronautical engineers believe that one of the most important results of the flights of' the supersonic Bell X-1 rocket plane was the change it made in the thinking of aircraft designers.

THE "profiteering contractor" whom Mr. Churchill mentions as the constructor of the "shaky and lightly built" houses of Downing Street was Sir George Downing, a Harvard graduate and business-like opportunist of the Cromwell era, who was not averse to transferring his allegiance as ne cessity demanded.

Establishment of standards for rayon fabrics will be undertaken by the American Standards Association in conjunction with the National Retail Dry Goods Association, it was announced yesterday. The task, admittedly one of the largest to be started by ASA, will take upward of eighteen months before issuance of the first standards.

CAIRO, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The newspaper Al Misri said today the Iranian police had thwarted a plot to overthrow the government and declare a Communist state. The dispatch from Teheran said the recent attempt to assassinate the Shah was part of the plan.

Clifford Odets' new play, "The Big Knife," starring John Garfield, will be presented tonight at the National Theatre under the auspices of Dwight Deere Wiman. The curtain is announced to go up on the stroke of 8.

Citing the paper industry as an "outstanding example" of one that has responded fully to public demand, Cola G. Parker, president of the American Paper and Pulp Association, declared last night that the recent election may be taken as evidence that the American people intend "to make far greater demands upon industry than most people, including business executives, have expected."

With the outcome never in doubt, City College sped to a 58 -- 46 victory over the Fordham basketball team before 1,356 persons at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night. It was the fifteenth triumph for Nat Holman's Beavers, who handed Bo Adams' Rams their twelfth setback of the year.

Another flurry of selling in the rails which dropped this section to the lowest level in a year again upset the stock market yesterday. The session resembled Monday's performance on an exaggerated scale, and produced the largest over-all decline in about two weeks.

MANILA Feb. 23 -- Political warfare within President Elpidio Quirino's Liberal party drew toward a new series of climaxes today. There is every evidence that Senator Jose Avelino intends to fight to the bitter end his deposition by a parliamentary coup as President of the Senate.

Pioneer in the field of opening the gates of major league baseball to Negroes, Branch Rickey, president of the Dodgers, yesterday announced the acquisition of James Edward Pendleton, a 23-year-old shortstop from the Chicago American Giants of the Negro American League.

The United States must not flirt with Generalissimo Francisco Franco to stop Generalissimo or Premier Joseph Stalin, Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam, head of the New York district of the Methodist Church, declared last night.

John F. O'Connell, chairman of the State Liquor Authority, denounced the critics of his administration of that agency last night in an address at a dinner of the St. Francis College alumni at the Columbus Club in Brooklyn.

The Commercial Credit Company in 1948 had the most successful year in its history, according to the thirty-seventh annual report to stockholders and employes, issued for publication today. In its consolidated operations receivables acquired by its finance companies, gross premiums written by its insurance companies, net sales of its manufacturing companies and consolidated net income credited to earned surplus of the company were the highest on record.

PARIS, Feb. 23 -- France's National Assembly will interrupt its work tomorrow to call on Maurice Thorez, Communist leader in France, for a clear explanation of his statement indicating that French Communists would not in any circumstances resist an invasion by the Soviet Army.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 23 -- The whale-processing ship Anglo Norse, which completed recently a seven-month stay in whaling waters off the coast of Peru, began today to unload at the dock of the Werner G. Smith Company here a capacity cargo of sperm oil valued at $3,700,000.
GANDER, Nfld., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Anna Louise Strong arrived at Gander tonight on her way to New York by plane from Paris, obviously fatigued from her recent experiences and the trans-ocean trip.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Assurance that the low-rent housing problem would be considered on a bi-partisan plane came today as a Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee unanimously approved a compromise bill calling for 810,000 new units of such housing by 1955.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 23 -- Poland served notice in the United Nations Economic and Social Council today that the Eastern European countries would probably put up as much bitter opposition to President Truman's global program of aid to underdeveloped areas as they have given to the Marshall Plan.

BERLIN, Feb. 23 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, condemned today the new Russian plan for Germany's future, which stresses the withdrawal of all occupation forces and the establishment of a unified German state, as promising much and "settling nothing."

Solution of problems affecting lower production costs and the need for stimulated sales will be discussed at the national conference on packaging, packing and shipping in Atlantic City, it was announced yesterday by the Planning Council of the Packaging Division of the American Management Association.

Poetry, musicianship and technique have characterized Abbey Simon's piano playing since his debut nine years ago. And they have grown as he has progressed. On the basis of his recital last night at Carnegie Hall, one would add a fourth attribute, mastery.
LONDON, Feb. 23 -- The Permanent Commission of the Western Union approved today in principle the latest Washington formula for the proposed North Atlantic defense pact.

Homemakers must use brain instead of brawn to get the best results in the home laundry today, judging by laundering tips provided by expert yesterday in an all-day session conducted by the Electrical Women's Round Table at the Workshop for Electrical Living, 570 Lexington Avenue.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 23 -- What is believed to be the largest coal mine hoist in the world will be shipped from New Orleans to England sometime in the next few days. The hoist is being loaded on a Lykes Brothers Steamship Company vessel.

Up in Gloucester, salty nets have been stretched out to dry in the sun almost since the harbor attracted settlers in 1623. Over the 300-year period innumerable vessels have been fitted out, to return with innumerable hauls. The first fishing port to be opened in this country, it still ranks among the first in point of receipts.

Volumes four and five in Samue. Elliot Morison's "History of the United States Navy in World War II" are scheduled for publication this year by Little, Brown in association with the Atlantic Monthly Press. Tentatively set for August is volume four, "Coral Sea, Midway and the Submarines, May, 1942-August, 1942."

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Philadelphians today claimed fourth place in the American Bowling Congress doubles and singles events, while an Allentown (Pa.) team went into fifth place in the doubles.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Despite a strong plea from Mrs. Genesta Strong, Republican Assemblywoman from Nassau, the Assembly Agriculture Committee voted today to defer action indefinitely on her bill to legalize the sale of colored oleomargarine m New York.

Directors of the Packard Motor Car Company authorized yesterday the payment on March 28 of a dividend of 25 cents a common share. Last year shareholders received two payments; 15 cents in March and 20 cents in October.
Hoyt Brothers, Inc., Newark, N. J., to the Lewis Advertising Agency for advertising of its pie mix and dumpling mix. Newspapers, spot radio and direct mail will be used.

Collegiate theatrical productions will be televised by the National Broadcasting Company starting in the spring, under an exclusive agreement with the American Educational Theatre Association, Norman Blackburn, NBC's national television program manager, announced yesterday. The association represents more than 100 universities which operate theatres and schools of drama.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Arthur Henderson, Britain's Air Secretary, informed Parliament today that several types of jet bombers of "exceptionally high performance" were being developed as rapidly as possible for the Royal Air Force. The first of these is expected to fly in the "very near future," he added.

WHAT must we do to be saved? In a thousand forms -- and with a thousand answers -- that is still man's leading and most tormenting soliloquy. Man wants the good life, the full life, and as much security as possible, this side of paradise. No jesting Pilate, he will stay for all the answers that all the pilots can offer him in his wonderfully dogged pursuit of peace and happiness.

HELSINKI, Finland, Feb. 23 -By a record narrow margin of two votes, Karl August Fagerholm's Labor Government wriggled out of the tightest squeeze it has been in since its formation seven months ago and won a vote of confidence in the Finnish Parliament today, 97 to 95.

A reduction of $47,500 in added money for Belmont's spring stakes schedule was noted yesterday in the listing by the New York Racing Associations of Belmont's stakes dates. Although it already had been announced that the Belmont Stakes on June 11 would carry $75,000 instead of $100,000 added as in 1948, other cuts were made in four steeplechase events, and two flat races.

RHODES, Feb. 23 -- Egypt and Israel will sign an armistice agreement here at 10:30 A. M. tomorrow [3:30 A. M. in New York], Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, the United Nations acting Mediator for Palestine, announced this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Henry A. Wallace contended before the House Foreign Affairs Committee today that the European Recovery Program had failed as such, but had demonstrated that its objective was to intensify the "cold war" with Russia.

The Rev. Carl McIntire, president of the International Council of Christian Churches, announced yesterday that he had sent a telegram to the White House calling upon President Truman to apologize to the American people for using the initials "s. o. b." in a speech Tuesday night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The United States has protested to the Bulgarian Government against the arrest of fifteen Protestant churchmen on charges of espionage, treason and currency operations, the State Department announced today.
William Adams Delano, president of the New York City Art Commission, declared yesterday that President Truman had been "enlisted on the side of those desiring to save Fort Clinton."

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 23 -Searchers believe they have located the position of the fabulous "Lost Loot of Lima," pirate booty estimated to be worth $500,000,000. It supposedly is buried on the shore of Cocos Island, off the west coast of Costa Rica.

HONG KONG, Feb. 23 -- Notwithstanding the "cold war," a brisk trade has sprung up between British Hong Kong and Soviet-dominated North Korea. Ships flying the Panamanian, British, Filipino and Norwegian flags have docked at the North Korean ports of Konam and Chinnampo carrying manufactured goods, some of which have gone to Communist North China and Manchuria in direct and indirect barter transactions.
According to a poll just completed, Eugene O'Neill is the American author who stands the best chance of being regarded as a "classic" in the year 2000, it was announced yesterday.

The Argentine heavy cruiser Almirante Brown arrived here yesterday on a thirteen-day good-will visit to the United States, returning two courtesy calls to the South American country made by United States naval units during the last year.
Bulgarians blame a recent 20 per cent crop failure on "The Voice of America," Charles W. Thayer, director of the international broadcasting division of the State Department, said yesterday.
Rockland Light Power Company and California Electric Power Company borrowed $10,500,000 yesterday on long-term bond issues which are to be reoffered to investers later in the week.
Beethoven win beat baseball into Dodgertown this year. The Brooklyn Symphony Orchestra will take its first turn at bat with his Fifth Symphony on March 16 in the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
A three-way radio patrol service for better coverage of 771 miles of waterfront by customs officers was placed in official operation yesterday by Harry M. Durning, Collector of the Port of New York.

Eighty truckloads of food -- 1,000,000 pounds of various commodities for immediate needs of the people of Israel -- traveled yesterday in a motorcade to City Hall for official acceptance before shipment overseas.

ROME, Feb. 23 -- The Vatican newspaper Osservatore Romano this evening published an official protest against an article entitled "Cod and the Atlantic Pact" written by Communist leader Palmiro Togliatti for the Communist weekly Vie Nuove.

Medium and smaller banks throughout the state are showing increasing interest in profit-sharing and incentive-compensation plans for officers and employes, according to the New York State Bankers Association. Prompted by requests for information regarding such plans received recently, the association has begun a survey of its member banks, asking reports on the policy and experience of the individual institutions.

Directors of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad authorized here yesterday the payment of interest for 1948 on the road's general - mortgage income convertible 4 1/2 per cent, series A, bonds, payable on May 1. However, they deferred payment of a dividend on the $5 cumulative pre ferred stock.
RHODES, Thursday, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Egyptian-Israeli general armistice agreement:

Operations last year of the Eaton Manufacturing Company and its subsidiaries resulted in new high records for sales and earnings of this manufacturer of automotive and aircraft parts, according to the annual report released today.
War between the United States and Russia is not imminent, Edwin L. James, managing editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and Hanson W. Baldwin, its military editor, agreed yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 23 -- Over Russian objections, the United Nations Commission on Conventional Armaments decided today to go ahead with the job of planning an international agency to collect facts and figures on the world's armed forces and weapons -- all except the atomic bomb.

BOSTON, Feb. 23 -- Dr. Fred Field Goodsell, executive vice president of the missionary organization that founded Protestantism in Bulgaria, today called Sofia's charges on the arrest of fifteen churchmen "the statement of a Government which now wishes to deny any worthy connection with the West."

Columbia's basketball team, home from a three-game road trip on which it regained the leadership of the Ivy League, beat Brown by 58 -- 36 at the University Hall Gym last night before a crowd of 2,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23 -- A far-reaching campaign to triple the amount of money now spent for the nation's public school and double the teaching staff was mapped here today by the country's most influential educational organizations.
LONDON, Feb. 23 -- A wait-and-see attitude was prevalent in the stock market here today, political influences having a restraining factor.

Oscar Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, joined yesterday with delegates to a state CIO legislative conference in an attack on the state Republican Administration's approach to disability insurance.
BERLIN, Feb. 23 -- Taegliche Rundschau, Soviet Army newspaper, declared today that Soviet military forces were "steadily increasing."

Eventual establishment of international trade fairs in the United States, similar to those held in Europe on a large scale, was predicted yesterday by Jacques Kunstenaar, chief of the fairs and exhibitions branch of the Office of International Trade.

Bishop Tiran Nersoyan, Primate of the Armenian Apostolic Orthodox Church in North America, and eight Protestant clergymen issued a statement yesterday protesting a recent Appellate Division decision against the release of three children here to join their father in Soviet Armenia.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 23 -- Since a world government today would, in his opinion, be incomplete because it would exclude the Soviet Union, the North Atlantic Security Pact was the "next best step" toward international security, Dr. Philip C. Jessup declared here this evening.
The best financial "break" since commercial post-war shipping was resumed is accruing to steamship operators as a result of reduced fuel prices, it was reported here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 16:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -Spokesmen for a major part of the iron and steel industry opposed at a hearing today a proposal to have the Secretary of Labor reset prevailing minimum rates for work on government contracts.
A trilogy of colors in silhouettes both large and small provided the story for the Milgrim showing of spring custom-made millinery yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- A good many of President Truman's friends waited uneasily today for the revelation of popular sentiment toward his use, at a mixed, public dinner, of a vulgar term to describe certain critics. Persons who saw Mr. Truman today said the incident did not seem to weigh on his mind.

A warning that the condition of the Arab refugees from Palestine continues to be critical despite the assistance that has reached them was given last night by Dr. Bayard Dodge, president emeritus of the American University of Beirut, Lebanon, and adviser to the United Nations Relief of Palestine Refugees.

American aid under the European Recovery Program averages $17 a person. This figure, released yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board, means that aid ranges from $2 to $74 per capita in various countries.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- Price changes in the grain markets here were rapid on the Board of Trade today, but the average was higher with May deliveries showing independent strength. Wheat closed 3/8 to 1 cent higher; corn, 1 1/4 to 1 5/8 cents higher; oats, 5/8 cent higher to 1/8 cent lower, and soy beans, unchanged to 3 cents higher.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 23 -- The farmers who fatten livestock for the American dinner table foresaw today higher meat prices and even an acute meat shortage by midsummer.

After carefully, and we hope with open mind, reviewing once more the arguments for and against permanent personal registration of voters, we take our stand again in favor of such registration. It cannot be convincingly denied that it means a large net increase in convenience for the voters.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -The Supreme Court late today ordered a stay of execution for Samuel Tito Williams, New York Negro who was scheduled to die tomorrow for the killing of a 15-year-old white girl.

CORVALLIS, Ore., Feb. 23 -- Dr. A. L. Strand, president of Oregon State University, said today that he had dismissed an associate chemistry professor for supporting the genetics teachings of Prof. Trofim D. Lysenko, the Russian Communist.

Sitting comfortably in the pale pink atmosphere of Elizabeth Arden's salon at 691 Fifth Avenue, looking at the luxurious clothes designed by Castillo (Miss Arden persuaded this gifted young Spaniard to leave Paris for New York a few years ago), one forgets the hustle and bustle of the avenue and for an hour or so is transported into a world of fantasy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, today ordered a contraction of military hospital facilities in line with recommendations by his Committee on Medical and Hospital Services of the Armed Forces.

WARSAW, Feb. 23 -- The Polish Ministry of Foreign Affairs disclosed today that it had recently called its Ministers in Norway, Sweden, Denmark and Finland for a conference on the progress of the Atlantic pact.
A renewed school and community campaign to clean up garbage-strewn streets and lots in East Harlem will get under way Monday, it was announced yesterday.

A friend who always walks with a slight roll when reminded of his wartime experience as a mariner dropped in the other day, and he was rolling. "The greatest medical discovery of all time has just been made," he said, "made again, that is."
Maintenance men, porters, firemen and clerical help employed by the City Housing Authority on thirty-five low-rental housing developments called off their six-day work stoppage yesterday.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 23 (AP) -- The Atlantic Coast Line Railroad has filed notice of appeal from Federal Judge Samuel H. Sibley's order disapproving a plan of the Interstate Commerce Commission for reorganization of the bankrupt Florida East Coast Railroad.

The $10,000,000,000 American Telephone and Telegraph Company issued yesterday its annual report for 1948 in advance of its sixty- fourth annual meeting set for April 20. Consolidated net income of the system for the year amounted to $222,415,868, a rise of $61,227,245 over the $161,188,623 reported for 1947.

It is cheaper for business and industry to support the treatment of maladjusted children in an effort to cure them, than to cope with them as maladjusted adults, John A. Coleman, executive chairman of the Cardinal's Special Gifts Committee of the Laity in the annual drive for Catholic Charities, declared here yesterday.
Barnard College girls will take over their own housekeeping chores in the dormitories next fall to avoid paying an increase in room charges of $75.

SOFIA, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The Bulgarian Government today issued a booklet accusing the fifteen indicted Protestant churchmen of using religion to cloak espionage activities for the United States and Britain. The trial of the fifteen is scheduled to open here Friday.

A committee representing holders of more than 20 per cent of the Waltham Watch Company's common stock submitted to trustees yesterday a reorganization plan devoid of government loans for the ninety - nine - year - old Waltham (Mass.) watch-making concern which filed a petition in bankruptcy in the Massachusetts District Court on last Dec. 28.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The Ambassador of Mexico, Rafael de la Colina, on behalf of President Miguel Aleman of Mexico, awarded decorations today to twenty-six "distinguished Americans" for promoting inter-American understanding and comity.

THE German air assault on Britain is a tale of divided counsels, conflicting purposes and never fully accomplished plans. Three or four times in these months the enemy abandoned a method of attack which was causing us severe distress, and turned to something new.

Increased industrial unemployment among Negroes in Detroit, Omaha and Chicago was reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the National Urban League. The observation was made by Lester B. Granger, executive secretary, in the auditorium of the Russell Sage Foundation, 130 East Twenty-second Street.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Feb. 23 (AP) -- The United States women's squash racquets team won the Wolfe-Noel cup for the first time since 1937 today when it defeated England's leading players, 3 -- 2, at the Merion Cricket Club.

Sportsmen's Show sidelights. A number of the male show visitors are so occupied in watching the Marathon twins operate the line-braiding machine at the Marathon exhibit that they fail to look over the display of finished products on the shelves.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The United States is "good for 1,000 years," declared President Truman tonight in urging support for a new record-breaking savings bond drive, which will seek to raise $1,040,000,000 from individual buyers.
ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Favored teams, with the exception of Miss Patty Berg and Johnny Revolta, advanced in the first round of the international mixed two-ball golf tournament today.

VIENNA, Feb. 23 -- After having spent nearly a year in Vienna awaiting trial, Lieut. Col. Walter G. Rishel of the United States Air Force was found not guilty by a court-martial here today of the last of twenty-two charges made against him in connection with his service with the United States Military Mission in Hungary.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Republicans transformed the Senate chamber into a schoolroom today for a "lecture" by Senator Benjamin F. Feinberg, majority leader, on the money from the State Reconstruction Fund spent by the Dewey administration for highways.
The Library of Congress's Fellows in American Letters, when on Feb. 19 they awarded the first annual Bollingen prize for poetry to Ezra Pound, had this to say:

American Woolen Company opened its fall lines of women's wear worsteds and woolens yesterday, according to Charles Silver, vice president. Prices on the repeat numbers are the same as those currently prevailing, he said, and the company is introducing a large variety of new fabrics, priced on a comparable basis.
The Bank of New York and Fifth Avenue Bank has been appointed co-transfer agent for 2,869,948 outstanding shares of Royalite Oil Company, Ltd.

The Jones and Laughlin Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it will ask stockholders at the annual meeting on April 26 to authorize an additional 1,000,000 shares of common stock and raise the company's borrowing capacity by $62,266,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 23 -- In a surprise move, Screen Plays, Inc., the Stanley Kramer Producing Company, today announced plans for immediate film production of Arthur Laurents' Broadway play of three years ago, "Home of the Brave."

Some radio manufacturers and distributors are forcing dealers to accept unwanted quantities of smaller-screen television receivers and high-priced radio-phonograph combinations before filling orders for sixteen-inch tube television sets, Arthur Freed, president, Freed Radio Corporation, declared yesterday.

Full support and cooperation of the alcoholic beverage industry's tax council, formed last week to represent all tax interests of the industry, was voted by the National Retail Liquor Package Stores Association yesterday after a three-day meeting here in the Edison Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The Army went back into the marriage counseling business today.

An important line of attack upon the proposed Atlantic Pact has met with too little rejoinder. I refer to the argument that the pact, in so far as Great Britain is concerned, would be wholly inconsistent with the Anglo-Soviet treaty of May, 1942.

The fight of a life term convict to regain his freedom under a legal technicality drew near a close in Bronx County Court yesterday when Judge Samuel Joseph upheld the contention of John McAllister, 52 years old, that his constitutional rights had been violated.

Anna Louise Strong, American woman journalist who recently was expelled from Russia as a spy for this country, landed at La Guardia Airport at 12:50 A. M. today after a transatlantic flight from Paris. As she stepped from the plane a Federal subpoena was handed to her by an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Successful tests show that concrete highways can be waterproofed two ways and destruction caused by chloride brines from ice-removing chemicals virtually eliminated, more than 500 members of the forty-fifth annual convention of the American Concrete Institute were told yesterday at the Statler Hotel by engineers from the New York State Department of Public Works.

The nation's gasoline stocks were increased last week 2,753,000 barrels to a new peak of 122,533,000, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A week earlier supplies were 119,780,000 barrels, the previous high. A year earlier the total was 109,886,000 barrels.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 23 -- George D. Widener's Reveille pawed playfully as he went around Hialeah Park's walking ring before the running of the $12,325 Everglades Handicap today. Onlookers chuckled as he threw a succession of right jabs.

Richard Jarvis, 24-year-old pilot of Buzzards Bay, Mass., and his sister, Millicent Jarvis, 21, a college student, avoided serious injury at 12:30 P. M. yesterday when they made a forced landing in a Cessna-140 plane on the Bayside Golf Links, near 203d Street and Twenty-sixth Avenue, Bayside, Queens.

Retail grocers throughout the state are being warned to make careful reviews of their credit extension methods at this time, an official of the New York State Food Merchants Association disclosed yesterday.
TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 23 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll announced today his candidacy for re-election. He thus became the first New Jersey Governor in more than a century to seek to succeed himself.
LONDON, Feb. 23 -- An important man visited an unimportant street in an undistinguished borough of London this afternoon.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 - - Efforts were under way today to find a compromise satisfactory to both sides in the controversy between supporters of the Dewey administration and insurgent Republican legislators from Westchester and Erie counties over the Governor's $168,200,000 tax increase program.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 23 -It is estimated here, on the basis reports from provincial authorities, that approximately 3,000 persons have been arrested since the nation-wide Communist round-up began last Saturday. About a thousand persons have been incarcerated in a separate drive in Hydera-bad State and another thousand are held from previous arrests under public safety laws.

NANKING, Feb. 23 -- There is a growing conviction here that the split between the Nanking and Canton regimes may become final, with the faction led by Acting President Li Tsung-jen repudiating the other half of the Government and dealing with the Communists on its own.
The spring hat collection of Baroness Luly Radvanzky, shown yesterday in her salon at 867 Madison Avenue, included many silhouettes suitable for the mature woman.

A black metal valise that aroused the suspicions of the police was delivered at 6:50 P. M yesterday to the residence of Cardinal Spellman at 452 Madison Avenue, but its contents proved to be harmless.

Wanda Landowska provided her large audience with masterly music-making throughout her recital last night at Town Hall. The eminent harpsichordist presented a noble program of music of the eighteenth century, every offering of which she made both enchanting to hear and also a priceless educational experience for all interested in the proper interpretation of music of the period.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23 -- The Philadelphia Transportation Company applied today to the State Public Utility Commission for permission to put a basic 13-cent fare into effect immediately.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Dr. Paul B. Magnuson, chief medical director of the Veterans Administration, announced today a plan for country-wide medical care based on an all-out attack of its most costly element, diagnosis.

The National Federation of American Shipping sent a memorandum yesterday to all members of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee questioning proposed aid to Norway in the reconstruction of her merchant fleet.

The decision of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters to encourage, rather than obstruct, the development of central motor truck terminals of the kind the Port of New York Authority is building in this city and Newark is welcome news from several viewpoints.

As part of its revised expansion program, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has called in technicians of the Columbia Broadcasting System for advice on the installation of a television studio and television outlets throughout the museum, it was announced yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 23 -- Aubrey S. Eban, Israeli representative at the United Nations, issued a statement today declaring that the armistice agreement between Israel and Egypt "is an important landmark in the relations of Israel with the United Nations and with the Arab world."

A realistic and workable plan for reorganization of the National Guard and the Organized Reserves has been drawn up by the Army's Committee on Civilian Components. This plan would bring each organization to a state of peacetime readiness that would provide quick assimilation into the Regular Army in case of emergency.
Scotch whisky was selling yesterday for $1 a bottle -- but not in the package stores of New York.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Mildred E. (Axis Sally) Gillars testified at her treason trial today that she scorned a German proposal to betray American secrets "even if it meant my death."
March cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 20 points higher, and other months were 6 points higher to 6 lower.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 23 -- A Princeton University English instructor who has been informed that his contract would not be renewed at the close of the spring term announced today that he would contest his dismissal at the next general meeting of the Princeton faculty on March 7.

Phoenix, Ariz., announced yesterday that it would receive bids until March 22 on two issues of bonds aggregating $7,350,000. One issue will consist of $3,500,000 of water revenue bonds due on each July 1 from 1950 to 1978, and callable on July 1, 1967.

An invitation preview of a Degas loan exhibition at the Wildenstein Galleries, followed by a spring supper dance on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria on the night of April 6, will be given as a benefit for the New York Infirmary.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, said today that "it looks as though we are in for a continued prosperous period."

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 23 -- President Juan D. Peron, in one of his old line fighting speeches, said last night that within a matter of days he would call upon the Argentine workers "to come forth and defend our cause wherever it may be necessary."
Manhattan's track squad plans to go "all out" for team honors in the intercollegiate A. A. A. A. championships at Madison Square Garden on Saturday.
The bias of the current leadership in the New York State Legislature was painfully apparent in the conduct of the budget hearing in Albany on Feb. 16.
A case of third-period jitters that affected the Rangers pretty badly enabled the Boston Bruins to subdue New York at Madison Square Garden last night, 3 to 2.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Aliens who help spies of the United States abroad would receive sanctuary in the United States under a bill unanimously approved by the House Armed Services Committee today.

HERKIMER, N. Y., Feb. 23 -- The Mohawk Valley, which likes to describe itself as the "heart" of New York State industry, has been harder hit than any other district by the current rise in unemployment.

BOSTON, Feb. 23 -- Champion Carillon Colin of Puttencove, handsome black standard poodle, took best in show tonight in the thirty-sixth and most successful event of the Eastern Dog Club and secured additional glory thereby because his beaten opponents included Westminster's big boxer, Champion Mazeleine's Zazarac Brandy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Four weeks of acrimonious hearings by the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee on the Administration's labor relations bill ended tonight with the expectation by committee members that they could work out a measure for presentation to the Senate within ten days.

Bernie Reynolds, promising young Fairfield, Conn., heavyweight, had an easy time pounding out a decision over Walter Hafer of Maysville, Ky., last night in the feature ten-round bout at Manhattan Center. But the victory may cost Reynolds heavily.

The board of trustees of the American Medical Association was officially requested by a group of leading AMA members yesterday to invite representatives of labor, industry, agriculture and other lay interests to a nation-wide conference to work out a better plan of medical care for this country.

When President Truman spoke in his Inaugural Address of "a bold new program for making the benefits of our scientific advances and industrial progress available for the improvement and growth of underdeveloped areas," there was naturally some speculation as to how precise a plan he had in mind.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Over the objections of six Democrats, the Senate passed today the Feinberg bill to regulate the publication and sale of comic books through the State Education Department. The vote was 49 to 6.

Coffee futures, with the exception of spot March "D" were steady on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Trade covering absorbed the selling, which was scattered. Final prices for contract "D" were unchanged to 5 points higher.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 23 -- Eighteen witnesses testified concerning ten Westchester County burglaries at the opening here today of a grand jury investigation of crimes alleged to have been committed by Gerard Graham Dennis, the "Raffles" burglar.

The Dun and Bradstreet wholesale food price index, which fell sharply the first seven weeks after the Christmas holidays, has climbed for the second consecutive week, the agency reported yesterday, according to The United Press.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The Senate Democrats refused today, in a long and grave all-party conference, to thrust the filibuster-civil rights issue into the background next week in favor of early action on the reciprocal-trade program.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Gross weekly earnings of factory production workers averaged lower in mid-January as a result of a lower average work week, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

The Governments of Israel and Egypt signed formally at Rhodes yesterday a permanent armistice agreement amounting to a non-aggression pact. This puts an end to the war between them and clears the path to permanent peace in the Holy Land and the whole Middle East. The State of

New York City was host to more recreational visitors and convention delegates in 1948 than in any previous year except 1939, the first year of the World's Fair, Bernard F. Gimbel, president and chairman of the board of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, reported yesterday.

Affiliated clubs of the Advertising Federation of America, Inc., have been asked to report any state legislation which may make mandatory the registration of all trade marks upon penalty of owners' loss of common law rights to the marks, it was announced yesterday. In a memorandum to club presidents, George S. McMillan, AFA board chairman, noted that such legislation is now pending in New Hampshire, Washington, Indiana and Ohio.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 24 -- Political advisers of the three Western military governments negotiated today important agreements on their views of the Western German draft constitution.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Curtiss-Wright Corporation and Darryl F. Zanuck, movie producer, received the biggest of 32,000,000 corporate and individual tax refunds during the last fiscal year.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- After several years of study by the Joint Legislative Committee on Motor Vehicle Problems, a bill providing for compulsory inspection of automobiles will be introduced in the Legislature tomorrow, Senator Seymour Halpern of Queens, chairman of the committee, announced today.

Each piece in the new English dinnerware that Macy's will introduce Monday in its spring china and glass show is distinguished by a different floral motif arranged in a cluster. The individual decorations, planned to add variety to a setting, are harmonious in style and coloring.

Plans for the formation of an American corporation to promote a wide range of entertainment enterprises in the new state of Israel were discussed here yesterday by a group of motion - picture theatre owners and other business men.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- The Associated British Picture Corporation, Ltd., will spend 2,000,000 [$8,000,000] on ten feature productions this year, Robert Clark, the corporation's executive director, announced today. Unless conditions in the British motion-picture industry grow worse, he declared, a similar amount will be spent next year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Ohio Public Service Company, Cleveland, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 1,000,000 shares of $5 par value common stock and $10,000,000 of thirty-year first mortgage bonds, series due 1979.
