CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- Recent "rate wars" among savings and loan associations in various cities hold little promise of increasing the total volume of funds flowing into all institutions of this type and will mean only a redistribution of savings among them, in the opinion of Arthur M. Weimer, Dean of the School of Business of Indiana University.

Directors of the Baldwin Locomotive Works, at a regular meeting held yesterday in Philadelphia, declared a quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock, payable on April 30. Last year the company paid two dividens of 50 cents each in June and December.

The Board of Estimate implemented yesterday by an appropriation of $115,000 a plan to make cash payments to tenants willing to relocate themselves after being displaced from their homes because of public construction projects.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 24 -- The secretary general of the Communist party, Rudolf Slansky, today devoted a speech before an extraordinary session of the party general executive committee commemorating the February coup of a year ago to praise of President Klement Gottwald.

The Negro American has come of age, and a celebration of the achievements given to civilization by present day Negro scholars, singers, writers and scientists is in keeping with the American tradition of paying homage to leaders of every age and race. Some fear that Negro History Week has become
CANTON, Feb. 24 (UP) -- Finance Minister Hsu Kan today announced a broad program of financial and economic reforms authorizing a free market in gold and silver and a revised tax system.

Saying that the revolt of the States' Rights Southern Democrats in the last Presidential campaign was a magnification of a situation in the Democratic party that existed locally, Borough President Hugo E. Rogers, leader of Tammany, appealed last night for party unity as a preliminary to this year's city campaign.

Business loans by banks in this area continued to expand moderately last week, rising $11,000,000 in the fourth consecutive weekly advance. A principal factor in the growth in loans by the reporting New York City member banks during the week ended on Wednesday was an increase in borrowings by oil companies, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Senator Elmer F. Quinn of Manhattan, minority leader of the State Senate, criticized the Dewey administration last night for not giving more aid to education and hospitals out of the state's $600,000,000 post-war surplus.

Since Clifford Odets feels deeply about nearly everything, "The Big Knife" fairly snaps with emotion. Mr. Odets says that Hollywood is an evil place. With John Garfield at the head of an enthralling group of players, "The Big Knife" opened up the National Theatre last evening, and Mr. Odets revealed some of Hollywood's most monstrous abominations.

The mental picture invoked by the bill just passed by the State Senate, of an agent of the august Regents of the University of the State of New York ensconced in a Comic Book Division of the Department of Education for the purpose of pre-censorship of the millions of comic books sold in the state, is for some of us at least a comic one.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Administration leadership of the Congressional Joint Committee on the Economic Report will make a strong plea for higher taxes in findings to be published next week, it was learned today.

RED BANK, N. J., Feb. 24 -- The Watson Laboratories of the Air Materiel Command near here announced today the elimination soon of the human controller from the Ground Control Approach system for landing airplanes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that a union was responsible for strike violence directed or incited by qualified officers of the union.
ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 24 (AP) -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias and Walter Roman staged a birdie finish to knock the defending champions out of the international mixed two-ball golf tournament today.
For the last sixteen years, a small group of vigilant men has concerned itself with guarding the slumbers of New York State residents.
DUBLIN, Eire, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Irish blood boiled in the Eire Parliament today when somebody questioned an Irishman's right to own a gun.

Action on the proposed local law to increase taxicab fares by 27 per cent was postponed yesterday by the City Council until its meeting at 1:30 P. M. next Tuesday. Before voting postponement the Council received a minority report by Councilmen Genevieve B. Earle of Brooklyn Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan and Alfred J. Phillips of Queens, all Republicans, opposing the measure.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- The Court of Appeals, in a unanimous ruling, held in effect today that the Public Service Commission could not attach conditions in authorizing utilities to issue new securities. The ruling was made in a decision directing the commission to give the Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation the unconditional right to issue $23,677,000 of new securities.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- The main interest in the stock market here today centered on the Hammersmith by-election and conditions were quiet. But brokers are expecting a livelier price movement tomorrw as the result will be known before the market opens. But any changes will depend on which way the election goes.

After early steadiness on trade demand, coffee futures turned slightly easier on scattered selling on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Final prices for contract "D" were 4 to 20 points below the previous levels. The spot month was weak.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Department store sales in the week ended Feb. 19 were S per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:

Something new was added to the New York waterfront yesterday when the streamlined motor vessel Seattle, flying the flag of Sweden on a type of voyage rare in maritime annals, docked at pier 88, West Forty-fourth Street.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb 24 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today signed William Wellman to direct "Battleground," the studio's projected semi-documentary treatment of the Battle of the Bulge, in which Robert Taylor, Van Johnson, John Hodiak, Keenan Wynn and Ricardo Montalban will play the leading roles.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Sixty-three non-scheduled air passenger carriers, operating through an association named the National Independent Air Carriers, asked the Department of Justice today to investigate alleged breaches of the anti-trust laws in an advertising campaign conducted by the certificated and scheduled airlines.

Hats of classic design in exciting new straws and interesting fabric combinations were seen in a fashion show at the Plaza Hotel during luncheon yesterday. They were the designs of Eve Tartar of 676 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Feb. 19 totaled 697,335 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 2,107 cars, or 0.3 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 107,602 cars, or 13.4 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 79,354 cars, or 10.2 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

RHODES, Feb. 24 -- In an atmosphere of friendliness and general satisfaction, Egypt and Israel signed here this morning a general armistice agreement described by Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine, as "epochal" and "workable."
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Favored combinations showed the way through the early rounds of the women's national squash racquets doubles championship at the Philadelphia Cricket Club today.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 8, Curtis D. Epler criticizes the way in which the Austrian authorities are handling the problem of restitution. Of course, it is difficult -- if not impossible -- for somebody living in the United States to follow the developments in Austria accurately, and it appears that
An evening spent listening to the radio has left me disturbed and angered by the steady stream of worthless and actually harmful material offered as entertainment.

The Board of Education went on record yesterday as supporting a bill recently introduced into the State Assembly that would bar from the state's schools teachers who are members of the Communist party.

PARIS, Feb. 24 -- A strike of farmers next week unless the Government does something to aid them in the crisis of falling food prices was threatened today by Philip Lamour, secretary general of the French Confederation of Agriculture.
More than 40,000 additional reserve officers and enlisted men in the First Army area now are eligible to receive payment for attending authorized drills and meetings, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Julius A. Krug Secretary of the Interior, denied today that he was evading a law by keeping in their posts Reclamation Commissioner Michael W. Straus and Regional Director Richard L. Boke whose salaries were cut off Feb. 1 by action of the last Congress.

Frequently in preparing a fashion report this writer becomes so absorbed in the over-all picture that she neglects to treat with special care the items that have the greatest fashion appeal for her. It is like eating a good meal and having no room for the desert.

Underwriting syndicates here will offer to investors today four new issues of corporate securities totaling $36,500,000. The offerings, which include bonds of public utility enterprises, sinking fund debentures of a financial company, and railroad equipment trust serial obligations, are as follows:
LONDON, Feb. 24 -- British industry has agreed to extend for one year its voluntary "freeze" of dividends at levels ruling two years ago, it was announced today.

The International Workers Order denied yesterday that it had raised funds for the defense of Mrs. Rosa Lee Ingram, Georgia Negro woman who was convicted recently of the murder of John E. Stafford, a white neighbor. The organization also denied having "misused" funds contributed for the "welfare and education" of the Ingram children.
HARLINGEN, Tex., Feb. 24 (AP) -- Dave Douglas, golf's thin man, rolled in with an eight under par 63 today to take a two-stroke lead in the first round of the $10,000 Rio Grande Valley open.

Israel-bound from Shanghai, 447 Jewish refugees now on a transcontinental train from San Francisco will arrive at Jersey City Sunday morning and will be permitted to see relatives and friends during a three-day stay on Ellis Island.

Walter D. Fletcher, New York attorney, and Dr. Condict s. Cutler Jr., director of surgery at the Goldwater Memorial Hospital, Welfare Island, have been elected members of the board of trustees of Columbia University, Frederick Coykendall, chairman of the board, announced yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Governor Dewey has flatly rejected a request from insurgent Republican legislators that he suggest cuts in the $936,200,000 budget he has recommended so that his proposals for $168,200,000 in tax increases can be pared.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- Preston Tucker admitted today that the Tucker Corporation had made most of the expenditures alleged in a Government petition which brough a temporary court order restraining the company from dipping further into a special reserve account. He denied, however, the expenditure violated a Federal district order of Jan. 26 restricting the company's operations to maintenance on a shutdown basis.

Milton Berle, who is home from Florida, recovered from his illness, will return as master of ceremonies to "Texaco Star Theatre" on Tuesday evening, it was announced yesterday. On the 8 P. M. telecast over NBC, Mr. Berle will share the spotlight with Virginia O'Brien, Billy Gilbert, Pat Rooney Sr. and a tumbling team whose antics are said to include a spot for the versatile Mr. Berle.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- President Truman expressed extreme gratification today over the news of the armistice between Israel and Egypt, and promised to consider United States economic aid for the entire Middle East once peace is assured there.

PARIS, Friday, Feb. 25 -- By a vote of 386 to the Communists' 182, the French National Assembly this morning con demned the Communist leader, Maurice Thorez, for urging his followers to side with the Soviet Union's troops if they invaded France. The Assembly's resolution asked the French Government to defend the national independence and apply the law.

The 1948 Broun Memorial Award, given annually by the American. Newspaper Guild for "the most outstanding journalistic achievement in the spirit of Heywood Broun," went yesterday to Elias A. McQuaid for a series of stories he did for The New Hampshire News of Manchester, N. H.

Final educational authority in New York State still rests with the Board of Regents despite the creation of the Board of Trustees of the State University of New York, Dr. Alvin C. Eurich, president of the latter group, declared last night.

Commodity exchanges throughout the country "have not been handicapped unduly by Federal regulations," Harold D. Cooley, chairman of the House Agricultural Committee, told the Commodity Club of New York at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night.

Miss Marie Corridon, representing the Women's Swimming Association, captured the women's senior metropolitan 100-yard freestyle championship for the seventh consecutive time last night when she led home Miss Betty Mullen, a clubmate, in one of six title A. A. U. events held at the Downtown Athletic Club pool.

Two young infielders, Clarence (Buddy) Hicks and Bob Morgan, signed Dodger contracts yesterday, increasing the total of satisfied players to thirty-three and left only seven to be dealt with by Branch Rickey. As previously announced by the Brooklyn president, no trouble is expected landing the missing ones.

St. John's was at its best -- or close to it -- and accounted for a 71-64 upset victory over N. Y. U. in the afterpiece of the college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden last night. This outcome was in keeping with the theme of the program, which produced an even more startling reversal in the curtain-raiser, in which Manhattan overwhelmed La Salle of Philadelphia, 62 -- 53.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Heavy Republican Congressional pressure was put on the Truman Administration today for new material aid to Nationalist China or for a warning declaration against the Communist assailants of that regime.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- The leaders of Britain's ruling Labor party who are going away tomorrow to a secret week-end conference to draft the party's program for the next general election in 1950 had their confidence in victory fortified tonight by still another Labor triumph at the polls.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The latest and probably final draft of Article 5 of the proposed North Atlantic defense pact makes a specific reference to the possibility of the use of armed force to defend the North Atlantic community.

The right of a landlord to remove a tenant's unauthorized television antenna from the roof of an apartment house was upheld by an all-tenant jury in Bronx Municipal Court yesterday. Similar decisions have been handed down by Courts of Special Sessions in at least two cases, but this was believed to be the first to go to a jury.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- A rise of 56,000,000 ($224,000,000) in the expenditures of the British Government's civil departments for the next fiscal year was forecast today as a result of the appropriations that were recommended to Parliament.

Coincident with reporting record sales and earnings for 1948, the Chrysler Corporation announced yesterday that its directors had approved plans for increasing the authorized common stock from 15,000,000 to 20,000,000 shares and for raising the par value of the stock from $2.50 to $25 a share.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 24 -- The United Nations has become a debating society and "needs to get some solid accomplishment under its belt," Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, president of Kansas State College, declared today. He suggested it might do so with a world-wide attack on the problem of soil conservation and food production.
WASHINGTON, Feb 24 -- During the week ended Feb. 23, member bank reserve balances decreased $6,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee approved a subcommittee's bi-partisan housing bill today, 9 to 3, after crushing an attempt by Senator John W. Bricker, Republican, of Ohio, to insert an anti-segregation clause.

Alert detective work led yesterday to the apprehension of an alleged robber and rapist in his Harlem flat several hours after he was said to have assaulted a South Carolina schoolteacher in an automobile in Brooklyn.

CAPETOWN, Union of South Africa, Feb. 24 -- In a further endeavor to make South Africa live within her means, Finance Minister Nicholaas C. Havenga announced today a tighter and broader control over imports.

VIENNA, Feb. 24 -- Czechoslovakia's Communist leadership, which will tomorrow celebrate the first anniversary of the coup that brought the Communists into power a year ago, has set itself a tremendous task of revolutionary transformation to fit Czechoslovakia into the scheme of the Eastern European "people's democracies."

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Soviet dramatists effectively silenced theatre critics in a three-day Moscow conference, the Moscow radio announced today. The broadcast said that a group of critics were exposed as "anti-popular and hostile" to the Soviet Union.

With the comment that there is no reason for becoming "panicky about getting back to a free enterprise system," R. M. Fowler, president of the Canadian Paper and Pulp Association, urged yesterday that paper industry management use "imagination and good sense" in meeting the buyers' market challenge.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- President Truman tonight threatened to stump the country to force Congressional enactment of Democratic platform pledges if obstruction by "the special interests" continues.

As the Carnegie mansion at Fifth Avenue and Ninety-first Street was opened to the public for the last time yesterday, representatives of the New York School of Social Work, which is to take over the building, found that the steel executive had set the scene for their occupancy nearly fifty years ago.

Alton Jones, pianist, who has often been heard in this city, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. His program comprised the Bach-Liszt Prelude and Fugue in A minor; Haydn's Sonata in B flat major, No. 24; Prokofieff's Sonata, No. 6; Schumann's "Papillons"; Wallingford Riegger's "Four Tone Pictures" and Chopin's Polonaise in F sharp minor.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 24 -- Underwear swayed in the breeze on laundry lines criss-crossing the main streets of Beuel today as that town near here celebrated the 125th anniversary of Weiberfastnacht, honoring washerwomen.
LOS ANGELES, Calif., Feb. 24 -- Gov. Earl Warren explained today how California, with less population than New York, happened to have a $1,060,000,000 budget, topping New York's.

BOSTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Slugger Ted Williams' oft-intimated ambition to become baseball's first $100000 player appeared fulfilled tonight when he advised General Manager Joe Cronin he would sign his 1949 Red Sox contract on arrival at the Sarasota training camp on March 6.

Ralph E. Samuel, president of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, announced yesterday that he sided with the administration of Maimonides Hospital in the row going on there over a staff reorganization program.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Feb. 24 -- The current slump in industrial employment may affect farm incomes and farm labor requirements this summer, spokesmen for New York canners and food processors indicated here today.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 24 -- Owing partly to a decrease in freight shipments but mainly to a shrinking volume of trade, business in the Pittsburgh district last week fell to the lowest level reported in nearly two months, according to the Bureau of Business Research of Pittsburgh.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- President Truman was far from gloomy today over the reaction to his speech Tuesday night in which he applied an "s. o. b." epithet to a critic.

A minor but harmless mystery developed yesterday with the appearance of printed posters inside a number of buses of the Surface Transportation Corporation, carrying the message, "Release Cardinal Mindszenty."
CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- Women's eyes and ideas are bigger than their pocketbooks, so far as new dwellings under present construction costs are concerned.

Continuing increases in the numbers of relief applicants may force the Welfare Department to seek an additional rise of $5,000,000 in its budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1, Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard said yesterday. He spoke before the Women's City Club, in the New Weston Hotel.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- A second revolt of Republican members of the Legislature, directed against Governor Dewey's support of the State University trustees in their controversy with the Board of Regents over the state system of higher education, gained impetus today.

The legendary Englishman would rather die than exhibit emotion in public. Winston Churchill is a legendary Englishman in another sense. He seems more and more, as his story of the Second World War unrolls in our columns, an Englishman of the Elizabethan period. Something of Drake...

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Yugoslavia virtually abandoned today her long standing claims for a large slice of Austrian territory plus $150,000,000 in reparations and submitted instead a four-point program open to modification.

Three little Indians got back yesterday a tiny piece of Manhattan Island. Herbert Tough Eagle, 13 years old; Lamont White Antelope, 11, and Joseph Humming Bird, 14, dressed in the war paint of their tribes, were placated and made life members of the Children's Aid Society West Side Center, 409 West Thirty-eighth Street.

Despite the inherent antipathy that utilities seem to have for regulatory bodies, there occasionally arise situations that reflect a reluctant admission that such agencies serve the company and the customer. A case in point was the recent unsuccessful effort of the Florida Power Corporation to persuade the Legislature in the Orange Blossom State to set up a utility commission comparable to the forty agencies that exist elsewhere in the country.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Under bipartisan sponsorship and with the backing of a number of civic organizations and prominent educators, a bill was introduced in the Legislature today to provide state aid to nursery schools.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Representative John F. Kennedy, Democrat, of Massachusetts, introduced a bill today to separate air-mail payments from the subsidies now paid to certificated airlines as part of this compensation.

Charles W. Thayer, director of international broadcasts for the State Department's Division of Information and Cultural Affairs, feels reasonably sure after a three months' survey trip through Europe that "The Voice of America" is being listened to on both sides of the "Iron Curtain." Mr. Thayer

Implementing its plan for distribution of French-made women's apparel in the United States, Simon Cohen Co., Inc., has placed orders in Paris for 10,000 to 12,000 coats and suits for delivery during July and August, it was announced yesterday by Simon Cohen, president.
VALPARAISO, Ind., Feb. 24 (AP) -- A revolutionary process of canning fresh milk in which the milk retains its original taste was claimed yesterday by Jack Stambaugh, a dairy farmer here.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Feb. 24 (AP) -- Three Negro boys told police today that they were picked up at gunpoint by five white men last night, taken to Phenix City, Ala., and beaten. The men then drove them off with gunfire, the boys said.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UP) -- Mildred E. (Axis Sally) Gillars today admitted making "propaganda and political" broadcasts for Germany during the war, but insisted she did so for love, not treason.

Alexandra Danilova and Frederic Franklin last night gave their only performances this season of "Giselle" with the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the City Center before their departure for London at the end of the week and made quite an event of it.

Another book of Americana by Harlan Hatcher, author of "Lake Erie," which was issued in the American Lake Series, will be published this season by Bobbs-Merrill. It is "The Western Reserve: The Story of New Connecticut in Ohio," a history of the transcontinental, 120-mile-wide, strip that lay westward between latitude 41 and a point two minutes north of latitude 42, which Connecticut claimed as a colony.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UP) -- Former Gov. Mon Wallgren of Washington said today that he hired several former agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to make a complete loyalty check of his state administration.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UP) --Carroll L. Wilson, general manager of the Atomic Energy Commission, said today the United States had spent "a lot of money" on safety precautions at its plants, "but it was well worth it."

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 24 -- Speaking in the heart of the "states rights" country, where the rebellion against President Truman's civil rights program began, Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, declared tonight that sponsors of the States Rights

THESE were the times when the English, and particularly the Londoners, who had the place of honour, were seen at their best. Grim and gay, dogged anti serviceable, with the confidence of an unconquered people in their bones, they adapted themselves to this strange new life, with all its terrors, with all its jolts and jars.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Donald R. Richberg proposed today a coalition of Democrats and Republicans "in support of the liberalism of local self-government" and predicted that such a combination against "paternalism" could take control of the Congress within a hundred days.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 24 -- Confidence that the proposed North Atlantic pact might well prevent a third world war was expressed tonight by Vice President Alben W. Barkley.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 24 -- Aubrey S. Eban, Israeli representative, today requested the Security Council to reconsider Israel's application for membership in the United Nations in time for the General Assembly to take action when it reconvenes at Flushing Meadow on April 5.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals today unanimously upheld the conviction of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company and twenty-four officers and subsidiary companies on anti-trust charges.

Two Negro women testified at the trial of the eleven Communists yesterday that in the last few years each has served several times on Federal juries. In qualifying for jury duty, they said, neither was asked about her financial standing. They were called to the stand as Government witnesses to refute the defense charge that women and Negroes are systematically excluded from Federal juries.

Egypt is now developing huge plant-assembling industries outside Alexandria and bids fair to become the major trading center in the Near East, Mohamed Kamil Abdul Rahim Bey, Egyptian Ambassador to the United States, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Southern Senators marshaled today to begin on Monday their filibuster against a stiffening in the closure, or "gag," rule that is intended to strike that very weapon from them in the coming fight over President Truman's civil rights program.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 24 -- The statements of confession purportedly signed by five defendants in spy trial in Munich were read in court today, implicating the Polish secret service for the second day as instigators of an attempt to gather information about the military and industrial installations in the United States zone of Germany.

A pilgrimage in the modern manner, forsaking the pilgrim sandals and the chanting marches for trains, planes and fast ocean liners, halted briefly in New York yesterday on its way to the sacred shrines of Europe.

The Marine Marlin, carrying 547 passengers, docked at Pier 62 North River early yesterday after a stormy crossing from Hamburg, described by her master as so severe that he was forced to order passengers locked below as a safety precaution.

KASTORIA, Greece, Feb. 24 -- Greek Army men who have been in front-line positions along the northern frontier for eleven months without respite say that they have observed no change in the military situation resulting from the recent dropping of Gen. Markos Vafiades, Communist guerrilla chief, from the rebel command.

Joey de John, promising Syracuse middleweight, and Pete Mead of Grand Rapids, Mich., will box in the feature ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. De John, engaging in his first main event at the Garden, is a 1-to-2 1 1/2 favorite, despite the fact that Mead knocked him out in five rounds on Dec. 2, 1947, at Buffalo.

This is the month in which the country's tea interests are launching a nation-wide campaign in hopes of encouraging more people to drink more tea. Tea merchandisers last year spent approximately half a million dollars in an

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Wage rates of more than 270,000 General Motors Corporation employes will be cut 2 cents an hour next month as a result of the decline in living costs. On an annual basis this amounts to more than $10,000,000.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 24 -- Angel Timev, Bulgarian Deputy Minister of Justice, held a press conference tonight in a move to establish the good faith of the case prepared by the State against fifteen Protestant ministers who will go on trial tomorrow morning before the district court of Sofia.
HOW doth the little busy bee Improve each shining hour, And gather honey all the day From every opening flower!

Opposition to the creation of a state mental hygiene commission headed by the Commissioner of Mental Hygiene and including the Commissioners of Social Welfare, Health, Correction and Education, flared into the open yesterday. At the same time other aspects of the state's mental hygiene program came in for criticism.
THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial of Feb. 14, "Housing and the Family," shows that our efforts to provide housing must be directed toward building for low and medium income families.
ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 24 (AP) -- An engineering marvel of a century ago has been adapted by scientists of Cornell University to the study of cosmic rays.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- A bill to prevent the use of charitable organizations for tax evasion was introduced in the House today by Representative Robert W. Kean, Republican, of New Jersey.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 24 (AP) -- A steady drizzle fell at Santa Anita Park today, but weather experts were inclined to believe Saturday's $100,000 handicap would be run over a fast track.

Once more the American Automobile Association has opened its national "pedestrian protection" contests. These affairs have been helping in reducing accidents. The percentage of pedestrian deaths (out of all traffic accident fatalities) fell from 35 per cent in 1946 to 31 per cent in 1947, the latest year for which reports are available.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 24 -- Federal scholarships amounting to $100,000,000 annually, awarded to 100,000 high school graduates interested in becoming teachers, were proposed here today by the country's foremost educators.
A 40-year-old man, who was shot and captured by a detective early yesterday morning after a chase in Times Square, was disclosed later to be a jewel thief with a long record of criminal insanity.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 19 -- Sweden, birthplace of the middle way, is a victim today of economic dislocations abroad and a series of mistakes at home. The errors include a post-war spending spree that reduced her from the second strongest independent financial position in Europe to a reluctant recipient of Marshall Plan aid.

OSLO, Norway, Feb. 24 -- Norway's Storting (Parliament) was told today by Foreign Minister Lange that the Government wished to join in the Atlantic pact discussion as soon as possible so that the country would have a hand in shaping the final draft of the document.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Feb. 24 -- An extensive sixty-one-page report on the status of Jews behind the "iron curtain" will be one of the features of the seventh biennial convention of the Jewish Labor Committee, which opened here tonight.

This week-end's grocery bill will be higher than last Friday's, unless the housewife carefully plans her shopping list around the fewer foods remaining in the "reasonable" column. Pork and beef, for example, are best passed up, for on many cuts prices are 2 to 6 cents a pound higher.

Those of us who have a special place in our hearts for the welfare of our children are not surprised to learn that in the past half century the Children's Aid Society has grown to be the largest child-caring organization in the United States, providing a dozen essential services to 45,000 children of all creeds and races.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- All other legislation, as beset by doubts and disputes as the bill to authorize the next annual appropriations for the Economic Cooperation Act (the Marshall Plan), faces a most uncertain future in the Eighty-first Congress. Yet the belief persists among observers at the Capitol

Although Michigan State's star-studded array has been established as the favorite, with Yale and Army next in line, Coach-Emil Von Elling is not ready to concede the loss of the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. team title, which his New York University squad will defend at Madison Square Garden tomorrow.

Consolidated Edison workers strengthened last night the hand of union leaders who have threatened a city-wide utilities strike for some time after midnight Tuesday by voting in a ratio of ninety to one for a strike.

In the wake of half a dozen local previews, "Anybody Home" is to be formally presented tonight at the Golden by Phyllis Holden, an actress who has been absent from the Broadway stage since 1938. Not only will she be making her managerial debut but she will also portray the leading role opposite Donald Curtis.

A grim eyewitness picture of the life led by political prisoners in the forced labor camps of Soviet Russia, coupled with a charge that the Soviet State was seeking to create "an ethnic insulating barrier" from the Baltic to the Black Sea through repopulation of border areas, marked the opening yesterday of an investigation into forced labor, slavery and peonage in various areas of the world.
CONCORD, N. H., Feb. 24 -- Dr. Arthur S. Adams, president of the University of New Hampshire, asserted today that he could find no evidence of subversive activity on the campus of his institution.

Renewed pressure against the rail issues again spearheaded a general deterioration yesterday in values on the stock market. In the fifth consecutive day's decline, prices sank to the lowest levels since last November, mainly because of continued weakness in the carriers, which ended at the worst quotations since late in 1947.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- President Truman declared today that the Marshall Plan program should be continued until economic recovery in Europe was assured.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein ruled today, in a formal opinion, that acquisition - cost conferences such as insurance companies in the fidelity, surety and casualty fields had been using for twenty-five years to fix agents' commissions, violated a 1948 amendment to the Donnelly Act, state anti-trust law.

The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith denied yesterday that United States distribution of the J. Arthur Rank motion picture "Oliver Twist" had been deferred last summer as a result of a protest from the organization.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 24 (AP) -- After trailing by 17 points in the second quarter, the Providence Steam Rollers rallied strongly in the third period and outlasted the New York Knickerbockers, 89 -- 84, in a Basketball Association of America game tonight before 2,577 fans.

TUCKAHOE, N. Y., Feb. 24 -- Analysis of Governor Dewey's latest budget shows that his "administrative genius" is limited to the "realm of propaganda," Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, declared here tonight at the annual dinner of the Westchester County Democratic committee.
Following is the text of President Truman's address at the Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner in Washington last night, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES last night:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney was nominated today by President Truman to be Under-Secretary of Commerce. He has been Assistant Secretary of the Department of the Air Force since September, 1947.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Department of Agriculture recommended today a sweeping revision of the classification and pricing of excess milk in the New York market.

Provoking much interest in the Oldric Royce showing of custom-made fashions yesterday at 16 East Fifty-second Street, were the shorter hemlines which, though this designer mentioned fourteen inches, looked even a bit higher. Suits were cut with a pared-down slimness, with interest centered on jutting pockets at the hips or pockets draped into bow-like folds, the latter being a favored detail repeated several times throughout the collection.

The city of Philadelphia borrowed yesterday $44,200,000 on long-term bonds maturing serially from 1950 to 1999 at an interest cost of 2.57702 per cent. The bonds were sold to a syndicate of eighty-four banks and investment firms headed by Drexel Co.
Net income of the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company last year reached a new high record of $24,231,159 after all charges including $400,000 provision for contingencies, the annual statement reports today.

TOKYO, Feb. 24 -- The cabinet of newly elected Premier Shigeru Yoshida has reached agreement on a tentative national budget for 1949 of 578,000,000,000 yen or slightly more than $2,000,000,000 at the official exchange rate.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Complex, owned by A. Jeanfreau and ridden by C. Thacker, won the featured Momus Purse at the Fair Grounds today. Rodman Keenon was second and Scotland Yard third.

Anna Louise Strong, American writer deported from Russia as a spy for this country, was directed yesterday to appear this morning for questioning by the special Federal grand jury investigating subversive activities.

Application of the leased retail millinery department principle to the selling of robe is planned by a combination of robe manufacturers, it was stated yesterday by Leo C. Safir of the Safir Plan, Inc., makers of Rabhor Robes.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- Superior Judge Donald S. McKinlay today dissolved parts of a temporary order designed to prevent C. Arvid Johnson, president of Central-Illinois Securities Corporation, from moving the investment company's assets out of Chicago. A motion to dismiss a complaint seeking liquidation of the company and an accounting from Mr. Johnson of his operation of the company was continued to March 10, the date set for hearing on the complaint.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 24 -- The signing of the armistice agreement with Egypt appeared to place Israel firmly on the road to peace. Foreign Minister Moshe Shertok called it the "first link in a new chain of evolution" and added, "It is a momentous event in the life of the Middle East."

Net sales of the B. F. Goodrich Company last year were the highest in the company's history and earnings were the second best, being exceeded only by those for 1946, according to the annual report issued yesterday for publication today.

Increased roominess with a decrease in over-all length to aid in parking and garaging are among the new outstanding factors in the 1949 Dodge line introduced yesterday by the Dodge division, Chrysler Corporation. The cars will be on display today at the Chrysler International Auto Salon, 405 Lexington Avenue, and dealer showrooms throughout the metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Department of Commerce announced today that after a ten month lapse it would again license for export steel to be used in building the $125,000,000 Trans-Arabian pipeline from the Persian Gulf to the Mediterranean Sea.

Representatives of the Army and Navy and the city administration joined with postal officials yesterday at the unveiling of four large bronze plaques commemorating the war service of 4,824 employes of the New York Postoffice, including fifty-two who gave their lives in World War II.
BERLIN, Feb. 24 -- Differences in Soviet policy-making in Germany, which was described as "disjointed" by one prominent German politician, were bared today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 24 -- Despite Soviet and Ukrainian charges that the Republic of Korea is a "puppet government, supported by the bayonets of a certain foreign power," the Security Council's membership committee decided today by a vote of 8 to 2, with Cuba absent, that the republic is qualified for membership in the United Nations.

In a detailed refutation of charges by public power advocates that the nation is in the grip of an electric power shortage that threatens a state of emergency, Ernest R. Acker, president of the Edison Electric Institute, asserted yesterday that the private utilities were "intensifying their long-range sales efforts to make sure that the new capacity will be sufficiently utilized."

" No Minor Vices," a romantic comedy produced by Enterprise Studio and released by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, will have its local premiere this morning at the Rialto. Lilli Palmer, Dana Andrews, Louis Jourdan, Jane Wyatt and Norman Lloyd head the cast of the presentation, which was produced and directed by Lewis Milestone from an original screen play by Arnold Manoff.

A committee of representatives from leading buying groups here will be formed during the next few weeks to explain and emphasize to manufacturers current problems and needs of retailers, it was disclosed yesterday at a meeting of the Association of Buying Offices in the Statler Hotel.

Mayor O'Dwyer was examined under oath on Feb. 17, a few hours before he left on his eleven-day vacation trip to Havana, by a subcommittee of the New York State Temporary Commission to Study Rents, it was disclosed yesterday. The subcommittee, headed by Assemblyman Samuel Rabin, Queens Republican, was designated to investigate administration of the municipal rent control laws by the Temporary City Housing Rent Commission whose members were appointed by the Mayor.
H. E. Cardoze Jr., assistant manager of the marketing and analysis department, has been appointed used car manager of Nash Motors, Detroit.
The cotton market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved slowly yesterday and closed 15 to 22 points net lower.

Sectarian tensions in the United States and anti-Semitic attitudes of Americans abroad are hindering the development of democracy in Germany under American leadership, Dr. Sterling W. Brown, just back from two years as religious coordinator with the American Military Government in Germany, declared yesterday.
FARMINGDALE, L. I., Feb. 24 -- The United States Air Force put its newest jet-and-rocket powered fighter plane on public display for the first time here today, but did not fly it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Conferences looking toward the possible formulation of a new labor relations bill as a substitute for that of the Administration were begun here today and are expected to continue over the week-end.

NANKING, Feb. 24 -- The Nationalists' preliminary peace delegation has conferred with the Communist leaders Mao Tze-tung and Gen. Chou En-lai at Shihkiachwang, the Communist radio announced tonight. It added that the delegation had flown back to Peiping after the conference.

GENEVA, Feb. 24 -- Declaration of Senator Scott W. Lucas on the need for revision of the United States-Swiss commercial treaty in a manner further to protect the United States watch industry has caused concern and considerable chagrin in Switzerland.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government was unanimous today in asking that the Federal Government adopt the "performance budget," but split four ways on how accounting and auditing should be done.

President Truman's speech last night at the Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner consisted largely of an attack on the "special interests" which he thinks are opposing his legislative program and succeeding at least in delaying it.

An ultra-modern television room, outfitted with specially built furniture and wall paneling for video enthusiasts, proved to be the main attraction for throngs that flocked through "Dream House II," Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, after the ten-room French Provincial model dwelling was opened to the public at 11:45 A. M. yesterday.

Robert Grant 3d. the defending titleholder, and Clarence C. Pell Jr., with whom he holds the doubles crown, gained the semi-final round of the national amateur racquets championship yesterday. Advancing with them at the Racquet and Tennis Club were W. G. Holloway Jr. and Stanley W. Pearson Jr. of Philadelphia, 1948 squash racquets champion.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 24 -- An announcement issued here today that the Egyptians and Israelis had signed an armistice in Rhodes laid strong emphasis on the fact that it was purely a military agreement and did not settle the fate of Palestine. The text of the armistice is expected to be published here tomorrow.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 24 -- President Juan Peron expects to sign a decree soon by which the Government will take over all newsprint now in the country. This was revealed this morning, when Argentine newspaper publishers were invited to meet with the National Economic Council.
PARIS, Feb. 25 -- The United States must never allow France and Western Europe to be overrun by Russia as they were by Germany, Premier Henri Queuille said today in an interview.
Representative Jacob K. Javits of New York proposed last night a conference of labor, industry, farm and professional groups to work out a satisfactory plan for the nation's health.
ATHENS, Feb. 25 -- According to the Greek Red Cross, 4,000 petitions have thus far been received from parents who want their children returned from camps and asylums in Russia's satellite states.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- Continued lack of pressure of cash grain was again responsible for independent strength in May wheat, corn and oats on the Board of Trade today. Wheat led the advance, being 4 7/8 cents a bushel higher at one time, selling in new ground since Jan. 29, and closed 4 to 4 1/8 cents net higher than yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 25 -- To the surprise of all hands, and the amusement of some, ten names went into the entry box today for tomorrow's $50,000 added Widener Handicap over Hialeah Park's mile-and-a-quarter course.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- A dispute between Haiti and the Dominican Republic was settled peacefully today. The two countries, which share a Caribbean island, accepted a resolution from the council of the Organization of American States urging them to strengthen and consolidate good relations between them.

A bill calling for the use of the state's Abandoned Property Fund to increase aid for school construction will be introduced into both houses of the State Legislature on Monday, it was announced yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Feb. 25 -- The City Commission of Jersey City adopted a 1949 budget of $45,465,415 this afternoon after a six-hour hearing enlivened by charges that the administration was guilty of extravagance, fraud and exacting "kick-backs" from municipal employes to finance election campaigns.
WHITE SANDS, N. M., Feb. 25 -- A two-stage rocket combination soared 250 miles above the earth to a world record yesterday.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 25 -- Ray McIntyre, 19-year-old St. Lawrence sophomore, stole the limelight in the international sanctioned ski jump today, lone event of the Middlebury winter carnival not canceled by lack of snow.

The fight of seventy families against eviction from tenements in East Seventy-ninth Street was led yesterday, at a hearing of the City Rent Commission, by Representative Vito Marcantonio and Assemblyman Herman Katz of the Tenth Assembly District.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina fixed March 7 yesterday as the date when the eleven Communists must finally go to trial on charges of conspiracy. He also gave defense counsel two more court days -- Monday and Tuesday -- to complete their challenge to the jury.

Walter R. Lynch, 63-year-old lawyer and head of the estate and gift tax department of the Second New York District, United States Bureau of Internal Revenue, died yesterday in Columbus Hospital of an injury received at 11:30 P.M. Thursday in an accident at Broadway and Bond Street.

" Arabian Oil: America's Stake in the Middle East," a study of American petroleum interests since 1930, is the only book published today. The authors are Raymond F. Mikesell, Professor of Economics at the University of Virginia and former Government economist in the Middle East during the war, and Hollis B. Chenery, currently teaching economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The book is issued by the University of North Carolina and sells for $3.50.

The annual report of the Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company, issued for publication today, disclosed net earnings for last year of $5,942,008 after $3,790,000 provision for taxes, compared with $6,693,509 earned in 1947 after providing $4,381,100 for taxes.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- The Board of Regents announced today the appointment of Dr. Evan R. Collins, dean of the College of Education of Ohio University, as president of the Albany State College for Teachers at $12,000 a year.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 25 -- To prevent a return to nazism, the German system of education will have to be supervised for another ten to twenty years, Dr. Alonzo G. Grace, director of the education and cultural relations division of the Office of Military Government for Germany, declared this evening.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 25 -- India has invited four other members of the British Commonwealth to confer with her in New Delhi next Monday on problems raised by the revolution in Burma, a country that left the commonwealth thirteen months ago.

Present day scenes in Southern states reminiscent of "Uncle Tom's Cabin" were described yesterday to an unofficial commission investigating peonage, forced labor and slavery in various parts of the world.

Marking the first anniversary of the Communist coup in Prague, the new Council of Free Czechoslovakia proclaimed yesterday its determination to free the country from the tyranny of its Communist dictatorship.

Directors of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of $2 a share on the 953,668 shares of Class A stock, to be paid in regular quarterly installments, and a regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents on the 7,430,333 shares of common stock.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Lieut. Gen. J. Lawton Collins, Vice Chief of Staff of the Army, left little doubt today as to the role and temperament of United States troops in Japan. They would fight, he asserted, "if Japan were attacked."

CINCINNATI, Feb. 25 -- For the sake of the nation's economy the farmer's purchasing power must be maintained, even though most farmers, because of inefficient operations, do not deserve much help, Louis Bromfield, novelist, columnist and expert on agricultural economics, declared here tonight.

Definite training-period dates for officers and enlisted men of the Organized Reserve in the First Army area were set yesterday at the close of a two-day conference on Governors Island among Reserve and Regular Army officers.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 25 -- A grand jury investigation of burglaries in Westchester County alleged to have Been committed by Gerard Graham Dennis, society jewel thief, was resumed here today. The evidence was so voluminous that the jury, which heard some evidence on Wednesday, adjourned without completing any case and will reconvene next Wednesday.

Twenty years ago, it is noted in the sixth report of the Hoover Commission on governmental reorganization, the Department of Agriculture employed 22,000 persons and had a budget of $25,800,000. Today it has 82,000 employes and costs the taxpayer $834,000,000 a year. War and depression, shifts in population, and changing relationships between federal and state governments, coupled with amazing scientific progress, are listed by the Commission as the major elements underlying this expansion.

There will be more than the usual amount of activity on metropolitan college basketball courts today, with six games listed. Topping the slate will be the clash between Columbia and Navy, which will start on the Lions' court at 8:30 P. M.

Election of Alfred C. Howard as president and general manager of the Globe-Wernicke Company was announced yesterday. John J. Rowe, president of the Fifth Third Union Trust Company, was elected board chairman and F. H. Kunkel, chairman of the executive committee.

A special broadcast entitled "One Great Hour," incorporating a dramatic appeal to the American people in behalf of world relief, will be carried over the combined facilities of the Mutual Broadcasting System, the American Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System, on Saturday, March 26, from 10 to 11 P. M.

First it was the surrey with the fringe on top, which flourishes now only in Broadway shows. Then it was the Model T Ford, successor to the surrey, the passing of which was immortalized in The New Yorker magazine piece "Farewell, My Lovely." The Second World War gave the coup de grace to the five-cent cigar, of which the late Vice President Marshall spoke so eloquently. Must the penny postcard now follow these into limbo?
ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- The Board of Regents acted today to stamp out reports recently circulated about the Capitol that it is antagonistic to the development of a new State University.

Aided by the record volume of trade in December, Brazil was able to achieve a favorable balance estimated at $16,000,000 in 1948, against a trade deficit of $200,000,000 in 1947, according to analysis made here yesterday by the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Dr. Harold C. Urey of Chicago, atomic scientist, said tonight the United States should disclose the number of atom bombs it had in stockpiles and also release the long-withheld Bikini A-bomb report.

Segregation based on race, creed or color is the greatest single obstacle to good intergroup relations in this city, a special fact-finding committee of the National Conference of Christians and Jews said in a report to Mayor O'Dwyer made public yesterday.

Mediation spokesmen in the labor controversy between the Consolidated Edison Company and the Utility Workers of America, CIO, announced late last night that "new avenues of possible settlement" had been reached in the dispute. The 27,000 utilities workers have authorized a strike call for some time after midnight Tuesday.

Homer Laughlin China Company, largest dinnerware producer in the country, will cut back production between 10 and 15 per cent in the next ninety days, J. M. Wells, president, disclosed yesterday. He emphasized that the company does not consider the cutback serious.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Dr. Millspaugh's comment on the Iranian Ambassador's letter in THE TIMES of Feb. 9 is more a general assault on Persia than a reply. It reads as if Dr. Millspaugh had a grievance which he wished to air regardless. What he says about the deficiencies of the Iranian Government would hold for most countries in the world just now.

A boon to women who make their own clothes is the new "Tryonn" pattern of plastic fabric, introduced yesterday by Harry Collins, custom-designer of 647 Fifth Avenue, and B. Altman Co., where the patterns are for sale.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 25 -- The official list of the names of twelve Germans submitted by the Bizonal Economic Administration to the Western Allied Military Governments as managerial trustees of the Ruhr iron and steel works was disclosed today. It included a heavy sprinkling of former big industrialists and incensed the Socialists and trade union leaders.
Most of the Export-Import Bank loan of $100,000,000 will be spent in the United States to purchase capital goods that Israel urgently needs, Eliezer Kaplan, Minister of Finance, said yesterday.
ALBANY, N. Y., Feb. 25 (AP) -- The State Commerce Department reported today the following conditions at New York ski centers. Alpine Meadows (South Corinth) -- No skiing.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The AMA's health program will not remedy the maldistribution of medical facilities and the financial burden of hospital services upon the lower and intermediate income groups. The problems of high costs of hospital services and the faulty distribution of medical aid cannot permanently be solved by governmental subsidies or voluntary hospital insurance.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In an Associated Press dispatch from Chicago which was published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 17 it was announced that three European scholars had accepted invitations to attend the international Goethe convocation at Aspen, Col., this summer.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board tonight handed substantial presents to seven airlines, including the three largest, in the form of higher retroactive mail-pay rates for 1948.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Under a proposed exemption rule released today by the Securities and Exchange Commission for public comment, short-term trading profits resulting from the acquisition of bonus stock by officers of companies would not be recoverable by the issuing company.
A plan to transfer nine Maritime Commission passenger vessels to the Army for the transport of displaced persons has been advanced by President Truman, it was reported here last night.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 25 (AP) -- Dinner Gong stepped into the role of favorite for the Santa Anita Handicap tomorrow as fifteen thoroughbreds were named today to race for $100,000 guaranteed to the winner.
When a sealed train carrying 447 Jewish refugees bound for Israel arrives in New York tomorrow from San Francisco it will bring together again, for a short reunion, a father and three sons.

A magnificently played all-Chopin recital was given by Robert Casadesus, the eminent French pianist, last night at Carnegie Hall in commemoration of the centenary of the composer's death. The artist was distinctly in the vein for superb music-making, his performances proving of the highest order, both from the standpoint of virtuosity and of interpretation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Anthracite Health and Welfare Fund has paid $7,261,784 in benefits to hard-coal miners and their families, Thomas Kennedy, chairman of the fund's board of trustees, reported today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Paramount Pictures Corporation has signed a consent decree to divorce the company's domestic exhibition business from its production and distribution enterprises, the Department of Justice announced today.

An advertising campaign is scheduled to begin on March 1 in trade papers, and later in consumer publications, for Hank Chief, a cellophane-sealed package of five handkerchiefs with a guarantee of six months' wear, manufactured and distributed by the Lehigh Handkerchief Company, 45 West Thirty-fourth Street, it was announced yesterday by Kurt H. Glass, sales manager.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Dr. James G. McDonald, special representative of the United States in Israel, was nominated by President Truman today to serve as Ambassador to Israel.
Barring interference at the Cabinet level, the 1949 Army-Navy football game will be played in Philadelphia, The Associated Press reported yesterday, and here is why:

CLEVELAND, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Randolph Eide, president of the Ohio Bell Telephone Company, reported today that the company experienced its greatest period of expansion, service improvements and overall growth in 1948, but the return on capital investment declined for the second consecutive year.
BUFFALO, Feb. 25 -- The "Niagara Frontier," which is an American counterpart of Germany's Ruhr Valley, is confident on its industrial outlook, even though unemployment has doubled in the last year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Spokesmen for the Texas Sheep and Goat Raisers Association, joined by Representative Fisher (D., Texas), have asked Agriculture Secretary Charles Brannan to start mmediately a price-support program for mohair. Sayers Farmer of Junction, president of the association, headed the group that met various Government officials.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Publicker Industries, Inc., today cut pure alcohol prices 2 cents a gallon. The action reduced the price per gallon from 23 to 21 cents.
Nine indictments accusing three exporters of circumventing quota restrictions on American exports were returned yesterday by the Federal grand jury.
Children who have helped most in the clean-street drive now being conducted by two Queens communities were honored yesterday at a ceremony in City Hall.
Lent starts next Wednesday: it brings along with its religious observances certain foods that are among its traditions, too. Examples:
The City of Los Angeles, Calif., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on March 15 on an issue of $10,000,000 sewer bonds dated March 1, 1949, and due on March 1, 1950 to 1969.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 25 -- RKO today announced the signing of a deal with Roberto Rossellini, Italian director of "Open City" and "Paisan," to finance and distribute Rossellini's projected Ingrid Bergman picture, which will be filmed on the island of Stromboli in the Mediterranean. Production is scheduled to start April 1, according to the announcement.

ROME, Feb. 25 -- The Communists were accused by Minister of the Interior Mario Scelba in the Chamber of Deputies this evening of having a criminal organization in Milan known as the "Red Flying Squad" that has been responsible for more than one recent murder that has particularly alarmed the public.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- American cotton exporters see chances for a decline in their world market.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Eleven Democrats and eleven Republicans joined in informally presenting to the Senate today a broad new housing bill that is virtually assured of passage once the floor has been cleared of the impending struggle over curbing filibusters.

YONKERS, N. Y., Feb. 25 -- Dr. Edward Johnson, 28-year-old resident physician at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, reported to the Yonkers police at 6:45 A. M. today that he had been kidnapped in his automobile, taken for a ride of several miles, robbed of $15 and a wrist watch, and then put out in Yonkers by three soldiers who fled with his automobile.

This morning's newcomer is "The Fighting O'Flynn," a costume adventure produced by the Fairbanks Company for Universal-International release and starring Douglas Fairbanks Jr. in the title role, at Loew's Criterion. Arthur Pierson directed from a screen play by Mr. Fairbanks and Robert Thoeren based on a novel by Justin Huntly McCarthy.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- Negotiations in London on the occupation statute for Western Germany, which will determine the future relationship between the occupying powers and a Western German Government, have been temporarily suspended while the United States delegation awaits instructions from Washington.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- President Truman nominated Michael J. Galvin of Boston today to be Under Secretary of Labor. Maurice J. Tobin is the Secretary. The post has been vacant since David A. Morse resigned last summer to become director general of the International Labor Organization.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Average primary market prices were unchanged in the week ended on Feb. 22, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index is 158.5 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.2 per cent lower than four weeks ago and 0.9 per cent less than the comparable week of 1948.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 25 -- Forty ships carrying 20,000 sailors and marines steamed in through the Golden Gate today after the First Task Fleet's month-long sub-arctic maneuvers in the Gulf of Alaska, which were appraised by Vice Admiral Gerald F. Bogan as "reasonably successful" within "the limitations of the force."
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Feb. 25 (AP) -- Members of the American Bowling and Billiard team of New York bowl better as a group than as individuals, it seems.

Dr. Alfred H. Williams, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, received last night the thirty-first annual William Guggenheim award at a dinner given in his honor at the University of Pennsylvania Club, 106 West Fifty-sixth Street.

Wholesale dry goods orders in the primary markets are restricted to small lots wanted for rush delivery, it was pointed out in trade sources yesterday. Wholesalers, anticipating further adjustments in soft goods prices, have given a clear indication that they are buying only what can be used in the next thirty days.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson announced today that he was already putting into force recommendations of the Hoover Commission for reorganization of the State Department.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Feb. 25 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, admitted here today that it was "touch and go" whether the Administration's bill repealing the Taft-Hartley Act would pass the Senate.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 25 -- The trial of fifteen Protestant churchmen, accused of espionage on behalf of United States and British intelligence services with intent to provoke Western intervention against the Bulgarian Communist regime, opened today with oral confessions by two of the accused.

The thirty-sixth semi-annual New York Gift Show closed yesterday in the New Yorker and Statler Hotels with buying definitely more satisfactory than during the recent Chicago gift show, according to exhibitors. The George F. Little Management, which directs the event, expects a total buyer registration of approximately 8,000.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 20 -- Aside from the major task of increasing exports by 25 per cent, Sweden's hope of full recovery by 1952 depends on the ability of its Socialist Government to cut down home consumption while increasing production in essential industries.

Carl Lischer of Detroit, Mich., has sold his residence at 21 Rockland Avenue in the Larchmont section of Mamaroneck, N. Y., to Mr. and Mrs. Richard Cohn, who are occupying the property. The house contains six rooms and two baths. Peter C. Doern Jr., was the broker.
DETROIT, Feb. 25 -- The following table shows the new and old factory prices of all General Motors passenger automobiles and the decrease for each:
Further protests over Mayor O'Dwyer's intervention with the Board of Higher Education in its selection of a president for Queens College were registered yesterday.

An international fete, featuring an Oriental tea garden, a Brazilian coffee plantation and the distribution of peace pipes by a grandson of Sitting Bull, was held by the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church last night in observance of Brotherhood Week.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 25 -- David Ben-Gurion, who has been asked by President Chaim Weizmann to form Israel's first permanent Government, met the leaders of rival parties today and discussed a coalition. Mr. Ben-Gurion still is confined to his bed with rheumatism.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Republican leaders agreed today to expand Congressional membership on the organization policy committee and called two national meetings for early next month to coordinate plans for recapturing control of the House and Senate in 1950.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, called on young doctors and dentists today to volunteer for commissions in the armed forces to avert a critical shortage of military personnel trained in the medical sciences.

The National Audubon Society began yesterday to send out notices to its 15,000 members throughout the country in a move to arouse them against the enactment of New York State legislation it says eventually would cripple the enforcement of the state's Plumage Law.

Anna Louise Strong, American writer expelled from Russia as a spy, testified for thirty minutes yesterday before the special Federal grand jury investigating subversive activities. After giving the jury a brief resume of her life, she was excused, presumably because she was able to present a doctor's certificate saying she was suffering from exhaustion, but she was directed to return Tuesday.

Retail sales have declined during the week, according to estimates made yesterday. Department store sales were believed to be about 6 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were 6 per cent below last year. Department store stocks on hand Jan. 31 were down 2 per cent compared with the corresponding date last year, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday.

OTTAWA, Ont., Feb. 25 -- Revaluation of the Canadian dollar within the terms of the Bretton Woods Agreement was recommended today by George Drew, leader of the Progressive Conservative party in Canada at a press conference here.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 25 -- The current labor unrest throughout India, coupled with the Communist aggravation of grievances, is producing several trends likely to have important effects upon the future of the Indian labor movement, communism and politics in general.
Vaudeville, which lost its last stronghold on Broadway back in 1947 when it was taken off the boards of Loew's State Theatre after an existence there of twenty-six years, may return once again.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- A White House that will remain the same as to its exterior, and look substantially the same within, after the proposed $5,400,000 reconstruction was promised today at a hearing of a Senate Appropriations subcommittee.

It is inconceivable that a strike should be permitted to occur that would cut off almost all of New York City's electricity and gas supply. Yet we must bear in mind that such a thing did happen in Pittsburgh as recently as 1946, when the city was demoralized by a twenty-seven-day power strike, and in Camden last month, when there was a two-day strike of gas workers.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 25 -- President Truman's world-wide program of technical aid to underdeveloped areas was placed before the United Nations Economic and Social Council today as a plan enabling backward countries to "cast off oppressive economic ties" and resist foreign domination. It brought a mixed reaction ranging all the way from enthusiasm to deep disappointment.

MEMPHIS, Ten., Feb. 25 -- Clinical observations of humans provide further evidence that dietary deficiencies of proteins and vitamins of the B-complex family are "an important predisposing cause of cancer of the mouth," it was reported here today at the National Cancer Conference.

COPENHAGEN, Feb. 25 -- Denmark's participation in the Atlantic pact is under active consideration, Danish Foreign Minister Gustav Rasmussen said today in an interview. Short of the present complete isolation with which the Danish political parties will never be satisfied, no other course is open now that Norway appears irrevocably committed to the Atlantic pact, Mr. Rasmussen declared.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- The gay music of the hunting horn rang merrily down Piccadilly this morning and unwonted cries of "Yoicks!" and "Tantivy!" rent the air outside the Ritz. Buses swerved, cab drivers growled and mounted bobbies cantered up to find twenty red faced farmers from the west of England riding gaily down the avenue tossing leaflets to onlookers and carrying banners over their heads.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 25 (AP) -- There may be an occasional ship on the Great Lakes by the middle of March, but it will not be loaded with iron ore or coal

Selden Chapin, United States Minister to Hungary, reiterated yesterday his denunciation of the trial of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty and indicated that he might be prepared to discuss more fully both the trial and the activities of the Communist Hungarian regime after reporting to the State Department.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 25 -- Harry M. Warner, president of Warner Brothers, announced today in the Hollywood trade press that his company would not sign a consent decree in the Department of Justice's current anti-trust action aimed at divorcement of theatre chains from film producing and distributing companies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Lower prices for apparel and house furnishings, rather than food, were chiefly responsible for a decline of 0.3 per cent in the consumers' price index in the month ended Jan. 15, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

With "the finest product in the world to sell," the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, Inc., at 500 Park Avenue, New York 22, has done an excellent job in its work of seeking to bring additional travel business to this city. The annual report of the bureau shows that 1948 was a year of progress and of preparing to campaign for business which will affect the city's economic welfare for the next several decades.

A vacant plot of land, 200 by 275 feet, on the east side of Atlantic Avenue between Eighty-ninth and Ninetieth Streets in Woodhaven, Queens, has been purchased by the General Outdoor Advertising Company for improvement with a building containing showrooms and offices. The seller was the Lalance Grosjean Manufacturing Company, which had held the property for more than sixty years.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 25 -- The South African Praliament adjourned today to enable members to campaign for the provincial elections on March 9.

FRANKFORT, Feb. 25 -- This year Frankfort is reviving the Faschung or pre-Lenten carnival in the Romersberg, the ancient platz where it used to be held. In the newer parts of Frankfort shattered walls are being repaired at an extraordinary rate, but in the old city the ruin is so complete that there is little to reconstruct except the Goethe house, the old Saint Paul's and a few other historic buildings.

The achievement of the National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church for an effective program of radio evangelism received official recognition yesterday from The Pulpit Digest, interdenominational publication in the field of evangelism.

Modern art proved again last night to be a fertile subject for its friends and opponents. Four artists and art experts met in a forum sponsored by the New School Associates at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, to present their views on the ever controversial topic.

The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday that 5,055 employes who were furloughed on Feb. 11 at four car shops and six locomotive shops would be recalled for work on March 16. Skeleton forces now are operating the shops.

DETROIT, Feb. 25 -- The General Motors Corporation, benefiting from an automatic wage reduction under its contract covering 273,000 workers, announced today its first post-war price decreases for its entire line of passenger automobiles and trucks.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., Feb. 25 -- March will be moving time for 5,000 shining brook and brown trout that have been darting through cold artesian waters in wide raceways at the Cold Spring Harbor fish hatchery, unmolested by fishermen and untempted by ingenious fly hooks.

New carpet patterns for 1949 did everything but lie flat on the floor yesterday afternoon at the Ziegfeld Theatre, where "It's No Dream," a dramatized carpet fashion show, was presented by the Carpet Institute, Inc., before an audience of 1,800.

Even the lightest weight concrete mixtures, some of which may have little actual strength, may still have wide uses in insulation of buildings, Ralph W. Kluge, associate professor of structural engineering, Purdue University, told more than 500 members of the American Concrete Institute during the closing sessions of their forty-fifth annual convention at the Statler Hotel yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- Otto G. Klein, regional director of the War Assets Administration, was appointed today by Federal District Judge Michael L. Igoe to supervise financial matters of the Tucker Corporation, embattled automobile company now under investigation by a Federal grand jury.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- A six-point program designed to encourage development of this country's merchant marine by liberalizing generally the relationships between the Government and private operators was presented here today by the National Federation of Shipping, Inc.

An electric clothes dryer that Abraham Straus will introduce to this area Monday is outstanding not only for its low price but also for the fact that it needs no special wiring. It works on 110-volt current -- standard in most apartments and small homes -- and on direct as well as alternating current.
TOKYO, Feb. 25 -- The Japanese Cabinet today ordered all Government agencies to produce by March 15 specific plans for reducing their payrolls by an average of 25 per cent.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The country's railroads said today that they acceted on Jan. 18 a Presidential fact-finding board's recommendations for ending a ten-month dispute with their 1,000,000 non-operating employes. However, the unions rejected the findings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UP) -- The Federal Communications Commission hinted today that it would like more power to regulate chain broadcasting. The agency said it believed it was time for a new investigation of radio and television network practices.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Retail sales in January were estimated at $9,500,000,000 today by the Commerce Department. This was $184,00O,000 below the January record level set last year, but the department said that one less trading day in the month this year resulted in almost equal performances in each year.

PARIS, Feb. 25 -- Government police officials raided the offices of three Communist weekly newspapers today following the condemnation of Maurice Thorez, Communist leader, by the National Assembly early in the morning for his avowal of the Soviet cause.
Robert Grant 3d will defend his national amateur racquets championship against Clarence C. Pell Jr. at 12:30 today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- Private business was urged today to take steps of its own to combat the traditional boom-bust cycle instead of leaving the entire responsibility in the hands of the Government. Methods which may be used were outlined by speakers at the first 1949 Economic Institute sponsored by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 25 (AP) -- Miss Louise Suggs and Gus Novotny defeated Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias and Walter Roman today to enter the semi-final round of the international mixed two-ball golf tournament on the Dubsdread course.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- Many British commentators challenged today the interpretation put in the United States on statements attributed to Christopher P. Mayhew, the British Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, that British economic recovery is virtually completed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Dallas Power and Light Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $10,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds, due in 1979, that are to be offered at competitive bidding.
