WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 The Civil Aeronautics Board was told today that Pan American World Airways was "waging a rate war" against Eastern Airlines on the New York-San Juan, Puerto Rico, run.

Sportsmen's Show sidelights. The decoy exhibit on the fourth floor has continued to hold its place as one of the most popular and interesting displays at the show and Tom Marshall of Fairfield, Conn., exhibit chairman, is kept busy explaining the methods and tricks of decoy construction.

BOSTON, Feb. 25 -- The even tenor of the review hearing on the ouster of Dr. Miriam Van Waters as superintendent of the Massachusetts Women's Reformatory was interrupted today by two new developments.

People want more for their money than they have been getting and it is possible for stores to give it to them. Q. Forrest Walker, economist for R. H. Macy Co., Inc., told 300 members of the American Marketing Association yesterday at a luncheon in the Commodore Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- A new delay developed today for the Administration's substitute for the Taft-Hartley Labor Act.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- In his first report, Frederick W. Hoeing, administrator of the Education Practice Act, told the Board of Regents today that the program to eliminate discrimination in admissions to colleges and universities in the state was making "good progress."

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- A three-year campaign to assure a measure of security to the state's 600 public libraries will begin on Tuesday, it was announced here today. Many of the libraries now lack adequate fiscal support.

LITTLE or nothing had been done before the war or during the passive period to provide bomb-proof strongholds from which the central government could be carried on. Elaborate plans had been made to move the seat of government from London. But now under the bombardment the desire and resolve of the Government and of Parliament to remain in London was unmistakable, and I shared this feeling to the full.
GENEVA, Feb. 25 -- Under the growing pressure of competition coal is beginning to move more freely in inter-European trade.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The Maryland Jockey Club and State Racing Commission agreed today that Pimlico race track should be abandoned.

NANKING, Feb. 25 (UP)--Acting President Li Tsung-jen returned today from an apparently victorious attempt to line up some faltering Government leaders behind is policy of negotiating an immediate peace with the Communists.

GUATEMALA, Feb. 25 (UP) -- Government and management officials disclosed yesterday that a formula had been reached by which they expected to resolve a labor dispute in the United Fruit Company's Guatemalan holdings.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Republicans retorted angrily today to President Truman's Jefferson-Jackson Day speech in a day of major political fighting here.

NEWARK, N. J., Feb. 25 -- A tax program for New Jersey, proposed by the Congress of Industrial Organizations in this state, would "meet the peoples needs and lower the burdens of its citizens simultaneously in 1949," according to a statement issued today by Carl Holderman, president of the New Jersey CIO.

Support of the nation-wide campaign of Histadrut, the Israeli Labor Federation, to raise $10,000,000 for the organization's work in the new state of Israel was urged yesterday by Acting Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri in a proclamation issued from City Hall. The proclamation designated the period from beginning tomorrow and ending March 6 as Histadrut Week.

Because he is a more experienced ringman, Pete Mead, Grand Rapids, Mich., middleweight, last night knocked out Joey De John, solid-thumping husky from Syracuse, in the seventh round of their scheduled ten-round bout in Madison Square Garden.

Five students, three seamen and a Brooklyn merchant who rescued persons from drowning last year in waters of the metropolitan and eastern Long Island areas yesterday received awards by the Life Saving Benevolent Association of New York, Inc.

Five students, three seamen and a Brooklyn merchant who rescued persons from drowning last year in waters of the metropolitan and eastern Long Island areas yesterday received awards by the Life Saving Benevolent Association of New York, Inc.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt received tonight the 1948-1949 Distinguished Service Medal of the national Phi Beta Kappa Association. It was presented at the association's annual Founders' Day dinner by Dr. Louis L. Mann, president of the Chicago chapter.

The Press Photographers of New York have been holding their thirteenth annual exhibit of more than 300 prints that illustrated last year's book of days in the life of our city. Here are spot news, sports, feature, pictorial, portrait and personality shots of people and events, most of them snapped against the relentless metronome of deadlines.

With a pair of local players, Tommy Byrnes and Lionel Malamed, in their line-up, the Indianapolis Jets will oppose the New York Knickerbockers in the Basketball Association of America clash at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Continuation of price support for hogs at 90 per cent of parity until April 1, 1950, was announced today by Secretary of Agriculture Brannan as a means of improving the prospects of supplies of meat and of insuring orderly marketing.

Appointment of a "task committee" to prepare recommendations for a joint shipper-carrier-underwriter export packaging improvement program was announced yesterday by James A. Farrell Jr., president of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York. The action is the first step in a campaign to reduce huge losses caused by insufficiently packaged cargo, and was authorized at a mass meeting of shipping, exporting and packaging groups on Feb. 2.

The Real Estate Board of New York endorsed yesterday the proposed Constitutional amendment to exempt from the city's debt limit $150,000,000 of its bonds issued to finance new hospital construction. The proposed amendment was approved by the 1948 Legislature and is pending in the 1949 session.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 25 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie said today that the armistice between Egypt and Israel "is a good example of the kind of influence the United Nations is best fitted to exercise during the present severe tension of the world -- that is, to act as a mediating and conciliating influence for peace."

Activity and strength in sugar futures resulted in a volume record for a single day's trading in No. 4 contract on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. New highs for the life of the current contracts were established.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 25 -- The City College of New York basketball team dazzled Baldwin-Wallace with its passing wizardry tonight to gain a 62-57 victory in the finale of a double-header at the Arena. In the opening contest Loyola of Chicago defeated John Carroll of Cleveland, 57 to 50.
BERLEN, Feb. 25 -- Dr. Kurt Schumacher, head of Germany's powerful Social Democratic party, delivered today a long, sharp attack on the International Authority for the Ruhr.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Senate's bi-partisan majority of Northern Democrats and Republicans intends to seek before the next week ends a showdown with the Southerners on the first aspect of the filibuster controversy.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 25 -- The United Nations Atomic Energy Commission deferred action today on a Soviet proposal to fix a deadline of June 1 for drafting international agreements for the prohibition of atomic weapons and for the control of atomic energy.

Travel conditions and port faciliies in the Mediterranean are much improved in the opinion of two steamship executives who arrived here yesterday aboard the American Export Lines passenger vessel Exeter. The vessel docked yesterday morning with seventy-five passengers at Exchange Place, Jersey City, after a forty-five-day voyage to the Mediterranean.

If existing state law is amended by legislation now pending in Albany, a planned increase in the number of facilities for higher education in New York State will not take place in 1949 or even 1950, the Board of Trustees of New York State University warned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The fight of Senator Harry P. Cain, Republican, of Washington, to block Senate approval of Mon C. Wallgren to head the National Security Resources Board wound up with a minimum of fireworks today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Great Britain's tentative allocation of $940,000,000 for the second year of the Marshall Plan program will be re-examined by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in the light of a British spokesman's report to the United Nations that his country was nearing recovery.

Equity financing will reappear in the new capital issues scheduled for offering next week. On Tuesday, a Harriman Ripley Co. syndicate will manage the stand by offering of 286,496 shares of Central Maine Power Company common stock, of which total 219,196 shares subscribable by the New England Public Service Company will instead be placed at the disposition of the market.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The North Atlantic defense pact negotiators met for three hours today and Secretary of State Dean Acheson told reporters later they had made such excellent headway that an approved text of the treaty could be expected next week for submission to interested governments.

With Michigan State favored by a narrow margin over Yale and Army while defending New York University and Cornell cling hopefully to an outside chance, the most stirring team contest in years shapes up in the twenty-eighth annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden today.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 25 -- Winston Churchill declared here today that the ultimate purpose of European unity lay in deliverance of the Continent's Eastern countries from the "grip of a tyranny more permanently devastating than that of Hitler."

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- Investments made by American educational institutions in real estate were dwelt upon by two speakers today at the closing session of the regional clinic of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America.
DETROIT, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Pontiac Motors, which built its first automobile in 1926, assembled its 3,000,000th car today.

HARLINGEN, Tex., Feb. 25 (AP) -- Glenn Teal, 29-year-old professional from Jacksonville, Fla., making his third tour along the P. G. A. trail but never winner of a tournament, today shot into the lead in the $10,000 Rio Grande Valley open with 131 for 36 holes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UP) -- The International Monetary Fund warned South Africa tonight that it would not tolerate any more sales of gold at "premium" prices because the metal might wind up in the European black market.

The clay model for the bronze plaque that is to be erected in the Yankee Stadium in memory of Babe Ruth has been approved, it was announced yesterday by the New York Yankees. A cast will now be made and the memorial will be ready for dedication on April 19, when the Yankees open their home season against Washington.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 25 -- The junior college was pictured today as an institution, unbound by tradition, which faced a great opportunity to promote education in family life and thus provide an antidote to "youthful cynicism suggesting that people cannot live happily in families."

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Governor Dewey is considering a state-wide broadcast to explain his position on his proposed $936,200,000 budget and his proposal for $168,200,000 in new state taxes. He will make a final decision on the broadcast tomorrow.
VIENNA, Feb. 25 -- Seven Deputies of the former party of Istvan Barankovics fled from Hungary to Austria this week rather than form a new Catholic party within the "Independent People's Front."

Members of the twenty-seven Protestant and Eastern Orthodox denominations affiliated with the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America have been urged by Bishop John S. Stamm of Harrisburg, Pa., president of the council, to pray for the fifteen Protestant ministers who went on trial yesterday in Sofia, Bulgaria, on treason charges.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The top-seeded English team of Margaret Carlisle and Betty Cooke was eliminated in the women's national squash racquets doubles championship today as three of the four semi-final brackets were filled at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

When crocus, snowdrops and several of the spring-flowering shrubs are reported blooming outdoors a month ahead of time, flowers again seem a necessary addition to living rooms. Florist shops also are stocked with an assortment that bring spring to the city.

The reorganization of Paramount Pictures into two separate theatre operating and producing-distributing companies will be carried through on a tax-free basis under plans submitted to and approved by the Treasury Department, it was learned yesterday.
SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Feb. 26 -- Local matters, such as transportation, food prices and jobs, have been of top interest in the conversation of Westerners this week.

In "The Madwoman of Chaillot," current Broadway success, Jean Giraudoux has written an allegorical fantasy at once witty and sharply penetrating in its comments on today's society. A high spot in the play, laid in Paris, is the scene between the Countess (the Madwoman) and Pierre, or Roderick, an unwilling agent of a gang of crooks.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 26 -- A nation-wide campaign to add 1,000,000 teachers to public schools in the United States is to be undertaken by leading American educators.

THE recent installation of Franklin Watkins' two ambitiously scaled interpretations of the "Death" and "Resurrection" in the Philadelphia home of Henry P. McIlhenny, well-known collector and museum curator, concluded a rare contemporary revival of the kind of grand-flourish, unfettered collaboration between artist and patron that has all but passed out of common experience.

IN this age few tragedies are written. It has often been held that the lack is due to a paucity of heroes among us, or else that modern, man has had the blood drawn out of his organs of belief by the skepticism of science, and the heroic attack on life cannot feed on an attitude of reserve and circumspection.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26 -- Hundreds of thousands of residents of the Pacific Northwest had an opportunity this week to contemplate the effects of a strike which had shut down Portland's two daily newspapers on Feb. 18 in a contract dispute.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Changes in prices of grains were small today on the Board of Trade and trends were mixed. May wheat ran into some profit-taking after yesterday's sharp advanced falling more than a cent a bushel at times, but the weakness in this delivery was not reflected in deferred months.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26 -- Although losses were not quite as severe as those of the previous week, retail business activity continued to fall far below last year. All areas showed marked decreases in sales, according to reports from larger stores. Total retail trade in the Pacific Coast states during December showed wide variations.

The last but one in the series of music history lectures conducted by Dr. Curt Sachs, consultant to the New York Public Library's Music Division, will be held tomorrow at 8:30 P. M. in the Central Building, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Feb. 26 -- Ch. Mazelaine's Zazarac Brandy, the boxer belonging to Mr. and Mrs. John P. Wagner of Milwaukee, made another conquest in the breed judging that opened the twenty-fourth annual Kennel Club of Buffalo show today.

LAURENCE Sterne established the two standard types in British military fiction when he created Corporal Trim and Uncle Toby back in 1759. The corporal, not too strong on top but full of unassuming courage and kindly instincts, worshiped his superior officer even for his eccentricities; Uncle Toby, quite silly, but brave and unassuming, too, felt for the soldier the same affection he would for a large retriever.

ROME, Feb. 26 -- Communist Leader Palmiro Togliatti challenged the Government today by declaring that it would be the duty of the Italian people to help the Soviet Union if the Russian Army were to enter their country in pursuit of an aggressor.

THE charter for the International Trade Organization tentatively approved about a year ago by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment at Havana represents, perhaps, the most ambitious of the many international economic agreements concluded in the last few years.

All the talents of all the members of Christian churches, male and female, are needed in church work in an age of "mounting secularism," is the conclusion of a survey on "Women in American Church Life." The survey was summarized in yesterday's issue of "Information Service," a weekly bulletin published by the department of research and education of the Federation Council of the Churches of Christ in America, 297 Fourth Avenue.

Although holding office as president of the American Power Boat Association only since last month's election during the National Motor Boat Show in New York, C. King Brugman, the breezy Californian, has been re-energizing A.P.B.A. affairs with a new hum, zest and zing.

With only mathematics on their side, the New York Rangers open their final lap of the National Hockey League race tonight by opposing the high-flying Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden. The New Yorkers have ten games to play, two against every other sextet in the loop.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 26 -The disturbing progress of the various restive movements in Asia has cast a new uncertainty over the future of half of the world's peoples.

ALICIA MARKOVA and Anton Dolin join the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo tonight as guest stars, replacing Alexandra Danilova and Frederick Franklin, who have left to appear in a like capacity with the Sadler's Wells Ballet in London. It will be the first time either of them has appeared in the City Center.

ALTHOUGH nobody seems to realize it, Sean O'Casey has been writing his autobiography during the past ten years -- writing it, moreover, with genius. The first volume, "I Knock at the Door," is the most beautifully perceptive book I have read about the touching, wondrous experience of coming into an adult world and blundering around in search of a place in society.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 (AP) -- A British team and an unseeded pair from New England swept into the final of the Women's National Squash Racquets Doubles Championship today.

A ROBIN may be a harbinger of spring to a poet but to a baseball writer the true harbinger is either the National League's Green Book or the American League's Red Book. When these twin sources of information reach his desk, he knows that spring training is just around the corner and that he'd better start packing his bags for Florida, Arizone or California where the palm trees aren't in pots in hotel lobbies.

SLAM bidding becomes more difficult when a side has a part-score and need not go very far to reach a "game contract." Both partners feel hesitant to risk an easy game by pushing on to a contract that may not be made. Besides, bridge players have a perfectly human fondness for bargains, and an opportunity to make game at a cheap contract like two clubs or one no trump is all but irresistible.

President Truman's recommendations for legislation on civil rights and the campaign to abolish segregation and racial discrimination in the nation's capital will be emphasized by Roman Catholic college students in discussions this week at 147 institutions.
LONDON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The statement issued by the Chancellor was as follows:

TORONTO, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs battled the Chicago Black Hawks to a 2-2 draw tonight. Cal Gardner made the tying goal for the National Hockey League champions early in the final period.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- A parliamentary tactic that would practically immobilize the Senate's entire legislative machinery, in committees as well as on the floor, was projected today by Southern Senators mapping a no-compromise fight against a curb on filibusters
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26 -- The Port of San Francisco, operated by the state, is running at a loss and officials are looking for ways to increase revenues by $600,000 a year.

BERLIN, N. H., Feb. 26 -- Running a strong race throughout, Silas Dunklee, University of New Hampshire veteran, turned in an impressive performance in leading a formidable field in the Federation Internationale de Ski (F. I. S.) 18-kilometer (11.2 miles) cross-country test today.
GOVERNMENT financial support for the theatre is expected to be a controversial topic at a free-day conference scheduled to begin Wednesday at the Hotel Astor.

Activity in department stores here last week was generally good, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Spring ensembles were featured in dress promotions and millinery and blouses continued to show a seasonal sales increase, it was said.
Manhattan kept alive its tournament aspi rations last night by turning in a stirring 57-52 triumph over the Fordham quintet before an overflow crowd of 3,800 in the Rams' gymnasium.

Although consumer response to better values and lower prices in many ready-to-wear lines has been favorable, retailers found it necessary last week to continue vigorous promotions in order to keep sales on a satisfactory level, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 -- Showing superior ball control and shooting ability, Pennsylvania easily defeated Dartmouth in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game at the Palestra today, 64 -- 43, before 2,000 spectators.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 26 (AP) -- Thomas Cooper of Kansas City, son of the late Jack (Pops) Cooper, motor-boat racer, today won the Governor's Cup race in the second Fort Lauderdale Power Boat Regatta. Jack Cooper was killed in a motor-boat race at Picton, Ontario, last summer.
MONTREAL, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens upset the National Hockey League's first-place Detroit Red Wings, 1-0, at the Forum tonight. Roger Leger defenseman, scored in the opening period.

IN July of 1938, during his London exile and in the painful last year of his long life, Sigmund Freud set down, in what we now know to be his ultimate formulation, the principles of the science he had created. He did not bring the brief work to an actual conclusion, but its translator is surely right in saying that it cannot be far from its planned end.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Sean MacBride, Eire's Minister for External Affairs, said today at the end of a three-day visit here that he believed the British public was moving toward closer understanding of Eire's case for the ending of the partition of Ireland.
HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 26 (AP) -- Two surprise entries meet tomorrow in the 36-hole final of the thirty-first annual Houston Country Club invitational golf tournament.

THE sources of various everyday objects are told in words and pictures in this where-and-how book. The objects include bread, butter, marmalade, dishes and honey. Each topic is simply and briefly discussed, and the several steps in the development of each product are made clear.

PRICES which "marched right up the hill" are now "marching right down again." General Motors joined the procession last week with a reduction of $10 to $40 a car when the cost of living index declined for the fourth month, thereby ushering in an automatic decline in wages under the current labor contract.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 26 -- President Truman heads a list of seven persons cited by the Negro Newspaper Publishers Association here for "impressive contributions to the advancement of Negroes in the previous year." Amherst College, the University of Arkansas and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People were also cited.

AMONG the newly opened exhibitions are two group events which, through their carefully selected paintings, throw light on the modern movement, presenting work by European masters of the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.

When the General Motors Corporation and its 270,000 employes negotiated a two-year contract in May of last year prices and living costs were still spiraling rapidly upward. A wage agreement especially designed to fit the needs of that situation was worked out.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Senator Robert A Taft of Ohio, predicted today that Congress would ignore the March 4 deadline President Truman asked for extending his authority to reduce tariffs under reciprocal trade agreements. The leader of his party's policy committee in the Senate said Republicans would discuss the entire Administration program on trade and tariff policies before the Senate acted on the extension.
TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 26 -- By this time next week Kansans may legally possess a thimbleful or a tankful of liquor, but, today, legal liquor is bogged down in a morass of dissension.
WESTMINSTER, Md., Feb. 26 -- Dick Harlow is returning to football. He quit in 1947 after twenty-seven years of coaching because of ill health.
IRON MOUNTAIN, Mich., Feb. 26 (AP) -- Joe Perrault of Ishpeming, Mich., won the John Mitchell Roning ski-jumping tournament today as the American distance record was broken five times.
BUFFALO, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Notre Dame turned back Canisius, 59 -- 51, tonight in Memorial Auditorium before the largest crowd in Buffalo's basketball history -- 11,921 persons.

Herman L. Weisman, acting national chairman of the United Palestine Appeal, sent a telegram yesterday to Henry Morgenthau Jr. advising him that he could not agree to his proposal that Henry Montor be the sole executive director of the United Jewish Appeal campaign this year.

FIVE manuals on photography which range in appeal for all levels of experience from the beginner to the advanced worker have recently been published. Each of the five, however, tries to cover its subject with sufficient thoroughness to be useful to photographers on several levels of experience.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UP) -- The Rankin bill to pension war veterans would add more than $100,000,000,000 to Federal spending over the next fifty years, new Government estimates showed tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, said today the chances were "not very good" that he and two Republican colleagues would agree on a substitute for the Truman labor bill.

Igor Stravinsky's Mass, for mixed chorus and ten wind instruments, received its American premiere at a concert devoted to his compositions, given by the Chamber Art Society, Robert Craft, director, late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall.

Participation in programs designed to aid displaced persons coming to the United States was urged for Catholic college students yesterday by Miss Joan Christie of the resettlement division of the National Catholic Welfare Conference's War Relief Services.

RHODES, Feb. 26 -- When the Egyptian representatives put their signatures to the armistice agreement with Israel here on Thursday they marked more than the end of tension between Egypt and Israel. Their act can be taken as symbolic of the Arab world's acceptance of the fact that the State of Israel exists.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 26 -- Rebounding from its upset by Princeton last Tuesday, the Yale basketball team was in a record-making mood tonight and so was Capt. Tony Lavelli. With Lavelli swishing the nets for an astounding 52 points, the Elis swamped Williams under a likewise amazing 100-64 score.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Netherlands military action in Indonesia and the subsequent reaction of the Southeast Asia nations bring up once again the urgent need for the formation of a Southeast Asia League.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was rather quiet yesterday, and final prices were 2 points lower to 3 points higher than the day before.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Feb. 26 -- The Executive Committee of the International Mine Workers Union accepted today a resolution endorsing the endeavors of the German miners -- newly accepted into membership -- toward the so cialization of the German mines.

TRIP TIKET, an all-inclusive travel plan sponsored by a European travel agency, is designed to smooth the path of the person who wants to see Europe without being bothered with the details of tickets, hotel reservations and set schedules.

GREAT horses -- Bucephalus, Smoky, the Black Stallion, and many others -- gallop through the eighteen stories in this book. Riding herd on the band are such top-flight writers of horse stories as Ernest Thompson Seton. Will James, Walter Farley and C. W. Anderson.

More riding comfort and less exterior bulk are outstanding features in the 1949 De Soto line, announced yesterday by the De Soto division, Chrysler Corporation. Particular attention has been given to safety through the expansion of vision area and interior construction.

THE Baliards in "Tender Mercy" are the victims of a situation that has made the headlines a number of times. They have an imbecile son, Aaron, nearly as handicapped physically as mentally. Being high-minded and well off, too, they have taken the hard way of caring for Aaron at home instead of placing him in an institution.
The list of unsigned Yankee ball players was reduced to four yesterday when an agreement on salary matters was reached with Yogi Berra.

William M. Leiserson's article makes informative reading. It states, however, the substance of a popular philosophy whose aim is to make institutional liberty superior to individual liberty. This argument bears striking similarity to that of the framers of our Constitution who insisted on leaving out the Bill of Rights.

Red Cross Sabbath will be observed today in New York places of worship, with appeals from pulpits asking congregations to support the city campaign to raise $4,635,000 for the 1949 Red Cross Fund. Similar Red Cross messages were delivered in synagogues yesterday.

THIS book is a plea for the "Open Society" as an answer to communism and a prescription for what ails democracy. The author, Australian by birth, saw naval service in the Pacific during the recent war, attended "the major post-war conferences and the early sessions of the United Nations," and, in general, has been around where the intellectual conflicts of our day are hottest.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Following is the text of today's statement by the Netherlands Government on the Indonesia question:

THIS evening The Bohemians give their annual dinner for the benefit of the Musicians Foundations, the organization established by them to aid musicians in need. It is their excellent custom to invite to this dinner as guest of honor a musician of particular eminence in his field.

BARTY DALE, whose earlier adventures were told in "Ship Aground," shipped as apprentice aboard an East India merchantman under a good and just captain. Soon, however, this captain was injured. His successor allowed Barty to be falsely accused of theft and, for punishment, transferred to a man-o'-war.

ORCHID growing is a gardening hobby that is becoming more popular every day. Generally thought to be expensive, specialized and tedious, gardeners are discovering that orchid culture is no more difficult than coaxing along any other plant of peculiar habit. Also, it demands little time from a busy day.
GENEVA, Feb. 26 -- Unemployment increased significantly in five European countries in the closing months of 1948, the International Labor Office announced today.
BUFFALO, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Rebellious members of the Republican party announced today they would submit amendments to reduce Governor Dewey's record-breaking budget by $102,330,000.
OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 26 -- "The easy money days are ended, and we all know it."

I enjoyed Sam Boal's imaginative story of the future of aviation ("Into the World of 'Nothingness'"). * * * In one of the pictures that accompanied the article, Lockheed's chief engineer, Hall L. Hibbard, is holding a model of an airplane that is to me, a former naval aviator, very strange appearing indeed.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Feb. 26 (AP) -- The singles and doubles champions of 1948 rolled themselves out of the big money today in the American Bowling Congress tournament.

ROBERT ROSSEN'S ten years in Hollywood were not just the most recent ones. They began when he came here under contract to Mervyn LeRoy to write, and were interrupted after seven years at Warners -- even LeRoy left first -- when he returned to New York for a year to sit and think about which medium he really wanted to work in, stage or screen.

THE academic community throughout the United States is currently being disturbed by the perennial issue of the nature and limits of academic freedom. The specific event which has precipitated intense interest and discussion, not only in college classrooms but in all circles interested in education, is the expulsion of some professors from the University of Washington for being members of the Communist party.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Maryland Jockey Club announced today plans to make Laurel Park a de luxe racing plant. Henry A. Parr 3d, club president, said Laurel would be rebuilt from "bottom to top" and enlarged to a capacity of 40,000 fans.

LONDON, Feb. 26 (Reuters) -- Manchester United, making a bold bid to win the Football Association Cup two years running, advanced today with a 1-0 victory over Hull City. The result was a disappointment for thousands of Hull fans who held hopes that the home team would make soccer history by being the first third division club to reach the semi-final round.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- A Treasury Department report that the Government paid more than $56,000,000 last year in interest at 6 per cent on tax overpayments increased demands today for a lower interest rate.
NEWARK, Feb. 26 -- Cornell University, a threat for the national intercollegiate title, rode to an 11 -- 5 indoor polo victory over Princeton at Essex Troop Armory tonight.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Governor Dewey will tell the people of the state in a radio broadcast tomorrow night that any reductions made by the Legislature in his $936,200,000 budget and $168,200,000 program of tax increases "must be in terms of service-cutting."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Even the Weather Bureau will admit that there has never been another winter quite like this one.

Two weeks ago this column pointed out the acute need in the armed forces for medical personnel. Friday, at one of his infrequent press conferences, Secretary of Defense James Forrestal, said that adequate medical care in the armed forces was one of the many factors upon which national security rested.

The indoor Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. team title went West for the first time last night, as Michigan State's power-packed squad rolled up the high total of 35 2/5 points in a stiring spiked-shoe carnival watched by 10,000 persons at Madison Square Garden.

MONSIEUR BONHOMME walks along the Boulevard St. Germain these days with the best intentions in the world of buying a book, but he rarely does. The ordinary novel that cost 20 francs before the war now costs about a franc a page or 300 to 400 francs.

VIENNA, Feb. 26 -- Although the direction of the Communist attack on the Christian religion in Iron Curtain countries shifted last week to Protestantism in Bulgaria, there has been no relaxation of the steady pressure on Roman Catholicism that began long before Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty was arrested and tried in Hungary.

As much as one wants to encourage the people of Hollywood in the making of straight - thinking movies about matters of current consequence, one wonders -- when suddenly confronted by such a picture as "Knock on Any Door."

BERLIN, Feb. 26 -- Another step in the move to have a model type "people's democracy" ready for the expected proclamation of an Eastern German state was taken by the Communist administration of the Soviet zone today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -Secretary of Defense James Forrestal said today that from the point of view of national defense the proposed St. Lawrence seaway and power project would be "clearly advantageous."

HAROLD LLOYD apparently thinks this is a time for comedy. By way of implementing that theory the comedian has completed arrangements with the recently formed Motion Picture Sales Corporation to redistribute throughout the world seven of his comedies, silent and talking, which were originally released between 1922 and 1934.

The Board of Transportation restored to service yesterday thirty of the 110 new subway cars that were withdrawn to correct mechanical defects that caused couplings to part when sudden train stops were made. The board promised that the remaining eighty cars would be back on the job, free from defects, within two weeks.

IVAN, a 40-year-old farmer, lives on one of the 240,000 collective farms in the U.S.S.R. His family consists of his wife Maria, 36, his 14-year-old son Stepan, his 12-year-old son Mikhail and his post-war daughter Galya, 2. With them lives Maria's aged mother, who cannot work.

MOST stories of the Pilgrims begin either at old Plymouth or the new. This novel, however, goes back to those anxious disheartening days when the dissenters of Scrooby were trying secretly to reach safe haven in the Netherlands.

A NEW diagnosis of what ails the motion-picture industry has just been made public by the Allied States Association of Motion Picture Exhibitors, an organization composed largely of small, independent theatre owners.

" THERE fell to Marshall perhaps the greatest place that ever was held by a judge * * * If American law were to be represented by a single figure, skeptic and worshiper alike would agree without dispute that the figure could be one alone, and that one, John Marshall."
The armistice between Israel and Egypt was hailed as a promise of peace in the Near East by some rabbis is sermons here yesterday. Other rabbis preached on brotherhood and the economic "recession."

Three of the Republican county leaders in the city met yesterday afternoon at the National Republican Club with the Republican members of the Legislature from the city. They set next Thursday evening as the time for the first meeting of the Republican committee named recently to cooperate with other parties and groups to nominate fusion candidates for the city election.

John J. Sullivan, 42-year-old Brooklyn waterfront checker with a record of a dozen arrests and six convictions on charges including grand larceny, burglary and assault, was booked yesterday in Queens on a charge of homicide in the killing of Anthony Murawski, a longshoreman, in 1946.

The numerous problems involved in eye care and safety in industry and the armed forces will supply one of the major topics to be discussed at the three-day conference of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness, which opens at the New Yorker Hotel March 16, it was announced yesterday.

Through the development of precision gauges which operate by compressed air it is now possible, even with employes who have little or no training, to obtain a simple and low-cost means of high-accuracy inspection. This was disclosed here yesterday by C. Stead, product research and development engineer, the Taft-Pierce Manufacturing Company, Woonsocket, R.I.

The force of the decline in industrial activity is diminishing and business may level off and maintain present lower rates for a few months, according to Robert C. Swanton, director of purchases in the Winchester Repeating Arms Corporation, division of Olin Industries, Inc., New Haven, in his report of the composite opinion of purchasing agents who comprise the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

The passage last week by the House of Representatives of H. R. 858, a bill to clarify the overtime compensations under the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 with respect to stevedoring, has been greeted with no enthusiasm by members of the industry, it was learned yesterday.

THIS Review has received a number of letters regarding Annalee Jacoby's review of Claire Lee Chennault's "Way of a Fighter" (Jan. 30). Correspondents who disliked the review well outnumbered those who liked it. With few exceptions the letter, whether pro or con, did not single out specific statements or opinions for comment.

The United States must be "vigilant" against the twin dangers of sliding into a dictatorship or being enslaved by one, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, warned in his third and final letter in a series to the university alumni made public yesterday.

CANTON, China, Feb. 26--Formal reconciliation of the Nanking and Canton branches of China's divided Nationalist Government loomed today as Premier Sun Fo announced that he would proceed to Nanking within a few days to participate in governmental conferences concerning "peace, economic and political reforms, and army reduction."

A MAJOR and often frustrating problem in planning a holiday to the Caribbean, Mexico or Central America is the choice of which island, which country, which city to visit. We solved it by settling for a combination tour with ten days in Mexico, a week each in Guatemala and Yucatan and a day in Havana.

THE eighth annual Short Course in Press Photography, sponsored by Kent State University, will be held in Kent, Ohio, March 22 to 25. Leading press photographers and editors will participate in a program on editor-photographer relationships, with Merle Armitage, art director of Look Magazine, giving The principal address on "New Attitudes in Photography" at the annual Short Course banquet March 24.

Long Island University will establish next month a new unit, to be known as the In-Service Division, to help working men and women improve their basic education and to enable them to advance in their vocational fields.

IN the past few years there has been a slow -- very slow -- trend throughout the country toward the development of small orchestras. As the conductor of a small orchestra, I have watched this trend with eagerness, hope and impatience.

SAN MARINO, Feb. 26 -- San Marino, the oldest republic in the world, will hold tomorrow its first political election in four years. An estimated 4,500 male voters will then decide whether they should continue to have the only Communist Government in Europe outside the Iron Curtain.

SO firmly has the notion of the Pony Express worked its way into our folklore that it is probably not realized by most readers that its time span was only a year and a few months and that the total mail that it carried could be loaded today on one good-sized truck.

Westinghouse Electric Corporation soon will ask its 120 major appliance distributors throughout the country to assist dealers in setting up complete facilities for reconditioning refrigerators traded in on purchases of new units, I. Frank Brownson, major appliance manager, announced last week.
A PRELIMINARY report by the five universities cooperating with the National Broadcasting Company in its radio correspondence courses discloses an extremely lively interest in the subjects available.

FIFTY years ago it was heresy even to intimate that there were normal sex interests in children, a heresy for which Dr. Sigmund Freud was castigated by the critics. But Freud's conceptions of "infantile sexuality," and particularly of the importance of a proper normal development of the sex impulse at these early levels, have outlived their critics and are now generally accepted.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- It is an old and probably necessary habit, common to all men and especially to Government officials, to elude the problems of today by speaking about the shining glories of tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- America's production machine is doing nothing more serious than throttling down to cruising speed, according to the experts.
MOSCOW, Feb. 26 -- The Soviet Government has demanded that United States occupation authorities rescind an order closing the Soviet repatriation mission in the United States zone of Germany March 1.

Readjustment is taking its toll in current quotations for securities, but it is having a sharper impact on the morale of the businessman. The flush of war and post-war left business and industry in a state of fluff, almost akin to that soaring feeling that comes with solo flying.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- A Foreign Office spokesman denied today the Soviet charge that British occupation authorities in Germany and Austria were impeding the work of Soviet repatriation teams in the British zones.

IF Hollywood's estimable "Oscar" appears strangely crestfallen these days, his dejection is quite understandable. The object of heated controversy here during recent weeks, "Oscar" has discovered that a large section of the film industry, of which he has long been a proud boast, is reluctant to come to his aid with the $18,500 that is needed to restore his drooping morale as he celebrates his twenty-first birthday on March 24.

GENERATIONS of students, required to read Poor Richard's aphorisms and the smug Autobiography, have felt that Benjamin Franklin was a pretty stuffy character. In her lively book Miss Eaton demonstrates that, to the contrary, Ben Franklin was a lively man, a good companion and perennially young in heart.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- In a spacious seaside manor on the Isle of Wight, Prime Minister Attee, members of his Cabinet and twenty-eight members of the Labor party's national executive settled down today to a secret two-day conference to cogitate on the party's program for the general elections of 1950.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Feb. 26 -- The possibility that the great increase of cigarette smoking during the past quarter of a century may be one of the many factors responsible for the great increase in the incidence of lung cancer in the human male in the corresponding period was discussed here today at the first national cancer conference held under the auspices of the American Cancer Society and the National Cancer Institute.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (AP) -- With its harmonized attack topped by Wally Osterkorn's 24 points, Illinois romped over Northwestern, 81 -- 64, tonight to tighten its Big Nine basketball lead in record-breaking style before 17,095 Chicago Stadium fans.

In an effort to bring about a quick settlement of the controversy between the Federal Government and the states over the ownership of ocean tidelands, a movement has been started in the oil industry to work out some sort of compromise agreement by which the offshore lands would be held jointly by the adjacent states and the United States Government.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 26 -The Rev. Vasil Ziapkov, pastor of the First Evangelical Church in Sofia and leader of the fifteen Protestant ministers on trial before a Sofia District Court on charges of espionage, pleaded guilty today to all accusations, including the charge that he was a "link" between British and American intelligence services and a "spy ring."

DONALD LAM, partner in the detective business with hardboiled, beady-eyed Bertha Cool, gets himself so close to a murder charge in this one that he can hear the fatal trap-door banging under his feet. It starts out with a rather phony case of trailing a man paying court to an elderly woman.

OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 26 -- Mid-western cities in increasing numbers are attacking their housing problems on a community wide basis. Both the builders and city officials agree on what is needed: homes for sale in the $6,000-$8,000 class and rental units in the $75-a-month classification.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 26 -- Through rain and over the sloppiest track in the history of the event. Vulcan's Forge scored a resounding upset triumph in the $139,100 Santa Anita Handicap today.

TO most of the English-speaking world Haydon's name is own today -- if it is known at all -- as the painter to whom Keats, Leigh Hunt, Charles Lamb, William Wordsworth and Elizabeth Barrett Browning addressed poems.

Coming on H. R. Trevor-Roper's "Stalin Would Have Liquidated Marx," this subscriber suddenly became aware of the fact that he had finally become fed up with and allergic to the cold war as waged by editors.
I WAS interested in Harold Kennedy's "Cure for the Fabulous Invalid" because we, the Carolina Playmakers, way down off the beaten track, are trying our own panacea.

" ANERO WOLFE THREESOME" is the subtitle for this collection of mysteries. The opening situation in each story is that of a man who feels sure he is going to be killed and wants to pay Wolfe handsomely to stave off the evil day -- permanently if possible.

THE unrehearsed action of children as they really are -- active, curious. imaginative, learning from each other and in their own way -- is shown in an unusual 16-mm sound film, "Children learning by Experience," made for the British Ministry of Education and distributed here By British Information Services, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, New York 20.

In his pre-election campaign last fall President Harry S. Truman told voters again and again: "We need a Democratic Congress to protect your pocketbooks, your homes, your futures, and the happiness of your children.'' He got the Democratic Congress on Nov. 2, along with his own new lease on the Executive Mansion for four full years.

A FISHING village off the coast of Maine is the setting for this story of 10-year-old Cordelia's adventures during a summer spent with her grandparents. Joining in the escapades of the neighbors' children and learning to fish, swim and sail a boat provide good fun for the young visitor.

LONDON, Sunday, Feb. 27 -- Viscount Kemsley, newspaper publisher and prominent Conservative party supporter, renewed today the suggestion that Winston Churchill should share the responsibility of his party's leadership.

THE dogface of World War II didn't go into battle in neat West Point ranks, his head high amid a mass of fellow-fighters. He slithered, crept, or dashed, out of a hole according to the exigencies of the moment. His cosmos was narrowed to spotting and killing the enemy before the enemy spotted and killed him.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (AP) -- How did the big meat packers make out in 1948? That was the year meat prices-went to astronomical highs. Such price tags as appeared in the butcher shops had never been seen before. Since then, they've gone down.

While the stock market continues to languish in Wall Street, the effort of private enterprise to promote the investment function among individual citizens is continuing on a broad but haphazard front visible all the way from Pennsylvania Avenue to Main Street.

Retail stores and buying groups are gradually revising their buying policies of recent years, according to a survey made here last week. More and more merchandise is being bought for specific promotions and general "stock" buying is becoming much less evident in the retail operation, according to reports.

SHAGGY GI pensioners and shiploads of shoestring students and youth hostelers from America have dimmed the devout French faith in the old myth that everyone in the United States is rich. But when Henri Troyat. after a visiting French professorship at Mills College, announced in his kindly book, "The Case of Uncle Sam," that mattresses are thrown away every two years, no Frenchmmu was astonished.

A VERY modern house containing twelve rooms and four baths is not everyone's dish of tea. But the house which architect Alexander Girard recently completed for himself and his family in Grosse Pointe, Mich., incorporates innumerable ideas for interiors which might be adapted for more modest dwellings, even apartments.

The concentration this week-end of large elements of the Atlantic Fleet in the Caribbean Sea for the country's greatest post-war naval maneuvers emphasizes the new importance of the Atlantic in the nation's naval concepts.

BERLIN, Feb. 26 -- The political campaign launched by the Russians and the German Communists against the formation of a Western German state is reaching its climax, according to United State political observers.
NOW and again vast armies of insects mobilize to wage war in the vegetable kingdom. It has happened in many lands, often with devastating effect. It is happening today in the Bermudas.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 -- Unsettled trade conditions in the hardwood industry, for the first time since the war ended, have caused some idle time on the part of hardwood inspectors, the National Hardwood Lumber Association reported today.

On May 15, 1948, a few hours after Israel declared her independence, Egyptian bomb fell on Tel Aviv. In the bitter war over Israel's independence the Kingdom of Egypt was the most adamant, if not the most effective, of Israel's foes. Last week Egypt formally called the war off.

Seventy per cent of this city's daily supply of packaged bread and cake will be cut off beginning tomorrow if 200 bakery drivers strike against one large baking company and 1,300 others are simultaneously locked out by five other companies as threatened.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Controversy in Albany over the state tax rates to be collected on 1948 incomes has confused many taxpayers, who are sending in early payments under both the old rate, 60 per cent of normal, and the rate of 100 per cent of normal recommended by Governor Dewey.

Malcolm Johnson, veteran reporter of The New York Sun, received yesterday the first annual Award of Merit presented by the Women's Press Club of New York City "in recognition of an outstanding example of journalism in 1948."

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer and economic "boss of Britain" repudiated tonight an assertion by Christopher P. Mayhew, Foreign Under - Secretary, that Britain was completing her economic recovery.

PARIS, Feb. 26 -- Four of fifteen Communists who were questioned in connection with the alleged leak of defense secrets were indicted today by a military court on charges of holding or divulging defense secrets, punishable by a prison sentence of one to five years.

ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 26 -- Harvard almost scored an upset tonight, tying Cornell, 48 -- 48, on Walt McCurdy's field goal with 24 seconds to go. But Tom Turner popped in a one-hander from the corner and Cornell won its fifth Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game in nine starts, 50 -- 48.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UP) -- Representative J. Parnell Thomas, who was to have gone on trial here March 7 for alleged payroll frauds, suffered a stomach hemorrhage today and was removed to the Army's Walter Reed Hospital. His condition was described tonight as "good."
A NUMBER of the individual and group shows this week in local galleries maintain a respectable level of achievement and toward a modernity of effect.

IF the Mad Hatter and the Ugly Duchess had had a child, and the child had almost grown up, these are almost the kind of short stories he could be expected to write. Reading Truman Capote's first collection is, in fact, a good deal like a trip down the rabbit hole with a metropolitanized Alice, for the fey quality which underlay Mr. Capote's first novel, "Other Voices, Other Rooms," is here fortunately absent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- It is doubtful if any other proposal on President Truman's agenda for Congress will whip up quite so great a controversy as his program for national health insurance. For it is the most radical reform yet to be broached by his Administration.
Moscow now claims that there are some 25,000,000 followers of the Communist party line throughout the world. If this is true, it would indicate that Communist strength is at an all-time high.

BACK in the early days of air transportation it was enough that a plane had seats that resembled primitive deck chairs and interior decorations that might include burlap curtains and a coat of any color paint. Air travelers then were too excited over flying to pay much attention to how the plane was furnished.

WILLIAM RIDGEWELL'S alibi for the hour when his wife was murdered sounds a bit fishy to the local police. A call to Scotland Yard brings Supt. Jimmy Waghorn to the scene. He decides it is quite possible that someone has rigged the evidence to point toward the husband.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 26 -- A powerful regional organization, embracing all of Europe, must be formed to bolster the United Nations which has degenerated into a "brawling cockpit where insults may be flung back and forth," Winston Churchill asserted here tonight.

Domestic motion picture companies have reached a turning point, the result of the convergence of a series of unfavorable developments which seem certain to lead the industry to a position of lesser importance among the nation's industries, according to financial observers.

Despite efforts to get young people to enter the teaching profession, the teacher shortage is still the greatest problem facing American education today. With an increased school enrollment on the way, the shortage is expected to worsen during the next decade.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Radio-isotopes, valuable by-products of the nation's atomic energy program, will be made available without charge to qualified cancer research workers in the United States, the Atomic Energy Commission announced today.

Leaders criticized yesterday a tendency by Negroes to give publicity to the "first" employment of members of that race in offices and businesses. They said that "the custom often brings embarrassment to the employe as well as the employer."
RADIO listeners in Mexico enjoy many programs similar to those in the United States, but there also are decided points of difference in broadcasting below the border.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Feb. 26 -The dinghy sailors at the Larchmont Yacht Club won their match with Yale today, but by as narrow a margin as a wish of breeze.

ROME, Feb. 26 -- A Cabinet crisis was averted tonight when Premier Alcide de Gasperi rejected the resignation as a Vice Premier of Giuseppe Saragat, leader of the Right-Wing Socialists, who form a part of the Government's coalition. The question will come up again next week when Signor Saragat's party executive committee will meet to decide whether to continue to support Dr. de Gasperi or go over to the Opposition.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Behind the Republican revolt over Governor Dewey's tax and budget recommendations which broke into the open this week is the first full-scale challenge of his control over the Republican party in New York State, which has been undisputed since 1942.

THE forthcoming performances of the six quartets of Bela Bartok, to be given by the Juilliard String Quartet on the Monday evenings of Feb. 28 and March 28, bring to the fore our gratitude for that great legacy and prompt me to attempt to evaluate partially -- in a short space, alas -- this particular category among the late Hungarian composer's collective works.

OUT of a small incident in the day of three small children, Charlotte Becker has fashioned a simple yet dramatic story. It revolves around a pet canary, Dickie Boy, who comes into the family of Jim, Ginger and Johnny, and soon flies out again.

High police officials and a large number of detectives and policemen were working last night on a bizarre case in which the John David clothing store at Forty-third Street and Fifth Avenue, was reported to have been robbed of $2,000 to $5,000, after the kidnapping of its manager.

FOR all of its youth, video already has its verbotens. As the first mass medium to bring visual entertainment into the living room, television has adopted both taboos and precautionary measures which are different from anything experienced in radio.

AFTER seven years' scarcity, bock beer will again inundate taprooms in the metropolitan area beginning on March 10, bringing satisfaction to many gourmets and reviving a brewing practice 700 years old this year.

YUKON, Okla., Feb. 26 (AP) -- Grady the cow was freed from her silo prison today. The Hereford -- whose plight as a captive inside the forty-foot-high structure had North Americans guessing on the best means to free her -- was liberated with grease and plenty of pushing.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Go Jeep Go, descendant of the mighty Man O' War, won his third straight race over a muddy Fair Grounds course today by capturing the $5,000 added Duncan F. Kenner Stakes.

Charles Capozzoli of Bayside High School set a meet record of 4:26.3 in the one-mile run, to provide the feature of the interscholastic track program at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon, in conjunction with the trials of the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. championships.

HAMILTON, N. Y., Feb. 26 -- Putting on a brilliant scoring drive in the second half, Colgate University's basketball forces overpowered Rutgers for an impressive 77-54 victory before 1,800 winter carnival fans tonight.

THE third annual Hartford Flower Show will be held in the West Hartford State Armory, West Hartford, Conn., from March 17 to 22. Special "days" will give recognition to cities and sections contributing to the event, with "Greater Hartford Day" opening the show.

Regarding your picture quiz. "Who Said What?" it was not Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt who said "The public be damned." It was his son, William K. Vanderbilt, who remarked it in an understandable bit of petulance after he had been bothered a couple of hours by reporters who insisted that the public was entitled to a statement in regard to a certain policy. * * *

The New York Knickerbockers broke a four-game losing streak by defeating the Indianapolis Jets, 81 -- 76, in a Basketball Association of America contest at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night. A crowd of 3,529 fans saw the Knicks erase a 12-point deficit to win.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The nation's leaders in virtually every field paid tribute to the American Red Cross today in connection with the opening of the March fund campaign for $60,000,000.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 26 -- Coming back in the second half, Princeton's basketball team defeated Army, 47 -- 42, as 2,800 rooters sat in on the proceedings at the Dillon Gymnasium tonight in the feature of an action-packed sports day.

HAD this book been written in the United States; it would have cost about $250,000 of some foundation's funds and combined the efforts of at least a dozen scholars. England, however, remains in some matters a stronghold of individual enterprise.

VIENNA, Feb. 26 -- In spite of an emphatic denial by Tass, the official Soviet news agency, broadcast by the Prague radio, informed Czechoslovak sources tonight confirmed the report that Russia had proposed to move a large number of Sudeten Germans from the Russian zone of Germany back into the industrialized frontier areas of Czechoslovakia to raise production.

SANTA FE, N. M., Feb. 26 -- While New Mexico wool growers were deriving some comfort from the fact that they were less seriously hit by the West's hard winter than ranchers in other states, livestock men throughout the Southwest found many things to fret about this week.

" THE BIG BARBECUE" is a light-hearted, blandly amusing story about a pretty girl with a purpose in life. Her father is a timid hack on a copy desk and her mother a good cook with her heart in her work. Quite surprisingly, Ariadne Pontius herself is a girl in the Serene Blandish or Zulieka Dobson tradition.

IF it's opera you are interested in, Victor is making a splash with it these days. The company is releasing recordings of three operas: Benjamin Britten's The Rape of Lucretia, with only a small cut in the second act (eight twelve-inch disks); Verdi's Aida (two albums, ten twelve-inch disks each), and Mascagni's Cadvalleria Rusticana (eleven twelve-inch disks).

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 26 -- Coaltown gave another chock-full-of-run exhibition today. And that's just about what the $60,900 Widener Handicap amounted to -- an exhibition tour of the Hialeah Park track by Citation's sidekick, who triumphed under wraps to give Warren Wright's Calumet Farm its fourth success in the mile-and-a-quarter event.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- German women have less to unlearn than German men, and should be aided to undertake the political responsibility of their country since they outnumber the men by a 60-to-40 ratio, Pauline E. Mandigo, New York public relations consultant, has advised the Department of the Army.

RECOGNIZING the postage stamp as a common denominator in friendship among the world's peoples, the United Nations Council of Philadelphia announced last week that the scope of its "Hands Across the Sea" program for developing fellowship by mail is being broadened to provide machinery for "stamp collectors around the globe" to exchange philatelic possessions.

LLAO LLAO, Argentina -- The paradoxical position of the United States in the field of hemisphere travel was emphasized here this week with the closing of the Third Inter-American Travel Congress attended by government and private delegates from all countries of the Western World.

THE trend toward curtailing dimensions of passenger cars to make for easier driving, parking and garaging is exemplified in the 1949 De Soto models which will be displayed in this city and throughout the country next Saturday. Although there is a longer wheelbase the length, height and width have been reduced.

Construction costs will stabilize or decline slightly in 1949, according to a nation-wide survey made public yesterday by the Associated General Contractors of America, Inc., on the eve of its thirtieth annual convention opening tomorrow at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

In its final non-league test of the season before resuming its drive in the Eastern Intercollegiate race, Columbia University's quintet turned in another workmanlike performance last night in defeating Navy, 53 -- 41, before a crowd of 2,500 in the Morningside Heights gymnasium.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Several changes in the Taft-Hartley Law were recommended today in a report released by the Committee on Labor Law and Social Security Legislation of the New York State Bar Association.

EIGHTEEN-HOUR service on the 873-mile run between Kansas City and New Orleans is planned by the Kansas City Southern when its completely re-equipped streamliner, the Southern Belle, goes into service on April 3.

CORNELL -- School Administration The School of Education of Cornell University has developed a program in which students of school administration can acquire practical experience by serving as apprentices to local school superintendents and principals. Under the project, students are instructed on the curriculum needs of pupils, relations with the public and the community, development of effective parent-teacher organization and other important phases of school administration.

Which Will It Be? One of the questions for the future to determine is whether international business relations on the tourist level will be carried on in pidgin English or pidgin Russian. This prospect is discovered by a classical scholar, Prof. Revilo P. Oliver, who writes an article in The Classical Journal on the need, greater now than ever before, of a universal auxiliary language known to educated people everywhere.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 26 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay gave assurance today that "individuals who cannot reflect desirable public interests will be excluded" from the group of German trustees who are to run the Ruhr iron and steel plants until a German government decides the ultimate ownership of them.

TENNESSEE'S Constitution (Article XIV, Section 2) declares that no person who denies a future state of rewards and punishments may hold any office in the civil department of the state. Its people, generally regarded as shrewd as well as amiable, have not been restive under this particular ancient provision.

Trade contract problems which arose after the licensing by the United States of exports to Russia are expected to be highlighted in the suit brought against the Amtorg Trading Corporation by the United States Wall Board Machinery Company, now pending in Trial Term, Part II, of the New York Supreme Court.

Admiral H. Kent Hewitt, who sank so many enemy ships in two wars that he lost count, has found the house in the country toward which he and his wife will set their course after his retirement next Tuesday as United States Naval representative on the United Nations Military Staff Committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Dr. Eelco N. van Kleffens, the Netherlands Ambassador, said today that through the plan of his Government for expediting the transfer of sovereignty over Indonesia to a Federal Government, the Netherlands contemplated the transfer of sovereignty more than a year earlier than the date mentioned in the Jan. 28 resolution of the Security Council.

Contributions totaling $15,000,000 to be collected in one day, Sunday, March 27, will be sought from communicants of all Christian churches in the United States for relief projects overseas, it became known here yesterday.
RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 26 -- Agricultural and industrial matters attracted top interest this week in the Upper South.

MR. SENCOURT does not profess to be a Pauline specialist or to have presented a new conception of the "Apostle to the Gentiles." But, as he states in his preface: "For more years than I can think I have been fascinated by St. Paul as the first and greatest of Christian writers." His primary interest is the inner recesses of Paul's thought.

WITH very few exceptions, all the characters in this mystery are or have been connected with British Military Intelligence. Now that the war is over, this organization is doing what might be described as a clean-up job.

Many United States Presidents have been plain-speaking men. George Washington was known to "cuss out" subordinates when occasion demanded. Andrew Jackson often got profane when angry. Lincoln was criticized for his backwoods stories and earthy language.

With a strong field of fifteen teams scheduled to face Starter David F. Soden, the sixty-ninth edition of the international six-day bicycle race will get under way tonight at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory. The riders will get started at 9 o'clock and continue until next Saturday night.

PARIS, Feb. 26 -- The new Communist offensive against the Atlantic Pact in France and Italy will profit by the profound fear of war and the almost equally profound ignorance of the projected pact, in the opinion of government and diplomatic circles here.

Taking a tip from Community Concerts, the theatrical unions should organize a non-profit corporation -- call it Community Drama -- capitalized at $100,000, contributed by members of the profession whose investment would be returned as soon as practicable.

DETROIT, Feb. 26 -- It appeared unlikely that other automobile manufacturers would follow the lead of the General Motors Corporation in reducing the price of passenger cars and trucks when a Ford Motor Company official denied rumors that Ford planned to adjust price schedules.

The appointment of Clement J. Rodden as director of the Atomic Energy Commission's new laboratory for analytical control of uranium and other special materials at New Brunswick, N. J., was announced yesterday by Wilbur E. Kelley, manager of New York operations of the commission.
THE critics of polls have had their innings since Nov. 2. Now I think the public should hear the other side. Naturally, I am a prejudiced witness.

Dick Button, the Englewood (N. J.) skating star who sucessfully defended his world amateur figure skating championship in Paris this month, arrived in New York yesterday aboard a Pan American Clipper. The 19-year-old Button, a freshman at Harvard, was accompanied by his mother and his trainer, Gustave Lussi.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Feb. 26 -- Attorney General Tom Clark charged here today that "prophets of gloom" were conspiring to manufacture a depression to cut the wages of workers.

Efforts of savings bankers to reach an agreement with the State Banking Department on a revision of the so-called "legal list," which would broaden their investment powers, appear to have reached an impasse. The bankers have been attempting since 1945 to develop a formula acceptable to the Banking Department to allow investments in securities other than those that the agency formally lists as suitable.

OSLO, Norway, Feb. 26 -- European recovery depends on the termination of the Marshall Plan on schedule in 1952 and the early resumption of United States private capital investment on the Continent "according to the rules of the game," Norway's economic "strong man," Erik Brofoss, said today.

The stock market managed yesterday to rally for the first time in a week, although most increases held to fractions. The stimulant for the rebound was supplied by the air transport issues, which were helped by plans of the Civil Aeronautics Board for an extensive economic program designed to help the financial status of the nation's airlines.

THE medical career of David Bradley has been temporarily interrupted by the atomic bomb. Or, to be more specific, by the second bomb at Bikini -- the one that was exploded in the water of the Lagoon, leaving a lingering contamination of radioactivity.

FOR a season that had been giving every indication of being remembered for its unusually large number of musicals, revues and the lighter touch, matters certainly have taken a bloody turn. Suddenly, gore has come to the fore -- murder, suicide and violence stalk the local temples of Thespis.

WHEN Ezra Pound in 1912 announced a new school of poets and called them Les Imagistes, he made a flamboyant gesture and presented us with a term that resists analysis. The term "Imagist" has, in the textbooks and anthologies at least, been hung like an albatross around the neck of William Carlos Williams.

A Brooklyn College quintet that did not figure to extend the opposition threw quite a scare into the St. John's camp before succumbing, 64 -- 55, to the over-all superiority of the Redmen yesterday at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory. The contest was deadlocked eleven times and Brooklyn was in front as late as the four-minute mark in the second half.

WHEN science becomes involved as a direct issue in politics, the results frequently are not exactly beneficial to mankind. A notable American example was the Scopes trial in Tennessee in the Twenties; it left as a legacy laws on the statute books of that and several other states forbidding the teaching of the doctrine of evolution.

FOLLOWING a pattern already established (by James Thurber, Wolcott Gibbs, the late Russell Maloney and others), E. J. Kahn has put a generous helping of his shorter, lighter New Yorker pieces between hard covers. Magazine publication of these selections ranges from 1937 to 1948 and Mr. Kahn reports on experiences as diverse as crashing a deb party to being accused of Communist tendencies because of an addiction to horn-rimmed glasses.

Your picture quiz on statues, "Who Said What?" started me to thinking about "Who Put Them There and Why?" Bolivar deserves to stand at the head of the Avenue of the Americas, just as Ben Franklin deserves his spot in Printing House Square.

THE cooking or the South is as mysterious as that of Tibet to most Yankees. Nowhere is this plainer than in the simple matter of fried chicken. Two local authorities, transplanted to New York from Alabama and Tennessee, ask just one question when non-Southerners fry a young bird: "What has steaming to do with it?" Either Northerners fry a chicken, then steam it, or steam and then fry it.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 26 (AP) -- Two former baseball players matched par today to lead the field of thirty contestants in the Tenth Annual National Baseball Players' Golf tournament.

ERIC JOHNSTON, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, whose prestige in Hollywood has been threatened in recent months by a series of setbacks, came to town last week and set about mending his fences.

Substantial progress toward a settlement of the dispute between the Consolidated Edison system and the Utility Workers of America, CIO, was made at a four-hour negotiating session that ended at 7 o'clock last night.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 26 -- Mediation between the Burmese Government and the Karen rebels, who demand a separate state, will be the first item discussed by a meeting of five Commonwealth nations called here for Monday by Indian Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru.

APPROACH-OF-NORMALCY Note: Used-car prices have calmed down, steamer and railway rates likewise, spring is only four weeks away and the peaceful old travel-and-guidebook business is blooming. The New American Library has a complete series of paper-covered state guides (35 cents each) up its sleeve.

THE world's 160,000 Quakers wield an influence far beyond their numerical strength. For one thing, the rest of the world respects the willingness of Quakers to practice as well as profess religious belief. Dr. Comfort, president emeritus of Haverford College, thinks that modern man can learn much from the Quakers.

MUNICH, Germany, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Red tape and official lethargy are seriously hampering the United States' first line of defense in Europe, Col. Hubert Zemke of the United States Air Force charged today.

The presentation of Verdi's "Falstaff" yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House was a virtuoso performance. This was not because every detail of it was impeccable, or because one agreed with every stroke in individual interpretation or stage business.

IN your issue of Feb. 6 you have a page devoted to the British writer Mr. E. M. Forster. In your editorial note you rather deplore that the output of so distinguished an author has been so curtailed. This leads me to believe that one of Mr. Forster's books that has long been a favorite of mine isn't known in this country well.

Thirteen years ago The Colophon, a quarterly devoted to fine books and fine printing, asked its readers to nominate the ten living writers, American by birth or naturalization, most likely to be considered as classics in the year 2000. The New Colophon, happily revived after an eight years' vacation, has just repeated the experiment.

HARLINGEN, Tex., Feb. 26 -- Cary Middlecoff, Memphis, Tenn., dentist, let the birdies sing in the rain for him today as he sloshed through mud and water to a great 63 and leadership at the three-quarter mark in the $10,000 Rio Grande Valley open golf tourney.

Lieut. Col. Walter G. Rishel said yesterday that he knew Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty of Hungary "very well" and would not recognize the Hungarian primate from photographs taken at the trial where he was sentenced to life imprisonment for treason.

World federation as a means of achieving permanent peace was endorsed yesterday by a majority of six high school students serving on a Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over WQXR.

IF every seed and plant turned out exactly according to the catalogue's description or last year's experience, half the excitement of gardening would be gone. Certain kinds, however, can be depended on to vary from year to year -- garden to garden.

JEROME WEIDMAN'S new novel is really three things in one -- a fast-moving story of contemporary cross and double-cross, a candid-camera study of people you first met in an old nursery rhyme ("We're all in the dumps, for diamonds are trumps"), and an indictment of an age in which "convictions yield no dividends" and "integrity has no Dow-Jones average."

Lou DeFilippo, former star center at Fordham, will serve as Ram line coach for the 1949 football season, Jack Coffey, graduate athletic manager, has announced.
