The appointment, following the signing of George (Eck) Allen as backfield tutor, left the Rams with only one gridiron staff vacancy, the freshman coaching post.
William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, is scheduled to speak Saturday at a testimonial dinner to Ralph Wright, Assistant Secretary of Labor, in the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26 -Greater attention to development of instruction and activity programs emphasizing "moral and spiritual values" and "family-life education" was urged upon administrative leaders of junior colleges at the closing business session of the annual convention of the American Association of Junior Colleges here today.
The State of Israel plans to double its Jewish population within three years, Dr. Abraham Granovsky, chairman of the World Jewish National Fund, reported here yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- It is a mark of the parochialism of post-war Europe that news of deflationary tendencies in the American economy has caused hardly a ripple in public opinion. It is a matter of grave concern and speculation, however, among European business men, economists and statesmen charged with the responsibility of restoring their countries' economic stability.
Robert Grant 3d won the national amateur racquets championship for the seventh time yesterday to complete a season of uninterrupted success in one of the fastest of all games played afoot.

In his article, "Behind the Closed Door of the Grand Jury," Robert G. Whalen describes the Communists' plaint that the selecting of members for the grand jury is discriminatory since college and business alumni directories are used as sources for names.

A drive for contributions from friends of the Coast Guard toward the cost of an interfaith memorial chapel at the Coast Guard Academy, New London, Conn., will be announced at the 11 A. M. service today at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

Al Parsells, playing his fourth game in eight days and his second within twenty-four hours, was one of the key players in the Ramapo Polo Club's 14-12 victory over the Squadron A regulars in the feature game of a double-header at the Squadron A Armory last night. Parsells, riding at back, and Paul Miller, No. 2, scored five goals each.

The French and Italian Communist parties, among the largest outside Russia, have an aggregate membership of about 3,400,000. This figure is only one measure of the Communists' strength. In both countries they hold large blocs of seats in Parliament.

Evidences of Russian slave labor involving an estimated 8,000,000 to 20,000,000 persons were offered yesterday by Soviet refugees testifying before an unofficial commission finishing a three-day investigation of peonage, slavery and forced labor throughout the world.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 26 -- Temple University's agile tumblers clinched the Eastern intercollegiate gymnastic team title today by defeating Army, 56 to 40, before a crowd of 3,000 that jammed the cadet gymnasium to capacity.

A. A. Noble, in commenting on Hanson W. Baldwin's story on "'The Snorkel' in the War of the Future," says: "The Navy's first submarine, the Holland, was built, I believe, in 1898.'' In August, 1897, I enlisted in the Navy aboard the receiving ship Vermont, lying at the old Cob Dock, in the Brooklyn Navy Yard.
CHICAGO, Feb. 26 -- Some State Legislatures in this region are striving to provide more adequate support of public schools.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the horse and buggy days traffic was regulated by horse or mule sense, and if the driver did not interfere one could take a drink or sleep and even on a dark night travel with reasonable certainty of happy locomotion and safe delivery home.

HAVING chosen a subject which would strain any writer's talent, the second coming of the Lord, Mr. Clewes only partly confirms the promise he gave in his previous novel, "Thus Am I Slayn." The action of this story takes place in a sort of composite post-war country situated about where Austria should be.

RHINELANDER, Wis., Feb. 26 -- The sulphite pulp industry in Wisconsin is optimistic over what it believes may prove a solution to its decades-old problem of stream pollution and at the same time provide an important new by-product.

BOSTON, Feb. 26 -- New England business and industrial leaders maintained this week their optimism about current developments in the present period of "readjustment" in the nation's economy. But a note of anxiety was detected among the general public in discussing the significance of increasing lay-offs.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 26 -- The Knights of the Ku Klux Klan were in the headlines again this week, but some of the news this time was made by public officials who took a firm stand against masked mobs which have been terrorizing citizens in various parts of the South.

RYE, N. Y., Feb. 26 -- The Westchester County members of the Legislature agreed unanimously today to "stick it out" in their decision to block passage of Governor Dewey's $936,000,000 budget unless the Governor eliminated his proposal for an additional 1-cent-a-gallon tax on gasoline and substantially reduced the proposed increase in the state income tax.
LAST Sunday's pioneering production of "Twelfth Night" by the Actors Equity-Philco Television Playhouse on NBC provided a case of extremes in television drama.

One of Europe's most famous picture collections will be auctioned on Thursday at the Kende Galleries, 119 West Fifty-seventh Street. It was formed by Oscar Bondy of Vienna, who died in 1946, and was brought here shortly afterward by his widow, Mrs. Elizabeth A. Bondy, at whose order it will be sold.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 26 -- An international grade school will be opened here this fall to give children of United Nations staff members and delegates a chance to learn "the three R's" and keep pace with the studies that they would be following in their homelands.
GENEVA, Feb. 26 -- Nearly 400,000 lost European freight ears have been found, according to the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Feb. 26 -Decisions to transfer sovereignty over Indonesia at a date earlier than that laid down in the United Nations Security Council's resolution, to set free immediately Republican leaders and to convene a round-table conference for the furtherance of effective discussions were announced today by the Dutch Government.

" AS a 'native' I do not have any rights to assert," wrote Soetan Sjahrir, a 25-year-old Holland-educated Indonesian to his Dutch wife on March 29, 1934. On that date he had been in the Dutch prison at Tjipinang, Java, for a month.

ONE of the first astronomical oddities that a child learns to recognize is the "face" of the "man in the moon." Seen through a telescope, however, the illusion of human features disappears and the moon's face appears to be distinguished chiefly by its pockmarks.

KOESTLER'S newest book should make interesting reading. Irwin Edman's article, "Arthur Koestler as Philosopher," (Feb. 6) does. There is no doubt that before Plato's "Banquet," Homer gave an example of humor which ought not be forgotten: Ridens lacrimosum would be the Latin for it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- President Truman gave over a portion of this week to self-revelation, but there are two groups in this country -- one very small and one very large -- which did not discover anything new in the disclosures.

MUCH of the pruning that is required to keep ornamental trees shapely and to correct any tendency toward abnormal form is done before new growth begins -- in late February or March. The novice, however, may be at a loss to know just where and how much to prune.

WASHINGTON. THE time of glory has returned in a kind of bright autumnal sunburst for Sam Rayburn of Texas. His new era has made him the most powerful Speaker of the House since the days of "Czar" Joe Cannon, and the most influential elected man in the United States apart from his friend Harry -- Mr. Truman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Representative Daniel A. Reed of New York, ranking Republican member of the Ways and Means Committee, called on President Truman today to withdraw his recommendation for a $4,000,000,000 tax increase and thus help to restore public confidence "in these times of a tumbling economy."

Senator Tom Connally of Texas, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, declared last night that the United States would continue on a "worthy and lofty conception of international affairs" to contribute materially and spiritually to the brotherhood of nations and peoples.
Retail trade here last week continued its downward trend in comparison with a year ago. Department store sales were estimated as showing a decline of about 6 per cent.

Tonight will see the curtain drawn on the National Sportsmen's Show for another year. We have wandered through the four floors of the exposition like a homeless ghost since its opening, and are satisfied that this year's offering was much more satisfactory to the visitors than that of 1948.

William M. Leiserson, in "For a New Labor Law -- a Basic Analysis," left out one point which seems to me the most important of all, so neatly and completely it seems that it must have been done on purpose -- that is, unions in politics.

Accusing the National Audubon Society of advocating a "shocking, undemocratic" move for "sheer economic waste," Harold A. Felix, counsel to Feather Industries of America, Inc., struck back yesterday at the bird preservation agency.

AFTER ten years of intensive work in which he has become a ranking choral conductor, 32-year-old Robert Shaw has decided to turn definitely to the orchestra. Because he feels he does not know enough about orchestral technique, he is dropping nearly all his activities for a period of study that he thinks will probably last two years.

It is becoming more difficult to reconcile the optimistic views regarding the nation's economy, emanating chiefly from Washington, with the realistic facts that a mild recession in business is at hand. Financial markets last week reflected pessimism more than optimism, as unemployment increased, retail sales declined and carloadings continued downward in the yearly comparison.
Women, it is said, have difficulty making up their minds, but not Miss Sybil Park Appel of 2065 Grand Concourse, the Bronx. Miss Appel always knew what she wanted -- she wanted to be a teacher.
" I HAVE sometimes been mistaken in my opinion of a book I have read," a friend of Simeon Strunsky once told him, "but I have never been mistaken in my opinion of a book I have not read."
ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Governor Dewey, in a statement urging generous response to the American Red Cross fund drive, pointed out today that New York communities had received Red Cross disaster aid.

The establishment of a new Venezuelan-flag service between New York and La Guayra, with the initial sailing scheduled for late next month, was announced last week by M. S. Crinkley, vice president of Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., 26 Broadway, agents for the new line.

BOTTOM, Saba, Netherlands West Indies -- There is still adventure in the Caribbean for enterprising tourists who set their course for the island of Saba, a tiny dot on the map of the West Indies. Its rugged cliffs, descending almost perpendicularly to the sea, are an awesome sight and its main town of Bottom is curiously situated in a natural bowl on the mountainous island's summit.

Protests were voiced yesterday against a reduction of foreign language requirements for students enrolled under the projected Brooklyn College experimental curriculum, scheduled to start this fall. According to the plan, a student with as few as three years of a foreign language taken in high school could be exempt from taking any college courses in that language.

The Governments of the United States and of Israel have now completed their new relationship by designating their respective special representatives as Ambassadors. James Grover MacDonald will be our envoy to Tel Aviv if, as expected, his appointment is confirmed by the Senate.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Four highway safety bills, one requiring applicants for drivers' licenses to obtain "fitness certificates" from physicians at least once every three years, were drafted today by Senator Thomas C. Desmond, Newburgh Republican, for introduction in the Legislature Monday night.

Appointment of a "task committee" to recommend a course of action for the joint shipper-carrier-underwriter export packaging improvement program signals the start of the campaign's rapid the development into the "brass tacks" stage, shipping officials agreed yesterday.

THIS symposium contains a wealth of up-to-date information on the cultures and peoples of Africa, Latin America and the East. It consists of an introduction by the editor Ralph Linton, a Professor of Anthropology at Yale University, and twelve articles, each by a well-chosen expert.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Pete Harris, who retired from professional baseball some twenty years ago, today won the tenth annual national baseball players' golf tournament with a 36-hole total of 142.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- Trading in grain futures on the Board of Trade last week was featured by aggressive buying of May wheat, corn and oats. This resulted in the nearby delivery gaining on the deferred, especially in wheat, for which there was a broad Government demand for Feb. 28 shipment to Gulf of Mexico ports, where steamers are waiting to load the grain.

Atomic energy will take a small but highly symbolic role in construction at 4 P. M. tomorrow when it furnishes the starting power in laying the cornerstone for the new nineteen-story Crowell-Collier building at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- As the members of the International Typographical Union, AFL, were making their final payments of 4 1/2 per cent of weekly wages to the union's special defense fund, Woodruff Randolph, president, moved for a vote on continuance of the assessment.

William F. Stewart has been appointed vice president and general manager of FitzSimons Steel Company, a subsidiary of the American Steel and Pump Corporation. William A. Lampe was appointed vice president in charge of sales.

The United Jewish Appeal announced last night the opening of its 1949 campaign for $250,000,000. The drive will get under way immediately regardless of opposition by the United Palestine Appeal, a major beneficiary, although hope was expressed that that organization would join in the campaign and thus end all controversies.
The Philadelphia Americans, champions of the American Soccer League, bowed, 3 -- 0, to the New York Americans before 2,500 at Sterling Oval yesterday.

The subject of labor legislation is treated much of the time as if it were merely a question of the balance of bargaining power between the labor unions on the one hand and management on the other. But the unions and management are not, of course, the only parties that are going to be directly affected by what happens to the Taft-Hartley Act in Congress.

Plans for the erection of a one-story office and warehouse building for the distribution of dental supplies were announced in connection with the purchase by the J. Wurm Dental Enamel Company of a vacant plot on the south side of Forty-sixth Road, ninety-nine feet west of Twenty-first Street, in Long Island City, Queens.

MONT TREMBLANT, Que., Feb. 27 (AP) -- The visiting French ski team today put on a tremendous show of slalom power on the "Flying Mile" to capture the first five places and make a clean sweep of all the big trophies in the 1949 Canadian downhill and slalom championships.

Some of the concern being expressed over problems facing advertising in a full-bloom buyers' market was attributed by a number of officials last week to realization that much of the ad trade is "out of condition." There is no lack of knowledge among veteran ad leaders as to what basic strategy is required to meet the change, it was noted.

April 1 has been chosen by the Philosophical Library as the publication date of "A Short History of Existentialism," by Jean Wahl. The volume includes an appendix containing a discussion among the author and the contemporary philosophers, Berdiaeff, de Candillac, Gurvitch, Koyre, Levinas and Marcel.

KENT, Conn., Feb. 27 -- The folk of this town, situated in the foothills of the Berkshires, which has not grown a great deal since its founding in 1737 -- the last census listed 1,245 inhabitants -- displayed their talents and skills in a weekend exhibit of handicraft in the Community House.
Alicia Markova and Anton Dolin made their bows last night as guest artists with the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the City Center. The ballet was, of course, "Giselle."
GAMBIER, Ohio, Feb. 27 -- Edwin Collins of Grosse Pointe, Mich., accomplished an almost unbelievable feat of physical strength today in saving the lives of two Kenyon College students.

Immediate passage of the Labor Education Extension Bill before Congress was urged yesterday by Miss Hilda W. Smith, chairman of the National Committee for the Extension of Labor Education, at a conference sponsored by the American Labor Education Service at the New School for Social Research.

Christianity is the only hope for China or the rest of the world, the Right Rev. K. H. Michael Chang, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Fukien, China, said yesterday in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
An early lead of three goals proved just enough for the New York Rangers in their National Hockey League game with the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden last night.

After a 15-year-old boy had been killed with a .25 caliber automatic pistol that he was borrowing for "protection," according to detectives, the police rounded up more than a dozen other youths for questioning and collected an assortment of rifles, air guns, "zip" guns and knives last night in the Brownsville area of Brooklyn.

Fourteen bus passengers were injured yesterday afternoon, and a young housewife, riding with her husband and child in their automobile, was killed when the two vehicles collided at Lorimer Street and Marcy Avenue in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

"As a result of our sales training program our unit sales are at an all-time high, we enjoy the best customer relations and probably the lowest distribution costs in the industry," a food company reported.

Fourteen teams took off in the latest of the "grinds to nowhere" last night, in the international six-day bicycle race before 10,000 spectators at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory, Fort Washington Avenue and 168th Street, Manhattan.

With Kelvin Burnett scoring three successive goals in the opening period, the Sherbrooke Red Raiders conquered the New York Rovers, 9 to 4, in the Quebec Senior Hockey League clash that featured the program at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

Paul Futterman and Mitchel Fein, who recently bought the two six-story apartment houses on a plot 83 by 100 feet at 3153-55 Broadway, at West 123d Street, in the vicinity of Columbia University, have resold them to investing clients of Earl Douglas Hansen, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- A booklet on the budgets of working women in twelve states, based on official computations for guidance in administering minimum-wage laws, was issued today by the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor.

Wool goods prices which have run counter to those of other textiles, cannot be maintained in the face of consumer demand for lower prices on clothing, according to Adolph Schuman, president of Lilli Ann Corporation, San Francisco, largest manufacturer of women's coats and suits on the West Coast.

Pennsylvania Station thronged with southbound ballplayers and shadowing autograph seekers yesterday afternoon. Main contingents of the Dodgers and the Yankees left for Florida from the same platform within the space of fifteen minutes, with members of the Boston Braves and Red Sox headed in the same direction on the same trains.

The Southwestern Public Service Company is offering to holders of its common stock until March 8 rights to subscribe to 112,486 shares of new common stock at $25 a share. Dillon, Read Co., Inc., and associates have underwritten the transaction.

John Feeney, Irish tenor, gave a recital last night at Town Hall, which attracted a large and responsive audience. The genial artist, who has made many appearances in this city since his local debut in 1941, had again arranged a program composed largely of folk songs of his native land, in which he specializes, but also containing such other offerings as operatic arias by Handel and Flotow, and items by Schubert, Arne and Rosa.

Your editorial of Feb. 18 about Walter Reuther's idea for producing housing on an assembly-line basis has one serious defect: it fails to distinguish between a "house" and a "home." If that strikes you as quibbling, then you have never experienced the agony of trying to persuade a prospective house buyer to own his or her own home.

One of the hottest collegiate basketball rivalries in America will be resumed tonight when Notre Dame tangles with New York University's Violets at Madison Square Garden. A capacity crowd is assured for this fracas despite the fact that it will be the only game on the program. The tap-off has been set for 8:45.

Two transatlantic vessels, the Cunard White Star liner Media and the emergency-class passenger ship Marine Tiger, arrived here yesterday with nearly 700 passengers after stormy crossings of the North Atlantic.

The Children's Fund of the United Nations is giving a practical demonstration of how nations can work together for the common good, but it is not reaching enough children. The trouble lies both in the Children's Fund and in our own Government. The former, which was entrusted by the last General Assembly in Paris to conduct and inspire the 1949 global U. N.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- There was a complete absence last week of hedging sales in corn on the Board of Trade, due to the smallest country shipments since the new crop started to move in volume, and brokers expressed the belief that there would be no increase in the movement until the price is more satisfactory to producers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 27 -- In a week-end casting switch, necessitated by the illness of Paul Christian, Universal - International has assigned Dana Andrews to the leading role in "Sword in the Desert," the studio's picture about Palestine, which will go before the cameras Tuesday on location in Monterey, Calif.

Three cone-shaped cloth bags lined with plastic and four metal tubes that may be fitted on to them comprise the new "cake decorator," manufactured by Bonley Products and sold at Bloomingdale's for $1. This week in THE NEW YORK TIMES' test kitchen, Ruth P. Casa-Emellos, home economist, showed what professional, not to say pretty, effects may be achieved with a set of this sort.

Harold Lewis, who has been a member of the piano department of the Juilliard School of Music for twenty-five years, made his first downtown appearance yesterday afternoon when he played at Times Hall in a joint recital with his wife, Louise Lewis, young New York soprano, who made her local debut.

SAN MARINO, Feb. 27 -- First returns of the national election held yesterday indicated that the sovereign republic of San Marino would continue to have the only Communist Government on this side of the Iron Curtain.

STOCKHOLM, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Members of the United States ice hockey team got involved in another fist-swinging affair today -- this time including spectators -- and the Swedish Ice Hockey Association protested to the American Embassy.

If present plans are carried out a score of United States Senators, at noon today, will attempt to paralyze the legislative branch of our Government until this small minority, representing a small minority of the nation's population, many of its members elected by a small minority of the adult citizens of their constituencies, has enforced its will.

YONKERS, Feb. 27 -- James Preater, 40 years old, of 1850 Riverside Drive, New York, was taken to St. Joseph's Hospital here today after the light seaplane he was piloting plunged shortly after noon into the Hudson River about three-quarters of a mile out from the Yonkers Seaplane Base at the foot of Ludlow street.

The Metropolitan Opera Guild is conducting a campaign to raise $250,000 to be used in preparation for another season of opera in New York. The production of a repertory of operatic performances of high merit is a costly matter. Only the highest of standards is acceptable at the Metropolitan.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 27 -- Armistice talks between Israel and Trans-Jordan will open Tuesday at Rhodes. On the same day Israeli and Lebanese delegates will begin armistice negotiations in Israeli territory.

Marc Brown, 23-year-old violinist, who made his New York debut two years ago, gave his second local recital late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. His program contained the Bach-Siloti Partita in E minor, Mozart's Sonata in E minor, Faure's Sonata in A major, Robert Russell Bennett's "Five Tune Cartoons" and the Concerto, No. 2, in D minor by Wieniawski.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 27 -- Denmark's largest party, the Social Democrats, called on the country today to look to the West for military security.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- The shrinkage in stock exchange business here to the lowest level of the year indicates rather clearly that neither business men nor investors are viewing the outlook with much confidence. However, that is not to say there is anything approaching real pessimism, as shown by the comparative steadiness of security prices.

"Exploration" and "guidance" to help early adolescents discover and develop native talents for learning and living are being emphasized by the city's junior high schools, according to a report released yesterday by the Board of Education.

The first step toward a better understanding between Russia and the United States is the removal of "obstacles" in "our own minds and hearts," the Rev. John Paul Jones, pastor of the Union Church of Bay Ridge (Presbyterian), Ridge Boulevard and Eightieth Street. Brooklyn, said yesterday in his sermon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Eight college faculty members have complained to the American Association of University Professors that they were dismissed because they openly supported Henry A. Wallace for the Presidency, the chairman of its committee on academic freedom and tenure said today.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Feb. 27 -- Carl Alfred Ebach, 42-year-old former correspondent for the British news agency Reuters and for The London Daily Telegraph, was killed late this afternoon when an ornamental concrete column in the garden of his rented home here collapsed when he leaned against it.

Henry Wysham Lanier, author, sportsman and historian, will finish his history of Greenwich Village on Wednesday. The 76-year-old son of Sidney Lanier, the poet, has been working sixteen to eighteen hours a day since September to meet a deadline set by his publishers.

Richard Strauss' "Salome," which has been the major hit of the Metropolitan Opera's season, will be presented twice during the fifteenth week, that beginning March 7, it was announced yesterday. But the box office also isued the warning that there were no tickets available for either performance.

The transport Edmund B. Alexander, one of the Army's largest troop carriers, which plied the North Atlantic forty years ago as the Hamburg - American liner Amerika, has retired from service for the fourth time in her long career.

TOKYO, Feb. 27 -- The statements of Army Secretary Kenneth C. Royall and Gen. J. Lawton Collins, Vice Chief of Staff, that American troops would fight if Japan were attacked has touched off some speculation here regarding the showing that occupation forces would make should a "shooting war" begin.

Negotiating committees representing the Consolidated Edison System and the Utility Workers of America, CIO, reached a settlement last night on all disputed issues between them, lifting the threat of a utilities strike that would have affected most of this city and Westchester County.
BATAVIA, Java, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Leaders of non-Republican Indonesian states said today that they "warmly received" a new Dutch plan to settle the Indonesian conflict. The states are Dutch-sponsored.

PARIS, Feb. 27 -- Charles de Gaulle's organization today issued another call to the French nation to reorganize the state to "wrest from the Communists their power over part of the people" and save France from Soviet invasion.

DUESSELDORF, Feb. 27 -- The Ruhr is in a state of dramatic transition. No more interesting development is taking place in Europe than the transfer of power in full process here. The bizonal boards managing iron and coal production, together with the German committees serving under them, are being liquidated to make way for a new set-up provided for in the Ruhr Statute.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Feb. 27 -So close was the competition among thirty Interclub Class dinghies today at the Larchmont Yacht Club that in over seven races Bob de Coppet won over Corny Shields by a single point, or his boat's leading position in a single contest.

GAMBIER, Ohio, Feb. 27 -- Two students are known dead and six are missing as the result of a fire that destroyed a dormitory of 125-year-old Kenyon College early today. Twenty-six others were injured, two critically.

According to reports from Washington, the negotiations regarding the North Atlantic Security Pact are now entering into their final phase and the text of the proposed treaty is expected to be ready for submission to the interested Governments sometime this week.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Governor Dewey declared tonight in a radio broadcast that he could not "in good conscience" recommend any reduction of his $936,200,000 budget even though it meant $168,200,000 i additional taxation and had provoked a sharp cleavage in the state Republican party, which he heads.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Feb. 27 -- As part of a broad program of public education in the field of nuclear sciences, the Oak Ridge Institute of Nuclear Studies has established the world's first permanent museum dealing with atomic energy.

MOSCOW, Feb. 27 (UP) -- A full-page review of Annabella Bucar's book "The Truth About American Diplomats" appeared in today's Culture and Life, official organ of the Communist party Central Committee's press and propaganda department.

The Phil Harris-Alice Faye Show, a key link in the NBC Sunday-night schedule, appears to have withstood the temptation to join the list of radio shows that have been switching to CBS. A week-end announcement released jointly by NBC and the Rexall Drug Company, sponsor of the program, said a contract had been signed which assures the continuation of the program on NBC for the rest of 1949 and also for 1950.

CANTON, China, Feb. 27 -- Gen. Chang Chih-chung's plan for negotiating a "local" agreement giving to the Soviet Union exclusive economic privileges in Sinkiang, restless province on China's northwest frontier, is meeting stiff opposition here from the Foreign Ministry.

There would be wide public interest, we believe, in a detailed report by the New York State Commission Against Discrimination of its successes and failures. If the commission is prevented by law from making such a report, the Legislature either should amend the Ives-Quinn Act that created the commission, or issue from Albany a report that will satisfy the intelligent public.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Feb. 27 --Following are excerpts from a survey by the Jewish Labor Committee, released at its convention here, on the fate of the 650,000 Jews who survived the war of extermination in Rumania, Hungary, Czechoslovakia and Poland:

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 27 -- Five weeks from Friday 28-year-old John Czechel, who delivers papers and bundles here as a United Nations messenger, will hurriedly put away his push cart and race via bus, train and subway to Carnegie Hall in Manhattan for a special date -- his debut as a concert singer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UP) -- The House Agriculture Committee will open four days of hearings Tuesday on repeal of Federal oleo-margarine taxes, with the oleo bloc confident the Democratic-steered Congress will erase the levies.

The Radio Corporation of America had a net income of $24,022,047 from operations last year, compared with $18,769,557 in 1947, it was disclosed in the twenty-ninth annual report issued for release today. Share earnings increased 38 cents to $1.50 a snare.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Miss Janet Morgan and Mrs. Alice Teague of England won the United States women's squash racquets doubles championship today by defeating the Connecticut pair of Miss Betty Howe of New Haven and Miss Barbara Banks of Greenwich. 13 -- 15, 18 -- 14, 15 -- 11, 18 -- 15.
CHICAGO, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks and the Boston Bruins battled to a 2-2 tie before 16,484 in tonight's National Hockey League game here.

In a surprise attempt to turn the tables on the vestry of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, a group of churchgoers called yesterday a special meeting of the parish to seek the ouster of nine of the eleven members of the church's governing body.

The Prison Association of New York urged the Legislature yesterday to adopt a policy of correction instead of "mere" detention in the state's penal institutions. This was one of twenty-three recommendations in the 104th annual report of the association, of which Edwin O. Holter of New York is president and E. R. Cass is general secretary.

By the end of the current year, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation will have in operation an annual ingot capacity of 15,000,000 tons, a gain of 30 per cent over its potential in 1939, E. G. Grace, chairman, declares in annual reports mailed yesterday to employes and stockholders.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 27 -- An increased birth rate coupled with a decreased teacher supply is endangering the future of the American free public school system, leading school authorities warned today.

One of the sharpest increases in crime, involving both juveniles and adults, has been noted in the last year by Salvation Army workers, Commissioner Donald McMillan, Territorial Commander of the organization, reported yesterday.

Art exhibitions opening this week range widely through time and latitude. On Friday the Metropolitan Museum will show ancient art of the Near East, including sculpture, pottery and metal work. Beginning tomorrow paintings, sculpture, prints and manuscripts given by artists, writers and collectors for the benefit of International Rescue and Relief Committee will go on view at the Laurel Gallery before auction later this month at the Kende Galleries.

Lubka Kolessa, whose piano recitals have pleased listeners here and in Europe, appeared with the Philharmonic-Symphony under the direction of Walter Hendl Saturday night at Carnegie Hall. She played the solo in Chopin's E minor Concerto in a program otherwise well-laden with twentieth-century compositions.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 19 -- Not since the end of the war has the problem of French-German relations so engrossed the German press and conversations among leading German personalities. A spurt was given to this trend recently with the formation in Ludwigsberg of the German-French Institute.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 27 -- Senator J. Howard McGrath, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, told 1,600 persons attending a Jefferson-Jackson victory dinner here tonight that the Democrats did not intend to compromise on civil rights even if it meant Congress' staying in session all summer.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 27 -- The nation's steel industry operated last week at 100.5 per cent of rated capacity, unchanged from a revised rate of the week before. Late last week there was no evidence of any drop in this unprecedented volume of steel ingots.

Travel-weary but in jubilant spirits, 489 Jewish refugees from Shanghai on a 15,000-mile journey to freedom, reached Jersey City at 9:03 o'clock last night after a five-day trip from San Francisco aboard a special "Liberty train."

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Desperado Bill Ray Gilbert, 28, was shot to death tonight while resisting arrest. He was trapped in a Phoenix auto court. Sheriff's deputies, police and Federal agents were at the scene. A policeman was shot in the leg in the battle.

Capt. Carlos A. Garzoni, commander of the 6,800-ton Argentine cruiser Almirante Brown, fifteen of the ship's officers and 125 members of the crew attended solemn high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Economic Outlook, a publication of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, declared today that American economy, as well as democracy throughout the world, had an interest in "orderly and expanding" international trade.

HARLINGEN, Tex., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Cary Middlecoff, the Memphis dentist who quit pulling molars in favor of pulling down cash on the golf trail, staged a great comeback today to capture first prize in the $10,000 Rio Grande Valley open with a 72-hole score of 267.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 27 (AP) -- A new device which concentrates the projection of movies and the facilities of radio and television in a single cabinet will go into production here soon. Fred C. Forney, architectural designer and illustrator and inventor of the unit, said a newly formed company "expects to go into production within two months."

The latest Knize collection upholds the standards of classic tailoring for which this house has been well known for many years. Presented on Friday morning in the new women's department on the second floor of the 24 East Fifty-sixth Street building, the collection included tailored town suits and casual sports costumes for beach, tennis and golfing.

GREAT FALLS, Mont., Feb. 27 -- Despite a three-day delay at Dawson Creek, Canada, caused by blizzards which blocked highways, the first scheduled truck shipment of perishables between Great Falls and Alaska has been completed successfully.

BERLIN, N. H., Feb. 27 -- Tor Arneberg, Dartmouth's spectacular Norwegian exchange student, twice rode out the treacherous Nansen, S. C.'s 900-foot-long hill, one of the steepest in the East, under full control, to garner Class A honors in the F. I. S. (Federation Internationale de Ski) sanctioned international jump today.

BANGKOK, Siam, Feb. 27 -- Soldiers fought sailors in the streets of Bangkok today after unidentified plotters had seized the Government radio station and declared that Siamese Premier Marshal Pibul Songgram and his Cabinet had resigned.
Although Michigan State enters the Big Ten fold next year, the East has not seen the last of the Spartans' powerful spiked-shoe legions.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 27 -- Egypt and Syria are seeking the means of mobilizing the Arab community of nations against any settlement of the Palestine question that would give Arab Palestine to Trans-Jordan, it was learned here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UP) -- A new crop, which "promises to be of unusual value, both commercially and strategically," has been introduced successfully in the Western Hemisphere, the Department of Agriculture reported today.
BENTON, Wis., Feb. 27 -- The last of sixteen miners who had been trapped for nearly seven hours in a fire-wrecked lead mine were brought to the surface in an improvised elevator today.

Complete restoration of the crumbling exterior of City Hall at an estimated cost of $1,000,000 or more will be undertaken this year if the project is approved by the Municipal Art Commission, which has it under consideration.

Let us mercifully avert our eyes from the Experimental Theatre's current folly. It is Iris Tree's "Cock-a-Doodle-Doo," put on at the Lenox Hill Playhouse Saturday evening, and it is gibberish. According to the most advanced philosophy, there is a reason for everything, including dramas.

Buyers in the wholesale apparel market here last week covered immediate requirements only, and orders for the most part were light, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Cotton dresses and summer suits were in greatest demand, it was said, and the rather slow activity in other ready-to-wear divisions reflected the cautious attitude which has been shown by retailers recently.

LINDENHURST, L. I., Feb. 27 -- Leo Paul Morin, 22 years old, a student skating champion at St. Michael's College, Winooski Park, Vt., was killed here at 2:25 o'clock this morning when an automobile in which he was a passenger failed to take a curve and turned over three times.

The Rev. Dr. Henry P. Van Dusen, president of Union Theological Seminary, said yesterday that creation was the purpose of life and the answer to much of man's restlessness and sense of futility. Speaking at the Broadway Tabernacle (Congregational), Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street, he extolled parenthood as the ultimate creative fulfillment.

A suggestion that the church "stop hiding like an ostrich, and instead jump with both feet forward" to meet the political and social problems confronting the world was voiced yesterday by Dr. Andrew V. Clements, dean of the Albany Law School.

Ovens supplying 70 per cent of the city's wrapped bread supply were shut down yesterday in a dispute between Local 550 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, and six major bakeries over wage guarantees and working conditions.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 27 -- Dr. Lewis M. Terman, Emeritus Professor of Psychology at Stanford University, who has made a long study of "geniuses," tonight attacked the statements of other educators who had questioned the value of intelligence-quotient tests in the American educational system.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Reassured by the Labor party's latest local election success, the party leaders returned to London tonight after a harmonious week-end house-party conference at which they assayed Labor's chances of winning another five years in office.

Members of the congregation of Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, paid tribute to the Rev. Dr. Samuel Schulman on his fiftieth anniversary as their rabbi for the lifetime of service he has given the cause of Judaism. Similarly honored was the Rev. Dr. Nathan Krass, celebrating his twenty-fifth year as rabbi of Temple Emanu-El.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 27 -- United States and British officials in Sofia, who have been studying the confessions and indictment of he Protestant clergymen who have testified thus far in the trial of fifteen Bulgarian church leaders on charges of treason, espionage and black-marketing, reject the accusations implicating former officials of American and British elements of the Allied Control Commission and Legations.

A number of musicians learned something more about music last night. They were a large part of the crowd which heard one of the concerts of the National Association for American Composers and Conductors at Times Hall, and from the smiles on their faces, the education was no bitter dose.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The American Federation of Labor said today that "a gradual and orderly decline in high prices is greatly needed now to increase buying power of workers and other consumers and bring them back into the market."

The Port of New York Authority has won a years-old fight to equalize rail rates on export grain shipments through New York, Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the bi-state agency, announced last night. For the first time in more than fifty years, he said, the Port of New York will soon have parity with Philadelphia and Baltimore on rail freight rates on Great Lakes export grain.

At an organization meeting in Washington, D. C., last week the new Building Research Advisory Board of the National Research Council instructed a subcommittee to obtain the services of a permanent, full-time director. The advisory group will not engage directly in research work but will limit its activities to presenting facts that will provide more and better building construction, including housing for more people at lower cost.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Feb. 27 -- The present rate of cancer cures can be doubled with present methods and techniques available for the detection and treatment of the disease that kills more than 180,000 Americans annually, according to a consensus of authorities in the field attending the National Cancer Conference.

The Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation reported yesterday for 1948 a net income of $102,335,053 after charges and taxes, equal to $3.55 each on the 28,807,314 shares of capital stock outstanding after a three-for-one split in April, last year.

WESTWOOD, N. J., Feb. 27 -- An organization of teen-age boys and girls, founded to aid the campaign for a Pascack Valley Hospital to serve this area, has been so successful in raising funds and combating juvenile delinquency that it is planning a nation-wide membership drive.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Feb. 27 -- Delegates to the convention of the Jewish Labor Committee here heard today a detailed report on Jewish life behind the Iron Curtain. It showed that Jews in the Russian sphere of influence had experienced the same treatment accorded to Protestants, Catholics and political minorities.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -The National Retail Credit Association today urged the Government to give people more time to pay for installment purchases.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Marshal of the Royal Air Force Lord Douglas of Kirtlesdie shortly will take over the chairmanship of the British European Airways Corporation, one of the country's three state owned airline, the Ministry of Civil Aviation announced tonight.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 27 -- Winston Churchill got a turbulent reception here this afternoon when several hundred Communists sought to disrupt a public, open-air meeting of the European Unity Movement at the Bourse by heckling, whistling, jeers, catcalls and half-hearted attempts to riot.

Emphasizing the growing anomaly of declining rates of return in a year of unprecedented activity, the New York Telephone Company's report for 1948, out today, shows that despite a volume of business unmatched in the last fifty-two years, the rate of return on invested capital dropped 1.2 per cent to 5 per cent last year.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- A new refinancing plan for the financially-troubled Tucker Corporation, broader in scope and more fully developed than any other program yet announced, was disclosed by the backers today. They include Fred Rockelman, executive vice president and director of the company, Kenneth Lyman, technical adviser, on leave, and attorney, Justus Chancellor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Southern Democrats in the Senate, whose filibuster weapon has not failed them before, unsheath it again tomorrow in a struggle which may prove the "main event" of the Eighty-first Congress.

BERLIN, Feb. 27 -- A guarded call for the establishment of some sort of defense organization to fight any forceful Communist expansion into Western Germany was made here today by three Berlin Socialist leaders. They carefully refrained from specifying what form the organization should take.
CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- Lard futures fluctuated in an erratic manner on the Board of Trade last week, but prices held within comparatively narrow limits.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 27 -- This winter's extraordinary freezing weather may cost California farmers upward of $20,000,000, a survey indicated today. However, from a number of angles, the weather's effects appear less severe than initially expected.

VIENNA, Feb. 27 -- The statement by the Soviet Government in a note presented in Moscow yesterday to the United States and British Embassies that the United States authorities in Austria had ordered Russian repatriation activities in the American zone of Austria to cease by March 1, was flatly denied here today.

ZURICH, Feb. 27 -- Uneasiness in Switzerland over the tactics employed in the United States in the present campaign aiming at restricting importation of Swiss watches reached a climax this week-end when competent spokesmen for the Swiss watchmaking industry protested forcefully against what they called misleading statements at the hearings of the Senate Finance Committee.

GENEVA, Feb. 27 -- Europe produced more than 40,000,000 tons of coal during January. Of the seven major producing countries, three were mining coal well above pre-war quantities. All but one country, Britain, which was not ahead of pre-war production, were getting coal at the cost of a vastly greater expenditure of manpower than was required before the war.

The city's campaign to clean Harlem streets and backyards will bring enforcement of 3,600 violation orders beginning March 15, Bernard J. Gillroy, Commissioner of Housing and Buildings, announced yesterday. The Citizens Planning Council, Inc., a Negro organization, also will seek cooperation of the tenants in a forty-six-block "study area."

PRATT, Kan., Feb. 27 -- Bill Veeck, owner of the world champion Indians not only has made off with a Negro ball player the Yankees thought they were about to sign, but it is possible he may wind up with another whom the Bombers were certain they had safely signed.
ROME, Feb. 27 -- Tear-gas bombs and bursts of machine-gun fire into the air were used by the police in Milan this afternoon to re-establish order against former Partisan demonstrators.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Feb. 27 -- The first simulated atomic bomb attack in the long history of this nation's naval maneuvers was adjudged tonight to have put the giant aircraft carrier Franklin D. Roosevelt temporarily "out of action," and to have "sunk" one destroyer.

Larry Evans, winner a second time of the tournament for the championship of the Marshall Chess Club, finished his schedule yesterday with a draw against Eliot Hearst, winding up with a total score of 14 -- 4.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 27 -- China's Communists closed off today the last outlet of news from their areas except that coming from the Communist radio. For "military reasons" they ordered foreign correspondents in Peiping to cease the gathering and transmitting of news.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 27 -- President Truman has been asked by the National Union of Marine Cooks and Stewards, CIO, to rescind his order to the Maritime Commission that it turn over for Army operation, eleven C-4 type ships nows operated by the USMC.

Prices of cotton fluctuated irregularly in the domestic market last week but held within a relatively narrow trading range. At the close on Saturday, active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were 28 points higher to 17 points lower. An the gains were recorded by the nearby deliveries.
Three new films, including an importation from Sweden, are slated to open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UP) -- Senator Arthur H. Vanderberg, Republican, of Michigan, today termed "satisfactory and adequate" the United States draft of the North Atlantic security pact pledging use of military force, if deemed necessary, to halt aggression in Europe.

The nation-wide campaign of Histadrut, the Israeli Labor Federation, to raise $10,000,000 this week for its work in Israel, was started here yesterday at a luncheon of presidents of 500 benevolent and fraternal societies.

DURING the human struggle between the British and German Air Forces, between pilot and pilot, between A. A. batteries and aircraft, between ruthless bombing and the fortitude of the British people, another conflict was going on step by step, month by month. This was a secret war, whose battles were lost or won unknown to the public, and only with difficulty comprehended, even now, to those outside the small high scientific circles concerned.

Although it spent the duration of the show wedged between an exhibit of Indian drums and basketwork and a simulated trading post, the display of the Marine Historical Association at the National Sportsmen's Show at Grand Central Palace attracted thousands of show visitors.

Leon H. Keyserling, vice chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, told representatives of 100,000 trade unionisis last night that labor should work "militantly" for higher wages and a better standard of living year after year.

OSLO, Norway, Feb. 27 -- Norway's heroic drive for a self-supporting status in 1952 has reduced her living standards to the point of diminishing returns. Three years of the present threadbare economy has about convinced the Government that the people must be better fed and clothed if the objectives are to be attained.

"Carousel," the Rodgers-Hammerstein musical, will close Saturday night at the Majestic Theatre, where it has been playing a return engagement since Tuesday. The production, which reopened at the Majestic after a four-week run at the City Center, failed to maintain the lively box-office pace set at the civic playhouse on Fifty-fifth Street, which can accommodate 3,025 persons.
I was astonished to read in THE TIMES of Feb. 13 an article from Edmund Demaitre in which misleading use is made of an article written by myself and published in my newspaper, Franc-Tireur, Paris.

PEIPING, China, Feb. 26 -- Plans seem to be accelerating here toward an early Communist move into central and southern China and the establishment of an over-all government. Yesterday thirty-five leaders of former "dissident" Hong Kong groups arrived here from Mukden. Among them was Gen. Li Chishen, oldtime Kuomintang [Government party] leader who is now head of the Kuomintang Revolutionary Committee.
Following is the text of Governor Dewey's radio address last night concerning the tax increases proposed in his budget, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Without a doubt, tomorrow will be the best day of the year. It will be so because there will be no tomorrow, and, as everyone knows, no day is quite so satisfactory as the one which does not exist. And tomorrow does not exist this year.
Pound sterling last week suffered its first reverse since the new year when heavy offerings by oil and motion-picture companies struck the rate down to $4.03, lowest since Jan. 5.
BUFFALO, N. Y., Feb. 27 -- A fine looking Great Dane, Ch. Fury, belonging to Creighton Hayne of Cleveland, took best-in-show in the twenty-fourth Kennel Club of Buffalo event tonight.

Millions of words have been written about post-war inflation in the United States, but this writer, at least, can recall no observation that has matched in pure distilled wisdom one made about three years ago in "American Affairs" by Garet Garrett.

TOKYO, Feb. 27 -- Occupation authorities are watching with considerable trepidation Japanese Cabinet preparations for establishing a Parliamentary Committee on Un-Japanese Activities. They have heard too many Japanese say:

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- Appealing for support of the 1949 Red Cross campaign for $60,000,000, which was opened here tonight, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower said it gave every American an opportunity to "prove again that generosity, greatness of heart and individual acceptance of responsibility are truly characteristic of this nation."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Mildred E. (Axis Sally) Gillars testified at her treason trial today that she refused to work with an American Air Force deserter who flew his plane into Germany and went to work for the Nazi wartime radio.

Sixty-one Polish and three Italian seamen representing more than a fifth of the crew of the Gdynia America liner Sobieski, are being sought by immigration authorities for failing to report for the sailing of their ship last Friday, it became known yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 28 -- Israel added another piece of Palestine to her occupied territory today and added another 1,000 persons to the Arab refugee problem when she officially took over control of the Faluja pocket, from which the Egyptian brigade was evacuated.

PRAGUE, Feb. 28 -- In a speech to be published on the front pages of all Czechoslovak newspapers tomorrow, Premier Antonin Zapotocky declared yesterday that there was no room in the present Government coalition for "those who would plot with the enemies of Soviet Russia."

In its report on our national security organization the Hoover Commission goes beyond the recommendations made by its special task force in urging legislative changes to strengthen civilian control over Army, Navy and Air Force and to provide for real unification of the three service arms.
The Long Island Rail Road, already in financial distress, appeared last night to have lost the support of its parent, the Pennsylvania Railroad.

Well-organized consumer relations programs do produce concrete results in creating a more favorable opinion of advertising, it was emphasized yesterday by Dr. Kenneth Dameron at the tenth annual meeting of the Committee on Consumer Relations in Advertisers, held in the Union League Club.

The City Housing Authority is preparing eviction proceedings against 600 families occupying apartments in low-rent housing projects whose incomes are above the maximum stipulated for residence there, it became known yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The American marine insurance industry won a part of its battle for a share in insuring cargoes of the Economic Cooperation Administration to Europe.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- Following the lead taken by the Communists in France and Italy, Harry Pollitt, general secretary of the British Communist party, said at a private meeting of party leaders yesterday that British Communists would try to stop any "imperialist aggressive war against the U. S. S. R."
Premature forecasts of spring vanished yesterday under a blanket of soggy snow as the warmest February in fifty-nine years unloosed a final wintry blast.
The much-battered Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, lost two more locals to the American Federation of Labor yesterday.

Garage and parking lot owners may have their fee increases fixed at 30 per cent above their 1946 charges, according to an amendment offered to the proposed law designed to block garage and parking lot gouging, it was learned yesterday.
Frank Bowden, Seventh Regiment star, advanced to the third round as play in the men's singles division of the Eastern indoor tennis championships continued yesterday at the Fifteenth Regiment Armory.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Apart from heavy dealings in Cable and Wireless stock, following the announcement of a compensation award of 35,250,000 ($141,000,000) fairly quiet conditions ruled in the stock market here today.

Although trading on the New York Stock Exchange for the twenty-two sessions of February was the smallest for any month since last August, the volume of business was slightly larger than in the corresponding month in 1948.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 1 per cent last week compared with the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 5 per cent.

LOCKLAND, Ohio, Feb. 28 -- Basic research on jet power plants that will function efficiently at a 70,000-foot altitude and at temperatures as low as 70 degrees below zero, Fahrenheit, is being conducted by the General Electric Company, it was learned here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers today filed a brief and exceptions to the recent findings of a trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board condemning as illegal the present union-shop provision in the agreement between the union and eighteen steel companies.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Feb. 28 -- Although ten members of the squad were reported stricken with dysentery in the afternoon, the City College quintet showed no signs of illness tonight when it sped to a 53-to-49 victory over Syracuse University before 3,723 fans at the State Fair Coliseum.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- A Congressional joint committee writing a report on President Truman's economic program divided today along party lines about the same as obtain in Congress as a whole.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- An objection by the Caribbean-Atlantic Airlines today prevented the Eastern Air Lines from proposing "the lowest rates in the history of air transportation" for service between New York City and San Juan, Puerto Rico.

The World Council of Churches will continue to aid religious groups behind the Iron Curtain despite the arrest and trial of fifteen Protestant clergymen in communist-controlled Bulgaria, an official of the council said yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Ezzard Charles of Cincinnati finished strongly tonight to win a 15-round boxing decision over Joey Maxim of Cleveland in a bruising battle before 14,062 fans in the Cincinnati Garden. Charles weighed 181 3/4 pounds, Maxim 184.
ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- Purification of the water courses and marine areas of New York State is the aim of an anti-pollution bill that was put to the Legislature tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- A loan of $16,000,000 was granted today to Belgium by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development. Two private Belgian steel corporations and a private electric company will use the proceeds of the loan to construct two steel mills and a power plant in the industrial district of Liege.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- Dr. Karl Gruber, Austrian Foreign Minister, rejected today two of the four latest Yugoslav "compromise proposals" put forward here at the Austrian treaty talks by Dr. Ales Bebler, Yugoslav Deputy Foreign Minister.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Air Transport Association, an organization of the certificated airlines, charged here today that the large irregular carriers competing with them operated under safety requirements far less severe, as stated in Government regulations, than their own.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, announced here today that execution of death sentences on twelve Nazi defendants convicted in the Malmedy war crimes trials had been deferred until March 15, pending a final decision by Lieut. Gen. Lucius D. Clay, American Military Governor in Germany.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- Informed political circles predicted today that the Labor party's platform for the next general election now taking final shape would emphasize strongly the reduction of the cost of living and propose only a moderate measure of additional nationalization for industry.

CANTON, China, Feb. 28 -- Despite the publicity that Canton has attracted as the seat of Premier Sun Fo's Cabinet, this city falls far short of being an impressive rallying center for any future Chinese Government resistance against the Communists.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- As the deadline arrived in the Assembly tonight for the introduction of resolutions, Assemblyman John R. Brook, Republican of Manhattan, proposed a resolution for an all-inclusive investigation of Mayor O'Dwyer's administration of New York City.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- On behalf of dissident Erie Republican legislators, Senator Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo detailed tonight a program for cutting $102,330,000 from Governor Dewey's $936,200,000 budget in order to reduce the need for $168,200,000 in new taxes.

Kentucky and St. Louis University, the nation's first and second ranking basketball teams, will renew their rivalry in the National Invitation basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden this month.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 28 -- Five more ministers pleaded guilty and made oral confessions to treason, espionage and illegal currency operations in today's session of the trial of fifteen Protestant clergymen before a Sofia court.

The flag of Israel will be hoisted on the first vessel of the new nation to enter transatlantic service in a special ceremony on Monday at Potts Cove Pier, Astoria, Queens, when the registry of a former Canadian Victory ship will be changed to that of Israel.

The Governor's speech to the people in defense of his $936 million budget and the tax increases that go with it was beneficial in at least one respect: those who heard or read him now have a much clearer understanding of the budget and how largely its size reflects state contributions to cost of local services.
BOSTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Ski conditions in the New England area were reported today. The forecast i for all points .was snow flurries, very cold and windy with temperatures far below freezing Tuesday.

Terming education the bulwark against totalitarianism, Deputy Mayor John J. Bennett asserted yesterday that "as long as we open more and better schools and continue to teach our children to think, Communism will have no chance in this country."

The local cotton trade has heard reports that some Congressmen will point to the growing competition cotton is facing from synthetic fibers as a reason for eliminating Government loans to cotton farmers. These sources, the reports say, will urge that cotton be permitted to seek a supply-and-demand price level, with the Government contributing a direct subsidy to cotton growers to the extent that the market price falls shy of parity.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 28 -- Running for the first time in the silks of Gustave Ring of Washington, who recently purchased him from the Maine Chance Farm, the 4-year-old colt Top Pilot made an up-and-at-'em finish to win the only non-claiming event at Hialeah Park today.

LONDON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The text of a decree by the Soviet Council of Ministers [Cabinet] and the Central Committe of the Communist party lowering state retail prices on mass consumption goods from March 1 as transcribed by the Soviet Monitor:
At a heated meeting last night, the New York County Medical Society voted disapproval of the $25 assessment decided upon last fall by the American Medical Association's House of Delegates.

Directors of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation have voted to submit to stockholders for approval a proposal authorizing expenditure up to $4,202,152 for purchase of outstanding common stock of the aircraft manufacturing company, it was announced yesterday.

GAMBIER, Ohio, Feb. 28 -- The death toll in the Kenyon College dormitory fire was put officially at nine tonight as Gordon K. Chalmers, president of the 125-year-old institution, abandoned hope for the six students who have been missing since the structure was destroyed early Sunday morning.

The Rev. Laurence J. McGinley, president of Fordham University, praised the faculty, alumni and students of the university for their loyalty and spoke of the need for expanding plant facilities in an address last night before a gathering of 1,000 persons at the ninety-fifth annual Fordham University Alumni Association dinner at the Biltmore Hotel.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- Supporting his company's petition for a $49,000,000-a-year rate increase, R. H. Hughes, vice president of the New York Telephone Company, told the Public Service Commission at a hearing today that the company would need at least $200,000,000 of new capital from investors to finance its proposed 1949-50 construction program.

The Government will complete three years of its debt-reduction program today but the outlook for a continuance after June 30, end of this fiscal year, is clouded by the possibility of a budget deficit.

Oakite Products, Inc., cleanser manufacturer, which long has placed major emphasis on newspaper advertising, will mark its fortieth anniversary by using its largest list of newspapers, including those in the foreign language field, it was announced yesterday by Frank A. Conolly, merchandising manager.

Manufacturers and wholesalers of stationery products were urged yesterday to make a large-scale increase in advertising and brand-name promotion, and to aim a major part of the drive at a virtually untapped home market.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company, Oklahoma City, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 89,000 shares of $20 par-value common stock to be offered to its common stockholders, one additional share for each ten shares held.

WILDWOOD, N. J., Feb. 28 -- A four-engine DC-6 plane of American Airlines flying from Washington to La Guardia Airport made an emergency landing today at 4 P. M. at Wildwood Airport after a short circuit in electrical equipment had filled the passenger cabin with smoke.

It didn't appear likely at half-time, but Notre Dame defeated N. Y. U., 71 -- 66, and going away, in their annual court clash at Madison Square Garden last night. This contest, which launched and popularized college basketball at the Eighth Avenue arena back in 1934, was witnessed by 17,382 fans and went the way of nearly all Notre Dame-N. Y. U. encounters.

Reporting on operations last year of the American Tobacco Company, Vincent Riggio, president, informed shareholders in the annual report released today substantial increases in sales, earnings and surplus; reduction in bank loans and improvement in inventory position partly with proceeds of long-term borrowing.

Buyers' cautiousness on women's apparel for spring will continue through most of March, it was learned yesterday from resident offices. Stocks, which were peaked last year for an early Easter, will be kept at a minimum this year for another thirty days, according to resident buyers.

ON May 15, [1940] as already narrated, I had in my first telegram to the President after becoming Prime Minister asked for "the loan of forty or fifty of your older destroyers to bridge the gap between what we have now and the large new construction we put in hand at the beginning of the war." I recurred to this in my cable of June 11, after Italy had already declared war upon us.
SHANGHAI, Feb. 13 -- The foreigners who built up this city and made it the most international metropolis in the world are fading from its streets.
John Haynes Holmes, for forty-two years minister of the Community Church, will retire from the active pastorate next Nov. 29 on his seventieth birthday.

The Jewish Labor Committee has called attention to the fact that the Soviet drive against the liberty and independence of the Christian Churches is being paralleled by a like drive against the liberty and independence of Jewish religious, cultural and communal life throughout the Communist-dominated world.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- Bills extending the stand-by State Residential Rent Control Law and the State Commercial and Industrial Rent Control Laws for another year were introduced in the Assembly tonight by Assemblyman D. Mallory Stephens, chairman of the Joint Rent Control Committee.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 28 -- At a mass meeting of employes of the Paramount Studio at noon today, Adolph Zukor, chairman of the Paramount board, and Barney Balaban, president of the company, announced that Mr. Balaban will remain chief of Paramount production and distribution when the corporation is split next year into a producing-distributing company and an exhibiting company under the terms of the divorcement consent decree signed by Paramount Friday.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Tuesday, March 1 -- In apparent defiance of an American order to withdraw, the personnel of the Russian Repatriation Mission here overstayed the deadline of last midnight after a bitter argument at United States Army headquarters in Heidelberg yesterday morning.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe yesterday dismissed a suit by Mme. Anne Vilbert de Sairigne, member of a prominent French family, to compel Frank Jay Gould, wealthy son of the late railroad man, to make good a $400,000 check he allegedly gave her in 1944 for keeping him out of the hands of the Germans.

PARIS, Feb. 28 -- Premier Queuille's plea that the United States prevent the advance of the Russian army beyond the Elbe River was severely criticized as provoca tive to the Soviet Union in an editorial in the independent socialistic newspaper Combat today.

SPRING training will officially get under way today and it's a cinch that the most energetic hustler in the New York Giant camp at Phoenix will be the recently acquired August John Galan. There is little possibility that Augie will become a regular but it won't be for the lack of trying. He always gives a full 100 per cent of his efforts, which is more than most Giants have done of recent seasons.

Ash Wednesday services, opening the season of Lent, will be held at liturgical and many evangelical churches tomorrow. Music appropriate to the devotions of the day will be sung by choirs and congregations.

Trade buying and scattered short covering advanced coffee futures prices in a moderately active market on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. At the close contract "D" showed gains of 20 to 29 points. Selling was scattered. On trade demand contract "S" advanced 10 to 20 points.

Although new bond financing last month was the smallest for any month in a year, the total was the largest for a February since 1940. However, the comparison with a year ago showed a mixed pattern in the types of issues marketed.

Gwilym A. Price, 54-year-old president of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, foresaw yesterday a continuation of the record volume of business done last year, but tempered his outlook with the observation that the Administration's program "proposes changes in the national structure which might lay impossible burdens on both corporate and individual taxpayers."

The Consolidated Edison System maintained silence yesterday on whether it would ask the State Public Service Commission to reconsider its recent temporary order cutting electric rates in the light of the company's decision to grant higher wages to its 27,000 employes.

Operation of Peruvian International Airways was suspended yesterday by L. Randolph Mason, attorney, who was appointed receiver in bankruptcy on Saturday by Judge Henry W. Goddard in the United States District Court.

The Standard Vacuum Oil Company, jointly owned by the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., have announced the election of Clifford B. Marshall as a director. He joined the company in 1920 and since has been connected mostly with its activities in India.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Following are the conclusions and recommendations in the report on the National Security Organization submitted to Congress today by the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government, Herbert Hoover, chairman:

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 28 -- A vigorous plea for immediate passage of a Federal aid-to-education bill was made here today by many of the nation's leading educators. At the same time they insisted that all funds must go to public schools and not to private or parochial institutions.

VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28 -- Tomorrow morning, on one of the numerous baseball diamonds dotting the 2,200 acres of "Dodgertown," Burt Shotton will begin conditioning the men that he has said "fifty times" will win the 1949 pennant.

The financing of new automobiles accounted for a marked increase in the earnings of C. I. T. Financial Corporation during 1948. Net profit was $17,071,475, or $4.57 a common share, compared with $7,282,086 or $2.03 in 1947, Arthur O. Dietz, president, reported yesterday.
ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- Five bills were introduced tonight by the special committee on social welfare to throw new safeguards around the adoption of babies and the care of children in foster homes.
A combination strike and lockout that shut down six big New York baking concerns had little effect yesterday on the availability of bread and cake in city stores and restaurants.

The Tennessee Gas Transmission Company, operator of a gas pipeline system between Texas and West Virginia, reported that for 1948, its fourth year of operation, net income was $6,761,000, a rise of $1,191,000 over the $5,570,000 for 1947.

VIENNA, Feb. 15 -- In all that has been said of late about the Eastern European states behind the Iron Curtain, it is the progressive elimination of freedom that has not been, and cannot be sufficiently emphasized.

Sophie, ace designer for Saks Fifth Avenue, seemed to throw herself entirely into the spring and summer mood when she created her new line, presented yesterday afternoon in the Salon Moderne. There was about the clothes an ease and fluidity of line that seemed to speak of the gentler seasons to come.

Irene Rosenberg, 22-year-old Brooklyn pianist, came back last night to fulfill the promise of her girlhood. She gave a recital at Town Hall that proved she has safely made the transition from prodigy to adult artist.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 28 -- In a counter move against the United States resolution urging investigation of slave labor practices in Eastern European countries, the Soviet Union demanded today that the United Nations set up a special commission to study living and labor conditions of workers in the Western World.

YONKERS, N. Y., Feb. 28 -- This city was deprived of garbage collection today when 500 workers in the municipal Public Works Department struck to avoid crossing a picket line of the local musicians' union.

A slimming effect achieved by draping material in diagonal folds over the hips of dresses in her spring and summer collection won for Rose Lash yesterday the approval of 2,000 members of the New York Chapter of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, meeting at the Astor Hotel.

Substantial backlogs for local aircraft manufacturers are reported in a survey of the industry appearing in Aviation Week. The industry as a whole, the survey reports, has $1,400,000,000 in orders for this year in which it should show an operating profit of $200,000,000.

In a letter to Dr. Raymond B. Allen, president of the University of Washington, 150 educators from fifty colleges and universities urged the reinstatement of the three professors dismissed recently from that institution for holding Communist party membership or for alleged Communist leanings, it was made known yesterday.

An exhibition and subsequent auction sale for the benefit of the International Rescue, Inc., organization, has been arranged at the Laurel Gallery, beginning today. Approximately 100 paintings and pieces of sculpture, together with unframed items such as prints and drawings, have been contributed by artists, galleries and collectors. A group of manuscripts has been donated by well known authors.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Administration's Senate leaders, at the signal of President Truman himself, opened today a bipartisan offensive to harden the closure, or "gag" rule against filibusters.

Increasing numbers of veterans are seeking help with non-service-connected emotional difficulties, it was reported yesterday by the New York City Veterans Service Centers. The centers noted also a decrease in the available resources in the city for psychiatric treatment for these veterans.

F. M. (Mike) Darr, chief of the Division of Traffic of the Maritime Commission for the last eleven years and a veteran of almost thirty years' service with the Government retired yesterday to go into private business. He was succeeded by Charles H. McGuire, assistant chief of the division.

With a sustained defense that proved invaluable, Dartmouth's basketball team toppled Columbia from the lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate League race by defeating the Lions on the Morningside Heights court, 47 to 38 last night.
