WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government urged forcefully today that the National Military Establishment be reconstituted under "firm civilian control" that is clearly above military authority and puts the national welfare above what it called narrow service interests.

Dr. Floyd H. Black, president of Robert College and of the American College for Girls in Istanbul, Turkey, yesterday revealed that he had helped obtain a one-year-theological scholarship in New York for the chief defendant in Bulgaria's spy trial who recently "confessed" that his espionage was inspired by a meeting with Dr. Black in 1932.

The National Orchestral Association, conducted by Leon Barzin, gave its third subscription concert of the season at Carnegie Hall last night. It was a program whose distinction lay almost entirely in the playing of George Ricci, 'cellist, although the professional readings by the orchestra were not to be disparaged.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Sgt. Robert L. Hodgkiss, whose heroism helped save the lives of thirty-six paratroopers, received the Distinguished Flying Cross today.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 28 -- The International Council of the European Movement, a privately sponsored venture inspired and led by Winston Churchill, adopted today a series of policy recommendations to be laid before the official Council of Europe [set up by the Brussels treaty powers] and widely publicized. It was the first meeting of the Council created last May in The Hague.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 28 -- Westchester Republican leaders rejected today the explanation given last night by Governor Dewey concerning the need for $168,200,000 in additional state taxes. The County Board of Supervisors went one step farther this afternoon by declaring its opposition to a pending state legislative bill that would readjust the distribution of gasoline tax refunds.

Opening of the bock beer season here March 10 with the greatest output ever produced by local brewers is being watched nationally as a possible yearly promotion for the entire country, it was learned here yesterday. Pointing out that bock beer season is the only promotion opportunity the industry has during the year, brewers believe that a nationally recognized "festival" would do much to stimulate sales.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer today urged American business men to cooperate "in following President Truman's suggestion that we launch a 'bold new program' of assistance to other countries."

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 28 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru stated in the Indian Parliament today that the Communist party's activities in India during the past year "bordered on open revolt." He said that the Government had refrained from action against the Communist party as such but had dealt firmly and quickly with individuals encouraging or participating in violence.

The run of "Diamond Lil," which was discontinued on Saturday, when its author and star, Mae West, injured her ankle, will not be resumed until next Monday, it was announced yesterday by a spokesman for the producers, Al Rosen and Herbert J. Freezer.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- President Truman urged his fellow- Americans tonight to "oversubscribe" the $60,000,000 that the Red Cross will seek to raise during the month of March for its 1949 operations.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 28 -- An ebullient, optimistic Leo Durocher embarked on his first full term as Giant manager today as his complete squad of players reported for the opening of the 1949 training campaign tomorrow.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28 -- Poised for his first full scale look at the Yankee squad with which he will charge on the American League pennant this year, Casey Stengel tonight was impatiently awaiting tomorrow's dawn.
Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, former Commissioner of Hospitals, was guest of honor last night at a dinner given by friends and associates at the Astor Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Supreme Court declined today to review protests by a group of bondholders of the Peoria Eastern Railway against a decree upholding a $2,500,000 claim by the line's parent companies.
After months of conflict, the board of directors of the United Palestine Appeal last night restored unity in the ranks of the United Jewish Appeal.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The $940,000,000 allocated tentatively to Great Britain for Marshall Plan operations through the second year is a "tight-fit minimum" which, if reduced, would affect adversely continued recovery in both the United Kingdom and Western Europe, Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Supreme Court upheld today one labor union and rejected the arguments of another in two decisions expected to have an important bearing on current efforts of Congress to rewrite Federal labor laws.

An immense sense of relief follows settlement of the dispute between Consolidated Edison and its employes. The suddenness with which agreement was reached as the strike deadline neared reflects, we assume, a recognition by management and union of the horrors that would be visited on the city if electricity and gas were shut off, even for a short time.

Arthur W. Wallander spent his last day yesterday as Police Commissioner bidding good-by to Mayor O'Dwyer, Commissioner-designate William P. O'Brien and to his staff. At informal ceremonies in Police Headquarters, he turned over his badge of office to his successor, recently appointed first deputy commissioner, whose term as commissioner began at midnight.

VIENNA, Feb. 28 -- Communization and semi-militarization of Hungarian university life will be the object of measures to be announced in Budapest during the next few days, according to students who fled to Vienna today to escape them.

ON BOARD U. S. S. POCONO, San Juan, Puerto Rico, Feb. 28 -- More than 100 ships of the Atlantic Fleet were converging on Vieques Island east of Puerto Rico tonight to commence tomorrow a two-day amphibious "assault" against the island's reef-rimmed southern coast.

Less than a year after a labor dispute that had Wall Street in confusion, representatives of the United Financial Workers, AFL, and the street's three big Exchange sat down together yesterday to break bread and sample the fanciest lamb chops available at the Commodore Hotel.

After nine days and nights of roaming the over-heated corridors at the Sportsmen's Show we were planning a check-up on the ice fishing and fox hunting, but the snowfall has anchored us to the desk, with no excuse to postpone a careful examination of accumulated mail.

The construction industry must give customers more for their money this year if it expects to maintain the high building volume of 1948. Prof. Sumner H. Slichter of Harvard University declared yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 28 -- Dominion representatives meeting here today decided to offer help to the Government of Burma in an effort to end the civil war in that country, which left the Commonwealth thirteen months ago.

Unlike many other home furnishings, bedding dollar volume at both wholesale and retail is holding up satisfactorily, manufacturers and buyers reported yesterday. For the first two months of the year retail volume is running from 1 or 2 per cent behind the like period last year to as much as 15 per cent ahead, retailers said.

Those who regularly send food abroad are acquainted with the fact that this country limits meat shipments to three pounds a package. Of interest to them is an announcement by Charles Co.'s Bon Voyage that enables donors to double this amount.

BOSTON, Feb. 28 -- The three court-appointed trustees of the Waltham Watch Company filed in Federal Court today a plan for reorganizing that concern through raising $8,000,000 in new capital. A hearing date on the proposal will be set later.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Senate and House conferees failed today to reach an agreement on legislation affecting this year's cotton crop.
CAMDEN, N. J., Feb. 28 -- How would you like to have a college named after you -- to have your name perpetuated by the sons and daughters of dear old Wintergreen -- or Jones -- College?

Bonds called before maturity for payment in February declined to $12,743,000 from $36,151,000 in the preceding month and $60,896,000 in February, 1948, to the lowest amount for any month since June, 1934, when $12,562,00 was retired.
The personality of a child is influenced by the emotional experiences of the mother during pregnancy, Dr. Milton J. E. Senn told a lecture audience at Town Hall yesterday afternoon.

Efforts are being renewed in foreign trade circles to have exchange made available for long-overdue accounts with American exporters y Latin-American countries. These accounts are estimated as running into millions of dollars, but frequently exchange is made available for current imports without taking care of the old accounts.

Eight young men and boys were taken into three Brooklyn courts yesterday for possession of dozens of firearms and knives found in their homes after a 14-year-old boy had been killed Sunday by the accidental discharge of an automatic pistol.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- At the very outset of the resistance by Southern Democrats in the Senate to a proposed new closure rule, the immediate objective of which is the passage of the President's bills against certain racial discriminations in local laws and folkways, the following facts should be borne in mind by interested observers:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to review Douglas Chandler's conviction for wartime treason. The refusal has the effect of upholding the conviction.

An account of the Jewish armed rebellion against the Nazis in Warsaw, entitled "The Stars Bear Witness," will be published by the Viking Press on April 19. Bernard Goldstein, an organizer of the rebellion and author of the account, covers the five years from the German invasion of Poland to his own escape from the Russian "liberators."

Dr. William F. Russell, dean of Columbia's Teachers College, urged yesterday in a letter to the college's 35,000 alumni that grants in aid of $1,000 to $3,000 be made to the thousands of potential education leaders.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Congress was assured today that no "vast new system" of home relief was contemplated as the Administration opened its case for liberalization of the public assistance program, including Federal aid to states for general relief of the destitute.

A new issue of $4,600,000 of Fernandina Port Authority, Fla., 4 per cent toll road revenue bonds due from 1952 to 1978 will be placed on the market here today by Shields Co. and other underwriters at prices to yield from 3.25 per cent to 4 per cent.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 28 -- Throughout the Rhineland, Rose Monday was celebrated today as the climax of eight weeks of pre-Lenten merrymaking, the robustness and duration of which have drawn admonitions from church prelates.

TOKYO, Feb. 28 -- Pressure continues to pile up against Gen. Douglas A. MacArthur's November hold- the-line order that forbade higher official prices or increased subsidies or loans for entrepreneurs.

Perry Grogan, who had tapped out on his "bug" many a reporter's story of championship boxing bouts, world's series baseball games and football "classics" in the East in his thirty-eight years as a telegrapher, retired yesterday as an employe of the Western Union Telegraph Company.

A matronly looking former social service worker was arrested yesterday and accused by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of illegally placing "hundreds of babies'' for adoption with foster parents throughout the United States.

Major Christopher P. Mayhew, British Under-Secretary of State, remarked last week at a session of the Economic and Social Council that British economic recovery was virtually complete. Mr. Mayhew meant no harm. He thought people might be pleased at this news, to the extent that it was news.

Federal Judge Henry W. Godard reserved decision yesterday on a plan submitted by Victor I. Tyler, trustee, for reorganization of the West Fifty-second Theater Company, Inc., operator of the Guild Theatre at 243 West Fifty-second Street.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier yesterday and closed 6 to 34 points net lower.

Eight metropolitan college basketball teams will participate in a "small college" tournament, it was announced by Jack McDonald, committee chairman, at the weekly luncheon-meeting of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association at Leone's yesterday.

PARIS. Feb. 25 -- The importance of French recovery, if possible within the time span specified by the Marshall Plan, is a matter of paramount importance to United States security. Geographically, agriculturally and militarily France is the keystone in the reconstruction arch being erected across Western Europe by United States policy.

Seventy-five press clipping books on grand opera that have been gathering dust in the cellars of the Metropolitan Opera House were presented yesterday to the New York Public Library. The contents of the weighty, somewhat rat-eaten books go back to 1908 when Giulio Gatti-Casazza as manager of the Metropolitan Opera began the practice of collecting clippings on its activities.

PARIS, Feb. 28 -- Two Communist officers in the French Army have been arrested in continuing raids on Communists, the Ministry of the Interior said today. One of them is reported by the police to have confessed giving information on French armament manufacture to the military attaches of a "people's democracy" -- in other words, a Soviet satellite state.

Anti-Semitism, the "terrible curse of our time," is growing in this country, Dr. Henry Smith Leiper, associate general secretary of the World Council of Churches, warned yesterday. He made this statement after he had told a luncheon gathering of the American Council for Judaism that American Jews must not identify themselves with the political State of Israel if they hope to be considered full-fledged members of the United States community.

HE said that he came from Boston and he wore the sober clothes of a Puritan shoemaker; but there was a dark glitter in his eye, a swaggering arrogance to his carriage and a sinister brightness all about him such as no Salem cobbler ever flaunted before or since. He had plenty of money to spend in the ale house and a way of looking at women which made their hearts melt in their bodies.
Counsel for the eleven Communists subpoenaed Senior Judge John C. Knox of the Federal District Court yesterday as a defense witness.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Through a decision that will basically affect the Navy's system of courts-martial, the Supreme Court today unanimously dismissed the conviction of Chief Signalman Harold E. Hirshberg of Brooklyn for allegedly striking two fellow Americans in Japanese prison camps.

Herbert McKenley and Lloyd LaBeach will flash their speed at the thirtieth annual athtletic meet of the New York Chapter, Knights of Columbus, listed for Madison Square Garden on Saturday night. The pair, residents of Jamaica in the British West Indies, recently arrived in New York after a tour of Australia, where they turned in consistently excellent performances.

BERLIN, Feb. 28 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor in Germany, who personifies Western resistance to the Russian political attack on Berlin, is expected to retire in the near future, according to his associates here.

Steel operations this week are scheduled at 100.5 per cent of ingot capacity, equaling a wartime record for sustained operations at or above theoretical capacity, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Senators Tom Connally, Democrat, of Texas, and Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, reassured Secretary of State Dean Acheson today that the draft of the North Atlantic Pact was satisfactory to them as it now stood.

Problems of racial and religious discrimination cannot be solved by statutes or speeches but require a militant personal living of brotherhood, former Governor Herbert H. Lehman said yesterday at the eighth annual luncheon of the rayon division of the National Conference of Christians and Jews at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

We hope that the Legislature will give careful study to the recommendation of the Prison Association of New York, contained in its annual report, that a policy of correction rather than detention be adopted for the state's penal institutions. It is logical to contend that in a prison system which has a population of 15,600 inmates there should be great emphasis on rehabilitation.

Nearly 500 persons made their way to Ellis Island yesterday for joyous reunions with relatives among the 489 Jewish refugees who arrived here Sunday night on their way from Shanghai to Israel and Europe.

The Firth Carpet Company, in its annual report mailed to stockholders today, disclosed an increase last year of 45 per cent in net sales and 51 per cent in earnings, both establishing new records for the company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration said today that a fourth salt substitute containing the dangerous lithium chloride is on the market. The agency said the product is Milosal, manufactured by Milani Diafoods, Maywood, Calif., a division of Louis Milani Diafoods, Chicago.
A land development program for Israel, to cost $100,000,000 in 1949, was outlined here yesterday by Dr. Abraham Granovsky, the new nation's leading expert on land problems.

A few weeks ago in reply to an invitation from the Committee on Uniform Code of Military Justice, Office of the Secretary of Defense, a subcommittee of the Special Committee on Military Justice of the New York State Bar Association, consisting of Philip J. McCook, Abel I. Smith Jr., and Niall Oran Meagher, wrote a letter to Professor Morgan's committee.

BATAVIA, Java, Feb. 28 -- Indonesian Republicans today rejected a Netherlands invitation to attend a round-table conference on the Indonesian problem at The Hague on March 12, designed to speed self-government for Indonesia.

Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and associated underwriters will place on the market today 219,196 shares of common stock of Central Maine Power Company at $15.875 a share. The public offering is concurrent with an offering by the company of 67,300 shares of new common stock at the same price to holders of the common and 6 per cent preferred stocks.

In anticipation of the maturity on July 1, 1952, of its first-consolidated-mortgage bonds, the stockholders of the Atlantic Coast Line Raliroad will be asked at their annual meeting on April 19 to amend the indenture of the general-unified-mortgage, dated April 1, 1914, to include about 705 miles of unmortgaged railroad lines.

One of the worst spills of the current sixty-ninth international six-day bicycle race took place early this morning at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory, sending two of the riders to near-by Medical Center.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The long arm of the Taft-Hartley Law reached today for the first time into occurrences inside a union meeting hall. Arthur Leff, a trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board, held that ten employes had been coerced and illegally restrained at union headquarters by threats of loss of their jobs if they failed to support their local union.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Two Catholic priests, a lay brother of the Jesuit order and a civilian pleaded guilty today to charges of black market dealings in foreign currency.
RHODES, Feb. 28 -- Transjordan's delegates arrived at Rhodes today to negotiate an armistice with Israel as a new chapter in the efforts of the United Nations to restore peace in the Middle East.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- A state building-code commission to formulate and promulgate a state building code, which could be used for construction throughout the state, was proposed tonight in a bill introduced by Senator William F. Condon, Republican, of Westchester, chairman of a joint legislative committee which has been studying construction problems for three years.

The three-story building at 190 Wyckoff Avenue, Brooklyn, containing two stores and six apartments, has been purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Degen from the estates of August Propfe and Mathilda Damm. The new owners plan to occupy the stores as a dry cleaning establishment Harry B. Richard was attorney for the buyers, who insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

The three-family house at 2716 Decatur Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Community Assets Corporation to Emilio Cermola for cash above a first mortgage of $9,000. The P. C. D'Onofrio Company was the broker in the sale of the property, which is assessed at $16,000.

"Portrait of Jennie," the David O. Selznick production starring Jennifer Jones, Joseph Cotten and Ethel Barrymore, will have its local premiere at the Rivoli on Tuesday, March 22, it was announced by the Selznick Releasing Organization yesterday.
MOSCOW, Feb. 28 -- Premier Stalin tonight proclaimed price cuts in forty-five classifications of food, clothing and other consumers' goods.

William Kral has sold the three-story apartment house at 24-15 Forty-first Street, Long Island City, Queens, to Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Isabella in a transaction negotiated by Frank M. Goetz as broker. The Title Guarantee and Trust Company insured the title.

The stock market added yesterday to the gains made on Saturday and prices rallied from 1 to 2 points on limited buying. The session was highly selective, with scant attention accorded the pivotal issues but most demand was for stocks seldom traded in any volume.

The quiet look of quality marked the spring custom order collection designed by Sally Milgrim and presented yesterday at this store. Only fine pure silk was used in prints and such enriching touches as braid, applique, faggoting and openwork were frequently employed.

Shortly before old 1948 tottered off the stage there was presented in this corner a review of the twenty-nine commemorative stamps issued during the year by the Post Office Department at the behest of Congress in the course of which it was observed that if a "do-nothing" Eightieth Congress found it possible to approve so generous a number of special stamp issues the Eighty-first might be expected to send its predecessor's record tumbling.

The Juilliard String Quartet -- Messrs. Robert Mann and Robert Koff, violinists; Raphael Hillyet, viola, and Arthur Winograd, 'cellist -- did a public service and rendered fitting homage to a composer of genius when they presented a program of the string quartets of the late Bela Bartok last night in Times Hall.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Feb. 28 -- Setting up of a "simple inter-industrial committee" to coordinate existing talents and to formulate a common non-competitive theme was suggested here today as the first step in the proposed national promotion of men's clothing by Michael Daroff, president of H. Daroff Sons, Inc., men's clothing manufacturers, Philadelphia.
Jimmy Walters of East New York scored an upset victory over Jimmy Flood, Yorkville middleweight, in the main bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

If the public had any impression that Mr. Ewing and the proponents of compulsory sickness insurance are waging a fight based on sound fact, the recent debate at the Town Meeting of the Air should dispel such naive thinking.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 28 -- The Browns today ordered the Cardinals out of Sportsman's Park by April 1 in a surprise move that brought into the open the smouldering feud between this city's two major league baseball clubs.

The National Broadcasting Company's answer to the Columbia network raids on its talent came yesterday from Chicago at a special meeting in the Hotel Stevens of the owners and operatore of the National's affiliated stations.

MOSCOW, Feb. 28 -- Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, called Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, United States Ambassador, a "professional spy" today and former Ambassador W. Averell Harriman a "spy by avocation."

CHICAGO, March 1 -- Directors of the financially harassed Tucker Corporation met in a secret session at the plant more than four hours today and then declined to disclose what action had been taken or what matters were considered.

LONDON, March 1 -- The deadlock between Austria and Yugoslavia over the Austrian treaty negotiations hardened perceptibly here today when representatives of the two countries appearing before the deputies of the Council of Foreign Ministers refused to budge from their positions.

Rayon weavers will look for a reduction in the price of filament yarns as well as staple fiber, it was pointed out in the trade yesterday. An adjustment of rayon material costs must be made by April 15, textile men said, to prevent sharp curtailment of production on the basis of new fabric prices recently announced.
Somewhat of a mystery has piqued the imagination of officials of three city departments. Yesterday they referred to it as "The Case of the Missing Family."

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo last night presented the only novelty scheduled for its season at the City Center. This was Ruth Page's "Love Song" set to miscellaneous bits of Schubert in an orchestration by Lucien Gailliet, who also conducted it.

Wolfgang Borchert, the author of "Outside the Door," which the Dramatic Workshop of the New School presented in this country for the first time last night at the President Theatre, died in 1946 at the age of 26. He was a victim of tuberculosis, contracted on the Eastern Front while he was serving with the Wehrmacht.

From White Sands, New Mexico, came the news recently that the Army has a two-stage rocket which has reached a height of 250 miles and attained a speed of 5,000 miles an hour. The record of 114 miles for altitude established in 1946 for a German V-2 was broken. The new rocket was composed of a German V-2 in the nose of which was a smaller rocket known as the Wac Corporal.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., March 1 -- The City Commission was asked today to consider leasing a large tract of waterfront property, with riparian rights, for the construction by private capital of a $60,000,000 marine terminal facility.
OTTAWA, March 1 (AP) -- Sam Carr, alleged head of a Russian spy ring, was held for trial on a charge of conspiring to forge a passport for a Soviet agent, Magistrate Joachim Sauve said today.

Oklahoma A. and M., which for the past two seasons has had the number of St. Louis University, yesterday took over the No. 2 spot in The Associated Press basketball rankings, formerly occupied by the Billikens.

The collision last Jan. 30 over Port Washington, L. I., between a Pan American Airways Constellation, bound for London with a full load of passengers, and a light Cessna plane whose pilot and passenger were the only fatalities, turned out yesterday to have been perhaps the best observed accident in aviation history -- and one of the most mysterious.
Two major scheduled airlines announced yesterday further plans to invade the air coach service that the irregular carriers have been claiming as their own before the Civil Aeronautics Board.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, March 1 -- Five defendants today repudiated pre-trial confessions that they had engaged in illegal money deals in a conspiracy with Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty.

ALBANY, March 1 -- Administration of New York City's hotel rent law was described today in a report to the Temporary State Rent Commission as ineffective, inefficient, wasteful and permeated with politics. It was further charged that the City Rent Commission had failed to prevent unreasonable rent increases and had decontrolled, without warrant, a third of the hotel apartments originally put under control.

We should like to call attention to and commend the 110th Street Community Center, which has been observing the first anniversary of its interesting work: to teach by example that Negro and white, Spanish, Italian and English speaking peoples, Protestants, Catholics and Jewish people can live together in harmony.

A thin thread of crime, spun by a 200-pound divorcee and her balding partner around lonely widows seeking companionship, broke yesterday when the pair confessed to Michigan and New York police that they had murdered three persons. The bodies of two victims, a mother and daughter, were found in Byron Center, Mich., and the third was unearthed last night in South Ozone Park, Queens.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 1 (UP) -- The text of the letter to the National Boxing Association Commissioner, Abe Greene, in which Joe Louis outlined his plans to become a promoter, follows:

Howard Hughes, owner of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation, announced yesterday that he has arranged to have Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane and the First Boston Corporation receive proposals from prospective purchasers of his stock holdings in a new theatre company which will acquire RKO's theatre business.
ORMOND BEACH, Fla., March 1 (AP) -- Two newcomers to Ormond Beach set the pace today in the qualifying round of the women's South Atlantic golf tournament.

The State of West Virginia sold yesterday an issue of $2,000,000 road bonds due on Dec 1, 1949 to 1973, to Graham, Parsons Co. and associates at a bid of 100.0084 for 4s, 1 1/4s and 1 1/2s, an interest cost of 1.5819 per cent. Reoffering was made only of bonds maturing from 1954 to 1973, which were priced to yield from 1.05 per cent to 1.75 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Created by a Republican Congress, headed by the nation's only living former president, a Republican, but welcomed by the Democratic President in office, a group which has made the most comprehensive and thorough study of the federal government in history virtually disbanded today.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The nations negotiating the proposed North Atlantic defense pact are divided on inviting Italy into their security association.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1 -- On the most elaborate scale experienced by a Yankee ball club since the days of the late Miller Huggins, Casey Stengel today sent through their opening training drill thirty-nine regulars and rookies from whom he expects to mould an American League pennant winner for 1949.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- A bill providing for a sixteen-month moratorium on possible new anti-trust actions based on the Supreme Court's recent decision on industrial delivered-price systems was approved today by the House Judiciary Committee.

The sons of John D. Rockefeller Jr. were acclaimed as perfect models of what a rich man's sons should be in a luncheon speech yesterday by Louis Hollander, state president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Joe Louis, heavyweight champion of the world since June 22, 1937, yesterday officially relinquished boxing's richest and most glamorous title with the formal announcement from Miami Beach, Fla., of his retirement from active competition in the ring.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- Government agencies were reported at odds today over a proposal from Gen. Lucius D. Clay to let the Western Germans build and operate ocean going ships.

E. Robert Schmitz, in his annual recital last night at Carnegie Hall, presented a program devoted to modern French music. Satie was the pianist's earliest composer, Messiaen the latest, and the evening opened with Ravel and closed with Debussy, both of whom the pianist knew.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Arthur J. Altmeyer, Social Security Commissioner, testified today that the expanded social security program proposed by President Truman would require ultimately special payroll taxes of 8.5 to 10 per cent of the country's wages and salaries.
BATAVIA, Java, March 1 (AP) -- The Dutch announced tonight that they would transfer sovereignty to all Indonesia by July 1, regardless of whether Indonesian Republican leaders agreed.

ON BOARD, U.S.S. POCONO, Vieques Island, March 1 -- The steep tree-covered slopes of Mount Jalobre and the tropic-green hills and valleys of eastern Vieques were cratered by live shells, bombs and rockets this morning as the Navy commenced its greatest post-war amphibious exercises.
Nationally advertised food lines are currently enjoying an all-time high in consumer popularity, Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., disclosed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Republican leaders of the House decided by unanimous vote today that reduction of excise taxes to pre-war levels should be "one of the first orders of business" in the Eighty-first Congress.

Your lead editorial of Feb. 17 drew some inferences from three quotations in my statement of Feb. 8 before the Joint Committee on the Economic Report which, among other things, led you to characterize the "Economic Stabilization Act of 1949," just introduced in Congress, as "arrogant economic planning."
Cotton futures trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was not very heavy yesterday and final prices were 5 points lower to 5 points higher.

The stock market registered gains yesterday for the third consecutive session, eliminating the losses of last week. The rally again was without force, however, and prices rose on the scantiest of bidding, with fractional changes predominating the composite rate up 0.62 point on the day.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- From noon to dusk today, with but two brief intervals, Southern Senators cried out against the proposed hardening of the closure, or "gag," rule against filibusters.

The first September primary in six years is scheduled for the 1949 elections, it became known yesterday. A tentative agreement calls for the passage in Albany of legislation setting Sept. 6 as the date. Last year's primary was on Aug. 24.
Some of the "old timers," rated among the all-time great cyclists, were among the guests last night at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory where the international six-day grind is under way.

Two locals of the Utility Workers of America, CIO, unanimously ratified yesterday the proposed contract with the Consolidated Edison Company. Two others will hold meetings on Friday and Saturday to vote on the negotiated settlement that headed off a strike scheduled for 12:01 A. M. today.

ALBANY, March 1 -- The Public Service Commission granted a $3,280,000 interim increase in commutation fares to the Long Island Rail Road today in an emergency move to save the carrier from "possible collapse or bankruptcy."

Reading the excellent editorial in THE TIMES of Feb. 27 on the appointment of James G. McDonald as first American Ambassador to the Republic of Israel, I feel it is appropriate to call attention to one of the most courageous and unselfish acts of his notable career.
PARIS, March 1 -- Foreign Minister Robert Schuman defended the proposed North Atlantic defense pact before the Council of the Republic today by saying its purpose was to prevent a third world war.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 1 -- Warner Brothers and William and James Cagney announced today that they had reached agreement on a deal whereby the Cagneys independent company will make three pictures for Warner release, while James Cagney will star in three additional pictures to be produced by Warners.

Herbert Hoover and Samuel Spewack have something in common. Each in his own analytical manner has been examining the modus operandi of the Washington merry-go-round. Based on personal experiences as a reporter and a Government employe, Mr. Spewack has incorporated his findings anent governmental agencies in a comedy of farcical intent called "Two Blind Mice," opening tonight at the Cort.

To have an effective knowledge of medicine on the part of the laity there must be a satisfactory medical library available to the public as well as to physicians, and rooms and halls where discussions and meetings can be held for the exchange of information. The New York Academy of Medicine is qualified to give these services and has an excellent record as a meeting place and a public library in the field of medicine.

Market for New Bonds The market for high-grade new capital issues seems to be in a state of delicate balance right now. The unflagging competition by banking syndicates for new public issues of bonds is a conspicuous factor on the bullish side; also, the evident unwillingness of most institutional investors to pass up a choice portfolio item.

PENNHURST, Pa., March 1 (UP) -- Esther Henne, 41-year-old school teacher, said she was married to Raymond Fernandez for one month in New York last year, but left him because she was "deathly afraid" of him.
DUESSELDORF, March 1 -- Twenty-four hours of gales in Germany have taken a toll of at least thirty lives with many more persons injured.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The United States and Saudi Arabia are in the final stages of negotiations that would give the United States Air Force certain limited rights for continued use of the Army-built Dhahran airfield on the Persian Gulf, it was learned today.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 1 -- The last of the fifteen Protestant ministers on trial in Sofia completed their oral confessions today.
RHODES, March 1 -- An Israeli delegation arrived here today to begin armistice talks with Transjordan.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 1 -- Five persons were convicted in Munich today of spying on military installations in the United States zone in the pay of the Polish Secret Service. Their sentences ranged from twelve years to thirty years at hard labor for the ring-leader.

PARIS, March 1 -- The French Communist party appears to be putting into operation its openly avowed doctrine of prior allegiance to the Soviet Union by preparing for mass action to slow down all forms of arms production as France, in line with the Western European Union pact, seeks to build up her national defenses.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The House passed overwhelmingly today a bill to lift the last remaining barriers to the admission to the United States and subsequent naturalization of Asiatics.

The Italian liner Vulcania arrived here yesterday with 1,220 passengers, including a Viennese brewer, Manfred Von Mautner Markhof, who said he was spared the horrors of the Dachau concentration camp through a whim of Hitler's propaganda chief, Joseph Goebbels.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 1 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay said today that the three Western military governors had "reached wide agreement, perhaps full agreement." in their views on the Western German draft constitution.

JOE LOUIS has finally resigned as the heavyweight champion of the world and no news could be more welcome or soul-satisfying than that. He wore his crown with honor and distinction for a longer time than any man had worn it before and it was eminently fitting that he should put it aside with dignity rather than have some second-rater rudely knock it off his head.

Well, Adrian has come to town again. When this Hollywood designer arrives he always gives one plenty to talk about. Yesterday morning, when he opened his collection in the room especially arranged for him at Gunther's, he had quite a bit to talk about himself.

Talks looking to an end of the bakery tie-up at the "top management level" of the six major baking companies whose ovens have been shut down since Saturday were reported under way yesterday as the city began to feel the pinch of a bread shortage.
The United Fruit Company reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $59,740,232, equal to $6.81 a capital share, for 1948, compared with $54,140,794, or $6.17 a share, in 1947.
Macy's-White Plains, fourth in the group of branch stores operated by Macy's New York, will open for business on Monday morning, March 21, Willard J. Gould Jr., manager, announced yesterday.

A force of 10,000 men during the day and 3,000 during the night cleared the city's principal thoroughfares yesterday of Monday's 9 to 17-inch snow. All important traffic arteries were opened as crews of the Sanitation Department and Borough Presidents' offices worked to beat a cold snap expected early today.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The railroads of the country fought back at charges of inefficiency, in their testimony at a hearing today before the Interstate Commerce Commission on a petition for an increase of 13 per cent in freight rates and charges.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 1 -- The three-member United Nations Commission for Indonesia cabled a report today in which it blamed the Netherlands for creating a political deadlock in the islands of the East Indies by ignoring the instructions of the Security Council.

An optimistic view of the prospects for European Union and a pessimistic picture of the operations of the United Nations were presented yesterday by two correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES. They spoke to 500 school teachers taking a course in "Evaluating the News," sponsored by THE TIMES and the Board of Education, at Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- A solid Democratic majority in the Congressional Joint Committee on the Economic Report delivered in the committee's report to Congress today full approval of the President's "anti-inflation" program against united Republican opposition.

CHICAGO, March 1 -- Daniel J. Tobin, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, told a meeting of teamster officials today it did not appear that the Taft-Hartley Law would be repealed as promised in the Democratic platform of last year.

Through a comprehensive new field-tested "tool-control system," lowered "break-even points" in metal-working industries can be achieved with as much as a 10 per cent increase in output, using the same equipment and plants and the same number of machine-hours and man-hours, W. G. Robbins, president of Carboloy Company, Inc., of Detroit, said last week.

Henry Morgenthau Jr., former Secretary of the Treasury, announced yesterday that he had accepted the chairmanship of the 1949 campaign of the United Jewish Appeal. He also headed the campaigns of 1947 and 1948. His announcement ended months of internal conflict that had jeopardized the huge program of aid for Israel and for the relief and rehabiliation of Jews in other areas of the world.

LONDON, March 1 -- Piled up by squalls that touched seventy miles an hour in London and eighty on the east coast, the waters of the Thames today rose over its embankments at many points in Lon don. The pressure of water broke the gates of a dry dock at Silvertown and flung them on to a 2,500-ton collier, which sank immediately.

Hundreds of flowering trees and shrubs will be added to the beauty of city parks and squares this spring through the Ciitizens Golden Anniversary Planting Program of the Park Association of New York City, it was announced yesterday.

The City Rent Commission, which controls hotel rates, also would control garage and parking lot rates under a proposed law approved yesterday by the committee on general welfare of the City Council. The Council as a whole deferred action on the proposal.

The Barnsdall Oil Company reported yesterday for 1948 a record net income of $13,473,629 after charges and taxes, equal to $6.06 a share on the capital stock. This compares with $9,119,030, or $4.10 a share, in 1947, making a gain of nearly 50 per cent.

A match was in the making last all when Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson introduced Postmaster Bernard F. Dickmann of St. Louis and Mrs. B. Pat Harrington, Postmaster of Mount Olive, Miss., at the Postmasters Convention in the Statler Hotel here.
BERLIN, March 1 -- The West Berlin Magistrat today asked the Allied Kommandatura to make a major change in the Western Allies latest denazification order for Berlin and grant general youth amnesty.
TOKYO, March 1 -- Certain circles within the occupation are beginning to show fear that Congress may materially reduce the funds that it has been appropriating for Japanese recovery.

Charitable and educational institutions share the residuary estate of Mrs. Edith Lawrence Speyers Kelley, widow of Robert Weeks Kelley, and former president of the Navy League of the United States, who died on Feb. 18, according to her will filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court.
V. W. Blackney has been promoted to assistant to the president of the United States Radiator Corporation. J. Roy Knox has been named general manager of sales.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- A plan providing for dissolution of the Electric Power and Light Corporation was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission after the company had filed certain suggested amendments to the proposal. The plan is in compliance with an order issued in 1942 by the commission directing such dissolution.
PARIS, March 11 -- The police announced today that demonstrations on Paris streets would be prohibited as the Communists prepared a series of demonstrations on behalf of peace with the Soviet Union.

Reports from several Maine and New Hampshire lakes indicate that the mild winter probably will result in an unusually early ice-out this spring, so those who plan to make their regular ice-out trip would do well to contact guides on their favorite waters for a report on ice conditions.

Edgar Kobak was re-elected president of the Mutual Broadcasting System at a meeting yesterday in Chicago of the network's board of directors. He continues in a post which he assumed in November, 1944, upon his resignation as executive vice president of the Blue Network.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina put an end yesterday to the defense challenge to the jury in the trial of the eleven Communists. He denied a defense motion to dismiss the indictment, and indicated he would reject the challenge by saying he "anticipated" the main trial would begin Monday.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 1 -- Poland's move to call home her envoys in the Nordic countries for a conference on the "Atlantic pact progress" has given rise to fears here that Moscow is planning economic reprisals through Poland, particularly against Denmark and Norway for their gravitation toward the "aggressive" North Atlantic pact.

The 1949 Red Cross campaign in New York started officially yesterday with city-wide ceremonies, after which 50,000 volunteer workers began soliciting funds to meet the city's quota of $4,635,000. The national goal is $60,000,000.
A new first-class steamship passenger service in the New York-Mediterranean route will be started in May, Granville Conway, president of the Cosmopolitan Shipping Company, announced yesterday.

The Merchants Limited, for forty-five years the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad's crack train between New York and Boston, started the fastest schedule in the history of the run yesterday with its regular 5 P. M. departure from track 26 in Grand Central Terminal.

New highs were established in early trading of domestic No. 5 sugar futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. The market, however, eased toward the close, and prices dropped 2 to 5 points below the previous levels. World No. 4 futures were easier in moderate trading activity. Final prices were 1 to 5 points lower.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., March 1 (AP) -- Head Football Coach Reaves (Ribs) Baysinger and his staff of assistants were ousted today in a move by Syracuse University to produce a winning football team.
SHANGHAI, March 1 -- China's one heavy warship, the cruiser Chungking, has deserted to the Communists. This was confirmed today by authoritative sources.
FRANKFORT, Germany, March 1 -- Eight members of the Soviet repatriation mission in Frankfort bedded in tonight in their big sandstone building for what may turn out to be a long siege.

MIAMI, Fla., March 1 -- Make Swing, a trim, fleet but nervous Maryland-bred filly by Swing and Sway, gave no cause for nervousness to her backers during the $17,450 Hialeah Juvenile Stakes over the three-furlong nursery course today.

Persons active in behalf of the Bryn Mawr College Fund have taken over the performance of "My Name Is Aquilon," with Jean Pierre Aumont and Lilli Palmer in the leading roles, on Monday night at the Lyceum Theatre to augment the fund.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,824, against 640 in the preceding week and 1,404 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 687 arrivals yesterday. During February 6,114 arrivals were recorded, compared with 4,839 in the same month of 1948, an increase of 26.3 per cent.
LONDON, March 1 -- End of account idleness led to slightly easier conditions in the stock market here today.

With emphasis on buyers' market problems, business sessions of the American Association of Advertising Agencies' annual meeting, April 6-8, will cover four subjects -- personnel, research, ethics and relations -- it was announced yesterday. The meeting, the organization's thirty-ninth, is scheduled at the Greenbrier, White Sulphur Springs, W. Va.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 1 -- Enlarging the list of countries that have indicated skepticism here over the United States program of proposed aid to underdeveloped areas, Lebanon today raised a series of critical questions before the United Nations Economic and Social Council.

Navy was the starred color in the spring fashions designed exclusively for Sada Sacks of 671 Madison Avenue and shown yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. Popular in such crisp fabrics as alpaca and faille, it was seen in a slim alpaca with a diagonal closing of buttons at the front and flaring revers of surah.

WITH the disappearance of France as a combatant and with Britain set on her struggle for life at home, Mussolini might well feel that his dream of dominating the Mediterranean and rebuilding the former Roman Empire would come true.

ALBANY, March 1 -- Residents of the Villages of Tarrytown and North Tarrytown in Westchester County would vote May 17 on the question of merging, under a bill submitted to the Legislature by Senator William F. Condon, Republican, of Yonkers, it was learned today.
BOSTON, March 1 -- The National Catholic Resettlement Council adopted today five resolutions based on proposed amendments to the McGrath-Neely bill on displaced persons.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 1 -- It probably was a California conspiracy that caused the Florida thermometers to take a nose dive last night on the eve of the first workout for the Dodgers and some 150 of their farm club players.

An analysis of the various uses of wood, "The Coming Age of Wood," by Egon Glesinger, chief of the Forest Products branch of the Food and Agriculture organization of the United Nations, will be issued by Simon Schuster on March 21. He says that wood, properly used, can eliminate want and may be turned into food, fuel, chemicals, clothing, oil, shelter, leather, soap, rubber, plastics and medicine.
